text: PAIMIO SANATORIUM
label: Title

text: Designed by Alvar Aalto and Aino Aalto; completed 1933
label: Caption

text: Paimio, Finland
label: Title

text: The Tuberculosis Sanatorium in Paimio, Finland, the contract won in competition by
label: Paragraph

text: Finnish architects Alvar and Aino Aalto in 1929, completed in 1933, synthesized two
label: Paragraph

text: potent modernist agendas. First, the design embraces modernism’s utopian social
label: Paragraph

text: commitment and its deep confidence in rational design processes. Second, the building
label: Paragraph

text: expresses explicitly the elemental organizational tactics of functionalist architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: its concomitant machine imagery. Metaphorically, if Le Corbusier’s Villa Savoye was a
label: Paragraph

text: machine for living in, the Aaltos’ Paimio Sanatorium was a machine for becoming
label: Paragraph

text: healthier in.
label: Paragraph

text: Following World War L, avant-garde architects proclaimed the emergence of a spirited
label: Paragraph

text: and vital new, modern age. This was to be a more orderly and healthy age, brought forth
label: Paragraph

text: by applying the lessons of modern industrial technique and rational thinking to the
label: Paragraph

text: outlived historicism of prewar architecture as well as to the disorder and squalor of
label: Paragraph

text: existing urban environments. Rooted in a strong sense of social commitment and relying
label: Paragraph

text: on the effectiveness of serial production and rational processes as design strategies,
label: Paragraph

text: modern architects sought a better, healthier world. The Aaltos’ Tuberculosis Sanatorium
label: Paragraph

text: at Paimio was both a symbol of the social role of the new architecture and a potent visual
label: Paragraph

text: paradigm of the new world that modern architecture intended to bring into being.
label: Paragraph

text: Sun. Light. Fresh air. The physical presence of these natural elements informed the
label: Paragraph

text: basis of building design and engendered the qualities of good health associated with
label: Paragraph

text: modernist social thinking. Moreover, as a polemic, sun, light, and fresh air were vital
label: Paragraph

text: images of the modern, healthier world. Few other building types were as convincing a
label: Paragraph

text: symbol of modern architecture as was the sanatorium. The actual medical treatment for
label: Paragraph

text: tuberculosis at the time—lots of sun, light, and fresh air—provided a strong image base
label: Paragraph

text: for the design of the building and coincided with the metaphor of “health” central to
label: Paragraph

text: modernist thought.
label: Paragraph

text: The completion of the Paimio Sanatorium acknowledged Alvar Aalto’s prominent
label: Paragraph

text: place among the modem architects of the day because it bore witness to his
label: Paragraph

text: understanding and mastery of modernism’s social as well as compositional tenets.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the sanatorium was not the Aaltos’ first modernist work. Having fostered
label: Paragraph

text: connections to the international avant-garde in the mid-1920s, they moved their office to
label: Paragraph

text: the city of Turku in 1927 and completed two important “functionalist” works.
label: Paragraph

text: “Functionalism” was the term used by Finnish architects to label the new, modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The first important work was the Standard Apartment Building in Turku
label: Paragraph

text: (1929), and the second was the Turun Sanomat Newspaper Building (1927), which was
label: Paragraph

text: the first work in Finland to incorporate Le Corbusier’s “Five Points of a New
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture,” setting the Aaltos apart from their contemporaries. During this period, the
label: Paragraph

text: Aaltos were active advocates and propagandists for Finnish functionalism.
label: Paragraph

text: Conceptually, the Paimio Sanatorium is a straightforward modernist composition: an
label: Paragraph

text: articulated but linked set of relatively discrete functional elements expressed in both plan
label: Paragraph

text: and volumes. The building complex is functionally zoned, with each element placed in
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape according to its requirement for sun and view. The primary functional
label: Paragraph

text: elements include the patient’s wing, comprised of an elongated suite of rooms with an
label: Paragraph

text: open-air terrace extension, and the communal dining and assembly areas. These two
label: Paragraph

text: pieces are linked by a seven-story volume, the entry, and control area, which houses the
label: Paragraph

text: vertical circulation. A circulation passage connects through these elements to the service
label: Paragraph

text: area—with its expressed water tank, smokestack, and staircase—which in turn joins the
label: Paragraph

text: garage. The housing units for both the doctors and the staff are separated from the main
label: Paragraph

text: building, being located in the surrounding forest. We have, then, the rational and orderly
label: Paragraph

text: composition of differimg human activities rendered into a highly visible and expressed set
label: Paragraph

text: of spaces and forms.
label: Paragraph

text: The Aaltos employed the material vocabulary that came to be associated with the
label: Paragraph

text: modernist machine aesthetic: concrete, white stucco, steel, and glass. The overall image
label: Paragraph

text: of the building comes from its concrete frame rendered in white stucco. The whiteness
label: Paragraph

text: not only stands in contrast to the fir forest setting in which it is located but also provides
label: Paragraph

text: an image of cleanliness and healthiness. Each activity volume incorporates a different
label: Paragraph

text: glazing pattern to articulate its particular function, further reinforcing the elemental
label: Paragraph

text: nature of the organization. The industrial glazing, with its steel sash and serially produced
label: Paragraph

text: image, complements the pipe-rail balustrades painted in primary colors; the bright,
label: Paragraph

text: colorful awnings; and other machined elements that give the building a somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: nautical quality.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite its mechanistic appearance, Paimio went beyond the conventions of modernist
label: Paragraph

text: elemental composition. Volumetrically and in plan, its discrete elements are not unified
label: Paragraph

text: geometrically or orthogonally, as in Gropius’s more regularized Bauhaus building (1926),
label: Paragraph

text: but form a more haptic pattern: a chain of architectural pieces in the landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: Eschewing the modernist tendency to place buildings as isolated elements on the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape, Paimio appears as a dialogue between the internal world of space and activity
label: Paragraph

text: and the exterior concerns of context and form. For example, the patient wing and
label: Paragraph

text: communal areas splay away from each other to form a cour de hounor, allowing the entry
label: Paragraph

text: court with its undulating canopy to gain more spatial prominence. Although the white,
label: Paragraph

text: rational image stands in contrast to the deep green forest, the sanatorium is actually a sun
label: Paragraph

text: trap. The patient wing, facing southeast, provides each patient with morning sunlight. The
label: Paragraph

text: open-air terraces at the east end of the wing have been rotated further south to catch more
label: Paragraph

text: sun. The dining and lounge area is oriented, with equal care, to receive the sun at
label: Paragraph

text: different times during the day.
label: Paragraph

text: Paimio is not without precedent, for the Aaltos were traveling throughout Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: meeting with the avant-garde architects and artists during the period of its design.
label: Paragraph

text: Influences from the Dutch architect Jan Duiker and his Zonnestraal Sanatorium (1926—
label: Paragraph

text: 28), the French architects Andre Lurcat and Le Corbusier, and Russian constructivism are
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the work. Yet it was the Aaltos’ ability to meld these influences into an
label: Paragraph

text: independent synthesis that is extraordinary. Moreover, their entry for the earlier
label: Paragraph

text: Kinkomaa Sanatorium competition (1927) used a similar elemental composition strategy,
label: Paragraph

text: whereas their later competition entries for the Kalvid Sanatorium (1929) and the Zagrev
label: Paragraph

text: Central Hospital (1931) demonstrate further refinement of the ideas seen in Paimio. The
label: Paragraph

text: sanatorium stands as witness to the Aaltos’ mastery of modernist design canons and
label: Paragraph

text: social programs, and its functionalist expression placed their name with those of Gropius,
label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe, and Le Corbusier, among others, in the international scene of the day.
label: Paragraph

text: The development of detail in Paimio is extraordinary. Attention was paid to the venting
label: Paragraph

text: of the windows, panel heating elements, nonsplash washbasins, and light fixtures that did
label: Paragraph

text: not cast light into a bedridden patient’s eyes. The suite of furnishings developed for
label: Paragraph

text: Paimio—chairs and tables incorporating continuously curved, bentwood frames and
label: Paragraph

text: backs and made of laminated, molded birch—represent the culmination of a series of
label: Paragraph

text: furniture studies and wood experiments that began in 1927. In the Paimio furniture, the
label: Paragraph

text: Aaltos combined serial production with Finnish laminated plywood technology. The free-
label: Paragraph

text: form quality of these pieces informed his buildings immediately following the sanatorium
label: Paragraph

text: and signaled their movement away from functionalist tenets toward the more personal
label: Paragraph

text: style that emerged in the late 1930s.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Over the course of Alvar Aalto’s 50-year career (Aino Aalto died in 1949), much has
label: Paragraph

text: been published on his architecture. The year 1998 marked the celebration of the
label: Paragraph

text: centenary of his birth, and a number of new interpretive works have appeared. In most
label: Paragraph

text: publications addressing the larger spectrum of his career, great emphasis is placed on the
label: Paragraph

text: significance of the Tuberculosis Sanatorium at Paimio to Alvar and Aino Aalto’s overall
label: Paragraph

text: development. The references listed below include those that have important or interesting
label: Paragraph

text: discussion or documentation of the Sanatorium.

text: PALACE OF THE SOVIETS
label: Title

text: COMPETITION (1931)
label: Title

text: The 1931 competition for the Palace of the Soviets in Moscow represents a turning point
label: Paragraph

text: in Soviet architecture. The competition prefaced the gradual demise of the Soviet avant-
label: Paragraph

text: garde movement known as Constructivism and the rise of a more historically attuned
label: Paragraph

text: approach to architecture that dominated in the Soviet Union up to and beyond the Cold
label: Paragraph

text: War. More specifically, the competition rejected the modernist aesthetic in favor of a new
label: Paragraph

text: architectural language, which was officially endorsed in 1937 at the First Conference of
label: Paragraph

text: Soviet Architects and was known as “socialist realism.”
label: Paragraph

text: Ostensibly, the Palace of the Soviets was intended to celebrate the anticipated
label: Paragraph

text: completion of the first Five Year Plan (to occur in 1933). The Palace of the Soviets
label: Paragraph

text: competition was also a deliberate Soviet response to the international competition for the
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters of the League of Nations, held in Geneva four years earlier. The project was
label: Paragraph

text: influenced heavily by the government and implemented by the Palace Construction
label: Paragraph

text: Council, a subsidiary of the Party Central Committee. The competition brief for the
label: Paragraph

text: building, which was developed by the Construction Council, called for a range of cultural
label: Paragraph

text: and political spaces. The primary function of the Palace was to house the nation’s highest
label: Paragraph

text: governing body, the elected assembly of the Supreme Soviet. In addition, it was also
label: Paragraph

text: intended to support Revolutionary festivals, conferences and musical and theatrical
label: Paragraph

text: productions. The building included two large halls (one seating 15000 people, the other
label: Paragraph

text: 6000), two smaller halls each seating 500 people, and two more seating 200 people. The
label: Paragraph

text: brief called for a new relationship between form and content that was capable of
label: Paragraph

text: representing socialist doctrine, class struggle, and the dominance of the proletariat. The
label: Paragraph

text: site chosen for the competition was on the Moskva River in Moscow, and it was decided
label: Paragraph

text: that the Cathedral of the Christ-Savior (built between 1838 and 1880 to celebrate the
label: Paragraph

text: Russian defeat of Napoleon) would be demolished to create a new site southwest of the
label: Paragraph

text: Kremlin for the Palace.
label: Caption

text: Initially, in February 1931, 12 Soviet architects were invited to submit proposals for a
label: Paragraph

text: preliminary closed round of the competition. The prominent Soviet modernist and
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist schools of SASS (formally OSA), ASNOVA, and ARU as well as the rival
label: Paragraph

text: school of VOPRA all submitted team proposals (at the request of the Construction
label: Paragraph

text: Council). Individual entries from Alexei Shchusev, Nikolai Ladovsky, Alexander
label: Caption

text: Nikolsky, Boris lofan, Genrikh Liudvig, and Daniil Fridman were also submitted.
label: Paragraph

text: On 18 July 1931, the competition was extended into a more open event and the already
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned designs (exhibited in August 1931) were included in this later stage.
label: Paragraph

text: Further to this, 12 architects were invited to submit proposals for this round, including
label: Paragraph

text: nine international architects such as Le Corbusier, Auguste Perret, Walter Gropius, Erich
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn, and Hans Poelzig. The three Soviet architects invited, Zholtovski, lofan,
label: Paragraph

text: and Krasin, were all experienced professional architects. In total, this revised competition
label: Paragraph

text: drew 160 entries, with 24 from foreign architects. A further 112 “noncompetitive” entries
label: Paragraph

text: were received from ordinary Soviet citizens, which, although not being considered for the
label: Paragraph

text: competition, received considerable attention in the press. Among the individual soviet
label: Paragraph

text: entries were schemes by leading figures at the time such as Konstantin Melnikov, Ivan
label: Paragraph

text: Leonidov, Moisei Ginzburg, and the Vesnin brothers.
label: Paragraph

text: Of the first-round entries, the majority belonged to the modernist or Constructivist
label: Paragraph

text: school of thinking. Many of the schemes, both local and international, borrowed heavily
label: Paragraph

text: from machine forms and industrial imagery. Of the international entrants, Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: generated the most interest because of its dynamic exposed roof structure. However, it
label: Paragraph

text: was his functional and symbolic representation of each of the elements of the brief, and
label: Paragraph

text: the manipulation of traffic to emphasize entry points, that most characterized his project.
label: Paragraph

text: In the context of architectural history, Le Corbusier’s scheme remains the most
label: Paragraph

text: influential of the entrants. In contrast, Mendelsohn’s scheme used the natural fall of the
label: Paragraph

text: site to arrange a compact but less expressive arrangement, and Gropius adopted a circular
label: Paragraph

text: configuration, connecting the two halls through a central circulation core. Of the Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: schemes, the project submitted by Ginzberg included a large sphere that anchored an
label: Paragraph

text: otherwise rectilinear composition. The scheme proposed by the Vesnins was composed of
label: Paragraph

text: a circular and rectilinear form, with a statue of Lenin situated above a tower. Among the
label: Paragraph

text: more original entries was that of Melnikov, who rejected both the classical and modernist
label: Paragraph

text: approaches, attempting instead to provide an architectural representation of the
label: Paragraph

text: achievements of the Revolution. The eventual form he proposed evoked the proletariat
label: Paragraph

text: symbol of an inverted cone that had been split apart by the forces of revolution.
label: Paragraph

text: At the end of this stage, the jury members (including Maxim Gorky among others)
label: Paragraph

text: awarded two first prizes to the strongly historical designs of the Soviet architects lofan
label: Paragraph

text: and Zholtovsky. An additional first prize was awarded to an American architect, Hector
label: Paragraph

text: Hamilton, with the majority of the remaining prizes being awarded to Soviet architects.
label: Paragraph

text: Even before awarding the prizes, the Construction Council announced that “the
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality, simplicity, integrity and elegance of architectural conception of the
label: Paragraph

text: Palace of Soviets was not found in totally acceptable form” in any of the entries. The jury
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated particular dissatisfaction with the modernist proposals that it maintained
label: Paragraph

text: were too industrial. Le Corbusier’s scheme was cited as representing “a complicated
label: Paragraph

text: machine,” which, in its over emphasis on function, was seen as detrimental to the
label: Paragraph

text: symbolism required by the brief.
label: Paragraph

text: On 5 May 1933, following two more stages in the competition that contained only
label: Paragraph

text: invited Soviet architects (and mostly with a bias toward Russian Revivalism), the
label: Paragraph

text: ultimate prize was awarded to the neoclassical design of Boris lofan. lofan’s scheme was
label: Paragraph

text: over 220 meters in height and consisted of a series of colonnaded tiers stacked on each
label: Paragraph

text: other and finally culminating in a statue of “the liberated proletariat.” A few days after
label: Paragraph

text: the winning entry was announced, Stalin proposed that the statue should be enlarged four
label: Paragraph

text: times in size to a height of 75 meters and made in the image of Lenin. This was the
label: Paragraph

text: beginning of what Kruschev would later denounce as Stalin’s “Cult of Personality.” The
label: Paragraph

text: intervention of the war in 1941 prevented lofan’s building ever being realized, despite the
label: Paragraph

text: completion of documentation by lofan in collaboration with the academics Shchuko and
label: Paragraph

text: Gelifreikh. In spite of this, the legacy of the project in not only Soviet but also
label: Paragraph

text: international architectural circles is immense. Most notably, it announced the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: energetic architectural avant-garde in the Soviet Union and ushered in a new age of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, dominated by political personalities, rather than architectural creativity.
label: Paragraph

text: PALAIS STOCLET, BRUSSELS
label: Caption

text: Designed by Josef Hoffmann; completed 1911 Brussels, Belgium
label: Caption

text: The Palais Stoclet is a villa designed by Josef Hoffmann in Brussels and built between
label: Paragraph

text: 1905 and 1911 for the Belgian millionaire Adolphe Stoclet and his wife. Although built
label: Paragraph

text: in Belgium, the Palais is one of the finest examples of Viennese Art Nouveau, or
label: Paragraph

text: Jugendstil, and is the most comprehensive realization of the design goals of the Vienna
label: Paragraph

text: workshops. The building represents an elaborate example of the synthesis of architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: interior design, and garden design that the Viennese movement accomplished. The Palais
label: Paragraph

text: is a design Gesamtkunstwerk, or total work of art—an important aesthetic goal of Central
label: Paragraph

text: European art that had, in addition to architectural design, important influences in opera
label: Paragraph

text: (Wilhelm Wagner) and painting (Wassily Kandinsky). Gesamtkunstwerk design sought to
label: Paragraph

text: create an aesthetic union of all components of a building. To achieve this, a single artist
label: Paragraph

text: would design all aspects of the building and its furnishings, as in work by Peter Behrens
label: Paragraph

text: and Henry van de Velde. The Palais, however, represented a collaborative effort
label: Paragraph

text: involving the full resources of the Vienna workshops. Led by Hoffmann as architect and
label: Paragraph

text: project coordinator, some 50 craftsmen contributed to the design, execution, and
label: Paragraph

text: decoration of the entire villa, including its furniture, artwork, light fixtures, wall
label: Paragraph

text: coverings, bathroom tiles, and cutlery. All aspects of Viennese modernism came together
label: Paragraph

text: in the Palais Stoclet.
label: Caption

text: Stylistically, the building represents the Viennese version of Art Nouveau, or what is
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes referred to as “secession-style,” because the forms are geometrical rather than
label: Paragraph

text: vegetative curves. Brussels had already been the home of Art Nouveau buildings by
label: Paragraph

text: Victor Horta and Henri van de Velde. The addition of the Palais Stoclet made Brussels
label: Paragraph

text: one of the few cities where organic and geometrical forms of Art Nouveau were
label: Paragraph

text: successfully combined.
label: Paragraph

text: The son of a wealthy Belgian banker, Stoclet lived in Vienna for about 18 months in
label: Paragraph

text: 1903-04 and was planning to build a home in the city. Impressed by the proportions of a
label: Paragraph

text: villa in Vienna’s suburbs built for the painter Carl Moll, the Stoclets learned that Josef
label: Paragraph

text: Hoffmann was the architect and approached him about building a villa. The Stoclets
label: Paragraph

text: originally intended to build in Vienna, but following the death of Stoclet’s father, they
label: Paragraph

text: returned to Brussels. The Stoclets gave Hoffmann carte blanche with the design and
label: Paragraph

text: building costs, which used only the finest and costiest materials. Construction took six
label: Paragraph

text: years, and each time something failed to please either Stoclet or the designers, it was
label: Paragraph

text: disassembled, redesigned, and rebuilt without regard to the mounting expense. The Palais
label: Caption

text: was to be a perfectly realized artistic dwelling, and its final cost never has been revealed.
label: Paragraph

text: The Palais stands in a suburb of Brussels at Avenue de Tervueren 279-281. The
label: Paragraph

text: building consists of two parts: a large residential block, and a service wing with a garage
label: Paragraph

text: and workshop for Stoclet, who was an auto enthusiast. The residential block has three
label: Paragraph

text: floors, plus a basement and an attic. The service wing had only a single floor. The strong
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal movement of the main structure balances the tall, vertical lines of the stairwell
label: Paragraph

text: tower. Four human figures sculpted by Franz Metzner crown the tower; they surround a
label: Caption

text: dome of gilded vegetation, similar to Olbrich’s Secession building. Figures of Hercules,
label: Caption

text: Apollo, Athena, and the Hindu god Ganesha also adorn the building.
label: Caption

text: Despite the use of rich materials, the building’s effect is serene rather than pompous.
label: Paragraph

text: The Palais was built of reinforced concrete and brick that was faced with plates of white
label: Paragraph

text: Norwegian marble. The exterior has a monumental quality created by the elegant use of
label: Paragraph

text: geometric forms and white surfaces punctuated by regular fenestration. Gilded bronze
label: Caption

text: bands unify the various elements and provide a counterpart to the generally white exterior
label: Paragraph

text: of the building.
label: Paragraph

text: The combination of volumes projecting from a basic rectangular prism was admired
label: Paragraph

text: widely in art circles, leading to comparison with baroque use of volumes; it created
label: Paragraph

text: formal drama and the illusion of even greater use of space. The gradual ascension of
label: Paragraph

text: formal elements was an attempt to blend the building into the countryside. Gardens
label: Paragraph

text: complement the house.
label: Paragraph

text: The interior of the Palais Stoclet was intended for an affluent lifestyle. Most rooms
label: Paragraph

text: have lavish proportions: the main bedroom is 30 by 18 feet, and Mme Stoclet’s dressing
label: Paragraph

text: room is 20 by 20 feet. Designers and patrons chose luxurious treatments for the public
label: Paragraph

text: rooms, featuring polychrome marble, rosewood, and parquet floors. The main dining
label: Caption

text: room is especially opulent, with an inlaid mosaic frieze designed by Gustav Klimt that is
label: Paragraph

text: artistically significant in its own right. The frieze’s themes are expectation and
label: Paragraph

text: fulfillment, amusing choices for a dining room. They were Klimt’s only opportunity to
label: Paragraph

text: actualize his painted mosaics.
label: Paragraph

text: The entire household was designed and created as a unit. In an extravagant
label: Paragraph

text: prefabrication, each room was completely assembled in Vienna for approval before being
label: Paragraph

text: dismounted and shipped to Brussels for installation. The utensils, furnishings, and
label: Paragraph

text: architecture were intended to complement one another in total harmony, like an organic
label: Paragraph

text: system. Subtle relationships reflected the Gesamtkunstwerk concept; for example, chairs
label: Paragraph

text: in the public rooms had backs that were exactly as high as the bronze bands on the
label: Paragraph

text: exterior of the building. The rooms and
label: Paragraph

text: Palais Stoclet, Brussels, designed by Josef Hoffmann (1905-11)
label: Caption

text: © Wayne Andrews/Esto
label: Title

text: arrangement also were intended to showcase the Stoclets’ art collection, but other than
label: Paragraph

text: the art collection, no preexisting furnishings or decorations were used.
label: Paragraph

text: Virtually every figure associated with the Vienna Workshops became involved in the
label: Paragraph

text: project. Klimt’s cartoons for the dining room mosaic were executed by the Vienna
label: Caption

text: workshops using inlay of white marble, gold, silver, enamel, coral, and other
label: Paragraph

text: semiprecious stones. The painters and designers Koloman Moser, Carl Otto Czeschka,
label: Caption

text: and Leopold Forstner contributed to the furniture and other design elements. Bertold
label: Paragraph

text: Léfler and Michael Powolny designed the ceramic decorations. Franz Metzner created
label: Paragraph

text: the exterior sculpture as well as an animal frieze for the nursery. From the wallpaper and
label: Caption

text: draperies to the garden terraces, trellises, and garden furniture, the Palais Stoclet is the
label: Paragraph

text: supreme achievement of the collaborative ideals of Hoffmann and the Vienna workshops.

text: PALLASMAA, JUHANI 1936—
label: Title

text: Architect, Finland
label: Title

text: Juhani Pallasmaa (born 1936 in Hameenlinna, Finland) is a Helsinki-based architect,
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition designer, and town planner. Pallasmaa is also a prolific essayist and the former
label: Paragraph

text: director of both the Finnish Museum of Architecture and the architecture program at
label: Paragraph

text: Helsinki University of Technology, where he graduated in 1966.
label: Paragraph

text: Pallasmaa’s modest oeuvre of built work belies his substantial influence in Finland and
label: Paragraph

text: abroad. His first project was characteristically intellectual and architectural: Moduli 225,
label: Paragraph

text: developed in 1969 with Kristian Gullichsen. The stick-built system of prefabricated
label: Paragraph

text: building components is based on a 75-by-225-cm module and sought a practical outlet for
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s interest in proportional systems, as standardization offered not only economies
label: Paragraph

text: of scale but also the possibility of relating a module of construction directly to a module
label: Paragraph

text: of proportion. Roughly 50 houses were built. The domestic scope of Moduli 225
label: Paragraph

text: characterizes it as both a reinterpretation of traditional Japanese construction as well as a
label: Paragraph

text: reworking of Finnish architect Alvar Aalto’s postwar inquiry into standardized dwellings.
label: Paragraph

text: However, Pallasmaa’s subsequent teaching and research persuaded him that modern
label: Paragraph

text: cities suffered more from standardization than they gained. Writing in 1983 that
label: Paragraph

text: “probably the greatest shortcoming of the Modern Movement is that it has not been able
label: Paragraph

text: to transform itself into a positive vernacular tradition,” Pallasmaa set out to diagnose the
label: Paragraph

text: causes of this failure as well as to attempt to explain what a “positive vernacular” might
label: Paragraph

text: be. This ongoing inquiry has involved stitching together psychological,
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenological, and architectural observations into broad themes while maintaining
label: Paragraph

text: concern for the social milieu or individual experience. These broad themes—already in
label: Paragraph

text: play with Moduli 225—center on two poles: a concern for the ordinary (the role of
label: Paragraph

text: traditional and quotidian in architecture) and the question of architectural and cultural
label: Paragraph

text: modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Pallasmaa’s interest in mute, harmonious proportions is paired with the ideal of an
label: Paragraph

text: unprepossessing, modest, even anonymous architecture, characterized by unheroic forms
label: Paragraph

text: and materials. A limited material and formal palette is typically deployed in contrasts:
label: Paragraph

text: open versus closed, hand-made versus machine-made, edge versus surface. In his
label: Paragraph

text: buildings and installations, the juxtaposition of disparate materials constitute Pallasmaa’s
label: Paragraph

text: efforts to appeal to the multiple senses—his built work is “experiential” rather than
label: Paragraph

text: cerebral. Also, the deployment of ordinary materials represents Pallasmaa’s own interest
label: Paragraph

text: in vernacular traditions, albeit as reimvented for a modern age.
label: Paragraph

text: Adopting poet Joseph Brodsky’s dictum that beauty can only be achieved by working
label: Paragraph

text: with the every day, Pallasmaa’s first important building, the Rovaniemi Art Museum
label: Paragraph

text: (1986) recycles a former postal depot into a gallery. The long masonry building was
label: Paragraph

text: originally reconstructed with bricks salvaged from war-destroyed Lapland; Pallasmaa’s
label: Paragraph

text: retrofit exposes these reclaimed bricks throughout the interior, providing a quiet,
label: Paragraph

text: poignant backdrop to the art mounted therein. On the exterior, Pallasmaa’s interventions
label: Paragraph

text: are subtle and deliberate: A new entrance threshold of glass and steel projects from the
label: Paragraph

text: facade, fronted by five columns of different granites, marking the entrance and
label: Paragraph

text: contrasting with the delicate entry pavilion behind.
label: Paragraph

text: Pallasmaa has also reworked the idea of the granite column entrance for the installation
label: Paragraph

text: “Driveway Square” at the Cranbook Academy (1994), where the columns play a role as
label: Paragraph

text: part of a cosmic marker. Another project in Lapland, the Sami Museum and Northern
label: Paragraph

text: Lapland Visitors Center (1998), inserts a minimalist building of modest scale into an
label: Paragraph

text: arctic fells landscape, with a sympathetic installation of Sami cultural artifacts inside.
label: Paragraph

text: Anonymity and harmony are hallmarks against which Pallasmaa measures
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary society and its architectures. Pallasmaa’s critical output in the 1980s
label: Paragraph

text: asserted that Postmodern architecture represented neither reforms of modern architecture
label: Paragraph

text: nor new “positive” vernaculars. A 1988 essay, “Tradition and Modernity,” revisits the
label: Paragraph

text: modernist canon using criteria different from formal innovation. Pallasmaa constructs an
label: Paragraph

text: archaeology of modernism with his 1996 text The Melnikhov House (with Andrei
label: Paragraph

text: Gozak}—an analysis of the modern house the Russian architect Konstantin Melnikhov
label: Paragraph

text: built for himself in Moscow. The contradictions between the house’s platonic
label: Paragraph

text: interlocking cylinders and its complicated, organic construction suggest traditional
label: Paragraph

text: precedents for Melnikhov’s otherwise unorthodox, Platonic home. Pallasmaa evokes
label: Paragraph

text: Melnikhov’s complicated milieu via an examination of materials and details.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, the idea of home is central to Pallasmaa’s thinking. Before 1986 nearly all his
label: Paragraph

text: built work was housing, including a summer atelier for Tor Arne (1970). His studies
label: Paragraph

text: concerning the idea of “home” are careful to avoid cliché, including the sentimental or
label: Paragraph

text: kitsch. Instead, Pallasmaa has relied on the work of French philosopher Gaston Bachelard
label: Paragraph

text: (La poétique de l’espace [The Poetics of Space], 1958) to construct a practical
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenology of architecture against the tactile and sensual poverty of modern
label: Title

text: construction. Pallasmaa’s work also extends to the scholarly, and his comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: survey of Aalto’s furniture as well as a monograph of the Villa Mairea, Aalto’s own
label: Paragraph

text: domestic Gesamtkunstwerk (total work of art), reflects his expansive approach to
label: Paragraph

text: domestic architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: PAMPULHA BUILDINGS BELO
label: Title

text: HORIZONTE, BRAZIL
label: Title

text: Designed by Oscar Niemeyer; completed 1942
label: Caption

text: Scattered around the Pampulha artificial lake in what was then the northern edge of the
label: Paragraph

text: city of Belo Horizonte, the four buildings by Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer
label: Caption

text: (completed in 1942) represent a landmark of Brazilian modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1941 the city’s mayor, Jucelino Kubitchek (who would be the president to build
label: Paragraph

text: Brasilia 15 years later), commissioned the young Niemeyer to design a series of buildings
label: Paragraph

text: around the Pampulha lake, inaugurating a partnership that would change the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: and urban face of the country. The designs for the four Pampulha buidings—Capela da
label: Paragraph

text: Pampulha, Casino, late Clube, and Casa do Baile—became the paradigm for Brazilian
label: Paragraph

text: architectural modernism as well as an international icon.
label: Paragraph

text: The Capela da Pampulha, or Chapel of Saint Francis of Assisi, is an intimate chapel
label: Paragraph

text: built on a small peninsula in a curved piece of land between the lake and its encircling
label: Paragraph

text: road. The chapel’s entire back wall, which faces the street, is covered by a mural of
label: Paragraph

text: azulejos (painted ceramic tiles) by the artist Candido Portinari. Azu/ejos is a Portuguese
label: Paragraph

text: technique widely used on Brazilian modernist buildings. Gardens by Roberto Burle Marx
label: Paragraph

text: guide visitors around the chapel to the adro (open area in front of churches used as
label: Paragraph

text: transition space) that spreads between the entrance and the lake edges. The floor is
label: Paragraph

text: designed in an amoeboid pattern in white marble and black granite that penetrates the
label: Paragraph

text: chapel and unites inside and outside. From the adro, one can see the whole form—its
label: Paragraph

text: parabolic vaults covered by small ceramic tiles (pastilhas), the glazing and bris-soleil at
label: Paragraph

text: the facade, and the inverted bell tower and its inclined canopy—uniting the tower with
label: Paragraph

text: the main door that marks and defines the entrance.
label: Paragraph

text: The Casino was also built on a peninsula between the lake and the road, this time with
label: Paragraph

text: the entrance to the main cubic volume facing Burle Marx’s gardens and the driveway.
label: Paragraph

text: Elements of the entrance, such as its free-form canopy supported by thin steel columns
label: Paragraph

text: and the continuous glass wall on the facade, would be exhaustively replicated all around
label: Paragraph

text: postwar Brazil. Inside the cubic main volume, the ramp dominates, and the round
label: Paragraph

text: concrete columns punctuate the rhythm of the interior space. At the back, closer to the
label: Paragraph

text: lake, an elliptical dance hall is integrated with the main volume by another ramp, and its
label: Paragraph

text: continuous glass wall brings the lake landscape inside the building. Kenneth Frampton
label: Caption

text: (1980) exalted that the “Niemeyer genius reached its height in 1942” at the Casino, where
label: Paragraph

text: he “reinterpreted the Corbusian notion of promenade architecturale in a spatial
label: Paragraph

text: composition of remarkable balance and vivacity.”
label: Paragraph

text: For the late Clube, Niemeyer experimented with the inverted roof to maximize the
label: Paragraph

text: view of the lake for those using the main upper hall. This roof form would become a
label: Paragraph

text: trademark of Brazilian modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: In the Casa do Baile (dance hall}, a small cylindrical building houses the bar, restaurant
label: Paragraph

text: area, and stage. Attached to this cylinder is a meandering canopy supported by rounded
label: Paragraph

text: columns that provide shelter and defme the space. The volumes are covered with painted
label: Paragraph

text: ceramic azulejos. The canopy is the highlight of the building and, following the curves of
label: Paragraph

text: the lake, defines the external space for those under it and frames the view for those
label: Paragraph

text: passing by the road.
label: Paragraph

text: Church of St. Francis of Assisi, Pampulha, Brazil, designed by Oscar Niemeyer
label: Caption

text: © Roberto Segre
label: Title

text: At Pampulha, Niemeyer (now working alone) produced an architecture that was, for the
label: Paragraph

text: first time, distanced from the Le Corbusian syntax of his early influence and that was
label: Paragraph

text: certainly more mature and personal than his designs for the Brazilian Pavilion at the New
label: Paragraph

text: York World’s Fair (1939) or the Hotel (1940) in Ouro Preto. If Niemeyer was applying
label: Paragraph

text: the Le Corbusian idea of spatial promenade, he was also challenging the Le Corbusian
label: Paragraph

text: idea of the “Five Points of a New Architecture,” especially at the Capela. The Pampulha
label: Paragraph

text: buildings masterfully solve the conflict between local versus international references,
label: Paragraph

text: representation versus abstraction, and industrialization versus artisan construction.
label: Paragraph

text: The relevance and originality of the Pampulha buildings resonated in Brazil and abroad
label: Paragraph

text: even before the buildings were completed. In 1942, as part of the good-neighborhood
label: Paragraph

text: policy toward South America, an exhibition was being organized at the Museum of
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Art in New York City. The “Brazil Builds” exhibition included works by Lucio
label: Paragraph

text: Costa, Affonso Reidy, Rino Levi, and the young Niemeyer, who was represented by the
label: Paragraph

text: Pampulha buildings, still under construction. The international debate of the following
label: Paragraph

text: decade would embrace the work, with Nikolas Pevsner labeling Pampulha as subversive
label: Paragraph

text: work, Reyner Banham discussing it as the first national style in modern architecture, and
label: Paragraph

text: Gino Dorfles defining it as neobaroque. In this sense, Pampulha defined the conceptual
label: Paragraph

text: foundation of what would be the best Brazilian architecture of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: PANAMA-PACIFIC INTERNATIONAL
label: Title

text: EXPOSITION, SAN FRANCISCO (1915-16)
label: Caption

text: The Panama-Pacific International Exposition, the great world’s fair held in San Francisco
label: Paragraph

text: in 1915-16 to celebrate the completion of the Panama Canal, is remembered primarily for
label: Paragraph

text: Berard Maybeck’s Palace of Fine Arts, his majestically overscaled rotunda. As
label: Paragraph

text: noteworthy as Maybeck’s structure is, the exposition should also be remembered for its
label: Paragraph

text: innovative site planning and its carefully considered use of color.
label: Paragraph

text: The completion of the Panama Canal was an event of such significance that it was
label: Paragraph

text: considered fitting that the United States should host a world’s fair in commemoration.
label: Paragraph

text: Although New Orleans was the early favorite, influential politicians from the Pacific
label: Paragraph

text: Coast ensured that San Francisco was eventually chosen to showcase both the canal and
label: Paragraph

text: the city’s reconstruction after the earthquake and fire of 1906. Planning for the exposition
label: Caption

text: began in 1911, when the Harbor View site (now the Marina) was selected for its views of
label: Paragraph

text: the bay and for its location at the termination of then-fashionable Van Ness Avenue. The
label: Paragraph

text: exposition’s physical layout was determined by an architectural commission that was
label: Paragraph

text: headed by Willis Polk and then George Kelham and included prominent California
label: Paragraph

text: architects and several eastern practitioners of national reputation, including Thomas
label: Paragraph

text: Hastings, Henry Bacon, and the firm of McKim, Mead and White. The Board of
label: Paragraph

text: Architects chose to develop Ermest Coxhead’s so-called court scheme, as developed by
label: Paragraph

text: Chicagoan Edward H. Bennett; this arrangement best unified the various exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: buildings and controlled the cold winds that blew off the bay by adopting an introverted
label: Paragraph

text: ground plan in which most facilities were surrounded by a high ornamented wall. Every
label: Paragraph

text: structure was to be in some way subordinate to the whole. As Polk put it, “The serene
label: Paragraph

text: goddess of harmony” was to be given her due by imposing a strict architectural unity on
label: Paragraph

text: the exterior of the general exhibition buildings—color, texture, and landscape were to be
label: Paragraph

text: tightly controlled.
label: Paragraph

text: The courts were designed around specific themes, such as “The Court of the Four
label: Paragraph

text: Seasons” or “The Court of Abundance.” The centerpiece of this circulation spine,
label: Paragraph

text: McKim, Mead and White’s Court of the Universe, focused on a pair of monumental
label: Paragraph

text: triumphal arches and was bounded by Corinthian colonnades on an elliptical plan that
label: Paragraph

text: was intended to recall Bernini’s Piazza at St. Peter’s Basilica. Despite this significant
label: Paragraph

text: gesture to the Western classical tradition, the architectural board thought of the complex
label: Paragraph

text: as a sprawling Islamic citadel, what Willis Polk called “an Aladin’s Palace, facing the
label: Paragraph

text: azure harbor and the mountains beyond.” This aesthetic sensibility was retained by many
label: Paragraph

text: of the exposition architects as they developed their individual projects, most of whom
label: Paragraph

text: employed a tower or a dome in one way or another. Carrére and Hastings’ signature
label: Paragraph

text: building, the Tower of Jewels, sported Byzantine details and 50,000 glass jewels,
label: Paragraph

text: fabricated in five colors by Austrian workshops. Louis Christian Mullgardt’s Court of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ages was modeled on Moorish prototypes such as the Alhambra, whereas the exposition
label: Paragraph

text: halls themselves were designed largely by another local architect, William B.Faville, in a
label: Paragraph

text: “Hispano-Moorish” style that employed
label: Paragraph

text: Palace of Fine Arts, Baker Street, designed by Bernard Maybeck (1915)
label: Caption

text: © Historic American Buildings Survey/Library of Congress
label: Caption

text: Roman classical motifs. Bakewell and Brown’s Palace of Horticulture was reminiscent of
label: Paragraph

text: the Blue Mosque in Constantinople with its enormous glass dome, spiky minarets, and
label: Paragraph

text: cascading semidomes (although it sported French baroque ornament).
label: Paragraph

text: Color was a distinguishing hallmark of the exposition. Unlike the use of white at the
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago, Buffalo, and St. Louis expositions, color was deemed to be an important actor
label: Paragraph

text: in setting the exotic mood of the exposition grounds. The architectural renderer Jules
label: Paragraph

text: Guerin was commissioned as the chief of decoration. He established a palette dominated
label: Paragraph

text: by a warm faux travertine, a russet red, a burnt orange, and sea-foam green. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: some critics were concerned that the wide use of color obscured the detailed ornament of
label: Paragraph

text: the architecture, most observers were enchanted by nightly illuminations and the
label: Paragraph

text: shimmering fields of color encountered when viewing the site from one of San
label: Paragraph

text: Francisco’s many hills.
label: Paragraph

text: The exposition’s most acclaimed building was Bernard Maybeck’s Palace of Fine Arts.
label: Paragraph

text: As chairman of the architectural commission, Polk had been given the assignment to
label: Paragraph

text: design the Palace of Fine Arts, which stood at one end of the primary axis. Because Polk
label: Paragraph

text: was busy with his other duties, he held an in-house competition to make a preliminary
label: Paragraph

text: design deadline. Maybeck made a quick charcoal sketch of a Roman ruin that met with
label: Paragraph

text: immediate acclaim and won him the role as architect of the building. Maybeck chose the
label: Paragraph

text: forms of ruined antiquity for his palace, but he freely mixed different periods and styles
label: Paragraph

text: of classical architecture. Unfortunately, contemporary writers and critics could not take it
label: Paragraph

text: for what it was and insisted on classifying every column, frieze, and architrave. Yet
label: Paragraph

text: anyone who analyzed the palace from a historical perspective was missing the entire
label: Paragraph

text: point of the building. Maybeck did not sketch a building as much as an emotion. As
label: Paragraph

text: Maybeck explained in a pamphlet issued at the exposition, the proper attitude with which
label: Paragraph

text: one should view art was “that of sadness modified by the feeling that beauty has a
label: Paragraph

text: soothing influence...to make a Fine Arts composition that will fit this modified
label: Paragraph

text: melancholy, we must use those forms in architecture and gardening that will affect the
label: Paragraph

text: emotions in such a way as to produce this modified sadness.” For Maybeck, Roman
label: Paragraph

text: ruins, French picturesque parks, and the engravings of Piranesi all evoked the desired
label: Paragraph

text: emotion. Although he does not use the term, he might well have been referring to notions
label: Paragraph

text: of the sublime.
label: Paragraph

text: The lagoon and all the other landscape elements were an integral part of the scheme.
label: Paragraph

text: Maybeck and John McLaren worked closely together to ensure this synthesis. The lagoon
label: Paragraph

text: reflected the palace in the water and forced the viewer to move around it, observing the
label: Paragraph

text: rotunda from many different angles and in many different lights. On reaching the
label: Paragraph

text: colonnades, the viewer was then swept along their lengths, appreciating the sculpture
label: Paragraph

text: placed in the intercolumnations and above on the capitals and looking out again toward
label: Paragraph

text: the rotunda, where the iconographic sculptural program of the palace was best revealed.
label: Paragraph

text: On reaching the rotunda, one paused and was drawn toward the lagoon into its space,
label: Paragraph

text: where the murals in the distended coffers of the dome were best appreciated. At the
label: Paragraph

text: water’s edge, Maybeck designed an alter to art, adorned with Ralph Stackpole’s Venus,
label: Paragraph

text: which was framed by great hedges planted by McLaren.
label: Paragraph

text: The landscape, colonnades, and rotunda were simply window dressing for the
label: Paragraph

text: exposition hall, which was simply a decorated shed of steel three-hinged arches lashed
label: Paragraph

text: together inside hollow tile walls and fitted out with frame partitions and numerous
label: Paragraph

text: skylights. Like the other buildings at the exposition, the colonnades and rotunda were
label: Paragraph

text: constructed out of timber and staff. Maybeck seriously proposed allowing the building to
label: Paragraph

text: rot so that children of the future might find bits of ornament and sculpture or a wondrous
label: Paragraph

text: ruin of a previous generation. Unique among the structures of the exposition, the Palace
label: Paragraph

text: of Fine Arts was spared the wrecker’s ball, but by the 1950s the structure was
label: Paragraph

text: decomposing. By the end of the decade, a movement to rebuild the structure in concrete
label: Paragraph

text: was begun, and in 1960 a sponsor was found. Today, the rebuilt palace is the backdrop
label: Paragraph

text: for numerous community activities, television commercials, and weddings.
label: Paragraph

text: The exposition included more than just the walled city. Numerous state and
label: Paragraph

text: international pavilions accompanied the thematic exposition halls. The international
label: Paragraph

text: pavilions were usually designed in a National Romantic mode or in a traditional national
label: Paragraph

text: style, whereas the state pavilions took on Beaux-Arts classical forms or replicated a
label: Paragraph

text: historic structure associated with the state, such as Massachusetts’s replica of Bulfinch’s
label: Paragraph

text: statehouse or Virginia’s faux Mount Vernon. Perhaps the most memorable state pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: was Oregon’s redwood-log temple, “reminiscent of the Parthenon in Athens.” The
label: Paragraph

text: entertainment midway, known as The Zone, contained the usual array of rides,
label: Paragraph

text: sideshows, and ethnographic exhibits but also featured replicas of the Grand Canyon and
label: Paragraph

text: Yellowstone Park, sponsored by the Santa Fe and Union Pacific Railroads, respectively.
label: Paragraph

text: The most visited attraction, however, was L.E.Myers’s five-acre scale model of the
label: Paragraph

text: Panama Canal, which visitors toured from a 1200-seat moving platform.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the celebratory mood of the exposition was dampened by World War I, the
label: Paragraph

text: directors and exhibitors at the exposition did their best to present an optimistic,
label: Paragraph

text: progressive view of human social and political development. Perhaps San Francisco itself
label: Paragraph

text: was the best object lesson in the tenacious desire of the human spirit to overcome natural
label: Paragraph

text: and political disaster. In nine years, the City by the Bay not only reconstructed itself from
label: Paragraph

text: the ashes of the 1906 earthquake and fire but also constructed on the rubble of the old
label: Paragraph

text: city the evanescent city of the Panama-Pacific International Exposition, a powerful
label: Paragraph

text: expression of the Progressive Era.
label: Paragraph

text: PARIS, FRANCE
label: Title

text: In terms of their phenomenal size and scale, in the use of iron, glass, or concrete for their
label: Paragraph

text: construction, or in the novelty of their form, many buildings of the 19th century in Paris
label: Paragraph

text: established an outstanding tradition of architectural innovation in the city that was
label: Paragraph

text: influential in the development of modern architecture all over the world. Architects such
label: Paragraph

text: as Anatole de Baudot, Henri Labrouste, and Louis-Auguste Boileau were at the forefront
label: Paragraph

text: in the use of new materials, and engineers such as Gustave Eiffel and Victor Contamin
label: Paragraph

text: designed structures of unprecedented height and span for the international exhibition of
label: Caption

text: From the beginning of the 20th century to its end, no decade (other than the period
label: Paragraph

text: 1940-50, of World War II and its aftermath) in Paris passed without seeing the building
label: Paragraph

text: of major landmarks in the progress of architectural design.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most densely populated cities in Europe, roughly circular and bisected from
label: Paragraph

text: east to west by the Seine River, central Paris is today encircled by the péripheérique, the
label: Paragraph

text: eight-lane motorway within which live some 1.6 million people in an area of great
label: Paragraph

text: historical importance, containing major Roman remains, great medieval buildings, and
label: Paragraph

text: narrow medieval streets traversed by wide, 19th-century boulevards. The whole city is
label: Paragraph

text: dominated by large-scale 17th-, 18th-, and 19th-century squares, gardens, palaces, and
label: Paragraph

text: public buildings. It is therefore not surprising that refurbishment is one of the main 20th-
label: Paragraph

text: century themes; re-use is another, and yet another has been the relocation of museums,
label: Paragraph

text: libraries, and administrative offices in new buildings. New housing is a constant focus of
label: Paragraph

text: activity.
label: Paragraph

text: The city began the century with a huge international exhibition for which many
label: Paragraph

text: temporary and some permanent buildings were erected. Two large exhibition halls, built
label: Paragraph

text: for the Exposition Universelle of 1900, were the Grand Palais by Henri-AdolpheAuguste
label: Paragraph

text: Deglane, Louis-Albert Louvet, and Albert Thomas and the Petit Palais by Charles
label: Caption

text: Girault, both still standing in what is now the Avenue Winston-Churchill. The Grand
label: Paragraph

text: Palais as well as the adjacent Pont Alexandre III (the first bridge to cross the Seine in one
label: Paragraph

text: span, designed by the engineers Résal and Alby) are, like the Petit Palais, flamboyant in
label: Paragraph

text: their neobaroque style, but they are also openly expressive of the iron structure to which
label: Paragraph

text: they owe their form.
label: Paragraph

text: An antthistoricist movement had already by then made its mark in Paris and was
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged by the opening of Samuel Bing’s Maison de l’Art Nouveau in the rue de
label: Paragraph

text: Provence in 1895.
label: Paragraph

text: Using exposed ironwork, reinforced concrete, or masonry, buildings in the short-lived
label: Paragraph

text: style known as Art Nouveau are remarkable for their curved and undulating lines; their
label: Paragraph

text: organic, floral decoration; and their studied avoidance of motifs associated with the past.
label: Paragraph

text: Important Art Nouveau buildings in Paris by Hector Guimard include the apartment
label: Paragraph

text: building Castel Béranger (1894-98) and the entrances to many Métro underground
label: Caption

text: railway stations (1899-1903). Some of these designs were still being carried out as late as
label: Paragraph

text: 1914. For his own house in the avenue Mozart (1909-12) and the synagogue in the rue
label: Caption

text: Pavée (1913), Guimard remained faithful to the Art Nouveau after it had fallen from
label: Paragraph

text: general favor. The Samaritaine department store (1905) by Franz Jourdain was
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic of the movement, in that exposed structural ironwork is combined with
label: Paragraph

text: lavish polychrome faience decoration.
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, significant buildings were being designed with little or no decoration
label: Paragraph

text: at all. Following the pioneering systems of reinforced concrete devised by Hennebique,
label: Paragraph

text: Coignet, and Considére, the brothers Auguste and Gustave Perret were the first architects
label: Paragraph

text: to make extensive use of this constructional technique in all their buildings. The
label: Paragraph

text: apartment house at 22 rue Franklin (1902-03), the garage in the rue Pontieu (1905-06,
label: Paragraph

text: demolished ca. 1969), the Théatre des Champs-Elysées (1910-13), and the church o
label: Paragraph

text: Notre Dame, Le Raincy (1922-23), are well-known examples of buildings revealing their
label: Paragraph

text: structure and with minimal or no decorative features. Henri Sauvage designed two
label: Paragraph

text: influential apartment houses: the Maison a Gradins in the rue Vavin (1911-12) and the
label: Paragraph

text: immeuble d’appartements (1924—26) in the rue des Amiraux explore the setting back o:
label: Paragraph

text: each successive floor, with full-length balconies and the use of whitetiled facades to bring
label: Paragraph

text: light to the apartments and to the street.
label: Paragraph

text: An elegant reinforced-concrete structure was designed for a cardboard factory at
label: Paragraph

text: Lancey near Paris by the Swiss engineer Robert Maillart (1872-1940), and a pair o
label: Paragraph

text: spectacular 300-meter-long aircraft hangars (destroyed 1939-45) at Orly in the form o
label: Paragraph

text: 62.50-meter-high parabolic arches were commissioned by the French government in
label: Caption

text: 1916 from Eugéne Freysinnet (1879-1962).
label: Paragraph

text: The work of such architects and engineers as Perret, Maillart, and Freysinnet were
label: Paragraph

text: among the sources of inspiration to the Swiss-born Charles-Edouard Jeanneret (Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier), who settled in Paris in 1917 and who built his first Parisian building, the Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Ker-Ka-Re (1922-23), at Vaucresson in the western suburbs. This house, with its
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetrical facade, had smooth, white, cement-rendered walls; horizontal and vertical
label: Paragraph

text: strips of windows; and a flat roof. Its design reflected the close interest the artist had in
label: Paragraph

text: Cubist painting. A studio house in the avenue Reille for the painter Amédée Ozenfant
label: Caption

text: was completed in 1924. Le Corbusier was subsequently to design a number of celebrated
label: Paragraph

text: and influential buildings in and near Paris, including the Maison Roche/Jeanneret (square
label: Paragraph

text: du Docteur Blanche, 1923-24), the Maison Planeix (boulevard Masséna, 1924—28), the
label: Paragraph

text: suburban villa Stein/de Monzie (Les Terrasses, 1926-28) at Garches, and the dazzling
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Savoye (Les Heures Claires, 1928-29) at nearby Poissy.
label: Caption

text: Other important Parisian houses of this period characterized by their pure, white, cubic
label: Paragraph

text: forms were the Maison Tzara
label: Paragraph

text: Samaritaine Department Store, designed by Franz Jourdain (1905)
label: Caption

text: © Charles Jean Marc/CORBIS SYGMA
label: Caption

text: (1925-27) by the Viennese architect Adolf Loos (although the ground floor is of coursed
label: Caption

text: rubble), the Villa Seurat (1924-26), and the Maison Guggenbuhl (1927) by André Lurgat
label: Paragraph

text: and the group known as the Cité Mallet-Stevens (1926-27) by Robert Mallet-Stevens.
label: Paragraph

text: The unique Maison de Verre (1929-31) by Pierre Chareau has, by contrast, a sheer wall
label: Paragraph

text: of glass as its facade.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1937 the Exposition des Arts et Techniques was the occasion for the erection of a
label: Paragraph

text: number of monumental public buildings that continue to impose on the modem
label: Paragraph

text: appearance of Paris: the Palais de Chaillot (Place du Trocadéro, by Carlus, Boileau, and
label: Caption

text: Azéma) and the twin Musées d’Art Moderne (Palais de Tokyo, by Dondel, Aubert, Viard,
label: Caption

text: and Dastugue) nearby on the Avenue de New York. Both are stone-clad reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete structures epitomizing the stripped neoclassicism in vogue in the more
label: Paragraph

text: conservative circles at the period.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, Le Corbusier continued to contribute buildings of fundamental importance
label: Paragraph

text: to the Modern movement in architecture: the Asile Flottant (1929), a converted barge
label: Paragraph

text: moored on the Quai d’Austerlitz to shelter vagrants, and the Cité de Refuge de l’Armée
label: Paragraph

text: du Salut (1929-33) were commissioned by the Salvation Army. The Swiss Pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: (1932) at the Cité Internationale of the Cité Universitaire is a hostel for Swiss students.
label: Paragraph

text: This building clearly differentiates its component parts, with its ground-hugging curved
label: Paragraph

text: lobby, its staircase tower, and its long, rectangular, curtain-walled dormitory slab raised
label: Paragraph

text: on in situ cast stilts, or pilotis. In many respects, it established themes that were to be
label: Paragraph

text: developed by Le Corbusier and countless other architects for the rest of the century.
label: Paragraph

text: During World War Il and the Occupation, there was no significant architectural
label: Paragraph

text: activity, and the economy took until the 1950s to recover sufficiently for serious new
label: Paragraph

text: buildings to be financed. Le Corbusier designed the twin Maisons Jaoul (1952-56) in
label: Paragraph

text: Neuilly, which, although of low cost and very modest in scale, were widely influential on
label: Paragraph

text: many architects: their use of simple, shuttered concrete forms and segmental vaults
label: Paragraph

text: resting on exposed brickwork walls heralded a new roughness and primitivism. In 1959
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier, with Lucio Costa, designed a new pavilion for Brazilian students at the
label: Paragraph

text: Cité Universitaire. Only 200 meters from the Swiss Pavilion and, like it, essentially
label: Paragraph

text: consisting of a dormitory slab raised on pilotis, straddling the ground-floor communal
label: Caption

text: spaces, the Brazilian Pavilion is by contrast rough, heavy, and vigorous in its concrete
label: Paragraph

text: forms. An overall grid of brise-soleil projecting balconies and screens extends over the
label: Paragraph

text: facade.
label: Caption

text: The Headquarters of UNESCO (1953-58) was one of the first large-scale undertakings
label: Paragraph

text: of the period, an eight-story building, in plan a curved Y shape, by Marcel Breuer (United
label: Paragraph

text: States), Bernard Zehrfuss (France), and Pier Luigi Nervi (Italy). It was
label: Paragraph

text: closes the axis of the avenue de la Grande Armée to the west of the Etoile, was the CNIT,
label: Paragraph

text: Palais des Expositions (1957-58), by Camelot, de Mailly, Zehrfuss, and Esquillan.
label: Caption

text: Triangular in plan and covered with a continuous fluted concrete-shell roof rising from
label: Paragraph

text: three points on the ground, the Italian Pier Luigi Nervi was the engineer, and the veteran
label: Paragraph

text: pioneer of metal cladding, Jean Prouvé, designed the vast elliptical curtain walls of glass
label: Paragraph

text: and steel on each side.
label: Paragraph

text: With the hostility felt by General de Gaulle and his government to the Montparnasse
label: Paragraph

text: Tower block, which rose above the southern skyline of Paris in the 1960s, skyscrapers
label: Paragraph

text: were banned from the central area, and the Défense, which is beyond the périphérique,
label: Paragraph

text: was the first area to develop a cluster of tall buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: A restrained but powerful, moving, and effective memorial to those who died in
label: Paragraph

text: concentration camps is the Memorial de la Déportation (1961-62) by Henri Pingusson It
label: Paragraph

text: is situated at the tip of the Ile de la Cité. The visitor descends a steep and narrow staircase
label: Paragraph

text: to a small open courtyard from which nothing can be seen but the sky above and the
label: Paragraph

text: parting of the waters of the river through a low metal grille ahead. An underground space
label: Paragraph

text: behind has the names of the camps and a tunnel of thousands of tiny lights stretching as
label: Paragraph

text: far as the eye can see.
label: Paragraph

text: With the establishment of the cultural Centre Georges Pompidou, or Beaubourg, the
label: Paragraph

text: era of “Grands Projets” began for Paris, in which successive presidents of France
label: Paragraph

text: committed the state to an astonishing series of monumental additions to the city. The
label: Paragraph

text: design of a London-based Anglo-Italian architectural practice, Renzo Piano and Richard
label: Paragraph

text: Rogers, the Pompidou Center (1970-77) is at once a realization of the ideas current in the
label: Paragraph

text: Archigram Group in London during the 1960s and a worthy successor to the Parisian
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of novel metal-and-glass buildings. Alongside a new square, or piazza, under
label: Paragraph

text: which there is a parking lot, rises the rectangular steel-framed block, with open floors
label: Paragraph

text: internally—all clear of any vertical structural supports. All services, heating, ventilation,
label: Paragraph

text: electricity, water, and drainage are on the exterior, making an until-then-unprecedented
label: Paragraph

text: exposure of all the technology required in a modern public building. Close by, IRCAM
label: Paragraph

text: (1977), an institute for interdisciplinary research into music, was designed by Piano and
label: Paragraph

text: Rogers as a network of spaces under the new Place Igor Stravinsky; in 1989, Renzo Piano
label: Paragraph

text: added to it a 25-meter tower aboveground. Since 1970 vast areas have been developed
label: Paragraph

text: underground in Paris. The remarkable 19th-century iron-and-glass market pavilions of
label: Paragraph

text: the Halles Centrales (by Victor Baltard and Felix Callet in 1869) were demolished during
label: Paragraph

text: the 1970s, and in their place, following gigantic excavations, an underground shopping
label: Paragraph

text: area, the Forum, was designed by Penchreac’h and Manoilesco. The subterranean
label: Paragraph

text: complex also contains a busy new RER/Métro transport interchange and, 20 meters
label: Paragraph

text: down, an Olympic-size swimming pool, a gymnasium, and a vidéothéque (1985) by Paul
label: Caption

text: Chemetov.
label: Paragraph

text: Two outstanding new museums were created in the mid-1980s, both inserted into old
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. One, the Musée d’Orsay (1986), in the disused Gare d’Orsay (1900, Victor
label: Caption

text: Laloux), was designed by the Italian architect Gae Aulenti with monumental but open
label: Paragraph

text: galleries and towers under the vault of the giant railway station nave. The Musée Picasso
label: Caption

text: (1985) was, by contrast, a transformation by Roland Simounet of a 17th-century house in
label: Paragraph

text: the Marais district, the Hotel Salé (Hotel Aubert de Fontenay). Simounet inserted into the
label: Paragraph

text: ancient fabric of the building a brilliant sequence of well-lit spaces and volumes while
label: Paragraph

text: respecting, where they had survived near dereliction, details of the original architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The Cité des Sciences et de |’Industrie, a very large science and technology museum,
label: Paragraph

text: was created in a conversion of the former slaughterhouses of La Villette by Adrien
label: Paragraph

text: Fainsilber in 1986. In 1988 the Archives Nationales were moved from the Hotel de
label: Paragraph

text: Soubise to a new building by Stanislas Fiszer, and in 1989 the Ministére de l’Economie
label: Paragraph

text: aet des Finances was rehoused in a building featuring a spectacular bridge over the Quai
label: Paragraph

text: de la Rapée (P.Chemetov and B.Huidboro), having been moved to clear the Richelieu
label: Paragraph

text: wing of the Louvre for yet another Grand Projet.
label: Caption

text: The Opéra de la Bastille (1989) by Carlos Ott was built on the site of the old Bastille
label: Paragraph

text: station. This was the first of President Mitterand’s projects, designed to bring opera to
label: Paragraph

text: mass audiences, leaving the old Opéra of Charles Garnier to concentrate on ballet. It is a
label: Paragraph

text: roughly triangular building in plan, with a vast backstage complex of machinery to
label: Paragraph

text: facilitate rapid scene changes and an ambitious succession of operas throughout the year.
label: Paragraph

text: The main entrance, at the blunt apex of the plan, is rounded to counterpoint the curved
label: Paragraph

text: plan of the Place de la Bastille. The 1980s also saw the construction of the Institut du
label: Paragraph

text: Monde Arabe (1987, Jean Nouvel, Pierre Soria, and G.Lezenne}, with its remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: curtain wall of 30,000 light-sensitive diaphragms that open and close irises to admit or to
label: Paragraph

text: exclude light, a reinterpretation of the latticework screens of the Moucharabieh.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps the most prominently visible addition to the city-scape of the period was the
label: Paragraph

text: Grande Arche de la Défense by the Danish architect Johann-Otto von Spreckelsen, a
label: Caption

text: giant 110-meter open cube that now frames the termination, at La Défense, of the great
label: Paragraph

text: seven-kilometer axis that begins at the Louvre and runs through the Arc de Triomphe.
label: Paragraph

text: These grand projects continued in the 1990s. The massive reorganization of the whole
label: Paragraph

text: of the Louvre and its new subterranean concourses is signaled by its new entrance, the
label: Paragraph

text: Grande Pyramide (1993). This and other major additions were by the American architect
label: Paragraph

text: IM. Pei. The new Bibliothéque de France (1995) by Domique Perrault, the largest
label: Caption

text: building of the Mitterand era, is the enormous focus of the Seine-Rive Gauche
label: Paragraph

text: redevelopment area, a project that will continue for the next 15 years and that will include
label: Paragraph

text: a new university campus. The Cité de la Musique (1991-94) by Christian de
label: Caption

text: Portzamparc, incorporating a museum, houses the Conservatoire National Supérieur de
label: Paragraph

text: Musique et de la Danse, and Kenzo Tange’s first European building, Le Grand Ecran,
label: Paragraph

text: was commissioned by President Jacques Chirac for audiovisual production and
label: Paragraph

text: projection. Its 55-meter-high open steel campanile on the Place d’Italie is transfixed by a
label: Paragraph

text: striking Constructivist composition of giant metal cubes and beams by Thierry Vide. Jean
label: Paragraph

text: Nouvel’s Fondation Cartier pour |’Art Contemporain (1994) is partly concealed by
label: Paragraph

text: freestanding screens of metal and glass on a monumental scale aligned with the
label: Paragraph

text: boulevard Raspail, so that the building is hidden and revealed by a complex interplay of
label: Paragraph

text: foliage, transparency, and reflections.
label: Paragraph

text: In the last decade of the 20th century, Paris has seen the creation of large new parks,
label: Paragraph

text: among them Le Parc André Citroén (1992) by Patrick Berger and others and Le Pare de
label: Paragraph

text: la Villette (1993) by Bernard Tschumi. Superb new sports stadiums have been built; for
label: Paragraph

text: example, the Stade Sébastien-Charléty (1994) by Henri and Bruno Gaudin and the Stade
label: Paragraph

text: de France (1998) at Saint-Denis by Macary, Zublena, Régembal, and Costantini.
label: Caption

text: Ambitious new hospitals have been built, such as the Hépital Robert Debré (1997) by
label: Paragraph

text: Pierre Riboulet, a long, curved building that follows the slope of a large site in the 19th
label: Paragraph

text: Arrondissement.
label: Paragraph

text: The 1990 project of the Ministére de la Poste to build 1500 dwellings on its sites has
label: Paragraph

text: already resulted in a number of attractive and imaginative new buildings, such as those in
label: Paragraph

text: the Place Jeanne d’Arc (Dubus and Richez) or in the rue Oberkampf (1993, Borel).
label: Paragraph

text: A constant program of restoration, new housing, new facilities, and refurbished street
label: Paragraph

text: furniture has improved the city in almost every quarter, a good example being the
label: Paragraph

text: enormous program of improvements made to the avenue de 1’Italie during 1999-2000.
label: Paragraph

text: The municipality of Paris set up enlightened agencies such as the RIVP (Régie
label: Paragraph

text: Immobiliére de la Ville de Paris) and the designation of areas of the city as ZACs (Zones
label: Paragraph

text: d’Aménagement Concertées, such as those at Reuilly, 1987-97, or Bercy, 1993-36) as
label: Paragraph

text: key elements of the continuing restructuring, repair, and embellishment of the urban
label: Paragraph

text: fabric of this great city.
label: Paragraph
