text: The Park Hotel (1934), also known as the Guoji Fandian (or the International Hotel),
label: Paragraph

text: was designed by Hungarian architect Laszlo Hudec (1893-1958) in Shanghai with the aid
label: Paragraph

text: of Chinese and European architects and assistants in his firm. Since its completion in
label: Paragraph

text: 1934, this skyscraper hotel has been a major landmark on the horizon of this enormous
label: Paragraph

text: city. At 284 feet, the Park Hotel stood as the tallest building in Shanghai until the 1980s.
label: Paragraph

text: Its value to the history of architecture lies in the circumstances of its origin, as witnessed
label: Paragraph

text: by a young 1.M.Pei, who cites his exposure to the hotel’s construction as the reason that
label: Paragraph

text: he decided to become an architect. The hotel is a significant vector where the steady
label: Paragraph

text: streams of European and American ideas and technology spreading around the world
label: Title

text: after World War | intersected with the self-conscious aspirations of certain Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: groups to a global culture.
label: Paragraph

text: Shanghai before World War Il was a cosmopolitan city that had seen tremendous
label: Paragraph

text: growth since the first Europeans settled in it in the early 19th century. As one of several
label: Paragraph

text: areas conceded to Britain in the aftermath of the Opium War in 1842, what had been a
label: Paragraph

text: small but prosperous trading center strategically located at the mouth of the Yangtze
label: Paragraph

text: River quickly changed through the influx of foreigners. By the 1930s, there were people
label: Paragraph

text: of 56 different nationalities living in the city. Foreigners and Chinese alike were attracted
label: Paragraph

text: by the city’s unique opportunities for economic success afforded by the autonomous and
label: Paragraph

text: iberal city regulations granting foreigners rights beyond those of the vast majority of
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese inhabitants. Many Chinese living in Shanghai had fled civil strife throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: century of Shanghai’s “glory days.” In this enclave of international trade within Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: borders, Chinese of different regional groups established bonds that evolved into
label: Paragraph

text: powerful economic, political, and social organizations.
label: Paragraph

text: It was from a group of successful Chinese bankers that the bank owning the Park Hotel
label: Paragraph

text: evolved in 1923. The Joint Savings Society (JSS) was one of the ten largest modern
label: Paragraph

text: banks in China by 1928, modeled on Western-style commerce by Chinese businessmen
label: Paragraph

text: with an overseas education. They were from the coastal provinces of Zhejiang and
label: Paragraph

text: Kiangsu, and some rose to a position where their advice—and their money—was sought
label: Paragraph

text: by Chiang Kai-shek’s government. This group’s political and underworld associations are
label: Paragraph

text: complex and unclear. However, as part of an elite group of financiers who believed that
label: Paragraph

text: China’s future lay in the participation of a global culture, they instituted new types of
label: Paragraph

text: services, such as the China Travel Agency and modern banks based on Western models.
label: Paragraph

text: The Park Hotel was operated by International Hotels Ltd., a Chinese company that also
label: Paragraph

text: ran the new International Hotel School as part of the hotel.
label: Paragraph

text: The hotel rose over the racecourse, the most important social center for the
label: Paragraph

text: international community, and participated tangibly in Shanghai’s symbiotic relationship
label: Paragraph

text: with foreign capital. It was the most visible structure on Nanking Road, a street famous
label: Paragraph

text: for its culture of consumption. Nanking Road has been called the source of the
label: Paragraph

text: transformation of the Chinese way of life. For many Chinese, who by a large margin held
label: Paragraph

text: the majority in a city famous for its international composition, the street’s shops, with
label: Paragraph

text: Western goods advertised by blazing neon signs, held out hopes of status and success and
label: Paragraph

text: symbolized impossible dreams of happiness.
label: Paragraph

text: At the time of its construction, local media praised the Park Hotel as a modern
label: Paragraph

text: enterprise in every aspect that made use of modern technology to provide up-to-date
label: Paragraph

text: services. Its Otis elevators were of the same model and speed installed in the Empire
label: Paragraph

text: State Building only three years earlier. Publications on
label: Caption

text: Park Hotel, Shanghai, designed by Laszlo Hudec (1934)
label: Caption

text: © Lenore Hietkamp
label: Title

text: the hotel in European, American, and Shanghai trade journals of the 1930s reveal an
label: Paragraph

text: appreciation for the use of new technology in air conditioning, sprinklers, and steel
label: Paragraph

text: manufacture as well as an acknowledgement of the growing trade of Western building
label: Paragraph

text: products in China.
label: Paragraph

text: The hotel is evidence of the creative opportunities available to Shanghai’s architects
label: Paragraph

text: not seen elsewhere in the world. The convergence in this city at this time of practitioners
label: Paragraph

text: and wealthy patrons from many different countries, as well as evolving or nonexistent
label: Paragraph

text: building codes in which to experiment, meant that architectural ideas from around the
label: Paragraph

text: world found unique expression in Shanghai. The unusual dual function of the Park as
label: Paragraph

text: hotel and bank clearly reflected its origins in the JSS. From the second to the 19th floor,
label: Paragraph

text: it was a hotel with all the latest modern amenities and a private suite for one of its board
label: Paragraph

text: of directors. The bank and its vaults occupied the first floor and basement.
label: Paragraph

text: The Park was an apartment hotel skyscraper in a streamlined Art Deco style, a building
label: Paragraph

text: type then popular in American cities and, when urban dwellings became fashionable for
label: Paragraph

text: their ability to represent sophisticated and progressive ideals, in Shanghai.
label: Paragraph

text: Hudec traveled widely to both Europe and the United States. In 1927-28 he sketched
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers and hotels in New York and California. This architect cited the work o
label: Paragraph

text: Raymond Hood as his principal source of inspiration in the Park Hotel and suggested
label: Paragraph

text: that, like Hood’s misunderstood skyscraper designs, the Park Hotel was innovative in its
label: Paragraph

text: solution to the problem of tall building design.
label: Paragraph

text: The hotel’s dark, brooding appearance can be attributed to the architect’s Central
label: Paragraph

text: European heritage. The creation of regional styles, a topic under close scrutiny at the time
label: Paragraph

text: of Hudec’s Beaux-Arts training in Budapest from 1911-14 continued to be of interest to
label: Paragraph

text: Hudec in Shanghai. Much of this architect’s work, observed in close proximity to a
label: Paragraph

text: widely diverse body of architectural styles in Shanghai, carries associations with Central
label: Paragraph

text: or Northern European architecture, especially through surface decoration and general
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility.
label: Paragraph

text: The hotel’s architect, Laszlo Hudec, is acknowledged in Shanghai today as a
label: Paragraph

text: significant contributor to the city’s historic architecture. His work is virtually unknown
label: Paragraph

text: outside Shanghai because China’s 20th-century culture avoided the close scrutiny o
label: Paragraph

text: Western scholars until the 1990s. The unusual architectural opportunities of this dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: city provided fertile proving ground, and Hudec’s own architectural office was wel
label: Paragraph

text: established by 1925, with a peak period of production between 1925 and 1934.
label: Paragraph

text: Like many other structures of note during the early 20th century, the Park Hote.
label: Paragraph

text: illustrates its architect’s concern with evolving an architecture that represented the
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic developments in technology as well as a growing awareness of the meaning o
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in society. Modern technology, American apartment hotel typology, and
label: Paragraph

text: hybrid skyscraper design easily convey sentiments of a humanity’s heroic and
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated presence on earth, just as other skyscrapers in the United States did.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the message is carried to further depths with this highly visible structure on
label: Paragraph

text: what continues to be China’s symbolic street of capitalist enterprise. The human
label: Paragraph

text: achievements acclaimed by the building of the Park Hotel were that of an elite group of
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese who firmly believed that the attainment of a global culture was the hope for
label: Paragraph

text: China’s future. It is a message that once again finds expression in the current
label: Paragraph

text: architectural climate of Shanghai.
label: Paragraph

text: PARKING GARAGE
label: Title

text: The development of the parking garage in the 20th century was a direct consequence of
label: Paragraph

text: the automobile’s unprecedented disruption of the 19th-century city. Whereas traditional
label: Paragraph

text: urban areas had been constrained by pedestrian speed and the centralizing logic of the
label: Paragraph

text: railroad station, the automobile’s omni-directional movement, its mass availability, its
label: Paragraph

text: high speeds, and its sheer physical size all demanded greater decentralization and
label: Paragraph

text: dispersal. In the friction between these two paradigms of city organization, the parking
label: Paragraph

text: garage emerged in the middle part of the century as a form of suture. Inside it, the
label: Paragraph

text: enormously scaled automobile-oriented urbanism of the strip and the freeway would
label: Paragraph

text: brush against that of the shopping arcade, the village green, and the office building. In
label: Paragraph

text: one side came a driver and his heavy cloak, and out the other emerged a pedestrian.
label: Paragraph

text: The roots of the parking garage typology begin in the closing years of the 19th century
label: Paragraph

text: with the invention of the motorcar. From the very beginning, it was understood that these
label: Paragraph

text: new machines were not fit to be left outdoors. Besides simply being expensive and
label: Paragraph

text: vulnerable to theft, most were too mechanically temperamental to be left to the vagaries
label: Paragraph

text: of the climate. The majority of their wealthy owners simply adapted their existing coach
label: Paragraph

text: houses to accommodate these new “horseless carriages.” Those without the room and
label: Paragraph

text: presumably without more reputable choices found space for rent in existing livery
label: Paragraph

text: stables. Such makeshift accommodation continued into the early 1920s, by which time
label: Paragraph

text: some underutilized warehouse facilities were also being pressed into service for
label: Paragraph

text: automobile storage. In the relatively rare cases in which these buildings made use of their
label: Paragraph

text: upper floors, vertical transport of the automobiles was easily handled by the preexisting
label: Paragraph

text: freight elevators.
label: Paragraph

text: Unfortunately, all these patchwork adaptations and accommodations were soon
label: Paragraph

text: overwhelmed by the enormity of the automobile’s crescendoing effect. Whereas at the
label: Paragraph

text: beginning of the century the total number of passenger cars was less than 10,000, by
label: Paragraph

text: 1920 there were eight million autos in use. By 1930, that number had tripled to 23
label: Paragraph

text: million. By 1950, despite the Great Depression and the rationing of World War II, the
label: Paragraph

text: number had nearly doubled again to 40 million. Between 1950 and 1960, two million
label: Paragraph

text: additional cars were added each year.
label: Paragraph

text: Compounding the congestion generated by the sheer number of these vehicles, all
label: Paragraph

text: requiring roadways on which to drive and spaces in which to park, was an irrefutable
label: Paragraph

text: geometric dilemma. Whereas a person at a baseball game sat comfortably in about five
label: Paragraph

text: square feet and an office worker was comfortable in about 50, a parked Cadillac required
label: Paragraph

text: almost 200 square feet. This meant that in densely used areas where crowds gathered in
label: Paragraph

text: large numbers—places such as office buildings, shopping malls, hotels, airports, or
label: Paragraph

text: downtown department stores—there was simply no room to store all their cars. Making
label: Paragraph

text: matters worse was the commonplace observation that no person arriving by car was
label: Paragraph

text: willing to walk more than a few hundred yards to get where he needed to go. The only
label: Paragraph

text: way to store that many cars that close to their final destinations was to stack them on top
label: Paragraph

text: of one another, thereby formalizing the notion of the multitiered automobile warehouse.
label: Paragraph

text: These new buildings, totally subservient to the spatial needs and mechanical capacities of
label: Paragraph

text: the automobile, were nevertheless named with an exotic word of French origin: garages.
label: Paragraph

text: Given a consensus by the late 1920s on the need for some sort of formalized structure
label: Paragraph

text: in which to store all these new cars but without strong typological or historical precedents
label: Paragraph

text: from which to work, the early parking garages were amazingly varied, with solutions
label: Paragraph

text: ranging from the prosaic to the utterly fantastic.
label: Paragraph

text: Miami parking garage, designed by Robert Law Weed (c. 1949)
label: Caption

text: © Esto. All rights reserved. Ezra Stoller
label: Caption

text: The most straightforward garages had floor plates, which were joined by a system of
label: Paragraph

text: ramps that the automobile would navigate under its own power. The simplest schemes,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Victor Gruen and Krummeck Associates’ Milliron’s Department Store in Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles (1949), continued an existing surface lot up a ramp onto the roof of a building.
label: Paragraph

text: Slightly more complex and certainly more elegant was Paul Schneider-Esleben’s use of a
label: Paragraph

text: ramp in his freestanding Haniel Parking Garage in Diisseldorf (1953), which externally
label: Paragraph

text: suspended two straight ramps alongside four enclosed floors of parking. In Miami
label: Caption

text: architect Robert Law Weed’s unnamed garage (1948) opted for an unenclosed “split-
label: Paragraph

text: level” plan that incorporated small and discontinuous half-level ramps within it.
label: Paragraph

text: Other designers preferred to use curved ramps. Venice’s famous Autorimessa (late
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s) designed by Eugeio Miozzi, often called Europe’s first major parking garage,
label: Paragraph

text: could store 2500 cars arriving from the mainland on seven rectangular floor plates
label: Paragraph

text: connected by two one-way helical (corkscrew) ramps. Toulouse’s Victor Hugo Parking
label: Caption

text: Garage designed by Cabinet Genard Architects (1959) also had two cylindrical ramp
label: Paragraph

text: towers, but each of these was composed of two intertwining ramps in a double helix
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement. Architects Albert C.Martin and Associates did away with all ramps for the
label: Paragraph

text: May Company Department Store on Wilshire Boulevard in Los Angeles (1953),
label: Paragraph

text: elegantly folding three parking levels so that each touched the existing grade
label: Paragraph

text: independently. Other designers developed what is now considered the most efficient
label: Paragraph

text: solution to the ramp-deck dichotomy and designed parking garages like the Rupert Street
label: Paragraph

text: Multi-Story Car Park in Bristol (R.Jelinek-Karl, 1960) in which one continuously coiled
label: Paragraph

text: floor plate is used for both ascent and parking simultaneously.
label: Paragraph

text: For locations in which ramped garages were not feasible, more fantastic solutions were
label: Paragraph

text: tried. For example, in densely developed downtown cores, where aesthetic discomfort
label: Paragraph

text: about unfamiliar parking garages dovetailed with the high value of real estate, the
label: Paragraph

text: difficulties of subterranean parking seemed worth contemplating. San Francisco was the
label: Paragraph

text: first city to donate the land under its Union Square Park for a privately run garage (1941),
label: Paragraph

text: but it was copied in Los Angeles (1951), Chicago (1954), Bern (1957), and Dresden
label: Paragraph

text: (1961) to name just a few places.
label: Paragraph

text: For other valued locations where even underground parking was not possible,
label: Paragraph

text: enormous building-scaled hoisting machines were built to store automobiles in giant
label: Paragraph

text: three-dimensional cubbyholes. By mechanizing the means of ascent and storage, these
label: Paragraph

text: structures minimized non-parking areas, such as ramps, lanes, and even door-opening
label: Paragraph

text: stall widths, thereby squeezing the absolute maximum storage capacity out of a parcel of
label: Paragraph

text: land. In Chicago, for example, Thielbar and Fugard’s Jewelers Building (1926)
label: Paragraph

text: incorporated a mechanical car parking system inside the skyscraper’s core, reaching 40
label: Paragraph

text: stories high. Two popular proprietary technologies were the “Bowser” overhead crane
label: Paragraph

text: system (Parking Facility #1, 1955, Chicago, by Shaw, Metz, and Dolio Architects) and
label: Paragraph

text: the totally automated, push-button “Pigeon-Hole” system (Park-O-Mat, 1951,
label: Caption

text: Washington, DC). Even more fantastic schemes were studied as prototypes, including the
label: Paragraph

text: extremely narrow “Speed-Park” forklift system (20 feet of street frontage required), a
label: Paragraph

text: revolving “ferris-wheel garage,” and the “Point-Lift System,” in which a central elevator
label: Paragraph

text: tower was surrounded by rotating floor plates.
label: Paragraph

text: Given that the form of the parking garage was so fluid during this midcentury period of
label: Paragraph

text: invention, it should be no surprise that the functional program was equally in flux. Many
label: Paragraph

text: early garages billed themselves as complete auto-service facilities and included refueling
label: Paragraph

text: pumps, service stations, valet parking attendants, and car-washing equipment. Others
label: Paragraph

text: incorporated restaurants and lounges. The most foresighted designers began to reconceive
label: Paragraph

text: the links between the parking garage and its surrounding contexts. In the simplest cases,
label: Paragraph

text: this meant a bridge or covered walkway that joined two adjacent structures (Ford
label: Paragraph

text: Administrative Building Garage, Dearborn, Michigan, by Skidmore, Owings and
label: Caption

text: Merrill). More developed schemes include Bertrand Goldberg’s 1962 Marina City in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago. Goldberg rejected a stand-alone garage in favor of a design that integrated the
label: Paragraph

text: necessary parking structure within the massing of the tower’s adjacent planta. Taken to
label: Caption

text: extremes, this tendency to combine the parking garage into a larger architectural program
label: Paragraph

text: gave rise to a fantastic collection of hybrid buildings—a walk-up/ drive-through/parking
label: Paragraph

text: garage bank (American National Bank, mid-1950s, Austin, Texas, by Kuehne, Brooks,
label: Caption

text: and Barr, Architects), a department store in which conveyor belts linked parking spaces
label: Paragraph

text: to retail counters (Foley’s Department Store, mid-1950s, Houston, by Kenneth
label: Caption

text: Franzheim, Architect), and LeRoy Warner’s mythologized park-at-your-desk office
label: Paragraph

text: building (Cafritz Building, 1954, Washington, DC).
label: Caption

text: By the end of century, most of these radical experiments in form and organization had
label: Paragraph

text: ended, and the parking garage began to be seen as a commonplace, utilitarian, and
label: Paragraph

text: predictable sort of building without great aesthetic or architectural significance. Probably
label: Paragraph

text: this was in part the result of a lingering memory of the parking garage’s utilitarian origins
label: Paragraph

text: in the warehouse and livery stable. Furthermore, the maturation of the typology
label: Paragraph

text: necessarily dimmed the exoticism and inventive wonder that had infused so many of the
label: Paragraph

text: earlier experiments. Finally, and most significant, the parking garage remained hostage to
label: Paragraph

text: the continuing friction between a traditional notion of the city and the rise of the
label: Paragraph

text: automobile. As a consequence, all too often garage designers had motivations that were
label: Paragraph

text: as much defensive as anticipatory, seeking bulwarks against the unwelcome automobile
label: Paragraph

text: rather than new models for architectural inhabitation and use. By the mid-1960s, for
label: Paragraph

text: every majestic and visionary project such as Paul Rudolph’s Temple Street Parking
label: Paragraph

text: Facility (1962) in New Haven, Connecticut, there were dozens of unimaginative
label: Paragraph

text: disappointments—cheap, ugly, and banal in every respect. Sadly, no designer seemed
label: Paragraph

text: able to realize the complex and redemptive vision imagined by Louis Kahn in his “Dock
label: Paragraph

text: Complex” plan (1956) for Philadelphia, in which a “street becomes a building” and the
label: Paragraph

text: parking garage assumed its rightful place as an integrated, complex, and celebrated
label: Paragraph

text: typology in the modern city.
label: Paragraph

text: PARKWAYS
label: Title

text: Parkways played an important role in the development of the modern landscape. As the
label: Paragraph

text: first comprehensively designed limited-access public motorways, parkways paved the
label: Paragraph

text: way for the expressways and interstate highways that transformed the American
label: Paragraph

text: landscape in the second half of the 20th century. As symbols of progress and modernity,
label: Paragraph

text: parkways embodied con-temporary conceptions of modern design, efficiency, and
label: Paragraph

text: technological progress. At the same time, their naturalistic landscaping and historical
label: Paragraph

text: allusions suggested that modern technologies and modernist principles could be
label: Paragraph

text: harmonized with traditional values and aesthetics.
label: Paragraph

text: Parkways long predated the automobile. Frederick Law Olmsted and his partner
label: Paragraph

text: Calvert Vaux introduced the term “park-way” to describe the attractive approaches they
label: Paragraph

text: proposed for Brooklyn’s Prospect Park in 1868. The idea of connecting suburban parks
label: Paragraph

text: with urban centers and elite residential developments by means of attractively landscaped
label: Paragraph

text: parkways soon became a key element of American city planning. Parkways were seen as
label: Paragraph

text: means of spreading the benefits of parks throughout the urban area, as verdant corridors
label: Paragraph

text: that enabled pleasure seekers to escape the dangers and disruptions of ordinary city
label: Paragraph

text: streets, and as powerful economic stimulants that enhanced property values and
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged high-class residential development. As the connecting fabric of metropolitan
label: Paragraph

text: park systems, parkways helped transform the focus of American city planning from
label: Paragraph

text: isolated developments to large-scale comprehensive improvements. Olmsted and other
label: Paragraph

text: planners, such as Horace Cleveland, Harland Bartholomew, John Nolen, George Kessler,
label: Paragraph

text: John C.Olmsted, and Frederick Law Olmsted, Jr., went on to design notable parkway and
label: Paragraph

text: boulevard systems for cities such as Buffalo, Boston, Chicago, Kansas City, Minneapolis,
label: Paragraph

text: Seattle, St. Louis, and Washington, DC.
label: Caption

text: The first parkways resembled contemporary boulevards. Brooklyn’s formally
label: Paragraph

text: andscaped Eastern Parkway consisted of a central pleasure drive bordered by tree-lined
label: Paragraph

text: park strips that were flanked by additional roadways for commercial vehicles and access
label: Paragraph

text: to abutting properties. The series of drives and bordering parkland that Olmsted planned
label: Paragraph

text: for Boston’s Muddy River in the 1880s, now known collectively as “The Emerald
label: Paragraph

text: Necklace,” redefined the basic parkway concept from an attractively landscaped but
label: Paragraph

text: essentially urban avenue to a winding roadway ensconced in an elongated, informal park.
label: Paragraph

text: The project represented a middle stage in the evolution from traditional boulevard to
label: Paragraph

text: modern limited-access parkway in circulation terms as well. Park development
label: Paragraph

text: constrained access on the stream side of the main roadway, but turning and entering
label: Paragraph

text: traffic from the urban side of the parkway remained a source of danger and disruption.
label: Paragraph

text: The proliferation of private automobiles in the first quarter of the 20th century
label: Paragraph

text: rendered 19th-century parkway and boulevard systems obsolete, creating a demand for a
label: Paragraph

text: new type of parkway geared toward the social, spatial, and technological demands of the
label: Paragraph

text: automobile age.
label: Paragraph

text: The first public parkway designed solely for automobile use was the Bronx River
label: Paragraph

text: Parkway, which was completed in 1925 and stretched for 15 miles from the Bronx Zoo to
label: Paragraph

text: the Kensico Reservoir in central Westchester County. The design team of engineer Jay
label: Paragraph

text: Downer and landscape architects Herman Merkel and Gilmore Clarke employed all the
label: Paragraph

text: features that would come to identify the classic mid-20th-century motor parkway. These
label: Paragraph

text: elements included the segregation of the main parkway drive in a broad, landscaped
label: Paragraph

text: corridor that provided ample room for broadly curving roadway alignments and aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: enhancements while screening out incompatible development; the elimination of access
label: Paragraph

text: from abutting properties; a significant reduction in the number of intersecting roadways,
label: Paragraph

text: most of which were carried over the main parkway drive on attractively designed grade
label: Paragraph

text: separations; construction through largely undeveloped locations to minimize costs and
label: Paragraph

text: maximize design flexibility; and a prohibition on slow, dangerous, and unsightly
label: Paragraph

text: commercial traffic. The Bronx River Parkway included several short landscaped medians,
label: Paragraph

text: but fully divided motorways did not make their appearance until the mid-1930s. The
label: Paragraph

text: driveways were laid out with gentle grades, ample sight lines, and broad, sweeping,
label: Paragraph

text: subtly banked curves. Careful attention was paid to harmonizing the roadway with the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding terrain to enhance the impression of gliding effortlessly through the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape, where traditional picturesque compositions were simplified for easy
label: Paragraph

text: appreciation at modern speeds.
label: Paragraph

text: The Bronx River Parkway proved tremendously successful as a scenic pleasure drive
label: Paragraph

text: and commuter thoroughfare. Motorists, landscape architects, and planners quickly
label: Paragraph

text: recognized that this new style of parkway was not only more attractive than conventional
label: Paragraph

text: roadways but also safer, faster, and more efficient. The Bronx River Parkway’s
label: Paragraph

text: popularity spurred a parkway building boom that lasted through the 1930s, as planners
label: Paragraph

text: sought to answer pressing demands for recreational amenities, transportation
label: Paragraph

text: improvements, and suburban recreational development. Westchester County constructed
label: Paragraph

text: numerous additional parkways, including the Saw Mill River, Hutchinson River, and
label: Paragraph

text: Cross County. New York public works czar Robert Moses oversaw construction of the
label: Paragraph

text: Northern and Southern State Parkways and their various offshoots to provide access to
label: Paragraph

text: suburban homes and new state parks on Long Island. The nation’s capital also embarked
label: Paragraph

text: on an ambitious parkway-building program. Although the general outlines of the
label: Paragraph

text: Washington parkway system antedated the Bronx River Parkway, Rock Creek and
label: Paragraph

text: Potomac Parkway, Mount Vernon Memorial Highway, and George Washington
label: Title

text: Memorial Parkway employed similar design strategies.
label: Paragraph

text: By the late 1930s, rising speeds and traffic volumes made it increasingly difficult to
label: Paragraph

text: combine efficient highway design with traditional park values. Connecticut’s 1938
label: Paragraph

text: Merritt Parkway was popular with commuters but lacked the aesthetic sophistication and
label: Paragraph

text: recreational amenities of earlier parkways. New York’s Belt and Henry Hudson
label: Paragraph

text: Parkways were also devoted more toward traffic movement than scenic appreciation, as
label: Paragraph

text: was Los Angeles’s Pasadena Freeway, which was conceived originally as the Arroyo
label: Paragraph

text: Seco Parkway but was renamed before its completion in 1940. Highway engineers soon
label: Paragraph

text: realized that they could appropriate the basic circulation features that made parkways safe
label: Paragraph

text: and efficient without incurring the expense of elaborate landscaping and recreational
label: Paragraph

text: development. This recognition led to the proliferation of minimally landscaped freeways,
label: Paragraph

text: expressways, and interstate highways that came to dominate the post-World War IL
label: Paragraph

text: American landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: Attractive parkways continued to be constructed during the expressway era. The
label: Paragraph

text: National Park Service (NPS) pressed on with the development of long-distance
label: Paragraph

text: recreational parkways initiated as public works projects during the Depression. The Blue
label: Paragraph

text: Ridge Parkway, stretching for 469 miles between Shenandoah and Great Smoky
label: Paragraph

text: Mountains National Parks, was completed in 1987 and stands as the paragon of the
label: Paragraph

text: parkway builder’s art. The 1954 Baltimore-Washington Parkway and postwar sections of
label: Paragraph

text: the George Washington Memorial Parkway demonstrated the appeal of independently
label: Paragraph

text: aligned roadways separated by broad, landscaped medians. New Jersey’s 1956 Garden
label: Caption

text: State Parkway posed a striking contrast to the neighboring Turnpike, and New York’s
label: Paragraph

text: Taconic State Parkway (1931-63) received widespread praise as the ultimate
label: Paragraph

text: manifestation of the modern, multiuse motor parkway. Although largely completed by
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s, the Natchez Trace Parkway through Tennessee, Alabama, and Mississippi
label: Paragraph

text: remains unfinished and will extend classic parkway development into the 21st century.
label: Paragraph

text: The sylvan surroundings and dynamic streamlined ribbons of mid-20th-century motor
label: Paragraph

text: parkways captured the imagination of contemporary designers, critics, and everyday
label: Paragraph

text: motorists. Sigfried Giedion hailed parkways as supreme embodiments of the space-time
label: Paragraph

text: ethos of modern design. Lewis Mumford proclaimed the Taconic State Parkway on par
label: Paragraph

text: with any artistic creation of the modern age. The “magic motorways” of Norman Bel
label: Paragraph

text: Geddes’s popular Futurama exhibit at the 1939 World’s Fair were predicated on parkway
label: Paragraph

text: design principles, and Nazi engineers studied the Westchester and Washington-area
label: Paragraph

text: parkways before designing the Autobahns, which eventually supplanted the slower-speed
label: Paragraph

text: parkways as paradigms for modern motorway design. By the 1960s, however, the
label: Paragraph

text: excesses of postwar expressway development prompted calls for a return to parkway-
label: Paragraph

text: style landscape aesthetics, which have found their way into some of the more attractive
label: Paragraph

text: late-20th-century interstate highways.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The best comprehensive treatments of the U.S. parkway were written by contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: observers. Several monographs have traced the evolution of individual parkways and a
label: Paragraph

text: few recent studies of 20th-century design, planning, and technology have touched briefly
label: Paragraph

text: on parkway development.

text: PARLIAMENT BUILDING, CHANDIGARH,
label: Caption

text: INDIA
label: Title

text: Designed by Le Corbusier; completed 1960
label: Caption

text: In 1963, at the inauguration ceremony for Le Corbusier’s Parliament building in
label: Paragraph

text: Chandigarh, Prime Minister Nehru described the design as “symbolic of the freedom of
label: Paragraph

text: India, unfettered by the traditions of the past...an expression of the nation’s faith in the
label: Paragraph

text: future.” Few man-made structures of any era evoke the same timeless, dignified, and
label: Paragraph

text: otherworldly presence of Le Corbusier’s Parliament. This monumental composition of
label: Paragraph

text: abstract concrete forms draws its inspiration from solar geometry and from the physical
label: Paragraph

text: and spiritual impact of the sun on the people of India. The end result of this approach to
label: Paragraph

text: design is a building that is as rich in symbolism as it is in composition and texture.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the origins of the Parliament building are terrestrial, not cosmic, and its
label: Paragraph

text: function and existence are predicated on political rather than transcendental forces.
label: Paragraph

text: Following the partition of the new state of Pakistan from India in 1947, the province of
label: Paragraph

text: Punjab was effectively split into two parts. With the primary Punjab city of Lahore now
label: Paragraph

text: in Pakistan, there was a strong political imperative to create a new capital city for the
label: Paragraph

text: Indian Punjab in the Ambala district north of New Delhi. This new city was to be sited
label: Paragraph

text: between two rivers on a vast plateau at the base of the Himalayas and was to be known as
label: Paragraph

text: Chandigarh. In 1950 a team of four architects—Le Corbusier, Maxwell Fry, Jane Drew,
label: Paragraph

text: and Pierre Jeanneret—was commissioned to undertake the design of the city and its
label: Paragraph

text: major public buildings. In February 1951 the team proposed that Chandigarh be founded
label: Paragraph

text: on a modernist street grid with the commercial district at its center and with its political
label: Paragraph

text: structures clustered together at its top (the northeast). It was these political structures,
label: Paragraph

text: collectively known as the “Capitol,” that were to occupy much of Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: attentions until his death in 1965.
label: Paragraph

text: The Capitol is an almost classical composition of buildings, monuments, artificial
label: Paragraph

text: landforms, and vast geometric piazzas, all viewed against the backdrop of the Himalayas.
label: Paragraph

text: To the top, or the northeastern extent, of the Capitol, Le Corbusier designed the
label: Paragraph

text: Governor’s Palace (unbuilt) as a “crown” for the central public square. To the right of
label: Caption

text: this square (southeast) is the High Court (1956), or Palace of Justice, and to its left,
label: Paragraph

text: directly facing the High Court across the central square, is the Parliament, or Assembly,
label: Paragraph

text: building. Farther to the left, beyond the Parliament, is Le Corbusier’s Secretariat (1956),
label: Paragraph

text: which houses the ministries of the government in a single nine-story building that echoes
label: Paragraph

text: his earlier Unité d’ Habitation (1953) in Marseilles.
label: Paragraph

text: The Parliament, which was not only the last completed building in the Capitol complex
label: Paragraph

text: but also the cheapest, was conceived by Le Corbusier as possessing a distinctive profile.
label: Paragraph

text: The silhouette of the Parliament is a direct result of the ingenious composition of four
label: Paragraph

text: discrete volumes. The largest of these volumes is three stories high at the piazza level, is
label: Paragraph

text: roughly square in plan, and in elevation is presented as a horizontal, rectilinear form.
label: Paragraph

text: Three of the sides of this volume are lined with the blades of Le Corbusier’s brises-soleil
label: Paragraph

text: (sunscreens for the offices inside), whereas the fourth facade, which faces the High Court
label: Paragraph

text: and the central piazza, is shielded by a large freestanding portico. Prominently positioned
label: Paragraph

text: in this facade is a centrally pivoted ceremonial door. This door is covered in a brightly
label: Paragraph

text: colored enamel collage by Le Corbusier that depicts a range of iconic signs (including
label: Paragraph

text: traces of Le Corbusier’s Modulor and solar path diagrams). The portico, which shelters
label: Caption

text: both this door and the entire facade, is covered with a heavy scooped roof and is
label: Paragraph

text: supported on eight concrete walls that are perforated with rounded holes, as if to belie
label: Paragraph

text: their structural function. The ceremonial entrance through this portico is flanked by twin
label: Paragraph

text: pools of water that provide reflections of the Parliament’s distinctive hyperbolic and
label: Paragraph

text: pyramid roof forms. The larger of these roof forms, a hyperbolic shell with a truncated
label: Paragraph

text: apex, was inspired by the industrial cooling towers of Ahmedabad. The base of this form
label: Paragraph

text: is situated within the main square volume, from which it rises through the latter’s roof.
label: Paragraph

text: The hyperbolic shell houses the assembly chamber for the Parliament at its base and a
label: Paragraph

text: variety of special-purpose viewing galleries at upper levels. The fourth and final form is
label: Paragraph

text: the council chamber, which is similarly located within the greater square volume and is
label: Paragraph

text: designated with a lopsided pyramid that also protrudes above the main roof. Adjacent to
label: Caption

text: this pyramid is a service tower to allow access, via a steel bridge, to the roof of the
label: Paragraph

text: assembly chamber. Both the pyramid and the truncated hyperbolic shell contain
label: Paragraph

text: elaborately sculptured skylights to partially illuminate the spaces below and to celebrate
label: Paragraph

text: the relationship among the sun, the building, and the people. Within the original square
label: Caption

text: volume, both chambers are surrounded by a regular grid of three-story-high concrete
label: Paragraph

text: columns and a series of ramp and mezzanine levels. This space, which is called the
label: Paragraph

text: Forum, is lit by clerestory windows and possesses a weight and majesty that few 20th-
label: Paragraph

text: century buildings have been able to emulate. Both internal and external surfaces are
label: Paragraph

text: finished in rough concrete (a necessity of construction in India at that time} and openly
label: Paragraph

text: display a dense patina of age. Enigmatic bas-reliefs in the concrete walls serve only to
label: Paragraph

text: amplify the curiously spiritual character of the building.
label: Paragraph

text: Paradoxically, it is this character of spiritual otherness that has attracted the majority of
label: Paragraph

text: the criticisms leveled at the building. The Parliament is unashamedly overpowering in its
label: Paragraph

text: scale, finish, and appearance. Much of this is the result of Le Corbusier’s fascination with
label: Paragraph

text: global issues: the passage of the sun, the weathering of materials, and what it means to
label: Paragraph

text: live so closely with the environment. All these preoccupations have produced a building
label: Paragraph

text: that is attuned more to the elements than to the government and the people of India. This
label: Paragraph

text: is both the building’s strength and its weakness.
label: Paragraph

text: PATKAU, PATRICIA AND JOHN
label: Title

text: Architects, Canada
label: Title

text: The work of Patricia and John Patkau can be characterized by a very particular
label: Paragraph

text: reference to site and by its discretely tectonic character. In developing their approach to
label: Paragraph

text: design, this young Canadian practice has sought to search out the particular and, in doing
label: Paragraph

text: so, avoid the generalized solutions that are so pervasive in modern architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: especially so in North America. Patricia and John Patkau founded their practice in 1978
label: Paragraph

text: in Edmonton, Alberta. Their early work consisted of houses and educational buildings on
label: Paragraph

text: the prairies. Six years later, they relocated to Vancouver, British Columbia, and during
label: Paragraph

text: the last 16 years, working from a studio in a loft in the heart of the city, they have
label: Paragraph

text: designed a series of private houses and public buildings for sites not only on the west
label: Paragraph

text: coast but across Canada as well.
label: Paragraph

text: Their winning competition design for the Canadian Clay and Glass Gallery (1986) in
label: Paragraph

text: Ontario marked a significant point in the development of their work. The construction of
label: Paragraph

text: this project was delayed by a lack of funding, but when it was eventually completed in
label: Paragraph

text: 1992, the Gallery also established an important landmark in contemporary Canadian
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: John Patkau studied at the University of Manitoba and graduated with a Master of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture degree in 1972, whereas Patricia Patkau (b. 1950} graduated from Yale
label: Paragraph

text: University after completing her undergraduate studies at the University of Manitoba.
label: Paragraph

text: Working together and with their colleague Michael Cunningham, they have developed
label: Paragraph

text: one of the most significant architectural practices in Canada. The Patkaus scrutinize the
label: Paragraph

text: site, construction, and materials in the settings in which they work so as to reveal the
label: Paragraph

text: special characteristics of the place. This concern for the nature of place, which they have
label: Paragraph

text: characterized as “investigations into the particular,’ has significantly shaped their
label: Paragraph

text: approach to design. In 1988 they designed a new school for the Seabird Island Band—a
label: Paragraph

text: Salish community at Agassiz in the Pacific Northwest. Organized to consider alternatives
label: Paragraph

text: to the institutional and prefabricated school building that were customarily provided by
label: Paragraph

text: government for remote First Nation communities, this project was developed by the
label: Paragraph

text: Patkaus, who worked in close collaboration with the Salish people to design a new
label: Paragraph

text: school, built by the community. The zoomorphic form of the building created some
label: Paragraph

text: construction problems, but despite this, the new school was well constructed by its
label: Paragraph

text: community builders in a government-sponsored scheme.
label: Paragraph

text: The Patkaus continue to receive private commissions; many of these have been within
label: Paragraph

text: areas of outstanding natural beauty. In sharp contrast to the long-established and densely
label: Paragraph

text: built landscapes of Europe, these buildings have frequently represented the first acts of
label: Paragraph

text: settlement on a site. This first settlement on a site has fundamentally influenced the
label: Paragraph

text: development of the residential architecture of the Patkaus. The Barnes House, for
label: Caption

text: example, which was completed in 1994, is located at the edge of rocky outcrop
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking the Straits of Georgia in British Columbia and sited in a depression in the
label: Paragraph

text: rock, but with the main living room on the upper floor turned to focus the long view to
label: Paragraph

text: the ocean. The house not only is embedded in the site but also serves to focus a view onto
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape. Their designs are derived from the topography and detail of the landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: However, they also relish the constructional detail and explore a heterogeneity in ways
label: Paragraph

text: that are reminiscent of Alvar Aalto’s work.
label: Paragraph

text: The design of new public buildings—a library at Newton, Strawberry Vale School on
label: Paragraph

text: the outskirts of Victoria, new facilities for the Emily Carr College of Art and Design in
label: Caption

text: Vancouver, as well as a new community school on the waterfront in Toronto—has
label: Paragraph

text: ensured that the architecture of Patricia and John Patkau has not been isolated within
label: Paragraph

text: private worlds or remote sites. These public buildings have been significant not only
label: Paragraph

text: because of their complexity and public presence but also because they embody elusive
label: Paragraph

text: and original qualities that make reference to the culture of Canada. In this respect, the
label: Paragraph

text: work can again be viewed alongside that of Aalto, an architect whose work became an
label: Paragraph

text: important part of the construction of a new nation. Canada can be viewed as a social
label: Paragraph

text: democratic nation that emerged from the British Commonwealth anxious to define itself
label: Paragraph

text: and to seek out differences that distinguish it from its expansive neighbor, the United
label: Paragraph

text: States. In the last few years, the architecture of the Patkaus has played a role in this
label: Paragraph

text: process.
label: Paragraph

text: Increasingly, the work of Patkau Architects has been seen on the international stage.
label: Paragraph

text: Since 1994 their work has been shown extensively in Europe and North America, and in
label: Paragraph

text: 1999 they were selected to represent Canada in the Venice Biennale. This notice has also
label: Paragraph

text: brought their work to the attention of the promoters of major national and international
label: Paragraph

text: architectural competitions. Invitations to compete for several significant design projects
label: Paragraph

text: have resulted in successful submissions for new buildings in the United States, and at
label: Paragraph

text: present they are designing new student residences for the University of Pennsylvania in
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia as well as for the Grande Bibliotheque du Québec in Montreal.
label: Paragraph

text: These young Canadian architects have stated that they see their work as “only at the
label: Paragraph

text: beginning of the issues of heterogeneity that we are interested in—the variety, the
label: Paragraph

text: difference and differentiation, the irregularity juxtaposed to regularity.” As they move
label: Paragraph

text: into the design of large civic buildings set within different urban contexts, it will be
label: Paragraph

text: revealing to see how their declared desires for the buildings that they design—to
label: Paragraph

text: “become more differentiated, more irregular, more various”—are made manifest.
label: Paragraph

text: PAUL, BRUNO 1874-1968
label: Title

text: Designer and Architect, Germany
label: Title

text: Bruno Paul was born in the village of Seifhennersdorf in rural Saxony in 1874. His
label: Paragraph

text: father was an independent tradesman, craftsman, and dealer in building materials. When
label: Paragraph

text: he was 12 years old, Paul left Seifhennersdorf for Dresden, where he attended the
label: Paragraph

text: Gymnasium and entered a teacher’s training school. By 1892 he was determined to
label: Paragraph

text: pursue a career in the arts. He learned to draw while working in the office of a local
label: Paragraph

text: architect. In 1893, he was accepted as a student at the Saxon Academy of Fine Arts.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1894 Paul moved to Munich, the artistic capital of Wilhelmine Germany. He
label: Paragraph

text: enrolled at the Munich Academy as a student of the painter Paul Hocker, one of the
label: Paragraph

text: founding members of the Munich Secession who provided Paul’s introduction to the
label: Paragraph

text: city’s circle of progressive artists. In 1896 Paul left the Academy and began a career as
label: Paragraph

text: an illustrator. He was a regular contributor to Jugend and, from 1897, a member of the
label: Paragraph

text: staff of the satirical journal Simplicissimus. Paul’s weekly contributions to Simplicissimus
label: Paragraph

text: between 1897 and 1906 won him international acclaim.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1898 Paul began working as an applied artist. He was a leading figure in the
label: Paragraph

text: development of Jugendstil and quickly established himself as the premier designer for the
label: Paragraph

text: Vereinigte Werkstdtten fiir Kunst im Handwerk, a maker of artistic housewares in
label: Paragraph

text: Munich. The Jugendstil Hunter’s Room he designed for the Vereinigte Werkstdtten in
label: Caption

text: 1900 received a gold medal at the Paris International Exposition and was the first of a
label: Paragraph

text: series of prestigious commissions that won widespread professional admiration. In 1906
label: Paragraph

text: Paul designed a festival decoration for a barracks in Munich, his first commission on an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural scale. His design impressed Kaiser Wilhelm II and facilitated his
label: Paragraph

text: appointment to the vacant directorship of the School of Applied Arts in Berlin.
label: Paragraph

text: Paul’s appointment in Berlin was integral to the program of educational reforms
label: Paragraph

text: promoted by Hermann Muthesius and Wilhelm von Bode. Paul, who was a member of
label: Paragraph

text: the Munich Secession and the Berlin Secession as well as being one of the 12 artists who
label: Paragraph

text: founded the German Werkbund, proved a committed reformer. He revised the curriculum
label: Paragraph

text: of the School of Applied Arts to promote practical craftsmanship as the basis of artistic
label: Paragraph

text: education. He emphasized the training of designers for the applied arts industries. Only
label: Paragraph

text: the most dedicated and talented students progressed to classes in architecture, painting, or
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture. Paul implemented the full scope of his program of reforms in 1924, when the
label: Paragraph

text: School of Applied Arts was merged with the Art School of the Prussian Academy. The
label: Paragraph

text: new institution, the United State Schools for Fine and Applied Arts, provided a coherent
label: Paragraph

text: educational program that encompassed every technical and creative aspect of artistic
label: Paragraph

text: endeavor. Until Paul was removed from the directorship of the combined schools in 1933
label: Paragraph

text: for his perceived antipathy to the Nazi government, he led an institution regarded by
label: Paragraph

text: Nikolaus Pevsner as one of the two most important in Germany—an honor shared with
label: Paragraph

text: the Bauhaus (Pevsner, 1936). In terms of the scope of its curriculum and the number of
label: Paragraph

text: its students, Paul’s school in Berlin far surpassed its contemporary in Dessau.
label: Paragraph

text: As a designer, Paul provided more than 2000 furniture patterns to the Vereinigte
label: Paragraph

text: Werkstdtten. He also designed furniture for the Deutsche Werkstdtten in Dresden as well
label: Paragraph

text: as designing ship interiors for the Nerddeutscher Lloyd, pianos for fbach, and streetcars
label: Paragraph

text: for the city of Berlin. Paul’s most significant design was the Typenmdbel of 1908, the
label: Paragraph

text: first example of modern, unit furniture conceived to allow an unlimited number of
label: Paragraph

text: combinations of standardized, machine-made elements. Like much of his work, the
label: Paragraph

text: Typenmébel was widely published in contemporary professional journals.
label: Paragraph

text: Paul’s architecture was closely related to his designs for furnishings and interiors.
label: Paragraph

text: Before World War I, he was best known as a residential architect whose houses were
label: Paragraph

text: simple and elegant, efficiently planned, and devoid of superfluous ornament. His favored
label: Paragraph

text: vocabulary, an abstracted classicism, had a profound influence on the work of his
label: Paragraph

text: students and apprentices, who included Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, Paul Thiersch,
label: Paragraph

text: Edwin Redslob, and Adolf Meyer. In 1914 Paul designed a model house and two
label: Paragraph

text: restaurants for the Werkbund exhibition in Cologne. His buildings reflected the
label: Paragraph

text: prevailing tone of the exhibition and underscored the extent to which his prewar work
label: Paragraph

text: reflected the harmonious culture advocated by the Werkbund.
label: Paragraph

text: After 1918 Paul’s architecture reflected the changing economic and social conditions
label: Paragraph

text: of the Weimar Republic. In 1924 he designed the Plattenhaus Typ 1018 for the Deutsche
label: Paragraph

text: Werkstdtten, a prefabricated-concrete dwelling developed in response to the pressing
label: Paragraph

text: need for affordable housing. Although the stark, prismatic volumes of the Plattenhaus
label: Paragraph

text: reflected the vocabulary of the Neue Sachlichkeit (New Objectivity), the elegant detailing
label: Paragraph

text: was typical of Paul’s prewar designs. By the end of the decade, he was completing large
label: Paragraph

text: commercial projects throughout Germany. In 1928 he was working on a department store
label: Paragraph

text: for the Sinn company in Gelsenkirchen, the Dischhaus office building in Cologne, and
label: Caption

text: the Hochhaus am Kleistpark, the first skyscraper in Berlin. All these buildings
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated Paul’s mastery of the emerging International Style. Although Paul’s
label: Paragraph

text: projects of the 1920s were frequently innovative, their carefully considered proportions
label: Paragraph

text: and practical detailing clearly derived from his earlier work. When Paul relinquished his
label: Paragraph

text: directorship in 1933, he returned to private practice and continued working as an architect
label: Paragraph

text: through the 1950s.
label: Paragraph

text: As a teacher, designer, and architect, Paul was one of the progenitors of the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: movement. His work embodied one of the most significant and frequently overlooked
label: Paragraph

text: directions in the history of progressive design in Europe: that of a pragmatic modernism
label: Title

text: attuned to the needs and desires of the middle class. Nikolaus Pevsner credited his work
label: Paragraph

text: with effecting a fundamental change in popular taste (Pevsner, 1936, p. 200). Paul’s
label: Paragraph

text: mature designs embodied simplicity and clarity of form, stylistic abstraction, and
label: Paragraph

text: functional elegance. By promoting these ideals through his involvement with the
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund, his leadership of the School of Fine and Applied Arts in Berlin, and his
label: Paragraph

text: prolific work as a designer, Paul facilitated the popular acceptance of modernism as the
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic style of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: PEACE MEMORIAL AND MUSEUM
label: Title

text: Designed by Kenzo Tange; completed 1955 Hiroshima, Japan
label: Caption

text: The Hiroshima Peace Memorial and Museum not only marked the grisly ending of
label: Paragraph

text: World War LI but also skillfully expressed the challenges that Japan’s architects faced in
label: Paragraph

text: the new era.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1949, when Kenzo Tange’s proposal took first place in a competition for the design
label: Paragraph

text: of the Peace Park, he was already widely known for successful entries in two wartime
label: Paragraph

text: competitions: a commemorative building (1942) for the Greater East Asia Coprosperity
label: Title

text: Sphere and the Japan-Thai Culture Center (1943). Today, most texts on Tange ignore
label: Paragraph

text: these projects, but they demonstrate the evolution of generating ideas ultimately
label: Paragraph

text: consummated in Hiroshima. In each, Tange’s solutions subsumed individual buildings to
label: Paragraph

text: a sweeping axial gesture that extended symbolically into the landscape. A central plaza
label: Paragraph

text: served to unite these compositions at the scale of the site; Tange had spent much of the
label: Paragraph

text: war researching urban design, and he embraced several models not found in Japan,
label: Paragraph

text: including the Greek agora, the Roman forum, and Capitoline Hill by Michelangelo.
label: Paragraph

text: These precedents also served to make the postwar design of Peace Park particularly
label: Paragraph

text: fitting; in an era when the American occupation forces were actively promoting
label: Paragraph

text: democracy and public assembly, the design called for a remarkable plaza, able to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate 50,000 people.
label: Paragraph

text: In the case of Tange’s Peace Park, the axis extended through the ruins of the 1914
label: Paragraph

text: Prefectural Industrial Promotion Hall, now generally referred to as the Atomic Dome—
label: Paragraph

text: the only competition proposal to incorporate this building, which is now a World
label: Paragraph

text: Heritage site. In the postwar master plan for the reconstruction of Hiroshima, also by
label: Caption

text: Tange, this axis continued, linking the Peace Park with zones devoted to children, sports,
label: Paragraph

text: and culture. Although he was commissioned to design a children’s library, ultimately
label: Paragraph

text: these areas were completed without reference to Tange’s master plan and without any
label: Paragraph

text: linkage to the Peace Park.
label: Paragraph

text: The earlier competitions also established a direction for Tange’s stylistic approach,
label: Paragraph

text: responding to fascist ideology by explicitly welding Japan’s architectural traditions to
label: Paragraph

text: modern expression and material use. In particular, Tange referred to Ise Shrine in these
label: Paragraph

text: projects; by the time of the Peace Park, he also drew on Katsura Imperial Villa for
label: Paragraph

text: inspiration. When postwar propaganda efforts concentrated on shifting the perception of
label: Paragraph

text: Japan from its bushido roots to the arts, Tange’s work was widely acclaimed for its
label: Paragraph

text: “Japanese” character. However, Tange was equivocal on this point. In his presentation of
label: Paragraph

text: the Peace Park to CLAM (Congrés Internationaux d’ Architecture Moderne) in 1951, he
label: Paragraph

text: noted, “The role of tradition is that of a catalyst, which furthers a chemical reaction but is
label: Paragraph

text: no longer detectable in the end result.... We Japanese architects, in our endeavors to
label: Paragraph

text: resolve the problems facing modern Japan, have devoted a great deal of attention to the
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese tradition, and have, in the end, arrived at the point which I have sought to
label: Paragraph

text: elucidate for you. If, however, there can be detected a trace of tradition in my works or in
label: Paragraph

text: those of my generation, then our creative powers have not been at their best, then we are
label: Paragraph

text: still in the throes of evolving our creativity.”
label: Paragraph

text: Tange later described the imprint of history in the Peace Park as twofold: Yayoi
label: Paragraph

text: traditions were elegant and intellectual, and the Jomon was vigorous and creative. The
label: Paragraph

text: delicate treatment of the louvered facade on the central Memorial Museum might be said
label: Paragraph

text: to reveal Yayoi influences, whereas the primitive strength of the buildings and the
label: Paragraph

text: plasticity found in the pilotis reflected Jomon influences. By embracing these “Jomon”
label: Paragraph

text: characteristics, he made a virtue of one of the challenges of postwar construction:
label: Paragraph

text: because wartime demands for steel had brought domestic building to a standstill, the
label: Paragraph

text: labor and experience needed for refined construction were unavailable, even in the case
label: Paragraph

text: of reinforced concrete, which was suddenly widely employed. Furthermore, despite the
label: Paragraph

text: maturity of the design, Tange had little experience in construction supervision, as this
label: Paragraph

text: was his first built work. Critics praised the “correct degree of roughness” found in the
label: Paragraph

text: execution of the Peace Park’s buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Tange did not have complete control of the Peace Park’s execution. He was ultimately
label: Paragraph

text: responsible for only two of the three main buildings in the complex: the Memorial
label: Paragraph

text: Museum (1952) and the Community Center (1955) to the east. A third building, an
label: Paragraph

text: international conference center located to the west of the museum, was constructed using
label: Paragraph

text: donations from the people of Hiroshima, and it was felt that a local architect would be
label: Paragraph

text: more suitable. Although the building generally conformed to the master plan in both
label: Paragraph

text: massing and the use of a module, Tange made a point of repudiating it.
label: Paragraph

text: At the heart of the Peace Park is a centograph that stands as a memorial to victims of
label: Paragraph

text: the atomic bomb. In the competition proposal, it was to have been the largest structure on
label: Paragraph

text: the site, an arch (inspired by Le Corbusier’s 1931 proposal for the Palace of the Soviets)
label: Paragraph

text: visible from the Inland Sea. Later, Tange came to the conclusion that this piece should in
label: Paragraph

text: fact be much smaller, more a sculptural piece than an architectural one, and he invited the
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese-American sculptor Isamu Noguchi to propose a solution. Because government
label: Paragraph

text: officials felt that having an American involved in the project was unacceptable, in the end
label: Paragraph

text: Noguchi was commissioned to design two bridges flanking the park to the north and
label: Paragraph

text: south. Tange’s centograph, a concrete saddle vault, was built instead; in 1985 this was
label: Paragraph

text: replaced with a granite version as part of a complete refurbishment, begun in 1983 and
label: Paragraph

text: supervised by Tange’s office.
label: Paragraph

text: The results of the remodeling are unfortunate; both buildings flanking the Memorial
label: Paragraph

text: Museum were replaced. The new buildings conform superficially to the original massing
label: Paragraph

text: and column/ beam organization of the earlier facades, but the detailing and use of
label: Paragraph

text: materials are contemporary and lack the power of the originals. Furthermore, the three
label: Paragraph

text: buildings have been physically linked with a second-floor passageway, and granite
label: Paragraph

text: cladding was added to some areas of the facade of the Memorial Museum. Tange’s office
label: Caption

text: is also supervising construction of a new building, the “National Hall Dedicated to
label: Paragraph

text: Mourning Hiroshima’s Atomic Bomb Fatalities,” to be located east of the centograph,
label: Paragraph

text: further altering the park.
label: Paragraph

text: Although it remains possible to have some sense of the original character of the
label: Paragraph

text: complex, much has been lost. The Peace Park continues to hold symbolic importance as
label: Paragraph

text: ground zero of the bombing of Hiroshima. In its current state, however, it can no longer
label: Paragraph

text: be said to hold the importance that it once commanded in architectural circles.
label: Paragraph
