text: PEI, LM. 1917-
label: Caption

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: I.M.Pei is one of the last and certainly the most accomplished of the architects trained
label: Paragraph

text: by Walter Gropius and Marcel Breuer at Harvard University’s Graduate School of
label: Caption

text: Design. (The best known of the others are Edward Larrabee Barnes, Philip Johnson, and
label: Paragraph

text: Paul Rudolph.) In a career spanning more than half a century, Pei has won virtually every
label: Paragraph

text: award of any significance in his profession, from the Gold Medal of the American
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of Architects to the Pritzker Prize. The durability of his prominence, however,
label: Paragraph

text: has much to do with his ability to grow as an artist as well as his skills in creating one of
label: Paragraph

text: the most respected firms in American architectural history.
label: Paragraph

text: Pei’s achievement is the more remarkable in light of his background. He was born in
label: Paragraph

text: 1917 in Canton, China, the son of a prominent banker, and received his early schooling in
label: Paragraph

text: Shanghai. He came to the United States in 1935 to study, first at the University of
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania and then at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he
label: Paragraph

text: concentrated in engineering.
label: Paragraph

text: After completing his degree, Pei went on to Harvard in 1940 to pursue architecture
label: Paragraph

text: during the heady days of Gropius and Breuer, who had brought with them the avant-
label: Paragraph

text: garde theories and practices they had developed at the Bauhaus in Germany. Pei received
label: Paragraph

text: his Master’s degree in 1946 and briefly served on the Harvard faculty.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite his training under European émigrés, Pei has always retained a recognizably
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese sensitivity to nature, art, and time. (Pei’s thesis under Gropius was a design for
label: Paragraph

text: an art museum in China.) This sensitivity was developed during childhood visits to his
label: Paragraph

text: family’s villa in the ancient city of Suzhou, not far from Shanghai. There, Pei was
label: Paragraph

text: exposed to the culture of “rock farming,” the traditional practice of selecting rocks in
label: Paragraph

text: nature and setting them aside to be eroded in lakes and rivers into ornamental elements
label: Paragraph

text: for the gardens of scholars and the wealthy.
label: Paragraph

text: Following his Harvard years, Pei was obliged to subsume his design sensibilities to
label: Paragraph

text: issues of planning and development when he went to work in 1948 for William
label: Paragraph

text: Zeckendorf as head of the New York real estate magnate’s in-house architectural team.
label: Paragraph

text: There, Pei oversaw schemes for the redevelopment of such cities as Denver, Philadelphia,
label: Paragraph

text: and Washington, DC, acquiring a sense of large-scale planning as well as an appreciation
label: Paragraph

text: of finance and management.
label: Paragraph

text: pil
label: Title

text: yi
label: Title

text: idl
label: Title

text: John F.Kennedy Library, Columbia Point, Massachusetts (1979)
label: Caption

text: anu aw
label: Title

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: With the financial decline of the Zeckendorf firm, Pei set out on his own in 1955. He
label: Paragraph

text: took with him several colleagues and went on with them to create 1.M.Pei and Partners,
label: Paragraph

text: which was to become one of the most respected architectural teams in the nation. Many
label: Paragraph

text: of the buildings that the partners were to design were mundane, however well engineered
label: Paragraph

text: and detailed, but many were of extremely high quality, and each partner was allowed to
label: Paragraph

text: pursue projects in a semiautonomous fashion. The shared affinity in the office for abstract
label: Paragraph

text: forms in concrete and glass often made it difficult to identify the lead designer for a
label: Paragraph

text: particular project, but Pei, who has been responsible for roughly one-third of the firm’s
label: Paragraph

text: nearly 200 buildings and urban design projects, can claim most of the best.
label: Paragraph

text: Pei’s first major achievement was the National Center for Atmospheric Research
label: Paragraph

text: (NCAR), finished in 1967, outside Boulder, Colorado. NCAR was a boldly sculptural
label: Paragraph

text: composition that sought to integrate the scientific needs of scientists with a form that was
label: Paragraph

text: visually sympathetic to the Rocky Mountains that rose behind it.
label: Paragraph

text: The success of the Colorado building contributed heavily to Pei’s selection in 1964 by
label: Paragraph

text: Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis as architect for the John F.Kennedy Memorial Library.
label: Caption

text: Originally intended for a site in Cambridge, Massachusetts, adjacent to Harvard
label: Paragraph

text: University, the project fell prey to local politics and was eventually transferred to a site
label: Paragraph

text: on Boston Harbor. Although the combination of crisp, abstract geometry with a large
label: Paragraph

text: glassed-in atrium overlooking the water was characteristic of the developing Pei
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic, in the end the extended delays and design changes that were imposed on the
label: Paragraph

text: original made the building a disappointment, as the architect himself has conceded
label: Paragraph

text: publicly.
label: Paragraph

text: Nevertheless, the momentum created for the firm by the Kennedy commission raised
label: Paragraph

text: I.M.Pei and Partners to national prominence. That momentum nearly stalled, however,
label: Paragraph

text: when the windows of the John Hancock Building, a sleek office tower completed by the
label: Paragraph

text: firm in 1976 in Boston, began to break and fall out. The designer of the building was
label: Paragraph

text: Pei’s partner, Henry Cobb, but the crisis affected the entire firm, and although the cause
label: Paragraph

text: of the failure was eventually attributed to the manufacturer of the glass, the negative
label: Paragraph

text: publicity slowed new commissions to a trickle.
label: Paragraph

text: The firm began its slow return to health largely on the strength of Pei’s work in art
label: Paragraph

text: museums, most notably the Everson Museum of Art (1968) in Syracuse, New York, and
label: Paragraph

text: the Johnson Museum (1973) at Cornell University. These were hard-edged, late
label: Paragraph

text: modernist geometric compositions in concrete but with interiors that were both dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: and sensitive and judged to be superior settings for their collections.
label: Paragraph

text: The enthusiastic reception of these buildings led to Pei’s selection as architect of the
label: Paragraph

text: East Building of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, DC, completed in 1978. Key
label: Caption

text: to the success of the building was the client, Paul Mellon, whose father had paid for the
label: Paragraph

text: original National Gallery (1941), designed by John Russell Pope. The East Building was
label: Paragraph

text: a full-fledged expression of Pei’s enduring affection for abstract form, yet it was inflected
label: Paragraph

text: on the interior with a skill at manipulating light to soften the effect of the hard materials,
label: Paragraph

text: primarily marble and glass, and organizing the movement of visitors to create added
label: Paragraph

text: visual interest.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1979, following the reopening of relations between the United States and China, Pei
label: Paragraph

text: accepted an invitation to design a hotel on the outskirts of Beijing. Pei hoped to develop a
label: Paragraph

text: modern architectural form for his native country, which had sunk into grim utilitarianism,
label: Paragraph

text: while maintaining traditional Chinese architectural themes. Although the building
label: Paragraph

text: enjoyed considerable critical success, it was neglected by its government owners and
label: Paragraph

text: failed to spark the stylistic progress that Pei had contemplated.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the pains of Fragrant Hill, completed in 1982, were minimal compared to
label: Paragraph

text: those of the Louvre museum in Paris, the first phase of which was completed in 1989.
label: Paragraph

text: French President Francois Mitterrand asked Pei to undertake a fundamental renovation
label: Paragraph

text: and reorganization of the museum, and Pei responded with a proposal that was as much
label: Paragraph

text: urban planning as architecture, redistributing the collection by emptying portions of the
label: Paragraph

text: palace formerly occupied by government agencies and creating a system of underground
label: Paragraph

text: access. However, the attention of the public was concentrated on the glass pyramid that
label: Paragraph

text: Pei inserted at the center of the composition. The initial reaction was outrage that a
label: Paragraph

text: nonFrench architect would have the temerity to tamper with what is arguably the most
label: Paragraph

text: sacred site of French culture. However, on completion of the pyramid itself, the reception
label: Paragraph

text: changed dramatically. Pei had hoped to minimize the effect of a new structure on the
label: Paragraph

text: existing historic architecture but ended up creating a landmark that rapidly began to
label: Paragraph

text: compete with the Eiffel Tower as a symbol of Paris itself.
label: Paragraph

text: The year 1989 saw a host of other openings in addition to the Louvre Pyramid,
label: Paragraph

text: including the Meyerson Symphony Center in Dallas and several smaller commissions.
label: Paragraph

text: All were distinguished by a softening of Pei’s austere modernist palette. The Meyerson in
label: Paragraph

text: particular displayed an almost Romantic use of curves that modulated the architect’s
label: Paragraph

text: familiar formal rigor to powerful effect. Even the 70-story Bank of China tower in Hong
label: Paragraph

text: Kong (his only true skyscraper design), with its irregular stepped shaft, displayed a
label: Paragraph

text: compositional delicacy that had been absent from many of Pei’s earlier works.
label: Paragraph

text: By no means were all of Pei’s commissions of this period uniformly good. The Rock
label: Paragraph

text: ’n’ Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland, Ohio, recalled the lifelessness of the Kennedy
label: Paragraph

text: Library and for some of the same reasons. Pei’s best work has always resulted from a
label: Paragraph

text: close personal relationship with a wealthy and powerful client, such as Paul Mellon or
label: Paragraph

text: Francois Mitterrand, and in the case of Rock ’n’ Roll, the instability of the funding and
label: Paragraph

text: disagreements among the backers aggravated Pei’s understandably limited familiarity
label: Paragraph

text: with the musical history that the building was meant to celebrate.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1989 Pei had already begun a gradual separation from his firm, by then named Pei,
label: Paragraph

text: Cobb, Freed, and Partners (in recognition of his longtime collaborators Henry Cobb and
label: Paragraph

text: James Freed), and while maintaining an office in the same building and still calling on
label: Paragraph

text: the organization’s staff, began to practice even more independently. The projects of this
label: Paragraph

text: period included the Shinji Shumeikai bell tower (1990) for a religious organization in
label: Paragraph

text: Shiga, Japan; the Regent (now Four Seasons) Hotel (1992), in New York City; and
label: Paragraph

text: projects for art museums in Athens and Luxembourg.
label: Paragraph

text: However, what might prove to be Pei’s last major work is the Miho Museum outside
label: Paragraph

text: Kyoto, Japan, completed in 1998. Designed for the religious organization that had
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned the Shiga bell tower, the museum was built on a remote site in a nature
label: Paragraph

text: preserve near Kyoto. To reduce the effect of the building on the natural surroundings, the
label: Paragraph

text: entire top of a small mountain was removed, the museum inserted, and the mountain—
label: Paragraph

text: including many of the original trees—restored. Access was provided by an elegant
label: Paragraph

text: suspension bridge and a tunnel, both designed by the architect, working with the
label: Paragraph

text: structural engineer Leslie Robertson, who was the engineer on the Bank of China tower,
label: Paragraph

text: among other Pei projects.
label: Paragraph

text: The museum is characterized by Pei’s familiar elegant detailing in glass and steel, but
label: Paragraph

text: its greatest success lies in the combination of crisp modernist forms with classic Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: architectural tradition rendered in contemporary materials. In that, the Miho Museum
label: Paragraph

text: represents a fulfillment of Pei’s most fundamental affections—for nature, for elegant
label: Paragraph

text: abstract form, and for the display of fine works of art.
label: Paragraph

text: PELLI, CESAR 1926
label: Title

text: Architect, Argentina and United States
label: Title

text: Having designed significant buildings around the world, Cesar Pelli has established
label: Paragraph

text: himself as one of the most important architects practicing in America today, with
label: Paragraph

text: important buildings spanning four decades. In 1991 the American Institute of Architects
label: Paragraph

text: (AIA) selected him as one of the ten most influential living American architects, and in
label: Paragraph

text: 1995 it awarded him the AIA Gold Medal.
label: Paragraph

text: Pelli has clearly articulated his views on the skyscraper as a building type. This attitude
label: Paragraph

text: is based on a clear desire, inherited from the legacy of Louis Sullivan, to integrate
label: Paragraph

text: solutions for the technical problems of core, structure, skin, and mechanical systems with
label: Paragraph

text: the creation of an appropriate expression and identity for a tall building in an urban
label: Paragraph

text: context. Pelli’s own writings on the skyscraper demonstrate clearly that, for him, the most
label: Paragraph

text: fundamental issue is the development of clear identity and urban image for what is
label: Paragraph

text: otherwise a large box of anonymous space.
label: Paragraph

text: Examples of Pelli’s investigation of the tower form can best be seen in the Bank of
label: Paragraph

text: America Corporate Center (1992; originally the Nations Bank Corporate Center) in
label: Paragraph

text: Charlotte, North Carolina, and the Carnegie Hall Tower (1991) in New York City. Both
label: Paragraph

text: exemplify the designer’s careful assimilation of precedent and are less diagrammatic than
label: Paragraph

text: earlier examples, such as the Four Leaf/Four Oaks Towers (1982) in Houston, Texas.
label: Paragraph

text: The Bank of America tower can be regarded as a “pure skyscraper” for two reasons: its
label: Paragraph

text: iconic verticality, marking the historic center of a revitalized downtown, and its clear
label: Paragraph

text: tripartite division into base, shaft, and a crowning capital that recalls Sullivan’s
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers as well as 1920s and 1930s precedents. The
label: Paragraph

text: Zurich Tower, The Hague, the Netherlands (1999)
label: Caption

text: © AVEQ Fotografie & AV Producties
label: Title

text: Carnegie Hall Tower also acknowledges history by its contextualization, making the 60-
label: Paragraph

text: story high-rise a fitting neighbor to the historic Carnegie Hall auditorium. In both
label: Paragraph

text: instances, Pelli’s architecture is characterized by a search for an appropriate and
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive formal expression that is at the same time responsive to history and context. In
label: Paragraph

text: the twin 85-story Petronas Towers (1996) in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, this appreciation
label: Paragraph

text: for context extends beyond purely architectural and urban matters and into broader
label: Paragraph

text: cultural realms. The twin towers, with their sleek cladding and distinctive profiles, define
label: Paragraph

text: a monumental urban gateway, whereas the correspondingly complex shapes of the office
label: Paragraph

text: floor plans—two rotated and superimposed squares with small circular in-fills—were
label: Paragraph

text: developed to relate to Islamic geometric principles.
label: Paragraph

text: Pelli’s tenure in Eero Saarinen’s office (1954-64) offered him firsthand experience of
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen’s free interpretation of the relationship between architecture, function, and
label: Paragraph

text: expression. This search for an architectural language for urban towers dovetails neatly
label: Paragraph

text: with a concern that has dominated Pelli’s architecture for decades, regardless of building
label: Paragraph

text: type: the technical construction and visual expression of the building’s skin.
label: Paragraph

text: The development of this interest in the building envelope can be charted through the
label: Paragraph

text: 1970s and 1980s, when Pelli’s work featured exquisitely detailed glass curtain walls that
label: Paragraph

text: pushed that modernist technology to its poetic aesthetic ends, exemplified by buildings
label: Paragraph

text: such as San Bernardino City Hall (1972); The Commons (1973) at Columbus, Indiana;
label: Paragraph

text: and the Pacific Design Center (Phase | 1975, Phase I] 1988) in Los Angeles. Midway
label: Paragraph

text: through the 1980s and continuing through the 1990s, Pelli rediscovered the relevance of
label: Paragraph

text: masonry construction. Instead of the sleek, homogeneous, fragile, and transparent curtain
label: Paragraph

text: walls of glass and other lightweight panels that had become his hallmark, Pelli’s interests
label: Paragraph

text: expanded to explore the contrasting aesthetics of opacity, orchestrated pattern, and
label: Paragraph

text: heaviness without mass.
label: Paragraph

text: In buildings such as Herring Hall (1984) at Rice University in Houston; the
label: Paragraph

text: Mathematics, Computing, and Engineering Center (1991) at Trinity College in Hartford,
label: Caption

text: Connecticut; and the Boyer Center for Molecular Medicine (1991, New Haven,
label: Caption

text: Connecticut) at Yale, Pelli’s interest focused deliberately on a reinterpretation of the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional masonry building envelope, transforming it from its historic origins of thick,
label: Paragraph

text: load-bearing brick and stone into thinner skins or layers of nonstructural enclosure
label: Paragraph

text: supported off the structural frame. An increasingly bright palette of colors invites
label: Paragraph

text: comparison to the theories of Victorian critic John Ruskin concerning “constructed
label: Paragraph

text: polychromy” and the work of High Victorian architects in England such as William
label: Paragraph

text: Butterfield. Pelli’s design for the Hakata Bay Oriental Hotel and Resort (1995) in Japan
label: Caption

text: melds together three decades of exploration regarding the building envelope, with the
label: Paragraph

text: curved 35-story hotel tower formed of alternating bands of tautly stretched glass and
label: Paragraph

text: brick-colored tiles rising through a four-story plinth of assertively patterned and colored
label: Paragraph

text: tile and masonry.
label: Paragraph

text: Pelli’s buildings span the difficult cultural transition from modernism to
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernism, and the tensions implicit in this major shift of attitudes, ideologies, and
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetics are apparent in much of his work. A crucial concern expressed by Pelli when
label: Paragraph

text: discussing his own work is the relationship between a building’s image and its social and
label: Paragraph

text: constructional reality, and the attempted resolution of this three-part equation is at the
label: Paragraph

text: heart of Pelli’s search for authentic expression.
label: Paragraph

text: The quality of Pelli’s architecture resides not in the modernist heroics of plan form or
label: Paragraph

text: in the witty historical allusions of Postmodern eclecticism but in a scrupulous attention to
label: Paragraph

text: appropriateness—of siting, material, and building detail.
label: Paragraph

text: PENNSYLVANIA STATION, NEW YORK
label: Caption

text: Designed by McKim, Mead and White; completed 1911
label: Caption

text: New York, New York
label: Caption

text: Pennsylvania Station (1902-11) was a landmark New York City railroad station
label: Paragraph

text: designed by McKim, Mead and White for the Pennsylvania Railroad. A “monumental
label: Caption

text: gateway” to the city, its construction was made possible by the very latest engineering
label: Paragraph

text: technology, although its neoclassical style was reminiscent of ancient Roman baths.
label: Paragraph

text: Recognized in its time as among the top architectural achievements of 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: American architecture, this famous terminal survived only half a century before it was
label: Paragraph

text: demolished.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1900 New York was served by Grand Central Station, owned by the New York
label: Paragraph

text: Central Railroad, which controlled all railways north and east of the city and was
label: Paragraph

text: reaching west to Chicago. The Pennsylvania Railroad, trying to gain New York traffic,
label: Paragraph

text: had completed a right of way as far east as Jersey City, directly across the Hudson River
label: Paragraph

text: from New York, but had not yet found a way to cross the river. Tunneling attempts in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1870s had been disastrous, and a bridge proposal failed. By 1900, however, technological
label: Paragraph

text: advances, such as the introduction of electric traction railways at the new Gare d’Orsay
label: Paragraph

text: (1897-1900) in Paris and the availability of stronger electric locomotives and heavier
label: Paragraph

text: tunneling equipment, had revived possibilities for the Hudson crossing. Pennsylvania
label: Paragraph

text: Railroad president Alexander Cassatt visited Paris to see the new system and returned
label: Paragraph

text: home ready to proceed, hiring the prominent firm of McKim, Mead and White.
label: Paragraph

text: The new Pennsylvania Railroad extension would run east over the Hackensack
label: Paragraph

text: Meadows, tunnel beneath the Hudson, and then continue underground to a majestic new
label: Paragraph

text: terminal at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street. A newly acquired interest in the Long
label: Paragraph

text: Island Railroad meant that the tunnels would then cross Manhattan and the East River to
label: Paragraph

text: connect to Long Island.
label: Paragraph

text: Of the firm’s three namesake partners, Charles Follen McKim (1847-1909) was most
label: Paragraph

text: responsible for Pennsylvania Station’s design. His work, inspired by classical and
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance Roman architecture, was noted for its monumentality and elegant restraint.
label: Paragraph

text: He worked closely with Pennsylvania Railroad chief executive officer Samuel Rea and
label: Paragraph

text: chief engineer William H.Brown. He was also assisted by two associates, William
label: Paragraph

text: Symmes Richardson and Tenunis Van der Bent. As McKim’s health gradually failed, his
label: Paragraph

text: associates took over primary responsibility for the work, and both he and Cassatt died
label: Paragraph

text: before the project was completed.
label: Paragraph

text: Design work began in 1902. Cassatt had proposed a “grand portal” that included a
label: Paragraph

text: high-rise European-style hotel, but McKim rejected that idea. Historian Leland Roth
label: Paragraph

text: speculates that this decision doomed the station years later, as a multipurpose structure
label: Paragraph

text: would have been more adaptable to changing times. Construction began in 1904, and
label: Paragraph

text: although the station opened in the fall of 1910, it was not completed until a year later.
label: Paragraph

text: Occupying two full city blocks, the finished Pennsylvania Station was a functional and
label: Paragraph

text: critical success; this New York landmark was widely published and admired in the
label: Paragraph

text: United States, England, and Europe. With its neighbor, Grand Central, Pennsylvania
label: Paragraph

text: Station did much to establish the classical form as the standard for large train stations of
label: Paragraph

text: the time. Even in 1924, Sir Charles Reilly praised the firm’s body of work, including
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania Station, as having “that sublime quality which makes great buildings akin
label: Paragraph

text: to the permanent works of nature.”
label: Paragraph

text: The pink granite exterior was a restrained classical composition, with Doric-columned
label: Paragraph

text: porticoes and pilasters delineating each of its facades. It departed from traditional train
label: Paragraph

text: station architecture in its low primary roofline, as its trains were entirely underground and
label: Paragraph

text: did not need the height of a train shed. The interior reflected McKim’s deep admiration of
label: Paragraph

text: Roman architecture, but its superstructure was modern steel, and the soaring spaces
label: Paragraph

text: within were made possible by this latest engineering element. From the Seventh Avenue
label: Paragraph

text: main entrance, one proceeded through a portico and an arcade of shops and then
label: Paragraph

text: descended a staircase into the majestic groin-vaulted main waiting room, lined in warm
label: Paragraph

text: buff travertine. This room, with an elaborate coffered ceiling supported by Corinthian
label: Caption

text: columns and lit by thermal windows, was the centerpiece of the design, a direct reference
label: Paragraph

text: to both the tepidarium of the Baths of Caracalla and the vast space of St. Peter’s in the
label: Paragraph

text: Vatican. Adjoining it was the equally dazzling concourse, with arched steel ribs and airy
label: Paragraph

text: latticed columns supporting a groin-vaulted glass roof that echoed the great European
label: Caption

text: train sheds. With its staircases cascading down to the underground platforms, the
label: Paragraph

text: concourse provided what Richardson called a transition “from the monumental side of the
label: Paragraph

text: station to the utilitarian.”
label: Paragraph

text: Traffic flow within the building was carefully planned. The station covered a fan of 21
label: Paragraph

text: parallel tracks 45 feet underground
label: Title

text: Pennsylvania Station, interior, designed by McKim, Mead and White (1911)
label: Caption

text: © Museum of the City of New York Print Archives
label: Caption

text: and a network of service tunnels at multiple levels. A special concourse with direct street
label: Paragraph

text: access served commuters, whose trains ran on the three northernmost tracks, and was
label: Paragraph

text: connected to nearby subway lines. The station’s concourses could be entered at numerous
label: Paragraph

text: points from surrounding streets, and two ramped driveways, entered from Seventh
label: Paragraph

text: Avenue on both sides of the arcade, allowed a sheltered and efficient means to drop off
label: Paragraph

text: and pick up both passengers and baggage by automobile or taxicab.
label: Paragraph

text: As time went on, the taste for monumental classicism dissipated, rail travel declined,
label: Paragraph

text: and Pennsylvania Station aged poorly. Increasing neglect, grime, and insensitive
label: Paragraph

text: architectural intrusions, most notably a glaring plastic shell covering a modern ticket
label: Paragraph

text: counter, diminished the station’s worth in its owners’ eyes. In the early 1960s,
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania Railroad announced plans to demolish Pennsylvania Station and replace it
label: Paragraph

text: with an entirely subterranean modern terminal above which would be a new Madison
label: Paragraph

text: Square Garden arena and an office skyscraper. Outraged architects, historians, and critics,
label: Paragraph

text: including Ada Louise Huxtable and Lewis Mumford, railed publicly against the proposal,
label: Paragraph

text: even offering a counterproposal that would generate income while preserving the
label: Paragraph

text: building; however, their efforts were in vain. Between 1963 and 1965, Pennsylvania
label: Paragraph

text: Station was torn down, and only a few statues were saved. Its lovely stonework was
label: Paragraph

text: dumped into New Jersey marshes as landfill. However, Pennsylvania Station’s loss
label: Paragraph

text: galvanized the historic preservation movement across the United States and led to
label: Paragraph

text: federal, state, and local laws protecting important structures from callous demolition.
label: Paragraph

text: Most critics agree that the second Pennsylvania Station, designed by Charles Luckman,
label: Paragraph

text: is grim and mediocre, even judged solely on its own merits. At present, architect David
label: Paragraph

text: Childs plans to renovate the nearby Farley Post Office Building as a third incarnation of
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania Station.
label: Paragraph

text: PERKINS AND WILL
label: Title

text: Architecture firm, United States
label: Title

text: Perkins and Will was formed in 1935 by two Cornell University classmates, Lawrence
label: Paragraph

text: Bradford Perkins (1907-97) and Philip Will, Jr. (1906-85). Part of a new generation of
label: Paragraph

text: young architects innovating in the years between the world wars, these men brought new
label: Paragraph

text: ideas and idealism to post-World War II building needs, particularly in the area of school
label: Paragraph

text: design. Their work is marked by the study of the program that the proposed structure
label: Paragraph

text: intends to solve by looking at the way in which people use buildings. This humanistic
label: Paragraph

text: approach was influenced to some extent by their collaboration with Eliel and Eero
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen. According to Lawrence Perkins, it is one of the qualities that has set their
label: Paragraph

text: firm’s brand of modernism apart from that of the more severe International Style
label: Paragraph

text: modernists, such as Mies van der Rohe, which was attractive to many young firms after
label: Paragraph

text: World War II.
label: Paragraph

text: Specifically, Perkins and Will’s practice and promotion of progressive, functional
label: Paragraph

text: school design in the 1940s and 1950s had a tremendous influence on American
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in the last half of the 20th century. It was natural for Lawrence Perkins to
label: Paragraph

text: participate in the design of schools; his father, the well-known Chicago architect Dwight
label: Paragraph

text: Perkins, designed nearly 40 schools in the early part of the 20th century and served as the
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago Board of Education architect. After moving to Chicago in 1933, Philip Will, Jr.,
label: Paragraph

text: was responsible for the necessarily simplified, modern design of prefabricated houses for
label: Paragraph

text: Howard Fisher’s firm General Houses, Inc. He worked directly on the company’s Steel
label: Paragraph

text: House for the 1933 Chicago Century of Progress Exposition.
label: Caption

text: Soon after forming their firm in 1935, the two architects were joined by E.Todd
label: Paragraph

text: Wheeler, and the firm was known as Perkins, Wheeler, and Will until 1946. The first
label: Paragraph

text: significant commission that the architects received was the Crow Island School (1940) in
label: Paragraph

text: Winnetka, Illinois. The eager young architecture firm combined with an enlightened
label: Paragraph

text: school superintendent, Carleton Washburne, and the respected modern visionaries Eliel
label: Paragraph

text: and Eero Saarinen, making for a highly successful and influential new school building
label: Paragraph

text: that provided major direction to the new firm.
label: Paragraph

text: Perkins thoroughly researched and rethought the school’s uses with an eye to providing
label: Paragraph

text: a new kind of educational facility. He interviewed grade-school children, teachers, and
label: Paragraph

text: administrators in the planning stages. As Perkins explains, “The program...said that that
label: Paragraph

text: classroom was to be a place for a fully rounded learning and living experience at each age
label: Paragraph

text: group; that each room was to be a colorful, flexible, child-scaled work space where the
label: Paragraph

text: learning activity of childhood could be channeled effectively and pleasantly...color,
label: Paragraph

text: warmth, and a place in which to work and act vigorously—these were keynotes of the
label: Paragraph

text: earliest program” (Perkins and Cocking, 1949).
label: Paragraph

text: As a result, Perkins and Will, along with the Saarinens, produced a very sensitively
label: Paragraph

text: designed school. One of the more striking aspects is the auditorium with progressively
label: Paragraph

text: smaller moldedplywood seating toward the front so that the children would be in seats
label: Paragraph

text: proportionate to their own sizes. The architects designed a new type of L-shaped
label: Paragraph

text: classroom with large window walls on two sides, allowing for more and better natural
label: Paragraph

text: light. Other innovations include individual bathrooms in each classroom, a separate
label: Paragraph

text: activity area, and round tables instead of marching desks. In addition, the trend was
label: Paragraph

text: toward a more healthful environment, and each class had a private courtyard, expanding
label: Paragraph

text: the possibilities for classroom activity.
label: Paragraph

text: Perkins published many of the revolutionary ideas employed in Crow Island School in
label: Paragraph

text: his book Schools (1949), written with school superintendent Walter Cocking. This
label: Paragraph

text: publication served a similar function in promoting progressive design for schools, as
label: Paragraph

text: George Nelson and Henry Wright’s Tomorrow’s House (1945) did for promoting the
label: Paragraph

text: postwar homes. For example, Perkins and Cocking pointed out that Greek and Roman
label: Paragraph

text: architecture were modern in their own time yet inappropriate for today’s American needs.
label: Paragraph

text: Changing philosophies regarding education, they held, meant rethinking school’s
label: Paragraph

text: functions. They argued for the functional reasons for the existence of features such as
label: Paragraph

text: continuous banks of windows, trying to relieve the stigma associated at the time with the
label: Paragraph

text: widespread acceptance of modern architecture. They illustrated Schools with
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary schools by famous architects, such as Richard Neutra and William
label: Paragraph

text: Lescaze, to prove the benefits of such well-considered schemes. In 1957 Perkins followed
label: Paragraph

text: up with Workplace for Learning, which featured many of the success stories of the ten
label: Paragraph

text: years since Schools was published. This included Perkins and Will’s Heathcote School
label: Paragraph

text: (1954) in Scarsdale, New York, which Perkins considered more successful than Crow
label: Paragraph

text: Island because of its complete interaction with nature on the site, aided by its numerous
label: Paragraph

text: glass corridors punctuated with lively colored panes.
label: Paragraph

text: Perkins and Will provided notable solutions to corporate building types, also conceived
label: Paragraph

text: around the people who were to use them. The Scott, Foresman, and Company
label: Paragraph

text: Headquarters (1965) in Glenview, Illinois, a campus planned for a publisher of
label: Paragraph

text: educational materials, was undoubtedly informed by the firm’s many educational
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. Here a series of interlinked glass and concrete pavilions housing different
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of the company were designed to give a sense of community on a 44-acre site.
label: Paragraph

text: Trees and fountains mix with walkways between the buildings to create a flow while
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously reinforcing a sense of repose.
label: Paragraph

text: Another example of the firm’s well-considered design solutions influenced later
label: Paragraph

text: generations of architectural form givers in the urban setting. The First National Bank of
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago (1966) was an anomaly on the Chicago skyline when it was constructed, as it
label: Paragraph

text: eclipsed most of the Loop buildings, helping to set a precedent for the new, taller
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers that became ubiquitous in American cities in the decades to follow. This
label: Paragraph

text: building, too, was a specific and inspired design solution to a complex program. The
label: Paragraph

text: bank had to enclose all its various activities in one building, as the State of Llinois at that
label: Paragraph

text: time forbade branch banking. Therefore, the 60-story-tall structure flares at the base to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate the numerous public banking facilities, and the building
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: wind” (Architectural Record 148 [September 1970]).
label: Paragraph

text: Over the decades, Perkins and Will has grown to include engineering and design
label: Paragraph

text: services. It remains one of the largest architectural firms in the nation, with offices in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago, Atlanta, Charlotte, Los Angeles, Miami, Minneapolis, New York, and Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: carrying on the work of the firm’s principals. The firm continues to specialize in
label: Paragraph

text: PERRAULT, DOMINIQUE 1953
label: Title

text: Architect, France
label: Title

text: Dominique Perrault is the principal and founder of the architectural practice Perrault
label: Paragraph

text: Projects, established in Paris in 1981. He achieved international recognition in 1989,
label: Paragraph

text: when at the age of 35 he was awarded the commission for perhaps the grandest of French
label: Paragraph

text: President Mitterand’s projects, the National Library of France in Paris, completed in
label: Paragraph

text: 1995. Perrault’s approach could be seen as part of a European trend, loosely defined as
label: Paragraph

text: Supermodernism, including the work of Norman Foster, Renzo Piano, Jean Nouvel, and
label: Paragraph

text: Rem Koolhaas. In Perrault’s architecture, technological expression is tempered by a
label: Paragraph

text: minimalist aesthetic, often making use of bold geometric forms at a monumental scale
label: Paragraph

text: combined with subtle tectonic qualities, material textures, and lighting effects.
label: Paragraph

text: The practice built its early reputation on a series of large-scale industrial commissions,
label: Paragraph

text: such as the Traffic Control Centre for the Peripherique in Paris (1984); the University for
label: Paragraph

text: Electric Engineering, Marne-la-Vallée, Paris (1987); and the Water Purification Plant,
label: Paragraph

text: Ivry-sur-Seine (1987, completed in 1993). Each of these projects deploys a complex
label: Paragraph

text: range of geometric forms, but it was the monumental simplicity of the Hotel Industriel
label: Paragraph

text: Jean-Baptiste Berlier (1990) in Paris that directed Perrault’s later work. This bold glass
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular slab containing ten stories of open-plan workspace stands out alongside a
label: Paragraph

text: chaotic edge-city context of highways and railroad tracks. The sleek external skin
label: Paragraph

text: contrasts with the concrete and stainless-steel interior, and the whole building displays a
label: Paragraph

text: quiet monumentality that sets it apart from its unpromising surroundings.
label: Paragraph

text: The Center for Book Treatment, Bussy St. Georges, France (1995), the Olympic
label: Caption

text: Velodrome and Swimming Pool, Berlin (1999), and the Media Library, Venissieux,
label: Caption

text: France (2001), display a similar combination of pure geometry and smooth external
label: Paragraph

text: surface treatment. The Olympic Velodrome and Swimming Pool project’s dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: sunken landscape setting also hints at another source of inspiration for Perrault, who has
label: Paragraph

text: written of his interest in the work of Earthworks artists such as Walter de Maria and
label: Paragraph

text: Richard Long. Another touchstone for this more recent preoccupation with the
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between architecture and landscape—or as Perrault describes it, a concern
label: Paragraph

text: with geography rather than history and a wish to create places as opposed to buildings—
label: Paragraph

text: is the house he designed for himself and his partner on the Normandy coast in the north
label: Paragraph

text: of France. Sunk into the ground along its northern side, the house seems little more than a
label: Paragraph

text: wall with a large opening framing a view of the garden, and it is the desire to dissolve the
label: Paragraph

text: building into the landscape design that characterizes two of the more substantial recent
label: Paragraph

text: projects. His mysterious, almost evanescent installation/house project titled
label: Paragraph

text: Kolonihavehus, Copenhagen, and designed for the Copenhagen as European Capital of
label: Paragraph

text: Culture Exhibition (1996) sits like a minimalist cube in a quiet forested landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: The redevelopment of the Uni Metal planning project in Caen (1995) and the Plant
label: Paragraph

text: APLIX (1999) in Nantes also adopt a landscape strategy comprising gridded territories to
label: Paragraph

text: define areas for building. A more extreme case of this deference to context can be seen at
label: Paragraph

text: the Conference Center Usinor-Salicor at Saint-Germain-en-Laye (1991), where an
label: Paragraph

text: underground space is created beneath an existing villa and roofed with a flat glass disk
label: Paragraph

text: sur-
label: Title

text: National Library of France, Paris, designed by Dominique Perrault (1995)
label: Caption

text: © Perrault and Partners
label: Title

text: rounding the historic structure. In addition to these and other built projects, Perrault has
label: Paragraph

text: also undertaken a number of competitions and studies, most notably Library Kansai
label: Paragraph

text: Khan, Kyoto (1996), the Museum of Modern Art, New York (1997), and the Cultural
label: Paragraph

text: Center, Santiago de Compostela (1999).
label: Caption

text: In 1997 he was awarded the Mies van der Rohe Foundation prize for his National
label: Paragraph

text: Library, deservedly the practices’ most widely regarded project, particularly for its effect
label: Paragraph

text: at the urban scale. The building consists of four 22-story L-shaped towers containing the
label: Paragraph

text: book storage spaces and administrative offices, sheathed in a double skin of timber
label: Caption

text: shutters and an outer curtain-wall of full-height glazing. The towers sit at the four corners
label: Caption

text: of a colossal elevated rectangular platform, which is covered in simple timber decking
label: Paragraph

text: and surrounded by steps leading up from the street level. The effect of this “ziggurat,”
label: Paragraph

text: which contains the reading areas, is to create a grand ceremonial space above—somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: isolated from everyday life—that increases the sense of ritual in approaching the
label: Paragraph

text: building. This is reinforced by the enormous central garden into which the visitor
label: Paragraph

text: descends toward the two main entrances, and once inside, a similarly monumental scale
label: Paragraph

text: is maintained through the smooth surfaces and minimal detailing. The most dramatic of
label: Paragraph

text: the interior finishes involves the use of woven metal textiles, which produce varying
label: Paragraph

text: effects of translucency that Perrault has experimented with on other projects.
label: Paragraph

text: PERRET, AUGUSTE 1874-1954
label: Title

text: Architect, France
label: Title

text: Auguste Perret occupied a pivotal position in the development of the use of reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete in modern architecture, a tradition extending from Hennebique to de Baudot.
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporary French concerns—on the one hand, an intense interest in new
label: Paragraph

text: constructional methods, and on the other, a desire for traditional, formalist systems of
label: Paragraph

text: proportioning and ordering—find eloquent and convincing confluence in Perret’s work.
label: Paragraph

text: Born in Brussels, Perret attended the Ecole des Beaux-Arts, where he was influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: rationalist theorists Gaudet and Choisy, who belonged to a tradition stemming from
label: Paragraph

text: Viollet-le-Duc and Laugier. Perret combined Gaudet’s classical compositional principles
label: Paragraph

text: and Choisy’s simple and direct structural solutions with the basics of building
label: Paragraph

text: construction acquired with his brother Gustave in their father’s firm.
label: Paragraph

text: The apartments in the Rue Franklin (1904) were the first to exploit the constructional
label: Paragraph

text: possibilities of reinforced concrete to gain a greater openness of plan, which was later to
label: Paragraph

text: influence Le Corbusier’s plan libre (free plan), and larger windows on a restricted site.
label: Paragraph

text: The external framework is emphasized and covered, partly for practical reasons, by
label: Paragraph

text: omamental tiles that follow the structural contours. The angular effect contrasts with
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary Parisian Art Nouveau apartments.
label: Paragraph

text: Decorative elements are eschewed in the Garage Ponthieu (1905), which Perret called
label: Paragraph

text: “the world’s first experiment in aesthetic reinforced concrete.” The concrete frame of the
label: Paragraph

text: interior, with its large spans and thin supports, allowed considerable flexibility in
label: Paragraph

text: accordance with the function of the building. The formal aspects include the strongly
label: Paragraph

text: geometric facade with classical resonances in its arrangement, the upper attic story, and
label: Paragraph

text: the two cylindrical, nonconstructional pillar supports of the main entrance. The Thédatre
label: Caption

text: des Champs-Elysées (1913) in Paris, originally planned by Henri van de Velde but
label: Paragraph

text: carried out to Perret’s designs, shows a contrast between the ingeniously delicate
label: Paragraph

text: framework of the building designed to allow uninterrupted views and the heavy walls,
label: Paragraph

text: pilasters, and cornices of the facade that betray Perret’s classical sympathies.
label: Caption

text: The church of Notre Dame at Le Raincy (1923) near Paris marks a departure from, and
label: Paragraph

text: yet a logical culmination of, Perret’s pre-World War | work. A building of high technical
label: Paragraph

text: innovation, this memorial church established him as the leading exponent of this
label: Paragraph

text: architectural system. The structure demonstrates the way in which a modern material
label: Paragraph

text: such as reinforced concrete could be used to reinterpret traditional ecclesiastical
label: Paragraph

text: typologies while maintaining a visual connection with established forms. The outer walls
label: Paragraph

text: constructed from prefabricated components create perforated concrete screens that allow
label: Paragraph

text: the light to filter into the interior. These combine with the nave, aisles, and slim columns
label: Paragraph

text: carrying low-arching vaults to create a light and graceful interior. Traditional principles,
label: Paragraph

text: both classical and Gothic, are invoked, and yet the building denies adherence to either.
label: Paragraph

text: After the war, Perret further pursued the neoclassical elements of simplicity and clarity
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited so clearly in the Théatre des Champs-Elysées. His command of the essentials of
label: Paragraph

text: classicism is well represented in designs for the competitions for the Palace of the League
label: Paragraph

text: of Nations (1927) in Geneva and the Palace of the Soviets (1931) in Moscow. Perhaps the
label: Paragraph

text: best expression of Perret’s doctrine was the Hotel du Mobilier National (1934) in Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: which addressed the problem of combining diverse practical requirements in one building
label: Paragraph

text: and the problem of a sloping site. The Musée des Travaux Publics (1932) in Paris served
label: Paragraph

text: as a museum for large engineering models, and so the internal columns were minimal.
label: Paragraph

text: The tide of opinion among the international avant-garde was indifferent to the classical
label: Paragraph

text: affinities of these buildings despite their structural novelty and ingenuity.
label: Paragraph

text: Special interest attaches to the apartment building (1932) built speculatively at 51-55
label: Paragraph

text: rue Raynouard in Paris. Perret occupied an apartment at the top, and a spiral staircase
label: Paragraph

text: gave access to the firm’s offices on the lower level. Perret accommodated the challenges
label: Paragraph

text: of the comer triangular site by building nine stories above the level of the rue Raynouard
label: Caption

text: and 12 above the level of the rue Berton. The structure introduced a radical approach in
label: Paragraph

text: that all the posts and beams were poured in place and the in-fills precast in bare concrete.
label: Paragraph

text: Perret’s most important postwar commission was the reconstruction of Le Havre
label: Paragraph

text: (1956), destroyed during the war. With a group of disciples, he developed a master plan
label: Paragraph

text: that serves as a model of 20th-century neoclassical town planning. Perret designed the
label: Paragraph

text: plaza that housed the new city hall as well as the church of St. Joseph (1957). He was the
label: Paragraph

text: first president of the Ordres des Architectes and was elected to the Institut de France.
label: Paragraph

text: ee
label: Title

text: St. Joseph’s Church, Le Havre, France (1957)
label: Caption

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: After receiving numerous international distinctions, he was named president of the
label: Paragraph

text: International Union of Architects. He died in 1954 in his rue Raynouard apartment.

text: PERRIAND, CHARLOTTE 1903-99
label: Title

text: Furniture and interior designer, France
label: Title

text: Charlotte Perriand, typically remembered as Le Corbusier’s privileged assistant,
label: Paragraph

text: remains not only one of the most significant figures of French modernism but also one of
label: Paragraph

text: the most influential French interior designers. Her artistic activity spans over three
label: Paragraph

text: quarters of the 20th century. Trained between 1920 and 1925 at the Ecole Centrale des
label: Paragraph

text: Arts Décoratifs under traditional French décorateurs committed to an Art Deco concept
label: Paragraph

text: of modernity, her first exhibition as an independent professional took place at the 1926
label: Paragraph

text: Salon d’Automne, where she presented a coin de salon in a conventional French art
label: Paragraph

text: décoratif manner. Her radical turn toward machine-derived furniture, however, occurred
label: Paragraph

text: at the 1927 Salon d’Automne with a bar sous le toit, which brought her instant notoriety.
label: Paragraph

text: She was almost immediately invited to join Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret’s office
label: Paragraph

text: and was soon to become, at age 25, their main furniture and interior designer. In
label: Paragraph

text: association with Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret, she furnished the villa Laroche in
label: Paragraph

text: 1928, the villa Church at Villed’Avray in 1929, the Swiss pavilion at the Cité
label: Paragraph

text: Universitaire in 1932, and the Cité Refuge of the Salvation Army in 1932.
label: Paragraph

text: Her early modernist work, oriented primarily to demonstrating the viability of
label: Paragraph

text: industrial materials and forms for elite purposes, was characterized by lightweight
label: Paragraph

text: furniture made of bicycle tubes enhanced with leather seats and a wealth of highly
label: Paragraph

text: reflective, chrome-plated and glazed surfaces evoking the glittery automobile wheels,
label: Paragraph

text: windshields, fenders, and hoods that were taking over the metropolitan landscape. Early
label: Paragraph

text: on, Perriand’s interest in mechanical metaphors broadened to include movement and
label: Paragraph

text: transformability, as her dining chairs began to rotate on ball bearings, similar to those she
label: Paragraph

text: wore around her neck; her tables expanded or shrank along rolling, rubber surfaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Although adopting Le Corbusier’s concept of furniture as “home equipment,”
label: Paragraph

text: Perriand’s contribution both to the Le Corbusier-Jeanneret office repertoire and to Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s own development in respect to interior design was considerable. She brought
label: Paragraph

text: to the office a distinctly new orientation, associated with a novel sense of the art de vivre.
label: Paragraph

text: Through a more personal and expressive rendition of modernism, Perriand introduced
label: Paragraph

text: an understanding for “total design” enhanced with lavish comfort and whimsical
label: Paragraph

text: sophistication. Perriand’s radical, comprehensive aesthetic approach to modern interiors
label: Paragraph

text: was complemented by Le Corbusier’s programmatic concept of équipement as opposed
label: Paragraph

text: to decoration. This self-proclaimed functionalist approach to interior design dominated
label: Paragraph

text: the first common exhibition of the Perriand-Le Corbusier-Jeanneret trio at the 1929 Salon
label: Paragraph

text: d’Automne. The exhibits presented under Thonet’s sponsorship were dedicated to the
label: Paragraph

text: Equipement de I’habitation: des casiers, des siéges, des tables—all characterized by
label: Paragraph

text: standardization and modular deployment, resulting in what became known as the Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusian concept of objet type. A characteristic example of such type-object in
label: Paragraph

text: Perriand’s production was her 1928 rotating dining chair—erroneously attributed to Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier—that she re-used over the years in different contexts.
label: Paragraph

text: Passionately involved with radical leftist groups among artists, Perriand joined in 1932
label: Paragraph

text: the Association des Ecrivains et Artistes Révolutionaires (AEAR), sponsored by the
label: Paragraph

text: Communist Party, and participated in the activities of the Maison de la Culture led by
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Aragon. She viewed this activity as a logical extension of her role in the 1930
label: Paragraph

text: creation of the Union des Artistes Modernes (UAM).
label: Paragraph

text: Informed by her social and political commitments, which included two trips to the
label: Paragraph

text: Soviet Union and projects for the Front Populaire government, in 1936 Perriand
label: Paragraph

text: presented at the Third Housing Exhibition of the Salon des Arts Ménagers inexpensive,
label: Paragraph

text: mass-produced home fittings, such as her innovative chaise pliable et empilable. She
label: Paragraph

text: combined with her own furniture standard Flambo metal shelving that could meet the
label: Paragraph

text: needs of a small worker’s apartment necessarily oriented toward multifunctional,
label: Paragraph

text: transformable spaces. Along with her new interest in affordable, industrially produced
label: Paragraph

text: house equipment, she increasingly turned to an art brut in which wood and natural forms
label: Paragraph

text: replaced metal, and artisanal objects took over designs emblematic of the machine.
label: Paragraph

text: Consistent with a newfound essentialism, Perriand explored further through
label: Paragraph

text: photography the aesthetic potential of “accidental” forms, whether natural or industrial.
label: Paragraph

text: Her first, 1938 tables en forme, replaced furniture boasting mechanical motion with static
label: Paragraph

text: objects shaped to fit the movement of the human body, thus providing metaphors for her
label: Paragraph

text: new organicism.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1940, three months before the Nazi invasion of France, Perriand accepted Japan’s
label: Paragraph

text: invitation to assume the position formerly held by Bruno Taut as industrial design adviser
label: Paragraph

text: to the government. Japan’s efforts at modernization without jeopardizing its intricate
label: Paragraph

text: cultural heritage met successfully with Perriand’s own efforts to achieve a seamless
label: Paragraph

text: symbiosis between the industrial and the artisanal, the fabricated and the natural. She
label: Paragraph

text: found in the everyday life of the Japanese house some principles that she had tried to
label: Paragraph

text: apply in her work with Le Corbusier: the influence of the environment on modes of
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitation and the liberation of the interior space through the absorption of household
label: Title

text: equipment into the walls of the dwelling. This concept emulated the Zen Buddhist
label: Paragraph

text: understanding of the Void as “stimulating emptiness” rather than sterile absence. Perriand
label: Paragraph

text: reinvented for Western needs the relationship between space and motion by adapting to
label: Paragraph

text: modern life the Japanese view that harmonious human movement is possible only within
label: Paragraph

text: emptiness. Her exhibitions for the Takashimaya department stores played a significant
label: Paragraph

text: role in adapting Western modern techniques to fit the Japanese traditional spirit and were
label: Paragraph

text: just the beginning of a series of similar exhibitions held simultaneously in France and
label: Paragraph

text: Japan after the war.
label: Paragraph

text: Ultimately, Perriand’s contact with Japan and its distinctive classicism—recognized as
label: Paragraph

text: germane to Western modernism at least since Frank Lloyd Wright and French
label: Paragraph

text: Japonisme—helped purify her own art brut into a postwar sophistication reminiscent, in
label: Paragraph

text: some respects, of her early modernist phase. Her 1950 adaptation of the chaise longue, in
label: Paragraph

text: which bent bamboo stems replaced the metallic tubular supports, is an example of this
label: Paragraph

text: transformation. In general, the Japanese lesson emerged in her work through the
label: Paragraph

text: reintroduction of simple, plain wood; sliding translucent panels that open widely on
label: Paragraph

text: natural environments; low, horizontal furniture; and transformable modular storing
label: Paragraph

text: PETRONAS TOWERS, KUALA LUMPUR
label: Caption

text: Designed by Cesar Pelli; completed 1996
label: Caption

text: Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia
label: Title

text: Claiming the title of the tallest buildings in the world at the time of their completion,
label: Paragraph

text: the Petronas Towers were designed by Cesar Pelli and completed in 1996. Built in Kuala
label: Paragraph

text: Lumpur City for the Petronas Company, the national petroleum company of Malaysia,
label: Paragraph

text: the twin towers are part of an enormous commercial development that contains the
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters of Petronas as well as a hotel and leased office space. Dominating the
label: Paragraph

text: central part of the city, the twin towers were the first phase of a “city within the city’—an
label: Paragraph

text: 18 million-square-foot complex located on the grounds of what was formerly a horse-
label: Paragraph

text: racing track.
label: Paragraph

text: Pelli’s Petronas Towers exemplify the never-ending quest to build taller structures—a
label: Paragraph

text: quest that inspired the building of the Tower of Babel, the city of San Gimignano, Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: cathedrals, and the modern skyscraper. The skyscraper building type emerged in the
label: Paragraph

text: United States in the late 19th century, with Chicago and New York competing to have the
label: Paragraph

text: tallest building in the world. Made possible by the invention of the elevator, improved
label: Paragraph

text: fireproofing technology, and metal structural cages, skyscrapers of the Chicago School
label: Paragraph

text: became important civic and corporate status symbols. Some of the earliest examples of
label: Paragraph

text: this type include the Home Insurance Building (1885) by William LeBaron Jenny;
label: Paragraph

text: Reliance Building (1894) by Burnham and Root; and Guaranty Building (1895) by
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan and Adler. Petronas Towers joins a list of buildings that have held the title of the
label: Paragraph

text: tallest building in the world: Masonic Temple (1892) by Burnham and Root in Chicago;
label: Paragraph

text: the Woolworth Building (1913) in New York City by Cass Gilbert; the Empire State
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1931) in New York City by Shreve, Lamb and Harmon; the World Trade
label: Caption

text: Center (1972-73, destroyed in 2001) in New York City by Minoru Yamasaki; and the
label: Paragraph

text: Sears Tower (1974) in Chicago by Skidmore, Owing and Merrill. The Petronas Towers
label: Caption

text: bested the Sears Tower by nine meters, standing at 452 meters to the tip of the spire.
label: Paragraph

text: There was some controversy about which building was actually higher, since the Sears
label: Paragraph

text: Tower has a higher occupiable floor, but Petronas reaches a higher overall height.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Petronas Towers will someday be eclipsed as the tallest
label: Paragraph

text: Petronas Office Towers, designed by Cesar Pelli
label: Caption

text: © Jeff Goldberg/ESTO. Photo courtesy of Cesar Pelli and Associates
label: Caption

text: in the world, it will remain the tallest concrete frame structure for many years to come.
label: Paragraph

text: After an international competition, the architectural commission for the towers was
label: Paragraph

text: awarded to Cesar Pelli Associates, a firm that had executed several tall buildings noted
label: Paragraph

text: for their rich palette of materials and elegant skyscraper profiles. The U.S. firm of
label: Paragraph

text: Thorton-Tomasetti Engineers with their Malaysian counterpart Ranhill Bersekutu
label: Paragraph

text: undertook the challenge of engineering the high-strength concrete frame. In addition to
label: Paragraph

text: the technical demands of these towers, the high profile of the project, and the nationalistic
label: Paragraph

text: nature of the program caused unusual stipulations to be placed on the design. The
label: Paragraph

text: technology to build the towers, while developed with international expertise, had to be
label: Paragraph

text: transferable to the Malaysians working on the project. The subcontractors were required
label: Paragraph

text: to develop fabrication plants in Malaysia and to train local workers, both of which would
label: Paragraph

text: have longterm benefits for the Malaysian economy.
label: Paragraph

text: Each of the two main towers stands 88 stories tall, with a slimmer “bustle” tower at 44
label: Paragraph

text: stories. The twin towers are joined with a skybridge at levels 41 and 42. The massing of
label: Paragraph

text: the towers is relatively slender with setbacks at levels 60, 73, 82, 85, and 88, terminating
label: Paragraph

text: in a 49-meter stainless-steel spire. The glass and stainless-steel skin of the building is
label: Paragraph

text: faceted as a result of the complex geometry of each tower’s plan.
label: Paragraph

text: Petronas Office Towers, designed by Cesar Pelli
label: Caption

text: © Jeff Goldberg/ESTO. Photo courtesy of Cesar Pelli and Associates
label: Caption

text: The eight-pointed star created by two interlocked squares is one of the fundamental
label: Paragraph

text: geometries underlying Islamic design. The basic square represents the earth and its four
label: Paragraph

text: cardinal points, or heaven and its four rivers. The development of simple forms into
label: Paragraph

text: complex geometry reflects the incomprehensibility of God. In the case of the Petronas
label: Paragraph

text: Towers plan, eight small circles were superimposed at each intersection, creating a
label: Paragraph

text: multifaceted floor plate. This result satisfied a programmatic desire for multiple commer
label: Paragraph

text: offices, each taking advantage of the complex’s park-like setting.
label: Paragraph

text: This geometry also dictated a structural solution that allowed the floor plates to be
label: Paragraph

text: apparently column-free. In addition to a central concrete core, there are 16 perimeter
label: Paragraph

text: columns, each 2.4 meters in diameter, arrayed in a 46-meter diameter circle. A ring beam,
label: Paragraph

text: haunched to allow mechanical systems to pass underneath, connects the columns. At the
label: Paragraph

text: setbacks, columns were engineered for a slight slope to eliminate transfer beams.
label: Paragraph

text: Cantilevers framed in steel create the triangles and arcs that make up the points of the
label: Paragraph

text: star.
label: Paragraph

text: Steel was the dominant structural material for tall buildings for most of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century, and the decision to depart from this norm was made early in the Petronas Towers
label: Paragraph

text: design process. High-strength concrete became the preferred material partially because of
label: Paragraph

text: its compressive strength and partially because of the government’s incentive to use
label: Paragraph

text: materials that could be fabricated domestically. Another advantage is that the concrete’s
label: Paragraph

text: mass stabilizes the towers so that movement is not a significant problem.
label: Paragraph

text: The site chosen for the towers, however, posed significant challenges. The nature of
label: Paragraph

text: the soil was extremely unpredictable, and in fact an underground cliff was discovered.
label: Paragraph

text: Master-plan changes had to be made to accommodate found conditions, and the
label: Paragraph

text: excavation for each “barrette pile” (concrete friction element) had to be surveyed to an
label: Paragraph

text: average depth of 80 meters.
label: Paragraph

text: The steel-framed connecting skybridge that attached to the towers at their midpoint
label: Paragraph

text: was another major technical challenge. A clear space between the towers was very
label: Paragraph

text: important in the design and massing of the building, and therefore the connector piece
label: Paragraph

text: had to be light and relatively transparent. The connector bridge was braced against each
label: Paragraph

text: tower with a pair of split “V” legs, each slender element containing a tuned mass damper.
label: Paragraph

text: Each set of legs was attached to its tower with a fully rotating ball joint that allowed for
label: Paragraph

text: movement up to 500 millimeters. The connector was prefabricated by a Korean
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturer and was raised over several days after a ceremonial celebration.
label: Paragraph

text: PEVSNER, SIR NIKOLAUS 1902-83
label: Title

text: Architecture historian and critic, England
label: Title

text: Nikolaus Pevsner transformed the discipline of architectural history in Britain. More
label: Paragraph

text: than any other single individual, architect, or critic, he molded the taste of English
label: Paragraph

text: architects throughout the 1940s and 1950s and developed public awareness and
label: Paragraph

text: appreciation of architecture in Britain for an even longer period. He was a naturally gifted
label: Paragraph

text: teacher, an indefatigable researcher, and a highly opinionated critic. Before he arrived in
label: Paragraph

text: Britain as a refugee from Nazi Germany in 1933, architectural history and criticism in
label: Paragraph

text: Britain was very largely a dilettante activity taken up by gentleman architects and
label: Paragraph

text: university professors. By the time he died, 50 years later, British scholarship in the fields
label: Paragraph

text: of architectural theory and history was second to none: vigorously disciplined, genuinely
label: Paragraph

text: enlightening and innovative, and securely based in higher academic institutions.
label: Paragraph

text: This transformation was not effected by Pevsner alone, of course. His fellow
label: Paragraph

text: countryman Sir Ernst Gombrich, the noted art theorist and historian, achieved as much in
label: Paragraph

text: academic circles. However, among architects, architectural students, and the general
label: Paragraph

text: public in Britain, Pevsner’s achievements and influence stand head and shoulders above
label: Paragraph

text: any other. He achieved this status through his prolific writings, which were scholarly yet
label: Paragraph

text: popular; through his editorship (1942-45) and long association with the Architectural
label: Paragraph

text: Review, Britain’s most prestigious monthly architectural journal; and through his many
label: Paragraph

text: years of teaching architectural history (as professor of history of art at Birkbeck College,
label: Paragraph

text: University of London, 1942-69, and as Slade Professor of Fine Art at the University of
label: Paragraph

text: Cambridge, 1949-55, and at the University of Oxford, 1968-69). Many generations of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural students have grappled with the question he asked in the introduction to his
label: Paragraph

text: book, An Outline of European Architecture (1942), “What is architecture?” and disputed
label: Paragraph

text: his answer, “A bicycle shed is a building; Lincoln Cathedral is a piece of architecture.” In
label: Paragraph

text: the late 1930s and throughout the 1940s, they were convinced by him of the intellectual
label: Paragraph

text: validity and inevitable victory of the Modern movement in architecture through reading
label: Paragraph

text: his Pioneers of the Modern Movement from William Morris to Walter Gropius (1936).
label: Paragraph

text: Modest and unassuming in manner, Pevsner had an iron will and determination. He
label: Paragraph

text: persuaded Sir Allen Lane, founder of Penguin Books, to embark on Penguin’s most
label: Paragraph

text: ambitious, extensive, and financially uncertain project: the publication in 46 volumes,
label: Paragraph

text: eventually, of a series, The Buildings of England. This was to consist of a series of
label: Paragraph

text: scholarly and entertaining catalogs of the most important, and the more interesting,
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, archaeological sites, urban neighborhoods and ensembles, towns, and
label: Paragraph

text: villages—historic, traditional-vernacular, and modern—country by country. The early
label: Paragraph

text: volumes were entirely researched and written by him. In later volumes, he was more
label: Paragraph

text: dependent, both in research and in the actual writing, on the assistance of others—many
label: Paragraph

text: his former students at Birkbeck College. However, when the series was finally completed
label: Paragraph

text: in 1974, the series was unmistakably his—his vigorous scholarship, acute observation,
label: Paragraph

text: and idiosyncratic likes and dislikes were evident in every volume—and, not content with
label: Paragraph

text: England, he persuaded Penguin to commission volumes on the countries of Wales and
label: Paragraph

text: Scotland.
label: Paragraph

text: The Buildings of England series made Pevsner a household name in Britain. Few
label: Paragraph

text: families would embark on a motor tour or a provincial holiday in England without
label: Paragraph

text: packing the appropriate volumes of The Buildings of England to take with them. As the
label: Paragraph

text: volume and extent of heritage tourism grew in Britain throughout the 1960s, 1970s, and
label: Paragraph

text: 1980s, so did sales of these particular books. He was a popular broadcaster as well,
label: Paragraph

text: delivering the Reith Lectures of 1955 on BBC radio on the subject “The Englishness of
label: Paragraph

text: English Art.”
label: Paragraph

text: Pevsner’s intellectual formation was rigorously academic. Born in Leipzig, Germany,
label: Paragraph

text: he was educated in Leipzig, Munich, Berlin, and Frankfurt and was destined for a career
label: Paragraph

text: in art history. He joined the staff of the Dresden Gallery in 1924 while engaged in
label: Paragraph

text: research for his doctorate. His doctoral dissertation was published, as Leipziger Barock,
label: Paragraph

text: in 1929. In the same year, he joined the staff of Gottingen University. He visited England
label: Paragraph

text: in 1930, developed an interest in English 19th-century design, and emigrated to England
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1930s, as an “enemy alien” in World War LI, life in England was not easy
label: Paragraph

text: for Pevsner but, rather, was precarious and insecure. It was not until after the war, under a
label: Paragraph

text: progressive government and with a tenured teaching appointment at London University,
label: Paragraph

text: that he could feel secure. In 1946 he became a naturalized British citizen. He acquired a
label: Paragraph

text: house, in Hampstead Garden Suburb, in which to bring up his family.
label: Paragraph

text: Responsibilities and honors were showered on Pevsner: the responsibilities he
label: Paragraph

text: welcomed and bore diligently, whereas the honors sat highly on his slightly bowed
label: Paragraph

text: shoulders. He was appointed to the Royal Fine Arts Commission, the Historic Buildings
label: Paragraph

text: Council, and similar organizations and was chairman of the Victorian Society, which he
label: Paragraph

text: was largely instrumental in founding, from 1958 to 1976. He was made a Commander of
label: Paragraph

text: the British Empire (CBE) in 1953 and a Fellow of the British Academy (FBA) in 1965
label: Paragraph

text: and was awarded the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA) Royal Gold Medal in
label: Paragraph

text: 1967 and knighted in 1969. In the same year, his native land honored him with the award
label: Paragraph

text: of the Grand Cross of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany.
label: Paragraph

text: Pevsner was a prolific writer and published many books and articles in learned
label: Paragraph

text: journals. For Sir Allen Lane, he edited the series King Penguins from 1941 and persuaded
label: Paragraph

text: his patron to publish the Pelican History of Art series, which was launched in 1953 with
label: Paragraph

text: Painting in Britain 1530 to 1790 by Ellis Waterhouse and The Art and Architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: india by Benjamin Rowland. Among his later books are Sources of Modern Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and Design (1968), Some Architectural Writers of the Nineteenth Century (1972), and A
label: Paragraph

text: History of Building Types (1976). He remained intellectually active until the end of his
label: Paragraph

text: life, although the onset of Parkinson’s disease in the early 1970s limited his mobility and
label: Paragraph

text: caused him and his many friends and colleagues considerable distress. He died in 1983.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Caption

text: London; lecturer, University of Cambridge 1949-55; lecturer, University of Oxford
label: Paragraph

text: 1968-69. Member, later chair and president, Victorian Society from 1958. Royal Gold
label: Caption

text: Medal, Royal Institute of British Architects 1967; knighted 1969. Died in London, 18

text: Pevsner was a prolific writer. He contributed regularly to learned journals in English,
label: Paragraph

text: German, and French and was widely translated into Spanish and Italian. Several of his
label: Paragraph

text: more popular books ran to several editions and were published in both Britain and the
label: Paragraph

text: United States. The select Pevsner bibliography included in Concerning Architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: edited by John Summerson (1968; see listing under “Further Reading”), contains almost
label: Paragraph

text: 300 entries up to the end of 1967 and does not claim to be comprehensive. The list below
label: Paragraph

text: contains only his more important books and a few key journal articles.
