text: PHILADELPHIA, PENNSYLVANIA
label: Title

text: Philadelphia began the 20th century as the third-largest city in the United States, after
label: Paragraph

text: New York and Chicago. It was an economically prosperous manufacturing center and a
label: Paragraph

text: significant port that attracted many immigrants from the poorer areas of Eastern Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: southern Italy, and the southern United States. Although it had lost its position as
label: Paragraph

text: America’s political, financial, and cultural capital to Washington, DC, and New York,
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia was a thriving industrial metropolis at the turn of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: The epitome of Philadelphia’s confidence at this time can be seen in its City Hall
label: Paragraph

text: (1871-1901), designed by John McArthur, Jr., and Thomas Ustick Walter in an ornately
label: Paragraph

text: decorative Second Empire style with sculptures by Alexander Calder. This imposing and
label: Paragraph

text: monumental structure fills a massive square block broken only by pedestrian passages
label: Paragraph

text: that continue Philadelphia’s axes of Broad and Market Streets into its center courtyard. In
label: Paragraph

text: addition, City Hall’s tower, with clock and sculpture of founder William Penn,
label: Caption

text: prominently stands out from all parts of the city. This was especially so before Helmut
label: Paragraph

text: Jahn’s Liberty Place (1987), when there was an unwritten “gentleman’s agreement” not
label: Paragraph

text: to build higher than City Hall’s tower.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 20th century, Philadelphia gradually moved away from its 19th-century
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturing history and developed into a service economy with the building of office
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, hotels, department stores, apartment buildings, banks, and cultural buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Daniel Burnham’s Land Title Buildings (1897 and 1902) introduced to Philadelphia
label: Paragraph

text: the practice of downsizing the presence of a building’s steel frame behind external
label: Paragraph

text: omament and a curtain wall. (City Hall is constructed with load-bearing stone
label: Paragraph

text: approximately 22 feet thick at its base.) This practice continued into the 20th century,
label: Paragraph

text: most notably with the Art Deco-style East Penn Square (1930) by Ritter and Shay. The
label: Paragraph

text: first Philadelphia building to break away from this tradition was George Howe and
label: Paragraph

text: William Lescaze’s Philadelphia Savings Fund Society (PSFS) Building (1932), one of the
label: Caption

text: first International Style skyscrapers in the United States and a daring architectural
label: Paragraph

text: statement by a conservative institution such as a bank.
label: Paragraph

text: The convention of expressing a tall building’s steel frame continued as modernism
label: Paragraph

text: flourished in the decades after World War Il. The Penn Center development (1953-82),
label: Paragraph

text: proposed by Edmund Bacon and Vincent Kling, was made possible by the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: Suburban Station (1924-29) and 30th Street Station (1927-34), both by Graham,
label: Paragraph

text: Anderson, Probst and White, and the 1953 demolition of Broad Street Station (1892-93)
label: Caption

text: and its elevated railroad tracks. Penn Center is worthy of mention if only because of its
label: Paragraph

text: integration of transportation, retail, and office facilities. Other notable buildings in this
label: Paragraph

text: area west of City Hall include the pyramid-topped Mellon Bank Center (1990) by Kohn
label: Caption

text: Pederson Fox and the electric-razor-like Bell Atlantic Tower (1991) by the Kling-
label: Caption

text: Lindquist Partnership.
label: Paragraph

text: Befitting a city with money to spend, Philadelphia produced a considerable amount of
label: Paragraph

text: large department stores and retail centers in the 20th century. The Lit Brothers Store
label: Paragraph

text: (1891-1907), Strawbridge and Clothier Department Store (1890s-1920s), and Gimbel’s
label: Paragraph

text: Department Store (1890s-1900, demolished 1980) were all major retail outlets around the
label: Paragraph

text: vicinity of Eighth and Market Streets composed of assorted buildings that were built or
label: Paragraph

text: converted as was needed. In contrast, Burnham’s John Wanamaker Department Store
label: Paragraph

text: (1902-11), a blocky Renaissance palazzo on the outside with an impressive atrium on the
label: Paragraph

text: inside, was purposely built to be a self-contained shopping experience.
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia’s last big foray into retail in the 20th century came between 1974 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1983 with the development known as “The Gallery” by Bower and Fradley (phase 1) and
label: Paragraph

text: Bower Lewis Thrower (phase 2). Basically an urban shopping mall, The Gallery can be
label: Paragraph

text: commended for its integration with the street grid
label: Paragraph

text: View of the city looking towards the Philadelphia Museum of Art, ca. 1933
label: Caption

text: © Library of Congress
label: Title

text: of Philadelphia and also with the underground Market East Train Station (1985). The
label: Paragraph

text: Gallery cannot be commended, however, for its typical and banal shopping mall
label: Paragraph

text: appearance and for the way it stole the street life away from nearby Chestnut Street,
label: Paragraph

text: which had been pedestrianized in 1973.
label: Paragraph

text: Prominent bank buildings in 20th-century Philadelphia include the Girard Trust
label: Paragraph

text: Company (1905-08), a brilliantly white lonic temple by McKim, Mead and White. The
label: Paragraph

text: Federal Reserve Bank (1931-35) by Paul Phillipe Cret is a bit more stripped down in its
label: Paragraph

text: classicism. The previously mentioned PSFS Building was internally innovative in the
label: Paragraph

text: way its banking hall was located on an upper floor of its sleek polished-granite base, with
label: Paragraph

text: street level given over to retail.
label: Paragraph

text: The major cultural project of the early 20th century was the creation of the Benjamin
label: Paragraph

text: Franklin Parkway (1907-41), a spacious boulevard modeled after Paris’s Champs-
label: Paragraph

text: Elysées, which cuts through Philadelphia’s street grid to connect City Hall with
label: Paragraph

text: Fairmount Park. The idea for the Parkway was first inspired by the World’s Columbian
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition of 1893 in Chicago, which promoted broad avenues with gleamingly white
label: Paragraph

text: neoclassical buildings under the guise of the City Beautiful Movement.
label: Paragraph

text: The Parkway itself was officially designed and planned by Jacques Grabér and Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Philippe Cret, but its crowning glory is the Philadelphia Museum of Art (1916-28) by
label: Paragraph

text: Horace Trumbauer, especially in the way it mediates Fairmount Park and the city. Along
label: Paragraph

text: the Parkway are other neoclassical civic buildings, such as the Rodin Museum (1927-29),
label: Paragraph

text: also by Grabér and Cret; the Franklin Institute Science Museum (1932-34) by John
label: Caption

text: Windrim; and the Philadelphia Free Library (1917-27) by Trumbauer and its near twin,
label: Paragraph

text: the Philadelphia County Courthouse (1938-41), based on a design by Windrim.
label: Paragraph

text: The second half of the 20th century produced two stars of the international
label: Paragraph

text: architectural scene from Philadelphia: Louis Kahn and Robert Venturi. Kahn’s
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia masterpieces include the Margaret Esherick House (1960) in Chestnut Hill,
label: Paragraph

text: a private residence that beautifully makes use of natural light to enhance the interior, and
label: Paragraph

text: the University of Pennsylvania’s Richards Medical Research Laboratory (1957-61)
label: Caption

text: whose “served” and “service” spaces influenced a generation of architects. Venturi was
label: Paragraph

text: born in Philadelphia and briefly worked for Kahn before establishing his own practice
label: Paragraph

text: with John Rauch in 1964 and Denise Scott Brown in 1967. His Philadelphia masterpieces
label: Paragraph

text: include the Vanna Venturi House (1962), a private residence for his mother, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Guild House (1960-63), an apartment house for the elderly both of which have been
label: Paragraph

text: mistakenly credited as the foundation of Postmodernist architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: After World War II, the character of Philadelphia began to change. Beginning in 1948,
label: Paragraph

text: under the good intentions of creating space around Independence Hall (the location of the
label: Paragraph

text: signing of the Declaration of Independence and the writing of the Constitution), many
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were cleared to form empty strips of land called Independence Mall and
label: Paragraph

text: Independence Park. For the United States’ bicentennial celebrations in 1976, all this
label: Paragraph

text: space began to make sense, especially coupled with the Liberty Bell Pavilion (1976) by
label: Paragraph

text: Mitchell/Giurgola, a glass box that displays the icon of Philadelphia tourism. After the
label: Paragraph

text: bicentennial, however, these areas became an empty wasteland. In brilliant opposition to
label: Paragraph

text: the fakeness of Independence Mall, Robert Venturi designed his Franklin Court (1976) as
label: Paragraph

text: a tubular steel outline of Benjamin Franklin’s former house, putting the actual exhibits
label: Paragraph

text: underground.
label: Paragraph

text: The tourist-world of Independence Mall is in the process of being reconstructed to
label: Paragraph

text: include an Independence Visitor Center and a National Constitution Center. In addition, a
label: Paragraph

text: new home for the Liberty Bell, designed by Bohlin Cywinski Jackson, that allows views
label: Paragraph

text: of Independence Hall without a background of skyscrapers will open in 2003. The view
label: Paragraph

text: of the city as a museum piece was especially reinforced after the construction of the
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania Convention Center (1994) by Thompson, Ventulett, Stainback, and
label: Caption

text: Associates, which converted the Reading Terminal train shed (1891-93) for part of its
label: Paragraph

text: facilities after its redundancy following the construction of the Market East Train Station.
label: Paragraph

text: With the anticipation of thousands of different visitors every week, hotel speculation
label: Paragraph

text: went rampant, with many office buildings converted into hotels, including the seminal
label: Paragraph

text: PSFS Building. Along with the hotels also came the tourist-traps that could be located
label: Paragraph

text: anywhere and not necessarily particular to Philadelphia—namely a Hard Rock Café and a
label: Paragraph

text: planned Disney Quest “family entertainment center.” Conversely, the Kimmel Center for
label: Paragraph

text: the Performing Arts (2001) by Rafael Vifioly Architects, part of a planned arts district on
label: Paragraph

text: South Broad Street, rises above the anonymity of the subsequent Convention Center
label: Paragraph

text: development and sets a good example for future development like a proposed
label: Paragraph

text: entertainment complex with tram across the Delaware River and a new downtown
label: Paragraph

text: baseball stadium.
label: Paragraph

text: PHOENIX CENTRAL LIBRARY
label: Title

text: Designed by Will Bruder (bruderD WLarchitects); completed 1995
label: Caption

text: Phoenix, Arizona
label: Title

text: The Phoenix Central Library was the first major commission for Will Bruder (1946-),
label: Paragraph

text: an artist and self-trained architect who lives and works in New River, Arizona, in the
label: Paragraph

text: desert north of Phoenix. Opened in 1995, the building has earned critical acclaim from
label: Paragraph

text: the architectural profession for its poetic and economical integration of everyday
label: Paragraph

text: materials, natural lighting, and environmental technologies as well as for its local and
label: Paragraph

text: regional specificity, achieved without recourse to historical pastiche. Planned in close
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration with the library’s professional staff, the building also received in 1997 an
label: Paragraph

text: Award of Excellence in a library building award program cosponsored by the American
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of Architects and the American Library Association.
label: Caption

text: The campaign for a new central library in Phoenix began in the early 1980s, but the
label: Paragraph

text: project began in earnest only in 1988, when the city passed a $1.2 billion bond issue to
label: Paragraph

text: finance the construction of several new cultural institutions. In the summer of 1989, the
label: Paragraph

text: city issued a request for proposals for the library, and by the end of the year a selection
label: Paragraph

text: committee had picked Bruder’s firm (known as bruderDWLarchitects) from a pool of
label: Paragraph

text: five finalists that also included Antoine Predock and Ricardo Legorreta. In the first half
label: Paragraph

text: of 1990, the design team (led by Bruder and Wendell Burnette) refined the building
label: Paragraph

text: program by conducting interviews with the entire library staff (including city librarian
label: Paragraph

text: Ralph Edwards, central library director Rosemary Nelson, and president of the library
label: Title

text: board of trustees Elinor Green Hunter) and by holding 28 citizen meetings. The basic
label: Paragraph

text: design concepts were in place by November 1990. Despite some resistance to the initial
label: Paragraph

text: design (fueled in part by Bruder’s description of the building as a “kinetically energized
label: Paragraph

text: arrival pavilion”), the city council approved the plan in early January 1991.
label: Paragraph

text: As a library, the Phoenix building owes a great deal to postwar developments of the
label: Paragraph

text: building type and particularly to the concept of the modular library. Using a planning
label: Paragraph

text: module based on the standard dimensions and spacing of bookshelves, this system
label: Paragraph

text: allowed bookshelves to be placed anywhere in the library and facilitated the integration
label: Paragraph

text: of reading and book storage areas. Such buildings typically had large, square (or nearly
label: Paragraph

text: square) footprints; uniform ceiling heights; and flat ceilings to conceal the requisite air-
label: Paragraph

text: handling equipment and artificial lighting. At the Phoenix Central Library, a skeleton of
label: Caption

text: concrete columns in the main body of the building rises from a planning module 32 feet,
label: Paragraph

text: 8 inches square, creating a nearly square footprint approximately an acre in area at the
label: Paragraph

text: upper floors. On the first four floors, these columns carry a precast T ceiling system that
label: Paragraph

text: houses the east-west chases for lighting fixtures, air ducts, and power and data lines;
label: Paragraph

text: concealed behind slightly concave aluminum panels, these chases are in turn served by
label: Paragraph

text: aluminum-covered soffits, called “power bellies,” which run north-south just inside the
label: Paragraph

text: main body of the building. Flexibility—the watchword of postwar library planning—is
label: Paragraph

text: here enhanced by housing ancillary and service functions in “saddlebags” (the architects’
label: Paragraph

text: term for the curved, copper-clad elements that flank the main body of the building along
label: Paragraph

text: its east and west sides) and extended to computer terminals that can be located anywhere
label: Paragraph

text: in the library.
label: Paragraph

text: Phoenix Central Library (1995), grand staircase leading to Reading Room
label: Caption

text: © Bill Timmerman. Photo courtesy William P.Bruder Architects
label: Caption

text: While the Phoenix Central Library updates the technology of the modular library, it also
label: Paragraph

text: moves beyond the monotonous interiors that characterized libraries in the postwar period.
label: Paragraph

text: In part, this is achieved by glazing the north and south walls and providing natural
label: Paragraph

text: lighting and dramatic views of the city and surrounding mountains. Computer-controlled
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical louvers on the building’s south side adjust continuously to block the strong
label: Paragraph

text: desert sun, and on the north side Teflon-covered sails prevent glare. Natural lighting is
label: Paragraph

text: also brought into the core of the building through the “crystal canyon,” a five-story skylit
label: Paragraph

text: atrium surrounded on three sides by glass and on the fourth by glass-encased elevators.
label: Paragraph

text: The Phoenix Central Library also updates the postwar type with the reintroduction of a
label: Paragraph

text: monumental public reading room. In this case, the room is on the fifth floor, where it can
label: Paragraph

text: take advantage of substantially taller ceiling heights and dramatic views; mechanical
label: Paragraph

text: systems at this level are laid beneath a raised floor deck. Dominated by 30-foot-tall
label: Paragraph

text: columns that taper from two feet at the base to ten inches at the top, this room has been
label: Paragraph

text: compared to the great reading room in Henri Labrouste’s Bibliothéque Nationale (1858—
label: Caption

text: 68) in Paris and to hypostyle halls of ancient Egyptian temples. Above each column is a
label: Caption

text: skylight of laminated glass seven feet in diameter; in each, a hole in the blue interlayer
label: Paragraph

text: provides clear glass opening four inches in diameter, calculated to allow the sunlight of
label: Paragraph

text: the summer solstice to “light” the candlestick columns. (The library sponsors
label: Paragraph

text: Phoenix Central Library (1995), South elevation
label: Caption

text: © Bill Timmerman. Photo courtesy William P.Bruder Architects
label: Caption

text: a solstice event each year, which has brought as many as 1500 people to witness the
label: Paragraph

text: effect.)
label: Paragraph

text: These skylights also call attention to the fact that the columns stop short of the ceiling,
label: Paragraph

text: which seems to float overhead. The ceiling is, in fact, supported by a “tensegrity”
label: Paragraph

text: structure developed by Michael Ishler, an engineer with Ove Arup and Partners.
label: Paragraph

text: Anchored to the steel caps bolted to the top of the columns, steel cables support vertical
label: Paragraph

text: struts that in turn support the north-south purlins of the galvanized-steel roof deck. The
label: Paragraph

text: roof deck also stops short of the walls on the east and west sides of the room, allowing
label: Paragraph

text: daylight to wash down their concrete surfaces.
label: Paragraph

text: The Phoenix Central Library is noteworthy also for its regional character. Bruder, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, drew on a number of regional metaphors in the process of refining the initial
label: Paragraph

text: design concept. In addition to the crystal canyon and the saddlebags mentioned
label: Paragraph

text: previously, Bruder has compared the building itself to a man-made mesa, its scaleless
label: Paragraph

text: mass rising abruptly from the desert floor. The building also acknowledges its locale
label: Paragraph

text: through its attention to the power of the desert sun. The 12-inch concrete walls, which
label: Paragraph

text: separate the main body of the building from the saddlebags to the east and west, insulate
label: Paragraph

text: those facades and allow the air conditioning to function smoothly. The experience of the
label: Paragraph

text: main reading room—where the glazing of the north and south walls is most apparent and
label: Paragraph

text: where sunlight washes the east and west walls—is particularly affected by the time of day
label: Paragraph

text: and the time of year.
label: Paragraph

text: The library’s regional specificity is also evident in the choice of materials: copper used
label: Paragraph

text: to clad the steel-frame saddlebags is one of Arizona’s most important natural resources
label: Paragraph

text: (although copper sheets of the size needed here could be found at a competitive price
label: Paragraph

text: only in Germany). Striations in the copper are the result of roll forming, a technique
label: Paragraph

text: normally used to construct metal grain silos. Its use here is both expressive (in that it
label: Paragraph

text: links the library to the industrialized agribusiness that sustains the state) and practical:
label: Paragraph

text: because of the rigidity of the corrugation that it achieves, the technique allowed the use of
label: Paragraph

text: an exceptionally thin gauge copper that cost only $1 more per square foot than the stucco
label: Paragraph

text: often used in the Southwest to imitate adobe. In the end, the library cost less than $100
label: Paragraph

text: per square foot, demonstrating Bruder’s commitment to an architecture in which “both
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatism and poetry are served with equal passion” (Bruder, quoted in Ojeda, 1999).
label: Paragraph

text: PIANO, RENZO 1937
label: Title

text: Architect, Italy
label: Title

text: Renzo Piano, born in 1937 in the Mediterranean harbor city of Genoa, has been one of
label: Paragraph

text: the most influential architectural personalities since the 1980s. He was strongly
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by Franco Albini and Emesto Rogers, who were his professors at the
label: Paragraph

text: Polytechnical University in Milan. Jean Prouvé, Pierluigi Nervi, and the work of
label: Caption

text: Buckminster Fuller also exerted a strong influence on the architect.
label: Paragraph

text: After Piano ended his academic career at the Polytechnical University, he founded
label: Paragraph

text: Studio Piano, his first architectural office (1964-70). During this period, Piano also
label: Paragraph

text: worked with Louis |.Kahn in Philadelphia and Z.S.Makowsky in London. He first gained
label: Paragraph

text: international recognition when he went into partnership with English architect Richard
label: Paragraph

text: Rogers from 1971 to 1977, emphasizing technology in architecture. From 1977 to 1981,
label: Paragraph

text: he partnered with engineer and humanist Peter Rice (1935-92), who influenced Piano’s
label: Paragraph

text: work significantly with his focus on structural systems. After the death of Rice, Piano
label: Paragraph

text: founded the Renzo Piano Building Workshop. The innovative and experimental character
label: Paragraph

text: of Piano’s work is based on team workshops that are filled with young talent from around
label: Paragraph

text: the world. Like only a handful of architects, Piano has planned and realized a broad range
label: Paragraph

text: of projects on a worldwide basis.
label: Paragraph

text: For Piano architecture is a creative process of communication and participation in
label: Paragraph

text: which architectural solutions follow a process of diagnosis, design, realization, and
label: Paragraph

text: documentation. This procedure was developed during the UNESCO-Workshop in
label: Paragraph

text: Otranto, Italy (1978). A mobile display and communication box covered with a tent
label: Paragraph

text: structure offered a central public forum. Piano created an environment allowing direct
label: Paragraph

text: verbal confrontation and active participation of the community in the search for
label: Paragraph

text: respectful restoration methods.
label: Paragraph

text: Piano and Rogers’s Georges Pompidou Center (1978) is located in a sensitive urban
label: Paragraph

text: environment in downtown Paris. Against considerable public and political resistance,
label: Paragraph

text: Piano and Rogers designed a cultural forum in the form of a highly visible machine.
label: Paragraph

text: Approximately 25,000 visitors participate daily in all sorts of cultural events on the inside
label: Paragraph

text: as well as on the rectangular plaza in front of the Pompidou Center. Visitors enter the
label: Paragraph

text: building through a transparent escalator that is attached to the external structural
label: Paragraph

text: framework, which opens to a multilevel, open spatial layout. The floor plan is flexible
label: Paragraph

text: and non-load bearing.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1982 Piano produced the space of the Palazzo a Vela in Turin, Italy, for the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition of the works of Alexander Calder. He put a stage installation together that
label: Paragraph

text: incorporated the play of light, space, and temperature. Piano was able to create an open
label: Paragraph

text: environment that liberated the boundaries of materiality. The dark and cool space offers a
label: Paragraph

text: dimension where the mobile structures of Calder have a maximal effect on their observer.
label: Paragraph

text: Piano’s work often experiments with the use of materials, which was especially evident
label: Paragraph

text: in the IBM Traveling Pavilion (1986). The 48-meter-long tube was designed to display
label: Paragraph

text: new forms of communication technology. The modular and transparent exhibition space
label: Paragraph

text: is remarkable in its unusual combination of old and new materials and their connecting
label: Paragraph

text: techniques.
label: Paragraph

text: In Turin Piano was engaged with the reorganization of a historical industrial
label: Paragraph

text: monument, the Lingotto (1995). In the 1920s, engineer Matté Trucco designed a 500-
label: Paragraph

text: meter-long and five-story-high industrial complex for the car manufacturer Fiat. At its
label: Paragraph

text: time, the structure followed the requirements of functionalism. Piano transformed this
label: Paragraph

text: highly visible sign of the industrial revolution into a “multifunctional service and
label: Paragraph

text: research center.” He placed a large auditorium space for cultural events into the existing
label: Paragraph

text: structure. An inner courtyard was transformed into a public garden that reflected the
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean character of Turin, and a rooftop, bubble-formed conference room located
label: Paragraph

text: close to a helicopter platform became a new symbol of innovation for the city.
label: Paragraph

text: For the 500-year anniversary of Columbus’s discovery of America, Piano completed in
label: Paragraph

text: 1992 his first large-scale urban project. His hometown, Genoa, commissioned Piano to
label: Paragraph

text: permanently reorganize the old harbor to revitalize the abandoned maritime area. Piano
label: Caption

text: was confronted with the difficult task of linking the industrial harbor with the historic
label: Paragraph

text: town structure by overcoming a division marked by an elevated major arterial road. Piano
label: Caption

text: demolished no buildings but, rather, carefully implemented new functions in restored
label: Paragraph

text: historical buildings or added new ones. His gentle revitalization concept helped to
label: Paragraph

text: develop the old harbor into a vital cultural and recreational center of Genoa.
label: Paragraph

text: Piano and Rice built the San Nicola sports stadium (1990) in Bari, Italy, for the soccer
label: Paragraph

text: world championship. The project requirements demanded that 60,000 people could enjoy
label: Paragraph

text: the game and that standards for security not be ignored. They focused on optimal
label: Paragraph

text: visibility, modular separation of fan masses, and an unusually high number of exit
label: Paragraph

text: systems. Staircases between the seating sections also enhanced the vertical and horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: cross ventilation. Piano and Rice created an elliptical floral-like stadium, expressing the
label: Paragraph

text: plasticity of reinforced concrete in the manner of Pier Luigi Nervi.
label: Paragraph

text: The 220 low-income apartments (1991) in the Rue de Meaux in Paris were Piano’s
label: Paragraph

text: first housing complexes in which he proved that architectural and spatial quality do not
label: Paragraph

text: always depend on large budgets. The facade demonstrates Piano’s passion to reinvent the
label: Paragraph

text: application of traditional and new materials. Glass, terra-cotta, and fiber-reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete exude Piano’s interpretation of Le Corbusian rationality.
label: Paragraph

text: Piano’s final project with Rice was the design and construction of the Kansai
label: Paragraph

text: International Airport (1994) in Osaka, Japan; a steel building of simple geometry in
label: Paragraph

text: which most internal structural elements were left visible. A physical site literally did not
label: Paragraph

text: exist, as the proposed location of the airport was in the oceanic bay of Osaka. An
label: Paragraph

text: artificial island on stilts first had to be built under extreme engineering demands. Piano
label: Paragraph

text: envisioned a 1.7-kilometer-long building whose form derived from precise mathematical
label: Paragraph

text: calculations following the laws of aerodynamics.
label: Paragraph

text: Piano unifies science and architecture in his work. Punta Nave, the Renzo Piano
label: Paragraph

text: Building Workshop in Genoa-Vesima (1991), also serves as a UNESCO laboratory for
label: Paragraph

text: climate and the use of natural light in architecture. The transparent building is located on
label: Paragraph

text: a significant slope, accessible only by cable car. The workshop building is organized in
label: Paragraph

text: sections that step topographically down hills, providing most workspaces with a view to
label: Paragraph

text: the Mediterranean Sea. The glass roof is partially covered with solar-controlled louvers
label: Caption

text: that interact automatically with changing daylight conditions. With this rather small
label: Paragraph

text: project, Piano was able to create a productive team space in which architects and
label: Paragraph

text: scientists are able to explore architectural solutions in tune with their environment.
label: Paragraph

text: Among others, this building exemplifies Piano’s methods and ideas pertaining to
label: Paragraph

text: sustainable architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In Switzerland, Piano realized the Fondation Beyler Museum (1997) in Riehen/Basel.
label: Paragraph

text: Similar to the Menil Collection, his most important building material was the natural light
label: Paragraph

text: that he physically enclosed with sandstone, steel, and glass. The strict and rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: building is covered by a glass roof and opens on three sides to a park. Like few other
label: Paragraph

text: architects, Piano understands how to dissolve the barriers between inside and outside.
label: Paragraph

text: One is reminded of Mies van der Rohe’s Barcelona Pavilion in the way that Piano
label: Paragraph

text: connects exhibition space on the inside and water ponds on the outside. The museum is
label: Paragraph

text: extended into a space continuum that finds a symbiosis between art and architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: At the very end of the 20th century, Piano’s most significant project was the new
label: Paragraph

text: multifunctional development of the Potsdamer Platz (1999) in Berlin. The Potsdamer
label: Paragraph

text: Platz was one of Europe’s most important centers of cultural life in the 1920s. For Piano
label: Paragraph

text: it meant that he had to redevelop what years ago was either destroyed by World War II or
label: Paragraph

text: erased by postwar city planners. Under the leadership of Piano, internationally renowned
label: Paragraph

text: architects, such as Arata Isozaki, Hans Kohlhoff, Lauber and Wohr, Rafael Moneo, and
label: Paragraph

text: Richard Rogers, have transferred the Postdamer Platz from a deserted empty historical
label: Paragraph

text: space back into a lively part of downtown Berlin. New architectural developments range
label: Paragraph

text: from shopping centers, theater, cinemas, restaurants, offices, and corporate headquarters
label: Paragraph

text: to apartment houses. Surrounded by the water of the nearby Spree River, Piano designed
label: Caption

text: eight of the 19 buildings of the Postdamer Platz. His buildings have the double-layered
label: Paragraph

text: terra-cotta facade to formally unify the large area as a whole. As the core project, he
label: Paragraph

text: created a new piazza between Potsdamer Strasse and Kulturforum as a metaphoric
label: Paragraph

text: intersection between the former East and West German cultures.
label: Paragraph

text: Piano’s projects are difficult to place in a particular category, but he is certainly one of
label: Paragraph

text: the most exceptional architects of the 20th century. He constantly tries to liberate his
label: Paragraph

text: design intentions from formal constricting preoccupations as he unifies art and technique.
label: Paragraph

text: For Piano, the design process is not a linear progression to the final product. Piano’s
label: Paragraph

text: architecture develops out of a circular process in which presolutions are constantly
label: Paragraph

text: reevaluated. For that reason, the team workshops develop a countless number of models
label: Paragraph

text: on an extraordinary high level of craftsmanship. His architecture often applies the latest
label: Paragraph

text: technology but is never dominated by it. As a result, most of his buildings appear rich in
label: Paragraph

text: details but often seem so light as to lift up in the wind. Stability is achieved by their
label: Paragraph

text: flexibility—an intelligent relationship to dominant cultural, historical, and environmental
label: Paragraph

text: facts.
label: Paragraph

text: PIETILA, REIMA (1923-93) AND RAILI
label: Title

text: Architects, Finland
label: Title

text: In the 1960s, Reima and Raili Pietilaé became the leading architects of Finland by
label: Paragraph

text: proposing an organic architecture as opposed to the uniform, prefabricated architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: that time, an approach that related their work to that of Alvar Aalto. The roots of Pietilis’
label: Paragraph

text: architecture lie partly in the tradition of European Expressionism of the 1920s; partly in
label: Paragraph

text: the theoretical influence of Aulis Blomstedt, the founder of the study group Le Carré
label: Paragraph

text: Bleu; and partly in the awareness of the genius loci. They created a theory of imitating
label: Paragraph

text: nature with architecture, and their design approach can be described as being natural and
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual at the same time.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Reima and Raili Pietila adressed issues such as language, literature,
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy, and art on the theoretical level, the formal approach of their architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: often directly related to the landscape and to the natural conditions of the building site.
label: Paragraph

text: Lasting until 1969, their most creative period began in 1958, when Reima won the
label: Paragraph

text: competition for the Finnish Pavilion at the Brussel’s World’s Fair.
label: Caption

text: After graduating in architecture from the Helsinki Institute of Technology, Reima
label: Paragraph

text: Pietila was first employed by the Master Planning Department of Helsinki City. In 1957
label: Paragraph

text: he set up his own private practice, having won the 1956 competition for the Finnish
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion, a monument to the Finnish sawmill industry. The wooden modular
label: Paragraph

text: structuralism of the exhibition building was based on a symbiosis of local features and a
label: Paragraph

text: strictly abstract composition, much in the spirit of the Le Carré Bleu group aesthetics. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1960 he was joined in his practice by his wife, Raili, who had also graduated from the
label: Paragraph

text: Helsinki Institute of Technology the year before and who had worked for a while at
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s office. The Kaleva church in Tampere, sited on an open hill, was their first
label: Paragraph

text: project together. The competition was won in 1959 and the building completed in 1966.
label: Paragraph

text: The floor plan is composed of U-shaped concrete curves that mark the outline of a
label: Paragraph

text: Christian fish symbol. The section is very simple, with a flat roof: the plan was extruded
label: Paragraph

text: to derive the interior space, a high volume with long, vertical window slits. The
label: Paragraph

text: sculptural monumentality of the interior with its mystical light choreography was
label: Paragraph

text: intended to recall organ music and was much indebted to the sculptural space concept of
label: Paragraph

text: Umberto Boccioni.
label: Paragraph

text: The Pietilds’ Dipoli student and conference center (1966) at Otaniemi is reminiscent of
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s habit of opposing a geometric form with an organic shape. The site where Dipoli
label: Paragraph

text: was built was given character by its large, exposed, granite shield originating from the
label: Paragraph

text: glacial era. The roofline is a simulation of the microgeography of the site while also
label: Paragraph

text: being a reptilian metaphoric image. The idea was to work against any tradition and
label: Paragraph

text: preconceived styles but to let the building become part of the forest. More than any other
label: Paragraph

text: project of the Pietilas, it is not architecture in the traditional sense but, rather, part of the
label: Paragraph

text: environment.
label: Paragraph

text: The modular strategy appears again in the Suvikumpu Housing Project (1969), a mixed
label: Paragraph

text: development of 162 apartment units sited on a steep, wooded hillside in Espoo that was
label: Paragraph

text: planned in 1962 with some additions made in 1983. To avoid the monotony of massing,
label: Paragraph

text: the apartments are connected along a line, following the form of the central hill. The
label: Paragraph

text: andscape is reflected in the varying vertical and horizontal masses of the building. The
label: Paragraph

text: facades are composed of white plaster and dark wooden surfaces that invoke the region’s
label: Paragraph

text: bright sunlight and respond to the changing patterns of light and textures of the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding woods.
label: Paragraph

text: After this project was realized, the Pietilas did not receive any important commissions
label: Paragraph

text: in Finland, except for two minor projects, until 1975. This period certainly had a negative
label: Paragraph

text: effect, as their later work did not achieve the strength of the earlier projects. Reima
label: Paragraph

text: Pietila was nominated a professor of arts, and from 1973 to 1979 he taught at the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Oulu, initiating the Oulu School—an architectural trend rich in form—and
label: Paragraph

text: applying regional and international features. In 1973 the Pietilas received the commission
label: Paragraph

text: for building the offices of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (1982) at the Sief Palace in
label: Caption

text: Kuwait, and in 1975 they won the competition for the Hervanta Congregational, Leisure,
label: Paragraph

text: and Shopping Center (1979) in a suburb of Tampere. In 1978 they won the competition
label: Paragraph

text: for the Tampere Main Library (“Metso”), which was finished in 1986. In these projects,
label: Paragraph

text: the Pietilas moved toward an early kind of Postmodernism. In the Sief Palace, they
label: Paragraph

text: combined environmental elements, such as sun baffles, with local cultural traditions and
label: Paragraph

text: metaphorical statements, such as fountains in the shape of coral flowers of the reef below
label: Paragraph

text: the building. For the Hervanta shopping center, the formal influence of railway stations
label: Paragraph

text: and the turn-of-thecentury mall in Tampere was most important. However, the architects
label: Paragraph

text: make references to the ruins of the Forum Romanum, and the adjacent congregational
label: Paragraph

text: center of Hervanta suggests a forest fable. The Tampere Main library grew out of two
label: Paragraph

text: images: a male wood grouse and a mollusk shell. This representational approach seems to
label: Paragraph

text: follow the tradition of organic-shaped library buildings that Aalto had established.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, the curved roof of the Metso recalls typical Aalto designs.
label: Paragraph

text: In their late works, the Pietilas returned to the design concepts of Dipoli: to create a
label: Paragraph

text: “naturalized” building. There is no longer any ambition to imitate natural forms but,
label: Paragraph

text: rather, one to set up a dialogue with nature. In the Finnish Embassy (1985) in New Delhi,
label: Paragraph

text: the roof patterns viewed from above simulate the geomorphology of Finland, with its
label: Paragraph

text: parallel furrows and hills, strip lakes, and islands. From the side, the eaves are shaped
label: Paragraph

text: like snow sculptured by the wind. The chimneys on the roof of Mantyniemi (1987), the
label: Paragraph

text: residence of the Finnish president in Helsinki, resemble a burnt forest, as a simulation of
label: Paragraph

text: a possible or fictional Stone Age scenery, and the elevations take their cue from the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape as well.
label: Paragraph

text: PILGRIMAGE CHURCH AT NEVIGES
label: Title

text: Designed by Gottfried Bohm; completed 1968 Neviges, Germany
label: Caption

text: After World War I, the Catholic Church began to change its position concerning
label: Paragraph

text: restraints between worship and the physical architecture of the church. By the end of
label: Paragraph

text: World War LI, the evenly proportioned synagogue-style or basilica plan of the past, where
label: Paragraph

text: the programmatic and visual thrust of the church centered on the sanctuary, was being
label: Paragraph

text: replaced by spaces conceived from individual congregational requirements. The
label: Paragraph

text: technological development of steel girders and concrete combined with relaxed church
label: Paragraph

text: regulations moved church building away from traditional ecclesiastical architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Mary, Queen of Peace, the Pilgrimage Church (1968) at Neviges, Germany, that is
label: Paragraph

text: today a quarter of the city of Velbert, is the oldest pilgrimage church north of the Alps
label: Paragraph

text: associated with the “Immaculata.” Built by Gottfried Béhm, it was a response to the
label: Paragraph

text: increased number of pilgrims of the 1950s.
label: Paragraph

text: The object of the pilgrimages is a 17th-century etching of the Virgin owned by the
label: Paragraph

text: monks at Dorsten, Germany. Mary is reported to have spoken through the picture directly
label: Paragraph

text: to one of the Franciscan clerics, instructing him in the art of healing. In 1680 the
label: Paragraph

text: engraving was moved for protection to the fortified, baroque church of Neviges. This
label: Paragraph

text: building housed the artwork until 1968, when it was moved to Béhm’s new pilgrimage
label: Paragraph

text: church.
label: Paragraph

text: Bohm, a third-generation architect and the son of the respected builder of Roman
label: Paragraph

text: Catholic churches, Dominikus Béhm, had designed a variety of buildings ranging from
label: Paragraph

text: museums to public housing when he was commissioned. Before the Neviges project,
label: Paragraph

text: Bohm had built an important church in Kassel, Germany, an assignment that introduced
label: Paragraph

text: many of the problems and solutions that he successfully integrated later at the Pilgrimage
label: Paragraph

text: Church.
label: Paragraph

text: Interior, Pilgrimage Church at Neviges, Germany (1968)
label: Caption

text: © Inge and Arvid von der Ropp
label: Title

text: An estimated 10,000 pilgrims make the annual visit to view the miraculous engraving of
label: Paragraph

text: Mary and the expressionistic church that houses it. They arrive by train, bus, or
label: Paragraph

text: automobile. All modes of transportation set the pilgrim on his or her journey at the
label: Paragraph

text: Elberfelder road. From here, the pinnacles of Bohm’s Pilgrimage Church can be glimpsed
label: Paragraph

text: from time to time as the traveler makes his way through the historic village of Neviges.
label: Paragraph

text: Bohm intended that the tantalizing glimpses of the church should be gained as the pilgrim
label: Paragraph

text: processes through the halftimbered, slate-roofed town. Eventually, the old baroque
label: Paragraph

text: church is reached, as is the monastery. Then time and architecture take a great leap
label: Paragraph

text: forward as the initial stages of the goal are reached. B6hm presents a gentle-stepped
label: Paragraph

text: polychromed stairway organically hugging the natural contours of the site. Workstations
label: Caption

text: as well as modular units of the pilgrim’s house containing welfare services and sleeping
label: Paragraph

text: cells are on the left; temporary tent-like coverings can be stretched over the slight steps to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate outdoor activities. Then, as one passes beyond the last pod of the pilgrim’s
label: Paragraph

text: house, the church thrusts upward like a prism reflecting the steep pitched roofs of
label: Paragraph

text: Neviges and the evergreen clad mountains in the background.
label: Paragraph

text: The Pilgrimage Church roof is constructed of a concrete skin 25 centimeters thick.
label: Paragraph

text: Therefore, the interior is a negative of the exterior; the form of the building is plastic and
label: Paragraph

text: boundless. The church is impossible to accurately measure, although approximate
label: Paragraph

text: dimensions are listed as 37 meters wide by 50 meters in
label: Paragraph

text: Exterior, Pilgrimage Church at Neviges (1968)
label: Caption

text: © Inge and Arvid von der Ropp
label: Title

text: length. The exterior walls measure between ten and 20 meters, with the apex of the
label: Paragraph

text: uppermost creased plane computed at 34 meters. No right angles exist, and the form is
label: Paragraph

text: totally asymmetrical. The floor is a multicolored design extrapolation of the outside steps
label: Paragraph

text: and sweeps the visitor into the structure, past loggias that are reminiscent of the cellular
label: Paragraph

text: administration pods directly outside. Quite simply, Bohm brings the pilgrim to the
label: Paragraph

text: village, the village to the administration buildings, and the administration buildings to the
label: Paragraph

text: Pilgrimage Church. Only in the sanctuary is the processional stopped.
label: Paragraph

text: The altar, unlike the synagogue-style church, is not fixed; it is movable, dependent
label: Paragraph

text: only on the function of the changing activity of the church. The chairs are likewise not
label: Paragraph

text: secured to one specific place. Like the village macrocosm Béhm’s structure imitates, the
label: Paragraph

text: pilgrim is at liberty to move about, to explore the ecclesiastical environment and reflect
label: Paragraph

text: on the architecture, the world, and the spirit.
label: Paragraph

text: Massive, vertical stained glass windows touch the muted concrete interior with pink
label: Paragraph

text: and burgundy light. The glass is designed with the traditional symbols associated with
label: Paragraph

text: Mary; however, the execution is anything but conventional. The outsized scale is
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes overwhelming. A single crimson rose burns in a window, the symbol of the
label: Paragraph

text: Virgin’s sacrifice; an emerald interlace evoking Hiberno-Saxon manuscripts uncoils
label: Paragraph

text: along the steps.
label: Paragraph

text: The Pilgrimage Church (Mary, Queen of Peace) is important in that it breaks
label: Paragraph

text: completely with the symmetrical designs of ecclesiastical architecture. It redefines the
label: Paragraph

text: concept of pilgrimage church and brings it into contemporary existence as conference
label: Paragraph

text: center, hostel, and spiritual focus.
label: Paragraph

text: PLAN OF CANBERRA, AUSTRALIA
label: Caption

text: Designed by Walter Burley Griffin; completed 1911
label: Caption

text: The plan of Australia’s capital city of Canberra, as designed in 1911 by the Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: architect Walter Burley Griffin (1876— 1937), is one of the major examples of a 20th-
label: Paragraph

text: century planned capital and the only one whose design was selected in competition. The
label: Paragraph

text: 12 sheets of drawings, as rendered by Marion Mahony Griffin (1871-1961) and her
label: Caption

text: assistants and presently housed in the National Archives of Australia, record one of the
label: Paragraph

text: most significant chapters in the history of modern urban planning.
label: Paragraph

text: The need for an Australian national capital arose when the six separate British colonial
label: Paragraph

text: states on the continent were federated in 1901 to provide a mechanism for dealing with
label: Paragraph

text: one another and with the outside world. From the Australian perspective, this need for a
label: Paragraph

text: new capital city was not great; the competition for its creation was announced only a
label: Paragraph

text: decade later. The decision to locate the new Australian Capital Territory between
label: Paragraph

text: Melbourne in Victoria and Sydney in New South Wales—the capitals of the two most
label: Paragraph

text: populous states and notorious rivals—was more political than practical and produced the
label: Paragraph

text: only major inland Australian city.
label: Paragraph

text: The competition for a capital city with an initial population of 25,000 was announced
label: Paragraph

text: on 30 April 1911 with a closing date of 31 January 1912. By that time (or at least by early
label: Paragraph

text: March, when the actual judging began), the Department of Home Affairs had received
label: Paragraph

text: 137 submissions. Although these included designs from around the world, British and
label: Paragraph

text: Australian architects had boycotted the competition because of the makeup of the
label: Paragraph

text: adjudicating committee as well as the Australian government’s position that the winning
label: Paragraph

text: design would not necessarily be implemented.
label: Paragraph

text: On 23 May 1912, the committee unveiled the winning designs and, in the presence of
label: Paragraph

text: reporters, ceremoniously cut open the envelopes, revealing the identities of the winners.
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Burley Griffin of Chicago was awarded first prize; second prize went to Eliel
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen of Helsinki, Finland; and third prize was given to Alf Agache of Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: The selection of Griffin, a youthful 35 years of age, came as a complete surprise to
label: Paragraph

text: nearly everyone. Raised in Chicago’s western suburbs, Griffin studied architecture at the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Illinois (1895-99); drafted for Dwight Perkins and Robert Spencer, two
label: Paragraph

text: members of the emerging Prairie School; and between 1901 and 1906, worked for Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd Wright as landscape designer, office manager, and site superintendent. Between
label: Paragraph

text: 1906 and 1914, Griffin practiced independently in Chicago before resettling in Australia
label: Paragraph

text: to supervise the construction of Canberra. His experience as federal capital director was
label: Paragraph

text: fraught with difficulties, and he resigned in 1920. Although Canberra was officially
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated in 1927 and has subsequently grown to a population of more than 300,000, it
label: Paragraph

text: bears only a general resemblance to Griffin’s original design.
label: Paragraph

text: Griffin’s career encompassed the three separate disciplines of architecture, landscape
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, and urban planning. Many of his most satisfying projects, like Canberra,
label: Paragraph

text: combine all three. Because nothing remains of his reputed plan for enlarging Shanghai,
label: Paragraph

text: China (ca. 1905-06), his earliest surviving urban scheme appears to be the small town of
label: Paragraph

text: Idalia, Florida, designed around February to March 1911, only a few months before the
label: Paragraph

text: official announcement of the Canberra competition. Griffin later recalled, however, that
label: Paragraph

text: he had known of the impending need for an Australian capital city for many years and
label: Paragraph

text: was eager to contribute to its success. As he explained in 1913 to King O’Malley, head of
label: Paragraph

text: the competition committee, “I...entered this Australian event to be my first and last
label: Paragraph

text: competition, solely because I have for many years greatly admired the bold radical steps
label: Paragraph

text: in politics and economics which your country has dared to take...yours is the greatest
label: Paragraph

text: opportunity the world has afforded for the expression of the great civic ideal.” As James
label: Paragraph

text: Weirick has explained, Canberra “was intended to express in its physical form, the true
label: Paragraph

text: nature of the democratic experience” (Weirick, 1998).
label: Paragraph

text: The site was composed of a rolling valley surrounded by hills and bisected by the wide
label: Paragraph

text: streambed of the intermittent Molonglo River. Griffin created a design whose basic
label: Paragraph

text: format was determined by this landscape. The axis defined by the crown of the nearest
label: Paragraph

text: high hill, Mount Ainslie north of the river (and just outside the city limits), to the most
label: Paragraph

text: prominent point in town, Kurrajong to the south, became the generating line of the entire
label: Paragraph

text: plan. Griffin termed this the Land Axis. At the point where this line crossed the
label: Paragraph

text: Molonglo, Griffin defined a perpendicular Water Axis, to be given expression by
label: Paragraph

text: damming the river to create a series of lakes, the central three of which would be formal
label: Paragraph

text: and geometric and the outer two left irregular and “natural.”
label: Paragraph

text: Griffin ordered the landscape by separating areas according to use: civic, cultural,
label: Paragraph

text: political, economic, and residential. He divided the city into hexagonal, octagonal, and
label: Paragraph

text: circular subcenters, connected by major boulevards that radiated from the subcenters. The
label: Paragraph

text: scheme was subtly configured to the changing topography while remaining part of a
label: Paragraph

text: clearly defined geometric diagram originating from Kurrajong.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the competition guidelines had called only for the general placement of some
label: Paragraph

text: 38 public buildings, most entries included perspective renderings that attempted to give a
label: Paragraph

text: corresponding architectural image to the proposed city. Although Mahony’s perspectives
label: Paragraph

text: at first glance suggest that this was also the case with Griffin’s entry, in fact Griffin went
label: Paragraph

text: beyond this, making complete designs for the group. By combining the footprints on the
label: Paragraph

text: plans with the elevations and section that appear on the various axial drawings, it is
label: Paragraph

text: possible to re-create the individual buildings. Griffin added another structure not listed in
label: Caption

text: the competition precis: atop Kurrajong Hill, he placed a design labeled as the Capitol
label: Paragraph

text: building, a stepped ziggurat that was to serve as a kind of national focal point, what
label: Paragraph

text: Griffin called “the figurative embodiment of the spirit of the Commonwealth” (Griffin,
label: Paragraph

text: 1923, quoted in Weirick, 1989).
label: Paragraph

text: Griffin intended his plan to provide a legible cipher of the interrelationships among the
label: Paragraph

text: political, economic, cultural, and spiritual forces at work in a progressive, democratic
label: Paragraph

text: nation. The very placement of the public buildings in the great triangle descending from
label: Paragraph

text: the Capitol to the central lake revealed the relative positions of the branches of
label: Paragraph

text: government.
label: Paragraph

text: The sources for Canberra are wide and varied. Griffin drew on such city plans as
label: Paragraph

text: Christopher Wren’s 1666 scheme for rebuilding London; Pierre L’Enfant’s plan for
label: Paragraph

text: Washington, DC (1790), and its reintroduction as the Senate Park Commission’s plan of
label: Paragraph

text: 1901; the City Beautiful movement, especially Daniel Burnham and Edward Bennett’s
label: Paragraph

text: Plan of Chicago (1906-09); and the English Garden City movement. There is no real
label: Paragraph

text: precedent, however, for the hierarchies of building placement, the configurations to
label: Paragraph

text: subtle changes in topography, and the unity of landscape to urban design found in the
label: Paragraph

text: plan of Canberra.

text: PLAN OF CHICAGO
label: Title

text: The Plan of Chicago, developed mainly by architect Daniel H. Burnham (1846-1912)
label: Paragraph

text: and his assistant Edward H. Bennett (1874-1954), was the first master plan for an
label: Paragraph

text: American city and its region in the 20th century. Burnham developed ideas for the plan
label: Paragraph

text: from 1894 on, though his consistent work on the project for Chicago’s Commercial Club
label: Paragraph

text: began in late 1906. The plan was published as a book in 1909 with renderings by Jules
label: Paragraph

text: Gueérin (1866-1946), when its drawings were exhibited at The Art Institute of Chicago.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the city’s form was discussed for decades after the Great Chicago Fire of 1871,
label: Paragraph

text: the plan was largely motivated by success of the World’s Columbian Exposition of 1893
label: Paragraph

text: in Chicago, for which Burnham had served as chief of construction and that had posited a
label: Paragraph

text: neoclassical model for urban design that integrated public buildings and parks. The Plan
label: Paragraph

text: of Chicago also owed much to Burnham’s work as head of the MacMillan Commission,
label: Paragraph

text: charged by the U.S. Congress with the planning of central Washington, DC, in 1901-02,
label: Paragraph

text: and to his plans for Cleveland (1903), San Francisco (1905), and Manila (1905). The Plan
label: Paragraph

text: of Chicago was also based on Burnham’s systematic consultation with local experts and
label: Paragraph

text: citizens, a process that helped to ensure its acceptance and partial implementation.
label: Paragraph

text: Burnham’s earlier urban plans featured a central focal group of neoclassical public
label: Paragraph

text: buildings linked to each other and to the surrounding city with broad, tree-lined avenues.
label: Paragraph

text: This idea was central to the Plan of Chicago, which featured large new railroad passenger
label: Paragraph

text: terminals and a cultural and civic center on the city’s near West Side, dominated by a tall,
label: Paragraph

text: domed city hall. Architecturally, the plan included recommendations for common cornice
label: Paragraph

text: heights for buildings and generous street widths, aiming to create a visually unified
label: Paragraph

text: cityscape on the model of Second Empire Paris. Burnham requested plans of pre- and
label: Paragraph

text: post-Haussmann Paris, along with information on over 20 American and 30 European
label: Paragraph

text: cities. As Burnham wrote: “the city has a dignity to be maintained; and good order is
label: Paragraph

text: essential to material advancement. Consequently, the plan provides for impressive
label: Paragraph

text: groupings of public buildings and reciprocal relations among such groups.” Burnham saw
label: Paragraph

text: his city some 70 years after its founding in 1833 as
label: Paragraph

text: Plan of Chicago
label: Title

text: © Dennis Gale
label: Title

text: having reached a stage of development that called for permanent monumentality in civic
label: Paragraph

text: buildings and landscapes.
label: Paragraph

text: The Plan of Chicago was to both enable and present an image of ordered economic
label: Paragraph

text: growth. In this it went further than many essays in the City Beautiful Movement by
label: Paragraph

text: proposing to consolidate Chicago’s extensive and varied rail traffic network, including
label: Paragraph

text: tracks of common width, and a shared system for handling freight. Presented in the same
label: Paragraph

text: year that the Model T Ford was introduced, the Plan of Chicago featured a regional
label: Paragraph

text: highway system for automobiles, including both radial arteries and circumferential ring
label: Paragraph

text: roads within a 60-mile radius of the city’s center to connect it with its suburbs and to link
label: Paragraph

text: suburbs to each other. The future city was to be an efficient transportation network for the
label: Paragraph

text: facilitation of commerce, with extensions of an ordered plan out into the surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: region. As Burnham wrote: “The plan frankly takes into consideration that fact that the
label: Paragraph

text: American city, and Chicago pre-eminently, is a center of industry and traffic. Therefore
label: Paragraph

text: attention is given to the betterment of commercial facilities; to methods of transportation
label: Paragraph

text: for persons and for goods; to removing the obstacles which prevent or obstruct
label: Paragraph

text: circulation; and to the increase of convenience.” Toward this end, the plan proposed
label: Paragraph

text: routing different types of motor traffic on double-decker streets connected by ramps, with
label: Paragraph

text: pleasure vehicles above freight trucks. Water transport was to be improved by
label: Paragraph

text: straightening the Chicago River and by building windbreaks stretching a mile into Lake
label: Paragraph

text: Michigan to protect new harbor facilities.
label: Paragraph

text: The plan included an inland park system that vastly extended Chicago’s earlier parks
label: Paragraph

text: with connecting carriage boulevards designed by Horace Cleveland and Frederick Law
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted. Perhaps most important for the city’s future development, the plan proposed a
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive treatment of 23 miles of lakefront parks for public recreation, including
label: Paragraph

text: lagoons for rowing, and numerous playgrounds, especially for the city’s poorer classes
label: Paragraph

text: who had little access to green space inland. As Burnham wrote, “When a citizen is made
label: Paragraph

text: to feel the beauty of nature, when he is lifted up by her to any degree above the usual life
label: Paragraph

text: of his thoughts and feelings, the state of which he is a part is benefited thereby.” The
label: Paragraph

text: plan’s aim was to promote good citizenship at a time when 1.3 of Chicago’s 1.7 million
label: Paragraph

text: residents were foreign born and when the deplorable working and living conditions of the
label: Paragraph

text: city’s poor were as described in Upton Sinclair’s The Jungle (1906). The plan aimed to
label: Paragraph

text: create an ideal built environment that would educate citizens’ tastes and shape social
label: Paragraph

text: norms according to bourgeois models and in the service of capitalist interests. Burnham
label: Paragraph

text: wrote: “It is realized, also, that good workmanship requires a large degree of comfort on
label: Paragraph

text: the part of the workers in their homes and their surroundings, and ample opportunity for
label: Paragraph

text: that rest and recreation without which all work becomes drudgery.” Although aimed at
label: Paragraph

text: improving the quality of life for all, the plan included no provisions for publicly funded
label: Paragraph

text: housing.
label: Paragraph

text: The Plan of Chicago directly influenced the subsequent development of the city from
label: Paragraph

text: the mayor’s appointment of an official planning commission in late 1909 through the
label: Paragraph

text: financial crash of 1929. Major improvements of these 20 years based on the plan
label: Paragraph

text: included the widening and enhancement of Michigan Avenue north of the Chicago River,
label: Paragraph

text: the landfills and development of Grant Park on the central lakefront and lakefront parks
label: Title

text: to the north and south, and the construction of Wacker Drive along the Chicago River.
label: Paragraph

text: The Plan of Chicago had rapid influence beyond the city, first in inspiring the German
label: Paragraph

text: Kaiser to appoint a commission in 1912 to replan the capital of Berlin. The Plan of
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago was also a point of reference for developing the Regional Plan of New York
label: Paragraph

text: City and its environs of 1929.
label: Paragraph

text: PLAN OF NEW DELHI
label: Title

text: At an imperial durbar in 1911 hosted outside the walled city of Shahjahanabad (later
label: Paragraph

text: called Old Delhi), King George V announced plans to transfer the seat of the government
label: Paragraph

text: of India from Calcutta to a new imperial capital to be built in the vicinity of that very
label: Paragraph

text: spot. It was to become the “New” Delhi. The aim was to present the British Raj as the
label: Paragraph

text: legitimate successor of the Mughal Empire precisely at a time when British rule was
label: Paragraph

text: being challenged by Indian nationalists. Near Shahjahan’s old capital, amid the ruins of a
label: Paragraph

text: score of erstwhile capital cities and far from the tumultuous nationalist politics of
label: Paragraph

text: Calcutta, a new imperial British capital was hoped to capture the fiction of peaceful and
label: Paragraph

text: benevolent domination of an alien people. The historic importance of the site of Delhi
label: Paragraph

text: was to be revived after a century of neglect to serve as a necessary counterpoint to the
label: Paragraph

text: demonstration of British power.
label: Paragraph

text: By early 1912, a Delhi Town Planning Committee was organized, comprising Edwin
label: Paragraph

text: L.Lutyens, an architect then known mostly for his design of country houses; John
label: Paragraph

text: A.Brodie, city engineer of Liverpool; and George S.C.Swinton, chairman-elect of the
label: Paragraph

text: London County Council. Henry V.Lanchester, who had a well-established architectural
label: Caption

text: practice in London, was appointed as an external consultant. Among them, only Swinton
label: Paragraph

text: had any previous firsthand knowledge of India. The committee’s responsibility was to
label: Paragraph

text: suggest a suitable site for the new capital and to formulate a general plan for the city.
label: Paragraph

text: From the very beginning, two assumptions were made clear. First, the new capital would
label: Paragraph

text: be used only as the government’s winter residence, with the customary annual migration
label: Paragraph

text: to Shimla during the summer months. Second, the centerpiece of this plan would be the
label: Paragraph

text: Government House (later called the Viceroy’s Palace, presently the Rashtrapati Bhavan),
label: Paragraph

text: the residence of the head of the British administration, the viceroy. Designed as the center
label: Paragraph

text: of government and not a commercial city, the imperial capital was to physically represent
label: Paragraph

text: the administrative and power hierarchy of the British Raj, complete with its class and
label: Paragraph

text: racial stratification.
label: Paragraph

text: At the initial stages, two different sites and two types of plans were proposed. One of
label: Paragraph

text: the sites was to the north of Shahjahanabad near the British Civil Lines and Durbar
label: Paragraph

text: Grounds; the other was to the south of the existing city between Raisina Hills and
label: Paragraph

text: Green spaces around the Jami Masjid, New Delhi
label: Caption

text: © Aga Khan Trust for Culture
label: Title

text: the Jamuna River. The Town Planning Committee favored the spacious southern site as
label: Paragraph

text: more suitable for their exaggerated monumental vision of the city and the ease with
label: Paragraph

text: which one could make visual reference to the historic monuments that were located on
label: Paragraph

text: the southern and eastern limits. The principal feature of the committee’s early plan was a
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial avenue with closely packed government buildings terminating at the
label: Paragraph

text: Government House and opening up a vista to the Jami Masjid, the largest Mughal
label: Paragraph

text: mosque in the existing city; the rest of the new capital was conceived on a rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: matrix of roads. The monotony of the plan raised questions, and Lanchester attempted to
label: Paragraph

text: improve on the committee’s scheme by suggesting replacing the rectangular pattern with
label: Paragraph

text: a series of radial streets. At the crossing of the ceremonial avenue and these radial
label: Paragraph

text: arteries, he proposed a plaza around which to arrange the Secretariat buildings. When the
label: Paragraph

text: committee was again asked to reconsider the northern site, their revised plan took some
label: Paragraph

text: hint from Lanchester’s layout. They proposed a more tightly knit ensemble o
label: Paragraph

text: government institutions headed by the monumental place of the Government House and
label: Paragraph

text: deviated from the rectangular pattern by making the peripheral roads adjust to the
label: Paragraph

text: topography.
label: Paragraph

text: When officially “opened” in 1930, the city was planned for a maximum population o
label: Paragraph

text: 65,000, covering an area of 3200 acres. The final plan, which underwent many
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent adjustments, was based on a revised treatment of the southern site that
label: Paragraph

text: retained several ideas from the preceding plans. The Government House, or Viceroy’s
label: Paragraph

text: Palace, was still the focal point. It was perched on Raisina Hills and connected by straight
label: Paragraph

text: avenues to the Purana Qila on the west, to the railway station on the northwest, and to
label: Paragraph

text: Safdarjung’s tomb on the south. The scheme borrowed from the principles of Beaux-Arts
label: Paragraph

text: planning as well as from new notions of the garden city but ultimately conformed to the
label: Paragraph

text: hierarchical planning pattern of British cantonments in India. By the time the final plan
label: Paragraph

text: was reached, Herbert Baker, an architect who had acquired a reputation for his work in
label: Paragraph

text: South Africa, was brought into the team and the specific architectural treatment of the
label: Paragraph

text: monuments were being prepared. Lutyens was awarded the design of the Viceroy’s
label: Paragraph

text: Palace and Herbert Baker the Secretariat and Council House. It was the monumental
label: Paragraph

text: classical architectural vocabulary, which Lutyens had rehearsed long before he was given
label: Paragraph

text: the building commission, that gave specific meaning to the plan that ultimately
label: Paragraph

text: developed. The appliqué of Indian decorative elements on this imperial classicism at a
label: Paragraph

text: later stage only enhanced the symbolic logic of the plan, which was meant to
label: Paragraph

text: unambiguously subordinate the “old” city and the Indian population to the new capital
label: Paragraph

text: and its British denizens.
label: Paragraph

text: A long, processional 440-feet east-west parkway, named King’s Way (presently
label: Paragraph

text: Rajpath) and a cross-avenue named Queen’s Way (presently Janpath) formed the central
label: Paragraph

text: armature of a multinode hexagonal plan. Traveling along King’s Way from the Purana
label: Paragraph

text: Qila, the visitor encountered a series of monuments along the Central Vista—a wide
label: Paragraph

text: expanse of green space accentuated by water channels. Anchored by the monumental
label: Paragraph

text: canopy that once housed the statue of King George V and, on the west, the War
label: Caption

text: Memorial, the parkway led to the “cultural” node, which was meant to house four
label: Paragraph

text: colonial institutions at the four corners of the crossing of King’s Way and Queen’s
label: Caption

text: Way—the Imperial Museum, the Oriental Institute, the Lmperial Library, and the Imperia!
label: Paragraph

text: Record Office (presently the National Archives, the only building constructed before
label: Paragraph

text: Indian independence). Then a dense arrangement of imperial symbols prepared the visitor
label: Paragraph

text: for the principal focus of the plan—the Secretariat Blocks on raised platforms on either
label: Paragraph

text: side framing the centrally located Viceroy’s Palace, which dipped from view as one
label: Paragraph

text: approached the Secretariat Plaza, only to emerge later in its full regalia once one reached
label: Paragraph

text: the top of the plaza. This vanishing vista was the result of a controversial miscalculation
label: Paragraph

text: of the street gradient. The Viceregal Estate, the entry to which was guarded by a series of
label: Paragraph

text: Britannia lions and anchored with the Jaipur column, covered approximately two-thirds
label: Paragraph

text: of a square mile and housed, in addition to the main palace and integral council chamber,
label: Paragraph

text: the symmetrically arrayed staff quarters and the elaborate “Mughal” garden. The rotund
label: Paragraph

text: Council House (included in the plan in 1919, presently the Parliament Building) played a
label: Paragraph

text: subsidiary role in the imperial administration and was located off the main axis to the
label: Paragraph

text: north of the Secretariat Blocks. Radial avenues from the Council House and War
label: Caption

text: Memorial, as well as Queen’s Way, converged on Connaught Place—the principal
label: Paragraph

text: commercial node—before leading to the railway station. Residential space was allocated
label: Paragraph

text: according to a strict sociospatial taxonomy based on site elevation, proximity to the
label: Paragraph

text: Viceroy’s Palace, dwelling and plot size, and most important, segregation along
label: Paragraph

text: occupational and racial lines. The houses of the members of the Executive Council were
label: Paragraph

text: located closest to the seat of power, whereas gazetted officers were allocated space to the
label: Paragraph

text: south of the Central Vista near the lavish and exclusive green recreational space of
label: Paragraph

text: racecourse and parks. Indian princes were encouraged to purchase land to the east,
label: Paragraph

text: whereas European clerks were assigned space to the north. Indian and Anglo-Indian
label: Paragraph

text: clerks and “menial” staff were situated on the periphery of the new city in separate
label: Paragraph

text: enclaves. The separation between the new and the old city was physically completed with
label: Paragraph

text: a surrounding wall (demolished in 1950) and a 100-yard-wide and mile-and-a-half-long
label: Paragraph

text: green space around the old city.
label: Paragraph

text: Obsessed with the demonstration of imperial power, the planners created an
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructure of inequity that would pose both physical and ideological problems when,
label: Paragraph

text: at midcentury, the city became the capital of a new democracy. Defined on the basis of
label: Paragraph

text: unequal access to resources and glaring population differentials between the old city and
label: Paragraph

text: the new, it was neither amenable to public transportation nor anticipatory of a significant
label: Paragraph

text: population increase and its attendant need for schools, shopping, and housing.
label: Paragraph
