text: PLASTICS
label: Title

text: At no time in history has a material developed so rapidly and became interwoven in the
label: Paragraph

text: fabric of our daily lives as have plastics. In fact, today’s styles of living would be
label: Paragraph

text: unimaginable without their existence. Less than 200 years old, these materials have
label: Paragraph

text: become part of almost every facet of our daily lives. Plastics have played a variety of
label: Paragraph

text: roles in the building and construction industry, but especially so in the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the invention of many forms of plastic has origins in the 19th century, their
label: Paragraph

text: practical application for consumer products and other industrial uses came about in the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century. For example, a major milestone was achieved in the evolution of plastics
label: Paragraph

text: when John Wesley Hyatt, an American, invented Celluloid in 1866 by adding camphor (a
label: Paragraph

text: derivative of the laurel tree) to nitrated cellulose. This was the first thermoplastic in the
label: Paragraph

text: sense that it could be molded under heat and pressure to form a shape and that it would
label: Paragraph

text: retain that shape after the heat and pressure were removed. In 1891 Louis Marie Hilaire
label: Paragraph

text: was trying to produce man-made silk in Paris when he modified nitrated cellulose to form
label: Paragraph

text: rayon. In 1907 Leo Baekeland, a New York chemist, discovered the first completely
label: Paragraph

text: synthetic man-made substance, which he called Bakelite. This liquid resin is considered
label: Paragraph

text: the first thermoset plastic ever produced because once it hardened, it would never change.
label: Paragraph

text: Later, in 1913, Dr. Jacques Edwin Brandenberger, a Swiss textile engineer, produced
label: Paragraph

text: viscose (now known also as rayon), which led to his invention of cellophane, the first true
label: Paragraph

text: waterproof wrapping material. After the use of cellophane spread worldwide, DuPont’s
label: Paragraph

text: laboratories, under Wallace H.Carothers, developed Fiber 66, which was later named
label: Paragraph

text: nylon. This fiber replaced animal hair in toothbrushes and silk stockings. In fact, nylon
label: Paragraph

text: stockings enjoyed great public acceptance when unveiled in 1939, and reinforced nylon
label: Paragraph

text: fabrics were being used in air-supported structures. At B.F.Goodrich, Waldo Semon, an
label: Paragraph

text: organic chemist, developed an inexpensive, fire-resistant, and easily formable substance
label: Paragraph

text: named polyvinyl chloride (PVC), or vinyl, which became the base material for thousands
label: Paragraph

text: of household products, from garden hoses to records. Meanwhile, in Germany,
label: Paragraph

text: H.Staudinger discovered the molecular structure of plastics, and Carothers, in turn,
label: Paragraph

text: realized that by adding and replacing elements into the chainlike molecules of plastics,
label: Paragraph

text: one could produce many types of new compounds. This particular discovery gave the
label: Paragraph

text: plastics industry its prolific nature vis-a-vis the many useful polymers introduced since
label: Paragraph

text: then, such as nylon, acrylics, neoprene, SBR (Styrene Butadiene Rubbers), saran,
label: Paragraph

text: polyethylene, Velcro, Teflon, Spandex, Nomex, and Kevlar, all of which replaced, at one
label: Paragraph

text: time or another, materials typically supplied by nature. The most widely utilized polymer,
label: Paragraph

text: however, has been polyethylene, a thermoplastic first discovered in 1933 by Fawcett and
label: Paragraph

text: Gibson. At present, polyethylene is the largest-volume plastic in the world, with such
label: Paragraph

text: uses as milk jugs, soda bottles, grocery and dry-cleaning bags, food storage containers,
label: Paragraph

text: packaging, and in the construction industry as a reliable source of water proofing.
label: Paragraph

text: After World War IL, plastic products were everywhere. Inventors were continuously
label: Paragraph

text: filing patents for new plastics, and the American public’s view of the image of such
label: Paragraph

text: products became increasingly negative. In reality, polymers had two main disadvantages.
label: Paragraph

text: First, they had relatively low stiffness, and as such they were rendered nonviable where
label: Paragraph

text: structural integrity was required. Second, they degraded rapidly when exposed to heat
label: Paragraph

text: and ultraviolet (UV) radiation. Consequendy, plastic products were thought of as cheap,
label: Paragraph

text: nonenduring, fake, and environmentally unfriendly. The U.S. military, however, noted
label: Paragraph

text: the desirable characteristics of polymers. As such, it was military applications in the mid-
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s and 1960s that carried the torch for the plastics industry. In aerospace applications,
label: Paragraph

text: higher rigidity and lighter weight led to a landmark development in the evolution of
label: Paragraph

text: plastics, and fiber-reinforced polymers were born. By combining the relative flexibility of
label: Paragraph

text: some thermosetting plastics, such as epoxies, and the high rigidity of fibrous materials,
label: Paragraph

text: such as graphite, aramid, and boron, new and far superior materials were created and
label: Paragraph

text: dubbed advanced composites. The notion that embedding fibers, short or long, in a
label: Paragraph

text: binding medium to create a new and improved plastic manifested itself in different forms
label: Paragraph

text: and led to the creation of such materials as ceramic/metal composites and braided Kevlar.
label: Paragraph

text: These superior plastics were used in applications ranging from armored personnel suits
label: Paragraph

text: and gear to intercontinental ballistic missiles and the space shuttle.
label: Paragraph

text: Plastics and the Construction Industry
label: Title

text: All the desirable qualities of 1950s plastics did not escape the watchful eyes of the
label: Paragraph

text: construction industry, which has always been on the lookout for more competitive
label: Paragraph

text: building materials to replace existing ones. Plastics appeared as vinyl siding and as foam
label: Paragraph

text: insulation in homes and buildings, making them much more energy efficient and
label: Paragraph

text: comfortable for their occupants. Plastics were also used in underground storage tanks and
label: Paragraph

text: in pipe systems. There were even a few adventurous attempts by individuals and
label: Paragraph

text: companies to construct all-plastic houses intended as showcases only and not for mass
label: Paragraph

text: production. A primary early example was the Monsanto House of the Future (1957-68) at
label: Paragraph

text: Disneyland in Anaheim, California. This structure was envisioned at the Massachusetts
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of Technology and assembled for Disneyland in 1957 using structural fiberglass-
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced polyester elements. Other attempts during the 1950s to build houses out of
label: Paragraph

text: plastics were made, but they never quite presented the construction industry with any
label: Paragraph

text: serious alternatives. The only notable effort to mass-produce affordable plastic housing
label: Paragraph

text: was made by lIonel Schein when he presented his Maison Plastique (Plastic House) in a
label: Paragraph

text: housing exhibition in 1956. The Bucharest-born designer used 15 different plastics and
label: Paragraph

text: three colors—yellow, red, or blue—in all 70 prototypes he produced. In 1974 the higher
label: Paragraph

text: prices of raw materials, resulting from the oil embargo and more competitive concrete
label: Paragraph

text: and steel industries, put an end to Schein’s production of plastic houses.
label: Paragraph

text: In the late 1970s and in response to the stabilization of oil prices as well as emerging
label: Paragraph

text: environmental concerns for conserving natural resources, most manufacturing industries
label: Paragraph

text: made serious and successful attempts at incorporating plastics into their design and
label: Paragraph

text: materials selection processes. Once again, plastics were gaining an excellent reputation
label: Paragraph

text: for superior and cost-effective performance in applications where their beneficial
label: Paragraph

text: characteristics can be best employed. The construction industry was not immune to this
label: Paragraph

text: movement. Plastics were recyclable, and as such they reduced construction waste; their
label: Paragraph

text: use in construction is environmentally responsible, conserves natural resources, and is
label: Paragraph

text: consistent with the concept of sustainability; in addition, their ease of fabrication,
label: Paragraph

text: transportation, and erection resulted in a relatively lower life-cycle cost. As a result, they
label: Paragraph

text: started appearing in many applications, such as glass-reinforced plastic (GRP) moldings
label: Paragraph

text: to replace cast-iron work, as cladding and roofing materials in multistory buildings, as
label: Paragraph

text: corrugated translucent sheeting (e.g. indoor swimming pools), as replacement of metals
label: Paragraph

text: for electrical insulation purposes (e.g. ladders, man lifts, light and telephone poles,
label: Paragraph

text: special hospital structures, CB radio antennas, radar and military facilities, airport control
label: Title

text: towers, transmission and electrical power towers, and power plant structures), as
label: Paragraph

text: structural and nonstructural elements in water/wastewater treatment and desalination
label: Paragraph

text: plants, as agricultural and irrigation equipment and structures (e.g. manure filters, weirs,
label: Paragraph

text: barn structures, and watergate guides), as cooling towers (e.g. housing units), as
label: Paragraph

text: industrial chimneys, and as waterfront and offshore structures (e.g. oil rigs and marine
label: Paragraph

text: risers).
label: Paragraph

text: Architecturally, plastics presented the designer with the advantage of controlling the
label: Paragraph

text: texture, color, and the shape of any designed element. This inherent quality of
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturing plastics allowed for greater design flexibility in such issues as shading,
label: Paragraph

text: form flow, and patterns repetition, all the while maintaining lower costs and faster
label: Paragraph

text: erection time than other conventional materials. Examples of such cases include but are
label: Paragraph

text: not limited to cladding panels for the Olivetti Training Centre (1972) in Haslemere,
label: Paragraph

text: Surrey, England; 50-meter-diameter roofing domes at the Sharjah International Airport
label: Caption

text: (1977) in the United Arab Emirates; and the access ramps to Terminal 2 (1978) at
label: Paragraph

text: Heathrow Airport in London. A more widespread use of FRPs (Fiber-Reinforeed
label: Paragraph

text: Plastics) in construction was hindered for three main reasons. First, there was still a
label: Paragraph

text: prevalent lack of knowledge in the general design philosophy, behavior, and limitations
label: Paragraph

text: of such materials, including their relative low stiffness and heat- and UV-light-resistive
label: Paragraph

text: capabilities. Second, there existed other competitive, long-established, and more familiar
label: Paragraph

text: construction methods and materials. Third, building and design codes dealing with the
label: Paragraph

text: design specifications and testing methods of plastics did not exist at the time. All these
label: Paragraph

text: reasons made it difficult for designers and builders to shift into unknown and untested
label: Paragraph

text: building materials. As such, during the 1970s and early 1980s, the usage of FRPs
label: Paragraph

text: remained limited to specific applications in which they were the only choice for the
label: Paragraph

text: conditions under which a specific structure existed.
label: Paragraph

text: Since the mid-1980s, the world has witnessed an unprecedented reliance on and use of
label: Paragraph

text: plastics in construction. The integration of plastics into the building industry proliferated
label: Paragraph

text: so rap-idly that in 1998 more than 20 percent of all plastic resin sales in North America
label: Paragraph

text: were used for fixed construction. In fact, about two-thirds of all thermosetting polymers
label: Paragraph

text: (mainly polyesters and vinylesters) produced today are consumed by the building and
label: Paragraph

text: construction industry. There were six main reasons for that remarkable growth:
label: Paragraph

text: environmental concerns increased regarding the sustainability, conservation, and
label: Paragraph

text: recycling of used materials; the prices of raw materials for producing plastics had
label: Paragraph

text: dropped significantly while costs of lumber soared; with much improved fire retardancy
label: Paragraph

text: and heat and UV resistance, FRPs had proven by then, through research and actual field-
label: Paragraph

text: performance track records, that they were solid substitutes for typical construction
label: Paragraph

text: materials; there were significant advances in the technology of producing polymers, in
label: Paragraph

text: improving their qualities, and in manufacturing their fiber-reinforced components; the
label: Paragraph

text: end of the Cold War allowed for a tremendous amount of information and expertise about
label: Paragraph

text: high-performance plastics (i.e. advanced composites} to migrate from the military and
label: Paragraph

text: aerospace industry into the construction world; and finally, a worldwide deterioration of
label: Paragraph

text: some infrastructures (i.e. bridges and highways) demanded the immediate attention of
label: Paragraph

text: governments worldwide and forced them to look for alternative construction materials.
label: Paragraph

text: As a testament to the energy-absorption capabilities and strength of fiberreinforced
label: Paragraph

text: plastics, the California Department of Transportation approved, after the 1994 Northridge
label: Paragraph

text: earthquake, the use of plastics for seismic retrofitting of reinforced-concrete highway
label: Paragraph

text: decking and column systems. In addition, the versatility of improved polymers allowed
label: Paragraph

text: inventors to come up with such structural elements as glue-laminated timber members
label: Paragraph

text: (glu-lams) and fiber-reinforced glu-lams. These elements allow for larger loadcarrying
label: Paragraph

text: and spanning capabilities, less natural wood to be used, and lower cost when compared
label: Paragraph

text: with lumber members. In addition, polymers were being used to produce plastic lumber
label: Paragraph

text: and polymer concretes, which, when reinforced with glass fibers, produced members with
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional strength and rigidity and of lighter weight and smaller dimensions.
label: Paragraph

text: As confidence and knowledge about plastics in the world of construction increased,
label: Paragraph

text: designers and contractors found themselves routinely adding them to their repertoire of
label: Paragraph

text: available options for building materials. Plastics have been successfully used in such
label: Paragraph

text: projects as the FRP Turret Sun Bank Building (1988) in Orlando, Florida; the Nations
label: Paragraph

text: Bank Tower (1989) in Atlanta, Georgia; and as window/door lintels (1993) at
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania State University in University Park, Pennsylvania. Realizing the potential
label: Caption

text: of plastics in construction, government agencies supported collaborative academic and
label: Paragraph

text: industrial research efforts to further the understanding of the nature and characteristics of
label: Paragraph

text: fiber-reinforced plastics. A landmark result of such efforts was the plastic industrial
label: Paragraph

text: building constructed at Weston, West Virginia, in November 1995. This 12.31-meter-
label: Paragraph

text: long, 6.45-meterwide, 4.31-meter-high structure was the result of a joint research-and-
label: Paragraph

text: development effort between the U.S. National Science Foundation, the West Virginia
label: Paragraph

text: Department of Transportation, and the Constructed Facilities Center at West Virginia
label: Title

text: University headed by Professor Hota GangaRao. Perhaps the most salient structural
label: Paragraph

text: building achievement for plastics to date is the Eyecatcher (1999). This is the first five-
label: Paragraph

text: story residential/ office building constructed completely out of fiber-reinforced plastic
label: Caption

text: (glass and polyester) pultruded structural profiles. Fiberline Composites of Denmark
label: Caption

text: unveiled the Eyecatcher Project during the Swissbau ’°99 Fair in Basel, Switzerland. After
label: Paragraph

text: the exhibition, the ten-meter-wide, twelve-meter-long, fifteen-meter-high building was
label: Paragraph

text: disassembled and brought to its new and permanent location at Miinchensteinerstrasse
label: Paragraph

text: 210, Basel. The Eyecatcher, which opened in 1999 as an office building, will require
label: Caption

text: absolute minimal maintenance over the next 50 years and will have a life expectancy of
label: Paragraph

text: 100 years.
label: Paragraph

text: The Future
label: Title

text: Today, with more than six billion human beings living and building on this planet,
label: Paragraph

text: environmental consciousness is at its peak, and the efforts of aggressive recycling
label: Paragraph

text: programs and conservation of our natural resources are at an all-time high. Plastics are
label: Paragraph

text: playing a major role in these conservational endeavors in the building industry, where
label: Paragraph

text: plastics are competing in the main arena of conventional construction materials and in
label: Paragraph

text: structurally demanding applications. Given their remarkably short history, the prolific
label: Paragraph

text: nature of their industrial evolution during the 20th century, and the inherent likelihood of
label: Paragraph

text: accidental discoveries in their field, one could only conclude that the use of plastics in
label: Paragraph

text: general, and in the building and construction industry in particular, will experience an
label: Paragraph

text: even larger proliferation in the new millennium. As such, the 20th century will always be
label: Paragraph

text: remembered as the dawn of the plastics age.
label: Paragraph

text: PLATE GLASS
label: Title

text: Glass is an unusual material created from the basic components of earth-sand, soda, and
label: Paragraph

text: lime. In buildings, glass can be the source of both intriguing delight and distress. Used as
label: Paragraph

text: fenestration in building envelopes, it creates the well-balanced and skillful face of a
label: Paragraph

text: building, the facade. Glass allows light to enter, warms interior spaces in the winter, and
label: Paragraph

text: is capable of establishing a flowing relationship to the outside. Glass can contribute like
label: Paragraph

text: no other building material to the enjoyment of architecture; it encloses, protects from the
label: Paragraph

text: environment, and visually connects at the same time.
label: Paragraph

text: The origins of glass and glassmaking can be traced back to Phoenician times, around
label: Paragraph

text: 5000 B.C.Sailors, lacking stones on which to place their cooking pots, used as an
label: Paragraph

text: alternative the soda carried as cargo by their ships. As the fire’s heat increased, the sand
label: Paragraph

text: and soda turned into molten glass. The public baths in ancient Pompeii were among the
label: Paragraph

text: first usages of plate glass; records indicate that a single sheet of glass measuring 3 by 4
label: Paragraph

text: feet (800 by 1100 millimeters) was used as a window, an extraordinary achievement at
label: Paragraph

text: the time.
label: Paragraph

text: Between the 10th and 15th centuries, the small island of Murano near Venice was the
label: Paragraph

text: unchallenged center of glassmaking, although the technology quickly spread via France
label: Paragraph

text: to Germany, Belgium, and England. Other techniques to produce high-quality building
label: Paragraph

text: glass included the blowing of glass cylinders that were then split, reheated, allowed to
label: Paragraph

text: flatten, and then rolled on a flat surface.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early 18th century, larger and relatively inexpensive pieces of glass increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: entered the building trade in Europe. It cannot be denied that the quality of the product
label: Paragraph

text: had much improved from the humble beginnings of Venetian glass manufacturing, yet
label: Paragraph

text: one area remained where the glass quality was insufficient: the making of mirrors.
label: Paragraph

text: Mirrors, more than regular glass panes, required a much higher surface quality, free of
label: Paragraph

text: distortion. The goal to create a high-quality glass material to be used in mirrors led to the
label: Paragraph

text: invention of plate glass. The casting of mirrors was developed in France by Abraham
label: Paragraph

text: Thevart around 1688 and led to the founding of the St. Gobain glassworks, which was at
label: Paragraph

text: the time the major glass-producing center in the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Because of milestone inventions of the industrial age at the end of the 19th century,
label: Paragraph

text: such as steam machines and electricity, plate glass and thus mirrors became
label: Paragraph

text: commonplace. Water-power, steam engines, and electrical machines made the polishing
label: Paragraph

text: and grinding of the glass plate material easier and faster: plate glass became affordable.
label: Paragraph

text: At the end of the 19th century, storefronts and the facades of commercial buildings in the
label: Paragraph

text: metropolitan centers of the Western world used vast quantities of plate glass.
label: Paragraph

text: Because plate glass has a rough surface, as opposed to sheet glass (the Libbey Owens
label: Paragraph

text: Glass Company developed continuous sheet glass production in the United States in 1905
label: Paragraph

text: in Charleston, West Virginia), which is transparent as it is formed, it needs to be
label: Paragraph

text: manually ground flat and then polished with coarse, sand-based abrasives. Through
label: Paragraph

text: manual grinding and polishing, one surface was first treated, followed by the reverse side.
label: Paragraph

text: The result of this time-consuming process was a glass with almost perfect optical quality,
label: Paragraph

text: nearly free of distortion (depending on the quality of the mixture of base materials), and
label: Paragraph

text: of an unprecedented size.
label: Paragraph

text: After being monopolized in France, Belgium, and Germany, in 1895 the Pittsburgh
label: Paragraph

text: Plate Glass Company (PPG) became the first successful manufacturer of plate glass in the
label: Paragraph

text: United States. The company was founded in 1883, with the first glass production plant in
label: Paragraph

text: Creighton, Pennsylvania, near Pittsburgh. The company produced plate glass in varying
label: Paragraph

text: thickness, generally between one-quarter and one-and-one-quarter inches. The beginning
label: Paragraph

text: of the 20th century brought further development in the area of glass production, mainly
label: Paragraph

text: because of improved polishing and grinding techniques. In 1925 the company of
label: Paragraph

text: Pilkington Brothers in Doncaster, England, developed the technology of continuous
label: Paragraph

text: grinding and polishing. By 1937 the plate of glass was horizontally moved through a
label: Paragraph

text: double roller and then ground and polished in the same line of production—with both
label: Paragraph

text: sides handled simultaneously (twin grinding).
label: Paragraph

text: Large panes of polished plate glass allowed the initial floors of commercial buildings
label: Paragraph

text: to be opened up to the eager and curious eyes of “window shoppers,” a term that
label: Paragraph

text: described a significant change in the behavior of consumers to view and select
label: Paragraph

text: merchandise without crossing the threshold of the respective enterprise. The first four
label: Paragraph

text: floors of the 14-story Reliance building were designed in this manner in 1890 by Charles
label: Paragraph

text: B.Atwood of Daniel Burnham’s office and the structural engineer E.C.Shankland: all
label: Caption

text: perimeter bay windows were filled with plate glass.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1930 and 1940, glass products moved forward in importance as new uses of
label: Paragraph

text: glass were suggested. The all-glass door appeared and was soon widely favored. The
label: Paragraph

text: glass door, without structural elements obstructing the view to the inside of stores,
label: Paragraph

text: reduces the visual barrier that formerly prevented potential customers from entering.
label: Paragraph

text: Advertisements by the glass in-
label: Title

text: Plaza and PPG Place Skyscraper (formerly Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company,
label: Paragraph

text: PPG Industries, Inc.), Philip Johnson and John Burgee (1979-84)
label: Caption

text: © Richard Bickel/CORBIS
label: Caption

text: dustry in architectural magazines of the time noted, “Today store fronts of large plate
label: Paragraph

text: glass try to make sure that passers-by won’t pass them by!” (Pittsburgh Plate Glass
label: Caption

text: advertisement in Progressive Architecture, 1946). Large display windows made of
label: Paragraph

text: structural plate glass successfully competed with other, more traditional materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Designs for large stores by the architect Morris Lapidus in the 1950s turned storefronts
label: Paragraph

text: into eye-catching, gigantic, and glittering display cases made of plate glass.
label: Paragraph

text: Not only in the area of storefront design did plate glass try to establish new records. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1950 the UN Board of Design Consultants, under the directorship of Wallace K.Harrison
label: Caption

text: and the contracting firm of Fuller-Turner-Walsh-Slattery Inc., designed and built on the
label: Paragraph

text: island of Manhattan in New York “the world’s largest window,” a window wall made of
label: Paragraph

text: heat-absorbing plate glass with dimensions of 280 by 500 feet. The UN Headquarters also
label: Paragraph

text: boasts 5400 individual plate-glass windows and large numbers of opaque spandrel glass
label: Paragraph

text: elements.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1961 Libbey-Owens-Ford developed new testing methods for large plate-glass
label: Paragraph

text: elements with a thickness of a quarter inch. Tests indicated that thickness rather than the
label: Paragraph

text: ratio of width to length is the important factor governing the strength of plate glass for
label: Paragraph

text: larger panes.
label: Paragraph

text: Plate glass also became more and more favored in residential design in the 1950s and
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s. The Case Study Houses, commissioned by John Entenza and published in his
label: Paragraph

text: influential magazine Arts and Architecture, formed the cutting edge of design in America
label: Paragraph

text: and abroad in the postwar period. In these designs for progressive residences by Richard
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra, Pierre Koenig, Rudolph R.M.Schindler, and others, plate-glass walls extend from
label: Paragraph

text: floor to ceiling, creating a tall interior space, with the transparent walls allowing a spatial
label: Paragraph

text: flow between the interior and exterior. The crisp, pure geometry of these house designs,
label: Paragraph

text: using large panes of polished plate glass and the interweaving of interior and exterior
label: Paragraph

text: spaces, became hallmarks of the International Style in residential architecture. The
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal roof planes of these Californian residences, which were largely copied in other
label: Paragraph

text: parts of the world, seem to float without gravity on large surfaces of vertical plate glass.
label: Paragraph

text: Plate glass was also used in school designs of the time to add a feeling of spaciousness;
label: Paragraph

text: designers also selected plate glass because of its ease of maintenance. With glass being
label: Paragraph

text: widely used, it was more than natural that issues of solar heat gain, glare, and safety of
label: Paragraph

text: the material became more necessary to consider than any other building material issue.
label: Paragraph

text: Tinting of plate glass to reduce the large heat gain of uninterrupted glass walls was
label: Paragraph

text: developed in the early 1950s; the trade names Solargrey, Solarbronze, and Solex, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, described the color in which the surface of plate glass was treated to reduce
label: Paragraph

text: thermal conductivity. Safety issues were addressed by the development of tempered plate
label: Paragraph

text: glass, mainly used for doors. An excellent late example of the use of green-tinted plate
label: Paragraph

text: glass is the Lever House in New York by architect Gordon Bunshaft of Skidmore,
label: Paragraph

text: Owings and Merrill.
label: Paragraph

text: In the United States and most other industrialized nations, plate glass is no longer
label: Paragraph

text: produced. It was superceded by float glass, the most recent advancement in glass
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturing.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: living and working conditions in the village of Saint Gobain, France, the center of 18th-
label: Paragraph

text: century European glass manufacturing. Godfrey traces the background of medieval
label: Paragraph

text: glassmaking, the political and legal battles related to the manufacturing process, the glass

text: PLATT, CHARLES ADAMS 1861-1933
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: Charles Adams Platt was one of the leading American domestic architects and
label: Paragraph

text: landscape architects of the early 20th century. He was born in 1861 in New York City,
label: Paragraph

text: where he eventually established his practice as an architect and landscape designer. His
label: Paragraph

text: father was a corporate lawyer and his mother a member of the Cheney family, important
label: Paragraph

text: silk-mill owners from Manchester, Connecticut. He began his artistic education during
label: Paragraph

text: summer vacations in Manchester, where two uncles were artists. While still in his teens,
label: Paragraph

text: he became an early member of the Etching Revival, learning to etch from the
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia artist Stephen Parrish. Platt trained briefly in painting at the National
label: Paragraph

text: Academy of Design and the Art Students League before going to Paris in 1882 for further
label: Paragraph

text: study at the Académie Julian. While in Paris, he met architecture students at the Ecole
label: Paragraph

text: des Beaux-Arts and discussed with them his emerging interest in this art. In 1886 he
label: Paragraph

text: matried a New Yorker, Annie C.Hoe, while in Europe; she died the following year,
label: Paragraph

text: losing twin daughters in childbirth. While slowly recovering from this tragedy, Platt
label: Paragraph

text: continued to paint and spent the summer of 1890 with artist friends in Cor-nish, New
label: Paragraph

text: Hampshire. He would continue to summer in the Cornish art colony, where the quality of
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape and the collegiality of sympathetic friends remained an important force
label: Paragraph

text: throughout his life.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1892 Platt invited his brother William, then an apprentice in the landscape architect
label: Paragraph

text: office of Frederick Law Olmsted, to accompany him on a tour of the gardens of Italy.
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Platt used the sketches and photographs they made of approximately 25 gardens
label: Paragraph

text: from throughout the Italian peninsula to illustrate two articles for Harper’s magazine in
label: Paragraph

text: 1893. He expanded these articles into a book, ftalian Gardens, published in 1894. This
label: Paragraph

text: modest volume was one of the first illustrated publications in English depicting the
label: Paragraph

text: gardens of Renaissance Italy, and it heavily influenced the emergence of a formal garden
label: Paragraph

text: style in America.
label: Paragraph

text: Platt turned from this book to a career as a designer of gardens and then as an architect,
label: Paragraph

text: both without any academic training or apprenticeship. He had begun to experiment with
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in his own summerhouse and garden at Cornish in 1890. He expanded and
label: Paragraph

text: refined the gardens for his house, following the lessons learned from his travels in Italy.
label: Paragraph

text: In the summer of 1893, he married Eleanor Hardy Bunker, the widow of his Paris friend
label: Paragraph

text: and fellow painter Dennis Miller Bunker.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout the 1890s, Platt’s Cornish neighbors commissioned him to design informal
label: Paragraph

text: residences and geometric gardens, all influenced by what he had seen in Italy. Among
label: Paragraph

text: these early clients was the architectural critic Herbert Croly, who became an important
label: Paragraph

text: promoter of Platt’s architectural and landscape architectural talents in his articles for The
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Record. By the late 1890s, he was executing significant commissions as a
label: Paragraph

text: garden designer for patrons beyond Cornish. Most important among these early designs
label: Paragraph

text: were his plans for Faulkner Farm, the Charles F. Sprague estate (1897-98), and for Weld,
label: Paragraph

text: the Larz Anderson estate (1901), both in Brookline, Massachusetts. These projects
label: Paragraph

text: illustrate Platt’s adaptation of the Renaissance villa garden to American conditions. By
label: Paragraph

text: the turn of the century, he had established himself as an architect, producing mainly
label: Paragraph

text: designs for country houses and gardens. He relied in these early days on the advice of a
label: Paragraph

text: wide circle of artistic friends in New York City and in Cornish, including the architect
label: Paragraph

text: Stanford White. Platt’s associates at the Century Association, the private club for
label: Paragraph

text: professionals and amateurs in literature and the arts, proved invaluable as advisers and
label: Paragraph

text: clients. Having no formal training in horticulture or engineering, he often worked in
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration with other landscape architects, including the Olmsted Brothers, Warren
label: Paragraph

text: Manning (1860-1938), and Ellen Biddle Shipman (1869-1950), his Cornish neighbor
label: Paragraph

text: and most frequent collaborator. He developed a small office in New York from which he
label: Paragraph

text: executed commissions throughout the country, relying on the professional expertise of
label: Paragraph

text: younger men and carefully controlling the design solutions of the firm. By 1904, when
label: Paragraph

text: Herbert Croly published a review article on Platt’s work for The Architectural Record, he
label: Paragraph

text: had established a recognized style in planning and design of domestic architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Commissions for “Platt houses” and their landscapes annually grew in number and scale.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the most influential of Platt’s designs for country houses and gardens were
label: Paragraph

text: those for Maxwell Court, the Francis T.Maxwell House (1903) in Rockville, Connecticut;
label: Caption

text: Gwinn (1908), the William G.Mather place near Cleveland, Ohio; the Manor House
label: Caption

text: on
label: Title

text: 911), the John T.Pratt estate in Glen Cove, New York; and Villa Turicum (1918), the
label: Paragraph

text: immense country estate of Harold and Edith Rockefeller McCormick in Wake Forest,
label: Paragraph

text: linois. Platt’s work was frequently illustrated and discussed in architectural and
label: Paragraph

text: landscape magazines, including The Architectural Record and Country Life in America.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1913 he became the subject of the first commercially produced monograph on a living
label: Paragraph

text: American architect or landscape architect. In addition to his work on country houses, he
label: Paragraph

text: designed a series of elegant tall office buildings and apartment houses in New York City
label: Paragraph

text: throughout his career. Institutional designs monopolized much of his time in the 1910s
label: Paragraph

text: and 1920s. He became recognized as a leading architect for art museums, which included
label: Paragraph

text: the Freer Gallery of Art (1923) on the Mall in Washington, DC, and an unrealized
label: Paragraph

text: proposal for a National Gallery of Art (1924). He also gained national recognition as an
label: Paragraph

text: architect and planner for schools and colleges, especially the master plans he prepared for
label: Paragraph

text: Phillips Academy in Andover, Massachusetts, between 1922 and 1930 and the plans for
label: Paragraph

text: the University of Illinois, Urbana, that he prepared between 1921 and 1933. He designed
label: Paragraph

text: numerous buildings for both campuses and other schools and universities throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: country.
label: Paragraph

text: Platt was a careful student of history and applied the lessons he learned to the needs of
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary buildings, pleasure gardens, and public spaces. In all his work, Platt
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized careful planning, evident in the meticulous axial relationships of rooms or
label: Paragraph

text: the integration of exterior and interior space through the use of architectonic garden
label: Paragraph

text: components and strong vistas. Although he almost never wrote about his own work, his
label: Paragraph

text: designs were frequently published and exerted a strong influence on his generation.
label: Paragraph

text: PLAZA
label: Title

text: The term plaza is a Spanish word for an open space in the city. It is cognate with the
label: Paragraph

text: French and English place, which are ultimately derived from the Greek word plateia,
label: Paragraph

text: meaning “broad street.” The Italian-word equivalent is piazza. The contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: American term is square, although the terms park and green are also utilized. In all cases,
label: Paragraph

text: the terms mean an urban space (which might be paved or landscaped) surrounded by
label: Paragraph

text: streets and defined by buildings on one or more sides. They vary highly in both size and
label: Paragraph

text: geometric configuration. A plaza is inextricably related to the architectural frame that
label: Paragraph

text: defines it, as it is the functions in these buildings and their density that directly influence
label: Paragraph

text: its use and design.
label: Paragraph

text: Plazas are the public open spaces in a city whose primary purpose is to provide a
label: Paragraph

text: gathering place for the people to foster the creation of community. They are sometimes
label: Paragraph

text: called urban living rooms, places of formal and informal socialization. They are also
label: Paragraph

text: places of spatial focus providing orientation, repose, and historical continuity.
label: Paragraph

text: Plazas can also accommodate specific activities, such as markets, performances,
label: Paragraph

text: celebrations, protests, and recreation. The traditional use of public spaces for political
label: Paragraph

text: activity waned in the 20th century in democratic countries but remains alive in socialist
label: Paragraph

text: countries, as evidenced by the recent incidents at Wenceslas Square in Prague and
label: Paragraph

text: Tiananmen Square in Beijing. The use for markets also waned during this century in the
label: Paragraph

text: industrialized cities of the world. The other uses remain current.
label: Paragraph

text: Virtually all Western historical cities, planned and unplanned, were formed around one
label: Paragraph

text: or more urban plazas. The vast majority of these cities throughout the world were
label: Paragraph

text: founded before the 20th century. Thus, the primary design activity of this century has
label: Paragraph

text: been preservation with only modest changes. Many cities have renovated their primary
label: Paragraph

text: plazas. This is most evident in Savannah, Georgia, with its integrated pattern of historical
label: Paragraph

text: squares.
label: Paragraph

text: In cities where there has been dramatic change in density and transportation, the plazas
label: Paragraph

text: have changed in design. This occurred in the 20th century primarily in the United States,
label: Paragraph

text: Canada, and Australia. The most common response has been to build a parking garage
label: Paragraph

text: beneath the plaza and concomitantly redesign it. This occurred first at Union Square in
label: Paragraph

text: San Francisco in 1942.
label: Paragraph

text: Existing plazas in some cities needed to be redesigned in the 20th century to correct
label: Paragraph

text: design deficiencies. Bryant Park behind the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue
label: Caption

text: and 42nd Street had become the turf of drug dealers because of its physical and visual
label: Paragraph

text: separation from the surrounding streets. Landscape architects Hanna/Olin produced a
label: Paragraph

text: highly acclaimed scheme that took out the perimeter hedge and widened the entry points.
label: Paragraph

text: They also provided abundant seating and luxuriant plantings.
label: Paragraph

text: In other cities, the plaza had to be redesigned because of a changed context. This is the
label: Paragraph

text: case with Boston’s Copley Square, which has been the subject of periodic design
label: Paragraph

text: competitions since 1893. The 1966 design treated the square as a terraced Italian piazza,
label: Paragraph

text: windswept and inhospitable and lacking pedestrian amenities. The battle to preserve its
label: Paragraph

text: scale was essentially lost with the construction of the 60-story John Hancock Building on
label: Paragraph

text: a comer of the square. It overwhelms the two masterpieces of historical architecture on
label: Paragraph

text: the square: Trinity Church and the Boston Public Library. Another design competition in
label: Paragraph

text: 1984 resulted in a scheme based on a village green. Now, increased pedestrian traffic
label: Paragraph

text: from surrounding development threatens the survival of the soft landscape in this small
label: Paragraph

text: but precious public place.
label: Paragraph

text: In Barcelona, Spain, more than 150 open spaces have been rebuilt in an effort to
label: Paragraph

text: revitalize the city after the neglect during the Spanish civil war. These range from
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhood parks to urban plazas, many featuring large sculptural works. All are
label: Paragraph

text: designed as multiuse gathering spaces. Their designs are a dialectic between formal and
label: Paragraph

text: informal geometries taking advantage of circumstantial opportunities. The Mediterranean
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of paved places has been continued with judicious use of trees and planting. For
label: Paragraph

text: the 1992 Olympics, the port was reconstructed as an urban plaza defined by shops and
label: Paragraph

text: restaurants featuring twin high-rise towers.
label: Paragraph

text: In Italy there is a great urban tradition of the piazza as the social and spatial focus of a
label: Paragraph

text: town. Some of these have been artistically redesigned to foster new vitality. Redesigned
label: Paragraph

text: piazzas in Cormans, Vilanova, Pirano, and Santa Severina are abstract minimalist
label: Paragraph

text: compositions of paving geometry and urban elements that create new perceptions of these
label: Paragraph

text: places as they relate to the historic buildings that define them.
label: Paragraph

text: Some cities have had to create plazas where none existed. This occurred in Portland,
label: Paragraph

text: Oregon, because of the need for a true central civic place. A design competition in 1980
label: Paragraph

text: resulted in a highly contextual scheme created by a design team led by architect Willard
label: Paragraph

text: Martin. The resulting Pioneer Square is almost completely paved in brick, an unusual
label: Paragraph

text: condition in the United States, which favors green, open spaces. To ensure the successful
label: Paragraph

text: use of this square, a private association programs 300 events throughout the year,
label: Paragraph

text: including dinners, dances, concerts, exhibits, and fairs. This draws 2.5 million people
label: Paragraph

text: annually to a city whose population is only 500,000.
label: Paragraph

text: New squares in Boston and Toronto were created in conjunction with new city halls.
label: Paragraph

text: The Boston City Hall Plaza (1962-
label: Caption

text: Avenue de los Presidentes, E] Vedado, Havana, Cuba
label: Caption

text: © Library of Congress, courtesy Archive of Hispanic Culture Collection
label: Caption

text: 68) is a large, tiered, brick-paved space reminiscent of the Campo in Siena, Italy. Nathan
label: Paragraph

text: Phillips Square in Toronto is formed around a large pool and fountain that becomes an
label: Paragraph

text: ice-skating rink in winter.
label: Paragraph

text: Most new plazas designed and built in the 20th century in the United States, Canada,
label: Paragraph

text: and Australia have been in conjunction with real estate developments. The modern era of
label: Paragraph

text: the developer plaza begins with the design and construction of Rockefeller Center (1931—
label: Paragraph

text: 39) on three blocks in Manhattan. John D.Rockefeller, Jr., wanted to create an appealing
label: Paragraph

text: complex of buildings around an urban space to make his development succeed during the
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s Depression era. The team of architects created a design that brought pedestrians
label: Paragraph

text: through a garden from Fifth Avenue to a sunken plaza in the middle of the complex. The
label: Paragraph

text: sunken urban space connected the street-level shops to an extensive underground
label: Paragraph

text: concourse system, creating pedestrian links between all the buildings. The plaza reflects
label: Paragraph

text: the change of seasons, being an ice-skating rink in winter and an outdoor cafe with a
label: Paragraph

text: fountain in summer. What started as a real estate venture has developed into one of the
label: Paragraph

text: best social spaces in New York City.
label: Paragraph

text: Corporations have often built plazas in conjunction with new urban headquarters. One
label: Paragraph

text: of the first of this type was the Seagram Building (1958) on Park Avenue in Manhattan
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe. This flat, elevated, granite-paved plaza was
label: Paragraph

text: intended to showcase the modern office tower that was set back from the street. The only
label: Paragraph

text: features are two shallow pools of water, surrounded by ledges that separate the plaza
label: Paragraph

text: from the side streets. Inadvertently, this plaza has become one of high pedestrian use
label: Paragraph

text: because of its direct physical and visual connection to Park Avenue.
label: Paragraph

text: There are now dozens of corporate plazas in Manhattan alone, including Union
label: Paragraph

text: Carbide, Chase Manhattan Bank, and Marine Midland Bank. Perhaps the bleakest is at
label: Paragraph

text: the World Trade Center: five acres of paving with an overscaled fountain to match the
label: Paragraph

text: overscaled 110-story buildings. Chicago has the Sears Tower, San Francisco the Bank of
label: Paragraph

text: America, and Los Angeles the Wells Fargo Bank, each with its own plaza. Every large
label: Paragraph

text: American city has its share of corporate plazas. Usually, these are windswept expanses of
label: Paragraph

text: paving with token landscaping and few if any pedestrian amenities. Many have been
label: Paragraph

text: created through zoning bonuses that allow taller and/or bigger buildings if plazas are
label: Paragraph

text: provided. The research of William H.Whyte has been instrumental in making these plazas
label: Paragraph

text: more pedestrian friendly.
label: Paragraph

text: There is an extensive legacy of urban open spaces in the cities of the world. In some
label: Paragraph

text: countries, these are still utilized for traditional purposes. In other countries, they are
label: Paragraph

text: anguishing in use because of changing cultural norms and dispersal of the population.
label: Paragraph

text: The suburban shopping mall has become the most ubiquitous substitute for the urban
label: Paragraph

text: plaza. The primary question for the 21st century will be whether historic urban places can
label: Paragraph

text: be preserved, redesigned, and utilized.
label: Paragraph

text: MICHAEL J.,BEDNAR

text: PLECNIK, JOZE 1872-1957
label: Title

text: Architect, Yugoslavia
label: Title

text: An old modest house, located at No. 4 Karunova Street in the Trnovo district to the
label: Caption

text: northeast of Ljubljana’s core, has remained as Joze Pleénik’s modest legacy; he was
label: Paragraph

text: undoubtedly one of the most significant 20th-century Slovenian architects and a
label: Paragraph

text: prominent pioneer of modern architecture in Central Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: Pleénik’s house is characterized by frugality and an elegant, albeit monastic, ambience.
label: Paragraph

text: The search for an identity for Slovenian architecture; the fascination with folk traditions;
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmanship; the interest in the classical world, particularly the Renaissance and
label: Paragraph

text: Mannerist periods; and a devotion to the sacred are among the themes that characterize
label: Paragraph

text: Pleénik’s oeuvre.
label: Paragraph

text: His architectural career unfolds from the last quarter of the 19th century to the mid-
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century. Vienna, Prague, and Ljubljana became the geographic areas of the
label: Paragraph

text: architect’s activities, each one coloring a phase of his production. In 1891 Pleénik’s
label: Paragraph

text: father passed away, a circumstance that contributed to Pleénik’s decision to move to
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna as opposed to returning to Ljubljana to take over his father’s woodworking
label: Paragraph

text: workshop.
label: Paragraph

text: The following year, with assistance from the architect Leopold Theyer, who procured
label: Paragraph

text: him employment with the firm K.K.Hof-Bau und Kunsttischelerei J.W.Miller, Pleénik
label: Paragraph

text: finally moved to Vienna. His arrival in the capital of the Austro-Hungarian Empire was
label: Paragraph

text: timely as it coincided with the transformation of the imperial city into one of the centers
label: Paragraph

text: of world architecture. The architectural and urban efforts of Otto Wagner and several of
label: Paragraph

text: his followers were decisive contributions to the transformation of this city’s infrastructure
label: Paragraph

text: and physiognomy. In 1894 Ple¢énik met Wagner, who accepted him as a student at the
label: Paragraph

text: Academy of Fine Arts. This was a definitive period in the formation of the future
label: Paragraph

text: architect, who became a devoted adherent of Wagner’s ideals. Wagner gave primacy to
label: Paragraph

text: technique over form and to innovation over tradition and emphasized a positive
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalist position, thus anticipating many of the critical themes developed later as part
label: Paragraph

text: of the Modern movement.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1898 Ple¢nik graduated third in his class after Josef Hoffman and Jan Kotera. His
label: Paragraph

text: efforts earned him a bursary that allowed him, from 1898 to 1899, to travel to Italy with
label: Paragraph

text: short incursions into France and Spain. Although the death of his mother prompted the
label: Paragraph

text: young architect to put an abrupt end to this Grand Tour, the rich extant correspondence
label: Paragraph

text: and drawings from the period show Pleénik as a very sensitive and keen observer of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and art.
label: Paragraph

text: Pleénik’s Viennese period, marked by an initial devotion to Wagner’s rational
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic, also reflects the architect’s involvement with the Vienna Secession movement,
label: Paragraph

text: founded in 1897 by architects Joseph Hoffman and Joseph Maria Olbrich and painter
label: Paragraph

text: Gustav Klimt. Pleénik worked on projects for the Secession, which included designs for
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary furniture and household furnishings. His first important commission, the
label: Paragraph

text: Zacherl House (1903-05) in central Vienna, dates from this epoch. Undoubtedly the
label: Paragraph

text: architect’s early masterpiece, the Zacherl House is innovative in the use of concrete
label: Paragraph

text: technology for the structural support.
label: Paragraph

text: Pleénik’s interest in sacred art, a theme that would pervasively appear throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: architect’s career, also emerged during the early years of the 20th century. His Church of
label: Paragraph

text: the Holy Spirit in Ottakring (1910-13), the first reinforced-concrete church in Vienna, is
label: Paragraph

text: an excellent example of the expressive use of materials.
label: Paragraph

text: The second period of Pleénik’s professional career began in Prague in 1911. With the
label: Paragraph

text: help of his friend Jan Kotera, he was appointed to a teaching position at the Prague
label: Paragraph

text: School of Applied Arts. Ple¢nik’s stay in the Czech city, which included many visits to
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna until the outbreak of World War I, permitted him to distance himself from the
label: Paragraph

text: strong German nationalism then emerging in Vienna and to concentrate on the study of
label: Paragraph

text: Slavic art, a theme that would shape his later work.
label: Paragraph

text: The search for Wagner’s replacement as a director of the Academy of Fine Arts in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna during the early 1910s gave Pletnik the hope for a return to the city that he
label: Paragraph

text: considered his home. Although Pleénik was the faculty’s choice for the post, the students
label: Paragraph

text: protested the appointment, and after two years the position was given to Léopold Bauer
label: Paragraph

text: instead. Disillusioned by this turn of events, Ple¢nik discarded any plans to return to
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna.
label: Paragraph

text: The second decade of the century saw Ple¢nik actively involved in teaching in Prague.
label: Paragraph

text: This phase was distinguished by a lack of built production that was nonetheless
label: Paragraph

text: counteracted by a return to a preoccupation with craft—particularly metalworking—
label: Paragraph

text: through his teaching activities. During this period, the architect often traveled to
label: Paragraph

text: Slovenia, beginning a process of reacquaintance with his family and native land that
label: Paragraph

text: greatly contributed to his desire to return to Ljubljana.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early 1920s, Pleénik concluded his academic activities at the Prague School of
label: Paragraph

text: Applied Arts and returned to Slovenia, where he began teaching activities at the
label: Paragraph

text: Polytechnic School of Ljubljana. However, before his departure for Slovenia, he received
label: Paragraph

text: the offer from the newly elected president of the Czech republic, Tomas Masaryk, to
label: Paragraph

text: become the architect of the Prague Castle. This important commission, through which
label: Paragraph

text: Masaryk intended to transform Prague’s highly visible historical royal compound into the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural symbol of the new democracy, became Pleénik’s obsession throughout a
label: Paragraph

text: great part of this period. He returned to Prague each year until 1935—the year Masaryk
label: Paragraph

text: abdicated—to supervise the work. Other significant buildings from this period include his
label: Paragraph

text: restoration of the Presi-dent’s summer residence in Lany (1921—23) and the Sacred Heart
label: Caption

text: Church in Prague (1928-32).
label: Paragraph

text: Ljubljana marks the last, and undoubtedly most productive, period in the architect’s
label: Paragraph

text: career. After the return to his homeland, Pleénik devoted himself to an architectural and
label: Paragraph

text: cultural campaign that produced significant buildings raging from sacred architecture to
label: Paragraph

text: institutional projects and urban interventions, transforming the architectural fabric of that
label: Paragraph

text: city. The buildings from this phase clearly express the architect’s search for a national
label: Paragraph

text: Slovenian language, idiosyncratic nonetheless, but craftily executed and based on
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean rather than Nordic precedence. This period includes the Church of Saint
label: Paragraph

text: Francis of Assisi, Siska (1925-31); Saint Michael’s Church, Barje (1937-38); and the
label: Paragraph

text: renovation of the Chamber of Commerce, Craft, and Industry (1925-27), the
label: Paragraph

text: Headquarters of the Vzanjemna Insurance Company (1928-30), the National University
label: Paragraph

text: Library (1936-41), and the Central Funerary complex at the Zale Cemetery (1938) in
label: Paragraph

text: Ljubljana. The Ljubljana oeuvre epitomizes the syncretic amalgam of themes and
label: Paragraph

text: motives, influenced by classic, neoclassic, and vernacular imagery that persistently
label: Paragraph

text: nourished the production of Pleénik—without doubt one of the significant, yet
label: Paragraph

text: overlooked, figures of modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: POELZIG, HANS 1869-1936
label: Title

text: Architect, Germany
label: Title

text: Hans Poelzig was an important exponent of German Expressionism. Together with
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Gropius, Adolf Meyer, and Peter Behrens, he was one of the most important
label: Paragraph

text: German architects before 1914.
label: Paragraph

text: From 1889 to 1894, Poelzig studied architecture with the renowned Gothic Revivalist
label: Paragraph

text: Karl Schafer at the Technical University (Technische Hochschule) in Berlin-
label: Paragraph

text: Charlottenburg. From 1899 to 1916, he taught at the Academy of Fine and Applied Arts
label: Paragraph

text: (Akademie fiir Kunst und Kunstgewerbe) in
label: Paragraph

text: style (Fach Stilkunde) and after 1903 as dire
label: Paragraph

text: also served as city architect (Stadtbaurat) in
label: Paragraph

text: Technical University. In 1920, he moved to
label: Paragraph

text: the Prussian Academy of Arts. In 1923
label: Paragraph

text: Breslau (now Wroclaw), first as professor of
label: Paragraph

text: ctor of the academy. From 1916 to 1920 he
label: Paragraph

text: Dresden and visiting lecturer at the Dresden
label: Title

text: Berlin, where he had a master workshop at
label: Paragraph

text: he was appointed professor at the Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: Technical University. In 1933 he succeeded Bruno Paul as director of the U.S. School for
label: Paragraph

text: Free and Applied Arts in Berlin, only to be
label: Paragraph

text: stripped of all his academic offices shortly
label: Paragraph

text: thereafter by the National Socialists. In 1936 he accepted a professorship in Ankara,
label: Paragraph

text: Turkey; however, he died before being able to begin work in this émigré position. Poelzig
label: Paragraph

text: was a member of the “Novembergruppe” and the Workers’ and Soldiers’ Council for Art,
label: Paragraph

text: the presiding officer of the German Werkbund (1919-21), and a member of the
label: Paragraph

text: governing council of the League of German Architects (Bund Deutscher Architekten,
label: Paragraph

text: Poelzig was passionate about the arts generally, and he also created large-format
label: Paragraph

text: paintings. His contemporaries considered him to be an unpredictable, temperamental
label: Paragraph

text: creative force. In addition to being an innovative architect, Poelzig was an influential
label: Paragraph

text: teacher whose concepts and ideas reached a large audience. Especially during his tenure
label: Paragraph

text: in Breslau, he promoted a program of cooperative effort between handicrafts and art, and
label: Paragraph

text: thus—years before the Bauhaus program was formulated—he represented a similar,
label: Paragraph

text: pathbreaking position.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike many of his contemporaries, Poelzig was less rooted in Jugendstil and more
label: Paragraph

text: inspired by new concepts of living and house design, such as those formulated by Alfred
label: Paragraph

text: Lichtwark and Hermann Muthesius. He was also significantly influenced by rationalist
label: Paragraph

text: ideas about style based on an honest use of building materials. Fundamental traits such as
label: Paragraph

text: these are apparent even in early works, such as his own house near Breslau/Wroclaw
label: Paragraph

text: (1906), the Zwirners house in L6wenberg/Lwowek Slaski (1909-10), and the house for
label: Paragraph

text: the Breslau Art and Crafts Exhibition (1904). Ever more pronounced, Poelzig had a
label: Paragraph

text: strong interest in deriving plastic architectonic forms from the chosen building materials,
label: Paragraph

text: a practice that he had given theoretical form in his 1899 study Materialstillehre (Lessons
label: Paragraph

text: in Materialist Style). Alongside his designs for country houses, his industrial designs bear
label: Paragraph

text: this trademark. The first such work of importance was the water tower
label: Paragraph

text: (Oberschlesienturm) in Posen/Poznan (1911, partially destroyed) with its crystalline
label: Paragraph

text: features, which was built as an exhibition pavilion in conjunction with a mining exhibit.
label: Paragraph

text: The exterior featured an exposed iron skeleton open to the elements into which he placed
label: Paragraph

text: brick niches that were clearly meant only to fill in the gaps in the exposed frame.
label: Paragraph

text: Poelzig also used building materials symbolically. Rather than rely on ornament
label: Paragraph

text: borrowed from historicist or Jugendstil models, he allowed the special character of the
label: Paragraph

text: building materials to determine the decorative shape of a building’s interior and exterior.
label: Paragraph

text: In this way, he composed visual confrontations based on the innate qualities of the
label: Paragraph

text: materials. In his design for the Werdermihle in Breslau (1906-08), facade portions in
label: Paragraph

text: glass contrast with massive brick walls. Similarly, in an office building (1912) on
label: Paragraph

text: Breslau’s Junkernstrasse, he juxtaposed steel-framed concrete construction reminiscent of
label: Paragraph

text: half timbering with horizontal bands of windows running unbroken around the rounded
label: Caption

text: corners of the building. In this way, even before World War I, he created a design motif
label: Paragraph

text: that was frequently used by the rationalistic architecture of the 1920s and 1930s and that
label: Paragraph

text: for him was suggested by the plastic potential of glass, steel, and brick.
label: Paragraph

text: Poelzig successfully combined diverse elements into harmonious architectural designs.
label: Paragraph

text: In many projects, he wanted to decrease the monotony of large industrial complexes and
label: Paragraph

text: administrative buildings. Into such designs, he incorporated a variety of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: forms to artistically balance large-scale architectural masses and expressive construction.
label: Paragraph

text: A good example of his use of these principles is found in the avant-garde, pseudo-
label: Paragraph

text: objectivist buildings for a chemical factory (1911-12) in Luban. There, Cubist forms
label: Paragraph

text: blended into each other. Round-arched windows set flush with the masonry contrast
label: Paragraph

text: sharply with rectangular windows. To show off the design’s engineering, rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: windows were specifically chosen for the parts where load-bearing steel beams visible in
label: Paragraph

text: the facade made such windows possible. Occasionally, he punctuated such rationalist,
label: Paragraph

text: material-derived effects with purely decorative elements; for example, Gothicinspired
label: Paragraph

text: stepped gables.
label: Paragraph

text: Poelzig’s work after World War | was rooted in the Expressionist movement,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly his practice of overplastering plastic architectonic elements to heighten their
label: Paragraph

text: effect. He began a series of crystalline structures, including his design for the House of
label: Paragraph

text: Friendship (1916) in Istanbul, the plans for a Town Hall (1917) in Dresden, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Festival Hall (1920) in Salzburg. These projects show how he moved toward an ever
label: Paragraph

text: more individualistic treatment of design elements and materials. He combined new
label: Paragraph

text: architectural concepts with an extremely personal interpretation of formal traditions.
label: Paragraph

text: These developments culminated and were most demonstratively realized in his best-
label: Paragraph

text: known building, the Grosses Schauspielhaus (1918-19), a transformation of the
label: Paragraph

text: Schumann Circus in Berlin undertaken for Max Reinhardt as an experimental theater. In
label: Paragraph

text: the theater’s vaulted auditorium, he created a famous cavelike effect by covering the
label: Paragraph

text: domed ceiling with a sheath of stalactite forms. The room’s organic appearance was in
label: Paragraph

text: part the result of his use of a post-and-lintel system. Poelzig’s use of light as an aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: element in giving form to the space was innovative, creating a total spatial effect based
label: Paragraph

text: on an elaborate conception of color—his “light architecture,” or Lichtarchitektur. The
label: Paragraph

text: theater’s exterior was flat, with little surface decoration, although decidedly monumental
label: Paragraph

text: in appearance. Together with the simply delineated and sparsely decorated structure of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1.G.Farben administrative building (1930) in Frankfurt am Main, the exterior of the
label: Paragraph

text: Grosses Schauspielhaus pointed the way to the International Style of the 1930s.
label: Paragraph

text: The Radio House in Berlin (Haus des Rundfunks, 1929-30) likewise stands in this path
label: Paragraph

text: of development. It was the first German broadcasting building to be built. Based on a
label: Paragraph

text: triangular floor plan, Poelzig articulated a brick-masonry facade with colored ceramic
label: Paragraph

text: plates, creating a fenestration of high plasticity that, in pillar fashion, emphasizes the
label: Paragraph

text: perpendiculars of the three wings of the building, each of which reaches over 150 meters.
label: Paragraph

text: Simple yet striking articulation of the volumes typifies Poelzig’s subsequent sketches,
label: Paragraph

text: designs, and buildings. These include the Capitol Cinema (1925) in Berlin, the Mosaic
label: Paragraph

text: Fountain (1926) in Dresden, the competition designs for the expansion of the Reichstag
label: Paragraph

text: (1929) in Berlin, the new plan for the Luxemburg Platz (1929), proposed designs for
label: Paragraph

text: numerous gas stations (1927), and Poelzig’s participation in the competition for the new
label: Paragraph

text: Reichs Bank building (1932). Poelzig’s late work shows increasing neoclassical
label: Paragraph

text: tendencies; for example, in his contest entries for a theater (1935) in Dessau. In addition
label: Paragraph

text: to his activity as an architect, Poelzig designed scenery for the theater and films, notably
label: Paragraph

text: for The Golem (1920) and other films by P. Wegener.
label: Paragraph

text: James Stewart Polshek has restored to late-20th-century practice one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: admirable legacies of modernism—its belief that architecture is wedded to ethics, that the
label: Paragraph

text: primary concern is not the creation of personal monuments but of functional and
label: Paragraph

text: structurally sound buildings that answer the evolving programmatic and economic needs
label: Paragraph

text: of the time. By extending that notion to embrace the vital importance of context as a key
label: Paragraph

text: ingredient of such responsibility, Polshek mediates the dogmatic utopian
label: Paragraph

text: oversimplifications that often flawed modernist practice. Thus, his works are not isolated
label: Paragraph

text: icons of style but rather buildings that defer to both the site and the people who inhabit
label: Paragraph

text: them.
label: Paragraph

text: Born in 1930 in Akron, Ohio, Polshek entered the premedical program at Case Western
label: Paragraph

text: Reserve University in Cleveland, but an introductory course in architectural history led to
label: Paragraph

text: a dramatic change in plans. He transferred to the School of Architecture for his fourth and
label: Paragraph

text: final year and in 1951 entered Yale University’s graduate program, receiving a master of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture degree with honors in 1955. After a brief stint under L.M.Pei at Webb and
label: Paragraph

text: Knapp developers in New York City, in January 1956 he accepted a Fulbright scholarship
label: Paragraph

text: in Copenhagen that allowed him to obs

label: Paragraph

text: travel to see the work of such early heroes as
label: Paragraph

text: On returning to New York City in 1957,

text: progressive country while permitting him to

label: Paragraph

text: 962 he embarked on a remarkable odyssey
label: Paragraph

text: for a young man: the commission for two major buildings in Japan for the Teijin Textile
label: Caption

text: Company. He lived in Japan until 1964, absorbing the lessons not only of modern masters
label: Paragraph

text: such as Kenzo Tange and Kunio Maekawa but also of traditional Japanese architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The two concrete behemoths for Teijin, in the Brutalist idiom then current, received
label: Paragraph

text: awards in Japan and the United States, and Polshek’s career was launched. One measure
label: Paragraph

text: of his growing visibility was the invitation in 1968 to design the Quinco Mental Health
label: Paragraph

text: Center in that town of trophy works by leading architects, Columbus, Indiana. Set in a
label: Caption

text: wooded area, Quinco’s béion brut planes create a “bridge” over an existing creek,
label: Paragraph

text: incorporating the structure into its natural surroundings.
label: Paragraph

text: Subsequently, Polshek received a broad range of commissions to include master plans
label: Paragraph

text: for cities, campuses, colleges, and cathedrals, designs for public housing, corporate
label: Caption

text: headquarters, sewage treatment plans, embassies, theaters, convention centers, museums,
label: Paragraph

text: libraries, and apartment houses. Polshek undertook domestic commissions (such as
label: Paragraph

text: private homes for individuals) as well, although his preference for community
label: Paragraph

text: architecture prevailed, including projects involving preservation, restoration, and
label: Paragraph

text: adaptive re-use. Especially noteworthy are the reconstructions of such landmarks as
label: Paragraph

text: Camegie Hall (1978-87), Cass Gilbert’s U.S. Customs House, the American Museum of
label: Caption

text: Natural History, and the Cooper-Hewitt Museum of Design, all in Manhattan, and Delano
label: Paragraph

text: and Aldrich’s Sage Hall, Smith College, in Northampton, Massachusetts.
label: Caption

text: A particular triumph of what Polshek terms “reinforcement” is 500 Park Tower in New
label: Paragraph

text: York City (1980): the sleek aluminum, glass, and stone surfaces of the 40-story
label: Paragraph

text: residential and commercial tower, the massing of which is inspired by the PSFS building
label: Paragraph

text: in Philadelphia, form a bold but empathetic backdrop to the former Pepsi-Cola
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters of 1959 by Gordon Bunshaft, which Polshek has restored. His “Cinderella
label: Paragraph

text: wand” has endowed even modest relics with new lives as stunning images and functional
label: Paragraph

text: ensembles: at the Seamen’s Church Institute in New York’s South Street Seaport (1991),
label: Caption

text: which houses as many different kinds of spaces as an ocean liner—offices, a navigation
label: Paragraph

text: training laboratory, dining services, an art gallery, and a chapel, among others—a
label: Paragraph

text: nautical note is struck by the upper floors, clad in white enameled steel, which rise
label: Paragraph

text: dramatically but compatibly from the base of the resurrected 18th-century brick facade.
label: Paragraph

text: Such opportunities profoundly influenced Polshek’s architectural vocabulary no less than
label: Paragraph

text: his design philosophy. Asked to insert a new building into an existing configuration or to
label: Paragraph

text: expand or alter structures from various stylistic periods, he responds with a nuanced
label: Paragraph

text: sensitivity while avoiding historical pastiche. Through the devices of abstraction and the
label: Paragraph

text: selection of materials, he transforms references to traditional details into contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: solutions.
label: Paragraph

text: Polshek relishes commissions for entirely new buildings, which he handles with a
label: Paragraph

text: similar gusto for resolving complex programs that must be embodied symbolically as
label: Paragraph

text: well as served practically. Whether starting from scratch or renewing, a number of
label: Paragraph

text: favorite motifs appear repeatedly, in particular the figure of the square, which he learned
label: Paragraph

text: in February 2000. A pure sphere encased in a meticulously detailed glass box, the design
label: Paragraph

text: brings together the modernist geometry that Polshek loves—the Phileban solids
label: Paragraph

text: employed by late-18th-century precursors like Claude-Nicholas Ledoux and Etienne
label: Paragraph

text: Boullee—with the current search for symbolic meaning in architecture, for the sphere
label: Paragraph

text: embodies the universe as it discloses its secrets. The year 2000 as well saw Polshek
label: Paragraph

text: embarking on the commission for the William Clinton Presidential Library in Little
label: Caption

text: Rock, Arkansas.
label: Caption

text: The way in which Polshek has organized his successive partnerships is key to his
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy. He understands that collaboration is the essence of architectural achievement.
label: Paragraph

text: The client is an indispensable member of the design team along with the members of his
label: Paragraph

text: office, whose various contributions Polshek encourages and scrupulously credits. The
label: Paragraph

text: size of the office has varied from 30 to more than 100 over the years and represents at
label: Paragraph

text: once a model of the American large architectural practice and an exception in the
label: Paragraph

text: camaraderie and collegial interchange among participants.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1972 Polshek became dean of the Graduate School of Architecture, Planning, and
label: Paragraph

text: Preservation at Columbia University where he served for 15 years, assembling an
label: Paragraph

text: unprecedented diverse faculty and shaping the curriculum to respond to the complex
label: Paragraph

text: needs of the last quarter of the 20th century. He also transmitted his vision of the
label: Paragraph

text: professional architect as urbanist, who must cope with the megascale of complexes that
label: Paragraph

text: engage entire portions of cities no less than the individual building, and as
label: Paragraph

text: preservationist, who must patiently repair the rifts in the urban fabric. By example, he
label: Paragraph

text: continues to teach that architects should not aim for the instantly identifiable individual
label: Paragraph

text: statements of dubious practical utility that tend to be glorified by the media and that they
label: Paragraph

text: can responsibly fulfill their social and professional responsibilities while making works
label: Paragraph

text: that communicate and bring sensual pleasure and intellectual delight to their viewers.
label: Paragraph
