text: POMPIDOU CENTER
label: Title

text: Designed by Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers; completed 1977
label: Caption

text: Paris, France
label: Title

text: From the moment the results of the open international competition for a new cultural
label: Paragraph

text: center in Paris were announced in 1971, the Pompidou Center attracted both strong praise
label: Paragraph

text: and fierce criticism. Designed by architects Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers together
label: Paragraph

text: with structural engineers Ted Happold and Peter Rice of Ove Arup and Partners, the
label: Paragraph

text: winning scheme was conceived as an antimonumental democratic palace of culture. Since
label: Paragraph

text: opening in 1977, the Pompidou Center—also known simply as Beaubourg, the name of
label: Paragraph

text: the site where it is located—has proved to be immensely successful in fulfilling the
label: Paragraph

text: ambition of its designers, becoming both a focus of the contemporary visual arts in
label: Paragraph

text: France and one of the most popular tourist destinations in Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: The competition, initiated by French President Georges Pompidou, attracted 681
label: Paragraph

text: entries. The nine-person jury included four architects of international distinction: Jean
label: Paragraph

text: Prouvé (president of the jury), Philip Johnson, Oscar Niemeyer, and Jorn Utzon. In the
label: Paragraph

text: event, Utzon was ill and unable to participate in the selection process. The winning
label: Paragraph

text: scheme, selected in the first round of deliberations by a vote of 8 to 1, caused controversy
label: Paragraph

text: when it was discovered that the designers were young and relatively unknown and that
label: Paragraph

text: they were not French.
label: Paragraph

text: The building offered a bold vision of a new kind of monument that, instead of being
label: Paragraph

text: pompous and elitist, would be populist and fun. Its thinking reflected a number of
label: Paragraph

text: influences: Le Corbusier’s principles of pilotis (Stilts), the free plan, and the occupiable
label: Paragraph

text: roof; the provocative avant-garde visions of Archigram and Cedric Price; and ideas about
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated systems buildings as advanced by architects including Jean Prouvé and
label: Paragraph

text: Ezra Ehrencrantz. The architects organized the building as a disarmingly simple
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular volume overlooking an enormous new public square. Pushing structure,
label: Paragraph

text: services, and circulation to the exterior created vast open floors—each providing 7500
label: Paragraph

text: square meters of column-free space—that fulfilled the internal flexibility required by the
label: Paragraph

text: competition brief. The envelope itself, inspired by a famous unbuilt scheme for the
label: Paragraph

text: Maison de la Publicité (1935) on the Champs Elysées by the German architect Oscar
label: Caption

text: Nitzchke, was to be an information machine animated by changing images and text.
label: Paragraph

text: The completed building, built under political pressure and to an extremely fast
label: Paragraph

text: timetable, is remarkably faithful to the com-petition scheme. It is one of the outstanding
label: Paragraph

text: achievements of the century and of the movement that subsequently would be called
label: Paragraph

text: High Tech. A fastidious attention to detail that far surpassed conventional building
label: Paragraph

text: technology of the time complements the building’s formal simplicity, setting new
label: Paragraph

text: standards for both the architectural profession and the building industry.
label: Paragraph

text: Like the Eiffel Tower built a century earlier, the Pompidou Center uses technology to
label: Paragraph

text: capture the spirit of the time. Happold and Rice were determined to use cast steel for the
label: Paragraph

text: structure of the building. Although cast iron had been widely used in the 19th century, it
label: Paragraph

text: had been supplanted by steel alloys that were less brittle and by rolling processes that
label: Paragraph

text: were more efficient. Marrying 19th-century techniques with 20th-century knowledge of
label: Paragraph

text: fracture mechanics, Rice was particularly interested in using cast steel as a way of
label: Paragraph

text: reintroducing the human imprint of craft into techniques of industrial mass production.
label: Paragraph

text: A single row of columns along the east and west facades carries enormous castings
label: Paragraph

text: called gerberettes, named in honor of Heinrich Gerber, a 19th-century German bridge
label: Paragraph

text: engineer who developed the cantilever principle that defines the structural concept of the
label: Paragraph

text: building. The gerberettes, connected to the columns with giant steel pins, are rotating
label: Paragraph

text: arms with the inboard end shaped to carry 44.8-meter clear spanning steel trusses on
label: Paragraph

text: seated connections without welds or bolts. To counterbalance these loads, “sputnik”
label: Paragraph

text: bosses at the outer ends of the gerberettes are tied to the foundations with a series of
label: Paragraph

text: tension rods. The gerberettes are shaped to reflect structural forces and, appropriately in
label: Paragraph

text: view of Rice’s intentions, also have been described as strongly anthropomorphic.
label: Paragraph

text: The 95,000-square-meter building—which includes a mix of art galleries, design
label: Paragraph

text: centers, libraries, theaters, cinemas, and restaurants—was constructed in just four-and-
label: Paragraph

text: one-half years. To compress the construction program, the steel superstructure, like many
label: Paragraph

text: of the building components, was prefabricated during the 26-month period when the cast-
label: Paragraph

text: in-place concrete foundations, mechanical plant rooms, and parking floors were built
label: Paragraph

text: below grade. Following a diplomatic intrigue, the steel contract controversially was
label: Paragraph

text: awarded to the German firm Krupp. The steel was brought to Paris by rail and, because of
label: Paragraph

text: its enormous scale, transported to site at night on specially designed trucks. The
label: Paragraph

text: contractors assembled the superstructure in vertical slices without scaf-folding. With an
label: Paragraph

text: astounding 1500 tons of steel erected per month, it took just eight months to complete
label: Paragraph

text: both frame and floors. Like the primary structure, the enclosure and secondary systems of
label: Paragraph

text: the building were all designed as prefabricated kits of parts.
label: Paragraph

text: In the public imagination, the Pompidou Center is embodied in the color-coded vertical
label: Paragraph

text: services risers and mechanical plant
label: Title

text: Pompidou Center, Paris
label: Caption

text: Designed by Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers (1977)
label: Caption

text: © Michael Dedandcé
label: Caption

text: Pompidou Center, aerial view from a distance
label: Caption

text: © Gianni Berengo Gardin
label: Caption

text: that define the east facade and the public escalators that are hung in clear plexiglass and
label: Paragraph

text: steel tubes along the west facade. Viewed from the narrow medieval streets that surround
label: Caption

text: the site, the services—characterized as irreverent, strident, and playful—express the
label: Paragraph

text: radical spirit of the building. Although the envelope was not realized as an information
label: Paragraph

text: machine, the escalators and public circulation galleries animate the west facade, making
label: Paragraph

text: it an extension of the square. The public promenade rises far above the rooftops of the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding historic quarter to reveal spectacular panoramic views of Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: Following the completion of the Pompidou Center and an adjacent building for the
label: Paragraph

text: Institute for Research and Coordination of Acoustics and Music (IRCAM) in 1977, the
label: Paragraph

text: partnership of Piano and Rogers ended. Propelled to international prominence by the
label: Paragraph

text: success of the Pompidou Center, each went on to achieve a distinguished reputation in his
label: Paragraph

text: own right. Their subsequent individual collaborations with Peter Rice, ended by Rice’s
label: Paragraph

text: untimely death in 1992, produced a number of distinguished buildings noted for both the
label: Paragraph

text: advancement and humanization of technology.
label: Paragraph

text: PONTI, GIO 1891-1979
label: Title

text: Architect and designer, Italy
label: Title

text: One of the most accomplished and prolific Italian architects of the 20th century, Gio
label: Paragraph

text: (Giovanni) Ponti was not only an architect but also a poet, painter, ceramist, graphic
label: Paragraph

text: artist, and designer of exhibitions, theater costumes, glassware, tableware, furniture,
label: Paragraph

text: lighting fixtures, and ocean-liner interiors.
label: Paragraph

text: Ponti graduated with a degree in architecture from the Milan Polytechnic in 1921. That
label: Paragraph

text: same year, he set up a studio with architects Mino Fiocchi and Emilio Lancia. Later, he
label: Paragraph

text: went into partnership with Lancia—forming Studio Ponti-Lancia (1926-33)—and then
label: Paragraph

text: with engineers Antonio Fornaroli and Eugenio Soncini—forming Studio Ponti-Fornaroli-
label: Paragraph

text: Sancini (1933-45). This became Studio Ponti-Fornaroli-Rosselli in 1952, when Alberto
label: Paragraph

text: Rosselli became a partner. After Rosselli’s death in 1976, Ponti continued work with
label: Paragraph

text: Fornaroli.
label: Paragraph

text: Ponti’s early works, such as the house he designed for himself and his wife (née Giulia
label: Paragraph

text: Vimercati) at no. 9, Via Randaccio (1925), in Milan; Villa Bouilhet, Garches (1926), in
label: Caption

text: Paris; and the furnishing for Palazzo Contini-Bonacossi (1931), in Florence reflect the
label: Paragraph

text: Novecento ftaliano’s neoclassic revivalism that was prevalent at the time.
label: Paragraph

text: The creation of the Movimento Italiano per I’Architettura Razionale (Italian
label: Paragraph

text: Movement for Rational Architecture) in 1927 presented Italian architects with the
label: Paragraph

text: opportunity to discard their reliance on the classical effects of arches and columns for a
label: Paragraph

text: new approach to architecture, one that took into account new developments in building
label: Paragraph

text: technology. Through his architectural work, his writings in Domus magazine (which he
label: Paragraph

text: founded in 1928), and his involvement with the Triennial Exhibitions of Milan, Ponti
label: Paragraph

text: promoted a renewal of Italian architecture and decorative arts and transformed the
label: Paragraph

text: “classic” language into a rationalist vocabulary. In his articles and books, such as La
label: Paragraph

text: Casa all’ftaliana (1933; House Italian Style), he imparted his conviction that architecture
label: Paragraph

text: must always preserve some national characteristics.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1930s, Ponti produced the Domuses, or “typical houses” (1931-36) in Milan; the
label: Paragraph

text: Universal Exhibition of the Catholic Press (1936) in Vatican City; and the first
label: Paragraph

text: Montecatini Building (1936) in Milan. In these projects, he gradually abandoned the
label: Paragraph

text: neoclassical conventions and replaced them with a rationalist system of aesthetics. The
label: Paragraph

text: first Montecatini building also marks his first integrated project. Here he designed not
label: Paragraph

text: only the building but also the fittings, appliances, and furniture.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1940s, Ponti’s efforts were dedicated to writing, painting, and industrial
label: Paragraph

text: design, but during the 1950s, Ponti was very productive architecturally. He traveled to
label: Paragraph

text: Brazil, Mexico, Venezuela, the United States, and the Middle East. He carried out a
label: Paragraph

text: series of projects in some of these countries, such as Villa Planchart (1955) and Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Arreaza (1956) in Caracas, an auditorium on the eighth floor of the Time and Life
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1959) in New York, and a building for government offices (1958) in Baghdad.
label: Paragraph

text: It is during this decade that Ponti produced his most renowned building: the Pirelli
label: Paragraph

text: Skyscraper (1955-58) in Milan. An office block of over 30 stories, it was at one time the
label: Paragraph

text: tallest building in Europe and still is one of the world’s most refined and elegant tall
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. Lessons inherent in the design of this building have been absorbed all over the
label: Paragraph

text: world. Pier Luigi Nervi, acting as structural engineer, contributed to the building’s
label: Paragraph

text: elegant stature by designing a structure based on two full-width reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: diaphragm walls that reduce in size toward the top. The thickness of the floors was
label: Paragraph

text: dispensed with by making them taper at the edge. This allowed Ponti to design a facade
label: Paragraph

text: that does not have the arbitrary repetitiveness of curtain walling but, instead, one that
label: Paragraph

text: emphasizes the finiteness of the building and creates the illusion of lightness.
label: Paragraph

text: The quest for lightness in mass was an underlying element in Ponti’s architecture. The
label: Paragraph

text: concept of using walls as screens to give a sense of transparency first appeared in his
label: Paragraph

text: competition project for the Palace of Water and Light at the “E42” Exhibition (1939) in
label: Caption

text: Rome. The idea was further developed in the Pakistan House Hotel (1963) in Islamabad,
label: Paragraph

text: the Church of San Francesco (1964) in Milan, the Church for the Hospital of San Carlo
label: Paragraph

text: (1966) in Milan, and the facade of the INA building at no. 7 Via San Paolo (1967) in
label: Caption

text: Milan. It culminated in the Taranto Cathedral (1970) and the Denver Art Museum (1971)
label: Paragraph

text: in Denver, Colorado, where the walls are purely an enclosure surrounding the volume
label: Paragraph

text: within.
label: Paragraph

text: Ponti’s 60-year architectural practice was paralleled by a host of other activities.
label: Paragraph

text: Commencing with his public debut at the Biennial Exhibition of the Decorative Arts in
label: Paragraph

text: Monza in 1923, Ponti became involved in the organization of the subsequent Triennial
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition (known as the Ponti Triennale) in Milan as a member of the executive
label: Paragraph

text: committee. From 1923 to 1930, he worked at the Manifattura Ceramica Richard Ginori
label: Paragraph

text: in Milan and Sesto Fiorentino, changing the company’s whole output. From 1936 to
label: Paragraph

text: 1961, he was professor on the permanent staff of the Faculty of Architecture at the Milan
label: Paragraph

text: Polytechnic. In 1941
label: Paragraph

text: Denver Art Museum, designed by Gio Ponti (1971)
label: Caption

text: © G.E.Kidder Smith/CORBIS
label: Caption

text: he resigned as editor of Domus and set up the magazine Stile, which he edited until 1947.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1948 he returned to Domus, where he remained editor until his death. He also wrote an
label: Paragraph

text: article in every one of the 560 issues of the magazine. He designed fabrics for the Jsa
label: Paragraph

text: factory from 1950 to 1958. In 1957 he created the Superleggera, or Ponti-chair, for
label: Paragraph

text: Cassina. Light enough to be lifted with one finger, the Superleggera chair has become a
label: Paragraph

text: universally classic feature.
label: Paragraph

text: Ponti’s vitality was proverbial among those who knew him. He worked relentlessly to
label: Paragraph

text: promote Italian culture and over the years produced work that maintained the freshness of
label: Paragraph

text: experiment and influenced generations of Italian designers and architects.
label: Paragraph

text: POPE, JOHN RUSSELL 1873-1937
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: After World War I, John Russell Pope’s neoclassical architecture helped define an
label: Paragraph

text: American national image as the United States took on grandiose powers and managerial
label: Paragraph

text: confidence. Pope sought to create a nationally recognized American architecture along
label: Paragraph

text: conservative Roman and Greek classical design. From his earliest proposals for the
label: Paragraph

text: Lincoln Memorial and the proposal requested by Assistant Secretary of the Navy
label: Title

text: Franklin D.Roosevelt to romanize Alfred Mullett’s State, War, and Navy Building to his
label: Paragraph

text: completed plans for the National Gallery of Art, Scottish Rite Temple, Constitution Hall,
label: Caption

text: Pharmaceutical Building, National Archives, and Jefferson Memorial, no one else would
label: Paragraph

text: so successfully dominate the look and space of the U.S. capital.
label: Paragraph

text: Pope studied architecture under William Robert Ware at the Columbia University
label: Paragraph

text: College of Mines. After graduating from Columbia in 1894, he won both the McKim
label: Paragraph

text: Traveling Fellowship and the first student award granted by the American School of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture in Rome (later the American Academy in Rome). After a year and a half in
label: Paragraph

text: Rome, Pope attended the Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris. These experiences marked
label: Paragraph

text: Pope’s architecture for the rest of his career. The influence of the Beaux Arts school as
label: Paragraph

text: well as his personal connection to Charles Follen McKim set Pope on a path of large-
label: Paragraph

text: scale public buildings of neoclassical design that relied on a wide range of classical
label: Paragraph

text: tropes. These ideas, as well as landscape, art, and writing, created a sense of reflection for
label: Paragraph

text: the visitor. Also of some significance to Pope’s early career and future success was his
label: Paragraph

text: matriage to Sadie Jones, the stepdaughter of Henry Walters, a cousin of the Delano
label: Paragraph

text: family—a fact not lost on Franklin Delano Roosevelt.
label: Paragraph

text: Pope apprenticed with Bruce Price, an architect notable for his domestic Shingle style.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1905 Pope opened his own office. During this time, his chief intellectual mentor,
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Follen McKim, became the architectural adviser on the Senate Park Commission,
label: Paragraph

text: where he designed the dome for the first building the Senate Park Commission built on
label: Paragraph

text: the north side of the National Mall, the United States National Museum, which is now the
label: Paragraph

text: Natural History Museum. Along with Daniel Burnham, McKim played a central role in
label: Paragraph

text: the creation of a planned monumental core for Washington, D.C., that followed the
label: Paragraph

text: neoclassical design of the Capitol and James Hoban’s White House. McKim and
label: Caption

text: Burnham were picked by Senator James McMillan of Michigan, chairman of the Senate
label: Paragraph

text: Committee on the District of Columbia, to be the architectural advisers for the Senate
label: Paragraph

text: Park Commission. The Senate Park Commission’s plan to memorialize Abraham Lincoln
label: Paragraph

text: became one of the most significant design programs of the National Mall. In 1911
label: Paragraph

text: Congress appropriated money to create the Lincoln Memorial Commission, which began
label: Paragraph

text: an 11-year process of designing and locating the monument to Lincoln. The commission
label: Paragraph

text: requested that Pope and Henry Bacon, both protégés of McKim, prepare designs for the
label: Paragraph

text: memorial, but the commission finally chose Bacon’s beautiful adaptation of the
label: Paragraph

text: Parthenon for the western end of the Mall.
label: Caption

text: Pope’s work was to come later. During the first two decades of the 20th century, he
label: Paragraph

text: designed classically inspired mansions: the Robert and Katharine McCormick House, the
label: Paragraph

text: John R. McLean House, and the Henry White House, all in Washington, D.C. In 1929 he
label: Paragraph

text: contributed a classical addition to the Constitution Hall and designed the National City
label: Caption

text: Christian Church. This work, along with his work on the Baltimore Museum of Art
label: Paragraph

text: (1929) and connections to Roosevelt, made him the preeminent architect for the nation’s
label: Paragraph

text: capital during the third decade of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Pope’s American Pharmaceutical Association Building (1933) was so cleanly designed
label: Paragraph

text: that it received some praise from modernists for its compatibility with Bacon’s Lincoln
label: Paragraph

text: Memorial. However, his other projects would not receive such positive notices from the
label: Paragraph

text: modernists. In 1937 Frank Lloyd Wright attempted to convince Franklin Roosevelt that
label: Paragraph

text: Washington, D.C., needed to represent a distinctly American architecture and not just
label: Paragraph

text: repeat the historicist styles of Europe. No one was more responsible than Pope for the
label: Paragraph

text: miles of columns in the national capital.
label: Paragraph

text: Pope’s most successful building is generally agreed to be the National Gallery of Art
label: Paragraph

text: (1936-41), in which he revised the Roman Pantheon as a Beaux Arts temple of art. The
label: Paragraph

text: exterior view of the building is designed to prepare the visitor for entry to the building.
label: Paragraph

text: The exterior volumes of the building express the plan and elevation of the building.
label: Paragraph

text: Andrew Mellon, the major art donor to the national collection, selected pink Tennes-see
label: Paragraph

text: marble for the exterior. The color of the solid blocks of marble gradually lightens toward
label: Paragraph

text: the top of the walls to keep the large scale of the walls from being perceived as
label: Paragraph

text: overwhelming.
label: Paragraph

text: Built at the same time, the Jefferson Memorial was one of Pope’s least successful
label: Paragraph

text: buildings and provoked Wright to compose another letter to President Roosevelt
label: Paragraph

text: expressing his disdain for what he characterized as an “arrogant insult to the memory of
label: Paragraph

text: Thomas Jefferson.” Although the open monument, also inspired by the Roman Pantheon,
label: Paragraph

text: can appear as a restful gazebo from some vistas—mostly when viewed from across the
label: Paragraph

text: tidal
label: Title

text: National Archives building, Washington, DC (1935)
label: Caption

text: © Historic American Buildings Survey/Library of Congress
label: Caption

text: basin or the Potomac River—it fails to work as successfully as Bacon’s Lincoln
label: Paragraph

text: Memorial. Like the National Gallery of Art, it is a model example of Beaux Arts design,
label: Paragraph

text: in which architecture, sculpture, and engraved inscriptions are organized to create a sense
label: Paragraph

text: of balance and harmony.
label: Paragraph

text: Pope was consistently able to create monuments and buildings that captured the
label: Paragraph

text: popular taste of many Americans during the first half of the 20th century. Remarkably,
label: Paragraph

text: they retained a great deal of their appeal and presence during the changes of the second
label: Paragraph

text: half of the century, and that accomplishment has a lot to do with his architectural
label: Paragraph

text: language of classicism, which continues to speak to Americans about themselves and
label: Paragraph

text: their place in the world.
label: Paragraph

text: PORTLAND PUBLIC SERVICE BUILDING
label: Caption

text: Designed by Michael Graves; completed 1982 Portland, Oregon
label: Caption

text: After its completion in 1982, Michael Graves’s Portland Public Service Building
label: Paragraph

text: quickly became a major icon of Postmodernism, notable for its references, symbolism,
label: Paragraph

text: and ornament. With its stylized pilasters, rusticated surfaces, oversize keystone motif,
label: Paragraph

text: and strong colors, Graves’s design was clearly a turn away from modernism. Almost
label: Paragraph

text: immediately, Graves’s design became an icon representing the reinvented eclecticism of
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernism, and soon it became both an emblem and a target. For supporters of
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernist aesthetics and approaches to architecture, the Portland Building (Portland
label: Caption

text: Public Services Building) became an emblem of a renewal of architectural vitality.
label: Paragraph

text: Graves’s design represented an alternative to a fussy, intellectualized, and overly
label: Paragraph

text: complicated modernism that spoke to no one but the architectural elite. With the Portland
label: Paragraph

text: Building, architecture regained the symbols and syntax from past historical styles, thus
label: Paragraph

text: allowing the architect to communicate with a larger segment of the public. In contrast,
label: Paragraph

text: modernists, including Pietro Belluschi, attacked the design of the Portland Building and
label: Paragraph

text: the Postmodernist approach that it represented. Standing apart from its neighboring
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, the Portland Building represented a return of revivalist eclecticism—with a
label: Paragraph

text: new twist—that they had fought so valiantly to overcome in the early decades of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century.
label: Paragraph

text: In June 1979, the City of Portland sponsored a competition for the design of the
label: Paragraph

text: Portland Building. This new building was to house city offices and commercial offices on
label: Paragraph

text: the upper floors and to provide space for retail businesses at the street level. Philip
label: Caption

text: Johnson and his architectural partner John Burgee were appointed advisers to a
label: Paragraph

text: committee of jurors drawn from local political and business circles. In January 1980,
label: Paragraph

text: three competition finalists were chosen: Michael Graves, Arthur Erickson, and
label: Paragraph

text: Mitchell/Giurgiola. Graves’s design was declared the winner, but the city council,
label: Paragraph

text: unready to accept that design, called for a second competition between Graves and
label: Paragraph

text: Erickson. Graves was again declared the winner. Graves’s victory was in part the result
label: Paragraph

text: of his strict adherence to the stated budgetary restriction placed on the project. The
label: Paragraph

text: competition called for 362,000 square feet of interior space for just over $22 million, or
label: Paragraph

text: $51 per square foot. Graves’s plan was the only one that met these budgetary goals.
label: Paragraph

text: The decision to award Graves first prize was clearly influenced by Philip Johnson, who
label: Paragraph

text: was sympathetic to Postmodernist objectives. Portland’s city council had specified that it
label: Paragraph

text: wanted an excellent and exciting design that would symbolize civic pride and responsible
label: Paragraph

text: government.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, the Portland Building focused the attention of the architectural and popular
label: Paragraph

text: media on Portland. When the building
label: Paragraph

text: was opened in October 1982, the response was mixed. Certainly, this is the norm for any
label: Paragraph

text: architectural design that breaks with tradition. In the instance of the Portland Building,
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernism is expressed through a colorful exterior with dark red-brown verticals and
label: Paragraph

text: blue-green base contrasted with cream-colored walls while two-dimensional garlands
label: Paragraph

text: ormament the facades on the north and south sides. On the east and west facades, large
label: Paragraph

text: pilaster-like vertical bands of windows and wall topped with massive, projecting capitals
label: Paragraph

text: support a keystone-shaped segment made up of alternating bands of windows and bands
label: Paragraph

text: of painted concrete. Graves plays with color, spatial illusion, and architectural elements
label: Paragraph

text: from the classical canon to provide associations with past traditions of ornament. He also
label: Paragraph

text: suggested that a large symbolic sculpture be placed above the main entrance on Fifth
label: Caption

text: Avenue. Although omitted originally because of cost, a 25-foot-tall hammered copper
label: Paragraph

text: statue, Portlandia, by Michael Kaskey, was eventually added to the structure, giving
label: Paragraph

text: additional prominence to the main entrance. The design has been both criticized and
label: Paragraph

text: praised by architects and critics.
label: Paragraph

text: Praise comes from Gavin Macrae-Gibson: “It is not the cosmic harmony of the
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance, the Nature of the Enlightenment, or the machines of Utopian modernism but
label: Paragraph

text: the nature of the new sublime that holds the fragments of the Portland Service Building in
label: Paragraph

text: uneasy unity” (see Macrae-Gibson, The Secret Life of Buildings, 1985). Macrae-Gibson
label: Caption

text: admired Graves’s juggling act that provides active balance of forms and symbols. In
label: Paragraph

text: referring to the three finalists for the competition, Philip Johnson exclaimed, “It was
label: Paragraph

text: perfectly clear as we opened the submissions that only one spoke of genius” (Jencks,
label: Paragraph

text: 1983). Susan Douibilet, on the other hand, found fault with the lack of integration with
label: Paragraph

text: the park across Fourth Avenue to the east of the structure. Belluschi asserted, “So they
label: Paragraph

text: demolish the hated glass box and erect the enlarged juke box or the oversized beribboned
label: Paragraph

text: Christmas package, well-knowing that on completion it will be out-of-date” (Bosker). A
label: Paragraph

text: supporter of Michael Graves, Charles Jencks, provides a more balanced response: “The
label: Paragraph

text: Portland [Building] still is the first major monument of Post-Modernism, just as the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus was of Modernism, because with all its faults it still is the first to show that one
label: Paragraph

text: can build with art, ornament and symbolism on a grand scale in a language the
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants can understand” (Jencks, 1983).
label: Paragraph

text: PORTMAN, JOHN C., JR. 1924
label: Caption

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: John Portman’s self-declared mission as an architect was to create an architecture for
label: Paragraph

text: people. He combined his skills as entrepreneur, developer, architect, and real estate
label: Paragraph

text: manager to reinvigorate downtown Atlanta, a city that at the time Portman began his
label: Paragraph

text: practice in 1953 had not built a high-rise building since 1930. If Portman did little to
label: Paragraph

text: house Atlanta’s citizens, he was intent on designing better environments for work:
label: Paragraph

text: functional marketplaces for buying and selling and attractive hotels for tourists,
label: Paragraph

text: conventioneers, and traveling businessmen. His Atlanta Merchandise Mart (1961)
label: Caption

text: initiated the development of Peachtree Center, where he would continue to build for
label: Paragraph

text: nearly 40 years. Perceiving the city as fundamentally an economic and social entity,
label: Paragraph

text: Portman resolved to return the historic agora to modern Atlanta.
label: Paragraph

text: It was there, at the Hyatt Regency (1967), that Portman introduced the modern atrium
label: Paragraph

text: hotel, transforming the urban hotel, as traditionally found in dense congested downtowns,
label: Paragraph

text: to a new, experiential structure. The old form was re-created, traditionally enclosed
label: Paragraph

text: spaces opened out in order to create active internal public environments promoting social
label: Paragraph

text: interaction and positive human response. Multistoried, ivy-clad balconies oriented hotel
label: Caption

text: rooms and corridors inward to a 21-story atrium. The hotel lobby became a piazza, with a
label: Paragraph

text: textured floor inspired by European cobblestone streets and patterned sidewalks. Natural
label: Paragraph

text: light, water, and trees softened concrete surfaces, and the free movement of pedestrians
label: Paragraph

text: animated the urban space perceived as an internal park or oasis within the city. Portman
label: Paragraph

text: gave further expression to the life of the space through the dynamic vertical movement of
label: Paragraph

text: space-age style, glass-enclosed elevator cabs rocketing through the skylight overhead to a
label: Paragraph

text: rotating rooftop restaurant called Polaris.
label: Paragraph

text: Portman enlarged the Hyatt in subsequent years and added two more hotels to
label: Paragraph

text: Peachtree Center: the Westin Peachtree Plaza (1976) and the Marriott Marquis (1985).
label: Paragraph

text: The latter was a theatrical demonstration of architectural space-making that broadened
label: Paragraph

text: the hotel atrium at its base (to dramatize the interior effect} and extended the volume
label: Paragraph

text: upward to a staggering 50 stories in height. Office slabs as well as enlarged and newly
label: Paragraph

text: built exhibition and market structures continued a coordinated expansion of Peachtree
label: Paragraph

text: Center throughout the 1970s and 1980s until Portman crowned the complex in 1993 with
label: Paragraph

text: the 60-story office tower, One Peachtree Center.
label: Caption

text: In addition to Peachtree Center, Portman’s other multiuse urban centers included
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance Center (1976) in Detroit and the Embarcadero Center (1974, 1976) in San
label: Paragraph

text: Francisco. He has applied his concepts about livable environments for work, market, and
label: Paragraph

text: hotel to suburban sites in Atlanta at Riverwood (1989) and Northpark Town Center
label: Paragraph

text: (1986, 1989). Northpark projected an 18-year, edge-city development to incorporate
label: Paragraph

text: office towers, hotels, and nearly one million square feet of shopping mall, but the project
label: Paragraph

text: was cut short by the recession of the early 1990s, by which time only two office towers
label: Paragraph

text: had been constructed. Portman’s Marina Square hotels and shopping mall (1987) in
label: Paragraph

text: Singapore and his Shanghai Center (1990) in China spread his ideas internationally.
label: Paragraph

text: Portman’s architectural language embodied an eclectic modernism. His influences
label: Paragraph

text: range from such disparate figures as Louis Kahn (whose monumental geometry,
label: Paragraph

text: exquisitely surfaced concrete, and use of light Portman admired) to Edward Durell Stone
label: Paragraph

text: (to whose bourgeois ornamentalism and stylizing Portman could not always remain
label: Paragraph

text: immune). When competing markets forced Portman in 1986 to redesign the lobby of his
label: Paragraph

text: 1976 Westin Peachtree Plaza Hotel, he adopted the artificial historicism of
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernism and transformed the lobby into a classical masquerade, a stage-set of
label: Paragraph

text: architectonic props of the kind Charles Jencks has decried as the carnivalesque.
label: Paragraph

text: Portman’s remodeling was an effort to redress a constricted concrete-encased hotel lobby
label: Paragraph

text: that was originally little more than the leftover space
label: Paragraph

text: Portman, John C., Jr. (United States)
label: Caption

text: R.Howard Dobbs University Center, Emory University, the Asbury Circle
label: Caption

text: entrance (1986)
label: Title

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: around the elevator core. Portman took a lesson from the Mediterranean bazaar and
label: Paragraph

text: crowded into the lobby an assemblage of elongated arcades, pedimented pavilions, and
label: Paragraph

text: glittering lights; attracted by published images of a now upscale hotel, the people
label: Paragraph

text: returned.
label: Paragraph

text: One of Portman’s most successful projects outside the arena of commerce and trade
label: Paragraph

text: was the Emory University Student Center (1986) in Atlanta, sited on an axis with his
label: Paragraph

text: earlier Physical Education Center (1983). Portman preserved the exterior facade of
label: Caption

text: architects Ivey and Crook’s dining hall (1926) as a backdrop for a theatrical interior space
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed by a semicircle of terraced balconies reminiscent of theater loges, dress circles,
label: Paragraph

text: and balconies. The classicism of the integrated dining hall elevation appears to be
label: Paragraph

text: onstage, and the whole calls to mind Andrea Palladio’s Teatro Olimpico (1580) in
label: Paragraph

text: Vicenza, Italy. This referential focal point is set against elements of Le Corbusier-
label: Paragraph

text: inspired white modernism outside, where pi/otis and interpenetrating ramps join a formal
label: Paragraph

text: geometry shaping the main entry. The travertine-like surface richness of the exterior
label: Paragraph

text: walls and trim references as well the marble cladding were perhaps inspired by Kahn and
label: Paragraph

text: Emory’s earlier architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The quintessential Portman project is the beach house he designed for himself on Sea
label: Paragraph

text: Island, Georgia—a 22,000-squarefoot retreat named Entelechy Il (1986). It was one of
label: Paragraph

text: Portman’s most controversial projects but was unquestionably his most personal.
label: Paragraph

text: Although it embodied Portman’s life experiences and public work, it also expressed in
label: Paragraph

text: very personal ways his various interests in art, including his own painting and sculpture,
label: Paragraph

text: and it reveals Portman as a modernist who is open to a wide range of eclectic possibilities
label: Paragraph

text: in design. The name Entelechy is inspired by the Aristotelian concept of “becoming,” and
label: Paragraph

text: the beach house followed Portman’s creation of Entelechy | (1964), the architect’s
label: Paragraph

text: suburban home in north Atlanta. Entelechy | was the early progenitor of Portman’s
label: Paragraph

text: fundamental vocabulary. It was the first significant project to generate Portman’s forms,
label: Paragraph

text: architectural conceits, and environmental design devices—including “exploding
label: Paragraph

text: columns,” water and plantings, and a geometric ordering in plan—and to employ art
label: Paragraph

text: objects as appointments—all features later evidenced in his hotel and urban center
label: Paragraph

text: complexes. In the same way, Entelechy II recapitulated and embodied in visual form a
label: Paragraph

text: life enriched by travel, reading, observing, and studying art.
label: Paragraph

text: Entelechy Il was a synthesis of house and museum, studio and retreat, weekend
label: Paragraph

text: vacation home and monumental megastructure. The house provided enclosed garden
label: Paragraph

text: settings, poolside terraces, courtyards, lawns, and traditional rooms in which to display
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture and paintings that its architect-owner admired, including reduced-scale
label: Paragraph

text: maquettes of sculptural forms that adorn major public spaces in Portman’s urban projects.
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, the studio-retreat was a workplace for Portman’s own production of art.
label: Paragraph

text: Since the mid-1980s, Portman has expanded his artistic range by creating art in other
label: Paragraph

text: media: abstract expressionist paintings filled with the colors and light of the South; metal,
label: Paragraph

text: stone, and bronze figural sculptures; furniture (including his delightful Rickshaw Chair
label: Paragraph

text: [1985] made for the poolside at Sea Island); and large-scale abstract, yet referential, pop
label: Paragraph

text: sculptures inspired by such disparate personalities as Mickey Mouse, Dolly Parton, and
label: Paragraph

text: Cyclopes Polyphemus.
label: Paragraph

text: This Pop side of Portman’s work suggests that as a popular modernist in architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: his kindred spirits extend from the heroic form-makers of the 1950s and 1960s to such
label: Paragraph

text: commercial stylists as Morris Lapidus. Despite his thoughtful introspection about his
label: Paragraph

text: work, the public admires him not for the intellectual content of his work but for his
label: Paragraph

text: inherent romanticism. His travel experiences in the East and West have been as rich as
label: Paragraph

text: those of the most cosmopolitan of his contemporaries. His intention always has been to
label: Paragraph

text: gather these disparate forces, influences, and stimuli in service to the creation of
label: Paragraph

text: environments for life and work—architectural spaces embodying human values and
label: Paragraph

text: promoting social interchange. If his buildings may be said to display a signature, it is
label: Paragraph

text: reflected in their references to fundamentals: to nature, to art, and to an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: beauty based in humanistic and organic principles.
label: Paragraph

text: Portman’s The Architect as Developer (1976, with Jonathan Barnett) and John Portman
label: Paragraph

text: (1990, with Paolo Riani and Paul Goldberger) offer the best overviews of Portman’s
label: Paragraph

text: work. The first focuses on his joint role as developer and architect (as does the 1969
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Forum article on Atlanta’s downtown development); the second includes
label: Paragraph

text: color photographs of Portman’s major projects. Saxon treats Portman’s prototypical
label: Paragraph

text: atrium hotels historically as well as from the viewpoint of design, fire safety,
label: Paragraph

text: construction, and other technical perspectives. “Back to Babylon” discusses the
label: Paragraph

text: prototypical atrium hotel masterpiece, the Regency Hyatt House (Hotel) in Atlanta.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: PORTOGHESTL, PAOLO 1931
label: Title

text: Architectural historian and Architect, Italy
label: Title

text: Paolo Portoghesi, an architectural historian in Italy, single-handedly revived interest in
label: Paragraph

text: baroque architecture in the 1960s, leading to important contributions to Postmodern
label: Paragraph

text: design and theory. A series of books and articles include Guarino Guarini (1956),
label: Paragraph

text: Borromini nella cultura europea (1964), Roma barocca (1966), Bernardo Vittone (1966),
label: Caption

text: Francesco Borromini (1967), and Borromini, architettura come linguaggio (1967;
label: Paragraph

text: Borromini, Architecture as Language). Every historian of Italian baroque architecture
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledges Portoghesi for generating interest in this area. Subsequently, during the
label: Paragraph

text: 1970s and 1980s, Portoghesi was a leading figure in the Postmodern movement in Italy
label: Paragraph

text: and beyond, both as a historian and as an architect. In the 1990s, Portoghesi has been a
label: Paragraph

text: leading figure in the Architecture and Nature movement in Italy. He is a prodigious
label: Paragraph

text: architect as well as a prolific writer and is recognized internationally as an articulate critic
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture and urban projects.
label: Paragraph

text: Portoghesi was born in Rome in 1931 and graduated from the University of Rome in
label: Paragraph

text: 1957. From 1962 to 1966, he taught the history of criticism at the Faculty of Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: in Rome. He was also professor of the history of architecture at the Milan Polytechnic
label: Paragraph

text: from 1967 to 1979 and the dean there from 1968 to 1976. In 1966 he was elected a
label: Paragraph

text: member of the Accademia di San Luca, Italy’s most prestigious arts academy. Since 1979
label: Paragraph

text: he has been the director of the architecture section at the highly important Venice
label: Paragraph

text: Biennale. There he received great praise for making important progress in the
label: Paragraph

text: advancement of Italian architectural culture. He currently teaches architecture at the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Rome. He recently moved his studio from Viale Aventino in Rome to
label: Paragraph

text: Calcata, a medieval borgo 30 miles north of Rome, where he lives in a house that he
label: Paragraph

text: restored.
label: Paragraph

text: Portoghesi’s other books include /nfanzia delle macchine (1968; The Infancy of
label: Paragraph

text: Machines), Victor Horta (1969), Le inibizioni dell’architettura moderna (1974; The
label: Paragraph

text: Inhibitions of Modern Architecture), Dopo /’architettura moderna (1980), and
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodern, L’architettura nella societa post-industriale (1982). In 1997 he published an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition catalog called Arte e natura, and a new book, Natura e Architettura, was
label: Paragraph

text: published in 1999. Important architectural projects include the Casa Balsi (1961), the
label: Paragraph

text: Casa Bevilacqua (1973), the Church of the Holy Family in Salerno (1974), and the
label: Paragraph

text: Mosque and Islamic Cultural Center (1984) in Rome. Whereas many architectural
label: Paragraph

text: historians and architects have learned from Portoghesi’s writings about baroque
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and contemporary architecture, several writers have in turn made Portoghesi
label: Paragraph

text: the subject of their own books and articles. The long list of authors includes Francesco
label: Paragraph

text: Moschini, Mario Pisani, Carlo Argan, and Christian Norberg-Schulz, a conclusive
label: Paragraph

text: testimony to Portoghesi’s importance to 20th-century architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: As a historian, Portoghesi was influenced mainly by the methods of Carlo Argan and
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolf Wittkower. Like them, he has always seen architecture as a language, with a
label: Paragraph

text: particular vocabulary and syntax. This approach has dominated his analyses of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in its historical context and its relevance to contemporary practice. He even
label: Paragraph

text: went so far as to classify the various design motifs incorporated by Francesco Borromini
label: Paragraph

text: as language tropes to explain the architecture in terms of language itself. A
label: Paragraph

text: Mosque, Rome, designed by Paolo Portoghesi (1984)
label: Caption

text: © John Hendrix
label: Title

text: freedom from restraint can be seen as common to Portoghesi’s career: the baroque, the
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodern, and art and nature all suggest his theoretical interests in an architecture that
label: Paragraph

text: embraces discipline and spontaneity in its study of the past.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout his career, Portoghesi’s architecture reflects his preoccupations as a
label: Paragraph

text: historian. His early work is based on the appropriation and reinvention of baroque forms.
label: Paragraph

text: A historical consciousness is present in all his designs, especially those of the
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodern period, in which he sought, both as a historian and as an architect, a new
label: Paragraph

text: language of architecture. His most successful designs contain the presence of history, yet
label: Paragraph

text: they are free from the restraints of the formalized systems of 20th-century architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and modernism. In the Postmodern movement, Portoghesi found sympathy in the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Philip Johnson, Michael Graves, and Stanley Tigerman, among others, which he
label: Paragraph

text: introduced to a receptive Italian audience in his book Postmodern. The themes from this
label: Paragraph

text: book evolved to include Portoghesi’s more recent concern with the relation between
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and nature. In this ageless relationship, he seeks to develop and explain
label: Paragraph

text: architecture as a natural organism, an “architecture born of architecture.” According to
label: Paragraph

text: Portoghesi, the, architect is seen as an element in a great biological process in which
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is seen as an instrument for understanding this process. Portoghesi’s
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, for example, has been characterized as “crystallized music.” For inspiration,
label: Paragraph

text: Portoghesi has looked to the work of Frank Lloyd Wright and Louis Kahn, among others,
label: Paragraph

text: who brought a profound understanding of nature and architecture to the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: profession. As always, Portoghesi continues to search for new languages of architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: new forms of expression, always rooted in the study and lasting memory of history.
label: Paragraph

text: POST OFFICE SAVINGS BANK, VIENNA
label: Caption

text: Designed by Otto Wagner; completed 1904
label: Caption

text: Designed by Viennese architect Otto Wagner, the Post Office Savings Bank was
label: Paragraph

text: completed in 1904. A member of the Viennese Secession, Wagner was educated at the
label: Paragraph

text: Weiner Technische Hochschule, or Polytechnique (a program modeled on the Paris
label: Paragraph

text: L’Ecole Polytechnique), and the prestigious Bauakademie in Berlin, where he was
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by members of the Schinkelschule.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner’s approach to architecture at the turn of the century was essentially an
label: Paragraph

text: amalgamation of the rationalism of the Schinkelschuler (members of the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: Schinkel School, so named after the 19th-century German architect Karl Friedrich
label: Paragraph

text: Schinkel) and the 19th-century “architects of the Ringstrasse” (Gottfried Semper and
label: Paragraph

text: Karl von Hasenauer). Yet Wagner’s polytechnical education also made him aware of the
label: Paragraph

text: significance of technology and impending social change for architecture. Like his
label: Paragraph

text: predecessor Gottfried Semper, his awareness led him to formulate an antiacademic
label: Paragraph

text: position—one against the stodgy rule-based and tradition-bound education of the Vienna
label: Paragraph

text: Academy of Fine Arts. Supported by Wagner, architects Josef Maria Olbrich (Wagner’s
label: Paragraph

text: chief assistant) and Josef Hoffman (his most prized student) joined with two prominent
label: Paragraph

text: Viennese artists, Gustav Klimt and Koloman Moser, to form the Viennese Secession in
label: Paragraph

text: 1897. Under the skilled leadership of Klimt, the Secession group developed a new vision
label: Paragraph

text: for architecture, inscribing Ver Sacrum, a publication devoted to the aims and ideas of the
label: Paragraph

text: Secessionists, with works and ideas expressive of their revolutionary approach to the arts
label: Paragraph

text: and architecture. The Secessionist claims and actions were indeed revolutionary. Wagner
label: Paragraph

text: stood as an elder statesman of the group, supporting not only the program of the Viennese
label: Paragraph

text: Secession but also its leaders and adherents through his pedagogy and his works of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: A principal example of Wagner’s embrace of Secessionist ideas for architecture is his
label: Paragraph

text: design for the Imperial and Royal Vienna Post Office Savings Bank, known as the
label: Caption

text: Postsparkasse. The building, completed in two phases (1904-06 and 1910-12), is
label: Paragraph

text: regarded as one of the primary examples of early modern architecture. Although
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner’s Secessionist colleagues—Klimt, Moser, and to some degree Olbrich and
label: Paragraph

text: Hoffman—were caught up in esoteric and utopian visions, Wagner remained attentive to
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary technical and social developments and their effect on architecture in a
label: Title

text: similar manner to those architects who understood the nature of building in their own
label: Paragraph

text: context as well as the context of the history of architecture. In an essay titled “Die
label: Paragraph

text: Qualitat des Baukiinstlers” (The Quality of the Building-Artist) in 1912, Wagner argued
label: Paragraph

text: that “the ultimate goal of the architecture of his day was to add a building from our own
label: Paragraph

text: time to the symphony of monumental buildings of all times” (Mallgrave, 1996). Yet he
label: Paragraph

text: did not discount the symbolist aspects of the Secessionist movements; elaborate and
label: Paragraph

text: diverse material and structural details adorn the building’s exterior and interior.
label: Paragraph

text: The essential form of the building is trapezoidal, with the main hall—the public area of
label: Paragraph

text: the building—axially placed in almost equal measure between the two major wings
label: Paragraph

text: extending perpendicularly from the building’s main facade. Programmed as large work
label: Caption

text: spaces that could be partitioned as necessary, the bank administration, postal offices, and
label: Paragraph

text: mailrooms are located in these wings.
label: Paragraph

text: The exterior of the building is sheathed in thin sheets of Sterzing marble, the details of
label: Paragraph

text: which Wagner obsessively manipulated to produce an undulating plane along the
label: Paragraph

text: projected face of the long, horizontal main facade. The building’s foundation is faced
label: Paragraph

text: with granite, and the bolts holding the granite slabs are countersunk, giving them even
label: Paragraph

text: greater prominence on the facade. Wagner also used aluminum—a material that only
label: Paragraph

text: since the mid-19th century could be mined in great quantities—to refine certain details on
label: Paragraph

text: the facade. The acroteria—an ornamental aluminum “structure” and details by the
label: Caption

text: Viennese artist Othmar Schimkowitz—crowns the building. The liberal and pointed use
label: Paragraph

text: of aluminum signals both Wagner’s embrace of advanced technologies and materials and,
label: Paragraph

text: in his accentuated use of materials and ornamental detailing, his adoption of Secessionist
label: Paragraph

text: ideas.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner continues his essay on the use of technology and materials throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance sequence and interior of the main public hall. The main facade, fronting a fairly
label: Caption

text: natrow street, opens out to the Ringstrasse across a public square that focuses the main
label: Paragraph

text: entry and extends slightly into the urban space. Immediately on crossing the building
label: Paragraph

text: threshold, the space of the city is compressed into a stair hall of elaborate plasticity.
label: Paragraph

text: Flowing forms and animated light stancheons reduce the scale of the space even further,
label: Paragraph

text: lending it an aura of mystery. The stair—reminiscent of Michelangelo’s stair leading into
label: Paragraph

text: the Laurentian Library or perhaps, more directly, similar to Schinkel’s elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: orchestration of public and private space in the entry of the Altes Museum—leads
label: Paragraph

text: through a cross axis of discrete secondary circulation just beyond the view of the public.
label: Paragraph

text: The entire procession—from the Ringstrasse through the square into the projected face of
label: Paragraph

text: the main entry—attenuates both time and the usual sense of separation accorded
label: Paragraph

text: thresholds; in this case, the movement from the scale of the city into a series of zones or
label: Paragraph

text: chambers suggests a new kind of threshold where one side (the public) borrows and
label: Paragraph

text: extracts from the other (the private) and vice versa. Accordingly, the spaces produce a
label: Paragraph

text: quizzical, even aporetic form of experience, a kind of “intimate urbanism”—a scenario
label: Paragraph

text: that
label: Paragraph

text: Post Office Savings Bank, Vienna, designed by Otto Wagner (1904)
label: Caption

text: © Howard Davis/GreatBuildings.com
label: Caption

text: Fritz Neumeyer suggests is akin to a railroad car or an “economical, efficient modern
label: Paragraph

text: mask” (Mallgrave, 1996). Wagner’s expressive use of form and materials on the interior
label: Paragraph

text: furthers the building’s sense of intimacy, in particular where the interior spaces are
label: Paragraph

text: punctuated by animated figures choreographed within dynamic, rarified spaces. With
label: Paragraph

text: great discipline, Wagner engages every available design opportunity, and stancheons,
label: Paragraph

text: details, light, and materials together engage the range of bodily senses. The light of the
label: Paragraph

text: public spaces, in particular the triple-naved counter space covered by the horizontal lights
label: Paragraph

text: of the etched glass ceiling and the glass-and-steel floor, suggests mysterious activities
label: Paragraph

text: just beyond that which can be seen. Distinctions between artificial and natural light are
label: Paragraph

text: blurred to this effect, and the concrete structure and mechanical systems, both designed
label: Paragraph

text: with contemporary technological advances in mind, only add to Wagner’s conflation of
label: Paragraph

text: symbolist ideas and built form.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout the interior, Wagner continued to fashion the spaces and furniture in
label: Paragraph

text: accordance with the tactility of the materials used (marble, glass, aluminum, ceramic tile,
label: Paragraph

text: and iron), pervasive diffuse light, and the animated details that constitute a seamless
label: Paragraph

text: marriage of function and ornament. In so doing, he wedded what were generally regarded
label: Paragraph

text: as two separate domains of architecture: urbanism and interior (private) space. The
label: Paragraph

text: sensuousness of the building’s interiors, suggested by the erotic attention to detail on the
label: Paragraph

text: exterior, promoted the unmasking of bourgeois sensibilities and restraint that defined fin-
label: Paragraph

text: de-siécle Viennese society—one of the primary aims of the Secessionists. Thus,
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner’s architecture was motivated by social and cultural aims; he understood that
label: Paragraph

text: buildings must strive to communicate significant cultural ideals, in particular those that
label: Paragraph

text: embraced change and development. Yet Wagner also affirmed another deeply held belief
label: Paragraph

text: for modern architects: the need to embrace modern technologies, materials, and
label: Title

text: constructional methods. The marriage of both in the Vienna Postal Savings Bank—social
label: Paragraph

text: and cultural responsibility and technological—marks an important step for the nascent
label: Paragraph

text: Modern movement in architecture.
label: Paragraph
