text: POSTMODERNISM
label: Title

text: Postmodernism became an intellectual buzzword within architectural circles in the 1980s
label: Paragraph

text: and 1990s. Traced to literary theory, where Postmodernism was used to refer to new
label: Paragraph

text: modes of fiction characterized by self-reflexivity, linguistic play, and the use of
label: Paragraph

text: referential frames within frames (the “Russian doll” effect), the term rapidly entered
label: Paragraph

text: other fields, such as the visual arts and architecture, to end up as a common denominator
label: Paragraph

text: to describe the cultural climate of the last decades of the 20th century. The precise
label: Paragraph

text: content of the term has always been elusive—the more it was in vogue, it seemed, the
label: Paragraph

text: less precise its meaning. In architecture, however, Postmodernism has been understood to
label: Paragraph

text: refer to a formal language that could clearly be distinguished from its modernist
label: Paragraph

text: predecessor because of its free use of historical, vernacular, or populist references. A
label: Paragraph

text: closer look, however, reveals that also in architecture, the confusing connotations and
label: Paragraph

text: paradoxical overtones of the term “Postmodernism” often gain the upper hand.
label: Paragraph

text: Important Publications and Exhibitions
label: Title

text: Charles Jencks, in his widely influential The Language of Postmodern Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (1977), argued that modern architecture had run its course. He even provided a precise
label: Paragraph

text: “death” of modernity: in St. Louis, Missouri, on 15 July 1972, at 3:32 p.m., when several
label: Paragraph

text: of the 14-story slab blocks that together formed Pruitt Igoe, a prize-winning social
label: Paragraph

text: housing scheme designed by Minoru Yamasaki and built only 20 years before, were
label: Paragraph

text: demolished—the final proof, thought Jencks, that modern architecture could not live up
label: Paragraph

text: to its promises and failed to provide its users with a liveable environment. Lacking in
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture, Jencks stated, was communication: modern architecture did not
label: Paragraph

text: conceive of buildings as conveyors of meaning and did not treat architecture as a
label: Paragraph

text: language. Modern architecture’s ideals of purity, transparency, and functional efficiency
label: Paragraph

text: (elements of the established International Style) failed to relate to a general public. A
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernism characterized by meaningful architecture that was sensitive to its urban
label: Paragraph

text: context would provide the substitute. For Jencks the most important feature of this new
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was its “double coding”: Postmodernist buildings communicate on two levels
label: Paragraph

text: at once—they convey a specific meaning to a minority public of experts (other architects,
label: Paragraph

text: art historians, and the like), who recognize formal references to historical styles,
label: Paragraph

text: innovations, or ironic gestures, while at the same time they communicate with a larger
label: Paragraph

text: public by invoking images that satisfy feelings of nostalgia and continuity. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: modernism rejected all popular references as kitsch, Postmodern architecture would
label: Paragraph

text: rather embrace the input of mass culture.
label: Paragraph

text: The criticism of modern architecture formulated by Jencks was not completely new. In
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s, there had been a growing literature that critiqued modern architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: urbanism for their abstract and anonymous character, their paternalistic attitudes, and
label: Paragraph

text: their negation of history. In 1961 Jane Jacobs published her widely influential book The
label: Paragraph

text: Death and Life of Great American Cities, in which she attacked modern urbanism for
label: Paragraph

text: failing to design liveable and safe environments. She argued that modern architecture’s
label: Paragraph

text: hatred of the street was especially noxious, for it led to the creation of monotonous,
label: Paragraph

text: monofunctional, utterly boring, and even unsafe dwelling environments in which social
label: Paragraph

text: interaction was hampered rather than stimulated. Robert Venturi complained in his 1966
label: Paragraph

text: Complexity and Contradiction that modernist ideals such as purity or directness led to a
label: Paragraph

text: kind of order that was rigid and stereotypical, whereas the complexity and contradictions
label: Paragraph

text: of ambivalent formal languages, such as mannerism, were much more capable of evoking
label: Paragraph

text: a continuing interest. Instead of the puritanically moral language of orthodox modem
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, he preferred “hybrid” rather than pure elements, compromising rather than
label: Paragraph

text: clean, distorted rather than straightforward, and ambiguous rather than articulated.
label: Paragraph

text: Aldo Rossi, in L’architettura della citta (1966; The Architecture of the City, 1982),
label: Caption

text: claimed that the modernist precept “form follows function” was naive. Study of the
label: Paragraph

text: history of the city reveals a persistence of historical forms rather than constant
label: Paragraph

text: innovation: urban forms tend to endure, even if their functions wither; this persistence
label: Paragraph

text: gives rise to the emergence of new functions. For Rossi the city (and context) is a crucial
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenon at the heart of architecture. A contemporary architecture, therefore, has to
label: Paragraph

text: base itself on the morphotypological study of the city (morphology referring to the
label: Paragraph

text: historical development of the form of the city, typology to the study and classification of
label: Paragraph

text: types in their relationship to the urban form).
label: Paragraph

text: The books of Jacobs, Venturi, and Rossi are some of the earliest significant
label: Paragraph

text: publications that analyzed a nascent Postmodernism. Other publications, such as Sibyl
label: Paragraph

text: Moholy-Nagy’s Matrix of Man (1968), Peter Blake’s Form Follows Fiasco (1977), and
label: Paragraph

text: Colin Rowe’s and Fred Koetter’s Collage City (1978) exerted influence. For Rowe and
label: Paragraph

text: Koetter, it was clear that modern architecture’s utopian beliefs had grown outdated. They
label: Paragraph

text: proposed a “collage city,” in which the modernist technique of collage would bring
label: Paragraph

text: together several urban fragments stemming from different traditions. The collision of
label: Paragraph

text: these fragments would lead to an amalgam of simultaneous order and disorder that would
label: Paragraph

text: allow for diverging interpretations, thus opening up the city for choice and freedom, as
label: Paragraph

text: well as multiplicity and ambiguity.
label: Paragraph

text: Another important impulse during the 1960s and 1970s concerned the interest in
label: Paragraph

text: popular and vernacular architecture. These populist architects criticized modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture for its paternalistic, bureaucratic, and antidemocratic character. Publications
label: Paragraph

text: such as Sibyl Moholy-Nagy’s Native Genius in Anonymous Architecture (1957), Bernard
label: Paragraph

text: Rudofsky’s Architecture without Architects (1964), or Amos Rapoport’s House, Form
label: Paragraph

text: and Culture (1969) provoked a genuine interest among a whole generation of architects
label: Paragraph

text: for such factors as culture, site, climate, or conventions, which had been more or less
label: Paragraph

text: neglected within modernism. John Turner (1968) pointed to squatter settlements as “an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that works” (p. 355), arguing that the housing problems in developing
label: Paragraph

text: countries should be solved by a bottom-up approach, relying on the experiences of self-
label: Paragraph

text: builders in squatter settlements, rather than by the top-down approach favored by large-
label: Paragraph

text: scale modernist housing programs. Advocacy planning and participatory design gained
label: Paragraph

text: influence in the United States as well as in Europe. At the same time, there was a
label: Paragraph

text: growing interest in built products such as Levittown, New York, or Las Vegas. This trend
label: Paragraph

text: culminated in Venturi, Scott Brown, and Izenour’s Learning from Las Vegas (1972), a
label: Paragraph

text: book in which they pleaded for the ordinariness of everyday life.
label: Paragraph

text: That Postmodern architecture also sought a different relation with history was
label: Paragraph

text: evidenced at the 1980 Venice Biennale The Presence of the Past, organized by Paolo
label: Paragraph

text: Portoghesi, who characterized the evolution away from modernist orthodoxy as “the end
label: Paragraph

text: of prohibition.” The exhibition featured work by Venturi, Charles Moore, Hans Hollein,
label: Paragraph

text: and Ricardo Bofill, as well as Aldo Rossi’s Teatro del Mondo, a small wooden theater,
label: Paragraph

text: built on a ship, echoing the shape of the monuments of the San Marco basin where it was
label: Paragraph

text: temporarily moored. Another important, dually sited exhibition—“Revision der
label: Paragraph

text: Moderne” (Frankfurt, 1984) and “Nouveaux Plaisirs d’Architectures” (Paris, 1985)—
label: Paragraph

text: included the work of Peter Eisenman, Frank Gehry, Rem Koolhaas, Oswald M.Ungers,
label: Paragraph

text: Hollein, Moore, Rossi, and Venturi. Curator Heinrich Klotz argued that Postmodern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture meant not a rejection but rather a revision of modern architecture, thus
label: Paragraph

text: aiming at a third way between reaction and rupture. For Klotz, Postmodernism embraced
label: Paragraph

text: fiction alongside function: a building is not just an instrument but also a work that
label: Paragraph

text: involves representation, poetics, and metaphor.
label: Paragraph

text: Tendencies within Postmodernism
label: Title

text: A dominant distinguishing strand of Postmodernism is that of the vernacular, relying on
label: Paragraph

text: popular images and references. Robert Venturi’s first building, the house for his mother,
label: Paragraph

text: Vanna Venturi (Philadelphia, 1962), cleverly played with the archetype of the house. Its
label: Paragraph

text: front facade looks appealingly conventional, but a closer look reveals that the interior
label: Paragraph

text: layout is quite complex and that what at first appears as a rather large chimney in fact
label: Paragraph

text: hides a shifted stair and a small extra room. The house features ornamental strips, mullion
label: Caption

text: windows, and arches—elements that were banished from any modernist building.
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Moore, Michael Graves, and Robert Stern have contributed a great deal to
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodern architecture in the United States. Moore’s Piazza d’Italia (New Orleans,
label: Caption

text: 1979) is without doubt one of the most influential projects exemplary of a populist and
label: Paragraph

text: pluralist approach. The Piazza was commissioned to reflect the identity of the Italian
label: Paragraph

text: community in New Orleans. Moore combined several references to Italy in the design,
label: Paragraph

text: such as columns in an Italian order, a raised platform in the form of the Italian boot, and a
label: Paragraph

text: fountain. At the same time, the design was built in a highly unusual combination of
label: Paragraph

text: materials, using not only marble and stainless steel but also neon and cardboard. Michael
label: Paragraph

text: Graves’s Portland Public Service Building (1982) in Portland, Ohio, and his Humana
label: Paragraph

text: Tower (1985) in Louisville, Kentucky, show how a Postmodernist language can be
label: Paragraph

text: applied to the facades of office buildings that in terms of program and plan differ only
label: Paragraph

text: slightly from their modernist predecessors. Stern did a similar exercise with his Point
label: Paragraph

text: West Place (1984) in Framingham, Massachusetts, but is also capable of reinterpreting
label: Paragraph

text: more faithfully historical languages, such as the Shingle style (e.g., Bozzi Residence,
label: Paragraph

text: 1983, East Hampton, Long Island).
label: Caption

text: Whereas in the United States the populist tendency relies on play with formal
label: Paragraph

text: elements, the best-known examples of participatory design are found in Europe; namely,
label: Paragraph

text: Lucien Kroll’s building for the Medical Faculty of the Catholic University of Louvain
label: Caption

text: (Brussels, 1974} and Ralph Erskine’s Byker housing project (Newcasde upon Tyne,
label: Caption

text: 1981). Kroll’s “La Mémeé,” as it is affectionately called, provides its student inhabitants
label: Paragraph

text: with the possibility of continuously redesigning the distribution of its interior spaces. The
label: Paragraph

text: building’s facades appear as hybrid collages bringing together a surprising diversity of
label: Paragraph

text: styles and references, implying that behind these walls a similar diversity of students has
label: Paragraph

text: found shelter. Erskine’s housing project in Newcastle resulted from a laborious design
label: Paragraph

text: process involving the future inhabitants. Where the project faces a highway at its northern
label: Paragraph

text: side, it features a very high wall with only a few openings. It shows a much more friendly
label: Paragraph

text: face toward the other side, sprinkling the facade with a multitude of balconies made of
label: Paragraph

text: wood and painted in bright orange and blue.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout the 1980s, however, in Europe the neorationalist tendency became
label: Paragraph

text: eclipsed by the populist model. Following the theoretical lead of Ross is Architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: the City, neorationalism favored an urban architecture imbued with analyses of historical
label: Paragraph

text: urban fabrics and forms. Instead of inventing new prototypes, neorationalists argued, new
label: Paragraph

text: contributions to the city should be based on the rational transformation of existing types
label: Paragraph

text: in accordance with their historical and urban context. This approach has been highly
label: Paragraph

text: successful in the work of Aldo Rossi, Giorgio Grassi, Rafael Moneo, and Oswald Ungers.
label: Paragraph

text: For example, Rossi’s Modena Cemetery (1985) combines multiple references to urban
label: Paragraph

text: forms and to symbols of life and death with an abstracted language to convey a feeling of
label: Paragraph

text: melancholy. Moneo designed the impressive Roman Museum (1983) in Merida, where he
label: Paragraph

text: included archaeological findings in the foundations of the building and managed to
label: Paragraph

text: provide the whole with a magnificent sense of Roman grandeur. Ungers’s highly
label: Paragraph

text: regarded Deutsches Architektur Museum (Frankfurt am Main, 1985) reinterpreted the
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of the urban villa by including in a bourgeois residence alongside the Main
label: Paragraph

text: River a house within a house, thus evoking a fundamental architectural theme appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: for a museum of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas the neorationalists saw their work as the continuation and transformation of a
label: Paragraph

text: progressive historical genealogy, there were other protagonists of the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction of the city who advocated a straightforward return to classicism. Authors
label: Paragraph

text: such as Demetri Porphyrios, Maurice Culot, and Leon Krier—with the occasional support
label: Paragraph

text: of England’s Prince Charles—argued that only a faithful reproduction of 18th-century
label: Paragraph

text: typologies and formal idioms would be capable of providing a true sense of urbanity.
label: Paragraph

text: According to such critics, industrialization and modernization had deprived architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and the city of their very essence, turning architecture into a soulless repetition of the
label: Paragraph

text: same and the city into a loose conglomerate of freestanding buildings without any streets
label: Paragraph

text: or squares in which public life could unfold. The desire for a return to preindustrial forms
label: Paragraph

text: has led to various built projects in Brussels (the complex in the Lakense Straat [1994]
label: Paragraph

text: designed by different architects commissioned by the Archives d’ Architecture Moderne),
label: Paragraph

text: London (Richmond Riverside [1988] by Quinlan Terry), and elsewhere. Its most
label: Paragraph

text: successful exponent might well be the increasingly influential movement of New
label: Paragraph

text: Urbanism in the United States, which combines urbanist ideas similar to those of Léon
label: Paragraph

text: Krier and Culot with an architectural imagery that refers to the American colonial
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of small towns.
label: Paragraph

text: A classicist revival can also be recognized in the work of the Belgian Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Vandenhove, who built in Belgium, Holland, and France. Vandenhove began his career
label: Paragraph

text: developing an eloquent modernist language in a series of individual houses and larger
label: Paragraph

text: projects, gradually transforming this language toward a more classicist idiom.
label: Paragraph

text: Vandenhove’s Theatre des Abesses complex (1996) in Paris faithfully finishes the urban
label: Paragraph

text: block it is part of, looking as if it has always been there. The buildings facing the street
label: Paragraph

text: are inconspicuous, built in the Parisian idiom familiar since the mid-19th century. The
label: Paragraph

text: theater, lying in the back, is more outspoken, featuring a Palladian entrance with a
label: Paragraph

text: fronton and a vestibule with pillars.
label: Caption

text: In the United States, Philip Johnson has, with his partner John Burgee, occasionally
label: Paragraph

text: designed projects that were faithful replicas of historical examples (e.g., his College of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture [1985], Houston, Texas, a replica of a project by Claude-Nicholas Ledoux),
label: Caption

text: but his Postmodernist stage is rather characterized by a free and informal use of historical
label: Paragraph

text: references (such as his AT&T Building [1984], New York).
label: Paragraph

text: There are also many architects whose work is clearly Postmodernist but who cannot be
label: Paragraph

text: categorized straightforwardly in any of the previously mentioned classifications (populist,
label: Paragraph

text: neorationalist, or classicist). Ricardo Bofill of Spain, for example, is well known for his
label: Paragraph

text: unorthodox use of classicist elements (columns, pilasters, pediments, cornices, and
label: Paragraph

text: moldings) within social housing schemes. James Stirling combined classicist references
label: Paragraph

text: with highly populist elements in his Neue Staatsgalerie (1984, with Michael Wilford) in
label: Paragraph

text: Stuttgart, a building that can be seen as exemplary of Postmodernism’s multiple
label: Paragraph

text: references, urban sensitivity, and witty connotations. Austrian Hans Hollein’s Abeitburg
label: Paragraph

text: Museum (1982) in M6nchengladbach, Germany, sensitively interacts with its urban
label: Paragraph

text: context, reinterpreting several building types and combining these into a difficult whole
label: Paragraph

text: that nevertheless has a clear signature. In Japan and in Southeast Asia, an eclectic attitude
label: Paragraph

text: has been especially prolific, as exemplified in the work of Arata Isozaki. His Tsukuba
label: Paragraph

text: Civic Center (Tsukuba, Japan, 1983) features a replica of Michelangelo’s Campidoglio
label: Caption

text: that is sunk under a plaza among other Western sources.
label: Paragraph

text: Such examples underline Jencks’s initial characterization of Postmodernism as a
label: Paragraph

text: radical eclecticism. Postmodern architects are free to borrow elements from the context,
label: Paragraph

text: from the past, from classicism, from popular culture, and from the architectural language
label: Paragraph

text: and concepts of modernism. The latter makes up for a confusing connotation, for it means
label: Paragraph

text: that sometimes the work of architects such as Richard Meier or Rem Koolhaas has been
label: Paragraph

text: labeled Postmodernist, although it clearly continues a modernist tradition (be it with
label: Paragraph

text: ironic or even cynical overtones).
label: Paragraph

text: The Postmodern Condition
label: Title

text: The common element among the different strands of Postmodernism in architecture
label: Paragraph

text: seems to be the rejection of the narrow focus on functionality and efficiency that
label: Paragraph

text: characterized modernism. Postmodernity is brought about by the loss of the grand
label: Paragraph

text: narratives of modernism: the modernist ideal of an increasing rationality that would result
label: Title

text: in progress and emancipation for all mankind has lost its validity and is seen as an
label: Paragraph

text: illusion. In this sense, Jencks’s diagnosis of Postmodernism in architecture corresponds
label: Paragraph

text: with the French philosopher Jean-Frangois Lyotard’s interpretation of La Condition
label: Paragraph

text: Postmoderne (1979; The Postmodern Condition). According to Lyotard, the main feature
label: Paragraph

text: of the Postmodern condition is that the grand narratives (in literature, history, art, and
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy} have come under scrutiny. Grand narratives are collectively shared ideas and
label: Paragraph

text: convictions that are communicated by repeatedly told stories that grant legitimacy to
label: Paragraph

text: institutions and values that form the basis of society. Such grand narratives, Lyotard
label: Paragraph

text: argues, have lost their self-evident character, and their importance tends to become
label: Paragraph

text: devalued in the minds of the people to whom they are addressed. Hence, there is a
label: Paragraph

text: general loss of shared ideals that can act as guidance for decisions about future
label: Paragraph

text: developments in our society.
label: Paragraph

text: This, however, is about as far as the correspondences between Jencks and Lyotard can
label: Paragraph

text: be stretched. Jencks describes Postmodernism as that which chronologically succeeds
label: Paragraph

text: modernism, whereas Lyotard discerns much more complex relations between the modern
label: Paragraph

text: and the Postmodern. In his later essays on Postmodernism, Lyotard claims that the
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between modern and Postmodern can never be simply chronological because
label: Paragraph

text: the modern includes in a certain way the Postmodern: modern is what is new, but this
label: Paragraph

text: means that it always follows on the previous thing, which was new (Lyotard, 1991).
label: Paragraph

text: Jencks, moreover, stresses the aspect of communication and symbolism: Postmodernism
label: Paragraph

text: treats architecture as a language, capable of conveying meanings, although he does not
label: Paragraph

text: question how cultures navigate such communication. One of the arguments raised by
label: Paragraph

text: Lyotard is precisely that the power of the grand narratives rests on their presumed
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensibility by all, whereas it has become clear to him that societies, generations,
label: Paragraph

text: and classes do not share a universal “metalanguage.”
label: Paragraph

text: Criticizing Postmodernism
label: Title

text: One of the earliest critics of Postmodernism in architecture was Jiirgen Habermas (1980,
label: Paragraph

text: 1981). Habermas blamed Post-modernism for hiding a conservative attitude behind a
label: Paragraph

text: seemingly progressive mask. For him, Postmodernists have given up the project of
label: Paragraph

text: modernity, the project of emancipation, to seek refuge in nice and pleasant but socially
label: Paragraph

text: irrelevant formal games. Americans David Harvey (1990) and Fredric Jameson (1991)
label: Paragraph

text: elaborated similar criticisms. According to Harvey, the post-Fordist version of capitalism
label: Paragraph

text: produces a need to express social distinctions among people and classes. This need brings
label: Paragraph

text: forth the fascination for ornaments and decorations, which are seen as codes and symbols
label: Paragraph

text: expressing social distinction. At the same time, these codes are not clearly legible but,
label: Paragraph

text: rather, tend to dissimulate the real geography of social unevenness by piling up a series of
label: Paragraph

text: images and reconstructions that act as costume dramas, rendering invisible the tragedies
label: Paragraph

text: going on behind the screens. Jameson also sees Postmodernism as a discourse generated
label: Paragraph

text: by the economic necessities of late capitalism in which the commodity consumption has
label: Paragraph

text: usurped modernity’s critique of those very forms and processes.
label: Paragraph

text: Kenneth Frampton (1980) has most rigorously criticized Postmodernism’s tendency
label: Paragraph

text: toward superficiality and sheer visual attractiveness. He pleads for a critical regionalism
label: Paragraph

text: that would uphold modernism’s longing for authenticity and critical responsibility while
label: Paragraph

text: at the same time respecting local factors of site, climate, and materials. Diane Ghirardo
label: Paragraph

text: (1991) blamed Postmodernist and other star architects for the fact that their return to art
label: Paragraph

text: and their interest in issues of appearance had diverted attention away from the toughest
label: Paragraph

text: issues in land development and the building process toward trivial matters of surface.
label: Paragraph

text: Further Reading
label: Title

text: Jencks (1977) wrote the publication introducing the term Postmodernism in the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural discourse. Jencks has later published a lot more on Postmodern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Of these later publications, the lavishly published book from 1987 is most interesting, as
label: Paragraph

text: in this publication Jencks narrows down Postmodernism to new classicism. Good surveys
label: Paragraph

text: of Postmodernism in architecture can be found in Klotz 1988 and Ghirardo 1996.
label: Paragraph

text: Portoghesi 1983 rather focuses on theoretical issues. Tzonis and Lefaivre 1976 is
label: Paragraph

text: especially recommended for giving an overview of participatory and populist tendencies.
label: Paragraph

text: General introductions into Postmodernist culture at large, also covering other fields
label: Paragraph

text: (philosophy, visual arts, performance art, film, television, and so on) are Connor 1997
label: Paragraph

text: and Woods 1999, and both also offer very helpful bibliographies. Docherty 1993 is a very
label: Paragraph

text: good reader collecting key texts in different fields. An early critique is formulated in
label: Paragraph

text: several essays in Foster 1983, with influential texts by A-O.Habermas, Frampton, Crimp,
label: Paragraph

text: and Baudrillard. Harvey 1990 and Jameson 1991 analyze Postmodernist culture from a
label: Paragraph

text: point of view that is informed by neo-Marxist analytical tools and that stresses the links
label: Paragraph

text: between cultural phenomena and the economic realities of late capitalism. Larson 1993
label: Caption

text: focuses on the links between architectural culture, economy, and the struggle for
label: Paragraph

text: professional excellence. Watson and Gibson 1994 is a very interesting reader, collecting
label: Paragraph

text: materials from architecture, urbanism, and geography.

text: POWER PLANT
label: Title

text: Energy consumption is directly related to gross national product, and the expansion of the
label: Paragraph

text: world market due to industrialization has accelerated the demand for energy. Originally,
label: Paragraph

text: small electrical generators were built by factory owners in Europe and the United States
label: Paragraph

text: for their own manufacturing, but in the 20th century the proliferation of electric lights
label: Paragraph

text: and appliances required the construction of centralized stations. Throughout most of the
label: Paragraph

text: century, power plants were icons of progress, but since the last quarter of the century, the
label: Paragraph

text: power plant has come to embody the threat of environmental degradation. The high-tech
label: Paragraph

text: exoskeletal aesthetic organic to many steam-generated power plants has been borrowed
label: Paragraph

text: and modified by architects such as Richard Rogers (England) and Eric Owen Moss
label: Paragraph

text: (United States). Curiously, however, power plants themselves have received almost no
label: Paragraph

text: attention, remaining virtually invisible features in the landscape unless identified as an
label: Paragraph

text: environmental hazard.
label: Paragraph

text: Power plants come in a variety of types and forms, but ultimately they do the same
label: Paragraph

text: thing: spin a turbine connected to an electric generator, thus producing electricity. One
label: Paragraph

text: type is distinguished from another by the mechanism used to spin the turbine. Power
label: Paragraph

text: plants are large-scale machines converting kinetic energy into electrical energy, usually
label: Paragraph

text: by transforming thermal energy into kinetic energy first. The form of a power plant often
label: Paragraph

text: expresses this process by architecturally compartmentalizing the stages of transference in
label: Paragraph

text: distinct structures connected by plumbing and other conveying systems. Some types are
label: Paragraph

text: spread across the landscape, however, taking advantage of the energy stored in local
label: Paragraph

text: meteorological phenomena, such as wind blowing through a pass, a river propelled
label: Paragraph

text: downstream by gravity, or the sun’s energy after it filters through the earth’s atmosphere.
label: Paragraph

text: Steam-Generated Power Plants
label: Title

text: Most power plants use steam to generate electricity, and the first public electric-
label: Paragraph

text: generating stations were built in Europe and the United States in the late 1880s. Boilers
label: Paragraph

text: of increasing size and complexity were developed in the 20th century, fired successively
label: Paragraph

text: by wood, coal, oil, and natural gas and then by nuclear, solar, and geothermal energy.
label: Paragraph

text: In steam-powered electricity generators, water is pumped into a steel chamber called a
label: Paragraph

text: boiler, where it is heated by the consumption of the fuel (e.g., the burning of coal}. The
label: Paragraph

text: resulting steam is then channeled to nozzles that inject the steam against the fins of a
label: Paragraph

text: turbine, forcing it to spin. Coal-fired plants are the most common, and a typical coal-
label: Paragraph

text: burning plant will produce 600 megawatts of energy in this process. The steam is then
label: Paragraph

text: condensed back into water and returned to the boiler or expelled for cooling either in a
label: Paragraph

text: cooling tower or in artificial ponds. Cooling towers are perhaps the largest and most
label: Paragraph

text: architecturally distinctive features of power plants, usually constructed of reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete and parabolically tapered from a broad base to a narrower top. Although
label: Paragraph

text: condensed steam is clean, if discharged prior to cooling in such a tower (or in its
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal equivalent, a cooling pond), its high temperature can disturb and even kill fish
label: Paragraph

text: and other wildlife. Waste from fuel, especially coal and oil, must also be expelled.
label: Paragraph

text: Chimney stacks, like boilers, became increasingly complex throughout the century, and a
label: Paragraph

text: system of scrubbers and filters have been developed to reduce levels of sulfuric dioxide,
label: Paragraph

text: which creates acid rain. By the 21st century, a coal-fired steam-generating electrical plant
label: Paragraph

text: could be expected to have three principal structures: the multistory boiler, the precipitator
label: Paragraph

text: or scrubber, and the chimney stack (the streamlined character of the chimney belies the
label: Paragraph

text: complex machinery inside its tapered conical form).
label: Paragraph

text: Non-Fuel-Burning Power Plants
label: Title

text: There are two types of active solar power electric-generating plants, and both are rare
label: Paragraph

text: compared to fuel-burning plants. The first reflects the sun’s rays by the use of hundreds
label: Paragraph

text: of reflectors arrayed in a field. The reflectors, called heliostats, are mechanically tilted to
label: Paragraph

text: follow the sun’s arc and to reflect light onto a parabolic receiver located approximately
label: Paragraph

text: 50 meters atop a tower to the south. Water is pumped to the receiver, where it is boiled by
label: Paragraph

text: the reflected thermal energy, thus producing steam. The experimental Eurelios plant at
label: Paragraph

text: Adrano, Italy, built in the 1980s, utilizes this process and produces 1 megawatt of
label: Paragraph

text: ectricity. The second type of solar plant uses semiconductors called solar cells to
label: Paragraph

text: directly transform the sun’s energy into electricity. Like the first type, a solar field
label: Paragraph

text: consists of hundreds of panels mechanically aligned to track the sun’s trajectory. The first
label: Paragraph

text: plant of this variety was built in Hysperia, California, in 1982 and produces as much
label: Paragraph

text: electricity as the Eurelios plant and occupies the same land area, approximately 1,000
label: Paragraph

text: square meters.
label: Paragraph

text: Hydroelectric plants skip the steam-generating process, using the force of water to spin
label: Paragraph

text: the turbines. Dams are the best-known hydroelectric generators and the most
label: Paragraph

text: monumental, but water may also be pumped to a high point (a hill or a tower) and then
label: Paragraph

text: allowed to rush down to the turbines. Wind farms utilize the kinetic energy of air currents
label: Paragraph

text: to produce electricity, and a typical farm consists of thousands of steel windmills 30 to 50
label: Paragraph

text: meters high, each installed with an electrical generator behind the propeller. The surreal
label: Paragraph

text: landscape of the wind farm is highly visible since they are often sited in passes where the
label: Paragraph

text: flow of air is funneled and where civil engineers are likely to situate highways. The
label: Paragraph

text: 6,500-turbine wind farm at Altamont Pass, California (1986), for example, generates only
label: Paragraph

text: 300 megawatts (at maximum capacity, which it rarely reaches}. By comparison, Hoover
label: Paragraph

text: Dam (1936) generates 650 megawatts, while the Volta Dam (1965) in Ghana generates
label: Paragraph

text: 750 megawatts (and nuclear power plants typically generate nearly 900 megawatts).
label: Paragraph

text: Although these two types of plants do not pollute the environment like fuel-burning
label: Paragraph

text: plants do, they still have an impact on the landscape. Dams, especially when built in a
label: Paragraph

text: series called a cascade (such as those in the Tennessee Valley in the United States or on
label: Paragraph

text: the Dnepr River in the former Soviet Union), often raise the water table in areas on the
label: Paragraph

text: o
label: Title

text: upstream side of the reservoir, even flooding basements in urban areas. Farms along
label: Paragraph

text: rivers can be inundated, impacting local economies and ecologies. Even windmills can
label: Paragraph

text: have adverse environmental effects since the siting of wind farms on migration routes
label: Paragraph

text: seriously disturbs the nesting and foraging habits of birds.
label: Paragraph

text: Geothermal power plants have been constructed since the last third of the 20th century
label: Paragraph

text: in Ireland, the United States, and parts of Europe. These plants, or fields, consist of a
label: Paragraph

text: scattering of wells several kilometers deep, each well comprised of two bores. The
label: Paragraph

text: objective is to tap in to the heat generated in the earth’s core and stored in the earth’s
label: Paragraph

text: mantle. Water is pumped into the first bore and heated by the magma or dry rock at the
label: Paragraph

text: bottom of the well. It is then pumped back out the second bore as steam, at temperatures
label: Paragraph

text: of 200 degrees Celsius or greater. The steam is then used to power the electric-generating
label: Paragraph

text: turbines.
label: Paragraph

text: Nuclear Power Plants
label: Title

text: Nuclear power was hailed in the third quarter of the 20th century as a clean source of
label: Paragraph

text: energy, and the first power plant was constructed in 1956 at Calder Hall in Great Britain.
label: Paragraph

text: With core meltdowns in the United States (Three Mile Island in 1979) and the Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: Union (Chernoby! in 1986), however, the former, optimistic view has been substantially
label: Paragraph

text: revised.
label: Paragraph

text: In nuclear plants, a steel-encased core consisting of thousands of fuel rods (usually
label: Paragraph

text: uranium, sometimes plutonium) encased in zircaloy creates heat via fission. Discovered
label: Paragraph

text: in 1938, fission is the splitting of uranium or plutonium atomic nuclei, a process that
label: Paragraph

text: creates energy in the form of heat. The fuel rods are cooled by either water (at high
label: Paragraph

text: pressure), gas, or liquid steel, which circulates through the core before it is pumped into
label: Paragraph

text: another steel container called a heat exchanger. There, the heated coolant is circulated in
label: Paragraph

text: pipes inside a secondary water supply that in turn becomes heated, thus producing steam.
label: Paragraph

text: In some cases, the heat exchanger is omitted, and water circulates directly from core to
label: Paragraph

text: turbine. More so than in other steam-generating systems, nuclear power plants require an
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate network of plumbing and instrumentation to monitor the flow of coolant.
label: Paragraph

text: Because radioactivity is generated during fission, the core and its coolant are extremely
label: Paragraph

text: hazardous, and containment structures are usually constructed around the reactor and the
label: Paragraph

text: heat exchanger. If too little coolant is present in the reactor core, fission accelerates, and
label: Paragraph

text: heat is increased to the point of meltdown. This is what happened at both Three Mile
label: Paragraph

text: Island and Chernobyl, and in the case of the latter, the remaining water in the core
label: Paragraph

text: became so hot under pressure that a steam explosion blew the roof off the reactor,
label: Paragraph

text: exposing the core to the atmosphere. The reactors at Chernobyl were not enclosed in a
label: Paragraph

text: containment building. After the catastrophe, the Soviets encased the dangerous reactor in
label: Paragraph

text: a steel-reinforced concrete bunker dubbed “the tomb,” an allusion to the 10,000-year
label: Paragraph

text: half-life of the contaminated material buried inside.
label: Paragraph

text: PRAGUE, CZECH REPUBLIC
label: Title

text: The Vitava River (Moldau), a natural axis of the settlement basin surrounded by hills,
label: Paragraph

text: forms a favorable area for habitation. The city of Praha (Prague) was established in the
label: Paragraph

text: 8th and 9th centuries, when the center of the then-Slavonic state was transferred to
label: Paragraph

text: Bohemia (Czech lands). The old town of Prague, with its narrow, winding streets along
label: Paragraph

text: with the churches, monasteries, and palaces, was built in the Romanesque period. The
label: Paragraph

text: new town, built as a medieval city, was established in 1348 by a royal edict issued by
label: Paragraph

text: Charles |V. At that time, the city, adorned by more than 100 churches and chapels with a
label: Paragraph

text: population of 50,000, was larger than London or Paris. Today, Prague holds more than
label: Paragraph

text: 1.5 million people. The epithet given to Prague—the Hundred Spire City—is more than
label: Paragraph

text: deserved, and this ancient character continues to define Prague’s 20th-century urban
label: Paragraph

text: setting.
label: Paragraph

text: In the middle of the 19th century, architecture became an instrument to obtain a
label: Paragraph

text: political autonomy from the Habsburg monarchy. One building in particular, the National
label: Paragraph

text: Theater, had been a political and cultural symbol for the rise and culmination of the
label: Paragraph

text: Czech national revival. Built from the national collection, the original theater, designed
label: Caption

text: by Josef Zitek, was located on the prominent Vltava riverfront and was completed in
label: Paragraph

text: 1881. Three months later, however, it burned down, only to prompt another collection to
label: Paragraph

text: rebuild the burned building. The theater, rebuilt by Josef Schulz, an associate of Zitek’s,
label: Paragraph

text: was constructed in 1883. Thus, the patriotic Czechs have been very emotional regarding
label: Paragraph

text: their National Theater and any changes with it or its surroundings.
label: Paragraph

text: Ever since 1918, when Prague became the capital of the new republic of Czecho-
label: Paragraph

text: Slovakia, proposals were made to modernize and enlarge the theater. Shortly after World
label: Paragraph

text: War II, it was determined that both the exterior and the interior of the National Theater
label: Paragraph

text: needed reconstruction and that the operation and running of the theater needed more
label: Paragraph

text: space for expansion. Two national design competitions were held, and a number of
label: Paragraph

text: design studies were made on the subject of expansion. The design submitted by the Brno
label: Paragraph

text: architect Bohuslav Fuchs was selected as the winner. However, reservations about the
label: Paragraph

text: decision-making process slowed down the design development of the project. After the
label: Paragraph

text: death of Fuchs in 1972, the team resigned from the project commission. The necessity of
label: Paragraph

text: the reconstruction overshadowed the expansion project. After seven years of work, in
label: Paragraph

text: 1983 the reconstruction and addition to the National Theater in Prague was completed in
label: Paragraph

text: time to mark the centennial. Although the result of the arduous effort is there, the polemic
label: Paragraph

text: is continuing. The relationship between old and new remains a topic of debate among
label: Paragraph

text: citizens of the city and the nation alike.
label: Paragraph

text: At the turn of the 20th century, historicism was countered by Jan Kotera (1871-1923),
label: Paragraph

text: Pavel Janak (1882-1956), Josef Gocar (1880-1945), and Otakar Novotny (1880-1959).
label: Paragraph

text: In the midst of Art Nouveau, these architects were characterized by rationalism. The first
label: Paragraph

text: important Art Nouveau design by Kotera, the Peterka House (1899-1900) on Wenceslas
label: Caption

text: Square, clearly expresses the different building uses on the street elevation. The
label: Paragraph

text: Mozarteum (Urbanek Department Store, 1912—13) is a symmetrical composition with the
label: Paragraph

text: ground-floor commercial storefront and second-floor ribbon-window fenestration. The
label: Caption

text: upper residential consists of three progressively upward-recessed bays of brick in-fill
label: Paragraph

text: framed into stepped concrete verticals. This dynamic facade predates Kotera’s later
label: Paragraph

text: Cubist period.
label: Paragraph

text: The Jan Stenc Publishing House (1909-11) by Novotny, finished in patterned bricks of
label: Paragraph

text: different colors, features a functional layout. Daylight pours into the printing press halls
label: Paragraph

text: through the large expanses of glass. Janak was at first the ideological leader who later
label: Paragraph

text: designed fine Functionalist buildings, relying on Cubist forms. The stately Reuinone
label: Caption

text: Adriatica Insurance Company building (1923-25) of a late Cubism, referred to as Rondo
label: Paragraph

text: Cubism, has a dominating presence on the busy Narodni Trida (the Nation’s Avenue).
label: Paragraph

text: However, the key buildings of Prague’s Cubism are Grocar’s House at the Black
label: Paragraph

text: Madonna (1912) and the Josef Chochol’s (1880-1956) tenement and single-family
label: Title

text: houses (1912-14) below Vysehrad Hill. Side chairs, armchairs, tables, desks, dressers,
label: Caption

text: and sofas were designed in Cubist language by Chochol, Gocar, Janak, and Novotny as
label: Paragraph

text: well as Vlastimil Hofman (1884-1964), Jiri Kroha (1893-1974), Antonin Prochazka
label: Paragraph

text: (1882-1945), and Rudolf Stockar (1886-1950).
label: Paragraph

text: The 1918 foundation of the democratic Republic of Czechoslovakia gave the
label: Paragraph

text: intelligentsia a new platform of liberal ideology. In 1920 an avant-garde group of artists,
label: Paragraph

text: writers, architects, musicians, and actors started a society called the “Devetsil” (the Nine
label: Paragraph

text: Powers). The group published a journal and organized lectures and exhibitions. The
label: Paragraph

text: ARDEV (the Architects of Devetsil) members produced studies of different housing
label: Paragraph

text: types. The “Purist Four’—Jaroslav Fragner (1898-1967), Karel Honzik (1900-66),
label: Paragraph

text: Evzen Linhart (1900-47), and Vit Obrtel (1901-88) with Josef Havlicek—were
label: Paragraph

text: instrumental in founding the ARDEV. In 1932 the art critic and theorist Karel Tiege, the
label: Paragraph

text: leader of Devetsil, published housing studies in the book Nejmensi byt (The Smallest
label: Paragraph

text: Flat). The ideas of communal housing came from the socialist ideas of Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivism. Novotny, on the other hand, was active in the “SVU (Society of the Fine
label: Paragraph

text: Artists) Manes.” The building for this important institution, which housed a gallery,
label: Paragraph

text: meeting rooms, and a restaurant, was designed in 1927-30 by Novotny. Straddling the
label: Paragraph

text: Vitava River and executed in a clear modern idiom, the Manes has held shows of
label: Paragraph

text: trendsetting artists and architects of Prague ever since.
label: Paragraph

text: To demonstrate new ideas of modern dwelling, Prague architects organized a housing
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition with goals similar to the Weissenhofsiedlung in Stuttgart (1927-29) or the
label: Paragraph

text: New House in Bmo (1928). Master planned by Janak, the Baba Housing (1928-32)
label: Caption

text: single-family homes were designed by Gocar, Janak, Jan E. Koula, and Linhart. The
label: Paragraph

text: family living was extended outdoors by means of large window openings, balconies,
label: Paragraph

text: verandas, and roof terraces. A new type of office building was defined in the Pensions
label: Paragraph

text: Institute (1929-34), designed by Havlicek and Honzik. The architects employed here the
label: Paragraph

text: quintessential elements of functionalist architecture: a uniform structural modular system,
label: Paragraph

text: expressed vertical circulation, ribbon windows bringing maximum daylight into a free-
label: Paragraph

text: plan interior, and a roof terrace.
label: Caption

text: Following the 1938 Munich Treaty, then the devastation of World War Il, the
label: Paragraph

text: Communist takeover in 1948, the invasion of Czechoslovakia by the Red Army in 1968,
label: Paragraph

text: and the political and social changes brought about by these events, Prague suffered many
label: Paragraph

text: setbacks. During the 41 years of the Communist Party totalitarian regime, architects were
label: Paragraph

text: expected to design in a government-dictated style called socialist realism. Functionalism
label: Paragraph

text: was condemned as an expression of bourgeois cosmopolitanism. The November 1989
label: Paragraph

text: “Velvet Revolution” marked the fall of the Communist government, and free Prague
label: Paragraph

text: emerged again.
label: Paragraph

text: In the last quarter of the 20th century, despite the totalitarian regime’s restriction of
label: Paragraph

text: free expression and the imposition of Moscow-style aesthetics, several new buildings
label: Paragraph

text: stand out as important contributions to 20th-century Prague architecture. These include
label: Paragraph

text: the Department Store “Maj” (1973-75) on the Narodni Trida by Miroslav Masak (1932-
label: Paragraph

text: ), Martin Rajnis (1944—-), and Johnny Eisler (1946—); the Tennis Stadium (1986-89) on
label: Paragraph

text: Stvanice Island by Jana Novotna (1946—) and Josef Kales (1934—); and the Retirement
label: Paragraph

text: Home (1983-89) at Chodov by Jan Lynek (1943-), Vladimir Milunic (1941—), Tomas
label: Caption

text: Kulik (1954—-), and Jan Louda (1949-). The husband-and-wife team of Jan Sramek
label: Paragraph

text: (1924-78) and Alena Sramkova (1929—) designed a key transportation hub of the Main
label: Paragraph

text: Train Station (1972-79) and the CKD Building (1976-83) on the Narodni Trida. The
label: Paragraph

text: Vitava riverfront has been complemented by the National Netherlands Building (1992-
label: Paragraph

text: 95), known as the “Fred and Ginger,” by Frank Gehry with Vladimir Milunic.
label: Paragraph

text: PRAIRIE SCHOOL
label: Title

text: The Prairie School was an indigenous Midwestern phenomenon. Beginning in the
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago suburbs during the 1890s, it spread outward through the entire region in the first
label: Paragraph

text: two decades of the 20th century. Many of its most distinctive achievements were in small
label: Paragraph

text: towns, such as Mason City, lowa, and Owatonna, Minnesota. Unquestionably, the
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual leader of the movement was Louis Sullivan (1856-1924), who developed a
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy that emphasized the organic quality inherent in a successful building. In his
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, by his writings, and by the force of his charismatic personality, he passed this
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy on to a group of young architects who became his disciples. Without doubt,
label: Paragraph

text: the most gifted of these was Frank Lloyd Wright, who was with Adler and Sullivan for
label: Paragraph

text: six years prior to his departure to found his own office in 1893. Wright saw the provision
label: Paragraph

text: of well-designed houses for the newly affluent Midwestern upper-middle class as a great
label: Paragraph

text: opportunity. His clients did not possess great fortune but were generally technological
label: Paragraph

text: entrepreneurs. Many had a taste for music. Wright gave them dwellings that responded to
label: Paragraph

text: the vision of Sullivan and that at the same time went beyond that vision to achieve a
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis very much his own. For the next 15 years, he pursued his goals with remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: vigor and great success. The first executed houses in which the new style was fully
label: Paragraph

text: visible were the Bradley house (1900) in Kankakee, Illinois, and the Ward Willits house
label: Paragraph

text: (1901) in Highland Park, Illinois. In the next few years, there followed a number of
label: Paragraph

text: important works, notably the Davenport, Dana, Heurtley, Huntley, and Thomas houses,
label: Paragraph

text: all finished by 1904. These houses had important elements in common: flowing interior
label: Paragraph

text: space, directional or centrifugal lines, generous low roofs with pronounced overhangs,
label: Paragraph

text: broad chimneys, reduced floor heights, rows of casement windows, geometric leaded
label: Caption

text: glass, and an intimate relationship to the site. The interiors featured furniture and
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes fabrics designed by the architect. Wright’s objective was to control every
label: Paragraph

text: aspect of the architectural experience. All were designed on a unit system, meaning that
label: Paragraph

text: they were based on a single module with a length equal to some specific architectural
label: Paragraph

text: element, often, as in the Willits house, the distance between center lines of window
label: Paragraph

text: mullions. None of these houses show any hint of historicism. Although most were located
label: Paragraph

text: in suburbs, with varying kinds of topography, all reflected the horizontal lines of the
label: Paragraph

text: prairie.
label: Paragraph

text: The sources of these designs, for Wright and for the gifted young men and women in
label: Paragraph

text: his Oak Park studio, were mixed. They owed something to the earlier Shingle style, and
label: Paragraph

text: they owed much to the contemporary English Arts and Crafts movement. The houses of
label: Paragraph

text: Voysey and the theoretical writings of C.R.Ashbee were discussed as they appeared in
label: Paragraph

text: the pages of The Studio. In addition, they owed a debt to Japanese art, which most of
label: Paragraph

text: them knew through prints (Hokusai and Hiroshige were familiar names). After 1904, the
label: Paragraph

text: year of the St. Louis World’s Fair, there was a bit of influence from Germany and
label: Paragraph

text: Austria. All these influences, however, were melded by Wright and the staff of his studio
label: Paragraph

text: into a distinctive Midwestern and American expression.
label: Paragraph

text: Among Wright’s studio apprentices, the most important were Marion Mahony, Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Burley Griffin, William Drummond, and Barry Byrne. All were substantially influenced
label: Paragraph

text: by Wright, and all in later years made substantial contributions of their own. Their
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaries spoke of a “New School of the Midwest.” Outside the studio, Hugh
label: Paragraph

text: Garden, Robert Spencer, and George Maher, at different times in their careers, produced
label: Paragraph

text: excellent designs in the Prairie School manner.
label: Paragraph

text: In Minneapolis the firm of Purcell and Elmslie developed its own distinctive version of
label: Paragraph

text: the style. By 1910 it was generally recognized in the nation’s architectural press that the
label: Paragraph

text: most progressive tendencies in American architecture were in the Mid-west. Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: own series of articles in The Architectural Record titled “In the Cause of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture” (1909) were perhaps the clearest evidence of this evaluation. International
label: Paragraph

text: recognition came with the publication of the famous Wasmuth folio on his work (Berlin,
label: Paragraph

text: 1910) and with the influential articles of Hendrik Berlage for the Schweizerische
label: Paragraph

text: Bauzeitung in 1911. These publications had substantial impact on the Modern movement
label: Paragraph

text: in Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: For Wright the climax of his Prairie period came with the great houses of 1908-09,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly the Robie (1908) and Coonley (1909) houses, the first in Chicago and the
label: Paragraph

text: second in Riverside, Illinois. Among public buildings, his major achievements were
label: Paragraph

text: Unity Temple (1904—05) in Oak Park and the headquarters for the Larkin Company in
label: Paragraph

text: Buffalo, New York, done in the same years. The Prairie School idiom, however, was not
label: Paragraph

text: one that lent itself easily to large public buildings and industrial structures. There are a
label: Paragraph

text: few of these. In the latter category, Hugh Garden made some noteworthy contributions
label: Paragraph

text: with the Grommes and Ullrich Building (1901), the Schoenhofen Brewery (1905), and
label: Paragraph

text: the Dwight Building (1910), all in Chicago. The last structure was for a printing company
label: Paragraph

text: and was framed in flat-slab concrete. The Prairie School architects also did a few
label: Paragraph

text: churches. Of these, Sullivan’s Methodist Episcopal Church (1910) in Cedar Rapids,
label: Paragraph

text: Iowa, with a contribution by George Elmslie, is perhaps the finest. On the whole,
label: Paragraph

text: however, the Prairie School aesthetic lent itself to houses and small commercial
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, and it is these building types by which its practitioners should be judged.
label: Paragraph

text: Prairie School architects attempted almost every problem in the decorative arts, and
label: Paragraph

text: they had great success with chairs, tables, case furniture, fabrics, and perhaps most
label: Paragraph

text: important of all, leaded glass; their achievements would have been impossible without
label: Paragraph

text: the cooperation of cabinetmakers such as John W.Ayers and glass studios such as
label: Paragraph

text: Giannini and Hilgart and the Linden Glass Company; and for Wright, the assistance of
label: Paragraph

text: the Milwaukee interior decorator George Niedieken was vital in such large commissions
label: Paragraph

text: as the Robie and Coonley houses and the May house (1909) in Grand Rapids, Michigan.
label: Paragraph

text: The architects saw building as a cooperative process in which client, designer, and artisan
label: Paragraph

text: all had important roles to play. Among themselves, they deplored the tendency of Wright
label: Paragraph

text: to claim all the credit for their achievement, as he commonly did after 1913-14.
label: Paragraph

text: In certain respects, the Prairie School style can be understood as an idiom that could be
label: Paragraph

text: employed by architects who had little or no contact with Wright, Sullivan, or Chicago.
label: Paragraph

text: For the central figures—Wright, Sullivan, Griffin, and Purcell and Elmslie—architectural
label: Caption

text: design was an act of faith, an optimistic faith in the liberal ideals of American
label: Paragraph

text: democracy. They liked to think
label: Paragraph

text: Arthur Heurtley House, Oak Park, Illinois, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright
label: Caption

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: of their architecture as “progressive” and strongly disliked the academic traditionalism of
label: Paragraph

text: McKim, Mead and White and their Eastern contemporaries. In fact, they viewed it as a
label: Paragraph

text: rehash of outworm European forms. The Prairie School manner, however, was sufficiently
label: Paragraph

text: attractive that it was sometimes employed by architects who had relatively little
label: Paragraph

text: sympathy with the ideals of the leaders. Thus, Osgood and Osgood in Grand Rapids, a
label: Paragraph

text: firm that was essentially eclectic, did two houses in a distinctly Prairie School manner.
label: Paragraph

text: These dwellings might well have been responses to client demand. Sidney Robinson and
label: Paragraph

text: Richard Guy Wilson have shown that lowa is dotted with buildings that have Prairie
label: Paragraph

text: School elements. The same kind of demonstration could easily be made for Minnesota,
label: Paragraph

text: Wisconsin, and Illinois. Wilson and Robinson also argue that the Prairie School had two
label: Paragraph

text: distinct and separate phases. The first has been identified as from 1900 to about 1920.
label: Paragraph

text: They date the second from Wright’s return to the Midwest in the 1930s and cite his later
label: Paragraph

text: Iowa houses and the work of Alfred Caldwell in Dubuque. This position is arguable, and
label: Paragraph

text: it has recently received support in Frank Lloyd Wright and Colleagues: Indiana Works
label: Paragraph

text: (Michigan City, Indiana, 1999). This exhibition catalog also includes certain projects by
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape architect Jens Jensen, whose stature in his field is comparable to that of
label: Paragraph

text: Wright in the building arts. Jensen certainly had a prominent role in the development of
label: Paragraph

text: the Prairie symbolism.
label: Paragraph

text: The gradual decline of the original Prairie School after 1914 was the result of several
label: Paragraph

text: broad historical factors. For a variety of reasons, the supply of clients willing to accept
label: Paragraph

text: the innovations advocated by the architects dwindled considerably. Women were
label: Paragraph

text: becoming increasingly important in American society, and as Thomas Tallmadge pointed
label: Paragraph

text: out, wives now received their education from magazines edited in Boston and New York.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1910 House Beautiful, which had always been sympathetic to the Prairie School
label: Paragraph

text: architects, moved its offices to New York. The last prairie houses appeared in its pages in
label: Paragraph

text: 1914. The story of Country Life in America is similar. Its last mention of a prairie house
label: Paragraph

text: was in January 1914, when it featured a dwelling in Seattle by Andrew Willatzen, who
label: Paragraph

text: had worked in Wright’s office and absorbed some of his thought. The general shift of the
label: Paragraph

text: publishing industry to New York had enormous consequences for the cultural life of the
label: Paragraph

text: entire nation, as it meant a homogenization of American culture. The Prairie School had
label: Paragraph

text: flourished as a healthy type of regionalism, and regionalism became unfashionable.
label: Paragraph

text: The architects themselves withdrew from the Midwestern scene. Wright’s personal life
label: Paragraph

text: was chaotic, and he spent much of the decade of World War | in Japan. Sullivan, the
label: Paragraph

text: philosophical leader of the group, was able to build only a handful of small banks and
label: Paragraph

text: gradually descended into poverty and alcoholism. Walter Burley Griffin and Marion
label: Paragraph

text: Mahony, two of Wright’s most talented apprentices, went to Australia in 1913 and spent
label: Paragraph

text: most of their careers in that country. Purcell went to Philadelphia in 1918 to enter the
label: Paragraph

text: advertising business and in 1922 moved to the West Coast because of ill health.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, the achievement of the Prairie School was substantial, and it left the Mid-
label: Paragraph

text: west a great legacy in the form of a large number of buildings that are sought out and
label: Paragraph

text: admired to this day.
label: Paragraph

text: PRECAST CONCRETE
label: Title

text: Precast construction typically refers to concrete that is manufactured in a factory rather
label: Paragraph

text: than at the site. Poured-in-place concrete, in contrast, is a process where formwork and
label: Paragraph

text: reinforcing bars are set and the wet concrete and its aggregates poured in the precise
label: Paragraph

text: position that they are to occupy in the completed building. Poured-in-place construction
label: Paragraph

text: allows contractors to tailor the various components of a building and more easily
label: Paragraph

text: compensate for minor discrepancies discovered during the course of a project. In many
label: Paragraph

text: cases, however, precast construction offers both technical and cost advantages. Precast
label: Paragraph

text: components are manufactured in factories, transported to the site, and then assembled and
label: Paragraph

text: fastened together on the job. They may or may not be reinforced, but if so, they are
label: Paragraph

text: usually prestressed.
label: Paragraph

text: The technical advantages of forming reinforced-concrete components in a factory first
label: Paragraph

text: involve environmental factors. Heat and humidity influence the length of time that
label: Paragraph

text: concrete requires to set and cure as well as its load-bearing strength. The factory
label: Paragraph

text: environment allows manufacturers to control these atmospheric variables far better than
label: Paragraph

text: at a site. Precast structural members are often designed at higher strength than most on-
label: Paragraph

text: site counterparts (which are designed typically for 3,000 pounds per square inch, 28 days
label: Paragraph

text: after pouring). Temperature can be raised in a factory, accelerating the amount of time
label: Paragraph

text: that concrete requires to cure. Also, reinforcing can be more precisely set into place, and
label: Paragraph

text: the tolerances and coverage of concrete around the reinforcing steel can be more
label: Paragraph

text: accurately controlled, thus producing more efficient structural components. Complex
label: Paragraph

text: rebar configurations and more accurate lapping of one rebar over another can be more
label: Paragraph

text: easily managed and inspected in a factory, where the movement of laborers and
label: Paragraph

text: technicians is not inhibited by on-site obstacles. Site conditions are also rarely conducive
label: Paragraph

text: to the pretightening of steel tendons, and thus prestressed structural sections are far easier
label: Paragraph

text: to construct in a factory setting. Prestressing is a process where steel cables called
label: Paragraph

text: tendons are anchored to the ends of formwork and tensioned before concrete is poured.
label: Paragraph

text: After the concrete hardens and gains sufficient strength, the cables are released. This
label: Paragraph

text: internally applies a precompressive stress, which potentially reduces or minimizes
label: Paragraph

text: undesirable tensile stresses created by the structural member’s own weight as well as the
label: Paragraph

text: load that it will have to support once installed in the building. Prestressing tends to
label: Paragraph

text: minimize cracking as well as de-flections. Finally, factory conditions also tend to allow
label: Paragraph

text: better control over the finished appearance of concrete, including surface sheen,
label: Paragraph

text: aggregate density, and color.
label: Paragraph

text: The cost advantages of precast construction derive from an economy of scale. Factory
label: Paragraph

text: settings are economical when manufacturing multiple copies of the same component.
label: Paragraph

text: Poured-in-place construction requires assembling the formwork for components on-site,
label: Paragraph

text: setting the rebar, pouring the concrete, and then removing the formwork for reassembly
label: Paragraph

text: at the next pour, usually requiring more time and labor than manufacturing the equivalent
label: Paragraph

text: part in a factory. This is important because it can have a significant impact on the overall
label: Paragraph

text: cost and length of time to complete a building project.
label: Paragraph

text: Precast construction comes with inherent limits, however, dictated primarily by the
label: Paragraph

text: problem of transportation. Manufactured components must be transported from the
label: Paragraph

text: factory to the building site via ship, train, or truck and sometimes by a combination of
label: Paragraph

text: means. Consequently, components must not be so long or heavy that they prohibit
label: Paragraph

text: transportation. Generally, components longer than 30 feet are impractical. Weight is an
label: Paragraph

text: especially crucial factor in transportation, and it is common for engineers to anticipate the
label: Paragraph

text: problem of transport by incorporating steel hooks or loops anchored in the concrete for
label: Paragraph

text: the purpose of lifting and lowering by crane. The cost-effectiveness of precast
label: Paragraph

text: construction can be compromised by building sites located in remote areas or in regions
label: Paragraph

text: where infrastructure is insufficient. A mountainous site, for example, may be a poor
label: Paragraph

text: choice for precast construction if existing roads twist and turn at radii that a large truck
label: Paragraph

text: cannot negotiate.
label: Paragraph

text: The ramifications of precast construction affect both engineering and aesthetics.
label: Paragraph

text: Construction schedules must be carefully planned so that needed components arrive on-
label: Paragraph

text: site when needed. Since some parts may be built on-site and others manufactured in a
label: Paragraph

text: remote factory, and in many cases precast components may be manufactured in separate
label: Paragraph

text: factories miles apart, the interface between components is a crucial concern of engineers
label: Paragraph

text: and architects. A kit-of-parts approach to construction encourages the manufacturing of
label: Paragraph

text: standardized parts that can fit together in a variety of configurations. Generally, irregular
label: Paragraph

text: building designs can be problematic, while modularity tends to be advantageous in
label: Paragraph

text: precast construction.
label: Paragraph

text: The most common precast structural components tend to be linear: beams, ribbed
label: Paragraph

text: beams (also called T beams), inverted T beams, solid flat slabs, hollow-core slabs, and
label: Paragraph

text: tilt-up wall panels. Unreinfbrced-concrete components include wall panels with specific
label: Paragraph

text: finishes either poured or applied as veneer. Unlike poured-in-place reinforced concrete,
label: Paragraph

text: precast construction lacks the structural advantage of continuity, where rebar segments
label: Paragraph

text: can be lapped in a series the entire length of a structure. This is why connections between
label: Paragraph

text: components require great care. Slip-slab construction is a hybrid method where floor
label: Paragraph

text: slabs are poured on grade at the site, then lifted into place by jacks secured to building
label: Paragraph

text: columns. This process is cost-effective for multistory buildings with repetitive floor
label: Paragraph

text: configurations since the forms do not need to be moved from one floor to the next.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the connection between floor slabs and columns requires the same expertise as
label: Paragraph

text: precast construction connections.
label: Paragraph
