text: PREDOCK, ANTOINE 1936
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: The architectural vision of Antoine Predock is spiritual, environmental, and symbolic.
label: Paragraph

text: His work, grounded in ideas derived from the varied landscapes of the American
label: Paragraph

text: Southwest, returns to architecture a mysterious connection with place and human feeling
label: Paragraph

text: that many believe has been eroded by 20th-century life. A key element in his approach to
label: Paragraph

text: design is context. For Predock, however, context goes beyond contextualism to embrace
label: Paragraph

text: the site and all that will happen there over time. Predock has applied his architectural
label: Paragraph

text: vision to a variety of building types, but his ideology is most vivid in his institutional
label: Paragraph

text: works—such as the Spencer Theater for the Performing Arts (1998) in Alto, New
label: Paragraph

text: Mexico; the Arizona Science Center (1997) in Phoenix; and the American Heritage
label: Paragraph

text: Center Art Museum (1993) at the University of Wyoming, Laramie—and in his designs
label: Paragraph

text: for domestic space, including the Venice House (1991) in Venice, California; the
label: Paragraph

text: Rosenthal House (1993) in Manhattan Beach, California; and the Hotel Santa Fe (1992)
label: Caption

text: at Euro Disney, outside Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: Predock’s work is affected by all his life experiences, ranging from a visit to the
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian pyramids to a ride on his motorcycle. He received his bachelor of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: degree from Columbia University in New York City in 1962 after beginning his
label: Paragraph

text: education at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque in 1957. While a student in
label: Paragraph

text: New York, he became involved in the art of dance. Predock translated the movement of
label: Paragraph

text: the body in dance into spatial elements within his architecture as both a strong
label: Paragraph

text: processional component and a focus on an accumulation of viewpoints. Through the
label: Paragraph

text: many different buildings of the complex, the Nelson Fine Arts Center (1989) at Arizona
label: Paragraph

text: State University in Tempe architecturally offers a number of processional choices that are
label: Paragraph

text: further multiplied by the transition from daytime to nighttime. The complex can also be
label: Paragraph

text: interpreted as a piece of performance art with its numerous balconies, arcades, loggias,
label: Paragraph

text: and steps, each providing a different stage for the user to engage and act on.
label: Paragraph

text: Predock’s early work was relatively modest in scale. After working for three years as a
label: Paragraph

text: designer in the offices of L.M.Pei and Partners in New York City and Gerald McCue
label: Paragraph

text: Associates in San Francisco, Predock founded his own firm in Albuquerque in 1967. The
label: Paragraph

text: four-person office built its reputation on houses and institutional buildings that blended
label: Paragraph

text: comfort with the vernacular Southwest image, depicted by Predock in the employment of
label: Paragraph

text: natural desert colors and contextual materials in a tough, defensive architecture. The 1986
label: Paragraph

text: completion of the Fuller House in Scottsdale, Arizona, marked the national and
label: Paragraph

text: international recognition of his bold, abstracted, and original style. The house is deeply
label: Paragraph

text: set into the earth and oriented with respect to the east-west axis, which provides the
label: Paragraph

text: potential heating and cooling properties of each room. Nature is brought into the design
label: Paragraph

text: through the inclusion of a sunrise terrace and a sunset tower separated by a circular pool,
label: Paragraph

text: which acts as the terminus of the water channel that runs parallel to the east-west axis of
label: Paragraph

text: the house.
label: Paragraph

text: Inspired by architects such as Louis ].Kahn and Frank Lloyd Wright, Predock included
label: Paragraph

text: with his regional sensibility the elements of the modern in his 1993 design of the Turtle
label: Paragraph

text: Creek House in Dallas, Texas. Giant limestone ledges recall the geologic setting of
label: Caption

text: Dallas, and the great glass wall recalls architecture of the International Style. The house,
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded with trees and plantings, provided a specialized setting for the patrons who
label: Paragraph

text: were avid bird-watchers. Not only do the plantings welcome the birds but also the siting
label: Paragraph

text: of the house along the major north-south migratory flyways greets the feathered
label: Paragraph

text: creatures. This same axis also became the dominant processional path through the house.
label: Paragraph

text: Predock’s interpretation of the Tucson, Arizona, environment dictated the design of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ventana Vista Elementary School (1995). From a distance, this “city for children” nestles
label: Paragraph

text: into the landscape and color palette of the desert site. At the heart of the complex,
label: Paragraph

text: Predock placed a large white tent, reminding the children of the larger environment and
label: Paragraph

text: imparting his notion that life in the desert was not always so predictable or sedentary. The
label: Paragraph

text: fourth- and fifth-grade neighborhood is located on the highest part of the site. The walls
label: Paragraph

text: of this neighborhood’s classrooms are easily opened up to the exterior by large rolled-up
label: Paragraph

text: garage doors. The second- and third-grade neighborhood revolves around spaces for
label: Paragraph

text: reading, such as the sorcerer’s terrace, and
label: Paragraph

text: American Heritage Center and University Art Museum, University of
label: Caption

text: Wyoming, Laramie, designed by Antoine Predock (1993)
label: Caption

text: © G.E.Kidder Smith/CORBIS
label: Caption

text: spaces for contemplation and dreaming, including the desert kaleidoscope, where
label: Paragraph

text: children can peer through cylindrical skylights into a shallow dome and out to the sky.
label: Paragraph

text: The sense of discovery continues for all children on the path to the celestial realm and the
label: Paragraph

text: solstice wall, the apertures of which not only frame distinct views of the landscape and
label: Paragraph

text: sky but also align with the sun during the summer and winter solstices. Spy holes in the
label: Paragraph

text: classroom walls enable children to catch a glimpse of their classmates at work.
label: Paragraph

text: Predock’s firm continues to receive outstanding commissions, including the San Diego
label: Paragraph

text: Padres Park at the Park in San Diego, California, and the Cornerstone Arts Center at
label: Paragraph

text: Colorado College in Colorado Springs. Underway at the University of Minnesota in
label: Caption

text: Minneapolis is the Gateway Center, a granite-clad geode attached to two parallel copper
label: Paragraph

text: boxes. Its architectural distinctiveness draws from Minnesota themes, particularly in the
label: Paragraph

text: 90-foot-high granite geode that evokes Lake Superior’s north shore. Fissures of glass,
label: Paragraph

text: allowing natural light in during the day and bathing the surrounding area with projected
label: Paragraph

text: light at night, crisscross the granite planes. The Gateway Center illustrates Predock’s
label: Paragraph

text: fascination with engineering and architecture, developed early in his career at the
label: Paragraph

text: University of New Mexico under the tutelage of his mentor, Don Schlegel.
label: Paragraph

text: Predock’s creative and insightful work has won numerous worldwide awards and has
label: Paragraph

text: been the subject of many architectural exhibitions. His projects, invigorated by the form
label: Paragraph

text: and spirit of the place, including its environment, rituals, and culture, have brought to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture a soul and character unknown in the work of many of his contemporaries.
label: Paragraph

text: Although his buildings are not easily copied in the formal sense, the ideology of his
label: Paragraph

text: design provides an exciting model for those practicing today. For Predock, architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: more than a fleeting moment in a designer’s mind. A building has a life all its own, one
label: Paragraph

text: that takes on a magical quality from things that come before, during, and after its original
label: Paragraph

text: conception. As Predock has stated, “We remind ourselves that we are involved in a
label: Paragraph

text: timeless encounter with another place, not just a little piece of land. All of the readings
label: Paragraph

text: that have accumulated and been assimilated there, that are imagined there, that may
label: Paragraph

text: happen there in the future—all of these collapse in time and become the raw material
label: Paragraph

text: with which we interact.”
label: Paragraph

text: PREFABRICATION
label: Title

text: Buildings are traditionally constructed by assembling materials and components of the
label: Paragraph

text: building trades according to an approved set of design drawings and specifications on a
label: Paragraph

text: given site. Having a smooth and timely pace for erecting buildings is highly dependent on
label: Paragraph

text: the quality and steadiness of supplies, the availability of qualified labor, a safe and
label: Paragraph

text: conflict-free working environment, and, last but not least, the weather. Because all these
label: Paragraph

text: more or less controllable variables pose substantial risks, the desire to standardize the
label: Paragraph

text: design and to relocate the production process into a highly controllable, productive
label: Paragraph

text: factory environment is an old dream of builders and clients alike. The technique dates
label: Paragraph

text: back to the early stages of industrialization, at the turn of the 20th century, with prime
label: Paragraph

text: examples being London’s Crystal Palace, built in 1851 for the Great Exhibition in Hyde
label: Paragraph

text: Park, London, by Joseph Paxton, and cast-iron building facades created for commercial
label: Caption

text: structures in the fire hazard-prone early metropolitan areas of our times.
label: Paragraph

text: The term “prefabrication” in architecture normally describes the assembly of buildings
label: Paragraph

text: or their components at a location other than the building site. With the help of this
label: Paragraph

text: method, the risk-creating variables of cost control, weather, and a dependable and,
label: Paragraph

text: because of repetition, experienced workforce helps to optimize the use of materials and
label: Paragraph

text: time in a controlled environment. Prefabricated units can range from singular building
label: Paragraph

text: parts that later find their way into a conventional on-site construction project, such as
label: Paragraph

text: doors, windows, and roof trusses, to room-size elements, from bathrooms to entire
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. Prefabrication can also take place on-site if the scope of the project is very
label: Paragraph

text: large, as in the case of housing developments of the 1960s, 1970s, and 1980s in Eastern
label: Paragraph

text: Europe, the former Soviet Union, and Scandinavia.
label: Paragraph

text: Historically, the main materials for prefabrication are wood, iron, and concrete. Early
label: Paragraph

text: traces of wood for prefabrication date back to the 1848 gold rush in the United States;
label: Paragraph

text: experiments with prefabricated housing units made of wood in Great Britain, Germany,
label: Paragraph

text: and Sweden were conducted between the two world wars. In 1850 in New York,
label: Paragraph

text: complete wooden houses where shipped as building kits to California in response to the
label: Paragraph

text: huge demand in the West. Several hundred housing units made of other materials, such as
label: Paragraph

text: corrugated galvanized iron, were imported from Manchester, England, completely fitted
label: Paragraph

text: with wallpaper, water closets, and furniture to satisfy the demand for housing in
label: Paragraph

text: California, where an established building industry was not yet available. Patented
label: Paragraph

text: plantation and camp buildings produced by lumber dealers in New York and Boston
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of a number of interchangeable parts and could be erected in hours. In Germany
label: Paragraph

text: the company of Christoph and Unmack, founded in 1882, produced load-bearing wood
label: Paragraph

text: panels for cabins and camp buildings that were shipped in very large quantities to many
label: Paragraph

text: parts of the world. The oldest known U.S. firm specializing in prefabrication was founded
label: Paragraph

text: in Boston in 1892. Ernest F.Hodgson manufactured dwellings of wood, which the firm
label: Paragraph

text: labeled in a patent, dating back to 1861, “the portable house.” Other derivatives of early
label: Paragraph

text: prefabrication in the United States are so-called mail-order houses. Companies such as
label: Paragraph

text: Sears, Roebuck, and Company (Newark, New Jersey), Montgomery Ward (Chicago,
label: Paragraph

text: Illinois), Aladdin Company (Bay City, Michigan), Gordon-Van Tine Company
label: Paragraph

text: (Davenport, lowa), and many others produced “precut” timber kits of parts, designed for
label: Paragraph

text: owner erection. Many might consider the system of precutting not to be a true
label: Paragraph

text: prefabrication process. The enormous number of produced units, the industrialized
label: Paragraph

text: process of factory-controlled cost estimating, the purchasing and cutting of wood
label: Paragraph

text: products, numbering industrialized quality control, and packaging all were carried out in
label: Paragraph

text: a efficient factory-assembly-line manner. Between 1908 and 1940, customers ordered
label: Paragraph

text: some 100,000 houses from Sears, Roebuck, and Company alone. The designs could be
label: Paragraph

text: selected from a catalog, ordered by mail, and shipped by rail. Approximately 450 ready-
label: Paragraph

text: to-assemble designs covered almost every style, from cottage to mansion. Beside Sears’s
label: Paragraph

text: brick and concrete masonry unit homes, the traditional wood frame erected on a wooden
label: Paragraph

text: platform was used as the standard method of construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Industry in the United States also experimented with concrete and iron as
label: Paragraph

text: prefabrication methods. In 1920 story-height precast reinforced-concrete stone elements
label: Caption

text: were produced under trade names such as “Armostone,” “Moore Unit,” and “Tee-Stone.”
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright designed a precast system in 1920 that consisted of two precast-
label: Paragraph

text: element walls: one interior wall and one outside, reinforced and connected with tie-rods
label: Caption

text: and separated by an insulating air space. The large sizes of concrete elements made
label: Paragraph

text: handling on a conventionally equipped, small-scale construction site difficult. Smaller-
label: Paragraph

text: scaled precast units, such as 16-by-8-by-8-inch concrete blocks, were, and still are today,
label: Paragraph

text: more widely accepted.
label: Paragraph

text: Early experiments of prefabrication in Great Britain with elements made of iron date to
label: Paragraph

text: Victorian times, when numerous prefabricated buildings were shipped from Britain to
label: Paragraph

text: every corner of the world. British settlers on the Australian west coast could order
label: Paragraph

text: corrugated-iron cottages from the Phoenix Iron Works in Glasgow, Scotland, and from
label: Paragraph

text: the firm of Richard Walker. Other requests from Australia called for the shipment of
label: Paragraph

text: “portable” churches, temporary metal structures to replace the hastily improvised timber
label: Paragraph

text: structures of the early days. In Melbourne alone, 19 metal churches were erected with kits
label: Paragraph

text: shipped from the homeland between 1836 and 1851. When it was packed and ready for
label: Paragraph

text: shipment to the colonies, a church weighed about 50 tons; the cost in the second half of
label: Paragraph

text: the 19th century was £1000, and the building was ready to be used in five weeks. Before
label: Paragraph

text: shipment to foreign coasts, it was common practice to fully assemble the structure on the
label: Paragraph

text: grounds of the factory as a final quality check, which always attracted public attention.
label: Paragraph

text: The lighthouse in Gibb’s Hill, Bermuda, is a sturdy, prefabricated iron structure shipped
label: Paragraph

text: from England in 1857; the so-called Gordon’s Lighthouse in Barbados, a fully
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated-metal construction, stood for 112 years. The Iron Palace for King Eyambo
label: Caption

text: on the banks of the Calabar River in Nigeria, erected in 1843, was built by the foundry of
label: Paragraph

text: Laycock, Liverpool, “a composite structure of plate and panels of iron upon a wooden
label: Caption

text: skeleton merely,” as the Liverpool Times described it.
label: Paragraph

text: Besides prefabricated galvanized sheet-metal elements, cast iron contributed to a large
label: Paragraph

text: degree to the importance of metal prefabrication techniques. James Bogardus is more
label: Paragraph

text: identified with the advances of cast-iron prefabrication than any other inventor. Already
label: Paragraph

text: holding numerous patents for metal fabricating tools and mills, Bogardus conceived the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of taking cast iron beyond its already widely accepted role as a decorative building
label: Paragraph

text: material to a multistory structural system. His first building would be his own factory in
label: Paragraph

text: New York City, for which he tried to associate with other veteran iron makers to raise the
label: Paragraph

text: necessary funds. Bogardus’s system consisted of basic elements: a hollow column with
label: Paragraph

text: flanged sides, a C-shaped hollow beam, a spandrel panel, and a diversity of decorative
label: Paragraph

text: cast-iron elements, such as cornices, entablatures, window elements, cornerstones, and
label: Paragraph

text: Medusa-head keystones, the trademark of the Bogardus Ironworks. With these decorative
label: Paragraph

text: elements, which suited the Victorian taste of the time, a variety of designs could be
label: Paragraph

text: created. The buildings were assembled by bolted connections, hidden on the inside of
label: Paragraph

text: every element, forming rigid moment connections between columns and beams.
label: Paragraph

text: Bogardus was granted a patent for his “building system” in 1850. It did not take long for
label: Paragraph

text: numerous commercial buildings with cast-iron facades to surface, and other founders and
label: Paragraph

text: builders created competition. It was also clear that the new technique would not be
label: Paragraph

text: confined to New York but instead would spread to every major commercial center in the
label: Paragraph

text: United States. Stove makers, founders of cook pots, and hardware manufacturers soon
label: Paragraph

text: entered the field of cast-iron architecture. Part of the attraction of cast iron as a building
label: Paragraph

text: material was its fire resistance. Despite Bogardus’s claim that his own factory was made
label: Paragraph

text: entirely out of metal, many cast-iron buildings used a significant amount of timber and
label: Paragraph

text: stone building materials. Many of Bogardus’s own designs, both in Baltimore (1904) and
label: Paragraph

text: in Chicago (1871), were consumed by fire. At the end of the Victorian period, the
label: Paragraph

text: material and the associated prefabrication techniques fell out of favor. Despite early
label: Paragraph

text: hopes, they were not fire safe, nor could they resist strong winds, as shown by the
label: Paragraph

text: entirely demolished cast-iron warehouses in Havana, Cuba—destroyed in 1906 by a
label: Paragraph

text: hurricane.
label: Paragraph

text: Neither fire safety nor resistance against wind is a major concern for reinforced precast
label: Paragraph

text: concrete. With the invention of heavy trucks in the 1930s, reinforced precast concrete
label: Paragraph

text: elements could be transported to almost every construction site. The first modern use of
label: Paragraph

text: precast concrete was in the Notre Dame du Haut Cathedral in Raincy, France, by the
label: Paragraph

text: architect-engineer Auguste Perret in 1922. The main structural systems of the church still
label: Caption

text: show a largely in situ concrete system, yet the wide use of precast elements for in-fill
label: Paragraph

text: walls and partitions led the way for the industry. Such is the case with iron: prefabricated
label: Paragraph

text: structures in concrete can be distinguished as load-bearing elements, such as columns,
label: Paragraph

text: beams, and floor slabs, and in-fill materials and components, such as windows, panels,
label: Paragraph

text: and utility cores. Yet concrete lends itself to a few interesting new techniques, developed
label: Paragraph

text: in the years before World War II and employed in the years after the war, that are
label: Paragraph

text: uncommon in any other prefabricated process. The technique of a “lift slab” casts the
label: Paragraph

text: reinforcedconcrete slabs of a multistory building on grade, one over the other, with
label: Caption

text: sleeves designed for slab connections to previously erected columns. After the curing
label: Paragraph

text: process is completed, the “stack” of slabs is lifted into place and bonded to the
label: Paragraph

text: connections with the vertical structural member, the column. Volumetric steel forms with
label: Paragraph

text: a high degree of precision and built-in heating equipment to accelerate the curing process
label: Paragraph

text: can produce U-shaped “tunnel forms” stacked on top of each other. It was mostly
label: Paragraph

text: building types with a high degree of equally sized room cells, such as hotels and
label: Paragraph

text: apartment buildings, that were erected with this method. Advantages to prefabrication
label: Paragraph

text: methods employing concrete are an organized, orderly supply and storage of aggregates
label: Paragraph

text: at a different place than the site of erection; a clean construction site; the multiple re-use
label: Paragraph

text: of expensive formwork; and the improved surface quality of the finished product. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: these advantages, the prefabrication of entire room cells (or “big boxes”) or ceiling-
label: Paragraph

text: height big panels never caught on in the United States. In Europe, South America, and the
label: Paragraph

text: former Soviet Union, including most of its allies, a significant number of housing
label: Paragraph

text: projects were carried out with prefabricated-concrete panels. Notable innovations in the
label: Paragraph

text: technique originated in Scandinavia and France and were paralleled by extensive large-
label: Paragraph

text: scale developments in East Germany, Yugoslavia, and the Soviet Union. Most of the
label: Paragraph

text: panel systems in these cases were based on the full wall-size big panels. Despite the large
label: Paragraph

text: number of projects executed, big panels proved to be expensive overall, called for
label: Paragraph

text: multitude of joints that had to be made in the field, and seldom permitted the degree of
label: Paragraph

text: prefinishing and shop incorporation of utilities as originally anticipated.
label: Paragraph

text: Today, prefabricated “architectural” precast concrete is widely used in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States and worldwide mainly as building components (not as a primary structural
label: Paragraph

text: material), either for enclosure or highly repetitive elements, such as staircases. The
label: Paragraph

text: surface quality of architectural precast concrete produced in developed countries is high
label: Paragraph

text: compared with the beginnings of the industry. Because of the advantages in thermal
label: Paragraph

text: properties over glass, mainly because of thermal mass inertia, precast concrete for
label: Paragraph

text: building envelopes has the chance to become a prime material in times of increased
label: Paragraph

text: energy costs.

text: PRIMITIVISM
label: Title

text: Primitivism is a set of ideas arising in Western Europe during the 18th century, a period
label: Paragraph

text: of unprecedented European colonial expansion. Primitivism does not name a group of
label: Paragraph

text: artists or architects or a style arising at a particular moment but, rather, encompasses the
label: Paragraph

text: various responses produced by contact between Western and non-Western societies
label: Paragraph

text: during the colonial period. It has three primary meanings: a belief in the superiority of a
label: Paragraph

text: simple life close to nature, a belief in the superiority of non-industrial society to that of
label: Paragraph

text: the present, and a valorization of the art and architecture of primitive peoples or primitive
label: Paragraph

text: creators. All three definitions indicate that primitivism is a critical attitude toward present
label: Paragraph

text: society, culture, and art and a preference for societies, cultures, and art from simpler
label: Paragraph

text: times, states of evolution, or mentalities. It is also used to indicate the art and architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of primitive peoples or cultures, although this is not a correct usage, as primitivism is a
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenon of Western culture, not the product of “primitive” peoples. The word
label: Paragraph

text: primitivism (primitivisme) was used first in France in the 19th century; William Rubin
label: Paragraph

text: traces its appearance to the Nouveau Larousse between 1897 and 1904, meaning
label: Paragraph

text: “imitation of primitives.” The term primitive has a wide range of meanings, including
label: Paragraph

text: original, primeval, little evolved, elemental, natural, naif, characteristic of an early stage
label: Paragraph

text: of development, and produced by a relatively simple people or culture or a self-taught
label: Paragraph

text: artist. This term is generally used to designate societies considered to have a lower level
label: Paragraph

text: of evolutionary development than Western societies.
label: Paragraph

text: There are two tendencies in primitivism: a search for origins in the classical,
label: Paragraph

text: exemplified by the primitive hut of Enlightenment theories, and the valorization of
label: Paragraph

text: peasant, vernacular, or non-literate culture as a means for producing a more primal art or
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. This latter meaning is used extensively in the history of modern art but
label: Paragraph

text: applies to modern architecture as well. In his groundbreaking book of 1938, Primitivism
label: Paragraph

text: in Modern Painting, Robert Goldwater defined “primitivism” as a search among Western
label: Paragraph

text: artists for something below the surface of things—further back in time, psychology, or
label: Paragraph

text: geography—that is simpler and more profound, valuable, or powerful because of its
label: Paragraph

text: simplicity. The primitivists assumed that delving beneath the surface would reveal this
label: Paragraph

text: basic quality. This search for simplicity unites the disparate primitivist movements, but
label: Paragraph

text: the nature of “simplicity” varies with the goals of the seeker. Primitive art is usually,
label: Paragraph

text: according to Goldwater, a stimulus or catalyst to modern art, not directly borrowed from
label: Paragraph

text: or the direct cause of primitive qualities in that art. The primitive helped Western artists
label: Paragraph

text: and architects formulate their own goals and methods and served as a referent, not a
label: Paragraph

text: direct source. Colin Rhodes, historian of primitivism in modern art, points to an
label: Paragraph

text: equivocal issue at the heart of primitivism: although artists used the primitive as a support
label: Paragraph

text: and justification for cultural or social change, their efforts were directed toward change
label: Paragraph

text: expected to emerge within the West. There was no question of the comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: substitution of Western culture, or its unacceptable aspects, by the primitive.
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment primitivism was motivated by a search for origins, a “higher” source,
label: Paragraph

text: and a belief in the superiority of a simple life close to nature, exemplified by Montaigne’s
label: Paragraph

text: and Rousseau’s valorization of the savage who lived in a more natural, less corrupt state
label: Paragraph

text: of being. Enlightenment theories of architecture posited a primal architectonic form, the
label: Paragraph

text: primitive hut, from which all forms of architecture derived. The glorification of the
label: Paragraph

text: “noble savage,” as Peter Collins notes, contributed to the 19th-century revivals of Greek
label: Paragraph

text: and Gothic architecture and the valorization of such styles as primitive, pure, and natural.
label: Paragraph

text: In the mid-19th century, artists and architects sought a lost, relatively simple style that
label: Paragraph

text: was part of their tradition. This form of primitivism demonstrates a preference for non-
label: Paragraph

text: industrial society to that of the present. A.W.N.Pugin, John Ruskin, and William Morris
label: Paragraph

text: shared a distaste and distrust for the mechanization and materialism of the industrial age.
label: Paragraph

text: They called for the revival of medieval art and architecture as a way of healing society
label: Paragraph

text: and people, who had become extensions of machines rather than whole beings. Their
label: Paragraph

text: theories stimulated the Gothic Revival, illustrated by Charles Barry and Pugin’s Houses
label: Paragraph

text: of Parliament (1836-51) in London and the Arts and Crafts movement. The Mission
label: Paragraph

text: Revival in the United States merged Arts and Crafts sensibility with a primitivist vision
label: Paragraph

text: of early California under the Spanish missionaries (Charles Lummis, El Alisal, Los
label: Caption

text: Angeles, begun 1898).
label: Paragraph

text: In the 19th century, the search for primitive origins converged with Darwinism and the
label: Paragraph

text: “discovery” of primitive civilizations by Western colonizing powers to produce a
label: Paragraph

text: hierarchy of races and cultures, with Europe and the United States at the apex.
label: Paragraph

text: Colonization was justified, in part, by reference to the crude technology and material
label: Paragraph

text: culture of the colonized peoples, seen as a sign of their innate evolutionary inferiority.
label: Paragraph

text: Certain figures, such as Paul Gauguin, resisted the characterization of non-European
label: Paragraph

text: culture as inferior; instead, they championed primitive cultures as an alternative to the
label: Paragraph

text: overcivilized art and intellect of Western society. Primitivist artists appreciated archaic
label: Paragraph

text: and non-Western styles for their sincerity, vigor, and expressive power, qualities that
label: Paragraph

text: these artists and architects missed in the official art of their day. Whereas bourgeois
label: Paragraph

text: society prized the virtuosity and finesse of academic realism and classicism, some artists
label: Paragraph

text: and architects began to value the simple and naif and even the crude and raw. Primitivism
label: Paragraph

text: in this sense is a comparative concept, a theory of difference, and an implicit challenge to
label: Paragraph

text: the assumption that Western culture was superior to the primitive. The Greene brothers,
label: Paragraph

text: for example, emulated Japanese architecture in their Gamble House (1908) in Pasadena,
label: Paragraph

text: California. They took the craftsmanship of the Eastlake and Craftsman styles and
label: Paragraph

text: combined them with Japanese influences to create a freer attitude toward the organization
label: Paragraph

text: of spaces and an integrated system of woodwork, stained glass, and custom furniture.
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright drew on Japanese and Mayan architecture, recreations of which he
label: Paragraph

text: saw at the World’s Columbian Exhibition of 1893 in Chicago. The effect of Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: architecture asserted itself in the horizontal lines, unpainted wood, and delicate colors of
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s Prairie-style work. In his concrete, textile block houses of the 1920s, such as La
label: Paragraph

text: Miniatura (1923) in Pasadena, Wright may have been inspired by Mayan sculpture and
label: Paragraph

text: massing.
label: Paragraph

text: Art Nouveau, Jugendstil, or Style Liberty was heavily influenced by primitive sources.
label: Paragraph

text: The “new art,” which flourished from about 1893 to 1905, was so called because it
label: Paragraph

text: rejected historical precedent, academic regulation, and static convention. Art Nouveau
label: Paragraph

text: borrowed from Japanese decorative art and Mycenaean art and was motivated by a
label: Paragraph

text: primitivist intent to create a more direct, less refined art by means of light, sinuous
label: Paragraph

text: ormmament and materials. Victor Horta, in Belgium, combined the emphasis on structure of
label: Paragraph

text: the Gothic Revival, new materials such as iron and plate glass, and the inspiration of
label: Paragraph

text: natural forms from the Arts and Crafts. Horta’s first important Art Nouveau work was the
label: Paragraph

text: Tassel House (1892-93) in Brussels, in which the twisting iron columns and ornament
label: Paragraph

text: united with painted decoration to create a total environment of serpentine forms. He used
label: Paragraph

text: iron without stone cladding along with materials and vocabulary derived from industrial
label: Paragraph

text: and public buildings, such as railway stations.
label: Paragraph

text: By this time, according to Goldwater, the search for beginnings had shifted from
label: Paragraph

text: cultural to physical-emotional and became a search for “lower” rather than “higher”
label: Paragraph

text: origins. In the 20th century, exotic, indigenous arts and those made by children and
label: Paragraph

text: madmen were valued for expressing emotional intensity. Expressionism exhibits this
label: Paragraph

text: tendency toward emotional primitivism. Expressionist architects in the Netherlands and
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, such as Michel de Klerk (Eigen Haard, 1917-20, in Amsterdam) and Hans
label: Paragraph

text: Poelzig (Chemical factory, 1911-12, in Luban), explored highly individualistic,
label: Paragraph

text: expressive form. Modern architects looked to the primitive as a source of artistic and
label: Paragraph

text: architectural stimulus that was not regulated by the norms of European civilization and
label: Paragraph

text: that would provide the means for a more primal architecture. Bruno Taut wrote several
label: Paragraph

text: visionary books in the 1910s and 1920s, including Stadtkrone (1919), in which he
label: Paragraph

text: imagined agrarian, craft-based settlements reminiscent of Morris’s vision of medieval
label: Paragraph

text: society. Each city had a crystalline “city crown” (Stadtkrone), a religious and spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: center, designed in pyramidal form like a Gothic cathedral, that acted as a symbol of the
label: Paragraph

text: community spirit uniting the city’s dwellers. The Bauhaus was, at its foundation, based
label: Paragraph

text: on similar utopian ideals of community and the cooperation of all the arts under
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. It was a social project for the future, realized through educating a new guild
label: Paragraph

text: of craftsmen. Architecture would be the one unifying element in society, according to the
label: Paragraph

text: ideals of the Bauhaus founders. They chose to emulate the Gothic cathedral because all
label: Paragraph

text: the people of the cathedral towns had participated in building these monuments and
label: Paragraph

text: because they unified sculpture, painting, weaving, and the other arts within one structure.
label: Paragraph

text: The Glass Chain participants—Walter Gropius, Bruno and Max Taut, the Luckhardt
label: Paragraph

text: brothers, Hans Scharoun, and others—explored free, unconscious form, an extension of
label: Paragraph

text: utopian Expressionism, as an alternative to rational, machine-based design.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier passed through the three types of primitivism during his career. His early
label: Paragraph

text: work in La Chaux-de-Fonds was part of a regional Arts and Crafts movement, creating
label: Paragraph

text: design founded on natural forms and vernacular buildings (Villa Stotzer, 1907). After his
label: Paragraph

text: Voyage d’Orient (1911), Le Corbusier became a staunch advocate of universal, classical
label: Paragraph

text: language, translated into the undecorated, machine vocabulary that he believed was
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate for the times (Villa Savoye, 1929, in Poissy). In his later work, he employed
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular types and emphasized less finished materials, such as brick arches and stone
label: Paragraph

text: (Maisons Jaoul, 1954-56, in Neuilly). This “peasantism” influenced younger architects,
label: Paragraph

text: especially members of Team X and the New Brutalists in Britain.
label: Paragraph

text: In the post-World War Il period, there was a shift toward a universalizing view of
label: Paragraph

text: humanity: the Family of Man. The earlier emotional primitivism continued, manifested in
label: Paragraph

text: psychosocial references to primal qualities, such as shelter, enclosure, and place. Bernard
label: Paragraph

text: Rudofsky’s Architecture without Architects (1964) devalued professional training and
label: Paragraph

text: “designed” form in favor of organic, natural architecture produced by indigenous peoples
label: Paragraph

text: in non-industrialized countries. The New Brutalism, which took its name from Dubuffet’s
label: Paragraph

text: art brut, attempted to create a simpler, more immediate architecture that expressed a new
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic of coarseness and the primitive. Allison and Peter Smithson’s proposal for
label: Paragraph

text: Golden Lane housing (1952) in London was illustrated with images of Greek islands,
label: Paragraph

text: working-class backyards, Casbahs, and other dwellings expressive of a place and a way
label: Paragraph

text: of life. Dutch architect Aldo van Eyck referred to the settlements of the Dogon in Africa
label: Paragraph

text: and the Pueblos in the southwestern United States to create a more socially responsive
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, as in his Orphanage (1957-62) in Amsterdam. In Italy the firm BBPR
label: Paragraph

text: revived elements of the medieval palazzo tower in the Torre Velasco (1956—58) in Milan,
label: Paragraph

text: rendered in concrete. Bruce Goff used an extravagant naturalism in the Bavinger House
label: Caption

text: (1950) in Norman, Oklahoma, as Dell Upton notes, that connects to a wider anti-artificial
label: Paragraph

text: primitivism. Upton links American primitivism to European trends, with the difference
label: Paragraph

text: being that the noble savage was the Indian in American mythology.
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernism contains primitivism as a return to highclassical origins and a search
label: Paragraph

text: for “low” origins in vernacular or popular sources. The rigorous classicism of Quinlan
label: Paragraph

text: Terry, for example, revived a universal, timeless classical language; by contrast, Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Moore employed forms derived from such vernacular sources as northern California
label: Paragraph

text: barns (The Sea Ranch, 1965) and Italian hill towns (Kresge College, University of
label: Paragraph

text: California, Santa Cruz, 1974). Frank Gehry’s appropriation of the ephemeral, vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: constructions of southern California—lifeguard stations, chain-link fences, plywood
label: Caption

text: walls, and strip-mall stucco (Gehry House, 1977 and 1992, Santa Monica)—exhibits a
label: Paragraph

text: primitivism of low building sources.
label: Paragraph

text: The issue of “primitivism” in Third World countries challenges its definition as a
label: Paragraph

text: purely Western phenomenon. Work by Western-trained architects such as Hassan Fathy,
label: Paragraph

text: Luis Barragan, Balkrishna Doshi, and Geoffrey Bawa combines local materials and
label: Paragraph

text: traditional building forms with modern programs and systems. This postcolonial
label: Paragraph

text: architecture confounds the hierarchies and patronizing attitude established by social
label: Paragraph

text: Darwinism, imperialism, and primitivism. Instead of a search for origins in a distant time,
label: Paragraph

text: place, or culture, these architects produce hybrids of modernism and indigenous forms
label: Paragraph

text: responsive to particular local conditions. The classical primitive hut has been abandoned
label: Paragraph

text: in favor of other traditions.

text: PRISON
label: Title

text: The prison is an ancient building type and has always served essentially the same purpose
label: Paragraph

text: of involuntary detention. The pris-on’s status among architects has varied over time: in
label: Paragraph

text: the 19th century, the creative possibilities opened by the reinvention of the building type
label: Paragraph

text: occupied many of architecture’s recognized leaders, and hopes for the reform of society
label: Paragraph

text: through architectural means were widely shared. However, as most of today’s experts
label: Paragraph

text: affirm, this first period of inventiveness generated most of the major ideas in prison
label: Paragraph

text: architecture: the broad outlines of debate have stayed the same since that time. Private
label: Paragraph

text: prisons, “direct supervision,” and other contemporary preoccupations are simply
label: Paragraph

text: refinements and restatements of century-old strategies that have come in and out of favor
label: Paragraph

text: over the years. For most of the 20th century, the construction of prisons was a healthy
label: Paragraph

text: industry but had relatively little to offer to, or gain from, the architectural imagination.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the key principles in the development of modern prison architecture was the
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to render imprisonment in itself neutral. Other than the deprivation of liberty for
label: Paragraph

text: a certain length of time according to the offense, the prisoner was, at least theoretically,
label: Paragraph

text: to suffer no other punishment. This generated a new need for self-contained buildings
label: Paragraph

text: that could provide for a relatively complete range of human needs and behaviors. The cell
label: Paragraph

text: in particular stimulated early experiments in central plumbing and heating. Some of the
label: Paragraph

text: seminal ideas in both architectural and judicial reform were stated by the utilitarian
label: Paragraph

text: philosopher Jeremy Bentham in his Panopticon, first published in 1787. At once an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural and a social project, the proposed building consisted of a stacked ring of
label: Paragraph

text: cells open toward a shuttered surveillance tower in the center. Although strict copies of
label: Paragraph

text: this project were rare, such ideal geometries of surveillance were taken up in a significant
label: Paragraph

text: number of projects, built and unbuilt, that followed.
label: Paragraph

text: Early debates over round-the-clock confinement led to reformers’ taking sides between
label: Paragraph

text: the “Pennsylvania” and “Auburn” systems. The former and more radical of the two had
label: Paragraph

text: been developed from the 1780s by Quaker reformers, finding its definitive statement in
label: Paragraph

text: William Haviland’s Eastern State Penitentiary, opened in Philadelphia in 1829. Each cell,
label: Paragraph

text: arranged in double-loaded cell blocks radiating from a central hub, was equipped with
label: Paragraph

text: complete furnishings for solitary life and work, including a small individual courtyard.
label: Caption

text: Although developed in the United States, the system was much more widely adopted in
label: Paragraph

text: Europe. The Auburn system, named after a New York State prison completed in 1816
label: Paragraph

text: (W.Britten and J.Cray), provided a combination of individual cells for sleeping and
label: Paragraph

text: spaces for collective—but silent—work by day. Perhaps because it was less expensive to
label: Paragraph

text: operate, it became the norm in the United States for the next century and a half, and
label: Paragraph

text: elements of the system are still embraced all over the world. The architecture of the
label: Paragraph

text: Auburn-style prison placed cells back to back in long, rectangular volumes, separated by
label: Paragraph

text: a galleried surveillance space from the exterior wall. The main cell block at Alcatraz,
label: Caption

text: completed in 1912 (and now part of a popular national park site), is an example of this
label: Paragraph

text: approach, which quickly took advantage of advances in reinforced-concrete and steel
label: Paragraph

text: technology. Here, cells could be smaller and simpler than under the Pennsylvania system,
label: Paragraph

text: as they were to be used only for sleeping.
label: Paragraph

text: The first decades of the 20th century essentially prolonged the 19th century’s debate
label: Paragraph

text: over solitary confinement and its variants. The cell remained the heart of the system, and
label: Paragraph

text: it continued to be designed as a single-occupancy space, even though population
label: Paragraph

text: pressures were such that very few remained so for long. After the radial plans associated
label: Paragraph

text: with the Pennsylvania system, the barracks-like rectilinear arrangements of the Auburn
label: Paragraph

text: system, and a few experiments with courtyard and Panopticon-type cylindrical
label: Paragraph

text: arrangements, all of which had been explored in the 19th century, the 20th century began
label: Paragraph

text: with a new enthusiasm for what became known as the “telephone-pole” prison. The
label: Paragraph

text: principle, first seen at Fresnes Prison (1898, F.-H.Poussin) near Paris, was the
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical distribution of rectilinear cell blocks along a covered security corridor—the
label: Paragraph

text: “pole” of the arrangement. This arrangement, like radial plans, put an emphasis on
label: Paragraph

text: efficient and secure circulation but without the difficulties linked to the use of the
label: Paragraph

text: triangular outdoor spaces left over.
label: Paragraph

text: Beginning in the 1920s and continuing to the present, some city jails on limited sites
label: Paragraph

text: have been built as high-rise buildings, although these pose special security problems. Not
label: Paragraph

text: long after, on the eve of World War I, some minimum-security prisons began to be
label: Paragraph

text: conceived according to a so-called campus or open arrangement, where buildings
label: Paragraph

text: representing different services would be scattered across a relatively open site plan and
label: Paragraph

text: where only the perimeter was definitively secured. Like the (physically) similar forced-
label: Paragraph

text: labor camps found notably in the Soviet Union and Germany at the same time, the
label: Paragraph

text: architecture inside was less specialized—and less expensive—than that of the high-
label: Paragraph

text: security institutions. However, as this provocative comparison indicates, the human
label: Paragraph

text: relations component of incarceration became more central, with corresponding
label: Paragraph

text: possibilities, as the direct preventive role of the architecture diminished.
label: Paragraph

text: Since the 1970s, cell blocks have become “housing units,” and surveillance is often
label: Paragraph

text: deemphasized through the use of less “institutional,” but no less carefully placed, guard
label: Paragraph

text: stations. Indeed, as with hospitals and hotels, the size of new projects is measured in
label: Paragraph

text: beds, not prisoners or cells. Some experts contend that as such efforts to normalize prison
label: Paragraph

text: life intensify, the prison itself will dissolve into the community, with only a vestigial
label: Paragraph

text: presence in the form of decentralized services provided to the inmates. Others predict the
label: Paragraph

text: increasing dominance of wholly electronic means of surveillance, already in partial and
label: Paragraph

text: experimental use in several parts of the world. However, apart from an apparent tendency
label: Paragraph

text: to rely more and more on private subcontractors, most modern states maintain an
label: Paragraph

text: extensive prison system—led by the United States and Russia, where per capita
label: Paragraph

text: imprisonment is reaching historic high levels. “Correctional architecture,” as prison
label: Paragraph

text: design is now known, will likely remain an important and lucrative, if somewhat obscure,
label: Paragraph

text: specialty field in architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: PRITZKER ARCHITECTURE PRIZE
label: Title

text: The Pritzker Architecture Prize, established in 1979 and awarded annually, is a major
label: Paragraph

text: international prize for architecture given to a living architect for a body of work. Created
label: Paragraph

text: by Jay and Cindy Pritzker and funded by the Hyatt Corporation through the Hyatt
label: Caption

text: Foundation, the prize is intended to “honor a living architect whose built work
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrates a combination of those qualities of talent, vision, and commitment, which
label: Paragraph

text: produced consistent and significant contributions to humanity and the built environment
label: Paragraph

text: through the art of architecture.” From its inception, the prize was intended to increase
label: Paragraph

text: public awareness of both individual architects and the profession. The high standards for
label: Paragraph

text: selection, the open nominations procedure, and the independence of the international jury
label: Title

text: have led to the prize being referred to as the “Nobel Prize” of architecture, after which
label: Paragraph

text: many of the procedures are modeled. Laureates receive a $100,000 grant, a formal
label: Paragraph

text: citation certificate, and (since 1987) a bronze medallion. Before 1987 a limited edition
label: Paragraph

text: Henry Moore sculpture was given to each winner. Although the award is a form of
label: Paragraph

text: competition, there is no commission for a project to build; rather, the winner receives the
label: Paragraph

text: honor of being recognized as one of the best in the profession.
label: Paragraph

text: There is an open nomination process for the Pritzker Architecture Prize, continuous
label: Paragraph

text: from year to year, with more than 500 architects under consideration annually. The
label: Paragraph

text: executive director accepts nominations from any licensed architect and also seeks them
label: Paragraph

text: actively from critics, the jurors, past prizewinners, professionals in related disciplines,
label: Paragraph

text: and academics—in short, from anyone interested in advancing the profession of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The nomination procedure closes every January and is followed by jury
label: Paragraph

text: deliberations in the early part of the year that include site visits to as many projects as
label: Paragraph

text: possible. These site visits to experience the buildings in context are considered an integral
label: Paragraph

text: part of the jury process because winners are judged primarily by their built works, not by
label: Paragraph

text: publications, theoretical ideas, portfolios, or other means. An international jury makes the
label: Paragraph

text: final selection, and all the jury deliberations and voting are done in secret. A decision and
label: Paragraph

text: its official announcement are made annually in the spring, followed in May or June by an
label: Paragraph

text: awards ceremony with a dinner for several hundred members of the architecture and art
label: Paragraph

text: communities.
label: Paragraph

text: The jury consists of eight people on average and has been chaired from the beginning
label: Paragraph

text: by J.Carter Brown, director emeritus of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C.,
label: Caption

text: and chairman of the United States Fine Arts Commission. Jurors are selected for their
label: Paragraph

text: extensive and broad knowledge of the field, professional integrity, and capacity for
label: Paragraph

text: unbiased judgment. The Pritzker family participates neither in the selection of the jury
label: Paragraph

text: nor in the selection of the winner. Jury members have included Cesar Pelli, architect and
label: Paragraph

text: former dean of the Yale University School of Architecture; Giovanni Agnelli, chairman
label: Paragraph

text: of Fiat of Torino, Italy; Ada Louise Huxtable, American author and architectural critic;
label: Paragraph

text: and architects Frank Gehry, Philip Johnson, Arata Isozaki, Ricardo Legorreta, Fumihiko
label: Caption

text: Maki, and Charles Correa. Although the composition of the jury has changed gradually
label: Paragraph

text: over the course of the prize’s first 21 years, its purpose and procedures remain relatively
label: Paragraph

text: constant.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the Pritzker Architecture Prize has achieved its stated goals of making the
label: Paragraph

text: public more aware of the discipline of architecture and the work of the laureates, some of
label: Paragraph

text: the weaknesses in the structure of the profession are reflected in the juries’ selections. For
label: Paragraph

text: example, as of the year 2000, no women have been awarded the prize. In addition,
label: Paragraph

text: because the prize is awarded to a body of work, most of the winners are already
label: Paragraph

text: established architects. The award has not been a vehicle for the discovery of younger
label: Paragraph

text: architects, and in general, the juries have historically avoided the avant-garde.
label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore, the winner’s contribution to the discipline and effect on the profession do
label: Paragraph

text: not always seem to be considered in the decision-making process. In some cases, such as
label: Paragraph

text: Christian de Portzampare (1994) and Tadao Ando (1995), the prize was awarded to an
label: Paragraph

text: architect whose work has not had a significant effect on their peers, whereas more
label: Paragraph

text: influential architects, such as Jorn Utzon of Denmark, have been overlooked. In the
label: Paragraph

text: history of architectural awards, the Pritzker is still relatively young, and the extent of its
label: Paragraph

text: lasting effect remains to be seen.
label: Paragraph

text: The Pritzker Architecture Prize laureates to date are Philip Johnson of the United
label: Paragraph

text: States (1979), Luis Barragan of Mexico (1980), James Stirling of Great Britain (1981),
label: Paragraph

text: Kevin Roche of the United States (1982), I.M. Pei of the United States (1983), Richard
label: Caption

text: Meier of the United States (1984), Hans Hollein of Austria (1985), Gottfried Boehm of
label: Paragraph

text: Germany (1986), Kenzo Tange of Japan (1987), Gordon Bunshaft of the United States
label: Paragraph

text: and Oscar Neimeyer of Brazil (1988), Frank O.Gehry of the United States (1989), Aldo
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi of Italy (1990), Robert Venturi of the United States (1991), Alvaro Siza of Portugal
label: Paragraph

text: (1992), Fumihiko Maki of Japan (1993), Christian de Portzampare of France (1994),
label: Paragraph

text: Tadao Ando of Japan (1995), Rafael Moneo of Spain (1996), Sverre Fehn of Norway
label: Paragraph

text: (1997), Renzo Piano of Italy (1998), Sir Norman Foster of the United Kingdom (1999),
label: Paragraph

text: and Rem Koolhaas of the Netherlands (2000).

text: PRUITT IGOE HOUSING
label: Title

text: Designed by Minoru Yamasaki; completed 1954-76 St. Louis, Missouri
label: Caption

text: Pruitt-[goe was an early and important post-World War II public housing project. Built
label: Paragraph

text: on the near north side of St. Louis as part of a massive urban-renewal program, Pruitt-
label: Paragraph

text: Igoe was one of the largest public housing complexes in the United States. With 33
label: Paragraph

text: buildings rising through 11 stories and towering over 57 acres of the city, it was hailed in
label: Paragraph

text: the early 1950s as an innovative application of modernist design principles to the
label: Paragraph

text: problem of chronic urban-housing shortages. At its peak, it housed some 14,000 people in
label: Paragraph

text: 2870 apartments. Yet by the early 1970s, the project was crumbling and nearly derelict,
label: Paragraph

text: its residents plagued by crime, isolation, and persistent poverty. Pruitt-lgoe was not only
label: Paragraph

text: the worst housing project in the city but also one of the most glaring failures of federal
label: Paragraph

text: housing provision in U.S. history. For many architects, planners, and critics, the
label: Paragraph

text: demolition of three Pruitt-[goe buildings in 1972 symbolizes the death of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Pruitt-Igoe emerged as one piece in a larger postwar urbanrenewal program. As with
label: Paragraph

text: most northern and midwestern cities, World War II had taken a toll on St. Louis, as large
label: Paragraph

text: numbers of southern black and white migrants streamed into already dense inner-core
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods in search of industrial work. Returning soldiers and their burgeoning
label: Paragraph

text: families further exacerbated a widespread strain on housing and municipal services. To
label: Paragraph

text: provide cities with the legal and fiscal tools to cope with deepening urban problems,
label: Paragraph

text: Congress passed the 1949 Housing Act, which enabled municipalities to create
label: Paragraph

text: redevelopment authorities with broad powers to assemble land parcels for clearance and
label: Paragraph

text: “urban renewal.” The St. Louis urban-renewal program, overseen by veteran city
label: Paragraph

text: engineer Harland Bartholomew, made full use of the federal provisions. Bartholomew
label: Paragraph

text: and his protégé, Charles Farris, working for a succession of Democratic-machine mayors,
label: Paragraph

text: undertook an unprecedented transformation of St. Louis through a program of slum
label: Paragraph

text: clearance, zoning application, expressway construction, and public housing development.
label: Paragraph

text: As prerequisites for improving their city, planners and politicians viewed the
label: Paragraph

text: eradication of blighted neighborhoods and the reorganization of the urban landscape into
label: Paragraph

text: modern, efficient land uses. Thus, the St. Louis public housing program developed both
label: Paragraph

text: as a catchment system for urban residents displaced through slum clearance and as a way
label: Paragraph

text: to funnel federal largesse into a visible showcase of modern municipal action. In 1950 the
label: Paragraph

text: city was ready to translate this “city-efficient” vision into reality with federal backing for
label: Paragraph

text: 5800 units of public housing. Disposed toward large-scale project design and
label: Paragraph

text: development, Bartholomew and then-Mayor Joseph Darst allocated nearly half of these
label: Paragraph

text: units to one public housing development: Pruitt-Igoe.
label: Paragraph

text: Designed by Minoru Yamasaki of Hellmuth, Yamasaki, and Leinweber, the Pruitt-lgoe
label: Paragraph

text: plan called for a Le Corbusier-like “ville radieuse” of garden apartments and high-rise
label: Paragraph

text: edifices interspersed with broad tree-lined and landscaped plazas. Innovative skip-stop
label: Paragraph

text: elevators would open onto every third floor, enabling a broad gallery to stretch for 85 feet
label: Paragraph

text: across the front of the building. Not only would the skip-stop elevators reduce costs,
label: Paragraph

text: architects argued, but the galleries would provide space for “vertical neighborhoods” to
label: Paragraph

text: replace the streets and sidewalks of the low-rise city. Here, above the noise and
label: Paragraph

text: congestion of the old neighborhoods, children could play, and adults could gather without
label: Paragraph

text: fear for their safety.
label: Paragraph

text: In an attempt to ameliorate both white residents and segregationist political interests,
label: Paragraph

text: the project was divided on the drawing board into racially distinct clusters. Officials
label: Paragraph

text: designated the Wendell Olliver Pruitt Homes for black families and the James Igoe
label: Caption

text: Apartments for white families. However, Pruitt-lgoe was completed in 1954, in the wake
label: Paragraph

text: of the Brown vs. Board of Education decision, and the project had to be integrated on
label: Paragraph

text: settlement. As a result, most white families dropped off the rolls, leaving the project
label: Paragraph

text: desegregated by law while segregated in fact.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, federal cost-cutting measures eliminated many of the best features of
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki’s design, such as scattered lowrise units, landscaping, playgrounds, and
label: Paragraph

text: recreation facilities, while increasing the density from 30 to 50 units per acre. Federal
label: Paragraph

text: officials also insisted on the elimination of ground-floor bathrooms and most recreational
label: Paragraph

text: facilities. With little foresight, they ordered an increase in the number of two-bedroom
label: Paragraph

text: apartments at the expense of spaces for larger families, which led to overcrowding and
label: Paragraph

text: structural strain.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite these problems, most families that initially settled the project regarded their
label: Paragraph

text: move into Pruitt-[goe as an improvement in their housing conditions. Many enjoyed
label: Paragraph

text: indoor toilets and laundry facilities for the first time, and the project did eventually boast
label: Paragraph

text: a number of amenities, including a playground, recreation center, public library branch,
label: Paragraph

text: Boy Scout troop, day care center, and health clinic. Families managed to carve out new
label: Paragraph

text: networks within the project and to raise children amid difficult circumstances. Many
label: Paragraph

text: residents were involved in tenant organizing and civil rights campaigns through the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s. Today, many former residents remember Pruitt-I[goe not simply as the desolate
label: Paragraph

text: landscape of media and scholarly accounts but as home—the place where they grew up
label: Paragraph

text: and where they experienced many important life events.
label: Paragraph

text: Statistics collected by the St. Louis Housing Authority show that Pruitt-Igoe residents
label: Paragraph

text: were similar in nearly all respects to residents of other public housing projects—at least
label: Paragraph

text: in the first five years. Over time, however, they came to differ in one crucial respect: the
label: Paragraph

text: high percentage of female-headed households. Many better-off families left the project
label: Paragraph

text: for market-rate housing in the increasingly depopulated neighborhoods around the
label: Paragraph

text: project, creating an irreversible occupancy crisis. The Housing Authority tried to
label: Paragraph

text: maintain occupancy by filling Pruitt-lgoe with very poor, single-parent, female-headed
label: Paragraph

text: families. The relative absence of black male adult residents, sociologists have argued, left
label: Paragraph

text: women and children more vulnerable to crimes of property and violence. By the mid-
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s, Pruitt-[goe was regarded as the most dangerous public housing project in the city.
label: Paragraph

text: Firefighters routinely refused to answer alarm calls, and mail carriers and other service
label: Paragraph

text: agents avoided the project. A series of highly publicized murders and snipings sealed the
label: Paragraph

text: project’s fate as a symbol of inner-city urban decay and crime.
label: Paragraph

text: As the personal safety and morale of residents declined with an alarming rapidity, the
label: Paragraph

text: physical structure of Pruitt-lgoe deteriorated as well. Shoddy construction had already
label: Paragraph

text: resulted in constant problems with doors, locks, windows, cabinets, heaters, and electric
label: Paragraph

text: wiring. However, rising vacancy rates in the project left dwindling funds for maintenance
label: Paragraph

text: and upkeep, placing the Housing Authority in a severe financial strain. The skip-stop
label: Paragraph

text: elevators frequently malfunctioned, and the dim stairwells and galleries became gauntlets
label: Paragraph

text: of crime that residents had to run on a daily basis. Plumbing systems that were poorly
label: Paragraph

text: installed and maintained frequently froze and burst, causing widespread water damage.
label: Paragraph

text: Without ground-floor bathrooms, children constantly urinated in the stairwells and
label: Paragraph

text: elevators. Ongoing disagreements between the Housing Authority and the City of St.
label: Caption

label: Title

text: Photo by Richard Moore © Missouri Historical Society
label: Caption

text: trash pickup and project maintenance resulted in an environment littered with refuse and
label: Paragraph

text: garbage.
label: Paragraph

text: Numerous attempts were made in the mid- to late 1960s to improve the project. Pruitt-
label: Paragraph

text: Igoe happened to exist in a city with a renowned collection of urban sociologists and
label: Paragraph

text: political scientists who were loosely connected through Washington University’s Urban
label: Paragraph

text: Research Institute and Social Sciences Institute. Scholars such as Alvin Gouldner,
label: Paragraph

text: Eugene Mechan, Roger Montgomery, Lee Rainwater, George Wendel, and William
label: Title

text: Yancey lent their talents to the study of Pruitt-lgoe and to the implementation of
label: Paragraph

text: intervention strategies. The project was part of a Model Cities target area, and a variety of
label: Paragraph

text: urban poverty programs and tenant control strategies came and went in an effort to
label: Paragraph

text: reverse the decline. Pruitt-Igoe tenants themselves joined other public housing residents
label: Paragraph

text: in a citywide rent strike that drew national attention to their plight. The strike dramatized
label: Paragraph

text: the physical and mental stress of life in the projects and called attention to the civil rights
label: Paragraph

text: and social justice issues involved.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet no interventions proved successful in the long term. By 1972 Pruitt-Igoe had
label: Paragraph

text: become such an embarrassment to the city government and the Housing Authority that
label: Paragraph

text: they decided to demolish it. Even the residents themselves were divided over the fate of
label: Paragraph

text: the project: some favored partial demolition, whereas others favored low-rise retrofitting.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1972 and 1976, however, the project was detonated, leaving a 57-acre empty lot
label: Paragraph

text: in the middle of the city. Aside from a small elementary school built on the southwest
label: Paragraph

text: corner in 1992, the site remains empty.
label: Paragraph

text: Over the years, scholars and critics have grappled with the causes of the project’s
label: Paragraph

text: failure. Architectural critics generally hold that design is at the heart of the matter. Oscar
label: Paragraph

text: Newman’s widely read manifesto Defensible Space argues that high-rise public housing
label: Paragraph

text: projects such as Pruitt-Igoe fail because they preclude spatial regulation and defense by
label: Paragraph

text: tenants, leaving them vulnerable to crime. Colin Rowe and Fred Koetter argue in Collage
label: Paragraph

text: City that the spatial organization of Le Corbusier-influenced landscapes reveals a deep-
label: Paragraph

text: seated authoritarian impulse toward social engineering inherent in modernist design. Both
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Jencks (The Language of Post-Modern Architecture) and Peter Blake (Form
label: Paragraph

text: Follows Fiasco) use Pruitt-lgoe as a metaphor for the failure of modernist architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Jencks argues that the modern design idiom abolishes history and ignores the contexts of
label: Paragraph

text: place—attributes that had long governed architectural practice. Blake presses Pruitt-lgoe
label: Paragraph

text: into a broad attack on CLAM (Congrés Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne) design
label: Paragraph

text: principles, arguing that they result in sterile, inhuman environments. Each of these critics
label: Paragraph

text: regard the 1972 detonations as a clarion call for a new era of architecture, one sensitive
label: Paragraph

text: both to the weight of history and to the contingencies of local environments.
label: Paragraph

text: Social scientists, on the other hand, hold that Pruitt-Igoe’s failure has less to do with
label: Paragraph

text: design and more to do with structural conditions of racism and poverty. Lee Rainwater’s
label: Paragraph

text: now classic Behind Ghetto Walls, derived from lengthy interviews with Pruitt-lgoe
label: Paragraph

text: residents in the mid-1960s, demonstrates that racial segregation, joblessness, and chronic
label: Paragraph

text: poverty result in socio-economic isolation and anomie among public housing residents.
label: Paragraph

text: Eugene Meehan’s definitive policy analysis The Quality of Federal Policy Making holds
label: Paragraph

text: that public housing was doomed to failure from the outset because it never addressed the
label: Paragraph

text: root causes of poverty and inadequate housing. Rather, the provision of public housing
label: Paragraph

text: was always an ambivalent goal, hamstrung by fiscal austerity and lack of commitment.
label: Paragraph

text: Roger Montgomery’s concise article “Pruitt-I[goe: Policy Failure or Societal Symptom?”
label: Paragraph

text: shows how problems endemic to the St. Louis housing market led to the decline of the
label: Paragraph

text: city’s public housing program. He rejects the prevalent view among politicians and
label: Paragraph

text: journalists that Pruitt-lgoe failed because of inadequate design or liberal welfare policies,
label: Paragraph

text: arguing instead that the project unraveled because of declining land values, increased
label: Paragraph

text: housing options in neighborhoods depopulated by “white flight,” persistent racism, and
label: Paragraph

text: inner-city poverty.
label: Paragraph

text: More recent research by historians and urban analysts supports this latter view.
label: Paragraph

text: Although design was clearly a factor in the decline of Pruitt-lgoe, scholars such as Mary
label: Paragraph

text: Comerio and Kate Bristol demonstrate that it was not the cause. In fact, Bristol argues
label: Paragraph

text: that the decline-by-design thesis is a rhetorical strategy common among architects and
label: Paragraph

text: critics, one that serves to bolster the power of the profession by inflating the role that
label: Paragraph

text: architects actually play in housing policy. Architects, Bristol argues, deceive themselves
label: Paragraph

text: with their own rhetoric because they fail to grasp the basic fact that design cannot by
label: Paragraph

text: itself compensate for drastic social inequalities. Moreover, Pruitt-Igoe itself was never
label: Paragraph

text: the example of modernist hubris that its critics claim. Contrary to standard memory,
label: Paragraph

text: Pruitt-lgoe won no architectural awards, and its own designers were critical of the high-
label: Paragraph

text: rise form as a strategy for mass housing. Their designs were merely constrained by
label: Paragraph

text: criteria dictated in advance by the Housing Authority, which favored high-rise, high-
label: Paragraph

text: density public housing.
label: Paragraph

text: Mary Comerio’s research takes the onus off design and places Pruitt-I[goe’s failure
label: Paragraph

text: within the broader historical context of urban renewal and redevelopment, industrial
label: Paragraph

text: relocation and economic restructuring, “white flight,” and the dwindling urban tax base.
label: Paragraph

text: Pruitt-Igoe, she argues, and the larger public housing program in the United States were
label: Paragraph

text: caught up in entrenched historical processes over which architects—and even, to an
label: Paragraph

text: extent, planners and municipal officials—had little control. Moreover, treating public
label: Paragraph

text: housing as an issue of design obscures the social realities of race and class in urban
label: Paragraph

text: environments and distracts critics from the deeper political and economic structures
label: Paragraph

text: within which designers and planners operate.
label: Paragraph

text: In the end, Pruitt-I[goe reflects a federal capital investment of $50 million, a relatively
label: Paragraph

text: small portion of the postwar federal housing chest. Tens of thousands of people found
label: Paragraph

text: themselves directly involved with the project, whether as designers, planners, politicians,
label: Paragraph

text: builders, residents, social workers, librarians, or police. This is a small number when
label: Paragraph

text: compared with the tens of millions of Americans affected by the federal underwriting of
label: Paragraph

text: suburban expansion and home building. However, the power that Pruitt-lgoe continues to
label: Paragraph

text: exercise over the practices of architecture, policymaking, and planning is
label: Paragraph

text: disproportionately great. For better or worse, and with more passion than accuracy,
label: Paragraph

text: Pruitt-Igoe will long stand as a symbol of flawed urban design ideals, municipal
label: Paragraph

text: redevelopment schemes, and federal housing policies.
label: Paragraph

text: JOSEPH HEATHCOTT
label: Title

text: Further Reading
label: Title

text: While there is an extensive literature on Pruitt-[goe, much of it is dispersed through
label: Paragraph

text: scholarly and trade journals, edited collections, occasional papers, and conference
label: Paragraph

text: presentations. Three book-length monographs from the 1970s use Pruitt-lgoe as a
label: Paragraph

text: backdrop for research on social issues such as black family life and structure, welfare
label: Paragraph

text: programming, and public housing policy. Most of the literature falls within either social
label: Paragraph

text: science, policy analysis, or architectural criticism. Only recently have scholars outside of
label: Paragraph

text: these fields turned attention to PruittIgoe and to its history as an urban place.
