text: PUBLIC HOUSING
label: Title

text: Often used loosely, the term public housing describes several very different categories of
label: Paragraph

text: housing. In a narrow sense, particularly in the United States, public housing tends to refer
label: Paragraph

text: to dwellings funded by the national government and owned and operated by a local
label: Paragraph

text: authority. In a broader interpretation, public housing consists of those units whose
label: Paragraph

text: occupants cannot afford housing available on the so-called free market and who benefit,
label: Paragraph

text: according to income-linked criteria, from some form of public assistance, extended either
label: Paragraph

text: directly to the tenants or to developers or owners, who in turn provide discounted rent.
label: Paragraph

text: Finally, one may argue that all housing targeted for any type of public subsidy is public
label: Paragraph

text: housing, regardless of who owns it.
label: Paragraph

text: This last perspective would indicate that in the United States and many other countries
label: Paragraph

text: most housing is, in fact, subsidized with public funds. This is so because its cost to
label: Paragraph

text: private owners is lowered by national, state, and local governments through tax
label: Paragraph

text: expenditures (for example, the deduction of mortgage interest and property tax from
label: Paragraph

text: personal taxable income, amounting to more than $65 billion annually) and the provision
label: Paragraph

text: of public infrastructure (such as roads), among other subsidies. Indirect subsidies of this
label: Paragraph

text: type are not tenure neutral (they benefit owners much more than renters}, and they are
label: Paragraph

text: also highly regressive (they benefit households with high incomes much more than those
label: Paragraph

text: with low incomes).
label: Paragraph

text: These distinctions and their implications are highly significant in the debates that help
label: Paragraph

text: shape housing policies and programs in the United States and elsewhere. However, it is
label: Paragraph

text: not possible here to engage the full scope of this discussion. This brief article focuses
label: Paragraph

text: mainly on U.S. public housing in the more conventional, narrower definition.
label: Paragraph

text: Historical Background
label: Title

text: Public housing is a means-tested, non-cash transfer program. Only households with
label: Paragraph

text: incomes below specified levels are eligible. At present, they pay 30 percent of income for
label: Paragraph

text: rent. Initially authorized by the (Wagner Steagall) Housing Act of 1937, public housing
label: Paragraph

text: in the United States was meant to house families who were temporarily poor as a result of
label: Paragraph

text: the economic depression. Its establishment came after a hard-fought, lengthy battle in
label: Paragraph

text: which the National Association for Real Estate Boards, the U.S. Savings and Loans
label: Paragraph

text: League, and the U.S. Mortgage Bankers Association opposed “socialist” government
label: Paragraph

text: intervention in the housing market. The compromise that was reached has been seen by
label: Paragraph

text: many as more an effort to boost the construction industry and reduce unemployment than
label: Paragraph

text: to provide affordable housing.
label: Paragraph

text: After World War I, the Housing Act of 1949 declared the goal of “a decent home and
label: Paragraph

text: suitable living environment for every American family.” It called for the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: 810,000 public housing units in six years. However, production fell far short, and private
label: Paragraph

text: commercial interests succeeded in appropriating funds that had been tied to residential
label: Paragraph

text: redevelopment. In the following decades, the U.S. commitment to public housing steadily
label: Paragraph

text: declined, and in January 1973 President Richard Nixon imposed a moratorium on all
label: Paragraph

text: federal housing assistance. The moratorium was lifted the following year with the
label: Paragraph

text: enactment of legislation oriented to demand-side subsidies.
label: Paragraph

text: Subsequent significant changes in housing policy included a shift away from large
label: Paragraph

text: projects (scattered-site approach), a trend toward privatization (e.g. in management and
label: Paragraph

text: sale of units), and especially an increased use of the existing housing stock through a
label: Paragraph

text: system of allowances and vouchers that reduced the cost of housing to tenants. Today,
label: Paragraph

text: few new units are built. The total number of public housing units is, in fact, declining at
label: Paragraph

text: present, as large problem projects are being torn down and replaced by higher-quality
label: Paragraph

text: redevelopments built at lower densities.
label: Paragraph

text: Profile and International Scope
label: Title

text: Public housing in the United States provides homes to about 3.3 million people,
label: Paragraph

text: accounting for about 1.5 percent of all occupied dwelling units. The percentage is also
label: Paragraph

text: relatively low in other countries that have traditionally relied heavily on the private-sector
label: Paragraph

text: supply to meet housing demand: Australia (6 percent), New Zealand (5 percent), and
label: Paragraph

text: Canada (5.5 percent), to name three. In Japan, which has also favored a minimal role for
label: Paragraph

text: government in housing provision, public housing for low-income households similarly
label: Paragraph

text: constitutes 5 percent of the total stock. These figures contrast sharply with those in
label: Paragraph

text: regions where national government has played an active role in creating a relatively large
label: Paragraph

text: postwar social housing sector, such as Israel (13 percent), France (18 percent), Germany
label: Paragraph

text: (20 percent), Denmark (24 percent), Britain (31 percent), Sweden (36 percent), The
label: Paragraph

text: Netherlands (45 percent), Hong Kong (50 percent}, and Singapore (86 percent).
label: Paragraph

text: Privatization trends have more recently resulted in a decline of some of these figures,
label: Paragraph

text: although they remain high in comparison. Countries in Eastern Europe and Russia have
label: Paragraph

text: long had a very large housing sector controlled by the central state. During the 1990s,
label: Paragraph

text: their economies underwent a process of transformation oriented to a more market-based
label: Paragraph

text: organization of society. Nonetheless, at the end of the 20th century, after significant sell-
label: Paragraph

text: offs to tenants against nominal prices, diminished but still significant public housing
label: Paragraph

text: stocks remained in, for example, Russia (49 percent), Poland (25 percent), and Hungary
label: Paragraph

text: (13 percent).
label: Paragraph

text: In the United States, the popular image of public housing conjures up mass-produced
label: Paragraph

text: high-rises and superblocks built at high densities with low-quality construction materials
label: Paragraph

text: according to bad designs and situated in undesirable locations. Undeniably, many
label: Paragraph

text: projects fit that description. The Department of Housing and Urban Development
label: Paragraph

text: estimates that about 100,000 units are “severely distressed,” that is, physically
label: Paragraph

text: deteriorated and with high vacancy and unemployment rates. However, such units
label: Paragraph

text: constitute a minority of public housing, concentrated in a few large cities, and they are
label: Paragraph

text: not representative. In fact, the largest proportion of public housing developments in the
label: Paragraph

text: United States, 38 percent, comprises two- or three-story walk-ups; 34 percent are single-
label: Paragraph

text: family attached or detached dwellings. Only 28 percent consist of buildings of four or
label: Paragraph

text: more stories, a share that is dwindling under the HOPE VI program. Public housing in the
label: Paragraph

text: United States includes many examples of fine designs, and some of the most recent
label: Paragraph

text: developments incorporate design concepts strikingly similar to some of the earliest public
label: Paragraph

text: housing in the country.
label: Paragraph

text: Initially, U.S. public housing was intended as temporary housing for poor households
label: Paragraph

text: expected to work their way up to private-market housing. However, increasingly it
label: Paragraph

text: became a last resort for people with no prospects for other housing options. As a result,
label: Paragraph

text: over time, public housing has become residualized. Many residents are dependent on
label: Paragraph

text: welfare (over 50 percent} and social security or disability payments (25 percent). About
label: Paragraph

text: 75 percent of households are headed by a single adult, usually an elderly person or a
label: Paragraph

text: single parent. A majority are nonwhite.
label: Paragraph

text: In western and northern Europe after World War Il, many governments embarked on
label: Paragraph

text: large-scale housing programs to meet pent-up demand and make up for housing stock
label: Paragraph

text: destroyed in the war. More than 5 million units were built. Most of this construction
label: Paragraph

text: occurred in the form of high-rises built on peripherally located estates. By the mid-1970s,
label: Paragraph

text: the absolute shortages had been eliminated. Demand fell. Households with rising incomes
label: Paragraph

text: moved out, leaving behind those without choice. Vacancies rose, revenues declined, and
label: Paragraph

text: conditions quickly deteriorated. Since then, local authorities and nonprofit landlords,
label: Paragraph

text: oriented to providing and managing social housing, have increasingly faced social
label: Paragraph

text: welfare challenges engendered by economic, political, and demographic trends in the
label: Paragraph

text: larger society.
label: Paragraph

text: In eastern Europe, national governments controlled property rights and financial
label: Paragraph

text: resources. Central planning produced a mass-housing sector owned and operated by state
label: Paragraph

text: agencies and state-run industries. Large estates comprising prefabricated dwelling units
label: Paragraph

text: in multistory buildings became home to 170 million people. Access to housing was a
label: Paragraph

text: legislated entitlement, and since wages were low, households spent only a small
label: Paragraph

text: proportion of their income on rent (often around 3 percent). Limited rent revenues and
label: Paragraph

text: subsidies insufficient for operating and maintenance needs, often combined with low-
label: Paragraph

text: quality building materials and fast construction, caused the housing to fall into disrepair
label: Paragraph

text: quickly. Responsibilities for upkeep and repair became a salient issue in the transition of
label: Paragraph

text: the former state socialist systems into more market-oriented societies.
label: Paragraph

text: In the developing countries, with a few exceptions, public housing has constituted only
label: Paragraph

text: a minute portion of housing production. Typically, self-help and other informal processes
label: Paragraph

text: of housing provision have been much more important. Insofar as scarce resources were
label: Paragraph

text: used for the building of public housing, the beneficiaries have usually been civil servants
label: Paragraph

text: rather than the poorest segments of the population. Current efforts are generally directed
label: Paragraph

text: toward enabling housing markets to work, although it remains to be seen whether this
label: Paragraph

text: approach will extend access to housing to the lowest-income groups.
label: Paragraph

text: Design in Context
label: Title

text: In terms of architecture and project layout, there have been three stages in the evolution
label: Paragraph

text: of public housing in the United States. In the 1930s and the early 1940s, semienclosed
label: Paragraph

text: courts with walk-up buildings dominated, aligned with the streets but with entries usually
label: Paragraph

text: from the interior of the site. Open areas between lines of row houses or walk-ups or
label: Paragraph

text: around widely spaced elevator high-rises placed at an angle to the street or in closed
label: Paragraph

text: streets were more characteristic of projects built from the 1940s through the 1960s. From
label: Paragraph

text: the late 1970s onward, public housing designs more typically include private yards and
label: Paragraph

text: semi- or fully enclosed courts for row houses and low-rises with entrances reoriented to
label: Paragraph

text: front the streets. The different designs have been seen as the enactment of prevailing
label: Paragraph

text: belief systems concerning the place of public housing and its residents in the surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: community and society at large.
label: Paragraph

text: Illustrative of the broader context of design is the Pruitt-lgoe project in St. Louis,
label: Paragraph

text: which opened its doors to the first tenants in the early 1950s amid high praise for its
label: Paragraph

text: design. When it was dynamited scarcely 20 years later, many critics decried design
label: Paragraph

text: features, such as the lack of semipublic space and the mismatch between the social and
label: Paragraph

text: physical environment (for example, large families in high-rise apartments), attributing to
label: Paragraph

text: them the project’s failure. Others, however, have downplayed the significance of design
label: Paragraph

text: in the demise of Pruitt-[goe and similar projects, instead emphasizing the role of
label: Paragraph

text: insufficient budgets and discriminatory policies.
label: Paragraph

text: Current Approaches
label: Title

text: Public housing remains a valuable resource. It is home to millions of households who
label: Paragraph

text: cannot afford market housing. Maintaining this resource requires that extant challenges
label: Paragraph

text: be effectively met. Current approaches fall into two categories. The first is tenant based,
label: Paragraph

text: primarily under the Section 8 program. It seeks to ameliorate the concentration of poverty
label: Paragraph

text: by portable subsidies, such as vouchers and allowances, aimed at increasing household
label: Paragraph

text: mobility, and sometimes provides additional supports, such as job training. The second,
label: Paragraph

text: area-based, supply-side approach focuses on the housing estates themselves in an attempt
label: Paragraph

text: to address problems in a comprehensive manner. The latter approach is multipronged
label: Paragraph

text: (incorporating more accountable forms of management, providing programs and services
label: Paragraph

text: in support of resident needs, attracting mixed-income tenant populations, and carrying
label: Paragraph

text: out research-based design) and seeks to avoid past mistakes that led to higher rates of
label: Paragraph

text: vandalism and crime. HOPE VI funding has stimulated improved architecture and site
label: Paragraph

text: planning to foster neighborly interactions and promote safety (crime prevention through
label: Paragraph

text: environmental design). In addition, examples are growing of public housing that
label: Paragraph

text: integrates programs to assist residents in becoming economically more self-reliant (for
label: Paragraph

text: example, Project Self-Sufficiency) and that provides services that facilitate independent
label: Paragraph

text: functioning (such as Section 202).
label: Paragraph

text: The problems facing U.S. public housing—problems of design, siting, maintenance,
label: Paragraph

text: and population composition—are often attributable to oppositional economic and
label: Paragraph

text: political forces rather than to causes inherent in the public subsidy of housing. Smaller
label: Paragraph

text: schemes that use individual street addresses rather than project names and that are woven
label: Paragraph

text: into the fabric of the surrounding community by integrating services and mixing different
label: Paragraph

text: income groups will make public housing less distinguishable from private housing.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, evidence links the emergence of successful public housing to the dissolution of
label: Paragraph

text: its standout image and to its being an integral part of a comprehensive approach to
label: Paragraph

text: housing.
label: Paragraph

text: PUIG I CADAFALCH, JOSEP 1867-1956
label: Caption

text: Architect, Catalonia
label: Title

text: Josep Puig i Cadafalch was one of the leading architects of the modernisme movement
label: Paragraph

text: that flourished in the Spanish region of Catalonia during the first decades of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century. In many ways, Puig moved elegantly between the organic extravagance of
label: Paragraph

text: modernisme and the ordered geometry of novecentismo. This was in part because of the
label: Paragraph

text: fact that he was much younger than Antoni Gaudi i Cornet and Lluis Doménech i
label: Paragraph

text: Montaner, the leading architects of the first movement, and somewhat older than the next
label: Paragraph

text: generation. Puig drew inspiration from 15th-century Catalan Gothic architecture, a style
label: Paragraph

text: that was decidedly different from classic High Gothic. Despite his almost religious zeal
label: Paragraph

text: for regional historical traditions, he also looked outside Spain for inspiration. Puig
label: Paragraph

text: traveled widely throughout Europe, especially Germany and Austria, and wrote
label: Paragraph

text: approvingly of the work of Henry-Clement Van de Velde, Josef Maria Olbrich, and Otto
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner. He particularly admired Olbrich’s designs for buildings at the Darmstadt artist’s
label: Paragraph

text: colony. The English Arts and Crafts also had an enormous effect on his architectural
label: Paragraph

text: style.
label: Paragraph

text: Puig rigorously examined and studied the historical architecture of Catalonia,
label: Paragraph

text: eventually publishing several leading scholarly texts. He rejected monumentalism and
label: Paragraph

text: classical forms in favor of a style firmly rooted in Catalan culture and society. Puig
label: Paragraph

text: abhorred classical styles, declaring that they had little to do with native tradition and were
label: Paragraph

text: simply another non-Catalan fashion imposed by the central government in Madrid. In his
label: Paragraph

text: own work, Puig attempted to combine the folk traditions of rural Catalonia with the
label: Paragraph

text: deliberate artistry and modern materials of urban society. In all his structures, he
label: Paragraph

text: combined a commitment to local tradition and history with a strong faith in modernity
label: Paragraph

text: and internationalism.
label: Paragraph

text: Puig emphasized simple volumes that echoed the traditional floor plans of Catalan
label: Paragraph

text: farmhouses. These areas had an organic layout with spaces that gently flowed together.
label: Paragraph

text: His interiors became known for their remarkable sense of intimacy and warmth produced
label: Paragraph

text: through diffuse lighting and lavish use of wood as decoration. A strong sense of
label: Paragraph

text: nationalism and history led him to encourage local craft techniques, including wood-
label: Paragraph

text: working, ceramics, stained glass, and sgraffito. Puig’s structures emphasized a richness
label: Paragraph

text: of detail combined with a simplicity of form. The exteriors often faced the street with
label: Paragraph

text: large, planar facades of stucco or unadorned brick punctuated with almost baroque-like
label: Paragraph

text: stone oriels and decoration. The specific decorative elements ranged from organic
label: Paragraph

text: flowers and animals to heraldic devices, shields, and symbols of nobility.
label: Paragraph

text: His first major work was the Casa Marti (1896) in Barcelona’s Gothic quarter. The
label: Paragraph

text: hulking building recalled a feudal manor house of the medieval Catalan past. The
label: Paragraph

text: exposed brick walls combined with stonework decoration to give the structure an
label: Paragraph

text: artisanal feel. The interior contained large spaces covered by wood beams and
label: Paragraph

text: illuminated by delicate iron chandeliers. This illustrated Puig’s deliberate combination of
label: Paragraph

text: traditional form with modern ornament. It was this interior that, a year after completion
label: Paragraph

text: of the structure, housed a cafe called the Els Quatre Gats (the Four Cats). The building
label: Paragraph

text: soon became the social gathering place of Pablo Picasso, Miquel Utrillo, Ramon Casas,
label: Paragraph

text: Santiago Rusinyol, artists who would soon bring Catalan modernisme an international
label: Paragraph

text: reputation.
label: Paragraph

text: The politics of Catalan nationalism, combined with a growing class of wealthy patrons,
label: Paragraph

text: led to a series of important commissions during the period 1900-05. It was with these
label: Paragraph

text: houses that the architectural style of Puig found its greatest expression. The first,
label: Paragraph

text: constructed for a wealthy chocolate maker, was the Casa Amatller (1900). Puig designed
label: Paragraph

text: the house to be a jewel of individuality set within what he viewed as the rigid conformity
label: Paragraph

text: of Ildefons Cerda’s gridlike urban plan for Barcelona. He wished to express the opulence
label: Paragraph

text: and power of his wealthy clients through extravagant use of rich materials and
label: Paragraph

text: symbolism. The plan exhibited the characteristics typical to rural Catalan homes, with a
label: Paragraph

text: large central courtyard and a central stair rising to the main public room of the first floor.
label: Caption

text: The interior was richly appointed in wood and plaster. The public rooms contained ornate
label: Paragraph

text: columns, and the highly decorated wooden ceiling beams recalled traditional Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: mudéjar ornamentation. The flat wall facing the street, however, revealed that Puig was
label: Paragraph

text: not simply blindly following the ancient tenets. Instead, the wall was peppered with
label: Paragraph

text: sgraffito and topped by an ornate pediment decorated with brightly colored tiles. The
label: Paragraph

text: outline of the structure resembled the stepped triangular rooflines of Northern European
label: Paragraph

text: homes. In addition to the tiles, the architect decorated the front of the structure with both
label: Paragraph

text: whimsical and pious sculpture. Saint George, the patron saint of Catalonia, shared space
label: Caption

text: with rats, pigs, and frogs. Eventually, Doménech built the Casa Lled Morera to the left,
label: Paragraph

text: and the building on the right was replaced by Gaudi’s Casa Batll6, making the short
label: Paragraph

text: block one of the single greatest concentrations of modernist architecture in the entire city.
label: Paragraph

text: A second home designed for a wealthy patron was the Casa Terrades (1905), better
label: Paragraph

text: known as the “Casa de les Punxes” (House of the Points). The nickname came from the
label: Paragraph

text: building’s four small round turrets and a large main tower topped by sharp spires. It again
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated Puig’s affection for Northern European designs. A series of profusely
label: Paragraph

text: decorated doorways and window openings punctuated the plain brick walls. The
label: Paragraph

text: decorative sculpture again included a large ceramic plaque dedicated to St. George. The
label: Paragraph

text: choice of decoration illustrated the ostentatious religiosity of the wealthy bourgeoisie and
label: Paragraph

text: also their nationalism.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to being a practicing architect, Puig had a second career as an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: historian. He employed a scientific approach that emphasized observation and
label: Paragraph

text: measurement. Puig was convinced of the connections between all aspects of a region’s
label: Paragraph

text: culture, including language, art, and architecture. He thought of architecture as a
label: Paragraph

text: communal art form created by peoples and nations rather than individuals and that
label: Paragraph

text: historic forms had been dictated by the particular needs and traditions of the region.
label: Paragraph

text: Although exiled following the Spanish civil war, Puig’s theory and practice continued to
label: Paragraph

text: influence Spanish architecture. The emphasis on regional design elements and quality
label: Paragraph

text: decoration was later taken up by members of the loosely organized School of Barcelona,
label: Paragraph

text: which included Ricardo Bofill, Oriol Bohigas, and Studio Per.
label: Paragraph

text: PURCELL, WILLIAM GRAY, AND
label: Title

text: GEORGE GRANT ELMSLIE
label: Title

text: Architecture firm, United States
label: Title

text: The partnership of William Gray Purcell (1880-1965) and George Grant Elmslie
label: Paragraph

text: (1871-1952) was remarkable in the annals of architecture. It lasted from 1909 until 1922.
label: Paragraph

text: During these years, the two men made a major contribution to the Prairie School and
label: Paragraph

text: created some of its finest buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Born on a farm in northeastern Scotland, Elmslie attended the famous Duke of Gordon
label: Paragraph

text: School in Huntly. His education included a strict Presbyterianism along with a
label: Paragraph

text: consciousness of the mysticism that is a strong feature of the Scottish heritage. With his
label: Paragraph

text: family, Elmslie immigrated to the United States in 1884. They settled in Chicago, where
label: Paragraph

text: his father was already working. After a brief period in business school, Elmslie followed
label: Paragraph

text: the suggestion of his parents and began the study of architecture in the office of Joseph
label: Paragraph

text: Lyman Silsbee, where George Maher and Frank Lloyd Wright were already working.
label: Paragraph

text: When Wright left Silsbee in 1889 to join Adler and Sullivan, he asked Elmslie to come
label: Paragraph

text: with him. The offer was accepted, with momentous consequences for both Sullivan and
label: Paragraph

text: Elmslie. When Wright left the office in the mid-1890s, Elmslie became Sullivan’s chief
label: Paragraph

text: draftsman, a position that he held for 15 years. During this period, Elmslie learned
label: Paragraph

text: thoroughly the principles of organic architecture and became adept at designing ornament
label: Paragraph

text: in the Sullivan manner. He detailed nearly all the exterior ornament for the Wainwright
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1890) in St. Louis, designed the ironwork entrance for the Carson Pirie Scott
label: Caption

text: Store (1901-03) in Chicago, and had a major share in the design of the National Farmers
label: Paragraph

text: Bank (1908) in Owatonna, Minnesota. By 1909 business in the Sullivan office had
label: Paragraph

text: declined to such an extent that Elmslie was open to the offer of a partnership from
label: Paragraph

text: William Gray Purcell, a young Minneapolis architect whom he had known since 1903.
label: Paragraph

text: Purcell had grown up in Oak Park, Illinois, in comfortable circumstances. He was
label: Paragraph

text: educated in its excellent schools, at a liberal private academy, and at Cornell University,
label: Paragraph

text: where he took an architectural degree in 1903. The academic curriculum was profoundly
label: Paragraph

text: distasteful to Purcell. (In correspondence with this writer, he always referred to it
label: Paragraph

text: contemptuously as “Bozart.”} Nonetheless, he mastered conventional drafting techniques
label: Paragraph

text: and, after graduation, was briefly in Sullivan’s office, an experience that stayed with him
label: Paragraph

text: for the rest of his life. He also worked in Berkeley for John Galen Howard and in Seattle.
label: Paragraph

text: Then, in 1906, at the suggestion of his father, Purcell departed for a yearlong odyssey in
label: Paragraph

text: Europe in company with his Cornell classmate George Feick. The two young men not
label: Paragraph

text: only visited the classical sites in Greece and Italy and the French cathedral towns but also
label: Paragraph

text: called on such progressive leaders as Hendrik Berlage in the Netherlands, Martin Nyrop
label: Paragraph

text: in Denmark, and Ferdinand Boberg in Sweden. On their return to the United States, Feick
label: Paragraph

text: convinced Purcell that there was room for a new kind of architectural firm in
label: Paragraph

text: Minneapolis. They opened an office in February 1907. Elmslie joined them in 1909, and
label: Paragraph

text: in 1913 Feick withdrew. Although Purcell moved to Philadelphia in 1916, he continued
label: Paragraph

text: his association with Elmslie until 1922.
label: Paragraph

text: The great years for Purcell and Elmslie and for the other Prairie architects were those
label: Paragraph

text: immediately preceding World War |. Elmslie brought with him much domestic work
label: Paragraph

text: from clients who wanted progressive houses but could no longer endure the difficulties of
label: Paragraph

text: working with Sullivan. These clients included
label: Paragraph

text: Babson Stable and Service building, inner court showing east elevation of
label: Caption

text: garage Riverside, Illinois (c. 1916 additions and alterations to the
label: Caption

text: 1908 original Babson House by Louis Sullivan)
label: Caption

text: © Historic American Buildings Survey/Library of Congress
label: Caption

text: Henry Babson, the Cranes, and the Bradleys. For Babson there were several additions to
label: Paragraph

text: his estate in Riverside, Illinois, and for the Bradleys there was the much-admired
label: Paragraph

text: “bungalow” (1913) at Cape Cod. There were other important domestic commissions as
label: Paragraph

text: well: the Powers House (1910) in Minneapolis, the Decker House (1913) at Lake
label: Paragraph

text: Minnetonka, the E.S.Hoyt House (1915) at Red Wing, and an exquisite small house on
label: Paragraph

text: Lake Place in Minneapolis for Purcell himself in the same year. This last dwelling has
label: Paragraph

text: been beautifully restored and is today the property of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts.
label: Paragraph

text: All these houses had in common an open plan, beautiful proportions, a knowing choice of
label: Paragraph

text: materials, and where the budget allowed, furniture and leaded glass in a_ highly
label: Paragraph

text: individualized manner. Superficially, they resemble the contemporary Prairie houses of
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright, whose work Purcell and Elmslie had earlier admired. The houses of
label: Paragraph

text: Purcell and Elmslie, however, were usually lighter in feeling and often more livable.
label: Paragraph

text: The other great specialty of the firm was the small-town bank. Encouraged by the
label: Paragraph

text: success of the Sullivan-Elmslie Bank (1908) for Carl K. Bennett at Owatonna,
label: Paragraph

text: Minnesota, the new partnership actively sought similar omissions throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: Midwest. Happily, they found a number of similar progressive-minded bankers. Their
label: Paragraph

text: banks in Leroy, Grand Meadow, and Adams, Minnesota, and in Rhinelander, Wisconsin,
label: Paragraph

text: are particularly fine. These banks stand like jewel boxes in hamlets that are reminiscent
label: Paragraph

text: of Gopher Prairie in the novels of Sinclair Lewis. The largest of their banks, a superlative
label: Paragraph

text: creation, is the Merchants’ Bank (1912) of Winona, Minnesota. For this building, the
label: Paragraph

text: firm used pier-and-lintel framing with steel girders set on brick piers to define the cubic
label: Paragraph

text: form of the banking room, thus relieving the walls of support function so that they could
label: Paragraph

text: be opened up for large panes of leaded glass. There was also a great deal of terracotta
label: Paragraph

text: ormmament, and the chairs and the other furniture were designed to match the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: elements, all in keeping with Prairie School principles.
label: Paragraph

text: The largest building to be constructed by Purcell and Elmslie was the Woodbury
label: Paragraph

text: County Courthouse for Sioux City, lowa, done in association with William L.Steele.
label: Caption

text: Steele won the commission in 1916 and then asked Elmslie to develop a plan expressing
label: Paragraph

text: the agricultural wealth of the region and the sturdy population of its inhabitants. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: opposition from several quarters, the Elmslie concept was carried through. It featured an
label: Paragraph

text: amazing amount of terra-cotta ornament and a series of massive friezes by Alfonso
label: Caption

text: Jannelli, who had earlier worked with Wright at the Midway Gardens. About 60 percent
label: Paragraph

text: of the designing was done by Elmslie, who moved to Sioux City for the duration of the
label: Paragraph

text: job. The remainder came through the Minneapolis office. The courthouse is a building of
label: Paragraph

text: an almost indigestible richness.
label: Paragraph

text: Design procedures in the office of Purcell and Elmslie were essentially democratic,
label: Paragraph

text: with both partners contributing at differ-ent stages to the finished project. In a profound
label: Paragraph

text: sense, the two men were necessary to each other. Elmslie had a deep understanding of the
label: Paragraph

text: organic principles underlying the architecture of Louis Sullivan, but at times his
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupation with the role of ornament could degenerate into decorative efflorescence.
label: Paragraph

text: Purcell, equally convinced of organic and democratic principles but more cautious by
label: Paragraph

text: nature, was a restraining influence and at the same time was stimulated by his partner to
label: Paragraph

text: explore the essential nature of design. Elmslie tended to think graphically. Purcell was
label: Paragraph

text: happy with verbal expression and in later years wrote a column of architectural criticism
label: Paragraph

text: for The Minnesota Architect. Both were committed to social progress and to
label: Paragraph

text: experimentation with the low-cost dwelling. Their work can generally be distinguished
label: Paragraph

text: from that of Wright and the other Prairie School architects by its generally axial order
label: Paragraph

text: and frequently by a whimsical touch. Spatially, they were not as adventurous as Wright,
label: Paragraph

text: but in many ways they were more humane. Although Wright did his best to denigrate
label: Paragraph

text: Purcell and Elmslie, their achievement has been largely recovered by a later generation of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural historians. Today, it is generally recognized that they made a major
label: Paragraph

text: contribution to the Prairie School and to the American architecture of their period.
label: Paragraph

text: George Grant Elmslie
label: Title

text: Born in Huntly, Scotland, 20 February 1871; family moved to Chicago 1884. Educated in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago public schools. Joined the office of J.Lyman Silsbee, Chicago 1888; joined firm
label: Caption

text: of Adler and Sullivan, Chicago 1889; became head draftsman when Frank Lloyd Wright
label: Paragraph

text: left the firm 1893. Partner, with William Gray Purcell and George Feick, Purcell Feick
label: Paragraph

text: and Elmslie, Chicago 1909-13; partner, Purcell and Elmslie, Chicago 1913-22.
label: Caption

text: Continued working in Chicago from 1922. Died in Chicago, 23 April 1952.
label: Paragraph

text: R
label: Title

text: RAILROAD STATION
label: Title

text: The railroad station as a building type was born in the early 19th century, when vehicles
label: Paragraph

text: that traveled on their own “railroads” began to be used for the transportation of not only
label: Paragraph

text: goods but also humans. The primary reason for such a building was the basic need to
label: Paragraph

text: shelter both trains and people. However, the railroad station fulfilled a psychological
label: Paragraph

text: need as well. Before the widespread use of railroads, traveling was an arduous and
label: Paragraph

text: extended affair consisting of a series of gradual transitions from one place to another. By
label: Paragraph

text: means of the railroad (and later the airplane), traveling became an easier task consisting
label: Paragraph

text: of merely embarking and disembarking a vehicle, with no stops in between. For the
label: Paragraph

text: industrial city, the railroad station became what the city gate had been for the medieval
label: Paragraph

text: city—that special inbetween transitional location, the first and last view of a city, the
label: Paragraph

text: physical and psychological location of entrance and exit.
label: Paragraph

text: The architectural history of the railroad station suggests a dialogue between the
label: Paragraph

text: building and its train tracks. Buildings were first placed alongside of the tracks, as is still
label: Paragraph

text: the case in many suburban and rural train stations. Those on both sides of the tracks were
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes linked with naturally lit steel-and-glass atriums, or train sheds. Those stations
label: Paragraph

text: that terminated a train line, usually in large urban metropolises, tended to screen both
label: Paragraph

text: tracks and shed from view by means of either a separate construction, as in Euston
label: Paragraph

text: Station (1839, Philip Hardwick, demolished 1962) in London, or a third building that
label: Paragraph

text: linked shed and buildings either side, as in Gare de |’Est (1852, Frangois Duquesney) in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris. The shed and buildings of St. Pancras Station in London, although touching, were
label: Paragraph

text: designed and built separately by engineer William H.Barlow (1868) and architect Sir
label: Paragraph

text: George Gilbert Scott (1876). Toward the end of the 19th century, the size of a railroad
label: Paragraph

text: station’s train shed became its qualifying criterion, and a contest began to see who could
label: Paragraph

text: build the largest. Broad Street Station (1893, Joseph and John Wilson, demolished 1953)
label: Caption

text: in Philadelphia reached a limit with its ingenious 300-foot three-hinged wrought-iron
label: Paragraph

text: shed.
label: Paragraph

text: By the turn of the 20th century, the areas around such large urban terminals were no
label: Paragraph

text: longer on the outskirts of town in unwanted industrial areas. Instead, the city had usually
label: Paragraph

text: grown up around them, and they found themselves on valuable real estate. To take
label: Paragraph

text: advantage of this, some train tracks, originally at street level or elevated, were buried
label: Paragraph

text: below ground, and their land was sold for development. A new station building, not just
label: Paragraph

text: shed and facade, could then be built on top of these sunken tracks. The main
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic of this new type of station was its central hall or concourse—large enough
label: Paragraph

text: to accommodate huge numbers of people and lofty enough to present itself as the center
label: Paragraph

text: of the city, if not the whole world. Such is the case with Pennsylvania Station (1910,
label: Paragraph

text: McKim, Mead, and White, demolished 1964) in New York; Union Station (1907, D.H.
label: Caption

text: Burnham and Company) in Washington, D.C.; and Grand Central Station (1913, Warren
label: Paragraph

text: and Westmore and Reed and Stem) in New York.
label: Paragraph

text: In Chicago, the acknowledged railroad city of the early 20th century, Daniel
label: Paragraph

text: H.Burnham and Edward H.Bennett gave lengthy consideration to the location, multimode
label: Paragraph

text: functions, and style of the modern railroad terminal in their influential Plan of Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: (1909). For the next decade or so, City Beautiful architects and planners often made a
label: Paragraph

text: new railroad terminal one of the chief urban forms.
label: Paragraph

text: By hiding the tracks from view, the concourse-type railroad station eliminated the
label: Paragraph

text: previously mentioned design problem of separate buildings and train sheds. This
label: Paragraph

text: elimination of separate building and shed is also characteristic of modernist railroad
label: Paragraph

text: stations where train tracks and their roof covering, instead of being hidden below ground,
label: Paragraph

text: became integrated into a complete design. Helsinki Station (1910—20, Eliel Saarinen),
label: Paragraph

text: which does not rely on any 19th-century Gothic, Doric, or Moorish eclecticism for its
label: Paragraph

text: decoration, is an early example of this. The main station in Florence, Italy (1934-36,
label: Paragraph

text: Giovanni Michelucci), was one of the first International Style railroad stations,
label: Paragraph

text: integrating its building and shed so easily perhaps because steel and glass were part of the
label: Paragraph

text: whole building’s palette.
label: Paragraph

text: Because of the increased usage of the automobile and the airplane, there were not
label: Paragraph

text: many new railroad stations built after World War II, with the exception of those rebuilt
label: Paragraph

text: because of war damage. Stazione Termini (1951, Montuori and Calini) in Rome,
label: Caption

text: although newly built, was a prototype followed by most rebuilt stations: long, flat, and
label: Paragraph

text: unarticulated facades, attempting to unify both building and shed into one composition.
label: Paragraph

text: A general period of railroad station decline occurred in the 1960s and 1970s, as many
label: Paragraph

text: were abandoned and even de-
label: Paragraph

text: Continental Train Platform, Waterloo Station, London, designed by Nicholas
label: Caption

text: Grimshaw and Partners (1993)
label: Caption

text: © Don Barker/GreatBuildings.com
label: Caption

text: molished, particularly in the United States. During the 1980s, a small railroad station
label: Paragraph

text: renaissance occurred as existing stations were enlarged and appended to become home to
label: Paragraph

text: shopping malls, restaurants, office space, and other non-rail-related functions. In this
label: Paragraph

text: way, railroad stations became more of a place to visit and stay rather than just a place to
label: Paragraph

text: pass through. Charing Cross Station in London had its 1906 train shed removed and
label: Paragraph

text: replaced with an office building (1984, Terry Farrell). Similarly, Union Station in
label: Paragraph

text: Washington, D.C., turned its concourse into a giant shopping mall by pushing back its
label: Paragraph

text: platforms (1988, Benjamin Thompson Architects).
label: Paragraph

text: Newly built railroad stations at the end of the 20th century were mostly constructed in
label: Paragraph

text: response to increased high-speed train lines or the creation of city-center links to out-of-
label: Paragraph

text: town airports. Atocha Station in Madrid turned its central hall into a palm-treed shopping
label: Paragraph

text: mall, and another station was built next door to handle a new Madrid-Seville express
label: Paragraph

text: (1984-92, Rafael Moneo). Waterloo Station in London was appended with a
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary reinterpretation of a 19th-century train shed to accommodate a high-speed
label: Paragraph

text: service under the English Channel to continental Europe (1993, Nicholas Grimshaw and
label: Paragraph

text: Partners). Roissy Station at Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris cleverly joined high-speed
label: Paragraph

text: and regional train lines with not only the airport but also a hotel (1994, Paul Andreu).
label: Paragraph

text: Finally, the form of the Lyon-Satolas Station for Lyon Airport (1996, Santiago Calatrava)
label: Paragraph

text: in France uses bird-in-flight imagery similar to the TWA Terminal (1962, Eero Saarinen)
label: Paragraph

text: in New York.
label: Paragraph

text: The future of the building-type railroad station in the 21st century obviously depends
label: Paragraph

text: on the future of rail travel. However, as indicated by the French examples cited
label: Paragraph

text: previously, a new and faster means of transportation, such as the airplane, does not
label: Paragraph

text: necessarily mean the decline of new railroad stations and facilities.
label: Paragraph

text: RAMSES WISSA WASSEF ARTS CENTRE
label: Title

text: Designed by Ramses Wissa Wassef, completed 1989 Harrania, Egypt
label: Caption

text: The School and Arts Centre at Harrania, which bears his name, is the magnum opus of
label: Paragraph

text: Ramses Wissa Wassef (1911-74), a prominent Egyptian architect and educator.
label: Paragraph

text: Convinced of the value of and the need for training and practice in arts and crafts and in
label: Paragraph

text: the educational and cultural development of young children, he began teaching weaving
label: Paragraph

text: to a small group of children who attended a primary school that he had designed in Old
label: Paragraph

text: Cairo in the 1940s. The satisfaction and benefit that those children gained from his
label: Paragraph

text: devoted teaching and the high quality of the work they produced persuaded Wissa
label: Paragraph

text: Wassef to establish a school specifically for training children in the arts and crafts.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1951, he and his wife bought a plot of land at Harrania, a small village near Giza,
label: Paragraph

text: for that purpose. There was no precise brief. Wissa Wassef was his own client, and the
label: Paragraph

text: demand for the sort of school he had envisioned was unknown, unproven; initially, it
label: Paragraph

text: would have to be funded solely from his own resources. It would have to be built
label: Paragraph

text: economically, and it must not alienate the community of fe//lahin (peasant farmers and
label: Paragraph

text: farm laborers) among whom, in the village of Harrania, he had settled. He would use only
label: Paragraph

text: local materials—the silty brown earth of the narrow fertile plain between the Nile and the
label: Paragraph

text: desert escarpment to the west—and he would design and build in the vernacular tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: From the field study visits that he had made with his architectural students to Upper
label: Paragraph

text: Egypt, he had discovered the quality and the beauty of the Nubian villages; his colleague
label: Paragraph

text: at the School of Fine Arts, Hassan Fathy, had recently embarked on the planning and
label: Paragraph

text: design of a new village, in the Nubian vernacular tradition, on the west bank of the Nile
label: Paragraph

text: near Luxor in Upper Egypt. Encouraged by Hassan Fathy’s example and fired with
label: Paragraph

text: enthusiasm by his own discovery of Nubian architecture, Wissa Wassef described his
label: Paragraph

text: decision to build in the traditional way:
label: Paragraph

text: I had just visited Aswan, where | had been struck by the beauty of the Nubian
label: Paragraph

text: houses in the villages of the area, | learnt that it was still possible to find
label: Paragraph

text: bricklayers who could make vaulted roofs for houses. | felt a strange excitement
label: Paragraph

text: when I thought that these same methods had existed since the first dynasties of
label: Paragraph

text: the Pharaohs. They had survived throughout Egyptian, Coptic and Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: history, and were still used in popular architecture. | decided to make use of
label: Paragraph

text: some these bricklayers from Aswan, and turn their experience to account in
label: Paragraph

text: building vaults for my school. (de Stefano, n.d.)
label: Caption

text: The school grew slowly. Village children were enrolled to learn weaving, and they were
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged to assist the Nubian builders in making mud bricks and building adobe walls
label: Paragraph

text: for the school buildings: weaving workshops, storerooms, and display spaces. Later,
label: Paragraph

text: Wissa Wassef introduced the teaching of pottery: kilns, pottery workshops, and
label: Paragraph

text: storerooms were needed. By the late 1950s, tapestries and carpets designed and made by
label: Paragraph

text: the students were being exhibited internationally—in the United States, Switzerland,
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, and Sweden—and money earned from the sale of the students’ work was
label: Paragraph

text: shared between the weavers themselves and the school. The pace and scale of building
label: Paragraph

text: increased; by 1970, the first phase of building was complete.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early 1970s, his daughters Suzanne and Yoanna joined Wissa Wassef and his
label: Paragraph

text: wife, Sophie, in teaching at the school. The small ceramic sculpture museum was
label: Paragraph

text: designed and built and named after Sophie’s father, the sculptor Habib Gorgy. In 1973,
label: Paragraph

text: Suzanne married the architect Ikram Nosshi, one of her father’s former students at the
label: Paragraph

text: School of Fine Arts. After Wissa Wassef’s unexpected death in 1974 at the age of 63,
label: Paragraph

text: Nosshi continued the architectural development of the school under the direction of
label: Paragraph

text: Sophie Habib Gorgy, Wissa Wassef’s widow. She expanded and extended the scope of
label: Paragraph

text: the school, acquiring more land, encouraging the building of houses on the site for her
label: Paragraph

text: daughters and their families, and creating the Ramses Wissa Wassef Museum, which
label: Paragraph

text: houses the permanent collection of the Arts Centre and traces the development of tapestry
label: Paragraph

text: weaving, ceramics, and all the crafts taught there since the early days of its foundation.
label: Paragraph

text: Completed in 1989, the museum, designed by Nosshi, forms the culmination of the
label: Paragraph

text: complex and, although designed by a different hand, fits perfectly into the environment
label: Paragraph

text: created by Wissa Wassef and his wife.
label: Paragraph

text: On entering the main gate of the Arts Centre, one enters a new world. The immediate
label: Paragraph

text: environment is bleak; the village of Harrania has grown out of all recognition since the
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s, when the Wissa Wassefs began to realize their vision, and has become a peri-
label: Paragraph

text: urban suburb of greater Cairo. Within the boundary walls, the naturally rendered adobe
label: Paragraph

text: walls, roof terraces, vaults, and domes of the congeries of buildings are linked by arcaded
label: Paragraph

text: verandas, courtyards, brick-paved passageways, open staircases, and small shady gardens,
label: Paragraph

text: all planned in an organic and apparently spontaneous way. The whole complex is
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by an extensive garden, planted with a wide variety of trees and shrubs, and
label: Paragraph

text: has the appearance of an old, established rural community. Internally as well, the various
label: Paragraph

text: working spaces, large and small, and the museums and galleries for displaying the
label: Paragraph

text: tapestries, carpets, textiles, batiks, pottery, and ceramics are comfortably cool and
label: Paragraph

text: appropriately lit with tiny skylights set into domes and vaults, clerestory windows, and
label: Paragraph

text: simply designed perforated screen walls. The whole place is an oasis of calm and peace
label: Paragraph

text: and at the same time an ever-flowing spring of creativity. In 1983, its merits were
label: Paragraph

text: internationally recognized by winning the Aga Khan Award for Architecture. In the
label: Paragraph

text: award citation, the project was commended “for the beauty of its execution, the high
label: Paragraph

text: value of its objectives and the social impact of its activities, as well as its influence as an
label: Paragraph

text: example...for its role as a centre of art and
label: Paragraph

text: Pottery Studio in Courtyard, Ramses Wissa Wassef Arts Centre
label: Caption

text: Photo by Charles Avedissian © Aga Khan Trust for Culture
label: Caption

text: life and for its endurance, its continuity and its promise” (quoted in de Stefano, n.d.).
label: Paragraph

text: At the dawn of the 21st century, the Arts Centre has become an icon of “green
label: Paragraph

text: architecture,” a model of holistic design for architects around the world; and for
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptians, trying to cope with the environmental pollution and population pressure of
label: Paragraph

text: peri-urban greater Cairo, it has become a beacon of hope.
label: Paragraph

text: RANCH HOUSE
label: Title

text: After World War L, the American ranch house replaced the bungalow and the Cape Cod
label: Paragraph

text: cottage as the preeminent American house type. Because housing costs had doubled in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1940s, most architects designed flexible, multiuse spaces emphasizing both function
label: Paragraph

text: and convenience, including the ranch house. However, because of both the Depression
label: Paragraph

text: and wartime materials shortages, most consumers could fulfill dreams of a new house
label: Paragraph

text: only with glossy magazines and corporate-sponsored scrapbooks. The end of World War
label: Paragraph

text: Il brought an enormous demand for new housing. The wartime development of new
label: Paragraph

text: materials and new manufacturing methods enabled merchant builders to meet postwar
label: Paragraph

text: consumer demand, which was subsidized by new federal loan programs. Concurrently,
label: Paragraph

text: consumer magazines, merchant builders, and museum exhibitions promoted the ranch
label: Paragraph

text: house as affordable shelter for the newly informal, family-oriented, and frequently
label: Paragraph

text: suburban American lifestyle. Consumers embraced the ranch house as the paradigm for
label: Paragraph

text: new, modern, and convenient housing, a preference endorsed by consumer magazines, an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural pedigree that included Frank Lloyd Wright, and the unprecedented growth
label: Paragraph

text: of suburbia after World War IL.
label: Paragraph

text: The postwar ranch house is characterized by spaciousness facilitated by new building
label: Paragraph

text: techniques, new materials, and interior design. The single-story house typically featured
label: Paragraph

text: three zones: an open-plan common space, a centralized service core, and a cluster of
label: Paragraph

text: private bedrooms. The open plan emphasized the flow of space between rooms,
label: Paragraph

text: modulated by pass-throughs, open shelving, and built-in storage units. Indoor-outdoor
label: Paragraph

text: iving areas and large expanses of glass promoted the interpenetration of interior and
label: Paragraph

text: exterior space. The rambling plan, horizontal em-phasis, and low-pitched roof ideally
label: Paragraph

text: integrated the ranch house into the landscape. Although the single-story ranch house
label: Paragraph

text: proved prototypical, both the split level and the raised ranch abounded. Architects and
label: Paragraph

text: merchant builders tailored the plan, exterior facings, and features such as appliances to
label: Paragraph

text: the home owner’s means. For example, in 1959, American Home featured a 1040-square-
label: Paragraph

text: foot ranch house for $12,950 (including lot), and the House Beautiful Pace Setter House
label: Paragraph

text: boasted 3100 square feet for $51,500 (including indoor pool and air conditioning).
label: Paragraph

text: Ranch house designers drew on numerous sources, including Spanish colonial
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, Frank Lloyd Wright’s Usonian houses, and California modernism, to create
label: Paragraph

text: a distinctly American house type. Architect Cliff May traced the postwar ranch house to
label: Paragraph

text: the 19th-century Spanish colonial rancho in the West. Arguing that form followed
label: Paragraph

text: function, May claimed that the casual, outdoor-oriented “California life” of a small
label: Paragraph

text: population of wealthy ranchers had generated the rambling, open-plan, singlestory, adobe
label: Paragraph

text: house with a corredor, or porch, instead of a hallway. The 20th-century suburban ranch
label: Paragraph

text: house retained its associations with California casualness, indoor-outdoor living, and the
label: Paragraph

text: notion of a putatively native architectural heritage.
label: Paragraph

text: Designers also adapted Frank Lloyd Wright’s Usonian houses, first realized in the
label: Paragraph

text: Herbert Jacobs House (1937). The Jacobs House used the L-shaped, “pollywog plan.”
label: Paragraph

text: The head of the pollywog contained both common spaces and the service core, including
label: Paragraph

text: kitchen, bath, and other utilities. The interior expressed Wright’s notion of organic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture consisting of an open-plan space subdivided by ceiling levels, lighting
label: Paragraph

text: effects, and built-in furniture. Private rooms, such as bedrooms, the study, and the
label: Paragraph

text: workshop, formed the tail of the pollywog. Generous eaves, natural materials, and a
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal silhouette integrated house and landscape. Wright’s rhetoric also commended
label: Paragraph

text: his domestic architecture to postwar readers of magazines such as House Beautiful, which
label: Paragraph

text: promoted Wright as an American genius whose vision of American individualism
label: Paragraph

text: embodied by the single-family home not only accorded with Cold War ideology but also
label: Paragraph

text: affirmed the postwar development of suburbia.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s reorientation of the kitchen, or “work space,” from backstairs to the
label: Paragraph

text: ideological and spatial center of the Usonian house proved fundamental to the postwar
label: Paragraph

text: ranch house. The kitchen served as the control center, allowing the homemaker physical,
label: Paragraph

text: visual, and even verbal access to the entire house, such as that afforded by the intercom
label: Paragraph

text: system, one of a new array of appliances that facilitated the self-sufficiency of the
label: Paragraph

text: postwar family. Whereas previously even working-class women had hired help to do
label: Paragraph

text: laundry and heavy cleaning, the postwar economy dictated that most women labored
label: Paragraph

text: alone, assisted by appliances rather than servants.
label: Paragraph

text: Both Wright and California modernists, such as Richard Neutra, used large expanses of
label: Paragraph

text: glass—including picture windows, window walls, and sliding-glass doors—to integrate
label: Paragraph

text: interior and exterior space. Similarly, Sunset promoted the “total combination of indoor-
label: Paragraph

text: outdoor space” created by ground-level access to outdoor living areas as the ideal
label: Paragraph

text: situation for casual living and informal entertaining. The low rambling profile,
label: Paragraph

text: overhanging eaves, and features such as planter boxes integrated into the facade further
label: Paragraph

text: unified house and landscape. Exterior adornment drew on both vernacular tradition and
label: Paragraph

text: architectural design, at times simultaneously. A ranch house might combine the scalloped
label: Paragraph

text: bargeboards of the Swiss chalet with geometric arrangements of facing materials
label: Caption

text: indebted to modernists such as Edward Durell Stone.
label: Paragraph

text: The open plan essential to the ranch house not only maximized space on a limited
label: Paragraph

text: budget but also promoted American political and cultural values. In a series of articles
label: Paragraph

text: written during the 1950s, House Beautiful associated the open plan with Wright’s organic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, American sociability, and democratic freedom of choice. Similarly, the
label: Paragraph

text: ranch house served as a vehicle for American nationalist ideology at the American
label: Paragraph

text: National Exposition in Moscow in 1959, where exhibits of domestic technology included
label: Paragraph

text: a “six-room, ranch-type house, completely furnished, within the price range of [the]
label: Paragraph

text: average US worker” sectioned like a dollhouse and dubbed “Splitnik” (“‘Made in
label: Paragraph

text: U.S.A.’—In Red Capital,” U.S. News & World Re-port 47 [3 August 1959]). Despite the
label: Paragraph

text: frequent association of the ranch house with the American way of life, critics such as
label: Paragraph

text: John Keats noted that the open plan, often curtailed by restricted budgets, actually
label: Paragraph

text: prohibited the gracious living promised by consumer magazines.
label: Paragraph

text: Ultimately, the postwar American ranch house catered to traditional families who not
label: Paragraph

text: only craved comfort and convenience on a limited budget but also anticipated the
label: Paragraph

text: American lifestyle promised by consumer magazines, television, and merchant builders’
label: Paragraph

text: plan books. The postwar popularity of the ranch house eroded regional architectural
label: Paragraph

text: differences, replacing local traditions with a national archetype. The ranch house
label: Paragraph

text: embodied the American dream of planned suburban communities populated by city
label: Paragraph

text: commuters and housebound homemakers who graciously entertained with an array of
label: Paragraph

text: convenience foods consumed in the spacious confines of the open-plan, indoor-outdoor
label: Paragraph

text: iving area.
label: Paragraph

text: RASMUSSEN, STEEN EILER 1898-1990
label: Title

text: Architect, architectural historian, and critic, Denmark
label: Caption

text: Steen Eiler Rasmussen’s broad range of talents were manifest in his activities as an
label: Paragraph

text: architect, town planner, educator, historian, and critic. Although he exerted influence in
label: Paragraph

text: all these areas in his native Denmark, his ideas were disseminated to a wider audience via
label: Paragraph

text: his translated books and his work as a visiting scholar in England, Turkey, Australia, and
label: Paragraph

text: the United States. Born in Copenhagen in 1898, Rasmussen entered the two-year
label: Paragraph

text: preparatory course at the Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts at the age of 18 and, on
label: Paragraph

text: completion, joined the office of Carl Brummer. During his first year at Brummer’s office,
label: Paragraph

text: he collaborated with Knud Christiansen on three first prizewinning competition entries
label: Paragraph

text: for the renewal of the Prinsensgade Quarter in Copenhagen and town plans for Ringsted
label: Caption

text: and Hirtshals. Rasmussen was elected as a member of the Academic Council of the Royal
label: Paragraph

text: Danish Academy of Fine Arts in 1922 and two years later was appointed as its first
label: Paragraph

text: lecturer in town planning. In 1938, he was promoted to professor of architecture, a post
label: Paragraph

text: that he held until 1968. During this period, he also served as a member of the
label: Paragraph

text: Copenhagen Building Commission and the Copenhagen Traffic Commission and as
label: Title

text: chairman of the Danish Planning Laboratory and the Regional Planning Committee for
label: Paragraph

text: Copenhagen.
label: Paragraph

text: The early inclination toward town planning would continue to occupy Rasmussen
label: Paragraph

text: throughout his life. His most significant work in this area is undoubtedly “The Finger
label: Paragraph

text: Plan of 1948,” which was an attempt to produce an overall regional plan for greater
label: Paragraph

text: Copenhagen. Conceived in collaboration with a team headed by Peter Bredsdorff, the
label: Paragraph

text: plan called for the city to grow along a series of “fingers” marked by railway lines
label: Paragraph

text: extending radially from the center. The area between these transport corridors was
label: Paragraph

text: intended for forests and agricultural lands. According to Rasmussen, no one was to live
label: Paragraph

text: farther than a 10-minute walk to a station, and those living in the outermost areas should
label: Paragraph

text: be able to reach the center of the city within 30 to 45 minutes. Although the plan was
label: Paragraph

text: never accorded legal status, the main structure of the plan was carried out in principal at
label: Paragraph

text: local levels. The significance of the “Finger Plan” lies in the fact that although many
label: Paragraph

text: other European cities sought to limit the growth of the town and establish “satellite
label: Paragraph

text: towns,” Rasmussen devised a means by which the city could remain a singular entity and
label: Paragraph

text: extend outward in a controlled manner.
label: Paragraph

text: Rasmussen’s interest in the city was not confined to his town-planning proposals but
label: Paragraph

text: also extended to his work as a historian and critic. In 1927, he was afforded the
label: Paragraph

text: opportunity to serve as a guest lecturer at the Architectural Association in London. Struck
label: Paragraph

text: by the differences between life in Copenhagen and life in London, Rasmussen began to
label: Paragraph

text: record the observations made during his initial period of residence and many subsequent
label: Paragraph

text: visits and compiled the material into the book titled London: The Unique City, which was
label: Paragraph

text: published in 1934. Although the book was almost immediately translated into English
label: Paragraph

text: and has appeared in a number of editions, Rasmussen experienced disappointment
label: Paragraph

text: because the book did not fulfill his intention of initiating a debate among legislators and
label: Paragraph

text: politicians. Speaking of his disappointment in his foreword to the 1973 revised edition of
label: Paragraph

text: the book, he stated that he had learned that one could not provoke discussion with a large
label: Paragraph

text: book, but only with short, concentrated attacks in periodic publications. Rasmussen’s
label: Paragraph

text: commitment to debates regarding the quality of the physical environment are clearly seen
label: Paragraph

text: in the numerous published articles in Danish newspapers and in his work as editor of the
label: Paragraph

text: journal Arkitekten from 1927 to 1933.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to his book on London, two more of Rasmussen’s books have been
label: Paragraph

text: translated into English: Experiencing Architecture and Towns and Buildings. Both works
label: Paragraph

text: can be described as primers that provide a clear and cogent introduction to architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and town planning, and they represent Rasmussen’s range of interest and breadth of
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge. Soon after publication of the English editions of his books, Rasmussen was
label: Paragraph

text: invited as a guest professor to various schools throughout the world, including the
label: Paragraph

text: Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Yale University; the University of California,
label: Paragraph

text: Berkeley; the Royal College of Art; and the University of New South Wales.
label: Paragraph

text: Rasmussen described himself as an “unsuccessful” architect as the result of many of
label: Paragraph

text: his town-planning proposals not being carried through to an acceptable level of resolution
label: Paragraph

text: because of a lack of commitment by municipal authorities. However, he was involved in
label: Paragraph

text: a number of architectural projects that demonstrate both his aptitude as an architect and
label: Paragraph

text: his adherence to the tenets of functionalism as they were expressed in Denmark at the
label: Paragraph

text: time. Of particular note are Rasmussen’s own residence (1937), an extension to the hotel
label: Paragraph

text: Hornbaekhus (1942), the Rungsted School (1953), and the “Blanche” hostel (1961) in
label: Paragraph

text: central Copenhagen. Two multifamily housing projects, “Skovgaarden” (1958, 1961) and
label: Paragraph

text: “Banehegnet” (1962), serve as examples of how Rasmussen’s ideas about town planning
label: Paragraph

text: and architecture could be realized.
label: Paragraph

text: Speaking on his teaching methods that were developed over a career that spanned more
label: Paragraph

text: than 60 years, Rasmussen stated that it was not his wish to tell students how problems
label: Paragraph

text: should be solved but merely to get their minds working. A survey of his work reveals that
label: Paragraph

text: his most significant contribution to 20th-century architecture came about not through his
label: Paragraph

text: architectural and town-planning projects but through acute observations that continue to
label: Paragraph

text: instruct his readers that architecture and town planning are not ends in themselves.
