text: RATIONALISM
label: Title

text: The Rational School in mid-nineteenth century was an amorphous body of architects who
label: Paragraph

text: held that architecture was ornamented construction, essentially structural form, however
label: Paragraph

text: refined or adorned. Found in the philosophy that reason is the source and test of
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge and best served by deductive inquiry, and as an extension of the
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment, it was French in tradition as bequeathed by master masons of the so-
label: Paragraph

text: called Middle Ages. It was differentiated from the British empirical tradition that
label: Paragraph

text: ultimately was popularized as the picturesque, a distinction to exist well into the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century. Yet French and German architects consistently applied the theory to classical
label: Paragraph

text: buildings; an early epitome was J.G. Soufflot’s Church of St. Genevieve (Pantheon),
label: Paragraph

text: Paris, 1757, a building to lead into Romantic Classicism. Academic design rituals were
label: Paragraph

text: then perpetuated by the Ecole des Beaux-Arts, Paris, followed by its many imitators in
label: Paragraph

text: North America 1890-1940.
label: Paragraph

text: But the Ecole had devolved to classique formalism, much to the chagrin of committed
label: Paragraph

text: rationalists such as Jean-Baptiste Rondolet, who in 1802 argued that architecture derives
label: Paragraph

text: from construction and is not an imaginative art. Or those impressed by the influential
label: Paragraph

text: books of J.N.L.Durand, Rondolet’s contemporary. Proposing that architecture be
label: Paragraph

text: conditioned—as his fellow revolutionaries insisted—by social demand, that style be the
label: Paragraph

text: “visible expression of its functioning parts,” axial symmetry and classical forms in simple
label: Paragraph

text: geometry were Durand’s aesthetic preferences. As a planning methodology, he used a
label: Paragraph

text: square grid to order structure and explain plan. It was a type of orderliness that post-1850
label: Paragraph

text: attracted theorist and architect E.E. Viollet-le-Duc. But Durand’s obsession was French
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic with its constructional clarity of parts, not just expressed but plainly exposed. His
label: Paragraph

text: written expositions on modernism (that is, speculation as to an appropriate architecture
label: Paragraph

text: for his day), on the use of new materials and technologies, on reasoned “principles, as
label: Paragraph

text: opposed to rules” or imitative forms, on buildings as organisms, on style rather than the
label: Paragraph

text: styles, and so on, remains highly persuasive.
label: Paragraph

text: Traditionally, the architecture of rationalism tended toward classicism, thereby
label: Paragraph

text: emphasizing its foundation in 18th-century mathematics (measurable truth), therefore
label: Paragraph

text: geometry plays a significant role. More lately this can be seen, for instance, in the early
label: Paragraph

text: works of Frank Lloyd Wright, those post-1937 by a disciplined Ludwig Mies van der
label: Paragraph

text: Rohe, and those beginning in the 1960s by Louis I.Kahn and his intelligent follower
label: Paragraph

text: Mario Botta. From their individualistic variety we also can see that there is no coherent
label: Paragraph

text: rationalistic style.
label: Paragraph

text: It is generally held that Rationalism arrived in the United States c. 1800 through
label: Paragraph

text: French emigrant architects such as Joseph J.Ramée, Maximilian Godefroy, and Benjamin
label: Paragraph

text: H.Latrobe. But it was swamped by Jeffersonian Romanticism and formalism. The counter
label: Paragraph

text: was found first in the words of Ralph Waldo Emerson and then in the might of
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization and concomitant technical and engineering developments.
label: Paragraph

text: Emersonian nature and utility and inspired sculptor Horatio Greenough, who praised
label: Paragraph

text: monumental buildings that addressed the “sympathies, the faith, or the taste of a people.”
label: Paragraph

text: He wrote Emerson that architecture was: “A scientific arrangement of spaces and forms
label: Paragraph

text: to functions and to sit,... features proportioned to their graduated importance in function.”
label: Paragraph

text: The expression of functionality was the demonstration of reason. (The philosopher,
label: Paragraph

text: whose tool is words, would refer to positivism.) Borrowing from American architect
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Sullivan, who drew from Kant, Emerson, Greenough, and others, Wright was
label: Paragraph

text: inspired by the “form follows function” aphorism, extending it by reflection on his
label: Paragraph

text: family’s love of Emerson, who urged a link with those “pertinent object lessons nature so
label: Paragraph

text: readily furnishes,” as Wright said. Is there anything in nature that does not function
label: Paragraph

text: correctly, wondrously? Rationalism easily becomes entangled with the notion of utility
label: Paragraph

text: and nearly synonymous with functionalism. But nature was the perfect teacher.
label: Paragraph

text: The application of rationalism reached a practical epitome beginning in the 1880s with
label: Paragraph

text: the frighteningly tall buildings in New York City and Chicago. They had adopted
label: Paragraph

text: structural systems evolved by engineers and building contractors and contained utilitarian
label: Paragraph

text: features and technical innovations within a variety of facades. The expression of stacked
label: Paragraph

text: spaces (to the Romantic), of stacked floors (to the rationalist), and vertical systems
label: Paragraph

text: (water, people, structure, waste, etc.) was—and is—the architectural problem.
label: Paragraph

text: Although many were inspired by Viollet-le-Duc’s words Wright made them
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary and vital by speaking of an organic architecture for America’s modern
label: Paragraph

text: society and by producing works of an articulated (functional) clarity. The demonstration
label: Paragraph

text: is the Darwin Martin house of 1904-05, and the Larkin Administration building (1903—
label: Paragraph

text: 06), both in Buffalo and both a rationalist’s paradigm for differing building types.
label: Paragraph

text: Many of Wright’s buildings possessed what he referred to as “picturesque”
label: Paragraph

text: characteristics as he interpreted them from the English Arts and Crafts movement. His
label: Paragraph

text: persuasion had a marked influence on European theory post-1910. Thus Wright and
label: Paragraph

text: many of those founding modernists who were inspired by his words (not necessarily by
label: Paragraph

text: his romantic designs), such as Walter Gropius, Le Corbusier, even Louis Sullivan (from
label: Paragraph

text: whom Wright had drawn much nationalistic and transcendentalist fervor), and by Albert
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s industrial architecture, extracted intellectual sustenance from 19th-century theory
label: Paragraph

text: and speculation.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1902 Sullivan wanted to impress on his audience “the simple truth—immeasurable
label: Paragraph

text: in power of expansion—of the subjective possibilities of objective things.” The
label: Paragraph

text: architect’s role was to interpret those things. In Europe Hendrik P.Berlage wrote about
label: Paragraph

text: the “pure art of utility” and believed his Amsterdam Exchange buildings (1897-1903)
label: Paragraph

text: followed principles espoused by Viollet-le-Duc. Auguste Perret was perhaps France’s
label: Paragraph

text: most ardent classical rationalist so dramatically expressed in concrete structures and axial
label: Paragraph

text: symmetry from 1903-25; consider Notre-Dame Le Raincy (1922-24). Up to the 1960s
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier was France’s most versatile structural rationalist, as a comparison of
label: Paragraph

text: Monzie house, Garches (1927), and the monastery of Le Tourette, Lyon (1957-60)
label: Caption

text: patently reveal. Yet his three-dimensional compositions are also picturesque in manners
label: Paragraph

text: that baffle rigid theorists.
label: Paragraph

text: When in the 1920s the central Europeans, in particular the Germans, absorbed the
label: Paragraph

text: visual aspects of the rationalism inherent in Albert Kahn’s industrial architecture (where
label: Paragraph

text: primary considerations were daylight, production process, functionality, money,
label: Paragraph

text: construction time, and structure), they elected for a reductive, chaste, plain interior and
label: Paragraph

text: exterior aesthetic constructed in glass, concrete, or steel, usually exposed. Wright and
label: Paragraph

text: others (such as the Dutch) worried that such an architecture might lead to a rejection of
label: Paragraph

text: its traditional role as a social art to become merely utilitarian, rationalized rather than
label: Paragraph

text: rational. In the 1920s the Modern movement was driven by rationalism until its industrial
label: Paragraph

text: style was found to be a useful expression for internationalism as promoted by the political
label: Paragraph

text: left. Mies van der Rohe in the 1920s, for example, took much from Wright (and others) to
label: Paragraph

text: generate a dynamic architecture based on American industrial buildings. By the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s he settled for what is best classified as a severe classicism, appearing rational but
label: Paragraph

text: in fact it was prescriptively formal and abstract. Thus the reasons for Kahn’s industrial
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic were abandoned by the Germans when they accepted an aesthetic that claimed
label: Paragraph

text: to be expressively functional but was in fact a style applied to all building types,
label: Paragraph

text: regardless of all other considerations.
label: Paragraph

text: In the late 1920s seven architects launched the Italian Rationalist Movement,
label: Paragraph

text: announcing that a “[n]ew architecture, true architecture, must emerge from a strict
label: Paragraph

text: adherence to logic, to rationality.” Their buildings and projects, supposedly born in
label: Paragraph

text: Italy’s traditions (and in opposition to the bustling but defunct futurists) and in fascism
label: Paragraph

text: were widely diverse in appearance, many with structural clarity while immodestly
label: Paragraph

text: betraying the influence of Russian Constructivists, Le Corbusier, and the Bauhaus.
label: Paragraph

text: Giuseppe Terragni was their more expert apostle through the 1930s.
label: Paragraph

text: Then in 1941, a theoretical work was released on antecedents of 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: architecture by Siegfried Giedion, Space Time and Architecture. \t was a faithful
label: Paragraph

text: rationalist document in praise of functionalism. Giedion’s intention was to concentrate on
label: Paragraph

text: “the interrelations with other human activities...[on] architecture, construction, painting,
label: Paragraph

text: city planning, and science” (1954). This was followed in 1948 by his second seminal
label: Paragraph

text: study, Mechanization Takes Command, whose title reveals all.
label: Paragraph

text: In the decades after midcentury, rationalism became both clarified and distorted. Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn believed that a building had measurable qualities, that there were ordinate and
label: Paragraph

text: subordinate spaces with natural hierarchies, that these functional aspects wanted to be
label: Paragraph

text: defined by their unique form, and that perceptual awareness of architecture was in the
label: Paragraph

text: orderly arrangement of forms. Supported by his poetic philosophy, these relationships
label: Paragraph

text: were vigorously exploited by simple volumetric geometry, notably his A.N.Richards
label: Paragraph

text: Laboratories, Philadelphia (1957-61), the second paradigm of 20th-century rationalism.
label: Paragraph

text: If we accept that architectural form is shaped by programmatic functions, and this should
label: Paragraph

text: include social and economic conditions, or by the spirit of its time, or by timeless
label: Paragraph

text: principles, then the two extremes at midcentury were Kahn’s romantically, picturesquely
label: Paragraph

text: ordered forms and Mies van der Rohe’s internally preordered forms classically
label: Paragraph

text: composed. The reaction was the exploitation of form over function and hierarchies that
label: Paragraph

text: were so apparent in 1950s sensualism and later the work of Arata Isozaki and Morphosis,
label: Paragraph

text: to cite two examples.
label: Paragraph

text: A new neorationalism arose in the 1960s, again in Italy and composed by Fabio
label: Paragraph

text: Reinhart and Aldo Rossi, among others, who rejected their predecessors. Soon there was
label: Paragraph

text: the Madrid School, then in Germany architects Mathias Ungers and J.P. Kleihus, and in
label: Paragraph

text: the United States, architects such as the New York Five, of whom the prolific Richard
label: Paragraph

text: Meier has since remained the most faithful to original tenets. Again, these architects
label: Paragraph

text: produced a wide variety of characteristics, none architectonically related, all distinct yet
label: Paragraph

text: often claiming a mix of rationalistic and existential foundations.
label: Paragraph

text: Much of neorationalism was a theoretical twist with the attempt to relate architecture to
label: Paragraph

text: political theories (usually Marxist) or to social theories, particularly through semiotics,
label: Paragraph

text: which recognizes that buildings carry meanings (signs) and symbolic overtones, more
label: Paragraph

text: often than not because of cultural continuity or history. Much of its theory was derived
label: Paragraph

text: from or instituted in linguistics. Therefore one can understand that the problem of
label: Paragraph

text: analogies with the complexities of architecture are many, not the least that semiotics (and
label: Paragraph

text: the earlier structuralism) is evaluative, tending to operate postmortem, therefore only
label: Paragraph

text: clumsily relevant to the processes inherent in creating architecture let alone to design
label: Paragraph

text: methodology.
label: Paragraph

text: There is something strangely romantic in the architectonic application of those
label: Paragraph

text: socioeconomic theories. Perhaps this reflects the continuing debate between rationalism
label: Paragraph

text: and Romanticism, between the ongoing search for objective principles of design with
label: Paragraph

text: universal application (regardless of complexity or culture, all functions are naturally
label: Paragraph

text: similar throughout history), and the personal freedom that followed the collapse early in
label: Paragraph

text: the century or generally agreed principles: witness Expressionism in the 1920s or
label: Paragraph

text: sensualism in the 1950s or the independent Oscar Niemeyer and Frank O.Gehry.
label: Paragraph

text: The house in Riva San Vitalo, Italy (1972-73), by Mario Botta, should send shivers of
label: Paragraph

text: joy through a rationalist because of its precisely extended square, obvious structure and
label: Paragraph

text: responding use of materials, consistent vertical organization, functional expression,
label: Paragraph

text: deceiving formality and careful proportions, all providing a modern clarification of
label: Paragraph

text: Viollet-le-Duc’s ideas, of Wright’s organic song, and a sensible adaptation of Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s functional geometry.

text: RAYMOND, ELEANOR 1887-1989
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: Eleanor Raymond was one of a minority of women architects practicing in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States in the early 20th century and was a significant figure in the history of American
label: Paragraph

text: modernism. After several years of work in Boston’s settlement houses, participation in
label: Paragraph

text: the suffrage campaign, and an internship in the office of Boston landscape architect
label: Paragraph

text: Fletcher Steele, Raymond entered the newly founded Cambridge School of Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and Landscape Architecture for Women in the summer of 1916. Directed by Harvard
label: Caption

text: University professor and architect Henry Atherton Frost, the Cambridge School offered
label: Paragraph

text: women a unique opportunity to master a Beaux-Arts-inspired curriculum within an
label: Paragraph

text: allfemale environment. However, enduring discrimination in the architectural profession
label: Paragraph

text: and the Cambridge School’s lack of accreditation remained obstacles for many graduates.
label: Paragraph

text: After Raymond’s completion of the program in 1919, she was made a partner in Frost’s
label: Paragraph

text: Cambridge firm, where she remained until opening her own practice in Boston in 1935.
label: Paragraph

text: Trained solely in the practice of domestic architecture, Raymond completed nearly 100
label: Paragraph

text: houses in her 50 years as an architect. She is best known for several projects that reflect
label: Paragraph

text: her early interest in European modernism; most notably, the Rachel Raymond House in
label: Paragraph

text: Belmont, Massachusetts (1931), and a studio for Boston sculptor Amelia Peabody in
label: Paragraph

text: Dover, Massachusetts (1933). Much of Raymond’s work, however, was firmly rooted in
label: Paragraph

text: the still popular period styles of the Colonial Revival—a fact partially explained by the
label: Paragraph

text: relatively conservative taste of New England clients and Raymond’s own reservations
label: Paragraph

text: about modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Her early work was influenced in massing and in ornamental detail by the domestic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of colonial and early 19th-century New England. The planning of these
label: Paragraph

text: houses, however, reflected a new concern for economy, efficiency, and the up-to-date
label: Paragraph

text: amenities requested by her upper-middle-class suburban clients. In 1923, Raymond built
label: Paragraph

text: her own house out of a partially demolished townhouse on Charles Street on Boston’s
label: Paragraph

text: Beacon Hill. Designed to be in keeping with the red brick Federal architecture of this
label: Paragraph

text: historic neighborhood, 112 Charles Street (1923) was also home to several other single
label: Paragraph

text: women involved in the design profession, including Raymond’s longtime companion
label: Paragraph

text: Ethel Power. Power, who served as editor of House Beautiful magazine from the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s until the mid-1930s, was an important promoter of Raymond’s work. The women
label: Paragraph

text: of 112 Charles Street often collaborated on projects, creating a valuable network of
label: Paragraph

text: female colleagues and clients.
label: Paragraph

text: During a 1928 trip to Paris and a 1930 trip to Germany, Raymond and Power viewed
label: Paragraph

text: the work of European modernists such as Le Corbusier and Walter Gropius. The Rachel
label: Paragraph

text: Raymond House in Belmont, Massachusetts (1931), designed for Raymond’s sister, an
label: Paragraph

text: interior decorator, reflected her interest in creating a regional modernism on her return to
label: Paragraph

text: Boston. Built of a traditional wood frame with rough-sawed cedar cladding, the house
label: Caption

text: differed in materials from the concrete and stucco monuments of the International Style.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the house’s rectilinearity and its flat roofs and upper-story terraces recall
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius’s housing for the faculty of the Bauhaus, which Raymond had visited in the fall
label: Paragraph

text: of 1930. The interior continues these themes; an L-shaped, combined living room and
label: Paragraph

text: dining room embodies the open planning principles of European modernism, whereas the
label: Paragraph

text: retention of a central hall plan and the inclusion of decorative wood trim and antique
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese hardware on the built-in cupboards disavow the machine age aesthetic. This
label: Paragraph

text: merging of European and American sources significantly pre-dates the house that
label: Paragraph

text: traditionally is credited with introducing modernism to the United States, Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius’s house in Lincoln, Massachusetts (1937).
label: Caption

text: Raymond’s clientele included a number of notable women who shared her professional
label: Paragraph

text: aspirations and unmarried status. Most prominent was Amelia Peabody, a Boston
label: Paragraph

text: sculptor and philanthropist who commissioned 16 projects between 1933 and 1972. Many
label: Paragraph

text: of these commissions exemplified Raymond’s interest in modernism and advanced
label: Paragraph

text: building technologies. For example, the three-room studio that she designed for Peabody
label: Paragraph

text: on her farm in Dover, Massachusetts (1933), featured easily cleaned cinder block walls,
label: Paragraph

text: factory-ordered windows, a streamlined sitting room, and an experimental forced hot air
label: Paragraph

text: system of heating. Raymond’s Dover Sun House (1948), a house designed around
label: Paragraph

text: Hungarian chemist Maria Telkes’s pioneering solar heating system, was also funded by
label: Paragraph

text: Peabody. The heat collectors, which ran along the length of the attic story of the southern
label: Caption

text: facade, stored a five-day supply of solar heat for the small two-bedroom house.
label: Paragraph

text: Internationally recognized, the Dover Sun House was listed as one of Raymond’s greatest
label: Paragraph

text: contributions to the development of domestic architecture in her successful nomination to
label: Paragraph

text: the American Institute of Architects Fellowship in 1961.
label: Paragraph

text: Raymond’s interest in preserving the building traditions of colonial New England is
label: Paragraph

text: best represented by the compound that she designed in Gloucester, Massachusetts, for
label: Paragraph

text: mining heiress Natalie Hays Hammond (1942). Perched on a dramatic shoreline site, the
label: Paragraph

text: Hammond Compound consists of three residences and a central dining hall grouped
label: Paragraph

text: around a central courtyard. The buildings’ steeply pitched roofs, small-paned casement
label: Paragraph

text: windows, and dark-stained clapboarding hearken back to the domestic architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: 17th-century New England, reflecting Hammond’s fascination with American and British
label: Paragraph

text: history. Despite its conservative appearance, the Hammond Compound reflects
label: Paragraph

text: progressive planning principles in its attention to the needs of three single professional
label: Paragraph

text: women.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to domestic projects, Raymond also designed several chapels, an addition
label: Paragraph

text: to an airplane parts manufacturing plant, and numerous farm outbuildings. As is the case
label: Paragraph

text: with many women architects, Raymond received relatively little critical attention during
label: Paragraph

text: her lifetime, an omission attributed in part to the eclectic nature of her work, which defies
label: Paragraph

text: the stylistic categories of conventional architectural history. The rise of the women’s
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: that helped to recover Raymond’s career; in 1981, Raymond was the subject of a one-

text: REGIONAL PLANNING
label: Title

text: Regional planning began from the idea that the essential basis for planning should be
label: Paragraph

text: geography, not municipal jurisdictional lines. Although today this idea is easily accepted
label: Paragraph

text: in principle, its history has been that of a reasonable proposition often ignored and
label: Paragraph

text: frequently difficult to implement.
label: Paragraph

text: The beginning of regional planning in the United States is marked by the publication of
label: Paragraph

text: Patrick Geddes’ Cities in Evolution (1915), which first noted the tendency of large cities
label: Paragraph

text: to disperse as they grew because of the influence of the automobile and industrial power.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the idea of regional planning and governance had been considered as early as
label: Paragraph

text: 1909, when the National Municipal League had its annual conference, Geddes recognized
label: Paragraph

text: that the concept of a “city line” was being transformed by the growth of metropolitan
label: Paragraph

text: regions, which no longer stopped at the end of municipal jurisdictions but were stretching
label: Paragraph

text: into vast, spread-out areas that he termed “conurbations.” Geddes observed the dispersed
label: Paragraph

text: growth of areas such as Pittsburgh, Chicago, and the entire region between New York
label: Paragraph

text: and Boston and predicted that such growth was the wave of the future, where “millions of
label: Paragraph

text: people” would congregate in a way that ignored the significance of city boundaries.
label: Paragraph

text: Geddes, a Scotsman, had a significant influence on a small group of idealistic planners,
label: Paragraph

text: especially Lewis Mumford, who nourished his ideas, elaborated on them with the help of
label: Paragraph

text: other innovative planning founders, and eventually put them into practice in the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s. However, it was Geddes who established the idea of the geographic region as the
label: Paragraph

text: proper object of the planner’s focus.
label: Paragraph

text: Geddes was an eccentric man who conducted masques and pageants to recapture past
label: Paragraph

text: civic life. His was a large vision of not only how cities should be planned but also how
label: Paragraph

text: the world must be transformed from the rule of technology and money into a new utopia.
label: Paragraph

text: This transformation would take place, he maintained, by the creation of a “neotechnic”
label: Paragraph

text: order that evolved through the public conservation of resources, eventually replacing the
label: Paragraph

text: present of “more and more of worse and worse.”
label: Paragraph

text: According to Geddes, the regional environment was the appropriate locale for this
label: Paragraph

text: evolution because it contained the seeds for ideal human growth. Thus, his famous
label: Paragraph

text: maxim “Survey before plan” meant that attention should be focused on the natural
label: Paragraph

text: geographic characteristics of a region, such as its river basins, watersheds, and geology,
label: Paragraph

text: and its social and cultural composition as well. Without naming it, he described urban
label: Paragraph

text: sprawl as a dan-ger to community life (“Towns must now cease to spread like expanding
label: Paragraph

text: ink stains and grease spots.”). Geddes was certain that the remedy could be found by
label: Paragraph

text: understanding the varied organic composition of regional settlements and planning for
label: Paragraph

text: growth by integrating nature into towns that grow “botanically.”
label: Paragraph

text: These ideas were a shock to the system of early 20th-century urban planners, most of
label: Paragraph

text: whom were firm in the embrace of the City Beautiful movement, with the girded, formal,
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical orthodoxy it entailed. A diverse group of unconvinced planners and
label: Paragraph

text: architects, however, sought a different direction. The group, which included Lewis
label: Paragraph

text: Mumford, Clarence Stein, Benton Mackaye, and Charles Harris Whitaker, came under
label: Paragraph

text: the influence of Geddes and concocted a scheme that led to the Regional Planning
label: Paragraph

text: Association of America (RPAA).
label: Paragraph

text: In 1923, the RPAA published a five-part program that set forth the principles for
label: Paragraph

text: regional planning that included the development of new garden city types of communities
label: Paragraph

text: over the next few years. The group elaborated on the need for regional planning as an
label: Paragraph

text: antidote to the type of cities such as New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, and Boston that
label: Paragraph

text: were turning into “dinosaurs” because of the dispersed urbanization that was being
label: Paragraph

text: created by the automobile. Mumford termed this development the “fourth migration,” the
label: Paragraph

text: result of a technological revolution that was turning the movement of population centers
label: Paragraph

text: outward for the first time. The goal of the RPAA was to lead it into “new channels” by
label: Paragraph

text: developing a national plan that would define regions by unified geographic
label: Paragraph

text: characteristics consisting generally of climate, soil, vegetation, industry, and culture.
label: Paragraph

text: Part of the RPAA’s argument was economic. Stuart Chase contended that regional
label: Paragraph

text: planning could achieve vast improvements over the inefficiencies of transport and energy
label: Paragraph

text: that existed without it. Another part of the argument was based on the conservation of
label: Paragraph

text: resources (“Regional planning is the new conservation,” said Mumford), recognizing that
label: Paragraph

text: a regional focus can treat “people, industry and the land” as single unit so that the
label: Paragraph

text: population is distributed in a way that is compatible to its resources. Finally, the
label: Paragraph

text: argument rested on the issue of attaining a “fuller quality of life” through regional
label: Paragraph

text: planning by developing new communities that harmonized with the natural environment.
label: Paragraph

text: These communities were not suburban housing tracts but rather “garden cities” that took
label: Paragraph

text: their influence from Ebeneezer Howard and strengthened “indigenous America” against
label: Paragraph

text: the tide of disbursed, thoughtless development.
label: Paragraph

text: The RPAA’s diagnosis of the direction of urbanization in the United States was nearly
label: Paragraph

text: prophetic. Much of its interpretation of the endemic problems of what Mumford
label: Paragraph

text: described as the fourth migration is heard from contemporary urban planners who are
label: Paragraph

text: daily confounded by the effects and consequences of urban sprawl. Moreover, most of
label: Paragraph

text: the current remedies that are proposed to combat sprawl are contained, at least in concept,
label: Paragraph

text: within the proposals originally described by the RPAA. In terms of policy
label: Paragraph

text: implementation, however, the RPAA’s influence remains solidly within the realm of
label: Paragraph

text: good ideas. The two major experimental communities directly linked to the RPAA—
label: Paragraph

text: Sunnyside Gardens in Queens, New York, and Radburn, New Jersey—exist mainly as
label: Paragraph

text: curiosities on the road to suburbanization, which in the years following the RPAA
label: Paragraph

text: developed as such a powerful tide that regional planning, as envisioned by Mumford,
label: Paragraph

text: Stein, and the rest of RPAA, was essentially pushed out of the picture.
label: Paragraph

text: If the RPAA comprised the formative idealists of regional planning, the planners who
label: Paragraph

text: first conceived of the Regional Plan of New York in 1923 were sober pragmatists. The
label: Paragraph

text: group, headed by Thomas Adams and brought together by the Russell Sage Foundation,
label: Paragraph

text: set out to create a regional plan for New York that was rooted in achieving economic
label: Paragraph

text: efficiencies for a growing concentration of economic activities in the New York area
label: Paragraph

text: through a scheme of “recentralization” of business and industry.
label: Paragraph

text: The plan, which encompassed an area of more than 5000 square miles, proved to be
label: Paragraph

text: widely influential in the evolution of the New York metropolitan area, mainly because of
label: Paragraph

text: its congeniality to business investment and its grasp of emerging trends in population
label: Paragraph

text: movement and industrial development. Many of its suggestions for highways, bridges,
label: Paragraph

text: and tunnels were eventually brought to realization by the power broker Robert Moses.
label: Paragraph

text: Distinctly nonutopian in outlook, the plan called for new roads, parks, and beaches at the
label: Paragraph

text: same time that it designated the last significant open space near Manhattan—Hackensack
label: Paragraph

text: Meadows in New Jersey—for commercial development and omitted any consideration of
label: Paragraph

text: public housing. In addition, although it steered away from consideration of garden cities
label: Paragraph

text: and ideal communities, it nevertheless included a section by Clarence Perry that
label: Paragraph

text: described the development of “neighborhood units,” which offered a significant
label: Paragraph

text: alternative to the model of the suburban single-family house and a source for ideas on
label: Paragraph

text: clustered development planning years afterward.
label: Paragraph

text: The Regional Plan of New York was the first attempt to address the needs of a
label: Paragraph

text: metropolitan area outside its municipal boundaries. Without any regulatory power of
label: Paragraph

text: enforcement, such as zoning, it relied on the power of good planning ideas to achieve its
label: Paragraph

text: goals, which could ill afford to antagonize those engaged in business and investment. To
label: Paragraph

text: Mumford, however, the plan was dreadfully misconceived. His criticisms of the plan and
label: Paragraph

text: Thomas Adams’s defense of it constituted one of the most famous dialogues in American
label: Paragraph

text: planning history: Mumford proselytizing for the ideal, Adams for the obtainable.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the significant participants in the Regional Plan of New York was Frederic
label: Paragraph

text: Delano, the uncle of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who was receptive to the idea of
label: Paragraph

text: regional planning well before he became president of the United States. While governor
label: Paragraph

text: of New York, he proposed a state commission (“cooperative planning for the common
label: Paragraph

text: good”) in rural homes and frequently spoke supportively of regional planning as a means
label: Paragraph

text: to relieve congestion in the cities and redistribute population and industry more equitably
label: Paragraph

text: and responsibly. At about the same time (1930), the National Municipal League
label: Paragraph

text: described municipal boundaries as “obsolete” and called for expanded jurisdictional lines
label: Paragraph

text: to “give reality to the work of planning principles.”
label: Paragraph

text: In June 1933, shortly after taking office, President Roosevelt pushed a $25 public
label: Paragraph

text: works bill through Congress that included funds to establish a resettlement
label: Paragraph

text: administration, which was set up to plan a series of experimental greenbelt towns on the
label: Paragraph

text: periphery of large metropolitan areas. However, the Resettlement Administration’s
label: Paragraph

text: creator, Rexford G.Tugwell, soon came into conflict with Congress, which considered
label: Paragraph

text: this effort at regional planning by the federal government the bulwark of socialism.
label: Paragraph

text: Within months, Tugwell and the Resettlement Administration were put out of business,
label: Paragraph

text: although three greenbelt towns were eventually built (Greenbelt, Maryland, near
label: Paragraph

text: Washington, D.C.; Greenhills, near Louisville, Kentucky; and Greendale, Wisconsin,
label: Paragraph

text: near Milwaukee).
label: Paragraph

text: The most shining symbol of New Deal regional planning was the Tennessee Valley
label: Paragraph

text: Authority (TVA), which was the last direct federal involvement by the federal
label: Paragraph

text: government before World War Il. President Roosevelt described the project as an
label: Paragraph

text: exercise in regional planning, but it was actually much more, as it included a massive
label: Paragraph

text: flood control project on the 650-mile-long Tennessee River basin and a huge power-
label: Paragraph

text: producing operation that by 1944 was generating half the nation’s power. Originally, it
label: Paragraph

text: was intended also as an armaments production facility, a proposal that President
label: Paragraph

text: Roosevelt was successful at eliminating.
label: Paragraph

text: The period immediately following World War I saw a resurgence of interest in the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of regional planning as the idea of reshaping local governments into regional
label: Paragraph

text: jurisdictions was frequently debated. In 1950, Atlanta adopted its plan for improvement,
label: Paragraph

text: which integrated the relationship of the City of Atlanta to Fulton County. In 1953, the
label: Paragraph

text: Ontario Parliament approved the federated municipality of Metropolitan Toronto,
label: Paragraph

text: reflecting what seemed to be the current tide of good planning. Numerous reports and
label: Paragraph

text: studies in the early 1950s called for “intergovernmentalizing” services and frequently
label: Paragraph

text: petitioned for new interjurisdictional initiatives to better coordinate policies and planning.
label: Paragraph

text: Fueled by a surge in federal spending, these efforts generally sought to make capital
label: Paragraph

text: planning on the municipal level more efficient and to coordinate the federal government’s
label: Paragraph

text: spending programs. When Congress passed the Housing Act of 1954, for example, it
label: Paragraph

text: included direct federal assistance to regional and metropolitan planning agencies. Shortly
label: Paragraph

text: thereafter, the National Municipal League responded by developing a so-called model
label: Paragraph

text: state and regional planning law. In 1955, the Commission on Intergovernmental
label: Paragraph

text: Relations, known as the Kestnbaum Commission, emphasized that metropolitan areas
label: Paragraph

text: were the most critical “focal points” for dealing with urban needs.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the increased attention to jurisdictional reform, local governments were
label: Paragraph

text: reluctant to disturb traditional lines of authority. Efforts at metropolitan reorganization in,
label: Paragraph

text: for example, Cleveland and St. Louis were ineffective. By 1959, the Advisory
label: Paragraph

text: Commission on Intergovernmental Relations was forced to conclude that metropolitan
label: Paragraph

text: reorganization, whether through consolidation or internal restructuring, faced an uphill
label: Paragraph

text: battle because of strong local resistance. When voters were faced with public
label: Paragraph

text: referendums, they were either indifferent or opposed. Jurisdictional reform held little
label: Paragraph

text: appeal outside Washington, D.C., or among urban planners focusing on regional matters.
label: Paragraph

text: By the early 1960s, the idea of jurisdictional reform—and with it regional planning and
label: Paragraph

text: governance—had lost much momentum. The continued expansion of federal funding and
label: Paragraph

text: the mounting complexity of urban problems, however, required that some new structural
label: Paragraph

text: solution be found. The answer, for the most part inadvertently created, was the
label: Paragraph

text: development of new area-wide organizations of locally elected officials, which soon
label: Paragraph

text: came to be referred to as Councils of Governments (COGs).
label: Paragraph

text: A veritable nationwide COGs movement soon developed, nurtured by federal funds. It
label: Paragraph

text: began with the creation of the Detroit-area Inter-County Supervisor’s Committee in 1956,
label: Paragraph

text: and by 1960 more than one half of 212 metropolitan areas had created new COGs.
label: Paragraph

text: Areawide planning was gaining ground all across the nation. COGs provided a means to
label: Paragraph

text: effectively address metropolitan problems, satisfying federal priorities for increased
label: Paragraph

text: coordination of planning functions within the metropolitan region while avoiding the
label: Paragraph

text: issue of jurisdictional reform. The federal preference for such planning was
label: Paragraph

text: unambiguous. In the 1960s and 1970s, federal aid programs for highways, mass transit,
label: Paragraph

text: and open space insisted on metropolitan planning as a funding requirement. By 1979, 39
label: Paragraph

text: separate federal programs required regional or metropolitan planning as a requirement for
label: Paragraph

text: local participation.
label: Paragraph

text: Regional planning had found its home within the arms of COGs. Sustained by federal
label: Paragraph

text: financial assistance in the form of Section 701 comprehensive planning grants, regional
label: Paragraph

text: planning at long last gained institutional credibility as COGs joined with the National
label: Paragraph

text: Association of Regional Councils. Regional planning commissions proliferated as never
label: Paragraph

text: before by becoming COGs. At the same time, however, because of their voluntary nature,
label: Paragraph

text: regional planning functions were separated from the idea of regional governance. The
label: Paragraph

text: Miami Valley Regional Planning Commission, the Association of Bay Area
label: Title

text: Governments, and the Metropolitan Washington (D.C.) Council of Governments were
label: Paragraph

text: examples of this type of structure. Although countless regional plans were developed,
label: Paragraph

text: few were implemented in any meaningful way, and many suffered from overly general
label: Paragraph

text: recommendations. Whatever their virtues, most of these plans had the problem of being
label: Paragraph

text: politely ignored by local jurisdictions. The regional planning COGS settled into a
label: Paragraph

text: comfortable existence of clearinghouses for federal grants, including those for water-
label: Paragraph

text: quality planning, air-quality planning, solid-waste management, and the A-95 review
label: Title

text: process. Many were limited to information exchange, coordination, technical assistance,
label: Paragraph

text: and the provision of some services.
label: Paragraph

text: In speaking about regional planning in the 1930s, the National Municipal League had
label: Paragraph

text: warned that “to be of value plans must be executed.” In the early 1960s, this advice
label: Paragraph

text: seemed particularly relevant as the goals of regional planning became separated from
label: Paragraph

text: regional governance through the establishment of COGs that had no real ability to
label: Paragraph

text: implement their plans.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the COGS structure of regional planning has become the dominant one, there
label: Paragraph

text: are significant exceptions. Since 1967, the Twin Cities Metropolitan Council has been a
label: Paragraph

text: prime model for regional planning in a major metropolitan area that effectively combines
label: Paragraph

text: planning, policies, and implementation. Significantly, it came into being as an action by
label: Paragraph

text: the State of Minnesota, not a local referendum. It is distinctive because its role in making
label: Paragraph

text: regional policy is authoritative rather than advisory. With its own political base, it has
label: Paragraph

text: enjoyed a relatively productive history working with local municipalities within a seven-
label: Paragraph

text: county area, particularly since passage of the Land Planning Act of 1976, an important
label: Paragraph

text: effort in regional growth management.
label: Paragraph

text: Similarly, the Portland (Oregon) Metropolitan Area developed a regional approach to
label: Paragraph

text: planning. Its evolution encapsulates both the weaknesses and the strengths of regional
label: Paragraph

text: planning. In the early 1960s, Portland, like many metropolitan areas, established a
label: Paragraph

text: voluntary association of governments to address areawide planning needs. The Columbia
label: Caption

text: Region Association of Governments (CRAG) originally encompassed an area of four
label: Paragraph

text: counties and 14 cities. CRAG emphasized intergovernmental cooperation to combat a
label: Paragraph

text: number of regional problems, such as loss of farmland and the escalating public cost of
label: Paragraph

text: spread-out development.
label: Paragraph

text: By the early 1970s, however, it became clear that CRAG’s advisory influence was
label: Paragraph

text: powerless to overcome conflicts among member jurisdictions. In 1973, in response to
label: Paragraph

text: heightened environmental concern, the Oregon State Legislature passed a bill that
label: Paragraph

text: significantly strengthened CRAG’s role. It made local membership in CRAG mandatory
label: Paragraph

text: and gave it authority to overrule local development plans within 27 participating
label: Paragraph

text: jurisdictions that did not conform to the regional comprehensive plan. This bill, in
label: Paragraph

text: conjunction with the passage of a state land use development law, eventually led to the
label: Paragraph

text: Metropolitan Service District (METRO), a directly elected regional government with
label: Paragraph

text: wide responsibilities. With strong land use powers, METRO became the rare bird of
label: Paragraph

text: regional planning, an organization that came into being from broad public consensus that
label: Paragraph

text: is able to address regional land use policies effectively.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the federal government retracted many programs fostering regional planning
label: Paragraph

text: in the early 1980s, such as Section 701 comprehensive planning grants, other federal
label: Paragraph

text: programs brought about new regional planning responsibilities. The most significant was
label: Paragraph

text: the Coastal Zone Management Act of 1972, which provided grants to states to develop
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive programs for preserving coastal resources. The result was the
label: Paragraph

text: establishment of state-run coastal programs in 18 coastal states that assumed regional
label: Paragraph

text: planning responsibility and varying levels of land use control in waterfront areas.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the most significant helping hand that regional planning has received came
label: Paragraph

text: about on the state level as a result of heightened interest in growth management
label: Paragraph

text: programs. Numerous states have passed some sort of growth management (or “smart
label: Paragraph

text: development”) controls in the last two decades. Usually, state growth management
label: Paragraph

text: strategies have relied on regional planning agencies that came out of COGs, strengthened
label: Paragraph

text: with additional funding and new authority. In general, these regional planning agencies
label: Paragraph

text: implement state growth management goals by identifying valuable regional resources and
label: Paragraph

text: developing regional growth management plans. In Florida, for example, eleven regional
label: Paragraph

text: planning councils were established to develop plans and review local jurisdiction plans
label: Paragraph

text: for consistency. Even states in which regional councils do not exist within a strict
label: Paragraph

text: government framework with regulatory authority, such as Florida, Georgia, Vermont, and
label: Paragraph

text: Maine, nonetheless have regional statutory authority over local plans.
label: Paragraph

text: Most growth management strategies are concerned with directing development to
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate regions within a regional environment—to limit urban sprawl in favor of
label: Paragraph

text: preserving open space and balancing service capacities. In Oregon, this effort has relied
label: Paragraph

text: on the establishment of regionally drawn urban service boundaries, which attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: attain a regional balance between compact development and protection of natural
label: Paragraph

text: resources. In all cases, regional planning councils are concerned with identifying the
label: Paragraph

text: greater-than-local planning issues that must be dealt with through an integrated growth
label: Paragraph

text: policy. Increasingly, the recognition that a problem such as urban sprawl requires a
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive area-wide solution has reinvigorated the role of regional planning.
label: Paragraph

text: Further Reading
label: Title

text: Further readings on Regional Planning begin with its roots in English Utopian Planning
label: Paragraph

text: and extend through its appeal to urban theorists such as Lewis Mumford and more recent
label: Paragraph

text: ecological planners. The distance between these theories and actual implementation of
label: Paragraph

text: regional plans rounds out one of the most influential planning stories in the 20th century.

text: REGIONALISM
label: Title

text: Regionalism in architecture is the desire to shape buildings according to the particular
label: Paragraph

text: characteristics of a specific place. Regionalism aims to obtain a visual harmony between
label: Paragraph

text: the building and its geographical setting, to connect with the culture and architectural
label: Paragraph

text: traditions of the local area, and to manage the local climate as naturally and as efficiently
label: Paragraph

text: as possible. Because regional buildings in a particular place respond to a similar set of
label: Paragraph

text: local characteristics, they will possess a similar look that can often be described as a style
label: Paragraph

text: like “Southwestern” or “Cape Cod,” and as these characteristics vary from place to place,
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in different regions will have distinctly different appearances relative to each
label: Paragraph

text: other.
label: Paragraph

text: Regionalism is the oldest and most pervasive of all building ideas. In the prehistoric
label: Paragraph

text: world, and in vernacular settlements throughout the world, builders used local materials
label: Paragraph

text: because they were conveniently at hand. They also adapted their forms to the local
label: Paragraph

text: climate in order to moderate temperature swings and to manage precipitation for comfort
label: Paragraph

text: and survival. For example, buildings in hot, dry climates are often constructed of thick
label: Paragraph

text: adobe walls, which first absorb heat during the hot days, providing a cool interior, and
label: Paragraph

text: then radiate the heat into the building during the colder nights. Buildings in the wet
label: Paragraph

text: climate of Northern Europe evolved steep roofs to shed rain and snow. Most regions of
label: Paragraph

text: the world have similarly developed vernacular traditions of building that are well adapted
label: Paragraph

text: to their particular geographical circumstances. Distinctive regional vernacular traditions
label: Paragraph

text: include Greek fishing villages, Italian hill towns, and the adobe of Santa Fe. Even today,
label: Paragraph

text: a great deal of the mass-produced built environment may be seen as regional in character.
label: Paragraph

text: Houses in the suburbs of London look different from those in Switzerland, which look
label: Paragraph

text: different from those in Thailand. When builders are not self-conscious about style or
label: Paragraph

text: fashion, regional tendencies are most likely to emerge because they make practical sense
label: Paragraph

text: and derive from successful traditions in the area.
label: Paragraph

text: In the world of high-style or high-status architecture, however, the concept of
label: Paragraph

text: regionalism has had a more complex history. For buildings like temples, public
label: Paragraph

text: monuments, palaces, and corporate headquarters, clients and their designers often seek to
label: Paragraph

text: express power, status, or philosophical outlooks that are not about the practical realities
label: Paragraph

text: of dealing with the local climate or geography. These statements are usually about
label: Paragraph

text: abstractions and are often meant to apply more universally than to a particular location.
label: Paragraph

text: For example, ancient temples were designed as appropriate homes for deities whose
label: Paragraph

text: powers transcended a local place and time. These buildings therefore employed a
label: Paragraph

text: rigorous orthogonal geometry that was thought to be more universal and time-less in
label: Paragraph

text: character than the more casual geometries that adapted themselves to the peculiarities of
label: Paragraph

text: the local site. More recently, proponents of the International Modernist movement
label: Paragraph

text: between the World Wars used a similar palette of industrial forms and materials for
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in widely diverse geographical areas, because they wanted to express a
label: Paragraph

text: universal view of modern life and industrialization that transcended individual places.
label: Paragraph

text: These two ideas—regionalism and the universal—are not necessarily mutually
label: Paragraph

text: exclusive. One might express a universal sense of beauty while still accommodating local
label: Paragraph

text: conditions and traditions, for example. But many times in the history of Western
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, the one has been pursued at the expense of the other and vice versa. Builders
label: Paragraph

text: sensitive to regional practicalities may scoff at higher aesthetic concerns and meanings,
label: Paragraph

text: whereas high-fashion designers may disparage regional concerns as parochial or
label: Paragraph

text: inconsequential in relation to bigger philosophical issues. From the Renaissance on, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, many architects transplanted ancient Roman Classical forms to other regions to
label: Paragraph

text: express their connection with the high civilization of Rome, even
label: Paragraph

text: Phoebe Apperson Hearst Administration Building, Asilomar, designed by Julia
label: Caption

text: Morgan
label: Title

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: though the shallow roofs that were originally designed for the Italian climate did not
label: Paragraph

text: work as well in the wetter climates of northern Europe or the east coast of America.
label: Paragraph

text: To understand the history of regionalism in high-status Western architecture in the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century, one must look back to the end of the 18th century. Until then, high-status
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was dominated by various versions of Roman Classical architecture applied
label: Paragraph

text: irrespective of the local conditions. But several broad cultural movements in Europe and
label: Paragraph

text: America led to a renewed appreciation of different regions and their possibilities for
label: Paragraph

text: design. Namely, the Romantic movement in the arts drew attention to the raw and varied
label: Paragraph

text: beauty of nature and to picturesque vernacular villages and cottages that appeared to live
label: Paragraph

text: in harmony with nature. Second, as people began to identify more with their cultural
label: Paragraph

text: groups than with the kingships that had often transcended cultural boundaries, they began
label: Paragraph

text: to look for the special qualities of their own nationality and place, including the
label: Paragraph

text: indigenous architectural traditions that they could claim as their own. Third, the rapidly
label: Paragraph

text: expanding Industrial Revolution created manufactured goods of such variable quality that
label: Paragraph

text: many began to call for a revival of handcraft by skilled craftspeople. Crafts were
label: Paragraph

text: distinctly regional in character, which encouraged a renewed look at local traditions.
label: Paragraph

text: House in Aspen, Colorado, designed by Harry Teague (1997)
label: Caption

text: Photograph © Robert Millman
label: Caption

text: All of these combined in the Gothic Revival movement in the first decades of the 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century, which in turn led to the Arts and Crafts Movement in the latter half of the 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century and the first decades of the 20th. The Arts and Crafts architects in Britain revived
label: Paragraph

text: the medieval vernacular traditions of building in their local regions, which they believed
label: Paragraph

text: fitted the local culture and climate while embodying good craftsmanship. Charles Rennie
label: Paragraph

text: Macintosh derived a number of his forms from Scottish Baronial castles, Sir Edwin
label: Paragraph

text: Lutyens drew on medieval house forms in the southern English county of Surrey, and
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Annesley Voysey stripped down medieval house forms to their underlying
label: Paragraph

text: essences, leading to some of the first simplified modernist architectural forms that
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless still exuded a regional sense of place.
label: Paragraph

text: This new focus on regionalism invaded the Ecole des Beaux Arts, the school of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and art in Paris that had become the world center for teaching the principles
label: Paragraph

text: of ancient Roman Classicism. The professor of theory at the Ecole at the turn of the
label: Paragraph

text: century, Julien Guadet, taught that a building in the city should be different from one in
label: Paragraph

text: the country, just as one at the seaside must be different from one in the mountains. This
label: Paragraph

text: helped inspire a movement later named Academic Eclecticism by the historian Richard
label: Paragraph

text: Longstreth, which among other things attempted to fuse the regional with the universal.
label: Paragraph

text: These architects derived their ideas from traditional architectural styles that they believed
label: Paragraph

text: embodied timeless and universal principles of design, but at the same time they chose
label: Paragraph

text: their precedents to fit the particular geographical setting.
label: Paragraph

text: The Arts and Crafts tradition and aspects of Academic Eclecticism influenced Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd Wright, who became America’s most influential spokesperson for the regionalist
label: Paragraph

text: idea. Borrowing the phrase “organic architecture” from Louis Sullivan and drawing on
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese design sensibilities, Wright insisted that buildings should harmonize with nature
label: Paragraph

text: and sensitively address the local geology and site conditions. While living in Chicago in
label: Paragraph

text: the first decades of the 20th century, he developed the Prairie School, whose low,
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal lines he said captured the essence of America’s Midwestern plains. The
label: Paragraph

text: buildings that he later designed for the Arizona desert looked distinctly different from the
label: Paragraph

text: ones he designed in Wisconsin, as each responded to the particular local characteristics.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s contemporary, Bernard Maybeck, also pursued the regionalist implications of
label: Paragraph

text: Academic Eclecticism and the Arts and Crafts movement. After moving to the Bay Area
label: Paragraph

text: of San Francisco before the turn of the century, he began to develop a distinctive style for
label: Paragraph

text: the area that was based in part on medieval vernacular German forms and in part on the
label: Paragraph

text: Shingle Style that had enjoyed a brief popularity in the northeast seacoast resort towns
label: Paragraph

text: several decades earlier. Despite these disparate and remote sources, Maybeck fused them
label: Paragraph

text: into an organic whole that inspired other architects, including Julia Morgan, and that still
label: Paragraph

text: defines much of the special character of the East Bay area today.
label: Paragraph

text: In the first two decades of the 20th century, many other builders and architects
label: Paragraph

text: followed this pattern of adapting and combining various architectural traditions to fit a
label: Paragraph

text: particular location. The Greene brothers Henry and Charles combined Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: and Japanese traditions for their distinctive version of the Craftsman style in Pasadena.
label: Paragraph

text: Their shallow roofs, open sleeping porches, and casual assymetric forms suited well the
label: Paragraph

text: moderate climate and emerging southern California culture.
label: Paragraph

text: Regionalism faded in popularity for high-status buildings after the Second World War.
label: Paragraph

text: The mood in America and Europe had changed to favor an international outlook and a
label: Paragraph

text: positive view of industrialization, and these were best expressed with the ahistorical,
label: Paragraph

text: technological, and non-regional forms of Modernism. In the 1970s, however, the mood
label: Paragraph

text: changed again. As the world economy became more pervasively global in character and
label: Paragraph

text: universal in taste, and as generic office buildings and chain retail stores began to make
label: Paragraph

text: London look like Los Angeles or Houston, many people began to seek again a special
label: Paragraph

text: quality in their particular place. Out of this grew the Historic Preservation movement,
label: Paragraph

text: which sought to save historic buildings and districts for their local character, rather than
label: Paragraph

text: risk another blandly generic redevelopment.
label: Paragraph

text: A number of architects have sought regional expressions from the 1980s, including
label: Paragraph

text: Robert Venturi in Philadelphia, Robert Stern in New York, Antoine Predock in New
label: Caption

text: Mexico, Harry Teague in Colorado, and Glenn Murcutt in Australia. Like their
label: Paragraph

text: regionalist predecessors before World War Il, most of these new regionalists have
label: Paragraph

text: explored aspects of the traditional styles and vernacular forms that might provide clues to
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate design qualities in their region; but in most cases, their Modernist roots have
label: Paragraph

text: led them to find fresher or more contemporary expressions of the traditional ideas.
label: Paragraph

text: For example, a traditional Colorado barn form inspired Harry Teague’s design for a
label: Paragraph

text: vacation home in Aspen, Colorado. This sensitively expresses the forms of the landscape
label: Paragraph

text: and the traditions of the area, whereas the uninterrupted space within supports the casual
label: Paragraph

text: life-style of living in one large great-room. On closer inspection, however, one can see
label: Paragraph

text: that the architect has stripped away the outer skin on part of the facade to reveal the inner
label: Paragraph

text: structure and a recessed wall of windows that carefully frames external views. The
label: Paragraph

text: modifications to the traditional form are Modernist in spirit, and the materials, massing,
label: Paragraph

text: siting, and connections between inside and outside unmistakably link this building to its
label: Paragraph

text: local context.
label: Paragraph

text: REICHSTAG, BERLIN
label: Caption

text: Initially designed by Paul Wallot, completed 1894; redesigned by Sir Norman Foster,
label: Paragraph

text: completed 1999 Berlin, Germany
label: Caption

text: Built at the end of the war-ravaged 20th century, the new German Parliament building
label: Paragraph

text: is significant for the refurbishing of a tarnished image—not of the Reichstag itself, but of
label: Paragraph

text: German national identity. The conversion of the Reichstag by Sir Norman Foster,
label: Paragraph

text: completed in 1999, was the building’s most optimistic incarnation of its troubled history.
label: Paragraph

text: The Reichstag always had symbolized a democratic German forum, although it was not
label: Paragraph

text: until 1999 that a fairly elected democratic body convened within its chambers.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1871 the German Parliament, operating under the strict control of Kaiser Wilhelm
label: Paragraph

text: and Chancellor Bismarck, had very limited power. Traditionally convened at the
label: Paragraph

text: convenience of the emperor, the appointed parliament was finally allowed to have a
label: Paragraph

text: meeting place of its own in 1882. After two competitions, the design was awarded to Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Wallot, a little-known German architect. The neo-Renaissance building was constructed
label: Paragraph

text: between 1884 and 1894 after many design compromises negotiated between the Kaiser,
label: Paragraph

text: Bismarck, and the parliamentarians.
label: Paragraph

text: The building was a gift from the Kaiser to his people, but he actively hated it—
label: Paragraph

text: reluctantly inscribing Dem Deutschen Volke (“to the German people”) over the entry in
label: Paragraph

text: 1916, while privately referring to it as Reichsaffenhaus (“the imperial monkey house”).
label: Paragraph

text: The seating arrangement reflected the emperor’s power—his ministers and officials sat
label: Paragraph

text: on a raised rostrum at the end of the room, presiding over the members. Members could
label: Paragraph

text: only address the body formally; interruptions and debate were rare.
label: Paragraph

text: A fire, rumored to be an act of arson by the Nazis, devastated the building in 1933. The
label: Paragraph

text: scarred building was then shelled and vandalized by the Russian army in 1945, leaving it
label: Paragraph

text: a ruin. A poorly executed partial renovation in 1961 restored the building’s functionality,
label: Paragraph

text: but parliamentary sessions were not held due to political opposition by Russia and
label: Paragraph

text: England—two of the four occupying forces in then-divided Berlin. Existing in the
label: Paragraph

text: shadow
label: Title

text: rr
label: Title

text: De
label: Title

text: Reichstag building showing Wallot’s Facade and Norman Foster’s dome
label: Caption

text: Photo © Dennis Gilbert/VIEW
label: Caption

text: of the Berlin Wall, the Reichstag was the backdrop of several historic takeovers, protests,
label: Paragraph

text: speeches, and concerts.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1991, two years after the fall of the Berlin Wall and reunification of West and East
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, the Bundestag narrowly approved a move of the capitol from Bonn back to
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin. It was a controversial decision; the wrecked and ill-regarded Reichstag was
label: Paragraph

text: chosen over the popular provisional Parliament Building then nearing completion.
label: Paragraph

text: A competition for converting the Reichstag was held in 1992. In the second stage of
label: Paragraph

text: the competition, Foster and Associates were awarded the commission. Reconstruction
label: Paragraph

text: began in 1995 after a dramatic wrapping of the building by the environmental artists
label: Paragraph

text: Christo and Jean-Claude. Work was completed in 1999, and the first parliamentary
label: Paragraph

text: session was held on 19 April 1999.
label: Paragraph

text: The competition’s winning scheme called for a light steel and glass roof hovering over
label: Paragraph

text: the entire Reichstag. This proposal could be seen as similar in spirit to the elegant
label: Paragraph

text: wrapper Foster designed for the Carré d’Art in Nimes (1984-93). As the design of the
label: Paragraph

text: master plan of the surrounding area evolved, the huge glass cover was eliminated. Design
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis was shifted to a new dome that would become a lantern for the building.
label: Paragraph

text: From the exterior, the renovation was restrained. The sleek interiors of metal and glass
label: Paragraph

text: were visible behind the old masonry colonnade. The gigantic dome, mostly glass and
label: Paragraph

text: striated by spi-
label: Title

text: Reichstag, interior of the dome
label: Caption

text: Photo © Nigel Young/Foster and Partners
label: Caption

text: raling ramps, was the most visible change to the 19th-century facade.
label: Paragraph

text: Internally, the old and new materials were clearly separated and placed in dialogue.
label: Paragraph

text: Exposing layers of history found during the renovation became part of the design
label: Paragraph

text: strategy. Marks of the masons, 19th-century decorative moldings, Russian bullet holes,
label: Caption

text: and graffiti all were framed by fresh plaster walls.
label: Paragraph

text: The main organization of the original building was preserved—a central parliament
label: Paragraph

text: chamber flanked by two exterior courts. The chamber was semi-circular and gently raked
label: Paragraph

text: with a concentric public viewing gallery cantilevered from the second floor. In a notable
label: Caption

text: departure from the 19th-century room, the ceiling of the chamber followed the geometry
label: Paragraph

text: of the dome above. Light was distributed evenly through a series of mirrors and filters. A
label: Paragraph

text: central reflective element formed the hub of a bicycle-wheel cable system anchored at the
label: Paragraph

text: spring point of the dome. Light and airy, the room’s focus was an enormous eagle, an
label: Paragraph

text: icon moved from Bonn.
label: Paragraph

text: Circulation in the building was organized to reflect a genuine democracy. Citizens,
label: Paragraph

text: lawmakers, and visitors all entered through the same portal and used the grand stair. The
label: Paragraph

text: formality of the original plan was restored, removing the many small revisions from the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s renovation that had obscured the secondary axes. Most of the massive masonry
label: Paragraph

text: walls were retained, but a new transparency was gained through skillful manipulation of
label: Paragraph

text: natural and artificial light.
label: Paragraph

text: At the end of the public sequence was the spectacular glass dome with intertwining
label: Paragraph

text: double helical ramps. The structure of the 40-meter dome, along with ramps and central
label: Paragraph

text: mirror, all are hung from the original masonry walls. This required the construction of a
label: Paragraph

text: significant temporary structure and the use of a 40-meter crane (one of only four in
label: Paragraph

text: Europe at the time).
label: Paragraph

text: From the dome, visitors gained a panoramic view of the city as well as a limited view
label: Paragraph

text: down to the parliamentary chamber illuminated beneath. In the middle of the dome was a
label: Paragraph

text: mirrored sculptural element that had multiple functions: it directed light, which was
label: Paragraph

text: diffused by a shade, to the chamber below; it reflected focused artificial light beams
label: Paragraph

text: across the city at night; and it acted as a heat chimney, exhausting hot air from the
label: Paragraph

text: chamber below.
label: Paragraph

text: Appropriate to Germany’s innovative environmental legislation in the latter part of the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century, the Reichstag followed many sustainable building practices. The building
label: Paragraph

text: adapted the original 19th-century heating and cooling strategy, relying on two existing
label: Paragraph

text: aquifers. These underground lakes were used to store heated or cooled water, which then
label: Paragraph

text: flowed into radiators in the floors or ceilings. Power was generated by burning vegetable
label: Paragraph

text: and seed oils, renewable resources that burned with minimal waste.
