text: REINFORCED CONCRETE
label: Title

text: Several European engineers, working independently, developed reinforced concrete
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the 19th century. Francios Hennebique of France was one of many to patent
label: Paragraph

text: his experimental work (1887), and in the last two decades of the 19th century, he devised
label: Paragraph

text: a coherent system of reinforced concrete. By 1917, Hennebique’s international firm had
label: Paragraph

text: completed a staggering 17,000 contracts, forging a worldwide industry. Although the use
label: Paragraph

text: of this type of construction was widespread in Europe, North Africa, and North America
label: Paragraph

text: at the turn of the century, most builders were interested in its fireproofing characteristics,
label: Paragraph

text: and few understood the tensile potential inherent in the reinforcing. The notion that steel
label: Paragraph

text: and concrete could function monolithically had already been demonstrated on paper and
label: Paragraph

text: in practice by many engineers, but the structural ramifications of that fact required time
label: Paragraph

text: to disseminate. Some early experiments erroneously failed to demonstrate that iron
label: Paragraph

text: embedded in concrete could withstand a greater load than iron without concrete.
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss engineer Robert Maillart was one of the first designers to break from the
label: Paragraph

text: masonry past by using steel-reinforced concrete in forms and configurations appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: to its technical properties. The monolithic potential of this new material offered great
label: Paragraph

text: advantages in weight and labor, and with new theories of structural analysis emergent in
label: Paragraph

text: the early 20th century, standards for both the design and the construction of reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete were adopted in several countries as early as 1902. These standards were
label: Paragraph

text: ultimately invested with quasi-legal status, incorporated into building codes later in the
label: Paragraph

text: century.
label: Paragraph

text: Reinforced concrete is the union of two materials: concrete, which is strong in
label: Paragraph

text: compression, and steel, which is strong in tension. Without reinforcing, concrete’s tensile
label: Paragraph

text: strength is typically only 10 per cent of its compressive strength. This tensile strength is
label: Paragraph

text: so minimal, in fact, that it is typically omitted from structural calculations. Steel comes in
label: Paragraph

text: the form of bars ranging from 3/8 inch to nearly 3 inches in diameter. Placed into
label: Paragraph

text: formwork before the concrete is poured, the steel reinforcing bars, or rebars, are typically
label: Paragraph

text: located where engineers expect stress due to tension to be greatest, referred to as the
label: Paragraph

text: tensile zone (in the case of a simply supported beam, the tensile zone occupies the bottom
label: Paragraph

text: half of the beam). Because steel is also strong in compression, rebars are employed even
label: Paragraph

text: when tension is not expected to be severe, such as in axially loaded columns. One of the
label: Paragraph

text: advantages of reinforced concrete is that the concrete insulates the steel during a fire.
label: Paragraph

text: Another is that concrete and reinforcing steel expand at approximately the same rate
label: Paragraph

text: during fluctuations of temperature. This is important because if the embedded steel were
label: Paragraph

text: to expand at a greater rate than the surrounding concrete, stress and possible failure may
label: Paragraph

text: result.
label: Paragraph

text: The embedment of the rebar requires care, however, because several factors can spoil
label: Paragraph

text: the advantages of its use. Proper concrete mixes are required so that the steel and the
label: Paragraph

text: concrete bond and thus work as one unit. Also, the concrete must protect the rebar from
label: Paragraph

text: corrosion, although corrosion in limited quantity actually increases bonding. Pouring the
label: Paragraph

text: concrete also presents opportunity for error because efforts to force the wet concrete and
label: Paragraph

text: its aggregates to fill the formwork can dislocate rebars from their intended position.
label: Paragraph

text: This is also true for wire-mesh reinforcement, which is often used instead of rebar in
label: Paragraph

text: slab-on-grade applications, such as sidewalks, driveways, and floor slabs. Welded strands
label: Paragraph

text: of steel formed in a gridlike mesh are often used to resist light tensile stress or to prevent
label: Paragraph

text: concrete from cracking because of temperature changes. This form of reinforcing is
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes used to resist more severe stresses, such as the conical shaped wire mesh used
label: Paragraph

text: in the columns of Frank Lloyd Wright’s Johnson Wax Company Administration Building
label: Caption

text: (1939) in Racine, Wisconsin. Twenty-two-foot-tall columns were supported by a base
label: Caption

text: only 9 inches in diameter, tapering lotuslike at the ceiling. When a test column was
label: Paragraph

text: axially loaded on the site, the concrete and its welded wiremesh reinforcing supported 60
label: Paragraph

text: tons, five times the anticipated load.
label: Paragraph

text: Generally, there are two ways that a reinforced-concrete structure can fail, namely,
label: Paragraph

text: excessive compressive stress or tensile stress. Engineers typically design reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete to fail in tension rather than compression by underdesigning the rebar. Most
label: Paragraph

text: codes require this because steel fails gradually by yielding before reaching its ultimate
label: Paragraph

text: capacity. When a reinforced-concrete structure fails because of tensile yielding,
label: Paragraph

text: deflection gradually increases and becomes visually detectable. Compressive failure, on
label: Paragraph

text: the other hand, is often sudden and sometimes drastic and even explosive.
label: Paragraph

text: Because concrete is poured rather than cut, rolled, or extruded, designers sometimes
label: Paragraph

text: can afford the liberty of shaping structural elements to take special advantage of
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete’s inherent properties. Roof slabs, for instance, can be made 6 inches
label: Paragraph

text: thick and folded or curved in dynamic forms. Rebar can be stretched taut in its forms
label: Paragraph

text: before the concrete is poured, thus prestressing the structural member and allowing for
label: Paragraph

text: lighter and thinner and thus more efficient structural elements. Reinforcing tenons may
label: Paragraph

text: also be stretched after concrete has set, in a system called post-tensioning, which also
label: Paragraph

text: increases the reinforced concrete’s ability to carry loads. As analytical and mathematical
label: Paragraph

text: sophistication has increased, engineers can often anticipate where the most severe lines of
label: Paragraph

text: stress are likely to develop in a given structure. The pattern of reinforcing can therefore
label: Paragraph

text: be superimposed over those same lines, called isostatic lines, which is exactly how Italian
label: Paragraph

text: engineer Pier Luigi Nervi devised his dramatic scheme for a factory in Rome (Gatti Wool
label: Paragraph

text: Factory, 1951). The underside of the factory’s floor slabs were articulated with an
label: Paragraph

text: irregular grid of reinforced beams radiating out from columns and crisscrossed by circles
label: Paragraph

text: of beams concentrically ringing out from those same columns. This irregular, nearly
label: Paragraph

text: curvilinear waffle pattern is a classic example of what advocates would call beauty
label: Paragraph

text: derived from pure structure. However, it was a structural solution that may have been
label: Paragraph

text: efficient in its use of concrete and reinforcing, but the irregularity of the grid pattern
label: Paragraph

text: required ex-tremely elaborate formwork, thus reducing the solution’s cost-effectiveness.
label: Paragraph

text: For this reason, as well as the analytical complexity of determining the pattern of stress,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: where reinforced beams intersect one another at right angles, forming square voids rather
label: Paragraph

text: than irregular voids and thus becoming more amenable to repetitive formwork, have been
label: Paragraph

text: widely used.

text: RENAULT DISTRIBUTION CENTRE
label: Title

text: Designed by Sir Norman Foster; completed 1983 Swindon, England
label: Caption

text: Foster and Partners designed the Renault Distribution Centre in Swindon, England, on
label: Paragraph

text: a 16-acre sloping site at the western edge of the town. Renault needed a distribution
label: Paragraph

text: facility for spare parts for the car dealers in England, office space, exhibition space, and a
label: Paragraph

text: cafeteria. Being a fairly rural area, the town planners and Renault were concerned with
label: Paragraph

text: making a visually interesting building that would enhance the surroundings.
label: Paragraph

text: With its sea of yellow steel masts, the Distribution Centre has come to embody the
label: Paragraph

text: essence of the work of the often-called High-Tech architecture, which, although it
label: Paragraph

text: explores new materials and their highly technological capacities, is also an “appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: technology,” with its lightweight and flexible metal structure, for the automotive
label: Paragraph

text: industry.
label: Paragraph

text: As an alternative to the ubiquitous “big box” or factory-in-ashed—as are many of
label: Paragraph

text: Richard Foster’s buildings, such as the Willis Faber and Dumas offices (1975) in
label: Paragraph

text: Suffolk—the Centre is inventive and expressive of a second machine age of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The unique suspension structure is exposed as a bridge, and it exemplifies the
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration between architect and engineer in fabricating nonstandardized parts for a
label: Paragraph

text: building rather than employing off-the-shelf products. Although the metal parts are
label: Paragraph

text: produced with the help of the computer, they are customized to the specific structure of
label: Paragraph

text: the building. The architects, with the engineers Ove Arup and Partners, developed a
label: Paragraph

text: repeatable single-story module to be built over the site with a lightweight roof suspended
label: Caption

text: from a mast structure with an interior filled with natural light. It successfully continues
label: Paragraph

text: the idea of modular construction and the machine aesthetic as exemplified in the Reliance
label: Paragraph

text: Controls Center (1967), also in Swindon, designed by Team 4, and Foster’s Modern Art
label: Paragraph

text: Glass Factory (1973) in Kent.
label: Paragraph

text: Foster’s design began with a building module 24 square meters, 7.5 meters high at the
label: Paragraph

text: edges, and up to 9.5 meters at the center, suspended from a 16-meter-high tubular steel
label: Paragraph

text: mast to create an open network. Forty-two of these modules were then erected in a 9-by-
label: Paragraph

text: 4-meter grid with 36 modules housing the warehouse space laid out in a two-directional
label: Paragraph

text: grid for easy access to the parts and equipment. Six additional modules comprise the
label: Paragraph

text: distribution and office spaces, a car showroom, a training school, workshops, seminar
label: Paragraph

text: rooms, and a cafeteria. The entrance is composed of one module left open at the sides like
label: Paragraph

text: a canopy. The building can be expanded by continuing the same modular system.
label: Paragraph

text: The modules are constructed of diverse metal components in a portal frame. Steel
label: Paragraph

text: beams faceted into an arch are supported from the top of the prestressed circular rolled
label: Paragraph

text: hollow steel masts by thin steel tension rods at 45-degree angles. The tension rods reach
label: Paragraph

text: the beams and continue beneath the roof and with supports from below to join with the
label: Paragraph

text: next beam. The beam-and-mast system creates an umbrella shape that supports each
label: Paragraph

text: other, and the steel ties at each mast provide the moment connection. The steel beams
label: Paragraph

text: have holes to reduce the weight but also to provide an aesthetic lightness that is clearly
label: Paragraph

text: visible in the way the circular holes are lined up from roofline to roofline.
label: Paragraph

text: Tubeworkers Limited developed the rods and their bolts and pin joints in a custom-
label: Paragraph

text: made system originally developed for sailing rigging, but here in a spheroidal graphite
label: Paragraph

text: cast iron, which has a low melting point for shaping and the tensile properties of cast
label: Paragraph

text: steel. This was the first time the product was used for a building.
label: Paragraph

text: The facades are a combination of steel panels and glass. A Pilkington system of 10-
label: Paragraph

text: millimeter-thick flatbed armor-plated glass in 4-by-2-meter sheets is suspended on bolts
label: Paragraph

text: countersunk into the glass and held in place with special steel spider legs. Lightweight
label: Paragraph

text: steel transoms span between the mullions with the same spider-leg fastener.
label: Caption

text: The insulated steel wall panels are custom made by a caravan company with a 4-meter-
label: Paragraph

text: long horizontal span between the steel mullions, placed on edge fastened by flanges at the
label: Paragraph

text: back. The few interior wall divisions are the same lightweight steel panels or glass for
label: Paragraph

text: visibility between spaces. The exterior walls are recessed from the roofline, bringing the
label: Paragraph

text: structure to the fore. The end modules, each with a corner mast, are tied down with
label: Paragraph

text: tension rods and stabilized on concrete foundations.
label: Paragraph

text: The roof is one PVC membrane with insulation secured by metal disks that seal the
label: Paragraph

text: openings from the penetrations of the masts and vents. Twenty-seven trapezoidal-shaped
label: Caption

text: roof lights at the point of each module are held in place by 6-millimeter bolts at the top of
label: Paragraph

text: each plate. The roof lights, recalling early 20th-century factories, provide views, natural
label: Paragraph

text: sunlight, and smoke ventilation.
label: Paragraph

text: A fascia seals the wall and the roof connection with a flexible neoprene-coated nylon
label: Paragraph

text: fabric often used for hovercraft skirts, and the fastenings are those used for truck trailer
label: Paragraph

text: covers. Foster also designed office furniture for the complex that he had used in other
label: Paragraph

text: Renault projects.
label: Paragraph

text: The Distribution Centre is a flexible building, not a static monument, but one that
label: Paragraph

text: reflects the ever-changing automotive technologies. The building bespeaks customized
label: Paragraph

text: standard sys-tems for its own construction, specific to its own needs yet is fully
label: Paragraph

text: adaptable, a feature that is also visible in Foster’s Hong-kong and Shanghai Bank
label: Paragraph

text: Headquarters (1986). The vertical yellow masts on the horizontal landscape have been
label: Paragraph

text: compared to sailing ships or umbrellas basking in the sun, and the building has become
label: Paragraph

text: an identifiable trademark for Renault in England.
label: Paragraph

text: REPRESENTATION
label: Title

text: “At the End of the Century: One Hundred Years of Architecture,” the traveling exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: organized by the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, offered a vast array of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural representation, from the 1914 Sant’Elia Italian futurist drawings to the
label: Paragraph

text: working model of Gehry’s 1997 Bilbao Guggenheim Museum. Although the futurists did
label: Paragraph

text: not produce any built work, Sant’Elia’s depictions of an imagined architecture befitting
label: Paragraph

text: the new machine age have become part of the canon of modern architecture; eloquent and
label: Paragraph

text: seductive, the drawings constitute the most radical architectural proposition that gave
label: Paragraph

text: expression to a modern city driven by agile transportation systems. Whereas in
label: Paragraph

text: Sant’Elia’s work the drawings became the architecture, in Gehry’s Guggenheim new
label: Paragraph

text: means of representation begot a new architecture. The building’s insistence on irregular
label: Paragraph

text: forms challenged the traditional orthogonal architectural drawing conventions of plans
label: Paragraph

text: and sections, and both design and construction had to rely greatly on the latest computer-
label: Paragraph

text: modeling technology.
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural representation provides the visualizing context in which architects think
label: Paragraph

text: through a design. Drawings, models, sketches, cross sections, axiometric views, and most
label: Paragraph

text: recently computer-generated walk-throughs are where architecture is initially conceived
label: Paragraph

text: and displayed. If developments in materials and technology make possible new
label: Paragraph

text: construction methods, it is through the different means and uses of representation that
label: Paragraph

text: architects configure the idea and desire for the new building’s iterations; representation
label: Paragraph

text: ceases to be merely the communication of design and becomes instead an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: manifestation as potent and valid as the built results. In some cases, as with the Italian
label: Paragraph

text: futurists, there is no built outcome, yet the visualization of a dynamic new architecture in
label: Paragraph

text: Sant’Elia’s drawings that posited itself firmly against the historicism of the 19th century
label: Paragraph

text: was an influential reference for modern architects. In others, as in Gehry’s Guggenheim,
label: Paragraph

text: new ways of building are directly reliant on means of representation that allow the
label: Paragraph

text: visualization of new formal configurations. To many theorists, critics, and architects,
label: Paragraph

text: architecture rests as much in representation as it does in the built form itself.
label: Paragraph

text: Differences in the means of representation are often indicative of the biases of the
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The importance of the plan in the works of Frank Lloyd Wright, Ludwig
label: Caption

text: Mies van der Rohe, and Le Corbusier was in part what pitted modern architecture against
label: Paragraph

text: the historicism that preceded it. The new plans proposed a radically new arrangement and
label: Paragraph

text: delineation of rooms, but more important, positing the plan as the building’s critical
label: Paragraph

text: generator implied that its corresponding elevation, or what the building might look like,
label: Paragraph

text: was directly borne out of it and not arbitrarily applied as one might have applied
label: Paragraph

text: architectural styles in the 19th century. The elevation regained importance later in the
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodern architecture of Robert Venturi, Michael Graves, Charles Moore, Robert
label: Caption

text: Stern, and others, whose designs relied substantially on the representation of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: signs and languages. Reacting against simplistic interpretations of modern architecture
label: Paragraph

text: principles after World War HU, they imbued their work with allusive, recognizable
label: Paragraph

text: imagery and symbolism, calling on and reinterpreting classical or vernacular forms.
label: Paragraph

text: Although plans and elevations are two-dimensional drawings, architects see their three-
label: Paragraph

text: dimensional buildings through them.
label: Paragraph

text: In their 1978 classic, Collage City, Colin Rowe and Fred Koetter used not a particular
label: Paragraph

text: drawing but rather a manner of making as a metaphor for an urban-planning idea. As
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture developed in the first decades of the 20th century, the Cubists probed
label: Paragraph

text: the nature of painting and two-dimensional representation by breaking with perspectival
label: Paragraph

text: conventions in place since the Renaissance. Instead, they created innovative paintings
label: Paragraph

text: that simultaneously represented three dimensions and called attention to the two-
label: Paragraph

text: dimensionality of the canvas. One work by Picasso, Sail Life with Chair Caning (1911-
label: Caption

text: 12), was used in the book to illustrate a composite approach to the design of urban
label: Paragraph

text: environments. Rowe and Koetter proposed treating the found urban fabric minutiae of old
label: Paragraph

text: cities and the newly made sweeping urban-renewal schemes of modern architecture as the
label: Paragraph

text: colliding pieces with which to compose a multivalent collage city, much like Picasso had
label: Paragraph

text: used the found-chair-caning print and applied paint strokes to make a harmonious
label: Paragraph

text: composition. There is wit, they argued, in finding linkages between two seemingly unlike
label: Paragraph

text: pieces by virtue of their carefully orchestrated adjacency, and collage was proposed as a
label: Paragraph

text: way of thinking in the design of architecture and cities. A comparison to painting also
label: Paragraph

text: calls attention to the dual nature of cities as two-dimensional entities as seen from
label: Paragraph

text: airplanes and on architects’ boards and as three-dimensional environments.
label: Paragraph

text: The ability to think about a building through its representation does not end at its
label: Paragraph

text: construction. Photography, as it represents and conjures architecture, offers additional
label: Paragraph

text: ways to understand and interpret built forms, and this ultimately affects one’s
label: Paragraph

text: understanding of it. The early acknowledged master in the eloquent use of photography to
label: Paragraph

text: convey architectural ideas is Le Corbusier, who composed the photographic
label: Paragraph

text: representations of his buildings as carefully as if the photographs were the buildings
label: Paragraph

text: themselves. Since the last decades of the 20th century, the dominance of glossy pictures
label: Paragraph

text: in magazines and books as the purveyors of architecture has raised the objection of some
label: Paragraph

text: pundits, who fear that this reliance on the photograph for one’s understanding of a
label: Paragraph

text: building is not conducive to great architecture. It is true that carefully framed
label: Paragraph

text: photographs can raise expectations about a building not fulfilled at the site visit and that
label: Paragraph

text: the great architectural spaces of Louis Kahn are notoriously difficult to photograph.
label: Paragraph

text: Ultimately, however, we must remember Susan Sontag’s important 1977 book, On
label: Paragraph

text: Photography, in which she argues that the photograph is too malleable a medium to be
label: Paragraph

text: merely a record of reality but that it becomes instead a reality all its own, as valid as its
label: Paragraph

text: unmediated counterpart.
label: Paragraph

text: Advances in digital media have cast anew the question of what constitutes a truthful
label: Paragraph

text: depiction of reality, architectural or otherwise. It has become increasingly facile to
label: Paragraph

text: simulate the continuous sequence of views through an environment generated entirely in
label: Paragraph

text: a computer. These immersive environments are reminiscent of Walt Disney in their
label: Paragraph

text: promise of habitation, albeit mediated, in an imaginary world. Theme parks are fictions,
label: Paragraph

text: the way in which a painting and a film are fictions or something like full-scale
label: Paragraph

text: representations of an idealized world. They are three-dimensional theatrical sets with
label: Paragraph

text: which one interacts as both spectator and participant. For both, their potency lies not in
label: Paragraph

text: how closely they approximate reality but in the believability of their illusory reality. As
label: Paragraph

text: with other forms of representation, some architecture today remains exclusively in digital
label: Paragraph

text: form. As such, it is reduced to a system of three-dimensional coordinates inside the
label: Paragraph

text: computer and is infinitely malleable. However, even when it becomes manifest in
label: Paragraph

text: physical reality, the medium radically changes the nature of the architecture, as in
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s previously mentioned Guggenheim project, in which a direct connection
label: Paragraph

text: between digital configurations and manufacturing processes allowed formal
label: Paragraph

text: configurations that had proved impossible to visualize through traditional drawing
label: Paragraph

text: methods.
label: Paragraph

text: RESEARCH CENTER
label: Title

text: A research center consists of a building or complex of buildings devoted to the service of
label: Paragraph

text: scientific inquiry that include astronomical observatories and biological, chemical,
label: Paragraph

text: medical, and physical laboratories as well as buildings for related demands. As a modern
label: Paragraph

text: building type, these facilities share their appearance with the institutionalization of
label: Paragraph

text: Western science that occurred during the 17th and 18th centuries but that took a
label: Paragraph

text: recognizable form only after the middle of the 19th century. As the value of science
label: Paragraph

text: began to make itself felt on the progress of technology during the last half of the 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century, and as a career in the sciences was seen as the best hope of improving the life of
label: Paragraph

text: the common individual, distinctive buildings devoted to teaching and the development of
label: Paragraph

text: each scientific discipline emerged.
label: Paragraph

text: At the beginning of the 20th century, the dominant location of research centers was to
label: Paragraph

text: be found on university campuses. Of the various scientific disciplines, buildings for
label: Paragraph

text: chemistry generally presented the largest capital investment and the most difficult
label: Paragraph

text: architectural problems. Laboratory siting was commonly downwind of the campus center
label: Paragraph

text: because of the increased production of unhealthy fumes, corrosive chemicals, water
label: Paragraph

text: pollution, and occasional mishaps. Daylighting and natural ventilation strategies were
label: Paragraph

text: paramount in the development of plans and building massing of which the Chandler
label: Paragraph

text: Chemical Laboratory (1884) at Lehigh University in South Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, by
label: Paragraph

text: Addison Hutton, was perhaps the dominant model of this period. Solid construction and
label: Paragraph

text: excellent materials typify these facilities.
label: Paragraph

text: At the beginning of the 1920s, powered ventilation systems were introduced to this
label: Paragraph

text: type. One of the first laboratories to solely employ powered systems was the Sterling
label: Paragraph

text: Chemistry Building (1923) at Yale University in New Haven, Connecticut, by Delano
label: Caption

text: and Aldrich. Located on the northern edge of the campus, the building was finished in a
label: Paragraph

text: Collegiate Gothic style with engaged pilasters and ornamented terra-cotta chimney flues.
label: Caption

text: More important, however, the building was massed as a block. Using the crawl space
label: Paragraph

text: beneath the main floor of the building as a flue, similar to a Roman hypocaust (an
label: Paragraph

text: underground furnace system), the building was to be continuously flushed with fresh air
label: Paragraph

text: with a single motorized fan.
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast, industrial laboratories begin to appear during the 1930s and were usually
label: Paragraph

text: sited adjacent to their manufacturing counterpart. Freed from the architecturally sensitive
label: Paragraph

text: environment of university settings, laboratory designs were either a singly or a double-
label: Paragraph

text: loaded corridor type and usually limited to three stories in height because of the
label: Paragraph

text: efficiency of the mechanical systems. Their construction was typical of industrial
label: Paragraph

text: buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: The most striking and progressive design of this era appeared in 1938, when Russian-
label: Paragraph

text: born and British-educated architect Serge Chermayeff was commissioned to design a
label: Paragraph

text: laboratory for the Dyestuff s Division of the Imperial Chemical Industries in Blackley,
label: Caption

text: England. The building form was massed as a series of long, narrow fingers several
label: Paragraph

text: hundred feet in length and roughly 24 feet in width. The form was a result of a
label: Paragraph

text: rationalized examination of ergonomic and physical factors to achieve the maximum
label: Paragraph

text: daylight penetration for bench-top experiments and the most effective mechanical
label: Paragraph

text: ventilation system layout. The confidence in the mechanical system at this time permitted
label: Paragraph

text: the laboratory ceilings to be lowered, reducing total building volume, cost, and
label: Paragraph

text: equipment size. Fusing scientific research with a futuristic image, this is perhaps the
label: Paragraph

text: earliest example in which the design of the building structure became a secondary
label: Paragraph

text: consideration to the mechanical and related building systems. This new approach to
label: Paragraph

text: laboratory design of systems first and structure second came to be the recommended
label: Paragraph

text: approach for this building type by the end of the 1950s. Typical examples from this era
label: Paragraph

text: include the Chemistry Laboratory (1947) of the Illinois Institute of Technology in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago by Mies van der Rohe and the Science and
label: Caption

text: Hysolar Research Institute, University of Stuttgart, designed by Gunter
label: Caption

text: Behnisch (1987)
label: Title

text: © Donald Corner and Jenny Young/GreatBuildings.com
label: Caption

text: Pharmacy buildings (1947) at Drake University in Des Moines, lowa, by Saarinen,
label: Caption

text: Swanson and Saarinen. The form has remained a cost-effective approach into the 21st
label: Paragraph

text: century.
label: Paragraph

text: Recent efforts at trying to provide an improved research facility have led to several
label: Paragraph

text: striking laboratory designs. The Patscenter (1982) in Princeton, New Jersey, by Peter
label: Caption

text: Rice of Ove Arup and Partners, resulted in a masted tensile structure supporting a rigid
label: Paragraph

text: roof with an externally exposed mechanical system in an effort to integrate the
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical systems with building structure and produce a clean interior environment.
label: Paragraph

text: Similarly, the Schlumberger Cambridge Research Center (1985) in Cambridge, England,
label: Paragraph

text: by Michael and Patty Hopkins, was based on a masted tensile structure with a Teflon-
label: Paragraph

text: coated fabric membrane. However, relying on the use of advanced structural systems that
label: Paragraph

text: produce a high-tech expression has not resulted in an innovation to laboratory design that
label: Paragraph

text: has been widely accepted.
label: Paragraph

text: In the decade following World War II, the representational question posed by scientists
label: Paragraph

text: to architects became the promotion of a humanistic face for science. New laboratories
label: Paragraph

text: were expected to improve the negative social image of science that producing weapons of
label: Paragraph

text: mass destruction had in part created. The new labs were to also provide creative
label: Paragraph

text: environments in which scientists were encouraged to interact and remain sensitive to the
label: Paragraph

text: larger human condition. Notable examples based on these ideas are the Richards Medical
label: Paragraph

text: Research Center (1962) at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia and the Salk
label: Paragraph

text: Institute (1967) in La Jolla, California, both by Louis Kahn. Of the two projects,
label: Paragraph

text: however, it is the Salk Institute, with its romantic siting, full-height interstitial service
label: Paragraph

text: spaces above each laboratory for maximized flexibility, and the originally intended
label: Paragraph

text: housing and conference support facilities, that has proven to be an inspiring model for an
label: Paragraph

text: institutional research community.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Kahn’s approach proved more costly, the extra flexibility to meet changing
label: Paragraph

text: demands is a more effective solution in the long run for medical and biochemical
label: Paragraph

text: research centers. Prominent examples of this type are the E.R.Squibb and Sons, Inc.,
label: Paragraph

text: World Headquarters (1972) in Princeton, New Jersey, by Hellmuth, Obata and
label: Caption

text: Kassabaum, which has remained the preeminent corporate research complex. Comprised
label: Paragraph

text: of interconnected modules with labs and offices at the perimeter and support instruments
label: Paragraph

text: at the plan core, it has become a well-accepted solution. Another excellent example of the
label: Paragraph

text: interstitial approach arranged as an urban campus is the Fred Hutchinson Cancer
label: Paragraph

text: Research Center (1993) in Seattle, Washington, by Zimmer Gunsul Frasca Partnership,
label: Caption

text: with laboratory planner McLellan and Copenhagen, Inc. Although these designs were
label: Paragraph

text: approached from differing architectural points of view, they managed to succeed in
label: Paragraph

text: balancing the difficult technical, social, and representational demands that accompany
label: Paragraph

text: this building type.
label: Paragraph

text: Large-scale government team research methods contributed greatly to global
label: Paragraph

text: transformation initiated by science in the last half of the 20th century. Resulting from the
label: Paragraph

text: lessons learned in two world wars, plus the ever-growing cost and scale of research
label: Paragraph

text: complexity, by the end of the century research centers came to be dominated by
label: Paragraph

text: government programs and corporate facilities. National laboratories, such as Argonne,
label: Paragraph

text: Los Alamos, and Oak Ridge, date from World War II and are small-scale cities in their
label: Paragraph

text: own right. Large-scale corporate research complexes, such as those of IBM, Kodak, and
label: Paragraph

text: Microsoft, now serve every major industry. Typically removed from an industrial
label: Paragraph

text: environment, these facilities can occur in a pastoral setting coupled to an administrative
label: Paragraph

text: center to form a corporate headquarters that announces a global presence. The most
label: Paragraph

text: prominent at midcentury was the General Motors Technical Center (1946-54) in
label: Paragraph

text: Michigan by Eero Saarinen and Associates. Recent prominent examples include the
label: Paragraph

text: Panasonic Information and Communications Systems Center (1992) in Tokyo by Nikken
label: Caption

text: Sekkei, and the Max Planck Institute for Chemical Ecology and Biogeochemistry (2000)
label: Caption

text: on the Beutenberg Campus in Jena, Germany, by Ottow, Marx, Bachmann. Conflicting
label: Caption

text: issues of security, seclusion, and public and environmental safety versus unbounded
label: Paragraph

text: exploration, complex technical demands, and maximum building flexibility remain key
label: Paragraph

text: factors that impact this building and campus form.
label: Paragraph

text: RESORT HOTEL
label: Title

text: The resort hotel is an outgrowth of its 19th-century counterparts, including the spas and
label: Paragraph

text: seaside resorts of Great Britain and the United States and the mountain resorts of
label: Paragraph

text: Switzerland. The importance of the natural setting makes the relationship between
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and site a key component of resort hotel development that continues
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the 20th century. The hotel building grouped with associated recreational
label: Paragraph

text: facilities and out-buildings seeks to enhance the experience of natural landscape features,
label: Paragraph

text: such as mountains and bodies of water. For instance, the Suvretta House (1912, Karl
label: Paragraph

text: Koller) in St. Moritz, Switzerland, is closely linked to the adjacent ski slopes, while Hotel
label: Paragraph

text: Negresco (1910-13, Edouard-Jean Niermans) in Nice, France, features water-based
label: Paragraph

text: activities. In comparison to urban commercial hotels, resort hotel architecture emphasizes
label: Paragraph

text: linking interior spaces with the outdoors using balconies, verandas, and courtyards. This
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis descends from the horizontal forms and rambling porches of 19th-century
label: Paragraph

text: resort hotels.
label: Paragraph

text: Otherwise, resort hotel architecture addresses many of the functional needs that other
label: Paragraph

text: hotels do. The architect must carefully blend elegant public spaces, efficient service
label: Paragraph

text: spaces such as kitchens and laundries, and comfortable guest rooms. With the expansion
label: Paragraph

text: of tourism in the 20th century, many new resort hotels are constructed in places such as
label: Paragraph

text: the Caribbean, the South Pacific, and southern and western portions of the United States,
label: Paragraph

text: making these landscapes newly accessible to tourists traveling by bus, automobile,
label: Paragraph

text: airplane, or train.
label: Paragraph

text: Improved railroad transportation during the late 19th and early 20th centuries
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged tourism and the development of resort hotels. Railroad companies built and
label: Paragraph

text: operated many resort hotels to encourage travel to western Canada or the southwestern
label: Paragraph

text: United States from eastern locations. At the time, these resorts offered the only modern
label: Paragraph

text: facilities in ruggedly beautiful locations, thereby providing a tamed adventure for
label: Paragraph

text: travelers. These ventures could be highly profitable but also risky. Resort hotels linked to
label: Paragraph

text: the railroads failed when newer, competing resorts opened nearby; when transportation
label: Paragraph

text: patterns changed to favor the automobile; or when other locations became more
label: Paragraph

text: fashionable.
label: Paragraph

text: With the growth of tourism in the early 20th century, particularly in the United States
label: Paragraph

text: during the boom years of the 1920s, resort hotels became accessible to a wider economic
label: Paragraph

text: range of guests. Many famous resorts, such as the Greenbrier in White Sulphur Springs,
label: Paragraph

text: West Virginia, remain exclusively upper-class playgrounds, but places such as Coney
label: Paragraph

text: Island, Atlantic City, the Poconos, and the Catskills offer resort facilities for middle- and
label: Paragraph

text: prosperous working-class urban residents. This proliferation of resorts in the 20th century
label: Paragraph

text: represents the expansion of leisure culture across class lines.
label: Paragraph

text: Resort hotels often feature eclectic and evocative design motifs to attract guests.
label: Paragraph

text: Creative adaptations of regional motifs and historic architectural features give resort
label: Paragraph

text: hotels a distinctive ap-pearance and sense of place. A good example is Old Faithful Inn
label: Paragraph

text: (1902-03, Robert C.Reamer), built by the Great Northern Railway at Yellowstone
label: Caption

text: National Park. Materials such as boulders, logs, and peeled branches create an oversized,
label: Paragraph

text: romantic version of a frontier cabin combined with a Swiss alpine resort. This theme is
label: Paragraph

text: echoed in other park structures in the West, such as the Canyon Hotel (1910-11), also
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Reamer for Yellowstone, or the Lake McDonald Lodge (1913-14, Cutter
label: Caption

text: and Malgram)} in Glacier National Park, Montana. Despite the rustic motifs, these
label: Paragraph

text: examples are full-service resort hotels dedicated to guest comfort. In each case, the hotel
label: Paragraph

text: is situated to provide guests with spectacular views of the natural landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: Another noteworthy resort idiom that developed during the first half of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century was a modified Spanish mode popularized by the resorts of Florida, California,
label: Paragraph

text: and the southwestern United States. The work of architect Addison Mizner in Palm
label: Paragraph

text: Beach and Boca Raton typifies the use of fanciful Spanish motifs to create an exotic
label: Paragraph

text: regional look promoting Florida as a tourist destination. Mizner’s Cloister Inn (1925-26)
label: Caption

text: in Boca Raton is a prime example, featuring the pale pink stucco and red-tiled roof that
label: Paragraph

text: was typical of Florida architecture and resort landscape. A carefully asymmetrical plan
label: Paragraph

text: arranged around a series of courtyards deliberately invokes the history and incremental
label: Paragraph

text: development of Old World buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Resort hotels in the southwestern United States and California use another variation on
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish motifs that emphasize the plainer tradition of Spanish Colonial missions in the
label: Paragraph

text: region. The Mission Inn (1902-03, Arthur B.Benton) in Riverside, California, is an
label: Paragraph

text: important early example that combines artistic use of white stucco and red tile with
label: Paragraph

text: selective copying from extant missions. Resort hotel architecture frequently promotes a
label: Paragraph

text: romanticized sense of place for visitors while providing modern accommodations and
label: Paragraph

text: comforts.
label: Paragraph

text: After the upheaval of World War LI, tourism resurged in the 1950s, inspiring the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of a new generation of resort hotels. A key figure during this period is
label: Paragraph

text: Morris Lapidus, a set designer turned architect who created the most influential resort
label: Paragraph

text: hotels of the 1950s. Lapidus’s Fontainebleau Hotel (1953) in Miami Beach was wildly
label: Paragraph

text: popular among the public and criticized by the architectural profession for its hybrid of
label: Paragraph

text: International Style and updated French Renaissance motifs. The sleek elegance of
label: Paragraph

text: Lapidus’s high-rise resort hotels influenced resort hotel design in many of the newly
label: Paragraph

text: developing resort locations, such as Hawaii, Tahiti, Mexico, and South America.
label: Paragraph

text: Inexpensive air travel allowed increasingly large numbers of tourists from around the
label: Paragraph

text: world to reach faraway vacation places.
label: Paragraph

text: In the second half of the 20th century, the resort setting became secondary to the
label: Paragraph

text: theatricality of the architecture itself, as signaled by Lapidus’s hotels. This new trend is
label: Paragraph

text: most evident in places such as Las Vegas and Orlando, where the location is virtually
label: Paragraph

text: unimportant compared to the grandiose stage set of the resort hotel. The element of
label: Paragraph

text: fantasy and play inherent in resort architecture is exaggerated as hotels using a variety of
label: Paragraph

text: regional and historical themes coexist in their competitive efforts to attract guests. In the
label: Paragraph

text: late 20th century, the resort hotel employs a wide variety of forms while still sharing a set
label: Paragraph

text: of functional purposes. These trends and variations reinforce the creativity and luxury
label: Paragraph

text: inherent to the best resort hotel development throughout the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: RESTAURANT
label: Title

text: Of all the structures, signs, and symbols that stream by the automobile window, none
label: Paragraph

text: appears more suggestive than the orange roofs, golden arches, and smiling faces of the
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary restaurant-scape. Here, the designs suggest, is a secret code revealing
label: Paragraph

text: Americans’ most basic desires and needs. As Americans have become more and more
label: Paragraph

text: reliant on their automobiles, the early tendency of eating a meal of convenience in a
label: Paragraph

text: luncheonette has grown into a consistent alternative to eating at home. Initially, though,
label: Paragraph

text: the desire for restaurants needed no automobile.
label: Paragraph

text: Eat-and-run cuisine took shape following the Civil War. The Civil War encampment,
label: Paragraph

text: the chuck wagon of the American West, and the railroad dining car each helped to
label: Paragraph

text: introduce Americans to fast cooking and fast eating. Industrial workers, with a bit of
label: Paragraph

text: discretionary income and very limited time, became some of the first consumers of
label: Paragraph

text: meals—particularly lunch—at establishments called beaneries, greasy spoons, and stool
label: Paragraph

text: lunches. By the end of the 19th century, the expansion of commercial cities into white-
label: Paragraph

text: collar labor combined with mass transportation’s creation of the commuter to further
label: Paragraph

text: American interest in eating out. Cafeterias designed specifically for the luncher on a
label: Paragraph

text: timetable allowed customers to move along a line while selecting from a display of daily
label: Paragraph

text: items. Delicatessens provided sandwiches, and stores such as Woolworth’s installed
label: Paragraph

text: lunch counters.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1910 and 1927, the estimated number of restaurants grew by 40 percent. In
label: Paragraph

text: New York City, the number of eating establishments grew from 7500 in 1915 to 17,000
label: Paragraph

text: in 1925. Scholars suggest many factors for this change in American behavior: a greater
label: Paragraph

text: number of men and women working a way from home, a decline in the use of domestic
label: Paragraph

text: help to prepare meals, and Prohibition, which eliminated bars and the social life that
label: Paragraph

text: accompanied them. There were also technological advances that facilitated this type of
label: Paragraph

text: food preparation, including, refrigeration, shipping, storing, packing, and so forth. At this
label: Paragraph

text: point, the propensity to eat out met its mate for the rest of the 20th century: the
label: Paragraph

text: automobile.
label: Paragraph

text: As the automobile became more familiar in everyday American life after 1920,
label: Paragraph

text: planners and developers formalized refueling stations for the human drivers. Tearooms
label: Paragraph

text: were one of the earliest way stations designed to support family travel. The term conjured
label: Paragraph

text: an obviously safe establishment during the era of the speakeasy. With a limited menu,
label: Paragraph

text: based around afternoon tea, ice cream, cold drinks, and standard lunches or dinners,
label: Paragraph

text: packaging was critical for the first time in the industry. Owners used quaint names such
label: Paragraph

text: as Copper Kettle, Wishing Well, Pine Cone, or Silver Spring to reinforce their family
label: Paragraph

text: image. Most often, such establishments could be found along major tourist routes to
label: Paragraph

text: resorts. This was the model followed by one of the industry great entrepreneurs.
label: Paragraph

text: Beginning in 1925, Howard D.Johnson took the form of the tearoom to develop the
label: Paragraph

text: nation’s first great restaurant chain. During his family’s own travels, Johnson realized
label: Paragraph

text: that the new highways of the Northeast were almost entirely without food services for the
label: Paragraph

text: traveler. After opening a few restaurants, Johnson expanded his operation in 1935 by
label: Paragraph

text: permitting individual investors (called agents rather than franchisees) to build their own
label: Paragraph

text: Howard Johnson’s. The restaurants combined all the aspects of the tearoom with the first
label: Paragraph

text: recognizable, roadside architectural form: the orange roof combined with a colonial
label: Paragraph

text: motif. In doing so, Johnson married the familiar with striking oddity. By 1940, the chain
label: Paragraph

text: included 125 restaurants, and Johnson had secured exclusive access to the nation’s
label: Paragraph

text: greatest expressway: the Pennsylvania Turnpike. Details from colonial architecture were
label: Paragraph

text: used by Johnson as well as by the Dutchland Farms chain to add dignity to restaurants.
label: Paragraph

text: Along the highway, such restaurants loomed like a colonial mansion, often with trappings
label: Paragraph

text: of farm or country life added as well. After World War Il, Howard Johnson’s and other
label: Paragraph

text: similar restaurants would abandon colonial detail to become bastions of modernist
label: Paragraph

text: design. In many ways, such restaurant design defines the postmodern landscape that we
label: Paragraph

text: call the “strip.”
label: Paragraph

text: No structure reflected the connection between modern design and eating-out like the
label: Paragraph

text: American diner. First manufactured as lunch-cars in the early 1900s, the metal, self-
label: Paragraph

text: contained diner could be set down and wired up almost anywhere. Offering low cost and
label: Paragraph

text: instant gratification for purchasers, the diner quickly became a standardized form on the
label: Paragraph

text: American roadway. This provided owners with a bit of recognition without the central
label: Paragraph

text: control demanded from Johnson and other chains. After World War II, many diners could
label: Paragraph

text: not compete with the newer fast-food chains. The survivors often exaggerated their
label: Paragraph

text: Modern detail, abandoning the resemblance to a rail car for a wider form—still pre-
label: Paragraph

text: fabricated steel—that could seat family diners. The competitors, however, were not
label: Paragraph

text: slowing down.
label: Paragraph

text: From the earliest days of auto travel, food stands informally provided refreshment in
label: Paragraph

text: rapid, accessible fashion with no thought toward image or ambience. Convenience
label: Paragraph

text: defined such locations, though there was variation within the fast-food form. White
label: Paragraph

text: Castle hamburgers (1921) combined the food stand with the restaurant to create a
label: Paragraph

text: restaurant that could be put almost anywhere. Drive-in restaurants would evolve around
label: Paragraph

text: the idea of quick service, often allowing drivers to remain in their automobile. Fast food
label: Paragraph

text: as a concept, of course, derives specifically from Ray Kroc and the McDonald’s concept
label: Paragraph

text: that he marketed out of California (1952). Clearly the idea of providing service to
label: Paragraph

text: automobile drivers had created an entire offshoot of the restaurant industry.
label: Paragraph

text: The design of such establishments quickly became part of the attraction. Most
label: Paragraph

text: important, each of these types accentuated its contemporariness by incorporating modern
label: Paragraph

text: design, including heavy use of glass, metal, and neon lighting. Kroc was one of the first
label: Paragraph

text: restaurateurs to understand the importance of the physical structure. He required each
label: Paragraph

text: franchise to duplicate the standard building design—the now-famous structure with its
label: Paragraph

text: overhanging slanted roof, visual front, wall panels decorated in striped tile, and flanking
label: Caption

text: golden arches. The form would, of course, change with consumption patterns. For
label: Paragraph

text: instance, restaurants would eventually incorporate drive-through windows into the overall
label: Paragraph

text: design. The standardization of such structures defined American eating patterns along the
label: Paragraph

text: “strip” through the end of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Although each restaurant and shopping mall bore its own design and architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: planners and developers synched the entire composite into a design referred to as the
label: Paragraph

text: commercial strip. Restaurants led the way from Main Street and downtown into the
label: Paragraph

text: suburban regions. The trend toward automobility demanded a new organization to the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape and restaurants had already pointed toward planned areas outside of urban or
label: Paragraph

text: town centers. Fast food became the anchor of such “strips,” with McDonald’s or Burger
label: Paragraph

text: King generally acting as the first wave of commercial development. Design has followed
label: Paragraph

text: this trend while adding a dash of the amusement park: postmodern designs such as those
label: Paragraph

text: of Taco Bell cartoon bone fide architectural styles such as Mission to distinguish
label: Paragraph

text: themselves from the rest of the strip. Although diners have largely been squeezed out of
label: Paragraph

text: the market, new family dining restaurants such as TGlFridays have created a
label: Paragraph

text: homogenized form that is somewhere between fast food and a “sit-down” restaurant. The
label: Paragraph

text: strip is the home for each, as it is for most contemporary restaurants.
label: Paragraph

text: In urban areas, the restaurant landscape has continually evolved to meet the demands
label: Paragraph

text: of changing tastes and needs. Although dining rooms for the wealthy established
label: Paragraph

text: themselves by the middle of the 19th century, these were often luncheonettes or inns and
label: Paragraph

text: taverns. Demographic trends (including residential patterns in ethnicity and economic
label: Paragraph

text: class) significantly influenced the overall development of restaurants for other classes of
label: Paragraph

text: patrons. In urban areas, restaurants, with department stores, theaters, and hotels, were
label: Paragraph

text: made more viable and widely available by the introduction of electricity during the
label: Paragraph

text: 1890s. Entire shopping and eating districts could now be open into the evening; most
label: Paragraph

text: important, restaurants were no longer stifled by the limitations of midday meals or
label: Paragraph

text: overnight patronage. This new opportunity was seized by many entrepreneurs.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1910 and 1930, Americans began to consider eating out a much more viable
label: Paragraph

text: option. Most important, many more men and women were working away from home and
label: Paragraph

text: required the convenience of available dining. This trend coincided with a drop in
label: Paragraph

text: available domestic helpers to assist in making meals and Prohibition, which eliminated
label: Paragraph

text: barrooms between 1919 and 1933. This, of course, created a social void for many
label: Paragraph

text: Americans. Finally, technological developments such as refrigeration and food packing
label: Paragraph

text: and shipping made it much more conceivable to produce meals for many customers at
label: Paragraph

text: once.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early 1900s, efforts to differentiate restaurants as well as the growing diversity
label: Paragraph

text: of American population stimulated the growth of ethnic eateries. In urban areas, ethnic
label: Paragraph

text: cuisine became a way of sharing cultural enclaves with patrons from other ethnic groups.
label: Paragraph

text: For instance, Chinatowns became well defined at least partly through the restaurateur.
label: Paragraph

text: This diversity has only grown more obvious. From barbecue pits in the Southeast and
label: Paragraph

text: beef houses in the Great Plains to fish houses in the Pacific Northwest, regional cuisines
label: Paragraph

text: have become a terrific indicator of cultural plurality, which the U.S. began to achieve
label: Paragraph

text: after 1980. Although mass communications has flattened out much of the dining
label: Paragraph

text: experience nationally, diverse opportunities in dining allow Americans in many urban
label: Paragraph

text: areas to choose from as many as 100 different cuisines.
label: Paragraph

text: Although ethnicity continues to be a driving force in the distribution and selection of
label: Paragraph

text: restaurants, other patterns are also observable in the demographics of the restaurant
label: Paragraph

text: business. Technologies such as the automobile allowed restaurants to move outside of
label: Paragraph

text: urban areas. This trend placed a priority on modern design elements such as signage and
label: Paragraph

text: the use of windows, each of which suggested the streamlining trend of modern design.
label: Paragraph
