text: REVELL, VILJO GABRIEL (also Rewell)
label: Caption

text: Architect, Finland
label: Title

text: When Viljo Revell was born in 1910 in the Finnish coastal town of Vaasa, his
label: Paragraph

text: homeland was nearing the end of almost eight centuries of its being a pawn in the
label: Paragraph

text: political and economic struggles between Sweden and Russia. The 20th century would
label: Paragraph

text: prove to be one of Finland’s most tumultuous, and the political and economic climate of
label: Paragraph

text: the country had an irrefutable impact on the design and construction industry during the
label: Paragraph

text: period when Viljo Revell practiced architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: During the Napoleonic Wars, Russia successfully invaded Finland in 1809 and to
label: Paragraph

text: appease the Finns established the Grand Duchy of Finland, leaving intact the traditions of
label: Paragraph

text: the subject nation. Early in the 20th century, attempts to “Russify” Finland resulted in the
label: Paragraph

text: formation of numerous resistance movements. Furthermore, the unstable political
label: Paragraph

text: situation in Russia and Europe indirectly deflated the resource and agrarian economy of
label: Paragraph

text: the entire region. Even though Russia finally accorded to Finland its independence late in
label: Paragraph

text: 1917, competing domestic interests manifested themselves in the Red and White Armies,
label: Paragraph

text: which embarked upon a brutal, class-based civil war.
label: Paragraph

text: The 1920s saw the brief emergence of an architecture that responded to Finland’s
label: Paragraph

text: independence, a national romanticism characterized by a prevalence of wooden materials
label: Paragraph

text: used in Finnish vernacular building. Classicism inspired the symmetrical floor plans and
label: Paragraph

text: exterior elevations, as well as the building ornament—garlands, medallions, columns, and
label: Paragraph

text: arched porticoes. However, this style was quickly superseded by the practical economies
label: Paragraph

text: of the functionalist movement, which was evolving in continental architecture and city
label: Paragraph

text: planning. Stressing that purpose and function should determine form, these buildings
label: Paragraph

text: were characterized by a spartan simplicity and utilitarian decoration. By the mid-1920s,
label: Paragraph

text: Scandinavian journals reviewed the concepts proposed by Le Corbusier, a proponent of
label: Paragraph

text: this new design philosophy, and innovative young architects visited the Continent to see
label: Paragraph

text: concrete examples. Admired for its vitality and honesty, its airiness, light, and soundness,
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism appeared in Finland and Sweden during the late 1920s, just as Viljo Revell
label: Paragraph

text: was embarking on his architectural education at Helsinki’s Institute of Technology,
label: Paragraph

text: where he studied until 1937.
label: Paragraph

text: Finland’s slow recovery from the repercussions of World War | and the ensuing Civil
label: Paragraph

text: War was further hampered by the effects of the depressed world economy of the 1930s.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, Viljo Revell’s first building was constructed during this period on the site of
label: Paragraph

text: an abandoned Russian military barracks building in central Helsinki. Initially conceived
label: Paragraph

text: in 1933 by a five-student team as a temporary bazaar structure, the design was expanded
label: Paragraph

text: to include a bus coach station and a commercial building with a cinema, restaurants, and
label: Paragraph

text: shops. To the astonishment of the local architectural community, the city council
label: Paragraph

text: supported Revell’s proposed new design over that of the city’s own architect. The final
label: Paragraph

text: project design for the Lasipalatsi Building (1936), or Glass Palace, was completed by a
label: Paragraph

text: trio of students: Viljo Revell, Niilo Kokko, and Heimo Riihimaki.
label: Paragraph

text: The Lasipalatsi Building was definitely outside the bounds of the prevailing classically
label: Paragraph

text: inspired or Jugend style buildings, and it initially aroused public criticism. A swath of
label: Paragraph

text: large windows extended along the entire two-story street frontage, wrapping around the
label: Paragraph

text: curved corners and lending to the white-plastered structure a modern quality that heralded
label: Paragraph

text: future architectural innovations. Above the main entrance a multistoried glass wall canted
label: Caption

text: out over the street. The state-of-the-art Bio-Rex Cinema was housed in a large cubic
label: Paragraph

text: form, set well back from the street behind a one-story section with a roof terrace. The
label: Paragraph

text: complex also contained the HOK restaurant, its 700-person capacity making it the
label: Paragraph

text: country’s largest public dining facility. Lasipalatsi was constructed according to
label: Paragraph

text: functionalist precepts: bright and light open spaces with attention given to hygienically
label: Paragraph

text: smooth textures of the finishing materials. Technical ingenuity was evident in the
label: Paragraph

text: ferroconcrete structure and in the latest kitchen equipment and cinema projection
label: Paragraph

text: systems. Brightly colored blinds controlled the sunlight, and neon lights advertised the
label: Paragraph

text: businesses within. Artisans coordinated the interior decor with the overall building
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Separate from the building and to the rear, near the bus loading area, was an
label: Paragraph

text: iconographic smokestack, clock, and light tower marking the underground heating and
label: Paragraph

text: power plant for the complex. Designed for a ten-year life span, the Lasipalatsi Building
label: Caption

text: has survived in the hub of the capital city, and it was recently restored in 1998 to reflect
label: Paragraph

text: the structural, functional, and ideological intentions of its original designers.
label: Paragraph

text: The international conflict precipitated by Germany in 1939 resulted in strategically
label: Paragraph

text: situated Finland being caught in the midst of a battle between the Soviets and Germany.
label: Paragraph

text: Unwilling to transfer any territories to the Soviets, the Finnish mounted a valiant
label: Paragraph

text: resistance to their invading troops along the Mannerheim Line. The resultant peace
label: Paragraph

text: agreement in March 1940 ceded or leased substantial territory to the Soviet Union,
label: Paragraph

text: forcing the expulsion of all Finnish occupants and land owners. In order to regain these
label: Paragraph

text: lands, the Finnish government permitted Germany to use Finland as a military staging
label: Paragraph

text: base for attacks on Norway and the Soviet Union. When the Soviets retaliated in June
label: Paragraph

text: 1941, Finland felt justified in declaring war on this Western ally. Ensuing diplomatic
label: Paragraph

text: negotiations proved fruitless, and in 1944 the Soviets regained much of the territory
label: Paragraph

text: previously lost to Finnish and German troops.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1936, Revell had worked briefly in the office of Alvar Aalto, assisting with the
label: Paragraph

text: Finnish Pavilion for the 1937 Paris International Exhibition. He then designed a small
label: Paragraph

text: commercial building for his hometown of Vaasa, but the outbreak of war halted the
label: Paragraph

text: construction industry until the Finnish Association of Architects established a Bureau for
label: Paragraph

text: Reconstruction in 1942. Revell was named to head this institution, and for the next seven
label: Paragraph

text: years his energies were devoted to conducting research into the development of standards
label: Paragraph

text: for new construction materials and techniques, the modular systematization of buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: and methods for prefabrication. Revell’s first large-scale project did come out of this era,
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless. The Romantic style of his vocational school for the Liperi Rehabilitation
label: Paragraph

text: Centre for War Consumptives (1948) was indicative of the nostalgia that briefly
label: Paragraph

text: developed after World War Il, as Finland renounced modernism and reverted to the
label: Paragraph

text: Romantic Nationalism that had dominated the early decades of the century.
label: Paragraph

text: After entering private practice, Revell’s first successful competition entry was for the
label: Paragraph

text: Industrial Centre and Teollisuuskeskus Building, also known as the Palace Hotel (1952),
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking the Helsinki harbor and market. Designed in collaboration with Keijo Petaja,
label: Caption

text: the Palace Hotel was one of many design projects in which Revell was quite content to
label: Paragraph

text: share the limelight with others, even those with less experience than himself. His
label: Paragraph

text: unprejudiced attitudes and his ability to encourage innovative design solutions became a
label: Paragraph

text: trademark of Revell’s approach to architectural practice, and because of this, he attracted
label: Paragraph

text: young and talented newcomers to his studio.
label: Paragraph

text: The floor plan for the Palace Hotel forms an asymmetrical “H,” with the rooms
label: Paragraph

text: opening off corridors whose widths corresponded with anticipated circulation loads. In a
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusian manner, the mass of the building was elevated on two-story-tall columns,
label: Paragraph

text: or pilotis. Revell’s logical approach to design was evident in the hotel’s clearly
label: Paragraph

text: articulated circulation patterns and floor plans. His attention to details, particularly
label: Paragraph

text: noticeable in the fashionable Grill Restaurant, was evident throughout.
label: Paragraph

text: Postwar conditions had a tremendous impact on the Finnish economy, and beginning
label: Paragraph

text: in the 1950s, the government’s policy of reconciliation and declared state of neutrality
label: Paragraph

text: saw Finland precariously balanced between the Soviet Union and Western Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: Revell’s Reconstruction Agency was just one aspect of the social-welfare system that
label: Paragraph

text: Finland adopted to care for war survivors and to establish a thriving industrial sector in
label: Paragraph

text: what had previously been an agricultural economy. With the 1953 Housing Production
label: Paragraph

text: Act, the government embarked on two decades of intensive construction programs to
label: Paragraph

text: provide subsidized housing for the over 400,000 refugees who had arrived from the
label: Paragraph

text: Soviet territories. Severely restricted funding often resulted in sterile and boring
label: Paragraph

text: apartment blocks and row houses, suburban developments, and new towns. Occasionally,
label: Paragraph

text: some were internationally recognized for the excellent quality of their design, but more
label: Paragraph

text: often they became bleak dormitory villages for newly uprooted migrants, isolated far
label: Paragraph

text: from essential services and lifestyle amenities. Revell’s architectural commissions
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to find suitable solutions for these issues, and his systematic approach enabled
label: Paragraph

text: him to become a master of conservative, yet innovative, use of space, materials, and
label: Paragraph

text: energy resources.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1952 construction began on Tapiola, the internationally admired garden-city suburb
label: Paragraph

text: of Helsinki. Revell’s office designed five standardized apartment buildings and a school
label: Paragraph

text: during the community’s first and second development phases. Typical of government-
label: Paragraph

text: supported projects of this era, the apartment sizes were strictly limited, and whenever
label: Paragraph

text: these were exceeded, Revell had to compensate by making other apartments even
label: Paragraph

text: smaller. For these projects, Revell experimented with using prefabricated elements, at the
label: Paragraph

text: time a novel application for residential construction in Finland.
label: Paragraph

text: Revell was also able to apply his rational approach to smaller scale housing, such as
label: Paragraph

text: the Karjensivu Rowhouse (1955), sited on a rocky hillside fronting a bay near Helsinki.
label: Paragraph

text: To minimize costs and maximize comfort, he selected the row house form, putting all
label: Paragraph

text: living spaces on the upper level and utility rooms, garage, sauna, and entrance on the
label: Paragraph

text: ground floor. Movable partitions and modular cupboards enabled occupants to customize
label: Caption

text: the interiors. Radiant floor heating provided evenly distributed warmth at minimum cost.
label: Paragraph

text: Energy expenses were also addressed by constructing the entire wall overlooking the bay
label: Paragraph

text: of fixed triple-glazed windows, thus creating Finland’s first glass-walled building.
label: Paragraph

text: In conjunction with community and residential projects, Revell’s office applied the
label: Paragraph

text: systematic process to the design of several schools. The Meilahti Primary School (1953)
label: Caption

text: in Helsinki was designed with Osmo Sipari. Classrooms were arrayed in a sinuous line,
label: Paragraph

text: part of which curved protectively around an outdoor play area, sheltering the students
label: Paragraph

text: from the winds and reflecting the sun’s warmth. The school’s design was adapted to the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape, its plan being clearly separated into distinct functional modules, which along
label: Paragraph

text: with the outdoor play areas stepped up the sloping terrain.
label: Paragraph

text: The postwar peace treaty negotiated between Finland and the Soviet Union also
label: Paragraph

text: included reparations in the form of “goods in kind” to be paid to the Soviet Union until
label: Paragraph

text: 1952, and in order to meet these obligations, Finland undertook industrial development
label: Paragraph

text: on a massive scale. Many architectural practices designed factories with workers’
label: Paragraph

text: accommodations, and the competition for the Hyvon-Kudeneule hosiery factory and
label: Paragraph

text: employee housing (1955) near Hanko was won by Viljo Revell and Osmo Lappo.
label: Paragraph

text: Primary attention was given to planning an efficient assembly process, minimizing
label: Paragraph

text: energy consumption, and reducing operational costs. Revell specified a combination of
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated and cast-in-place reinforced concrete elements, as well as corrugated
label: Paragraph

text: anodized aluminum sheets for finishing the exterior walls. To visually unify the complex,
label: Paragraph

text: all buildings contained a limited variety of materials and structural forms. The designs of
label: Paragraph

text: such industrial complexes were a natural expression of Revell’s functional design talent.
label: Paragraph

text: Revell’s work was not confmed to utilitarian projects, however. In 1958, he completed
label: Paragraph

text: a private commission for the Danish-born entrepreneur and art collector Gunnar
label: Paragraph

text: Didrichsen—a villa on the Helsinki island of Kuusisaari. Revell used the hilltop site to
label: Paragraph

text: advantage, creating a two-story wall of triple-glazed windows overlooking the water. The
label: Paragraph

text: flat roof with its thick parapet extended out over the window walls, but the central portion
label: Paragraph

text: of the roof was raised, and clerestory windows let natural light flood the central portion
label: Paragraph

text: of the house. Revell also designed the built-in furnishings and architectural hardware. In
label: Paragraph

text: the wooded surroundings the Didrichsens installed a sculpture garden that included, at
label: Paragraph

text: Revell’s request, the Archer by Henry Moore. To house their growing art collection, a
label: Paragraph

text: new wing was added in 1965, and the villa now functions as the Didrichsen Art Museum,
label: Paragraph

text: Viljo Revell’s architecture being a major theme.
label: Paragraph

text: Given the international renown of Finnish architects Alvar Aalto and Eero Saarinen
label: Paragraph

text: and the provocative urban development projects, the outside world began to take note of
label: Paragraph

text: this small northern country. In 1958, Revell was prompted to enter the competition for a
label: Paragraph

text: new city hall in Toronto, Canada, and from among a field of over 500, the jury selected
label: Paragraph

text: his proposal. Revell worked in association with the large Canadian modernist firm of
label: Paragraph

text: John B. Parkin Associates. His design for the Toronto City Hall (1965) included two
label: Paragraph

text: towers of unequal height rising facing each other above a multistoried plinth. Between
label: Caption

text: the towers, the saucer-shaped council chamber was a discrete element supported on
label: Paragraph

text: slender piers. The elliptically shaped floor slabs of the office towers cantilevered out
label: Caption

text: from the massive rear walls, creating open floor areas that would provide maximum
label: Paragraph

text: flexibility for interior layouts. The building group created by these three elements was
label: Paragraph

text: fronted by an open plaza (Nathan Phillips Square) containing a large reflecting pool
label: Paragraph

text: spanned by elliptical arches, an elevated walkway around the perimeter, and a massive
label: Paragraph

text: rendition of Henry Moore’s sculpture, the Archer. As with many publicly funded
label: Paragraph

text: projects, the issue of cost overruns soon came to the fore, and Revell was constantly
label: Paragraph

text: forced to compromise his unique design, even after construction was well underway.
label: Paragraph

text: Massive columns soon interrupted the open interior spaces, the council chamber was
label: Paragraph

text: supported on an immense concrete cylinder that overwhelmed the interior spaces below,
label: Paragraph

text: and building finishes were frequently modified. In the view of several critics of the day,
label: Paragraph

text: Revell’s bold and innovative concept was altered to such a degree that construction of the
label: Paragraph

text: City Hall should not have proceeded. In spite of the controversy, the Toronto City Hall
label: Paragraph

text: became a well-loved nexus for the city’s inhabitants, and as an international landmark of
label: Paragraph

text: Modern architecture, it garnered an international reputation for Viljo Revell.
label: Paragraph

text: Unfortunately, Revell’s health seriously declined during this period, and close friends
label: Paragraph

text: ascribed his premature death to the turmoil surrounding this project.
label: Paragraph

text: While living in North America, Revell designed a lakeside cottage (1960) for the
label: Paragraph

text: H.F.Johnsons in northern Wisconsin. The cottage, with its sauna overhanging the water’s
label: Paragraph

text: edge, was built using traditional, load-bearing timber construction methods. The
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal emphasis and open planning concepts of modernism provide a counterpoint to
label: Paragraph

text: the natural materials.
label: Paragraph

text: When the World Health Organization held a competition for the design of their new
label: Paragraph

text: Geneva Administrative Headquarters in 1960, Revell was one of the 15 architects invited
label: Paragraph

text: to participate. The collaborative entry, submitted by Revell and three other Finnish
label: Paragraph

text: colleagues, garnered an Honourable Mention. They adhered to modernist principles,
label: Paragraph

text: elevating the low-rise building above a broad terrace. Recognizing that employees would
label: Paragraph

text: be from many countries, the designers minimized the use of long, isolating office
label: Paragraph

text: corridors. They created a triangular-shaped central volume containing an open hall,
label: Paragraph

text: council chamber, and museum, which connected the three projecting wings.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1962, Revell worked on his final project submission with a team of Finnish
label: Paragraph

text: architects and engineers. Although never constructed, the design of the office tower for
label: Paragraph

text: Peugeot in Buenos Aires displayed an innovative use of concrete and steel technology.
label: Paragraph

text: The competition drawings described a pedestrian plaza and massive underground parking
label: Paragraph

text: garage at the base of the building, surmounted by a skyscraper, which was subdivided
label: Paragraph

text: into three groups of 12 to 14 floors. Each group was separated by three-story-high
label: Paragraph

text: concave beams spanning between tapering pairs of structural piers located at each corner
label: Caption

text: of the tower. Each cluster of concrete floor slabs was supported by internal prestressed
label: Paragraph

text: cables and exterior cable nets, suspended from the centrally located services core and the
label: Paragraph

text: massive tie beams.
label: Paragraph

text: In hindsight, the architectural community has realized that Finland produced several
label: Paragraph

text: talented designers during the postwar decades although they were, at the time, eclipsed
label: Paragraph

text: by the greater reputations of Aalto and Saarinen. In achieving national and international
label: Paragraph

text: recognition, Viljo Revell is considered a leader of this group. Revell did not limit his
label: Paragraph

text: modernist ideals to a particular genre of architecture, and his designs covered the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural spectrum from customized luxury homes to mass housing projects,
label: Paragraph

text: industrial plants, commercial centers, and educational and institutional buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Revell’s untimely death in midcareer terminated the ascent of a talented modem
label: Paragraph

text: architect.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Recently published English-language resources devoted to Viljo Revell are limited, so the
label: Paragraph

text: following list includes an older survey of his work, edited by Alander Kyésti, and still
label: Paragraph

text: available in libraries. The more recent work, Heroism and the Everyday, Building
label: Paragraph

text: Finland in the 1950s, edited by Nikula Riitta, was published as a catalogue for an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition describing the work of several architects whose designs contributed to the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of Finland’s international architectural reputation—naturally, Viljo Revell is
label: Paragraph

text: among them. Furthermore, Revell’s work and the manner in which it contributed to the
label: Paragraph

text: development of Finland is frequently discussed in general surveys of the modernist
label: Paragraph

text: tradition in the Scandinavian countries. Such historical overviews, as well as discussions
label: Paragraph

text: of the legacy of earlier 20th-century architectural styles, assist us in understanding the
label: Paragraph

text: environmental context for Revell’s designs and the contribution that he made toward the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural landscape that is particular to Finland.

text: REWAL, RAJ 1934—
label: Title

text: Architect, India
label: Title

text: Despite his rigorous education and training in modernist design aesthetics, Raj Rewal
label: Paragraph

text: remains rooted in the culture of his native India. As Rewal himself noted, “Our
label: Paragraph

text: generation has been trying to discover the common thread in which the fabric of Indian
label: Paragraph

text: architecture has been woven in the past and its significance for our times.”
label: Paragraph

text: Rewal’s concern is with understanding the architectural history of India (especially of
label: Paragraph

text: the Mughal period) and forms such as the Aaveli (or urban courtyard house) of the
label: Paragraph

text: Rajasthan region; the attention to materials and climatic design mark each of his projects.
label: Paragraph

text: Most of the architect’s buildings have been erected in the public sector, mainly
label: Paragraph

text: institutional complexes and low- to middle-income housing. Most of his buildings are in
label: Paragraph

text: New Delhi, the Indian capital, although since the 1980s he has built more widely,
label: Paragraph

text: including outside the country.
label: Paragraph

text: Rewal’s early project for the French Embassy Staff Residences (1967-69) reveals his
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupation with concrete as a structural material with brick-and-stone in-fill. The
label: Paragraph

text: clustering of the lowrise units and their orientation to the sun and wind are a proto-type
label: Paragraph

text: for his later, larger housing schemes. This is taken to much greater heights in his
label: Paragraph

text: Permanent Exhibition Complex (1970-74) at Delhi’s trade fairgrounds, consisting of the
label: Paragraph

text: Hall of Nations and the Hall of Industries—large single-volume spaces—the largest of
label: Paragraph

text: which spans 78 meters and is 34 meters high. The structures are articulated as precast-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete space frames. This experimentation, with the engineer Mahendra Raj, translates
label: Paragraph

text: the use of steel and concrete, adapting the technology for local conditions and labor-
label: Paragraph

text: intensive building skills.
label: Paragraph

text: Rewal’s consistent use of concrete structure with block in-fill, usually clad in the beige
label: Paragraph

text: and red sandstone used in many historic buildings, gives his architecture a signature
label: Paragraph

text: quality. The sense of stability and mass in his works are, to some extent, offset by their
label: Paragraph

text: verticality and cantilevering of forms, as is evident in his office building, Engineers India
label: Paragraph

text: House (1979-83) and Standing Conference of Public Enterprises (SCOPE) office
label: Paragraph

text: building (1980-89), both in New Delhi. In the latter project, the fragmentation of
label: Paragraph

text: volumes and the series of interlocking polygonal structures with their deep recessed
label: Paragraph

text: opening and sunscreens help to modulate his “metabolic Brutalism.” This form of
label: Paragraph

text: expression was continually refined until he produced his elegant World Bank Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1993), built around a central square courtyard.
label: Paragraph

text: In another of Rewal’s preoccupations—that of housing—he tries, usually successfully,
label: Paragraph

text: to reconcile a rationalist sense of function, structure, and fabrication with typologies
label: Paragraph

text: abstracted from the past. His Sheikh Serai Housing (1970-82), with its cruciform site
label: Paragraph

text: plan and large central public square connected by pathways, keeps parking in central
label: Paragraph

text: areas surrounded by housing clusters. The notion of pedestrian streets and the grouping of
label: Paragraph

text: low-rise units was further developed in the elegant Asian Games Village (1980-82).
label: Paragraph

text: Comprised of 500 units, the Village is clustered in groups around courtyards, separated
label: Paragraph

text: by “gateways” and connected internally by a series of open spaces and paths reserved for
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrians. It provides an insight into his strategy for dense low-rise (up to four stories)
label: Paragraph

text: development.
label: Paragraph

text: Rewal’s notion of the “living unit” as a combination of indoor and outdoor flexible
label: Paragraph

text: space and patterns of growth that can be multiplied in numerous combinations is taken to
label: Paragraph

text: new heights in his CIDCO mass-housing scheme (of which 1048 units were built by
label: Paragraph

text: 2000) in Belapur, New Mumbai, as part of a much larger settlement. The units (each an
label: Paragraph

text: average of 40 square meters) on a site of 19 acres achieve a density of 55 units per acre.
label: Paragraph

text: The units are organized in seven neighborhoods, each defined by a system of peripheral
label: Paragraph

text: roads built along contours of the site. Here, as in all his works, Rewal’s attention to open
label: Paragraph

text: landscaped (planted and hard) areas is an integral part of his conception of space and
label: Paragraph

text: movement through the project.
label: Paragraph

text: Rewal is perhaps best known for his institutional projects. These complexes respond to
label: Paragraph

text: the hot, dry climate and urban environment, providing interlocking spaces, streets,
label: Paragraph

text: pavilions, terraces, and gardens surrounded by buildings. As the architectural critic Razia
label: Paragraph

text: Grover noted,” [They] are meshed in a system that responds to climate as well as the
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic requirements of each scheme.” For example, the National Institute of
label: Paragraph

text: Immunology (1983-90) uses the rocky site and central courtyard around which to
label: Paragraph

text: organize the building. Again in the Central Institute of Educational Technology (CIET;
label: Caption

text: 1986-89), the courtyard generates the spatial complexity of the building.
label: Paragraph

text: With the Parliament Library (1989-2001) and the World Bank Building (1990-93),
label: Paragraph

text: both in New Delhi, and the Ismaili Centre in Lisbon, there is a shift in Rewal’s
label: Paragraph

text: architecture to a concern with what one might term a “symbolic ethos” that reflects the
label: Paragraph

text: essence of culture in building. Rewal’s term for this is rasa (literally, “the juice of the
label: Paragraph

text: core”). The Library, won through a major competition, forms part of Lutyn’s Capitol
label: Paragraph

text: Complex in Delhi. In response to the built surroundings and the climate, the building is
label: Paragraph

text: essentially depressed under a plaza forming its roof, with parts visible above this plane.
label: Paragraph

text: This formal contextual gesture is a success. The World Bank also reveals a similar
label: Paragraph

text: introspective stance and attention to detail with a resolution seldom found in
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary Indian buildings. This synthesis of classicism with modern sensibilities
label: Paragraph

text: evokes a feeling that the architect has been able to draw on what the anthropologist
label: Paragraph

text: Claude Lévi-Strauss called the “deep structure” of society without having to resort to
label: Paragraph

text: using imagery of the past.
label: Paragraph

text: A departure from Rewal’s more familiar imagery, materials, and technology was made
label: Paragraph

text: in a social and religious complex, the Lisbon Ismaili Center (1995-99). The garden court
label: Paragraph

text: is surrounded by an expressive steel structure, clad in stone, marble, and more steel, in a
label: Paragraph

text: more fragmented and Western version of his buildings in India. Here, too, there is a
label: Paragraph

text: concerted effort to come to terms with the local climate, culture, and built environment.
label: Paragraph

text: The vocabulary of interlocking spaces, expression of structure, use of materials and
label: Paragraph

text: technology, attention to detail, and craftsmanship define the contemporary sensibility that
label: Paragraph

text: identifies Rewal’s buildings as his work. His work is like a tectonic puzzle that, once
label: Paragraph

text: solved, reveals the nature and essence of time and place to the people who experience it.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: RICOLA STORAGE BUILDING, LAUFEN,
label: Caption

text: SWITZERLAND
label: Title

text: Designed by Herzog and de Meuron, completed 1987
label: Caption

text: Designed and constructed in 1986-87, the Ricola Storage Building in Laufen,
label: Paragraph

text: Switzerland, is an important example of Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron’s
label: Paragraph

text: architectural work. Their effect has been felt by theoreticians and practitioners in equal
label: Paragraph

text: measure, in large part because of the essential idea that lies behind the Herzog and de
label: Paragraph

text: Meuron’s views on the discipline of architecture. This idea, what the architects refer to as
label: Paragraph

text: Architektur Denkform, supports the notion that the discipline of architecture cannot be
label: Paragraph

text: split neatly into the two poles of theory and practice but is instead based on the
label: Paragraph

text: recognition that architecture constitutes a seamless whole in which theory and practice
label: Paragraph

text: are reconciled and inclusive of each other. This approach is an idea that translates
label: Paragraph

text: roughly as “architecture as built thought,” “architecture as a form of thought,” or, even
label: Paragraph

text: more reductively, “architecture as thought.” This approach is consistent with a long-
label: Paragraph

text: standing search for alternatives to Enlightenment ideals in architecture, a search that in
label: Paragraph

text: the 20th century resulted in the adaptation of phenomenological ideals to architecture-
label: Paragraph

text: philosophical ideals that Herzog and De Meuron, in both building and codifying their
label: Paragraph

text: idea of Architektur Denkform, attempt to carry to a logical conclusion in works such as
label: Paragraph

text: the Ricola Storage Building.
label: Caption

text: The Storage Building, an addition to Ricola’s existing administrative and factory
label: Paragraph

text: offices, is located in a former limestone quarry and functions as the area for products and
label: Paragraph

text: materials used in the manufacture of herbal sweets. Like many of Herzog and De
label: Paragraph

text: Meuron’s projects, the circumstances and conditions of the site and program provide the
label: Paragraph

text: initial foundation for the architectural idea, an idea that is quickly modified according to
label: Paragraph

text: a suggested use of materials, structure, and the mechanics of the construction process. As
label: Paragraph

text: a result, the building is understood as “a part of the sequence of events, of a dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: process and not a static one” (Wang, 1992). Site and program, coupled with materials,
label: Paragraph

text: structure, and constructional means, provide the visual and intellectual organization.
label: Paragraph

text: The final result is an exceptionally rigorous project that, although encapsulating the
label: Paragraph

text: architects’ highly reflexive approach to architecture, deserves further elaboration. The
label: Paragraph

text: Storage Building is constructed of simple building components: a steel-frame structure
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by a cladding assembly. The external envelope comprises a system of
label: Paragraph

text: interwoven horizontal and vertical elements made of wooden battens, wood-cement
label: Caption

text: (Eternit) panels, and sheet metal. In maintaining the identity of each component part, the
label: Paragraph

text: building details express the nature and process of construction, exposing the “thinking”
label: Paragraph

text: of the building process. The Eternit panels, their width expanding as they ascend the
label: Paragraph

text: facade, are largest at the top of the cladding system. Furthering the sense of identity
label: Paragraph

text: accorded each building component, each vertical member is supported by numerous
label: Paragraph

text: individual foundations. A kind of “constructed parapet,” the cantilevering timber
label: Paragraph

text: construction projecting from the top, serves to expose the building’s internal
label: Paragraph

text: constructional system, thereby suggesting the qualities associated with an assemblage.
label: Paragraph

text: Accordingly, the building’s internal system, a galvanized sheet-metal box that serves
label: Paragraph

text: as an inner liner or container, is again revealed externally on the inner facade at the
label: Paragraph

text: connection to the original administration building, where it is detailed with extraordinary
label: Paragraph

text: precision. According to Wang, the use of exposed timber construction, coupled with the
label: Paragraph

text: delineated exposure of the cladding materials, “enables visual references to the stacking
label: Paragraph

text: of sawn timber boards around the numerous saw mills in the area as well as to the
label: Paragraph

text: limestone quarry in which the building sits.” Thus, the building is known for only what it
label: Paragraph

text: is: a building for storage. Herzog and De Meuron’s recognition of the mechanics of the
label: Paragraph

text: building’s construction as a significant aspect of the architectural form—enunciated by
label: Paragraph

text: the formal and material nature of the various systems—creates a woven tapestry of
label: Paragraph

text: resonating, highly reflexive relationships. These relationships, arrayed through the
label: Paragraph

text: multiple elements provided by the processes and materials of site, construction, function
label: Paragraph

text: (use), and materials, embody a “unified field theory of architecture,” a Zenlike
label: Paragraph

text: restfulness.
label: Paragraph

text: Herzog and De Meuron consistently abide by their self-described ideology of
label: Paragraph

text: Architektur Denkform in all aspects of their architectural production, a conceptual
label: Paragraph

text: apparatus that deserves further explanation. Unlike traditional methods of design, the
label: Paragraph

text: architects do not begin with a formal idea (what is sometimes referred to as a parti or, in
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary terms, diagram); rather, the “beginning” of architecture is actually a series
label: Paragraph

text: of beginnings, each re-informing the others in turn. By revealing particular facets of
label: Paragraph

text: design, the mixed media record of sketches, drawings, photographs, and models assume a
label: Paragraph

text: heightened level of importance as well, as much for the results yielded by the various
label: Paragraph

text: techniques as for the information gathered for further study. Hence, the elements of
label: Paragraph

text: design and building, garnered through the activity of design process, are not isolated from
label: Paragraph

text: other components of the building process; rather, they act as equivalent elements within a
label: Paragraph

text: field of elements, all of which are informed and adjusted by their consequent relations to
label: Paragraph

text: one another. As has been the case with most if not all of their architectural projects over
label: Paragraph

text: the past two decades, Architektur Denkform aptly describes Herzog and De Meuron’s
label: Paragraph

text: approach to the design and construction of the Ricola Storage Building. Decisions
label: Paragraph

text: regarding the use of materials and structure, the means of construction, and the
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances of the project’s siting provide the complex primary ground for the design,
label: Paragraph

text: a process that bears all of the building’s attributes at all stages of the design process.
label: Paragraph

text: “Materialized thought,” the resulting architecture is a constructed gestalt, a unified entity
label: Paragraph

text: or work of art that requires no explanation other than or beyond itself.
label: Paragraph

text: RIETVELD, GERRIT THOMAS 1888-1964
label: Title

text: Architect and furniture designer, the Netherlands
label: Title

text: Gerrit Thomas Rietveld was a prolific designer of furniture and architecture whose two
label: Paragraph

text: most famous works, the Red-Blue Chair (1918) and the Schréder-Schrader House (1924),
label: Paragraph

text: are considered icons of early modern architecture and design. Rietveld’s career spanned
label: Paragraph

text: more than 40 years and included numerous designs for buildings and furniture as well as
label: Paragraph

text: a number of published articles. An important figure in the De Stijl movement, Rietveld
label: Paragraph

text: was concerned primarily with the experience of architectural space. Through the
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of component parts, scale, and structure, he created designs that, although not
label: Paragraph

text: monumental, provided a setting that elevated the life of the occupant.
label: Paragraph

text: Born on 24 June 1888 in Utrecht, Rietveld left school at age 11 to work in his father’s
label: Paragraph

text: furniture maker’s shop. He left his father’s shop in 1906 to work as a draftsman in the
label: Paragraph

text: jewelry studio of C.J.Begeer in Utrecht, simultaneously pursuing architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: drawing courses in the evening. In 1911, Rietveld established his own furniture maker’s
label: Paragraph

text: shop in Utrecht and continued his evening architectural studies under the architect
label: Paragraph

text: P.Houtzagers. During this time, he designed several shops and a collection of furniture
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned by H.G.J.Schelling, an architect for Dutch Rail.
label: Paragraph

text: The first design for which Rietveld received recognition was the Red-Blue Chair.
label: Paragraph

text: Originally of unfinished wood, Rietveld added the color to articulate the individual
label: Paragraph

text: components. Two planes set at an angle to each other create the seat and back and rest on
label: Paragraph

text: a composition of horizontal and vertical rails. Extension of the wooden rails and planes
label: Paragraph

text: beyond their intersection points accents the open quality of the composition. An early
label: Paragraph

text: version of the chair had side panels that were later removed to create a greater feeling of
label: Paragraph

text: openness. The cross section of the rail, emphasized with the bright yellow paint,
label: Paragraph

text: establishes a modular system for the chair. The Red-Blue Chair was followed by other
label: Paragraph

text: pieces of furniture, including a buffet, in a similar style of horizontal and vertical rails.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1921, Truus Schréder-Schrider commissioned Rietveld to design a study in the
label: Paragraph

text: house she shared with her husband and three children. This small commission was the
label: Paragraph

text: beginning of a collaboration and friendship that continued for many years and resulted in
label: Paragraph

text: his most famous design: the Schréder-Schrader House. Considered to be the preeminent
label: Paragraph

text: architectural manifestation of the De Stijl movement, the house is the creation of a total
label: Paragraph

text: living environment based on Mrs. Schréder-Schrader’s ideas about modern living and
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld’s spatial explorations. Rietveld saw in De Stijl an alignment with his own
label: Paragraph

text: interest in the study of new definition of architectural space. Both the Red-Blue Chair and
label: Paragraph

text: the Schréder-Schrider House were prominently featured in the publication De Srijl,
label: Paragraph

text: edited by Theo van Doesburg.
label: Caption

text: In 1928, Rietveld was a founding member of the first CLAM (Congrés Internationaux
label: Paragraph

text: d’Architecture Moderne) in Switzerland and was a deputy delegate in the 1930 CIAM in
label: Paragraph

text: Frankfurt with Mart Stam. Rietveld’s interest in modernism included the role of
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization and mass production in architecture and design. In 1929, he proposed the
label: Paragraph

text: “core” house in which vertical circulation, plumbing, and heating were condensed into a
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated core around which the house would be built. Presented in a 1929 exhibition
label: Caption

text: in Utrecht, the concept was well received, but none was ever built. Rietveld designed a
label: Paragraph

text: number of housing projects, many in conjunction with Truus Schréder-Schrader,
label: Paragraph

text: including a series of row houses across from the Schréder-Schrader House. In 1930,
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld designed, on invitation, five row houses for the 1930-32 Werkbund Siedlung in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna.
label: Paragraph

text: This interest in industrialization can also be seen in a series of designs for economical
label: Paragraph

text: furniture by Rietveld and produced by Metz & Co. These included a line of “crate”
label: Paragraph

text: furniture (1934), easily assembled from precut parts, and the famous Zig-Zag Chair
label: Paragraph

text: (1934), a single bent plane of wood. Industrialization for Rietveld provided a means by
label: Paragraph

text: which good design could be made accessible as well as having the ability to eliminate the
label: Paragraph

text: repetition of tasks required in hand production. Although economy was key in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: both cost and manufacture, Rietveld was equally concerned with the function and
label: Paragraph

text: flexibility of an item.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite his early successes, however, it was not until the 1950s that Rietveld began to
label: Paragraph

text: receive larger commissions. Prior to that time, he had produced small commercial and
label: Paragraph

text: residential designs, some in a distinctly vernacular character. In 1954, Rietveld received
label: Paragraph

text: the commission for the Netherlands Pavilion for the Venice Biennale, where he used the
label: Paragraph

text: architecture to create a distinct yet subdued exhibition space through the integration of
label: Paragraph

text: natural light. Also in 1954, and initially intended as a temporary
label: Paragraph

text: Gerrit T.Rietveld, Red and Blue Armchair, designed 1918
label: Caption

text: © Mario Carrieri. Photo courtesy Cassina S.p.A.
label: Caption

text: structure, was the Sonsbeek Pavilion in Amhem, which was later reconstructed in
label: Paragraph

text: Otterlo. As in the Schréder-Schrider House, Rietveld explored the layering of spaces
label: Paragraph

text: through the dissolution of boundaries. The Pavilion is a composition of seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: independent horizontal and vertical planes creating a series of spaces that are
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously redefined by glass walls. Rietveld manipulated economical materials,
label: Paragraph

text: such as concrete block stacked on its side so that the holes are visible, wood, and glass, to
label: Paragraph

text: create an interpenetration of space similar to the work of Mies van der Rohe’s Barcelona
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion.
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld began designs for two prominent art academies, as well as for the De Ploeg
label: Paragraph

text: Textile Factory (1956), that exemplify his later works. In 1961, he entered into a
label: Paragraph

text: successful partnership with the architects Johan van Dillen and Johan van Tricht and
label: Paragraph

text: received a number of larger commissions, some of which, such as the Rijksmuseum
label: Paragraph

text: Vincent van Gogh (1963-72) in Amsterdam, were completed by the partners after
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld’s death.
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld received a number of awards and honors during his life, including the Crown
label: Paragraph

text: Order of Belgium, the Order of Oranje-Nassau, and the Sikkens Prize. He was recognized
label: Paragraph

text: by his peers with the Bond van Netherlandse Architecten and an honorary degree from
label: Paragraph

text: the Technische Hogeschool in Delft. Although Rietveld did ultimately receive
label: Paragraph

text: recognition for his contribution to modern architecture, no single other work was to have
label: Paragraph

text: the impact of his early designs: the Red-Blue Chair and the Schréder-Schrader House.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: father’s business, Utrecht 1899-1906; draftsman, C.J.Begeer’s Jewelry Studio, Utrecht
label: Caption

label: Caption

text: practice, Utrecht 1919-60; collaborated with Mrs. Truus Schréder-Schrider, Utrecht
label: Caption

label: Caption

label: Caption

text: RIO DE JANEIRO, BRAZIL
label: Title

text: The city of Rio de Janeiro was founded on the margins of Guanabara Bay in 1556 and
label: Paragraph

text: remained a small village until the 17th century, when it developed into an important
label: Paragraph

text: commercial port. In 1763, Rio became the capital of Brazil, and in 1808 it was named the
label: Paragraph

text: capital of the whole Portuguese Empire when the king and the nobility moved there,
label: Paragraph

text: fleeing Napoleon. The city remained the capital of the Brazilian Empire after
label: Paragraph

text: independence in 1822 and entered the 20th century as the capital of the Brazilian
label: Paragraph

text: Republic (proclaimed in 1889) until the federal government moved to Brasilia in 1960.
label: Paragraph

text: From 1930 to 1960, Rio was the core of Brazilian modernism while carioca (native of
label: Paragraph

text: Rio) architects reshaped the whole country. Fortunately, inspired by the fantastic natural
label: Paragraph

text: beauty of the city, this generation of modernist architects was able to give Rio some of
label: Paragraph

text: the finest buildings of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Brazilians entered the 20th century under strong influence of positivism and sanitary
label: Paragraph

text: engineering, and the city of Rio de Janeiro, being the capital of the republic and the
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual center of the country, was dominated by such ideas. The republic adopted
label: Paragraph

text: French eclecticism as the appropriate language to affirm its power and convey
label: Paragraph

text: technological advancement. The 1900s would be marked in Rio by the urban
label: Paragraph

text: reformations of Pereira Passos, with avenues being opened and slums being displaced
label: Paragraph

text: with civic buildings in French neoclassical style taking their place (Teatro Nacional,
label: Paragraph

text: 1906). A few years later, another plan by French urbanist Alfred Agache (1927) would be
label: Paragraph

text: the structure for Rio’s main transformations of the first half of the century. Still, in the
label: Paragraph

text: second decade of the century, Rio would experiment with issues of local identity and
label: Paragraph

text: their relationship to interna-tional images, with the arrival of Art Deco on one hand and
label: Paragraph

text: the development of neo-Colonial styles on the other. The Deco tradition left landmarks
label: Paragraph

text: such as the Cristo Redentor statue over Corcovado hill, and the neo-Colonial movement,
label: Paragraph

text: led by José Mariano Filho, would battle against the modernist avant-garde ideas
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the 1920s and 1930s. In 1929, the high points of this debate would be a series
label: Paragraph

text: of conferences by Le Corbusier when, visiting Rio for the first time, he produced the
label: Paragraph

text: famous sketches of an elevated highway along the shore.
label: Caption

text: In 1930, in what would be one of the key moments of Brazilian architecture, Lucio
label: Paragraph

text: Costa was named director of Rio’s ENBA (National School of Beaux-Arts). As soon as
label: Paragraph

text: he was named, Costa began a radical reformation of the art and architecture curriculum,
label: Paragraph

text: based on the Bauhaus pedagogy and Le Corbusier’s ideas. The strong reaction against
label: Paragraph

text: these proposed changes led to Costa’s substitution, but the ideas that he installed
label: Paragraph

text: flourished with a generation of students known later as the carioca school: Oscar
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer, Roberto Burle Marx, Affonso Raidy, Jorge Moreira, Milton Roberto, and Luis
label: Title

text: Nunes, among others.
label: Paragraph

text: Also in the 1930s, young architects such as the Roberto brothers (Milton and Marcelo)
label: Paragraph

text: built the ABI building (Brazilian Press Association headquarters, 1935) and the Santos
label: Paragraph

text: Dumont Airport (completed 1944). Atilio Correa Lima designed the Seaplane station
label: Caption

text: (1940), and Niemeyer designed a nursery (Obra do Bergo, 1937) and his own house
label: Paragraph

text: (1939) at Lagoa.
label: Caption

text: In 1936, Le Corbusier was invited as a supportive consultant for the team of architects
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned to design the new building for the Brazilian Ministry of Education and
label: Caption

text: Health (MES). The invitation of Le Corbusier served as a support for canceling the
label: Paragraph

text: previous competition, as the government considered the winning design incompatible
label: Paragraph

text: with the modern image that they were trying to establish. The MES building would
label: Paragraph

text: inspire a whole generation of young architects and artists with the murals by Candido
label: Paragraph

text: Portinari, sculptures by Bruno Giorgi, and gardens by Burle Marx around the architecture
label: Paragraph

text: developed by Lucio Costa, Carlos Lefo, Jorge Moreira, and Oscar Niemeyer, all a result
label: Paragraph

text: of Le Corbusier’s visit.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1940s, many important modernist buildings were developed and designed
label: Paragraph

text: by the carioca generation. The Roberto brothers were using precast concrete in industrial
label: Paragraph

text: projects, Niemeyer designed the Boavista Bank (1946), and Jorge Moreira was designing
label: Paragraph

text: the University Campus at Ilha do Fundio (1949). Meanwhile, Afonso Reidy completed
label: Paragraph

text: the Pedregulho residential complex (1947), a curvilinear apartment building that reflected
label: Paragraph

text: the terrain’s contours.
label: Paragraph

text: The architecture of the 1950s is still considered a high point in Brazilian modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: For example, Affonso Raidy’s Museum of Modern Art (1952) is an exposed-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: structure disposed horizontally at the Flamengo seashore in order not to disturb the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape. Burle Marx was responsible for the gardens that surround the museum and the
label: Paragraph

text: whole Flamengo park shore. The 1950s would also witness fascinating buildings by
label: Paragraph

text: Sergio Bernardes (House for Lota M.Soares and Elizabeth Bishop, 1952), Henrique
label: Caption

text: Mindlin (Avenida Central building, 1957), and Francisco Bolonha (Joseph Bloch school,
label: Paragraph

text: 1960). In a time of accelerating industrialization and urbanization, housing lies at the core
label: Paragraph

text: of the 1950s debate and practice, led by Carmen Portinho at the municipal office. One of
label: Paragraph

text: the best apartment buildings of this time is the Parque Guinle complex (Bristol and
label: Paragraph

text: Caledénia buildings, 1950) by Lucio Costa.
label: Caption

text: After the 1950s boom, Rio de Janeiro would suffer with the transfer of the federal
label: Paragraph

text: government to Brasilia in 1960. A general loss of investments and decreasing
label: Paragraph

text: construction activities led not only to fewer buildings but also to problematic changes in
label: Paragraph

text: the municipal codes that would allow faster construction to bring profits. The quality of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1950s was lost, and after the military coup in 1964, few interesting buildings or
label: Paragraph

text: projects appeared in Rio.
label: Paragraph

text: The military regime exiled architects such as Niemeyer and repressed schools of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that were a focus of cultural and political discussion on the 1960s. The 1970s
label: Paragraph

text: experienced accelerating wealth disparity, with architecture losing its social commitment
label: Paragraph

text: in favor of apartment buildings, hotels, and financial institutions for the wealthy classes.
label: Paragraph

text: The Petrobras building (state oil company, 1968) by Gandelfi and Assad and the
label: Caption

text: CocaCola headquarters (1972) by Edison and Edmundo Musa represent the paradigm of
label: Paragraph

text: those times. Costly apartment buildings with security devices dominated the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: scene at Barra da Tijuca, Lagoa, and Ipanema. The major public buildings of the military
label: Paragraph

text: period in Rio include the State University Complex (1968) by Luis Paulo Conde and the
label: Paragraph

text: Copacabana sidewalks (1970) by Roberto Burle Marx.
label: Caption

text: With the redemocratization of the 1980s, a series of public buildings by Oscar
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer was built in Rio. The CIEPSs, a full-time school program built in modulate
label: Paragraph

text: precast concrete, were scattered around the peripheral areas of the city, serving the needy
label: Paragraph

text: communities. In downtown Rio, the Sambdédromo, a half-mile-long open walkway for the
label: Paragraph

text: samba schools’ carnival parades, ends in a elegant plaza dominated by a sculpture
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Niemeyer. Across the bay in Niterdi, the Museum of Contemporary Art
label: Caption

text: (1996) was also designed by the 90-year-old Niemeyer.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1990s, an extensive project of urban design, public facilities, and renovation was
label: Paragraph

text: put forward by architect Luis Paulo Conde, first as municipal secretary of urbanism
label: Paragraph

text: (1992-96) and then as mayor (1996-2000). Rio Cidade (downtown urban design
label: Paragraph

text: renovations) and Favela-bairro (improvements and infrastructure at the shanty hills) are
label: Paragraph

text: among the successful cases of good architecture serving the public at the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: century, reshaping and improving the already astonishing landscape of Rio de Janeiro.
label: Paragraph

text: RIYADH, SAUDI ARABIA
label: Title

text: The city of Riyadh (plural of rawdhah, oasis) was founded on the ruins of several
label: Paragraph

text: communities around 1740. Although it was chosen as the capital of the second Saudi
label: Paragraph

text: state in 1824, it came to prominence only after its independent governor, Abdulaziz Al-
label: Paragraph

text: Saud, began a campaign to consolidate modern Saudi Arabia in 1902. The speed and
label: Paragraph

text: scale of Riyadh’s transformation since, particularly during the 1970s, has had few
label: Paragraph

text: parallels. From a walled city of less than 1 square kilometer in 1920, it has grown into a
label: Paragraph

text: sprawling modern capital of 1,500 square kilometers. Its population has increased from
label: Paragraph

text: an estimated 14,000 in 1902, to 666,480 in 1974, to more than 2.8 million in 1992, to an
label: Paragraph

text: estimated 3.5 million by 1998.
label: Paragraph

text: The physical transformation of Riyadh began in the mid1930s with King Abdulaziz’s
label: Paragraph

text: decision to build a large palace and administrative complex two kilometers north of the
label: Paragraph

text: existing city. Known as al-Murabba’, it covered an area of 16 hectares and was linked to
label: Paragraph

text: the town by a paved stone road. The complex was complemented in the late 1940s by a
label: Paragraph

text: new residential quarter, al-Futah, to the west of the road, where palatial mansions were
label: Paragraph

text: built for the king’s younger sons. Abdulaziz’s building program had several lasting
label: Paragraph

text: impacts on the form of the city: it stretched its size, it set a northerly direction for its
label: Paragraph

text: future growth, it showed that the old walls could no longer be considered a barrier to
label: Paragraph

text: growth, and it introduced a new means of transportation—the private motor vehicle.
label: Paragraph

text: Architecturally, the buildings of al-Murabba’ relied on traditional processes, techniques,
label: Paragraph

text: and materials adapted by local craftsmen to a new scale and new requirements. The result
label: Paragraph

text: was a magnificent Najdi style.
label: Paragraph

text: Transformation of the city continued after World War I] with construction of an airport
label: Paragraph

text: and a railway. Railroad tracks were laid between Riyadh and the Persian Gulf city of
label: Paragraph

text: Dammam, with a station built 4 kilometers east of the old city in 1951. In 1952, a
label: Paragraph

text: terminal building and mosque were constructed 7 kilometers north of the city at a landing
label: Paragraph

text: strip that had been in use since 1946. In 1951, Crown Prince Saud also built a palace at
label: Paragraph

text: the garden plot of Nasiriyyah northwest of the city. These three projects necessitated the
label: Paragraph

text: city’s first major road-building program. Nasiriyyah was linked to Murabba’ Palace and
label: Paragraph

text: the town, with a branch leading to the railway station. Another road was built connecting
label: Paragraph

text: the airport to the city center. The early 1950s also brought the end of the old city as an
label: Paragraph

text: intact physical entity. Its walls were removed, the old governor’s palace and main
label: Paragraph

text: mosque were rebuilt, and streets were widened to provide access for motor vehicles.
label: Paragraph

text: After succeeding to the throne in 1953, King Saud made three decisions directly
label: Paragraph

text: bearing on the future of Riyadh. He transferred all government agencies from Mecca and
label: Paragraph

text: began a program of building new ministries to the west of the airport road; he ordered
label: Paragraph

text: construction of al-Malaz, a new suburb 4 kilometers northeast of the city, to house
label: Paragraph

text: transferred government employees; and he expanded and rebuilt his palace at Nasiriyyah.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1957, seven ministry buildings, designed by the Egyptian architect Sayid Krayim,
label: Paragraph

text: were complete. Nasiriyyah had been expanded to cover 250 hectares, employing a grid
label: Paragraph

text: pattern of boulevards, gardens, and modern structures, and al-Malaz was well on the way
label: Paragraph

text: toward a goal of providing 750 villas, 180 apartment units, buildings for a new
label: Paragraph

text: university, and support facilities. These projects brought new conceptions of space, street
label: Paragraph

text: patterns, building types, and materials to the city, and together they came to be known as
label: Paragraph

text: New Riyadh (although al-Malaz, in particular, acquired this name). Al-Malaz would have
label: Paragraph

text: a particularly important impact because it introduced the grid as a street pattern and the
label: Paragraph

text: villa as a house type, forms that would become pervasive in the future development not
label: Paragraph

text: only of Riyadh but also of every city and town in Saudi Arabia.
label: Paragraph

text: As Riyadh continued growing through the 1950s and into the early 1960s, other
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods were built, and apartment buildings appeared along al-Thumairi, al-Wazir,
label: Paragraph

text: and al-Khazan Streets. Distinct among these were the Fahd bin Moh’d building (late
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s), the Moh’d bin Saud building (1959), the al-Riyadh building (1960), and the
label: Paragraph

text: Zahrat al-Riyadh building (1968). Two larger noteworthy projects were also initiated in
label: Paragraph

text: the late 1960s. These were the Riyadh Intercontinental Hotel and Conference Center
label: Paragraph

text: (1971) by Trevord Dannat, which avoided the faceless style typical of the time by
label: Paragraph

text: adopting indigenous architectural elements, and the King Faisal Specialist Hospital
label: Paragraph

text: (1974), designed by Hospital Design Partnership.
label: Paragraph

text: A new phase of Riyadh’s urban growth arrived in the late 1960s, when the Saudi
label: Paragraph

text: government contracted with Doxiadis Associates of Athens to prepare a master plan for
label: Paragraph

text: the capital city. The plan, approved in 1973, called for a supergrid of boulevards 2
label: Paragraph

text: kilometers apart, a major commercial and civic spine extending north to south with an
label: Paragraph

text: administrative area perpendicular to it, and residential districts extending on both sides of
label: Paragraph

text: the spine. Among other important effects, the plan confirmed the role of the private
label: Paragraph

text: automobile as the primary mode of transportation in the city. To implement the plan, the
label: Paragraph

text: government created a technical committee chaired by the Riyadh governor that would
label: Paragraph

text: later form the nucleus for the Arriyadh Development Authority (ADA). Since its
label: Paragraph

text: inception in 1974, this government authority has guided Riyadh’s development and
label: Paragraph

text: carried out large-scale building and renovation projects in the city center, the alMurabba’
label: Paragraph

text: district, and elsewhere in the metropolitan area.
label: Paragraph

text: Great changes arrived in Riyadh following the oil boom of the early 1970s, leading
label: Paragraph

text: some critics to describe the city as the biggest construction site in human history. In terms
label: Paragraph

text: of design excellence, three major projects stand out from the late 1970s: the General
label: Paragraph

text: Organization for Social Insurance (GOSI} Headquarters (1978), the Saudi Arabian
label: Paragraph

text: Monetary Agency Towers (1978), and the Saudi Fund for Development (SFD)
label: Paragraph

text: Headquarters (1980). The GOSI Headquarters, designed by Nabil Fanous and Basim Al-
label: Paragraph

text: Shihabi, is a graceful modern composition of interlocking Cubistic volumes reminiscent
label: Paragraph

text: of the Boston City Hall. Its 1987 extension, also by Al-Shihabi (Omrania: Architects,
label: Paragraph

text: Planners and Engineers), today provides a stark contrast to the original design by using
label: Paragraph

text: reflective glass on a six-story triangular block to mirror the older building. In his design
label: Paragraph

text: for the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency, Minoru Yamasaki employed two massive ten-
label: Paragraph

text: story towers, identical in structure and facade. In the SFD Headquarters, Urban Coile
label: Caption

text: International took a different
label: Title

text: King Abdulaziz Historic Center (1998), Beeah Group Consultants and Rasem
label: Paragraph

text: Badran
label: Title

text: © Saleh Al-Hathloul
label: Title

text: approach, attempting to create a modern office building with local roots. Its use of old
label: Paragraph

text: Diriyyah buildings as a point of reference for exterior expression and its interior
label: Paragraph

text: alrangements around a covered courtyard have since been emulated by a number of other
label: Paragraph

text: projects.
label: Paragraph

text: Distinctive projects in the 1980s included al-Khairia Center (1982) by Kenzo Tange,
label: Paragraph

text: the Institute of Public Administration (1982) by The Architects Collaborative and M. al-
label: Paragraph

text: Sabiq, and the King Khalid International Airport Terminal Complex (1983) by HOK.
label: Paragraph

text: Today, the twin, triangular 14-story office towers of al-Khairia Center provide a
label: Paragraph

text: landmark for the northern areas of the city. By choosing a cylindrical shape for the dome
label: Paragraph

text: of the center’s mosque and an elegant square column for its minaret, Tange also
label: Paragraph

text: introduced new forms into mosque architecture. The structure of the King Khalid
label: Paragraph

text: Terminal, located 35 kilometers north of the city, consists of four equilateral triangles
label: Paragraph

text: arranged in a linear form, providing the shortest possible walking distance from curbside
label: Paragraph

text: or parking to departure and arrival gates. The triangular forms also provide an ample area
label: Paragraph

text: for security controls while allowing open space to penetrate through to the arrival floor.
label: Paragraph

text: Another important 1980s addition to Riyadh was King Saud University (1984),
label: Paragraph

text: designed and engineered by HOK+4 consortium. The master plan for this 20,000-student
label: Paragraph

text: campus by United Planner Schwanzer GMBH Vienna called for individual buildings to
label: Paragraph

text: be compactly clustered and interconnected by a system of “spines” serving both as
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrian “streets” on the main level and as service ways at ground level. Courtyards
label: Paragraph

text: were used on the upper level for climate control, and windows and other openings were
label: Paragraph

text: kept small to minimize the intrusion of harsh sunlight.
label: Paragraph

text: Since the mid-1980s, local architects have assumed an increasingly important role in
label: Paragraph

text: the design of the city, and individual buildings have attempted to become more sensitive
label: Paragraph

text: to local tradition. These trends are especially evident in the work of two local design
label: Paragraph

text: teams: Basim Al-Shihabi of Omrania, whose most impressive projects have been Tuwaiq
label: Paragraph

text: Palace (1985), the General Organization for Social Insurance (GOSI) Headquarters
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1978, 1987), and the Gulf Cooperation Council Headquarters (1987); and Ali
label: Paragraph

text: Shuaibi and Abdulrahman Al-Hussaini (of Beeah Group Consultants), particularly their
label: Paragraph

text: designs for al-Kindi Plaza (1986). International architects have also become more
label: Paragraph

text: responsive to local conditions. One excellent example is King Fahad International
label: Paragraph

text: Stadium (1987) by Ain Friezer and Partners, a masterpiece of tent architecture. Another
label: Paragraph

text: is Imam Moh’d Bin Saud Islamic University (1988). The master plan and design for this
label: Paragraph

text: 15,000-student campus was produced by Techni Beria using a compact organic plan and
label: Paragraph

text: a system of courtyards repeated throughout the academic buildings to provide human
label: Paragraph

text: scale and shorten walking distances.
label: Paragraph

text: Especially noteworthy designs in the 1990s have included the Ministry of Interior
label: Paragraph

text: (1992) by Mousalli, Shaker, Mandily and Archi-System, whose inverted pyramid form
label: Paragraph

text: produced an instant landmark; the Ministry of Municipal and Rural Affairs (1995) by
label: Paragraph

text: Zuhair Fayez, which takes the form of an oasis in the middle of the city; the Al-Jazirah
label: Paragraph

text: Newspaper Headquarters (1995) by Suter and Suter and al-Shathri; and the King Fahad
label: Paragraph

text: Cultural Center (1991) by Widle Plan.
label: Caption

text: Since 1974, the ADA has also undertaken a number of large-scale building and
label: Paragraph

text: renovation projects. One of the most important has been development of the Diplomatic
label: Paragraph

text: Quarter (DQ). A 586-hectare site was allocated for this project 8 kilometers northwest of
label: Paragraph

text: the city center after the Saudi government decided to transfer foreign diplomatic missions
label: Paragraph

text: from Jeddah to Riyadh in 1975.
label: Paragraph

text: The master plan for the DQ was by Speerplan, Regional Und Stadtplaner GMBH; its
label: Paragraph

text: central area urban design was by Beeah of Riyadh, and the layout of its residential
label: Paragraph

text: districts was by Farahat Tashkandi. The DQ may one day hold as many as 120 embassies
label: Paragraph

text: and 30,000 inhabitants. Today, more than 51 embassies and more than 40 other public or
label: Paragraph

text: service-sector projects have been completed. Many of the embassies have been designed
label: Paragraph

text: by well-known architects from their respective countries, including the Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: Embassy (1985) by Kenzo Tange; the Canadian Embassy (1985) by Sanky Partnership;
label: Paragraph

text: the Tunisian Embassy (1987) by Mimita, Bin Mahmoud and Faraj; and the French
label: Paragraph

text: Embassy (1988) by Guy Naizot. Three other DQ projects have won international awards:
label: Paragraph

text: Al-Kindi Plaza (1986) by Beeah; DQ Landscaping (1986) by Bédeker, Boyer, Wagenfeld
label: Caption

text: and Partners; and Tuwaigq Palace (1985) by Atelie Otto, Biiro Happold, and Omrania.
label: Paragraph

text: Four other ADA initiatives have been extremely important to the overall design of the
label: Paragraph

text: city. One was the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (1984) by Henning Larsen and its attendant
label: Paragraph

text: Staff Housing (1983) by Speerplan Regional Und Stadtplaner GMBH and CRS (with the
label: Paragraph

text: involvement of Ali Shuaibi as ADA adviser). This successful housing project, employing
label: Paragraph

text: dwelling clusters around cul-de-sacs with exterior access and an auto-free recreational
label: Paragraph

text: spine, has now been emulated in the al-Hamra neighborhood (1994) of Riyadh, in
label: Paragraph

text: Medina, and elsewhere in Saudi Arabia.
label: Paragraph

text: Also important has been ADA’s rebuilding of Qasr al-Hukm, the Justice Palace
label: Paragraph

text: District, including the entire old walled city and an additional area to its west. The first
label: Paragraph

text: redevelopment plan here was by Franco Albini (1978); the second was by Beeah (1983),
label: Paragraph

text: subsequently revised by ADA staff. Individual building projects have included the
label: Paragraph

text: Governorate, Municipality, and Police Department buildings (1985) by Albini; the Great
label: Caption

text: Mosque and Redevelopment of the Old City Center (1992) by Rasem Badran; the al-
label: Paragraph

text: Migliyah Commercial Center (1992); the al-Ta’meer Center-1 (2000) by Dar Al-Mimar
label: Caption

text: (Abdulhalim and Badran) with Arrow, Inc., and Site International; and the Riyadh Court
label: Paragraph

text: Complex (2000) by M.Makkiyah and Saud Consult.
label: Caption

text: Finally, ADA has recently been involved in the redevelopment of al-Murabba’, known
label: Paragraph

text: as the King Abdulaziz Historic Center (1998). The urban design for this project was by
label: Paragraph

text: Beeah and Rasem Badran, and it has subsequently involved the renovation or new
label: Paragraph

text: construction of a series of buildings designed by several architects. This project
label: Paragraph

text: represents a return to the city’s roots. Located on the old Murabba’ site, its completion
label: Paragraph

text: marks the centennial of the beginning of the process that led to Saudi Arabia’s
label: Paragraph

text: unification. Its high-quality urban spaces, magnificent architecture, and well-thought-out
label: Paragraph

text: linkages of traditional and modern forms create a complementary focal point to Qasr Al-
label: Paragraph

text: Hukm in the center of the city.
label: Paragraph
