text: ROADSIDE ARCHITECTURE
label: Title

text: Roadside architecture, the bastard offspring of the automobile, had a pervasive effect on
label: Paragraph

text: the American landscape during the 20th century. Often denounced for crassness and
label: Paragraph

text: monotony yet irresistibly convenient to a population getting around on four wheels,
label: Paragraph

text: roadside architecture was both the bane of the aesthetically sensitive and a boon to
label: Paragraph

text: motorists looking for food, fuel, and lodging.
label: Paragraph

text: When the century opened, the automobile had been in existence just seven years, and
label: Paragraph

text: only 8000 sputtering, self-propelled vehicles plied the streets and roads. The promise of
label: Paragraph

text: freedom of movement proved so compelling, however, that the number of registered
label: Paragraph

text: automobiles reached 458,000 by 1910, surpassed eight million by 1920, and exceeded 23
label: Paragraph

text: million by 1930. New automobile-oriented building types, such as filling stations, motels,
label: Paragraph

text: and drive-in movie theaters, arose. Older building types, such as restaurants, banks, and
label: Paragraph

text: grocery stores, gradually changed form.
label: Paragraph

text: A mere seven per cent of the nation’s roads were hard surfaced by 1904, but many
label: Paragraph

text: organizations, such as the Lincoln Highway Association, were formed in the 1910s and
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s to lobby localities, state governments, and federal authorities to construct reliable,
label: Paragraph

text: all-weather roads. Filling stations dispensing motor oil and gasoline were among the first
label: Paragraph

text: automobile-oriented facilities to crop up as the roads improved. In urban districts, it was
label: Paragraph

text: not uncommon for a two-story or taller building containing stores, offices, and
label: Paragraph

text: apartments to be razed so that its site could be occupied by a diminutive gas station,
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by pavement, Chester Liebs observes in Main Street to Miracle Mile. The
label: Paragraph

text: traditional urban practice of placing buildings shoulder to shoulder, right up to the
label: Paragraph

text: sidewalk, gave way to a looser, more discontinuous pattern, with each building standing
label: Paragraph

text: alone, farther back from the street.
label: Paragraph

text: Because gas stations soon invaded settled residential districts and desirable business
label: Paragraph

text: areas, petroleum companies felt pressure in the 1910s and 1920s to design stations whose
label: Paragraph

text: appearance would be seen as an asset rather than an eyesore. In Indianapolis in 1927, for
label: Paragraph

text: instance, the Ohio-based Pure Oil chain introduced an English cottage-style station that
label: Paragraph

text: skillfully drew from the romantic house designs popular at the time. Scholars such as
label: Paragraph

text: Liebs have viewed the styles employed by roadside businesses as “sales costumes,”
label: Paragraph

text: donned with salesmanship and appeasement of popular taste in mind. John A.Jakle and
label: Caption

text: Keith A.Sculle, two leading scholars of roadside architecture, have attributed much of the
label: Paragraph

text: character of roadside architecture to the concept of “place-product-packaging,” in which
label: Paragraph

text: all the physical aspects of an enterprise, including signs, logos, uniforms, architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: lighting, and landscaping, are part of a carefully coordinated effort to establish a strong
label: Paragraph

text: corporate identity. The consistent identity links all the units in a chain and reassures the
label: Paragraph

text: customers, thereby helping the chain outsell local competitors.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the best roadside architecture sprang not only from hardheaded marketing
label: Paragraph

text: calculations but also from imaginative and occasionally even idealistic impulses. Pure Oil
label: Paragraph

text: adopted the English cottage-style station not only because it would ease the station’s
label: Paragraph

text: acceptance but also because the station’s architect, Carl A.Petersen, regarded the design,
label: Paragraph

text: with its “Romantic Suburb” connotations, as the most beautiful and appropriate choice, a
label: Paragraph

text: judgment heartily shared by the company’s president, Henry M. Dawes. Similarly, when
label: Paragraph

text: Howard Johnson was establishing his Massachusetts-based restaurant chain in the latter
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s and early 1940s, his chief architect, Joseph G.Morgan, produced balanced,
label: Paragraph

text: dignified compositions that far surpassed the public’s usual expectations for eating along
label: Paragraph

text: the road. Morgan adapted the traditional architecture of New England churches and town
label: Paragraph

text: halls to the visibility requirements of highway commerce—covering the roofs of Howard
label: Caption

text: Johnson’s outlets with conspicuous shiny orange tiles, just as Petersen had clad Pure
label: Paragraph

text: Oil’s roofs with fade-resistant blue tiles—but he gave the buildings pleasingly set-back
label: Paragraph

text: wings, a carefully detailed row of dormers, a deftly proportioned rooftop lantern, and
label: Paragraph

text: other touches that bespoke a concern for quality.
label: Paragraph

text: Diners, which evolved from lunch wagons that first appeared in Providence, Rhode
label: Paragraph

text: Island, in 1872, were popular-priced restaurants that for many years resembled streetcars
label: Paragraph

text: or railroad dining cars. By the end of the 1910s, a number of manufacturers were making
label: Paragraph

text: diners in factories and shipping them to their sites, first in urban locations, later along
label: Paragraph

text: outlying highways. Over the years, they increasingly adopted a machine aesthetic, refined
label: Paragraph

text: through the extensive use of stainless steel. By 1940, the streamlined diner, a striking
label: Paragraph

text: product of American industrial design, had made its debut.
label: Paragraph

text: In the West, the California coffee shops of the 1940s and 1950s by Los Angeles
label: Paragraph

text: designers such as John Lautner, Douglas Honnold, and Martin Stern wowed motorists
label: Paragraph

text: with an energetic modernism characterized by large sculpted roofs, expansive walls of
label: Paragraph

text: glass, and dramatic lighting effects. Some critics dismissed the coffee shops as
label: Paragraph

text: excessively flamboyant, labeling them “googie,” a put-down inspired by the Googie’s
label: Paragraph

text: restaurant that Lautner designed in West Hollywood (built in 1949). However,
label: Paragraph

text: architectural historian Alan Hess has argued that the expressive modernism of southern
label: Paragraph

text: California chains such as Biff’s, Ship’s, Norm’s, and Tiny Naylor’s—an approach spread
label: Paragraph

text: nationwide in the 1950s and 1960s through designs by the Los Angeles firm of Armet
label: Paragraph

text: and Davis for chains such as Denny’s and Bob’s Big Boy—represented an important
label: Paragraph

text: instance of modernism becoming broadly popular, a kind of modernism for the common
label: Paragraph

text: man. Because some designers of “googie,” such as Lautner, produced houses and other
label: Paragraph

text: buildings that commanded respect within the profession, Hess argued that no clear-cut
label: Paragraph

text: boundary existed between serious architecture and many buildings that served everyday
label: Paragraph

text: commercial purposes.
label: Paragraph

text: There had, of course, been a streak of amateurism and in some cases humorous
label: Paragraph

text: iteralism in some roadside buildings from the beginning of the century through the
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s. In 1931, along Route 25 in Riverhead, New York, poultry grower Martin Maurer
label: Caption

text: built “The Big Duck,” a 20-foot-high, 30-foot-long structure of wood, galvanized wire,
label: Paragraph

text: and cement, shaped to look like the Long Island Peking ducks that he sold inside it. Its
label: Paragraph

text: eyes were taillights from a Model T Ford. Giant fish, hot dogs, teapots, chili bowls, root
label: Paragraph

text: beer barrels, and other objects were common in the 1920s and 1930s. This was especially
label: Paragraph

text: so in the Los Angeles area, where a Brown Derby restaurant was built in the shape of a
label: Paragraph

text: hat in 1926, ice cream was dispensed from The Igloo beginning in 1928, the Zep Diner
label: Paragraph

text: was built in the shape of a Zeppelin in 1930, and many other giant objects were created.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most noted chains in that vein was Wigwam Villages, which began in Horse
label: Paragraph

text: Cave, Kentucky, in 1933 and eventually grew to seven locations scattered from Orlando,
label: Paragraph

text: Florida, to San Bernardino, California. Wigwam Villages featured lunchrooms and
label: Paragraph

text: overnight lodging in buildings shaped like tepees.
label: Paragraph

text: A variety of new building types appeared as the car became central to American life. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1933 in Camden, New Jersey, Richard M.Hollingshead, Jr., built the first drive-in theater,
label: Paragraph

text: allowing people to watch movies while sitting in their cars. About 50 drive-in theaters
label: Paragraph

text: were in operation throughout the country by the outbreak of World War II. After the war,
label: Paragraph

text: their numbers grew rapidly, to more than 1700 by 1950, according to Liebs. The tall,
label: Paragraph

text: wide tower supporting the drive-in’s screen became a roadside landmark, sometimes
label: Paragraph

text: interestingly stylized. The popularity of outdoor theaters peaked in 1958, after which
label: Paragraph

text: came a long decline.
label: Paragraph

text: Drive-in restaurants started to appear in the early 1920s, beginning with the first Pig
label: Paragraph

text: Stand drive-in, on the Dallas-Fort
label: Caption

text: “The Big Duck” (1931); originally on Route 25, Riverhead, Long Island, NY;
label: Caption

text: moved in 1936 to Flanders, NY
label: Paragraph

text: © Philip Langdon
label: Title

text: Worth Highway in Texas in 1921. Tray boys and tray girls, later known as carhops,
label: Paragraph

text: brought food and beverages to customers, who ate in their cars. At many drive-ins, a
label: Paragraph

text: canopy extended above the cars, supplying midday shade. For visual interest, the canopy
label: Paragraph

text: could take a variety of shapes, from undulating to angular. Some drive-ins, especially in
label: Paragraph

text: California, gained visual excitement by having a circular or octagonal central building
label: Paragraph

text: from which a tall illuminated pylon rose. At round or octagonal drive-ins, the cars
label: Paragraph

text: clustered, nose in, all the way around the building. Drive-ins flourished nationwide in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s and began declining in the 1960s because of community reaction against their
label: Paragraph

text: noise, trash, and rowdiness and because of growing competition from other kinds of
label: Paragraph

text: restaurants, especially coffee shops, which were comfortable no matter what the weather,
label: Paragraph

text: and fast-food establishments, whose self-service method got the food to the customers
label: Paragraph

text: cheaply and more quickly.
label: Paragraph

text: By the 1920s, the demand for overnight lodging along the roads gave birth to the
label: Paragraph

text: motel, which typically took the form of a continuous one-story structure with the rooms
label: Paragraph

text: opening directly to the parking area, thereby eliminating the formal spaces and corridors
label: Paragraph

text: associated with hotels. “Motel” was a contraction of “motor” and “hotel” and has been
label: Paragraph

text: traced as far back as 1926, when Arthur Heineman opened the Milestone Mo-tel in San
label: Paragraph

text: Luis Obispo, California. The generally modest buildings sometimes formed an “L” or a
label: Paragraph

text: “C” around a central lawn or a swimming pool.
label: Paragraph

text: Roadside commercial buildings usually borrowed structural and stylistic ideas from
label: Paragraph

text: other types of buildings; they were popularizers rather than pioneers. However, they were
label: Paragraph

text: quick to adopt modern materials. The Wichita, Kansas-based White Castle System of
label: Paragraph

text: Eating Houses in 1928 commissioned the first use of porcelain-enameled steel panels for
label: Paragraph

text: the cladding of an entire building. The interchangeable steel panels were secured with a
label: Paragraph

text: locking device that eliminated the use of rivets or bolts, thus making it easier to take the
label: Paragraph

text: structure apart and move it. Superb for projecting an image of cleanliness, white
label: Paragraph

text: porcelain-enameled panels became standard not only for the White Castle hamburger
label: Paragraph

text: restaurants but for many companies’ gas stations in the 1940s and 1950s. The most
label: Paragraph

text: famous gas station design using white panels on a crisp, boxlike building was Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Dorwin Teague’s prototype for Texaco, introduced in the mid-1930s. The design
label: Paragraph

text: integrated an office, rest rooms, and service bays into a sleek, flat-roofed structure clad in
label: Paragraph

text: white panels that could be hosed down to restore their sparkle.
label: Paragraph

text: As retailers built new stores along suburban roads, they frequently used a facade with
label: Paragraph

text: glass from floor to ceiling to put the interior on display, give a glimpse of their
label: Paragraph

text: merchandise, and show that they were open. Although many retailers occupied stand-
label: Paragraph

text: alone buildings, there was demand for collections of stores that could conveniently serve
label: Paragraph

text: customers arriving by car. From this developed the shopping center, a linked series of
label: Paragraph

text: storefronts that usually faced a parking area shared by all the center’s stores. Shopping
label: Paragraph

text: centers, bringing architectural unity to a row of stores set back from the street, have been
label: Paragraph

text: traced by Liebs all the way back to a development in Baltimore in 1907, when the
label: Paragraph

text: customers came in carriages. Shopping centers proliferated in the 1920s and 1930s,
label: Paragraph

text: serving people arriving by car. By the 1950s, these small centers were ubiquitous, and the
label: Paragraph

text: next stage in the evolution of roadside retailing was at hand: the enclosed, inward-
label: Paragraph

text: focused, climate-controlled shopping mall. The first complete example was the Southdale
label: Paragraph

text: mall, designed by Victor Gruen and Associates and built in Minneapolis in 1956.
label: Paragraph

text: Commercial development of the American roadside periodically resulted in eruptions
label: Paragraph

text: of hostility from a public fed up with billboards, bright lights, primary colors, and
label: Paragraph

text: clashing architectural forms. Peter Blake’s 1964 jeremiad God’s Own Junkyard, which
label: Paragraph

text: declared most highways to be “hideous scars on the face of this nation” (109), voiced
label: Paragraph

text: repulsion at the crassness and ugliness that afflicted much of the roadside environment.
label: Paragraph

text: Lady Bird Johnson led a campaign for roadside beautification in the mid-1960s, and
label: Paragraph

text: municipalities increasingly used design control regulations to tranquilize roadside
label: Paragraph

text: architecture—discouraging unusual forms, forbidding flashing lights and revolving signs,
label: Paragraph

text: requiring landscaping, and generally insisting on a softer, more subdued look. Such
label: Paragraph

text: regulation was rarely welcomed by avantgarde architects such as Robert Venturi, Denise
label: Paragraph

text: Scott Brown, and Steven Izenour, whose 1972 book Learning from Las Vegas valiantly
label: Paragraph

text: searched for virtue among the dross. The Big Duck, cited in God’s Own Junkyard as an
label: Paragraph

text: example of what is bad about roadside architecture, was celebrated by the Venturi group.
label: Paragraph

text: However, by the 1970s the “vitality” of Las Vegas, where casinos were willing to invest
label: Paragraph

text: in enormous outdoor displays, had little in common with most stretches of American
label: Paragraph

text: road, which were dominated by aesthetic dullards such as McDonald’s and Wendy’s. The
label: Paragraph

text: golden arches, which burst through the roof of the McDonald’s prototype that Stanley
label: Paragraph

text: C.Meston created for Richard McDonald in 1952, had been reduced to a sign and logo in
label: Paragraph

text: front of a pseudo-mansard-roofed building that lacked the pleasurable detail and
label: Paragraph

text: proportions exhibited by the prewar Howard Johnson’s and also lacked the exuberance
label: Paragraph

text: and spontaneity of the “googie” 1950s Big Boy.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1977, the Society for Commercial Archeology (SCA) was founded to document and
label: Paragraph

text: preserve worthy examples of 20th-century commercial design, especially the nation’s
label: Paragraph

text: rapidly disappearing roadside sights. In the years since, pleas from organizations such as
label: Paragraph

text: the SCA have averted the demolition of a number of buildings, including the oldest
label: Paragraph

text: surviving McDonald’s, which had been serving hamburgers and shakes beneath pulsating
label: Paragraph

text: neon in Downey, California, since 1953. Roadside architecture in the final three decades
label: Paragraph

text: of the century became soullessly formulaic. Motorists who hoped for something quirky
label: Paragraph

text: and full of character looked to “blue highways” (minor roads, often colored blue on road
label: Paragraph

text: maps) or sought out old thoroughfares, such as the National Road. There, remnants of
label: Paragraph

text: history remained, testifying to the imagination of the automobile age.
label: Paragraph

text: ROADWAY SYSTEMS
label: Title

text: Although the road preceded the automobile, it was the invention of the motorcar that
label: Paragraph

text: transformed meandering muddy paths into functional roadways. The first 20 years of the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century marked a transportation revolution that began with the automobile and that
label: Paragraph

text: brought about a new national system of roadways. In 1905, only one in every 1078
label: Paragraph

text: Americans owned an automobile; by 1920, one in every 13 Americans had become proud
label: Paragraph

text: owners of the century’s most remarkable invention.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the automobile was a French invention dating to as early as the 1860s
label: Paragraph

text: (witness such French words as garage, chassis, chauffeur, and of course, automobile), the
label: Paragraph

text: North American adaptation of the motorcar in the early 20th century was distinctly non-
label: Paragraph

text: European. Instead of expensive motorcars designed for the wealthy, American auto
label: Paragraph

text: designers concentrated on affordable, mass-produced vehicles, such as Ransom E.Olds’
label: Paragraph

text: 1900 horseless buggy. By 1910, more than two dozen companies were producing
label: Paragraph

text: unpretentious low-cost vehicles, including Henry Ford’s 1908 Model T. Their
label: Paragraph

text: affordability countered the warning that Woodrow Wilson had made in 1906 when he
label: Paragraph

text: cautioned that the popularity of the motorcar would lead to socialism by stirring
label: Paragraph

text: dangerous envy of the rich.
label: Paragraph

text: As a practical vehicle for the average American, the automobile needed to be more
label: Paragraph

text: than a curiosity for display. Its utility depended on reliable roadways. As the proud
label: Paragraph

text: motorist ventured into the realm of travel, limited by a top speed of four miles per hour
label: Paragraph

text: and requirements that he be preceded by a man with a red flag so as not to scare the
label: Paragraph

text: horses, the need for improved roadways became strikingly apparent.
label: Paragraph

text: The first public organizations to get involved in road improvements were
label: Paragraph

text: municipalities, many of which had grown weary of the problems of the automobile’s
label: Paragraph

text: predecessor: the horse. Horses cost cities large amounts of money to remove manure and
label: Paragraph

text: haul away abandoned carcasses. Many municipalities welcomed the automobile as a
label: Paragraph

text: cleaner, more trouble free alternative. Thus, the first decades of the 20th century marked
label: Paragraph

text: a change in many cities from cobblestones to more even road surfaces, built at public
label: Paragraph

text: expense. The cobblestones had kept horses from slipping since the Middle Ages, but for
label: Paragraph

text: the automobile, new smooth and quiet road surfaces, such as macadam (a form of crushed
label: Paragraph

text: stone}, were required. As traffic increased, tougher surfaces were applied, such as asphalt
label: Paragraph

text: and eventually concrete—all initiated before the 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: By the middle of the 1920s, smooth road surfaces had significantly enhanced the utility
label: Paragraph

text: of the automobile, speeding its way into the future at faster and faster speeds. Road
label: Paragraph

text: building became a major function of local governments, which were prodded by a
label: Paragraph

text: collection of pressure groups that included automobile manufacturing, oil companies, and
label: Paragraph

text: tire manufacturers who lobbied intensely for new roadways. Others were also quick to
label: Paragraph

text: see the economic dividends attached to highway building, such as real estate speculators
label: Paragraph

text: who argued in front of city councils for new roads as a basis for increasing property tax
label: Paragraph

text: revenues in new areas.
label: Paragraph

text: At a pace, new thoroughfares were built as an emblem of modernity and forward
label: Paragraph

text: thinking. Following the lead of William K. Vanderbilt’s Long Island Motor Parkway, the
label: Paragraph

text: first limited-access thoroughfare opened in 1911, and roadways were built for higher
label: Paragraph

text: speeds and greater efficiency. The Bronx River Parkway, in New York’s Westchester
label: Caption

text: County, featured limited access and landscaping when it was completed in 1923. The first
label: Paragraph

text: thoroughfares accentuated the scenic qualities of the roadside. The use of “parkway” in
label: Paragraph

text: their names implied their primary use for pleasure driving. The Hutchison River Parkway
label: Paragraph

text: in 1928, the Saw Mill River Parkway in 1929, the Cross County Parkway in 1931, and
label: Paragraph

text: the Henry Hudson Parkway along the West Side of Manhattan in 1934 all exemplified the
label: Paragraph

text: scenic qualities of the new roadways. However, it was not long before this idea of
label: Paragraph

text: roadways for recreation was replaced by the utility of commuter expressways.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1929, New Jersey began construction of a 13-mile expressway between Elizabeth
label: Paragraph

text: and Jersey. In Boston, two new expressways were completed at opposite sides of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago opened Wacker Drive, a new, elevated bilevel motorway that was designed for a
label: Paragraph

text: daily commute of 60,000 vehicles. In Los Angeles, the Arroyo Silo Parkway was opened
label: Paragraph

text: in 1940 after nearly 40 years of planning. Backed by downtown department stores, the
label: Paragraph

text: new freeway became an instant success, but instead
label: Paragraph

text: Aerial view of George Washington Memorial Parkway, 1992
label: Caption

text: © Jack Boucher, Historic American Engineering Record)/Library of Congress
label: Caption

text: of funneling shoppers into the downtown area, it launched a massive suburban migration
label: Paragraph

text: that powered the development of the nation’s most elaborate freeway system.
label: Paragraph

text: From the beginning, public subsides advanced the development of new roadways. The
label: Paragraph

text: Federal Road Act of 1916 founded new highway departments, and a 1921 reenactment
label: Paragraph

text: created the Bureau of Public Roads and provided matching funds for more than 200,000
label: Paragraph

text: miles of roads. State gasoline taxes, starting in 1919, provided another source of road-
label: Paragraph

text: building funds, enabling the value of highway construction projects to surpass $1 billion
label: Paragraph

text: By 1943, the enormous economic potential of road building had become obvious not
label: Paragraph

text: only to suburban land developers but also to a diverse group of oil and tire manufacturers,
label: Paragraph

text: construction industrialists, and automobile manufacturers who united as the American
label: Paragraph

text: Road Builders Association. Spearheaded by General Motors, the group’s largest
label: Paragraph

text: contributor, the association became exceedingly influential, second only to the munitions
label: Paragraph

text: industry. Their influence, along with a campaign by Cold War scientists to attain
label: Paragraph

text: “Defense Through Decentralization,” led to the Interstate Highway Act of 1956, which
label: Paragraph

text: called for a 42,000-mile system of federally funded limited-access thoroughfares at a cost
label: Paragraph

text: of $26 billion.
label: Paragraph

text: The influence of the Interstate Highway Act has ranged broadly across American
label: Paragraph

text: society, transforming it into a suburban nation. With this expansion, architects designed a
label: Paragraph

text: range of building types suited to automobile commuters and travelers, including hotels,
label: Paragraph

text: shopping malls, office campuses, and others. With the advent of air travel, architects
label: Paragraph

text: designed large and distinctive airports, all linked to their nearby cities by expressways.
label: Paragraph

text: With each completed link of the nationwide system of high-speed, limited-access
label: Paragraph

text: roadways, the population has spread farther from abandoned urban cores to satellite cities
label: Paragraph

text: and low-density suburbs. To be sure, other factors abetted this extraordinary migration,
label: Paragraph

text: such as federal mortgage subsidies and home ownership tax credits, but the Interstate
label: Paragraph

text: Highway Act paved the way. As the nation has been increasingly consumed by highways,
label: Paragraph

text: traffic jams, and endless commutes, the conventional wisdom of highway building has
label: Paragraph

text: been challenged. Led by numerous “freeway revolts” that began in California in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s, opposition to “more and more of worse and worse” has mounted, sometimes
label: Paragraph

text: halting highway construction projects or seriously modifying their size. Efforts to
label: Paragraph

text: develop public transportation alternatives have increased, even in Los Angeles, where the
label: Paragraph

text: freeway was once seen as the spine of life. Still, overall, no unanimously accepted
label: Paragraph

text: alternative has gained precedence over the drive of highway expansion.
label: Paragraph

text: ROBIE HOUSE
label: Title

text: Designed by Frank Lloyd Wright; completed 1910 Chicago, Illinois
label: Caption

text: When Frederick Robie went to Frank Lloyd Wright in the winter of 1908 for a house
label: Paragraph

text: on fashionable Woodlawn Avenue at the corner of Fifty-eighth Street in Chicago, Robie
label: Caption

text: worked with his father, who among other things was a supplier of parts to the growing
label: Paragraph

text: automobile industry. Like Wright, Robie was fascinated with the new machine and even
label: Paragraph

text: planned to open his own automobile factory. This surely explains the three garages (and
label: Paragraph

text: no stable) that Wright incorporated into Robie’s house. Preliminary plans for Robie
label: Paragraph

text: House were completed in November 1908, with working (or contract) drawings
label: Paragraph

text: following in March 1909. Construction began in the spring of 1909 and ended in the early
label: Paragraph

text: winter of 1910. The house was furnished between September 1909 and May 1910.
label: Paragraph

text: Because Wright turned his business over to architect Herman Von Holst in September
label: Paragraph

text: 1909 and went to Europe for a year, completion of the house was left to Marion Mahony,
label: Paragraph

text: long an associate of Wright, whom Von Holst had hired to complete Wright’s unfinished
label: Paragraph

text: commissions. It is likely that she designed the art glass of the house and iron gates of the
label: Paragraph

text: auto court, as these had not been detailed before Wright left for Europe. George
label: Paragraph

text: Niedecken, an interior architect from Milwaukee, already at work in the house before
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s departure, continued to have furniture and furnishings made according to
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s plans until they ran out, then designed additional furniture himself, mostly for
label: Paragraph

text: the living room.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s brick house for Frederick Robie is the most monumental of his Prairie houses
label: Paragraph

text: having the main living space on the second floor. Although Wright wrote frequently in a
label: Paragraph

text: rationalist vein about his distaste for dank basements and cluttered attics, his real reason
label: Paragraph

text: for wanting to eliminate basements and attics was both visual and psychological. As a
label: Paragraph

text: place of shelter and refuge, he felt that the home ought to be wedded visually to the earth,
label: Paragraph

text: which to him meant relatively low structures spreading out horizontally, anchored by
label: Paragraph

text: massive chimneys at the center and protected by overhanging hip roofs of low pitch.
label: Caption

text: Typical 19th-century houses elevated above partially exposed basements with rooms
label: Paragraph

text: Having high ceilings and crowned by massive hip or gable roofs were anathema to him.
label: Paragraph

text: Early photographs of Robie House looking north show just such a house behind it.
label: Paragraph

text: Although in later years Robie thought that it was he who had inspired Wright to design
label: Paragraph

text: for him a house with the visual and functional characteristics that mark Robie House,
label: Paragraph

text: Wright had actually developed the design over a ten-year period for other clients with
label: Paragraph

text: different tastes and requirements. The first house of this type was erected in Chicago in
label: Paragraph

text: 1899 for Joseph Husser. Except for having many details of late 19th-century origin, the
label: Paragraph

text: Husser house was remarkably like Robie House, even to having its entrance halfway
label: Paragraph

text: down the left side, a common practice in Chicago for siting large houses on the deep but
label: Paragraph

text: narrow lots of that city. For example, Robie House stands on a parcel 60 feet wide by 180
label: Paragraph

text: feet deep. The result of thus reviving for Robie House the plan of the Husser house,
label: Paragraph

text: which was not built on a commer and had residential lots on either side of its narrow front,
label: Paragraph

text: has been to cause both laypersons and academicians to suppose that the right side of
label: Paragraph

text: Robie House facing on Fifty-eighth Street is actually its front rather than Woodlawn
label: Paragraph

text: Avenue, which is its address. This confusion has fostered the myth that Wright intended
label: Paragraph

text: when designing the house to lead the observer slowly and inevitably around the house
label: Paragraph

text: from its Fifty-eighth Street side to the Woodlawn Avenue front, where at last he would
label: Paragraph

text: discover the entrance door sequestered in shadow at the end of a long walk.
label: Paragraph

text: Another residence, designed in 1905 and built of stucco on frame in Riverside, Illinois,
label: Paragraph

text: for Frederick Tomek, served as the intermediary for translating the late 19th-century
label: Paragraph

text: forms of the Husser house into the mature Wrightian style of Robie House. In fact,
label: Paragraph

text: Wright has stated that the Tomek house served as a model for Robie House. Originally,
label: Paragraph

text: the entrance to the Tomek house was to have been halfway down its right side, just the
label: Paragraph

text: reverse of the Husser and Robie houses. However, before construction began, the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance was moved to its left side, which faced the street. Both the Tomek and the Robie
label: Paragraph

text: house consist of a lower floor at grade with the main living floor above it. The latter is
label: Paragraph

text: devoted primarily to a large living and dining room connected through a passageway
label: Paragraph

text: illuminated by a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: Frederick C.Robie House, Chicago, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright (1910)
label: Caption

text: © James Reber. Photo courtesy The Frank Lloyd Wright Archives
label: Caption

text: bank of windows, actually French doors at Robie House. The living room opens onto a
label: Paragraph

text: porch. A partial third floor, looking something like a low tower or “belvedere,” as Wright
label: Paragraph

text: termed it, contains the bedrooms.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1905, when Wright designed the Tomek house, his style had become highly
label: Paragraph

text: abstract and rectilinear in character. Almost invariably, he built his residences after 1902
label: Paragraph

text: of rectangular masses, piers, and panels. These were sometimes solid, as for walls and
label: Paragraph

text: piers, and sometimes transparent, as for doors and windows, the latter always casements
label: Paragraph

text: grouped in horizontal banks. When possible, Wright carried the geometry of the exterior
label: Paragraph

text: into the interior, where he applied it with equal vigor to walls, piers, screens, furniture,
label: Paragraph

text: and furnishings.
label: Paragraph

text: In fact, it is the slope of the hip roofs of Robie House that deny for it the logical and
label: Paragraph

text: final next step in Wright’s aesthetic development, complete rectilinearity, a goal already
label: Paragraph

text: achieved by him through his use of the overhanging flat roof for Unity Temple and the
label: Paragraph

text: Yahara Boat Club, both designed in 1905, and for the proposed Fireproof House of 1907.
label: Paragraph

text: It was not until 1909, however, that Wright first built a residence in which he abandoned
label: Paragraph

text: the hip in favor of the flat roof. This was the thoroughly rectilinear house that he erected
label: Paragraph

text: for Laura Gale in Oak Park, Illinois. As a result, Robie House, despite its unrelenting
label: Paragraph

text: rectilinear geometry and horizontal massing, remains a transitional work
label: Paragraph

text: Interior dining room, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright (1910)
label: Caption

text: © James Reber. Photo courtesy The Frank Lloyd Wright Archives
label: Caption

text: along with Wright’s great Coonley House of 1907 because of the dissonant angularity of
label: Paragraph

text: its overspreading hip roofs.
label: Paragraph

text: Given the abstract geometry here and there in Wright’s work from the Winslow house
label: Paragraph

text: of 1894 onward, one might suppose that the European avant-garde was somehow affected
label: Paragraph

text: by this aspect of his work. Certainly, Wright was aware of developments in Europe
label: Paragraph

text: through European publications and from his visits to the St. Louis Exposition in 1904.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet, except for a few European architects who passed through Chicago before 1910 and
label: Paragraph

text: who might have returned with illustrations of Wright’s work, the only important
label: Paragraph

text: presentation of Wright’s architecture did not appear until March 1908, when the
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Record featured his work. In it, Europeans would have seen the massive
label: Paragraph

text: abstract geometries of the Larkin Building and Unity Temple along with those of the
label: Paragraph

text: Fireproof House. However, as Robie House was not completed until early 1910, its
label: Paragraph

text: potential for effecting the evolution of European architecture had to wait until 1911,
label: Paragraph

text: when it appeared in the German publications of Wright’s work by Wasmuth. As a result,
label: Paragraph

text: if Wright’s abstract style did inspire European architects to move in that same direction,
label: Paragraph

text: Robie House could not have played a part until after 1911.
label: Paragraph

text: Robie House does relate, however, to developments in European modernism going
label: Paragraph

text: back to the 1890s and earlier. Certain aspects of Wright’s style, especially his extensive
label: Paragraph

text: use of casement windows, presumably derive from the English Victorian Gothic and
label: Paragraph

text: probably more directly from the use of such windows by Voysey, Baillie Scott, and other
label: Paragraph

text: English architects in the 1890s. Wright’s continuing interest in creating artistic interiors
label: Paragraph

text: for his houses whenever he found a pliable client with sufficient resources and in the art
label: Paragraph

text: furniture with which he furnished those houses also surely goes back to the English Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts movement of the 1860s to 1890s. That Wright also sought to devise a style of
label: Paragraph

text: his own, one no longer derived from the historic styles, also served to align him with
label: Paragraph

text: Europe’s avant-garde architects.
label: Paragraph

text: Unfortunately, Robie got to live in his house for little more than a year. His wife left
label: Paragraph

text: him in April 1911, and he sold the house to another family in December of that year.
label: Paragraph

text: After the new owner died suddenly in 1912, the house passed to a third family, who
label: Paragraph

text: occupied it until 1926, when they sold it to the Chicago Theological Seminary for use as
label: Paragraph

text: a dormitory. In 1957, a preservation battle erupted when the seminary proposed
label: Paragraph

text: demolishing the house. Fortunately, Robie House was saved by developer William
label: Paragraph

text: Zeckendorf and eventually became the property of the University of Chicago. It is now
label: Paragraph

text: being restored and maintained by the Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio Foundation
label: Caption

text: and is a historic site of the National Trust for Historic Preservation.
label: Paragraph

text: ROCHE AND DINKELOO
label: Title

text: Architecture firm, United States
label: Title

text: Kevin Roche (1922-) and John Dinkeloo (1918-81) met in 1950 when they joined the
label: Paragraph

text: office of Eero Saarinen and Associates at Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, where they worked
label: Paragraph

text: for 11 years along with Robert Venturi, Chuck Bassett, Tony Lumsden, Gunnar Birketts,
label: Paragraph

text: and Cesar Pelli. After Saarinen’s sudden death in 1961, Roche and Dinkeloo formed a
label: Paragraph

text: partnership in Hamden, Connecticut, to complete the projects that were under way at that
label: Paragraph

text: time. The nascent partnership saw not only the successful completion of ten international
label: Paragraph

text: projects but also went on to receive many other important commissions. Roche and
label: Paragraph

text: Dinkeloo practiced together until 1981, and during that 20-year period they designed a
label: Paragraph

text: number of outstanding buildings for a diverse group of corporate and institutional clients.
label: Paragraph

text: The ten buildings that Roche and Dinkeloo inherited from Saarinen were projects that
label: Paragraph

text: they had been centrally involved in designing and included some of the most significant
label: Paragraph

text: American buildings of the period, sharing innovative approaches to technology and new
label: Paragraph

text: materials: the Gateway Arch, St. Louis, Missouri; the TWA Terminal, New York City;
label: Caption

text: Dulles International Airport, Washington, D.C.; the Headquarters for John Deere and
label: Caption

text: Company in Moline, Illinois; and the CBS Headquarters in New York.
label: Paragraph

text: The first project awarded to the new practice was the Oakland Museum (1961-68) in
label: Paragraph

text: California. Eero Saarinen had been on the original list of architects being considered for
label: Paragraph

text: the project, and Roche Dinkeloo, who asked to be considered after his death, was selected
label: Paragraph

text: from a group of 35 architects. Their award-winning museum design included landscaped
label: Paragraph

text: roofs that created a new park at the heart of the city. Over the next 20 years, the practice
label: Paragraph

text: grew to become one of the most vital American offices of that era, designing a wide
label: Paragraph

text: range of different building types for both civic and corporate clients.
label: Paragraph

text: The most significant buildings designed by Roche Dinkeloo include a series of
label: Paragraph

text: university facilities, the office tower (1965-69) for the Knights of Columbus together
label: Caption

text: with the neighboring Coliseum (1965-72) in New Haven, and arguably the most
label: Paragraph

text: important, the Headquarters for the Ford Foundation (1963-68) in New York. These
label: Paragraph

text: monumental buildings made innovative use of novel materials such as glass, advanced
label: Paragraph

text: glazing systems, and self-rusting steel while at the same time exploiting the potential of
label: Paragraph

text: structural forms as large-scale ordering systems. Projects such as the factories and offices
label: Paragraph

text: for Cummins Engine in Darlington, England (1963-65), and later at Columbus, Indiana
label: Paragraph

text: (1970-73), developed these ideas in ways that improved the industrial working
label: Paragraph

text: environment, whereas a series of designs for corporate headquarters for Richardson-
label: Paragraph

text: Merrell Inc. (1970-74), Union Carbide (1976-82), and General Foods (1977-82)
label: Paragraph

text: explored the needs of large new office buildings sited in green-field sites by integrating
label: Paragraph

text: offices and parking within the landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1967, Roche Dinkeloo began work on the renovation and extension of the
label: Paragraph

text: Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, a project that would extend over more than
label: Paragraph

text: 30 years. In addition to a new gallery wing and a bookshop, a series of glassy pavilions
label: Caption

text: were designed for the Robert Lehman Collection in 1974 and subsequently for the
label: Paragraph

text: Temple of Dendur.
label: Caption

text: Since Dinkeloo’s death, Roche has directed the practice with a group of associates and
label: Paragraph

text: continued the design for the Metropolitan Museum of Art, creating new galleries and
label: Paragraph

text: restoring the existing building. The work of Roche’s office has become increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupied with formal issues and the development of a historicist eclecticism.
label: Paragraph

text: Roche and Dinkeloo were the recipients of numerous honors and awards. In 1974, they
label: Paragraph

text: received the Architectural Firm Award from the American Institute of Architects (AIA),
label: Paragraph

text: and eight years later Roche was awarded the Pritzker Architecture Prize. In
label: Paragraph

text: Knights of Columbus Headquarters, New Haven, Connecticut (1969)

text: © G.E.Kidder-Smith, courtesy of Kidder Smith Collection, Rotch Visual
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: for an outstanding building of distinction.

text: ROCKEFELLER CENTER, NEW YORK
label: Caption

text: Designed by Raymond Hood, completed 1940 New York City
label: Caption

text: Rockefeller Center is widely considered to be a handsome commercial building
label: Paragraph

text: complex, and it has been the model for other groups of structures dedicated to a mix of
label: Paragraph

text: business and entertainment. The Center comprises 30 buildings (although some are
label: Paragraph

text: connected), with another being planned as of 1999. They extend from Fifth Avenue
label: Paragraph

text: toward Seventh Avenue, between 48th and 52nd Streets, although the original and most
label: Paragraph

text: famous structures were limited to most of the three blocks between 48th and 51st Streets,
label: Paragraph

text: Fifth to Sixth Avenues.
label: Paragraph

text: The original group, planned and built from 1929 to 1940, was erected on land that
label: Paragraph

text: belonged primarily to Columbia University. John D.Rockefeller, Jr, who leased the
label: Paragraph

text: Columbia properties, bought several additional lots on Sixth Avenue as plans progressed.
label: Paragraph

text: At first, the blocks were intended for bulky office towers on three sides of a large open
label: Paragraph

text: square. A new Metropolitan Opera House was to occupy the fourth side, at the west,
label: Paragraph

text: extending toward Sixth Avenue. When the stock market crash of 1929 made this plan
label: Paragraph

text: unworkable, Rockefeller requested new plans for high and low commercial buildings
label: Paragraph

text: around a smaller plaza. Most were to be office buildings with shops at ground level and
label: Paragraph

text: along a subterranean concourse connected to a subway line that replaced a noisy elevated
label: Paragraph

text: railway on Sixth Avenue. Other buildings, at the west end near the noise, were
label: Paragraph

text: windowless, sound-proof theaters; of the two originally there, only Radio City Music
label: Paragraph

text: Hall has survived. A cinema was introduced later in the middle of the north block. The
label: Caption

text: leasing program was focused on broadcasting (later television) and film industry tenants,
label: Paragraph

text: and on individually owned international shops. Travel and airline offices, foreign
label: Paragraph

text: consulates, the U.S. passport agency, and auxiliary services such as passport
label: Paragraph

text: photographers, restaurants, pharmacies, and a post office completed the primary rental
label: Paragraph

text: program. The adaptability of the owner and his professional colleagues, the targeting of
label: Paragraph

text: tenant groups, and the refined, varied design in handsome materials helped to ensure the
label: Paragraph

text: project’s eventual profitability and public esteem, although, in its early years, the project
label: Paragraph

text: suffered financially as a result of the Depression.
label: Paragraph

text: Only the central one of the three original blocks was designed and executed according
label: Paragraph

text: to a fixed plan. Here, twin low buildings flank a path adorned with plants, fountains, and
label: Paragraph

text: small statues. The path leads to the central plaza, depressed so as to allow commercial
label: Caption

text: premises around the perimeter. Zoning regulations made it impossible to build ground-
label: Paragraph

text: level shops and restaurants, because just west of the plaza, a 66-story tower rises, taking
label: Paragraph

text: up most of the bulk and height allowed under the zoning rules then in force. On the north
label: Paragraph

text: block, Radio City Music Hall and an office building above it were determined at the start,
label: Paragraph

text: whereas the high International Building along Fifth Avenue, with additional low wings
label: Paragraph

text: for shops and offices, was added in the mid1930s. The south block contained the Center
label: Paragraph

text: Theater along Sixth Avenue, now replaced by an office tower. Buildings for the
label: Caption

text: Associated Press and Eastern Air Lines, among others, were

label: Caption

text: and public seating. Connoisseurs of architectural detailing admire the metalwork in the
label: Paragraph

text: focal tower and the frames of the original shop windows. Urbanists praise the extra street
label: Paragraph

text: added west of the plaza, the underground concourse with its subway access and
label: Paragraph

text: connections among the Center’s buildings, and the provision of public space in a private
label: Paragraph

text: enclave. The combination of low and high structures shows that aesthetic considerations,
label: Paragraph

text: and not exclusively financial ones, were present in the minds of the owner, John
label: Paragraph

text: D.Rockefeller, Jr., the property developers he employed (Todd, Robertson and Todd),
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: K.Harrison, and Raymond Hood were the principal designers).
label: Paragraph

text: In the years between 1947 and 1973, several new buildings were added, primarily by
label: Paragraph

text: Harrison and his later partner, Max Abramovitz. Most interesting are their buildings
label: Paragraph

text: across Sixth Avenue, starting with the Time-Life Building (1957-60), an example of
label: Paragraph

text: technological expression of supports and ducts. The three blocks south of this contain
label: Paragraph

text: visually coordinated single towers, completed by 1973. The two central ones have large
label: Paragraph

text: plazas, mandated by revised zoning rules but realized with more plants, seats, and other
label: Paragraph

text: public amenities than were customary at the time. West of these buildings are additional
label: Paragraph

text: small public parks. In these years and later as well, various architects remodeled some of
label: Paragraph

text: the lobbies and other spaces that were not protected from change by the Center’s
label: Paragraph

text: designation as a city landmark in 1985.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1999, the Landmarks Preservation Commission permitted the new owners to enlarge
label: Paragraph

text: windows on the facades of the four low buildings on Fifth Avenue and to make
label: Caption

text: alterations in the central plaza. Less-controversial changes include the introduction of a
label: Paragraph

text: facade for the Christie’s auction house in the center of the original south block, and
label: Caption

text: repaving of the original private street introduced into the project to increase the number
label: Paragraph

text: of offices with street frontage.
label: Paragraph

text: Through assiduous maintenance, upgrading of technical features, and expert public
label: Paragraph

text: relations, the Center has managed to retain its position as a premier location for business
label: Paragraph

text: and as a popular tourist attraction in midtown, an area that the Center itself helped to
label: Paragraph

text: establish as the heart of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: ROGERS, RICHARD 1933-
label: Title

text: Architect, England
label: Title

text: Richard Rogers was born in Florence in 1933 of British parents. He received his
label: Paragraph

text: architectural education at the Architectural Association School in London and at Yale
label: Paragraph

text: University, where he held a Fulbright Scholarship. At Yale, he heard lectures by Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolf and Louis Kahn and also met his British contemporaries, Norman Foster and
label: Paragraph

text: James Stirling.
label: Paragraph

text: He began work by designing a family house at Creek Vean in Cornwall, with white
label: Paragraph

text: walls and large windows, a house of impeccable modernity that still appears fresh after
label: Paragraph

text: nearly half a century. His career took off when he designed a factory, in partnership with
label: Paragraph

text: Sue Rogers and Norman and Wendy Foster, a double husband-and-wife group that set up
label: Paragraph

text: under the name of “Team 4.” The Reliance Controls Ltd. Factory at Swindon (1967)
label: Caption

text: became well known as an example of industrial architecture that makes its impact from
label: Paragraph

text: the visual quality of its structural system, in this case a clear succession of rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: bays stiffened by tensioned diagonal braces.
label: Caption

text: Rogers has become increasingly devoted to the architecture produced by structural
label: Paragraph

text: tours-de-force. Of these, the Pompidou Center in Paris (1971-77, with Renzo Piano) is
label: Paragraph

text: the most famous. As with Reliance, the building is essentially a shed, and the main
label: Paragraph

text: elevation is similarly marked by a clear succession of rectangular bays overlaid by
label: Paragraph

text: diagonal tension cables. The designs for Lloyds in the City of London and for Inmos at
label: Paragraph

text: Newport South Wales both continue to gain their principal effect from the display of
label: Paragraph

text: structure and service elements on the exterior. Rogers (like Foster) has therefore become
label: Paragraph

text: a principal proponent of a “true” functionalist architecture, going beyond Louis Kahn in
label: Paragraph

text: the analysis of form and mechanism, in an attempt to eliminate the arbitrary and willful
label: Paragraph

text: character of facade making.
label: Paragraph

text: Through this development, modernism was pushed closer to the machine, but also
label: Paragraph

text: closer to sculpture: Rogers’s work emerges from this conjunction. He was also influenced
label: Paragraph

text: by Archigram, for whom expression was as important as technology. Disciples of the
label: Paragraph

text: Archigram group, in fact, as employees of Piano and Rogers, realized the design
label: Paragraph

text: development and working drawings for the Pompidou Center, so that it became the
label: Paragraph

text: nearest thing we have to a completed Archigram building. But it is also the building that
label: Paragraph

text: most completely expresses Rogers’s attitude to architecture: for it has no hint in it, as has
label: Paragraph

text: the Lloyds Building, of a conventional interior dominated by ancient tribal rituals, but is
label: Paragraph

text: entirely the product of an intellectual movement toward the “real” sources of functional
label: Paragraph

text: truth: the exposure of the bones and guts along with devotion to the principles of change
label: Title

text: and indeterminacy in use, of which the prophet was the Archigram guru, Reyner Banham.
label: Paragraph

text: From 1977 Rogers’s work has had the benefit of a multidisciplined approach, with the
label: Paragraph

text: formation of the Richard Rogers Partnership, bringing in the collaboration of John
label: Paragraph

text: Young, Marco Goldschmied, and Mike Davies, and improved access to inhouse
label: Paragraph

text: engineering services. With this improved organization, the firm has become something of
label: Paragraph

text: an icon of the High-Tech aspect of modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: It is not that the High-Tech architect eschews beauty. But the beauty to be uncovered
label: Paragraph

text: has to be identified with necessity, the result of applying reason along with engineering
label: Paragraph

text: principles. The method of construction becomes an artistic strategy and hence an end in
label: Paragraph

text: itself. In the Tokyo Forum Project of 1991, for example, the spaces of use are first
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed in a gleaming semitransparent shell, then suspended from a metal armature, then
label: Paragraph

text: approached by a complex of escalators. The object becomes a symbol of its own
label: Paragraph

text: otherworldliness, a chapel to progress.
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd’s Bank Building, London (1984)
label: Caption

text: © GreatBuildings.com
label: Title

text: A more balanced approach is envisaged in the design for the European Court of
label: Paragraph

text: Human Rights (1989-94) at Strasbourg. Here the elements into which the complex is
label: Paragraph

text: broken down are not the service elements as such, but spaces of use; they stand on the
label: Paragraph

text: ground, forming a composition that is less obsessively analytical and more expressive of
label: Paragraph

text: human habitation and intercourse, whereas the building takes its scale and shape from its
label: Paragraph

text: context on the curve of a river and from its situation within the city. This increased
label: Paragraph

text: sensitivity toward the city is also evident in the very elegant project for the Alcazar, in
label: Paragraph

text: Marseilles (1988). Within a seven-story height limit (surely a donné for the French city)
label: Paragraph

text: he inserted a wedge-shaped volume closely into the texture of the adjoining blocks.
label: Paragraph

text: Service elements are still lied up on one side, office space on the other, with between
label: Paragraph

text: them, a “spine,” which at ground level becomes a pedestrian route linking the frontage on
label: Paragraph

text: the Cours Belsunce to the quiet contained space of the Place de la Providence. The way
label: Paragraph

text: the building draws back to allow the space of this quiet square to be drawn into the
label: Paragraph

text: scheme, the way it curves gently to make an entrance from the Cours Belsunce, show a
label: Paragraph

text: distinct sensitivity not only to an analytical idea of urban form but also to the sense of
label: Paragraph

text: civic propriety. In France, where Rogers has many projects under consideration, there are
label: Paragraph

text: several that seem to open up a less machine-oriented perspective, such as the master
label: Paragraph

text: plans for Dunkirk Neptune (1990) and Port Aupec (1990) and schemes for Bussy St.
label: Paragraph

text: Georges (1989—) and Sextius Mirbeau (1990). In all of these there is a distinct element of
label: Paragraph

text: contextual relevance.
label: Paragraph

text: Rogers has been accepted as a master of modern design, to judge by his creation as a
label: Paragraph

text: Chevalier de l’Ordre National de la Légion d’Honneur in 1985 and in his own country,
label: Paragraph

text: too, as is evident from his election to the Royal Academy in 1978, the award of the Royal
label: Paragraph

text: Gold Medal of the RIBA in 1985, his knighthood of 1991 for services to architecture, and
label: Paragraph

text: his peerage of 1996, the latter giving him a role that could strongly influence in political
label: Paragraph

text: and therefore in practical terms the future of architecture within Britain. He will, of
label: Paragraph

text: course, go down to posterity as the principle author of the Millennial Dome at
label: Paragraph

text: Greenwich, a tour de force in which a tent suspended from steel gantries is given the
label: Paragraph

text: spread and authority of an immense domed space. His designs continue to exploit the
label: Paragraph

text: cutting edge of architectural technology, as with the Headquarters for the Lloyd’s
label: Paragraph

text: Register of Shipping and the new Terminal 5 at Heathrow Airport.
label: Caption

text: In 1995 Rogers was invited by the BBC to give the Reith Lectures, and he chose to
label: Paragraph

text: build his lectures around the theme of the dense modern city. In his argument, although
label: Paragraph

text: the city has in the past been a major pollutant, this is not necessarily so: It can be
label: Paragraph

text: rethought scientifically so that it contributes to a sustainable environment while
label: Paragraph

text: preserving the social vivacity that makes a society vital.
label: Paragraph

text: ROMANACH, MARIO 1917-1984
label: Title

text: Architect, Cuba
label: Title

text: Mario Romajiach excelled among the vanguard professionals of 1950s modern Cuban
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, including Frank Martinez, Nicolas Quintana, Manuel Gutiérrez, Emilio del
label: Paragraph

text: Junco, Joaquin Crist6fol, Humberto Alonso, Nicolas Arroyo, Eduardo Montelieu, Alberto
label: Caption

text: Beale, and Antonio Quintana. Although Romajiach’s work is still under studied, his
label: Paragraph

text: oeuvre constituted a model of contemporary design adapted to the material and
label: Paragraph

text: environmental conditions of the tropic, an example soon to be followed by the new
label: Paragraph

text: generations of Caribbean architects. On graduation from the University of Havana in
label: Paragraph

text: 1945, Romaiiach designed collaboratively with Silverio Bosch until 1955, when he began
label: Paragraph

text: to work independently.
label: Paragraph

text: He collaborated with Antonio Quintana in the competition for the main building of the
label: Paragraph

text: College of Architects (1943) and the Havana Regulatory Plan (1944). Afterward,
label: Paragraph

text: Romafiach, Quintana, and Pedro Martinez Inclan received the commission to design the
label: Paragraph

text: Workers’ Neighborhood of Luyan6 (Barrio Obrero de Luyano, 1944-48), the first Cuban
label: Paragraph

text: structure to use modern blocks for residential housing. Concurrently, he developed
label: Paragraph

text: friendships with Walter Gropius, Richard Neutra, and José Luis Sert, who visited the
label: Paragraph

text: School of Architecture in Havana, where Romafiach was a professor from 1951 to 1952.
label: Paragraph

text: His introverted character kept him at the margins of the student political struggles that
label: Paragraph

text: grew in reaction to Fulgencio Batista’s dictatorship (1952-58). Nonetheless, Romaiiach
label: Paragraph

text: defended the progress of the Modern movement; he participated in ATEC (Tectonic
label: Paragraph

text: Group for Contemporary Expression) and ARCA (Renovating Association of the College
label: Paragraph

text: of Architects). Between 1945 and 1955, he designed and built 58 works including private
label: Paragraph

text: homes, apartments, and various public buildings. Early in his career, Romafiach’s houses
label: Paragraph

text: possessed a commercial and functionalist character, fulfilling the aesthetic requirements
label: Paragraph

text: of the traditionalist Cuban middle class. Despite its relative conservatism, the Julia Cueto
label: Paragraph

text: de Noval House (1948) in Havana achieved a clear and volumetric organization.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the innovative residence built for the son, José Noval Cueto (1949), was less
label: Paragraph

text: well received. This house marked the apex of Cuban and perhaps Antillean rationalism,
label: Paragraph

text: integrating precise compositional structure, smooth white facades, the articulation of
label: Paragraph

text: functional spaces, and structural regularity. Organized within a rectangular box supported
label: Paragraph

text: by beams and divided into two blocks joined by open circulation galleries (after the
label: Paragraph

text: model of Marcel Breuer’s bipolar house) the house’s interior included a pool and a
label: Paragraph

text: tropical garden. Thus, through a system of transparencies, double facades (real and
label: Paragraph

text: virtual}, and shaded spaces, Romajiach adapted the formal models of Mies van der Rohe,
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Gropius, and Le Corbusier, issuing from Europe and the United States to the
label: Paragraph

text: tropical environment.
label: Paragraph

text: Works built in the 1950s express Romajiach’s experimentation with the individual and
label: Paragraph

text: collective dwelling and arrive at a particular type that is defined as Cuban “modern
label: Paragraph

text: regionalism,” an elaboration of the influences of Richard Neutra and traditional Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The Havana house of Luis H.Vidafia (1953), the residence of Ana Carolina
label: Caption

text: Font (1956), and the mansion of Rufino Alvarez (1957) mark Romajfiach’s maturation. In
label: Paragraph

text: these innovative works, he designed walls of refracting colored bricks cement blocks,
label: Paragraph

text: created a system of canopy ceilings that appear almost suspended in air, explored the use
label: Paragraph

text: of natural wood, and achieved sophisticated spatial articulations with the organization of
label: Paragraph

text: transparent and shaded environments.
label: Paragraph

text: The buildings for the Territorial Company of La Sierra in Miramar (1956) and the
label: Caption

text: Company for the Investment of Private Goods and Bonds (1958) display the innovative
label: Paragraph

text: and illuminating spatial treatments found in Romafiach’s apartment buildings and private
label: Paragraph

text: homes. These effects achieve a monumental dimension in the “Las Palmas” Presidential
label: Paragraph

text: Palace (1956) that he designed with José Luis Sert and Gabriela Menéndez for the
label: Paragraph

text: dictator Fulgencio Batista as part of a governmental commission that also hired Wiener,
label: Paragraph

text: Sert, and Schulz, Town Planning Associates.
label: Paragraph

text: As Chief of the Havana Plan of the National Planning Group (1955), Romajfiach
label: Paragraph

text: developed several urban projects that were never executed in La Coronela, La Habana del
label: Paragraph

text: Este, and the proposed Satellite City of Columbia, intended to house 10,000 inhabitants.
label: Paragraph

text: With the arrival of Fidel Castro’s government (1959), Romafiach immigrated to the
label: Paragraph

text: United States to teach at Harvard University at the invitation of Sert. He developed
label: Paragraph

text: innumerable public and private projects in his Philadelphia office. Even though some of
label: Paragraph

text: his works received significant prizes (such as Chatam Towers in New York City, 1967)
label: Paragraph

text: they were lacking, along with the work of other architects who had emigrated from Cuba,
label: Paragraph

text: the poetic depth and creativity that characterized his works in Havana.
label: Paragraph
