text: ROMANIA
label: Title

text: At the beginning of 20th century, Romania was much indebted to Western European
label: Paragraph

text: architectural currents. The recently created national style had only a feeble impact on the
label: Paragraph

text: public.
label: Paragraph

text: Foreign architecture, mainly Neoclassicism and Romanticism, was progressively
label: Paragraph

text: introduced in the principalities of Wallachia and Moldavia during the 19th century as a
label: Paragraph

text: consequence of the process of opening up to Western European civilization. The two
label: Paragraph

text: principalities, vassals of the Ottoman Empire, sought a model for emancipation and also
label: Paragraph

text: political assistance, aspiring to create an independent unified state. After this state was
label: Paragraph

text: founded in 1859, and particularly after it obtained its independence in 1878, its first
label: Paragraph

text: institutions embraced foreign architectural currents as a sign of modernization. At this
label: Paragraph

text: time, the most widespread was the ecclecticism of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: which eventually became the official style of the Romanian kingdom. French architecture
label: Paragraph

text: was practiced not only by French nationals but also by the first Romanian architects, who
label: Paragraph

text: were themselves trained at the Ecole.
label: Paragraph

text: Some of these young architects trained in France, where they came in contact with the
label: Paragraph

text: theories of E.E. Viollet-le-Duc, the French archaeological school, and the innovative
label: Paragraph

text: concepts of Guadet. Once home, they relentlessly worked to create a new Romanian
label: Paragraph

text: architecture based on the local tradition. Among them, the most fervent was lon Mincu,
label: Paragraph

text: the father of this new style called either “national” or “Romanian,” which mirrored the
label: Paragraph

text: national ideology that animated the Romanian intelligentsia of the time.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet the first decade of 20th century was still strongly dominated by French
label: Paragraph

text: ecclecticism, which maintained its status of official architecture and was also very in
label: Paragraph

text: vogue for the rich residencies. The Beaux-Arts style was displayed in a variety of forms,
label: Paragraph

text: going from classic solemnity (the Palace of the Chamber of Deputies, 1907, by Dimitrie
label: Caption

text: Maimarolu in Bucharest) to a light elegance (the Casino, 1913, by Petre Antonescu in
label: Paragraph

text: Sinaia) or to flamboyant fantasies (the town hall of lasi, 1907-26, by loan D.Berindey). If
label: Paragraph

text: the Beaux-Arts style was perfectly assimilated, Romanian architects were less familiar
label: Paragraph

text: with other currents, such as Art Nouveau, one of the rare examples of which is the Casino
label: Paragraph

text: in Constanta (1910) by Daniel Renard. In contrast, Art Nouveau was very popular in
label: Paragraph

text: Transylvania, where it radiated from Central Europe. A province of the Austro-
label: Paragraph

text: Hungarian Empire until 1918, Transylvania adopted the multiple facets that the inventive
label: Paragraph

text: vocabulary of Art Nouveau developed on the vast territory of the empire: the aesthetic of
label: Paragraph

text: Lechner’s Art Nouveau, as in several works of Jakab Deszé and Marcel Komor,
label: Paragraph

text: including the “Black Eagle building,” 1907-09, in Oradea and the Palace of Culture,
label: Paragraph

text: 1913, in Tirgu-Mures; the researches of a new Hungarian national image of the “Young
label: Paragraph

text: Architects,” including the Museum, 1911, by Karoly Kos, in Sfintul Gheorghe; and
label: Paragraph

text: compositions inspired by Sezession and Jugendstil, including the work of E. Thoroczkai-
label: Paragraph

text: Wigand in Tirgu-Mures.
label: Paragraph

text: Starting in 1906, the date of the General National Exposition in Bucharest (Stefan
label: Paragraph

text: Burcus and Victor Stefanescu), which celebrated 40 years of reign of King Carol I, the
label: Paragraph

text: national style gained an important place on the architectural scene of Romanian kingdom.
label: Paragraph

text: The exposition, with its multitude of pavilions, brought recognition for this style. In their
label: Paragraph

text: quest for an expression of the Romanian specificity, the exponents of the national style
label: Paragraph

text: sought relevant examples in local tradition that they referred to as both major art history
label: Paragraph

text: monuments and folk art. Among the chief promoters of the national style were Petre
label: Paragraph

text: Antonescu, Paul Smarandescu, Statie Ciortan, Toma T.Socolescu, and Nicolae Ghika-
label: Paragraph

text: Budesti.
label: Paragraph

text: As its doctrine responded perfectly to the aspirations of national unity and as its
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic satisfied the taste for picturesque dispositions, the new style was progressively
label: Paragraph

text: embraced in several architectural programs. First adopted in residential architecture, it
label: Paragraph

text: spread progressively to administrative buildings, schools, and post offices, some of the
label: Paragraph

text: most significant examples of this period being the Prefecture of Galati (1906) by Ion
label: Paragraph

text: Mincu, the Prefecture of Craiova (1912-13) by Petre Antonescu, and the town hall of
label: Paragraph

text: Constanta (1913) by Victor Stefanescu. At the creation of greater Romania, by the
label: Paragraph

text: unification of the ancient kingdom with Transylvania, Bessarabia, and Bukovina at the
label: Paragraph

text: end of World War I, the national style was unsurprisingly appropriated as an official
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The establishment of the new state generated a period of prosperity and of
label: Paragraph

text: economic as well as cultural effervescence, which explains the unprecedented growth of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The sustained building campaign obviously benefited the national style,
label: Paragraph

text: which now covered all the architectural programs and all the territory of Romania. To
label: Paragraph

text: mention the huge operation of rising orthodox churches in Transylvania, the construction
label: Paragraph

text: of oversize churches, called “cathedrals,” was a symbolic act of recuperating a territory
label: Paragraph

text: released from Catholicism.
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas the national style responded to the new context of the acknowledged national
label: Paragraph

text: spirituality, modernism expressed the opening toward European culture and the efforts of
label: Paragraph

text: synchronizing Romanian culture with European tendencies. The architect and artist
label: Paragraph

text: Marcel Iancu played an important role in the introduction and assimilation of the
label: Paragraph

text: principles of Modern architecture. He contributed to the initiation to modernism through
label: Paragraph

text: a sustained publishing campaign, writing numerous articles in the style of the avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: manifestos in the magazine Contimporanul from 1924 to 1930. The diffusion of
label: Paragraph

text: modernism was encouraged by the commands of the intellectual milieu, opened not only
label: Paragraph

text: to the new architectural trends, but also by the prosperous members of the middle classes
label: Paragraph

text: as well as by several societies, institutions, and industries that appropriated Modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture as the emblem of their efficiency. After 1930, the period of early modernism
label: Paragraph

text: in Romania, the incontestable center of new trends was Bucharest. However, several
label: Paragraph

text: examples, remarkable by their perfect adherence to the formal vocabulary of modernism,
label: Paragraph

text: were erected in other areas of the country. These examples belong less to the housing
label: Paragraph

text: program (except for the villas executed by I. Boceanu in Cimpina or the villa Tataru in
label: Paragraph

text: Cluj, designed in Gio Ponti’s studio) than to the field of public buildings. It was an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that advanced the idea of autonomy from the geographic environment—such
label: Paragraph

text: as the sanatoriums in the mountain zones (Toria, 1933-34, by Grigore lonescu in Ciuc
label: Caption

text: and Bucegi, 1934, by Marcel lancu in Predeal) and the hotels in the seaside resorts
label: Paragraph

text: (Belona, 1933, by G.M.Cantacuzino in Eforie}—and that underscored the expressive
label: Paragraph

text: potential of the reinforced-concrete structure—such as the Central Market in Ploiesti
label: Paragraph

text: (1931-33) by Toma T.Socolescu. The industrial buildings of the 1930s exclusively
label: Paragraph

text: adopted the vocabulary of modernism, employing vigorous structures with large openings
label: Paragraph

text: in reinforced concrete (the IAR Industries building, 1933, by G.M. Cantacuzino in
label: Caption

text: Brasov) and emphasizing the expressiveness of the volumes and the materials,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly brick (the Banloc Plants, 1937-38, by O.Doicescu and the Astra Plants,
label: Paragraph

text: 1936-37, by Costinescu in Brasov).
label: Caption

text: Parallel to the boom of modern architecture and obviously influenced by its principles,
label: Paragraph

text: the national style developed a new expression that adopted the formal simplicity and
label: Paragraph

text: functionality of modernism. Not only was this new image a transgression of a clear
label: Paragraph

text: decline of the style (the result of an epigonic production), but it also brought a change of
label: Paragraph

text: vision. Instead of the historic examples, sometimes quoted in a historicist manner,
label: Paragraph

text: tradition was now understood as the essence of Romanian spirituality through the
label: Paragraph

text: perspective of folk art values. The new expression found adepts among the old exponents
label: Paragraph

text: of the national style (Andrei Saguna Orthodox College, 1938-39, by George Cristinel in
label: Caption

text: Sibiu), but it was particularly popular with young architects (the Military Club by C.lotzu
label: Paragraph

text: in Brasov and the numerous villas designed by H.Delavrancea-Gibory at the seaside).
label: Paragraph

text: The State Circus (1960), Bucharest, Romania. Designed by Nicolae
label: Caption

text: Porumbescu and Constantin Rulea.
label: Paragraph

text: © Carmen Popescu
label: Title

text: The second half of the 1930s was a time of increased authoritarian politics, which
label: Paragraph

text: culminated in the dictatorship of King Carol II and was followed at the beginning of the
label: Paragraph

text: 1940s by the creation of the military state. The adoption of the new classicism perfectly
label: Paragraph

text: mirrored this shift in the state politics. Frequently called “the style Carol IL,” this
label: Paragraph

text: tendency became the symbol of the official architecture and was developed mainly in the
label: Paragraph

text: capital.
label: Paragraph

text: The important political changes that followed World War II and that culminated in the
label: Paragraph

text: installation of the Communist regime on 30 December 1947 brought a radical
label: Paragraph

text: transformation for the development of architecture. The state established almost total
label: Paragraph

text: control over architecture and urbanism, which became dependent on the strictly
label: Paragraph

text: centralized economic and social politics. The evolution of postwar architecture was
label: Paragraph

text: decisively conditioned by the dominance of standardized plans and of serialized
label: Paragraph

text: industrial methods of construction, by the reduction in investment costs, and by the
label: Paragraph

text: replacement of theoretical and critical discourse with the authoritarian intervention of the
label: Paragraph

text: party ideology. However, this pattern was transgressed in particular cases, as when
label: Paragraph

text: requested by the importance of representation. This representation emphasized either the
label: Paragraph

text: regime itself or its ideology, either the urban role of the building or the uniqueness of its
label: Paragraph

text: function—in the city or in the whole country.
label: Paragraph

text: The regime exercised a progressive control over architecture that was reflected in each
label: Paragraph

text: phase of this period. The first part of 1950s was marked by the so-called realist-socialist
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of Soviet influence. In these years, housing developments were built in
label: Paragraph

text: numerous cities in Romania, as were plants and the infrastructure for the International
label: Paragraph

text: Youth Festival, which took place in 1953 in Bucharest. The utmost symbol of this
label: Paragraph

text: architecture remains Casa Scinteii (House of the Spark, 1950-51, by architects H.Maicu,
label: Caption

text: L.Staadecker, M.Alifanti, N.Badescu, and others in Bucharest), a local reproduction of
label: Paragraph

text: the Soviet models, where the forms, mainly classical, were adorned with details inspired
label: Paragraph

text: partly by national tradition. Parallel to that, the old generation of architects continued to
label: Paragraph

text: use the vocabulary of the interwar rationalism that was present in Romanian architecture
label: Paragraph

text: until the end of the decade. The most relevant examples are the Clothing Industries
label: Paragraph

text: APACA building (1948) by M.Alifanti, I.Ghica Budesti, and others and the Palace of the
label: Caption

text: National Broadcasting (1960) by T.Ricci, L.Garcia, and M.Ricci, both in Bucharest.
label: Paragraph

text: The most interesting period of evolution in Romanian architecture started in the 1960s
label: Paragraph

text: and lasted until the mid-1970s against the background of an apparent ideological
label: Paragraph

text: liberalization. Functionalist architecture became official, and the urbanist prin-ciples of
label: Paragraph

text: the Athens Charter were conclusively adopted. The dormitory districts built in almost all
label: Paragraph

text: Romanian cities, with their impersonal architecture and huge dimensions (up to hundreds
label: Paragraph

text: of thousands of inhabitants), were erected according to these principles of the Athens
label: Paragraph

text: Charter. Starting at the end of the 1960s, the Black Sea littoral became the experimental
label: Paragraph

text: ground for both New Urbanism and Modern architecture. The necessity of modern public
label: Paragraph

text: equipment in the cities brought the opportunity for various architectures, some of them of
label: Paragraph

text: an incontestable value, to be employed. Among the most significant buildings of this
label: Paragraph

text: period are a series of hotels (particularly at the Black Sea in the resorts Neptun, Olimp,
label: Paragraph

text: and Aurora and in the mountain resorts, such as Poiana Brasov), theaters (the National
label: Paragraph

text: Theater, 1972-74, by Al. lotzu in Craiova), cultural centers (such as those built in 1968
label: Paragraph

text: by N.Porumbescu in Suceava and in 1975 in Baia Mare, where he employed a stylized
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation of the traditional decorative patterns), and higher-education institutions and
label: Paragraph

text: administrative centers (the Administrative Center 1972, by M.Alifanti in Baia Mare is
label: Paragraph

text: considered one of the most valuable works of the period). The Catholic church (1976) by
label: Paragraph

text: 1.Fackelman in Orsova is unique in the whole postwar period.
label: Caption

text: The years following the devastating earthquake of 1977 coincided with the emphasis of
label: Paragraph

text: the totalitarian and nationalistic ideology of the Communist regime. This mutation in the
label: Paragraph

text: official ideology had dramatic consequences for architecture. Although numerous cities
label: Paragraph

text: were affected by rapid degradation because of the demolitions of their historical
label: Paragraph

text: downtowns (increasing the damage caused by the earthquake), the tentative decision to
label: Paragraph

text: rebuild urbanlike villages, according to controlled planning, threatened to destroy the
label: Paragraph

text: environment of traditional life. The architectural structures that replaced the demolished
label: Paragraph

text: edifices, often reorganized as new civic centers, reflected the strict application of the
label: Paragraph

text: regime ideology, resulting in a schematic and simplistic vocabulary. The control over
label: Paragraph

text: architecture harshened, and a reduction in the quality of architecture became evident.
label: Paragraph

text: Official architecture clearly was oriented to a rhetoric of monumentality that was specific
label: Paragraph

text: to dictatorships, the most significant example being the Pharaonic complex of the House
label: Paragraph

text: of the People in Bucharest by Anca Petrescu and collective. This enormous architectural
label: Paragraph

text: complex concentrated the most important part of the state investments, a fact that
label: Paragraph

text: drastically diminished the construction activity, and only a few buildings succeeded in
label: Paragraph

text: escaping the anonymity of a common architecture. This explains why the Postmodernism
label: Paragraph

text: of the 1980s did not produce noteworthy experiments.
label: Paragraph

text: Starting in 1990, after the fall of the Communist regime, Romanian architecture
label: Paragraph

text: entered a new period of intense researches and the rediscovery of former local marks and
label: Paragraph

text: of integration in the contemporaneous international movement. Unlike previous periods,
label: Paragraph

text: Bucharest is no longer the only center of architectural experiments. Several other cities
label: Paragraph

text: have developed such experiences, the most significant example being the city of
label: Paragraph

text: Timisoara for the refined architecture of Serban Sturdza, I. Andreescu and V.
label: Paragraph

text: Gaivoronschi, R. Mihailescu, and others.
label: Paragraph

text: ROME, ITALY
label: Title

text: In the history of the city of Rome, it was not just the Church that appropriated and used
label: Paragraph

text: art and architecture for political or propagandistic purposes. From the city’s annexation to
label: Paragraph

text: the kingdom of Italy in 1870, Rome became a space of contest in which the contrasting
label: Paragraph

text: discourses of the classical Roman Empire, the papacy of a universal Church, and the
label: Paragraph

text: secular Savoyard monarchy were articulated. Such discourses affected and often reshaped
label: Paragraph

text: the urban landscape. One of the best examples is constituted by the Vittorio Emanuele II
label: Paragraph

text: monument (or Vittoriano), built between 1885 and 1911 to honor the memory of the first
label: Paragraph

text: king of united Italy. Some 80 meters high, it irrevocably changed the cityscape, throwing
label: Paragraph

text: out of scale the capitol itself. The architect, Giuseppe Sacconi, winning an international
label: Paragraph

text: competition, employed a dazzling white “bottocino” marble from Brescia that further
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized the monument with respect (or disrespect) to its surroundings. The Vittoriano
label: Paragraph

text: was constructed in the Beaux Arts architectural style, which was popular at the time as
label: Paragraph

text: appropriately “imperial” for urban monuments throughout all the major European
label: Paragraph

text: capitals. Interestingly, both Liberal and Fascist governments between the wars
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized the Vittoriano’s centrality within the city’s space and Italian territory.
label: Paragraph

text: Mussolini in particular used the monument to promote an imperial spatiality through his
label: Paragraph

text: performative rhetoric, which often unfolded while facing the monument in the adjacent
label: Paragraph

text: Piazza Venezia.
label: Caption

text: The advent of Fascism had quite an effect on the architectural history of Rome. In the
label: Paragraph

text: early 1930s, the population of Rome had grown from 244,000 to over a million. The
label: Paragraph

text: practical necessity to provide a modern infrastructure in terms of public transport and
label: Paragraph

text: utilities and to boost the regime’s image in Italy and abroad threatened to put Fascism on
label: Paragraph

text: a conflicting course both with the papacy (some 18 churches and Church buildings were
label: Paragraph

text: destroyed from 1928 to 1939) and with the city’s own classical heritage (many
label: Paragraph

text: archaeological sites were disrupted to build those grand avenues that had to host the
label: Paragraph

text: regime’s parades and other mass events). It soon appeared evident that the key issues of
label: Paragraph

text: planning in the city had to deal with finding a feasible compromise between the
label: Paragraph

text: conflicting double logic of conservation or demolition. It has been convincingly argued
label: Paragraph

text: that the three principal laws that informed Fascist design, architecture, and urban
label: Paragraph

text: planning were the law of health (hygienic reasons were often at the basis of many
label: Paragraph

text: interventions in the city), the law of speed (in the sense of both fast execution and, from a
label: Paragraph

text: futurist perspective, active traffic, Hght, and air), and the Roman law, with its insistence
label: Paragraph

text: on the grandiose in the sense of the imposing and powerful. From Mussolini’s early years
label: Paragraph

text: in power, his ideas on monumental interventions in the city center reflected such laws.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the best examples in this sense is the plan to free the Mausoleo di Augusto (or
label: Paragraph

text: Augusteo). According to the project devised by the architect Vittorio Morpurgo, new
label: Paragraph

text: porticoed buildings of the National Fascist Institute of Social Insurance were to define the
label: Paragraph

text: piazza in which the Mausoleo stands on the north and east sides. A wide street piazza was
label: Paragraph

text: created between the churches of San Girolamo and San Rocco. Moreover, a
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction of the Ara Pacis was located in glazed protective building (an example of
label: Paragraph

text: rationalist architecture in sharp contrast with its classical content) between Via Ripetta
label: Paragraph

text: and il Lungotevere. Quite different from the works around the Augusteo is the EUR
label: Paragraph

text: project (also known as E 42). In this case, the plan was to build a new Rome, a modern
label: Paragraph

text: one but with the same characters of monumentality and universality, on a hilltop five
label: Paragraph

text: miles south of piazza Venezia. The EUR was meant to house the World Exhibition of
label: Paragraph

text: Rome in 1942; thus, the task was to create a city of representation that conjugated the
label: Paragraph

text: scenographic and artistic necessities of a world exhibition with the practicalities of a real
label: Paragraph

text: city. Although the first plan was not extremely original, it must be said that it lacked the
label: Paragraph

text: usual iconography of fasces, eagles, statues, or epigraphs that would come later.
label: Paragraph

text: However, Romanita and modernity, monumentality and rationalist aspirations could not
label: Paragraph

text: coexist, so it happened that the more advanced projects were relegated to the temporary
label: Paragraph

text: exhibitions buildings, whereas the permanent buildings had a neoclassical style. The
label: Paragraph

text: EUR was not completed because of the war; still, what is left proves wrong the
label: Paragraph

text: widespread misconception that after Bernini and Borromini, little of significance was
label: Paragraph

text: built in Rome.
label: Paragraph

text: EUR lies to the south of the city, toward the sea, in an area that had been open
label: Paragraph

text: countryside until only a few years before. The building project was entrusted to the top
label: Paragraph

text: architects of the day, who sought to blend the principles of ancient classical architecture
label: Paragraph

text: with European rationalism. One fine example of this composite style is the Palazzo della
label: Paragraph

text: Civilta del Lavoro, familiarly known as the “square colosseum.” The defining features of
label: Paragraph

text: this original zone are the broad avenues and wide-open squares.
label: Paragraph

text: The Fascist era also saw the building of another major example of this type of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture: the Foro Italico. Formerly named after Mussolini, the Foro Italico is a large
label: Paragraph

text: sports complex that encloses several facilities, including an indoor swimming pool
label: Paragraph

text: decorated with mosaic work. It also contains the Stadio dei Marmi, a stadium encircled
label: Caption

text: by 60 marble statues of athletes donated by towns and cities around the country. A sphere
label: Caption

text: measuring three meters in diameter rests in the forecourt.
label: Caption

text: The Dora zone, completed in 1926, offers a unique example of Roman architectural
label: Paragraph

text: eclecticism from the early years of the 20th century. A large, decorated arch leads rather
label: Paragraph

text: unexpectedly into a remarkable area designed by Gino Coppedé, whose surname provides
label: Paragraph

text: the popular name for the zone. Every building has its own special ornamentation, though
label: Paragraph

text: Art Nouveau and mock-medieval motifs stand out in the rich mix of styles.
label: Paragraph

text: After the war, the Italian architects who had best represented the cause of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture were dead: G.L.Banfi, G. Pagano, E.Persico, and G.Terragni. However, a
label: Paragraph

text: new sensation started influencing Italian culture: that of making contact with reality in a
label: Paragraph

text: new way, seeing reality with new eyes. It was this sensation that gave rise to Neorealism,
label: Paragraph

text: which became widely known thanks to the films of Roberto Rossellini and Vittorio De
label: Paragraph

text: Sica but that influenced the arts and architecture as well. The best example of the latter is
label: Paragraph

text: the architecture of Ridolfi at Terni and the Tiburtino district in Rome in the early 1950s.
label: Paragraph

text: To the design of the Tiburtino district, a sort of manifesto of architectural neorealism,
label: Paragraph

text: C.Aymonino, C.Chiarini, M.Fiorentino. F.Gorio, M.Lanza, S.Lenci, P.Lugli,
label: Caption

text: C.Melograni, G. Menichetti, L.Quaroni, and M.Valori also contributed.
label: Paragraph

text: Neorealism, particularly for the architects of the Roman School (Ridolfi, Quaroni, and
label: Paragraph

text: Fiorentino), is characterized by a concern for everyday reality, a preference for popular
label: Paragraph

text: forms, an interest for one’s immediate environment, and the rejection of any abstraction.
label: Paragraph

text: Such concerns were already evident in the design for the Stazione Termini (1947), the
label: Paragraph

text: new Rome railway station, by Quaroni, Ridolfi, and Fiorentino. Between 1950 and 1954,
label: Caption

text: Ridolfi also designed what was a nucleus of innovative tall houses on the Viale Etiopia,
label: Paragraph

text: the so-called African quarter. In the years between 1954 and 1962, three different plans
label: Paragraph

text: were prepared for Rome while architects were facing a cultural and political debate that
label: Paragraph

text: included the status of a new town-planning discipline and a new legal ruling on building
label: Paragraph

text: land. In the 1962 plan, inspired by Quaroni and Piccinato, a multifunctional axis girdling
label: Paragraph

text: the east zone of the city was due to connect up with the national superhighway system. In
label: Paragraph

text: addition, the plan included the creation of three areas of expansion that would deploy
label: Paragraph

text: some of the functions of the congested city center. Unfortunately, the Rome plan was not
label: Paragraph

text: realized, mainly because of administrative deficiencies.
label: Paragraph

text: For the Olympic Games in 1960, the Palazzo and Palazzetto dello Sport and the
label: Paragraph

text: Flaminio Stadium were built by Vitellozzi and Pier Luigi Nervi; these structures
label: Paragraph

text: combined technological inventions with neomonumental organisms. In the 1960s, the
label: Paragraph

text: EUR came to prominence again by developing into an efficient business district and a
label: Paragraph

text: residential area for the upper-middle class. It became the only real administrative pole of
label: Paragraph

text: the capital at a time when Italy was in the midst of a real economic miracle. Also
label: Paragraph

text: noticeable are the new magistrates’ courts, designed by the Perugini-Monteduro group
label: Paragraph

text: between 1959 and 1969, on Piazzale Clodio; the Vitellozzi’s project (1959-67) for the
label: Paragraph

text: Biblioteca Nazionale at castro Pretorio; the RAI-TV office building (1963-65) on Viale
label: Caption

text: Mazzini by Berbarducci and Fioroni; and Albini’s Rinascente department store in the
label: Paragraph

text: area of Piazza Fiume/Via Veneto. Also worth mentioning is the residential complex
label: Paragraph

text: (1973-82) in Corviale (Rome), which contained new building types and was realized
label: Paragraph

text: with advanced techniques of prefabrication.
label: Paragraph

text: From 1975 to 1984, while Rome had a left-wing administration, there were plans for
label: Paragraph

text: rehabilitating the most derelict districts (borgate), building new public housing, acquiring
label: Paragraph

text: more green space, and recovering historical buildings. The projects implemented after the
label: Paragraph

text: national Roma Capitale law have given rise to 445 projects, mainly relating to road
label: Paragraph

text: improvements and public facilities.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early 1980s, the Italian architect Paolo Portoghesi launched a style that has been
label: Paragraph

text: designated postmodern and is characterized broadly by a taste for citation, pastiche, and
label: Paragraph

text: free association. Portoghesi’s only projects in Rome are the mosque and the cultural
label: Paragraph

text: Islamic center in Via Magnani and the City of Science for the site of the old
label: Caption

text: slaughterhouse in Testaccio.
label: Paragraph

text: The sprawling metropolis that now extends all over the 4gro romano has its roots in
label: Paragraph

text: the idea of a centralized Italian state, and its development as a bureaucratic city has been
label: Paragraph

text: plagued by an army of land speculators and builders. Since its annexation to the kingdom
label: Paragraph

text: of Italy, architects working in Rome have often been caught in an inextricable web of
label: Paragraph

text: bureaucratic and political difficulties. In the past 30 years, the city has changed
label: Paragraph

text: remarkably, yet the contrast between a dominant center and a subaltern periphery is still a
label: Paragraph

text: sharp one. Rome is only recently starting to live up to what is expected of it given its
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional past.

text: ROSSI, ALDO 1931-97
label: Title

text: Architect, Italy
label: Title

text: Aldo Rossi was an influential architect, designer, teacher, and theoretician whose
label: Paragraph

text: works emphasized historical types and memories as poetic elements in architectural
label: Paragraph

text: design. Working primarily in Italy, his later work was designed and constructed for cities
label: Paragraph

text: in the United States, Germany, Argentina, and Japan.
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi’s representations of architecture, from the scale of furniture to that of urbanism,
label: Paragraph

text: were reminiscent of Giorgio de Chirico’s metaphysical paintings and the Enlightenment-
label: Paragraph

text: era projects of Etienne-Louis Boullée. Rossi’s design sketches contain haunting
label: Paragraph

text: irregularities of scale and typology, disciplined and refined in their final construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi’s timeless vocabulary of forms remained relatively constant throughout his career,
label: Paragraph

text: although the scale, material, and functions shift across projects. His works synthesized
label: Paragraph

text: pure repetition, modern space, and remembered forms into a singular vision that he
label: Paragraph

text: named “analogous architecture,” and the frequent return to the questions of cultural
label: Paragraph

text: meaning and signification in architectural forms permeated his writings, images, and
label: Paragraph

text: buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi’s professional education at the Milan Polytechnic brought him into close contact
label: Paragraph

text: with Marxist critical theory and the revolutionary potentials in architecture under the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of Italian Neorealism in the arts. These sources influenced his work as a writer
label: Paragraph

text: and editor of the journal Casabella-Continuita (1961-64). Although his early written and
label: Paragraph

text: built work was sympathetic to the ascetic modernism of the Viennese architect Adolph
label: Paragraph

text: Loos (1870-1933), he moved far from this position in his later career.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1966, Rossi published his influential book on urban theory titled L'Architettura
label: Paragraph

text: della citta (The Architecture of the City). Identifying building typology and urban
label: Paragraph

text: morphology as inseparable and always saturated with history, the city is conceived as a
label: Paragraph

text: political construct. Written from a rationalist perspective indebted to the Enlightenment,
label: Paragraph

text: the text places politicized humanist concerns over the orthodoxy of modernist
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism and forms. Monuments and housing types are saturated with unique social
label: Paragraph

text: and political meanings and cannot be considered purely functionalist forms. This
label: Paragraph

text: reconceptualization of the historically structured meanings of cities operated as the
label: Paragraph

text: foundation for his and others subsequent designs.
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi’s later writings and projects moved from an ascetic architecture of concrete to
label: Paragraph

text: rich metaphoric constructions invoking memories of cities (as fragments). It was a
label: Paragraph

text: progression from ideological concerns to questions of memory and a revival of humanist
label: Title

text: referents, an attempt to recuperate what modern urbanism had eliminated. Rossi’s works
label: Paragraph

text: were a deeply personal examination and reconstruction of architecture’s own history.
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi did not copy or imitate existing models but proposed reduced typological elements
label: Paragraph

text: to allow cultural and personal meanings to be projected into them. Relying on a limited
label: Paragraph

text: number of significant classical types and anonymous vernacular forms that are
label: Paragraph

text: immediately familiar, Rossi’s architecture animated memories of these architectural
label: Paragraph

text: forms to create a strong visual and spatial effect of timelessness.
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi’s architecture communicated simultaneously personal and archetypal concepts,
label: Paragraph

text: much like a visual language. He frequently described this method as “analogous
label: Paragraph

text: architecture,” which he derived from the work of psychologist Carl Jung, who described
label: Paragraph

text: analogous thought as “sensed yet unreal, imagined yet silent...it is archaic, unexpressed,
label: Paragraph

text: and practically inexpressible in words.” Analogous architecture draws on the dialogue
label: Paragraph

text: between the real and representation (as in photography or theater) to communicate
label: Paragraph

text: meaning through nonlinguistic associations, fusing past and present into experience and
label: Paragraph

text: remembering.
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi examined the limits of analogous architecture at a large urban scale in his later
label: Paragraph

text: works and specifically through drawing in the hypothetical designs for an Analogous City
label: Paragraph

text: (1976) and an invited entry to the Roma Interrotta (1977). Given the original segment of
label: Paragraph

text: Nolli’s map of Rome containing the Baths of Caracalla, Rossi proposed a historically
label: Paragraph

text: self-conscious architecture that was to be “borrowed, converted, and invented,” a habitual
label: Paragraph

text: urban strategy examined in his text Scientific Autobiography (1981). In this text, he
label: Paragraph

text: stated, “The construction of a logic of architecture cannot omit the relationship with
label: Paragraph

text: history.”
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi’s design projects originated in a Loosian search for reductive, rational, and
label: Paragraph

text: precise architectural expression but then involved distinct Platonic shapes found in books
label: Paragraph

text: of perspectival drawing and stereometrics. In his many designs for urban spaces, he
label: Paragraph

text: situated autonomous and enigmatic monuments in the voids of public space to make their
label: Paragraph

text: haunting presence and silence obvious. Their timelessness was animated only by cast
label: Paragraph

text: shadows. The competition project (1962) for a Monument to the Resistance in Cuneo,
label: Caption

text: Italy, offers a cube with a slit framing the distant battlegrounds. The built iron bridge
label: Paragraph

text: (1962) for the Milan Triennale and the Monument de la Piazzetta Manzoni (1988-90) in
label: Caption

text: Milan continue to develop this language of concrete form without any scale or material
label: Paragraph

text: references, as if they were childhood memories. The unbuilt Piazza del Municipio (1965)
label: Caption

text: in the Segrate district of Milan appears as a fusion of monument and tomb, the two
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of architecture that Loos identified as belonging to art. These dematerialized but
label: Paragraph

text: visually heavy forms invoke political and historical associations between modernism and
label: Paragraph

text: Fascism as inevitable and fated.
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi’s first built large-scale project, the urban housing project Gallaratese (1969-73)
label: Paragraph

text: in Milan, was a fusion of high-modernist housing typology within an attenuated form
label: Paragraph

text: nostalgic for premodern Milanese urban housing, galleries, or barracks. As a
label: Paragraph

text: representation and inventory of earlier precedents, they are built in the grammar of the
label: Paragraph

text: early monuments and plazas. A relentless repetition of panel-like columns is punctuated
label: Paragraph

text: only by two massive round columns in the center of this arcade, marking a small crevice
label: Paragraph

text: in the form above. These support the undifferentiated flats in an extended linear schema.
label: Paragraph

text: The circulation is arranged as corridors or elevated private streets unseen from the ground
label: Paragraph

text: plane. Each housing unit appears identical, with identical fenestration, and the overall
label: Paragraph

text: stark and simplified result implies that there is no individuality in a social class.
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi completed two schools that evoked a concern with childhood memories through
label: Paragraph

text: his emergent vocabulary. The elementary school (1972-76) at Fagnano Olana, Italy, and
label: Paragraph

text: a secondary school (1979) at Broni, Italy, are both organized around a dominant central
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard containing individualized central elements as in the early plaza designs. The
label: Paragraph

text: public space is defined spatially by a strong perimeter boundary created by the repetition
label: Paragraph

text: of identical classrooms. This classical ordering schema appears in most later projects
label: Paragraph

text: when the functional program contains a diversity of spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: The role of timeless forms and historical memories in architecture is evident in Rossi’s
label: Paragraph

text: competition-winning design for the addition to the Cemetery of San Cataldo (1971-84 in
label: Caption

text: phased construction) in Modena, Italy. Rossi fuses monument and tomb within a larger
label: Paragraph

text: concept of the cemetery as a city of the dead, designed to evoke memories of urban
label: Paragraph

text: conditions through its volumes and plazas. Other funerary architecture is distributed
label: Paragraph

text: axially as diverse object-types through the center space like scaleless volumes or districts.
label: Paragraph

text: The communal graveyard is inside and beneath a cone-shaped form, marking one end of
label: Paragraph

text: the axis. The opposite end holds the shrine to the war dead. This monumental
label: Paragraph

text: metaphysical object is constructed as an orange cube perforated with square openings, its
label: Paragraph

text: insides containing unadorned metal balconies arranged like fire escapes. It is a disturbing
label: Paragraph

text: house of the dead, roofless and windowless. Between these two object-types, more
label: Paragraph

text: ossuaries are arranged in a riblike diminishing pattern of linear construction, forming a
label: Paragraph

text: triangular district articulated as a labyrinth or mandatory path. The cemetery complex
label: Paragraph

text: draws heavily on visual and historical references to history, memory, and death through
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi’s remembered archetypal forms.
label: Paragraph

text: During San Cataldo’s construction, Rossi’s written and drawn works began to attract
label: Paragraph

text: significant international recognition, defining a place for the reemergence of history in
label: Paragraph

text: the postmodern period. Contemporaneous with San Cataldo, Rossi’s architecture began to
label: Paragraph

text: include increasingly differentiated materiality (pattern, color, and textures) and overt
label: Paragraph

text: references to nostalgic memories of historic precedents. Timeless historical types become
label: Paragraph

text: specific to their unique sites and contexts. Rossi’s early interest in cinema and theater
label: Paragraph

text: became a dominant analogy in the theoretical and urban projects that followed.
label: Paragraph

text: The Teatro del Mondo (Theater of the World), created for the Venice Biennale (1979),
label: Paragraph

text: was a floating pavilion enclosing a centralized theater space. The steel frame of its
label: Paragraph

text: octagonal wood form was welded to a functioning barge that traveled the seas of Italy,
label: Paragraph

text: creating a transitory object that combined building, barge, and folly. Its echoes of
label: Paragraph

text: historical theaters in the round and its toylike appearance showcased Rossi’s personal
label: Paragraph

text: rediscovery of the Renaissance relationship between theater and architecture, first
label: Paragraph

text: explored in his furniture-size theoretical project the Little Scientific Theater (1978). In
label: Paragraph

text: the Carlo Felice Theater (1983-89) in Genoa, Italy, a unique historical precedent became
label: Paragraph

text: the site of construction for “civil architecture.” Barbarino’s prior neoclassical theater
label: Paragraph

text: facing the ducal palace was reborn as a large, 2000-seat balconied theater. A chimney-
label: Paragraph

text: ike cone, used in earlier projects, distributes light by penetrating through the internal
label: Paragraph

text: public spaces. A stone-clad tower block rises above the theater, and the entrance to the
label: Paragraph

text: theater acts as a filter between city and spectacle.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1981, Rossi submitted the winning housing scheme for the international design
label: Paragraph

text: competition for urban renewal in the former West Berlin (IBA). Finished in 1988, the
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter-block housing project exhibits a wide range of materials and scale. Although
label: Paragraph

text: housing is supported by an arcade as in Gallaratese, the vertical circulation towers facing
label: Paragraph

text: the interior courtyard, pitched spires over elevators, and gridded glass facades between
label: Paragraph

text: masonry housing blocks materially differentiate each element of the project, creating the
label: Paragraph

text: impression of linkages between identical small buildings. Only the oversize columns at
label: Paragraph

text: both ends of the project recall his earlier works. Other works in Berlin included the
label: Paragraph

text: smaller apartment building (1983) in Berlin-Tiergarten on Rauchstrasse and an unbuilt
label: Paragraph

text: competition design (1978) for the Museum of German History.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1980s, Rossi turned his methodology toward commercial institutions within
label: Paragraph

text: urban contexts. The Commercial Center of Fontivegge (1982-89) in Perugia, Italy, is a
label: Paragraph

text: U-shaped complex of shops and offices framing a multistory house form on exaggerated
label: Paragraph

text: piers. The Commercial Center “Centro Torri” (1985-88) in Parma, Italy, adopts the
label: Paragraph

text: typology of Renaissance market stalls to recuperate commerce as “the center of human
label: Paragraph

text: life.” Ten brick towers mark the dominant central arcade that holds the stores together.
label: Paragraph

text: The office building (1984) for Officine GFT in Turin and the unbuilt Edificio Techint
label: Caption

text: (1984) in Buenos Aires, Argentina, turned back from normative modernism to three-
label: Paragraph

text: dimensional assemblages of historical elements. In 1989, the Il Palazzo Hotel and
label: Paragraph

text: Restaurant Complex in Fukuoka, Japan, drew on Roman construction forms, presenting a
label: Paragraph

text: blank public facade of travertine with exquisitely detailed, disengaged columns separated
label: Caption

text: by iron banding at each floor level. Constructed on a raised public plaza, this project
label: Caption

text: translates premodern urban gestures into a frenetic high-tech context, offering the
label: Paragraph

text: qualities of serenity, silence, and eternity that Rossi pursued in all his works.
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi’s earliest passions and vocabulary remained a constant referent throughout his
label: Paragraph

text: career, reemerging and slowly transforming into more sophisticated compositions, all
label: Paragraph

text: with increasing sensitivity to materiality and related connections. Virtually every project
label: Paragraph

text: can be read as an examination of the historical essence of architectural form and an
label: Paragraph

text: interrogation of the city as a historical force. His highly personal approach placed the
label: Paragraph

text: human condition at the conceptual and physical center of the works, and by offering
label: Paragraph

text: unique memories of historical forms, he created an architecture that invites the projection
label: Paragraph

text: of individual meanings on the constructed forms. His widely disseminated writings,
label: Paragraph

text: drawings, and buildings encouraged the turn away from dehistoricized modern urbanism
label: Paragraph

text: in Europe and elsewhere.
label: Paragraph

text: ROTTERDAM, THE NETHERLANDS
label: Title

text: Descriptions of Rotterdam, in the province of South Holland, abound in quantitative
label: Paragraph

text: superlatives: the world’s largest port, Europe’s densest metropolis (more than 4,000
label: Paragraph

text: people per square kilometer), one of the country’s most industrialized areas, the Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: town most grievously destroyed during the German occupation of 1940-1945, and also
label: Paragraph

text: the tallest, boasting many more skyscrapers than any other city in the Netherlands.
label: Paragraph

text: Moreover, even in a country renowned for creating itself from land won from the sea,
label: Paragraph

text: Rotterdam stands out, aggressively reclaiming portions of Maasviakte (Maas Flats; the
label: Paragraph

text: Maas is the major river) for its expanding terminals, chemical plants, and petroleum
label: Paragraph

text: refineries as well as for satellite towns. A thoroughly 20th-century city in which
label: Paragraph

text: remarkably few buildings from previous periods survive, Rotterdam enters the new
label: Paragraph

text: millennium with a vigorous architectural and urbanistic growth that bids fair to surpass
label: Paragraph

text: other Dutch contenders.
label: Paragraph

text: The population of almost 600,000 (more than 1 million live in adjacent municipalities}
label: Paragraph

text: makes Rotterdam second in size only to Amsterdam (c.728,000), and comparisons are
label: Paragraph

text: instructive no less than inevitable. Both were chartered in the early 1300s on sites that
label: Paragraph

text: began as a dam on a river (the Rotte and the Amstel, respectively), but thereafter their
label: Paragraph

text: fortunes diverged. Amsterdam rose to power in the Golden Age of the 17th century;
label: Paragraph

text: Rotterdam, based more exclusively on shipping-related activities, began its economic
label: Paragraph

text: challenge only after 1872, when the opening of the New Waterway (Nieuwe Waterweg),
label: Paragraph

text: which connected the port city directly with the North Sea, set it on the path to eventual
label: Paragraph

text: maritime dominance. Urbanistically Rotterdam followed at a somewhat later date a
label: Paragraph

text: trajectory similar to Amsterdam’s: the late 19th century brought severe overcrowding in
label: Paragraph

text: the inner city, unplanned speculative growth on the outskirts, and the gradual adoption of
label: Paragraph

text: municipal codes and extension plans to counter these problems. Although both cities are
label: Paragraph

text: water-girt, Rotterdam’s aqueous bodies are larger and more intrusive; instead of
label: Paragraph

text: picturesque canals, it offers major rivers and harbors spanned by imposing bridges very
label: Paragraph

text: different in size from those of Amsterdam. Although Amsterdam’s new construction is
label: Paragraph

text: mainly outside the inner city, Rotterdam’s heart is one huge construction site constantly
label: Paragraph

text: in transition. That makes it dynamic if a bit unsettling, oriented to the future with little
label: Paragraph

text: fidelity to the past. Rotterdam has also been more hospitable to foreign firms: Marcel
label: Paragraph

text: Breuer (De Bijenkorf Department Store, 1955-57, with Dutchman A. Elzas), and
label: Paragraph

text: Skidmore, Owings and Merrill (the three Europoint 24-story towers, 1971-75) have
label: Paragraph

text: worked there, and in the 1990s it has been the first to welcome such international figures
label: Paragraph

text: as Norman Foster, Renzo Piano, and Helmut Jahn.
label: Paragraph

text: Architecturally the contrast was noted already in 1923, in the oft-quoted letter by Erich
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn describing Rotterdam as analytic in danger from the deadly chill in its veins
label: Paragraph

text: and Amsterdam as visionary, threatened by the fire of its own dynamism. The claim may
label: Paragraph

text: be somewhat exaggerated, but its basic premise about the distinct characters of each city
label: Paragraph

text: touches on a truth that has obtained throughout much of the century. Rotterdam was the
label: Paragraph

text: stronghold of Dutch functionalism, the Nieuwe Bouwen, which exalted usefulness over
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetics. Until recently, its major monuments were almost exclusively for practical
label: Paragraph

text: ends—housing, commercial, and industrial structures rather than cultural buildings—and
label: Paragraph

text: the stunning elegance that several attained was a byproduct of efficiency and economy;
label: Paragraph

text: speed and size took precedence over beauty.
label: Paragraph

text: During the fin-de-siécle, Rotterdam was overshadowed artistically by The Hague, its
label: Paragraph

text: near neighbor and the seat of government, and followed it in favoring the Franco-Belgian
label: Paragraph

text: variant of the Art Nouveau, unlike Amsterdam, where the more sober, indigenous, and
label: Paragraph

text: enduring version of Niewwe Kunst prevailed. The major work during this period is the
label: Paragraph

text: Witte Huis of 1897-98 (one of the few buildings in the center to have survived the
label: Paragraph

text: firebombing), the first Dutch, indeed European, skyscraper. Designed by W.Molenbroek,
label: Paragraph

text: the mansard-roofed, 138-foot-high, 11-story office building with load-bearing walls of
label: Caption

text: stone and white brick was prophetic of Rotterdam’s future as the dominant skyscraper
label: Paragraph

text: city of the Netherlands. Henry Hobson Ricardson’s work (one of its stylistic influences)
label: Paragraph

text: was familiar in Holland through the teachings of H.P.Berlage, who, regrettably, found
label: Paragraph

text: few opportunities in Rotterdam. A workers cooperative (1906-07) and an insurance
label: Paragraph

text: company (1911; destroyed) were his only executed works; his grand redesigns of the
label: Paragraph

text: Hofplein square (1921 and 1926), commissioned by the municipality, were rejected. The
label: Paragraph

text: most conspicuous public building of the first two decades was the neo-Northern
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance Town Hall by Henri Evers (1855-1929), professor at Rotterdam’s Academy
label: Caption

text: of Fine Arts and Technical Sciences from 1887-1902. Subject of an invited competition
label: Paragraph

text: of 1912, the choice of Evers’s ecclectic design, an anachronism before it was completed
label: Paragraph

text: in 1920, indicated the city’s conservatism, for it might have chosen the much more
label: Paragraph

text: original entry by Willem Kromhout (1864-1940).
label: Caption

text: Kromhout, whose work was akin to Berlage’s but more playful and exotic, left a
label: Paragraph

text: distinguished career in Amsterdam as architectural leader and teacher to move in 1910 to
label: Paragraph

text: Rotterdam to teach at the academy and reestablish his practice. If earlier he had inspired
label: Paragraph

text: the Amsterdam School, now among his students were future leaders of the Mieuwe
label: Paragraph

text: Bouwen such as J.J.P.Oud, Cor van Eesteren, and Leendert van der Vlugt. Kromhout’s
label: Paragraph

text: own free style retained allusions to architecture from the early Christian, Byzantine, and
label: Paragraph

text: medieval periods laced with Arabic and Art Nouveau motifs, the whole transformed by a
label: Paragraph

text: unique imagery that expressed the individual program.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1920 Kromhout, who had been president of the Amsterdam club, Architectura et
label: Paragraph

text: Amicitia, was instrumental in founding, with Michiel Brinkman (1873-1925), a new
label: Paragraph

text: association, De Opbouw, dedicated to architectural debate. It would attract various
label: Paragraph

text: factions, including representatives of De Stijl, theosophists (the universalist philosophy
label: Paragraph

text: popular with many Dutch cultural leaders), and dedicated functionalists, who brought in
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde architects from Germany and the Soviet Union and rejected the aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: priorities of other members, in part as a response to the urgent task facing architects and
label: Paragraph

text: city officials—creating inexpensive housing.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1916 Rotterdam established a Municipal Housing Service, which embarked on
label: Paragraph

text: constructing extensive new residential quarters outside the center. Among the most
label: Paragraph

text: acclaimed are the blocks (1919-21) by Brinkman on Justus van Effenstraat in Spangen, a
label: Caption

text: new worker’s neighborhood, which provide housing for 270 families and community
label: Paragraph

text: facilities—a bathhouse, a laundry, and a children’s play space—in the generously sized
label: Paragraph

text: interior courtyards. The first two stories are composed of flats; those at ground level have
label: Paragraph

text: modest private gardens. Portals provide access to the interior terrain where the entries to
label: Paragraph

text: most of the dwellings are located. Comprising the top two stories are maisonettes, the
label: Paragraph

text: doors of which open onto a continuous gallery wide enough to permit delivery vans and
label: Paragraph

text: provide exercise space for children.
label: Paragraph

text: Spangen also is home to the first municipal housing by Oud, city architect from 1918—
label: Paragraph

text: 1933; | & V (1918-20), and VIII & IX (1919-20). These necessarily sober brick
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter blocks are enlivened by abstract sculptural effects at the corners and over
label: Paragraph

text: entryways and windows, which reveal, however tenuously, the impact of De Stijl, to
label: Paragraph

text: which Oud briefly belonged but felt obliged to leave when he took the municipal job,
label: Paragraph

text: believing that social projects precluded its formal tactics. More obviously indebted to that
label: Paragraph

text: movement was the red, yellow, and blue temporary superintendent’s office of 1923
label: Paragraph

text: (recently reconstructed) belonging to the Witte Dorp (white village) in Oud-Mathenesse,
label: Paragraph

text: another worker’s quarter. The modest one-and-a-half story row houses, intended as
label: Paragraph

text: semipermanent, remained in use until the 1990s. Oud’s most mature housing project in
label: Paragraph

text: Rotterdam, Kiefhoek (1925-29), is a canonical example of the International Style, with
label: Paragraph

text: its continuous strip windows and taut, whitestuccoed surfaces.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most justly celebrated examples of the Niewwe Bouwen is the Van Nelle
label: Paragraph

text: Factory and Administration Building, by Johannes Andreas Brinkman (1902-1949) and
label: Caption

text: L.C. van der Vlugt (1894-1936) assisted by Mart Stam. The architects exploited all the
label: Paragraph

text: possibilities of transparency and dynamic movement in this interconnected complex in
label: Paragraph

text: which each of the varied functions is signaled by the contrasts of curved with rectilinear
label: Paragraph

text: volumes, and rendered stucco planes with large sheets of glass. The structure, which
label: Paragraph

text: includes novel mushroom-shaped columns, and the skin are skillfully distinguished in the
label: Paragraph

text: prescribed manner of the International Style.
label: Paragraph

text: Another functionalist active chiefly in Rotterdam is Willem van Tijen (1894-1974),
label: Paragraph

text: who shares responsibility—and fame—for two groundbreaking blocks of flats:
label: Paragraph

text: Bergpolder (1932-34) and Plaslaan (1937-38), the former in association with Brinkman
label: Paragraph

text: and Van der Vlugt, the latter with H.A.Maaskant (1907-77), who became his partner in
label: Paragraph

text: 937. Both were erected at the behest of the company NV Volkswoningbouw Rotterdam,
label: Caption

text: established on the initiative of the municipal planner, A.Plate, to experiment with new
label: Paragraph

text: construction techniques. Each stands discretely in a parklike setting, reflecting the tenets
label: Paragraph

text: of Congrés Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne (CIAM), which was very influential
label: Paragraph

text: in Dutch planning circles and was headed from 1930 to 1947 by Van Eesteren.
label: Paragraph

text: Bergpolder, the first high-rise housing slab in the Netherlands, has balconies facing west
label: Paragraph

text: and, on the eastern side, a gallery at each of its nine levels. The steel skeleton was
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed with numerous prefabricated elements, still a rarity in the Netherlands at the
label: Paragraph

text: time. The ten-story Plaslaan has a concrete frame and is more luxurious, with larger flats
label: Paragraph

text: for the middle class. Orientation is reversed for views; the galleries are on the west. It has
label: Paragraph

text: a roof terrace and at ground floor a laundry space, the concierge’s dwelling, a few guest
label: Paragraph

text: rooms, a shop, and storage space.

label: Title

text: Represented also in Rotterdam is the most conservative movement in the Netherlands, the
label: Paragraph

text: Delft School, comprised mainly of Roman Catholics and nationalists who believed in
label: Paragraph

text: building according to the timeless Dutch tradition of loadbearing brick. The garden
label: Paragraph

text: village Vreewijk, by Marinus Granpré Moliére (1883-1972), with its pitched-roofed low-
label: Paragraph

text: rise row houses is a significant example. So is the Museum Boymans-Van Beuningen of
label: Paragraph

text: 1928-35, by A. van der Steur (1893-1953), city architect from 1931-39, who adapted the
label: Paragraph

text: round arches and brick-and-stone vernacular worshipped by this school to the rare
label: Paragraph

text: institutional building found in Rotterdam in this period. Yet a third way appeared in the
label: Paragraph

text: singular architecture of Rotterdam native (and from 1915 to 1959 designer in various
label: Paragraph

text: capacities for the National Dutch Railways), Sybold van Ravesteyn (1889-1983), who in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1930s abandoned the functionalist route to introduce baroque themes and moderne
label: Paragraph

text: decoration, as demonstrated in his various stations in Rotterdam (Beurs, Delftse Poort,
label: Paragraph

text: and Feyenoord, 1934—37) and elsewhere and in the delightful Blijdorp Zoo (1937-41). In
label: Paragraph

text: 1957, after many alterations from his first proposals of 1941, Van Rayestevn’s Central
label: Paragraph

text: Station for Rotterdam was completed.
label: Paragraph

text: On 14 May 1940, to force the Netherlands to capitulate, Nazi planes made a terrifying
label: Paragraph

text: example of Rotterdam’s inner city. Reconstruction after 1945 was as pedestrian as it was
label: Paragraph

text: expedient, in part because of the attempt by municipal and national planners to negotiate
label: Paragraph

text: a compromise between modern functionalists and the Delft School. One thoroughly
label: Paragraph

text: functionalist project to receive international approbation was De Lijnbaan (1949-53),
label: Paragraph

text: arguably the first car-free shopping precinct in the modern world. What made it
label: Paragraph

text: particularly successful was its mixture of boutiques, offices, and housing, each in its own
label: Paragraph

text: container (i.e., functions were combined not in a single building but in a single urban
label: Paragraph

text: district). The two-story rows of shops are accessed on the front from pedestrian streets,
label: Paragraph

text: with deliveries made in the rear via service streets that also serve the blocks of flats and
label: Paragraph

text: offices behind. The concrete frame that structures the shops allows internal flexibility
label: Paragraph

text: according to the needs of each retailer. Kiosks, plantings, and handsome paving
label: Paragraph

text: articulating the module that governs the proportions are palliatives to the rather bland
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The apartments are by H.Maaskant and others, the shopping center by the
label: Paragraph

text: firm of Van den Broek (J.H.; 1898-1978) and J.B.Bakema (1914-1981), which garnered
label: Paragraph

text: innumerable commissions, and not just in Rotterdam, in the sixties and seventies.
label: Paragraph

text: Rotterdam has continued to expand its boundaries to create huge housing districts on
label: Paragraph

text: the periphery. In 1974 the city again embarked on an aggressive policy of renewal, which
label: Paragraph

text: as well as restoration of existing areas included new construction like the 549-unit
label: Paragraph

text: superblock by Carel Weeber (b.1937), De Peperklip (1978-82), named for its unusual
label: Paragraph

text: footprint. Its multicolored, tile-faced, prefabricated concrete panels acknowledge the
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch fondness for polychromy, and its mix of apartment types is heir to the spatial
label: Paragraph

text: ingenuity frequently encountered in this densely populated land. Exciting new
label: Paragraph

text: developments are occurring as well on the Southern Tip, which besides housing includes
label: Paragraph

text: commercial and government buildings such as Cees Dam’s Central Tax Bureau and
label: Paragraph

text: Wilhelmina Tower (1997-99), their strong cubic, curving and prow-shaped volumes
label: Paragraph

text: boldly contrasting with each other.
label: Paragraph

text: A healthy shift began in the later ‘80s when institutional structures took their place
label: Paragraph

text: beside the more practical building types. In the Rotterdam Schowburg (theater; 1982-88),
label: Paragraph

text: Wim Quist (b. 1930) was asked by the municipality to provide for a complex program
label: Paragraph

text: including opera, ballet, and different kinds of theatrical performances; it is a serious and
label: Paragraph

text: sober building with an intricately sectioned interior that respects the functionalist
label: Paragraph

text: tradition. More striking and lucid are the Deconstructivist Kunsthal (1988-92) by Rem
label: Paragraph

text: Koolhaas and the Office of Metropolitan Architecture, and the Erasmus Bridge (1990-
label: Caption

text: 96) by UN Studio, headed by Ben van Berkel (b. 1957). Affectionately dubbed the baby-
label: Paragraph

text: blue Monster, the 139-meter concrete and metal sky-colored bridge that spans 800 meters
label: Paragraph

text: over the Maas challenges the skyscrapers in height and functions simultaneously as a
label: Paragraph

text: thoroughfare for cars, cycles, pedestrians, and trams and as urban stage, lighted at night
label: Paragraph

text: to reveal the dematerialized reflection of its daytime self.
label: Paragraph

text: Rotterdam’s architectural position has been ratified by the fact that it now is the home
label: Paragraph

text: of two prime institutions, both of which have moved from Amsterdam: first the
label: Paragraph

text: Netherlands Architectural Institute (NAi), which in 1995 was installed in its remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: polychrome and polytextured intertwined series of buildings by Jo Coenen (b. 1949), and
label: Paragraph

text: the Berlage Institute, an internationally recognized educational facility established in
label: Paragraph

text: 1990, that in 2000 relocated to the former bank building at Botersloot 25 (1951) by Oud.
label: Paragraph

text: Further, Rotterdam takes pride in the fact that it resembles a giant construction site that is
label: Paragraph

text: never fixed in place. It has embraced with unparalleled enthusiasm the new pluralism
label: Paragraph

text: manifest during the last decade of the 20th century and, as European Design City of
label: Paragraph

text: 2001, is determined to retain its uniqueness in the new millennium.

text: ROW HOUSE
label: Title

text: The row house, also known as a town house in the United States or a terrace house in
label: Paragraph

text: England, is a ubiquitous feature of Western urban landscapes. It is defined as one unit of
label: Paragraph

text: a series of attached houses that shares at least one common wall with its neighbor. The
label: Paragraph

text: traditional urban row house front is parallel to the street and shares sidewalls with its
label: Paragraph

text: neighbors, giving it a narrow, rectangular footprint and only two facades. Generally, it is
label: Paragraph

text: one or two rooms wide but varies in depth and height.
label: Paragraph

text: Certain features of the row house are timeless. It has housed the entire socioeconomic
label: Paragraph

text: spectrum and thus ranges from luxurious in size and appointments to small and
label: Paragraph

text: functional. Although it remained essentially a static, relatively rigid form until this past
label: Paragraph

text: century, it has been affected by changes in architectural styles and societal needs in ways
label: Paragraph

text: similar to freestanding homes. It is cheaper to build and easier to maintain, and its street
label: Paragraph

text: access keeps residents attuned to their neighborhood. Its efficient land use and sense of
label: Paragraph

text: private space make it an attractive alternative to higher-density apartment blocks. It has
label: Paragraph

text: consistently fought the idea that attached housing is less desirable than freestanding
label: Paragraph

text: housing and in the final decades of the 20th century has experienced a renaissance as a
label: Paragraph

text: solution to many housing issues in historic and newly developing cities around the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Formerly, row houses were built by individual owners or in groups by small-scale
label: Paragraph

text: speculators. Twentieth-century row houses, however, were most commonly built in entire
label: Paragraph

text: blocks or complexes by developers who included community facilities as part of the
label: Paragraph

text: complex. Row houses were designed not as individual entities but as component parts of
label: Paragraph

text: a larger whole and were seen in relation to the community at large. Despite this emphasis
label: Paragraph

text: on the whole, market-driven builders still attempted to make attached houses
label: Paragraph

text: individualized and private by varying the facades, building materials, floor plans, and
label: Paragraph

text: home sizes from unit to unit and minimizing intrusions from neighbors. There was
label: Paragraph

text: increased attention to row house surroundings as well. It became universal to provide
label: Paragraph

text: each unit with private outdoor living spaces, such as patios, balconies, and gardens, and
label: Paragraph

text: landscaping became a crucial part of town house design. Access to services and private
label: Paragraph

text: garages was provided by alleys linked to the urban street grid.
label: Paragraph

text: The form of the 20th-century row house had infinite variations defined by local or
label: Paragraph

text: regional preferences or characterized by broader architectural design trends. Those built
label: Paragraph

text: as urban in-fill often attempted to blend in by echoing older houses in scale, materials,
label: Paragraph

text: and orientation, but architects emphasized individuality by varying the facades or
label: Paragraph

text: staggering the houses by height or setback. As many were built in suburban areas, the
label: Paragraph

text: row house form was liberated in these more expansive settings from the gridlike plots of
label: Paragraph

text: city streets. Traditional straight rows continued, but circles, clusters, steps, and curves
label: Paragraph

text: were common as well. Groups of houses were often designed to follow the topography of
label: Paragraph

text: their location, rising up hillsides or curving along a shoreline, as seen in San Francisco or
label: Paragraph

text: Miami. The shape of each house unit itself varied widely, from a plain gabled block to
label: Paragraph

text: such extremes as a trapezoid or even a tilted cube, as in Piet Blom’s Pole Houses (1978—
label: Paragraph

text: 84) near Rotterdam. The widespread adoption of central heating and electricity enabled
label: Paragraph

text: open floor plans designed to meet the needs of different populations. Interior space was
label: Paragraph

text: greatly expanded by the use of split-level floor plans. Large windows and glass walls
label: Caption

text: brought in more air and light than ever before. Another universal change was the addition
label: Paragraph

text: of the garage, as convenient parking was a much-desired amenity after the automobile
label: Paragraph

text: was made affordable to the middle classes. Initially, the garage was tucked under or
label: Paragraph

text: behind the house, but more recently it has become part of the ground-level facade. In
label: Paragraph

text: terms of style, eclecticism was mixed with pure form; 20th-century row houses expressed
label: Paragraph

text: all the major architectural trends of the century and admixtures thereof and were designed
label: Paragraph

text: by idealistic architects and profit-minded developers alike.
label: Paragraph

text: Twentieth-century changes in society and land use have had an immeasurable impact
label: Paragraph

text: on the row house, which diverged dramatically from its constricted plan and adapted
label: Paragraph

text: itself to both city and suburban lifestyles with astonishing flexibility. Initially, its popular
label: Paragraph

text: image was negative, as older row house neighborhoods became slums and the attached
label: Paragraph

text: house seemed to connote an undesirable ethic. The vast spread of suburbs and commuter
label: Paragraph

text: culture led to the building of millions of detached homes across the countryside while
label: Paragraph

text: row houses were left behind in the cities to deteriorate. Although innovative row house
label: Paragraph

text: designs were explored in prewar Europe and working-class row houses were still built in
label: Paragraph

text: growing cities, the form was obsolete elsewhere. Urban-renewal efforts in the 1960s led
label: Paragraph

text: to the razing of entire row house neighborhoods in favor of high-rise public housing, seen
label: Paragraph

text: as the best way to house the inner-city poor. By the 1980s, however, social reformers
label: Paragraph

text: concluded that this housing type bred crime, misery, and a sense of isolation, and soon
label: Paragraph

text: many cities began tearing down the high-rise projects and replacing them with new row
label: Paragraph

text: houses.
label: Paragraph

text: The rediscovery of the row house was not limited to public housing, however. By the
label: Paragraph

text: 1970s, faced with environmental conservation efforts and rising land costs, developers
label: Paragraph

text: began to reconsider town houses as a commercially viable option. The row house lent
label: Paragraph

text: itself nicely to the concept of a condominium development, which gave it a more upscale
label: Paragraph

text: image, and increasing concerns about sprawl have made town house communities a
label: Paragraph

text: popular option. Greater appreciation of historic town houses has added to the appeal of
label: Paragraph

text: new ones. Vacation homes have become another force behind the row house revival, as
label: Paragraph

text: many resort developments were restricted in size because of land conservation and
label: Paragraph

text: higher-density attached housing was needed to shelter increasing numbers of vacationers.
label: Paragraph

text: Finally, changes in the traditional family unit also supported town house developments,
label: Paragraph

text: with increasing numbers of single people, divorced parents, childless couples, and
label: Paragraph

text: retirees seeking smaller-sized homes. For many members of these groups, a row house
label: Paragraph

text: fulfills the need for one’s own house and garden while providing certain amenities not
label: Paragraph

text: found in a detached home. Increased security, decreased maintenance, lower costs, and a
label: Paragraph

text: feeling of community among neighbors are common motivations. Many architects
label: Paragraph

text: designed successful town house communities by targeting these demographic groups,
label: Paragraph

text: adapting the once-inflexible row house to meet highly specific needs.
label: Paragraph
