text: ROWE, COLIN 1920-99
label: Title

text: Architecture historian and critic, England
label: Title

text: Colin Frederick Rowe was born in 1920 in Rotherham, Yorkshire. He studied
label: Paragraph

text: architecture at the Liverpool School of Architecture and wrote a thesis on the
label: Paragraph

text: unpublished drawings of Inigo Jones under Rudolf Wittkower at the Warburg Institute.
label: Caption

text: His studies with Rudolf Wittkower led to his coming into a Palladian inheritance, but his
label: Paragraph

text: fascination with Palladio was not that of an art historian but that of an architect who saw
label: Paragraph

text: in Palladio’s use of harmonic proportions a series of clues that could be exploited to
label: Paragraph

text: imbue all plans with intellectual qualities.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1951, Rowe was awarded a Fulbright Scholarship for study in the United States and
label: Paragraph

text: at Yale University was able to work with Henry Russell Hitchcock. Hitchcock raised his
label: Paragraph

text: interest in the transformations by which modernism developed out of 19th-century
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. He also communicated his enthusiasm for walking in the city, whether it
label: Paragraph

text: was New York or London, examining the evidence as it presented itself to the eye. This
label: Paragraph

text: immediacy had a lot to do with Rowe’s appeal, and it is also represented in both his
label: Paragraph

text: writing and his lecturing style, which tended toward the conversational.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1952 and 1953, Rowe traveled in the United States and worked in Vancouver
label: Paragraph

text: with Sharp, Thompson, Berwick and Pratt on the Blue Cross Building and on Bakersfield
label: Caption

text: Junior College in Los Angeles; he also traveled in Mexico and between 1953 and 1956
label: Paragraph

text: was at the University of Texas, Austin, where he taught for five semesters, collaborating
label: Paragraph

text: with the design teacher Bernhard Hoesli and creating an entirely new framework for
label: Paragraph

text: teaching architectural design. His brief intervention at Austin created the legend of the
label: Paragraph

text: Texas Rangers, a band of teachers who saw a way of teaching modernity consistent with
label: Paragraph

text: traditional architectural principles.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1958 and 1962, Rowe was a lecturer at Cambridge University. There, Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Eisenman fell under his spell and was induced to study Terragni closely and to become
label: Paragraph

text: interested in Italian mannerism. Rowe’s enthusiasm for the inherent contradictions that
label: Paragraph

text: made Italian mannerism, allied to frequent trips to Italy, created something of a legend,
label: Paragraph

text: and when he came to inhabit the Palazzo Massimi during a spell running the Rome
label: Paragraph

text: program of Cornell University, it seemed perfectly appropriate, a personal apotheosis.
label: Paragraph

text: From 1962, Rowe was professor of architecture at Cornell, took up residence in Ithaca,
label: Paragraph

text: and remained there as a teacher until his retirement. Under his influence, a whole
label: Paragraph

text: generation of students at Cornell learned about the social nature of city space, well before
label: Paragraph

text: it became a new orthodoxy, the inspiration for New Urbanism. For example, in the
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan Project of 1966, organized by Peter Eisenman’s Institute for Architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: Urban Studies, Rowe suggested that the city would be better approached not as a series of
label: Paragraph

text: individual object buildings but as a basic ground—the city fabric—like a field of standing
label: Paragraph

text: com waiting to have spaces made in it. His approach was undoubtedly influenced by his
label: Paragraph

text: experience of Italian cities, where the still-vital tradition of the passagiatta continued to
label: Paragraph

text: represent the popular appeal of city space. This acute sense of the space as social
label: Paragraph

text: conferred on Rowe’s whole view of architecture an important freedom from the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional art-historical approach.
label: Paragraph

text: It was Rowe’s peculiar virtue to imbue the present moment of creation with an
label: Paragraph

text: excitement derived from past moments of creation, and students were often sent to the
label: Paragraph

text: library to check out the plan of a Palladian villa before drawing up their plan for a
label: Paragraph

text: secondary school. In his very personal method of analyzing architecture as a sourcebook
label: Paragraph

text: of new ideas, Rowe imbued Le Corbusier with a style that he hardly deserved. By the
label: Paragraph

text: same token, architecture of any period could be scrutinized for its potential as idea. He
label: Paragraph

text: never lost his sense of architecture as a unique form of mental activity: a story of how
label: Paragraph

text: thought and feeling can imprint themselves on inert material. Without adopting any
label: Paragraph

text: fashionable theory, he drew attention to the psychological dimension in architectural
label: Paragraph

text: form, and without ever managing his career, he conveyed possibilities that have changed
label: Paragraph

text: the course of architecture in England and in America.
label: Paragraph

text: Rowe was attracted by the openness of American society (he became an American
label: Paragraph

text: citizen in 1984) and by the extraordinary effect that this freer horizon had on architectural
label: Paragraph

text: models imported from Europe. During his five semesters at the University of Texas,
label: Paragraph

text: Austin, he not only revolutionized the teaching of architectural design by bringing in
label: Paragraph

text: European models but also alerted Americans to their own heritage by his praise for the
label: Paragraph

text: city of Lockhart and generally by pointing to the continuity in the American revitalization
label: Paragraph

text: of the classical and the dynamic quality of American settlements.
label: Paragraph

text: Rowe’s life as a scholar was bent on the discoveries that come only through close
label: Paragraph

text: reading. A master of hermeneutics, he was not intimidated by cultural studies and
label: Paragraph

text: preferred to ignore “the whole semiology thing.” His first essay, “The Mathematics of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ideal Villa” (Architectural Review, 1947), remains in some ways his best, but all his
label: Paragraph

text: writing was tremendous in showing how modern architecture, just as clearly as classical
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, can be understood through the subtleties of form that it employs. In this
label: Paragraph

text: way, he established a crucial continuity in architectural culture.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1981, Rowe was awarded the American Institute of Architects’ Topaz Award for
label: Paragraph

text: services to teaching. In 1985, he was awarded the Andrew Dickson White Professorship
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture at Cornell and became emeritus in 1990. After retirement, he resided for a
label: Paragraph

text: time in London, bemoaning the death of James Stirling, whose “education” he had
label: Paragraph

text: intended to complete. Bereft of old friends, he returned to Washington. In 1995, he
label: Paragraph

text: received the Royal Institute of British Architect’s Gold Medal. His books include The
label: Paragraph

text: Mathematics of the Ideal Villa, and Other Essays (1976), Collage City (1978, with Fred
label: Caption

text: Koetter), The Architecture of Good Intentions (1994), and As 1 Was Saying (three
label: Paragraph

text: volumes, 1996). He died in 1999 in Washington, DC.
label: Paragraph

text: ARCHITECTS (RIBA)
label: Title

text: The Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA) began its life in 1834 under the name
label: Paragraph

text: “Institute of British Architects.” After a Royal Charter was obtained from William IV in
label: Paragraph

text: 1837, the term “Royal” was added, and the purpose of the RIBA was clearly expressed:
label: Paragraph

text: “(for) the general advancement of Civil Architecture and for promoting and facilitating
label: Paragraph

text: the acquirement of the knowledge of the various Arts and Sciences connected therewith.”
label: Paragraph

text: During the period from 1834 to 1900, most of the structure and workings of the 20th-
label: Paragraph

text: century RIBA were put into place. Its Register of Architects, Architectural Library and
label: Paragraph

text: Drawings Collection, Competitions Committee, Professional Practice Committee,
label: Caption

text: Qualification Examinations, Scale of Charges, Code of Professional Conduct,
label: Paragraph

text: membership rules, and publication of building contracts were all established during this
label: Paragraph

text: time.
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural examinations became a compulsory condition of RIBA membership in
label: Paragraph

text: 1882, but it was not until 1905 that the RIBA adopted the policy of statutory (rather than
label: Paragraph

text: discretionary) registration of architects. This policy move was brought on by pressure
label: Paragraph

text: from the Society of Architects, a body formed in 1884 by dissatisfied RIBA members.
label: Paragraph

text: The Society of Architects and the RIBA later merged in 1925.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1931, a competition was held to design the national headquarters of the RIBA on
label: Paragraph

text: Portland Place in London. This competition was won by George Grey Wornum (1888—
label: Paragraph

text: 1957), and the building opened in 1934. The building’s appearance is very much a
label: Paragraph

text: product of its time period: not quite completely modernist—instead, a rather stripped-
label: Paragraph

text: down classicism bordering on Art Deco in its subtle usage of a limited palette of
label: Paragraph

text: materials, generous proportions, and low-relief sculpture. The RIBA’s London
label: Caption

text: Headquarters, however, does befit a building representing a professional body: it is
label: Paragraph

text: prominently located on the corner of Portland Place and Devonshire Street and contains
label: Paragraph

text: the RIBA’s library, a large auditorium, a bookshop, several sizes of gallery spaces, and
label: Paragraph

text: the RIBA’s administrative offices, all organized around a central main stairway.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most significant changes to the RIBA in the 20th century was the
label: Paragraph

text: Architects’ Registration Act, which came into force on | January 1932. This took the
label: Paragraph

text: responsibility for the architects’ register away from the RIBA and gave it to a newly
label: Paragraph

text: formed Architects Registration Council of the United Kingdom (ARCUK). This
label: Paragraph

text: separation of duties came about because the RIBA was beginning to be seen by the
label: Paragraph

text: government less like the representative body of the profession and more as merely a
label: Paragraph

text: “gentleman’s club.” It was thought that if the register were kept separately from the
label: Paragraph

text: RIBA, then the public’s interests would be better served.
label: Paragraph

text: The RIBA, however, still maintained control over professional examinations and the
label: Paragraph

text: schools of architecture that were accredited to conduct them. This division of labor is
label: Paragraph

text: completely opposite to the situation in the United States, where the National Council of
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Registration Boards (NCARB) is responsible for architectural examinations
label: Paragraph

text: and the American Institute of Architects (AIA) for professional registration. Membership
label: Paragraph

text: in the RIBA (of which registration with ARCUK is mandatory) gives an architect the
label: Paragraph

text: right to call him- or herself a “chartered architect,” whereas registration with the ARCUK
label: Paragraph

text: allows only for the title “registered architect.”
label: Paragraph

text: The years following World War II saw a large increase in the number of architects in
label: Paragraph

text: England to match the increased amount of construction, especially in the area of public
label: Paragraph

text: housing. A widening of architects’ responsibilities also occurred. In addition to the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional roles of building designer and construction manager, British architects began
label: Paragraph

text: to take leading roles in processes from large-scale town planning to smaller-scale
label: Paragraph

text: furniture design. During this time, the RIBA focused its attention mainly on influencing
label: Paragraph

text: the way that architects functioned and were treated. Topics such as fee scales, salaries,
label: Paragraph

text: government interference, economic fluctuations, and the promotion of “good”
label: Title

text: architecture were addressed and attempted to be regulated.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1969, three separate companies owned by the RIBA were formed to provide
label: Paragraph

text: additional services for RIBA members above those provided by membership fees. RIBA
label: Paragraph

text: Publications Ltd issues legal and professional documents used by architects and the
label: Paragraph

text: construction industry and also runs the RIBA Bookshops in London, Manchester, Leeds,
label: Paragraph

text: Birmingham, and Belfast. RIBA Services Ltd provides technical and other services, such
label: Paragraph

text: as the RIBA Product Selector, Office Library Service, Conference and Exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: Service, Appointments (Employment) Bureau, and RIBA-approved Building Site
label: Caption

text: Signboards. Finally, National Building Specifications Ltd publishes specification
label: Paragraph

text: documents to be used in conjunction with professional contracts. The ownership of these
label: Paragraph

text: companies was transferred to a holding company, RIBA Companies Ltd, in 1985.
label: Paragraph

text: The British economic boom of the 1980s, combined with government policies that
label: Paragraph

text: decreased social architecture expenditure, saw many British architects move away from
label: Paragraph

text: jobs with local government authorities and into the private sector. During this same time
label: Paragraph

text: period, the RIBA was forced by the Thatcher government to change its standard fixed-
label: Paragraph

text: percentage scale of charges from “mandatory” to “recommended.” The result was a more
label: Paragraph

text: competitive atmosphere in which architects began undercutting each other in hopes of a
label: Paragraph

text: commission—devaluing the knowledge, skill, and experience that a professional architect
label: Paragraph

text: possesses.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1990s, the RIBA endeavored to become more open to its members and the
label: Paragraph

text: general public. The most physical result of this campaign was renovating and restyling its
label: Paragraph

text: London headquarters; incorporating a privately run cafe, a new bookstore, additional
label: Paragraph

text: gallery space, and handicapped access; and founding an Architecture Center open to the
label: Paragraph

text: public. In 1995, the RIBA introduced a program of compulsory Continuing Professional
label: Paragraph

text: Development for its members, similar to the ALA’s Continuing Education System (CES),
label: Paragraph

text: in which members must periodically update their knowledge of professional and
label: Paragraph

text: technical issues to keep abreast of new developments.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1993, a report to the Department of the Environment recommended abolishing
label: Paragraph

text: architects’ statutory registration with ARCUK and ending the protection of the title
label: Title

text: “architect.” These recommendations did not come to be. Instead, in 1997, ARCUK was
label: Paragraph

text: changed to the “Architects Registration Board” (ARB), a majority of whose council
label: Paragraph

text: members are external lay members (nonarchitects). The consequences of this on the
label: Paragraph

text: RIBA is yet to be seen in the 21st century.
label: Paragraph

text: RUDOLPH, PAUL 1918-97
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: The American architect Paul Marvin Rudolph is best known for his large-scale, rough-
label: Paragraph

text: surfaced concrete buildings of the 1960s. His architecture, inspired by the postwar work
label: Paragraph

text: of Le Corbusier and Frank Lloyd Wright, is often confused with the Brutalism practiced
label: Paragraph

text: by the Smithsons and theorized by Reyner Banham. Along with Eero Saarinen, Philip
label: Paragraph

text: Johnson, Edward Durell Stone, and Minoru Yamasaki, Rudolph rejected functionalism in
label: Paragraph

text: favor of a highly expressionist architecture based on historical precedents. He turned
label: Paragraph

text: away from the Bauhaus-derived values that he had learned from Walter Gropius at
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard University’s Graduate School of Design in an attempt to reconcile Wright and
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier to produce a monumental, urban architecture. Rudolph’s architecture is one
label: Paragraph

text: of the most complete expressions of the humanistic and often heroic ambitions of postwar
label: Paragraph

text: American architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: During the late 1950s and early 1960s, Rudolph was internationally acclaimed as one
label: Paragraph

text: of the most imaginative heirs to the first generation of modernists. He was widely
label: Paragraph

text: emulated for his boldly graphic drawing style, which emphasized the section, and for the
label: Paragraph

text: rugged surfaces of his buildings. Rudolph accomplished a great deal in a short period of
label: Paragraph

text: time, but by the early 1970s his highly ambitious works had fallen out of favor with the
label: Paragraph

text: rise of Postmodernism, and he received little notice afterward.
label: Paragraph

text: As chairman of Yale University’s architecture department (1958-65), Rudolph made it
label: Paragraph

text: one of the most important American architectural schools of the decade. He was well
label: Paragraph

text: regarded as a teacher, attracted top students, and fostered an Anglo-American axis that
label: Paragraph

text: introduced such important figures to the United States as James Sterling, Colin St. John
label: Paragraph

text: Wilson, and the Smithsons to serve as critics and teachers at Yale. Most remarkably, he
label: Paragraph

text: was the architect of his own school, Yale’s Art and Architecture Building (1958-64),
label: Paragraph

text: which is among the most controversial of the large-scale concrete buildings of the 1960s.
label: Paragraph

text: Born in 1918 in the small town of Elkton, Kentucky, to the family of a Methodist
label: Paragraph

text: minister, Rudolph spent his formative years not far from the public works projects of the
label: Paragraph

text: Tennessee Valley Authority in the mountainous region where Alabama, Kentucky, and
label: Paragraph

text: Tennessee intersect. He excelled in music and art. A formative experience was secing
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright’s Usonian Rosenbaum House (1939) in Florence, Alabama. As an
label: Paragraph

text: undergraduate from 1935 to 1940, Rudolph studied architecture at the Alabama
label: Paragraph

text: Polytechnic Institute (now known as Auburn University), where he received a Beaux-
label: Paragraph

text: Arts education and first noted the potential that the regional buildings of the Deep South
label: Paragraph

text: had for modern architecture. Rudolph’s talents were recognized, and he received a
label: Paragraph

text: scholarship from Harvard’s Graduate School of Design, newly reorganized under Joseph
label: Paragraph

text: Hudnot and Walter Gropius.
label: Paragraph

text: Before matriculating at Harvard in 1941, in 1939 Rudolph journeyed south to see
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s Florida Southern College in Lakeland, Florida, which would inform many of his
label: Paragraph

text: later campus designs. In Florida, Rudolph met Ralph Twitchell, an architect who was
label: Paragraph

text: building beach houses in nearby Sarasota based on Wright’s Usonian designs. Rudolph
label: Caption

text: worked briefly with Twitchell before leaving for Harvard in the fall of 1941. There, he
label: Paragraph

text: studied under Walter Gropius and Konrad Wachsman and made the acquaintance of
label: Paragraph

text: students who would become his life-long colleagues, such as ILM. Pei and, most
label: Paragraph

text: significant, Philip Johnson.
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph spent most of World War II supervising ship construction in the Brooklyn
label: Paragraph

text: Navy Yards, where he recognized the significance of the new wartime materials and
label: Paragraph

text: developed his unique drawing style. After the war, Rudolph completed his degree in just
label: Paragraph

text: one semester (1947), traveled to Europe on a prestigious Wheelwright Fellowship (1948—
label: Paragraph

text: 49) from Harvard, and entered into a partnership with Ralph Twitchell in Florida. In
label: Paragraph

text: Sarasota, Rudolph’s design talents complemented Twitchell’s salesmanship to produce
label: Paragraph

text: between 20 and 30 eloquent, structurally expressive beach houses. These houses received
label: Paragraph

text: international attention, mainly because of Rudolph’s innovative graphic presentation. His
label: Paragraph

text: pen-and-ink chiaroscuro-like style was instantly recognizable and easily reproduced in
label: Paragraph

text: architectural journals. Twitchell and Rudolph’s best-known house was the Cocoon, or
label: Paragraph

text: Healey Guest House (1948), which used cocoon—a preservative plastic spray used to
label: Paragraph

text: mothball ships in the Brooklyn Navy Yards—to create a dramatic catenary roof.
label: Paragraph

text: Always intensely individualistic, Rudolph began his own practice in 1952. At the same
label: Paragraph

text: time, he renounced Gropius’s concept of “teamwork” and the functionalism that he had
label: Paragraph

text: been taught at Harvard. He lectured extensively in architecture schools throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: United States and soon formulated a philosophy that reacted against functionalism in
label: Paragraph

text: favor of the expressionism that he would adhere to for life. In his 1956 lecture and article,
label: Paragraph

text: “The Six Determinants of Architectural Form,” Rudolph said that in addition to function,
label: Paragraph

text: architects should consider the importance of environment (by which he meant
label: Paragraph

text: surroundings rather than a concern for nature), regionalism, materials, psychology, and
label: Paragraph

text: spirit of the times.
label: Paragraph

text: An early advocate of urbanism, Rudolph attempted to integrate his buildings into the
label: Paragraph

text: preexisting conditions of the site, as in his first major public commission, the Mary
label: Paragraph

text: Cooper Jewett Arts Center (1958) in Wellesley, Massachusetts. His early efforts were
label: Paragraph

text: often classed with the formalist or eclectic work of Philip Johnson, Minoru Yamasaki,
label: Paragraph

text: and Edward Durell Stone. The Jewett Center featured screens in the manner of Stone and
label: Paragraph

text: received widespread acclaim for the sensitive manner in which it dealt with the problem
label: Paragraph

text: of inserting a modern structure into a historic campus. Before the project was completed,
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph was named chairman of Yale’s architecture department at the age of 39.
label: Paragraph

text: Yale University Art and Architecture Building, New Haven, Connecticut.
label: Caption

text: Designed by Paul Rudolph (1964)
label: Caption

text: © G.E.Kidder-Smith, courtesy of Kidder Smith Collection, Rotch Visual
label: Caption

text: Collections, M.L.T.
label: Title

text: Soon after, Rudolph received the commission for Yale’s Art and Architecture Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1958-64), a building that would unite the teaching of the arts in one monumental
label: Paragraph

text: structure in fulfillment of many of Rudolph’s developing ideas about urbanism. The
label: Paragraph

text: building was a monumental gateway marking the western edge of the campus. It was the
label: Paragraph

text: culmination of a processional that led the pedestrian from the New Haven Green past
label: Paragraph

text: Yale’s earlier arts building, among them Louis Kahn’s Yale University Art Gallery
label: Paragraph

text: (1955). The rough-edged, corduroy-like exterior was achieved by first pouring the
label: Paragraph

text: concrete into forms and then breaking the ridged edges with a bush hammer to create an
label: Paragraph

text: irregular outline that would cast an ever-changing play of shadows across the facade.
label: Paragraph

text: Although it was similar to Le Corbusier’s beton brut, this method was actually derived
label: Paragraph

text: from the precisely rendered parallel lines in Rudolph’s pen-and-ink drawings. The
label: Paragraph

text: building resembled both Le Corbusier’s La Tourette (1955) and Wright’s then recently
label: Paragraph

text: demolished Larkin Building (1903).
label: Caption

text: However, in violation of the established norms of modernism, the labyrinthine interior
label: Paragraph

text: seemed to have little relation to the exterior. The 36 or so different levels were arranged
label: Paragraph

text: in a pinwheel-like form around two double-height central spaces containing a drafting
label: Paragraph

text: room and jury pit. The building was topped by a glamorous penthouse that housed
label: Paragraph

text: visiting lecturers and critics overnight. The sublimely gloomy, cavernous interior spaces
label: Paragraph

text: disconcerted many who thought that they were more like a glimpse into the maker’s
label: Paragraph

text: unconscious than a rational design for a school for the arts. Rudolph carpeted the building
label: Paragraph

text: in a startling bright orange and decorated the interior with works of art, including a
label: Paragraph

text: curtain by the abstract expressionist artist Willem de Kooning.
label: Paragraph

text: Critics such as Nikolaus Pevsner, who still upheld the Bauhaus as the norm, warned
label: Paragraph

text: students in a dedication speech not to emulate so individualistic a building. Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Jencks labeled the building “camp”—the exaggerated homosexual style first theorized by
label: Paragraph

text: Susan Sontag in her 1961 essay, “Notes on ‘Camp.””
label: Paragraph

text: Camp, however, was precisely the point. With its intricate interiors and decorative use
label: Paragraph

text: of Beaux-Arts plaster casts and ornamental fragments from demolished Louis Sullivan
label: Caption

text: buildings, the interior of the building can be interpreted as a product of the homosexual
label: Paragraph

text: camp, also practiced by Philip Johnson at this time, that reacted against the normative
label: Paragraph

text: conditions enforced by postwar modernism and society. Most remarkably, the rough-
label: Paragraph

text: edged concrete surfaces found both inside and out gave the building an aura of aggression
label: Paragraph

text: that had as much to do with the hypermasculinization of postwar homosexual culture
label: Paragraph

text: (e.g. the interest in bodybuilding and male figures of rebellion, such as James Dean and
label: Paragraph

text: Marlon Brando) as it did with anything found in the culture of architecture. Vincent
label: Paragraph

text: Scully said that the roughened surfaces were sadomasochistic. “The building repels
label: Paragraph

text: touch: it hurts you if you try,” he wrote in Architectural Review in 1964. Rudolph
label: Paragraph

text: intended his surfaces to be a statement in favor of decoration and expression—qualities
label: Paragraph

text: long repressed by the Modern movement—and against the alienation and corporate
label: Paragraph

text: conformity of the slick, glass-walled structures of the International Style.
label: Paragraph

text: Although it was soon called “Brutalist,” the building’s highly aestheticized values were
label: Paragraph

text: in fact the diametric opposite of the British Brutalism practiced by the Smithsons. In fact,
label: Paragraph

text: Banham said that the Art and Architecture building had nothing to do with his definition
label: Paragraph

text: of Brutalism. The building was actually the culmination of the monumental, heroic
label: Paragraph

text: humanism of the 1950s practiced in the United States. It was the final project of Yale
label: Paragraph

text: President A.Whitney Griswold’s campaign to create for Yale a museum of modem
label: Paragraph

text: architecture with buildings by Eero Saarinen, Philip Johnson, and others that would
label: Paragraph

text: defend the liberal arts against the sciences and mass culture.
label: Paragraph

text: The accidental burning of the building in 1969 at the height of student unrest and the
label: Paragraph

text: apocrypha that this has generated has unfortunately overshadowed Rudolph’s other
label: Paragraph

text: achievements. Leaving Yale in 1965 for private practice, Rudolph began a series of
label: Paragraph

text: campus buildings and master plans in a similar vein, among them the Charles Dana Arts
label: Paragraph

text: Center (1963-66) at Colgate University in Hamilton, New York; the chapel and master
label: Paragraph

text: plan for the Tuskegee Institute (1958-69) in Tuskegee, Alabama; the Boston Government
label: Caption

text: Services Center (1962-71); and the master plan for a campus that he regarded as the most
label: Paragraph

text: complete expression of his ideas: the University of Massachusetts (1963-72) in
label: Paragraph

text: Dartmouth. An idea for which Rudolph is rarely given credit was the development of a
label: Paragraph

text: rough-surfaced, mass-produced concrete block ubiquitous in American construction
label: Paragraph

text: during the 1970s that economically imitated the effects of his bush hammer construction.
label: Paragraph

text: By the early 1970s, Rudolph’s monumental projects had fallen out of favor with clients
label: Paragraph

text: who thought that they were expensive and impractical and with a younger generation that
label: Paragraph

text: now saw them as representing the Establishment. A casualty of state politics, the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Massachusetts campus was taken away from Rudolph and completed by
label: Paragraph

text: others, and the Boston Government Services Center—intended to house the health,
label: Paragraph

text: education, and welfare bureaucracy of the Great Society—was never completed. This
label: Paragraph

text: virtual ruin became a symbol of the demise of the liberal idealism of the 1960s after the
label: Paragraph

text: political and economic disarray of the early 1970s. The chorus of critical voices that had
label: Paragraph

text: begun to turn against Rudolph culminated with the publication in 1972 of Robert Venturi,
label: Paragraph

text: Steven Izenour, and Denise Scott Brown’s unfavorable comparison in Learning from Las
label: Paragraph

text: Vegas between his Crawford Manor Housing for the Elderly (1962-66) in New Haven,
label: Paragraph

text: Connecticut, and Venturi and Rauch’s Guild House (1960-63) in Philadelphia,
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania. Ironically, Rudolph had hired Venturi to teach at Yale, and there were
label: Paragraph

text: many similarities between their ideas.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1970s and 1980s, Rudolph returned to practicing architecture in an austere,
label: Paragraph

text: almost 19th-century atelier-like environment. He maintained rigorous control of his
label: Paragraph

text: drawings as the key to his creativity and produced two important private works: the Bass
label: Paragraph

text: House (1970-72) in Fort Worth, Texas, a large villa that combined elements of Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: Fallingwater with the lightweight architecture of the 1920s and 1930s, and his own
label: Paragraph

text: multilevel private penthouse apartment (1977-97) on Manhattan’s Beekman Place, a
label: Paragraph

text: sybaritic fun house of multiple layers and transparent Plexiglas surfaces derived from his
label: Paragraph

text: drawing methods and designed to accommodate his roving, homoerotic gaze.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1980s, Rudolph embarked on an ambitious new career in Southeast Asia as the
label: Paragraph

text: designer of a series of startling sculptural skyscrapers in Hong Kong, Singapore, and
label: Paragraph

text: Jakarta. These buildings were infrequently published and seen by few in the West, thus
label: Paragraph

text: giving rise to the myth that Rudolph was inactive. By the late 1980s, however, Rudolph
label: Paragraph

text: had developed a devoted following among critics such as Michael Sorkin, who saw
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph as the last holdout against Postmodernism at a time when many of his
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaries had turned their backs on their modernist past. Few acknowledged that
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph’s reaction against functionalism and the International Style had in fact informed
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernism, particularly the branch theorized by Venturi.
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph died in 1997 just at the moment when his architecture was undergoing a
label: Paragraph

text: reappraisal by subsequent generations. He left behind a remarkably varied group of
label: Paragraph

text: students in the United States and Britain who have become the leading practitioners of
label: Paragraph

text: the last quarter of the century: Stanley Tigerman, Robert A.M.Stern, Charles Gwathmey,
label: Caption

text: Der Scutt, Sir Norman Foster, and Richard Rogers.
label: Paragraph

text: Born in Elkton, Kentucky, 23 October 1918, the son of a Methodist minister. Attended
label: Paragraph

text: Alabama Polytechnic Institute (now Auburn University) 1935-40; studied under Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius at the Graduate School of Design, Harvard University, fall 1941. War years were
label: Paragraph

text: spent as a lieutenant supervising ship construction in the Brooklyn Navy Yards. Returned
label: Paragraph

text: to Harvard and received master’s degree in 1947. Winner of a Harvard Wheelwright
label: Paragraph

text: Fellowship for travel 1948-49. Chairman Yale University’s School of Architecture
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: Scutt, Sir Norman Foster, and Richard Rogers. Partners with Ralph Twitchell, Sarasota,
label: Caption

text: Florida, 1947-52. Independent practice, 1952-97. Died in New York, 8 August 1997.

text: RUSSIA AND SOVIET UNION
label: Title

text: The origins of 20th-century Russian architecture derive not only from technological
label: Paragraph

text: advances in construction at the turn of the century but also from a reaction to 19th-
label: Paragraph

text: century Western eclectic styles that architects in St. Petersburg and Moscow applied
label: Paragraph

text: profusely to the facades of apartment houses and commercial buildings. By the 1870s,
label: Paragraph

text: there arose a national style based on decorative elements from medieval Muscovy as well
label: Paragraph

text: as on motifs from folk art and traditional wooden architecture. Major examples of the
label: Paragraph

text: Russian style in Moscow include the Historical Museum (1874-83), built on the north
label: Paragraph

text: side of Red Square to a design by Vladimir Shervud (1833-97), and the Upper Trading
label: Caption

text: Rows (1889-93) by Alexander Pomerantsev (1848-1918), assisted by the construction
label: Paragraph

text: engineer Vladimir Shukhov (1853-1939). The influence of this historicism continued
label: Paragraph

text: through the early 1900s as the “neo-Russian” component of the style moderne. Painters
label: Paragraph

text: such as Viktor Vasnetsov (1848-1926), who created the entrance building at the
label: Paragraph

text: Tretiakov Gallery (c. 1905), and Sergei Maliutin (1859-1937) were particularly active in
label: Paragraph

text: using traditional Russian decorative arts as part of a new architectural aesthetic.
label: Paragraph

text: The “new style,” or style moderne, that arose in Russian architecture at the turn of the
label: Paragraph

text: century included among its diverse sources the Arts and Crafts component of the Russian
label: Paragraph

text: Revival style as well as Art Nouveau and the Vienna School. Its main emphasis was on
label: Paragraph

text: the innovative use of materials such as glass, iron, and glazed brick in functional yet
label: Paragraph

text: highly aesthetic designs. The style flourished above all in Moscow, where its leading
label: Paragraph

text: practitioner was Fedor Shekhtel (1859-1926). Shekhtel worked primarily for patrons
label: Paragraph

text: among Moscow’s entrepreneurial elite, such as the extended Riabushinsky family. His
label: Paragraph

text: most notable work was a mansion (1900-02) for Stepan Riabushinsky, which is rivaled
label: Paragraph

text: by his more modernist design for the Alexandra Derozhinsky mansion (1901). Shekhtel
label: Paragraph

text: also designed a number of commercial buildings and public buildings in Moscow, such as
label: Paragraph

text: the Yaroslavl Railway Station.
label: Paragraph

text: Other leading architects of the early 20th century in Moscow include Lev Kekushev
label: Paragraph

text: (1863-1919), Adolf Erikhson, and William Walcot (1874-1943). All three were involved
label: Paragraph

text: in the prolonged construction of one of the largest and most significant moderne
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in Russia: the Hotel Metropole (1899-1905). Like Shekhtel, both Kekushev
label: Paragraph

text: and Walcot produced major examples of the modern style in the design of private houses
label: Paragraph

text: for wealthy clients.
label: Paragraph

text: In St. Petersburg, the style moderne appeared primarily in the design of apartment
label: Paragraph

text: complexes by architects. (St. Petersburg’s relatively compact urban plan impeded the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of detached private houses.) Yet, despite the rapid expansion of apartment
label: Paragraph

text: space, the lack of adequate housing, particularly for workers, remained a major social
label: Paragraph

text: problem. The style moderne also appeared in St. Petersburg’s commercial buildings, such
label: Paragraph

text: as the Singer Building (1902-04) on Nevsky Prospekt by Pavel Siuzor (1844-c.1919).
label: Paragraph

text: After 1905 the style moderne began to merge with a form of modernized classicism,
label: Paragraph

text: known in Russia as neoklassitsizm. Architects in St. Petersburg were especially receptive
label: Paragraph

text: to the neoclassical revival, and they applied it to almost every major structural type,
label: Paragraph

text: including banks, department stores, apartment buildings, and private houses. One of the
label: Paragraph

text: most accomplished and versatile architects in this style was Fedor Lidval (1870-1945),
label: Paragraph

text: designer of the Hotel Astoria (1911-12).
label: Caption

text: In Moscow the most accomplished revivalist was Roman Klein (1858-1924), architect
label: Paragraph

text: of the Museum of Fine Arts (1897-1912; known since 1937 as the Pushkin Museum) and
label: Paragraph

text: the Muir and Mirrielees department store (1906-08). Although less prolific than Klein,
label: Paragraph

text: other architects distinguished themselves in a more austere variant of the neoclassical
label: Paragraph

text: revival for major office buildings in Moscow’s commercial center. In contrast to
label: Paragraph

text: Territorial Executive Committee Building, by A.D.Kriachkov and others,
label: Caption

text: Norosibirsk, Russia
label: Title

text: © William C.Brumfield
label: Caption

text: their American contemporaries, Russian architects made little use of the skeletal frame in
label: Paragraph

text: the design of large buildings, but they frequently applied new techniques of reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Russia’s rapidly developing industrial base lay in a shambles after a war, a revolution,
label: Paragraph

text: and a civil war; technological resources were extremely limited in what was still a mainly
label: Paragraph

text: rural nation; and Moscow’s population—poorly housed before the war—increased
label: Paragraph

text: dramatically as the city became in 1918 the administrative center of a thoroughly
label: Paragraph

text: administered state. One of the USSR’s earliest edicts, in August 1918, repealed the right
label: Paragraph

text: to private ownership of urban real estate. Even as the country plunged into civil war,
label: Paragraph

text: groups of architects in Moscow and Petrograd (formerly St. Petersburg) designed
label: Paragraph

text: workers’ settlements that represent an extension of the Garden City movement which had
label: Paragraph

text: already tentatively appeared in Russia during the decade before World War I.
label: Paragraph

text: The prerevolutionary building boom had established a viable foundation, in both
label: Paragraph

text: architectural theory and practice, for urban development on a large scale. Furthermore,
label: Paragraph

text: the Russian architectural profession was relatively intact after the emigration that
label: Paragraph

text: decimated other areas of Russian culture after the revolution. In addition, the most
label: Paragraph

text: prominent art and architectural schools in Moscow and Petrograd were capable of
label: Paragraph

text: providing a base for the development of new cadres despite sometimes sweeping changes
label: Paragraph

text: in the composition of the faculty. Nonetheless, there were enormous problems in
label: Paragraph

text: resuscitating these institutions, of allocating resources for new construction, and of
label: Paragraph

text: devising a plan for coordinating further development.
label: Paragraph

text: With the gradual recovery of the economy in the 1920s, bold new designs—often
label: Paragraph

text: utopian in concept—brought the USSR to the attention of modern architects throughout
label: Paragraph

text: the world. The assumption that a revolution in architecture (along with the other arts)
label: Paragraph

text: would inevitably accompany a political revolution was soon put to the test by social and
label: Paragraph

text: economic realities. The brief history of the Soviet avant-garde in architecture was marked
label: Paragraph

text: by theoretical debates and factional disputes, such as that between rationalism and
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivism. At the same time, the role of artists such as El Lissitzky, Kazimir
label: Paragraph

text: Malevich, Vladimir Tatlin, and Nikolai Punin in defining new approaches to volume and
label: Paragraph

text: structure had a profound impact on the conceptualization of avant-garde architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivism, the most productive modernist movement, adopted a rigorously
label: Paragraph

text: functional approach to design that rejected “bourgeois” decorative effects and
label: Paragraph

text: concentrated on clearly defined geometric volumes articulated on a monumental scale
label: Paragraph

text: that expressed the ethos of the new state. Ironically, the backward condition of Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: building technology in the 1920s often re-
label: Paragraph

text: “SAL 4

label: Caption

text: sulted in a primitive realization of those Constructivist projects that reached the stage of
label: Paragraph

text: implementation.
label: Paragraph

text: In Moscow leading Constructivist architects and theoreticians included Moisei
label: Paragraph

text: Ginzburg (1892-1946), whose most notable building was the apartment house (1928-30)
label: Paragraph

text: for the People’s Commissariat of Finance; Grigory Barkhin (1880-1969), designer of the
label: Paragraph

text: Izvestiia Building (1925-27); Ilya Golosov (1883-1945), architect of the Zuev Workers’
label: Paragraph

text: Club (1927-29); Panteleimon Golosov (1882-1945), author of the Pravda Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1930-35); and the Vesnin brothers, Leonid (1880-1933), Viktor (1882-1950), and
label: Paragraph

text: Alexander (1883-1959), architects of a number of major projects, such as the Likhachev
label: Paragraph

text: Palace of Culture (1931-37), built for the workers of a large automobile factory.
label: Paragraph

text: These and other Constructivist projects in Moscow set a standard for functional design
label: Paragraph

text: in administrative and apartment buildings as well as social institutions, such as workers’
label: Paragraph

text: clubs. Another prominent modernist active during the same period but not a part of the
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist movement was Konstantin Melnikov (1890-1974), known for his designs
label: Paragraph

text: for exposition pavilions, a number of workers’ clubs (most notably the Rusakov Club,
label: Paragraph

text: 1927-28), industrial structures such as the Leyland Bus Garage (1926-27), and his own
label: Paragraph

text: house (1927-29) in the Arbat district of Moscow.
label: Caption

text: Important projects by Constructivist architects also appeared in other Soviet cities,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Leningrad, Kharkov, Gorky (Nizhnii Novgorod), Sverdlovsk (Ekaterinburg), and
label: Paragraph

text: Novosibirsk. Notable examples in Leningrad include the Kirov District Soviet complex
label: Paragraph

text: (1930-35), whose overall design was entrusted to the architect Noi Trotskii (1895-1940).
label: Paragraph

text: Beginning in 1928, the five-year plans, with their emphasis on the rapid expansion of
label: Paragraph

text: heavy industry, led to the massive rebuilding of industrial centers. In Kharkov, a massive
label: Paragraph

text: complex of several buildings known as the State Industry Building (Gosprom, 1926-28)
label: Caption

text: was designed by an architectural team headed by Sergei Serafimov (1878-1939). In
label: Paragraph

text: Sverdlovsk, whose entire city center was redesigned with the participation of architects
label: Paragraph

text: such as Moisei Ginzburg, a model housing development known as “Chekists’
label: Paragraph

text: Village” (1929-38) was designed by LAntonov, V.Sokolov, and A.Tumbasov. Industrial
label: Paragraph

text: architecture also received much attention, as foreign architects such as Ernst May, Erich
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn, Hannes Meyer, and Albert Kahn collaborated with Soviet architects and
label: Paragraph

text: engineers in creating mammoth industrial complexes. Theoreticians such as Ivan
label: Paragraph

text: Leonidov (1902-59) developed concepts of the “linear city” for new industrial centers.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1930s, more conservative trends asserted themselves in major buildings
label: Paragraph

text: sponsored by the bureaucratic apparatus, as designs inspired by classical, Renaissance,
label: Paragraph

text: and other historicist models received the party’s approval. Prominent traditionalists,
label: Paragraph

text: trained in the prerevolutionary neoclassical revival, included Ivan Zholtovskii (1867—
label: Paragraph

text: 1959), Aleksei Shchusev (1873-1949), and Noi Trotskii (1895-1940). Despite the formal
label: Paragraph

text: break with Constructivism, earlier work by Shchusev and Trotskii belongs to the
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist movement, and other connections with the architecture of the 1920s
label: Paragraph

text: continued throughout the 1930s. The grandomania of prewar Stalinist architecture is best
label: Paragraph

text: expressed by the project for the Palace of the Soviets (1933-35) in Moscow, designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Boris lofan (1891-1976), Vladimir Gelfreikh (1885-1967), and Vladimir Shchuko
label: Paragraph

text: (1878-1939). The structure was to be built on the site of the massive Cathedral of Christ
label: Paragraph

text: the Savior (demolished in 1931), but the project was canceled in the late 1940s.
label: Paragraph

text: After World War IL, architectural design became more firmly locked in traditional,
label: Paragraph

text: often highly ornate eclectic styles, epitomized by the postwar skyscrapers in Moscow and
label: Paragraph

text: other Soviet cities. Of the seven such towers in Moscow, the largest is the building of
label: Paragraph

text: Moscow State University (1949-53) by Lev Rudnev (1885-1956), Pavel Abrosimov
label: Caption

text: (1900-61), and Alexander Khriakov (1903-76). On this, as on several other projects
label: Paragraph

text: during the Stalinist period, much of the construction was done by prison labor.
label: Paragraph

text: In the period following Stalin’s death, in March 1953, a reassessment of priorities,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly in regard to the housing crisis, led to a functionalism that had been among the
label: Paragraph

text: goals of Soviet design and planning during the 1920s. Teams of engineers and architects
label: Paragraph

text: began to produce standardized plans that could be applied with relatively simple
label: Paragraph

text: technology, and the pursuit of a historical framework for architectural style was largely
label: Paragraph

text: discarded, as indicated by the abolition of the Academy of Architecture in the early
label: Paragraph

text: Khrushchev era. The acceleration of standardized construction achieved an impressive
label: Paragraph

text: volume, first with five-story apartment buildings that appeared throughout the country
label: Paragraph

text: and subsequently with mass-produced buildings as high as 20 stories and, in rare cases,
label: Paragraph

text: even higher.
label: Paragraph

text: The industrialization of building and the curbing of decorative pomposity produced a
label: Paragraph

text: different set of problems. Apart from the general monotony of design, creative projects
label: Paragraph

text: were constrained by the processes of standardized, “industrial” construction based on
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated modules or precast-concrete forms assembled on-site. The seams and
label: Paragraph

text: cracks that resulted from such methods of assembly gave many buildings a shoddy
label: Paragraph

text: appearance. Whatever the project type, Soviet architects were usually faced with a
label: Paragraph

text: natrow range of options limited by mass-construction methods and meager financial
label: Paragraph

text: resources.
label: Paragraph

text: Even showcase projects with considerable support shared in the general monotony.
label: Paragraph

text: The most prolific practitioner of postwar Soviet modernism was Mikhail Posokhin
label: Paragraph

text: (1910-89), who had collaborated in the design of a Stalinist apartment tower on
label: Paragraph

text: Insurrection Square but shifted adroitly into the new functionalism of the Sputnik era. His
label: Paragraph

text: design for the Kremlin Palace of Congresses (1959-61, in collaboration with A.
label: Caption

text: Mndoiants and others) had the appearance of a modern concert hall of huge proportions,
label: Paragraph

text: whose marble-clad rectangular outline was marked by narrow pylons—also faced with
label: Paragraph

text: white marble—and multistoried shafts of plate glass. The main virtue of its style was how
label: Paragraph

text: relatively unobtrusively the large structure stood among the historic Kremlin ensemble,
label: Paragraph

text: part of which had been destroyed in the 1930s.
label: Paragraph

text: Not all Soviet architecture of the modern period descended to nondescript conformity.
label: Paragraph

text: Futuristic construction technology appeared in the Ostankino Television Tower (1967,
label: Paragraph

text: N.Nikitin, L.Batalov, and others), a reinforced-concrete monolith of impressive design
label: Paragraph

text: and engineering. The ferroconcrete shaft, 385 meters in height (on a foundation of only
label: Paragraph

text: four meters), supports a steel-frame antenna superstructure that rises another 150 meters.
label: Paragraph

text: Technological ingenuity also characterizes the design of many contemporary sports
label: Paragraph

text: arenas, which, like television, served the regime’s propaganda interests. Large stadium
label: Paragraph

text: complexes began to take shape even in the late Stalinist period, such as Leningrad’s
label: Paragraph

text: Kirov Stadium (1950, A.Nikolskii and others) on Krestovskii Island and culminating with
label: Paragraph

text: the Luzhniki stadium complex (1955-56, A.Vlasov and others) in south Moscow. The
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on the culture of sports, which reached a crescendo in the preparations for the
label: Paragraph

text: 1980 Summer Olympics, produced some of the most interesting forms in contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: Russian architecture. An example notable for its high technology and sweeping lines is
label: Paragraph

text: the Velotrek bicycle racing stadium (1978-79, Natalia Voronina and others) in the west
label: Paragraph

text: Moscow suburb of Krylatskoe, with a bifurcated roof composed of rolled-steel
label: Paragraph

text: membranes four millimeters thick stretched between a pair of tilted elliptical arches
label: Paragraph

text: supported by a truss frame system.
label: Paragraph

text: With the demise of the Communist system in the USSR, the revival of private practice
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture seems likely to change the face of the profession, even as new problems
label: Paragraph

text: arise in zoning, housing, and resource allocation. Foreign investment has encouraged the
label: Paragraph

text: assimilation of Western commercial architecture, from modernism to postmodernism to
label: Paragraph

text: deconstructivism. At the same time, historicist elements from Russian and even Stalinist
label: Paragraph

text: architecture are being recycled in new projects for cities such as Moscow in order to
label: Paragraph

text: achieve a distinctive, colorful urban environment. It would be premature to comment on
label: Paragraph

text: the success of these efforts, but Russian architecture is rapidly regaining the variety that
label: Paragraph

text: characterized it at the beginning of the 20th century.

text: SAARINEN, EERO 1910-61
label: Title

text: Architect, Finland
label: Title

text: Eero Saarinen shared the same date of birth with his famous architect father, Eliel (20
label: Paragraph

text: August 1873 and 1910); both the elder and the younger Saarinen were and are very likely
label: Paragraph

text: to remain the only father-son duo recipients of the Gold Medal of the American Institute
label: Paragraph

text: of Architects.
label: Paragraph

text: The younger Saarinen was born in Kirkkonummi (Kyrkslate), Finland (then Russia)
label: Paragraph

text: and grew up in the secluded retreat of “Hvittrisk,” the home/studio where Eliel Saarinen
label: Paragraph

text: entertained many of Finland’s intellectuals and artists and produced ideas in architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and planning. Saarinen attended high school at a special progressive school housed
label: Paragraph

text: within the University of Michigan’s School of Education (then nearby Baldwin High
label: Paragraph

text: School in Birmingham, Michigan) and apprenticed in the Cranbrook architectural office
label: Paragraph

text: from 1928 to 1931, taking eight months in Paris, France, beginning in late 1929 to study
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture at the Académie de la Grande Chaumiére. After his return to Cranbrook,
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen developed furniture designs from 1930 to 1931 that concurrently embraced a
label: Paragraph

text: conscious variety of styles, from handicraft to an industrial aesthetic. He entered Yale
label: Paragraph

text: University in the fall of 1931 and completed Yale’s five-year program in three years.
label: Paragraph

text: With the award of a traveling fellowship, Saarinen visited Europe and the Near East
label: Paragraph

text: and then worked in Finland, where he came in more direct contact with European
label: Paragraph

text: modernism. Thus began his own synthesis of historic architecture and the progressive
label: Paragraph

text: trends of technological innovation and its expression. On his return to the United States
label: Paragraph

text: in 1936, Saarinen entered into a partnership with his father separate from Cranbrook
label: Paragraph

text: (Eliel Saarinen and Eero Saarinen, 1936-42). Through small commissions, independent
label: Paragraph

text: competition entries, and collaborations, he achieved national recognition for his
label: Paragraph

text: American modernism. He briefly worked as a designer for the office of Norman Bel
label: Paragraph

text: Geddes on the General Motors “Futurama” building for the 1939 New York World’s
label: Caption

text: Fair. In buildings such as the Kleinhans Music Hall (1938-41, with Kidd and Kidd) in
label: Paragraph

text: Buffalo, New York, and Crow Island School (1940, with Perkins, Wheeler and Will of
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago) in Winnetka, Illinois, as well as first place in the 1939 national competition for
label: Paragraph

text: the Smithsonian Art Gallery (unexecuted}, the Saarinens became synonymous with a
label: Paragraph

text: progressive style free of the radical overtones of the International Style.
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Eames was among the younger designers with whom Eero collaborated, and
label: Paragraph

text: their molded-plywood furniture designs for the “Organic Design in Home Furnishings”
label: Paragraph

text: competition and exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art (1941) established their
label: Paragraph

text: position among a new generation of modernists. World War Il saw a number of
label: Paragraph

text: transformations in their practice, changes that also represented the gradual independence
label: Paragraph

text: of the son from the aesthetic dispositions of his father. It was at the end of this period that
label: Paragraph

text: Eero’s entry in the 1948 competition for the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial (St.
label: Paragraph

text: Louis, Missouri) was awarded first prize (both father and son submitted designs under the
label: Paragraph

text: firm name, resulting in a brief confusion as to the winner). Presenting a “Gateway to the
label: Paragraph

text: West,” its abstract 630-foot-high catenary-arch form combined symbolism with
label: Paragraph

text: technological daring and structural innovation.
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen’s aesthetic took on its own character during the 1940s with buildings such as
label: Paragraph

text: the suspended tensile-roof structure of the “Demountable Space”/Community House
label: Caption

text: project (1941, with Ralph Rapson} for the United States Gypsum Company, the
label: Paragraph

text: “Unfolding House” project (1943-44) based on trailer/containers, and the “Serving Suzy”
label: Paragraph

text: restaurant project (1944) featuring a mobile food service for the Pittsburgh Plate Glass
label: Paragraph

text: Company. Built works included the Opera-Concert Hall and Berkshire Music Center at
label: Paragraph

text: Tanglewood (1940-41) in Stockbridge, Massachusetts (a structure that employed
label: Paragraph

text: laminated wood arches and tensile rod-suspended roofs); the steel Case Study House #8
label: Paragraph

text: and #9 (1945-50, with Charles Eames; #9 built as John Entenza House) for Arts &
label: Caption

text: Architecture in Pacific Palisades, California; and the lightweight Music Tent (1949, with
label: Paragraph

text: Smith, Hegner and Moore, Associate Architects} for the Goethe Bicentennial
label: Caption

text: Convocation Music Festival in Aspen, Colorado.
label: Caption

text: The most significant example of this evolution was the postwar, $100 million General
label: Paragraph

text: Motors Technical Center (1951-56, designed with Smith, Hinchman and Grylls,
label: Paragraph

text: Associate Architects) in Warren, Michigan. The initial scheme of 1945 combined
label: Paragraph

text: familiar design motifs of Eliel Saarinen, such as the interplay between a horizontal space
label: Paragraph

text: (the man-made lake) and the vertical accent of a water tower and the younger Saarinen’s
label: Paragraph

text: desire for industrial objects. After three years, a new scheme, influenced by Mies van der
label: Paragraph

text: Rohe, was proposed. This included the use of a standard planning module and a new thin-
label: Paragraph

text: skin technology for the building envelopes based on car-manufacturing techniques,
label: Paragraph

text: including the innovation of neoprene gaskets for window installation, modeled on the
label: Paragraph

text: system developed for car windshields. The GMTC plan formed the background of a
label: Paragraph

text: portrait of Saarinen on the 2 July 1956 cover of Time magazine.
label: Caption

text: The 1950s saw work ranging from the reductivist, anonymous, and abstract, such as
label: Paragraph

text: the visually neutral indeterminacy of the IBM Manufacturing Plant (1956-59) in
label: Paragraph

text: Rochester, Minnesota, and the Bell Telephone Laboratories (1957-62) in Holmdel, New
label: Caption

text: Jersey, to the evocative expressionism in the forms of the thin-shell Trans World Airlines
label: Paragraph

text: (TWA) airport terminal (1956-62) in New York City and the suspended roof of the
label: Paragraph

text: David S. Ingalls Hockey Rink (1956-59) at Yale University in New Haven, Connecticut.
label: Caption

text: Structure and construction were used to serve themes other than structure in Saarinen’s
label: Paragraph

text: search for form. Formal invention was paralleled by technical innovation, where
label: Paragraph

text: technique and evocative imagery were often merged. Representation was manifested in
label: Paragraph

text: metaphorical forms, most notably in the TWA terminal’s evocation of a “bird in flight.”
label: Paragraph

text: The Ezra Stiles and Samuel F.B.Morse Colleges (1958-62) at Yale University consisted
label: Paragraph

text: of injection-formed concrete walls that alluded to a medieval community of scholars. The
label: Paragraph

text: campus of Concordia Lutheran Senior College (1953-59) in Fort Wayne, Indiana,
label: Paragraph

text: represented a Scandinavian village. At the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in
label: Paragraph

text: Cambridge, the Kresge Auditorium (1950-55) and MIT Chapel (1953-55) oppose the
label: Paragraph

text: advanced thin-shell technology of the auditorium dome against the primal imagery of a
label: Paragraph

text: closed brick cylinder placed in a circular moat for the chapel. His only tall building, the
label: Paragraph

text: Columbia Broadcasting System Headquarters (1960-64) in New York City, was also the
label: Paragraph

text: last design of his career. Its solid, masonry cladding proposed his first departure from the
label: Paragraph

text: modernist glass box, where he alluded instead to the context of Manhattan.
label: Paragraph

text: SAARINEN, ELIEL 1873-1950
label: Title

text: Architect, Finland
label: Title

text: Eliel Saarinen was a leading proponent of a humane approach to modernist architecture
label: Paragraph

text: whose work was influential in bringing about a transition from the decorative obsession
label: Paragraph

text: of Romantic Nationalist architecture to modernism. As designer and president of
label: Paragraph

text: Cranbrook Academy (1932-50) in Bloomfield, Michigan, Saarinen had a significant
label: Paragraph

text: impact on the teaching of architects and designers. Born in Rantsalami, Finland, the son
label: Paragraph

text: of a highly educated and culturally aware Lutheran pastor, his early years were divided
label: Paragraph

text: between rural towns and the city of Moscow. As a youth, Saarinen, who was impressed
label: Paragraph

text: with the art of the Hermitage in Moscow, was more devoted to painting than to his formal
label: Paragraph

text: studies at the lyceum. In 1893, his devotion to painting led him to study painting at the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Helsinki while simultaneously studying architecture at the Polytekniska
label: Paragraph

text: Institutet (1893-97). In 1896, while still an architectural student, he formed a partnership
label: Paragraph

text: with two fellow students, Herman Gesellius and Armas Lindgren. They quickly won first
label: Paragraph

text: prize in the competition to build the Talberg Building (1897) in Helsinki. More
label: Caption

text: significant prizes and commissions followed. A first prize in the competition to design
label: Paragraph

text: the Finnish Pavilion for the Paris Exposition of 1900 brought the partnership critical
label: Paragraph

text: acclaim in Europe. Compared with the pavilions of other nations, the Finnish Pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: was simple in form and refined in its combination of restrained and appropriately Nordic
label: Paragraph

text: omamentation, including frescoes by Akseli Gallen-Kallela.
label: Caption

text: Saarinen’s ability to spend the long hours necessary for solving complex architectural
label: Paragraph

text: problems was the basis for his subsequent success. With his designs for the Helsinki and
label: Paragraph

text: Viipuri Railroad Stations, he moved away from seeking a uniquely Finnish solution and
label: Paragraph

text: toward International Style modernism, allowing function to play an ever-larger role in
label: Paragraph

text: determining his architectural solutions. Never sacrificing functionality for avant-gardism,
label: Paragraph

text: his urban planning designs for Helsinki, Canberra, and Chicago retained a concern for
label: Paragraph

text: community and context. Although none of these large-scale plans was realized, Saarinen
label: Paragraph

text: was able to put his planning skills to good use in his designs for Cranbrook Academy.
label: Paragraph

text: First Christian Church (originally the Tabernacle Church of Christ), (1942)
label: Caption

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: Saarinen’s early architectural practice focused on defining and creating a Finnish style of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, giving focus to the notion of Gesamtkunstwerk, or the total work of art.
label: Paragraph

text: Exteriors tended toward the rugged and plastically picturesque using local rusticated
label: Paragraph

text: soapstone or granite. Interiors were richly detailed, with the partners attending to every
label: Paragraph

text: detail, from the design of tiled stoves to decorative carvings, many of which were derived
label: Paragraph

text: from Finnish culture or landscape. This interest in Gesamétkunstwerk led the firm to
label: Paragraph

text: design and construct Hvittrask (1901-03), a communal office and dwelling complex
label: Paragraph

text: located 18 miles from Helsinki. At Hvittrask, they emphasized a cultured rusticity with
label: Paragraph

text: exposed-log interiors, copper fireplace hoods, exposed beams, and a functional approach
label: Paragraph

text: to the arrangement of space. A log tower and effective placement on a sloping, dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: site above White Lake (Hvittrask) emphasized a romantic attachment to the wilderness of
label: Paragraph

text: the northern forests. Even as Hvittrask was under construction, the partnership, and
label: Paragraph

text: eventually Saarinen on his own after the partnership began to dissolve in 1905, moved
label: Paragraph

text: away from Romanticism toward greater simplicity of ornament and formal clarity. The
label: Paragraph

text: rugged stone-and-log construction and informality of Hvittrask gave way to the smoother
label: Paragraph

text: stuccoed exterior and formality of the Molchow House (1905-07) in Mark-Brandenburg,
label: Caption

text: Germany. Saarinen’s designs for the Helsinki Railway Station provide an excellent
label: Paragraph

text: opportunity to observe changes in his approach to design; the medieval-style tower and
label: Paragraph

text: crenellations of his early drawings gave way to the simpler, more streamlined elevations
label: Paragraph

text: of the final design. His final design for the Helsinki Railroad Station demonstrates his
label: Paragraph

text: awareness of German architecture in general and the influence of Behrens in particular.
label: Paragraph

text: Glass and concrete play a large role in his railroad station designs. At Viipuri, a large
label: Paragraph

text: concrete barrel vault with minimal ornamentation dominated the interior of the station’s
label: Paragraph

text: main hall. Large windows above the main entrance created an overall feeling of openness
label: Caption

text: and efficiency. Ormamented soapstone columns and oak furnishing balanced this
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on function with their tactility.
label: Paragraph

text: After the disruptions of the Russian Revolution and World War I, Saarinen’s second-
label: Paragraph

text: place finish in the competition for the Tribune Tower (1922) in Chicago brought him
label: Paragraph

text: again into the architectural limelight. Shortly thereafter, he traveled to Chicago and was
label: Paragraph

text: soon working on plans to develop the lakefront of Chicago. In 1924, Saarinen became a
label: Paragraph

text: visiting professor of architecture at the University of Michigan. In 1925, he was asked by
label: Paragraph

text: George G. Booth to develop educational plans for what would eventually include
label: Paragraph

text: Cranbrook Academy. From 1925 to 1950, Saarinen was architect-in-residence, and in
label: Paragraph

text: 1927 he became the chief architectural officer for Cranbrook. Designs for Cranbrook
label: Paragraph

text: include the Cranbrook School for Boys (1926-30), the Saarinen Residence (1928-29),
label: Paragraph

text: the Kingswood School for Girls (1929-30), the Institute for Science (1931-33), and the
label: Paragraph

text: Museum and Library (1942-43). Saarinen’s design for the Museum and Library
label: Caption

text: structures connected by a peristyle exemplifies his later, more austere approach to design.
label: Paragraph

text: Large functional spaces, straight lines, and geometric formal relationships and the wall of
label: Paragraph

text: glass on the north face of the library connect Saarinen’s design with the International
label: Caption

text: Style. On the other hand, the choice of brick and stone, the abstract designs of the ceiling,
label: Paragraph

text: the figurative sculpture of Carl Milles’ Orpheus Fountain to the north of the peristyle,
label: Caption

text: and attention to the relationship between landscaping
label: Title

text: First Christian Church (originally the Tabernacle Church of Christ), interior
label: Caption

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: and structure maintain a humanity not always present in International Style architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: SAFDIE, MOSHE 1938-
label: Title

text: Architect, Israel and Canada
label: Title

text: An Israel-born and Canada-educated architect who has maintained practices in
label: Paragraph

text: Jerusalem, Montreal, Boston, and elsewhere, Moshe Safdie is best known for his
label: Paragraph

text: internationally recognized modern revisionist project, the Habitat housing experiment for
label: Paragraph

text: the 1967 World’s Exposition in Montreal.
label: Paragraph

text: The initial idea for Habitat came to Safdie when he was working on his student thesis
label: Paragraph

text: concerning cellular housing, questioning the social, environmental, ethical, and tectonic
label: Paragraph

text: ideas of modernist architecture. Safdie drew on his childhood memories of the Israeli
label: Paragraph

text: settlements to create an unsentimental articulate structure based on these traditional
label: Paragraph

text: forms. Habitat was one of the first prefabricated housing complexes built at the time and
label: Paragraph

text: was the forerunner of R.Buckminster Fuller’s megastructure Triton City (1968). Fuller’s
label: Paragraph

text: project model introduced a floating city comprised of prefabricated cellular units, a
label: Paragraph

text: flexible structure that was never realized. It was during the late 1960s that Safdie, like
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller, began to believe in the promise of industrialization and prefabrication for low-cost
label: Paragraph

text: and improved structures. The 1960s espoused various collective social agendas by
label: Paragraph

text: architects as well as politicians; similarly, architects and urban designers were reassessing
label: Paragraph

text: the urban and architectural ideas of the modernists. Expo ‘67’s Habitat project proved to
label: Paragraph

text: be too expensive, and many difficulties arose in its construction. Greatly reduced in size,
label: Paragraph

text: Habitat proved to evoke Safdie’s revisionist attitude, one that rejected the Le Corbusian
label: Paragraph

text: and Miesian vertical models of Unite d’Habitation and the Lake Shore Drive Apartments
label: Paragraph

text: in Chicago.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1970s Safdie concentrated his efforts on massive urban design schemes that
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized context. One of these schemes was a plan (1971) for a new town, Coldspring,
label: Paragraph

text: close to Baltimore, Maryland. During this time, he also produced a number of urban
label: Paragraph

text: projects in Israel including the Yeshivat Porat Joseph Rabbinical College (1971-79) in
label: Paragraph

text: Jerusalem and the Desert Research Institute (and Ben Gurion Archives) (1974) in the
label: Paragraph

text: Negev. The Rabbinical College, located in the center of the Jewish Quarter of the old
label: Paragraph

text: city, combines a traditionally shaped structure with traditionally shaped domes of the
label: Paragraph

text: region, using modern construction and materials. In this work, Safdie explored the use of
label: Paragraph

text: natural lighting and its symbolic quality. This symbolic use of lighting played a key role
label: Paragraph

text: in his later works. Corresponding to its site and its context within the city, the Rabbinical
label: Paragraph

text: College marries tradition with modernist invention. Safdie’s work in Jerusalem
label: Paragraph

text: particularly corresponds with the indigenous architecture of the city, blending with its
label: Paragraph

text: traditional geometric shapes and colors as well as with the site.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1982, Safdie was commissioned by the Canadian government to design the new
label: Paragraph

text: National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa. The building was completed in 1988, when he was
label: Paragraph

text: then asked along with the firm Belzile, Brassard, Gallienne, Lavoie, with Sungur Incesulu
label: Paragraph

text: and Maurice Desnoyers, to offer a scheme for a competition held for the Quebec Museum
label: Paragraph

text: of Civilization (1988). They won the commission, and Safdie used ideas from his
label: Paragraph

text: Jerusalem projects concerning the importance of place and cultural traditions; only this
label: Paragraph

text: time, the northern and French culture of Canada was considered in the design process.
label: Paragraph

text: Safdie’s writings, including Beyond Habitat (1970) and For Everyone a Garden
label: Paragraph

text: (1974), argue for a reevaluation of modernism that promotes the humanistic and ethical
label: Paragraph

text: dimensions of architecture. Safdie is also dedicated to the idea of the importance of
label: Paragraph

text: designing public buildings that are intertwined with city street life. Bevond Habitat by
label: Paragraph

text: Twenty Years (1987) reviews the architectural, aesthetic, and political concerns of the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s, from Habitat project through Postmodernism of the 1980s. Safdie admonishes the
label: Paragraph

text: postmodernist agenda of historical eclecticism that centers on architecture concerned
label: Paragraph

text: mainly with stylization and detachment from site. Safdie’s technological ideas (manifest
label: Paragraph

text: in Habitat) are also viewed as a starting point for other projects concerned with high-
label: Paragraph

text: volume housing construction. He remains committed to a practice of contextualized
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that is achieved through locality, iconography of site, color, and building
label: Paragraph

text: technologies found geographically. His work investigates the importance of place,
label: Paragraph

text: history, cultural identity, tectonics, and materiality.
label: Paragraph
