label: Caption

text: completed in 1876, and subsequently, galleries were added in piecemeal fashion in 1887,
label: Paragraph

text: 1911, 1927, and 1970, but these are deferentially tucked behind the original building’s
label: Paragraph

text: main facade on Trafalgar Square. In contrast, the Sainsbury Wing confidently gestures
label: Paragraph

text: toward its monumental urban setting and complements a building long perceived as
label: Paragraph

text: awkward and compromised. The architects have cunningly mirrored the more pleasing
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic features of Wilkins’ Neoclassical structure while quietly serving practical needs
label: Paragraph

text: by using the most sophisticated technology available in museum design.
label: Paragraph

text: The controversial history of this wing commenced in 1958, when the government
label: Paragraph

text: acquired the site of the former Hampton’s furniture store immediately to the west of the
label: Paragraph

text: National Gallery. To encourage the government to raise funds to use these premises for
label: Paragraph

text: museum purposes, the Sunday Times newspaper the following year mounted a
label: Paragraph

text: competition that garnered an unmemorable group of proposals in the monolithic Brutalist
label: Paragraph

text: style then dominating British architecture. Nothing came of the Times’s intervention, and
label: Paragraph

text: plans to extend the National Gallery on this site languished until December 1981, when
label: Paragraph

text: the government launched its own contest. However, the program, addressed to developers
label: Paragraph

text: as well as architects, was tainted from the outset by the requirement, for financial
label: Paragraph

text: reasons, that the galleries should form but a small part of a larger commercial enterprise.
label: Paragraph

text: From 79 entrants to the first phase in April 1982, seven architectural firms, each with its
label: Paragraph

text: own developer, were selected to pursue the project. After much debate, Ahrends, Burton,
label: Paragraph

text: and Koralek won the opportunity to finalize their proposal, but their definitive scheme
label: Paragraph

text: met with general public dismay, most poignantly encapsulated in the words of Charles,
label: Paragraph

text: prince of Wales, who in 1984 likened it to a “vast municipal fire station” as well as a
label: Paragraph

text: “monstrous carbuncle on the face of a much loved and elegant friend.” The misguided
label: Paragraph

text: brief was set aside, and in 1985 the Sainsbury brothers—Simon, John, and Timothy,
label: Paragraph

text: owners of a thriving supermarket chain and generous donors to the arts—offered a
label: Paragraph

text: munificent gift to make possible the erection of an extension solely at the disposal of the
label: Paragraph

text: National Gallery.
label: Paragraph

text: A reformulated competition was then held in which four British firms—James Stirling
label: Paragraph

text: and Michael Wilford, (Alan) Col-

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The choice in 1986 of Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown in the face of such a
label: Paragraph

text: strong English showing was somewhat of a surprise, especially because Venturi, Scott
label: Paragraph

text: Brown, while not inexperienced in museum additions, had not previously executed a
label: Paragraph

text: building in Britain. However, the jury found their scheme the most sensitive to the
label: Paragraph

text: scenography of London’s most celebrated square. Although all six entries, unlike the
label: Paragraph

text: aggressively modernist designs in the 1982 competition, incorporated some references to
label: Paragraph

text: the classical vocabulary of Wilkins’ building, it was Venturi, Scott Brown, and
label: Paragraph

text: Associates’s proposal that most skillfully integrated the new with the old rather than
label: Paragraph

text: standing as a separate entity. Their dramatic but sympathetic resolution turns on a
label: Paragraph

text: veritable cascade of the Corinthian order, which begins to the west of the main entrance
label: Caption

text: as a fluted, fully engaged column faithfully reproducing those on Wilkins’ original
label: Paragraph

text: portico. Then the rhythm quickens as a crescendo of irregularly spaced Corinthian
label: Paragraph

text: pilasters form a masonry screen of Portland stone that inflects toward the National
label: Paragraph

text: Gallery before terminating along the side as prelude to a glazed curtain wall, behind
label: Paragraph

text: which lies the grand staircase. The concrete and steel frame facilitates the skillful
label: Paragraph

text: composition of a complex variety of interior spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Standing sentry at the entrance are slender, brightly painted metal columns reminiscent
label: Paragraph

text: of John Nash (1752-1835) in an Egypto-Pompeiian mood. Within and immediately to the
label: Paragraph

text: left is a large shop that also can be accessed directly from a side street. The foyer
label: Paragraph

text: comprises a checkroom, an information desk, and an area sufficiently generous to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate informal concerts and performances. This space leads to the grand
label: Paragraph

text: stairway, that icon of public architecture that has been strategically displaced from the
label: Paragraph

text: center to the extremity of the wing, a parti used in other Venturi, Scott Brown
label: Caption

text: institutional facilities, such as the Seattle Art Museum. The glazed envelope on the
label: Paragraph

text: by the firm in an appropriately contextual way. Each white-walled room, scaled to the
label: Paragraph

text: works on display, is articulated by cool gray pietra serena moldings, doorframes, and
label: Paragraph

text: Tuscan Doric columns, a combination beloved by the Florentine Filippo Brunelleschi.
label: Caption

text: Another architect to whom homage is paid is Louis Kahn, whose museums gave Venturi,
label: Paragraph

text: Scott Brown valuable lessons in circulation and lighting. Although a few British critics
label: Paragraph

text: have faulted certain features of the Sainsbury Wing as being overly theatrical, eclectic,
label: Paragraph

text: and mannered, the galleries have won widespread praise for their serenity and purity,
label: Paragraph

text: qualities attained through the dignified details and the natural light that, purged of
label: Paragraph

text: harmful ultraviolet rays and supplemented by artificial lighting, illuminates the Old
label: Paragraph

text: Master pictures in a way that most favorably enhances their colors and textures.
label: Paragraph

text: Clerestoried monitors, square or oblong according to the plan of their respective galleries,
label: Paragraph

text: are set under a double-glazed roof that admits measured light via electronically controlled
label: Paragraph

text: louvers. Passage through the collection may vary according to the visitor’s preference,
label: Paragraph

text: but enfilades give order to the spatial sequences. At this topmost level, the link to the
label: Paragraph

text: main building provides an inviting vista toward the more richly colored and ornate older
label: Paragraph

text: rooms.
label: Paragraph

text: Immediately below, on level 4, are restaurant facilities and other visitor services,
label: Paragraph

text: including a unique computerized Micro Information Gallery. Level 3 contains the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance foyer, and the auditorium and temporary galleries are located on the two lowest
label: Paragraph

text: floors, beneath ground level, where daylight would inhibit the requisite flexibility. The
label: Paragraph

text: galleries comfortably accommodate diverse types of exhibitions, whether monographic
label: Paragraph

text: shows devoted to a single artist or epoch or thematic displays rich in objects and artifacts.
label: Paragraph

text: The historical references that enrich the architectural language of the Sainsbury Wing
label: Paragraph

text: are particularly apposite to a museum, and allusions to Christopher Wren, medieval,
label: Paragraph

text: Georgian and Victorian London, Italian masters of the Renaissance, and mannerist and
label: Paragraph

text: baroque periods, as well as 20th-century heroes such as Sir Edward Lutyens, are
label: Paragraph

text: discernible. One of the hallmarks of Venturi, Scott Brown, and Associates’s variety of
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernism is the recognition that after modernism, one cannot return to history pure
label: Paragraph

text: and simple; thus, they offer a piquant palimpsest rather than a revivalist copy, an
label: Paragraph

text: interplay between past and present that is enriched by witty transpositions in scale,
label: Paragraph

text: materials, and the putative functions of their sources and quotations.

text: SALK INSTITUTE, LA JOLLA,
label: Caption

text: CALIFORNIA
label: Title

text: Designed by Louis Kahn; completed 1966
label: Caption

text: In 1959 the City Council in San Diego, upon learning of the Salk Institute’s intention
label: Paragraph

text: to build a research institute, offered a number of sites for the development including a
label: Paragraph

text: unique piece of coastal land in La Jolla. The remoteness of the site and its relationship to
label: Paragraph

text: the vast Pacific Ocean are often commented on in relation to the building’s function, as a
label: Paragraph

text: place of cutting-edge research with philosophical implications. In February 1960 Salk
label: Paragraph

text: had a site meeting with Kahn, who soon began work on a master plan. The complex was
label: Paragraph

text: to include the laboratories, as well as two unbuilt components—a meeting hall and
label: Paragraph

text: residences to the extreme west of the site. Apparently due to over expenditure on the
label: Paragraph

text: laboratories, design work on the unbuilt components was suspended in 1963. Meanwhile,
label: Paragraph

text: the property was deeded to Salk in April 1960, and construction of the laboratories
label: Paragraph

text: proceeded from June 1962 until 1965.
label: Paragraph

text: Stage one of the Salk Institute comprises two parallel laboratory buildings that
label: Paragraph

text: delineate the long sides of a rectangular courtyard space. Each laboratory block contains
label: Paragraph

text: a column-free space that is 60 feet wide by 240 feet in length. Significantly, Kahn’s
label: Paragraph

text: design allowed each of the laboratory spaces to be coupled with a service floor. This
label: Paragraph

text: allows each block to consist of two laboratory and associated service levels above ground
label: Paragraph

text: and another such coupling of levels below ground—light reaches the lower laboratories
label: Paragraph

text: via sunken courtyards on either side. Although the structure of the Richards Building fails
label: Paragraph

text: to provide a satisfactory “servant” space for pipes and ducts at ceiling level, the Salk
label: Paragraph

text: laboratories are each “served”—to use Kahn’s words—by ninefoot-deep service floors,
label: Paragraph

text: or “pipe laboratories.” At the time these spaces seemed to provide excessive room for
label: Paragraph

text: pipes and ducts, but since that time much of the space has been filled. These service
label: Paragraph

text: floors occupy the spaces between a series of Vierendeel trusses, which Kahn developed
label: Paragraph

text: with August Komendant, his engineer and collaborator on this and many other projects.
label: Paragraph

text: In what would become a signature motif of his later work, Kahn rejected his
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaries’ rough handling of concrete, choosing instead to detail the off-form
label: Paragraph

text: concrete for these laboratory blocks with great care and finesse. Like Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: rough concrete (béton-brut), which was made famous in his Unite d’ Habitation (1952) in
label: Paragraph

text: Marseilles and his Capitol Complex (1952-60) in Chandigarh, concrete at the Salk
label: Caption

text: Institute is presented as unmaniupulated. However, whereas Le Corbusier made a virtue
label: Paragraph

text: of the often-unintentionally rough finish he achieved in his buildings in Marseilles and
label: Paragraph

text: Chandigarh, Kahn’s concrete at the Salk only displays the marks of carefully planned
label: Paragraph

text: formwork and ties.
label: Paragraph

text: In the intermediate zone between the laboratory buildings and the central plaza are a
label: Paragraph

text: series of small towers that comprise individual studies for the scientists. Each study
label: Paragraph

text: features a 45-degree angled wall section providing oblique views of the Pacific Ocean to
label: Paragraph

text: the west. The studies have weathered teak wall panels, providing the only moment of
label: Paragraph

text: relief and counterpoint to the off-form concrete used elsewhere. Befitting their domestic
label: Paragraph

text: scale, the study windows feature finely crafted glazing, insect screen, and sliding louver
label: Paragraph

text: components, reminiscent of those found in Kahn’s houses.
label: Paragraph

text: The Salk Institute’s most memorable feature—its ascetic treeless plaza of travertine
label: Paragraph

text: and concrete—was intended to feature two parallel rows of Italian cypress trees, until the
label: Paragraph

text: laboratories were almost complete and Kahn began to have misgivings. Credit for the
label: Paragraph

text: potent image that is so familiar today belongs to the Mexican architect Luis Barragan,
label: Paragraph

text: who recommended to Kahn that the open space be left completely bare. Kahn conceived
label: Paragraph

text: the resulting plaza as a “facade to the sky,” with a central canal that marks the
label: Paragraph

text: development’s axis of symmetry. From the rear of the plaza, also known as the Theodore
label: Paragraph

text: Gildred Court, the canal appears to extend to the ocean horizon; in fact, it spills into a
label: Paragraph

text: series of pools below and to the west of the plaza.
label: Paragraph

text: According to Kahn, particular buildings of the same type share an archetypal
label: Paragraph

text: counterpart, or form, which is seen in the mind’s-eye as a vague idea that can only be
label: Paragraph

text: represented by an esquisse-like diagram. The Salk Institute is important in this context
label: Paragraph

text: because it provided Kahn with an ideal arrangement, or archetypal form, for a laboratory
label: Paragraph

text: building and a model for subsequent laboratory proposals, such as the University of
label: Paragraph

text: Virginia Chemistry Building (unbuilt). In its form it would also be an intimation toward
label: Paragraph

text: what Kahn termed “the unmeasurable,” a transcendent realm of inspiration with mystical
label: Paragraph

text: and divine connotations.
label: Paragraph

text: SALMONA, ROGELIO 1929-
label: Title

text: Architect, Columbia
label: Title

text: The designs of Rogelio Salmona comprise over 70 projects built during the past 40
label: Paragraph

text: years and range from domestic to large housing complexes as well as institutional
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. He is undoubtedly one of the most prolific and significant architects of Latin
label: Paragraph

text: America,
label: Title

text: Wanting to study fine arts but advised by his father to take a similar but more
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic route, Salmona entered the National University to study architecture in 1948.
label: Paragraph

text: His first year of studies coincided with Le Corbusier’s visit to Bogota, where he had been
label: Paragraph

text: invited to develop an urban master plan. In 1948, Salmona’s father decided to send his
label: Paragraph

text: children to France in light of the increasing political unrest in Colombia. Salmona began
label: Paragraph

text: working for the architect at the atelier de la rue de Sévres 35, where he would stay for the
label: Paragraph

text: next ten years. Under Le Corbusier, he would further develop his passion for drawing,
label: Paragraph

text: thereby coming in direct contact with the pragmatic aspects of architecture though his
label: Paragraph

text: work in projects such as the Jaoul and the Rob et Roq houses and in the projects for
label: Paragraph

text: Chandigarh. At this same time, however, he began attending the lectures given by the art
label: Paragraph

text: historian Pierre Francastel at La Sorbonne and developing a strong friendship with him.
label: Paragraph

text: Francastel’s social concerns and humanistic views deeply influenced Salmona’s attitudes
label: Paragraph

text: toward architecture and led him in particular to develop a sense for an architecture in tune
label: Paragraph

text: with the Latin American reality and in opposition to both the precepts imparted by Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier and those emerging from the International Style.
label: Paragraph

text: From the onset, Salmona’s preoccupations with craftsmanship infused his work with
label: Paragraph

text: the tectonic aspects of architecture and a concern for its experiential qualities. His
label: Paragraph

text: understanding of history, his intimate relation with the Colombian landscape, and his
label: Paragraph

text: affinity for the use of brick (Bogota’s local material par excellence) and concrete (with
label: Paragraph

text: which he had worked extensively while at Le Corbusier’s atelier) became his trademarks.
label: Paragraph

text: Three significant projects serve as a watershed in the career of the architect: the Torres
label: Paragraph

text: del Parque residential complex (1967) in Bogota, the President’s House for Illustrious
label: Paragraph

text: Guests (1981) in Cartagena, and the National Archives of Colombia (1992) in Bogota.
label: Paragraph

text: Las Torres del Parque is without doubt one of the most significant housing projects of its
label: Paragraph

text: kind, built in the Americas at the precise moment at which the International Style
label: Paragraph

text: precepts were being questioned. The project consists of three brick towers built on a steep
label: Paragraph

text: plot at the northern edge of the Parque de la Independencia (Independence Park) at the
label: Paragraph

text: beginning of the Monserrate foothills. Las Torres del Parque was designed to house some
label: Paragraph

text: 1,500 dwellers in 300 units.
label: Paragraph

text: An architecture aligned neither to the vanishing ideals of the International Style nor to
label: Paragraph

text: the emerging and multifaceted postmodern trends of the 1960s that replaced them, Las
label: Paragraph

text: Torres is uncompromisingly fresh and vigorous, and it expresses a profound sympathy
label: Paragraph

text: for a sense of urbanity, evocative of memorable places. In this project, Salmona also
label: Paragraph

text: introduced a major choreography of urban places in which plant materials play a major
label: Paragraph

text: role, giving a precise character to the outdoor zones of the project and integrating it with
label: Paragraph

text: the adjacent park.
label: Paragraph

text: Salmona’s President’s House for Illustrious Guests in Cartagena is a careful
label: Paragraph

text: intervention in the topography. While respecting and enhancing the silhouette of
label: Paragraph

text: neighboring El Manzanillo fort, it creates a new landscape on what previously was a
label: Paragraph

text: barren site occupied by ruins. To accomplish this, Salmona used simple pragmatic
label: Paragraph

text: principles derived from the Spanish-Moorish tradition as well as from pre-Hispanic
label: Paragraph

text: sources.
label: Paragraph

text: The President’s House is a compound formed of seven courtyards. Quarters for the
label: Paragraph

text: president, his guests, and accompanying personnel have been carefully arranged around
label: Paragraph

text: these courtyards. Additional facilities include a living room, a dining room, meeting
label: Paragraph

text: rooms, a library, and service areas. Throughout the house, the materials used in its
label: Paragraph

text: construction are consistent: brick, tile, coral stone, concrete, and hardwood. Rooms vary
label: Paragraph

text: in proportion according to their function, yet they maintain a continuous unity.
label: Paragraph

text: Differentiation is evident everywhere, carried out with extreme subtlety. The President’s
label: Paragraph

text: House speaks clearly of solemnity and becomes a lesson in the restrained use of materials
label: Paragraph

text: and forms.
label: Paragraph

text: In the General Archives of Colombia, site, history, and distance become integral
label: Paragraph

text: elements of Salmona’s form-making process. It is not accidental that Salmona, although
label: Paragraph

text: alluding to the traditions of Colonial architecture in Colombia, reintroduces two
label: Paragraph

text: important concepts evident in pre-Columbian buildings and poetry: the roof ambulation
label: Paragraph

text: and the skewed access to precincts along diagonal lines. It is possible to experience both
label: Paragraph

text: wandering and wondering on the Archives’ roof, which has become the ludic area of the
label: Paragraph

text: building occupied by a garden and areas adjacent to the cafeteria. Pedestrians on the roof
label: Caption

text: can view and seize the entire surrounding urban panorama modulated by the distant
label: Paragraph

text: landscape while observing the comings and goings of users traversing the building’s great
label: Paragraph

text: central cylindrical void. The central space of the Archives is undoubtedly a significant
label: Paragraph

text: addition to the public spaces of Bogota. Acting as a sounding box that gathers the echoes,
label: Paragraph

text: the light, and some of the landmarks of the city, it is, in every sense, a memorable place.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Returned to Colombia in 1958; began a successful architectural practice in Bogota and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: SANT’ELIA, ANTONIO 1888-1916
label: Title

text: Architect, Italy
label: Title

text: Sant’ Elia attended a technical school in Como and graduated as master builder in 1906.
label: Paragraph

text: He moved to Milan in 1905, where he worked as a draftsman for a canal company, then
label: Paragraph

text: for the municipal engineering department. In 1909, his study for a villa appeared in the
label: Paragraph

text: Milanese review La Casa, and he enrolled at the Brera Academy. Between 1911 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1914, Sant’Elia participated in numerous competitions and exhibitions that would prepare
label: Paragraph

text: him for the most significant project of his oeuvre: La Citta Nuova (The New City). In
label: Paragraph

text: 1914, he exhibited 60 drawings in the show of the group Nuova Tendenze, which he co-
label: Paragraph

text: founded. Its catalogue contained his Messaggio, a text later transformed into the
label: Paragraph

text: Manifesto, with six views of La Citta Nuova. These, with the sketches, represent the peak
label: Paragraph

text: of his graphic work. He probably met the Futurist Fillipo Tomaso Marinetti at this time.
label: Paragraph

text: When Italy entered the war in 1915, Sant’ Elia was among the first to volunteer, joining
label: Paragraph

text: the same regiment as Umberto Boccioni, Marinetti, and Mario Sironi, among other
label: Paragraph

text: Futurists. He enjoyed a brief period of leave, but his relations with the Futurists were then
label: Paragraph

text: interrupted. Conscripted and sent to the front again, as second lieutenant in the infantry
label: Paragraph

text: during the ensuing attacks against enemy trenches between June and July 1916, he was
label: Paragraph

text: wounded and decorated. At this time, Sant’Elia was commissioned to design a cemetery
label: Paragraph

text: for the Arezzo Brigade at Monfalcone. It was still under construction when he fell during
label: Paragraph

text: an assault, shot in the forehead by a machine gun bullet.
label: Paragraph

text: Before Futurism, there had been pragmatic solutions to the problems of urbanism
label: Paragraph

text: through the use of new materials—steel, glass, and concrete—but without a radical
label: Paragraph

text: renewal of architectural language. The symbolic and typological themes of the
label: Paragraph

text: metropolis, skyscrapers, factories, residential and commercial complexes, power- and
label: Paragraph

text: railway stations, had already been treated by Otto Wagner, Tony Garnier, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago School, but the first real urban vision of the future in Italy was presented by
label: Paragraph

text: Sant’Elia in his Messaggio and drawings of La Citta Nuova. Here he proposed, even if in
label: Paragraph

text: utopian terms, the profound modifications that were needed to connect architecture to
label: Paragraph

text: urban structure. The power and originality of his vision derives from an ability to
label: Paragraph

text: interrelate, in all their complexity, the forms and volumes of his chosen elements. He
label: Paragraph

text: shows an interconnected system of circulation and communication that is different from
label: Paragraph

text: the American model of isolated skyscrapers. Though it would seem partly to derive from
label: Paragraph

text: illustrations of futuristic American visions, he presents an architectural understanding of
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneity derived not only from crisscrossing circulation but, above all, from a close
label: Paragraph

text: relation between urban form and building type. The layered traffic suggests a new and
label: Paragraph

text: mutual dynamism between building and circulation that may be understood by reference
label: Paragraph

text: to the concepts that Umberto Boccioni had pioneered: fusion, all-embracing atmosphere,
label: Paragraph

text: and a concept of space as a field. The radical innovation of his imagery, his conception of
label: Paragraph

text: the city as flows, acceptance of the world of machinery, use of industrial types as models,
label: Paragraph

text: and promotion of undecorated flat surfaces with brilliant hues are all original. Sant’ Elia
label: Paragraph

text: was concemed with showing how industrialization and the working city required new
label: Paragraph

text: forms of art, thought, behavior, and language.
label: Paragraph

text: The Fascists tried to claim him as their national architect, but his work is without a
label: Paragraph

text: consciously national character. In the postwar decade Futurism was seen as little more
label: Paragraph

text: than an offshoot of Fascism, so the discovery of the Messaggio 42 years after it originally
label: Paragraph

text: appeared offered hope of severing Sant’Elia from Futurism, and hence Fascism. Both
label: Paragraph

text: documents were apparently ghost written, and despite the absence of the word
label: Paragraph

text: “Futurism”
label: Title

text: La Citta Nuova, Apartment block with external elevators, tunnel, covered
label: Caption

text: passage, on three traffic levels (tramway, road for cars, metal
label: Caption

text: gangway), beacons and wireless telegraphy; ink and pencil on tracing
label: Paragraph

text: paper
label: Title

text: © Musei Civici, Como Italy. Photo courtesy Ross Jenner
label: Caption

text: in the Messaggio, in inspiration and form, both are under the pervasive influence of
label: Paragraph

text: Marinetti and Boccioni. Saint’Elia never disclaimed the Manifesto, and if his designs
label: Paragraph

text: show evidence of originality, it has to be proven that he was not also the principal source
label: Paragraph

text: of the written ideas.
label: Paragraph

text: Provincial, untraveled, caught between modernity and tradition, Sant’Elia in his last
label: Paragraph

text: works reveals a nostalgic return to the Viennese orbit under whose sway he began. The
label: Paragraph

text: ideas that Sant’ Elia developed before the war became ever more a part of the mainstream
label: Paragraph

text: of Modern architecture but were never again so vigorously or freshly presented.
label: Paragraph

text: SANTIAGO, CHILE
label: Title

text: The city of Santiago was founded in the 16th century, between two rivers at the base of a
label: Paragraph

text: hill, following the Spanish grid plan for American cities. Until the 19th century,
label: Paragraph

text: references in the skyline were churches and significant public buildings. In the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century, the city center included high-rise buildings of six to ten stories.
label: Paragraph

text: Parallel to the downtown area, a peripheral zone, unbounded from the city center,
label: Paragraph

text: began to grow, separating the working activities from housing. Appearing toward the
label: Paragraph

text: east, the communes of Providencia in 1897 and Las Condes in 1901, together with the
label: Paragraph

text: city center, concentrate the best examples of 20th-century architecture in the city.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1900, the city of Santiago had emerged with clear recognition of its limits and
label: Paragraph

text: structure because of the ideas of the intendant, Benjamin Vicuifia Mackenna inspired
label: Paragraph

text: himself in the French baron Haussman and the Spanish Idelfonso Cerda, which later was
label: Paragraph

text: further developed by the Austrian Carl Brunner, differentiating a center and four sections
label: Paragraph

text: in a concentric scheme that was maintained well into the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: By the 1930s, the first manifestations of the leading urban and architectural trends
label: Paragraph

text: prevailing in Europe and the United States appeared, introducing Art Nouveau and Art
label: Paragraph

text: Deco expressions, followed by modernism and the International Style. In the 1950s,
label: Paragraph

text: residential growth in the communes of Providencia and Las Condes, inspired by the
label: Paragraph

text: Garden City movement, broke the urban scheme that had prevailed since colonial times.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1970s, a large commercial axis with high-rise buildings developed, connecting the
label: Paragraph

text: center with these communes and transferring traditional business to new centers in these
label: Paragraph

text: areas.
label: Paragraph

text: The primary architectural expression in Santiago remains the skyscraper. The first
label: Paragraph

text: manifestations, built between 1920 and 1940, borrow their image from those prevailing in
label: Paragraph

text: the United States and Europe, expressed as an eclectic mix of styles in rapid succession.
label: Paragraph

text: Formally, the first examples of tall buildings use the pa/azzo model in its two versions,
label: Paragraph

text: referring to the image of the palazzo itself or stretching the middle part up to the needed
label: Paragraph

text: height. In the first case, classical elements are used: in the second, a variety of styles are
label: Paragraph

text: adopted. Clear examples of the classical palazzo are the Banco del Pac ’fico (Bank of the
label: Paragraph

text: Pacific, 1921) by Shade, Oyarzin and Phillippi and the office building of the Banco
label: Caption

text: Hipotecario (Mortgage Bank, 1925) by Siegel and Sons. Fine examples of the stretched
label: Paragraph

text: palazzo are the Edificio Ariztia (Ariztia Building, 1921) by Alberto Cruz Montt and the
label: Caption

text: Diaz Building (1925) by Valdivieso and de la Cruz.
label: Caption

text: Around 1927, the first Art Deco designs appear, with a nationalistic character showing
label: Paragraph

text: local indigenous elements, such as the Merced 849 (1927) by Luciano Kulczewski or the
label: Paragraph

text: Ministerio de Hacienda (Exchequer Ministry Building, 1930) by Smith Solar and Smith
label: Caption

text: Miller. At the same time, the first rationalist designs appear, such as a streamlined
label: Paragraph

text: version, an example being the Oberpauer Building (1929) by Sergio Larrain, today a
label: Paragraph

text: national monument. Especially interesting in this period is the architecture of J.Martinez,
label: Paragraph

text: with works such as the University of Chile’s Law School (1934) and the Military School
label: Paragraph

text: (1943), which suggests the Fascist architecture of the 1930s in Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: In a second stage of architecture in Santiago, between 1945 and 1960, rationalism
label: Paragraph

text: precedes the International Style. Early
label: Paragraph

text: examples include the Banco del Estado (State Bank, 1945) by Hector Mardones and later
label: Paragraph

text: the Plaza Italia Building (1956) by Santiago Roi. A fine Le Corbusier-inspired building is
label: Paragraph

text: the Benedictine Church and Monastery (1954-65), by J.Bellalta, P. Gross, J.Swimburn,
label: Caption

text: R.lrarrazaval, and Fathers M.Cotrea and G.Guarda.
label: Caption

text: From 1960 to 1980, the volume of the block disappears, and the isolated tower
label: Paragraph

text: emerges with an open space, surely inspired by Mies’ Lake Shore Drive Apartments or
label: Paragraph

text: the Seagram Building. In this period, clearly the International Style is consolidated,
label: Paragraph

text: producing buildings with volumetric purity and the use of curtain walls. Fine examples of
label: Paragraph

text: this period are the Reval Building (1963) by Jorge Aguirre; the Costanera Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1975) by Echenique, Cruz and Boisier; and the Torre Santa Maria, Santa Maria Tower
label: Caption

text: (1977), by C.A.Cruz, J.M.Figueroa, J.Claude, Alemparte and Barreda. This period also
label: Caption

text: sees the development of large complexes inspired by Le Corbusier that in some cases
label: Paragraph

text: wiped out extended areas of the city. These include the Remodelacion San Borja (San
label: Paragraph

text: Borja Unit, 1960s) by the Ministry of Housing; the Unidad Vecinal Providencia
label: Paragraph

text: (Providencia Neighborhood Complex, 1966) with its twin towers by Esquenazi and
label: Paragraph

text: Barella; the Torres de Tajamar (Tajamar Towers, 1962-67) by Bresciani, Valdes, Prieto,
label: Caption

text: Castillo, Lorca, Huidobro and Bolton; and the Villa Presidente Frei (President’s Frei
label: Paragraph

text: Complex, 1965) by J.Larrain, O.Larrain, and D.Balmaceda. Other complexes also began
label: Paragraph

text: to appear in the garden city communes toward the new areas farther east of the city, such
label: Paragraph

text: as the Remodelacion San Luis (San Luis Renovation, 1974) by Sandoval and Arancibia
label: Paragraph

text: and the Torres de Vitacura (Three Towers of Vitacura, 1973) by Mauricio Despouy. An
label: Caption

text: important Le Corbusier-inspired building is the Cepal Headquarters for Latin America
label: Paragraph

text: (1963-68) by E.Duhart, R.Goycoolea, C.de Groote, and O.Santelices.
label: Caption

text: A fourth and final period of architectural development includes the last two decades of
label: Paragraph

text: the 20th century, when several of the models used in the previous stage continued to
label: Paragraph

text: prevail, such as the curtain wall-isolated high-rise, as demonstrated by the building
label: Paragraph

text: Estado 10 (1982) by Borquez, Paredes and Sotomayor, or using the mirror glass wall as a
label: Paragraph

text: covering, such as the Edificio Catedral (Cathedral Building, 1982) by Echenique, Cruz,
label: Paragraph

text: Boisier and Dunner or the Shell Building (1989) by Asahi and Associates. Other
label: Caption

text: interesting examples include the Consorcio Nacional de Seguros-Vida (Insurance
label: Paragraph

text: Building, 1992) by B.Huidobro, E.Browne, and Judson (with European influences) and
label: Paragraph

text: the CTC Building (1995) by M.Paredes, J.Iglesis, and L.Prat.
label: Caption

text: The Lever House (designed by Gordon Bunshaft, New York City, 1951) model
label: Caption

text: continues its influence in the Crowne Plaza Hotel (1981) by Alemparte and Barreda.
label: Paragraph

text: Other examples increasingly use mirror glass. The interior galleries used in the past,
label: Paragraph

text: penetrating the city block, are now rescued and reinterpreted in several fine examples,
label: Paragraph

text: such as the Panoramico Building (1981) by San Martin, Browne and Wenborne, which is
label: Paragraph

text: later renovated by Record-n and Sartori (1990), and the Edificio Plaza Lyon (1977) by
label: Paragraph

text: Larrain, Murtinho and Associates and the Shell Building (1989) by Asahi and Associates.
label: Caption

text: New in the 1980s and 1990s is the presence of more local and contextual aspects that
label: Paragraph

text: adhere to Postmodern currents. Examples include the use of pre-Colombian references in
label: Paragraph

text: the Montolin Building (1988) by C.Fernandez and Associates, Art Deco references in the
label: Paragraph

text: Financo Building (1989) by Alemparte and Barreda, classical elements in the Codelco
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1984) by Boza and Associates, and the CCT Building (1991) by G.Mardones
label: Paragraph

text: and Associates, inspired in the old brick buildings of downtown Santiago.
label: Paragraph

text: The recognition of scale of place directed the design of the Fundacion Building (1982)
label: Caption

text: and the Americas Building (1990) by Boza and the Torre San Ramon (San Ramon
label: Caption

text: Tower, 1988) by Flafio, Nufiez, and Tuca.
label: Caption

text: The use of color or the curve is also present as a strong plastic element applied to
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, such as that located at Callao and Versalles Streets (1991) by Boza and
label: Paragraph

text: Associates and the Banmedica Building (1998) by B.Huidobro and Associates.
label: Caption

text: At present, architects are reinterpreting famous existing buildings, such as the Simon
label: Paragraph

text: Bolivar Building (1991) by Paredes and Associates, with a clear reference to the AT&T
label: Paragraph

text: Building by Philip Johnson in New York, and the Cruz Blanca Building (1991) by
label: Caption

text: G.Kreft, producing a bizarre reference to the Chrysler Building in New York. We leave
label: Paragraph

text: the 20th century and enter the 21st with an increasingly eclectic architecture that, together
label: Paragraph

text: with the mall culture, is slowly making our cities lose their local character in a world of
label: Paragraph

text: globalization.
label: Paragraph

text: SANTOS, ADELE NAUDE 1938-
label: Title

text: Architect, South Africa
label: Title

text: Adéle Naudé Santos’ early design projects in southern Africa in collaboration with her
label: Paragraph

text: first husband, Antonio de Souza Santos, included innovative private houses, apartment
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, and low-cost workers’ housing and facilities, including a church and school.
label: Paragraph

text: Her early houses incorporated principles of planning the “house as a city,” controlling
label: Paragraph

text: space through section, and a process for analyzing site and social issues that would
label: Paragraph

text: govern her design and teaching throughout her career. The most remarkable of these early
label: Paragraph

text: projects were the five Molteno houses at Rowan Lane, Kennilworth, Cape Town (1973),
label: Paragraph

text: fitted into an existing garden grove, and House Stekhoven (1972), a private residence that
label: Paragraph

text: opened like a grand piano from a dull cul-de-sac of suburban houses dramatically toward
label: Paragraph

text: Table Mountain, seen as the culmination of a private garden from carefully segregated
label: Paragraph

text: family spaces through glazed walls and across shared walkways sheltered by an
label: Paragraph

text: undulating bris-soleil.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout her career as architect and educator, Naudé Santos treated practice as a
label: Paragraph

text: component of research. “The work is usually designed experimentally, imagining space
label: Paragraph

text: or spatial sequences,” she wrote. “The cross-section is a design tool that often precedes
label: Paragraph

text: the plan.” Research projects have included urban design studies such as “Open Space
label: Paragraph

text: Choice for Blighted Inner City Neighborhoods” (1985) and “Urban Design Strategy for
label: Paragraph

text: Center City East, San Diego” (1993) as well as the development of housing prototypes
label: Paragraph

text: for Misawa Homes, Tokyo (1989), and for the city of Kitakyushu, Japan (1992-94),
label: Paragraph

text: where the Kadota and Dairi Nishi housing projects were built (1996).
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1980s, Naudé Santos often used entries in national and international design
label: Paragraph

text: competitions as a means to further her research into contextualizing design. She won
label: Paragraph

text: competitions of the Hawaii-Loa Pacific Center for the Media Arts (1986), the Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles ArtsPark (1989), and the Perris California Civic Center (1991) and had
label: Paragraph

text: premiated entries in competitions for In-fill Housing, Harlem, New York (1986) and
label: Paragraph

text: Hillside Housing, Cincinnati (1985). In 1988, she also won an invited competition
label: Paragraph

text: sponsored by the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, and the Community
label: Paragraph

text: Redevelopment Agency for New Case-Study Houses. Replacing dingbat models for low-
label: Paragraph

text: cost housing with a “small-town” structure made up of courtyards linked by offset
label: Paragraph

text: walkways, with 40 interlocking, variably functioned units with distinctive curved roofs
label: Paragraph

text: and balconies, her winning Franklin-La Brea project, with revisions, was built (1995),
label: Paragraph

text: nestled atop the intersection of Franklin and La Brea Avenues in Los Angeles.
label: Paragraph

text: Expanding her practice to Japan, Naudé Santos was commissioned to design a mixed-
label: Paragraph

text: use building in Harajuku, Tokyo (1984), where she interlocked shared and private spaces
label: Paragraph

text: for a joint family, ideas worked out further in a two-unit family house in Tokyo (1990).
label: Paragraph

text: As Philip Arcidi wrote in Progressive Architecture (November 1990), “In this house,
label: Paragraph

text: Santos’s spatial strategy yields results that complement those of her public buildings. ...
label: Paragraph

text: She renders the interior an exceptional sequence of layered volumes, where Nature is
label: Paragraph

text: encountered within an urban refuge.”
label: Paragraph

text: Other major projects in Japan included a playful small office building of interlocking
label: Paragraph

text: spaces, bringing light deep into a very constrained Ichiban-Cho urban site (1988), that
label: Paragraph

text: has adjusted gracefully to changing uses since it was built; the Ohgimi Beach House
label: Paragraph

text: (1988), a company lodge that “settles like a leaf’ into a protected pine forest in exurban
label: Paragraph

text: Ninomiya; and Tokyo Fantasia, an unbuilt atrium office building organized around a
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable six-story garden stairway.
label: Caption

text: Yerba Buena Gardens (1998), San Francisco, California
label: Caption

text: Photo © Antonio Garbasso. Courtesy Adele Naude Santos and Associates with
label: Caption

text: LDA Architects.
label: Paragraph

text: In the United States in the 1990s, Naudé Santos designed public spaces that
label: Paragraph

text: interpenetrated spatially complex interiors with the variable light and nature of a variety
label: Paragraph

text: of exterior landscapes, including the Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia (1991);
label: Paragraph

text: Albright College Center for the Arts, Reading, Pennsylvania (1991), a series of buildings
label: Caption

text: that reshaped a campus around an open atrium-amphitheater that incorporated a
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration sponsored by the National Endowment for the Humanities between Naudé
label: Paragraph

text: Santos and the environmental artist Mary Miss; the Natatorium at Albright College
label: Paragraph

text: (1990); and the unbuilt Perris California Civic Center. These public projects culminated
label: Paragraph

text: in the Zeum and Rooftop Complex at Yerba Buena Gardens, San Francisco (1998),
label: Caption

text: intertwining a children’s museum, a child-care center, a glazed pavilion for an antique
label: Paragraph

text: carousel, a bowling alley, a cafe, and an indoor ice-skating rink forming a subtle people’s
label: Paragraph

text: acropolis on top of the city’s Moscone Convention Center.
label: Caption

text: Throughout her career, Naudé Santos explored housing in sociologically sensitive
label: Paragraph

text: spatial terms, nowhere more experimentally than in a series of lofts, some for her own
label: Paragraph

text: use in Boston (1980) and Philadelphia (1983) and others responding to San Francisco’s
label: Paragraph

text: demand for live-work units, as in the five lofts that she interwove around a shared court
label: Paragraph

text: that she carved into the center of an old warehouse between Rich and Zoe Streets (1998).
label: Paragraph

text: These issues of space, design, and society also governed her teaching and formed a
label: Paragraph

text: rigorous frame for the new curriculum that she and the formidable faculty whom she
label: Paragraph

text: recruited had begun to frame for the new school that she conceived for the University of
label: Paragraph

text: California, San Diego. As a final gift to that city, the school sponsored the production of
label: Paragraph

text: an urban design strategy that the city adopted, as the school itself was being dismantled in
label: Paragraph

text: 1994 during one of California’s deep financial downturns and was able to graduate only a
label: Paragraph

text: SAO PAULO, BRAZIL
label: Title

text: The city of SAo Paulo, capital of the state with the same name and the industrial and
label: Paragraph

text: financial center of Brazil, has been described since the last decades of the 19th to the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century as a locomotive. Unlike cities with outstanding natural beauty, such as Rio de
label: Paragraph

text: Janeiro, Sao Paulo has been likened to a powerful engine, the product of human impact,
label: Paragraph

text: altering and overcoming natural obstacles in favor of civilization.
label: Paragraph

text: Sao Paulo was founded by the Jesuits in 1554 as a mission center (the central colonial
label: Paragraph

text: area called Patio do Colégio) on a plateau 760 meters (2,493 feet) above sea level,
label: Paragraph

text: although only 72 kilometers (35 miles) from the Atlantic coast. It remained a small town
label: Paragraph

text: for a long time and would have to wait until the 18th century to be chartered as a city
label: Paragraph

text: (1711) and a further century and a half to experience unparalleled urban growth to
label: Paragraph

text: become today one of the largest cities in the world, housing more than 15 million
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants in its metropolitan area.
label: Paragraph

text: Local pride had attributed the industriousness of Sio Paulo inhabitants (“Paulistas”) to
label: Paragraph

text: the “bandeirantes” who had the city as a base for their expeditions. They were explorers
label: Paragraph

text: responsible for marking territory for the Portuguese crown while imprisoning or killing
label: Paragraph

text: native Indians and searching for precious stones. However, it was the massive European
label: Paragraph

text: immigration at the turn of the 20th century (Italian, Portuguese, Spanish, German, Syrian-
label: Paragraph

text: Lebanese, and later Japanese), together with the coffee export boom and industrialization,
label: Paragraph

text: that defined the modern city and its architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: As a result, if in 1895 So Paulo had 130,000 inhabitants, in 1900 its population had
label: Paragraph

text: almost doubled. Disorderly growth was met with remarkable urban improvements,
label: Paragraph

text: including the opening of avenues, lighting, gasworks, public transportation, and works
label: Paragraph

text: for embellishment. Municipal commissions prepared reports on the living conditions of
label: Paragraph

text: the working classes of the industrial neighborhoods of the city, especially Luz, Bom
label: Paragraph

text: Retiro, Bras, and Mooca. Epidemics such as smallpox, Spanish flu, and yellow fever, as
label: Paragraph

text: well as the moral and physical menace of slums, were to be avoided by sanitation, street
label: Paragraph

text: planning, and drainage and channeling of rivers, all planned by the local administration
label: Paragraph

text: and the newly created Engineering School (Escola Politécnica, 1894). The opening of
label: Paragraph

text: Avenida Paulista (1891) and the building of Viaduto do Cha (1892), uniting the old
label: Paragraph

text: center to new industrial areas, and of the So Paulo Railway Station (Estacfo da Luz,
label: Paragraph

text: 1901) were seen as proof of progress.
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture was a major force behind these changes. The style chosen—
label: Paragraph

text: ecclecticism—teflected European models and was considered to be the most civilized
label: Paragraph

text: and appealing to bourgeois taste. It can be found at Carlos Ekman’s Vila Penteado (rua
label: Paragraph

text: Maranhao) and in the works of architect engineer Francisco de Paula Ramos de Azevedo
label: Paragraph

text: (1851-1928), who studied in Belgium and planned a large number of private mansions
label: Paragraph

text: and public buildings, such as the school Caetano de Campos (1894), the Palacio das
label: Paragraph

text: Industrias (Industry Palace, 1911-24, with Domiziano Rossi), and the Municipal Theatre
label: Paragraph

text: (Teatro Municipal, 1895-1911, with associates).
label: Paragraph

text: In 1912, the City of Sio Paulo Improvements and Freehold Company (known as the
label: Paragraph

text: “City”) was established in London with the aim to develop distant suburban areas in Sao
label: Paragraph

text: Paulo following the pattern of Ebenezer Howard’s (1850-1928) garden cities. Raymond
label: Paragraph

text: Unwin (1863-1940) and Barry Parker (1867-1941) were commissioned to develop the
label: Paragraph

text: areas of Jardim America and City Lapa and to rearrange the Trianon Park at Avenida
label: Paragraph

text: Paulista (1917-19). The growth of Séo Paulo and workers’ unrest during the first decades
label: Paragraph

text: of the century led Mayor Washington Luis to declare during the opening of Sao Paulo
label: Paragraph

text: Industry Palace that the city was “Chicago and Manchester together in one.”
label: Paragraph

text: Copan Building (1957) designed by Oscar Niemeyer
label: Caption

text: © Eduardo Costa
label: Title

text: During the 1922 Sao Paulo’s Modern Art Week, spearheaded by the intellectuals Mario
label: Paragraph

text: de Andrade and Oswald de Andrade, among others, there was an urgent cry for devising
label: Paragraph

text: a national style in the arts and a modern aesthetics rooted on indigenous sources.
label: Paragraph

text: Ecclecticism was substituted for a vigorous modern architecture and urban planning.
label: Paragraph

text: Skyscrapers were built, and the Plano de Avenidas, an ambitious design of radial streets
label: Paragraph

text: by the engineer Francisco Prestes Maia (1826-1965; twice mayor, nominated 1937-45,
label: Caption

text: elected 1961-65), was partly executed.
label: Paragraph

text: Modern architecture in Brazil has created a regional version of the International Style.
label: Paragraph

text: Although there are examples of the Art Deco style, such as Rino Levi’s cinemas and
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers of the 1920s (Columbus Building, Rino Levi, 1932, demolished; Martinelli
label: Caption

text: Building, 1934, 105 meters and 26 floors, the largest ever built in South America at the
label: Paragraph

text: time), Sio Paulo houses several examples of the local adoption of Le Corbusier’s “five
label: Paragraph

text: steps.” Gregori Warchavchik (1896-1982) designed several residences, including his
label: Paragraph

text: own (1928, rua Santa Cruz), a boxlike building based on geometry, symmetry, and
label: Paragraph

text: standardization of building materials that was visited by Le Corbusier himself in 1929.
label: Paragraph

text: The Esther Building (Praga da Republica, 1938) by Alvaro Vital Brazil (1909-97), with
label: Caption

text: Ademar Marinho (1909-), featured a roof terrace, continuous window strips, and free
label: Paragraph

text: facade composition in a residential and commercial building.
label: Caption

text: In the postwar period, with about two million inhabitants, Sdo Paulo experienced huge
label: Paragraph

text: and disorderly growth as a result of real estate speculation, clandestine housing, and lack
label: Paragraph

text: of basic public services. Verticalization was regarded as a symbol of the city’s economic
label: Paragraph

text: power, beating its rival Rio de Janeiro. During his 1958 visit, Roger Bastide noted with
label: Paragraph

text: astonishment, “Here the architect’s hand replaced God’s hand.” The highlights of this
label: Paragraph

text: period are the Masp Building (Modern Museum of Art, 1957-68) by Lina Bo Bardi
label: Paragraph

text: (1914-92) and Niemeyer; several buildings, such as Copan, a lyrically curved residential
label: Paragraph

text: and commercial building; the buildings of Ibirapuera Park and the park itself; and
label: Paragraph

text: landscapist Burle Marx (1909-94). The park was conceived as a 1.6-million-square-meter
label: Paragraph

text: green area inside the metropolis. Niemeyer’s Memorial da America Latina (Latin
label: Caption

text: America Memorial) was built only in 1988-89.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1960s, Sao Paulo found in the architect Vilanova Artigas (1915-85) a voice
label: Paragraph

text: of renovation. He created the architecture courses at the University of Sio Paulo and
label: Paragraph

text: planned its building (1961-68), defending that design as a tool for political, social, and
label: Paragraph

text: ideological emancipation. His engaged and revolutionary style cost him a serious
label: Paragraph

text: persecution during Brazil’s dictatorial rule but enabled him to open the road for a
label: Paragraph

text: “Paulista School” against Rio de Janeiro’s “Niemeyer School.”
label: Paragraph

text: The Paulista Brutalism movement was soon to follow, with several examples in the
label: Paragraph

text: houses built by Carlos Milan (1927-64). Among the new crop of architects, several stood
label: Paragraph

text: out, such as Rodrigo Lefevre (1938-84), Paulo Mendes da Rocha (1928-), Fabio
label: Paragraph

text: Penteado (1928-), Julio Katinsky (1932-), Siegbert Zanetiini (1934—-), Ruy Othake
label: Paragraph

text: (1938-), Joaquim Guedes (1932-), and Sérgio Ferro (1938-).
label: Paragraph

text: The city’s underground was built during 1973-79, a remarkable engineering work
label: Paragraph

text: featuring an original use of reinforced concrete in all stations.
label: Paragraph

text: The last decades of the 20th century witnessed Sao Paulo stepping, perhaps too late,
label: Paragraph

text: into the preservation era, listing several buildings and areas and sponsoring daring
label: Paragraph

text: revitalization projects, such as the Pinacoteca do Estado (1998, Paulo Mendes da Rocha).
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, however, pollution and urban violence had worsened, social inequality
label: Paragraph

text: had mounted, and urban growth continued at a chaotic pace. “Postmodern” architecture
label: Paragraph

text: has had its share at Avenida Paulista, once the setting for the mansions of the local
label: Paragraph

text: bourgeoisie and today a corridor of skyscrapers; the same happened at the Avenida
label: Paragraph

text: Berrini skyscrapers for offices and banks, many of them the work of Carlos Bratke and
label: Paragraph

text: his associates. These huge glass towers are a few steps away from one among several
label: Paragraph

text: existing favelas (shantytowns). Housing problems have escalated, and about 2.5 million
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants live today in clandestine urban areas, constituting a parallel city inside Sao
label: Paragraph

text: Paulo the size of the country’s third-largest city in population.
label: Paragraph

text: SARASOTA SCHOOL
label: Title

text: The Sarasota School was the name given to a group of architects practicing from 1940 to
label: Paragraph

text: 1960 in and around Sarasota, Florida, on the Gulf of Mexico. The Sarasota School was
label: Paragraph

text: one of several regional interpretations of modern architecture in the United States to
label: Paragraph

text: emerge in the years following the end of World War LI, including the Bay Area School in
label: Paragraph

text: San Francisco and the Case Study Houses group in Los Angeles. By comparison to these
label: Paragraph

text: other regional movements, the Sarasota School was the least intentional, evolving as it
label: Paragraph

text: did from Ralph Twitchell’s fortuitous presence during one of Florida’s building booms.
label: Paragraph

text: From the very start of his Sarasota career in 1936, Twitchell’s work exhibited a respect
label: Paragraph

text: for the unique landscape and climate of the west coast of Florida, his interest in local
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular building culture, and his desire to employ newly emerging construction
label: Paragraph

text: materials and methods to appropriately house the particularly American version of a
label: Paragraph

text: tropical lifestyle then being defined in Sarasota.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1941, Twitchell was joined by Paul Rudolph, who moved to Florida as a result of
label: Paragraph

text: his interest in Frank Lloyd Wright’s recent works, in particular Florida Southern College.
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph was a designer of remarkable ability, and the buildings and projects that resulted
label: Paragraph

text: from this partnership were astonishing in their consistent high quality. In their designs,
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph and Twitchell endeavored to engage the landscape and to develop individual
label: Paragraph

text: buildings that employed modernist concepts of spatial liberation framed by a
label: Paragraph

text: complementary urban order. Their project for the Finney residence on Siesta Key (1947),
label: Paragraph

text: a design that Rudolph had made the previous year while a graduate student at Harvard
label: Paragraph

text: University, proposed a series of walls, bridges, and dredged inlets that allowed the house
label: Paragraph

text: to be fully integrated with its site, acting to join remote bodies of land and water while
label: Paragraph

text: remaining delicately suspended above the landscape. The Rudolph and Twitchell project
label: Caption

text: for six linked residences on the Revere property in Siesta Key (1948) represents a
label: Paragraph

text: remarkably prescient and constructive critique of postwar American suburban
label: Paragraph

text: development. These six houses, of which only the Revere residence was built, opposed
label: Paragraph

text: the typical suburban distribution of houses as freestanding objects, proposing instead a
label: Paragraph

text: series of plastically interlocked walls and horizontal planes, providing a mix of shade and
label: Paragraph

text: sun to open-air courts while weaving interior and exterior space to yield both increased
label: Paragraph

text: privacy and significantly greater density.
label: Paragraph

text: The paradise-like settings of the Sarasota School houses, which today appear so lushly
label: Paragraph

text: “natural,” were in fact the result of a process of ruthless scalping, shaping, and dredging
label: Paragraph

text: of the original mangrove-covered, water-saturated landscape to produce navigable canals
label: Paragraph

text: and buildable sites. These newly created and virtually barren lots on the Gulf coast
label: Paragraph

text: required the architects of the Sarasota School to design not only the houses but also their
label: Paragraph

text: sites. The result was a series of buildings that subtly wove their sharp-edged geometric
label: Paragraph

text: forms into the relentless horizontality of the Florida landscape, employing structural and
label: Paragraph

text: constructional techniques developed for the local climate, economy, and available
label: Paragraph

text: materials and providing their occupants varied seasonal experiences of sun-drenched
label: Paragraph

text: interior and exterior spaces. The Healy “Cocoon House” (1950), built on the edge of a
label: Paragraph

text: canal in Siesta Key, with its suspended rubberized roof secured with cable stays,
label: Paragraph

text: exemplified the manner in which Twitchell’s interest in engaging new building
label: Paragraph

text: technologies complemented Rudolph’s capacity to explore their liberative spatial
label: Paragraph

text: possibilities.
label: Paragraph

text: Following the establishment of his individual practice in 1951, Rudolph began to
label: Paragraph

text: receive significant national and international attention. His Revere model house was
label: Paragraph

text: visited by more than 16,000 people during 1949. His working relationship with the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural photographers Ezra Stoller and Joseph Steinmetz (Steinmetz Studio,
label: Paragraph

text: Sarasota, 1947) was instrumental in Rudolph’s ability to create his own publicity. Skillful
label: Paragraph

text: photographs highlighted the crisp lines and thin planes of the Leavengood residence built
label: Paragraph

text: in St. Petersburg (1951), the Sandeling Beach Club built in Siesta Key (1952), the Walker
label: Paragraph

text: Guest House built on Sanibel Island (1952), and the Hiss “Umbrella House” built on Lido
label: Paragraph

text: Shores (1953). When combined with Rudolph’s signature perspective drawings of both
label: Paragraph

text: built and unbuilt projects, these publications conveyed a sense of informality and
label: Paragraph

text: naturalness of lifestyle while exhibiting an inevitability and precision in their
label: Paragraph

text: architectonic resolution.
label: Paragraph

text: At its height, the Sarasota School included Mark Hampton, Victor Lundy, Tim Siebert,
label: Paragraph

text: Jack West, Gene Leedy, Carl Abbott, Bert Brosmith, Joseph Farrell, William Rupp, and
label: Title

text: Ralph and William Zimmerman, many of whom began their careers working for Rudolph
label: Paragraph

text: and Twitchell. Each of these architects developed his own distinct qualities of space and
label: Paragraph

text: form, from Lundy’s sweeping pagoda-like wood roofs (St. Paul’s Lutheran Church,
label: Paragraph

text: Sarasota, 1958) to Leedy’s rhythmic lines of precast concrete beams (First National
label: Paragraph

text: Bank, Cape Canaveral, 1963) to Abbott’s elegantly articulated geometries (Weld
label: Paragraph

text: Residence, Boca Grande, 1966). The variety of designs within such a small community
label: Paragraph

text: defied the stereotypical representation of modern architecture as lacking richness and
label: Paragraph

text: diversity.
label: Paragraph

text: After starting construction on his four final Florida masterworks—Riverview High
label: Paragraph

text: School in Sarasota (1958), Sarasota High School (1959), the Deering residence in Casey
label: Paragraph

text: Key (1959), and the Milam residence in Ponte Vedra (1960)}—Rudolph in 1958 was
label: Paragraph

text: appointed dean of the School of Architecture at Yale University, where among his first
label: Paragraph

text: students were Norman Foster and Richard Rogers. With the exit from Sarasota in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s of Rudolph, Lundy, Hampton, Rupp, Farrell, Brosmith, and Leedy, the Sarasota
label: Caption

text: School ended.
label: Paragraph

text: Sarasota High School, Sarasota, Florida, designed by Paul Rudolph (1959)
label: Caption

text: Ezra Stoller © Esto
label: Title

text: Although the American architectural profession has been slow to recognize the quality of
label: Paragraph

text: the work of the Sarasota School (having failed to award Rudolph the American Institute
label: Paragraph

text: of Architecture Gold Medal at his death in 1997), it received extensive and immediate
label: Paragraph

text: international attention. Typical is the experience of British architects and Team 10
label: Paragraph

text: founders, Alison and Peter Smithson, who, in their search for alternatives to the universal
label: Paragraph

text: formula of the International Style in the early 1950s, were inspired by the works being
label: Paragraph

text: built in Sarasota. The Sarasota School exemplified the concept of a regionally inflected
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture, true to the universal intentions of spatial liberation yet capable of
label: Paragraph

text: engaging local climate, landscape, and building culture and demonstrating the significant
label: Paragraph

text: benefits of an evolutionary rather than revolutionary development of modern architecture.
label: Paragraph
