text: SAUDI ARABIA
label: Title

text: With a land area in excess of 2.2 million square kilometers, the kingdom of Saudi Arabia
label: Paragraph

text: today covers most of the Arabian peninsula. The recent history of its architectural and
label: Paragraph

text: urban development has been closely linked to its emergence as a modern nation and to
label: Paragraph

text: the development of a powerful economy based on the exploitation of natural resources.
label: Paragraph

text: Saudi Arabia’s opening to the international economy from the 1950s on introduced new
label: Paragraph

text: building technologies and styles that have today largely replaced centuries-old traditional
label: Paragraph

text: practices. However, since the 1980s, the maturation of native Saudi institutions and the
label: Paragraph

text: work of Saudi designers, engineers, and planners has led to many successful projects that
label: Paragraph

text: bridge modern design practices and technologies and still-valued traditional forms and
label: Paragraph

text: ifestyles.
label: Paragraph

text: Climate has played a key role in urban form and architectural production in Saudi
label: Paragraph

text: Arabia for centuries. The kingdom generally lies within one of the world’s hottest and
label: Paragraph

text: driest regions, with more than 50 percent of its land being desert. Yet within this
label: Paragraph

text: dominant climatic milieu, local characteristics vary considerably. This relationship was
label: Paragraph

text: long evident in the traditional approaches to the built environment in Saudi Arabia’s four
label: Paragraph

text: principal regions: the Central (Najd) and Northern region; the Western (Hijaz) region; the
label: Paragraph

text: Eastern region along the Persian Gulf; and the Southern mountainous region.
label: Paragraph

text: In the extremely hot and arid areas of the Central and Northern region, the courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: was long the main feature of any building. Courtyards traditionally acted as climatic
label: Paragraph

text: moderators and allowed a unique private lifestyle to develop. In desert communities, built
label: Paragraph

text: argely of adobe, open spaces generally only took the form of private courtyards and
label: Paragraph

text: natrow, winding streets.
label: Caption

text: In the Western (Hijaz) region, with its hot and humid climate of Red Sea coastal
label: Paragraph

text: communities, the basic traditional building type was the multistory row house built of
label: Paragraph

text: coral stone and imported wood. The refined building art of this region was also
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by an intermixing of cultures and the import of technological skills as the
label: Paragraph

text: result of trade and pilgrimage. One distinct vernacular form that developed here was the
label: Paragraph

text: mashrabiyah, a facade of transparent wooden screens, originally used in the houses of
label: Paragraph

text: Jeddah to afford both ventilation and visual privacy. When this form gained popularity as
label: Paragraph

text: a decorative element, it in turn influenced house design in the hot and dry inland cities of
label: Paragraph

text: Mecca and Medina and in the upland city of Taif.
label: Paragraph

text: The Eastern Region along the Persian Gulf includes the cities of al-Ahsa, Qatif,
label: Paragraph

text: Dammam, and Jubail and is characterized by a maritime inland desert climate. Here, two-
label: Paragraph

text: story courtyard houses built of mud were the typical building type. Such dwellings often
label: Paragraph

text: featured traditional bagdir or malgaf, wind catchers used to control ventilation.
label: Paragraph

text: The Southern region, which includes the Asir Mountains and extends from Taif
label: Paragraph

text: through Baha to Abha, is characterized by a cooler climate with considerable seasonal
label: Paragraph

text: rain. In its settlements, many located at altitudes greater than 2000 meters, buildings
label: Paragraph

text: generally took the form of square, multistory towers. Four principal construction types
label: Paragraph

text: developed based on the local microclimate and available materials: mud tower houses,
label: Paragraph

text: stone rubble houses, stone apron houses, and mud and slate tower buildings. A
label: Paragraph

text: particularly characteristic form of the Asir region was the gasabah, a freestanding tower
label: Paragraph

text: of mud or stone used in isolated farming villages both for defense and to warn of the
label: Paragraph

text: approach of raiders from other tribes.
label: Paragraph

text: Until the second half of the 20th century, these regional urban and architectural
label: Paragraph

text: traditions responded well to local cultural and material conditions and allowed people to
label: Paragraph

text: adjust their activity cycles to climatic variations. In more recent times, however, modern
label: Paragraph

text: forms and patterns have been introduced that have largely replaced these traditional
label: Paragraph

text: practices.
label: Paragraph

text: Two major building campaigns of the 1950s can today be judged as having initiated
label: Paragraph

text: this process: the expansion of the holy mosques of Mecca and Medina and the huge
label: Paragraph

text: program involved in transferring the nation’s capital from Mecca to Riyadh. From 1951
label: Paragraph

text: to 1955, the government undertook a major effort to repair and expand the Prophet
label: Paragraph

text: Mosque in Medina, with the result being a fourfold increase in the area for prayer; a
label: Paragraph

text: second huge project from 1955 to 1974 expanded the holy mosque in Mecca, where the
label: Paragraph

text: area available for prayer was increased from 29,127 to 193,000 square meters. The
label: Paragraph

text: building program in Riyadh likewise spanned many years. Its first phase, in the mid-
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s, included construction of both a complex of ministry buildings on the airport road
label: Paragraph

text: and a housing project for government employees in the Malaz area. Also a part of the
label: Paragraph

text: early work were the rebuilding and expansion of the royal palace at Nasirriyah to cover
label: Paragraph

text: 250 hectares, the rebuilding of the main mosque and government palace in the city center,
label: Paragraph

text: and the widening of the two main streets leading into the city.
label: Paragraph

text: Coupled with the Aramco grid plans for al-Khobar and Dammam in 1947 and the
label: Paragraph

text: Aramco Employees Home Ownership program launched in 1951, these government
label: Paragraph

text: building campaigns laid a foundation for the development of contemporary building and
label: Paragraph

text: planning practices in Saudi Arabia. However, the introduction of new processes,
label: Paragraph

text: materials, and techniques was first carried out largely through the import of foreign
label: Paragraph

text: expertise to the kingdom. From the early 1960s on, the gridded street pattern and the villa
label: Paragraph

text: as a preferred house type assumed primacy in the development of most every city and
label: Paragraph

text: town. Processes of urban change and expansion were given further impetus by the
label: Paragraph

text: compensation given private property owners in Mecca, Medina, and Riyadh following
label: Paragraph

text: the expropriation of their traditional city center houses to make way for government
label: Paragraph

text: projects. Apartment buildings also first began to appear in Riyadh, Mecca, Medina, and
label: Paragraph

text: Jeddah from the late 1950s on. In the mid-1950s, the government launched a national
label: Paragraph

text: school-building program, which brought international-style design in reinforced concrete
label: Paragraph

text: and cement block to the smallest towns and villages.
label: Paragraph

text: A further change in Saudi cities and towns in the 1960s was the introduction of high-
label: Paragraph

text: rise construction. Distinct among the earliest such projects were the Saudi Arabian
label: Paragraph

text: Airlines and the Saudi Radio Broadcasting buildings in Jeddah. However, the twenty-
label: Paragraph

text: two-story Queen building (1972) in Jeddah represented the most radical break with
label: Paragraph

text: tradition, and for many years it stood as a principal landmark on the city’s skyline. Other
label: Paragraph

text: notable projects in the early 1970s included the UPM Campus in Dhahran by CRS,
label: Paragraph

text: whose design considered the natural terrain and employed an exposed-aggregate texture
label: Paragraph

text: to blend with its surroundings; the Equestrian Club Building (1973) in Riyadh by Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Basil, which responded effectively to climate using new architectural forms; and the
label: Paragraph

text: Intercontinental Hotels and Conference Centers (1971) in Riyadh by Trevord Dannat and
label: Caption

text: in Mecca (1973) by Rolf Gutbrod and Frei Otto, which emerged from international
label: Paragraph

text: design competitions.
label: Paragraph

text: Following the oil boom of 1973, the new wealth had profound, wide-reaching
label: Paragraph

text: consequences for Saudi cities and towns. This was particularly evident in campaigns of
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructure development and in the design and construction of new universities,
label: Paragraph

text: schools, hospitals, hotels, airports and seaports, factories, housing estates, and entire new
label: Paragraph

text: towns. The oil boom also led to the establishment of the national Real Estate
label: Paragraph

text: Development
label: Title

text: Holy Prophet Mosque of Medina (1950-55, first phase; 1983-1994, second
label: Caption

text: phase)
label: Title

text: © Saleh Al-Hathloul
label: Title

text: Fund, offering individual Saudi citizens subsidized long-term loans to build private
label: Paragraph

text: houses, apartments, and office buildings. Half the country’s housing stock has been
label: Paragraph

text: replenished through this program since its initatiation. Coupled with government land
label: Paragraph

text: grants, available to every Saudi citizen 18 years of age or older, it has led to a several-
label: Paragraph

text: fold expansion of most Saudi cities and towns.
label: Paragraph

text: Although most early modern architecture and planning in the kingdom was carried out
label: Paragraph

text: by foreign-trained experts, from the 1980s onward, local architects, engineers, and
label: Paragraph

text: planners began to assume an increasingly important role. For instance, Ali Shuaibi and
label: Paragraph

text: Abdurrahman Al-Hussaini of Beeah Group Consultants have given special emphasis to
label: Paragraph

text: sociocultural values, in particular to the desire to relate modern construction methods to
label: Paragraph

text: the Islamic past. Their distinct planning work has included the al-Ugqair Tourist
label: Paragraph

text: Development Plan (1986), the Jubail Subregional Plan (1998), and the Strategic
label: Paragraph

text: Comprehensive Plan (1998) for the Holy Environs and Mecca, which addressed the need
label: Paragraph

text: to accommodate and transfer two million pilgrims between Mecca and the Holy Environs
label: Paragraph

text: during the five-day pilgrimage. Beeah Group Consultants has also been known for such
label: Paragraph

text: urban design work as its Central Spine, DQ(1980); the Qasr al-Hukm project (1983); and
label: Paragraph

text: the King Abdulaziz Historical Center (1998), all in Riyadh. The continued value of
label: Paragraph

text: seclusion and privacy in Saudi culture was evident in the design of al-Kindi Plaza (1986)
label: Paragraph

text: in Riyadh, which won the Agha Khan Award for Architecture. Other important designs
label: Paragraph

text: are the Saudi Embassy (1987) in Yemen, the King Saud Mosque (1992) in Riyadh, the
label: Paragraph

text: SAPICO Headquarters (1992) in Islamabad, and the Municipality of Medina Complex
label: Paragraph

text: (2000), all of which combine past and present, a necessity in the perpetuation of culture.
label: Paragraph

text: Equally impressive projects have been designed by the team known as Basim al-
label: Paragraph

text: Shihabi of Omrania. Their projects include the General Organization for Social Insurance
label: Paragraph

text: (GOSI) Headquarters (1978); the Twaiq Palace (1985), an Agha Khan Award winner; the
label: Paragraph

text: Gulf Cooperation Council building (1987); and the King Abdulaziz Archival building (al-
label: Paragraph

text: Darah) (1998), all in Riyadh. The current direction of ideas that al-Shihabi originally
label: Paragraph

text: synthesized in the 1970s are evident in the NNCI Headquarters building (1999) and the
label: Paragraph

text: Kingdom Complex, which includes a 330-meter-high tower to be completed in 2001.
label: Paragraph

text: A third noteworthy Saudi architecture firm, Mohammad Al-Naim and Farahat
label: Paragraph

text: Tashkandi of Al-Nai, has emphasized the importance of continuity in cultural traditions
label: Paragraph

text: in a changing world. This theme can be seen in their neighborhood layouts and land
label: Paragraph

text: subdivision projects for MOMRA (1993) and in layouts for the Namar and Uraid
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods (1994) in Riyadh. The team’s design for municipal prototype houses
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to revitalize the traditional Arab house, not through formalistic adaptation but
label: Paragraph

text: by reconstituting essential values in new forms. Other work has included the School of
label: Paragraph

text: Environmental Design building, KAU (1987), in Jeddah and the College of Architecture
label: Caption

text: and Planning, KFU (2000), in Dammam. Mohammad Al-Naim and Farahat Tashkandi’s
label: Paragraph

text: work on the Al Abbas Mosque (1995) in Riyadh won them an award for transforming
label: Paragraph

text: traditional aesthetic values to a more modern look.
label: Paragraph

text: Ziad Zaidan of Idea Center is another firm whose distinction lay in the team’s Master
label: Paragraph

text: Plan and Urban Design schemes for
label: Title

text: Al-Faisaliah Center (2000), designed by Norman Foster, in Riyadh
label: Caption

text: © Saleh Al-Hathloul
label: Title

text: Yanbu Industrial City, a contemporary settlement for 150,000 people aimed at combining
label: Paragraph

text: state-of-the-art technology with the principles of Islamic town planning. Ziad Zaidan is
label: Paragraph

text: also known for its Umm al-Qura University campus (1995) in Mecca, in association with
label: Paragraph

text: Perkins and Will, a carefully considered campus plan creating a harmonious synthesis of
label: Paragraph

text: old and new. Other projects have included the Asir Governorate Complex (1995) in
label: Paragraph

text: Abha, adapting elements of Asir architectural tradition with modern materials and
label: Paragraph

text: technology, and Aramco’s Western Region Headquarters (1989) in Jeddah, for which the
label: Paragraph

text: team won the American Institute of Architects’ Award for Excellence in Architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Zaidan also served as architectural consultant for the Institute du Monde Arabe (1987) in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris, designed by Jean Nouvel and the Architecture Studio.
label: Paragraph

text: Abdulla Bokhari of Archi-Plan is a strong believer in the influence and importance of
label: Paragraph

text: theories in design. Bokhari sees tradition as having no authority except as a platform for
label: Paragraph

text: further transformation or as an ongoing experiment. This approach is best seen in his
label: Paragraph

text: designs for the SANCST Cultural and Leisure Facilities Center (1989) and the UNDP
label: Caption

text: Headquarters (2000), both in Riyadh.
label: Paragraph

text: Several regional architects have also produced important work in Saudi Arabia,
label: Paragraph

text: including the contributions of Sami Anqawi, director of the Pilgrimage Research Center
label: Paragraph

text: for many years and a practicing architect in Amar. His strong commitment to tradition is
label: Paragraph

text: best reflected in the renovation of the Amar Office Building in Old Jeddah and in his
label: Paragraph

text: design of the al-Yamani residence (1980s) in Mecca. Saleh Qadah’s work in Asir is also
label: Paragraph

text: worth noting for his ability to use traditional architectural features as part of modern
label: Paragraph

text: designs. This was well demonstrated in Almiftah Village (1989) and in the Chamber of
label: Paragraph

text: Commerce Building (1989), both in Abha.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to these individual designers and design teams, the government-backed
label: Paragraph

text: Arriyadh Development Authority (ADA) has also been a major contributor to the shaping
label: Paragraph

text: of urban patterns and architecture styles in the kingdom. Among the most notable
label: Paragraph

text: projects carried out by the ADA in the Riyadh area have been the development of the
label: Paragraph

text: Diplomatic Quarter, a new town within the city; the MFA Staff Housing (1983); the
label: Paragraph

text: development of the Justice Palace District (1985-2000); and the development of the King
label: Paragraph

text: Abdulaziz Historic Center (1998). The award-winning quality of the ADA’s projects is
label: Paragraph

text: often demonstrated through magnificent architecture that marries traditional and modern
label: Paragraph

text: forms.
label: Paragraph

text: In the political arena, Mohammad Said Farsi, the well-known mayor of Jeddah from
label: Paragraph

text: the early 1970s to the mid-1980s, was also influential in the development of new trends
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture and planning in the kingdom. An architect and planner, his efforts to
label: Paragraph

text: preserve the old city and develop Jeddah’s architectural tastes had wide-ranging effects
label: Paragraph

text: on the architectural profession in Saudi Arabia.
label: Paragraph

text: In terms of architectural education, Ahmad Farid Moustafa was also extremely
label: Paragraph

text: influential on the course of architecture and planning in the kingdom. Moustafa served as
label: Paragraph

text: the first head of the Department of Architecture at King Saud University in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s. Later he was a founder and dean for the School of Architecture and Planning at
label: Paragraph

text: King Faisal University. In these positions, he had a tremendous effect on the first
label: Paragraph

text: generation of architectural students in Saudi Arabia. Adel Ismail and Mohammad Said
label: Paragraph

text: Mousalli were others who played major roles in the development of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: education, both through their teaching at King Saud University and through their
label: Paragraph

text: involvement as advisers for government agencies.
label: Paragraph

text: Formal architecture education began in Saudi Arabia with the establishment of the
label: Paragraph

text: Department of Architecture at King Saud University of Riyadh in 1967. Other schools
label: Paragraph

text: followed: the College of Architecture and Planning at King Faisal University, Dammam
label: Paragraph

text: (1975); the School of Environmental Design, King Abdulaziz University, Jeddah (1976);
label: Paragraph

text: the College of Environmental Design, University of Petroleum and Minerals, Dammam
label: Caption

text: (1979); and the Department of Islamic Architecture, Umm al-Qura University, Mecca
label: Caption

text: (1983). Some of the first graduates of these universities in turn began teaching careers of
label: Paragraph

text: their own in the 1980s. These have included Saleh Al-Hathloul, Mohammad Al-Hussayn,
label: Paragraph

text: Mohammad bin Saleh, Tarik Al-Sulaiman, and Jameel Akbar. Such educators have had a
label: Paragraph

text: broad effect on the field through teaching, writing, and involvement as jurors, reviewers,
label: Paragraph

text: and evaluators of major projects.
label: Paragraph

text: The role of national professional organizations has also increased in importance. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1982, the Engineering Committee was formed through the Chamber of Commerce to
label: Paragraph

text: oversee and organize design and consulting practice. The Saudi Association for
label: Paragraph

text: Architects and Planners (AL-UMRAN) was formed in 1989, and its membership now
label: Paragraph

text: exceeds 1000. Albenna magazine, covering architectural and development issues,
label: Caption

text: produced its first issue in February-March 1979.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to these local influences, the work of international architects in Saudi
label: Paragraph

text: Arabia has continued, and in recent years this has also become more responsive to local
label: Paragraph

text: conditions. Among the many excellent examples of work by international design teams in
label: Paragraph

text: Saudi Arabia have been the Haj Terminal (1982) at King Abdulaziz Airport in Jeddah by
label: Paragraph

text: Skidmore, Owings, and Merrill, a 20th-century adaptation of traditional tent structures;
label: Paragraph

text: the National Commercial Bank (1984) in Jeddah, also by Skidmore, Owings, and Merrill,
label: Paragraph

text: a modern corporate headquarters successfully integrated into a traditional setting; the
label: Paragraph

text: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (1984) in Riyadh by Henning Larsen, whose monumental
label: Paragraph

text: formalism presents an intelligent response to changing opinions; and King Fahad
label: Paragraph

text: International Stadium (1987) in Riyadh by Ain Friezer and Partners, a masterpiece of tent
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Other examples include the Central Government Complex (early 1980s) in Taif by
label: Paragraph

text: Leslie Martin, a complex that responds well to climatic requirements and blends with
label: Paragraph

text: local architecture; Imam Moh’d Bin Saud Islamic University (1988) by Techni Beria;
label: Paragraph

text: King Saud University, Al-Gassim Campus (1995), by Kenzo Tange Associates,
label: Caption

text: K.Baytarian and Associates, and Somait Engineering Services, a 10,000-student campus
label: Paragraph

text: based on a hierarchy of open spaces; and the Nuzul Hotel (1995) in Skaka by John
label: Paragraph

text: Lingly, which efficiently uses passive cooling systems and local design methods.
label: Paragraph

text: Many other projects from the last 25 years also deserve recognition: the Riyadh TV
label: Paragraph

text: Tower (1981), designed by ADIT of France; the Council of Ministers Building (early
label: Paragraph

text: 1980s) in Jeddah by Kenzo Tange; the King Khalid International Airport Terminal (1983)
label: Caption

text: in Riyadh by Hellmuth, Obata, and Kassabaum (HOK); and the King Fahad International
label: Paragraph

text: Airport Terminal (1993) in Dammam by M. Yamasaki, who was the designer for the
label: Paragraph

text: Dhahran Airport Terminal (1961).
label: Paragraph

text: Also of note have been Al-Ta’meer Center I (1999), designed by Arrowstreet, Inc., in
label: Paragraph

text: association with Dar Al-Mimar (Badran and Abdul Halim), a festival market in the heart
label: Paragraph

text: of Riyadh incorporating sustainable-design elements; Al-Khaleej Village (1990) in
label: Paragraph

text: Dammam, an earlier, influential model for a seaside resort city; Sultan bin Abdulaziz
label: Paragraph

text: City for Humanitarian Services (2000) in Riyadh by the OEO/HLW design partnership, a
label: Paragraph

text: hospital and training complex; and Al-Faisaliah Center (2000) in Riyadh by Norman
label: Caption

text: Foster, a 300-meter-high skyscraper to complement al-Khairia Center (1982) by Kenzo
label: Paragraph

text: Tange.
label: Paragraph

text: Since the late 1970s, urban renewal has also become an important trend in the
label: Paragraph

text: kingdom. Such urban design schemes were first developed for downtown Riyadh by
label: Paragraph

text: Albini (1978) and Beeah (1983) and were subsequently revised by the ADA’s staff. The
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilding of the al-Muraba area in Riyadh (1998), an urban design by Beeah and Badran,
label: Paragraph

text: will also create a cultural and historic center to complement Riyadh’s city center. Other
label: Paragraph

text: major urban-renewal programs have concerned further recent expansions of the holy
label: Paragraph

text: mosques in Mecca and Medina. In Mecca, an urban design scheme (1986) by Dar Al-
label: Paragraph

text: Handasah takes the Ka’bah as its center and proposes the continuation of prayer space on
label: Paragraph

text: the ground level up to the first Ring Road. In Medina, the whole area of the old city has
label: Paragraph

text: been encompassed in the Prophet mosque extension (1994), and the surrounding area up
label: Paragraph

text: to the first ring road has been transformed into a gridded plan.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, it is evident that various climates, regional materials, local vernacular traditions,
label: Paragraph

text: and economic and technological development have significantly directed architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: its practice in 20th-century Saudi Arabia. The first half of the century reflected centuries
label: Paragraph

text: of building habits and cultural needs, whereas the second half showed the immediate and
label: Paragraph

text: large-scale effect of economic prosperity in an internationally important region that
label: Paragraph

text: adapted new buildings types and modern urban planning to suit a variety of modern
label: Paragraph

text: needs.
label: Paragraph

text: SCARPA, CARLO 1906-78
label: Title

text: Architect, Italy
label: Title

text: For much of his career a figure isolated and detached from the mainstream, Carlo
label: Paragraph

text: Scarpa was recognized only after his death as one of the great architects of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century. His work does not fit easily into standard genealogical accounts of modernist
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. It is characterized by a virtuosity of light, color, and texture; an
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary refinement of detail; and complex manipulations of materials and
label: Paragraph

text: geometry.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapel, Brion Tomb, San Vito d’Altivole, Italy (1972)
label: Caption

text: © Ross Jenner
label: Title

text: Scarpa obtained a diploma as a teacher of architectural drawing from the Academy of
label: Paragraph

text: Fine Arts in Venice in 1926, when he also began teaching at the Architectural Institute of
label: Paragraph

text: Venice University. Before beginning his career as an architect, he gained an exceptional
label: Paragraph

text: understanding of materials working as artistic director of Venini, one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: prominent manufacturers of Venetian glass, from 1933 to 1947. He was influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright, but the sumptuous visual density of his work is rooted more in the
label: Paragraph

text: traditions of Venetian craftsmanship and Viennese ornamentation, typified by Josef
label: Paragraph

text: Hoffmann and the Wiener Werkstdtte. Scarpa taught at the IUAV from 1926 until his
label: Paragraph

text: death, becoming director in 1972.
label: Paragraph

text: Scarpa designed numerous exhibitions in London, Paris, Rome, and Milan. For over 30
label: Paragraph

text: years, beginning in 1942, he consulted for the Venice Biennale. A major break through in
label: Paragraph

text: his career was the 1948 “Paul Klee” exhibition, followed by a book pavilion in 1950.
label: Paragraph

text: Among his greatest contributions to post-war Italian architecture was the reconstruction
label: Paragraph

text: of several historic buildings as museums, most notably the Palazzo Abatellis (Palermo,
label: Paragraph

text: 1953-54), the Museo di Castelvecchio (Verona, 1956-64), and Quirini-Stampalia
label: Paragraph

text: (Venice, 1961-63), where he elevated restoration to the level of art form. The
label: Paragraph

text: restructuring of the Museo Correr (1953-60) and the Ca’ Foscari (1954-56) in Venice
label: Paragraph

text: received acclaim. At the same time, he undertook the layout and installation of the first
label: Paragraph

text: six rooms of the Uffizi in Florence (1954-56, with Ignazio Gardella and Giovanni
label: Caption

text: Michelucci) and planned the extension to the gypsum museum in Possagno (1955-57).
label: Paragraph

text: Other outstanding works include the Olivetti Showroom (Venice, 1957-58), and the
label: Paragraph

text: Gavina Showroom (Bologna, 1961-63). The Banca Popolare di Verona (1973-80), his
label: Paragraph

text: last large work, posthumously completed, suggests the directions he might have followed
label: Paragraph

text: had he not died prematurely. Among his domestic works, the Veritti House (Udine,
label: Paragraph

text: 1955-61) and Ottolenghi House (Bardolino, 1974—) are most notable. It is, however,
label: Paragraph

text: Brion-Vega Tomb and Cemetery (San Vito d’Altivole, 1970-72) that best typifies
label: Paragraph

text: Scarpa’s enigmatic quality and his tendency to realize form as a condition of process.
label: Paragraph

text: Rejecting the neutral spaces of mainstream modernism, Scarpa created settings
label: Paragraph

text: highlighting the uniqueness of objects. Container and content interact across history,
label: Paragraph

text: manifesting a new attitude to the past and a break with modernism’s utopian teleologies.
label: Paragraph

text: His architectural interventions create an overall artwork that embraces painting and
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture dialogically. Historical objects and contexts are no longer simply assimilated,
label: Paragraph

text: juxtaposed, or contrasted but rather interpreted by the architecture itself. At the
label: Paragraph

text: Castelvecchio, for example, Scarpa hauntingly entangles the principal threads of
label: Paragraph

text: circulation and lines of vision around the
label: Title

text: Entry and meditation pavilion, Brion Tomb, San Vito d’Altivole (1972)
label: Caption

text: © Ross Jenner
label: Title

text: equestrian figure of the Cangrande. At other times, the engagement amplifies the
label: Paragraph

text: displays: in the extension to the Possagno museum for Canova’s plaster casts a refined
label: Caption

text: arrangement admits the changing daylight through slots and cutout cubes of sky,
label: Paragraph

text: vivifying the chalky prototypes and walls.
label: Paragraph

text: Scarpa tended to approach his projects without fixed concepts. Instead, they grew out
label: Paragraph

text: of personal interactions with clients, craftsmen, artists, and preexisting contexts. Designs
label: Paragraph

text: were developed as processes of making, particularly in his unique mode of drawing that
label: Paragraph

text: proceeded, like the fabric of the final buildings, in strata and palimpsests, and with
label: Paragraph

text: meticulous attention to the smallest detail. In this sense, the works were both occasional
label: Paragraph

text: and decorative: They were befitting celebrations or commemorations of occasions and
label: Paragraph

text: persons—alien to both contemporary functionalist and later neorationalist approaches,
label: Paragraph

text: but located within a respect for tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: Scarpa’s interest in the facade points to an acceptance of convention in architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: a special attention to civic concerns, as in the Banca Popolare di Verona. His work is
label: Paragraph

text: grounded in the specificities of place and region but without fixation on local identity. It
label: Paragraph

text: is ornamental, arising from a complex poetics of differentiation and junction of nodes and
label: Paragraph

text: seams. The sheer complexity of his compositions embraces encryption, numerology,
label: Paragraph

text: astrology and mathematical games, the play of allusion, and a diffusion of associations by
label: Paragraph

text: the resonance of figures and motifs at multiple scales.
label: Paragraph

text: Scarpa was seen by many of his contemporaries as distanced from true modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. His ways of working were regarded as archaic, as a reactionary indulgence
label: Paragraph

text: in lost practices without future, obsessed with detail, precious materials, and luxurious
label: Paragraph

text: artifice. The Venice Order of Architects sued him for unlawfully practicing as an
label: Paragraph

text: architect, but he successfully defended the lawsuit. His nonchalance regarding the tasks
label: Paragraph

text: of the contemporary world, the fact that he worked for museums, foundations, and private
label: Paragraph

text: clients rather than for public administration, provoked ideological criticism. Although he
label: Paragraph

text: enjoyed considerable respect as a designer and specialist in restoration and the interior
label: Paragraph

text: design of museums and exhibitions, only Mazzariol and Zevi, his earliest defenders,
label: Paragraph

text: promoted his importance as an architect.
label: Paragraph

text: Since his death nonmodern perceptions have highlighted and legitimized the
label: Paragraph

text: metaphorical potential of Scarpa’s work. Its dispersed, fragmentary nature and its
label: Paragraph

text: perpetual capacity to defy geometric closure are acknowledged by Tafuri in his
label: Paragraph

text: comparison with Umberto Eco’s idea of the opera aperta. His composition by breaks and
label: Paragraph

text: scattering anticipated the disjointed work of the deconstructivists. Detail has now become
label: Paragraph

text: a source of interest to those concerned with ornament and tectonics alike—we are
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps closer to him today than his contemporaries were. Scarpa’s influence on
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent architecture has been diffuse but indirect; his work is too singular to be
label: Paragraph

text: directly emulated.
label: Paragraph

text: SCHAROUN, HANS 1893-1972
label: Title

text: Architect, Germany
label: Title

text: Although born in Bremen, Germany, on 20 September 1893, Hans Scharoun grew up
label: Paragraph

text: in the town of Bremerhaven, Germany’s major port just west of the industrial city of
label: Paragraph

text: Hamburg. Exhibiting a fascination with machines and architecture in his earliest sketches
label: Paragraph

text: and drawings, Scharoun took careful notice of the rapid changes he saw in the world
label: Paragraph

text: around him, changes even more exaggerated in the activities of the port. Bremerhaven,
label: Paragraph

text: Germany’s gateway to the world, felt the impact of cultures beyond Germany’s borders
label: Paragraph

text: and was thus more cosmopolitan than much of the country. It was also a place in which
label: Paragraph

text: new forms of technology and transport drove the city’s development; in this context, new
label: Paragraph

text: theories involving space and time were not abstract but quite real, leaving an imprint on
label: Paragraph

text: the port’s infrastructure and, consequently, the city’s architecture. As remarked by Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Blundell-Jones, a noted scholar of Scharoun’s work, Scharoun appeared to have received
label: Paragraph

text: the imprint of these ideas as well, for his architecture and planning ideas were anything
label: Paragraph

text: but sentimental. From his earliest attempts at architecture and urban planning, Scharoun
label: Paragraph

text: engaged the dynamics of economic exchange and technological development directly.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet Scharoun’s concept for architecture, or Baukunst (at the time German architects
label: Paragraph

text: pointedly used, after Schinkel, the term Bawkunst, or “building art,” rather than
label: Paragraph

text: “architecture” to describe their work), was not simply utilitarian but sought an expression
label: Paragraph

text: of the Modern era. Scharoun’s vision, one he shared with several other members of his
label: Paragraph

text: generation, espoused a kind of functionalism—although not the functionalism promoted
label: Paragraph

text: by several of his contemporaries, including the Sachlichkeit architects Hannes Meyer and
label: Paragraph

text: Ludwig Hilberseimer. Rather, Scharoun emphasized the spiritual foundation of organic
label: Paragraph

text: form, where the formation of the interior generated the exterior form.
label: Paragraph

text: Scharoun was accepted as a student of architecture at the Technische Hochschule in
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin-Charlottenburg in 1912 and became well versed in engineering technologies, the
label: Paragraph

text: primary emphasis of the architectural course at the time. He also worked as an assistant in
label: Paragraph

text: the Berlin office of Paul Kruchen, an assistant at the Technische Hochschule and
label: Paragraph

text: Scharoun’s first real mentor. While on holiday from his studies, the young architect
label: Paragraph

text: worked as a bricklayer’s apprentice. The curriculum of the Technische Hochschule did
label: Paragraph

text: not engage his imagination; unlike contemporary architectural education, there was little
label: Paragraph

text: focus on design in most German architectural programs at the time. Nonetheless,
label: Paragraph

text: Scharoun took part in numerous competitions, seeing them as opportunities in which he
label: Paragraph

text: could develop and exercise his architectural ideas. When World War | broke out,
label: Paragraph

text: Scharoun voluntarily entered military service, where he was eventually assigned to assist
label: Paragraph

text: Kruchen, who had by then become a military architect. His early reputation as an
label: Paragraph

text: architect was in fact based on these competitions; in comparison with other competition
label: Paragraph

text: entrants, Scharoun’s work was exceptionally progressive. The most significant of these
label: Paragraph

text: was his competition entry for the planning of the cathedral area in Prenzlau, a project that
label: Paragraph

text: led to an association with the noted Expressionist architect Bruno Taut and the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural critic Adolf Behne, both of whom resided in Berlin. Both Taut and Behne
label: Paragraph

text: were active in the utopian group Arbeitsrat fiir Kunst (Work Council for Art), an
label: Paragraph

text: association of architects, writers, and artists founded immediately after the November
label: Paragraph

text: 1918 revolution. The group, reflecting the burgeoning socialist sentiments of many
label: Paragraph

text: cultural figures during the Weimar Republic, sought to recover an art that was “for the
label: Paragraph

text: people” and vice versa, a people energized by their creative actions. In so doing, many of
label: Paragraph

text: them not only dispensed with the past but, in utopist fashion, overlooked the difficulties
label: Paragraph

text: of the present in favor of the possibility of future redemption. Seeing change and
label: Paragraph

text: development as modern architecture’s foundational premise, Scharoun quickly became an
label: Paragraph

text: associate and advocate of the group, participating in Taut’s “chain letters,” a secretive,
label: Paragraph

text: semianonymous correspondence known as the Gidserne Kette (Glass Chain). Scharoun’s
label: Paragraph

text: language and visionary sketches from the period, bursting with intense light, color, and
label: Paragraph

text: contrasts and using Expressionist symbols, are infused with utopian visions shared by
label: Paragraph

text: members of the group such as Wassily Luckhardt, Herman Finsterlin, and Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius. Typical Expressionist architectural programs, such as Volkshaus (House of the
label: Paragraph

text: People) and Stadtkrone (Crown of the City or City’s Crown), with titles such as
label: Paragraph

text: “Monument to Joy” and “Crystal on the Sphere” (Luckhardt) and Kudtbau, or “Cult-
label: Paragraph

text: Building” (Scharoun), exposed the underlying influences of German nature mysticism
label: Paragraph

text: and 19th-century German Romanticism. Although interested in fantasy and longing,
label: Paragraph

text: Scharoun’s legacy from the period centered around subtle aspects of architecture:
label: Paragraph

text: daylighting (Lichtfiihrung, literally “the control of daylight”) and organic form.
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism’s resort to quasi-mystical (spiritual) issues and forms of nature was
label: Paragraph

text: effectively subsumed into the development of functionalism in the 1920s. Ornament—the
label: Paragraph

text: rendering of ideas in architecture through surface application and detail—gave way to the
label: Paragraph

text: embrace of space and time, a shift dependent on changes in the ideas and methods of the
label: Paragraph

text: physical and natural sciences. Accordingly, space—immaterial and implied—became the
label: Paragraph

text: residence of Spirit (Geist), whereas form, perceived as plastic and mutable, was infused
label: Paragraph

text: with references to organisms, growth, and change.
label: Paragraph

text: Scharoun’s architectural work from this period mirrored his incorporation of these
label: Paragraph

text: influences, and his associations with certain architects and artists (several of whom
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited an interest in the a “constructed organicist” version of the post-Dada group
label: Paragraph

text: Neue Sachlichkeit, or New Objectivity) grew. Among his closest associates were artists
label: Paragraph

text: Kurt Schwitters, Hans Richter, and Theo van Doesburg, all of whom worked to sublimate
label: Paragraph

text: the mechanics and demands of persistent change and spirit in their art. Scharoun’s
label: Paragraph

text: particular interest in painting and collage—at this time highly gestural and expressive,
label: Paragraph

text: with a hint of attention to vernacular traditions—supported the architect’s functionalist
label: Paragraph

text: ethic. At the time, functionalism was both a method and a philosophy (or shared faith)
label: Paragraph

text: whereby the spirit moves from within to without; accordingly, “form” is the result of
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual expansion and expression moving out into the world. Scharoun’s incorporation
label: Paragraph

text: of fluid, complex forms and rhythms, coupled with his embrace of architecture’s new
label: Paragraph

text: technologies and materials, aided and abetted his general resistance to academic form.
label: Paragraph

text: Rather than static works resting on the landscape hidden behind an ordered facade,
label: Paragraph

text: Scharoun’s architectural designs—his spaces and forms—remained fluid and organic,
label: Paragraph

text: engaging the landscape directly in providing a place for the infusion of plant life within
label: Paragraph

text: while extending space into the landscape itself.
label: Paragraph

text: Ironically, Hans Scharoun’s reputation and significance as an architect increased just
label: Paragraph

text: as political and social tensions led to the demise of the Weimar Republic and the rise of
label: Paragraph

text: Fascism in Germany. In the mid-1920s, the “housing question” became a central focus
label: Paragraph

text: for the development of modern architecture. Although a professor at the Kunstakademie
label: Paragraph

text: in Breslau, Scharoun yearned for Berlin’s cosmopolitan cultural arena, finally relocating
label: Paragraph

text: to the city in 1927-28. It was a fortuitous move professionally, and he began to obtain
label: Paragraph

text: various commissions (his association with Berlin developer Georg Jacobowitz was
label: Paragraph

text: particularly fruitful). Scharoun also had the good fortune of participating with several of
label: Paragraph

text: his former Arbeitsrat colleagues, collaborating on several planning and housing
label: Paragraph

text: developments, including both the Modern Siemensstadt living/housing project (1928-31)
label: Paragraph

text: and a single-family dwelling for the Weissenhofsiedlung Stuttgart, a housing exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: organized by the Deutscher Werkbund, in 1927. Both projects, manifestos of “social
label: Paragraph

text: housing,” were “intended as...models for [a] new way of life.” However, the die had
label: Paragraph

text: been cast portending the rise of Fascism by the late 1920s, and options for further
label: Paragraph

text: exploration of Modern cultural and social ideas diminished substantially.
label: Paragraph

text: Although he did not immigrate during the period—an option taken by many of his
label: Paragraph

text: closest friends and associates—Scharoun suffered an internal exile throughout the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s and 1940s. The last building of his “Weimar years,” a house for industrialist Fritz
label: Paragraph

text: Schminke on the border of Czechoslovakia built in 1933, showcases Scharoun’s maturing
label: Paragraph

text: architectural vision; light, material, structure, form, space, function, furniture, and
label: Paragraph

text: landscape are fused into a seamless, organic whole. As German Fascism increased its
label: Paragraph

text: hold, Scharoun’s work went underground; exterior projections of his architectural
label: Paragraph

text: ideas—formal and material play and movement—became hidden behind the mask of
label: Paragraph

text: Nazism’s mandated, antimodern “German vernacular.” Nonetheless, Scharoun, in his
label: Paragraph

text: design of small, residential projects, clearly maintains his developmental trajectory,
label: Paragraph

text: exploring with even greater intensity the dynamics of interior space and light and exterior
label: Paragraph

text: form. These projects—the Mohrmann House (1938) in Berlin-Lichtenrade and the Endell
label: Paragraph

text: House (1939) in Berlin-Wannsee are primary examples—map the increasing
label: Paragraph

text: internalization of his architectural work and effectively mirror Scharoun’s internal exile.
label: Paragraph

text: Again ironically, it was during this same period that Scharoun’s most significant
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual relationship developed: Hugo Haring, 11 years Scharoun’s senior, became
label: Paragraph

text: Scharoun’s principal mentor, a relationship that would continue until Haring’s death.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1920s, Haring was known primarily for his architectural ideas and was,
label: Paragraph

text: according to Blundell-Jones, considered more of a contemplative (theoretical) architect
label: Paragraph

text: than a builder. During the years of fascist rule and World War II, Haring and Scharoun
label: Paragraph

text: developed a close relationship—like Scharoun, he was also an internal exile—with the
label: Paragraph

text: elder man fulfilling the role of mentor, Scharoun’s “intellectual authority.” Haring’s
label: Paragraph

text: architectural theories were quickly absorbed by Scharoun, who adopted them as
label: Paragraph

text: explanations for his own architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Immediately after the end of World War II, Scharoun was asked to help with the
label: Paragraph

text: planning and rebuilding of Berlin and was appointed Berlin city architect until the city
label: Paragraph

text: elections in 1946. Housing was a critical issue, and Scharoun began to work on numerous
label: Paragraph

text: city-planning and apartment projects, including those associated with the Planungs-
label: Paragraph

text: Kollektiv. His work in this area exhibited a concern for the entire built environment and
label: Paragraph

text: its future viability. Incorporating the necessary functions of daily life within his planning
label: Paragraph

text: schemes, Scharoun added public buildings, shopping areas, parks, schools, kindergartens,
label: Paragraph

text: administrative offices, and cultural and recreational elements, including crafts workshops
label: Paragraph

text: and spaces for weekly markets and provisions for small-scale industry and future growth.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition, his intro-duction of a wide range of transportation systems (with pedestrian
label: Paragraph

text: access being the most important) underlined Scharoun’s attention to the human
label: Paragraph

text: dimension of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Scharoun was able to build many of his designs after the war, including apartment
label: Paragraph

text: complexes, schools, and theaters—all building programs that directly engaged issues
label: Paragraph

text: pertaining to the human dimension and, even more specifically, the quality of life. As one
label: Paragraph

text: of the remaining architects of his generation still active in West Germany, Scharoun
label: Paragraph

text: continued to explore architectural themes that had governed his work throughout his
label: Paragraph

text: career: fluid space and change, program flexibility, technological advances, the primacy
label: Title

text: of the interior uses as a determinant of form, the dynamic interaction of landscape and
label: Paragraph

text: form, and contextual response. Although there are numerous examples, notable housing
label: Paragraph

text: projects include his design for apartments in Berlin, his “Romeo and Juliet” housing
label: Paragraph

text: project (1954-59) in Stuttgart, Charlottenburg-Nord (1950s—1960s), and the Béblingen
label: Paragraph

text: Flats (1965) near Stuttgart. Scharoun was extremely interested in the relationship
label: Paragraph

text: between architectural program, order, form, space, and light and the learning processes
label: Paragraph

text: associated with educational programs, and he designed several schools, such as the
label: Paragraph

text: Geschwister Scholl (1958-62) in Linen, where he adopted an aggressive color program,
label: Paragraph

text: and the Volksschule (1960-71) at Marl in Westphalia. Scharoun’s theaters included the
label: Paragraph

text: Kassel (1952), Mannheim (1953), and Ziirich (1964) theater projects. The Wolfsburg
label: Paragraph

text: Theatre (1965-1973), completed after Scharoun’s death on 25 November 1972, absorbs
label: Paragraph

text: the energy of the earlier projects and stands today as a testament to Scharoun’s
label: Paragraph

text: architectural genius. This is also the case in his design for the German Maritime Museum
label: Paragraph

text: (1969-75), a project commissioned by the State of West Germany and located in
label: Paragraph

text: Bremerhaven, where his earliest visions for a new architecture first took root. Likewise,
label: Paragraph

text: his most famous building, the Berlin Philharmonie (begun in 1968 and completed in
label: Paragraph

text: 1987), sublates many of the ideas found in his earliest architectural work, becoming
label: Paragraph

text: something of a refined exemplar of Expressionist architecture. The programs for the
label: Paragraph

text: Philharmonie and the later Chamber Music Hall appear as instruments themselves—fluid
label: Paragraph

text: airangements of myriad systems that lend themselves to Scharoun’s improvisational
label: Paragraph

text: approach to the making of form.
label: Paragraph

text: Among Scharoun’s last projects, a State Library (1964-79) and a Musical Instruments
label: Paragraph

text: Museum and Institute for Musical Research (1969-84), both sited immediately adjacent
label: Paragraph

text: to both the Berlin Philharmonie and Mies van der Rohe’s masterful National Gallery in
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin, display the full range of Scharoun’s vision. The created context is thoughtfully
label: Paragraph

text: nuanced, with the grouping of buildings open and responsive not only to one another but
label: Paragraph

text: to the entire city of (West} Berlin as well—a studied contrast in the closed conditions
label: Paragraph

text: presented by the city’s isolated context at the time. Completed after Scharoun’s death,
label: Paragraph

text: they represent not only the sum of one architect’s vision but also, in returning to the
label: Paragraph

text: opening themes of the 1910s and 1920s, the culmination of a generation’s vision, a
label: Paragraph

text: generation that, from the beginning, saw architecture as a form of redemption, a form of
label: Paragraph

text: life that engaged and affirmed the dynamics of social interaction.
label: Paragraph

text: As an architect, Scharoun was prolific. The number of projects designed amounts to
label: Paragraph

text: more than 300, the majority (238) of which were built despite the intervening years of
label: Paragraph

text: Fascist rule and the post-World War II economic difficulties. Scharoun’s insistence on a
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic, “organic” architecture, in particular an architecture fully engaged in the
label: Paragraph

text: rhythms of daily life, exhibits his concern for architecture as a form of life (Lebensform).
label: Paragraph

text: This idea encapsulates the sense of play and the use of fluid ordering systems in
label: Paragraph

text: Scharoun’s work; architecture did not exist as an object but rather functioned as an
label: Paragraph

text: organism, a viable, developmental, and flexible network of associations and
label: Paragraph

text: interrelationships.
label: Paragraph

text: SCHINDLER, RUDOLPH M. 1887-1953
label: Title

text: Architect, Austria and United States
label: Title

text: Rudolph M.Schindler practiced in the Los Angeles area from 1920 until his death,
label: Paragraph

text: producing a series of houses and apartment buildings that explored new concepts of form,
label: Paragraph

text: materials, and space. Critical of the reigning machine-oriented orthodoxy of most
label: Paragraph

text: advanced European and American modernists that became known as the International
label: Paragraph

text: Style, Schindler’s work is highly personal and individualistic.
label: Paragraph

text: Born in Vienna, Schindler studied structural engineering at the technical university,
label: Paragraph

text: architecture under Otto Wagner at the academy, and informally with Adolf Loos. Inspired
label: Paragraph

text: by Frank Lloyd Wright’s Wasmuth publications, Schindler immigrated to the United
label: Paragraph

text: States in 1914, met Louis Sullivan, and after repeated attempts secured employment with
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright and worked on several projects, including the Imperial Hotel. Wright
label: Paragraph

text: sent Schindler to Los Angeles to supervise work on the Barnstall residence, known as
label: Paragraph

text: Hollyhock. Schindler contributed a number of designs to Wright’s project (studio
label: Paragraph

text: residence A is generally credited to Schindler).
label: Paragraph

text: Schindler’s earliest work, from 1921 to 1928, initially contained certain Wrightian
label: Paragraph

text: mannerisms, but he also explored the possibilities of concrete and southern California’s
label: Paragraph

text: sybaritic living. His King’s Road, or Schindler-Chase House (1921-22) in Hollywood
label: Caption

text: was designed for two couples who shared common living spaces but who each had their
label: Paragraph

text: own room and an open sleeping porch. The house is a series of interlocked tilt-slab
label: Paragraph

text: concrete forms (which he derived from the American architect Irving Gill) paired with
label: Paragraph

text: large openings, originally covered in canvas and later with sliding glass. Built on a slab,
label: Paragraph

text: the building was in a sense a neutral container for the life within and without, with large
label: Paragraph

text: indoor and outdoor fireplaces.
label: Paragraph

text: The Lovell Beach House (1922—26) in Newport Beach was composed of five poured-
label: Paragraph

text: in-place concrete frames that carried what Schindler described as “space trays.”
label: Paragraph

text: Constructed of wood, the trays are multilevel and project beyond the end of the frames,
label: Paragraph

text: creating a dynamic sense of space. With abstract forms that referred to pier pilings,
label: Paragraph

text: Schindler’s Lovell house was probably his best-known work.
label: Paragraph

text: Beginning around 1928, Schindler began to use the wooden stud frame; his
label: Paragraph

text: architecture grew more cubic with flat, stucco-covered wall surfaces. Typically, his
label: Paragraph

text: houses are enclosed on the street elevation and open to gardens or views. Fenestration is
label: Paragraph

text: eccentric with varying shapes and sizes. With the C.H.Wolfe House (1928-29) on
label: Paragraph

text: Catalina Island, Schindler posed the building as a series of boxes with open porches on a
label: Paragraph

text: hillside, whereas the J.J.Buck House (1934) in Los Angeles spread across a lot as a series
label: Paragraph

text: of interlocked stucco-covered forms. As with all of Schindler’s work, the house was
label: Paragraph

text: conceived as a total unit incorporating site, landscape, and furniture into the plan and the
label: Paragraph

text: style.
label: Paragraph

text: Schindler’s final phase, from 1935 on, becomes more expressionistic, with roofs and
label: Paragraph

text: walls placed at eccentric angles, often resulting in radically dynamic space. The Guy
label: Paragraph

text: C.Wilson House (1935-38) in Los Angeles has floor-to-ceiling glass walls poised 50 feet
label: Caption

text: in the air and a butterfly roof that goes off at two angles. The S.T.Falk Apartment
label: Caption

text: Building (1940) in Los Angeles, also on a steep site, features a series of overlapping
label: Paragraph

text: geometries and bent forms; its volumes resemble precariously arranged boxes held in
label: Paragraph

text: equilibrium. The Ellen Jansen (1949) and Adolphe
label: Paragraph

text: King’s Road House (architect’s house), West Hollywood (1922)
label: Caption

text: © GreatBuildings.com
label: Title

text: Tishler (1950) houses in Los Angeles appear almost unfinished with their collision of
label: Paragraph

text: planes, forms, and beams. Spatially, Schindler’s late work defies verbal description, as
label: Paragraph

text: color and a multiplicity of surfaces resound in different directions.
label: Paragraph

text: The eccentric character of Schindler’s work, his bohemian demeanor, and the Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles location led to a dismissive attitude by eastern critics, who refused to
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledge his contributions to modern architecture. Schindler pursued lectures,
label: Paragraph

text: exhibitions, and publications of his work and was largely successful up to around 1949,
label: Paragraph

text: when he was diagnosed with cancer. Since the mid-1960s, Schindler studies have
label: Paragraph

text: blossomed, and his current status probably outranks that of his contemporary, Richard
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra. Although critics and historians have attempted to define his work with reference
label: Paragraph

text: to Wagner, Wright, Loos, De Stijl, and other movements, Schindler’s oeuvre escapes
label: Paragraph

text: classification. Schindler’s major effect came at least three decades after his death in the
label: Paragraph

text: work of Frank Gehry, Thom Mayne, and the Santa Monica School.
label: Caption

text: RICHARD GUY WILSON
label: Title

text: See also Brutalism; Gill, Irving (United States); Loos, Adolf (Austria); Neutra,

text: Biography
label: Title

text: Born in Vienna, 10 September 1887. Graduated with degree in structural engineering,
label: Paragraph

text: Imperial and Royal Technical University, 1911, and diploma in architecture under Otto
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner at the Academy of Fine Arts, 1913, both in Vienna. Worked for Mayr and Mayer
label: Paragraph

text: architects 1911-1914 in Vienna. Arrived in New York March 1914; worked as draftsman
label: Paragraph

text: and designer for Ottenheimer, Stern, and Reichert in Chicago until 1917. Toured New
label: Caption

text: Mexico, Arizona, and California in 1915; worked for Frank Lloyd Wright at Oak Park
label: Paragraph

text: Studio, Taliesin, and Los Angeles, 1917—ca. 1922. Married Sophie Pauline Schindler, 29
label: Caption

text: August 1919; one child Mark Schindler, born 20 July 1922. Moved to Southern

text: California, December 1920; lived in Los Angles and later Hollywood; became part of

text: SCHLUMBERGER CAMBRIDGE
label: Title

text: RESEARCH CENTER
label: Title

text: Cambridge, England
label: Title

text: Designed by Michael Hopkins and Partners; Phase | completed 1985; Phase IL
label: Caption

text: completed 1993
label: Title

text: The Schlumberger complex is located in a research park at the northwest edge of
label: Paragraph

text: Cambridge, England. Schlumberger, a global company that provides technical services to
label: Paragraph

text: support the exploration, drilling, and production of oil, is also a notable patron of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, having previously commissioned buildings by Philip Johnson and Renzo
label: Paragraph

text: Piano. Michael Hopkins was selected for the Cambridge project from a shortlist of 20
label: Caption

text: international practices.
label: Paragraph

text: Phase I, commissioned in 1982 and completed in 1985, includes laboratories, offices
label: Paragraph

text: for scientists, and a test station with a range of drilling pits used to simulate difficult and
label: Paragraph

text: dangerous field conditions. Because of noise, dirt, and the risk of explosion, test stations
label: Paragraph

text: traditionally had been isolated in separate buildings. However, both the preoccupations of
label: Paragraph

text: Hopkins and the aspirations of Schlumberger led to a radically different approach. The
label: Paragraph

text: test station is combined with a winter garden, which serves as both entrance hall and
label: Paragraph

text: restaurant, to form a long north-south central spine that is flanked on the east and west by
label: Paragraph

text: two slimmer bars comprised of laboratories overlooking the central space and offices
label: Paragraph

text: with views out to the surrounding pastoral landscape. The natural slope of the site is
label: Paragraph

text: utilized to sink the floor of the test station and service yard 2.5 meters below the winter
label: Paragraph

text: garden. This lower level also provides an easily accessible services undercroft.
label: Paragraph

text: The efficient, rational plan gives little hint of the drama of the section. A tensile roof
label: Paragraph

text: encloses the 24-meter-wide central zone, where a clear height of approximately 17 meters
label: Paragraph

text: is provided above the drilling pits. Framed by an exposed steel structure of lattice
label: Paragraph

text: columns and prismatic beams, raked booms and a network of tension rods support the
label: Paragraph

text: translucent skin. The structure of the single-story offices and labs, a derivation of
label: Paragraph

text: Hopkins’s Patera system, is also exoskeletal but, in contrast with the central spine, is
label: Paragraph

text: more restrained. Anthony Hunt Associates designed the steel structure, and the
label: Paragraph

text: lightweight structures unit of Ove Arup and Partners designed the fabric roof.
label: Paragraph

text: A zoned servicing strategy supports the contrasting spatial and structural characters of
label: Paragraph

text: the central spine and flanking wings. The winter garden and test station, although weather
label: Caption

text: tight, are conceived as quasi-external spaces; the labs are sealed spaces in which tightly
label: Paragraph

text: controlled environmental conditions for research can be maintained; and the offices have
label: Paragraph

text: opening windows and sunshading that can be adjusted by the occupants.
label: Paragraph

text: The building works as an icon in the heroic modernist tradition and, by addressing
label: Paragraph

text: human needs, significantly advances the idea of the workplace. Transparency—with fully
label: Paragraph

text: glazed walls between winter garden, test station, and labs and a glazed external
label: Caption

text: envelope—creates a high degree of visual interaction both within the building and
label: Paragraph

text: between the building and the outside world. An egalitarian workplace laced together by
label: Paragraph

text: open meeting spaces and the generosity of the winter garden integrates disparate
label: Paragraph

text: functions—clean and dirty, quiet and noisy, front and back of house. This social and
label: Paragraph

text: programmatic integration is reiterated in the marriage of orthogonal and curvilinear
label: Paragraph

text: geometries, of compressive and tensile structures, and of rational Miesian discipline with
label: Paragraph

text: more exuberant expressionism.
label: Paragraph

text: This building for Schlumberger was Michael Hopkins’s first use of a tensile fabric
label: Paragraph

text: structure and the first large-scale architectural use of Teflon-coated fabric in the United
label: Paragraph

text: Kingdom. Hopkins would further explore fabric structures in subsequent projects
label: Paragraph

text: including the Mound Stand at Lord’s Cricket Ground (1987), the amenity building and
label: Paragraph

text: ventilation towers at Inland Revenue (1995), and the Younger Universe Pavilion in
label: Paragraph

text: Edinburgh (1998).
label: Paragraph

text: As a product of systems-building thinking—inspired by the pioneering work of Ezra
label: Paragraph

text: Ehrencrantz and developed in Hopkins’s early association with Norman Foster—Hopkins
label: Paragraph

text: designed Phase | as an open-ended, extendible system of prefabricated parts. However,
label: Paragraph

text: oil research methods were changing rapidly. By the time Phase Il was commissioned in
label: Paragraph

text: 1990, Schlumberger was relying more on computer simulation, making the test station
label: Paragraph

text: less central in its research program. Phase II is consequently a separate building that
label: Paragraph

text: echoes Hopkins’s 1988 Solid State Logic scheme near Oxford. Located to the south of
label: Paragraph

text: Phase L, the extension plays the role of gatehouse, with two pavilions joined by an atrium
label: Paragraph

text: that houses the reception area for the site and defines a central axial path to the winter
label: Paragraph

text: garden. Each of the two-story pavilions is square in plan with offices for scientists at the
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter surrounding labs, computer suites, conference rooms, and mechanical plant.
label: Paragraph

text: Phases | and II are unified visually by similarly detailed glazed facades and conceptually
label: Paragraph

text: by the integration of the rational and expressive sensibilities of Hopkins’ work. However,
label: Paragraph

text: the structure of Phase I, for which Buro Happold were consultants, is utterly different.
label: Paragraph

text: The upper floor is prefabricated ferroconcrete used as permanent formwork for an in situ
label: Caption

text: concrete slab. Recalling Pier Luigi Nervi’s Gatti Wool Factory (1954) in Rome, the soffit
label: Caption

text: is detailed to express clearly the patterns of structural stresses in the slab. An understated,
label: Paragraph

text: light structure of air-filled pillows of clear PTFE (polytetra fluoroethylene) sheet
label: Caption

text: spanning between simple steel beams encloses the central atrium.
label: Paragraph

text: The Schlumberger Cambridge Research Center is one of the emblematic projects of the
label: Paragraph

text: so-called British High Tech movement led by Norman Foster, Richard Rogers, Nicholas
label: Paragraph

text: Grimshaw, and Michael Hopkins. However, like other buildings designed by Hopkins
label: Paragraph

text: during the same period—notably the David Mellor Cudery Factory (1988), Bracken
label: Paragraph

text: House (1992), Glyndebourne Opera House (1994), Inland Revenue, and the Emman-uel
label: Paragraph

text: College Music Room (1995) the ferroconcrete used in Phase II of Schlumberger signals a
label: Paragraph

text: shift away from the light steel and glass buildings of Hopkins’s early career and the
label: Paragraph

text: application of systems thinking and prefabrication to heavier, more traditional materials
label: Paragraph

text: and methods of construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Phase | received the Financial Times Architecture Award in 1985 and a Royal Institute
label: Paragraph

text: of British Architects (RIBA) National Award, a Civic Trust Award, and a Structural Steel
label: Paragraph

text: Award in 1988. In 1993, Phase Il received an RIBA Regional Award and was a finalist
label: Paragraph

text: for the Financial Times Award.
label: Paragraph
