text: SCHOOL
label: Title

text: School buildings have undergone tremendous change in the course of the 20th century. In
label: Paragraph

text: part, these changes were driven by a dramatic increase in school enrollments, as children
label: Paragraph

text: in industrialized nations were driven out of the workplace by new technologies and
label: Paragraph

text: protective labor legislation, and compulsory school attendance laws become more
label: Paragraph

text: commonplace. Even more important to the form of school buildings were new
label: Paragraph

text: pedagogical theories advanced at the turn of the century, notably by Maria Montessori in
label: Paragraph

text: Italy, John Dewey in the United States, and Karl Popper in Germany. Building on the
label: Paragraph

text: ideas of the 19th-century kindergarten movement, these thinkers popularized the concept
label: Paragraph

text: that children learn best by doing, rather than through rote memorization. Montessori
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized the importance of the Prepared Environment, in which furnishings were sized
label: Paragraph

text: and arranged to enhance the autonomy of young children. Dewey was equally influential
label: Paragraph

text: in arguing that high schools should prepare students for life, and not just for college.
label: Paragraph

text: Kindergartens were among the first educational environments affected by these new
label: Paragraph

text: pedagogical theories. In the United States and England they tended to take the form of a
label: Paragraph

text: specially shaped classroom attached to a primary school, while in Europe the
label: Paragraph

text: kindergarten tended to be a distinct building type. Those associated with the Waldorf
label: Paragraph

text: School Movement (which began in 1919 when Rudolph Steiner started Die Freie
label: Paragraph

text: Waldorfschule, for the children of the workers at the Waldorf-Astoria cigarette factory in
label: Caption

text: Stuttgart) tended to favor organic forms that seemed to support Steiner’s emphasis on
label: Paragraph

text: cultivating higher mental faculties through the total harmony of the senses. More
label: Paragraph

text: common in the 1920s and 1930s were kindergartens designed in a modern idiom, like the
label: Paragraph

text: 1934 nursery school on the outskirts of Ziirich where architect Hans Leuzinger provided
label: Paragraph

text: direct access to the out-of-doors, ample daylighting, and light movable furniture scaled to
label: Paragraph

text: young children.
label: Paragraph

text: Schools for older children took longer to address all of the implications of the new
label: Paragraph

text: pedagogy. The regimented classroom (with chairs bolted into place facing the teacher’s
label: Paragraph

text: desk) remained the basic unit of school design, although educators and architects refined
label: Paragraph

text: the arrangements of these rooms to insure that students could see the blackboard and hear
label: Paragraph

text: the teacher’s instructions. In the United States, the first architectural indication of the new
label: Paragraph

text: educational theories involved the provision of facilities beyond the classroom: fully-
label: Paragraph

text: equipped playgrounds, baths, gymmnasia, art studios, scientific laboratories, shops for
label: Paragraph

text: woodworking and handicrafts, and home economics classrooms. Auditoria and libraries
label: Caption

text: were often included as well, to serve both students and the wider community. In order to
label: Paragraph

text: make these amenities more affordable, the Gary, Indiana, school system introduced the
label: Paragraph

text: platoon system (also called the Gary plan) in 1909. Aimed at using all school facilities at
label: Paragraph

text: once, this system divided the student body into two platoons, each of which used
label: Paragraph

text: conventional classrooms for academic subjects while the other was involved in special
label: Paragraph

text: activities. Schools planned for this system typically included a large auditorium at the
label: Paragraph

text: center of the building, with special classrooms grouped together on lower floors. After
label: Paragraph

text: World War I, junior high schools (for grades 7-9) were also understood as a cost
label: Paragraph

text: effective and developmentally appropriate means of providing adolescents with the
label: Paragraph

text: manual training and home economics classrooms not used by students in the primary
label: Title

text: grades, where the focus remained on the acquisition of basic academic skills.
label: Paragraph

text: This new attention to the distinct needs of different age groups also extended to the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural expression of early 20th-century schools in the United States. San Francisco
label: Caption

text: school architect John J.Donovan, for one, argued that school architecture should
label: Paragraph

text: anticipate the psychological responses of children; elementary schools “should reflect the
label: Paragraph

text: spirit, quietness and refinement of a good home,” while high schools “should have the
label: Paragraph

text: character, repose, and presentation befitting the important work going forward
label: Paragraph

text: within” (Donovan, 1921, 27-28). In practice, this meant that high schools retained a
label: Paragraph

text: degree of monumentality, expressed in Colonial Revival or collegiate Gothic form in the
label: Paragraph

text: late 1910s and 1920s, and later in Art Deco and Moderne styles associated with civic and
label: Paragraph

text: commercial architecture. These two- and three-story buildings presented strongly
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical facades focused on a single main entrance set well above grade. In contrast,
label: Paragraph

text: elementary schools minimized the building’s scale. Not only did one-story buildings
label: Paragraph

text: become more common, but many schools (like the Ashland School in St. Louis by
label: Paragraph

text: William B.Ittner) provided two main entrances often at or near grade level. Articulated
label: Paragraph

text: with Tudor Revival, Colonial Revival, or Mission Revival details, these buildings used
label: Paragraph

text: historical vocabularies associated with domestic architecture to ease the child’s transition
label: Paragraph

text: from home to school.
label: Paragraph

text: In Europe, progressive educational reform often went hand in hand with attempts to
label: Paragraph

text: bring students into closer communion with the natural landscape. Early in the twentieth
label: Paragraph

text: century, open-air schools—with neither heating nor glazing—were built primarily for the
label: Paragraph

text: tubercular children; the first of these was the Waldschule (Forest School) established in
label: Paragraph

text: Charlottenburg, Germany in 1904. By the 1920s, however, open-air schools were
label: Paragraph

text: recommended for non-tubercular children as well. In Frankfurt, Germany, architects
label: Paragraph

text: working under the leadership of Ernst May in the 1920s designed decentralized schools
label: Paragraph

text: called Pavilionschule (pavilion schools) or Freiflachenschule (open plan schools) with
label: Paragraph

text: one-story wings disposed over large open sites to increase light and air circulation; the
label: Paragraph

text: Niederursel School designed by Franz Schuster in 1928, may be the first of this type.
label: Paragraph

text: Although there were some French pavilion schools (notably the open-air school in
label: Paragraph

text: Suresnes designed by Eugéne Beaudouin and Marcel Lods), France retained a tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: density, building multistory blocks with outdoor space provided on rooftop terraces.
label: Paragraph

text: By the late 1930s, architects and educators increasingly worked together to develop
label: Paragraph

text: new approaches to school design. In England, for instance, Walter Gropius and Maxwell
label: Paragraph

text: Fry designed Impington Village College (Cambridgeshire, 1940) to house a school that
label: Paragraph

text: educator Henry Morris envisioned as an innovative community center with its assembly
label: Paragraph

text: hall, workshops, library and recreational facilities available to adults. Its loose
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetrical plan increased natural lighting, improved cross ventilation, and provided
label: Paragraph

text: direct access to the out-of-doors from each classroom, while its flat roofs and modern
label: Paragraph

text: detailing eschewed any reference to traditional school architecture. In a similar vein,
label: Paragraph

text: Perkins, Wheeler, and Will designed Crow Island Elementary School (Winnetka, Illinois,
label: Caption

text: 1940) in close collaboration with teachers, using asymmetrical planning, low (9-foot)
label: Paragraph

text: ceilings, generous glazing, and direct outdoor access from each classroom to make the
label: Paragraph

text: school welcoming to young pupils.
label: Paragraph

text: In the postwar period, architects embraced industrial production techniques developed
label: Paragraph

text: during the war as the best way to meet an acute demand for schools fueled by the baby
label: Paragraph

text: boom. In England, the effort was pioneered in the architectural office of the Hertfordshire
label: Paragraph

text: County Council, under the direction of Stirrat Johnson-Marshall. There in the late 1940s,
label: Paragraph

text: county architects designed informally planned primary schools, like the Monkfrith
label: Paragraph

text: School in East Barnet (1950, Mary Crowley and Oliver Cox, job architects), where
label: Paragraph

text: daylighting from contiguous sides, warm-air heating systems, dispersed seating at
label: Paragraph

text: movable tables, and bright colors set new standards for child-centered classrooms.
label: Paragraph

text: Another effort to link prefabrication, modular planning, and school design was the
label: Paragraph

text: SCSD (School Construction Systems Development) system spearheaded by Ezra
label: Paragraph

text: Ehrenkrantz and implemented in high schools throughout California beginning in 1962.
label: Paragraph

text: Based on the coordinated manufacture of modular components, the SCSD system was
label: Paragraph

text: primarily intended to lower school construction costs. Educators, however, were drawn to
label: Paragraph

text: the system’s potential for providing spaces that could be quickly reconfigured for
label: Paragraph

text: individualized or group instruction. The trend toward open-plan schools (whether built on
label: Paragraph

text: the SCSD system
label: Title

text: Crow Island School, Winnetka, Illinois, designed by Eliel Saarinen with
label: Caption

text: Perkins and Will (1939-49)
label: Title

text: © Johnson Architectural Images/GreatBuildings.com
label: Caption

text: or not) developed rapidly in the 1960s and early 1970s, affecting half of the all schools
label: Paragraph

text: built in the United States between 1967 and 1969 and ten percent of all elementary
label: Paragraph

text: schools in use in the United Kingdom in 1985. The Mt. Hope, New Jersey, Elementary
label: Caption

text: School (Perkins and Will, 1971) displays several characteristics of the type: a large floor
label: Paragraph

text: plate (maximizing the building’s enclosed area in order to minimize costs and enhance
label: Paragraph

text: flexibility), heavy reliance on florescent lighting, open classrooms grouped on an upper
label: Paragraph

text: level (allowing fixed equipment required in the cafeteria and gymnasium to remain on the
label: Paragraph

text: ground level), movable furnishings used as classroom partitions, and spatial continuity
label: Paragraph

text: between classrooms and circulation space. Although such schools avoided the rigidity of
label: Paragraph

text: conventional classrooms, they also sacrificed daylighting and direct access to the out-of-
label: Paragraph

text: doors. Open plans also introduced new noise and discipline problems, while the systems
label: Paragraph

text: approach to school construction could result generic buildings with little architectural
label: Paragraph

text: character.
label: Paragraph

text: The last two decades of the 20th century saw a reaction against the open plan school.
label: Paragraph

text: The self-contained classroom returned, albeit with greater attention to providing a variety
label: Paragraph

text: of seating arrangements. Irregular planning also re-emerged, and for the same reasons it
label: Paragraph

text: had been popular in the 1930s and 1940s: to enhance natural lighting, improve access to
label: Paragraph

text: the out-of-doors, and decrease noise levels. Finally, the child’s reaction to the qualities of
label: Paragraph

text: place reappeared as an issue of concern to architects. At the same time, new
label: Paragraph

text: programmatic requirements—the need to incorporate computer technologies, a new
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis—on project-based learning, renewed calls to integrate educational and
label: Paragraph

text: community facilities—emerged to elicit new responses to this complex building type in
label: Paragraph

text: the 21st century.
label: Paragraph

text: SCHRODER-SCHRADER HOUSE
label: Title

text: Designed by Gerrit Thomas Rietveld; completed 1924 Utrecht, Netherlands
label: Caption

text: The Schréder-Schrader House is an icon of early modern domestic architecture and is
label: Paragraph

text: considered the greatest and most influential work of Gerrit Thomas Rietveld (1888—
label: Paragraph

text: 1964). Located in Utrecht at Prins Hendriklaan 50, the design is the result of the close
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration between Rietveld and the client, Truus Schréder-Schrider (1889-1985),
label: Paragraph

text: whose full contribution has only recently been recognized. They collaborated in 1921 in
label: Paragraph

text: the design of a study for Mrs. Schréder-Schrader in her house on Biltstraat. In 1923, on
label: Paragraph

text: the death of her husband, Frits Schréder, Mrs. Schréder-Schrader decided to build a small
label: Paragraph

text: house for herself and her three children that would represent her ideas of a new, modern
label: Paragraph

text: way of living.
label: Paragraph

text: Sitting at the end of a row of traditional Dutch houses, the Schréder-Schrader House is
label: Paragraph

text: a balanced, asymmetrical composition of seemingly independent planes and lines. The
label: Paragraph

text: ends of the elements slip past each other with balconies and roof planes also projecting
label: Paragraph

text: from the body of the house as though not fully containing the space inside. Rietveld
label: Caption

text: initially conceived of the house as constructed in concrete, and it was noted as such in
label: Paragraph

text: some early publications. This proved to be too costly, and only the foundations and
label: Paragraph

text: balconies are of concrete, and the walls are of traditional brick masonry with plaster.
label: Paragraph

text: Both wood and steel are used for structural support, wood generally at the floors and steel
label: Paragraph

text: for the balconies and flat roof.
label: Caption

text: Sheltered by the southeast balcony in the main entry to the house is a traditional Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: door lacquered black. The ground floor is a composition of fixed walls in which essential
label: Paragraph

text: functions have been carefully integrated into the design. Within the compact space of the
label: Paragraph

text: entry hall, a coat closet, a telephone counter, and a place for mail delivery, as well as
label: Paragraph

text: storage for the children’s toys, are carefully composed and built-in. Also on the ground
label: Paragraph

text: level is a small study with a built-in desk, bookshelves, and a door into the garden.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the room behind the study was intended as a garage, Mrs. Schréder-Schrader
label: Paragraph

text: never owned an automobile, and both Mrs. Schréder-Schrader and Rietveld periodically
label: Paragraph

text: used this room as a studio. To the right of the entry hall is the kitchen with room for four
label: Caption

text: people to dine. A small window and shelf for deliveries is built-in, as is a speaking tube
label: Paragraph

text: to the living-dining area on the upper level. Accessed from the kitchen is a small cellar,
label: Paragraph

text: and behind the kitchen is a maid’s room. Mrs. Schréder-Schrader, however, never had a
label: Paragraph

text: live-in servant, and this room was used primarily for reading. Closely linked to the site,
label: Paragraph

text: the garage, kitchen, and study have their own doors to the garden, and spatial connections
label: Paragraph

text: are made between the rooms with large transoms at the top of the walls.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the fact that the drawings given to the building commission indicate the ground
label: Paragraph

text: floor as the living area with the upper level noted as an “attic,” this was never the
label: Paragraph

text: intention. It is the upper level that most exemplifies Mrs. Schréder-Schrader’s desire for
label: Paragraph

text: an architecture to match her attitudes toward living. These ideas were manifested in an
label: Paragraph

text: inherent freedom in the ability to change the layout to accommodate a variety of spatial
label: Paragraph

text: configurations. A single, open room, the upper level can be divided by movable partitions
label: Paragraph

text: that follow tracks in the floor and guides along the ceiling. Closing the partitions creates
label: Paragraph

text: four smaller rooms that provided privacy for the children and Mrs. Schréder-Schrader
label: Caption

text: and a shared living-dining area. The three bedrooms are equipped with built-in storage
label: Paragraph

text: and a sink to promote self-sufficiency. A skylight above the stair provides access to the
label: Paragraph

text: roof and fills the center of the upper level with light. The bath and toilet area along the
label: Paragraph

text: party wall can be enclosed by movable partitions at the stair. Gerard van de Groenekan,
label: Caption

text: Rietveld’s assistant, constructed the built-in furniture; chairs and small tables were also
label: Paragraph

text: of Rietveld’s design. The living-dining area is a slightly larger space with a built-in table,
label: Paragraph

text: storage, and a shelf for the children to do their homework. It was here that the lively
label: Paragraph

text: discussions that Mrs. Schréder-Schrader envisioned occurred.
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld created the interpenetration of spaces and the connection to the surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: landscape by the dematerialization of boundaries either physically, as in the use of
label: Paragraph

text: movable partitions, or through the use of color. Rietveld’s offsetting of the support at the
label: Paragraph

text: comer window in the living-dining room literally opens the space and creates a direct
label: Paragraph

text: connection to the landscape. In turn, the colors of the floor and walls of the upper level
label: Paragraph

text: define spaces not constricted by the placement of partitions.
label: Paragraph

text: The Schréder-Schrader House is often considered a quintessential example of De Stijl
label: Paragraph

text: architectural principles. Theo van Doesburg, the founder of De Stijl, published the house
label: Paragraph

text: several times in his journal De Stij/. However, the house was not initially acknowledged
label: Paragraph

text: by the general Dutch press, despite its appearance in many influential European
label: Paragraph

text: architecture magazines and Henry Russell Hitchcock’s 1929 Modern Architecture. The
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s brought a resurgence of interest in the house in conjunction with a growth in the
label: Paragraph

text: popularity of Rietveld’s work.
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld moved to the house after the death of his wife and lived there until his own
label: Paragraph

text: death in 1964. Over time, a number of changes were made to the house; a dumbwaiter
label: Paragraph

text: was added from the kitchen to the upper living-dining area, and in 1935 a room was
label: Paragraph

text: added on the roof to give Mrs. Schréder-Schrader more privacy from the many visitors
label: Caption

text: who came to see the house. This room was later demolished. The original, rural context
label: Paragraph

text: of the house also has changed with urban expansion and the construction of a bypass in
label: Paragraph

text: 1964. Mrs. Schréder-Schrader established the Rietveld Schréder House Foundation in
label: Caption

text: 1970 to assist in the maintenance and preservation of the house. Five years later, the
label: Paragraph

text: foundation hired the architect Bertus Mulder to begin restoration of the interior and
label: Paragraph

text: exterior of the house. The Schréder-Schrader House was opened to the public in 1987.
label: Caption

text: SCOTT BROWN, DENISE 1931
label: Title

text: Architect and theorist, United States
label: Title

text: Controversial both for her ideas and for her prominence as a female theorist and
label: Paragraph

text: practitioner in a period when few women architects succeeded, Denise Scott Brown has
label: Paragraph

text: exercised a powerful influence on architecture and urbanism since the 1970s.
label: Paragraph

text: Reconnecting form to its social meaning and emphasizing architecture’s position within
label: Paragraph

text: its cultural environment, her concerns have coupled with Robert Venturi’s interest in
label: Paragraph

text: historical precedent to produce an inclusive interpretation of architecture’s context that
label: Paragraph

text: incorporates social, economic, historic, and formal dimensions. Along with a shared
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic of simplification, juxtaposition, and deadpan irony, their theories have been
label: Paragraph

text: central to the development of Postmodernism and the advancement of the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: profession generally.
label: Paragraph

text: Scott Brown was born in 1931 in Nkana, Zambia, into a well-to-do Jewish household
label: Paragraph

text: of Lithuanian and Latvian ancestry. After architectural studies at the University of
label: Paragraph

text: Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, she earned a diploma at the Architectural Association in
label: Paragraph

text: London in 1955 and was registered in the United Kingdom in 1956. Her teachers
label: Paragraph

text: included Arthur Korn, a Bauhaus émigré and coauthor of the MARS plan for postwar
label: Paragraph

text: London who emphasized the connections between social structure and urban form, and
label: Paragraph

text: historian John Summerson, whose preoccupations with mannerism and Georgian
label: Paragraph

text: urbanism contrasted with contemporary CLAM (Congrés Internationaux d’ Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: Moderne) and “townscape” planning ideas. Peter and Alison Smithson’s focus on
label: Paragraph

text: advertising, everyday experience, and neighborhood “association” also stimulated her
label: Paragraph

text: interest in pop art and ordinary urban environments. At the University of Pennsylvania,
label: Paragraph

text: she obtained masters degrees in city planning and architecture in 1960 and 1965, studying
label: Paragraph

text: under sociologist Herbert Gans, a “‘participant-observer” of Levittown, who defended the
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic validity of popular culture, and planner David Crane, an originator of advocacy
label: Paragraph

text: planning. An early article, “The Meaningful City” (1965), adapted Crane’s articulation of
label: Paragraph

text: three levels of urban meaning—“heraldic,” “physiognomic,” and “locational”—to urban
label: Paragraph

text: design. Her multifaceted education generated a sophisticated understanding of the
label: Paragraph

text: interaction between architectural form and social forces as well as the conviction that
label: Paragraph

text: architects should foster rather than negate patterns of urban order arising from the
label: Paragraph

text: aggregation of many individual social and economic decisions.
label: Paragraph

text: Scott Brown met Robert Venturi at the University of Pennsylvania in 1960. Sharing an
label: Paragraph

text: anthropological attitude toward their aesthetic environment and an affinity for the local,
label: Paragraph

text: the complex, and the irregular, they soon began collaborating, marrying in 1967 and
label: Paragraph

text: formalizing their architectural partnership in 1968. Their visits to Las Vegas led to the
label: Paragraph

text: publication of two seminal articles: “A Significance for A&P Parking Lots, or Learning
label: Paragraph

text: from Las Vegas” (1968) and “Ugly and Ordinary Architecture, or the Decorated Shed,
label: Paragraph

text: Parts | and Il” (1971). Their studios on Las Vegas and Levittown at Yale in 1968 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1970 employed interdisciplinary research and design methods and applied traditional
label: Paragraph

text: categories of architectural analysis to everyday postwar urban forms. In Learning from
label: Paragraph

text: Las Vegas (1972, with Steven Izenour), they argued that Las Vegas’s extravagant signs
label: Paragraph

text: and its large, low, generic buildings were extreme but informative models of current
label: Paragraph

text: building practices, the avatars of a new, late Modern—or what was soon to be called
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodern—vernacular. In an automobile-dominated culture, pedestrian-oriented,
label: Paragraph

text: modernist “space” was less significant than “symbolism over vast space.”
label: Paragraph

text: Carol M.Newman Library Renovation and Addition, Virginia Polytechnic
label: Caption

text: Institute and State University (1971)
label: Caption

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: They invented two new terms—the duck and the decorated shed—to describe the
label: Paragraph

text: operation of architectural symbolism. The duck’s entire form was an image of an idea.
label: Paragraph

text: The Las Vegas casino was a decorated shed: constructed conventionally and generically
label: Paragraph

text: but with an ornamented, symbolic facade. In both, symbolic considerations dominated
label: Paragraph

text: structural and functional ones. Drawing on linguistic theory as well as associational
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy, Venturi and Scott Brown argued that architecture is understood by
label: Paragraph

text: association to previous experience. Rather than emphasizing structural and functional
label: Paragraph

text: “truth,” therefore, buildings should make reference to what people already know: the
label: Paragraph

text: conventions of vernacular as well as historical forms. Their insistence on the validity of
label: Paragraph

text: the ordinary person’s aesthetic choices contested modernism’s belief that architecture
label: Paragraph

text: should create both a better world and a “modern man” suited to live in it. Theorist and
label: Paragraph

text: historian Kenneth Frampton’s dispute with Scott Brown over this distinction between
label: Paragraph

text: “is” and “ought” rested on a disagreement over the identity of architecture’s audience: the
label: Paragraph

text: worker to whom modern architecture had often been dedicated or the lower-middle class
label: Paragraph

text: denizens of Gans’s Levittown (Frampton, 1971; Venturi and Scott Brown, 1984).
label: Paragraph

text: Scott Brown’s interest in the everyday environment also engendered a four-year
label: Paragraph

text: investigation of the imagery of American suburbs. This research culminated in “Signs of
label: Paragraph

text: Life” (1976), an exhibition of suburban, strip, and city imagery mounted at the
label: Paragraph

text: Smithsonian Institution’s Renwick Galley in Washington, D.C. The exhibit consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: three sections: the Home, three dioramas of typical American housing types; the Strip,
label: Paragraph

text: neon signs and billboards, many especially constructed for the exhibit; and the Street,
label: Paragraph

text: texts and images describing Main Street. Its deadpan presentation delighted the public but
label: Paragraph

text: puzzled architects, who expected aesthetic judgments on American urbanism.
label: Paragraph

text: Scott Brown’s writing, which often delineates the connection between the personal and
label: Paragraph

text: the theoretical, encompasses architectural and urban theory, preservation, education, and
label: Paragraph

text: critiques of the “star system” in architecture. Her role as partner in charge of planning at
label: Paragraph

text: Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates is equally significant. Ranging from facilities
label: Paragraph

text: programming to the design of urban districts, Scott Brown’s work also includes important
label: Paragraph

text: contributions to the firm’s architectural projects. Her involvement in the Sainsbury Wing
label: Paragraph

text: of the National Gallery (1991) in London is especially notable. In 1992, she and Venturi
label: Paragraph

text: were awarded the Presidential Medal of the Arts. Her plans, the recipients of many
label: Paragraph

text: awards, emphasize user participation, sensitivity to existing urban fabric, practicability,
label: Paragraph

text: and what she calls a “feminist, darning and mending” approach to evolutionary change
label: Paragraph

text: (Gabor, 1995). They have sometimes generated controversy with their insertion of “pop”
label: Paragraph

text: elements into existing fabrics. Her Philadelphia Crosstown Community Plan (1968)
label: Paragraph

text: restored a oncevital, center-city commercial neighborhood that had undergone a steep
label: Paragraph

text: decline in the 1960s, suffering from both the loss of its middle-class population and the
label: Paragraph

text: city’s plan to cut a highway through it. Employing Edward Ruscha-style collages to
label: Paragraph

text: illustrate existing character, her proposal mixed sensitive reuse with new construction and
label: Paragraph

text: substituted one-way streets for the proposed expressway. Miami Beach’s Art Deco
label: Paragraph

text: District (1978) was a thriving but run-down area inhabited by Eastern European Jewish
label: Paragraph

text: retirees and Cuban immigrants. Scott Brown’s pragmatic approach, which included a
label: Paragraph

text: color palette, inexpensive facade renovations, street furniture, and paving patterns, won a
label: Paragraph

text: Progressive Architecture Urban Design Award in 1982.
label: Paragraph

text: Scott Brown’s innovative approach to studio teaching has influenced many
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary planners and architects. She has taught at the University of Pennsylvania,
label: Paragraph

text: at the University of California at Berkeley and Los Angeles, and at Yale, Harvard, and
label: Paragraph

text: Rice Universities. In 1996, she won the Association of the Collegiate Schools of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture and the American Institute of Architects Topaz Award for outstanding
label: Title

text: architectural educators, the first woman to receive this award.
label: Paragraph

text: SCULLY, VINCENT, JR. 1920
label: Title

text: Historian, United States
label: Title

text: One of the most inspirational and influential educators of the 20th century, Vincent
label: Paragraph

text: Scully, Jr., has been widely recognized as a leader of architectural historians and critics
label: Paragraph

text: of the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: When he was admitted to Yale College from New Haven’s Hillhouse High School in
label: Paragraph

text: 1936, he was only 15. At the time, his primary interests were literary criticism and
label: Paragraph

text: French, which would teach him Cartesian clarity and rigor and guide his search for facts
label: Paragraph

text: and the clearness of things. After graduating with a B.A. in 1940, he attempted to enlist in
label: Paragraph

text: the Royal Canadian Air Force and the U.S. Army Air Force but ultimately went into the
label: Paragraph

text: U.S. Marine Corps, serving in both Europe and the Pacific. At the end of World War LI,
label: Paragraph

text: Scully returned to Yale as a graduate student of art history. Within the next three years,
label: Paragraph

text: he received his M.A. (1947) and Ph.D. (1949) degrees from Yale. With the exception of a
label: Paragraph

text: year of study in Rome (1951-52) and another year of traveling in Greece (1957-58), he
label: Paragraph

text: would never leave his alma mater, where he has taught continuously from 1947 to the
label: Paragraph

text: present, even following his official retirement in 1991 as Sterling Professor Emeritus of
label: Paragraph

text: the History of Art.
label: Paragraph

text: At Yale, Scully benefited first from the teaching and later the collegiate friendship of
label: Paragraph

text: several outstanding scholars and teachers in the history of art, including George Kubler,
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Seymour, Jr., and Sumner McKnight Crosby, all of whom had in turn studied
label: Paragraph

text: under the preeminent French humanist Henri Focillon. Focillon’s conception of style in
label: Paragraph

text: the visual arts and of the structure and behavior of historical time, best described in his
label: Paragraph

text: seminal book Vie des Formes (1934), translated into English by Kubler as The Life of
label: Paragraph

text: Forms in Art (1942), must have attracted Scully’s attention in particular. Above all,
label: Paragraph

text: Focillon’s singular ability to penetrate beyond superficial phenomena to grasp the deeper
label: Paragraph

text: relationships would leave a lasting impression on him.
label: Paragraph

text: Scully’s dissertation, titled “The Cottage Style,” was a brilliant reassessment of 19th-
label: Paragraph

text: century American architecture, not a popular topic at the time. In it, he argued
label: Paragraph

text: convincingly that late 19th-century domestic architecture in the United States “had
label: Paragraph

text: clearly begun to demonstrate positive characteristics of originality and invention”—most
label: Paragraph

text: noticeable in the work of architects such as Bruce Price; McKim, Mead and White;
label: Paragraph

text: Henry Hobson Richardson; and Frank Lloyd Wright. Published as The Shingle Style in
label: Paragraph

text: 1955, the book became an instant classic, and after multiple reprintings, it remains the
label: Paragraph

text: definitive study on the subject. Not only would this work lead to a reevaluation of
label: Paragraph

text: American domestic architecture between 1872 and 1889, but it would serve as a source of
label: Paragraph

text: inspiration to 20th-century architects such as Robert A.M.Stern, Charles Moore, and
label: Paragraph

text: Robert Venturi, whose domestic designs of the 1960s and 1970s marked a full-fledged
label: Paragraph

text: revival of the American Shingle style.
label: Paragraph

text: Scully has covered an extraordinary range of topics in 19 books and some 200 articles,
label: Paragraph

text: including chapters and essays in books, journals, and book reviews. Scully has explored
label: Paragraph

text: the interaction of man, architecture, and the natural setting. Always considering
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in its broadest sense as the creation by man of the built environment in
label: Paragraph

text: relation to the natural environment, he examined ancient Greek architecture in The Farth,
label: Paragraph

text: the Temple, and the Gods (1962), indigenous North American architecture in Pueblo:
label: Paragraph

text: Mountain, Village, Dance (1975), and world architecture from prehistory to the present in
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture: The Natural and the Manmade (1991).
label: Paragraph

text: His writings in recent years have deeply explored the theme of the preservation of the
label: Paragraph

text: man-made in balance with the increasingly more fragile natural environment and the
label: Paragraph

text: ways architecture must respond in a sensitive way to societal needs. Appropriately
label: Paragraph

text: enough, when invited in 1995 by the National Endowment for the Humanities to deliver
label: Paragraph

text: the Twenty-fourth Annual Jefferson Lecture in the humanities at the John F.Kennedy
label: Caption

text: Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, D.C., his topic was “The Architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: Community.”
label: Paragraph

text: Even earlier, however, in American Architecture and Urbanism (1969), Scully had
label: Paragraph

text: written critically about the ravages of urban renewal and the drama of poor
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods that were so much affected across the nation during the 1950s and the
label: Paragraph

text: following decades. As a witness to the destruction of important buildings in downtown
label: Paragraph

text: New Haven, Scully wasted no time in becoming a spokesman for the cause of historic
label: Paragraph

text: preservation. During many years, he has participated in preservation battles that have
label: Paragraph

text: helped save important historic buildings. In 1999, his voice was a decisive factor in the
label: Paragraph

text: reversed decision that stopped the demolition of four buildings at the rear of the Sterling
label: Paragraph

text: Divinity Quadrangle of Yale.
label: Caption

text: Throughout his career, Scully has been the recipient of numerous awards and
label: Paragraph

text: recognitions. Starting as a Junior Sterling Fellow while a graduate student at Yale, he was
label: Paragraph

text: later also made Morse Fellow (1951-52), Senior Faculty Fellow (1962-63), and Paskus
label: Paragraph

text: Fellow in History at Jonathan Edwards College (1955-68). As Fulbright Fellow, he
label: Paragraph

text: traveled to Italy in 1951-52, and a Bollingen Fellowship allowed him to travel to Greece
label: Paragraph

text: in 1957-58. He holds four honorary doctorate degrees, from the University of Hartford
label: Paragraph

text: (1969), the New School for Social Research (1988), the University of Miami (1990) and
label: Paragraph

text: Albertus Magnus College (1992). In 1986, he received the Association of Collegiate
label: Paragraph

text: Schools of Architecture (ACSA)/(AIA) “Topaz” Award for Excellence in Architectural
label: Title

text: Education from the ACSA/American Institute of Architects (ALA) and in 1989 he was
label: Paragraph

text: made an Honorary Fellow of the Royal Institute of British Architects. During the 1990s
label: Paragraph

text: alone, he was honored with more than 15 major distinctions, including the “Golden
label: Paragraph

text: Plate” Award from the American Academy of Achievement (1993), the American
label: Paragraph

text: Academy of Rome Award (1994), the Lucy G.Moses Preservation Leadership Award
label: Paragraph

text: from the New York Landmarks Conservancy (1994), the ACSA Tau Sigma Delta Gold
label: Paragraph

text: Medal (1996), and the Byrnes-Sewall Prize for Teaching Excellence in Yale College
label: Paragraph

text: Scully has maintained close relationships with leading contemporary architects who
label: Paragraph

text: have respected him as a critic. Indeed, in his writings the distinction between historian
label: Paragraph

text: and critic have become blurred. As he puts it most eloquently in American Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and Urbanism, “Art history must therefore be conservative, experimental, and ethical. It
label: Paragraph

text: loves old and new things, and it demands value. The line between history and criticism
label: Paragraph

text: should therefore be difficult to draw in any field; in the modern field, it must be almost
label: Paragraph

text: nonexistent.”
label: Paragraph

text: SEAGRAM BUILDING, NEW YORK
label: Caption

text: Designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe; completed 1958
label: Caption

text: New York, New York
label: Caption

text: Of all the American monuments to the International Style, it is the Seagram Building
label: Paragraph

text: by Mies van der Rohe that fully defines the aesthetic and time of high modernism, the era
label: Paragraph

text: of postwar corporate and urban consciousness. In glass, steel, and bronze, the Seagram
label: Paragraph

text: symbolizes the bricks and mortar and martinis that were the 1950s.
label: Paragraph

text: The Seagram, a 40-story slab skyscraper of amber glass within a grid of bronze |
label: Paragraph

text: beams, rises above a fountained plaza on Manhattan’s Park Avenue. The body of the
label: Paragraph

text: building, in typical Mies fashion, is supported by a templelike entry that is reminiscent,
label: Paragraph

text: within a thoroughly modern composition, of the earliest post-and-lintel roots of archaic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The design is of interest not only for the glass slab that rises suavely above
label: Paragraph

text: mid-town Manhattan but also for the invention of the plaza fronting Park Avenue and the
label: Paragraph

text: resulting relationship of urban architectural object to its opposition, void space, within the
label: Paragraph

text: city grid. Architectural historian William H.Jordy, in his definitive analysis of the
label: Paragraph

text: building, spoke of the Seagram as modern expression of “the potential of structure to
label: Paragraph

text: create noble order, in the sense in which it created noble order in the past” coupled with
label: Paragraph

text: “truth of its time.”
label: Paragraph

text: For modernism, the Seagram is an ideal, perhaps even a Platonic ideal, of perfection
label: Paragraph

text: and purity of form. It symbolizes the type form of the gridded glass skyscraper, emblem
label: Paragraph

text: of the 20th century. The building has always seemed the epitome of form and function
label: Paragraph

text: united in its most integrated and reductive sense, the clearest expression of Mies’ edicts
label: Paragraph

text: that “form follows function” and that architecture is “almost nothing.” It is émigré Mies’
label: Paragraph

text: American sublime manifestation of his German utopian renderings.
label: Paragraph

text: Like its creator, the Seagram is both simple and complex. The simplicity is the gridded
label: Paragraph

text: steel frame with glass-curtain wall as a modern extension of the archaic building. The
label: Paragraph

text: complexity is inherent in the expression of that simplicity through the applied bronze |
label: Paragraph

text: beams, which, although they symbolically stand for the meaning of structure, are
label: Paragraph

text: themselves unstructural. Thus, the aesthetic of truth-in-structure is expressed through an
label: Paragraph

text: untruthfully convoluted visual metaphor.
label: Paragraph

text: Over the four decades since its design, the Seagram has drawn architecture and urban
label: Paragraph

text: planning into a number of problems. The primary problem is the truth-in-structure
label: Paragraph

text: problem, but other, more prosaic problems also exist. Unlike the ideal type-form
label: Paragraph

text: buildings of the past, such as the Parthenon and the Pantheon, the Seagram as a type form
label: Paragraph

text: was created within the fastest paced civilization in history. Thus, the Modern type form
label: Paragraph

text: engenders its own imitation and reaction within its lifetime. Thinking
label: Paragraph

text: Seagram Building Plaza: New York City (1958)
label: Caption

text: Ezra Stoller © Esto
label: Title

text: architects, after the Seagram, wrestled with the questions of, “Where can construction go
label: Paragraph

text: after total reduction?” and “How can the art of architecture follow perfection of form?”
label: Paragraph

text: For the thoughtful architect, the Seagram has been inspirational, a standard against
label: Paragraph

text: which tall buildings will always be judged. Less-gifted builders have simply lowered the
label: Paragraph

text: standard set by Mies for the gridded glass-and-steel skyscraper. His work has been
label: Paragraph

text: exploited, copied, and shortchanged as a standardized form by developers the world over,
label: Paragraph

text: cheaply, in terms of both dollars and aesthetics. Thus, it is critical for an appreciation of
label: Paragraph

text: early skyscraper design never to read the chronology of modern architecture backward,
label: Paragraph

text: blaming the beautiful early type forms, such as the Seagram, for the debased works of
label: Paragraph

text: later imitators.
label: Paragraph

text: A further problem engendered by the Seagram is inherent in the design of the slab
label: Paragraph

text: versus the plaza. For this revolutionary design, revised zoning rules had to supersede the
label: Paragraph

text: famous New York setback skyscraper law that had been passed to ensure that giant
label: Paragraph

text: buildings would not block light and air within the crowded Manhattan grid. As the rules
label: Paragraph

text: of the 1916 zoning law had dictated the aesthetics of the setback skyscraper, so now with
label: Paragraph

text: the Seagram plan would new zoning standards allow for new forms in American
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The Seagram plan meant that skyscrapers could go straight up to higher
label: Paragraph

text: elevations without setbacks, in giant continuous slabs. In exchange for height, the
label: Paragraph

text: footprint of the building would cover only a small percentage of the site, allowing an
label: Paragraph

text: open plaza to be created.
label: Paragraph

text: The assumption of city planners was that a public urban amenity would thus be created
label: Paragraph

text: and financed through private corporate funding. Although the concept of a plaza of
label: Paragraph

text: negative space could be fully animated by Mies, by a less-deft planner the modern plaza
label: Paragraph

text: has all too often proven to be no urban amenity. Poor imitation of the Seagram plaza has
label: Paragraph

text: led to urban plazas that are not, as Mies’s is, confined voids in an aesthetic dialectical
label: Paragraph

text: relationship with the solid form of a building but rather simply voids of leftover space.
label: Paragraph

text: Planners have learned that it is better to maintain a continuous street setback than to
label: Paragraph

text: disrupt it arbitrarily.
label: Paragraph

text: It is possible that the Seagram’s influence on architectural style has been even wider
label: Paragraph

text: than Mies could have expected, for the perfection and reduction of this building perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: engendered the reactionary excesses of Postmodernism. After working with Mies on the
label: Paragraph

text: Seagram, architect Philip Johnson left Mies but continued to react to the Miesian
label: Paragraph

text: influence for decades. Johnson’s prolific later ornamental Postmodernism, the antithesis
label: Paragraph

text: of his own International Style tenets, may be read as a reactionary comment on his own
label: Paragraph

text: work on the Seagram Building.
label: Caption

text: These problems, of course, are latter-day events for which Mies should not be held
label: Paragraph

text: responsible. It is not to his detriment that he sought, through his type form for the modern
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper, to create perfect architectural form; nor is it his fault that the imitators of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture so rarely comprehended the meaning of his architectural ideals. Mies would
label: Paragraph

text: not have concerned himself with such problems, for his concerns were solely with the
label: Paragraph

text: significance of his Baukunst.
label: Paragraph

text: SEARS TOWER, CHICAGO
label: Caption

text: Skidmore, Owings and Merrill; completed 1974 Chicago Illinois
label: Caption

text: The Sears Tower, today owned by a private investment firm and rented to a variety of
label: Paragraph

text: office tenants, serves as a landmark and a symbol of the Chicago skyline. The building is
label: Paragraph

text: seen from distant vistas in every direction in this flat, prairie-land city on the edge of
label: Paragraph

text: Lake Michigan, thus creating the awareness of the dynamic presence of the Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: skyline and urban environment.
label: Paragraph

text: During the period 1974-1997, the Sears Tower, at a height of 1454 feet and 110
label: Paragraph

text: stories, held the title of the world’s tallest building encompassing 4.5 million gross square
label: Paragraph

text: feet and 3.7 million square feet of net useable office space. In 1997 the Petronas Towers
label: Paragraph

text: in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia (designed by Cesar Pelli), although only 88 stories high,
label: Paragraph

text: usurped that honor with a height of 1483 feet. The Sears Tower continues to provide the
label: Paragraph

text: world’s highest occupied floors.
label: Paragraph

text: The generation of the form and concept of the vertical tower is an interesting
label: Paragraph

text: combination of client’s program, site and technology. The Federal Aviation
label: Paragraph

text: Administration who ruled that no building in Chicago could be higher than 2000 feet
label: Paragraph

text: above sea level determined the height. The site is at an elevation of 546 feet and, thus, a
label: Paragraph

text: final height of 1,454 feet was determined.
label: Paragraph

text: The initial goal was not to build the world’s tallest building. Sears, Roebuck and
label: Paragraph

text: Company determined that its floor space needs would eventually be 4.5 million gross
label: Paragraph

text: square feet. Skidmore, Owings and Merrill (SOM), the architects, conducted a study that
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated the company could save 30% of walking time in a department if floor areas
label: Paragraph

text: were stacked vertically and not arranged horizontally. Sears also determined that the ideal
label: Paragraph

text: department size was 110,000 square feet and that its initial needs were for only 60
label: Paragraph

text: percent of the gross 4.5 million square feet. The remaining 40 percent would initially be
label: Paragraph

text: rental space.
label: Paragraph

text: Following an initial concept of two separate towers, SOM began to develop a scheme
label: Paragraph

text: that was a number of vertical buildings tied together to make one building. Fazlur Kahn,
label: Paragraph

text: a structural engineer and partner in SOM, developed a system called “bundled tubes” for
label: Paragraph

text: the Sears Tower. The solution was a system composed of nine structural bays each 75
label: Paragraph

text: feet by 75 feet in plan and independent of each other. Nine skyscrapers of varying heights
label: Paragraph

text: are tied together in one building with the lateral wind loads resisted by the interlocked
label: Paragraph

text: exterior tubes, cantilevered from the ground augmented by horizontal diaphragms. With
label: Paragraph

text: this concept in place, it became possible to stop the tubes at any level without affecting
label: Paragraph

text: the structural integrity. The result was a vertical form that is composed of a nine-tube
label: Paragraph

text: base, floors 1 through 50; followed vertically by seven tubes on floors 51-65 where the
label: Paragraph

text: northwest and southeast tubes were discontinued; followed vertically by floors 66-90,
label: Paragraph

text: composed of five tubes in the shape of a cruciform in plan and finally the top floors 91—
label: Paragraph

text: 110 composed of two bundled tubes.
label: Paragraph

text: A building of this size and height is also strongly controlled by the vertical
label: Paragraph

text: transportation system. In order to satisfy user expectations as to speed and comfort of
label: Paragraph

text: movement, a point of density arrives wherein the ground floor elevators consume the
label: Paragraph

text: entire entry floor. To facilitate the size and density of the Sears Tower, technologies
label: Paragraph

text: involving double-deck elevators and high-speed express elevators were employed. The
label: Paragraph

text: Tower’s 103-cab system divides the building into three separate zones. Fourteen double-
label: Paragraph

text: deck elevators carry passengers, non-stop to either the 33rd—34th floors or the 66th—67th
label: Paragraph

text: floors where sky lobbies provide space for loading and unloading at two different floor
label: Paragraph

text: levels. Once at these levels passengers can go to local floors via 63 single-deck elevator
label: Paragraph

text: cabs. The 103rd floor is a public observation deck and serves large crowds by providing
label: Paragraph

text: two express elevators, which connect the ground and top floors. These elevators travel at
label: Paragraph

text: the rate of 1,800 feet per minute, reaching the summit in less than one minute.
label: Paragraph

text: The Sears Tower is the second in a series of three headquarters buildings for the
label: Paragraph

text: company. The first building constructed in 1904 was located at Arthington and Homan
label: Paragraph

text: Avenues in the Chicago West Side Lawndale community. It included a 14’4-story tower
label: Paragraph

text: and a campus of decentralized offices. It is still standing today. This environment
label: Paragraph

text: produced a corporate culture
label: Title

text: Sears Tower, Chicago (1974)
label: Caption

text: © Timothy Hursley. Photo courtesy $.0.M., Chicago
label: Caption

text: wherein a high degree of personal interaction occurred through chance meetings along
label: Paragraph

text: daily pedestrian routes. The present Sears Tower replaced this earlier structure in 1974.
label: Paragraph

text: The downtown Sears Tower served the Sears Corporation until 1992 when a new
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters was developed in Hoffman Estates in the Northwest suburbs of Chicago.
label: Paragraph

text: This building, designed by Perkins and Wills, Architects, returned to the culture of the
label: Paragraph

text: first building by creating a horizontal scheme that provided travel through atriums and
label: Paragraph

text: public corridors to encourage informal conversations and relationships among employees
label: Paragraph

text: and departments. The comparison of the three structures provides an enlightening
label: Paragraph

text: overview of the direction and styles of corporate America as to office building design.
label: Caption

text: The exterior appearance of the tubes is a dark, uniform surface composed of black
label: Paragraph

text: aluminum frames and bronze-tinted glare reducing glass. Although an aesthetic success
label: Paragraph

text: on the Chicago skyline, it is much less attractive and inviting at ground level. Its great
label: Paragraph

text: height is virtually imperceptible at its base. In 1985 to improve the relationship to the
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrian and make it more inviting for those entering the building, a new atrium entry-
label: Paragraph

text: way was created at the Wacker Street entrance and a new entry added at Jackson
label: Paragraph

text: Boulevard. In 1992 when Sears Corporation moved to its new location in Hoffman
label: Paragraph

text: Estates, the new owners determined to remodel the existing public spaces in a 70 million
label: Paragraph

text: dollar project. The goal was to make the building more attractive to new tenants. New
label: Paragraph

text: lobbies were added at the Franklin Street and Wacker Drive entrances.
label: Caption

text: Today the building is no longer the home of the Sears Corporation nor is it the world’s
label: Paragraph

text: tallest building, but it is still the dominant visual symbol on the Chicago skyline, a
label: Paragraph

text: symbol of the spirit and style of this Midwestern community and an attraction to
label: Paragraph

text: thousands of visitors each year.
label: Paragraph

text: SEASIDE, FLORIDA
label: Title

text: Seaside, Florida, is an 80—acre resort development on the Florida panhandle begun in
label: Paragraph

text: 1981 by Robert and Daryl Davis. Unlike the conventional high-rises or apartment clusters
label: Caption

text: lining the beach, Miami firm Andres Duany and Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk (DPZ) designed
label: Caption

text: Seaside as a traditional, small southern town of private residences and public streets.
label: Paragraph

text: Emblematic of what later became known as New Urbanism, Seaside’s design was
label: Paragraph

text: intended to produce a modest, mixed-income, mixed-use, pedestrian-oriented holiday
label: Paragraph

text: community.
label: Paragraph

text: Although various postmodernist architects in the 1970s had been incorporating
label: Paragraph

text: references to vernacular architecture into individual buildings and analyzing the figural
label: Paragraph

text: relationships between public and private urban space, Seaside represented the first effort
label: Paragraph

text: to reconfigure contemporary development in the form of a traditional American town. Its
label: Paragraph

text: use of conventional suburban-planning tools—codes and master plans—for this purpose
label: Paragraph

text: was unprecedented and has since stood as an alternative suburban development model to
label: Paragraph

text: urban sprawl. Its popularity, ever-higher prices, and pronounced traditional styling have
label: Paragraph

text: made it the subject of both tremendous praise and scorn. Along with later DPZ projects,
label: Paragraph

text: Seaside’s design revived interest among many allied disciplines in early 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: town-planning ideas, and its designers challenged the lack of attention to urbanism and
label: Paragraph

text: public space in both conventional land-planning practices and contemporary avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: architectural design.
label: Paragraph

text: DPZ’s interest in Team X ideas about using architecture to promote group social
label: Paragraph

text: relations dovetailed with Robert Davis’s desire not simply to develop the land he had
label: Paragraph

text: inherited but to found a town and community that would be part traditional small town
label: Paragraph

text: and part utopian social experiment. Together, the designers and the developer toured and
label: Paragraph

text: measured traditional southern towns. In an effort to reproduce the towns’ spatial quality
label: Paragraph

text: and authentic variety, DPZ refrained from designing any of the buildings at Seaside
label: Paragraph

text: themselves. Instead, through a charrette process, the firm developed a master plan and
label: Paragraph

text: codes to direct individual property owners’ design decisions. The design won a
label: Paragraph

text: Progressive Architecture citation for urban planning in 1984.
label: Paragraph

text: Town of Seaside, Florida
label: Title

text: © Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk
label: Title

text: The master plan extends the existing streets of neighboring Seagrove across the site,
label: Paragraph

text: locates a central green in an existing gorge, and straddles the two-lane coastal highway
label: Paragraph

text: with commercial activities. Its central focus and loose grid recall City Beautiful projects
label: Paragraph

text: from the 1920s. Unlike most coastal resorts, development along the 2800 feet of beach is
label: Paragraph

text: low and minimal, allowing water views to extend deep into the site and preserving public
label: Paragraph

text: access to the beach. There are approximately 300 residential lots, all of which are within
label: Paragraph

text: a five-minute walk of the center. A church, a school, a post office, and the resort’s
label: Paragraph

text: recreational amenities are prominently scattered throughout the site, where they visually
label: Paragraph

text: terminate vistas and serve as public or semipublic focal points to the various
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods. Private buildings, however, are visually unified through required build-to
label: Paragraph

text: lines, picket fences, percentage of porch frontage, number of stories, and general building
label: Caption

text: type.
label: Paragraph

text: Every lot on the master plan is keyed to one of eight different, regionally based
label: Paragraph

text: building types visually displayed in an easy-to-understand one-page urban code. North-
label: Paragraph

text: south streets call for relatively deep setbacks from the street and “Florida cracker” low,
label: Paragraph

text: porch-fronted “bungalows” so as to maximize public views of the Gulf of Mexico. East-
label: Paragraph

text: west streets, however, with no ocean view, offer smaller, more affordable lots, coded for
label: Paragraph

text: versions of the Charleston “single house”: taller and tight up to the street, with a side
label: Paragraph

text: yard. A diagonal boulevard (located to preserve existing trees) has the largest lots, and
label: Paragraph

text: “antebellum mansions” are able to serve as inns, apartments, or large single-family
label: Paragraph

text: residences. Three- to five-story, mixed-use, arcaded party-wall buildings, similar to those
label: Caption

text: found in New Orleans or Eufala, Alabama, line the central commercial area, whereas
label: Paragraph

text: three-story townhouses above shops and workshops create another, quieter square behind
label: Paragraph

text: it.
label: Paragraph

text: This diversity has been unified by a number of factors: the restriction of landscaping to
label: Paragraph

text: indigenous plants, the encouragement of construction of rear cottages, the allowance of
label: Paragraph

text: 215-square-foot towers, and an architectural code that allows for stylistic variation within
label: Paragraph

text: strict limits. It establishes acceptable window proportions, roof pitches, materials, and a
label: Paragraph

text: few mandatory construction details. Most of the homeowners have chosen to build in a
label: Paragraph

text: more or less Victorian or classical style, although the overall emphasis on design has
label: Paragraph

text: resulted in the commissioning of well-known contemporary designers including Steven
label: Paragraph

text: Holl, Aldo Rossi, Machado & Silvetti, Mockbee and Coker, Deborah Berke, and Walter
label: Caption

text: Chatham.
label: Paragraph

text: Counter to suburban privatization, Seaside consistently promotes the hierarchical
label: Paragraph

text: importance of the public realm and com-
label: Title

text: Town of Seaside, Florida (1979), designed by Duany and Plater-Zyberk
label: Caption

text: © Duany and Plater-Zyberk
label: Title

text: munity building. The codes discipline the private buildings into spatially, visually, and
label: Paragraph

text: socially defining the streets and squares as outdoor public rooms. Privileging the
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrian over the car, they are narrow and brick paved. The provision of shops, office
label: Paragraph

text: space, and a public junior high charter school in the town center has succeeded in
label: Paragraph

text: encouraging walking. Front porches are required to be close enough to the street to allow
label: Paragraph

text: for sociable interaction. There is a seasonal newspaper, and the Seaside Institute, a
label: Paragraph

text: nonprofit educational organization, programs public events to engage the immediate
label: Paragraph

text: community and the broader audience interested in New Urbanism.
label: Paragraph

text: The true community of Seaside however remains amorphous; there are very few year-
label: Paragraph

text: round inhabitants at Seaside. Most of the homes are vacation properties rented out
label: Paragraph

text: through the Seaside Rental Agency. Robert Davis argues that, as a resort, Seaside
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrates to more visitors the virtues of living in a walkable community of small lots
label: Paragraph

text: and shared public spaces. Critics point to Seaside as merely a simulation of community
label: Paragraph

text: and public life as well as a commodified nostalgia for the sentimental past. To some
label: Paragraph

text: critics, the seeming impossibility of dissent renders it a consensual tyranny rather than a
label: Paragraph

text: democratic utopia, a point made in the 1997 film The Truman Show, which was shot on
label: Paragraph

text: location in Seaside. Although such questions have in no way slowed the countless efforts
label: Paragraph

text: to emulate Seaside, they point to the continued controversy surrounding New Urbanism
label: Paragraph

text: and the questions it raises.
label: Paragraph

text: SEIDLER, HARRY 1923
label: Title

text: Architect, Australia
label: Title

text: In his first published article in 1949, Harry Seidler laid out a philosophy incorporating
label: Paragraph

text: relationships between modern European painting, the sculptural arts, and architecture. Its
label: Paragraph

text: outline was derived from Walter Gropius’s Harvard University Graduate School of
label: Paragraph

text: Design program and directed almost exclusively to visual elements (mass, transparency,
label: Paragraph

text: tension, polarity, and so on) that architecturally evolved in some measure from structural
label: Paragraph

text: exploitation. Seidler’s early houses were dedicated to these visual determinations but
label: Paragraph

text: showed a noticeable diversity as a result of experimentations with structure knitted to
label: Paragraph

text: easy formal architectonic considerations, such as plan and simple geometric shape.
label: Paragraph

text: The prize-winning house for his mother (1948-50) was first among works in the 1950s
label: Paragraph

text: that immediately captured attention worldwide, notably in Europe and the Los Angeles
label: Paragraph

text: magazine Arts and Architecture. They were recognized as an apogee of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: refinement and dynamic sensibility as promoted by central European émigré designers.
label: Paragraph

text: With Gropius, Seidler discovered a language for architectural thought; with Josef
label: Paragraph

text: Albers at Black Mountain College, he learned “to think in visual terms,” and with Oscar
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer he discovered form and mass, sun control, how to express structure, and
label: Paragraph

text: attention to site conditions. His early work was derivative of Marcel Breuer (he does not
label: Paragraph

text: apologize for this) but soon matured to reach a formal epitome in a block of apartments
label: Paragraph

text: (1962) at Diamond Bay, Sydney.
label: Caption

text: A close collaboration with Italian structural engineer Pier Luigi Nervi beneficially
label: Paragraph

text: changed Seidler’s large and tall buildings designs. The Australia Square development
label: Paragraph

text: (1962-67) in Sydney contains a round tower constructed of precast elements, repetitive
label: Paragraph

text: floor to floor—a lesson in constructional efficiency that clarified expression by
label: Paragraph

text: simplification. The tower stands on a stepped pedestrian plaza, open to but also partly
label: Paragraph

text: screening surrounding streets and shared with a shorter rectangular office building sitting
label: Paragraph

text: on giant sculpted piers. The Square set an urban design standard envied throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: Western world.
label: Paragraph

text: Parallel to this experience, Seidler referred to the series of paintings by American
label: Paragraph

text: postwar protominimalist painter Frank Stella that employed circular segments, and he
label: Paragraph

text: reexamined Albers’s free forms and the “richness” of Dutch-American Abstract
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist Willem de Kooning’s nonobjective paintings. The result was the
label: Paragraph

text: introduction of an overtly baroque character first explored tentatively for Condominium
label: Paragraph

text: Apartments (1969-70) at Acapulco, Mexico.
label: Caption

text: The 1970s were an expansive period that saw the completion of a number of major
label: Paragraph

text: commissions, including the Trade Group Office (1970—74) in Canberra, which employed
label: Paragraph

text: Nervi’s long-span, posttensional constructional system to a schemata based on the
label: Paragraph

text: functional responses of Louis I. Kahn; the MLC Center (1971-75) in Sydney, a
label: Paragraph

text: significant urban pedestrian precinct and office tower; and the Australian Embassy
label: Paragraph

text: (1973-74) in Paris, with Breuer as local consultant, a bipartite scheme of conceptual
label: Paragraph

text: maturity and constructional style that prevailed into the 1990s. Seidler maintained a
label: Paragraph

text: variety of commissions ranging from medium-size houses to civic centers (such as
label: Paragraph

text: Waverley, 1982-84, near Melbourne) to large urban-planning schemes. Of the latter, the
label: Paragraph

text: QVI building (1987-91) in Perth, Western Australia, and Grosvenor Place (1982-88) in
label: Paragraph

text: Sydney, with expansive pedestrian plazas and minimal site coverage by towers, are
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional.
label: Paragraph

text: For the most part, Seidler’s current architectural practice is directed to resolving formal
label: Paragraph

text: and social issues raised by tall buildings in urban situations. Following on from the MLC
label: Paragraph

text: Center, the most notable of these have been the lively Riverside Development (1983-86)
label: Paragraph

text: in Brisbane, typical of his concrete structural system, sun control aesthetic, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Albers-influenced two-and three-dimensional forms; the more angular Capita Center
label: Paragraph

text: office tower (1984-89) in Sydney, with a full-height stepped central space open to the
label: Paragraph

text: weather with occasional terraces land-scaped with 20-meter-high trees; and the elegantly
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated Hong Kong Club and Office Building (1980-84), whose baroque plan and
label: Paragraph

text: interior spaces meld perfectly with an expressive and exposed-concrete structural system.
label: Paragraph

text: The exclusive club occupies the lower 4 floors with 17 above for rental. Seidler has said
label: Paragraph

text: that his desire to
label: Paragraph

text: instill an aura of timeless serenity and yet elegance and pleasure led to the use
label: Paragraph

text: of curvilinear geometry and forms throughout. ...The curved forms, however,
label: Paragraph

text: are used within the geometric disciplines imposed by structural considerations
label: Paragraph

text: [and] harks back to...the Baroque era of the 17th and 18th centuries
label: Paragraph

text: This building’s “poetic geometry” suggests how his Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters might have appeared if he, rather than Norman Foster, had won the
label: Paragraph

text: competitive commission.
label: Paragraph

text: For the Vienna city government, Seidler has designed a complex of about 800
label: Paragraph

text: apartments in a 35-story triangular tower (similar to Lincoln Centre, 1996-98, in Kuala
label: Paragraph

text: Lumpur) and seven blocks of four to eight stories in a terraced garden (1993-c.2001),
label: Paragraph

text: each with views across the Danube to the old town. Diagonals, curves, and swirls
label: Paragraph

text: exaggerate structure and function and act as counterpoints to rectilinear elevations. They
label: Paragraph

text: are a further elaboration of forms found earlier, including the Horizon Apartment Tower
label: Paragraph

text: (1990-98) at Darlinghurst, Sydney, that provides a vigorous alternative response to the
label: Paragraph

text: glossy glass towers rising everywhere.
label: Paragraph

text: It is reasonable to compare Seidler’s work with that of a graduate student colleague at
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard, I.M.Pei. Both exhibit clarity of concept, a high level of sophistication, a love of
label: Paragraph

text: fluid geometry and plain forms, a certain monumentality, a correct and economical use of
label: Paragraph

text: expertly detailed materials, and a preference to boldly express structure.
label: Paragraph

text: Not from memory of days with Niemeyer but appearing as a reflective homage to the
label: Paragraph

text: nonagenarian Brazilian’s present-day white free forms is Seidler’s Berman house (1996—
label: Paragraph

text: c.2001). Sitting proud above a rugged stone and bush landscape, it is distinctly fresh,
label: Paragraph

text: from a young inquiring mind.
label: Paragraph

text: In the cause of architecture, Seidler has transcended earlier, merely visual precepts to
label: Paragraph

text: rs
label: Title

text: extend modernism (logically he believes) to avoid “transient fashion” and “‘post-mod’
label: Paragraph

text: cliches,” as he puts it, and engage in a most lively, rational architecture. His honorary
label: Paragraph

text: degrees, visiting teaching positions, and significant international awards attest to a
label: Paragraph

text: continuing influence.
label: Paragraph
