text: SEJIMA, KAZUYO 1956
label: Title

text: Architect, Japan
label: Title

text: Kazuyo Sejima’s works are cool-headed depictions of the social alienation of her
label: Paragraph

text: generation. She was born in Ibaraki prefecture, Japan, in 1956 and studied at Japan
label: Paragraph

text: Women’s University, receiving an undergraduate degree from the Housing Department in
label: Paragraph

text: 1979 and a master’s degree in architecture in 1981. On completing her studies, she joined
label: Paragraph

text: the firm Toyo Ito Architect and Associates, where she worked from 1981 until she
label: Paragraph

text: established her own office in 1987. While with Ito, her most notable contributions were
label: Paragraph

text: as the project architect for Pao (1985), a set of furnishings to accommodate the nomadic,
label: Paragraph

text: consumerist lifestyles of contemporary Japanese women. Although Sejima now
label: Paragraph

text: repudiates this project, the interpretation of society that it represents remains closer to the
label: Paragraph

text: outlook in her subsequent work than to Ito’s. In particular, Sejima continues to place an
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on emotionally unencumbered movement supported by functional flexibility.
label: Paragraph

text: Sejima also acknowledges Ito’s influence in her material vocabulary, especially
label: Paragraph

text: translucent films on glass, bright aluminum finishes, and attenuated steel structures.
label: Paragraph

text: However, a concern with light and reflectance has led Sejima to experiment with
label: Paragraph

text: wrapping buildings in a broader palette of unusual components and to using novel
label: Paragraph

text: approaches toward materials. Examples include polycarbonate panels at Y House (1994),
label: Paragraph

text: S House (1996), and M House (1997); patterned films applied to clear glass, with written
label: Paragraph

text: characters at the N Museum (1997), leaflike patterns at the Koga Municipal Park Cafe
label: Caption

text: (1998), or a rough striping referring to wood grain at the O Museum (1999); and
label: Paragraph

text: reflective louvers intended to create a collage of images by mirroring the sky and the
label: Paragraph

text: ground against the backdrop of interior activities at Hitachi Reflé (1998). Aesthetically,
label: Paragraph

text: these materials combine with flat, white surfaces to create an architecture that is luminous
label: Paragraph

text: and photogenic, contributing to her early recognition abroad.
label: Paragraph

text: Sejima’s 1990 design for a corporate residence, the Saishunkan Seiyaku Women’s
label: Paragraph

text: Dormitory (part of a series of well-publicized projects in the “Kumamoto Artpolis”),
label: Paragraph

text: brought her instantaneously to international attention. She impassively proposed an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural embodiment of the disciplined communal lifestyles of the women employee
label: Paragraph

text: residents, eschewing private space in favor of a polished, airy communal area. Limited
label: Paragraph

text: sleeping areas for four are ordered with military precision behind frosted glass, after
label: Paragraph

text: Sejima’s earlier proposals for a single large sleeping space proved too shocking.
label: Paragraph

text: Residential work remains Sejima’s most provocative. She describes herself as
label: Paragraph

text: designing for a new genus of family, one not always blood relatives or having any sort of
label: Paragraph

text: consistent structure or stability. Because of this, her designs lack sentimentality,
label: Paragraph

text: studiously avoiding privileging a location that celebrates the family unit, such as the
label: Paragraph

text: hearth or kitchen. Rather, her housing is organized in a way more reminiscent of
label: Paragraph

text: corporate environments: members of the household come together mostly in corridors,
label: Paragraph

text: while on the move, and individual private rooms, intended as bedrooms, have the
label: Paragraph

text: uniformity and barrenness of offices. These rooms often have folding doors or pivoted
label: Paragraph

text: shutters that allow the line between the common and private rooms to be adjusted. She
label: Paragraph

text: thus further reduces the private character of individual rooms: the walls between sleeping
label: Paragraph

text: spaces and more conventionally public areas are more or less permeable, as users like.
label: Paragraph

text: Critics fear that Sejima’s unruffled celebration of homogeneity is coldly prescient.
label: Paragraph

text: Less well recognized is that she mitigates these qualities by creating a defensive
label: Paragraph

text: boundary between residents and the outside, an approach that she shares with other
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese architects, such as Tadao Ando. In her work since 1993, this intention has been
label: Paragraph

text: reflected in establishing a core living space with little connection to the exterior and has
label: Paragraph

text: resulted in buildings where major spaces are below ground or where the exterior
label: Paragraph

text: envelope is almost entirely translucent, cutting off any views beyond the building
label: Paragraph

text: envelope. Although Westerners often see such designs as unusually harsh, they fit
label: Paragraph

text: comfortably within conventional Japanese residential expectations. However, in recent
label: Paragraph

text: nonresidential projects, Sejima has returned to an approach seen in her earliest residential
label: Paragraph

text: designs, extending interior space into the landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: Much of Sejima’s work to date has been commissioned by architects or clients
label: Paragraph

text: associated with the arts community, and her museum and studio spaces are also notable.
label: Paragraph

text: The Multi-Media Studio (1996) and N Museum have the same purity seen in Sejima’s
label: Paragraph

text: residential work, especially in their minimalism and contextual detachment. Sejima’s
label: Paragraph

text: proposal for an addition to the Sydney Museum of Art (1997) is her first overseas
label: Paragraph

text: commission, although the project has stalled. (A theater and culture center for Almere,
label: Paragraph

text: the Netherlands, designed in 1999, may ultimately be completed first.) Notably, in
label: Paragraph

text: Sejima’s oeuvre, retail and corporate facilities are unremarkable, in part because the
label: Paragraph

text: strategies that make her residential work extraordinary are more commonplace in the
label: Paragraph

text: building type.
label: Paragraph

text: Although sometimes described as ahistoric because of the abstraction of her work,
label: Paragraph

text: Sejima identifies closely with modernism but intensifies its formal effects. Ito’s work has
label: Paragraph

text: been a crucial foil for her: the remarkable Platform | (1988) and Platform II (1990) seem
label: Paragraph

text: to have been designed in response to Ito’s Silver Hut (1984), whereas the Villa in the
label: Paragraph

text: Forest (1994) builds on Ito’s White U (1976). Notably, Silver Hut and White U were for
label: Paragraph

text: Ito’s family and among his most challenging early works, whereas Sejima was able to go
label: Paragraph

text: further in her very first projects, with nonfamilial clients. Conventional prototypes also
label: Paragraph

text: serve as inspiration: in the Gifu Kitagata Apartments (Phase I, 1998), a public housing
label: Paragraph

text: complex, Sejima acknowledges the influence of Le Corbusier’s Unite d’Habitation and
label: Paragraph

text: Because Sejima emphasizes the intuitive side of her design process, the disciplined
label: Paragraph

text: structural innovations found in her buildings are less often noted. In the Police Box at

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Koga Municipal Park Cafe is enclosed with a strikingly thin roof and nearly nonexistent
label: Paragraph

text: walls, the result of recent collaborations with Mutsuro Sasaki. This project will perhaps
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Almost since the inception of the office, Ryue Nishizawa has worked closely with

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: SERT, JOSEP LLUIS 1902-83
label: Title

text: Architect and urban planner, United States
label: Caption

text: The career of Josep Lluis Sert and the ascendancy of modern architecture enjoyed a
label: Paragraph

text: fortunate simultaneity, for Sert emigrated to the United States just in time for the height
label: Paragraph

text: of his career to be synchronized with the American building boom and European postwar
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilding. Advancing the causes of the elder modernists who had preceded him, with a
label: Paragraph

text: freedom of aesthetic expression that they had had to eschew for functionalism, Sert built
label: Paragraph

text: buildings where they had often been confined to theorizing. True to his utopian modernist
label: Paragraph

text: roots as an early member of the Congrés Internationaux d’ Architecture Moderne (CIAM),
label: Paragraph

text: Sert’s oeuvre focused on the planning of public architecture for socially significant
label: Paragraph

text: projects. For Sert, however, aesthetics were never secondary to functionalism, and thus
label: Paragraph

text: the integration of the arts with architecture became an important tenet of his modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Associated with liberal causes in Spain, Sert debuted internationally at the Paris
label: Paragraph

text: World’s Fair of 1937 with his design for the Pavilion for the Spanish Republic, housing
label: Paragraph

text: Picasso’s Guernica. As a Catalonian refugee, the youthful Sert then followed an itinerant
label: Paragraph

text: life, renouncing his homeland; moving to Paris, where he worked with Le Corbusier, to
label: Paragraph

text: New York; and eventually attending Harvard University, where he followed Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius as head of the design school, concurrently establishing his own firm of Sert,
label: Paragraph

text: Jackson and Gourley.
label: Paragraph

text: Sert had thrown down the gaundet of modern urban planning with his seminal text for
label: Paragraph

text: the CLAM, Can Our Cities Survive? (1942), calling for the basic human rights to fresh
label: Paragraph

text: air, sunlight, space, and healthful environs. His ability to quantify such quality-of-life
label: Paragraph

text: issues set Sert at the apex of the fundamentals of modern urban planning, just as his
label: Paragraph

text: emotional commitment to a humane environment, coupled with a very rationally applied
label: Paragraph

text: methodology, made his the first really effective synthesis of the early modernists’
label: Paragraph

text: theories. Sert’s lifelong contribution was to fuse rationalism with humanity and
label: Paragraph

text: creativity.
label: Paragraph

text: Sert built his first socially significant project, the Barcelona Anti-Tubercular
label: Paragraph

text: Dispensary (1935, extant), to fight disease not only medically but also socially, for it
label: Paragraph

text: provided a poor population with a small but restorative environment. The double-winged
label: Paragraph

text: structure encloses a treed open courtyard, creating a miniature open space in a dense city
label: Paragraph

text: sector. Sert’s functional and imaginative solution raised the work to the level of oasis
label: Paragraph

text: amid urban chaos.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: ects his architecture for art and human spirit, the first of which was his Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion (1937), a tentlike, lightweight structure appropriate to its ephemeral existence as
label: Paragraph

text: exposition architecture. The simplicity of Sert’s reductivist statement—post and lintel

text: h stretched tent above—echoed richly of the archaic spiritual temple. Processional up
label: Paragraph

text: modern machined entrance ramp climaxed with Picasso’s modern interpretation of
label: Paragraph

text: ancient tragedy of war, Guernica, deftly moving the viewer between abstraction and
label: Paragraph

text: ity, from world’s fair to world war.
label: Paragraph

text: With the Spanish Pavilion, Sert embarked on an artistic journey that increasingly drew
label: Paragraph

text: most intense personal expression. The integration of art, architecture, and spirit via
label: Paragraph

text: archaic experience of processional; the light and space hinted at in this early work;
label: Paragraph

text: am
label: Title

text: the meditative possibilities of architecture would have their mature expression in
label: Paragraph

text: Sert’s late museums of art. His style evolved, retaining its Mediterranean roots for more
label: Paragraph

text: than
label: Title

text: The Fundacié Miré, (Joan Miro Center for the Study of Contemporary Art),
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona
label: Title

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: six decades: a thoughtful architecture of primary colors against pure white, agglomerative
label: Paragraph

text: massing of cubic forms, functionally derived flat pattern, and intense interest in space and
label: Paragraph

text: light.
label: Paragraph

text: Sert understood aesthetic dialectics, moving elegantly from art to architecture, from
label: Paragraph

text: architecture to nature, and from vernacular materials to the modern machined world,
label: Paragraph

text: always the modernist émigré drawn back to ancient echoes. In Sertian space, vacant walls
label: Paragraph

text: of poured concrete are held in a striking aesthetic tension to his signature saturated
label: Paragraph

text: colors, the solidity of his cubic forms is juxtaposed with the void space of courtyards, and
label: Paragraph

text: silence is always at the center of action.
label: Paragraph

text: In major international works commissioned at the height of his American career, from
label: Paragraph

text: the late 1950s into the early 1970s—the Fondation Maeght (1964, Provence, France), the
label: Paragraph

text: Fondation Miré (1975, Barcelona, Spain), and the Center for the Study of World
label: Paragraph

text: Religions (1958, Cambridge, Massachusetts)—Sert was able to give free rein at last to his
label: Paragraph

text: innate artistic and spiritual nature.
label: Paragraph

text: Processional and vista are important in these late Sertian works for art and spirit. As if
label: Paragraph

text: these were sacred sites, the Maeght and Miré museums are approached via long, winding
label: Paragraph

text: hill roads, integrated with the natural topography, white cubes amid landscape. The
label: Paragraph

text: Fondation Miré is vaulted, and the Fondation Maeght is topped by an inverted Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusian roof, whose origins can also be traced back to Sert’s own oeuvre in the white
label: Paragraph

text: awning above his Spanish Pavilion. Each art museum is com-posed of a series of masses
label: Paragraph

text: of cubic forms, like an indigenous hill town, built of positive and negative spaces, in
label: Paragraph

text: clusters resembling Iberian atrium houses. These modern compositions become visual
label: Paragraph

text: meditations on the accretions of time, space, and stucco.
label: Paragraph

text: For Sert, the active and the contemplative, the sacred and the secular, and the
label: Paragraph

text: integration of the arts with architecture were all significant pursuits of modernism. At
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard University, Sert left a legacy of buildings and plans exploring these themes, in
label: Paragraph

text: the Science Center (1970), Peabody Terrace (1964), an unrealized campus plan, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts (1963), a project in which he was affiliated with his
label: Paragraph

text: friend Le Corbusier.
label: Paragraph

text: The Harvard Center for the Study of World Religions, however, speaks most clearly of
label: Paragraph

text: Sert the man and his vision. One room of this work might be considered a summation of
label: Paragraph

text: Sert’s oeuvre: the meditation room, the metaphorical center of the design. Here Sert
label: Paragraph

text: planned for art, architecture, and spirit to be mutually enhancing in an empty room of
label: Paragraph

text: blank white walls illuminated by a sole natural light source. In this silent statement of
label: Paragraph

text: space, light, peace, and the universal imagery of spirit, Sert achieved a unity of beliefs
label: Paragraph

text: with artistic form, of form with spirit. Here, in Sert’s words, truly is “a different
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality.”
label: Paragraph

text: SHANGHAI WORLD FINANCTAL CENTER
label: Title

text: Designed by Kohn Pedersen Fox, to be completed in 2007
label: Paragraph

text: Shanghai, China
label: Title

text: Designed by the American architectural firm Kohn Pedersen Fox in 1994 for the Japan-
label: Paragraph

text: based Mori Building Development Co., the Shanghai World Financial Center will rise to
label: Paragraph

text: a projected height of 500 meters, making it the tallest building in the world by nearly 50
label: Paragraph

text: meters. The building is part of a global paradigm shift that has occurred over the last
label: Paragraph

text: decade, resulting in the world’s tallest buildings, traditionally located in Chicago or New
label: Paragraph

text: York, now emerging in rapidly developing parts of Asia. Cesar Pelli’s Twin Towers in
label: Paragraph

text: Kuala Lumpar were the first to announce this trend, and the Shanghai World Financial
label: Paragraph

text: Center (which is significantly taller than Twin Towers) is clearly destined to establish
label: Paragraph

text: itself as China (and Asia’s) tallest building.
label: Paragraph

text: Construction of the 94-story structure began in August 1997, and the first stage of
label: Paragraph

text: construction, involving the structural groundwork, was completed in October 1998. The
label: Paragraph

text: financial crisis that crippled Asian markets in the late 1990s forced a temporary halt to
label: Paragraph

text: construction, during which time financial backing was secured to recommence
label: Paragraph

text: construction of the tower. Following a range of delays, the tower, in a slightly modified
label: Paragraph

text: form, is now to be completed by 2007 in time for the Beijing Olympics in the following
label: Paragraph

text: year. Key changes to the design resulted in an increase in height from 460 meters to a
label: Paragraph

text: new projected height of 500 meters.
label: Paragraph

text: The building occupies a site on Pudong Road adjacent to the recently completed Jin
label: Paragraph

text: Mao Tower in the rapidly developing Lujiazhui financial and trade district in Pudong.
label: Paragraph

text: This area has been dedicated to development by the Chinese government and is intended
label: Paragraph

text: to become the Asian epicenter for international trade and banking. The Shanghai World
label: Paragraph

text: Financial Center is the second of a planned trilogy of high-rise towers in the area. The
label: Paragraph

text: program provides for a total of nearly 320,000 square meters of useable area, with a
label: Paragraph

text: combination of ground-floor retail, commercial office space, hotel suites, and an
label: Paragraph

text: observation deck at the top of the building.
label: Caption

text: The design of the tower represents a transition by Kohn Pedersen Fox from the
label: Paragraph

text: extravagant Post-modern towers that characterized the firm throughout the 1980s toward
label: Paragraph

text: the more streamlined and technological aesthetic that dominates their recent architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Such a shift demonstrates a nostalgia for the clean forms of modernism, diminishing the
label: Paragraph

text: role of the fagade of the tower in favor of more refined and monumental geometric forms.
label: Paragraph

text: This is evident in the design of the tower, which takes the form of a chiseled wedge,
label: Paragraph

text: carved by two sweeping arcs and punctuated dramatically at the apex by a circular void
label: Paragraph

text: 50-meters in diameter. The diminishing proportion of the floor-plates formed by the
label: Paragraph

text: tapered block allows for commercial office space at the lower levels and hotel suites
label: Paragraph

text: above in the more longitudinally proportioned zones of the building. An observation deck
label: Caption

text: is to be located on a bridge across the dynamic circular void at a height of 380 meters.
label: Paragraph

text: The tower is square at the base, tapering to a single line at the apex oriented along the
label: Paragraph

text: diagonal of the ground-floor plate. The sweeping arcs give the tower a twisted, animated
label: Paragraph

text: form providing unique views of the tower from different vantage points throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: city. This is most noticeable from the historical Bund area on the opposite side of the
label: Paragraph

text: Huang Pu River, which bends around the Pudong area and provides the primary sites for
label: Paragraph

text: viewing the building in the skyline. The circular void that dominates the top of the tower
label: Paragraph

text: is the same diameter as the sphere atop the nearby Oriental Pearl TV tower, initiating a
label: Paragraph

text: solid-void dialogue with the adjacent landmark, which the twisting form of the tower
label: Paragraph

text: addresses. The circular cutout is intended pragmatically to reduce the considerable wind-
label: Paragraph

text: loads on the building, especially significant in typhoon-stricken Shanghai. It also contains
label: Paragraph

text: thinly veiled references to traditional Chinese architecture and the circular moon-gate that
label: Paragraph

text: adorns many temples and gardens across China. The geometry of the square and the
label: Paragraph

text: circle that is pervasive throughout the tower is intrinsic to Chinese philosophy, symbolic
label: Paragraph

text: generally of the earth and the sky and ideas of unity and harmony.
label: Paragraph

text: Juxtaposed against the monolithic tower is a fractured podium, which responds to the
label: Paragraph

text: disparate urban cacophony of Pudong, induced by several years of rampant development.
label: Paragraph

text: Because of setback restrictions, the tower is confined to the center of the site, dissected
label: Paragraph

text: by a triangular shaft that slices through the building at ground level and forms the entry to
label: Paragraph

text: the lift-core. Based on the geometry of a perfect circle, from which the square floorplate
label: Paragraph

text: of the tower projects, the podium wraps around the rear of the building, peeling back to
label: Paragraph

text: reveal the intersection of the tower with the ground at the front, north-western edge of the
label: Caption

text: site. This gesture addresses the main road of the Lujiazui district and contains a
label: Paragraph

text: landscaped public space protected by an enveloping shield of trees. The southern and
label: Paragraph

text: western sides of the tower are bounded by a landscaped public garden that links several
label: Paragraph

text: parts of the urban Lujiazui district and connects the three projected towers. A large area
label: Paragraph

text: of on-grade car parking is located on the southeastern side of the tower, screened from
label: Paragraph

text: the parkland by a natural earth-berm.
label: Paragraph

text: The lower portions of the building are to be clad in a combination of smooth and
label: Paragraph

text: heavily rusticated granite. This is juxtaposed against the lightly reflective glass and
label: Paragraph

text: oO
label: Title

text: stainless steel of the tower, anchoring the composition at the base and celebrating the
label: Paragraph

text: lightweight elegance of the glass and steel as it disappears into the sky. The original
label: Paragraph

text: design called for a steel structure cased in concrete, using slender perimeter columns at
label: Paragraph

text: 3.6-meter intervals to transmit lateral loads and the reinforced concrete core to transport
label: Caption

text: loads to the ground. This was later rationalized to use steel-reinforced concrete perimeter
label: Paragraph

text: columns of the same size and spacing but to bolster the structure with a second concrete
label: Paragraph

text: tube around the central core. The columns are interconnected by horizontal steel trusses
label: Paragraph

text: and diagonal perimeter bracing throughout the tower, which binds the columns vertically.
label: Caption

text: Until its completion, it is difficult to gauge the significance of the building within the
label: Paragraph

text: broader architectural context. The design attempts to bridge the chasm between the latent
label: Paragraph

text: forces of ancient Chinese culture and the volatile global economy of modern Asia
label: Title

text: through the understated clarity of late modernism. As a result, the tower announces a new
label: Paragraph

text: phase in the architectural language of Kohn Pedersen Fox and a new direction in Asian
label: Paragraph

text: high-rise construction, but judgment of the success of the building must wait until the
label: Paragraph

text: completion of construction.
label: Paragraph

text: country houses, churches, commercial centers, and residential developments in and
label: Paragraph

text: around Chicago. An admirer of all things British, Shaw often combined elements
label: Paragraph

text: associated with Gothic, Tudor, Georgian and Arts and Crafts architecture to provide
label: Paragraph

text: buildings for such notable clients as Joseph Ryerson and Gustavus Swift. While Shaw
label: Paragraph

text: knew and admired progressive architects like Frank Lloyd Wright, and even sometimes
label: Paragraph

text: employed Prairie School motifs in his own work, he was inspired more by the works of
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary British architects like Edwin Lutyens to fulfill the needs of Chicago’s more
label: Paragraph

text: conservative clientele.
label: Paragraph

text: Shaw was born into a family of considerable wealth and social prominence, and raised
label: Paragraph

text: in Chicago’s fashionable Prairie Avenue neighborhood. In 1890 he entered the
label: Paragraph

text: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the most distinguished school of architecture in
label: Paragraph

text: the country at the time. At MIT Shaw was exposed to a curriculum modeled on the Ecole
label: Paragraph

text: des Beaux Arts in Paris, which stressed the importance of adapting the rules and forms of
label: Paragraph

text: classical and
label: Title

text: 731 S.Plymouth Building (1897), Chicago, Illinois. Designed by Howard Van
label: Caption

text: Doren Shaw
label: Title

text: Photo © GreatBuildings.com
label: Caption

text: medieval architecture to modern structures. Shaw completed the demanding two-year
label: Paragraph

text: curriculum in only one year, returning to Chicago in 1891 to work in the office of Jenney
label: Paragraph

text: and Mundie. The firm’s principal partner, Major William Le Baron Jenney, best known
label: Paragraph

text: as the architect of the first skyscraper, the Home Insurance Building of 1884,
label: Paragraph

text: undoubtedly refined Shaw’s knowledge of engineering and the design of tall structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Shaw’s first major commission was for the Lakeside Press Building in Chicago (1897—
label: Paragraph

text: 99), the earliest of several structures Shaw would undertake for Chicago’s printing and
label: Paragraph

text: publishing industry. In most ways the seven-story building is a typical late 19th century
label: Paragraph

text: “Chicago Style” skyscraper, though it was adorned with medieval English details and
label: Paragraph

text: equipped with reinforced open-shell concrete floors and an innovative system of
label: Paragraph

text: delivering water throughout the building in case of fire. The building’s fire resistance and
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic success led to Shaw’s selection to design the Henneberry Press Building in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago (1902), remarkable for its vast glass fagade under a shallow pediment, and an
label: Paragraph

text: impressive Beaux Arts style structure for Ginn and Company Publishers (1907). The
label: Paragraph

text: culmination of Shaw works for Chicago’s printing establishment was a massive Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: style factory for R.R.Donnelley and Sons (1911-29).
label: Paragraph

text: While Shaw designed many other commercial structures, the bulk of his practice was
label: Paragraph

text: centered on the production of fine coun-try houses, especially for well-to-do clients in
label: Paragraph

text: fashionable Lake Forest. Shaw built an extraordinary house there for himself,
label: Paragraph

text: “Ragdale” (1898), a structure reflecting the architect’s keen interest in the British Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts work of C.F.A. Voysey. Passionate about details and quality construction,
label: Paragraph

text: Shaw built much of Ragdale himself, proving in the process to be a skillful carpenter,
label: Paragraph

text: mason, roofer, painter and landscape designer. Known for his insistence of high quality
label: Paragraph

text: workmanship, Shaw designed and carefully supervised the construction of over twenty
label: Paragraph

text: houses in Lake Forest alone by 1915. He employed mostly Tudor styles at first, as in the
label: Paragraph

text: house for John Bradley (1898), and then Georgian, as in the house for A.A.Sprague
label: Paragraph

text: (1907). But Shaw was also capable of building a Florentine palace, as he did for Edward
label: Paragraph

text: Ryerson (1906), and a Mediterranean villa, like the one built for Donald McLennan
label: Paragraph

text: (1912). Whatever the style, though, Shaw plans typically revealed his training in the
label: Paragraph

text: methods of the Ecole des Beaux Arts: generously proportioned rooms were aligned along
label: Paragraph

text: axes that extended to geometrically defined gardens and lawns.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1915 Shaw turned his attention to small-scale urban planning when he became part
label: Paragraph

text: owner and sole architect for Market Square in Lake Forest. The first planned shopping
label: Paragraph

text: center in the country, Market Square revitalized a dilapidated section of town by
label: Paragraph

text: integrating commercial and residential quarters, coordinating both pedestrian and
label: Paragraph

text: automotive traffic, and wedding various English, Dutch and German architectural motifs
label: Paragraph

text: to create a charming “old world” village square. The idea of combining small-scale
label: Paragraph

text: residential and commercial buildings around a common, landscaped square also served as
label: Paragraph

text: the focus for Shaw’s design of Marktown (1917), a residential development for the
label: Paragraph

text: workers of the Mark Corporation of East Chicago, Indiana. With its creative mix of forty
label: Paragraph

text: different English-style cottages, Marktown proved to be one of the most sophisticated
label: Paragraph

text: adaptations of British Garden City Movement planning in America.
label: Paragraph

text: Even at the height of his career Shaw maintained a fairly small office of apprentices
label: Paragraph

text: and draftsmen, most notably David Adler. Shaw was gracious in social situations, a
label: Paragraph

text: member of several civic organizations, and noted for his sense of humor. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: persistent ill health, he traveled frequently to Europe to collect ideas and artifacts for his
label: Paragraph

text: clients. His love for the arts was manifested by his considerable devotion to the Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: Art Institute, for which he served as a long-time trustee and part-time architect.
label: Paragraph

text: Appropriately, his own house, Ragdale, has served since 1976 as home to the famous
label: Paragraph

text: Ragdale Foundation of writers, artists, and composers.
label: Paragraph

text: Most of what remains of Shaw’s letters, manuscripts, and drawings can be found today
label: Paragraph

text: in the Chicago Art Institute’s Ryerson and Burnham Libraries, which were designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Shaw himself from 1919-22.
label: Paragraph

text: GAVIN EDWARD TOWNSEND

text: Biography
label: Title

text: Born in Chicago, Illinois, May 7, 1869. Son of Theodore Shaw, a successful dry goods
label: Paragraph

text: wholesaler whose connections with Chicago’s business community would lead to some
label: Paragraph

text: of his son’s later architectural commissions. Attended Harvard School for Boys in
label: Paragraph

text: Kenwood, Chicago; left Chicago during his junior year to attend Yale University,
label: Paragraph

text: received a Bachelor of Arts in 1890; studied architecture at the Massachusetts Institute of
label: Paragraph

text: Technology, 1890-91. Worked in the Chicago firm of Jenney & Mundie, Traveled
label: Paragraph

text: throughout Europe 1892-93. Left for Europe in 1892; spent a year sketching and
label: Paragraph

text: photographing buildings in Spain, France, Italy, Germany and especially England;
label: Paragraph

text: returned to United States in 1893; married Frances Wells, 20 April 1893 and established
label: Paragraph

text: his own practice later that year. Trustee of the Art Institute of Chicago 1904-26. Served
label: Paragraph

text: as second vice president of the Illinois chapter of the AIA in 1905 and was elected a
label: Paragraph

text: Fellow of the AIA in 1907. Received the ALA Gold Medal in 1926 and died of pernicious
label: Paragraph

text: anemia May 6, 1926.

text: SHEKHTEL, FEDOR 1859-1926
label: Title

text: Architect, Russia
label: Title

text: Among Russian architects at the turn of the 20th century, Fedor Shekhtel is unique not
label: Paragraph

text: only in the range of accomplishment over some three decades but also in the degree to
label: Paragraph

text: which his work embodied the cultural aspirations of his era. As no other architect,
label: Paragraph

text: Shekhtel enlarged and gave coherent expression to the creative possibilities of the
label: Paragraph

text: modern style, yet after 1908 he retreated from modernism to a reworking of traditional
label: Paragraph

text: forms in Russian architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Shekhtel was born and raised in a middle-class environment in the Volga town of
label: Paragraph

text: Saratov. His father was a civil engineer of
label: Paragraph

text: House for Stepan Riabushinskii (1902), designed by Fedor Shekhtel
label: Caption

text: © William C.Brumfield
label: Caption

text: German extraction, and his mother, Maria, came from a distinguished merchant family,
label: Paragraph

text: the Zhegins, whose connections extended into the merchant elite of Moscow. After the
label: Paragraph

text: death of his father, Shekhtel moved with his family to Moscow around 1875. Having
label: Paragraph

text: spent a year (1876-77) in the third class at Moscow’s School of Painting, Sculpture, and
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture, he began private work that combined his love for architecture and theater
label: Paragraph

text: with the design of sets for impresarios such as Mikhail Lentovskii.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1880s, Shekhtel served his apprenticeship in the offices of Alexander
label: Paragraph

text: Kaminskii and Konstantin Terskii, architects for Moscow’s merchant elite in the 1870s.
label: Paragraph

text: By the end of the 1880s, Shekhtel had designed and built his first independent projects,
label: Paragraph

text: including the exuberantly eclectic mansion for S.P. von Dervis (1889) at the estate of
label: Paragraph

text: Kiritsy near Riazan. In 1894, Shekhtel received certification as a “technician-builder” for
label: Paragraph

text: his design of a large neo-Gothic townhouse for Zinaida Morozova, wife of the
label: Paragraph

text: industrialist Savva Morozov. The design, which dates from 1893, was some three years in
label: Paragraph

text: construction; and although both the interior and the exterior display the ostentatious
label: Paragraph

text: striving for effect typical of that time, Shekhtel also used the style to explore the dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: relation between interior space and its projection in the design of the exterior.
label: Paragraph

text: From this use of Gothic stylization as a path to structural innovation, Shekhtel moved
label: Paragraph

text: to a radically modern idiom in his house for Stepan Riabushinskii (1902) near the Nikita
label: Paragraph

text: Gates in central Moscow. Begun in 1900, the Riabushinskii house displays a stylistic
label: Paragraph

text: affinity with houses designed by Olbrich at the MatildenhGhe community, yet it also
label: Paragraph

text: incorporates the emphasis on decorative arts pioneered at Abramtsevo, the Arts and
label: Paragraph

text: Crafts colony established in the 1870s on the country estate of railroad magnate Savva
label: Paragraph

text: Mamontov. Shekhtel defined the exterior as a play of contrasting elements, angular and
label: Paragraph

text: sinuous, precise in line and complex in decorative form. In designing the interior of the
label: Paragraph

text: house, Shekhtel approached the limits of the free-form possibilities of the modern style.
label: Paragraph

text: The central space, extending the entire height of the structure and containing the main
label: Paragraph

text: stairway, serves as a core around which most of the rooms are grouped. The stairway
label: Paragraph

text: itself is one of the most theatrical moments in Russian modernism, a frozen wave of
label: Paragraph

text: polished gray aggregate cascading from the upper story to the bottom landing. His other
label: Paragraph

text: major residence of the period, designed in 1901 for Alexandra Derozhinskaia, wife of a
label: Paragraph

text: wealthy Moscow industrialist, represents a rejection of elaborate decoration in favor of a
label: Paragraph

text: monumental definition of mass and space.
label: Paragraph

text: In public architecture, Shekhtel defined some of Moscow’s most important spaces with
label: Paragraph

text: buildings such as the Moscow Art Theater (1902), with its superb interior detailing, and
label: Paragraph

text: the rebuilding of the Yaroslavl Railway Station (1902), with traditional decorative
label: Paragraph

text: elements in a modernized interpretation known
label: Title

text: Detail of staircase, House for Stepan Riabushinskii
label: Caption

text: © William C.Brumfield
label: Caption

text: as the “neo-Russian” style. This style was prefigured by Shekhtel’s designs for large
label: Paragraph

text: wooden pavilions at the 1901 Glasgow Exposition.
label: Caption

text: In commercial architecture at the turn of the 20th century, Shekhtel developed the
label: Paragraph

text: multi-storied arch, with spandrel beams and plate glass, as a defining tectonic element in
label: Paragraph

text: two commercial structures: the headquarters for the Kuznetsov porcelain firm (1898-99)
label: Caption

text: and the Arshinov Store in Kitai-gorod (1899), with its facade of glazed green brick. A
label: Paragraph

text: more picturesque approach was adopted in his “chateau” style for the main office of the
label: Paragraph

text: A.A.Levenson Printing Works on Mamontov Lane (1900), behind which was a printing
label: Paragraph

text: plant in a modern, functional design.
label: Paragraph

text: On a much larger scale, Shekhtel’s building for the Moscow Insurance Society on Old
label: Paragraph

text: Square (1901) represents a shift from the Renaissance detail and arched facades of his
label: Paragraph

text: earlier commercial buildings to an orthogonal, grid framework of brick and reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete. Although the Insurance Society building—more commonly known as “Boiars’
label: Paragraph

text: Court,” named after the hotel situated in the building—retains a number of stucco
label: Paragraph

text: decorative devices, the rationalism of its design signaled the beginning of the modern era
label: Paragraph

text: in Moscow’s financial district.
label: Paragraph

text: The clearest expression of the new rationalist approach in Shekhtel’s work occurred in
label: Paragraph

text: commercial buildings such as the Riabushinskii Brothers Bank (1903) in the center of
label: Paragraph

text: Moscow’s financial district and the office and printing works (1907) of the Riabushinskii
label: Paragraph

text: newspaper Utro Rossii (Russia’s Morning). The main facades of both consisted of a
label: Paragraph

text: plate-glass grid with a surface of high-quality pressed brick and no ornament, although
label: Paragraph

text: the corners are rounded and articulated—a characteristic feature of Shekhtel’s large
label: Paragraph

text: commercial projects, such as the building for the Moscow Merchants’ Society (1909) and
label: Paragraph

text: the Shamshin apartment building (1909).
label: Paragraph

text: In the final phase of his career, Shekhtel turned to new interpretations of retrospective
label: Paragraph

text: styles, such as the neoclassical revival for his own house in Moscow (1909) and the
label: Paragraph

text: museum dedicated to his close friend Anton Chekhov in Taganrog (1910). His design for
label: Paragraph

text: the Old Believers Church (1910) in Balakovo (Samara province) is a sensitive fusion of
label: Paragraph

text: traditional motifs within a modern structure.
label: Paragraph

text: In the union of modern form and function that characterized the main body of this
label: Paragraph

text: work, Shekhtel suggested the spirit of a new economic order in Moscow. Although that
label: Paragraph

text: order, as well as his professional practice, collapsed in the aftermath of war and
label: Paragraph

text: revolution, Shekhtel remained in Moscow with his family and continued to teach until his
label: Paragraph

text: death in 1926. A cautious revival of his legacy began in the 1960s, and he is now
label: Paragraph

text: considered one of the leading cultural figures of Russia’s “Silver Age.”
label: Paragraph

text: SHINOHARA, KAZUO 1925
label: Title

text: Architect, Japan
label: Title

text: Regularly described as a “philosopher of architecture,” Kazuo Shinohara is as well
label: Paragraph

text: known for his writing as he is for his designs. Despite producing barely 50 buildings in
label: Paragraph

text: almost as many years, each of his works has been exquisitely crafted to express a
label: Paragraph

text: particular philosophical position. Rather than discussing these buildings in isolation,
label: Paragraph

text: Shinohara presents them as models of how he believes architecture should respond to the
label: Paragraph

text: modern world. Through his writing and teaching, Shinohara influenced an entire
label: Paragraph

text: generation of post-World War II Japanese architects, including Toyo Ito, Itsuko
label: Paragraph

text: Hasegawa, and Issei Sakamoto, who were known collectively in the 1970s as the
label: Paragraph

text: “Shinohara school.”
label: Paragraph

text: Kazuo Shinohara was born in Shizuoka prefecture in Japan in 1925 and entered the
label: Paragraph

text: Department of Architecture at the Tokyo Institute of Technology at the age of 22.
label: Paragraph

text: Following graduation in 1953, Shinohara became an associate of the same institution,
label: Paragraph

text: where he remained for the following 40 years, being appointed associate professor in
label: Paragraph

text: 1962, professor in 1970, and professor emeritus in 1986. Shinohara completed a
label: Paragraph

text: doctorate on spatial composition in traditional Japanese architecture in 1967. Lronically, it
label: Paragraph

text: was after the completion of this research that he began to reject the ordered spaces of the
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese vernacular that characterized so many of his early designs in favor of a more
label: Paragraph

text: complex and technological approach to design.
label: Paragraph

text: Two themes, order and chaos, distinguish Shinohara’s early architectural works and
label: Paragraph

text: writings from his later ones. The shift between these two extremes, from a preoccupation
label: Paragraph

text: with order toward a fascination with disorder, took place between 1967 and 1970,
label: Paragraph

text: although traces of Shinohara’s growing interest in chaos are apparent as early as 1964.
label: Paragraph

text: Prior to 1967, Shinohara describes his designs, including such projects as the House in
label: Paragraph

text: Kugayama (1954), the House in Chigasaki (1960), and the House in Komae (1960), as
label: Paragraph

text: distinctly ordered and traditional. These projects, which are named after the locations in
label: Paragraph

text: which they are sited, are characterized by largely symmetrical spatial compositions that
label: Paragraph

text: are variants of historic Japanese house types.
label: Paragraph

text: Following these works, Shinohara began to refine his approach to geometry and
label: Paragraph

text: structure to even greater levels of abstraction. This growth in design method is seen in the
label: Paragraph

text: Umbrella House (1961), the House in White (1966), and the Suzusho House (1968), all
label: Paragraph

text: of which feature simple geometric forms, white walls, and exposed-timber beams.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the success of these buildings, in the years that followed, Shinohara began to
label: Paragraph

text: question the role played by the house in the city and the importance of order and
label: Paragraph

text: symmetry. In the Incomplete House (1970) and the House in Itoshima (1976) on the
label: Paragraph

text: Genkainada Sea, symmetry still governs the exterior of the dwelling, but inside the pure,
label: Paragraph

text: hierarchical planning that distinguishes so many of his early works has been eroded. This
label: Paragraph

text: shift is even more apparent in Shinohara’s Uehara House (1976) in Tokyo, which features
label: Paragraph

text: a stark concrete exterior perforated with irregularly spaced geometric windows. This
label: Paragraph

text: house, which is supported on a system of Y-shaped concrete columns, is asymmetrical in
label: Paragraph

text: both plan and section and does not possess the same polished finish of many of his early
label: Paragraph

text: works. The Uehara House is one of Shinohara’s first designs that expresses the dual
label: Paragraph

text: desire to isolate the interior from the exterior and to recognize the complexity of modern
label: Paragraph

text: life in the arrangement of spaces and forms. Shinohara describes these intermediate
label: Paragraph

text: works as possessing a “savage” or “barbarous” quality that is a result not only of his use
label: Paragraph

text: of raw concrete but also of his newly developed interest in the irregular geometry o
label: Paragraph

text: nature.
label: Paragraph

text: For Shinohara, both the dream of utopia that preceded World War II and the influx o
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture in Japan that followed in its aftermath were doomed to failure
label: Paragraph

text: because they did not take account of the need for complexity in urban space. It was only
label: Paragraph

text: in modernism’s aftermath that people began to see that cities such as Tokyo possess a
label: Paragraph

text: natural complexity that is intrinsic to its vitality. Shinohara describes the urban chaos o
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo as being paradigmatic of “the beauty of progressive anarchy,” a concept that for
label: Paragraph

text: him relates to the sense of energy and disorder often encountered in urban spaces. The
label: Paragraph

text: Ukiyo-e Museum (1982), Shinohara’s first nonresidential building, attempts to capture
label: Paragraph

text: this chimerical urban beauty in its facades through an irregular composition of squares,
label: Paragraph

text: triangles, and arcs. Internally, the museum is a mixture of contrasts, smooth floors are
label: Paragraph

text: juxtaposed against rough concrete walls, and natural finishes compete with vibrant red
label: Paragraph

text: and green window frames.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1987, Shinohara had begun to openly argue that “chaos is a basic condition of the
label: Paragraph

text: city” and that if architecture is to respond to this chaos, it must adopt a new guise that is
label: Paragraph

text: informed by both technology and the sciences of complexity. He maintains that architects
label: Paragraph

text: must focus their attention on machines (particularly computers, the F-14 fighter plane,
label: Paragraph

text: and the Apollo 71 lunar landing craft). Because modern machines are highly adaptable to
label: Paragraph

text: complex environments, Shinohara proposes that they are suitable metaphors for design in
label: Paragraph

text: an increasingly unpredictable world. Shinohara calls this approach to architecture, which
label: Paragraph

text: he documented in his 1988 article “Chaos and Machine,” Modern-next. Although
label: Paragraph

text: Shinohara has developed this philosophy of design in a number of projects, including the
label: Paragraph

text: Hanegi Complex (1988) in Tokyo and the inverted triangle of the Police Station (1990) in
label: Paragraph

text: Kumamoto, it is his Centennial Hall (1987) in Tokyo that has become iconic for the way
label: Paragraph

text: in which it expresses his philosophy of design. Externally, the Centennial Hall is visually
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of sections of an aircraft. The building is formed about a horizontal, metal-
label: Paragraph

text: clad, half cylinder that intersects two rectangular blocks at a point high above the street
label: Paragraph

text: level. The half cylinder is the literal evocation of the machine of Modern-next. The static
label: Paragraph

text: silver, gray, and white rectangular prisms provide connection between the ground and the
label: Paragraph

text: sky. The elaborate interlocking of these forms renders the overall building volume
label: Paragraph

text: difficult to read against the chaos of the surrounding city. For Shinohara, this is the only
label: Paragraph

text: way that architecture can capture the essential vitality of the modern world.
label: Paragraph

text: SHOPPING CENTER
label: Title

text: Two trends were crucial for the development and success of the shopping center:
label: Paragraph

text: decentralization at the urban scale and increasingly sophisticated techniques of
label: Paragraph

text: advertising and display that encouraged the purchase of goods. In this sense the
label: Paragraph

text: department stores, such as the famous Bon Marché of Paris (ca. 1862) and the much
label: Paragraph

text: larger Marshall Field’s store of Chicago (ca. 1880) prefigured the 20th-century shopping
label: Paragraph

text: center and its later manifestation, the shopping mall. The French example was
label: Paragraph

text: particularly important because it was fashioned as a place of “democratic luxury,” where
label: Paragraph

text: goods were presented to the clientele in the exciting manner of world’s fair displays. The
label: Paragraph

text: shopping center did not become identifiable as a distinct building type, however, until the
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s. The 18th- and 19th-century arcades, and the late 19th-century department stores
label: Paragraph

text: were not the precedents of this building type, per se, although they certainly influenced
label: Paragraph

text: retail architecture and the culture of consumption. Until the 1930s in the United States,
label: Paragraph

text: where it first materialized, a shopping center was nothing more than a term denoting an
label: Paragraph

text: assemblage of businesses, usually situated “downtown.” In fact, downtown centers that
label: Paragraph

text: sported a cluster of businesses, stores, and a department store were considered the
label: Paragraph

text: definition of a shopping core. Outlying districts that offered shops and businesses might
label: Paragraph

text: also have been considered a shopping center, but these types of gathered buildings and
label: Paragraph

text: spaces were not coordinated or planned as one. By 1930, however, developers and
label: Paragraph

text: architects created identifiable centers incorporating business factors as well as
label: Paragraph

text: architectural issues. The premeditated nature of this new landscape intervention marks
label: Paragraph

text: the shopping center’s most salient characteristic as a distinct building type.
label: Paragraph

text: The typology developed out of a larger effort to decentralize the urban nucleus, a trend
label: Paragraph

text: that originated in the previous century. The five-unit block built as an integral component
label: Paragraph

text: of the residential community at Riverside, Illinois, in 1870 is perhaps a more useful
label: Paragraph

text: precedent than, say, the Marshall Field’s store. Just as Riverside was an early prototype
label: Paragraph

text: of what would become a more powerful 20th-century movement to the suburb, so too
label: Paragraph

text: was its store building. As cities in the second half of the 19th century grew in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: density, land area, and pollution, the demand for neighborhoods in pseudopastoral
label: Paragraph

text: settings increased. Streetcar lines made such suburban communities viable, as resi-dents
label: Paragraph

text: could maintain ties to the city while remaining in what they considered to be a healthy
label: Paragraph

text: environment. As a method of enticing homebuyers, American developers found it
label: Paragraph

text: necessary to build a retail facility as part of these new communities. For such early
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods to be viable, residents had to feel many of their shopping necessities could
label: Paragraph

text: be met without trekking downtown.
label: Paragraph

text: Market Square in Lake Forest, Illinois, was an important and early example, built in
label: Paragraph

text: 1916 to cater to some of Chicago’s wealthiest families. Designed by Howard Van Doren
label: Caption

text: Shaw with the collaboration of real estate magnate Arthur Aldis, this was far more than a
label: Paragraph

text: mere retail building. It was part of a larger commercial project that cost more than half a
label: Paragraph

text: million dollars and was raised by investors as well as by bonds, resulting in twenty-eight
label: Paragraph

text: stores, twelve office suites, thirty apartments, and sundry other community facilities.
label: Paragraph

text: Built adjacent to existing merchants, the project was intended to offer a true center for
label: Paragraph

text: shopping, one that proved financially profitable as well as aesthetically unobjectionable.
label: Paragraph

text: The design team that matched a business mind with an architect went a long way to
label: Paragraph

text: assuring the project’s success and was largely responsible for the way the plan provided
label: Paragraph

text: for automobile access and parking. The main street was widened to facilitate parking for
label: Paragraph

text: the growing number of Lake Forest residents with automobiles. The collection of shops
label: Paragraph

text: was U-shaped, and patrons could park their cars in the tree-lined open space of the U. No
label: Paragraph

text: distinction was made between cars in motion and parked autos in this lot ornamented by a
label: Paragraph

text: fountain, but delivery vehicles used separate rear-side courts for service. Lauded as an
label: Paragraph

text: application of the City Beautiful movement to commercial architecture, Market Square
label: Caption

text: proved influential.
label: Paragraph

text: Consumer culture and the display of goods were revolutionized during this same
label: Paragraph

text: period, as architects like Morris Lapidus devised increasingly seductive techniques for
label: Paragraph

text: displaying goods for sale. Storefront windows grew until the facade became one large
label: Paragraph

text: display, signs were built overhead the size of entire buildings, and the scale of the
label: Paragraph

text: storefront was increased to catch the eye of the motorist at a distance. Meanwhile,
label: Paragraph

text: shopping had been a point of application for developments in psychoanalysis, as the task
label: Paragraph

text: of the psychologist in the first half of the century resembled that of the advertising firm’s
label: Paragraph

text: attempts to divine the buying impulse. Eventually, these shopping complexes grew so
label: Paragraph

text: large, and attendant parking lots were in turn so vast, developers and architects were
label: Paragraph

text: forced to experiment with organizational plans. The scheme that proved most successful
label: Paragraph

text: was a plan arranged around a pedestrian path often lined with grass and shaded by trees,
label: Paragraph

text: so that consumers would leave their cars behind as they strolled along on a new interior
label: Paragraph

text: shopping experience. Other schemes included the cruciform plan, a clustered or doughnut
label: Paragraph

text: shaped plan, and circular plans where shops all faced a common green space. The
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrian path was often punctuated with fountains or sculpture, whereas these shopping
label: Paragraph

text: centers were surrounded by massive parking lots that wrapped around the backs of the
label: Paragraph

text: stores in such a way that a customer could park near any given store. Perceptually
label: Paragraph

text: disconnected from the street, this “mall was an environment unto itself. As historian
label: Paragraph

text: Richard Longstreth noted, “Once divorced from their cars and walking amid what seems
label: Paragraph

text: like an entirely different world, customers tended to spend greater blocks of time
label: Paragraph

text: meandering, meeting friends, having meals, and buying goods.”
label: Paragraph

text: Northgate, built just outside Seattle in 1950, was one of the first malls to open in the
label: Paragraph

text: United States. Its 800,000 square feet of shops, anchored by a large department store,
label: Paragraph

text: were designed along a two-story, 1500-foot-long pedestrian path dubbed the “Miracle
label: Paragraph

text: Mall.” In 1956, a fully enclosed mall in Minnesota called Southdale opened. Designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Victor Gruen, who believed that malls held the potential for restoring social space to a
label: Paragraph

text: socially bankrupt society, the enclosure allowed for climate control so that shoppers
label: Paragraph

text: would not be deterred by heat, cold, or snow. The success of these malls was profound, as
label: Paragraph

text: by 1960 department store owners no longer had faith in the stand-alone branch store as a
label: Paragraph

text: viable business proposition. The dominance of the mall also had an ironic effect on the
label: Paragraph

text: role of the architect in the retail market, because such large-scale projects, financed and
label: Paragraph

text: built in one swoop as one integrated building and under single ownership, handed the
label: Paragraph

text: architect greater influence in the design process. After the 1970s, when the completely
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed pedestrian path became standard, architects were allowed even greater design
label: Paragraph

text: control over such projects.
label: Paragraph

text: The influence of American practices was also felt abroad. The first mall in Great
label: Paragraph

text: Britain, for example, opened at Brent Cross in 1976. It was an 800,000-square-foot
label: Paragraph

text: complex boasting 82 tenants, 4000 employees, and 3500 parking spaces. Site selection
label: Paragraph

text: and planning began in 1959, and before its opening, the investment company negotiated a
label: Paragraph

text: 125-year lease. For much of the century, the department store in Great Britain, once a
label: Paragraph

text: native product in the early 19th century, had been influenced by American display
label: Paragraph

text: techniques. These methods, coupled with the power of advertising, customer surveillance,
label: Paragraph

text: and changes in departmental organization, proved to have an effect beyond the shopping
label: Paragraph

text: center’s precincts. The new space of consumption ascribed explicit cultural meaning to
label: Paragraph

text: gender roles and greatly influenced the appropriate modes of heterosocial conduct.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the gender of shopping changed in the last quarter of the century, as men
label: Paragraph

text: proved as vulnerable as women to mass marketing and seductive advertising strategies,
label: Paragraph

text: the truly remarkable aspect of the shopping center was the way social space was
label: Paragraph

text: transformed into a consumer experience. By the end of the century, it was common for
label: Paragraph

text: sites intended for other purposes to be reconfigured as consumer opportunities, such as
label: Paragraph

text: railway stations, hotel lobbies, airports, and even museums that entice patrons to shop.
label: Paragraph

text: SHRINE OF THE BOOK
label: Title

text: Designed by Frederick Kiesler and Armand Bartos; completed 1965
label: Caption

text: Jerusalem, Israel
label: Title

text: The Shrine of the Book is a small, domed pavilion on the grounds of the Israeli
label: Paragraph

text: Museum complex in Jerusalem. It was built by two architects living in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States—Frederick Kiesler and his former student Armand Bartos—to house the Dead Sea
label: Paragraph

text: Scrolls, seven ancient manuscripts dating from the era of the Jewish revolts against the
label: Caption

text: Romans nearly 2,000 years ago. For Kiesler, who had achieved great prominence in New
label: Paragraph

text: York as an artist and architectural theorist but who had completed only a handful of built
label: Paragraph

text: commissions, the shrine provided an opportunity to construct his masterpiece.
label: Paragraph

text: The story of the discovery of the Dead Sea Scrolls is intimately tied up with the history
label: Paragraph

text: of the establishment of the state of Israel. In the summer of 1947, a Bedouin shepherd
label: Paragraph

text: boy stumbled into a cave near the town of Qumran and inside discovered clay jars
label: Paragraph

text: containing parchments sewn together into long scrolls wrapped in linen. In November of
label: Paragraph

text: that year, Dr. Elazar Sukenik, the head of Hebrew University’s Department of
label: Paragraph

text: Archaeology, was approached by an antiquities dealer eager to sell the newly discovered
label: Paragraph

text: documents. Although the next day the United Nations was scheduled to vote on the
label: Paragraph

text: partition of Palestine, Dr. Sukenik, realizing that the fragment he viewed through a
label: Paragraph

text: barbed-wire fence was almost 1,000 years older than the oldest known, disregarded the
label: Paragraph

text: violence around him and traveled to Bethlehem to make the purchase. As he studied the
label: Paragraph

text: scrolls that night in his living room, the radio brought the news that the UN motion had
label: Paragraph

text: carried and that the state of Israel was to be reborn.
label: Paragraph

text: All told, the Bedouin shepherd had discovered seven scrolls, of which Dr. Sukenik had
label: Paragraph

text: purchased three. The remaining four scrolls were acquired by the metropolitan of the
label: Paragraph

text: Syrian Orthodox Monastery of Saint Mark in the Old City of Jerusalem, who had shipped
label: Paragraph

text: them to New York in search of a better price. Although Dr. Sukenik died believing them
label: Paragraph

text: lost, his son, General Yigael Yadin, also an archaeologist, was on a 1954 speaking tour in
label: Paragraph

text: the United States when a journalist called his attention to an obscure, seven-line classified
label: Paragraph

text: advertisement in the Wall Street Journal offering “Four Dead Sea Scrolls for Sale.”
label: Paragraph

text: Yadin moved quickly to secure the scrolls from the vault of the Waldorf Astoria,
label: Paragraph

text: purchasing them with the financial backing of New York industrialist Samuel Gottesman,
label: Paragraph

text: Armand Bartos’s father-in-law. Following Gottesman’s death in 1956, the D.S. and R.H.
label: Paragraph

text: Gottesman Foundation agreed to provide the funds for the construction of the Shrine of
label: Paragraph

text: the Book in Jerusalem.
label: Paragraph

text: From its inception, the architectural program for the Shrine of the Book was
label: Paragraph

text: symbolically overdetermined. First were the scrolls themselves, breathtaking in historical,
label: Paragraph

text: archaeological, and religious significance. For Jews, often called “the people of the
label: Paragraph

text: book,” the discovery of a manuscript written so near to biblical times was theologically
label: Paragraph

text: earthshaking. Second was the coincidence between the discovery of the scrolls and the
label: Paragraph

text: founding of the state of Israel. Both the parchments and the nation had lain dormant from
label: Paragraph

text: the fall of the second Jewish state until the resurrection of the third. The scrolls provided
label: Paragraph

text: a link between those Jews whose revolt had been crushed by the Romans and those who
label: Paragraph

text: founded a new nation, bathing legitimacy on their territorial claims. Third was Kiesler’s
label: Paragraph

text: own struggle to practice architecture in a manner consistent with his critiques of the then-
label: Paragraph

text: dominant International Style. Against its ethos of rationalism and transparency, Kiesler
label: Paragraph

text: unleashed his surrealist passions for the mythological, the sexualized, the poetical, and
label: Paragraph

text: the primal. What better commission for Kiesler than a sacred shrine to ancient scrolls,
label: Paragraph

text: scratched from the prehistoric earth, that awed “the somnolent religious world of
label: Paragraph

text: cathedrals” and recounted a “war between the sons of light and the sons of darkness”?
label: Paragraph

text: Kiesler and Bartos flew to Jerusalem in October 1957 and met with Mazar Ben Zvi, the
label: Paragraph

text: president of Hebrew University. As Kiesler recounts the events that followed in his
label: Paragraph

text: journal fnside the Endless House, he persuaded the university to enlarge its ambitions and
label: Paragraph

text: construct a monumental sanctuary for the shrine on the new Givat Ram Campus (then
label: Paragraph

text: under construction). On the flight back to New York, using a pencil nub on the back of an
label: Paragraph

text: envelope from his jacket pocket, Kiesler scratched a double-parabolic dome, “a plastic
label: Paragraph

text: representation of ‘rebirth.’”
label: Paragraph

text: By late December 1957, preliminary drawings of the dome were complete. The scheme
label: Paragraph

text: called for a unified centralized chamber, partially buried in the ground, in which the
label: Paragraph

text: manuscripts and related artifacts would be displayed. The dome would fill the lobby of
label: Paragraph

text: the planned cubic library building, and its throat and tip would peek out of the roof.
label: Paragraph

text: Predictably, the campus architects objected, and the Shrine of the Book was removed to a
label: Paragraph

text: second site outside the library, to be entered via a subterranean corridor. By 1959,
label: Paragraph

text: detailed drawings were completed for this scheme, but in the fall of that year, the site was
label: Paragraph

text: moved again, this time to the new campus of the Israel Museum. Kiesler and Bartos’s
label: Paragraph

text: design process seems to have been essentially additive, and the dome and corridor were
label: Paragraph

text: transferred to the new location. Because they no longer had the strong mass of the library
label: Paragraph

text: to play against, the architects added a freestanding basalt wall to balance the composition.
label: Paragraph

text: Some ancillary office and library space was also added. Although Kiesler is credited with
label: Paragraph

text: the design sketches and poetic ideas, Bartos remained in Israel during most of the
label: Paragraph

text: construction and provided the essential on-site refinements and supervision.
label: Paragraph

text: The Shrine of the Book is composed of five primary pieces arranged in a linear
label: Paragraph

text: sequence. A visit to the shrine begins with a transverse walk across a stone entry plaza.
label: Paragraph

text: To the right, the massive white-tiled dome hovers in a rectilinear pool of water,
label: Paragraph

text: Shrine of the Book, Jerusalem, designed by Armand Bartos and Frederick
label: Caption

text: Kiesler (1965)
label: Title

text: Ezra Stoller © Esto
label: Title

text: and to left, the black wall looms overhead. Walking between these dueling giants, the
label: Paragraph

text: visitor turns and descends an open staircase to a sunken court. On one side of the court
label: Paragraph

text: are supporting offices, and to the other is the entrance to the shrine. Once inside the
label: Paragraph

text: lobby, the black wall reappears, but this time punctured with an opening at its base. As
label: Paragraph

text: one passes through that opening and its tubular gates, a dark passage descends slowly
label: Paragraph

text: through a sequence of asymmetrical arches. Display cases on the side walls provide the
label: Paragraph

text: primary illumination. At the end of this hall, another staircase climbs upward into the
label: Paragraph

text: ribbed open dome, which swings its concentrically corrugated surface from almost 80
label: Paragraph

text: feet at its base to just 6 at its throat. Desert sunlight pours down from a transparent
label: Paragraph

text: monocular void at the apex. Surrounding the periphery are more display cases, and atop a
label: Paragraph

text: central platform is a vertical shaft ringed with the unfurled “Book of Isaiah.” Below is a
label: Caption

text: subterranean corridor lined with rough-hewn stones, claustrophobic and cavelike, in
label: Paragraph

text: which nontextual artifacts are entombed. A single passage leads out from the dome and
label: Paragraph

text: back to the surface.
label: Paragraph

text: Not surprisingly, the double-parabolic dome proved difficult to build. Kiesler was
label: Paragraph

text: adamant that the dome be both monolithic and homogeneous—one vessel
label: Paragraph

text: programmatically, structurally, and aesthetically—and he vetoed all designs that had it
label: Paragraph

text: resting atop some form of cylindrical base or that used a system of structural ribs.
label: Paragraph

text: Although a difficult challenge for the shrine’s builder, Hillel Fefferman, Kiesler
label: Paragraph

text: prevailed, and the dome was built as a cast-in-place single concrete shell. The ribbing on
label: Paragraph

text: the interior prevented acoustical problems, and exterior tiles afforded its elegant white
label: Paragraph

text: finish. A small exterior lip protrudes from the side of the dome just atop the reflecting
label: Caption

text: pool, providing an illusion of buoyancy.
label: Paragraph

text: In accordance with Kiesler’s invocations of the primal, the Shrine of the Book
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to choreograph the four elements of the ancients. A literal penetration into the
label: Paragraph

text: earth is expressed materially through strata of progressively roughening and darkening
label: Paragraph

text: masonry. At the deepest point in the complex, an axis is opened through the eye of the
label: Paragraph

text: dome, linking the depths of the archaeological past with the bright skies of the heavens.
label: Paragraph

text: On the surface, a pool of water surrounds the dome, small jets sprinkle its exterior, and a
label: Paragraph

text: trough of water encircles the base of the black wall. Plans for an even more dramatic jet
label: Paragraph

text: of water that would have shot up from the central shaft and out of the dome’s eye were
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned when unexpected backsplash could not be solved. Similarly, Kiesler’s plans
label: Paragraph

text: for a flaming trough of fuel to cap the massive black wall were also abandoned, although
label: Paragraph

text: torches were installed for the opening ceremonies in 1965.
label: Paragraph

text: The importance of the shrine was recognized even before its completion, and it was
label: Paragraph

text: immediately seen to be Kiesler’s long-delayed masterpiece, a triumphant success
label: Paragraph

text: crowning a lifetime of deferred hopes and unrealized visions. It was awarded the Gold
label: Paragraph

text: Medal by the Architectural League of New York and is now considered by the Israeli
label: Paragraph

text: government to be one of its national treasures. Still, perhaps the greatest testimony to
label: Paragraph

text: Kiesler and to his lifelong struggle for poetic expression in architecture is the fact that the
label: Paragraph

text: Shrine of the Book continues to demand to be interpreted symbolically. Some are
label: Paragraph

text: compelled by the relationship to the scrolls themselves, reading the white dome as the lid
label: Paragraph

text: of a pottery jar and the shrine as a great cave, engaged together in a battle of light against
label: Paragraph

text: the darkness of the basalt wall. Others see the shrine as a symbol of rebirth; just as the
label: Paragraph

text: Hebrew nation was reborn after 2,000 years of exile, bringing an ancient language and
label: Paragraph

text: people back to Jerusalem, so, too, does the shrine emerge from the ground like a great
label: Paragraph

text: dormant seed. Others are drawn to shrine’s mysterious sexuality—seeing in the dome a
label: Paragraph

text: female breast and traveling a dark passage into a great protective womb, violated only by
label: Paragraph

text: the episodic sprays from the tall central shaft. Others draw parallels with the dream of
label: Paragraph

text: Jacob’s ladder, the staffs of the Jewish Torah, or the Roman Pantheon. Ultimately, the
label: Paragraph

text: significance of the Shrine of the Book does not lie in the selection of one of these
label: Paragraph

text: readings over another. Rather, by speaking mythologically, by simply opening up a field
label: Paragraph

text: of symbolic interpretation, Kiesler’s shrine sidestepped modern architecture’s dilemma of
label: Paragraph

text: the monument and created a sacred building as rewarding to, the heart, and the spirit as it
label: Paragraph

text: is to the mind.
label: Paragraph
