text: SIREN, HEIKKI (1918-) AND KAIJA SIREN
label: Title

text: Architects, Finland
label: Title

text: The husband-and-wife partnership Arkkitehtitoimisto Katja ja Heikki Sirén was
label: Paragraph

text: established in Helsinki in 1949. In 1985, they retired, and their son Jukka Sirén took
label: Paragraph

text: charge and continued the work of the firm. Heikki Sirén’s father, Johann Sigfrid Sirén,
label: Paragraph

text: designed the Parliament (1924-30) in Helsinki, which marked the climax of late Finnish
label: Paragraph

text: classicism. Both Heikki (1918—) and Kaija (1920—) studied under Professor Sirén at
label: Paragraph

text: Technical University in Helsinki. Born 20 years after Alvar Aalto, Heikki Sirén belonged
label: Paragraph

text: to the next generation, which was equally inspired and, at the same time, overshadowed
label: Paragraph

text: by Aalto.
label: Caption

text: The elder J.S.Sirén’s disciplined academic classicism emphasized the importance of a
label: Paragraph

text: clear plan as demonstrating the synthesis of the problem. The pair gained world
label: Paragraph

text: recognition with the Chapel of the Technical University at Otaniemi, west of Helsinki, in
label: Caption

text: 1957. No other single work ever matched the recognition that it achieved worldwide for
label: Paragraph

text: its brilliant classical simplicity allied to a uniquely Finnish identification with trees and
label: Paragraph

text: the forest. This concept echoed the primitive values of a forest people by its daring
label: Paragraph

text: selection of a forest clearing outside the chapel as the core site of spirituality and
label: Paragraph

text: redemption.
label: Paragraph

text: Its classicism was so well disguised beneath the chapel’s vernacular references that it is
label: Paragraph

text: easily missed. However, on closer analysis the clarity of plan is the secret foundation of
label: Paragraph

text: the chapel’s underlying simplicity and experiential impact. The modest mode of building
label: Paragraph

text: in brick and timber exploited the Finnish tradition of wooden houses with their spacious
label: Paragraph

text: yards. In one respect, the chapel’s simplicity is confusing. The building derives its power
label: Paragraph

text: from the synthesis of several sources, including the Finnish identification and rootedness
label: Paragraph

text: in nature found in the medieval Finnish national epic the Ka/evala, the Siréns’ obvious
label: Paragraph

text: admiration of anonymous indigenous architecture, and the notion that architecture creates
label: Paragraph

text: the “stage” for human life.
label: Paragraph

text: The arrangement of an entry courtyard preceding the chapel separated the sacred from
label: Paragraph

text: the profane. The chapel had its cross outside, a feature that is reminiscent of a
label: Paragraph

text: proscenium theater with the glass wall replacing the proscenium arch and the forest
label: Caption

text: clearing now reconstituted as a sacred stage. The cross set in the landscape was not
label: Paragraph

text: new—Gunnar Asplund used it for his 1940 Forest Crematorium at Sockenvagen—but
label: Paragraph

text: what is different in the Sirén version is the visual coupling of the cross with the chapel.
label: Paragraph

text: Subsequently, Tadao Ando repeated the outside cross formula in his Church on the Water
label: Paragraph

text: (1988) at Tomamu on Hokkaido.
label: Caption

text: Many people are attracted by the ultimate simplicity of the Siréns’ architectural
label: Paragraph

text: features. At the chapel, for example, the entry screen of horizontal timber poles in the
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard permits the outside to be visible and thus transmits metaphysical ideas of
label: Paragraph

text: considerable weight that mirror a Finnish identity linked at many levels to nature. Nature
label: Paragraph

text: belongs to a pantheistic religious experience imbued by a kind of rich poverty.
label: Paragraph

text: Prior to the chapel, the small stage of the Finnish National Theatre (1954) in Helsinki
label: Paragraph

text: had been the Siréns’ first and most noteworthy work. It was completed as an annex to the
label: Paragraph

text: theater building and the new auditorium and had a lobby and restaurant on the ground
label: Paragraph

text: floor. The interior spaces were reflected on the outside in the openings formed in the dark
label: Paragraph

text: clinker elevation, which provides a suitable backdrop to adjacent Kaisaniemi Park. The
label: Paragraph

text: Kontiontie terrace houses (1954) at Tapiola were built with black-stained prefabricated
label: Paragraph

text: wooden elevation units inserted between white blades of masonry to produce a starkly
label: Paragraph

text: striking effect in the winter landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: From this time, the work of the pair includes the Students’ Restaurant (1952) at
label: Paragraph

text: Otaniemi, the Concert Hall (1954) at Lahti, and a multistory apartment house, Otaniemi
label: Paragraph

text: (1956). Both the Aamivalkea School (1957) at Tapiola and the school (1958) at Espoo
label: Paragraph

text: employed a simple steel-frame and in-fill aesthetic in-spired by Mies van der Rohe, but
label: Paragraph

text: these were carried out with a flare for mating the cubic masses to their sites. The Town
label: Paragraph

text: Hall (1967) at Kankaanpaa and the Villa Punjo (1967) at Espoo testify to the Siréns’
label: Paragraph

text: capacity to unite their buildings with forest settings by a simple juxtaposition of a finely
label: Paragraph

text: tuned classical simplicity and rhythmic succession of masses.
label: Paragraph

text: The Siréns were unsuccessful when they entered architectural competitions. In 1974,
label: Paragraph

text: they won the Linz Brucknerhaus Concert Hall competition and the 1978 competition for
label: Paragraph

text: a Conference Palace (1984) for Baghdad, Iraq. The elegant radial arrangement of the
label: Paragraph

text: Linz auditorium, with the foyer running around the circumference and overlooking the
label: Paragraph

text: river, was reinforced by a warm timber interior of considerable elegance.
label: Paragraph

text: The Baghdad Conference Palace was faced in a bluish-glazed tile outside, selected out
label: Paragraph

text: of respect for Babylonian tradition, with the parapet of the concrete-unit external wall
label: Caption

text: curved inward so as to direct the hot outside air up between the glass-and-aluminium
label: Paragraph

text: fenestration and behind the screening concrete blades. The planning of the three-story
label: Caption

text: Conference Palace concentrated the auditoriums and foyers within a single compact
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular volume that was plainly expressed outside. As a consequence, the focus is
label: Paragraph

text: directed inside on the lobbies and foyers, all grouped around the large multiuse
label: Paragraph

text: auditorium. One of the aims was to remove any suggestion of superficial regional
label: Paragraph

text: ormamentation and, thus, to focus on such fundamental ideas as a disciplined floor plan
label: Paragraph

text: and a monumentality for the overall massing.
label: Paragraph

text: The Siréns’ holiday retreat (1966) on the island of Lingonsé exemplifies their respect
label: Paragraph

text: for tradition. The cottage, sauna, and annex house are linked by raised walkways. These
label: Paragraph

text: were built using an experimental prototype of prefabricated timber that was borrowed
label: Paragraph

text: from a traditional solid-log sauna system. Wood was selected for its weathering
label: Paragraph

text: properties to ensure that the buildings settled into the landscape gradually. In 1967, a sea
label: Paragraph

text: chapel was added to the group for meditating, relaxing, and sunbathing. Mounted on an
label: Caption

text: elementary horizontal timber platform on the bare shore rock, with round logs at the
label: Caption

text: corners and overhanging beams to support the flat roof, the sea chapel at Lingons6 is an
label: Paragraph

text: instance of a deliberately primitive yet highly refined temple beside the sea.
label: Paragraph

text: By remaining rooted in their Finnish heritage, the Siréns gained the confidence to
label: Paragraph

text: explore other entirely different traditions without running into accusations of cliché or
label: Paragraph

text: pastiche. This proves, as if any proof is required, the maturity and depth of their
label: Paragraph

text: commitment to respecting and creatively drawing on the resources of their Finnish
label: Paragraph

text: heritage.
label: Paragraph

text: SIZA, ALVARO 1933
label: Title

text: Architect, Portugal
label: Title

text: Portuguese architect Alvaro Siza (Alvaro Joaquim Melo Siza Viera), is one of the best-
label: Paragraph

text: known Portuguese architects of the 20th century. Although Siza produced numerous
label: Paragraph

text: projects for clients in Portugal (houses, schools, and other institutions), it was not until
label: Paragraph

text: the 1980s that he began to receive recognition through exhibitions and commissions in
label: Paragraph

text: other European countries.
label: Paragraph

text: Siza’s architecture is strongly rooted in the Modern movement, but incorporates a
label: Paragraph

text: subjective approach to concept and design, secking alternative interpretations of
label: Paragraph

text: modernism. Siza has stated, “Architecture is increasingly a problem of use and reference
label: Paragraph

text: to models.... My architecture does not have a preestablished language and does not
label: Paragraph

text: establish a language. It is a response to a concrete problem, a situation in transformation
label: Paragraph

text: in which | participate.”
label: Paragraph

text: The geographic and climatic conditions of the place of Siza’s architecture are of
label: Paragraph

text: profound importance to this thinking in addition to cultural and social concerns. In Siza’s
label: Paragraph

text: oeuvre sensitivity to context does not result in nostalgic historicism or critical
label: Paragraph

text: regionalism. It is rather a unique approach to a universal language transformed to respond
label: Paragraph

text: to a local situation. His built works strive to integrate conflicting demands and affinities,
label: Paragraph

text: often embodying points of tension that exist in a delicate balance.
label: Paragraph

text: For Siza, a building is at the same time autonomous and responsive, unified and
label: Paragraph

text: diversified. He eschews using technology for technology’s sake and employs local
label: Paragraph

text: materials such as stucco, brick, and stone—all traditional building materials that he uses
label: Paragraph

text: to create abstract compositions.
label: Paragraph

text: His swimming pools (1966) located in Lega de Palmeira, a small town near Porto, were
label: Paragraph

text: his first projects to receive acclaim outside Portugal. These seaside pools easily make the
label: Paragraph

text: transition from man-made concrete to the natural rock formations, creating sublime
label: Paragraph

text: bathing pools. The changing rooms are in an unobtrusive pavilion of concrete with wood
label: Paragraph

text: roofs that guide the visitor through a corridor-like space before opening on to the
label: Paragraph

text: expansive sea.
label: Paragraph

text: The Pinto e Sotto Maior Bank (1974) in Oliveira de Azmeis, a small town in northern
label: Paragraph

text: Portugal, is very representative of his early work. This small building does not adopt the
label: Paragraph

text: formal architectural vocabulary of the place but rather creates a dialogue with its
label: Paragraph

text: surroundings. The curved, glass facade looks out on to the square, however, creating a
label: Paragraph

text: formal juxtaposition with the traditional forms of the square. Another bank building, the
label: Paragraph

text: Borges and Irmao Bank (1986) in Vila do Conde, Portugal, takes a similar approach. It is
label: Paragraph

text: both a separate entity and a participant in the townscape, respecting the scale of its
label: Paragraph

text: surroundings. From the outside, little is revealed of the character of the interior.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the space flows because of the visual connection between floors.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1977, following the revolution in Portugal, the local government of Evora
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned Siza to plan a housing project in the rural outskirts of the town. It was to
label: Paragraph

text: be one of several that he would do for the national housing association, consisting of
label: Paragraph

text: 1,200 low-cost row houses, some one-story and some two-story units, all with courtyards.
label: Caption

text: The layout of the new section gave order to an area at the periphery of the town while
label: Paragraph

text: connecting it with existing housing areas.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1980s, Siza was asked to undertake increasingly larger institutional
label: Paragraph

text: projects, such as the School of Architecture (1992) at Porto University in Porto, the
label: Paragraph

text: Teachers Training College (1991) at Setubal, and the Centro Galiziano (Museum of
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Art, 1994) in Santiago de Compostela, Spain, located within the historical city.
label: Paragraph

text: This Centro Galiziano building fits into a complicated and historic site employing
label: Paragraph

text: concepts of integration and contrast. The reductive, elongated form of the museum—
label: Paragraph

text: produced by two adjacent wings—seeks to create classical order in an area that had
label: Paragraph

text: suffered decline. The granite exterior contrasts with the stark white interior. Once again,
label: Paragraph

text: Siza has approached the work with sensitivity to context without relinquishing the
label: Paragraph

text: autonomy and strength of the new construction. Other notable museum projects include
label: Paragraph

text: the addition to the Serralves Foundation and Museum in Porto (1999), the renovation and
label: Paragraph

text: extension to the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam (1997), and the Manzana del Revellin
label: Paragraph

text: Cultural Centre in Ceuta, Portugal (1997).
label: Caption

text: Other outstanding, widely published projects of Siza’s include the Aveiro University
label: Paragraph

text: Library at Aveiro, Portugal (1994); the Vitra Factory at Weil-am-Rein, Germany (1994);
label: Paragraph

text: Schlesisches Tor Apartments at Kreuzberg, Germany (1983); the Portuguese Pavilion at
label: Paragraph

text: Expo ‘98 in Lisbon, Portugal (1998); the Santa Maria Church in Marco de Canavezes,
label: Caption

text: Portugal (1997).
label: Paragraph

text: SKIDMORE, OWINGS AND MERRILL
label: Title

text: Architecture firm, United States
label: Title

text: An early proponent of the International Style, the architectural firm of Skidmore,
label: Paragraph

text: Owings and Merrill (SOM) was best noted for its technical innovations in skyscraper
label: Paragraph

text: design, especially during the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s. The “glass box” aesthetic, derived
label: Paragraph

text: from Mies van der Rohe, for SOM became an experiment in which, although the general
label: Paragraph

text: style and form remained quite consistent and even somewhat bland, subtle modifications
label: Paragraph

text: and structural enhancements were progressively undertaken. SOM’s version of corporate
label: Paragraph

text: architecture dominated the field of high-rise building during this period, even after
label: Paragraph

text: competing up-and-coming firms introduced more progressive design concepts and
label: Paragraph

text: seemingly left SOM a dinosaur living off past laurels. Yet owing to its vast resources,
label: Paragraph

text: stability, and reputation, the firm was able to maintain a consistently strong position with
label: Paragraph

text: corporate clients, even after the retirement of the founding partners and key designers.
label: Paragraph

text: Founded in Chicago in 1936, SOM emerged during troubled economic times and with
label: Paragraph

text: few early building projects. Law-renceburg, Indiana, native Louis Skidmore (1897-1962)
label: Caption

text: graduated with an architectural degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology
label: Paragraph

text: (MIT) in 1924. After working for Maginnius and Walsh for two years, Skidmore won the
label: Paragraph

text: prestigious Rotch Traveling Fellowship in 1926 and spent the next three years in Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: While in Paris, he met and married Eloise Owings, sister of his future partner Nathaniel
label: Paragraph

text: Owings (1903-84). Owings, a native of Indianapolis, had attended the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: school at the University of Illinois at Urbana in 1921. After becoming ill and passing up
label: Paragraph

text: an appointment to West Point, Owings eventually graduated with a bachelor of arts
label: Paragraph

text: degree in architecture from Cornell University in 1927. The first major work of the
label: Paragraph

text: brothers-in-law was for the 1933 Century of Progress International Exposition in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago, of which Skidmore was named assistant to the general manager. Their
label: Paragraph

text: collaborative effort consequently led to the opening of a second office in New York in
label: Paragraph

text: 1937, and a partnership strengthened by the addition in 1939 of another MIT graduate,
label: Paragraph

text: John Merrill (1896-1975). Merrill, born in St. Paul, Minnesota, had attended the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Wisconsin at Madison for two years before joining the U.S. Army during
label: Paragraph

text: World War |. After his graduation from MIT, Merrill had worked in Chicago for Granger
label: Paragraph

text: and Bollenbacher and had done some work for the U.S. Housing Administration.
label: Paragraph

text: Even though projects were few during the pre-World War II period, the firm’s
label: Paragraph

text: capability to skillfully provide both solid architectural and engineering design led to a
label: Paragraph

text: major commission in 1942. SOM was chosen to plan and design on 60,000 acres in
label: Paragraph

text: eastern Tennessee an entire community, Oak Ridge, as part of the U.S. government’s
label: Paragraph

text: secret nuclear production program. In this town, which eventually grew from a
label: Paragraph

text: population of zero to 75,000 by its completion in 1946, the production of uranium for the
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan Project occurred. After the war, an increasing number of projects began
label: Paragraph

text: flowing in, and the firm gained a reputation for proficient if not extraordinary design
label: Paragraph

text: work. It was the personal and professional relationships developed by the founding
label: Paragraph

text: partners during this era that led to substantial work later and wide recognition for their
label: Paragraph

text: planning abilities. In that context, Owings was appointed chairman of the Chicago Plan
label: Paragraph

text: Commission from 1948 to 1951.
label: Paragraph

text: The firm’s reputation was elevated to a new level with its first major skyscraper
label: Paragraph

text: commission, the highly acclaimed Lever House (1951) in New York City, designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Gordon Bunshaft (1909-90) for the Lever Brothers Soap Company. The 24-story green
label: Caption

text: glass curtain-walled and stainless-steel structure reflected in its design not only New
label: Paragraph

text: York’s changing zoning laws that now permitted slab skyscrapers without setbacks but
label: Paragraph

text: also the emergence of corporate modernism in the United States. Here, the form of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier met the surface treatment of Mies van der Rohe, resulting in a modestly scaled
label: Paragraph

text: structure in sharp contrast with the solid masonry of its neighbors.
label: Paragraph

text: SOM followed up the Lever House with another corporate commission, the Inland
label: Paragraph

text: Steel Building (1958) in Chicago, one of the first high-rise buildings constructed in the
label: Paragraph

text: Windy City after the Depression. With Walter Netsch (1920-) as chief designer, this 19-
label: Paragraph

text: story glass box with accompanying 25-story stainless-steel service tower exemplifies
label: Paragraph

text: Miesian abstraction. The architects separated the service core from the office block
label: Paragraph

text: through a stark contrast between metal and glass sheathing. Soon a trademark of SOM, it
label: Paragraph

text: was repeated most notably in the Crown Zellerbach Building (1959) in San Francisco.
label: Paragraph

text: The firm replicated the glass box skyscraper model in buildings of varying heights,
label: Paragraph

text: including the Manufacturers’ Trust Company (1954), the Union Carbide Building (1960),
label: Paragraph

text: and Chase Manhattan Bank (1961), all in New York. In 1961, the awarding of the AIA’s
label: Paragraph

text: first Architecture Firm Award solidified SOM’s position as a premier architectural firm.
label: Paragraph

text: Sin Mao Tower, China (1998)

text: © China Jin Mao Group. Photo courtesy Skidmore, Owings and Merrill,
label: Caption

text: Chicago
label: Title

text: During the 1970s, the firm reacted to changing economic conditions that required multi-
label: Paragraph

text: purpose megastructures, literally vertical cities in the sky. Two of its best-known
label: Paragraph

text: structures of this type were constructed in Chicago, both designed by Bruce Graham
label: Paragraph

text: (1925-) and engineered by Fazlur Khan (1929-82). The John Hancock Center (1970) is
label: Paragraph

text: by far the most satisfying. This multi-purpose 100-story structure of black anodized
label: Paragraph

text: aluminum with tinted bronze glass rises 1,107 feet as a single tapered shaft. It combines
label: Paragraph

text: retail, commercial, and residential functions into one colossal building. In order to
label: Paragraph

text: combat wind and gravity loads, large cross bracing was used on the building’s exterior, a
label: Paragraph

text: technique that had been employed slightly earlier by SOM in the Alcoa Building (1968)
label: Paragraph

text: in San Francisco, although there to provide stability against seismic disturbances, not
label: Paragraph

text: wind pressure. The cross bracing at the John Hancock Center became the building’s
label: Paragraph

text: decoration, its exoskeleton exploited in a very sculptural manner.
label: Paragraph

text: The Sears Tower (1974) in Chicago was for many years the tallest building in the
label: Paragraph

text: world at 1,454 feet. The black aluminum sheathing and dark smoked glass, without the
label: Paragraph

text: benefit of even the smallest degree of sculptural articulation, exhibits coldness and a lack
label: Paragraph

text: of human scale or interaction. Still, the general aesthetic of both the Sears Tower and the
label: Paragraph

text: John Hancock Center can be best understood within the context of contemporary min-
label: Paragraph

text: imalist sculpture and viewed as a continuation of SOM’s exploration of Miesian ideals.
label: Paragraph

text: While the firm’s skyscraper commissions progressively increased in the 1960s and
label: Paragraph

text: 1970s, other types of projects also came its way, most significantly the campus design
label: Paragraph

text: and buildings for the United States Air Force Academy (1962) in Colorado Springs. The
label: Caption

text: school’s Cadet Chapel offered SOM a rare opportunity to design a religious structure, and
label: Paragraph

text: Netsch responded with a unique approach, constructing three chapels (one Protestant, one
label: Paragraph

text: Jewish, and one Catholic, each of a varying aesthetic) under one roof. Certainly one of
label: Paragraph

text: the most expressionistic and symbolic of SOM’s works, the outward appearance
label: Paragraph

text: abstractly references forms associated with aircraft and flying. Shortly after this
label: Paragraph

text: commission, SOM began working on another campus plan, this time for the University of
label: Paragraph

text: Illinois at Chicago Center (1965).
label: Caption

text: The firm was not restricted to skyscraper or campus planning projects. Indeed, SOM’s
label: Paragraph

text: work spanned the entire range of architectural forms. Some of its key designs include the
label: Paragraph

text: technically sophisticated McMath Solar Telescope at Kitt Peak (1962) in Tucson,
label: Paragraph

text: Arizona, where a cooled mixture of glycol and water circulates through a specially
label: Paragraph

text: designed “skin” that absorbs the sun’s rays and prevents the generation of disruptive
label: Paragraph

text: thermal currents on the telescope’s surface. The environmentally conscious
label: Paragraph

text: Weyerhaeuser Headquarters (1971) in Tacoma, Washington, with its five long horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: ivy-covered terraces, contains the same amount of square footage as a 35-story
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper, approximately 354,000 square feet. The Haj Terminal (1982) in Jeddah,
label: Paragraph

text: Saudi Arabia, was designed using a Teflon-coated fiberglass membrane in forms that
label: Paragraph

text: references the tents set up by the million-plus pilgrims passing through the airport during
label: Paragraph

text: the yearly pilgrimage to Mecca. Bunshaft’s three-story concrete Hirschhorn Museum and
label: Caption

text: Sculpture Garden (1974) in Washington, D.C., devoted to housing modern art, appears as
label: Paragraph

text: a modemist’s response to Frank Lloyd Wright’s Guggenheim Museum in New York,
label: Paragraph

text: lifted up on massive pilotis as per the Le Corbusier model.
label: Paragraph

text: It is important to note that the firm’s three founders actually designed few of SOM’s
label: Paragraph

text: hallmark buildings. They developed and led an architectural firm modeled on a corporate
label: Paragraph

text: organization. Branch offices were opened in a number of cities with design principals in
label: Paragraph

text: charge of each office. Instead of the more typical hierarchical arrangement of power,
label: Paragraph

text: authority within SOM was arranged in a linear fashion, as each office head theoretically
label: Paragraph

text: had equal voice in how the firm was run. A stipulation in the founding partners’
label: Paragraph

text: agreement required retirement at age 65 for each principal, thus prompting a constant
label: Paragraph

text: renewal of the firm’s direction and focus.
label: Paragraph

text: With such an arrangement, it is not surprising that SOM’s designs exhibit a good deal
label: Paragraph

text: of diversity and quality, particularly during the 1970s and beyond. The firm grew to an
label: Paragraph

text: immense size in terms of both employees and offices. In addition to the original Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: and New York offices, a San Francisco office was opened in 1946 when the firm took on
label: Paragraph

text: the design of Subic Bay Naval Base in the Philippines and the Monterey Naval Post-
label: Paragraph

text: graduate School. In 1967, the Washington, D.C., office was established to handle the
label: Paragraph

text: firm’s work on the master plan of the Washington Mall. Other new offices were
label: Paragraph

text: established in Los Angeles and Miami. Not all the new offices survived, however, as the
label: Paragraph

text: firm constantly reacted to changing economic and building trends. Those offices founded
label: Paragraph

text: in Denver, Portland, and Boston were eventually closed in 1987, Houston’s closed in
label: Paragraph

text: 1988, and new offices were opened in the late 1980s in London and Hong Kong, as
label: Paragraph

text: construction boomed in those areas.
label: Paragraph

text: Netsch once bitingly complained that SOM in the 1980s was producing “Reagan
label: Paragraph

text: architecture for Reagan times.” The rejuvenation of design that the founding partners had
label: Paragraph

text: intended thus did not always come to pass. In fact, once SOM had reached its pinnacle in
label: Paragraph

text: the early 1970s with the visually satisfying John Hancock Center and the record-breaking
label: Paragraph

text: height of the Sears Tower, the firm had the luxury of essentially sitting back and waiting
label: Paragraph

text: for clients to come forward. Still, several fine structures were designed by SOM in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1980s, including Bunshaft’s post-modern National Commercial Bank (1984) in Jeddah,
label: Paragraph

text: Saudi Arabia, and the United Gulf Bank (1987) in Manama, Bahrain.
label: Paragraph

text: Because of its huge size and ability to provide numerous services ranging from
label: Paragraph

text: interiors to transportation planning, corporate SOM could easily service clients’ needs
label: Paragraph

text: and provide one-stop shopping. The size of the firm particularly suited the requirements
label: Paragraph

text: of developers in the 1980s, as the focus moved from single high-rise structures to large-
label: Paragraph

text: scale complex city developments, such as Rowes Wharf (1987) in Boston, World Wide
label: Paragraph

text: Plaza (1989) in New York, and Canary Wharf (1991) in London. This trend continued
label: Paragraph

text: into the 1990s, except that the location for building more often than not was in the Pacific
label: Paragraph

text: Rim. Among SOM’s more recent projects are the 88-story Jin Mao Tower (1998) in
label: Paragraph

text: Shanghai and the Korea World Trade Center (1999) in Seoul. The firm also won a
label: Paragraph

text: competition to design a master plan for Saigon South, a new community designed for one
label: Paragraph

text: million inhabitants south of Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.

text: SKYSCRAPER
label: Title

text: As the archetypal urban commercial building, the 20th-century skyscraper exhibited
label: Paragraph

text: continual structural innovation and stylistic exploration. Historicism and eclecticism
label: Paragraph

text: moved in and out of fashion throughout the century, interspersed with periods of a new
label: Paragraph

text: “modern” aesthetic that exploited the pure form created by the steel-frame and glass
label: Paragraph

text: curtain wall. In addition to concerns for ornamentation, constant competition to create
label: Paragraph

text: taller structures not only demonstrated the desire of patrons and architects to physically
label: Paragraph

text: outdo one another in creating a landmark structure but also reflected changing economic
label: Paragraph

text: conditions and building patterns within particular cities. Importantly, not every
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper was constructed in an attempt to outdo its neighbor, and not every high-rise
label: Paragraph

text: building exhibited innovation. Critically successful structures in terms of aesthetics were
label: Paragraph

text: also not always profitable. Mitigating factors such as material and technical innovation,
label: Paragraph

text: zoning regulations, economic climate, and the client’s purpose for construction affected
label: Paragraph

text: the skyscraper’s success as much as the designer or engineer did.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 19th century, the earliest high-rise buildings tended to simply be mere
label: Paragraph

text: enlargements of traditional forms, such as the tower, progressively adding stories and
label: Paragraph

text: increasing height without adequately addressing the aesthetic of a tall structure.
label: Paragraph

text: Designers such as Louis Sullivan, John Wellborn Root, and George B. Post eventually
label: Paragraph

text: tackled this problem, theoretically and in practice, by considering the nature of
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper form itself as a new building type. When combined with advances in
label: Paragraph

text: engineering and materials, the skyscraper thus became not only a monument to modern
label: Paragraph

text: progress but also a symbolic link to the historical past, a past that the United States
label: Paragraph

text: lacked and sought to evoke or, perhaps, to distance itself from.
label: Paragraph

text: Two perceived “schools” of skyscraper design embodied these purposes. The Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: School, with its emphasis on structural rationality and economy, personified what was
label: Paragraph

text: new about skyscraper design in the United States, breaking from historical ornament or
label: Paragraph

text: form. Speculative commercial construction thrived in Chicago after the devastating fire
label: Paragraph

text: of 1871 and dictated a simpler, more cost-effective method of exterior articulation as well
label: Paragraph

text: as making the best use of available land for office space. On the other hand, in New
label: Paragraph

text: York, corporate commissions had always demanded more ornamentation and more
label: Paragraph

text: historical references, all in an attempt to present a landmark structure that would elevate
label: Paragraph

text: and promote its occupants. Businesses such as insurance companies and newspapers
label: Paragraph

text: employed elaborate styles that not only were self-promoting but also galvanized civic
label: Paragraph

text: pride.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the Chicago School made an indelible impression on many American cities
label: Paragraph

text: and especially on European modernists, it was the Beaux-Arts-inspired style popular in
label: Paragraph

text: New York that dominated skyscraper construction as the 20th century dawned. Ironically,
label: Paragraph

text: the World’s Columbian Exposition of 1893 in Chicago, with its gleaming White City
label: Paragraph

text: image personifying monumentality and strength, prompted this classical interest and,
label: Paragraph

text: according to Louis Sullivan, set back architectural design by decades. Like the great
label: Paragraph

text: mercantile princes of the Italian Renaissance, businessmen turned to Beaux-Arts-trained
label: Paragraph

text: or-inspired architects to construct buildings that, by appropriating a classicized style,
label: Paragraph

text: implied power and respectability. Not surprisingly, the most popular high-rise design
label: Paragraph

text: firm at the beginning of the century was D.H.Burnham and Company, founded by the
label: Paragraph

text: man responsible for the plan of the White City. Its successor firm, Graham, Anderson,
label: Paragraph

text: Probst and White, continued this domination well into the 1910s.
label: Paragraph

text: A typical Beaux-Arts skyscraper consisted of either a simple yet ornamented tower
label: Paragraph

text: block, such as Burnham’s Flatiron Building (1903) in New York, or a basic office block
label: Paragraph

text: aggrandized with an elaborate tower, such as Emest Flagg’s Singer Building (1908) in
label: Paragraph

text: New York, with its Second Empire mansard roof that was dramatically lit at night, or
label: Paragraph

text: Napoleon Le Brun’s Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Building (1909) in New
label: Caption

text: York, a direct but much taller copy of the campanile of St. Marco in Venice. Corporate
label: Caption

text: commissions, such as the Singer and Met Life buildings, served as physical
label: Paragraph

text: advertisements for the companies that commissioned them, even if those businesses
label: Paragraph

text: occupied only a small amount of office space within each structure. Like the great
label: Paragraph

text: medieval cathedrals of Europe, competition for prestige led companies to request
label: Paragraph

text: towering structures that dominated their immediate environment as well as the city as a
label: Paragraph

text: whole.
label: Paragraph

text: Cass Gilbert’s Woolworth Building (1913) in New York turned appropriately enough
label: Paragraph

text: to Gothic style for inspiration, a style that more naturally emphasized verticality. As the
label: Paragraph

text: company was so decentralized, Woolworth actually used less than two stories of office
label: Paragraph

text: space; thus, it was not functional need but rather advertising and ego that created this
label: Paragraph

text: “Cathedral of Commerce,” emphasized by the Napoleonic imagery in Woolworth’s office
label: Paragraph

text: and other ornamentation. Individual patrons such as Woolworth were replaced after
label: Paragraph

text: World War II by corporate entities with far less interest in displaying so personal a
label: Paragraph

text: building program. Instead, the building material and form more directly referenced the
label: Paragraph

text: product sold by the company, such as the aluminum curtain walls of Wallace K.Harrison
label: Paragraph

text: and Max Abramovitz’s Alcoa Building (1953) in Pittsburgh and the plate-glass Gothic-
label: Paragraph

text: inspired
label: Title

text: Bank of China Tower, by I.M.Pei, Hong Kong
label: Caption

text: © GreatBuildings.com
label: Title

text: PPG Place (1984), also in Pittsburgh, by Philip Johnson and John Burgee.
label: Paragraph

text: In the first half of the century, two key moments in skyscraper design need to be
label: Paragraph

text: mentioned. The first was Graham, Anderson, Probst and White’s Equitable Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1915) in New York, not for any innovation but rather for the impact that its massive
label: Paragraph

text: scale and glut of office space had on New York. It was the stimulus for the famous 1916
label: Paragraph

text: zoning ordinance that necessitated setback construction, a requirement that other cities
label: Paragraph

text: soon adopted and an aesthetic that was endorsed by architects through the 1920s and
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s in the Art Deco and art moderne styles. The other event was the 1922 Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: Tribune Building Competition, which brought forth all the design variety and visionary
label: Paragraph

text: dreams of American and European architects regarding the skyscraper form.
label: Paragraph

text: European cities neither desired nor needed skyscrapers in the pre-World War II era;
label: Paragraph

text: thus, European architects created paper dreams of skyscraper cities. Futurist Antonio
label: Paragraph

text: Sant’ Elia’s Citta Nuova project (1914) and German Expressionist Bruno Taut’s Alpine
label: Paragraph

text: Architektur (1919) embraced modern technology and materials, albeit in an impractical
label: Paragraph

text: manner. Greater contributions were to be made later by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, but
label: Paragraph

text: his Friedrichstrasse Office Building project (1921) in Berlin revealed a logical conclusion
label: Paragraph

text: to the Chicago School in design with its honeycomb repetition of office stories and its
label: Paragraph

text: lack of applied ornament. Even Russian Constructivists, such as the Vesnin Brothers in
label: Paragraph

text: their Pravada Building project (1924) in Moscow, understood the underlying dictums of
label: Paragraph

text: decorative purity based on technical form, not historical precedents.
label: Paragraph

text: When the Chicago Tribune newspaper staged an architectural competition to design
label: Paragraph

text: “the most beautiful building in the world” for its headquarters, nearly 300 entries from 23
label: Paragraph

text: different countries were submitted. Entries ranged from the sublime (Walter Gropius’
label: Paragraph

text: design revealing both an understanding of the Chicago School’s functionality and the
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetry of De Stijl) to the ridiculous (Adolf Loos’ oversize Doric column). The
label: Paragraph

text: winning entry, by Raymond Hood and John Mead Howells, continued the Gothic revival
label: Paragraph

text: visible in the Woolworth Building, with the 1485 “Butter Tower” from Rouen Cathedral
label: Paragraph

text: as a direct design source and flying buttresses used decoratively, not structurally, on the
label: Paragraph

text: spire. Considering the winning entry, the clients apparently desired established aesthetics,
label: Paragraph

text: not innovation. However, second-place winner Eliel Saarinen’s design turned out to be
label: Paragraph

text: vastly more influential than Hood and Howells’ design, especially among Art Deco and
label: Paragraph

text: art moderne designers of the 1920s and 1930s who appreciated his ziggurat approach in
label: Paragraph

text: massing and the unbroken vertical emphasis in the building’s line.
label: Paragraph

text: Theoretical works by Hugh Ferriss (The Metropolis of Tomorrow, 1929) and Claude
label: Paragraph

text: Bragdon (The Frozen Fountain, 1932) lauded the setback style as visionary and dynamic,
label: Paragraph

text: yet in practical application it simply became necessary. Cities such as New York, Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles, Chicago, Pittsburgh, Boston, and others recognized the potential (and, as in the
label: Paragraph

text: case of the Equitable Building, the very real) damage that out-of-scale skyscrapers caused
label: Paragraph

text: to neighboring buildings and the business district as a whole. These problems were not
label: Paragraph

text: limited to blocking light and creating cavernous environs but were related directly to
label: Paragraph

text: economics, such as devaluating commercial office rental prices by creating an
label: Paragraph

text: overabundance of office space. Thus, the setback style became an aesthetic reality in
label: Paragraph

text: large part because of zoning regulations.
label: Paragraph

text: Considering the necessity of setbacks, American architects soon adopted and learned
label: Paragraph

text: from Eliel Saarinen’s Chicago Tribune design. Even Raymond Hood modified his Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: decor into a setback style for his American Radiator Building (1924) in New York and
label: Paragraph

text: eventually moved beyond medievalism in his McGraw-Hill Building (1930), also in New
label: Paragraph

text: York. Whether “modernizing” forms of Gothic or exploring the stepped-back form and
label: Paragraph

text: geometric patterns of pre-Columbian architecture, both Art Deco and art moderne were
label: Paragraph

text: styles created with big business in mind. Visually engaging works, not austere corporate
label: Paragraph

text: images, drew the public’s attention and created landmark buildings. A perfect example of
label: Paragraph

text: this phenomenon is William Van Alen’s Chrysler Building (1930) in New York, with its
label: Paragraph

text: modernized gargoyles resembling automotive hood ornaments and the great telescoping
label: Paragraph

text: stainless-steel arches at its spire. The building visually represented the company as
label: Paragraph

text: advertisement and, as it became the tallest structure in the world at 1048 feet, symbolized
label: Paragraph

text: the company’s strength through its dominance of the New York skyline.
label: Paragraph

text: Unfortunately, the Chrysler Building’s claim to fame did not last for long, as Shreve,
label: Paragraph

text: Lamb and Harmon’s more restrained Empire State Building (1931) in New York soon
label: Paragraph

text: outdistanced its competitor at 1250 feet in height. Not a corporate commission but rather
label: Paragraph

text: a speculative construction, the Empire State Building was far less theatrical than the
label: Paragraph

text: Chrysler Building. Still, its mere size guaranteed its landmark status. It also displayed an
label: Paragraph

text: impractical but reverent appreciation for modern air travel, as its spire was fancifully
label: Paragraph

text: designed to be a mooring dock for dirigibles. This romanticized vision of the skyscraper,
label: Paragraph

text: in its ornamentation and form, reflected well the giddiness of the jazz age and the
label: Paragraph

text: economic prosperity of American business, a situation that all too quickly ended in 1929
label: Paragraph

text: with the stock market crash and the beginning of the Great Depression.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1930s, new construction of skyscrapers slowed and then virtually halted. Yet,
label: Paragraph

text: with political upheaval and war brewing in Europe, architects who had only dreamed of
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers arrived in the United States as exiles, including Walter Gropius, Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier, and Mies van der Rohe. Their theoretical European modernism took root in
label: Paragraph

text: the architecture schools in which they taught, such as at Harvard University, the
label: Paragraph

text: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the Armour Institute of Technology (later the
label: Paragraph

text: Illinois Institute of Technology). A full rethinking of the skyscraper began by which its
label: Paragraph

text: external form became expressive of its internal functions and the structure’s form and
label: Paragraph

text: materials became the ornamentation. The earliest expression of this new aesthetic was
label: Paragraph

text: George Howe and William Lescaze’s Philadelphia Savings Fund Society Building (1932)
label: Caption

text: in Philadelphia, with its elevator core pulled out at the back of the building and its glass
label: Paragraph

text: curtain wall, steel-framed office tower cantilevered above the entrance block. Traditional
label: Caption

text: materials, such as polished granite, brick, and limestone, were used, but the look was
label: Paragraph

text: entirely new and not necessarily welcomed by the architectural establishment.
label: Paragraph

text: Nevertheless, the International Style had taken root and continued to strengthen through
label: Paragraph

text: midcentury.
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism, as preached by Mies van der Rohe, was a reductive architecture with a
label: Paragraph

text: strong underlying classical sensibility. Mies’s maxim “Less is more” personified his
label: Paragraph

text: belief that pure austere form should serve as all the necessary decoration. His Lake Shore
label: Paragraph

text: Drive Apartments (1952) in Chicago, although not a commercial but a residential
label: Paragraph

text: venture, demonstrated his tenets for high-rise construction. The black-painted
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated steel-frame and clear-glass windows simply encased the interior space
label: Paragraph

text: without expressing internal function. There is no projecting cornice, no grand entrance,
label: Paragraph

text: and no elements characteristic of the typical tripartite skyscraper design. He would repeat
label: Paragraph

text: this formula in the corporate Seagram Building (1958) in New York, done with Philip
label: Paragraph

text: Johnson, and in numerous commercial, residential, educational, and other high-rise
label: Paragraph

text: designs.
label: Paragraph

text: Designers who came in contact with Mies, affected by his commanding personality and
label: Paragraph

text: strength of convictions, embraced his tenets and adopted them in their own
label: Paragraph

text: interpretations of the Miesian glass box. For example, Eero Saarinen’s CBS Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1965) in New York took a more sculptural approach to modernism, as the vertical
label: Paragraph

text: granite piers projected out from the wall surface and all sense of human reference in scale
label: Paragraph

text: was denied through the building’s abstraction. The structure startlingly isolated itself
label: Paragraph

text: from its environment yet worked well as pure design. However, not all designers were as
label: Paragraph

text: talented as Saarinen was, and in the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, cities, towns, and college
label: Paragraph

text: campuses were polluted with poorly constructed and downright ugly Miesian copies gone
label: Paragraph

text: awry.
label: Paragraph

text: The most successful Miesian-inspired firm was Skidmore, Owings and Merrill. Their
label: Paragraph

text: early masterpiece, Lever House (1952) in New York, designed by Gordon Bunshaft,
label: Paragraph

text: celebrated light and openness, revealing a significant influence of Le Corbusier as well,
label: Paragraph

text: with the pilotis, or stilts, raising the main office tower off the humanly oriented space
label: Paragraph

text: below. Eventually, the firm developed a more sculptural version of Miesian-inspired
label: Paragraph

text: modernism, as visible in the John Hancock Building (1970) in Chicago, with its structural
label: Paragraph

text: yet decorative external cross bracing and tapered form.
label: Paragraph

text: Their next major commission, the unsatisfying Sears Building (1974) in Chicago, fell
label: Paragraph

text: victim to the ever-present corporate need to construct physically dominating, out-of-scale
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers. At 1454 feet and 110 stories, the Sears Building became the tallest building
label: Paragraph

text: in the world, yet its bundled setbacks, when combined with the Miesian aesthetic,
label: Paragraph

text: resulted in a very bland structure. Minoru Yamasaki’s 1350-foot-tall World Trade Center
label: Paragraph

text: (1976) in New York had no more success, as its twin towers (which thankfully played off
label: Paragraph

text: each other) appeared ready to capsize Manhattan, perched as they were on the edge of the
label: Paragraph

text: island. Cesar Pelli’s Petrona Towers (1998) in Kuala Lumpur, at 1483 feet, finally topped
label: Paragraph

text: the massive heights attained by both these structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Not all architects or critics appreciated the International Style and modernism as
label: Paragraph

text: preached by architects such as Mies van der Rohe and Skidmore, Owings and Merrill.
label: Paragraph

text: The International Style could be, just as the term implied, a form used in any location
label: Paragraph

text: because it had no cultural or historical ornamentation that would affect its contextual use.
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright in particular railed against “soulless” architecture that neglected
label: Paragraph

text: cultural context or interaction with its direct urban environment. Concerned as he was for
label: Paragraph

text: “small-town” development, Wright rarely attempted skyscraper design, and when he did,
label: Paragraph

text: it was usually undersized, such as the 15-story Price Tower (1955) in Bartlesville,
label: Paragraph

text: Oklahoma. Only once did Wright attempt the stratospheric proportions popular with
label: Paragraph

text: corporate patrons: his 1956 project for a Mile High Skyscraper for Chicago, a soaring
label: Paragraph

text: structure that was as impractical then as it is today. In his scheme, the skyscraper was not
label: Paragraph

text: placed in competition with other high-rise buildings in an urban environment; rather, it
label: Paragraph

text: rose isolated in the countryside. Ironically, Wright’s vision of the dominance of suburban
label: Paragraph

text: America was to become a reality as people increasingly migrated from the city center to
label: Paragraph

text: suburban developments in the post-World War II era.
label: Paragraph

text: Business interests moved with them. Increasingly, corporate headquarters took the
label: Paragraph

text: form of low, sprawling structures with green lawns and miles of employee parking lots.
label: Paragraph

text: The trademark corporate skyscraper was increasingly becoming a thing of the past, yet
label: Paragraph

text: those that did stay and built in the cities understood the need to contextualize their
label: Paragraph

text: presence. Thus, the stark, crisp modernism of Hugh Stubbins Associates’ Citicorp Center
label: Paragraph

text: (1978) in New York and I.M.Pei and Henry Cobb’s John Hancock Tower (1975) in
label: Paragraph

text: Boston increasingly battled a Postmodernism aesthetic that reintroduced historicism and
label: Paragraph

text: context. Plazas, gardens, and other public spaces became an important aspect of the
label: Paragraph

text: design, as much as the buildings’ materials, ornamentation, and form.
label: Paragraph

text: Begun in 1978, many consider Johnson and Burgee’s AT&T Building (1984) in New
label: Paragraph

text: York the first Postmodern skyscraper, with its broken pediment (Chippendale-like)} top
label: Paragraph

text: and emphasis on its pink-granite stone walls. The reintroduction of rich, colorful
label: Paragraph

text: materials as well as the appropriation of a wide variety of historical forms characterized
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodern design. It could be playful and fun, such as Michael Graves’s Portland
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1982) in Portland, Oregon, with its miniature Acropolis on top, demonstrating
label: Paragraph

text: not only the abstract way in which history could be referenced but also the new emphasis
label: Paragraph

text: on the skyscraper top lost during the modernist years. Postmodernism could also be
label: Paragraph

text: elegant and austere, as represented by the work of Kohn Pedersen Fox, arguably the most
label: Paragraph

text: successful skyscraper design firm of the late 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s. Their 333 Wacker
label: Paragraph

text: Drive (1983) in Chicago responded to its site and surrounding environs with its curving
label: Paragraph

text: green-glass curtain wall and specific design elements that alluded to nearby landmarks.
label: Paragraph

text: By attempting to integrate their buildings firmly into the urban environment,
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodern architects brought back an appreciation for historicism and traditional
label: Paragraph

text: materials that modernists had rejected in favor of pursuing pure form and modern
label: Paragraph

text: materials. Both “schools” continued to exist at the end of the century and adapted to
label: Paragraph

text: changing client needs, particularly in the 1980s, when skyscrapers increasingly became
label: Paragraph

text: part of larger urban development plans with a wide variety of buildings clustered
label: Paragraph

text: together. This usage differed from the traditional isolating nature of the skyscraper,
label: Paragraph

text: which, whether corporate commission or speculative investment, had historically been
label: Paragraph

text: multiuse structures themselves. They not only provided company headquarters but also
label: Paragraph

text: housed financial institutions, retail establishments, offices for professionals, and
label: Paragraph

text: residential units. Now those roles were being delegated to individual components within
label: Paragraph

text: the greater complex.
label: Paragraph

text: The slanted focus on American skyscrapers during the 20th century accurately reflects
label: Paragraph

text: where the most significant construction and designs were occurring, a situation that did
label: Paragraph

text: change during the century’s final two decades. Thriving economic markets in oil-rich
label: Paragraph

text: Middle Eastern countries in the 1980s and in Pacific Rim countries during the 1990s led
label: Paragraph

text: to a boom market in high-rise construction in those areas. Europe additionally presented
label: Paragraph

text: increasing skyscraper opportunities for builders, particularly in Germany and other
label: Paragraph

text: former Soviet-bloc countries after the collapse of the Berlin Wall and the USSR. Still,
label: Paragraph

text: clients in these countries turned primarily to American architectural firms such as
label: Paragraph

text: Skidmore, Owings and Merrill (National Commercial Bank, 1984, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia),
label: Caption

text: I.M.Pei (Bank of China Tower, 1989, Hong Kong), Kohn Pedersen Fox (Westendstrasse
label: Caption

text: 1/DB Bank Headquarters, 1993, Frankfurt), and Cesar Pelli.
label: Caption

text: It can be argued that in the 20th century, architects explored the full range of aesthetic,
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic, material, and structural possibilities for the skyscraper form. The design tastes
label: Paragraph

text: and innovations that dominated the earliest high-rise buildings in the 19th century either
label: Paragraph

text: mutated into various expressions of historicism or evolved into pure form with the aid of
label: Paragraph

text: European modernists. However, understanding these factors provides only a fraction of
label: Paragraph

text: the skyscraper story. More specific studies of the economic and business climates of
label: Paragraph

text: individual cities, particularly beyond Chicago and New York, and how that affected
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper design and construction have yet to be undertaken.
label: Paragraph

text: SMITH, CHLOETHIEL WOODARD 1910-92
label: Title

text: Architect and urban planner, United States
label: Caption

text: In her designs, Chloethiel Woodard Smith strove to combine functionalism and
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetics. Her concerns with “quality over quantity” and “improving the collective
label: Paragraph

text: neglect,” as she described her goals, were strongly influenced by Lewis Mumford and her
label: Paragraph

text: work for the Federal Housing Administration (FHA). Smith met Mumford during her
label: Paragraph

text: undergraduate studies and corresponded with him until his 1990 death. After completing
label: Paragraph

text: her M.Arch. in 1933, Smith spent two years working for different architectural firms
label: Paragraph

text: before accepting the position as chief of research at the FHA in 1935. She worked for that
label: Paragraph

text: organization until 1939. Consequently, she spent most of her career in Washington, D.C.,
label: Paragraph

text: and was a significant force in shaping the American capitol in the 1950s and 1960s.
label: Paragraph

text: Her projects in Washington include the E Street Expressway, office buildings, and
label: Paragraph

text: residential communities. Smith managed the unequaled feat of securing commissions
label: Paragraph

text: from three different developers to build three of the four office buildings at a prominent
label: Paragraph

text: intersection in a major American city: the corner of Connecticut Avenue and L Street in
label: Paragraph

text: Washington, D.C. Although they are competent modernist designs, the three corporate
label: Paragraph

text: structures at Chloethiel’s corner, as it is affectionately known, do not reflect Smith’s best
label: Paragraph

text: work. Her most inspired designs and those for which she is best known are her residential
label: Paragraph

text: communities. Among these are two that helped to revive southwest Washington: Capitol
label: Paragraph

text: Park and Harbour Square.
label: Paragraph

text: Both Capitol Park and Harbour Square reflect Smith’s determination to “add
label: Paragraph

text: something more” to the urban environment through the use of varied designs,
label: Paragraph

text: landscaping, control of automobile traffic, and providing support facilities instead of
label: Paragraph

text: adhering to stylistic dogma. In Capitol Park (1965-67), designed in partnership with
label: Paragraph

text: Nicholas Satterlee, Smith characteristically relied on landscaping and miniparks to
label: Paragraph

text: connect the different building types to one another and their surroundings. The changes
label: Paragraph

text: of scale within both the landscaping and the structures—five Le Corbusian high-rise
label: Paragraph

text: apartment buildings and wood-framed townhouses—provide diversity within unity. To
label: Paragraph

text: further avoid monotony, the facades of the high-rises are varied, and the exteriors of the
label: Paragraph

text: townhouses are painted in different pastel colors. In order to accommodate the different
label: Paragraph

text: types of housing, streets are not laid out along a grid pattern. They are arranged to allow
label: Paragraph

text: easy access to the housing. The automobile is accommodated yet does not determine the
label: Paragraph

text: plan. Smith also provided quality-of-life facilities, such as laundries and swimming pools.
label: Paragraph

text: A 1964 promotional brochure for Capitol Park described it as “The New Town in the
label: Paragraph

text: City.” “New Town” was the phrase that Smith preferred for her urban-renewal projects
label: Paragraph

text: such as Capitol Park.
label: Paragraph

text: Therefore, “New Town” was applied also to the 1966 Harbour Square development by
label: Paragraph

text: Chloethiel Woodard Smith and Associates. Although similar support services were
label: Paragraph

text: included, at Harbour Square Smith’s approach to the integration of contemporary and
label: Paragraph

text: traditional forms was different from the one she utilized in Capitol Park. Seven historic
label: Paragraph

text: houses from the 1770s were incorporated into a row of new townhouses. These are
label: Paragraph

text: balanced by high-rise apartment blocks. Smith placed all the new buildings on the ground
label: Paragraph

text: to relate them to the historic structures. Automobiles are not allowed into Harbour
label: Paragraph

text: Square, although access to the underground parking is convenient. Variety is provided
label: Paragraph

text: through the use of different building types, courtyards, and landscaping. In Harbour
label: Paragraph

text: Square, Smith again made the new development compatible with its surroundings by
label: Paragraph

text: respecting the historic fabric and strategic landscaping.
label: Paragraph

text: Smith’s innovative approach to the use of historic forms, her insistence that support
label: Paragraph

text: services be included, and the automobile corralled contributed to the success of LaClede
label: Paragraph

text: Township (1966-67) in St. Louis. In this federal housing project, two-and three-story
label: Paragraph

text: wood-frame houses are arranged along streets accentuated by traffic circles. Although
label: Paragraph

text: Smith was strongly criticized for designing a housing project closely resembling the
label: Paragraph

text: clutter of buildings that had been cleared for it, LaClede Town was truly an urban-
label: Paragraph

text: renewal project, unlike Capitol Park and Harbour Square, which were urban-removal
label: Paragraph

text: projects. LaClede demonstrates Smith’s belief it is possible to provide affordable, quality,
label: Paragraph

text: and pleasing housing despite the residents’ income levels. As such, LaClede stands in
label: Paragraph

text: direct contrast to the purely modernist design of another St. Louis housing project, Pruitt
label: Paragraph

text: Igoe, by Minoru Yamasaki, which was completed in 1954 and demolished in 1972.
label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore, in her reliance on traditional housing forms at LaClede, Smith was
label: Paragraph

text: anticipating such New Urbanist towns as Seaside and Celebration, albeit for completely
label: Paragraph

text: different residents. She understood that well-designed and well-built homes, support
label: Paragraph

text: facilities such as the delicatessen, art gallery, and controversial pub, and links to the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding areas are more capable than high mortgages of instilling community pride.
label: Paragraph

text: At LaClede, Smith strongly demonstrated well-designed public housing could provide a
label: Paragraph

text: positive environment while meeting government regulations.
label: Paragraph

text: Smith’s belief that good design resulted from many factors and not simple adherence to
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic dogma manifested itself early in her career. For example, in 1939 she organized
label: Paragraph

text: the exhibition “Washington, The Planned City without a Plan,” in which she criticized
label: Paragraph

text: the Washington Planning Commission for continuing to follow the L’Enfant and
label: Paragraph

text: McMillan plans. She advocated that these plans were outdated and unable to meet the
label: Paragraph

text: needs of a modern city. Her criticism was so shocking that the Washington chapter of the
label: Paragraph

text: American Institute of Architects (AIA) Retracted its sponsorship. Less problematic were
label: Paragraph

text: her articles about the spread of the International Style to South America. Instead of
label: Paragraph

text: belittling South American architects for importing the European style, she discussed the
label: Paragraph

text: positive aspects of South American modernism within its sociopolitical context.
label: Paragraph

text: These articles constitute one aspect of her international career. Although the majority
label: Paragraph

text: of Smith’s career was spent in Washington, she also lived and worked in Canada and
label: Paragraph

text: Bolivia. Her familiarity with South America and her responsiveness to local conditions
label: Paragraph

text: were instrumental in securing the commission for the American Embassy Chancery and
label: Paragraph

text: Residence (1959) in Asuncion, Paraguay.
label: Caption

text: Smith’s international projects were well received, but her most critically acclaimed
label: Paragraph

text: work was in the United States. She included the American Embassy in Paraguay and
label: Paragraph

text: Capitol Park among her most successful designs and surprisingly did not list LaClede
label: Paragraph

text: Town. It is difficult to understand by what criteria an architect judges her own work. As
label: Paragraph

text: early as 1960, Smith’s colleagues gave their approval by electing her a fellow to the AIA.
label: Paragraph

text: Her colleagues were expressing their confidence in her unflinching commitment to good
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and urban planning. They would not be disappointed. In 1960, Smith was
label: Paragraph

text: slightly past the midpoint of her 49-year career, and her best work was yet to come.
label: Paragraph

text: SMITHSON, PETER, (1923-) AND
label: Title

text: SMITHSON, ALISON, (1928-93)
label: Caption

text: Architecture firm, England
label: Title

text: Alison and Peter Smithson were, until 1993, principals of their own London-based
label: Paragraph

text: architectural practice and together were responsible for some of the most influential
label: Paragraph

text: writings and buildings in 20th-century British architecture. Their work is characterized by
label: Paragraph

text: the breadth of their projects, which range from city planning to furniture design. Their
label: Paragraph

text: involvement with the Pop art movement in 1950s London and, later, as cofounders of the
label: Paragraph

text: influential Team X group that grew out of the Congrés Internationaux d’Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: Moderne (CIAM), established their place within modern postwar architecture in Britain.
label: Paragraph

text: The firm built their early reputation on a winning competition design, the Hunstanton
label: Paragraph

text: School (1954) in Norfolk, inspired by the early Chicago School buildings of Mies van der
label: Paragraph

text: Rohe. This rectilinear pavilion in brick, steel, and glass became the first built landmark of
label: Paragraph

text: a new movement known as the New Brutalism (or simply Brutalism) in England. The
label: Paragraph

text: Economist Building (actually three buildings around a raised plaza built in concrete but
label: Paragraph

text: faced in Portland stone) followed in London in 1964. The Smithsons then designed two
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in disparate settings: student accommodations for St. Hilda’s College, Oxford
label: Caption

text: (1970), in essence a scaled-down version of one of the earlier Economist “towers” but
label: Paragraph

text: sensitively contextualized, and the housing at Robin Hood Gardens (1970), sandwiched
label: Paragraph

text: between highways in the east end of London and itself a fragment of their influential
label: Paragraph

text: competition project for Golden Lane (1952).
label: Paragraph

text: A number of competition entries from the early 1950s established the Smithsons
label: Paragraph

text: among a new avant-garde of architects eager to transcend the limits of the International
label: Paragraph

text: Style without betraying the rationality and rigor of modernist principles. The Smithsons’s
label: Paragraph

text: solution was radical although contradictory: on the one hand, their work made reference
label: Paragraph

text: to anthropological patterns of human association and settlement, and on the other,
label: Paragraph

text: advocated the embrace of new industrial technologies.
label: Paragraph

text: The Smithsons’ involvement with a movement of British Pop artists known as the
label: Paragraph

text: Independent Group at the Institute of Contemporary Arts (ICA) provided an opportunity
label: Paragraph

text: to present their work to an audience of avant-garde artists, curators, critics, theorists, and
label: Paragraph

text: other architects. The multimedia exhibitions “A Parallel of Life and Art” (ICA, 1953) and
label: Paragraph

text: “This is Tomorrow” (Whitechapel Gallery, 1956) included the Smithsons’ work. The
label: Paragraph

text: latter included a primitive hut surrounded by a sand-covered protected territory,
label: Paragraph

text: accompanied by a symbolic collection of relics, or “found objects’—reminders of human
label: Paragraph

text: activity as well as machine-age technologies. The concept of the house as the focus of
label: Paragraph

text: post-war domesticity and commodity fetishism provided the theme for the Smithsons’
label: Paragraph

text: “House of the Future” entry constructed for the Ideal Homes Exhibition in London
label: Caption

text: (1956). The Smithsons organic styling and built-in furniture, using molded plastic and
label: Paragraph

text: fiberglass construction, produced a startling contrast to the traditional brick-and-timber
label: Paragraph

text: palette of the prevailing residential architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Other projects diverted from the individualism of the home to consider large-scale
label: Paragraph

text: movement patterns in city centers. Like Golden Lane, the Smithsons’ project for the
label: Paragraph

text: Sheffield University competition (1953) used pedestrian circulation as its major ordering
label: Paragraph

text: device. This strategy was extrapolated in the Berlin Haupstadt competition (1958), in
label: Paragraph

text: which an elevated pedestrian network bridges the existing roadways. This project
label: Paragraph

text: represented the desire to imagine a new scale of urban architecture, one more suited to
label: Paragraph

text: the increased speed of movement and the loss of engagement between inhabitants and
label: Paragraph

text: their immediate surroundings. These goals dovetailed with the work and concerns of
label: Paragraph

text: Team X, a group that included other European architects such as Ralph Erskine,
label: Paragraph

text: Giancarlo di Carlo, and Aldo van Eyck. As editor of the Team X Primer (published
label: Paragraph

text: initially in Architectural Design in 1962), Alison Smithson articulated statements of
label: Paragraph

text: theory alongside diagrams and drawings of architectural projects that analyzed the crucial
label: Paragraph

text: nature of architectural context and the continuity of historic living patterns. Nonetheless,
label: Paragraph

text: the Primer illustrates proposals, such as the London Roads Study (1959), that appear to
label: Paragraph

text: disregard existing buildings and topographies.
label: Paragraph

text: By the 1970s, a shift in the Smithsons’s work acknowledged these earlier
label: Paragraph

text: contradictions, most clearly manifest in the campus buildings at the University of Bath.
label: Paragraph

text: The Smithsons defined the Bath architecture as Team X structures—through what they
label: Paragraph

text: termed “mat-building’—with blocks arranged along a raised pedestrian deck above a
label: Paragraph

text: ground-level service road. The inherent incompleteness of this extendable structure
label: Paragraph

text: provided a challenge to the Smithsons’s sensibility, demanding that they create at least a
label: Paragraph

text: suggestion of stability and closure to an otherwise infinite system. The Bath buildings
label: Caption

text: presented new themes not previously seen in their built work: the notion of
label: Paragraph

text: “conglomerate ordering,” referring to volumetric masses wrapped in a unifying skin; the
label: Paragraph

text: building as “climate register,” expressing its relation to the external environment; the
label: Paragraph

text: concern for the sensory pleasure to be gained from concrete materials; and the sensitivity
label: Paragraph

text: to inhabitation, making the building exquisitely appropriate to its function. All these
label: Paragraph

text: notions find built expression, having been briefly outlined in their earlier writings, and
label: Paragraph

text: thus, the Bath buildings represent a culmination of a long career of challenging and
label: Paragraph

text: thoughtful practice.
label: Paragraph
