text: SOCTAL SECURITY COMPLEX, ISTANBUL
label: Caption

text: Designed by Sedad Hakki Eldem; completed 1970 Istanbul, Turkey
label: Caption

text: The Social Security Complex, in the historic Zeyrek district of Istanbul, was
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned by the Turkish Social Security Agency (Sosyal Sigortalar Kurumu,
label: Paragraph

text: hereafter SSK), which is the public health care and retirement office for blue-collar
label: Paragraph

text: workers. Rental offices and stores made up the bulk of the initial proposal, which also
label: Paragraph

text: comprised a health clinic, a bank, and a restaurant in addition to a cafeteria and an unbuilt
label: Paragraph

text: coffee kiosk. After winning an Aga Khan Award for Architecture in 1986, the complex
label: Paragraph

text: gained international recognition as well.
label: Paragraph

text: Designed and built between 1962 and 1970 by Sedad Hakki Eldem, the significance of
label: Paragraph

text: the project comes primarily from its being, as stated in the Aga Khan jury report, one of
label: Paragraph

text: the first examples of contextualist architecture, which combines local architectural and
label: Paragraph

text: urban forms with the universal norms of modern architecture. It was an attempt for a
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis of traditional Turkish architecture and modern materials and techniques without
label: Paragraph

text: jeopardizing the requirements of a modern office building.
label: Paragraph

text: When the competition for the SSK was held in 1962, the monolithic, glass-sheathed
label: Paragraph

text: block of the International Style was becoming susceptible to criticism because of its
label: Paragraph

text: homogenizing qualities. Accordingly, quests for locally and contextually sensitive
label: Paragraph

text: architectures were under way both in Turkey and elsewhere in the West. It should suffice
label: Paragraph

text: to remember the “vernacular” shift that occurred in the work of someone such as Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier, who had earlier been a proponent of a universal machine civilization.
label: Paragraph

text: Likewise, by the 1960s, especially in Italy, the potential contribution of the past to
label: Paragraph

text: architectural production was being extensively meditated on by Franco Albini, Ignazio
label: Paragraph

text: Gardella, and the BBPR, among others. Typological and morphological studies were also
label: Paragraph

text: being undertaken on different urban sites, the pioneer of which was the work of Saverio
label: Paragraph

text: Muratori on Venice.
label: Caption

text: In Turkey as well, typological studies of traditional residential architecture had already
label: Paragraph

text: begun under the supervision of Eldem and a few others at the Academy of Fine Arts in
label: Paragraph

text: Istanbul. Those researches would have intermittent but considerable impact on Turkish
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Eldem, while displaying different architectural tendencies during his
label: Paragraph

text: remarkably long career, nevertheless maintained a lifelong interest in traditional
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. In the 1960s, he was, together with Turgut Cansever, among the notable
label: Paragraph

text: Turkish architects who were thinking on history and locale in relation to architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The SSK project, instead of concentrating in one singular block, diffused the program
label: Paragraph

text: to smaller units that are articulated around courtyards, streets, and bypasses. Its models
label: Paragraph

text: are the traditional Ottoman ‘déillive—mostly religious complexes in which different
label: Paragraph

text: functions are fulfilled by separate buildings organized around open spaces—and the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional urban residential pattern of Istanbul displayed by the very district where it was
label: Paragraph

text: placed.
label: Paragraph

text: With its wooden houses, small mosques, medreses, and tombs, in addition to the
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantine church of Pantocrator and the Roman aqueduct, the traditional organic fabric
label: Paragraph

text: of the Zeyrek area had already been dented by the opening of Atatiirk Boulevard, which
label: Paragraph

text: cut through the district and was quickly flanked by concrete high-rises. By constituting an
label: Paragraph

text: environmentally sensitive model, one of the objectives of the SSK project was to resist
label: Paragraph

text: land speculation, which was threatening the destruction of the area. Given the threat that
label: Paragraph

text: such historic areas are under in developing countries, that consciousness raising about
label: Paragraph

text: Zeyrek’s value is a crucial contribution of the SSK.
label: Paragraph

text: Situated on a steep triangular lot between Atatiirk Boulevard and the Zeyrek slope, the
label: Paragraph

text: complex aimed to harmonize with its physical context and topography. On the north, it
label: Paragraph

text: responded to the organic urban tissue of Zeyrek, which reproduced the fragmentary form
label: Paragraph

text: and the modest scale of its wooden houses. The southeastern facade, with its tall,
label: Paragraph

text: cascading masses, was in accord with the high-rises of Atatiirk Boulevard. At the
label: Paragraph

text: northeastern tip of the lot, where the unrealized coffee kiosk would have been built, the
label: Paragraph

text: boulevard is connected to the cobblestone slope by a skillful arrangement of steps that
label: Paragraph

text: lead to a small square at the adjacent higher level. This small plaza, which utilizes an
label: Paragraph

text: existing fountain, marks the end of an “inner street” that traverses the whole complex.
label: Paragraph

text: The project consists of blocks of different sizes, heights, and functions that are
label: Paragraph

text: arranged around the two-level “inner street” running parallel to the boulevard. Each of
label: Paragraph

text: the modular units, connected at lower levels and separate at the top—from the
label: Paragraph

text: southwestern office-and-store block to the central bank-and-restaurant and clinic blocks
label: Caption

text: to the northeastern cafeteria-and-store unit—displays its architect’s lifelong interest in the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional “Turkish house.”
label: Paragraph

text: Based on solid lower levels, as in traditional residential architecture, and gradually
label: Paragraph

text: projecting toward the top, the blocks repeat the same facade elements: rows of vertical
label: Paragraph

text: windows modulated by short concrete pilasters (a characteristic of Eldem’s architecture)
label: Paragraph

text: and below them tile in-fill panels emphatically distinguished from the reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: skeleton of the building. As in his other projects, Eldem, here as well, succeeds in lending
label: Paragraph

text: the lightweight, slender appearance of timber, which is part of the image of traditional
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, to his reinforced-concrete building. Likewise, he reconciles the flat-roof
label: Paragraph

text: requirement of the brief with his interest in traditional forms by creating a historical
label: Paragraph

text: expression through the wrapping of the roofs with large eaves.
label: Paragraph

text: The end product is a geometrically disciplined modern interpretation of tradition. In
label: Paragraph

text: Atilla Yiicel’s words, “[The SSK] stands in between the spatial morphology of a
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneously grown historic Istanbul quarter and the rigid architectonic discipline of an
label: Paragraph

text: August Perret classicism.”
label: Paragraph

text: Social Security Complex, Istanbul, designed by Sedad Hakki Eldem (1970)
label: Caption

text: Photo by Mustafa Pehlivanoglu © Aga Khan Award for Architecture
label: Caption

text: The SSK stands out also within the oeuvre of its architect, who often reflects the results
label: Paragraph

text: of his typological studies at the university in his architectural work. The “Turkish house”
label: Paragraph

text: to which Eldem’s architecture alludes is often seen as an idealized type based on the
label: Paragraph

text: upper-class mansions of Istanbul and one that stands by itself, indifferent to its
label: Paragraph

text: surroundings. At the SSK, as noted by Sibel Bozdogan, Eldem, for the first time,
label: Paragraph

text: transcends the freestanding object and goes beyond building typology “into the realm of
label: Paragraph

text: urban morphology.”
label: Paragraph

text: Although the SSK had considerable influence on later Turkish architecture (as
label: Paragraph

text: displayed by the Ziraat Bankasi in Bakirkéy, among others), in time the context—the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional urban tissue—with which the building tried to establish a dialogue
label: Paragraph

text: disappeared, leaving the initial intentions of the architect irretrievably undercut. The
label: Paragraph

text: original design was further weakened by the changes in the initial functions of the blocks
label: Paragraph

text: and the conversion of the large part of the circulation spaces and stores into storages for a
label: Paragraph

text: firm that rented the building.
label: Paragraph

text: SOLAR ARCHITECTURE
label: Title

text: The technique of passive solar design—the direct use of solar energy to provide heat and
label: Paragraph

text: light in buildings—has a long history in building design. Its evolution during the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century began as a reaction to what Reyner Banham (1969) subsequently termed “a dark
label: Paragraph

text: satanic century.” Rapid urbanization during the 19th century brought with it polluted,
label: Paragraph

text: unsanitary, and over-crowded conditions to the large industrial cities of Europe and North
label: Paragraph

text: America. In England, as epidemics of disease threatened entire urban populations, liberal
label: Paragraph

text: reformers reacted against a laissez-faire attitude to city development and instead
label: Paragraph

text: promoted hygiene and sanitation as the founding principles of healthy urban planning.
label: Paragraph

text: By the beginning of the 20th century, the bactericidal properties of direct sunlight had
label: Paragraph

text: been established, and countries such as England and Germany enacted laws ensuring sun
label: Paragraph

text: rights for all citizens. In England, architects such as Raymond Unwin (1863-1940) began
label: Paragraph

text: to systematically study solar geometry with the aim of maximizing solar access in and
label: Paragraph

text: around buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout the 1920s and 1930s, the health benefits of sunlight remained a strong
label: Paragraph

text: influence in European urban planning and building design. In Germany, large residential
label: Paragraph

text: complexes, such as Siemenstadt (1929) in Berlin, master planned by Walter Gropius
label: Paragraph

text: (1883-1969), utilized the Zeilenbau (row house) form. This functional and land-efficient
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement, influenced by the spirit of the Neue Sachlichkeit (New Objectivity),
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of high-density apartment blocks running north-south and set at precise
label: Paragraph

text: distances to maximize the penetration of sunlight from the east and west. The addition of
label: Paragraph

text: roof terraces or balconies provided further opportunities for occupants to soak up the sun.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1930s, in response to the harsh economic conditions of the interwar period,
label: Paragraph

text: the emphasis in passive solar design moved away from daylighting alone. Saving fuel,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly that used for winter heating, became a design priority. By 1933, the Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: solar community of Neubthl near Zurich consisted of rows of apartments oriented almost
label: Paragraph

text: directly south with large areas of south-facing glazing to trap winter heat. However, as
label: Paragraph

text: war loomed in Europe, the most significant developments in solar energy use for home
label: Paragraph

text: heating occurred in America.
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago-based architect George Fred Keck (1895-1980) had recognized the potential
label: Paragraph

text: of passive solar heating while working on the highly glazed “House of Tomorrow,” built
label: Paragraph

text: for the 1933 Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago. In 1940, following several years
label: Paragraph

text: of experimentation with different passive solar configurations, Keck designed a house for
label: Paragraph

text: Howard Sloan, a Chicago real estate developer. The detached house, situated in
label: Paragraph

text: Glenview, Llinois, established what was to become the archetypal form of the passive
label: Paragraph

text: solar house. All the necessary elements of the house—its walls, floors, roofs, and
label: Paragraph

text: windows—were arranged to maximize the benefits of solar energy in the form of heat
label: Paragraph

text: and daylight. The rectangular plan of the house was elongated along its eastwest axis and
label: Paragraph

text: arranged with the fully glazed living spaces facing directly south. Large monopitch roofs
label: Caption

text: overhung the glazing to intercept high-angle summer sun to prevent the house from
label: Paragraph

text: overheating in summer.
label: Paragraph

text: In America, Keck’s designs received wide publicity, and the 1940s saw a growing
label: Paragraph

text: market for energy-efficient, solar homes. This period also saw significant research and
label: Paragraph

text: development into passive solar design by a group of engineers at the Massachusetts
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of Technology who constructed and monitored a series of both passive and
label: Paragraph

text: active solar homes. Despite these developments, by the 1950s a plentiful supply of cheap
label: Paragraph

text: fossil fuels diminished economic incentives for solar energy. In both domestic and
label: Paragraph

text: commercial buildings, mechanical heating, cooling, and ventilation technologies had
label: Paragraph

text: become widely established, further reducing demand for solar alternatives.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1960s and early 1970s, passive solar design enjoyed a limited rebirth
label: Paragraph

text: inspired by two fundamental concerns. First, many had begun to question the
label: Paragraph

text: technological optimism of modernism and the International Style. Architects such as
label: Paragraph

text: Ralph Erskine (1914—-) began to draw on preindustrial and indigenous building
label: Paragraph

text: techniques as the basis of a climate-specific architecture that was both regionally and
label: Paragraph

text: culturally appropriate. Second, a more overtly political environmental movement grew
label: Paragraph

text: critical of the social and environmental effects of industrial capitalism. By the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1970s, a number of autonomous cooperative communities, such as Arcosanti (1970) in
label: Paragraph

text: Arizona and The Centre for Alternative Technology (1973) in Wales, had been
label: Paragraph

text: established. For those environmentalists such as Steve Baer, who chose to live this
label: Paragraph

text: alternative lifestyle, the development of independent and renewable energy from sources
label: Title

text: such as the sun was essential. Baer’s own house (1972) in New Mexico consisted of an
label: Paragraph

text: L-shaped organic cluster of 11 “Zomes” arranged to collect solar energy through large
label: Paragraph

text: areas of south-facing glazing and then store it as heat within the thermal mass of water-
label: Paragraph

text: filled drums. At night, large insulated shutters were pulled up over the glass to retain
label: Paragraph

text: heat.
label: Paragraph

text: By the late 1970s, passive solar design was no longer the sole preserve of
label: Paragraph

text: environmentalists. The oil crisis of 1973 had generated political concerns about the long-
label: Paragraph

text: term availability of fossil fuels and had resulted in widespread academic research into the
label: Paragraph

text: use of solar energy. A number of passive solar buildings were constructed on both sides
label: Paragraph

text: of the Atlantic. During the 1980s, these concerns for energy efficiency were extended to
label: Paragraph

text: global climate issues under the rubric of sustainability. In Europe, architects such as
label: Paragraph

text: Renzo Piano and Norman Foster and Partners began to utilize passive solar features in the
label: Paragraph

text: form of daylight and shading in order to naturally air-condition large-scale buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Among many, Norman Foster and Partners’ Commerzbank Headquarters (1997) in
label: Paragraph

text: Frankfurt, Germany, successfully utilizes principles of solar design and sustainable
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: SOLERI, PAOLO 1919
label: Title

text: Architect, Italy
label: Title

text: Paolo Soleri was born in 1919 in Turin, Italy, where he studied at the Polytechnic,
label: Paragraph

text: receiving a doctorate in architecture in 1946. From 1947 to 1948, he attended Taliesin
label: Paragraph

text: West, Frank Lloyd Wright’s famous architecture studio. After practicing in southern Italy
label: Paragraph

text: and Turin in the early 1950s, he emigrated with his wife, Carolyn Woods, to the United
label: Paragraph

text: States and settled in Arizona. Soleri devoted his life to the research of alternative urban
label: Paragraph

text: development. His chief interest was in cities as a framework in which to combine human
label: Paragraph

text: and natural resources and diversity of functions and events. This study moved him to
label: Paragraph

text: explore a new concept, arcologies, environments that fused architecture and ecology.
label: Paragraph

text: His concern for the relationship between human-made objects and the earth is
label: Paragraph

text: expressed in his early Dome house (1949) designed for Leonora Woods, his future
label: Paragraph

text: mother-in-law. Located on a hillside at Cave Creek, Arizona, the house had retaining
label: Paragraph

text: walls that were cast with red boulders and concrete, following Wright’s technique. Soleri
label: Paragraph

text: also explored thermal inertia resulting from a glazed dome above the living room and the
label: Paragraph

text: excavated areas underground. The dome can be shaded or opened according to the
label: Paragraph

text: seasons.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1951, Soleri moved with his wife to southern Italy and began his explorations in
label: Paragraph

text: ceramics. His first major building, a workshop for Ceramica Artistica Solimene (1953) in
label: Paragraph

text: Vietri-sulmare, faces the Mediterranean on the Amalfi coast. It was built on reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete covered outside with pottery. Here, Soleri anticipates later explorations using
label: Paragraph

text: materials from the area and relating engineering, site, and handicraft.
label: Paragraph

text: After returning to the United States in 1955, Soleri began his project for Cosanti (from
label: Paragraph

text: the Latin “before things”) on a five-acre site in Scottsdale, Arizona. The complex grew
label: Paragraph

text: according to the needs of the community and the experience gained in construction
label: Paragraph

text: techniques. Soleri explored here the technique of wash-away silt casting, using it in
label: Paragraph

text: construction of cast-concrete architectural buildings, wind-bells, sculptures, and models.
label: Paragraph

text: Cosanti consists of several units related with the site in an organic language of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural form. The first structure was the Earth House (1956), inmersed in the site
label: Paragraph

text: after the land was excavated. The ceramic studio (1956) consisted of a structure of ribbed
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete. Other spaces are the Cosanti Gallery, with a vault formed in a
label: Paragraph

text: mound; a series of working spaces with solar devices, the piscine and canopy; and the
label: Paragraph

text: foundation offices (1971). As a comprehensive site, Cosanti provided an array of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural prototypes. This was Soleri’s first experience relating craft, work, ecology,
label: Paragraph

text: and life in one complex.
label: Paragraph

text: Soleri’s chief aim was to keep the integrity of both the natural and the urban. He
label: Paragraph

text: needed a large-scale laboratory to research and develop his model for how to inhabit
label: Paragraph

text: cities in the future. To demonstrate how to improve urban conditions and to minimize the
label: Paragraph

text: impact of destructive forces of suburbia on the environment, Soleri started Arcosanti in
label: Paragraph

text: 1971. Still in the process of construction, Arcosanti is located in Cordon Junction, 70
label: Caption

text: miles north of Phoenix in the mesa country. Soleri defines Arcosanti as an urban
label: Paragraph

text: laboratory, an instrument for research meant to accommodate up to 7,000 people. Mostly
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrian oriented, this prototype arcology project will eventually rise up to 25 stories,
label: Paragraph

text: covering only 13 acres and leaving open 860 acres.
label: Paragraph

text: Arcosanti is composed of a series of public and semipublic areas, private zones, and
label: Paragraph

text: utilities, most of which rely on passive energy. The East Crescend Complex is considered
label: Paragraph

text: the essence of arcology, combining living and working spaces. These include the Colly
label: Paragraph

text: Soleri Music Center (1989), a semipublic area dedicated to studios and diverse types of
label: Paragraph

text: private housing. Arcosanti also has two greenhouses, gardens, a small vineyard, a field,
label: Paragraph

text: and an orchard.
label: Paragraph

text: Over the last three decades, Arcosanti has been built by thousands of volunteers, all
label: Paragraph

text: sharing part of Soleri’s approach and visionary ideas about the environment. In this
label: Paragraph

text: setting, workers share a communal way of life based on production of craft, agriculture,
label: Paragraph

text: and a healthy use and inhabitation of the land. Soleri calls this approach the ethic of the
label: Paragraph

text: urban and speaks of the culture of the automobile as the instrument of isolation and
label: Paragraph

text: segmentation. In his view, our cities will require planners not only to change cities
label: Paragraph

text: physically but also to change the habits and principles of human interaction. Presently,
label: Paragraph

text: about 70 individuals live and work in Arcosanti. The community hosts a music festival,
label: Paragraph

text: exhibits, lectures, and seminars. Arcosanti remains, essentially, a laboratory for multiuse
label: Paragraph

text: architecture based on pedestrian circulation, energy efficiency, and careful solar
label: Paragraph

text: orientation.
label: Paragraph

text: One of Soleri’s recurrent themes has been the notion of bridge cities, which were
label: Paragraph

text: published by the Museum of Modern Art in The Architecture of Bridges (1948). A large
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition of his drawings of bridges and ideas about arcology held at the Corcoran
label: Caption

text: Gallery of Washington in 1970 introduced the public to his notion of miniaturization,
label: Paragraph

text: concentration, and ecological balance. Soleri has written several books and lectures all
label: Paragraph

text: over the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Arcosanti concentrated most of Soleri’s energies and efforts, he also
label: Paragraph

text: designed the University of Arizona Cancer Center Chapel (1986) in Tucson. The interior
label: Caption

text: of the chapel, stylized as a tree, has a multitude of metal wind-bells cascading from the
label: Paragraph

text: ceiling. He also designed the De Concini residence (1982) in Phoenix and produced
label: Paragraph

text: urban studies for the development of Scottsdale (1992).
label: Paragraph

text: Soleri’s experiences in Cosanti and Arcosanti inspired him to develop a meaningful
label: Paragraph

text: and alternative urban theory. His notion of “evolutionary coherence” in the city argues
label: Paragraph

text: that urban megastructures share some characteristics with the complex systems of nature.
label: Paragraph

text: Soleri is critical of the explosive growth of some metropolitan areas, such as Phoenix and
label: Paragraph

text: Los Angeles. His planning thesis is based on concentration and miniaturization. Soleri
label: Paragraph

text: has been defined as a visionary architect, urban planner, and process philosopher, and his
label: Paragraph

text: work and books have advanced a new spirituality of technology, science, habitat, and
label: Paragraph

text: humankind. His life has been devoted to experimentation in urban planning, architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: and the applied arts. His idealism and research on the relationship between inhabitation,
label: Paragraph

text: life, and work constitute his fundamental contribution.
label: Paragraph

text: SOTA, ALEJANDRO DE LA 1913-96
label: Title

text: Architect, Spain
label: Title

text: Alejandro de la Sota is the maestro of many late 20th-century Spanish architects. On
label: Paragraph

text: the one hand, he was an influential teacher at the school of architecture in Madrid from
label: Paragraph

text: 1956 to 1972. On the other, he was a master builder whose projects set an example to be
label: Paragraph

text: followed by his many disciples. It is unfortunate that his influence did not extend beyond
label: Paragraph

text: the boundaries of Spain. He was recognized internationally only in the 1980s. Born in the
label: Paragraph

text: Galician region in the northwestern part of Spain in 1913, he graduated from the school
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture at the Polytechnic of Madrid in 1941. From 1942 to 1949, he worked for a
label: Paragraph

text: central government housing and relocation agency, creating a series of rural housing
label: Paragraph

text: developments for post-civil war Spain. Although the groupings relied on a rational plan
label: Paragraph

text: and the repetition of forms, he adorned the houses with elements of vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. With the exception of this first job, all his subsequent architecture was
label: Paragraph

text: clearly modernist and characterized by its simplicity, rationalism, and abstract geometry.
label: Paragraph

text: A follower of the Modern movement, de la Sota’s building always seemed understated,
label: Paragraph

text: although his genius was ever present. De la Sota, who suffered from Parkinson’s disease
label: Paragraph

text: in his final years, died in Madrid in 1996.
label: Paragraph

text: In the buildings, projects, and furniture designs of de la Sota, the primary idea is
label: Paragraph

text: paramount. The final design is the result of a process that eliminates, little by little,
label: Paragraph

text: extraneous and unrefined aspects. In the end, what is left is pure, concentrated, but also
label: Paragraph

text: poetic. The generating idea of a project does not always come from the same source. In
label: Paragraph

text: some cases, it may be the structure, the site, a technological aspect, or a programmatic
label: Paragraph

text: intention. Functional and technical concerns become the architectural language. The
label: Paragraph

text: tectonic quality of the building is always present, as de la Sota’s works make constant
label: Paragraph

text: references to the materials of which they are constructed. Each project seems to start
label: Paragraph

text: fresh from the new situation at hand. Once de la Sota remarked that there is no reason to
label: Paragraph

text: do the same thing over and over again. He expressed the idea that each project should
label: Paragraph

text: present a new challenge and a new opportunity for exploration. De la Sota practiced
label: Paragraph

text: architecture for about 50 years, maintaining an atelier type of approach. His body of
label: Paragraph

text: work, both built and unbuilt projects, is part of the rich heritage of Spanish architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: the end of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1955, a single-family house was built in Madrid on Doctor Arce Street. The site
label: Paragraph

text: exerted its influence on the final form. The required setbacks from the property lines
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged a compact structure on the widest part of the side. The house, on a busy
label: Paragraph

text: street, looks inward. The windows to the street facade are few and small. The facade
label: Paragraph

text: toward the garden is the exact opposite, with its large windows creating a transparency
label: Paragraph

text: between interior and exterior. The entire house is made of brick with uneven surfaces that
label: Paragraph

text: catch the changing natural light. The plan is simple; the staircase, with its gentle curve,
label: Paragraph

text: seems to push out the exterior wall of the house, creating a bulge in the facade.
label: Paragraph

text: The Civil Government Offices in Tarragona (1957), really the central government
label: Paragraph

text: building in the province during Franco’s regime, shows clearly the architect’s evolving
label: Paragraph

text: vocabulary. The building, for representation, administration, and housing, is the union of
label: Paragraph

text: three blocks, each used for one purpose: The entrance is pushed underneath the main
label: Paragraph

text: podium, which itself comprises the main government floors. The top of the podium forms
label: Paragraph

text: a terrace that dominates the square in front. It also creates a break between the building
label: Paragraph

text: used for government functions and the official residences located in the cube above. A
label: Paragraph

text: modular system of 18 by 18 feet is the underlying principle of the composition. The
label: Paragraph

text: residential cube is exactly three modules by three modules. The clear use of geometry
label: Paragraph

text: and the play between voids and solids call to mind Le Corbusier and Mies van der Rohe.
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s name also surfaces with a comparison made to the Casa del Fascio. The main
label: Paragraph

text: building material is cut and polished local marble.
label: Paragraph

text: The Maravillas Gymnasium (1965) had to respond to a very difficult site with limited
label: Paragraph

text: financial resources. The narrow, trapezoidal site, about 90 feet wide, has a steep slope of
label: Paragraph

text: about 36 feet. The solution is one of fitting the building into the void and occupying the
label: Paragraph

text: entire site. An ingenious structural solution using 60-foot trusses set at right angles to the
label: Paragraph

text: street span the gymnasium. On the upper level, the 18-foot spaces between the trusses are
label: Paragraph

text: used for classrooms. Below is the gymnasium, with the benches on one side and light
label: Paragraph

text: from the windows above flowing into the other. The materials used are few and grant an
label: Paragraph

text: idea of the thin skin enclosing the space, which becomes lighter and lighter as one goes
label: Paragraph

text: up. At the lower level, the building faces a busy street and therefore has a rather closed
label: Paragraph

text: facade at street level with brick. Higher up is glass, which seems to fold back and finally
label: Paragraph

text: on top, surrounding the play space, is a wire fence.
label: Paragraph

text: The Post Office and Telecommunications Building (1984) in Leon, Spain, can be
label: Paragraph

text: thought of as a functional building employing state-of-the-art technology. It is apparently
label: Paragraph

text: a simple cube that allows work to be carried out efficiently while admitting that changes
label: Paragraph

text: in use can occur over time. The structure is simple, and the interior is filled with light.
label: Paragraph

text: The materials echo the intention of the building. It is clad in Robertson panels and uses
label: Paragraph

text: glass, stainless steel, and straightforward fixtures.
label: Paragraph

text: The projects of de la Sota, from the early works, such as the TABSA Aeronautical
label: Paragraph

text: Plant (1957) near Madrid, to his final ones, such the University Library (1993) in
label: Paragraph

text: Santiago de Compostela, although always loyal to modernism, can also be seen as a quest
label: Paragraph

text: for purity, order, and simplicity.
label: Paragraph

text: SOUTHEAST ASIA
label: Title

text: The architecture of Southeast Asia is characterized by pitched overhanging roofs and
label: Paragraph

text: elevated floor archetypes. It has developed in political entities with varying cultures and
label: Paragraph

text: histories. North and South Korea, Singapore, Thailand, and Indochina (Vietnam, Laos,
label: Caption

text: and Cambodia) were all influenced by Confucian, Buddhist, and Taoist traditions,
label: Paragraph

text: whereas the Philippines incorporated Christian and some Muslim forms, and Malaysia,
label: Paragraph

text: Brunei, and Indonesia were influenced by Hindu and Islamic architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Colonialism and Western interventions in the 20th century, especially the introduction
label: Paragraph

text: of modernism, wrought dramatic changes on the built forms of all these countries. The
label: Paragraph

text: peoples of the area have nevertheless retained traditional cultural styles, sometimes
label: Paragraph

text: expressed in their architecture. At the beginning of the 21st century, almost as a reflection
label: Paragraph

text: of the global profusion of information and images, architecture in Southeast Asia has a
label: Paragraph

text: wide range of pluralistic architectural expressions.
label: Paragraph

text: Colonial Architecture
label: Title

text: Southeast Asia’s colonizers brought different approaches to architecture and urban
label: Paragraph

text: planning. In Malaysia/Singapore the British presence led to the development of the Indo-
label: Paragraph

text: Saracenic style that began with Indian architecture, exaggerating it with a baroque
label: Paragraph

text: overlay. British-run architectural firms sprang up and helped establish this style,
label: Paragraph

text: including the influential firms of Thompson, McPherson and McNair and Palmer and
label: Paragraph

text: Tumer, who practiced in several countries. Although alternative models were provided
label: Paragraph

text: by the Malay kampung, or village settlement, and by Chinese courtyard houses and
label: Paragraph

text: shophouses, the British influence prevailed. The 1933 British town plan for Kuala
label: Paragraph

text: Lumpur established the concept of the “orderly city,” reflecting “civilised life,” for
label: Paragraph

text: British colonies worldwide, and Singapore began to expand quickly on this model.
label: Paragraph

text: In 18th-century Indonesia, the houses retained their indigenous inward orientation,
label: Paragraph

text: with courtyards and gardens, but under Dutch Colonial influence were reinterpreted in a
label: Paragraph

text: mix of Amsterdam architectures. This changed when the Dutch architect Henri Maclaine
label: Paragraph

text: Pont studied the palace architecture of Java in the 1920s and incorporated climatic and
label: Paragraph

text: cultural lessons into his own designs, as did architects such as Thomas Karsten and
label: Paragraph

text: Notodiningrat. Three outstanding examples are the campus of the Institut Technologi
label: Paragraph

text: Bandung (1920) by Maclaine Pont, Bandung’s Government Complex (1925) by J.Gerber,
label: Caption

text: and Karsten’s design for the Semarang People’s Theatre (1920s).
label: Paragraph

text: In Thailand, the only country in the region that was never colonized, the 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: kings introduced European design, leading to hybrid styles of architecture. The grand
label: Paragraph

text: Victorian Government House (c. 1905) in Bangkok was built according to drawings by
label: Paragraph

text: Italian architect Annebale Rigotti in an Italianate classical style mixed with local Oriental
label: Paragraph

text: features, which became the vogue. Another foreign-influenced work was the Khrom Phra
label: Paragraph

text: Palace (c. 1926) by the French architect Charles Bequelin; later, in the 1960s, the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of modernist architecture is apparent. However, the critic Udo Kultermann
label: Paragraph

text: notes: “An important fact to remember is that in Thailand the majority of clients were
label: Paragraph

text: Thai and the choice of architectural language was theirs,” (1986, p. 58).
label: Paragraph

text: The French governance of Indochina from 1858 to 1954 included a mission
label: Paragraph

text: civilisatrice, which in its urban design and social planning can still be felt. A great effort
label: Paragraph

text: was directed at the end of the 19th century toward the master plans and architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: Phnom Penh, Hanoi, and Haipong. The new settlements were built apart from the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional city—for example, in Hanoi, the oldest area, the “36 streets quarter,” was left
label: Paragraph

text: largely intact, and the colonial development was put on the other side of the lake.
label: Paragraph

text: Early public buildings often imitated those in France: the Opera House (1900) in Hanoi
label: Paragraph

text: by Eugene Teston was a copy of the Paris Opera, as Saigon’s Hotel de Ville (1908) by
label: Paragraph

text: Fernand Gardes was a copy of the Paris town hall. However, when Ermest Hébard was
label: Paragraph

text: called to Indochina as the first director of urbanism
label: Paragraph

text: Dharmala Sakti Office (1986) in Jakarta, Indonesia, designed by Paul Rudolph
label: Caption

text: Photo courtesy Paul Rudloph © Aga Khan Award for Architecture
label: Caption

text: in 1921, he studied the region’s ancient past and, as Gwendolyn Wright noted, “freely
label: Paragraph

text: mixed elements from different countries, in order to generate his ideal of an innovative,
label: Paragraph

text: adaptive aesthetic” (1991, p. 64). This approach is well illustrated by his Ministry of
label: Paragraph

text: Finance (1927) and the Louis Finot Museum (1931), both in Hanoi.
label: Paragraph

text: Spain heavily influenced the Philippines, a Spanish colony since 1521, in its ornate
label: Paragraph

text: religious architecture. Under American governance after 1898, it was perhaps the first
label: Paragraph

text: country in Southeast Asia to embrace the International Style and Western planning; its
label: Paragraph

text: architecture remained imitative of the West. Daniel Burnham’s Plan for Manila (1906)
label: Paragraph

text: and William Parson’s Manila Hotel (1912) are good examples. The Manila Post Office
label: Paragraph

text: (1926) by Juan Arellano recalls Schinkel’s Altes Museum in Berlin.
label: Paragraph

text: Between the World Wars the colonial powers began to sponsor Modern European
label: Paragraph

text: architecture rather than the neoclassical indigenous amalgam. As a prelude to modernism,
label: Paragraph

text: some of the finest Art Deco buildings can be found in Bandung, Indonesia. Examples are
label: Paragraph

text: the Grand Hotel Preanger (1932) by C.P.Wolff Schoemaker and the “Denis” Gebouw
label: Caption

text: (1935) by A.F.Aalbers. Kallang Airport Terminal (1937) in Singapore by the PWD and
label: Caption

text: the Central Market (1936) in Kuala Lumpur by Y.T.Lee are also Art Deco. However, the
label: Paragraph

text: aftermath of World War II brought with it the functionalism of the Modern movement
label: Paragraph

text: and continuing Western cultural domination.
label: Paragraph

text: Independence, Nationalism, and Modernity
label: Title

text: The nationalist movements brought the need to express freedom from a colonial, foreign-
label: Paragraph

text: dominated past and, beyond that, even from local traditions. This rupture with the
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic and visual past was achieved partially through new building types, such as
label: Paragraph

text: airports, parliament complexes, and state mosques, expressing a national and collective
label: Paragraph

text: identity. From the late 1950s the International Style and, to some extent, Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: monumentalism gained adherents.
label: Paragraph

text: Local architects began to be influential in Malaysia and Singapore. An early modernist
label: Paragraph

text: building of note is the Federal Hotel (1957, with a 1969 addition) by Goh Hock Guan.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps the first truly local and most important firm, the Malaysian Architects Co-
label: Paragraph

text: Partnership (1960-67), was founded by four Chinese British-trained architects who also
label: Paragraph

text: studied in the United States—William Lim, Chen Voon Fee, Lim Chin See, and Lim
label: Paragraph

text: Chong Keat. Their modernist works include the Singapore Conference Hall (1965) and
label: Paragraph

text: the Seramban Mosque (1967). Lim Chong Keat went on to found Jurbina Bertiga (Team
label: Paragraph

text: 3) and undertook major projects including the tallest structure in Penang, the Komitar
label: Paragraph

text: Complex, built between 1976-87. Other important first-generation architects include Lai
label: Paragraph

text: Lok Kun, Ruslan Khalid, and especially Hijjas Kasturi, whose Luth Building (1986) and
label: Paragraph

text: Lot 10 (1994), a metal-clad shopping center, are good examples of contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: mainstream architecture in Kuala Lumpur.
label: Paragraph

text: Malay architects began to look back to the Malay house with its pitched overhanging
label: Paragraph

text: roofs for a contemporary Malaysian identity. The earliest examples of this can be found
label: Paragraph

text: in the Language and Literacy Agency Building (1959) by Y.T. Lee and in the National
label: Caption

text: Museum (1963) by the Singaporean firm Ho Kwong Yew and Sons. Around the same
label: Paragraph

text: time, Baharuddin Abu Kassim and colleagues of the PWD were forging the expression of
label: Paragraph

text: a national Islamic identity through architecture as in the National Mosque (1965), a
label: Paragraph

text: modern building that used a folded concrete-plate parasol roof.
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese-Malay architects dominated Malaysian building until the 1970s when
label: Paragraph

text: indigenous architects, aided by an affirmative action program, began to compete more
label: Paragraph

text: successfully in the building boom. Newly established government entities such as the
label: Paragraph

text: Urban Development Authority promoted public-private joint ventures. The 1980s begat a
label: Paragraph

text: profusion of commercial blocks and mass-housing and tall office buildings, such as the
label: Paragraph

text: 35-story Dayabumi Office (1984) in Kuala Lumpur, designed by the firms MAA and
label: Caption

text: BEP.
label: Paragraph

text: A second generation of Malaysian architects includes Hajeedar, who designed the
label: Paragraph

text: Subang View Hotel (1980), and Shahroun bin Dato Haroun of Dimensa, whose
label: Paragraph

text: Condominiums (1987) are sited in Port Dickson. Ken Yeang of T.R. Hamzah and Yeang
label: Paragraph

text: designed the Plaza Atrium (1983) in Kuala Lumpur and the 31-story MBF Tower (1993)
label: Caption

text: in Penang. His own residence, Roof Roof House (1984), conceived as “an environmental
label: Paragraph

text: filter,” sparked a long-term concern with tropical architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In Singapore after World War IL, designers were both foreign and Chinese. Palmer and
label: Paragraph

text: Tumer’s 1954 Bank of China Building and Ng Keng Siang’s Asia Insurance Building
label: Title

text: (1954) are examples. After independence in 1965 modernist buildings predomi-nated,
label: Paragraph

text: including the Jurong Town Hall (1974) by Raymond Woo of Team 3 International. RDC,
label: Caption

text: founded in 1974, undertook the Science Center (1975), while the Alfred Wong
label: Paragraph

text: Partnership designed the National Theatre (1963) and Scotts Shopping Complex (1984).
label: Paragraph

text: Foreign architects designed a majority of the landmark buildings. LM.Pei did the
label: Paragraph

text: Overseas Chinese Banking Corporation (with BEP Architects in 1976), and Moshe Safdie
label: Paragraph

text: designed the Habitat Singapore (1984). Australians Geoffrey Malone and Philip Conn of
label: Paragraph

text: IPC designed the high-tech Crystal Court (1985). Kenzo Tange’s works for years
label: Paragraph

text: dominated the city skyline, including Overseas Union Bank Plaza (1983-93) and
label: Paragraph

text: TeleTech Park (1994).
label: Paragraph

text: Asia’s famous shopping centers began in Singapore with the Golden Mile Shopping
label: Paragraph

text: Centre (1972) and Peoples’ Park (1973) by Tay Kheng Soon and William Lim of DP
label: Caption

text: Architects. Lim later left DP Architects to form a smaller, more experimental practice
label: Paragraph

text: and designed many fine projects such as Unit 8 condominiums (1984), Tampines
label: Paragraph

text: Community Center (1989), and the Design School (1995) at the LaSalle-SIA College of
label: Paragraph

text: the Arts. Akitek Tenggara, Tay Kheng Soon’s firm, designed Chee Tong Temple (1987)
label: Caption

text: and the dramatic steel-and-concrete Institute of Technical Education (1993) in Bisham. A
label: Paragraph

text: new generation of architects including Manop Architects, Richard Ho, and Tangguanbee
label: Paragraph

text: produces innovative work, including the latter’s playful Institution Hill Apartments
label: Paragraph

text: Government architects also play a major role in Singapore building. The PWD did the
label: Paragraph

text: Central Provident Fund (1977) and Changi International Airport (1981 and 1990). Lee
label: Paragraph

text: Kwan Yew, the country’s long-serving president, set up government agencies for
label: Paragraph

text: physical planning of the Central Business District and the New Towns. The Housing and
label: Paragraph

text: Development Board (HDB, founded 1960) designed and built the large housing estates
label: Paragraph

text: where more than 80 per cent of Singaporeans live. Liu Thai Ker, CEO of HDB until the
label: Paragraph

text: 1990s, was perhaps the most influential planner-architect shaping the physical fabric of
label: Paragraph

text: the country. The largely successful projects have made Singapore the epitome of the
label: Paragraph

text: modern Asian city.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the desire to be modern led to the razing of old buildings and whole areas,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Chinatown. It was only in the mid-1980s that the government realized that areas
label: Paragraph

text: with character and identity were being destroyed in favor of blandness.
label: Paragraph

text: Korea’s upheavals in the 20th century led to the division of the country. While North
label: Paragraph

text: Korea followed the Soviet Union’s monumental style of architecture, South Korea’s rapid
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction in the 1960s was greatly influenced by European and American
label: Paragraph

text: internationalism and the use of concrete, giving rise to what was referred to locally as the
label: Paragraph

text: “simple-structure style,” replacing country’s traditional low-rise timber buildings with
label: Paragraph

text: tiled roofs.
label: Paragraph

text: Until the 1980s foreign architects, such as Skidmore, Owings and Merrill, with their
label: Paragraph

text: Lucky-Goldstar twin towers (1986), designed the major buildings. Western influence can
label: Paragraph

text: be seen in the works of two major Korean architects who worked for Le Corbusier in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris before returning to Seoul. Kim Swoo Geun returned in 1952; he and his practice,
label: Paragraph

text: the Space Group of Korea, designed the National Assembly (1960) and the Gumi Arts
label: Paragraph

text: Complex (1990). The second, Kim Chung-up, designed over 200 buildings, later
label: Paragraph

text: returning to tradition and local crafts as in his last work, the Olympic Gate (1988).
label: Paragraph

text: The second generation of Korean architects began to appear in the 1990s. Kim Won of
label: Paragraph

text: Kwang-Jang Architects designed the Sisters Convent of Korean Martyrs (1993) in Seoul,
label: Paragraph

text: a brick-faced complex of clear geometric forms. His Gallery Bing and Zo Kunyong’s X-
label: Paragraph

text: Plus Building (1992), both in Seoul, are good examples of ultramodernist work. The 1998
label: Paragraph

text: Olympic Games provided a great impetus for architects such as kum and Woo and
label: Paragraph

text: Williams, who designed a large housing scheme for the Olympic Village. Kyu Sung Woo
label: Paragraph

text: also designed the elegant Wanki Museum (1993) in Seoul.
label: Paragraph

text: In the Philippines, among the post independence (1946) architects were Pablo Antonio
label: Paragraph

text: with the Gonzaga Building (1957) and Angel Napkil, the Werkbund Exhibition-like
label: Paragraph

text: National Press Club (1958). The government under Ferdinand Marcos produced
label: Paragraph

text: ambitious large-scale modernist monumental buildings, many of the best examples of
label: Paragraph

text: their 20th-century architecture. The leading and most prolific architect was Leandro
label: Paragraph

text: V.Locsin, who interpreted his heritage through abstraction. Among his works are the
label: Paragraph

text: Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice (1955) in Quezon City, the Hyatt Regency Hotel (1967),
label: Caption

text: Manila, and the Berguet Center (1984) in Manaluyong. His most important design is the
label: Paragraph

text: Cultural Center in Manila (1969-76), of which the Theatre of the Performing Arts (1969)
label: Paragraph

text: is perhaps his best building. Other influential Filipino architects are Gabriel Formoso,
label: Paragraph

text: Alfredo Luz and Jorge Ramos, and the Manosa Brothers, with their San Miguel Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1984), Manila. Francisco “Bobby” Manosa’s work combines traditional materials,
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmanship and forms with contemporary needs, as in his Tahanang Pilipino (1984),
label: Paragraph

text: popularly known as the Coconut Palace due to its use of materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Under Soekarno Indonesia’s “New Order” nationalism was expressed after
label: Paragraph

text: independence in 1945 by Modern architecture and Soviet monumentalism. Examples in
label: Paragraph

text: Jakarta are the National Mosque (1962) by Siliban, the National Monument, a tall stele
label: Paragraph

text: topped by a golden flame (1945-66), and Gadjah Mada Complex (1977) by Anthony
label: Paragraph

text: Lumsden. Later, President Soeharto favored architecture of traditional values to establish
label: Paragraph

text: a unifying identity for the diverse archipelago, and in 1975 Taman Mini Indonesia
label: Paragraph

text: (Indonesia in Miniature Park) was created to display all the country’s vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: architectural styles.
label: Paragraph

text: Firms such as Atelier 6, founded in 1969, designed both modernist buildings such as
label: Paragraph

text: Lippi Headquarters (1982) in Jakarta and the vernacular-inspired Carita Beach Hotel
label: Paragraph

text: (1993) in West Java. Additions to ITB (Bandung) in the early 1990s contained
label: Paragraph

text: neovernacular buildings by Iwan Sudradjat. In 1986 a new University of Indonesia
label: Caption

text: campus at Depok, near Jakarta, planned by The Lempaga Technologi-FTUL, was
label: Paragraph

text: designed to reflect Javanese-Indonesian forms, with buildings such as the Rectorate
label: Paragraph

text: Tower (1989) by Gunawan Tjahjono and the Mosque (1992) by Trianto Y.Hardjoko that
label: Paragraph

text: clearly express this dictate.
label: Paragraph

text: Foreign architects continued to build in Thailand with John Carl Warnecke’s 1956 U.S.
label: Paragraph

text: Embassy, Robert-Mathew Johnson-Marshall’s Asian Institute of Technology (1968), both
label: Paragraph

text: in Bangkok, and Kisho Kurokawa’s Japan Studies Institute (1985) in Rangsit. The most
label: Paragraph

text: prominent Thai architect is the English-trained Sumet Jumsai, whose firm SJA+3D was
label: Paragraph

text: established in 1969—applying technological innovations to local architecture. Buildings
label: Paragraph

text: that exemplify his approach are at the Campus of Thammasat University (1986), Rangsit.
label: Paragraph

text: They are all based on a square grid; most of them are raised above ground or water and
label: Paragraph

text: are unified by prominent pitched roofs that lend traditional character. In a very different
label: Paragraph

text: vein, he explores “high-tech aesthetic” in the Science Museum (1977) and a theory of
label: Paragraph

text: “robot architecture” (reflecting interaction between humans and machines} in his
label: Paragraph

text: controversial toy robot like Bank of Asia (1986) and the Nation Building (1991), all in
label: Paragraph

text: Bangkok. The second important Thai architect is the American-trained Strabandhu
label: Paragraph

text: Ongard. His later works, the Surijasat (1978) and Khun V.Ed (1983) houses and the
label: Paragraph

text: Toshiba Headquarters (1986), present an amalgam of Thai and European architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Other prominent practitioners include CASA, Suriysat, Tiptus, and Plan Architects.
label: Paragraph

text: Elsewhere in the region, Brunei and Vietnam for example, contemporary architecture
label: Paragraph

text: continues to be dominated by nonnative architects. In Bandar Seri Bagwan, the capital o
label: Paragraph

text: Brunei, the symbolic Sultan Omar Ali Saifuddin Mosque (1958, architect unknown)
label: Caption

text: expresses Islam, whereas the sultan’s palace, Istana Nurul Iman (1984), by Locsin, is a
label: Paragraph

text: monumental modernist complex. Kenzo Tange produced the new city center (1994) o
label: Paragraph

text: Ho Chi Minh City and also the Master Plan for Brunei’s capital in 1985. Vietnam now
label: Paragraph

text: sees itself developing an architecture that is characterized by Chinese-influenced
label: Paragraph

text: shophouses, French boulevards, Soviet housing, and Western-style commercia
label: Paragraph

text: development. This sense of ecclecticism and overlay is common to much architecture in
label: Paragraph

text: the region at the beginning of the 21st century.
label: Paragraph

text: Two topics provide a reading of the region’s architecture today: one is the issue o
label: Paragraph

text: identity as exemplified through hotel design, and the other is the form of the
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary Asian city including the ubiquitous skyscraper.
label: Paragraph

text: Tourist hotels, which are economically vital for Southeast Asia, usually try to present
label: Paragraph

text: the culture of the region. They take their clue from vernacular architecture, are built in
label: Paragraph

text: beautiful settings, and include all comforts. They present an imagined authenticity, using
label: Paragraph

text: replicated forms, and also stereotype the tourist’s notions of the local culture. They are,
label: Paragraph

text: however, an important modem building type that gives an image of regional
label: Paragraph

text: homogeneity. Among the earliest is the Tandjung Sari (opened in 1962) in Sanur, Bali,
label: Paragraph

text: conceived by its owner-operator, Wija Wawo Runtu; the Bali Hyatt (1973, renovated in
label: Paragraph

text: 1994) also in Sanur, by Palmer and Turner out of Hong Kong; and the Tanjong Jara
label: Paragraph

text: Beach Hotel (1973-80) on the east coast of Malaysia, by Wimberly, Whisenand, Allison,
label: Caption

text: Tong and Goo of Hawaii. The entrepreneur Adrian Zecha, who with his architects
label: Paragraph

text: established the “Bali style,” has developed some of the most remarkable ones, the Aman
label: Paragraph

text: Resorts. The American Ed Tuttle designed the Amanpuri (1987) on Phuket Island,
label: Paragraph

text: Thailand, and the Australian Peter Muller the Amandari (1989) in Ubud, Bali. More
label: Paragraph

text: recently, alternatives to the Bali style are provided by the ecological emphasis at the Pearl
label: Paragraph

text: Farms Beach Resort (1994) on Samal Island, Mindanao, Thailand, by Bobby Manosa,
label: Caption

text: and by the search for historical references at the neo-Art Deco hotel Chedi (1993) in
label: Paragraph

text: Bandung, by Kerry Hill.
label: Caption

text: High-rise buildings adapted to the region’s climate and local technology were
label: Paragraph

text: developed in the 1980s, and Ken Yeang wrote about and built “bio climatic skyscrapers.”
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps this is most successfully explored in his award-winning high-tech, metallic office
label: Paragraph

text: building with its vertically spiraling planting, the Menara Mesiniaga (1992) in Selangor,
label: Paragraph

text: near Kuala Lumpur, and by Paul Rudolph in his Dharmala Sakti Office (1986) in Jakarta,
label: Paragraph

text: a tall concrete building of stacked roofs on pilotis (stilts) that allow for natural ventilation
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the building. The skyscraper continues to be the most prominent image of
label: Paragraph

text: progress and modernity; note Kuala Lumpur’s twin Petronas Towers, designed by Cesar
label: Paragraph

text: Pelli, which at 450 meters, were the tallest buildings in the world on completion in 1998.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite these glittering constructions, a majority of the urban population in Southeast
label: Paragraph

text: Asia is poor and lives, sometimes as squatters, in sprawling settlements. Urban
label: Paragraph

text: population distribution is distinguished by the presence of one major city—the primate
label: Paragraph

text: city—of each country, characterized by rapid and uncontrolled growth, as in Jakarta,
label: Paragraph

text: Bangkok, and Manila. A successful project that deals with the urban situation in
label: Paragraph

text: Indonesia—the Kampung Improvement Program—was instituted by the government in
label: Paragraph

text: the late 1970s. Since the 1990s private entrepreneurs have also developed new
label: Paragraph

text: settlements, as in Lippo Karawaci, near Jakarta, a major urbanism that continues to
label: Paragraph

text: expand.
label: Paragraph

text: The theory of buildings and human settlement in the tropics found its voice (among
label: Paragraph

text: others in a multitude of disciplines) in architects Shlomo Angel, William Lim, Ken
label: Paragraph

text: Yeang, and Tay Kheng Soon. Their concern with expressing an abstraction of a pan-
label: Paragraph

text: Southeast Asian identity, instead basing it on regional or ethnic identity, has led to
label: Paragraph

text: notions of a modern tropical city. It is likely that their ideas will find form in the 21st
label: Paragraph

text: century. Tay’s Development Guide Plan for Kampung Bugis (1989) and Yeang’s JB2005
label: Paragraph

text: (1994) are excellent examples of this new thinking.
label: Paragraph

text: SOUTO DE MOURA, EDUARDO 1952
label: Title

text: Architect, Portugal
label: Title

text: Among the vanguard of modern Portuguese architects, Eduardo Souto de Moura
label: Paragraph

text: emerges from a recently revitalized architectural tradition that was singularly rich in the
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance and baroque periods. In the transition from the 15th to the 16th centuries,
label: Paragraph

text: with astounding wealth accruing from a growing number of colonies, Portugal
label: Paragraph

text: experienced a flourish of late Gothic building. This was the Manueline period, named for
label: Paragraph

text: Manuel | (reigned 1495-1521) under whom colonies in southern Africa, the Indies, the
label: Paragraph

text: Far East, and Brazil were discovered and settled. In the 18th century, with gold and
label: Paragraph

text: diamonds flowing into the country from Brazil, the Portuguese baroque reached one of its
label: Paragraph

text: most intense periods.
label: Paragraph

text: During most of the 20th century though, economically stagnant and politically
label: Paragraph

text: authoritarian, the only “modern” construction of buildings in Portugal were scattered
label: Paragraph

text: examples of a neoclassical block-like fascist structures. The impetus for modernist
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in the Portuguese-speaking world came not from Portugal but from Brazil,
label: Paragraph

text: primarily with the inauguration in 1960 of Brasilia. That futuristic capital’s signature
label: Paragraph

text: structures, the presidential residence, the cathedral, the Congress, and the Foreign Office
label: Paragraph

text: reflected the influence of Le Corbusier as interpreted with lyrical, tropical exuberance by
label: Paragraph

text: Lucio Costa and Oscar Niemeyer. Aesthetically Portugal itself only became free to
label: Paragraph

text: follow this style after the democratic revolution of 1974. Financially it only became
label: Paragraph

text: capable of supporting a significant increase in building after admission into the European
label: Paragraph

text: Union and the consequent growth of its economy.
label: Paragraph

text: Souto de Moura was born in the north of Portugal on 25 July 1952 in the country’s
label: Paragraph

text: second-largest city, Porto (also referred to as Oporto). It was there from the Escola de
label: Paragraph

text: Belas Artes that in 1980 he received his degree in architecture. He forms the third
label: Paragraph

text: generation in the Portuguese architectural “School of Oporto.” This movement originated
label: Paragraph

text: among young architects at the fine arts school in Porto during the decade of the 1960s,
label: Paragraph

text: the waning years of the Salazar dictatorship and its debilitating colonial wars in
label: Paragraph

text: Portuguese Africa. The Atlantic harbor of Porto, lying on the Douro River, is generally
label: Paragraph

text: known to the outside world for the port wine named after it, which originates from the
label: Paragraph

text: vineyards in the valley of the Douro. To those who live in Porto, however, the city is
label: Paragraph

text: known for the industriousness of its small businessmen, merchants, and manufacturers.
label: Paragraph

text: With the post-World War Il growth of European and coastal Atlantic trade, its
label: Paragraph

text: metropolitan area expanded to half a million people. This growth required much new
label: Paragraph

text: construction together with significant remodeling of older buildings. Responding to these
label: Paragraph

text: building and design needs were Portuguese architects trained in the School of Oporto.
label: Paragraph

text: The school began with the ideas of Fernando Tavora (1923—), seeking in the late 1950s
label: Paragraph

text: for a modernist building style that was socially responsible and allowed economy in the
label: Paragraph

text: use of basic forms and materials. This led him to minimalism and Alvar Aalto’s concepts
label: Paragraph

text: regarding discrete yet organically integrated construction elements. The great disciple of
label: Paragraph

text: Tavora was Alvaro Siza Vieira (1933-), whose purist poetic style won him the 1992
label: Paragraph

text: Pritzker architecture award. One of the leading students and longtime colleagues of Siza
label: Paragraph

text: Vieira has been Souto de Moura.
label: Paragraph

text: Like his predecessors, much of Souto de Moura’s work has been in Porto and cities in
label: Paragraph

text: the north of Portugal, particularly Braga and Evora. Throughout most of his career he has
label: Paragraph

text: designed houses, among his most famous works, and commercial spaces. He has also
label: Paragraph

text: done extensive restoration of historic and domestic structures. He has taught in Zurich
label: Paragraph

text: and Lausanne, and beginning in the late 1980s his work assumed a more international
label: Paragraph

text: projection, especially in Italy.
label: Paragraph

text: In Porto he has built or restored numerous houses and apartments, medical buildings, a
label: Paragraph

text: library, a museum, and a customs building. Possessing his own minimalist style, the
label: Paragraph

text: effectiveness of his work is borne by a subtle juxtaposition of elementary building
label: Paragraph

text: materials: stone, wood, glass, and metal. He incorporates these elements in structures
label: Paragraph

text: whose dramatic weight is often conveyed in basic geometric shapes of rectangles,
label: Paragraph

text: squares, cubes, cylinders, and circles.
label: Paragraph

text: Two important early works were the plan for the city market in Braga (1980-84) and
label: Paragraph

text: the “Casa das Artes” cultural center in Porto (1981-91). The city of Braga has now
label: Paragraph

text: outgrown the former, and he is redesigning the area as a complex of shops and cafes. The
label: Paragraph

text: cultural center projected a striking model that concentrated the accumulated design
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of international modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Most significant, though, was a small weekend home built in the Algarve (1984-89), in
label: Paragraph

text: the south of Portugal. Its all-white elements presented a subdued profile of long
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular walls over which hovered the low silhouette of a dome and, varying with the
label: Paragraph

text: angle of view, a triangle and cylinder. Occupying only one-fifth of the lot on which it
label: Paragraph

text: lies, the structure establishes a balance of subdued tensions between itself and its setting.
label: Paragraph

text: Of further significance has been a series of residences he has built since the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1980s in Nevogilde, a developing seaside neighborhood of Porto. On more restricted
label: Paragraph

text: terrains, these houses also have demonstrated a style achieved through balancing subdued
label: Paragraph

text: forces of contrast in structure and environment. However, they furthermore demonstrate
label: Paragraph

text: his command of interiors, a spare equilibrium of the elements of space and light, and a
label: Paragraph

text: progressive integration of a spectrum of structural elements, stone, wood, and glass,
label: Paragraph

text: respecting principles of Mies van der Rohe. In Braga he built (1989-94) a two-story
label: Paragraph

text: house that strikingly balances a stone environment on the lower floor with a glass one on
label: Paragraph

text: the upper.
label: Paragraph

text: Among his more recent and significant challenges have been designing a civic center
label: Paragraph

text: in Sicily, converting a monastery into a country inn, and redesigning the customs center
label: Paragraph

text: of Porto. He has received numerous awards and honors in Portugal and abroad, including
label: Paragraph

text: an Italian one for his use of stone. In 1998 he was the first architect to receive the coveted
label: Paragraph

text: Portuguese cultural distinction, the Premio Pessoa. In the same year the Swiss-Italian city
label: Paragraph

text: of Mendrisio mounted a retrospective exhibition of his work, emphasizing his skill for
label: Paragraph

text: balancing structures in terms of their component parts and their placement within an
label: Paragraph

text: environment.
label: Paragraph

text: SPACE FRAME
label: Title

text: A distinctly 20th-century structural form, the space frame is a three-dimensional system
label: Paragraph

text: that transfers gravitational and lateral loads through a network of interconnected
label: Paragraph

text: structural elements. In this efficient system, the load path is completely controlled,
label: Paragraph

text: utilizing mainly straight elements that are securely joined together to safely transfer
label: Paragraph

text: applied loads to other structural subsystems. The effectiveness of their structural form
label: Paragraph

text: comes from three factors. First, unlike other structural forms where entire members are
label: Paragraph

text: sized on the basis of maximum stresses that occur at singular points along their elements,
label: Paragraph

text: the peak stresses in lattice space structures are distributed more evenly through the use of
label: Paragraph

text: members transferring mainly tension and compression forces and, as such, requiring
label: Paragraph

text: smaller cross-sectional profiles. Second, the fact that they are highly indeterminate
label: Paragraph

text: structures causes stress redistribution in the event of one member or more failing during
label: Paragraph

text: the life expectancy of such frames. This fact allows for the increase in allowable design
label: Paragraph

text: code stresses and leads to smaller members. Third, coupled with their structural
label: Paragraph

text: efficiency, their simplified and repetitive assembly techniques afford them the versatility
label: Paragraph

text: to take on either flat or curved forms, making them systems of choice for designers and
label: Paragraph

text: builders.
label: Paragraph

text: Space frames are seen as an evolutionary step in the eternal quest for building and
label: Paragraph

text: spanning more with less natural resources and increased cost-effectiveness. Earlier efforts
label: Paragraph

text: to construct lighter-weight structural forms included Schwedler’s fully triangulated
label: Paragraph

text: framed domes in 1863. Even the famed Dr. Alexander Graham Bell experimented with
label: Paragraph

text: such spatial structural forms when, in 1907, he illustrated their effectiveness as structural
label: Paragraph

text: systems by building a tetrahedron-based frame that could be used for the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: kites, airplanes, and building structures. In 1942, architect Charles Atwood developed the
label: Paragraph

text: Unistrut system, consisting of steel elements bolted into a flat gusset plate to form a space
label: Paragraph

text: frame.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the major innovation in space frames came about when Dr. Max
label: Paragraph

text: Mengeringhausen introduced his Mero system in 1943. His system gave birth to today’s
label: Paragraph

text: space frame technology. Consisting of up to 18 hollow steel tubes that can be screwed
label: Paragraph

text: into a steel ball at the same time to form a single joint, the system simply and
label: Paragraph

text: expeditiously builds a huge network of solidly connected members to form a long span
label: Paragraph

text: structure.
label: Paragraph

text: Later, during World War Il, the military realized the massproduction and
label: Paragraph

text: prefabrication potential of such systems and utilized them in such structures as radar
label: Paragraph

text: domes. In the 1950s, designers such as Konrad Wachsmann were developing space frame
label: Paragraph

text: systems similar to the Mero. An example of Wachsmann’s tetrahedral tubular space
label: Paragraph

text: frame system is a U.S. Air Force hangar that measured 240 by 155 meters with a 50-
label: Paragraph

text: meter cantilevered roof extending in both directions. Buckminster Fuller also invented
label: Paragraph

text: geodesic domes known as “tensegrity” structures that became very popular optimal
label: Paragraph

text: building forms in the 1960s and 1970s and led to the publication of the do-it-yourself
label: Paragraph

text: books Domebook One and Domebook Two.
label: Paragraph

text: Expo ‘67 in Montreal featured space frame structures that opened the eyes of designers
label: Paragraph

text: and builders alike to the potential of such building forms. The 1970s witnessed an
label: Paragraph

text: eruption of space frames being used for airplane hangars, huge roofing systems, and
label: Paragraph

text: efficient building frames. The British Airways 01 hangar at Heathrow Airport, designed
label: Caption

text: by professor Z.S.Makowski, is a primary example of large roofing construction. The
label: Paragraph

text: hangar spans 135 meters, accommodates two jumbo jets at the same time, utilizes tubular
label: Paragraph

text: hollow sections, and can be mechanically jacked up in anticipation of future larger
label: Paragraph

text: aircraft. The Interfirst Bank Building (1981) in Dallas, Texas, designed by Skidmore,
label: Caption

text: Owings and Merrill, is an example of the versatility in the form design of space frame,
label: Paragraph

text: which matched the half-pyramid shape of the building itself.
label: Paragraph

text: The advent of faster and more accessible computational power to structural engineers
label: Paragraph

text: allowed for an explosion in the amount of shape complexity and design optimization of
label: Paragraph

text: those structural forms. The Javits Convention Center (1987) in New York City, designed
label: Paragraph

text: by I.M.Pei and Partners, is a primary example of how computer analyses allowed the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of such complex building shapes.
label: Paragraph

text: The attractive properties of high strength-to-weight ratios and considerable torsional
label: Paragraph

text: stiffness did not escape the everwatchful eyes of the aerospace industry, which started
label: Paragraph

text: utilizing the technology in their air-space frames. At the same time, the car
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturing industries began as early as the 1950s utilizing space frames in their high-
label: Paragraph

text: performance car chassis. Today, Audi’s A8 luxury car uses a very sophisticated form of
label: Paragraph

text: aluminum space frame for its chassis. The frame was designed in concert with Alcoa and
label: Paragraph

text: required 40 patents, ten years, and seven new aircraft aluminum alloys.
label: Paragraph

text: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration also invested for decades in space
label: Paragraph

text: frame research. The result is its U.S. Laboratory module for the International Space
label: Paragraph

text: Station currently under construction at the Marshall Space Flight Center station
label: Caption

text: manufacturing facility in Huntsville, Alabama. However, perhaps the epitome of
label: Paragraph

text: computer and space frame construction technologies coming together is the Fremont
label: Paragraph

text: Street Experience Light and Sound Show in Las Vegas, Nevada. A 90-foot-high steel
label: Caption

text: space frame, completed in September 1995, provides a high-tech display canopy over a
label: Paragraph

text: 1,400-foot stretch of the Fremont Street and serves also as a spectacular foyer for existing
label: Paragraph

text: casino and hotel resorts in the Las Vegas downtown district. The frame is arched, being 5
label: Paragraph

text: feet deep and 44 feet in curved radius. The inside of the canopy contains 2.1 million light
label: Paragraph

text: bulbs acting like television pixels and fully controlled by 21 computers generating
label: Paragraph

text: animated images perfectly syncopated to sound. The computer-generated light and sound
label: Paragraph

text: show is produced using concert-quality sound emanating from a system of 208 speakers
label: Paragraph

text: capable of generating 540,000 watts. Unofficially, this space frame is considered to be
label: Paragraph

text: the world’s largest graphics display system.
label: Paragraph

text: Today, there are tens of thousands of space frames all over the world. The future likely
label: Paragraph

text: will witness an even greater reliance on space frame construction for the simple reason
label: Paragraph

text: that computer, materials, manufacturing, and construction technologies are constantly
label: Paragraph

text: evolving and successfully thriving to reduce cost with improved products. As such, in the
label: Paragraph

text: very near future, architects, structural designers, and builders will have the option of
label: Paragraph

text: designing and building space frames out of materials that are far superior in strength and
label: Paragraph

text: much lower in weight than any of the currently conventional materials and methods.
label: Paragraph

text: Primary examples of such construction materials are fiber-reinforced plastic composites.
label: Paragraph

text: Their industry is extremely prolific, and they are light-weight, corrosion resistant, and
label: Paragraph

text: ideal for tailoring their fiber orientations to optimally resist principal stresses induced
label: Paragraph

text: under any loading conditions.
label: Paragraph
