text: SPAIN
label: Title

text: Spanish architecture of the 20th century has exhibited a dynamic eclecticism that is
label: Paragraph

text: rooted in the country’s turbulent political history and in the persistent individualism of its
label: Paragraph

text: historically autonomous provinces. The Castilian capital of Madrid and the Catalonian
label: Paragraph

text: capital of Barcelona were the epicenters of the nation’s architectural achievement
label: Paragraph

text: throughout much of the century, each having gained international recognition for both
label: Paragraph

text: their architecture schools and their architects of distinction.
label: Paragraph

text: By the early 20th century, Barcelona’s dramatic population growth prompted city
label: Paragraph

text: officials to address its urban expansion through an international competition that was
label: Paragraph

text: ultimately won by the French Beaux-Arts architect Léon Jaussely (1875-1932), whose
label: Paragraph

text: scheme was modified for implementation in 1917. At the same time, Antoni y Cornet
label: Paragraph

text: Gaudi’s (1852-1926) idiosyncratic use of Art Nouveau, Gothic, and Moorish influences,
label: Paragraph

text: evident in such projects as the Sagrada Familia (Expiatory Church of the Holy Family,
label: Paragraph

text: 1882-1926), dominated Catalan modernisme, a regional movement characterized by an
label: Paragraph

text: interest in aesthetic and political separatism coupled with a respect for traditional
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmanship and a personalized vocabulary of ornamentation. His structural
label: Paragraph

text: experimentation and militant interest in creating a distinctively regional form of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture had a profound impact on his contemporaries, Lluis Doménech i Montaner
label: Paragraph

text: (1849-1923) and Josep Puig i Cadafalch (1869-1957), as well as subsequent generations
label: Paragraph

text: of Barcelonese architects.
label: Paragraph

text: Antonio Palacios y Ramilo (1876-1945) was the primary architectural force in the
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish capital of Madrid. His grandiose Palacio de Correos y Communicaciones (1918)
label: Caption

text: went beyond the city’s Beaux-Arts classicism and its neo-Plateresque references in its
label: Paragraph

text: free use of space and light as well as in its indebtedness to the Wagnerschule of Vienna.
label: Paragraph

text: Palacios’ role as a professor at the Escuela de Arquitectura de Madrid (ETSAM) and as
label: Paragraph

text: an academician of the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando ensured his
label: Paragraph

text: impact on early 20th-century Madrilefio architecture; his brand of Beaux-Arts eclecticism
label: Paragraph

text: came to populate the Gran Via, a major artery through the city’s old slums that was
label: Paragraph

text: created between 1910 and 1930.
label: Paragraph

text: Fernando Garcia Mercadal (1895-1984), a 1921 graduate of ETSAM, led the group of
label: Paragraph

text: young architects known as the “Generation of 1925” to embrace contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: architectural avant-gardism after spending four years traveling on a Pension de Roma
label: Paragraph

text: (Rome Prize) study grant. His encounters with Peter Behrens (1920), Josef Hoffmann
label: Paragraph

text: (1924), Le Corbusier (1925), and Adolf Loos (1927) led him to introduce certain
label: Paragraph

text: rationalist tendencies in such projects as his small pavilion, the Rincén de Goya (1928,
label: Paragraph

text: demolished in the Spanish civil war}, in Zaragoza. In April of the same year, Garcia
label: Paragraph

text: Mercadal edited an issue of La Gaceta Literaria (The Literary Gazette) that was
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated solely to the theme “New Art in the World: Architecture, 1928” and that
label: Paragraph

text: featured an illustrated survey of the Dessau Bauhaus, quoted passages by Henry Van de
label: Paragraph

text: Velde and Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, as well as essays written by some of Garcia
label: Paragraph

text: Mercadal’s leading contemporaries. The group’s crowning achievement, the Madrid
label: Paragraph

text: university campus (1936), reconciled avant-garde eclecticism with the new rationalism
label: Paragraph

text: but was largely destroyed during the Spanish civil war (1936-39).
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus utopianism directly impacted the Spanish architectural scene of the 1930s
label: Paragraph

text: after Mies van der Rohe inaugurated his German Pavilion at the Barcelona International
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition of 1929. Standing for less than eight months, this linchpin of 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: avant-gardism provided a fluid architectural space of glass, water, marble, and travertine
label: Paragraph

text: and came to epitomize the precepts of the International Style.
label: Paragraph

text: The creation in 1930 of the Grupo de Arquitectos y Técnicos Esparioles para la
label: Paragraph

text: Arquitectura Contemporanea (GATEPAC) in Zaragoza was of significant importance to
label: Paragraph

text: the promotion in Spain of utopian modernism by the Congrés Internationaux
label: Paragraph

text: d’Architecture Moderne (CLAM) and the Comité international pour la Realisation des
label: Paragraph

text: Problemes d’Architecture Contemporaine (CIRPAC). GATEPAC’s rationalist aims,
label: Paragraph

text: articulated in the magazine A.C. (1931-27) and manifested in the early works of the
label: Paragraph

text: Catalonian Josep Lluis Sert (1902-83), came to be associated with the International Style
label: Paragraph

text: and especially the architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: Sagrada Familia, designed by Antoni Gaudi, Barcelona (1882-1926)
label: Caption

text: © Donald Corner and Jenny Young/GreatBuildings.com
label: Caption

text: Le Corbusier. The Catalonian group of GATEPAC forged direct connections with the
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss visionary: at the Fourth CIRPAC Congress, Le Corbusier assisted the group in
label: Paragraph

text: designing a new urban study for the city of Barcelona (Macia plan, 1935).
label: Paragraph

text: The rise of modernist architecture was stemmed by the Spanish civil war and the
label: Paragraph

text: establishment of the Franco regime (1939-75), which ultimately resulted in the
label: Paragraph

text: dissolution of GATEPAC and the exodus of many of the nation’s leading architects,
label: Paragraph

text: including Sert, who became dean of Harvard University’s Graduate School of Design.
label: Paragraph

text: Architects remaining in Spain were disconnected from the world’s architectural
label: Paragraph

text: community: access to documentation and foreign-language publications was minimalized
label: Paragraph

text: under Franco’s censors, and much of the Madrid Architecture Library had been destroyed
label: Paragraph

text: during the war years. Public building projects encouraged during the early years of the
label: Paragraph

text: dictatorship were generally antimodernist, with autarchic tendencies gleaned from the
label: Paragraph

text: classical architectural tradition in Spain, in which mimetic references to Rome’s legacy
label: Paragraph

text: on the Iberian peninsula and Philip II’s El Escorial (1582, Juan Bautista Toledo and Juan
label: Paragraph

text: de Herrera), the Renaissance palace and monastery outside Madrid, were highly
label: Paragraph

text: desirable. The Catalan-born José Antonio Coderch y de Sentmenat (1913-84) was the
label: Paragraph

text: most remarkable architect of the period. His ability to reconcile GATEPAC-era
label: Paragraph

text: rationalism, the vernacular traditions of Mediterranean villa architecture, the
label: Paragraph

text: Scandinavian organicism of Eric Gunnar Asplund and Alvar Aalto, and the austere
label: Paragraph

text: outlines and creative spatial layouts of Bruno Zevi resulted in private seaside homes of
label: Paragraph

text: great ingenuity. His use of local materials, in many instances brick and tile, along with a
label: Paragraph

text: so-called deep plan, became characteristics of the later Barcelona School (e.g., Ugalde
label: Paragraph

text: House, 1952, in Caldes d’Estrac; Apartment Building, 1954, in La Barceloneta).
label: Caption

text: During the early 1950s, Spain’s autarchic isolationist philosophy dissipated; new
label: Paragraph

text: interchanges were established with democratic nations, and Spain’s economic system was
label: Paragraph

text: bolstered by a new liberalism and a sizable monetary credit from the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: In Barcelona, “Group R” (1951-59) sought an imbrication of the regional Catalonian
label: Paragraph

text: architectural tradition with the rationalist idiom of such exiled architects as Sert. Meeting
label: Paragraph

text: formally for some eight years and organizing courses such as “Economics and Urban
label: Paragraph

text: Development” and “Sociology and Urban Development,” this group eventually
label: Paragraph

text: transformed into the so-called Barcelona School. Studio Per, Josep Martorell Codina
label: Caption

text: (1925-), Ricardo Bofill Levi (1939-), Oriol Bohigas Guardiola (1925—), and others were
label: Paragraph

text: able to explore the Group R ideals of rationalism and “poetic realism” under the Franco
label: Paragraph

text: regime primarily through commissions from the private sector (such as Editorial Gustavo
label: Paragraph

text: Gili, 1961, Bassé and Gili; Argentona House, 1955, Martorell and Bohigas; and
label: Paragraph

text: Meridiana Building, 1966, MBM). The Barcelona School came to reject the notion of a
label: Paragraph

text: utopian industrialized society and sought to redefine local and traditional construction
label: Paragraph

text: processes; as such, it was especially influenced by English New Brutalism and Italian
label: Paragraph

text: neorealism.
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporary attempts to establish connections with international modernism
label: Title

text: remained isolated in Madrid and were dependent on the influx of translated versions of
label: Paragraph

text: such authors as Zevi and Sigfried Giedion and the increasing ability for Spaniards to
label: Paragraph

text: travel outside the Iberian peninsula. Historian Juan Daniel Fullaondo, inspired especially
label: Paragraph

text: by the antirationalist leanings of Zevi, sought to create a new Madrid School around the
label: Paragraph

text: peri-odical Nueva Forma (New Form), and the Galician architect Alejandro de la Sota
label: Paragraph

text: (1913-) adopted an essentialist language far removed from the Franco regime’s
label: Paragraph

text: ideological framework of isolation and tradition (for example Gobierno Civil, 1957, in
label: Paragraph

text: Tarragona). Nonetheless, it was not until José Antonio Corrales (1921—-) and Ramon
label: Paragraph

text: Vazquez Molezun (1922) unified a simple geometric form on an irregular multileveled
label: Paragraph

text: site at the Exposition Universelle et Internationale in Brussels that a new era of freedom
label: Paragraph

text: in Spanish architecture was launched (Spanish Pavilion, 1958, World Expo).
label: Paragraph

text: From the 1960s on, as the urban fabric of Spain’s leading cities continued to stretch
label: Paragraph

text: along with the nation’s economic expansion, many of its architects became increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: engaged in solving problems associated with postindustrial urbanization, such as public
label: Paragraph

text: housing, integration between architecture and landscape, and the design of transportation
label: Title

text: infrastructures. The cities of Barcelona, Madrid, and Bilbao became epicenters of public
label: Paragraph

text: architecture with a social conscience as their perimeters burgeoned with shantytowns of
label: Paragraph

text: displaced workers from the country’s impoverished regions. A prominent advocate of the
label: Paragraph

text: primacy of the individual in an urban context, Coderch devoted the last decade of his life
label: Paragraph

text: to reconciling the autonomous apartment unit with the unified apartment block. After
label: Paragraph

text: nearly three decades of isolation from the world scene, Spanish architecture as a whole
label: Paragraph

text: became more widely disseminated in publications and exhibitions and more prominently
label: Paragraph

text: recognized as an increasing number of the nation’s architects began to gain international
label: Paragraph

text: attention and acclaim.
label: Paragraph

text: General Franco’s death in November 1975 propelled Spanish culture into a period of
label: Paragraph

text: significant changes; especially marked was the change from an authoritarian regime to a
label: Paragraph

text: constitutional monarchy and a democratic state as well as the partial restoration of the
label: Paragraph

text: nation’s historically autonomous provinces, which resulted in a renewed fervor to mark
label: Paragraph

text: the built environment with an emphatically regionalist aesthetic. Additionally, the
label: Paragraph

text: country’s architecture schools notably underwent significant modifications: increased
label: Paragraph

text: staffing by professional architects, greater specialization and diversification, and an
label: Paragraph

text: interest in redefining the architectural school as an intellectual forum. In the early 1970s,
label: Paragraph

text: the contemporary design theories of Aldo Rossi’s L’architettura della citta (1966;
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture and the City) and Robert Venturi’s Complexity and Contradiction in
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture (1966) became available in Castilian translations, and a number of new
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish architectural publications emerged, most notably the Italian-influenced 2C
label: Paragraph

text: Construccion de la Ciudad (1972-85; Construction of the City) and the more pragmatic
label: Paragraph

text: Catalonian Arquitectura Bis (1974 and later).
label: Paragraph

text: Oriol Bohigas, who in 1981 became the director of urbanism for the City of Barcelona,
label: Paragraph

text: promoted a regionalist urbanization program for the Catalonian capital. In the process,
label: Paragraph

text: much of the city was redesigned, and its distinctive neighborhoods, or barrios, were
label: Paragraph

text: revitalized with new plazas and parks. Helio Pifién (1942-) and Alberto Viaplana’s
label: Paragraph

text: (1933—) minimalist Plaga dels Paisos Catalans (1983, also called the Plaza de la Estacion
label: Paragraph

text: de Sants, designed along with Enric Miralles) was the first of a series of urban spaces
label: Paragraph

text: called plazas duras (“hard” squares) created under Bohigas’ administration that helped
label: Paragraph

text: establish Barcelona as a leading center of modern urban renewal and the host for the
label: Paragraph

text: 1992 summer Olympic Games.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1986, the Andalusian capital of Seville was officially proclaimed the site of the 1992
label: Paragraph

text: Universal Exposition commemorating the fifth centenary of the discovery of America.
label: Paragraph

text: This selection, as in the case of Barcelona, prompted a large-scale urban-renewal
label: Paragraph

text: program that included the redesign of the city’s transportation and communication
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructures and the renovation of the so-called La Cartuja district, a man-made
label: Paragraph

text: “island” along the Guadalquivir River. Neorationalist adherent Rafael Moneo (1937-)
label: Caption

text: sensitively designed the new airport to reflect its Sevillian roots, with austere Moorish-
label: Paragraph

text: inspired arches and a series of blue domes illuminated by a central oculus. Moneo’s
label: Paragraph

text: former students Antonio Cruz Villalén and Antonio Ortiz Garcia created the Santa Justa
label: Paragraph

text: Railway Station, a project that aligned the new transportation hub with a distinctively
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish Postmodernism.
label: Paragraph

text: The Franco regime’s continued promotion of mimetic architectural historicism deterred
label: Paragraph

text: many young Spanish architects of the 1980s from utilizing a postmodernist idiom;
label: Paragraph

text: however, Bofill and Oscar Tusquets (1941—) adopted postmodern tendencies that are
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the former’s INEF Building (1991) and the latter’s Mas Abello Housing
label: Paragraph

text: Complex (1990), both in Barcelona. A more expressive architectural language, the
label: Paragraph

text: inheritor of the legacy of Antoni Gaudi, was adopted by the Valencia-born Santiago
label: Paragraph

text: Calatrava (1951—), whose bridge and recent museum designs are neosurrealist versions of
label: Paragraph

text: avian osteomorphic forms.
label: Paragraph

text: In the latter decades of the century, both public and private sectors have contributed
label: Paragraph

text: significantly to the advance of innovative architecture by employing progressive young
label: Paragraph

text: architects. Regions such as the Basque provinces, Andalusia, and Valencia—bolstered by
label: Paragraph

text: the economic expansion correlated to the nation’s acceptance into the European
label: Paragraph

text: community in 1986—have promoted highly individualized and internationally recognized
label: Paragraph

text: building projects, including Frank Gehry’s titanium-sheathed Guggenheim Museum
label: Paragraph

text: (1997) in Bilbao and Giorgio Grassi’s University Library (1999) on the Nou-Campus in
label: Paragraph

text: Valencia.
label: Paragraph

text: ST. PETERSBURG (LENINGRAD), RUSSIA
label: Caption

text: At the beginning of the 20th century, St. Petersburg was in the midst of a transformation
label: Paragraph

text: of commercial and living space that had begun in the 1860s and would continue until
label: Paragraph

text: World War I. Although the great imperial monuments remained standing, practically
label: Paragraph

text: everything around them was rebuilt during this period in an eclectic array of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: styles, including the style moderne. The densely constructed St. Petersburg environment
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of buildings within a city plan that followed the straightedge wherever its
label: Paragraph

text: deltaic terrain permitted. The city’s height restrictions, which limited most construction at
label: Paragraph

text: five or six stories, also encouraged perspectival uniformity.
label: Paragraph

text: In this setting, the plasticity of structure and material that characterized the style
label: Paragraph

text: moderne in Moscow frequently assumed a two-dimensional form that depended on the
label: Paragraph

text: texture and shaping of the facade of contiguous apartment buildings. Of the several
label: Paragraph

text: hundred building projects undertaken in the city between 1898 and 1915, only a small
label: Paragraph

text: fraction applied the new style in anything other than a fragmentary, decorative manner.
label: Paragraph

text: There were, nonetheless, architects whose work defined a distinctive variant of the new
label: Paragraph

text: style known as the “Northern modeme.” Fedor Lidval (1870-1945) was the most
label: Paragraph

text: productive among them, and his career ranged from the early moderne to the more
label: Paragraph

text: austere neoclassical revival. Lidval’s buildings—primarily large apartment houses and
label: Paragraph

text: banks—also illustrate the developing links between large construction projects and
label: Paragraph

text: private capital resources in St. Petersburg.
label: Paragraph

text: Among other architects active in the apartment construction boom, the work of Aleksei
label: Paragraph

text: Bubyr is notable for its original approach to structure as a sculpted, textured block. A
label: Paragraph

text: 1902 graduate of the Institute of Civil Engineering, Bubyr often collaborated with the
label: Paragraph

text: architect Nikolai Vasilev, who also designed a number of large housing projects in St.
label: Paragraph

text: Petersburg. Yet Bubyr himself developed a distinctive interpretation of the rationalist side
label: Paragraph

text: of the style moderne, with equal attention to aesthetics and engineering. In the latter area,
label: Paragraph

text: he was a pioneer in the use of reinforced concrete for the walls as well as the floor
label: Paragraph

text: construction of apartment buildings, and this familiarity with new construction methods
label: Paragraph

text: is reflected in the free style of even his largest structures.
label: Paragraph

text: The apartment house that Bubyr built in 1910-12 on the Fontanka Quay (no. 159) is
label: Paragraph

text: striking not only for its lack of ornamentation but also for its massive outline, looming
label: Paragraph

text: above the largest of St. Petersburg’s canals. In constructing the facade, Bubyr resorted to
label: Paragraph

text: the familiar device of unfinished granite on the lower surface, but only to the level of the
label: Paragraph

text: first-floor window ledge. For the most part, the walls are covered with gray roughcast,
label: Paragraph

text: yet the facade is framed by a top floor and corner bays of smooth, light stucco that
label: Paragraph

text: produce a clarity of line and a bright exterior. Bubyr emphasized the tectonic character of
label: Paragraph

text: the building with multistoried window bays that define the vertical lines of the facade and
label: Paragraph

text: at the same time provide more light for the main rooms of each apartment. The upper
label: Paragraph

text: stories culminate in a complex line, beginning as a mansard roof with low, narrow
label: Paragraph

text: dormers (in effect, a seventh story) and rising at the corners to high gables and a series of
label: Paragraph

text: pyramidal forms covered by ceramic roofing tiles.
label: Caption

text: The style moderne also appeared in the design of public buildings for banking and
label: Paragraph

text: commerce. The most notable landmark of early 20th-century commercial architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: the headquarters of the Singer Sewing Machine Company (1902-04), at the corner of
label: Paragraph

text: Nevskii Prospekt and the Catherine Canal. Its architect, Pavel Siuzor (1844—c.1919), had
label: Paragraph

text: established a career remarkable not only for prodigious output (some 100 original
label: Paragraph

text: projects and reconstructions, of which more than 60 are extant) but also for its success in
label: Paragraph

text: adapting to stylistic and technical innovations. Among the technical advances in the
label: Paragraph

text: Singer Building is the use of something approaching a skeletal structural system,
label: Paragraph

text: although not the steel frame of the type widely used in the United States. The exterior
label: Paragraph

text: facades are supported with a ferroconcrete and brick frame, and the interior floors (also
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete) rest on iron columns. By surfacing the arcade of the first two floors
label: Paragraph

text: with rusticated blocks of polished red granite and using a lighter, gray granite for the
label: Paragraph

text: upper stories, Siuzor created a visual base for the structure, which rises in granite-
label: Paragraph

text: surfaced piers and glass window shafts that extend from the third to the sixth floor in a
label: Caption

text: secondary arcade pattern. The culminating element of the building is the elongated metal-
label: Paragraph

text: ribbed and glass cupola, which could be illuminated to advertise the Singer logo.
label: Caption

text: By 1910 the style moderne had yielded to various modernized forms inspired by
label: Paragraph

text: assical and Renaissance motifs, such as the Azov-Don Bank (1908-09) and the Hotel
label: Paragraph

text: Astoria (1911-12), both by Fedor Lidval; the Mertens Building (1922-12) by Marian
label: Paragraph

text: Lialevich (1876-1944); the Guards’ Economic Society department store (1908-09) by
label: Paragraph

text: Emest Virrikh (1860-after 1921), Stepan Krichinskii (1874-1923), and Nikolai Vasilev;
label: Paragraph

text: the Vavelberg banking building (1910-12) by Marian Peretiatkovich (1872-1916); and
label: Paragraph

text: various apartment buildings by Vladimir Shchuko (1878-1938) and Andrei Belogrud
label: Caption

text: (1875-1933). Perhaps the most accomplished architect of the neoclassical revival was
label: Paragraph

text: Ivan Fomin (1872-1936), who specialized in the design of private houses but also
label: Paragraph

text: conceived of an enormous apartment development known as New Petersburg (1911-12),
label: Paragraph

text: only a few buildings of which were completed before World War I.
label: Paragraph

text: After the outbreak of World War I, the overheated Russian economy led to a collapse
label: Paragraph

text: of the construction industry. The monumental buildings that had been erected by the
label: Paragraph

text: hundreds in the preceding decades could no longer be maintained. In addition, the terror
label: Paragraph

text: of the 1918-21 civil war led to the almost total collapse of services and infrastructure in
label: Paragraph

text: Petrograd, as the city was called after 1914. After the death of Lenin, the name was
label: Paragraph

text: changed again, to Leningrad, in 1924.
label: Paragraph

text: Under the direction of Sergei Kirov, the city began to recover from its precipitous
label: Paragraph

text: economic and political decline after the revolution. Although the historic central districts
label: Paragraph

text: of the city remained largely intact by virtue of a comprehensive preservation policy and
label: Paragraph

text: the limited resources of an abandoned capital, Constructivist architecture began to appear
label: Paragraph

text: in the late 1920s in the design of administrative and cultural centers for the city’s largest
label: Paragraph

text: outer districts, where workers’ housing was under construction. One of the earliest
label: Paragraph

text: examples was Moscow-Narva District House
label: Paragraph

text: is}
label: Title

label: Caption

label: Caption

text: of Culture (1925-27; later renamed the Gorkii Palace of Culture) by Alexander Gegello
label: Paragraph

text: and David Krichevskii. Essentially a symmetrical structure designed around a wedge-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped amphitheater of 1,900 seats, the compact building demonstrated the beginnings of
label: Paragraph

text: a functional monumentality dictated by actual circumstances—circumstances that had
label: Paragraph

text: been ignored in the earlier Workers’ Palace and Palace of Labor competitions.
label: Paragraph

text: The construction of a number of model projects occurred in the same district, including
label: Paragraph

text: workers’ housing (1925-27), by Gegello and others, on Tractor Street; a department store
label: Paragraph

text: and “factory-kitchen” (1929-30; to eliminate the need for cooking at home), built in a
label: Paragraph

text: streamlined early Bauhaus style by Armen Barutchev and others; and the Tenth
label: Paragraph

text: Anniversary of October School (1925-27), designed by Aleksandr Nikolskii, on Strike
label: Paragraph

text: Prospekt. The centerpiece of the district (subsequently renamed Kirov) was the House of
label: Paragraph

text: Soviets (1930-34), designed by Noi Trotskii. Its long four-story office block, defined by
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal window strips, ends on one side in a perpendicular wing with a rounded facade
label: Paragraph

text: and on the other in a severely angular ten-story tower with comer balconies.
label: Paragraph

text: A similarly austere, unadorned style emphasizing the basic geometry of forms was
label: Paragraph

text: adopted by Igor Ivanovich Fomin and A. Daugul for the Moscow District House of
label: Caption

text: Soviets (1931-35) on Moscow Prospekt. Yet the facade, composed of segmented
label: Paragraph

text: windows of identical size, signifies the repetition of an incipient bureaucratic style rather
label: Paragraph

text: than the streamlined dynamic of earlier Constructivist work. During the same period
label: Paragraph

text: (1931-35), Igor Fomin and Evgenii Levinson designed an apartment complex for use by
label: Paragraph

text: the Leningrad Soviet in the fashionable prerevolutionary Petrograd district, on the bank
label: Paragraph

text: of the Karpovka River near Kamennoostrovskii Prospekt (subsequently renamed after
label: Paragraph

text: Kirov). With an open passageway supported by granite columns in the center of the
label: Paragraph

text: curved facade, the design echoes the work of Moisei Ginzburg and, especially, of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier. A stylobate of gray granite provides a base for the rest of the structure, whose
label: Paragraph

text: facade is coated in artistic concrete with a scored surface. The careful attention to such
label: Paragraph

text: details of architectural and decorative design is unusual for this period and indicates the
label: Paragraph

text: privileged status of the city bureaucrats for whom the structure was built.
label: Paragraph

text: The 1935 Leningrad city plan, devised by Lev Ilin and modified in the late 1930s by
label: Paragraph

text: Nikolai Baranov, involved a shift from the historical central districts to a new grand
label: Paragraph

text: avenue—Moscow Prospekt—leading to the south and to a proposed administrative
label: Paragraph

text: complex centered on the House of Soviets. This building, and the plaza surrounding it,
label: Paragraph

text: formed the most grandiose project of the 1930s (if one considers the Moscow Palace of
label: Paragraph

text: Soviets to have been, in effect, utopian). Ultimately, the project was reduced in scale, and
label: Paragraph

text: the outbreak of war curtailed construction still further,
label: Paragraph

text: New Petersburg Apartment Building, by Ivan Fomin and E.Levenson (1912)
label: Caption

text: © William C.Brumfield
label: Caption

text: but the House of Soviets (1936-41), designed by an architectural collective headed by
label: Paragraph

text: Noi Trotskii, was completed in the purest form of totalitarian monumentality: 220 meters
label: Paragraph

text: long and 150 meters deep. The central facade is marked by 20 attached columns, above
label: Paragraph

text: which is a massive frieze depicting scenes from the construction and defense of the
label: Paragraph

text: socialist homeland. The design attempted to draw on the legacy of classical architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and city planning in St. Petersburg with its open squares and monumental facades and at
label: Paragraph

text: the same time to supersede that legacy by sheer exaggeration of scale.
label: Paragraph

text: The outbreak of World War Il found Leningrad catastrophically unprepared.
label: Paragraph

text: Surrounded by German and Finnish forces during the 900-day siege, the city was
label: Paragraph

text: subjected to almost constant artillery bombardment. With the breaking of the siege in
label: Paragraph

text: early 1944, architects and construction teams immediately began the process of restoring
label: Paragraph

text: not only the great monuments but also the city’s apartment buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: In the post-Stalinist period, most of the city’s growth occurred in large housing
label: Paragraph

text: projects of standardized design on the outskirts of the historic center, which itself
label: Paragraph

text: remained relatively well preserved. Following the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991,
label: Paragraph

text: the decline in funding for city services led to a crisis in maintaining the many
label: Paragraph

text: prerevolutionary apartment buildings that provide the city with its urban texture. In
label: Paragraph

text: addition, economic stagnation and lack of investment have hampered the development of
label: Paragraph

text: innovative architectural concepts. Under these circumstances, the primary goal is to
label: Paragraph

text: preserve and renovate the architectural legacy of a time when St. Petersburg was one of
label: Paragraph

text: Europe’s great capitals.

text: STADIUM
label: Title

text: Today, major cities heatedly debate the need for new structures for their most prominent
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants: their athletic teams. As sports have become primary generators of revenue
label: Paragraph

text: for cities, the cutting-edge stadium has become an earmark of a city on the move.
label: Paragraph

text: Hellmuth, Obata, and Kassabaum, Inc., Sports Facilities Group (HOK) has been the
label: Paragraph

text: trendsetter in contemporary stadium design since 1983. With 1400 architects, the
label: Paragraph

text: company now is building consistently enough to create divisions based around different
label: Paragraph

text: sports, including hockey, basketball, baseball, football, and soccer. HOK, based in
label: Paragraph

text: Kansas City, Missouri, is responsible for Oriole Park at Camden Yards, which defined a
label: Paragraph

text: return in baseball to traditional ballparks. Perfectly suited to alternative agenda in the
label: Paragraph

text: postmodern era, contemporary designers must walk careful lines between tradition and
label: Paragraph

text: cutting-edge enhancements to the sports spectacle.
label: Paragraph

text: —s
label: Title

text: Olympic Games Tent (1972) in Munich, designed by Gunter Behnisch
label: Caption

text: © GreatBuildings.com
label: Title

text: The first modern stadium appeared in Victoria, Britain, in the late 1890s. However, there
label: Paragraph

text: was obviously a precedent even before this: The ancestral prototypes for modern facilities
label: Paragraph

text: are the stadiums and hippodromes of ancient Greece. Here, Olympic and other sporting
label: Paragraph

text: contests were staged, starting in the eighth century B.c. Greek stadiums, which could be
label: Paragraph

text: found in many larger cities, were laid out in a U shape, with the straight end forming the
label: Paragraph

text: starting line for races. Some also followed the model of theaters and were built into
label: Paragraph

text: hillsides. Other forms during this early history included Roman amphitheaters and
label: Paragraph

text: circuses.
label: Paragraph

text: In the late 1800s, designers began experimenting with more modern facilities, although
label: Paragraph

text: they often relied on classical models. Ballparks for the nation’s most popular sport,
label: Paragraph

text: baseball, took shape in many cities. In the early 1900s, the ballparks in many cities were
label: Paragraph

text: used separately by major-league players and Negroleague players. From the era of the
label: Paragraph

text: smaller ballpark, the next epoch emerged in the form of great stadiums, such as New
label: Paragraph

text: York’s Yankee Stadium (1923), Philadelphia’s Shibe Park (1909), Chicago’s Wrigley
label: Paragraph

text: Field (1926) and Comiskey Park (1910), and Boston’s Fenway Park (1912), to name just
label: Paragraph

text: a few. The forms that today are called stadiums, ballparks, or sports facilities would not
label: Paragraph

text: appear until the 1940s. After World War II, a new wave of stadium building shifted to
label: Paragraph

text: multipurpose facilities with partial
label: Title

text: Detail of Munich Olympic Games tent (1972)
label: Caption

text: © GreatBuildings.com
label: Title

text: roofs. The Oakland Coliseum, Shea Stadium, and others were often located in suburban
label: Paragraph

text: areas and surrounded by acres of car parking. In addition to baseball, such stadiums could
label: Paragraph

text: be used for football and public gatherings, such as concerts.
label: Paragraph

text: The multipurpose form of stadium had its origins in the enclosed dome. The originator
label: Paragraph

text: of this form was the Houston Astrodome, which opened in 1964. Judge Roy Hofheinz,
label: Paragraph

text: with the quirky idea of combining attending a sports event with going to a cocktail party,
label: Paragraph

text: designed the dome around the idea of sky-boxes. These private boxes allowed high-
label: Paragraph

text: paying clients to attend games without interacting with other fans. A young pitcher for
label: Paragraph

text: the Houston Astros bounded into the stadium in April 1965, taking in the miracles of the
label: Paragraph

text: dome: air conditioning, grass growing indoors (artificial turf would be laid in 1966), the
label: Paragraph

text: translucent roof (greenhouse by day, a planetarium by night), and seating for 66,000.
label: Paragraph

text: Many traditionalists viewed attending baseball in airconditioned splendor as a travesty.
label: Paragraph

text: The players, however, were most critical of the roof, the panels of which created a glare
label: Paragraph

text: that made it impossible to see the ball. The league tried changing the color of the ball, but
label: Paragraph

text: to no avail. The team painted over the roof panels, banishing the sun and killing the
label: Paragraph

text: grass—Tifway 419 Bermuda, which had been specially developed by scientists in
label: Paragraph

text: Georgia. For the rest of the season, the Astros simply painted over the dead grass.
label: Paragraph

text: Following the season, Monsanto’s new artificial turf, renamed AstroTurf, was installed.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1973, five more stadiums would have synthetic surfaces, and many others would
label: Paragraph

text: follow.
label: Paragraph

text: Other domes would follow, including the Louisiana Superdome, the largest dome when
label: Paragraph

text: it was built in 1975, with a seating capacity of 76,800. Although traditionalists would
label: Paragraph

text: wage war against domes and artificial turf, there was practical value to the controlled
label: Paragraph

text: environment. Particularly when professional sports became more concerned with
label: Paragraph

text: moneymaking, these technologies reduced the games’ dependence on weather and made
label: Paragraph

text: these events more appealing for family and business groups. The effort to reconcile these
label: Paragraph

text: needs led to some significant innovations, including the retractable domed roof, which
label: Paragraph

text: was first installed in the Toronto Skydome, designed by Canadian architects Rod Robbie
label: Paragraph

text: and Michael Allen in 1989. As a site for concerts and other sports events, including
label: Paragraph

text: Canadian Football League games, in addition to baseball, this stadium featured movable
label: Paragraph

text: lower stands and a retractable AstroTurf surface that permits a baseball-to-football
label: Paragraph

text: conversion in 12 hours’ time. Large, domed sports stadiums continue to be built around
label: Paragraph

text: the world, including Milwaukee’s Miller Park (2001, HKS, Inc., Dallas; NBBJ of Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles; and others) and the Osaka Dome (1997, Nikken Sekkei). From 1965, when the
label: Paragraph

text: to 2000, nearly 30 significant domed sports stadiums were built, mostly in cities in the
label: Paragraph

text: United States, Canada, and Japan. Importantly, several domed stadiums were built as part
label: Paragraph

text: of a host city’s preparations for the Olympic Games; these include the Amsterdam Arena
label: Paragraph

text: (1996) and Paris architect Roger Tallibert’s Le Stade Olympique (1976). The domes have
label: Paragraph

text: fueled a return to the more traditional model of stadiums designed in the early 1900s.
label: Paragraph

text: Clearly, many communities now idealize the ballparks that predated Yankee Stadium.
label: Paragraph

text: The contemporary version of this early baseball park, however, is quite different in scale
label: Paragraph

text: and amenities.
label: Paragraph

text: Many late 20th-century stadium projects have followed the 1992 model of Oriole Park
label: Paragraph

text: at Camden Yards (HOK Sport, Kansas City, Mo.) in Baltimore and the new Comiskey
label: Paragraph

text: Park, designed by Osborn Engineering Company in Chicago, as well as stadiums in
label: Paragraph

text: Denver and Cleveland. Returning to the one-dimensional parks and often to natural
label: Paragraph

text: bluegrass surfaces, these forms combine modern convenience with nostalgic detail. The
label: Paragraph

text: postmodern fusion has been a universal success, functioning to attract entire families to
label: Paragraph

text: baseball games and revitalizing aging urban centers. Many stadiums have included
label: Paragraph

text: amusement and shopping facilities within the park for those less enamored with sports.
label: Paragraph

text: Twentieth-century stadiums often accommodate more than one sport and, thus, prolong
label: Paragraph

text: their function and profitability beyond a single sport season that lasts a few months.
label: Paragraph

text: During the last two decades of the 20th century, many major North American cities built
label: Paragraph

text: sports stadiums for their home teams in hockey, basketball, and football. Among more
label: Paragraph

text: recent American sports arenas, the Pepsi Center in Denver was designed in 1999 by HOK
label: Paragraph

text: for the city’s professional hockey and basketball teams and features luxury suites and a
label: Paragraph

text: 300-seat restaurant overlooking the sports field.
label: Caption

text: The 20th-century stadium as a prominent and innovative building type has served more
label: Paragraph

text: than just professional sports. As gathering places for national political events or other
label: Paragraph

text: large-scale public or state-sponsored occasions, North Korea’s May Day Stadium
label: Paragraph

text: (capacity 150,000), Iran’s National Stadium (capacity 128,000), and Pirouzi (capacity
label: Paragraph

text: 128,000) represent the world’s largest domed structures. Others include City Stadium

text: STEEL
label: Title

text: Steel is a material present in the structure of virtually all works of 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: architecture: in the connectors, plates, nails, bolts, and screws of timber floors and
label: Paragraph

text: frames; in the deformed bars hidden within the cement and stone matrix of reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete; and in the hot-rolled wide-flange columns and beams characteristic of steel
label: Paragraph

text: skeletal frameworks. Although its history as a building material can be traced back at
label: Paragraph

text: least to the fifth century B.C., and although its potential to revolutionize the whole
label: Paragraph

text: process and form of building was in many ways already evident in the 19th century, it is
label: Paragraph

text: in the 20th century that the architectural expression of steel was most thoroughly
label: Paragraph

text: explored.
label: Paragraph

text: Steel refers to any metal consisting primarily of iron, although the term is now
label: Paragraph

text: commonly used in a more restrictive sense, reserved for the mild carbon steels that first
label: Paragraph

text: appeared in the mid-19th century and the high-strength, corrosion-resistant
label: Paragraph

text: (“weathering”), and stainless steels developed more recently. Cast- and wrought-iron
label: Paragraph

text: products had been used extensively in building, especially in the 19th century, but were
label: Paragraph

text: largely superseded by the beginning of the 20th century by hot-rolled steel members. The
label: Paragraph

text: ultimate victory of steel over earlier forms of iron was the result of steel’s superior
label: Paragraph

text: structural properties along with an increasingly efficient manufacturing process—based
label: Paragraph

text: on the innovations of Bessemer, Siemens, Thomas, and others—that dramatically
label: Paragraph

text: reduced its cost while increasing its output. Stimulated first by the needs of the railway
label: Paragraph

text: industry in the mid-19th century and later by a dramatic increase in large-scale building
label: Paragraph

text: projects, construction in steel became inextricably linked with the accelerated pace of
label: Paragraph

text: commercial and industrial development in the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: The economic and social changes accompanying this development met with mixed
label: Paragraph

text: reactions. Chicago architect Louis Sullivan found a kind of spiritual poetry in the steel
label: Paragraph

text: frame’s aspiration for verticality; Italian futurist Sant’Elia proclaimed in 1914 that the
label: Paragraph

text: steel bridges, railway stations, cars, and planes of the modern epoch already signaled a
label: Paragraph

text: radical discontinuity with the traditional forms of the past; and Russian Constructivist
label: Paragraph

text: Vladimir Tatlin’s proposal for a spiraling steel monument to the Third International in
label: Paragraph

text: 1920 provided a dynamic and optimistic visual image for the new technology. Yet other
label: Paragraph

text: artists and critics saw only the negative social consequences of the 20th century’s new
label: Paragraph

text: steel-framed architecture: dark, canyonlike streets; anonymous, repetitive facades; and
label: Paragraph

text: degrading or dangerous working conditions. Steel was not simply the material par
label: Paragraph

text: excellence of the industrial revolution; at the dawn of the 20th century, it was also a
label: Paragraph

text: potent symbol of economic power and monopolistic arrogance, personified in the
label: Paragraph

text: legendary figures of Andrew Carnegie, J.P. Morgan, and Elbert H.Gary.
label: Paragraph

text: With the development of steel architecture, other formal and technical issues have
label: Paragraph

text: emerged: reconciling requirements for fireproofing and corrosion protection with the
label: Paragraph

text: desire for direct expression; exploiting the potential of standardization, prefabrication,
label: Paragraph

text: and mass production; expressing the ideal of lightness and elegance or the tectonics of
label: Paragraph

text: load and resistance; and incorpo-rating the image of the machine (whether derived from
label: Paragraph

text: industry, transport, or war) or the influence of other aesthetic tendencies (from
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivism to deconstruction). These issues are subsumed within the following
label: Paragraph

text: discussion, which is based on three critical 20th-century building types: the office
label: Paragraph

text: building, the long-span “shed,” and the house.
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago School architects pioneered the steel-framed office building in the late 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century, and similarly important skyscrapers were designed in New York City and most
label: Paragraph

text: major American urban centers. In New York, the 30-story Park Row Building (1898) was
label: Paragraph

text: soon surpassed in height by a series of early-20th-century stone-clad, steel-framed
label: Paragraph

text: towers, braced internally with diagonal trusswork or made rigid with riveted steel portal
label: Caption

text: frames. The most influential of these buildings was the Woolworth Tower (1913).
label: Paragraph

text: Designed by Cass Gilbert, it was the tallest building in the world at the time, having
label: Paragraph

text: overtaken the 50-story Metropolitan Life Insurance Building (1909), designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Nicholas Le Brun and Sons, which had just surpassed the 47-story Singer Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1907), designed by Ernest Flagg. At the beginning of the Great Depression, two steel-
label: Paragraph

text: framed structures in New York City took skyscraper design to new heights, both literally
label: Paragraph

text: and metaphorically: the Chrysler Building (1929) by William Van Allen and the Empire
label: Paragraph

text: State Building (1931) by Shreve, Lamb, and Harmon. The Chrysler Building is notable in
label: Paragraph

text: this context for its crown of stainless-steel cladding, one of the first extensive building
label: Paragraph

text: applications for the newly invented steel alloy.
label: Paragraph

text: Critics have argued about the architectural significance of these New York skyscrapers
label: Paragraph

text: and whether their exuberant facades of stone and brick—reminiscent in many cases of
label: Paragraph

text: medieval towers and Renaissance campanile—adequately express the nature of modern
label: Paragraph

text: steel construction. Although their effect as cultural icons is unquestioned, in general it is
label: Paragraph

text: the earlier-19th-century Chicago School buildings of Sullivan, Root, Burnham, and
label: Paragraph

text: Jenney that are cited as exemplars of steel-framed building and precursors of modern
label: Paragraph

text: design. After World War LIL, architects generally eliminated cornices and other traditional
label: Paragraph

text: decorative elements derived from historic architectural styles in favor of the
label: Paragraph

text: unornamented, rectilinear geometry associated with 20th-century modernism. Even so,
label: Paragraph

text: the expression of steel framing remained problematic. For example, in Mies van der Rohe
label: Paragraph

text: and Philip Johnson’s Seagram Building (1958) in New York City, the actual steel
label: Paragraph

text: structure is first encased in concrete fireproofing and then hidden behind a metal and
label: Paragraph

text: glass curtain wall. Even with bronze I-beams applied on the facade to stiffen the vertical
label: Paragraph

text: mullions, expression of the actual steel framework is, at best, indirect.
label: Paragraph

text: A more direct expression of steel structure is achieved by exposing the characteristic
label: Paragraph

text: flanged shapes of actual painted or corrosion-resistant steel beams and columns or by
label: Paragraph

text: celebrating the geometry of structural forms characteristic of steel—usually trussed or
label: Paragraph

text: rigid frameworks evocative of steel industrial or civil engineering works. In the first case,
label: Paragraph

text: Kevin Roche and John Dinkeloo’s use of exposed and unpainted corrosion-resistant steel
label: Paragraph

text: girders for the Knights of Columbus Headquarters (1969) in New Haven, Connecticut,
label: Caption

text: and Skidmore, Owings, and Merrill’s use of partially exposed painted steel girders (the
label: Paragraph

text: flanges being covered for fire protection) in the U.S. Steel Building (1972) in New York
label: Paragraph

text: City may serve as examples.
label: Paragraph

text: In the second case, the geometric form of truss or frame (rather than the shape of the
label: Paragraph

text: individual elements) evokes steel structure. Three buildings by Skidmore, Owings, and
label: Paragraph

text: Merrill illustrate this approach. The Inland Steel Building (1957) in Chicago expresses its
label: Paragraph

text: welded-steel framework by locating the vertical elements of the framework outside the
label: Paragraph

text: glass plane of the curtain wall, the Alcoa Building (1964) in San Francisco positions its
label: Paragraph

text: triangulated steel bracing structure 18 inches in front of its glass curtain wall, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Hancock Building (1970) in Chicago sets its steel trusswork into the plane of the facade.
label: Paragraph

text: Two buildings in Hong Kong provide additional examples based on the same principle.
label: Paragraph

text: The Bank of China (1990) by I.M. Pei selectively expresses the complex triangular
label: Paragraph

text: geometry of its steel frame, suppressing the articulation of horizontal truss elements and
label: Paragraph

text: thereby changing the apparent pattern of the framework on the facades from a series of
label: Paragraph

text: Xs—which would have negative cultural connotations—to a series of diamonds. Norman
label: Paragraph

text: Foster’s Hongkong and Shanghai Bank (1986) employs a more explicitly machine-
label: Paragraph

text: derived aesthetic, using tension elements to literally hang sections of the building—eight
label: Paragraph

text: floors at a time—from steel trusses that in turn are cantilevered from mammoth steel
label: Paragraph

text: columns. In these examples, the actual articulated steel structure is clad in sheet metal or,
label: Paragraph

text: in the case of Pei’s triangulated framework, stone veneer. Steel “exoskeletons” may also
label: Paragraph

text: be unclad, as at the Foundation Cartier (1994) in Paris by Jean Nouvel, where abstract
label: Paragraph

text: planar surfaces of parallel curtain wall screens are contrasted with exposed angular steel
label: Paragraph

text: frames designed to provide structural stability.
label: Paragraph

text: The Shed
label: Title

text: The use of steel for long-span roof structures has its roots in 19th-century bridges, train
label: Paragraph

text: sheds, market halls, and exhibition spaces. Structures such as the Crystal Palace (1851) in
label: Paragraph

text: London and the Galerie des Machines (1889) in Paris already showed the potential of
label: Paragraph

text: iron (or steel, in the case of the Galerie). New functions requiring long-span roofs
label: Paragraph

text: evolved in the 20th century, including hangars for airships and aircraft as well as single-
label: Paragraph

text: level factories oriented toward the new flexible assembly-line production techniques
label: Paragraph

text: pioneered in the automobile industry.
label: Paragraph

text: Long-span steel trusses, originating with 19th-century bridges (Benjamin Baker’s
label: Paragraph

text: steel-truss Forth Bridge in Scotland was the world’s longest spanning structure at the
label: Paragraph

text: time of its completion in 1890) were used in numerous factories and other building types
label: Paragraph

text: to create large, column-free interior spaces. Albert Kahn’s Glenn Martin Aircraft Plant
label: Caption

text: (1937) in Middle River, Maryland, is of interest not only because its 300-foot (91-meter)
label: Paragraph

text: trusses created the largest flat-roof span attempted up to that time but also because Mies
label: Paragraph

text: van der Rohe used a photograph of its interior to construct his famous collaged image for
label: Paragraph

text: a Concert Hall project, published in 1943. Additional representative examples in which
label: Paragraph

text: steel parallel-chord, horizontal trusses are featured as important architectural elements
label: Paragraph

text: include the New Haven Veterans Memorial Coliseum (1972) by Kevin Roche and John
label: Caption

text: Dinkeloo, where exposed corrosion-resistant steel trusses carry a multilevel parking
label: Paragraph

text: structure over the stadium below, and the McCormick Place Convention Center (1970) in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago by C.F.Murphy Associates, in which two perpendicular sets of parallel trusses
label: Paragraph

text: are used. An unusual multistory application of long-span steel trusses can be seen at the
label: Paragraph

text: Georges Pompidou Center (1977) by Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers, where the truss
label: Paragraph

text: span—and therefore the required depth of the structure—is reduced through the use of
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated cast-steel “‘gerberettes” cantilevered inward from water-filled tubular steel
label: Caption

text: columns to support the trusses, the columns being expressed on the building’s exterior
label: Paragraph

text: along with tensioned steel rods and diagonal cross bracing.
label: Paragraph

text: Variations on steel-trussed arches and frames, providing lightweight and structurally
label: Paragraph

text: efficient spans, can be seen in early20th-century hangars for airships (zeppelins) and
label: Paragraph

text: factory buildings, especially in Germany. An early example, influenced by the three-
label: Paragraph

text: hinged steel arch forms of 19th-century bridge and exhibition structures, is Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens’s AEG Turbine Factory (1909) in Berlin, in which hinges and vertical elements
label: Paragraph

text: making up the repetitive steel arches are expressed on the exterior of the side facade.
label: Paragraph

text: Norman Foster’s Sainsbury Centre (1977) in Norwich, England, uses tubular steel-trussed
label: Paragraph

text: rigid portal frames that contain the mechanical services for the building while providing a
label: Paragraph

text: clear span for the display and academic functions within. A more complex three-hinged
label: Paragraph

text: trussed arch appears in Nicholas Grimshaw’s Waterloo International Rail Terminal
label: Caption

text: (1994) in London. There, the required asymmetry results in steel tension elements of the
label: Paragraph

text: truss—expressed as thin rods—being located first above and then below the roof
label: Paragraph

text: structure, creating a form at once rational and counterintuitive. A final example is the
label: Paragraph

text: International Exhibition Center (1996) in Leipzig by lan Ritchie, in which arched trusses
label: Paragraph

text: with cast-steel support arms form an exoskeleton supporting the vaulted Main Hall.
label: Caption

text: Polyhedral-based_ structures—three-dimensional versions of simple planar trusses—
label: Paragraph

text: were pioneered by Alexander Graham Bell in 1907 and developed into more
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated space frames by Max Mengeringhausen in Germany in the 1940s and
label: Paragraph

text: Konrad Wachsmann in the United States in the 1950s. Buckminster Fuller invented the
label: Paragraph

text: geodesic dome, based on the triangulation of a spherical surface, in the late 1940s. Steel-
label: Paragraph

text: lamella roofs, consisting of intersecting, offset systems of parallel ribs, have been used in
label: Paragraph

text: hangars, stadiums, and other long-span applications. Later—20th-century versions of
label: Paragraph

text: these forms include the Javits Convention Center (1986) in New York City by 1.M.Pei,
label: Paragraph

text: consisting of a steel space frame used for both walls and roofs; Fuller’s geodesic dome
label: Paragraph

text: for the U.S. Pavilion (1967) at the Montreal Expo; and the steel-lamella Louisiana
label: Paragraph

text: Superdome (1975) by Sverdrup and Parcel Associates.
label: Paragraph

text: Long-span masted tension structures, inspired by 19th-century suspension bridge and
label: Paragraph

text: 20th-century cable-stayed designs, use steel rods in tension to support horizontal roof
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces. The Burgo Paper Mill (1962) in Mantua, Italy, by Pier Luigi Nervi quite
label: Caption

text: literally mirrors the form of conventional suspension bridges to create clear-span spaces
label: Paragraph

text: below its suspended roof. More recent masted steel structures exploit the same principles,
label: Paragraph

text: although their forms have become less derivative of bridge design and more articulate in
label: Paragraph

text: expressing the exposed-steel connections between tension rod, horizontal beam, and
label: Paragraph

text: vertical mast. Notable examples by Richard Rogers include the Fleetguard Distribution
label: Paragraph

text: Center (1979) in Quimper, France; the Inmos Microprocessor Factory (1982) in South
label: Paragraph

text: Wales; and the PA Technology Laboratories (1985) in Princeton, New Jersey. Norman
label: Caption

text: Foster’s Renault Distribution Center (1980) at Swindon, England, has a more complex
label: Paragraph

text: geometry defined by perforated, tapered beams; masts; and tension rods. The Darling
label: Paragraph

text: Harbour Exhibition Center (1988) in Sydney, Australia, by Philip Cox, Richardson, and
label: Caption

text: Taylor makes reference, in its masted supports and steel outriggers, to the adjacent
label: Paragraph

text: maritime harbor and its associated nautical motifs. The suppression of tension elements
label: Paragraph

text: and the elaboration of the mast into compressive “treelike” structural forms—first
label: Paragraph

text: systematically studied by Frei Otto—can be seen in several steel-framed projects by
label: Paragraph

text: Santiago Calatrava, including the BCE Place Gallery (1992) in Toronto and the Oriente
label: Paragraph

text: Station (1998) in Lisbon.
label: Paragraph

text: In tensioned-membrane structures, steel cables are combined with fabric membranes to
label: Paragraph

text: create extremely lightweight, long-span structures. Frei Otto’s tent structures for the
label: Paragraph

text: German Pavilion (1967) at the Montreal Expo and for the Munich Olympics (1972) are
label: Paragraph

text: landmarks in the development of these forms. Two late-20th-century long-span examples
label: Paragraph

text: are the Georgia Dome (1992) in Atlanta, engineered by Weidlinger Associates and based
label: Paragraph

text: on a patented “tensegrity” geometry defined by triangulated steel tension cables and
label: Paragraph

text: floating steel compression struts, and the Millennium Dome (1999) by Richard Rogers in
label: Caption

text: which the dome—historically a compressive structure—is transformed into a tensioned
label: Paragraph

text: membrane by hanging the steel cable net defining its domical surface from an array of
label: Paragraph

text: twelve inclined steel masts that penetrate the membrane. Lightweight domical surfaces
label: Caption

text: can also be formed with membranes by mechanically increasing the interior air pressure,
label: Paragraph

text: as in a balloon: An early example of such a pneumatic structure, contained by a net of
label: Paragraph

text: steel cables, is the American Pavilion at the Osaka Expo (1970) by Davis Brody
label: Paragraph

text: Associates.
label: Paragraph

text: With the development of welded connections—first invented in the late 19th century
label: Paragraph

text: but not used in buildings until the 1920s—steel beams and frames could more readily be
label: Paragraph

text: designed within the modernist syntax of interpenetrating line and surface, uninterrupted
label: Paragraph

text: by gusset plates, bolts, or rivets. The buildings of Mies van der Rohe at the Illinois
label: Caption

text: Institute of Technology in Chicago illustrate this type of abstract welded-steel expression,
label: Paragraph

text: most dramatically in the exposed parallel portal frames of Crown Hall (1956). Later
label: Paragraph

text: projects from the 1960s and 1970s, influenced by Mies’s work, include Roche and
label: Paragraph

text: Dinkeloo’s Cummins Engine Company plant (1966) at Darlington, England; the Reliance
label: Paragraph

text: Controls plant (1966) at Swindon, England, by Team 4 (including Norman Foster and
label: Paragraph

text: Richard Rogers); and Skidmore, Owings, and Merrill’s Republic Newspaper Plant (1971)
label: Caption

text: at Columbus, Indiana. Functional requirements—for example, the need for daylighting in
label: Paragraph

text: the immense new factory buildings of the steel, automotive, and aircraft industries—
label: Paragraph

text: could also be addressed using welded-steel frames, angled or stepped to accommodate
label: Paragraph

text: monitor skylights. Such bent frames can be found in Albert Kahn’s Chrysler Half-Ton
label: Paragraph

text: Truck Plant (1937) in Detroit and, more recently, in Helmut Jahn’s Terminal One
label: Paragraph

text: Complex for United Airlines (1987) in Chicago, the latter project using clusters of tubular
label: Paragraph

text: steel columns supporting perforated steel beams that define skylit, linear public
label: Paragraph

text: circulation spaces within the terminal. Curved, welded ribbed frames are used at an even
label: Paragraph

text: more monumental scale in Rafael Vifioly’s Tokyo International Forum (1996), defining
label: Paragraph

text: an immense elliptical tied-arch roof supported by two centrifugally spun steel pipe
label: Caption

text: columns 400 feet (124 meters) apart.
label: Caption

text: The House
label: Title

text: The use of steel in the construction of factories, train sheds, market halls, and office
label: Paragraph

text: buildings parallels the development of 19th- and 20th-century industry and commerce.
label: Paragraph

text: The use of steel in 20th-century residential design has less of an objective basis, despite
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s famous aphorism defining the modern house as a “machine for living in.”
label: Paragraph

text: Although steel-based technology was critical to the production of cars, trains, airships,
label: Paragraph

text: and airplanes, attempts to design mass-produced, prefabricated, standardized, and flexible
label: Paragraph

text: kits of steel parts applicable to the production of houses were generally less successful. In
label: Paragraph

text: fact, although at least one fireproof steel residence—the Reid House (1894) in Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: by Beers, Clay, and Dutton—was constructed before the 20th century, ambivalence about
label: Paragraph

text: the appropriateness of exposed steel within the domestic sphere, as well as its relatively
label: Paragraph

text: high cost compared with traditional residential construction systems, delayed the first
label: Paragraph

text: applications of steel framing to residential construction. An experimental steel-framed
label: Paragraph

text: house was produced for the German Bauhaus Exhibition of 1923 by painter Georg
label: Paragraph

text: Muche and Adolf Meyer, but this house, along with a subsequent design completed in
label: Paragraph

text: 1927, had little lasting influence.
label: Paragraph

text: The first truly influential steel-framed houses, built on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean
label: Paragraph

text: at the end of the 1920s, rely for their expressive power on the juxtaposition of steel
label: Paragraph

text: framing with large surfaces of glass. Among the most important are Richard Neutra’s
label: Paragraph

text: Lovell Health House (1929) in Los Angeles; Pierre Chareau’s Maison de Verre (1932) in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris; Mies van der Rohe’s Tugendhat House (1930) in Brno, Czechoslovakia; and
label: Paragraph

text: Leendert Cornelis van der Vlugt’s van der Leeuw House (1929) in Rotterdam. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: Chareau has made the specific character of rolled steel—the flanged column shapes and
label: Paragraph

text: the bolted and riveted connections—an integral part of his architectural expression,
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra’s steel frame is integrated into a more abstract gridded composition of glass and
label: Paragraph

text: cement, visible only on the exterior of the house, where the closely spaced vertical
label: Paragraph

text: members of the steel framework are selectively exposed as window mullions or supports
label: Paragraph

text: for projecting rooms and balconies. In Mies’ Tugendhat House, similar in its detailing
label: Caption

text: and expression to the better known German Pavilion (1929) designed for the World
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition at Barcelona the previous year, the actual bolted-steel framework is never
label: Paragraph

text: truly revealed. Instead, only the grid of columns, clad in chromium-plated sheet steel and
label: Paragraph

text: set didactically between abstract planes of floor and roof, can be seen. The van der
label: Paragraph

text: Leeuw House is perhaps the most literally “machinelike” of all, boasting a whole array of
label: Paragraph

text: electronic gadgetry and controls within a structure based on four parallel steel frames that
label: Paragraph

text: penetrated the house from front to back.
label: Paragraph

text: A different tendency can be seen in the polygonal Dymaxion House (1927), designed
label: Paragraph

text: by Buckminster Fuller, in which a rigorous analysis of functionality and structural
label: Paragraph

text: efficiency is combined with an interest in mass production at low cost, unfettered by the
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic preoccupations of the European modernists. Fuller refined the design during the
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s and 1940s and found manufacturers to build prototypes but was unable to
label: Paragraph

text: implement the idea commercially on a large scale.
label: Paragraph

text: During the period immediately after World War II, especially in the United States,
label: Paragraph

text: steel was vigorously promoted as a material suitable for residential construction. John
label: Paragraph

text: Entenza’s Art & Architecture magazine published a series of so-called Case Study
label: Paragraph

text: houses, the most influential of which was designed by Charles and Ray Eames for
label: Paragraph

text: themselves in Pacific Palisades, California. The Eames House (1949) pioneered an
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic derived from the assembly of off-the-shelf, mass-produced, standard steel
label: Paragraph

text: elements: open-web steel joists, corrugated-steel decking, and rolled-steel-column
label: Paragraph

text: sections.
label: Paragraph

text: Two non-Californian steel-framed houses designed in the late 1940s were also
label: Paragraph

text: extremely influential. Mies van der Rohe’s Farnsworth House (1951) in Plano, Illinois,
label: Caption

text: and Philip Johnson’s Glass House (1949) in New Canaan, Connecticut, evince less
label: Caption

text: concern with issues of economy, standardization, and mass production and more interest
label: Paragraph

text: in exploring the formal qualities of the rectangular glass box within a welded-steel frame.
label: Paragraph

text: The Farnsworth House was designed with its horizontal steel-framed floor and roof
label: Paragraph

text: planes cantilevered outward from within two rows of external steel columns, raising the
label: Paragraph

text: house off the ground. Johnson, however, by placing his Glass House directly on the
label: Paragraph

text: ground with no cantilevered elements and by positioning his black-painted steel columns
label: Paragraph

text: inside the glass plane, has shifted the emphasis from the steel frame to the glass
label: Paragraph

text: enclosure.
label: Paragraph

text: Many postwar steel houses combine in various degrees formal qualities associated with
label: Paragraph

text: the work of Eames and Mies. Influential Californian Case Study houses, such as Raphael
label: Paragraph

text: Soriano’s Olds House (1950) in Pacific Palisades, Craig Ellwood’s Bailey House (1958)
label: Caption

text: in Los Angeles, and Pierre Koenig’s Stahl House (1960) in Los Angeles, all are based on
label: Paragraph

text: rectilinear grids of steel columns, with steel beams and corrugated-steel roof decks
label: Paragraph

text: completing the framing schemes and largely defining the formal vocabulary. Beginning
label: Paragraph

text: in the mid-1950s, modern steel houses began to be built in England as well, including
label: Paragraph

text: Michael Manser’s Capel Manor House (Kent, 1970), the Richard Horden house (Dorset,
label: Caption

text: 1975), the John Winter house (1969) in London, and lan Ritchie’s Eagle Rock House
label: Paragraph

text: (1982) in East Sussex. Soriano, in particular, has been an influential figure for both
label: Paragraph

text: British and American architects building in steel. Having experimented with lightweight
label: Paragraph

text: steel trusses, beams, and columns since the late 1930s, he lent a certain credibility to the
label: Paragraph

text: well-publicized but still largely unrealized ideal of industrialized building based on
label: Paragraph

text: modularity, standardization, and prefabrication.
label: Paragraph

text: Interest in industrialized building—for housing, schools, and other building types—has
label: Paragraph

text: been a continuous current in architectural thought for most of the 20th century. Early
label: Paragraph

text: research into the mass production of lightweight steel structures, on the model of
label: Paragraph

text: automobile production, can be seen in the work of Jean Prouvé and Buckminster Fuller
label: Paragraph

text: from the 1920s and 1930s. Several industrialized steel systems for schools were
label: Paragraph

text: implemented in the period after World War IL, most notably the Hertfordshire County
label: Paragraph

text: Council and CLASP systems in Britain in the 1940s and 1950s and the School
label: Paragraph

text: Construction System Development Program in California led by Ezra Ehrenkrantz during
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s. By the end of the century, industrialized products were routinely used in a
label: Paragraph

text: variety of applications, ranging from metal building systems—consisting of heavy steel
label: Paragraph

text: frames with corrugated-steel cladding—to complete “volumetric” steel-framed housing
label: Paragraph

text: units, the latter accounting for a small but growing proportion of total new home
label: Paragraph

text: construction in Japan.
label: Paragraph

text: Steel-based industrialized housing systems were developed in Britain, the United
label: Paragraph

text: States, and France in the aftermath of World War II, including several designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Prouvé in the 1940s based on his earlier use of bent steel sheet in his Pavillion
label: Paragraph

text: Démontable (1939). Jerry Wells and Fred Koetter continued research into the potential of
label: Paragraph

text: light-gauge, cold-formed sheet steel for modular housing (1971), as did Cedric Price in
label: Paragraph

text: the same year. Other experimental steel-based building systems designed in the 1970s
label: Paragraph

text: and 1980s include Helmut Schulitz’s “Team for Experimental Systems and Building
label: Paragraph

text: Techniques” (TEST) at the University of California, Michael Hopkins’s Patera System in
label: Paragraph

text: Britain, Gunter Hiibner and Frank Huster’s prototype housing system in Germany, Renzo
label: Paragraph

text: Piano’s experimental houses in Italy, and Michiel Cohen and Jan Pesman’s Heiwo
label: Paragraph

text: system in the Netherlands. However, these industrialized building attempts were only
label: Paragraph

text: partially successful, with houses produced often only as prototypes, occasionally in
label: Paragraph

text: limited numbers, and sometimes not at all.
label: Paragraph

text: Notwithstanding the limited application of steel-framed industrialized building systems
label: Paragraph

text: to housing, the use of prefabricated, industrial steel elements has had a notable effect on
label: Paragraph

text: later-20th-century residential architecture. In particular, an ad hoc and idiosyncratic use
label: Paragraph

text: of corrugated-steel panels for roofing and siding can be seen in the provocative
label: Paragraph

text: residential work of Frank Gehry, beginning with his Davis Studio/Residence (1968-72)
label: Paragraph

text: in Malibu, California, and including the first addition to his own house (1978) in Santa
label: Paragraph

text: Monica, California. The Australian architect Glenn Murcutt has also used corrugated
label: Paragraph

text: steel and steel framing as crucial elements in many of his residential designs, including
label: Paragraph

text: the Marie Short House (1975) in New South Wales and the Ball-Eastaway House and
label: Paragraph

text: Studio (1983) in Glenorie, Sidney. Where the raw, industrial quality of steel cladding in
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s work reinforces a sense of displacement already evident in the deliberately
label: Paragraph

text: fragmented or truncated forms of his structures, Murcutt’s use of the same material
label: Paragraph

text: achieves an opposite effect, imparting what has been described as a sense of dignity to
label: Paragraph

text: the corrugated surfaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Steel as Skin
label: Title

text: Steel appears in architecture primarily as structure, but it is also used as nonstructural
label: Paragraph

text: cladding, or “skin.” Gehry’s corrugatedsteel panels and the Chrysler Building’s stainless-
label: Paragraph

text: steel crown have already been noted. Other representative examples include Jean
label: Paragraph

text: Prouvé’s innovative sheet-steel curtain wall for the Maison du Peuple (1939) at Clichy,
label: Paragraph

text: France; Skidmore, Owings, and Merrill’s stainless-steel mullions at Lever House (1953)
label: Caption

text: in New York City; Harrison and Abramovitz’s textured panels of stainless steel for the
label: Paragraph

text: Socony Mobil Building (1955) in New York City; Richard Meier’s gridded porcelain
label: Paragraph

text: enamel steel panels at the Athenium (1979) in New Harmony, Indiana; and Frank
label: Caption

text: Gehry’s overlapping galvanized-steel sheet cladding at the California Aerospace Museum
label: Caption

text: (1984) in Los Angeles.
label: Paragraph

text: The uniqueness of steel sheet and plate also manifests itself in a group of idiosyncratic
label: Paragraph

text: structures not easily categorized by function or formal type but having in common a kind
label: Paragraph

text: of sculptural presence in which distinctions between structure and skin become less clear.
label: Paragraph

text: Eero Saarinen’s 630-foot (190-meter)-high Gateway Arch (1965) in St. Louis uses a
label: Paragraph

text: double layer of steel, with quarter-inch (six-millimeter) stainless-steel plate forming the
label: Paragraph

text: outside layer, as both cladding and structure. Le Corbusier’s pavilion for Heidi Weber
label: Paragraph

text: (1967) in Zurich, based on his earlier steel project for the “Saison de l’eau” at the
label: Paragraph

text: Exposition de Liegé (1939), contains an angular sheet-steel roof cantilevered from a
label: Paragraph

text: series of steel piers and detached from but covering a rectilinear steel structure below.
label: Caption

text: Bernard Tschumi’s abstract, orthogonal sculptural “follies” and expressionistic “gallery”
label: Paragraph

text: structures within the Pare de la Villette (1982) in Paris provide a final example based on
label: Paragraph

text: the use of both painted and porcelain-coated sheet steel.
label: Paragraph
