text: STEEL-FRAME CONSTRUCTION
label: Title

text: This method of construction provides support by means of a closely knit structure of
label: Paragraph

text: steel. Primary and secondary members compose the skeleton of the structure, to which a
label: Paragraph

text: covering can be applied. With a steel frame, it is possible to enclose space with
label: Paragraph

text: suspension structures. Steel framing is the counterpart to vaulting, in which the materials
label: Paragraph

text: are in compression, and to pneu-
label: Paragraph

text: Reliance Building (detail, upper stories) Chicago, designed by Daniel Burnham
label: Caption

text: © Johnson Architectural Images/GreatBuildings.com
label: Caption

text: matic structures, in which the skins are held in place by air pressure.
label: Paragraph

text: The basic elements of the steel skeleton frame are vertical columns, horizontal girders
label: Paragraph

text: that span the longer distance between columns, and beams that span shorter distances.
label: Paragraph

text: The frame is reinforced to prevent distortion and possible collapse caused by uneven or
label: Paragraph

text: vibratory loads. Lateral stability is provided by connecting the beams, columns, and
label: Paragraph

text: girders and by diagonal bracing or rigid connections among columns, girders, and beams.
label: Paragraph

text: A frame composed of three end-connected members, more commonly known as a
label: Paragraph

text: truss, cannot change its shape, even if its joints could act as hinges. Moreover, the
label: Paragraph

text: principle of triangulation—attaching a horizontal tie beam to the bottom ends of two
label: Paragraph

text: peaked rafters—can be extended indefinitely. Thus, spanning systems of almost any
label: Paragraph

text: shape can be subdivided into triangles, the sides of which can be made of any appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: material (most commonly steel or wood), and assembled using suitable end connections.
label: Paragraph

text: Each separate part is then subject only to either compressive or tensile stress. The exterior
label: Paragraph

text: skin, or curtain wall, that is placed over the steel frame can be made of metal (stainless
label: Paragraph

text: steel, aluminum, or bronze), masonry (concrete, brick, or tile), or glass.
label: Paragraph

text: In the second half of the 19th century, builders in New York City and Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: experimented with high-rise buildings. A valuable learning experience came with the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of the Statue of Liberty (1886). Erected between 1883 and 1886, the statue is
label: Paragraph

text: a copper-sheathed enclosure standing 151 feet, making it comparable in size, if not in
label: Paragraph

text: weight, to the skyscraper of its day.
label: Paragraph

text: The sculptor of the Statue of Liberty, Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, posed a problem for
label: Paragraph

text: his engineer Gustave Eiffel that was less one of supporting vertical loads and more one of
label: Paragraph

text: resisting the force of wind on the extensive surface area surrounding the hollow interior.
label: Paragraph

text: Eiffel’s solution to the wind load problem involved several valuable innovations for
label: Paragraph

text: American building. Most important, the diagonally braced frame inside the figure
label: Paragraph

text: represented the most extensive system of wind bracing employed for any American
label: Paragraph

text: structure to that time other than a bridge.
label: Paragraph

text: The braced and riveted steel skeleton was used in New York with the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: Bruce Price’s American Surety Building (1895) at Broadway and Pine Street. With a
label: Caption

text: height of 20 stories, rising 303 feet above grade, a masonry wall was simply out of the
label: Paragraph

text: question. For this height, a wall without supplementary columns inserted in the masonry
label: Paragraph

text: would need to be at least seven and a half feet thick at the base. At this time, the Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: architect Louis Sullivan, in his Wainwright Building (1890-91) in St. Louis, Missouri;
label: Paragraph

text: his Guaranty Building (1895) in Buffalo, New York; and his Carson Pirie Scott
label: Paragraph

text: Department Store (1899-1904) in Chicago gave new expressive form to urban
label: Paragraph

text: commercial buildings, known as the Chicago School. These buildings made a successful
label: Paragraph

text: transition from the masonry-bearing wall to the steel frame, which assumed all the load-
label: Paragraph

text: bearing functions.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1895, engineers and architects in Chicago had contributed several innovations to
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper construction. The engineer Corydon T.Purdy, in collaboration with William
label: Caption

text: Holabird and Martin Roche, seems to have been the first to use portal arches as wind
label: Paragraph

text: bracing when he designed the steel frame of the Old Colony Building (1893-94) in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago. In this system of bracing, deepening the ends of the girder into quarter-circular
label: Paragraph

text: fillets gives the underside of the girder an arched profile.
label: Paragraph

text: The culmination of the Chicago School’s contributions to steel-frame construction
label: Paragraph

text: came with the Reliance Building (1894-95) after the plans of D.H.Burnham & Company
label: Paragraph

text: and the engineer Edward C.Shankland. The steel frame of this slender tower is carefully
label: Paragraph

text: braced in two ways: clinch-deep spandrel girders provide the usual portal bracing, and
label: Paragraph

text: two-story columns erected with staggered joints increase the rigidity of the vertical
label: Caption

text: members.
label: Paragraph

text: STEINER HOUSE, VIENNA
label: Caption

text: Designed by Adolf Loos; completed 1910 Vienna, Austria
label: Caption

text: The Steiner House is among the best known of Adolf Loos’s early residential works.
label: Paragraph

text: Loos designed the house in early 1910, at the same time he was working on the even
label: Paragraph

text: more controversial Michaelerplatz Building, and the two projects bear a certain kinship
label: Paragraph

text: despite their programmatic differences. Both works followed immediately in the wake of
label: Paragraph

text: Loos’s famed address, “Ornament und Verbrechen” (Omament and Crime), first
label: Paragraph

text: delivered in January of the same year, and as a result, they may be understood as
label: Paragraph

text: exemplars of the antiornamental ideas he laid out in the talk. The Steiner House,
label: Paragraph

text: however, which was completed by the end of 1910, more than a half year before the
label: Paragraph

text: much-discussed Michaelerplatz Building, initially drew little public notice, no doubt in
label: Paragraph

text: large measure because it was a private domicile in an inconspicuous residential
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhood.
label: Paragraph

text: The clients, wealthy textile manufacturer Hugo Steiner and his wife, Lily, a graphic
label: Paragraph

text: artist and painter, subsequently commissioned Loos to design the interiors of their elegant
label: Paragraph

text: Knize tailor shops in Vienna, Paris, and Berlin. The house itself, by contrast, is rather
label: Paragraph

text: modest in terms of both its scale and its detailing. The freestanding structure is roughly
label: Paragraph

text: square in plan (13.5 by 14.5 meters). Seen from the front, it appears to consist of a single
label: Paragraph

text: story with a high attic. In fact, the house has three stories, which are clearly visible from
label: Paragraph

text: the rear garden. The most distinctive feature of the building, the curving sheet-metal roof,
label: Paragraph

text: was Loos’ reply to the local building codes, which required that the streetfronts of houses
label: Paragraph

text: in the area be no more than one story, with a second-story mansard. Loos maximized the
label: Paragraph

text: space by concealing not one but two stories in the attic and connecting the half-barrel
label: Paragraph

text: vault in the front to a flat concrete roof covering the rear two-thirds of the structure. The
label: Paragraph

text: resulting configuration, despite its somewhat peculiar profile, allowed Loos to make use
label: Paragraph

text: of nearly the entire interior volume.
label: Paragraph

text: The front and rear facades of the house are symmetrically arranged, although the
label: Paragraph

text: windows and doors have varying formats and dimensions. By contrast, the fenestration
label: Paragraph

text: pattern on the two sides is irregular, and on the southeastern side is a projecting bay
label: Paragraph

text: topped by a small balcony accessible from the second story. Unlike Loos’ later residential
label: Paragraph

text: works, with their complex interlocking volumes, the regular horizontal layering of the
label: Paragraph

text: floors is maintained, but the rooms on the three levels are of different heights: the ceilings
label: Paragraph

text: on the ground floor are 2.85 meters, those on the second floor 3 meters, and those on the
label: Paragraph

text: uppermost floor 2.10 meters. The ground floor contains a large vestibule, a kitchen, and
label: Caption

text: an adjoining living and dining room, which extend the length of the house’s rear. On the
label: Caption

text: second story were originally two bedrooms, a servant’s room, a small children’s room,
label: Paragraph

text: and a studio for Lily Steiner (facing out to the street), and the third floor was taken up
label: Paragraph

text: with a laundry room and other service spaces. In addition, the house also has a basement,
label: Paragraph

text: which at the time of its completion housed a garage, another servant’s room, a furnace
label: Paragraph

text: room, and a coal storage space. As in all of Loos’ residences, there is a clear distinction
label: Paragraph

text: between the public and private domains and between the served and serving spaces. The
label: Paragraph

text: principal living areas and the bedroom above are linked with a stair, but there is a second
label: Paragraph

text: spiral staircase to allow the servants access to all four floors.
label: Caption

text: The original interior detailing was remarkably simple, combining white walls, dark-
label: Paragraph

text: stained oak wainscoting, and beamed ceilings on the ground floor and painted white
label: Caption

text: wainscoting and floral wallpaper in the upstairs bedrooms. A number of the rooms were
label: Paragraph

text: also originally furnished with both built-in and free-standing furniture of Loos’ own
label: Paragraph

text: design, including chairs, benches, stools, and a buffet. In contrast to the exterior, with its
label: Paragraph

text: associations to the Mediterranean vernacular, the interior evoked an air of contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: Anglo-Saxon domesticity, a feel-ing that was further enhanced by the flowing quality of
label: Paragraph

text: the principal ground-floor spaces—living room, dining area, and music room—that Loos
label: Paragraph

text: would further develop in his subsequent houses. Movement to and from these spaces,
label: Paragraph

text: however, was limited to a conventional enclosed hallway, a strategy that Loos would
label: Paragraph

text: later largely abandon.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early histories of modernism, much was made of the Steiner House’s simple,
label: Paragraph

text: planar walls and lack of traditional detailing, which seemed to directly presage the rise of
label: Paragraph

text: the new purist architecture of the post-World War | period—an idea further advanced
label: Paragraph

text: through views of the house’s rear garden facade, which were juxtaposed with later works
label: Paragraph

text: by Le Corbusier and others. Vincent Scully, writing in 1961, similarly noted the
label: Paragraph

text: connection between “the obsessive puritanism” of Loos’ prewar works and His polemical
label: Paragraph

text: statements concerning the elimination of ornament. More recently, however, it has
label: Paragraph

text: become clear that many of the features of the Steiner House, like Loos’ other buildings of
label: Paragraph

text: the time, derived as much from his attempt to find an appropriate modern language as
label: Paragraph

text: from his belief in continuing the Viennese tradition. Indeed, both the house’s sheet-metal
label: Paragraph

text: roof and its smooth stucco finish draw directly on traditional local building practices, and
label: Paragraph

text: the design must be seen not only in light of the turn-of-the-century Viennese interest in
label: Paragraph

text: abstraction but also in that of the contemporary Biedermeier Revival. Loos’ apparent
label: Paragraph

text: rejection of ornament in this view is less an expression of a new functionalism than a
label: Paragraph

text: reaffirmation of older ideas of bourgeois modesty and propriety, values that very much
label: Paragraph

text: suited the house’s first owners. The apparent contrast between the exterior and interior,
label: Paragraph

text: which has also been repeatedly observed, may also be understood not as an inherent
label: Paragraph

text: contradiction but as a reflection of Loos’ notion of the difference between the public
label: Paragraph

text: sphere, where propriety is paramount, and the private world, where a more relaxed
label: Paragraph

text: attitude may prevail. Such an interpretation suggests not only the complexity of Loos’
label: Paragraph

text: views but also the transitional nature of the house’s design.
label: Paragraph

text: STERN, ROBERT ARTHUR MORGAN 1939
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: A brilliant polymath in command of a daunting array of talents, Robert Stern is perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: the true successor to Philip Johnson, one of his mentors, as one of the prime figures in the
label: Paragraph

text: American architectural world. In 1998, Stern was appointed dean of the school of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture at Yale University, where he had earned a Master of Architecture degree
label: Paragraph

text: (1965). He was coeditor of Perspecta 9-10, the first double issue of that distinguished
label: Paragraph

text: periodical created by graduate architectural students at Yale. In 1970, he began teaching
label: Paragraph

text: in the Graduate School of Architecture, Planning, and Preservation at his undergraduate
label: Paragraph

text: alma mater, Columbia University (BA., 1960), and in 1984 undertook a four-year term as
label: Paragraph

text: first director of its Temple Hoyne Buell Center for the Study of American Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Stern’s eclecticism and reliance on quotation in his architectural practice has been
label: Paragraph

text: criticized, but as in the 19th century, exemplars are chosen according to their
label: Paragraph

text: appropriateness to program or context. Furthermore, the often dazzling spatial strategies,
label: Paragraph

text: as well as the techniques of collage and juxtaposition, are thoroughly of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Initially a disciple of Robert Venturi, whom Stern launched (when in 1966 he curated “40
label: Paragraph

text: under 40,” an important exhibition that brought a new generation of architects to public
label: Paragraph

text: attention) on the national stage while still a student at Yale, gradually Stern moved in a
label: Paragraph

text: more overtly historicizing direction. Nevertheless, the quality of wit and irony so
label: Paragraph

text: important to postmodernists such as Venturi and Charles Moore also pervades Stern’s
label: Paragraph

text: work; their affinity for Pop art is mirrored in his amusing allusions that at times approach
label: Paragraph

text: parody.
label: Paragraph

text: Stern’s Postmodernism, a movement that he did much to foster, has many different
label: Paragraph

text: sources, although he is particularly fond of the classical tradition (as explained in his
label: Paragraph

text: book Modern Classicism), especially as represented in late 18th-century France
label: Paragraph

text: (Poolhouse, Llewellyn Park, 1981, and Point West Place Offices, Framingham 1985 are
label: Paragraph

text: both based on Claude-Nicolas Ledoux), Colonial (Residence in at Apaquogue, East
label: Paragraph

text: Hampton, 1993), and Federal America (Observatory Hill Dining Commons, 1984, and
label: Paragraph

text: Darden School of Business, 1996 both at the University of Virginia and therefore,
label: Paragraph

text: predictably, transcriptions of Thomas Jefferson’s work); his “Late Entry to the Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: Tribune” (1980) marries Adolf Loos with Mies van der Rohe (each a classicist in his own
label: Paragraph

text: way). However, Stern also is one of the most skillful manipulators of the late 19th-
label: Paragraph

text: century Shingle style (houses on Martha’s Vineyard, 1983), which he learned about
label: Paragraph

text: firsthand from his Yale professor and later colleague Vincent Scully and from the
label: Paragraph

text: frequent commissions in his early career that comprised extensions to authentic Shingle-
label: Paragraph

text: style houses. When the building type demands it, he may turn to the Richardsonian
label: Paragraph

text: Romanesque; thus, the Ohrstrom Library, 1991, at St. Paul’s School is, in plan and
label: Paragraph

text: elevation, an interpretation of Richardson’s small-town libraries, complete with the
label: Paragraph

text: eyebrow dormer windows, and Stern himself identifies Charles Rennie Mackintosh as a
label: Paragraph

text: guide. Craftsman features, including touches
label: Paragraph

text: of Frank Lloyd Wright and Julia Morgan, inform the Roger Tory Peterson Institute, 1993,

text: of the nearby British Embassy and other Westernized buildings in Tokyo. Further, as
label: Paragraph

text: heroic modernism itself has passed into history, Stern is happy to emulate its most
label: Paragraph

text: positive aspects; as his remodeled loft duplex (1999) in New Haven attests, he is
label: Paragraph

text: especially fond of furniture produced under its banner, from Le Corbusier and Charlotte
label: Paragraph

text: Perriand to Eames and Saarinen.
label: Paragraph

text: Stern’s first executed work was the Wiseman House in Montauk (1967), an obvious
label: Paragraph

text: bow to the Vanna Venturi residence, though altered to suit a family with children and
label: Paragraph

text: incorporating elements from Le Corbusier. Houses of the next decade (including those
label: Paragraph

text: done with John Hagmann, a Yale classmate who was a partner from 1969 to 1977), such
label: Paragraph

text: as the Lang House in Washington, Connecticut, 1974, and the Beebe houses in Montauk,
label: Paragraph

text: 1972, continued Venturi’s lessons but revealed a penchant for interestingly varied
label: Paragraph

text: sections and sensitive treatment of natural light and of views toward the land- and
label: Paragraph

text: seascape. Stern has said that private houses are his obsession, and he has continued to
label: Paragraph

text: design them, although subsequently, more public building types have eclipsed the
label: Paragraph

text: domestic side of his practice.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the dense urban matrix composed of commercial structures informs his
label: Paragraph

text: work. His first job (1967-70) was with the New York Housing and Development
label: Paragraph

text: Administration, and he has published an invaluable series of exhaustively researched
label: Paragraph

text: books on New York City architecture. His firm has been responsible for many
label: Paragraph

text: renovations and additions in New York City and has erected tall buildings in Boston as
label: Paragraph

text: well as Manhattan. Yet small towns delight him, too: he has supported New Urbanists
label: Paragraph

text: such as Andreas Duany and Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk and mirrored their insights in his
label: Paragraph

text: planning, with Jacquelyn Robertson of Celebration, Florida, and other Disney sites. He
label: Paragraph

text: also acknowledges studying his summer hometown of East Hampton in this connection.
label: Paragraph

text: Stern even has affection for the much-maligned suburb, writing cogently on its virtues
label: Paragraph

text: and making several ideal schemes that exploit its possibilities.
label: Paragraph

text: STICKLEY, GUSTAV 1858-1942
label: Title

text: Architect and designer, United States
label: Caption

text: Gustav Stickley remains one of the most well known figures of early 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: American architectural history, not because he was an architect creating revolutionary
label: Paragraph

text: spaces or employing new materials or innovative structural systems but because he was
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps the most influential designer of his generation. Stickley furniture and the
label: Paragraph

text: Craftsman bungalow style established an appealing image that came to embody the
label: Paragraph

text: honest and simple life of an unsophisticated, independent, democratic American. It is
label: Paragraph

text: ironic that such an architectural influence would spring from a man who was not a trained
label: Paragraph

text: architect but whose career as a furniture designer prompted a widespread change in
label: Paragraph

text: domestic taste and residential design. Stickley’s model houses influenced builders and
label: Paragraph

text: home owners throughout the country to create whole neighborhoods of Craftsman
label: Paragraph

text: bungalows as well as an interior aesthetic that personified home for an entire generation.
label: Paragraph

text: Elements inspired by English domestic architecture and an Arts and Crafts attitude
label: Paragraph

text: toward craftsmanship especially informed the Stickley aesthetic. Inspired by the
label: Paragraph

text: communal character of medieval great halls, Craftsman living rooms displaced formal
label: Paragraph

text: parlors and opened to large dining rooms, creating gathering places for family and
label: Paragraph

text: friends: the fireplace hearth and ample-dining room table encouraged conversation,
label: Paragraph

text: intimacy, and conviviality, making the bungalow a place for social interaction as well as
label: Paragraph

text: private comfort. Built-in bookcases, stenciled walls, and objets d’art brought a cultural
label: Paragraph

text: enrichment and art into the lives of the inhabitant on a daily basis. Evidences of artisan
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmanship abounded as sconces and chandeliers were handcrafted, linens and textiles
label: Paragraph

text: omamented tabletops and chests, and tilework enriched fireplace surrounds. The
label: Caption

text: Craftsman interior was an artistic home in which art and life were synthesized, but not by
label: Paragraph

text: means of sophisticated, dust-collecting bric-a-brac and the excessive ornamentation that
label: Paragraph

text: had characterized Eastlake and Queen Anne interiors of the late Victorian Aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: movement, to which Stickley’s simplified forms and restraint may be seen to be in
label: Paragraph

text: reaction.
label: Paragraph

text: Gustav Stickley was the eldest son of a large family and one of the oldest of an
label: Paragraph

text: emerging generation of American Arts and Crafts figures: born in Wisconsin in 1858,
label: Paragraph

text: Stickley was two years younger than his archrival, Elbert Hubbard (b. 1856), founder of
label: Paragraph

text: the Roycrofters, but four years older than Bernard Maybeck (b. 1862) and a decade older
label: Paragraph

text: than Frank Lloyd Wright (b. 1867) and the Greene brothers (Charles Sumner Greene, b.
label: Paragraph

text: 1868; Henry Mather Greene, b. 1870). Toward the end of the 1890s and following a
label: Paragraph

text: series of enterprises in various furniture-making companies over about 15 years, Stickley
label: Paragraph

text: traveled to England and the Continent, where he was exposed to Arts and Crafts ideals
label: Paragraph

text: and the message of artisan handwork. William Morris (1834-96) had recently died, and
label: Paragraph

text: John Ruskin (1819-1900) was too ill to receive visitors, but Stickley’s affinity to their
label: Paragraph

text: ideals and philosophy was indicated by his devoting the first issue of The Crafisman
label: Paragraph

text: magazine (1901-16) to Morris and the second issue to Ruskin. Between Stickley’s
label: Paragraph

text: England visit and the establishment of The Craftsman in 1901, Stickley produced his first
label: Paragraph

text: pieces of Craftsman furniture, rejecting the stylish and ecclectic furniture of his earlier
label: Paragraph

text: business associations. As he began to make simpler Craftsman pieces, Stickley also
label: Paragraph

text: experimented with proportions, refined forms, and developed a finish that would
label: Paragraph

text: maintain the natural qualities of wood while protecting its surfaces and color.
label: Paragraph

text: Some 40 years earlier, when Philip Webb (1831-1915) completed Red House (1859)
label: Paragraph

text: for William Morris, the client realized proper furniture and interior fittings were
label: Paragraph

text: unavailable for his simple and “styleless” house, and so Morris looked to his artist and
label: Paragraph

text: artisan friends to design pieces to ornament the house, establishing William Morris and
label: Paragraph

text: Company to produce such furnishings for a wider audience and clientele. Stickley was
label: Paragraph

text: faced with the reverse situation. He had developed a simplified, styleless furniture
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic and realized that late Victorian houses, particularly the popular Queen Anne
label: Paragraph

text: domestic forms, were unsuitable for his simple, honest, and unadorned furniture, and thus
label: Paragraph

text: the Craftsman bungalow was born.
label: Paragraph

text: The earliest designs for Craftsman houses were amateurish, and Stickley’s first
label: Paragraph

text: architects less competent, but following a brief association (1903-04) with Harvey Ellis,
label: Paragraph

text: both the refinement of furniture and the quality of architecture improved. By the middle
label: Paragraph

text: of the first decade of the 20th century, Stickley’s Craftsman aesthetic had reached a
label: Paragraph

text: maturity that stimulated a national craze. Both Craftsman furniture and Craftsman houses
label: Paragraph

text: were marked by a frank structural expression that was strong and conspicuous in the
label: Paragraph

text: elimination of carving, inlay, moldings, and ornament. Built-in furniture (bookcases and
label: Paragraph

text: china cabinets) became part architecture, part furniture, and even freestanding furniture,
label: Paragraph

text: such as settles, thronelike armchairs, and large refectory-inspired dining room tables or
label: Paragraph

text: writing tables and appeared architectonic in their four-square, virtually “trabeated”
label: Paragraph

text: construction and form.
label: Paragraph

text: As Stickley first turned from the ecclectic historicism and revivalism of earlier
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetics, the United States was experiencing a surge of Arts and Crafts interest. Elbert
label: Paragraph

text: Hubbard had established his Roycrofter community in East Aurora, New York, in 1895
label: Paragraph

text: and was soon publishing The Philistine magazine and his Little Journeys to the Homes of
label: Paragraph

text: the Great book series. Arts and Crafts societies were founded in Boston and Chicago in
label: Paragraph

text: 1897, in Minneapolis in 1899, and in Grand Rapids, Michigan, in 1902. Frank Lloyd
label: Caption

text: Wright was buying and making artisan fittings and furnishings, including Stickley
label: Paragraph

text: furniture, for his home in Oak Park (built 1889 on), and he produced his own artisan
label: Paragraph

text: prairie houses during the first decade of the 20th century. Charles Keeler (1871-1937)
label: Caption

text: founded the Ruskin Club (1896) in Berkeley, California, and Bernard Maybeck was
label: Paragraph

text: building “simple homes” in the San Francisco Bay Area “tradition” already at the turn of
label: Paragraph

text: the century. Greene and Greene were building bungalows in southern California when
label: Paragraph

text: Stickley visited there in 1904, and the Greene brothers soon took the Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic to an extraordinary level of refinement and richness in such “ultimate
label: Paragraph

text: bungalows” as the Blacker House (1907) and the Gamble House (1908).
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout the period, Stickley’s Craftsman empire was widening. In November 1903,
label: Paragraph

text: The Craftsman magazine announced the Home Builder’s Club, through which any
label: Paragraph

text: subscriber could order free home plans for houses costing $2,000 to $5,000. By 1916,
label: Paragraph

text: when the magazine folded, some 200 plans had been published, appearing monthly since
label: Paragraph

text: 1904. By 1914 Stickley’s Craftsman furniture was being sold by some 50 dealers.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1905 Stickley was headquartered in New York City, although he maintained his
label: Paragraph

text: furniture factory earlier established at Eastwood (Syracuse), New York. In 1911 Stickley
label: Paragraph

text: built the Craftsman Farms in Morris Plains, New Jersey, and two years later he took the
label: Paragraph

text: dramatic step of leasing a small skyscraper in New York in which to consolidate his
label: Paragraph

text: enterprises. The 12-story, 200-foot-deep Craftsman Building on 39th Street in New York
label: Caption

text: City contained four lower floors of showrooms for furniture, draperies, and rugs; four
label: Paragraph

text: middle floors housing the Craftsman Permanent Homebuilders Exposition, in which
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturers rented space to display house and garden products and model rooms; and
label: Paragraph

text: four top floors for various Stickley enterprises supporting the Craftsman movement:
label: Caption

text: Craftsman workshops demonstrating crafts, Craftsman architects available to discuss
label: Title

text: house plans, and the editorial offices of The Craftsman as well as club rooms, lecture
label: Paragraph

text: rooms, a library, and a restaurant, the latter serving meats, vegetables, and fruits
label: Paragraph

text: homegrown on the Craftsman Farms in an ambiance in which restaurant patrons sat at
label: Paragraph

text: Craftsman dinner place settings amidst Craftsman chairs, Grueby tiled fireplaces, and
label: Paragraph

text: Craftsman fittings.
label: Paragraph

text: The whole was too much. Stickley had overextended, and by March 1915, The
label: Paragraph

text: Craftsman Inc. was bankrupt. The Crafisman magazine published its last issue in
label: Paragraph

text: December 1916 and merged with Art World in January 1917. Stickley left New York and
label: Paragraph

text: soon returned to Syracuse for a brief but unsuccessful effort to work with his brothers in
label: Paragraph

text: the furniture business (Stickley Associated Cabinetmakers, 1917-18). By 1918, Stickley
label: Paragraph

text: was 60, the country was at war, and his wife had died. Stickley moved back to his old
label: Paragraph

text: Syracuse home, now owned by his daughter and her husband, and for 24 years lived in a
label: Paragraph

text: third-floor suite with a small kitchen where he continued experimenting with wood
label: Paragraph

text: finishes, still working with his hands in admiration of the natural properties of wood.
label: Paragraph

text: From the end of the 19th century until World War I, Stickley created a national empire
label: Paragraph

text: of furniture and furnishings that inspired a national movement in architecture. When
label: Paragraph

text: Midwest regional artist Grant Wood painted the tapered piers of a bungalow porch and
label: Paragraph

text: called his picture “Main Street Mansion,” he made an icon of Stickley’s Craftsman
label: Paragraph

text: bungalow for Everyman: a simple American house characterized by a direct structural
label: Paragraph

text: expression of carpentry and joinery and an honest display of materials. The Craftsman
label: Paragraph

text: house was the product of entrepreneurial enterprise, Arts and Crafts ideals, and Stickley’s
label: Paragraph

text: reverence for simplicity. Within the short period of a single generation and in the
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of an Emersonian, self-reliant individualism, a furniture maker had become one
label: Paragraph

text: of the most influential designers in the history of American domestic architecture: In the
label: Paragraph

text: opening years of the 20th century, Stickley produced the quintessential house style for
label: Paragraph

text: democratic America.
label: Paragraph

text: STIRLING, JAMES 1926-92
label: Title

text: Architect, Scotland and England
label: Title

text: James Frazer Stirling was born in Glasgow in 1926 but was rather proud of having
label: Paragraph

text: been conceived on board a ship docked in Manhattan. His father was a marine engineer,
label: Paragraph

text: and this might account for Stirling’s love of tight, shipshape modern design. He studied
label: Paragraph

text: architecture at Liverpool University, where the presence of Colin Rowe as a fellow
label: Paragraph

text: student may help explain the classical and humanist tendencies seen in his later work.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1953 Stirling worked for Lyons Israel and Ellis in London, where he met James
label: Paragraph

text: Gowan. They commenced practice together in 1956 and soon became known for a series
label: Paragraph

text: of buildings that, although uncompromisingly modern, owed little to the thendominant
label: Paragraph

text: International Style. The principal works of the partnership were houses at Ham Common
label: Paragraph

text: (1955-58); a competition project for Churchill College, Cambridge (1958); a project for
label: Paragraph

text: Selwyn College, Cambridge (1959); and the Leicester University Engineering Building
label: Caption

text: (1959-63), which achieved worldwide fame both for its dramatic contrast of red bricks
label: Paragraph

text: and greenhouse glazing and for the audacity of its formal precision.
label: Paragraph

text: From 1964 to 1971, Stirling practiced alone. To this period belong many original
label: Paragraph

text: designs, including the Cambridge University History Faculty Building (1964-67);
label: Paragraph

text: residential units for students (1964-68) at St. Andrew’s University; the projects for
label: Paragraph

text: Dorman Long Headquarters (1965) in Middlesborough; the Florey Building (1966-71)
label: Caption

text: for Queen’s College, Oxford; housing for Runcorn New Town (1967-76); the Olivetti
label: Caption

text: Training Centre (1969-72) at Haslemere; and projects for Siemens AG (1969) in Munich
label: Paragraph

text: and for Derby Civic Centre (1970). In the two last projects, Leon Krier was assistant, and
label: Paragraph

text: his hand may be detected in drawings made between 1968 and 1970. It seems that
label: Paragraph

text: Stirling’s work did not conform sufficiently to the current ethos, and almost ten years
label: Paragraph

text: were to pass before he again received an important British commission—for the
label: Paragraph

text: extension of the Tate Gallery in London (1986).
label: Caption

text: From 1971 to 1992, Stirling was in partnership with his associate Michael Wilford.
label: Paragraph

text: Their more important work includes projects for the Olivetti Headquarters (1971) at
label: Paragraph

text: Milton Keynes
label: Title

text: The Clore Gallery for the Turner Collection, Tate Gallery, London (1986)

text: and for an Arts Centre (1971) at St. Andrew’s University, competition designs for the

label: Caption

text: After taking part in a competition for lower Manhattan in 1968 and serving as a
label: Paragraph

text: visiting critic and professor at the Yale University School of Architecture from 1960,
label: Paragraph

text: Stirling became well known in the United States. As a result, he received a number of
label: Paragraph

text: commissions, including an extension to the Rice University School of Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (1979-81) in Houston; the Sackler wing of the Fogg Art Museum (1984), Harvard
label: Caption

text: University, Cambridge, Massachusetts; and the Chemistry Department (1981), Columbia
label: Caption

text: University, New York. The latter project was abandoned, but the Performing Arts Center
label: Paragraph

text: for Cornell University in Ithaca, New York, was completed in 1988 and the Science
label: Paragraph

text: Library for the University of California, Irvine, in 1996.
label: Caption

text: Some critics have seen Stirling’s work after 1970 as taking on an increasingly formalist
label: Paragraph

text: tendency. Works such as the Staatsgalerie Stuttgart and the Tate Gallery extensions have
label: Paragraph

text: been referred to as Postmodern. Close examination, however, will show the underlying
label: Paragraph

text: unity of all his work, although there is certainly an important shift (somewhat analogous
label: Paragraph

text: to the shift in Le Corbusier’s late work with the Chapel of Notre Dame du Haut in
label: Paragraph

text: Ronchamp) in that, compared with his earlier buildings, a freer rein is given to expressive
label: Paragraph

text: gestures. Stirling is always consciously experimental in his use equally of eclectic
label: Paragraph

text: reference and formal structures. In freely admitting the premeditated nature of all artistic
label: Paragraph

text: creation, he has liberated himself from the false determinism that plagued so much
label: Paragraph

text: architectural production after 1945. The element of historicity in his work is no less self-
label: Paragraph

text: conscious and willful than was the element of modernity in his early work. It is this
label: Paragraph

text: candor and lack of preconception that perhaps makes his work so vital.
label: Paragraph

text: Some of Stirling’s most interesting work remains in the form of projects, such as the
label: Paragraph

text: superb design for a Public Library (1983) at Latina in Italy; the competition entries for
label: Paragraph

text: the National Gallery Extension (1985) in London; the Thyssen Art Gallery (1986) in
label: Paragraph

text: Lugano; a design for residential development (1988) at Canary Wharf, London; the
label: Paragraph

text: Philharmonic Hall (1988) for Los Angeles; the Bibliothéque de France (1989); and the
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo International Forum (1989).
label: Paragraph

text: However, other larger commissions have matured, giving us the Research and
label: Paragraph

text: Production Headquarters for Braun Pharmaceuticals (completed 1992) at Melsungen,
label: Paragraph

text: near Frankfurt, with the collaboration of Walter Nageli. Since Stirling’s death in 1992,
label: Paragraph

text: we have the Music Academy (completed 1995) at Stutt-gart; the Science Library
label: Paragraph

text: (completed 1996) for the University of California, Irvine; the Temesek Polytechnic
label: Caption

text: University (1998) in Singapore; a mixed development at No. | Poultry (completed 1998)
label: Paragraph

text: in the city of London; the mixed residential and offices building (completed 1999) in
label: Paragraph

text: Carlton Gardens; and the Performing Arts Centre (under construction) at Salford,
label: Paragraph

text: Lancashire.
label: Paragraph

text: Of these, the Braun Headquarters is especially remarkable for the expressiveness of its
label: Paragraph

text: forms. The single line of conical capitals carrying the administration building is rendered
label: Paragraph

text: immaterial in certain lights by the choice of materials, so that the building seems to float
label: Paragraph

text: rather than bear down. It is as though the language of modern architecture had been taken
label: Paragraph

text: into meditation and revised in the light of an inner vision.
label: Paragraph

text: All these works show a remarkable consistency in their conception and design, which
label: Paragraph

text: is probably explained by the talent and the loyalty of the architects that Stirling and
label: Paragraph

text: Wilford have employed. Since Stirling’s unnecessary death in 1992, the control of the
label: Paragraph

text: office has passed to his partner, Michael Wilford, who has affirmed his commitment to
label: Paragraph

text: the sort of architecture that Stirling practiced: experimental, making use of technology
label: Paragraph

text: but not allowing technology to impose its values alone, aiming always to extend and
label: Paragraph

text: improve the city fabric, and communicating enjoyment to ordinary people. The working
label: Paragraph

text: team remains largely intact, and the work continues in large measure to be imprinted with
label: Paragraph

text: his genius. In 1992, just before going into the hospital for a routine operation, Stirling
label: Paragraph

text: accepted a knighthood.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Born in Glasgow, Scotland, 22 April 1926. Studied at the Liverpool School of Art 1942;
label: Paragraph

text: attended the University of Liverpool School of Architecture 1945-50; exchange student
label: Paragraph

text: in New York 1949; degree in architecture 1950; studied at the School of Town Planning
label: Paragraph

text: and Regional Research, London 1950-52. Served in the British Army 1942-45. Worked
label: Paragraph

text: as senior assistant for Lyons, Israel, Ellis and Gray, London 1953-56; partnership with
label: Paragraph

text: James Gowan, London 1956-63. Private practice, London from 1964; partner, with
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: Associates, London 1971-92. Visiting lecturer, Architectural Association, London 1955;
label: Caption

label: Caption

label: Caption

text: Lecturer 1965; Davenport Professor, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut from
label: Caption

text: 1967; visiting professor, Akademie der Kiinste, Diisseldorf from 1977; Banister Fletcher
label: Paragraph

text: Professor, London University 1977; Architect-in-Residence, American Academy, Rome
label: Caption

label: Caption

text: STOCKHOLM PUBLIC LIBRARY
label: Title

text: Designed by Erik Gunnar Asplund; 1918-28; additions 1928-31
label: Caption

text: Stockholm, Sweden
label: Title

text: The City Library (Stadsbiblioteket) in Stockholm, designed by Erik Gunnar Asplund,
label: Paragraph

text: is one of those unusual 20th-century buildings that has had two lives. Design work began
label: Paragraph

text: in 1918, and the Library opened to widespread acclaim ten years later. Its second life
label: Paragraph

text: came in the late 1970s and the 1980s, when architects and critics were looking afresh at
label: Paragraph

text: early 20th-century architects such as Asplund, whose work represented a form of
label: Paragraph

text: modernity that did not involve the adoption of modernist functionalism.
label: Paragraph

text: The commission of the City Library was prompted by a gift from the Knut and Alice
label: Paragraph

text: Wallenberg Foundation. Their donation of one million kronor (Swedish crowns)
label: Paragraph

text: stipulated that matching funds as well as land and all design costs be provided by the
label: Paragraph

text: Stockholm City Council. Carl Westman (1866-1936), who had just completed the
label: Paragraph

text: Radhuset (1908-15), the municipal courthouse in Stockholm, was invited to serve as
label: Paragraph

text: architectural consultant, but he declined, and an offer was made to Asplund, then only 32
label: Paragraph

text: years old, who was appointed on 2 December 1918. It was an important commission, not
label: Paragraph

text: only for the prominence of building and site but also for its uniqueness: It was the first
label: Paragraph

text: public library building in Sweden from which patrons themselves could remove books
label: Paragraph

text: from the shelves.
label: Paragraph

text: The site chosen was the corner of Sveavagen and Odengatan, slightly outside the
label: Paragraph

text: center of the city, on a lot that included the termination of the Brunkebergsdsen ridge, on
label: Paragraph

text: which Carl Harleman had built an observatory (1746-53). The first plan (published 1921)
label: Paragraph

text: was to develop the entire lot, including a school of economics and law faculty for the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Stockholm as well as the Library and a market hall along Odengatan. Work
label: Paragraph

text: began initially on the Library program, and in May 1920 Asplund and the city librarian
label: Paragraph

text: Fredrijk Hjelmqvist were sent to the United States to study American libraries. Their
label: Paragraph

text: journey took them to the major cities on the East Coast and the Midwest, and the visitors
label: Paragraph

text: were particularly impressed by Cass Gilbert’s Main Library (1913-21) in Detroit,
label: Paragraph

text: Michigan, which provided a model for the centralized plan, second-story book room, and
label: Paragraph

text: upper-level down lighting later employed in Stockholm. Asplund was also impressed by
label: Paragraph

text: the functionalist process by which Americans studied libraries. “In America,” he wrote in
label: Paragraph

text: his travel journal, “one gets an overwhelming impression of the extraordinary, almost
label: Paragraph

text: scientific care with which the libraries are designed. It is a continuously evolving
label: Paragraph

text: development towards better result. Experiences of earlier libraries are studied and utilized
label: Paragraph

text: in every new one.”
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund was predisposed to a classically inspired solution for the Library. His earliest
label: Paragraph

text: sketches, possibly from 1919, employ circular spaces that suggest that the original
label: Paragraph

text: inspiration might have been Palladio’s Villa Rotunda in Vicenza. This kind of source
label: Paragraph

text: might have been expected for someone educated at the Klara School (1910-11), where
label: Paragraph

text: stripped-down classicism was used to evoke modernity. Revisions (1921) to the original
label: Paragraph

text: proposals, after the American trip, show a gridded facade with paired columns and a
label: Paragraph

text: truncated entablature that recalls, albeit much simplified, Ivar Tengbom’s contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: Konserthuset (1920-26). As part of this early scheme, a dome rises prominently from the
label: Paragraph

text: center of the block.
label: Paragraph

text: Changes were made by the time of construction. The building was raised to a broad
label: Paragraph

text: plinth above street level to accommodate the irregular terrain, and the university
label: Paragraph

text: buildings and market hall were suppressed. Along Sveavagen, shops were added, and
label: Paragraph

text: entry to the Library was placed on axis with the main door along a ramplike flight of
label: Paragraph

text: stairs through the (later) shopping block. The Library itself is a square with a projecting
label: Paragraph

text: cylinder rather than a raised dome, as originally proposed, to mark the circular reading
label: Paragraph

text: room rotunda. Around the outside of the Library is a low-relief Etruscan-Egyptian frieze,
label: Caption

text: and the marble door is Egyptian in style, with canted sides. From the marble entrance
label: Caption

text: lobby, a flight of narrow stairs between dark marble walls leads directly to the reading
label: Paragraph

text: room, a fact that is also revealed from street level.
label: Paragraph

text: The central reading room is the heart of the plan. Three levels of open-shelved books
label: Paragraph

text: surround the central space. This was Asplund’s clear design preference, and he argued to
label: Paragraph

text: the program committee that in addition to its formal value, the circular plan was more
label: Paragraph

text: functional, allowing more space along the walls for bookshelves and on the floor for
label: Paragraph

text: desks, chairs, and the librarians’ station. The reading areas were furnished with lights,
label: Paragraph

text: tables, and chairs designed by Asplund. All other rooms (for reading, study, and
label: Paragraph

text: periodicals) are subservient to the central space, located either in the surrounding square
label: Paragraph

text: or, as light wells, in the spandrels between the square and the rotunda. One of the most
label: Paragraph

text: noted rooms is a special section for children that was decorated with a semicircular fresco
label: Paragraph

text: by Nils Dardel depicting the dream figure of John Blund and his umbrella. (Blund is a
label: Paragraph

text: kind of sandman who brings sleep and happy dreams to Scandinavian children.)
label: Paragraph

text: There has been much discussion of the nature of Asplund’s sources. Roman sources
label: Paragraph

text: from the Pantheon to the Castel Sant’Angelo (Rasmussen, 1940) and to the Tomb of
label: Paragraph

text: Hadrian, as illustrated by Fischer von Erlach (Donnelly, 1992), have been the most
label: Paragraph

text: commonly cited for the square plus cylinder. Caldenby (1985) and others have suggested
label: Paragraph

text: that the Library might depend on Claude-Nicolas Ledoux’s Rotonde de la Villette (1785—
label: Paragraph

text: 89), one of his tollbooths for Paris. It has also been suggested that Asplund knew Etienne
label: Paragraph

text: Boullée’s Cenotaph for Isaac Newton (Wrede, 1980), an unlikely possibility, as Boullée’s
label: Paragraph

text: image was generally available only later. A more conventional source, one that is
label: Paragraph

text: typologically appropriate, would have been Sidney Smirke’s rotunda (1854-57) for the
label: Paragraph

text: British Museum in London. Perhaps the initial idea for a dome came from Harlemann’s
label: Paragraph

text: observatory on the hill above. Finally, it cannot be forgotten that the City Library stands
label: Paragraph

text: at the north end Sveavagen, a street that originates at Tessin’s Royal Palace on Gamla
label: Paragraph

text: Stan and that provides justification for the monumental character of the building. Indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: a specific recollection might be found in the ramplike entry, which recalls the approach to
label: Paragraph

text: the Royal Palace up Slottsbacken in addition to stairway sequences that had inspired him
label: Paragraph

text: during his Italian journey (1913-14), as has been observed by Winter. Finally, the
label: Paragraph

text: classicizing order of the building includes decorative motifs: Egyptian, Etruscan, and
label: Paragraph

text: Greek Revival, most notably from Michael Gottlieb Bindesbell at the Thorvaldsen
label: Paragraph

text: Museum in Copenhagen (1839-48), whose Egyptian-style portal seems to have been a
label: Paragraph

text: specific inspiration.
label: Paragraph

text: The precise symbolic program of the Library remains elusive. Of course, the circle
label: Paragraph

text: within the square and the dome recollect a heavenly universality. An early drawing
label: Caption

text: (1921) shows a medallic portrait of a bald-headed man with a short beard in profile over
label: Paragraph

text: the door, possibly a representation of an ancient philosopher. On the floor of the entry
label: Caption

text: mosaic is the inscription (in Greek) “Know Thyself.” In the entrance hall, the walls are
label: Paragraph

text: reliefs by Ivar Johnson with scenes from Homer’s /liad. Somewhat at odds with this
label: Caption

text: evocation of ancient myth and philosophy are the original door handles of the Library,
label: Paragraph

text: now preserved on the second floor. They represent Adam eating the apple (inside handle)
label: Caption

text: and Eve with the apple (outside handle}, and both needed to be gripped and held, if
label: Paragraph

text: briefly, by patrons entering and exiting the Library. Do they suggest the potential dangers
label: Paragraph

text: of knowledge or a recognition that it is in human nature to eat from the tree of
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge? Or are they prelapsarian guardians of a paradisaic place of knowledge?
label: Paragraph

text: The Library remains largely unaltered from its original construction. In 1974, a double
label: Paragraph

text: flight of stairs was built to handle traffic to the upper gallery, elevators were installed,
label: Paragraph

text: and building restoration was undertaken (1979-81) with the opening of a further light
label: Paragraph

text: well. The original entrance doors were replaced, the furnishings were renovated, and the
label: Paragraph

text: lighting was improved at that time. In 1994, the entire Library and terrace building was
label: Paragraph

text: replastered and painted.
label: Paragraph

text: Following the completion of the Library, Asplund plunged into work on the Stockholm
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition of 1930 and began his brief functionalist period. Already, the reflecting pool
label: Paragraph

text: (completed 1931) along Sveavégen evokes modernist architectural concerns as do the
label: Paragraph

text: retail shops at street level and the small rear facade addition (1928-31). Indeed, the
label: Paragraph

text: building was completed at a critical point in Swedish architectural history. Writing in the
label: Paragraph

text: magazine Byggmdstaren (1928), the architect Uno Ahrén declared, “New classicism is
label: Paragraph

text: dead.” The Library, he wrote, “stands at the border, not between two minor stylistic
label: Paragraph

text: tendencies of Swedish architecture, as some suggest, but between two phases of
label: Paragraph

text: fundamental difference in mentality.” Ahrén was right to the extent that the succeeding
label: Paragraph

text: years did not favor the classicizing references that Asplund deployed in the Library.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, writers on Asplund, such as the Englishman Eric de Mare (1955), continued
label: Paragraph

text: to praise the prefunctionalist phase of Asplund’s career despite—or perhaps because of —
label: Paragraph

text: its traditional nature.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1970s, when Asplund became a focus of attention for a generation of
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernist architects “stalking,” in the words of Treib (in Engfors, 1986), “the
label: Paragraph

text: considered balance between modernity and tradition,” the Library became a pilgrimage
label: Paragraph

text: site. Architects such as Leon Krier looked to the Library as a model of geometric
label: Paragraph

text: typology. In the United States and Italy, Romaldo Giurgola and Aldo Rossi helped revive
label: Paragraph

text: interest in Asplund; Kenneth Frampton and Stuart Wrede (1980) were also influential in
label: Paragraph

text: the United States, along with Michael Graves and Thomas Beeby, who were probably
label: Paragraph

text: introduced to Asplund by the architectural critic Colin Rowe (see the essay by Parsons in
label: Paragraph

text: Engfors, 1986).
label: Paragraph

text: STOCKHOLM, SWEDEN
label: Title

text: The center of Swedish activity in architecture during the 20th century was Stockholm, its
label: Paragraph

text: capital city. Not only was Stockholm the locus of political, financial, and cultural power,
label: Paragraph

text: but it was also the site of the major architecture school in Sweden, the Kunigligan
label: Paragraph

text: Teknikiska Hégskolan.
label: Paragraph

text: The two most significant buildings in Stockholm at the beginning of the 20th century,
label: Paragraph

text: the Nordiska Museum and the Town Hall, represent different aspects of national
label: Paragraph

text: consciousness in architecture. With its prominent position on the island of Djiirgarden,
label: Paragraph

text: Isak Gustaf Clason’s (1856-1930) Nordiska Museum (1889-1907) was intended to be a
label: Paragraph

text: temple for Swedish culture. Its towers recall the great castles of the Vasa period
label: Paragraph

text: (Gripsholm, Vadstena, and Kalmar), and its gables recall the Trefaldighetskyrkan (1658)
label: Paragraph

text: in Kristianstad. The entrance portal is in the form of a secular Gothic-style cathedral with
label: Paragraph

text: Mother Svea and Odin. The use of stone from around Sweden and the naturalistic carving
label: Paragraph

text: by local stonemasons recall principles enunciated by the English critic John Ruskin. At
label: Paragraph

text: the center of the building is a great room, evoking both castle hall and ecclesiastical nave,
label: Paragraph

text: and a monumental statue of Gustav Vasa by Carl Milles (1875-1955). In short, the
label: Paragraph

text: building celebrates national culture through its great moments of history, both real and
label: Paragraph

text: mythic, and representative examples of its geology.
label: Paragraph

text: By contrast, the Town Hall (1904—23), designed by Ragnar Ostberg (1866-1945), is
label: Paragraph

text: much less explicit in its sources; historic architecture is evoked through the lens of the
label: Paragraph

text: native traditions of arts and crafts. Although made of brick, traditionally common in
label: Paragraph

text: southern Sweden, its profile recalls an Italian communal palace rather than any Swedish
label: Paragraph

text: building. Ostberg has confected his historical references: part Romanesque, part Gothic,
label: Paragraph

text: and part Byzantine. The great top-lit hall at the center of the building, the so-called Blue
label: Paragraph

text: Hall, is slightly out of square, deliberately recalling the craft traditions of the Middle
label: Paragraph

text: Ages.
label: Paragraph

text: New influences arrived from the United States and from Germany in the 1910s and
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s. Sweden was especially receptive to North American architecture as a result of
label: Paragraph

text: emigration. Many architects and artists traveled to America, some to stay, some to profit
label: Paragraph

text: on their return. Ferdinand Boberg, for example, took advantage of his visit to Chicago for
label: Paragraph

text: the World’s Columbian Exposition of 1893 to study American building practices, and
label: Paragraph

text: Gustaf Wickman (1858-1916) and Carl Westman (1866-1936) visited the United States
label: Paragraph

text: and were inspired by H.H.Richardson. With the construction of a pair of concrete
label: Paragraph

text: skeleton-frame skyscrapers, North American influence became technological and
label: Paragraph

text: urbanistic. Over 60 meters tall, the skyscrapers were part of the 1919 master plan. The
label: Paragraph

text: new street, Kungsgatan, broke through the old ridgeline, leaving the old street as a flying
label: Paragraph

text: bridge. The northern skyscraper, inspired by Louis Sullivan, was designed by Sven
label: Paragraph

text: Wallander (1890-1968) and employed a tripartite division and vertical pilaster strips “to
label: Paragraph

text: describe,” as Wallander said, “the forces at work within.” The southern tower, similar in
label: Paragraph

text: form, was built by Ivar Callmander (1880-1951) in 1925. The urbanistic effect recalls the
label: Paragraph

text: multilevel visions of New York in Moses King’s Views of New York or even the most up-
label: Paragraph

text: to-date American architecture at Grand Central Terminal in New York City, where the
label: Paragraph

text: Park Avenue flyover had just been connected.
label: Paragraph

text: In this period, connections with Germany and Austria are decisive for the architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of Stockholm, as can be seen in works such as the Liljevachs Konsthall (1913-16), built
label: Paragraph

text: by Carl Bergsten (1879-1935) for the sawmill magnate C.F .Lilejevalch. It was built on a
label: Paragraph

text: grid plan with concrete piers and brick screen in-fill. In its rationalism, it recalls the work
label: Paragraph

text: of Peter Behrens and Heinrich Tessenow and thus marks a significant passage from
label: Paragraph

text: Ostberg’s Town Hall. Like Ostberg’s Blue Hall in the Town Hall, the main gallery is lit
label: Paragraph

text: by a clerestory window that encircles the room at the upper level, but the gray-concrete
label: Caption

text: trim and columns alternate with the white of the walls to recall Behrens’ favored
label: Paragraph

text: Italianate sources, as the coffered ceiling and decorative details further reveal. Bergsten
label: Paragraph

text: also built the church at Hjorthagen (1904-06), which recalls Wiener Werkstatte designs.
label: Paragraph

text: Architects such as Ivar Tengbom (1878-1968) also employed a simplified Italianate
label: Paragraph

text: classicism.
label: Paragraph

text: The figure that most effectively represents the advanced trends of architecture in this
label: Paragraph

text: period in Stockholm is Gunnar Asplund (1885-1940). In the early phase of his career, he
label: Paragraph

text: combined apparent opposites: the traditions of Ostberg’s folk architecture with the
label: Paragraph

text: reductionist geometry of the Germanic countries. His Woodland Chapel (1920), for
label: Paragraph

text: example, employed traditional materials (wrought iron, stone, and wood) but in rigid
label: Paragraph

text: geometric order. In his designs with Sigurd Lewerentz (1885-1975), with whom he
label: Paragraph

text: shared design responsibilities for the Woodland Cemetery (1915-40), these are integrated
label: Paragraph

text: into the traditions of Swedish landscape made mythic with biblical references.
label: Paragraph

text: Lewerentz’s Chapel of the Resurrection (1925) is strongly classical in inspiration, and in
label: Paragraph

text: the Skandia Cinema (1922-23) and City Library (1920-28), Asplund’s classicizing
label: Paragraph

text: tendencies emerge clearly.
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund soon moved in a new direction. In 1928, he was appointed chief designer for
label: Paragraph

text: the Stockholm Exhibition organized by Sléjdféreningen (the Society for Arts and Crafts),
label: Paragraph

text: which opened on 16 May 1930 on Djurgarden. Asplund took on the task of shaping
label: Paragraph

text: Swedish notions of European modernism. With his associates, notably Sven Markelius
label: Paragraph

text: (1889-1972), Uno Ahrén (1897-1977), and Wolter B. Gahn (1890-1985), he provided a
label: Paragraph

text: series of exhibition buildings decorated with flags, constructivist neon signs, nighttime
label: Paragraph

text: floodlighting, and playful graphics to display new techniques of construction and new
label: Paragraph

text: design approaches in housing, office design, and urbanism. With this group, which
label: Paragraph

text: included Gregor Paulsson (1889-1977) and Eskil Sundahl (1890-1974), Asplund
label: Paragraph

text: authored a manifesto of modern functionalism (1931) with the declarative title acceptera:
label: Paragraph

text: “Accept the reality before you only through it do we have any prospect of mastering it, of
label: Paragraph

text: coping with it so as to alter, and to create culture that is a handy tool for one’s life.”
label: Paragraph

text: Swedish architects were receptive to the ideas of functionalism. With many architectural
label: Paragraph

text: problems in need of solutions, notably in the field of housing, functionalism seemed to
label: Paragraph

text: offer a logical path toward their resolution. The strip window, for example, which might
label: Paragraph

text: need to be rationalized elsewhere, made perfect sense at 60 degrees north, where the sun
label: Paragraph

text: barely moved beyond the horizontal much of the year. At another level, however, the
label: Paragraph

text: success of functionalism reflected a broader cultural effort: 20th-century Swedes who
label: Paragraph

text: wanted a modern Sweden based on values other than those of the state, the church, or
label: Paragraph

text: bourgeois capitalism. The first public building in the functionalist style was Markelius
label: Paragraph

text: and Ahrén’s Karhus (student center, 1928-30) at the Kunigligan Teknikiska Hégskolan.
label: Paragraph

text: Lewerentz’s unadorned gridded facades for the Riksférsakrings-verket (1930-32), or
label: Paragraph

text: national insurance board, is a significant early example of government-commissioned
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism.
label: Paragraph

text: It was not until after World War I] that significant architectural inroads were made into
label: Paragraph

text: the old fabric of the city, although not always with happy results. The Hétorscity office
label: Paragraph

text: and commercial complex, for example, was started in 1945 and recalls Gordon
label: Paragraph

text: Bunshaft’s Lever House in New York City. By David Hellden (1905-90), Anders
label: Caption

text: Tengbom (1911-), Sven Markelius, Lars Erik Lallerstedt (1864-1955), and Backstrém
label: Paragraph

text: (1903-92) and Reinius (1907-95), of the firm Backstrém and Reinius, H6torscity
label: Paragraph

text: consists of five multistoried slab blocks (with a significant pedestrian component).
label: Paragraph

text: Construction was not completed until the mid-1950s. The development gave Stockholm
label: Paragraph

text: an American-style architectural skyline. In 1971-73, Kulturhuset, a megastructure at
label: Paragraph

text: Sergels Torg by the architect Peter Celsing (1920-74), inspired in part by Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: provided a city-sponsored communal center with theaters, restaurants, meeting space, and
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition space nearby. One of the most significant buildings of this period was
label: Paragraph

text: Celsing’s gridded facade to the Riksbanken (1976), behind Kulturhuset, which suggested
label: Paragraph

text: greater acceptance of historical forms. In effect, Lewerentz’s Riksférsak-ringsverket grid
label: Paragraph

text: of the 1930s was transformed into rusticated stone. Important church buildings by
label: Paragraph

text: Celsing (Olaus Petrikyrkan, 1957-59) and Lewerentz (Markuskyrakan in Bjérkhagen,
label: Paragraph

text: 1956-60) demonstrated a new attention to traditional materials.
label: Paragraph

text: By the 1970s, the era of large-scale city demolition was over. Protests in 1971 over the
label: Paragraph

text: felling of a stand of elms in Kungstrad-garden to make way for a subway station marked
label: Caption

text: the change in public sentiment, although the last of the great reconstructions was still
label: Paragraph

text: ongoing at the end of the century. Cityterminalen (1986-89) by Arken Arkitektur with
label: Caption

text: Ahlqvist and Culjat, Ralph Erskine (1914—), and Tengboms Arkitektkontor is a mixed
label: Paragraph

text: public-private venture adjacent to the Normmalm shopping district designed to create a
label: Paragraph

text: new business-conference center at Stockholm’s transportation node (bus, subway, and
label: Paragraph

text: train). Slowed by the downturn in the economy at the beginning of the 1990s, when
label: Paragraph

text: completed the project will form a new, efficient business center near the heart of the old
label: Paragraph

text: city.
label: Paragraph

text: Any survey of Stockholm in the 20th century must touch on housing. At the beginning
label: Paragraph

text: of the century, more than 50 percent of living quarters consisted of one room plus a
label: Paragraph

text: kitchen or less. There were various experiments: garden city-style suburban
label: Paragraph

text: developments at Gamla Enskede (1907) designed by Per Olof Hallman (1869-1941) and
label: Paragraph

text: Herman Ygberg (1844-1917), functionalist-style worker housing at Svarneholmen
label: Paragraph

text: (1928-1930) designed by Olof Thunstrém (1896-1962) of the firm KFAI, and the
label: Paragraph

text: founding in 1936 by the City of Stockholm of the Familjebostader and Stockholmshem
label: Paragraph

text: housing companies, both of which were responsible for the erection of large-family
label: Paragraph

text: housing in areas such as Abrahamsberg, Akeshov, Riksby, and Akeslund. The first
label: Paragraph

text: examples of collective housing were designed by Markelius at John Ericssonsgatan
label: Paragraph

text: The nature of housing construction changed after World War Il. In 1941, the
label: Paragraph

text: Stockholm City Council decided to build a new subway system, and construction began
label: Paragraph

text: between Slussen and Hékarangen (1950) and Hétorget and Vallingby (1952). The two
label: Paragraph

text: lines were linked at the main train station, T-Centralen, in 1957, and housing was
label: Paragraph

text: developed along these lines. The plan was to build developments of between 10,000 and
label: Paragraph

text: 15,000 inhabitants centered on a subway station with small commercial and service
label: Paragraph

text: centers, a school, and playing fields within walking distance. Among the newly
label: Paragraph

text: incorporated suburbs, Vallingby is among the best known and became an international
label: Paragraph

text: model for new town construction. Planning began as early as 1940, and ground was
label: Paragraph

text: broken in 1951. With its commercial center designed partially by Backstrém and Reinius,
label: Paragraph

text: its adjacent subway station by Magnus Ahlgren (1918—), churches by Celsing and Carl
label: Paragraph

text: Nyrén (1917-), and segregated pedestrian/cycle paths, it was model of efficiency. Around
label: Paragraph

text: the center were large slab blocks of multistory apartments, and farther out were row
label: Paragraph

text: houses. Farsta (1953-61) was a similar counterpart south of central Stockholm.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1965, the Swedish government sought to put an end to the housing shortage and
label: Paragraph

text: developed the Miljonprogrammet (Million Dwelling Program), which also had an effect
label: Paragraph

text: on Stockholm. In Rinkeby and Tensta, for example, huge anonymous apartment buildings
label: Paragraph

text: were built, and although later examples improved this type at Norra Jarva, Akalla, Husby,
label: Paragraph

text: and Kista, they were not popular. Additionally, terrace housing on an American pattern—
label: Paragraph

text: that is, without proximate public services and thus requiring the use of an automobile for
label: Paragraph

text: all activities—was built in areas such as Kalvesta and Hasselby.
label: Paragraph

text: At the end of the 20th century, it is difficult to isolate projects that will have lasting
label: Paragraph

text: architectural influence on the city. From a visual point of view, the Globen sports
label: Paragraph

text: complex by Berg Arkitektkontor AB (1986-88) is the most important but is not
label: Paragraph

text: universally welcome. The giant sphere looms over Sédermalm like an escapee from a
label: Paragraph

text: Walt Disney amusement park. More significant, Ralph Erskine’s Aula Magna (1988-90)
label: Paragraph

text: at Frescati represents the continuing engagement of Stockholm’s urban architecture with
label: Paragraph

text: its natural environment, and the Moderna Museet and Arkitekturmuseet (1990-98) by
label: Paragraph

text: Rafael Moneo (1937—) on Skeppsholmen and Ricardo Bofill’s (1939-) Bagen Residence
label: Caption

text: (1989-1991), a vast, crescent-shaped housing development at Sddra station, are examples
label: Paragraph

text: of the renewed influence of foreign architects, something not felt strongly in Stockholm.
label: Paragraph
