text: STONE
label: Title

text: Stone has two distinct architectural faces: in monumental architecture, it stands for
label: Paragraph

text: wealth, power, and permanence; on the other hand, especially when used at a domestic
label: Paragraph

text: scale and based on local craft traditions, it appears as modest, forthright, and natural.
label: Paragraph

text: These two aspects of stone correspond to the varying levels of effort and skill marshaled
label: Paragraph

text: in its fabrication, transportation, and erection. Finely worked, accurately cut blocks,
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes of exotic origin or polished to a jewel-like finish, characterize monumental
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, while fieldstone, rubble, or roughly worked stone set in thick mortar beds is
label: Paragraph

text: more often associated with modest works. Stone’s symbolic content is not determined by
label: Paragraph

text: these two traditions alone but also reflects the revolutionary changes brought about by
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization and by the attitudes—ranging from ambivalence to outright hostility—
label: Paragraph

text: with which those changes are greeted. Increasingly anachronistic from a purely functional
label: Paragraph

text: standpoint, stone survives in 20th-century architecture largely as a medium through
label: Paragraph

text: which these attitudes can be symbolically expressed.
label: Paragraph

text: At the beginning of the 20th century, monumental stone architecture is associated
label: Paragraph

text: primarily with neoclassical and Gothic Revival styles. McKim, Mead and White’s
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania Station (1910) and James J.Farley Post Office (1912), both in New York
label: Paragraph

text: City, employ classical stone facades—Doric and Corinthian, respectively—coexisting
label: Paragraph

text: with an infrastructure of glass and steel necessary to accommodate and express the
label: Paragraph

text: realities of modern urban life. Ralph Adams Cram, America’s leading Gothic Revivalist,
label: Caption

text: also incorporates modern construction technologies—including various hidden
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete decks, lintels, and bond beams—together with traditional limestone
label: Paragraph

text: detailing in projects such as his Princeton University Chapel (1922) in Princeton, New
label: Paragraph

text: Jersey.
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, neoclassical monumentality was attacked from several points of
label: Paragraph

text: view at the beginning of the 20th century. The Arts and Crafts movement, reacting to the
label: Paragraph

text: social and physi-cal fallout associated with industrialization, proposed a return to
label: Paragraph

text: “honest” craft values. These values are expressed in the rough stone walls of
label: Paragraph

text: W.R.Lethaby’s All Saints’ Church (1902) in Herefordshire, England, and the rounded
label: Caption

text: rubble stone foundations of the John Bakewell Phillips House (1906) designed by the
label: Caption

text: Greene Brothers in Pasadena, California. Edwin Lutyens’ use of rubble stone in early
label: Caption

text: 20th-century residential projects such as Grey Walls (1900) in Gullane, Scotland, is
label: Paragraph

text: similarly rooted in an Arts and Crafts sensibility, although his monumental Viceroy’s
label: Paragraph

text: House (1931) in New Delhi, clad with finely worked red-and-buff-colored Dholpur
label: Caption

text: sandstone, reaffirms the neoclassical tradition, albeit combined with vernacular elements.
label: Paragraph

text: The most radical of the reactions against traditional architectural styles was
label: Paragraph

text: International Style modernism. Modernists invoked the idea of “truth to materials” to
label: Paragraph

text: provide intellectual cover for the unsettling changes in the built environment associated
label: Paragraph

text: with the industrial revolution—specifically, the rationalization of the building process to
label: Paragraph

text: increase productivity and reduce costs. Eliminating gratuitous decoration (such as the
label: Paragraph

text: omamented stone facades of traditional monumental architecture) became a fundamental
label: Paragraph

text: tenet of modernism. However, the use of stone as honest bearing wall or smooth-surfaced
label: Paragraph

text: veneer was generally accepted.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s Villa de Mme de Mandrot (1931) in Le Pradet, France, illustrates the
label: Paragraph

text: use of undecorated stone walls within a modernist syntax, as does his earlier exploration
label: Paragraph

text: of parallel masonry bearing walls in the Maisions Citrohan projects of the early 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: While such structural stone walls remained fairly common in domestic-scaled
label: Paragraph

text: buildings—Frank Lloyd Wright’s dramatic use of stone piers supporting horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: cantilevers of reinforced concrete at Fallingwater (1938) in Bear Run, Pennsylvania, is a
label: Paragraph

text: notable example—the development of steel and concrete frameworks rendered stone
label: Paragraph

text: load-bearing walls virtually obsolete for larger institutional or commercial buildings. An
label: Paragraph

text: exception is Kevin Roche’s Creative Arts Center at Wesleyan University (1973) in
label: Paragraph

text: Middletown, Connecticut, consisting of 14-inch-thick limestone bearing walls laid
label: Paragraph

text: without mortar and capped by a reinforced-concrete roof structure. Roche uses a similar
label: Paragraph

text: stone system in his additions to the Metropolitan Museum of Art (1974-80) in New York
label: Paragraph

text: City.
label: Paragraph

text: Attitudes toward nonstructural cladding, articulated by 19th-century theorists such as
label: Paragraph

text: John Ruskin, Carl Bétticher, and Gottfried Semper and adapted in the 20th century by
label: Paragraph

text: European architect-theorists such as Otto Wagner and Adolf Loos, provided a theoretical
label: Paragraph

text: basis for the “honest” expression of thin stone veneer. Wagner’s Post Office Savings
label: Paragraph

text: Bank (1906) in Vienna, although constructed with conventional brick bearing walls, is
label: Paragraph

text: clad with thin marble panels visibly attached to the brick walls with aluminum-capped
label: Paragraph

text: iron bolts. Adolf Loos used stone and other cladding materials to develop richly surfaced
label: Paragraph

text: interior spaces that correspond not to the structure of his houses but to the logic of their
label: Paragraph

text: social functioning. Loos’ Miller House (1930) in Prague includes thin green-veined
label: Paragraph

text: Cipollino marble panels on key interior surfaces, emblematic of wealth and refined taste
label: Caption

text: but at the same time marked by a certain modern dissonance. Stone cladding was often
label: Paragraph

text: used to impart a kind of traditional legitimacy to otherwise modern buildings. Examples
label: Paragraph

text: include Mies van der Rohe’s Barcelona Pavilion (1929), Giuseppe Terragni’s Casa del
label: Paragraph

text: Fascio (1936; now Casa del Populo} in Como, Italy, Edward Durrell Stone and Philip
label: Paragraph

text: Goodwin’s Museum of Modern Art (New York City, 1939), and the United Nations
label: Paragraph

text: Secretariat Building (New York City, 1953) by Wallace K.Harrison and others.
label: Caption

text: On the other hand, rough stone was used to impart a more domestic or natural feeling
label: Paragraph

text: to modern buildings. Marcel Breuer and Walter Gropius’ Hagerty House (1938) in
label: Caption

text: Cohasset, Massachusetts, utilizes stone and stucco surfaces to create a picturesque though
label: Paragraph

text: still modern formal composition. Eero Saarinen’s IBM Facility (1956) in Yorktown, New
label: Caption

text: York, contrasts roughly worked stone walls reassembled from existing pasture barriers on
label: Paragraph

text: the site with modern glass curtain walls.
label: Paragraph

text: Still, stone use declined in the three decades following World War II in favor of more
label: Paragraph

text: technologically advanced materials and curtain-wall systems. Within the modernist
label: Paragraph

text: genre, stone was relegated to thin veneer without decorative embellishment, understated
label: Paragraph

text: in its color and texture. Saarinen’s CBS Building (1965) and Breuer’s Whitney Museum
label: Paragraph

text: of American Art (1966), both in New York City, are faced in a muted, thermal-finished
label: Paragraph

text: granite cladding consistent with the minimalist aesthetic of the time. Other examples
label: Paragraph

text: include Kevin Roche’s Ford Foundation Building (1968) in New York City, with granite
label: Caption

text: cladding defining the boundaries of its abstract cubic form, and I.M. Pei’s East Wing of
label: Paragraph

text: the National Gallery (1978) in Washington, D.C., similarly using stone veneer—in this
label: Paragraph

text: case Tennessee marble matching the original stone used in the museum’s West Wing—to
label: Paragraph

text: define its abstract angular geometry.
label: Paragraph

text: The 1980s saw an explosion in the use of stone cladding, typical of postmodern
label: Paragraph

text: exuberance, while advances in stone fabrication technology significantly reduced costs.
label: Paragraph

text: The postmodern synthesis—combining the symbolic values of traditional architecture
label: Paragraph

text: with the rational infrastructure of modernism—gained both notoriety and legitimacy with
label: Paragraph

text: the construction of Philip Johnson’s pink granite AT&T Building (1983) in New York
label: Paragraph

text: City. Other notable examples within this genre include Michael Graves’ Humana
label: Paragraph

text: Headquarters Building (1985) in Louisville, Kentucky, covered with several varieties of
label: Paragraph

text: exterior granites and interior marbles; Kohn Pedersen Fox’s Procter and Gamble World
label: Caption

text: Headquarters (1985) in Cincinnati, Ohio, clad in six-inch-thick buff-colored Indiana
label: Paragraph

text: limestone panels spanning from floor to floor; and Cesar Pelli’s World Financial Center
label: Caption

text: (1985-88) in New York City, consisting of two million square feet of stone, primarily
label: Paragraph

text: polished and thermal-finished granite.
label: Paragraph

text: Earlier attempts at such a synthesis can be seen in the abstracted monumental
label: Paragraph

text: classicism promoted by Mussolini during the 1930s and 1940s. Guerrini, Lapadula and
label: Paragraph

text: Romano’s Palace of Italian Civilization (1942) in Esposizione Universale di Roma
label: Caption

text: (EUR), just outside of Rome, is an example; its monumental cubic form, defined by rows
label: Paragraph

text: of deep-set travertine arcades, mimics the stone arches and axiality of classical and
label: Paragraph

text: baroque Rome while maintaining plain and unornamented surfaces. In the United States,
label: Paragraph

text: a variant form of abstracted neoclassicism can be seen in the arched travertine facade of
label: Paragraph

text: Wallace K.Harrison’s Metropolitan Opera House (New York City, 1966).
label: Caption

text: Especially outside the United States, Postmodernism draws on the platonic geometries
label: Paragraph

text: associated with such 18th-century visionary designers as Claude-Nicolas Ledoux and
label: Paragraph

text: Etienne-Louis Boullée. The stone block or panel becomes important in this context not
label: Paragraph

text: just for its symbolic resonance but also as the basic elemental unit to which the overall
label: Paragraph

text: geometric form of the building is inextricably tied. Charles Correa’s Jawahar Kala
label: Paragraph

text: Kendra
label: Title

text: Whitney Museum of American Art (1966), New York City, designed by
label: Caption

text: Marcel Breuer Ezra Stoller © Esto
label: Title

text: Museum (1990) in Jaipur, India, is based on a nine-square plan, with each square block
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrically stepping down at the corners, consistent with the module of its red
label: Paragraph

text: sandstone cladding; Aldo Rossi’s Monument to Sandro Pertini (1990) in Milan, Italy, is a
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical cubic block clad in gray and pink marble into which a monumental stair is
label: Paragraph

text: cut. Here, stone provides a historic link both to Milan’s Duomo (whose stone was cut
label: Paragraph

text: from the same quarry) and to the traditional rose granite street pavement removed for
label: Paragraph

text: subway construction and reused by Rossi on the site.
label: Caption

text: A self-consciously critical, if not overtly ironic, attitude toward the use of stone can
label: Paragraph

text: also be discovered in Postmodern architecture. Vittorio Mazzucconi’s 22 Avenue
label: Caption

text: Matignon (1976) in Paris juxtaposes fragments from an old stone facade within a new
label: Paragraph

text: glass curtain wall. Francesco Venezia’s Museum (1989) in Gibellina, Sicily, sets part of
label: Caption

text: an earthquake-damaged stone building into a new stone structure in which the old and
label: Paragraph

text: new are integrated yet clearly distinguished. Hans Hollein’s Jewelry Shop (1974) in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna creates a deliberately “cracked” stone facade that challenges not only the
label: Paragraph

text: modernist notion of honest expression but also the canonic meaning of stone as a signifier
label: Paragraph

text: of wealth and permanence. Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates’ Sainsbury Wing of the
label: Caption

text: National Gallery (1987) in London takes a Corinthian pilaster motif from the existing
label: Paragraph

text: museum’s 19th-century neoclassical facade, carefully reproduces it in a new stone
label: Paragraph

text: facade, and then incrementally transforms it into an increasingly abstract (modern) figure.
label: Paragraph

text: Rem Koolhaas’ Nexus World Kashii (1991) in Fukuoka, Japan, features a curving wall
label: Caption

text: whose concrete surface texture expertly simulates—and caricatures—the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: stonework of Japanese castles. Examples of the deliberate and didactic juxtaposition of
label: Paragraph

text: stone with more modern construction technologies include Alvaro Siza’s Galician Center
label: Paragraph

text: for Contemporary Art (1994) in Santiago de Compostela, where granite cladding rests on
label: Paragraph

text: exposed steel channels and posts, and Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron’s Stone
label: Caption

text: House (1982) in Tavole, Italy, in which a slatelike rubble in-fill wall is contrasted with a
label: Paragraph

text: rigorously orthogonal exposed reinforced-concrete frame.
label: Paragraph

text: Stone has also been “reinvented” by several 20th-century architects who have
label: Paragraph

text: developed wall systems combining aspects of stone masonry and concrete technology.
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright’s “desert rubble masonry”—first used at Taliesin West (1937) in
label: Paragraph

text: Scottsdale, Arizona—sets unworked stones tight against concrete formwork so that they
label: Paragraph

text: become visible on the wall’s surface. Similarly, Eero Saarinen’s Norwegian-based
label: Paragraph

text: system, adapted for his Stiles and Morse Colleges (1962) at Yale University, injects
label: Paragraph

text: pressurized concrete into forms filled with rough stones. Peter Zumthor, for his Thermal
label: Paragraph

text: Bath (1997) in Vals, Switzerland, created a composite concrete-masonry system in which
label: Paragraph

text: locally quarried gneiss blocks defining the continuous cavelike internal spaces and
label: Paragraph

text: external massing of the building are made integral with reinforced-concrete cores.
label: Paragraph

text: Finally, stone buildings have continued to be built in traditional ways throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century. Quinlan Terry’s Mait-land Robinson Library (1993) in Cambridge,
label: Caption

text: England, with its pedimented stone facade, may serve as an example of the continuing
label: Paragraph

text: interest in literal, neoclassical form. The use of stone based on local, vernacular traditions
label: Paragraph

text: can be seen in numerous 20th-century projects: examples include Ricardo Bofill’s
label: Paragraph

text: Sanctuary of Meritxell (1978) in Andorra, faced with thick stone excavated from the site
label: Caption

text: by Galician masons; Jan Olav Jensen and Per Christian Brynildsen’s Hospital (1985) in
label: Paragraph

text: Maharastra, India, featuring stone load-bearing walls built with local materials by local
label: Paragraph

text: masons; and Raffaele Cavadini’s Municipal Buildings (1995) in lragna, Switzerland,
label: Paragraph

text: faced with dry split stones detailed according to local tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: STONE, EDWARD DURELL 1902-78
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: Edward Durell Stone was one of a handful of architects who introduced historicism
label: Paragraph

text: and omament into the modernist architecture of the 1950s and 1960s. In an era dominated
label: Paragraph

text: by the modernist glass boxes of Mies van der Rohe and others, with abstract spaces
label: Paragraph

text: united behind increasingly anonymous facades, Stone sought an ornamental and exotic
label: Paragraph

text: version of modernism. Where some architects in this era explored a more expressive
label: Paragraph

text: modernism, as did Eero Saarinen, Paul Rudolph, and Gordon Bunshaft, Stone, Minoru
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki, and Philip Johnson independently explored the combination of modernist
label: Paragraph

text: forms and materials with classical motifs and elements. Although Stone began his career
label: Paragraph

text: as an International Style modernist, the ornamental detailing of his U.S. Embassy
label: Paragraph

text: building (1954) in New Delhi, India, exemplifies the stylistic characteristics of his mature
label: Paragraph

text: style. From the mid-1950s on, Stone explored a fusion of classical and arabesque
label: Paragraph

text: detailing with fundamentally modernist forms and materials, resulting in an architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of elegance and luxury. This decorative modernism proved extremely popular with both
label: Paragraph

text: the American public and his patrons, landing him a number of prominent commissions,
label: Paragraph

text: including the American Pavilion (1958) at the World’s Fair in Brussels and the John F.
label: Paragraph

text: Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts (1971) in Washington, D.C. Regardless of his
label: Paragraph

text: personal and professional success, architects, critics, and historians derided his work as
label: Paragraph

text: formalist and derivative. However, Stone exerted a powerful influence on the everyday
label: Paragraph

text: commercial and residential architecture of the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s in America.
label: Paragraph

text: Born in Fayetteville, Arkansas, Stone briefly studied art at the University of Arkansas
label: Paragraph

text: before moving to Boston (where his brother Hicks was an architect) in the early 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: Finding work as an office boy, Stone attended classes and lectures at the Boston
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Club. While continuing his studies in classical architecture, Stone joined
label: Paragraph

text: the firm of Henry R. Shepley (a Boston Beaux-Arts architect) as a draftsman. In 1926, he
label: Paragraph

text: won a scholarship to Harvard but, dissatisfied with its traditional curriculum, quickly
label: Paragraph

text: transferred to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) to study with Jacques
label: Paragraph

text: Carlu (an early exponent of modernism). While at MIT, Stone won the Rotch
label: Paragraph

text: Scholarship, then spent two years in Europe studying the monuments of antiquity and the
label: Paragraph

text: works of the European modernists. Stone returned to New York in the inauspicious year
label: Paragraph

text: of 1929 and eventually found work on Rockefeller Center’s Radio City Music Hall
label: Paragraph

text: (1932) under Wallace K. Harrison.
label: Paragraph

text: Following his work on Rockefeller Center, Stone came into his own as an architect
label: Paragraph

text: with the design of the modernist Mandel House (1933) in Mount Kisco, New York. The
label: Paragraph

text: house clearly evoked the major elements of European modernism as defined by the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style Exhibition (which had opened the previous year in New York),
label: Paragraph

text: including asymmetrical massing, smooth planar geometries, ribbon windows, and an
label: Paragraph

text: open plan. In addition to a number of other modernist houses, Stone was responsible
label: Paragraph

text: (along with Philip Goodwin) for the design of the Museum of Modern Art (1939) in New
label: Caption

text: York. In the 1940s and 1950s, Stone continued to explore other modernist idioms, from
label: Paragraph

text: the concrete grid of his El Panama Hotel (1946) in Panama City (reminiscent of the work
label: Paragraph

text: of Le Corbusier) to a series of houses that explored organic materials and siting.
label: Paragraph

text: Regardless of the style or materials of Stone’s architecture, his work was increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: infused by a classical sense of massing and order. Although present in a number of his
label: Paragraph

text: designs, Stone’s predilection for classical symmetry and detailing reached its most
label: Paragraph

text: elegant and compelling expression in his 1954 design for the U.S. Embassy in New
label: Paragraph

text: Delhi. The building consists of a rectangular cella surrounded by a series of attenuated
label: Paragraph

text: columns. Behind the colonnade is the building’s most interesting feature: the screen wall
label: Caption

text: that shelters the offices and the interior court from the searing heat.
label: Paragraph

text: Stone’s design was part of a large-scale embassy-building program initiated by the
label: Paragraph

text: U.S. government in 1954 that called for
label: Paragraph

text: State University of New York, Albany (1962) view of the entrance
label: Caption

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: embassy designs that harmonized with the climate and historical context of the host
label: Paragraph

text: country. The U.S. Embassy’s screen wall (composed of patterned concrete terrazzo
label: Paragraph

text: blocks) served both of these functions by filtering the heat and sun while evoking the
label: Paragraph

text: patterned walls of mosques and mausoleums. Indeed, with its rigid classical symmetry,
label: Paragraph

text: airy interior court, and arabesque screen walls, the embassy was praised as the new
label: Paragraph

text: American Taj Mahal. Intended as an act of architectural diplomacy, Stone’s willingness
label: Paragraph

text: to appropriate Indian imagery into his modern design has been criticized by recent
label: Paragraph

text: historians as an example of American cultural hegemony during the Cold War. Critics
label: Paragraph

text: initially praised the design for its success in reintroducing monumentality into modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture while relieving the monotony of glass-and-steel modernism. Stone had
label: Paragraph

text: borrowed much from the work of Mies van der Rohe and other modernists (e.g.,
label: Paragraph

text: cruciform columns, projecting horizontal slab roof, and recessed walls treated as abstract
label: Paragraph

text: geometry), but his lavish use of materials and the richly patterned screen wall set him
label: Paragraph

text: apart from his contemporaries.
label: Paragraph

text: Stone revisited the basic aspects of the U.S. Embassy with minor variations several
label: Paragraph

text: times in the following decades, using the same concrete-block pattern at the Stuart
label: Paragraph

text: Pharmaceutical Company (1956) Headquarters in Pasadena, California; a round version
label: Paragraph

text: of the embassy for the United States Pavilion (1958) in Brussels; and a rectilinear box
label: Caption

text: with screen walls and attenuated columns at the campus of the State University of New
label: Caption

text: York at Albany (1962) and the John F.Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Stone did
label: Paragraph

text: depart from these screen walls on several occasions, notably in his design of skyscrapers,
label: Paragraph

text: such as the General Motors Building (1968) in New York City.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Stone had served as a university professor (teaching at New York University
label: Paragraph

text: between 1935 and 1940, as an associate professor at Yale University from 1946 to 1952,
label: Paragraph

text: and as a visiting critic and professor at Princeton University, the University of Arkansas,
label: Paragraph

text: and Cornell University), his most lasting contribution to American architecture was his
label: Paragraph

text: decorative modernism. Although not popular with critics, Stone’s influence can be felt
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the popular vernacular both commercial and residential structures. By using
label: Paragraph

text: the concrete-block motif seen on the U.S. Embassy, countless Americans were able to
label: Paragraph

text: introduce modernism and exoticism into everyday architecture.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: STRUCTURAL SYSTEMS
label: Title

text: Structural systems are considered any collection of construction materials arranged in
label: Paragraph

text: specific configurations for producing the most efficient medium that safely transfers
label: Paragraph

text: applied gravity and lateral loads in any given structure. More specifically, structural
label: Paragraph

text: systems can be categorized into four main groups: solid, framed, surface, and tensile.
label: Paragraph

text: Typically, combinations of those groups, particularly the first three, which encompass a
label: Paragraph

text: huge and highly competitive variety of systems available for the designer to choose from,
label: Paragraph

text: are selected for the construction of any specific building project. In general, the bases of
label: Paragraph

text: such selection are economy, special structural requirements, problems of design and
label: Paragraph

text: construction, and materials and scale limitations. Realistically, however, in the majority
label: Paragraph

text: of built projects the overriding criterion for selecting systems is that of economy.
label: Paragraph

text: Solid and monolithic elements of foundations include footings (strip and isolated),
label: Paragraph

text: slab-on-grade, large piers, and abutments. They represent the last components of the load
label: Paragraph

text: path in a structure. Their main purpose is to safely transfer all applied loads to the
label: Paragraph

text: supporting soil.
label: Paragraph

text: Structural walls function either as supports for horizontal spanning systems (as bearing
label: Paragraph

text: walls} or as stabilizing elements for the lateral bracing of structures (as shear walls).
label: Paragraph

text: Depending on the way they are constructed, walls can be classified as either solid or
label: Paragraph

text: framed elements. Examples of such systems can be found in any building project, such as
label: Paragraph

text: supports for floor and roof structural subsystems. Examples of structural walls acting as
label: Paragraph

text: lateral bracing elements also abound, but particularly notable are shear walls in
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers. In 1976, architects Johnson and Burgee designed the 36-story Pennzoil Plaza
label: Paragraph

text: in Houston, Texas, with a concrete core for wind load resistance.
label: Paragraph

text: The oldest and most basic manner in which a frame is constructed is based on the post-
label: Paragraph

text: and-beam system. It is composed of two essential elements: the posts (typically vertical
label: Paragraph

text: compression members) and the beams (typically horizontal elements transferring applied
label: Paragraph

text: loads through shearing forces and bending moments). The degree of rigidity of the
label: Paragraph

text: connections between those elements determines the amount of moment being transferred
label: Paragraph

text: from the beams to the posts. The beams can be continuous over several posts (columns),
label: Paragraph

text: creating a multibay arrangement. Similarly, columns can be vertically continuous,
label: Paragraph

text: creating a multistory configuration. As such, this system can be expanded to form the
label: Paragraph

text: three-dimensional skeletal frame of a building structure. Examples of such systems
label: Paragraph

text: include the Empire State Building (New York City, designed by Shreve, Lamb and
label: Caption

text: Harmon, 1931).
label: Paragraph

text: Other frame-based arrangements include such innovative systems as geodesic domes.
label: Paragraph

text: Made famous by R. Buckminster Fuller in the 1960s, they utilize multiple stable
label: Paragraph

text: triangularly shaped units that, when framed side-by-side, form a shell-like structure.
label: Paragraph

text: Architects Murphy and Mackey in St. Louis, Missouri, implemented this framing concept
label: Paragraph

text: in their design of the Climatron, a geodesic dome used in the Missouri Botanical
label: Paragraph

text: Gardens.
label: Paragraph

text: Trusses
label: Title

text: Perhaps the most efficient framing elements are trusses used for horizontal spanning in
label: Paragraph

text: roofs and floors as well as for bridges. Trusses rely exclusively on straight members
label: Paragraph

text: framed together through bolted, welded, or a combination type of joints. By lining up the
label: Paragraph

text: axes of the joined members and directing applied loads to the joints only, a truss will
label: Paragraph

text: transmit tension and compression forces mainly through its members. The advantage of
label: Paragraph

text: trusses lies in the openness of their structure, allowing required electrical cables/conduits
label: Paragraph

text: and mechanical pipes/ducts to go through them without requiring additional dedicated
label: Paragraph

text: space. Because of their relatively lightweight and rigid triangularly based framework,
label: Paragraph

text: trusses are capable of spanning very large distances. There are many examples of truss
label: Paragraph

text: structural systems, but perhaps the most visible are the ones used in bridge construction.
label: Paragraph

text: The San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, opened in 1936, is one such example, with a
label: Paragraph

text: truss system connecting San Francisco to Treasure Island.
label: Paragraph

text: Arches and Vaults
label: Title

text: The main objective of the arch is to span horizontally, utilizing a structural system that
label: Paragraph

text: develops internal compression forces only. A temporary structure is erected in order to
label: Paragraph

text: hold the arch solid elements (voussoirs) while being placed starting at the ends of the
label: Paragraph

text: arch. Once both sides of the arch are completed, the last voussoir (keystone) is inserted in
label: Paragraph

text: place and the temporary shoring removed. If expanded in one direction, arches form
label: Paragraph

text: tunnel vaults. If crossed at 90 degrees, two vaults will produce a groin vault. Modern
label: Paragraph

text: arches and vaults are being achieved using structural systems such as framed truss
label: Paragraph

text: members forming the arch without resorting to solid elements. In 1998, Tate and Snyder
label: Paragraph

text: architects employed steel trusses, formed into arches, to support the curved roofing
label: Paragraph

text: system in the main lobby of Terminal D of McCarran International airport in Las Vegas,
label: Caption

text: Nevada.
label: Paragraph

text: Plates and Shells
label: Title

text: Classified as surface structures because of their very high surface-area-to-thickness ratio,
label: Paragraph

text: plates and shells encompass slabs, panels, folded plates, and shells with various simple,
label: Paragraph

text: as well as complex, geometric surface configurations (e.g., conical, spherical, and
label: Paragraph

text: hyperboloidal). Architectural history in filled with cases of those forms. Notably,
label: Paragraph

text: however, because of the vast repertoire of construction materials available to the designer
label: Paragraph

text: in the 20th century, today’s architects have found these forms very tempting. As such,
label: Paragraph

text: there are many cases where plates and shells have been successfully incorporated into the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural design. In 1997, the American architect Frank Gehry made use of the shell
label: Paragraph

text: system concept to encapsulate his entire Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, with
label: Paragraph

text: curved titanium surfaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Tent and Cable-Suspended Systems
label: Title

text: These systems act in an opposite way to the concept of arches and vaults, the difference
label: Paragraph

text: being that the internal forces induced in cable-suspended or tent systems are tensile in
label: Paragraph

text: nature. Engineers and builders have been successful in utilizing such systems whenever a
label: Paragraph

text: large span is desired. Completed in 1999 and spanning 1,198 feet (365 meters), the
label: Paragraph

text: Millennium Dome in Greenwich, London, is a contemporary example of the cable-
label: Paragraph

text: suspended tent system.
label: Paragraph

text: Because of their elegant design and structural efficiency, cable-suspended
label: Paragraph

text: constructions have also been mandatory when it comes to large-span bridges, for example
label: Paragraph

text: in the Golden Gate Bridge (with a span of 1280 meters) in San Francisco (1937). Another
label: Paragraph

text: type of tent construction, air-inflated structures, has domelike roof structures and has
label: Paragraph

text: become the preferred method of covering giant open-air public spaces. In 1988, architect
label: Paragraph

text: Nikken Sekkei and the Takenaka Corporation used an air-inflated membrane to cover the
label: Paragraph

text: 660-foot (201 -meter) span of the Tokyo Dome in Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo.
label: Caption

text: STRUCTURALISM
label: Title

text: The term structuralism is generally applied to the work of a diverse group of French
label: Paragraph

text: intellectuals working in the 1950s and 60s. Drawing on modern philosophy and the
label: Paragraph

text: human sciences that arose in the 19th and early 20th centuries—linguistics and
label: Paragraph

text: anthropology—and to a lesser extent on the hard sciences and mathematics,
label: Paragraph

text: structuralism’s influence continued long after its formal existence as a coherent
label: Paragraph

text: movement. In the most general sense, structuralism was the search for the most
label: Paragraph

text: elementary and universal patterns underlying cultural reality—patterns and structures that
label: Paragraph

text: form the basis of social life in its most fundamental expressions: language, economy,
label: Paragraph

text: science, and so forth. Less doctrine than method, the basic tenets of structuralism were
label: Paragraph

text: adapted to virtually every discipline in the academy. Simply stated, these tenets were,
label: Paragraph

text: first, individual phenomena (utterances, rituals, the formation of social institutions) only
label: Paragraph

text: have significance when considered as part of a larger system; second, the huge variety of
label: Paragraph

text: isolated phenomena that are discernible within the world or a given system are specific
label: Paragraph

text: permutations of a very few general principles; and third, the structure or conceptual
label: Paragraph

text: model constructed to chart these general principles (and the meaning of their individual
label: Paragraph

text: manifestations) is just that—a conceptual model or structure that by definition cannot be
label: Paragraph

text: empirically verified.
label: Paragraph

text: Even though generalizations like these can be identified, structuralism’s significance
label: Paragraph

text: lay in what it rejected as much as in what it adopted as its own method. By asserting the
label: Paragraph

text: necessity of distinguishing between specific phenomena and their underlying principles,
label: Paragraph

text: and placing the emphasis on the latter, structuralism leveled the cultural field to a certain
label: Paragraph

text: extent, doing away with a Eurocentric model that would maintain a qualitative difference
label: Paragraph

text: between, for instance, the social activities of modern and “primitive” societies. The
label: Paragraph

text: fundamental rejection of the dichotomy modern/primitive, especially evident in the work
label: Paragraph

text: of the anthropologist Claude Lévi-Strauss, was also a rejection of a century-and-a-half of
label: Paragraph

text: Hegelian determinism, or the myth of cultural progress. In addition, by insisting on the
label: Paragraph

text: syntactical consideration of phenomena—the relationships between them, as opposed to
label: Paragraph

text: their individual significance—structuralism rejected metaphysical hermeneutics as well
label: Paragraph

text: as phenomenology. This philosophical conflict was played out most dramatically in the
label: Paragraph

text: debates between Lévi-Strauss and the existentialist/Marxist philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre
label: Title

text: in the pages of the journals Les Temps Moderne, L’Homme, and L’Express. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: Sartre maintained the existence of conscious, human agency, Lévi-Strauss insisted on the
label: Paragraph

text: importance of the underlying elements that gave meaning to human action. The climate in
label: Paragraph

text: postwar France was much more conducive to Lévi-Strauss’s approach, which seemed
label: Paragraph

text: more objective than Sartre’s—an important attribute during a time in which many
label: Paragraph

text: academic disciplines sought grounding in the hard sciences and mathematics.
label: Paragraph

text: Lévi-Strauss’s “structural anthropology” was not developed ex nihilo; it drew on the
label: Paragraph

text: achievements of past ethnographers and, perhaps more important, on developments in the
label: Paragraph

text: field of linguistics. Whereas some earlier ethnographers had recognized the importance of
label: Paragraph

text: a comparative method, according to Lévi-Strauss they remained mired in empiricism,
label: Paragraph

text: which prevented them from ascending beyond the level of the specific. Lévi-Strauss
label: Paragraph

text: sought to do away with the endless observation and cataloguing of human behavior
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic of ethnography and to implement a more conceptual comparative model
label: Paragraph

text: that would establish underlying structural principles. For Lévi-Strauss, this gap was
label: Paragraph

text: bridged definitively when he was exposed to the work of the Swiss linguist Ferdinand de
label: Paragraph

text: Saussure.
label: Paragraph

text: Lecturing earlier in the century, Saussure had students whose notes were published as
label: Paragraph

text: the Course in General Linguistics. The essential lessons of “the course” established
label: Paragraph

text: Saussure as the founder of structuralism. By far the most significant idea in Saussure’s
label: Paragraph

text: teachings is the fundamental distinction he makes between the signifier and the signified.
label: Paragraph

text: For Saussure, there is no determined or natural relationship between a word and what it
label: Paragraph

text: represents—be it thing or idea. Rather, words are small units in a larger linguistic
label: Paragraph

text: system—phonemes whose meaning arises solely from their syntax, or relation to one
label: Paragraph

text: another. From this assertion, Saussure derived yet another important dichotomy—that
label: Paragraph

text: between /angue and parole, or the greater, underlying system of language and the
label: Paragraph

text: individual instances of its utterance or speech. Thus, Saussure broke language off from
label: Paragraph

text: the empirical world and established a method for studying it as an autonomous system.
label: Paragraph

text: Moreover, this system was to be studied synchronically as opposed to diachronically or
label: Paragraph

text: historically. The relational nature of the signifier meant that for any given word or phrase,
label: Paragraph

text: the relation to the rest of the system had to be considered simultaneously. Thus, the entire
label: Paragraph

text: structure is being studied at the same moment as an individual utterance. In the field of
label: Paragraph

text: linguistics, this constituted a break with etymological studies of language, but for French
label: Paragraph

text: structuralism, the emphasis on synchrony formed the basis for the later rejection of
label: Paragraph

text: classical history.
label: Paragraph

text: Saussure became one part of a triad of great thinkers to whom the new generation of
label: Paragraph

text: French intellectuals turned, the other two being Freud and Marx. Significantly, each of
label: Paragraph

text: these figures asserted systems that made a fundamental distinction between specific,
label: Paragraph

text: verifiable reality, and an underlying system: Saussure’s /angue/parole distinction, the
label: Paragraph

text: Freudian unconscious/conscious construction, and the fundamental tenet of Marxism, the
label: Paragraph

text: base/ superstructure dichotomy.
label: Paragraph

text: Saussure’s structuralist linguistic model allowed Lévi-Strauss to assert that like the
label: Paragraph

text: system of language (/angue), human cultural activity should also be analyzed relative to
label: Paragraph

text: its underlying, relational structure. Lévi-Strauss’s student thesis, The Elementary
label: Paragraph

text: Structures of Kinship, published in 1948, had a wide influence, far beyond the
label: Paragraph

text: disciplinary confines of anthropology. For supporters of Lévi-Strauss and structuralism,
label: Paragraph

text: who were growing in number, The Elementary Structures suggested a methodological
label: Paragraph

text: revolution that could bring all of the human sciences to the level of rigor and legitimacy
label: Paragraph

text: of the natural sciences. Thus, the promise of structuralism was initially that of objectivity
label: Paragraph

text: but was transformed as it disseminated throughout the academy.
label: Paragraph

text: The radical and highly influential psychoanalyst Jacques Lacan superimposed
label: Title

text: Saussure’s structuralism onto the Freudian model. He asserted that the Freudian
label: Paragraph

text: unconscious was in fact the system of language, whose structure is only partially
label: Paragraph

text: discernible through its specific manifestations or through speech.
label: Paragraph

text: Roland Barthes adapted the Saussurian/structuralist model to semiotics, opening the
label: Paragraph

text: gates of serious analysis to a huge array of cultural phenomena, from avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: literature to laundry detergent and the annual cycling race the Tour de France. For
label: Paragraph

text: Barthes, these practices and products formed units within a semiotic system, analogous to
label: Paragraph

text: words within a linguistic system. Instead of a “language,” however, the popular cultural
label: Paragraph

text: practices Barthes analyzed were specific instances of a system of cultural myth making
label: Paragraph

text: geared toward providing the illusion of drama and meaning to a neutralized and modern
label: Paragraph

text: quotidian existence. Barthes’s work was an early indication that although structuralism
label: Paragraph

text: was meant to be the scientific redemption of the human sciences, its other aspect was
label: Paragraph

text: cultural criticism. The idea that the system of cultural signs was itself a kind of
label: Paragraph

text: production and system of exchange provided an attractive alternative to Marxism, which
label: Paragraph

text: was plagued with ideological concerns in the postwar period. Marxists such as Henri
label: Paragraph

text: Lefebvre showed a great deal of interest in structuralism, and Louis Althusser embarked
label: Paragraph

text: on a rigorous structuralist re-reading of Marx’s works.
label: Paragraph

text: As structuralism was disseminated throughout the academy, its critical aspects came to
label: Paragraph

text: the fore. Determining the elementary structures within various disciplines meant casting
label: Paragraph

text: off many old paradigms. As these models were “deconstructed,” it became apparent that
label: Paragraph

text: some were imbued with incredible ideological significance. Namely, structuralism
label: Paragraph

text: initiated a new critique of several fundamental, modern concepts; diachronic history,
label: Paragraph

text: western metaphysics and phenomenology, and the unified human subject were the most
label: Paragraph

text: significant of these. Picking up on earlier critiques of occidental humanism and history,
label: Paragraph

text: Michel Foucault, Jacques Derrida, and Gilles Deleuze and Felix Guattari ushered in a
label: Paragraph

text: new phase of structuralism that some have dubbed poststructuralism.
label: Paragraph

text: Foucault refurbished Nietzschean genealogy to serve as a new historical method that
label: Paragraph

text: he used to interrogate the humanist legacy of the enlightenment and the industrial age.
label: Paragraph

text: His studies of the history of insanity and reason, law and punishment, and later of
label: Paragraph

text: sexuality unveiled the underlying concerns of cultural institutions, namely the exercise of
label: Paragraph

text: power. Derrida, following up on Martin Heidegger’s critique of modern philosophy,
label: Paragraph

text: conducted close, deconstructionist readings of seminal texts. He demonstrated the
label: Paragraph

text: moments in which the western discourse of reason and categorization collapsed on itself
label: Paragraph

text: or revealed weaknesses and lacuna within its own structure.
label: Paragraph

text: In a sense, structuralism predicated its own destruction: What began as an objective
label: Paragraph

text: method for the human sciences ended with a critique of the very notion of objectivity and
label: Paragraph

text: the objects of scientific study. Derrida read Saussure as critically as he read Kant. By the
label: Paragraph

text: late 1960s, structuralism itself had been added to the list of institutions being assaulted by
label: Paragraph

text: intellectuals and the popular press. Especially in the French context, where Charles de
label: Paragraph

text: Gaulle’s Fifth Republic was so quick to institute modern methods of bureaucracy and city
label: Paragraph

text: planning, the critique of technological modernity had deep implications. In May 1968,
label: Paragraph

text: one of the many slogans students scrawled on walls and blackboards during the uprisings
label: Paragraph

text: was “Structures do not march in the streets,” indicating what was correctly perceived as
label: Paragraph

text: structuralism’s lack of social engagement.
label: Paragraph

text: Structuralism and Architecture
label: Title

text: The exact effect of structuralism on architectural theory and practice is difficult to
label: Paragraph

text: determine but should not be underestimated. However, it is clear that it was the semiotic
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of structuralism that appealed to architects and critics much more so than the
label: Paragraph

text: anthropological facet. However, the very ubiquity of structuralism, especially in Europe
label: Paragraph

text: during the 1950s and 1960s, makes it possible to see connections even in cases in which
label: Paragraph

text: direct influence is not apparent. For instance, one finds an emphasis on social
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructure—explicitly opposed to architectural function—in the work of those
label: Paragraph

text: architects associated with Team X, the youthful offshoot of CIAM (Congrés
label: Paragraph

text: Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne): Alison and Peter Smithson, Aldo van Eyck, and
label: Paragraph

text: the firm Candilis, Josic, Woods. For this vanguard, architecture was to provide a
label: Paragraph

text: framework for the emergence of genuine social interaction—a conceptual model that
label: Paragraph

text: parallels the notion of underlying structure and its specific manifestations, which is
label: Paragraph

text: analogous to Saussure’s fangue/parole distinction. This lent to modernism a scientific
label: Paragraph

text: and sociological dimension that had been lacking from the utopian functionalism of the
label: Paragraph

text: However, it was the critical aspects of later structuralism and poststructuralism that
label: Paragraph

text: appealed to architects and theorists, such as Barthes’s critique of cultural mythology,
label: Paragraph

text: Foucault’s genealogies of institutional power, and Derrida’s notion of deconstruction, the
label: Paragraph

text: latter having evoked architecture as a foundational metaphor. Without exception, these
label: Paragraph

text: three writers acknowledged the importance of architecture and urbanism within any
label: Paragraph

text: semiology of modern society. Surprisingly, only a few notable architects and critics made
label: Paragraph

text: serious attempts to acknowledge or incorporate their theories: Peter Eisenman, Bernard
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi, Diana Agrest and Mario Gandelsonas, and Manfredo Tafuri are examples of
label: Paragraph

text: those who did. Although they are very different from one another, the work of these
label: Paragraph

text: practitioners and theorists used concepts from structuralism and Marxism to question,
label: Paragraph

text: analyze, and deconstruct the founding ideologies of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Though not strictly speaking structuralist, a much more widespread development is
label: Paragraph

text: apparent in the 1960s and 1970s: an interest in semiotics and its Anglo-American
label: Paragraph

text: equivalents, “communications theory” or semantics, all of which are related to
label: Paragraph

text: “postmodernism” in architecture. The interest in architectural meaning, or language, and
label: Paragraph

text: specifically the use of historicist elements such as classical ornamentation and devices is
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic of this movement. Charles Jencks and Robert Venturi and Denise Scott-
label: Paragraph

text: Brown were the foremost theorists of this tendency and called for the use of
label: Paragraph

text: conventionalized, familiar architectural elements as a critique of a failed functionalist
label: Paragraph

text: model.
label: Paragraph

text: Just as Lévi-Strauss’s structural anthropology attacked the facile empiricism of his own
label: Paragraph

text: discipline, architects have used structuralism to critique—more and less effectively—
label: Paragraph

text: architecture’s most basic assumptions and myths.
label: Paragraph

text: STUDIO PER
label: Title

text: Architectural firm, Spain
label: Title

text: Studio Per was a collaborative group formed in 1964 by Pep Bonet (1941-), Oscar
label: Paragraph

text: Tusquets (1941-), Cristian Cirici (1941—), and Lluis Clotet (1941-). Primarily because of
label: Paragraph

text: political considerations, Spanish culture remained relatively isolated from the main
label: Paragraph

text: currents of Western European art. Therefore, critics in Western Europe and the United
label: Paragraph

text: States largely ignored Spanish architecture. As Spain became more open, both politically
label: Paragraph

text: and culturally, a new generation of architects began to attract international recognition.
label: Paragraph

text: The four men of Studio Per came together in the burgeoning artistic climate of 1960s
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona and soon emerged as leaders of this movement. The designs of Studio Per and
label: Paragraph

text: others provided the foundations for the development and consolidation of contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish architecture. The work of this group continued into the postdictatorship period of
label: Paragraph

text: democratic Spain, and they participated in the dramatic refurbishing of Spain’s
label: Paragraph

text: architectural reputation, both nationally and internationally. In general, their work can be
label: Paragraph

text: characterized by a qualified acceptance of the International Style tempered with
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic revisions, including a legacy of the organic and an avoidance of unnecessarily
label: Paragraph

text: utopian theory. They contributed to general currents of postwar architecture that rejected
label: Paragraph

text: or modified the ideology of modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: All the men had been students of Federico Correa at the Escuela Técnica Superior de
label: Paragraph

text: Arquitectura and inherited a tradition of Catalan architecture going back to Antoni Gaudi
label: Paragraph

text: i Cor-net, Josep Puig i Cadafalch, and Lluis Doménech i Montaner. The group was part
label: Paragraph

text: of the newly recognized but loosely organized movement of Spanish architects, including
label: Paragraph

text: Ricardo Bofill and Oriol Bohigas, known as the School of Barcelona. Although a single
label: Paragraph

text: firm, Studio Per was actually the combination of two distinct tendencies: the
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernism of Clotet and Tusquets alongside the postrationalism of Bonet and Cirici.
label: Paragraph

text: This singular combination enabled the group to produce multivalent works that featured a
label: Paragraph

text: mixture of opposites. The group took inspiration from the architectural philosophies of
label: Paragraph

text: Robert Venturi and Aldo Rossi. An emphasis on form and composition along with an
label: Paragraph

text: unabashed faith in the value of historical tradition became important tenets of Studio
label: Paragraph

text: Per’s artistic philosophy. Despite this reverence for traditional forms, the architects
label: Paragraph

text: avoided slavish devotion to past styles and always injected their projects with the very
label: Paragraph

text: latest design elements and structural materials.
label: Paragraph

text: The work of Studio Per was characterized by a fine attention to detail and an honest
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatism. They viewed each project as a unique problem and opportunity, and the
label: Paragraph

text: group rejected adherence to rigidly programmatic solutions. The architects attacked basic
label: Paragraph

text: problems of location, client wishes, and legal constraints with an eye toward simple,
label: Paragraph

text: elegant solutions. The work of Studio Per questioned established norms and avoided the
label: Paragraph

text: blind implementation of romantic ideals. Instead, the architects constructed synthetic
label: Paragraph

text: designs aimed at achieving unorthodox yet convincing solutions. They often employed
label: Paragraph

text: high doses of irony and a respectful misappropriation of the past.
label: Paragraph

text: The guiding principles of Studio Per’s architectural philosophy can be seen in the Casa
label: Paragraph

text: Regas and Belvedere Giorgina (1972). The project was designed as a summer home in
label: Paragraph

text: the mountains near Girona, Spain. The site already contained the massive ruined
label: Paragraph

text: foundation of an ancient dwelling. The architects chose to build on the antiquated walls
label: Paragraph

text: while also constructing a new section of the house. This fusion of the traditional and
label: Paragraph

text: modern, the existing and the new, is one of the most important legacies of Studio Per.
label: Paragraph

text: The original home provided the location for the service elements of the household,
label: Paragraph

text: whereas the new building contained the living quarters. A short while later, the client
label: Paragraph

text: envisioned a second structure for the same site. In this project, the designers had to deal
label: Paragraph

text: with an extremely small space of approximately 40 square meters. The solution was a
label: Paragraph

text: single structure topped by a neoclassical belvedere. The work became somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: controversial at the time for its ironic appropriation of classical elements.
label: Paragraph

text: The House on the Island of Pantelleria (1974) continued the elements seen in the Casa
label: Paragraph

text: Regas and Belvedere Giorgina. The building is situated on a small island between Italy
label: Paragraph

text: and Tunisia. The site was in a protected natural park, and this imposed limitations on new
label: Paragraph

text: building. Clotet and Tusquets, the principal designers, chose to retain the ancient walls
label: Paragraph

text: and foundations. They reconstructed the dwelling with local volcanic rock and formed
label: Paragraph

text: simple volumes that echoed the modular form of traditional buildings on the island. The
label: Paragraph

text: home extended over two levels, one containing the sleeping quarters and the other the
label: Paragraph

text: kitchen and other service areas. The dual levels flow over the landscape, following the
label: Paragraph

text: natural slope to the sea. The most innovative design elements are the open-air terraces,
label: Paragraph

text: marked by rows of simple columns that again recall the island’s traditional architectural
label: Paragraph

text: elements. The house was a simple, elegant design that respected local materials and
label: Paragraph

text: forms while at the same time seeming modern.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to being an architectural firm, Studio Per also constituted itself as an
label: Paragraph

text: industrial design and furniture maker. A separate design studio, BD Ediciones de Disefio,
label: Paragraph

text: was formed in 1972. As designers, they helped raise international awareness of the
label: Paragraph

text: innovative artistic culture of both Spain and Barcelona in particular. The group achieved
label: Paragraph

text: some success as furniture and industrial designers, winning numerous Spanish and
label: Paragraph

text: international awards.
label: Paragraph

text: Although disbanded, the individual architects and designers of Studio Per have
label: Paragraph

text: continued to exert a great influence on Spanish and international architecture and design.
label: Paragraph

text: Tusquets and Clotet in particular played large roles in the 1980s rejuvenation of Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: design and construction. The project culminated in the Olympic Games of 1992, for
label: Paragraph

text: which Clotet designed apartment buildings in the Olympic Village and Tusquets a hotel.
label: Paragraph

text: STUTTGART, GERMANY
label: Title

text: Stuttgart, capital of the German state of Baden-Wiirttemberg, derives its architectural
label: Paragraph

text: distinction from its remarkable geographical position: the city lies in a basin of the
label: Paragraph

text: Neckar highlands and is almost completely surrounded by a high ridge. The only opening
label: Paragraph

text: is a narrow pass on the northeast leading toward the Neckar.
label: Paragraph

text: The city that grew from a horse farm founded around 950 (hence the name, derived
label: Paragraph

text: from Stuten-Garten or mares’ garden) gained its charter in 1250 and was enlarged,
label: Paragraph

text: especially during the 18th century, as the capital and princely residence of the counts and
label: Paragraph

text: later dukes of Wiirttemberg. The first systematic expansion plans occurred in 1832, just
label: Paragraph

text: as industrialization began to affect the capital as it transformed into a metropolis.
label: Paragraph

text: After an uninspired period of construction in the second half of the 19th century, the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century brought exemplary architectural achievements to the city, making Stuttgart
label: Paragraph

text: one of the most important centers of modern architecture in Germany.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most influential buildings in the history of the new architecture in Stuttgart
label: Paragraph

text: is the Central Station (1914-27) by Paul Bonatz and E.F.Scholer. In this monumental,
label: Paragraph

text: cubical building clad in shell-limestone blocks, all of the amenities of a modern train
label: Paragraph

text: station were cogently realized, from the passage of trains over optimal traffic and
label: Paragraph

text: transport ways, to travelers’ needs, to the Station Hotel and other functions. The
label: Paragraph

text: architects made effective use of steel and concrete, using construction techniques inherent
label: Paragraph

text: in these materials’ properties. Despite this innovation, they were unwilling to use the
label: Paragraph

text: same materials on the stone-clad fagade that features a tall, columned hall facing the city
label: Paragraph

text: center.
label: Paragraph

text: Another striking building that defines the cityscape is the newspaper headquarters,
label: Paragraph

text: Tagblatt Tower (1928), designed by E. Otto Osswald as Stuttgart’s first skyscraper.
label: Paragraph

text: Originally planned as a counterweight to the Erich Mendelsohn's Schocken Department
label: Paragraph

text: Store of 1928 (demolished 1960), the eighteenfloor, sixty-one-meter-high reinforced
label: Caption

text: concrete construction of the press tower was an important symbol of the new architecture
label: Paragraph

text: in Stuttgart and remains a milestone in the history of skyscraper construction in Germany.
label: Paragraph

text: Originally built in 1927 as part of an exhibition of the German Werkbund in the north
label: Paragraph

text: of the city, the Weissenhofsiedlung represents one of the most decisive steps in the
label: Paragraph

text: development of modern housing and constituted the high point of avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of the 1920s in the Wiirttemberg capital. The Weissenhofsiedlung essentially
label: Paragraph

text: created a model housing estate in which seventeen of the leading architects followed the
label: Paragraph

text: design motto Die Wohnung fiir den modernen Grofstadtmenschen (The Dwelling for the
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Metropolitan Man) in designing innovative structures. Architects included
label: Paragraph

text: Ludwig Mies van der Rohe (who designed the overall plan), J.J.P.Oud, Mart Stam, Victor
label: Caption

text: Bourgeois, Le Corbusier, Josef Frank, Peter Behrens, Walter Gropius, Ludwig
label: Caption

text: Hilberseimer, Hans Poelzig, Adolf Rading, Hans Scharoun, Bruno Taut, and Max Taut as
label: Paragraph

text: well as the Stuttgart architects Richard Décker and Adolf G. Schneck. The project
label: Paragraph

text: pursued the programmatic goal of demonstrating ways in which rationalization was
label: Paragraph

text: possible in housing construction and showing how planned development of affordable
label: Paragraph

text: and reduced-cost housing could provide, in the words of Lord Mayor Dr. Karl
label: Paragraph

text: Lautenschlager in 1925, an “improvement of total housing culture.” Critics of the project
label: Paragraph

text: claimed that although the small, affordable apartment stood in the foreground of
label: Paragraph

text: conceptual interests, in reality—with the exception of the J.J.P. OQud—the architects did
label: Paragraph

text: not design houses for the working class.
label: Paragraph

text: Approximately twenty-one individual buildings were finally constructed, with a total
label: Paragraph

text: of sixty-three apartments. Generally using steel skeleton construction, the individual
label: Paragraph

text: buildings showed a remarkable degree of uniformity manifest in their straight lines,
label: Paragraph

text: absolutely unadorned and shimmering white facades, flat roofs, and the balcony
label: Paragraph

text: treatment reminiscent of ship railings. Likewise, technical materials such as steel and
label: Paragraph

text: concrete were used within the interiors. Technical apparatus such as pipes and heating
label: Paragraph

text: units were not hidden but were placed demonstratively on the walls to underscore
label: Paragraph

text: functionality. Textiles as well as conventional furniture were generally rejected. The
label: Paragraph

text: walls had neither paneling nor molding, and the doors had neither frames nor curves.
label: Paragraph

text: After the Nazi seizure of power in 1933, the Weissenhofsiedlung was defamed as
label: Paragraph

text: Stuttgart’s eyesore (Schandfleck), its architects castigated as “cultural Bolsheviks.” World
label: Paragraph

text: War II left the project damaged from bombing and still unappreciated; the project was
label: Paragraph

text: neither protected nor rebuilt but was rather neglected and in part disfigured through
label: Paragraph

text: careless modifications or additions. Resurgence in interest in the project began in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s, when the Weissenhofsiedlung was recognized as an architectural monument in
label: Paragraph

text: need of protection and restoration, which was ultimately completed in 1987.
label: Paragraph

text: The first renewal of postwar modern design was the Liederhalle, designed and built in
label: Paragraph

text: 1955-56 by Adolf Abel, Rolf Gutbrod, and Blasius Spreng. The Liederhalle was a music
label: Paragraph

text: center with three large concert halls of various sizes, joined into a common complex
label: Paragraph

text: through a two-story foyer with a restaurant. A paved courtyard with shallow steps and
label: Paragraph

text: terraces leads to the squat main entrance on the west front. The exterior of the bastion-
label: Paragraph

text: like, projecting Mozart Hall is decorated with an overlay of quarzite plates of alternating
label: Paragraph

text: colors and sizes. The wide wall spaces of the high main building, however, had to be
label: Paragraph

text: satisfied with a plain segmentation into fields. The rear is pierced with countless
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular skylights.
label: Paragraph

text: The Neue Staaisgalerie (New National Gallery of Art) has been considered the most
label: Paragraph

text: important building in Stuttgart of the last 20 years and as one of the most important new
label: Paragraph

text: museum buildings constructed in Germany since 1945. It was built between 1979 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1984 by James Stirling, Michael Wilford, and Associates, London. The first concrete
label: Caption

text: plans for enlargement of the museum arose in 1974, but the present gallery dates from an
label: Paragraph

text: international competition for the design held in 1977, which set the task of architecturally
label: Paragraph

text: expanding the state art collection and new construction of a small theater. In total, eleven
label: Paragraph

text: participants were invited to compete, including seven of the most outstanding from the
label: Paragraph

text: first competition in 1974 as well as four foreign architectural firms. They were invited to
label: Paragraph

text: develop proposals with special consideration for urban renewal. In particular, the
label: Paragraph

text: Weissenhof Row Houses, designed by J.J.P.Oud for the Weissenhofsiedlung,
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: ameliorate the scars on the city center infrastructure left from World War IL. With the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: pastiche and even whimsy. Immediately adjacent to the preexisting national gallery
label: Caption

text: building, and joined to it by a “bridge” on the gallery level, the New National Gallery is
label: Paragraph

text: topographically sensitive. Stirling designed a public footpath through the museum
label: Paragraph

text: complex to integrate the historical buildings of the old National Gallery into the overal.
label: Paragraph

text: conception.
label: Paragraph

text: Stirling’s epoch-making achievement was to bring together these historicist elements
label: Paragraph

text: with the modern formal vocabulary of Functionalist architecture such as colored stee.
label: Paragraph

text: construction, visible concrete, or curving forms. Through the contradictions in form and
label: Paragraph

text: many-layered conception the museum gains in dynamism and seems predestined as a
label: Paragraph

text: house for the art of the 20th century.
