text: SUBURBAN PLANNING
label: Title

text: The evolution of suburbia as a distinct, and now predominant, terrain of American life
label: Paragraph

text: and culture is tied to broad shifts throughout American and global culture in the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century, particularly in transportation, economics, building technology, ideology of
label: Paragraph

text: family and home, and leisure. Already by the middle of the 19th century mechanized
label: Paragraph

text: transport facilitated daily commuting between home and work in major cities. Steam
label: Paragraph

text: ferries had connected New York to suburban Brooklyn and Staten Island as early as the
label: Paragraph

text: 1810s, and by mid-century trains extended to New Jersey suburbs such as Llewellyn
label: Paragraph

text: Park. By the 1870s distinct lines of railroad suburbs extended outward from such cities as
label: Paragraph

text: New York, Philadelphia, Cincinnati, and Philadelphia. From the opening of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century expanding trolley services filled in a nexus of “streetcar suburbs” surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: most major cities. Predominantly residential, the typology of rail and streetcar suburbs
label: Paragraph

text: varied from gated, exclusive tracts of single-family houses on plots of several acres, to
label: Paragraph

text: “three-decker” and other sorts of multiple-family dwellings, depending on such factors as
label: Paragraph

text: proximity to the city and the developer’s means.
label: Paragraph

text: The distinguishing shift in the 20th century was the proliferation of the private
label: Paragraph

text: automobile, especially from the 1920s onward, and the freedom it afforded for the
label: Paragraph

text: dispersal of dwellings at distances and densities that previously had been uneconomic.
label: Paragraph

text: Catering to the growing professional-managerial and other segments of the middle
label: Paragraph

text: classes, most developers responded with suburban layouts that only repeated low-density
label: Paragraph

text: 19th-century patterns based on horse and carriage transport, while higher-density
label: Paragraph

text: multiple-family units such as Sunnyside Gardens (Queens, New York) could take
label: Paragraph

text: advantage of urban subway connections. But the introduction of faster, limited-access
label: Paragraph

text: highways and parkways in the 1920s and 1930s, especially in the New York and Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles areas, also forced changes in the scale of suburbia, changes that were only
label: Paragraph

text: accelerated with the establishment of the interstate highway system in 1956.
label: Paragraph

text: Shifts in economic relations were equally crucial. Suburbia primarily evolved at the
label: Paragraph

text: hands of small-scale speculators, subdivi ders, and builders who developed tracts ranging
label: Paragraph

text: from a few houses to several acres at a time, most frequently on a piecemeal basis, quite
label: Paragraph

text: often according to street plans predetermined by prior subdivision or municipal
label: Paragraph

text: authorities. With the enormous increase in demand for housing following World War II,
label: Paragraph

text: as well as the availability of Federal Housing Administration (FHA) mortgages, extensive
label: Paragraph

text: government infrastructure programs, and standardized subdivision patterns such as those
label: Paragraph

text: provided by the FHA Land Planning Division, individual large-scale developers now
label: Paragraph

text: could consolidate in one enterprise the tasks of assembling land parcels, subdividing
label: Paragraph

text: them into house lots, providing infrastructure and landscaping, providing sites for
label: Paragraph

text: shopping centers and schools, and in some cases even building all the homes.
label: Paragraph

text: Federal government intervention transformed the economics of real estate, with
label: Paragraph

text: century-long consequences, beginning with establishment of the Home Owners Loan
label: Paragraph

text: Corporation (HOLC) in 1933 and then the FHA (1934). Endorsing the single family
label: Paragraph

text: house above all other types, the FHA eventually made it cheaper to own than to rent; and
label: Paragraph

text: by establishing minimum standards for housing and development, favoring homogeneous
label: Paragraph

text: tracts of detached, single-family, automobile-dependent dwellings, the FHA contributed
label: Paragraph

text: substantially to the postwar transformation and standardization of suburbs across the
label: Paragraph

text: nation. Even during World War II the urgent need to house defense workers had begun to
label: Paragraph

text: set the pattern for large-scale suburban expansion.
label: Paragraph

text: Since the early 18th century origins of modern residential suburbs in the Thames
label: Paragraph

text: Valley west of London, suburban planning and design have been substantially informed
label: Paragraph

text: by ideologies of individualism, privacy, and the nuclear family. These basic interests
label: Paragraph

text: underlie the predisposition of American suburban design toward private lots, single-
label: Paragraph

text: family houses, distinct front and back yards and, by the mid 20th century, a driveway and
label: Paragraph

text: garage for one or more cars. While individuality could be reinforced by encouraging
label: Paragraph

text: economic and environmental homogeneity among large lot owners in 19th-century elite
label: Paragraph

text: suburbs efforts to maintain individuality in 20th-century middle-class suburbs have
label: Paragraph

text: produced quite the opposite effect. Uniformity to the point of anonymity, and conformity
label: Paragraph

text: to the point of oppressive monotony, are exemplified in many subdivisions, especially
label: Paragraph

text: following World War II, when new production techniques facilitated mass replication of
label: Paragraph

text: houses of a single type, size, and plan in vast tracts seemingly stamped out in “cookie-
label: Paragraph

text: cutter” fashion (e.g., in the 1950s in Panorama City, California, or Park Forest, Ilinois).
label: Paragraph

text: Already in 1931 President Herbert Hoover had proclaimed the private dwelling to be
label: Paragraph

text: deeply embedded in Americans’ consciousness: “I am confident that the sentiment for
label: Paragraph

text: home ownership is so embedded in the American heart that millions of people who dwell
label: Paragraph

text: in tenements, apartments, and rented rooms... have the aspiration for wider opportunity
label: Paragraph

text: in ownership of their own homes” (quoted in Jackson 1985, 193-194). This confidence in
label: Paragraph

text: the private individual as the principal constituent element of American society, and in the
label: Paragraph

text: private house as the archetypal American dwelling, both of which notions long predate
label: Paragraph

text: Hoover, have continued to inform shifts and innovations in planning during the last third
label: Paragraph

text: of the century. Planned Unit Developments (PUDs), gated communities, and similar
label: Paragraph

text: homogeneous and exclusive subdivision types frequently are marketed explicitly as
label: Paragraph

text: effective means for articulating the individual residents’ status, privilege, and position.
label: Paragraph

text: Such exclusive enclaves, along with architectural shifts that increasingly have
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized withdrawal to indoor spaces, have served to intensify the character of
label: Paragraph

text: suburbia as a space of consumption, privacy, and the culture of the nuclear family.
label: Paragraph

text: Suburban planning also reflects the importance of leisure, evidenced in the visual
label: Paragraph

text: paradigm to which much of suburbia continues to adhere, a quasi-pastoral setting of
label: Paragraph

text: lawns, trees, and meandering streets, explicitly differentiated by means of landscaping
label: Paragraph

text: and zoning from proximate nexuses of commerce, transportation, and labor. Within
label: Paragraph

text: residential areas, both planning and architecture have accommodated the growing
label: Paragraph

text: penchant for personal, family, and community leisure activities, commonly through such
label: Paragraph

text: amenities as community sports fields and recreation centers, backyard barbecues, and
label: Paragraph

text: household recreation rooms, fitness areas, and entertainment centers.
label: Paragraph

text: The progressive theme that informed much of early 20th century planning originated in
label: Paragraph

text: Ebenezer Howard’s To-morrow: A Peaceful Path to Real Reform (1898), soon revised as
label: Paragraph

text: Garden Cities of To-morrow (1902). An English manifesto for social reform that took
label: Paragraph

text: aim at the evils of the “teeming metropolis,” Howard’s tract was an effort to tame the
label: Paragraph

text: evils of capitalism by promoting a new approach to community organization that he
label: Paragraph

text: termed “social individualism.” Critical to this process would be a new form of
label: Paragraph

text: community design, the garden city, which offered an attractive, almost romantic, vision
label: Paragraph

text: of housing at far lower density than the industrial city, and in far greater visual and
label: Paragraph

text: ecological harmony with the surrounding countryside, a design that with multiple
label: Paragraph

text: replications he expected could effect broadscale social, economic, and political change.
label: Paragraph

text: In America as in England, however, the city was not to be economically outmoded or
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned. Still, in designs for suburban adjuncts to America’s growing cities, American
label: Paragraph

text: designers did look to such figures as Howard and Sir Raymond Unwin, whose Town
label: Paragraph

text: Planning in Practice: An Introduction to the Art of Designing Cities and Suburbs (1909)
label: Caption

text: offered practical examples. What American designers took was a disposition toward
label: Paragraph

text: medium density, low rise, well landscaped, multiple family dwellings, together with a
label: Paragraph

text: conviction that such types of design could effect certain social reformist goals. John
label: Paragraph

text: Nolen based his design for Mariemont (1921), east of Cincinnati, explicitly on English
label: Paragraph

text: Garden City models, incorporating detached, semidetached, and row houses. His plan
label: Paragraph

text: combined a formal town center, framed by baroque radiating avenues, with outlying
label: Paragraph

text: residential areas consisting of curving avenues circumscribing tracts of house plots and
label: Paragraph

text: parklands. Consistent with the ideals of Howard and Unwin, Mariemont’s design
label: Paragraph

text: incorporated a philanthropic goal of establishing an affordable and healthy working-class
label: Paragraph

text: community; but unlike the ideal Garden City, Mariemont remained a commuter adjunct
label: Paragraph

text: to, not a replacement for, the industrial city. Palos Verdes, California, initially developed
label: Paragraph

text: in the 1920s according to a plan prepared by Frederick Law Olmsted, Jr., was a more
label: Paragraph

text: ambitious effort at social engineering, incorporating a mix of large and small single-
label: Paragraph

text: family dwellings along with some multiple family units, grouped into discrete
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods, each with an elementary school and adjacent shopping areas. Olmsted
label: Paragraph

text: argued that his design, along with the originally isolated location of this development,
label: Paragraph

text: would make it among the most stable and permanent of communities in an otherwise
label: Paragraph

text: changing and troublesome era.
label: Paragraph

text: The Regional Planning Association of America, founded in 1923, initiated an activist
label: Paragraph

text: approach to social reform through housing. In 1924-1928 two members of the group,
label: Paragraph

text: architects Henry Wright and Clarence Stein, working under the auspices of the limited-
label: Paragraph

text: dividend City Housing Corporation, laid out a section of already grid-platted Queens,
label: Paragraph

text: New York, within commuting distance of the central city, in an innovative pattern, with
label: Paragraph

text: low-rise terraces surrounding open interior courtyards. Abandoning the custom of
label: Paragraph

text: detached dwellings on individual house plots in favor of common interior greenswards
label: Paragraph

text: this development, called Sunnyside Gardens, was intended to improve both housing and
label: Paragraph

text: community for working-class people. Wright and Stein’s next project afforded
label: Paragraph

text: comparable innovation for white-collar families with automobiles. Radburn, New Jersey,
label: Caption

text: begun in 1929, was organized as a series of row-house terraces fronting on lawns and
label: Paragraph

text: walkways, with automobile access diverted to cul-de-sacs at the rear of the terraces.
label: Paragraph

text: Vehicular traffic thus was separated and screened from pedestrian walkways. Promoted
label: Paragraph

text: as “A Town for the Motor Age” and “A Town for Children,” it remains a well articulated
label: Paragraph

text: example of a planning type that ultimately succumbed to American predilections for
label: Paragraph

text: privacy, autonomy, and the trappings of automobile culture. Nevertheless some of the
label: Paragraph

text: strategies first articulated in Radburn continued to be elaborated in the 1930s New Deal
label: Paragraph

text: Greenbelt towns (Greenbelt, Maryland, Greendale, Wisconsin, and Greenhills, Ohio), and
label: Paragraph

text: enjoyed a revival in the 1960s and 1970s in developments such as Columbia, Maryland,
label: Paragraph

text: and Jonathan, Minnesota.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from the garden city, the other principal paradigm for early 20th century
label: Paragraph

text: suburbia was the private enclave of singlefamily dwellings, generally inhabited by
label: Paragraph

text: members of elite and near-elite social classes. Nineteenth-century exemplars of this type,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Tuxedo Park, New York (1886), in effect defined themselves as communities of
label: Paragraph

text: exclusion, often reinforced through gated perimeters. Indeed residence sometimes was
label: Paragraph

text: limited to those who could pass a social test, such as personal approval by the
label: Paragraph

text: community’s founder, or ability to gain membership in a private association such as the
label: Paragraph

text: community’s country club. While not all subsequent suburbs could even approach the
label: Paragraph

text: elite tenor of Tuxedo Park, the protection of social homogeneity remained paramount in
label: Paragraph

text: numerous developments well into the 1920s, notable examples being the Country Club
label: Paragraph

text: District developed by J.C.Nichols in Kansas City (1922) and the comparable Country
label: Paragraph

text: Club District in Edina, a suburb of Minneapolis (1924), both of which were explicitly
label: Paragraph

text: promoted as implements of an exclusive social milieu and lifestyle—amenities that
label: Paragraph

text: would be conserved through such devices as minimum lot sizes and racial exclusions.
label: Paragraph

text: Even in subdivisions targeted to a broader economic range of residents, such as Shaker
label: Paragraph

text: Heights outside of Cleveland (1911 ff.), developers used restrictions against two-family
label: Paragraph

text: houses, apartments, front porches, and other design and use characteristics to pointed
label: Paragraph

text: effect in marketing the suburb as a place where “standards” brought status and
label: Paragraph

text: restrictions safe-guarded a lifestyle.
label: Paragraph

text: The reformist and privatist-individualist trends in American suburban planning
label: Title

text: converged, to an extent, in Frank Lloyd Wright’s series of designs for a paradigmatic
label: Paragraph

text: American community that he termed Broadacre City (1913-16). Renewing a long-
label: Paragraph

text: standing American ideological aversion to the city, Wright’s design foresaw wholesale
label: Paragraph

text: replacement of all cities with uniformly low-density, single-family, automobile-
label: Paragraph

text: dependent dwellings.
label: Paragraph

text: Government too played a role in the shift toward the single-family suburban landscape,
label: Paragraph

text: first in zoning initiatives concurrent with municipal reform movements of the 1920s, and
label: Paragraph

text: then especially in housing programs that were among early efforts to address the
label: Paragraph

text: Depression. Empowered by a Supreme Court decision enabling a proliferation of zoning
label: Paragraph

text: codes in the 1920s, local zoning boards intent on refining suburbs’ residential character
label: Paragraph

text: commonly banned or restricted commerce and manufacturing, legislated minimum lot
label: Paragraph

text: sizes, and otherwise favored single-family dwellings. By establishing both locational and
label: Paragraph

text: design standards for affordable government-backed loans in the 1930s and 1940s, the
label: Paragraph

text: HOLC and FHA assured that the bulk of new housing in America would be single-family
label: Paragraph

text: dwellings located in neighborhoods that were preferentially newer, lower density and,
label: Paragraph

text: well into the 1950s, racially white.
label: Paragraph

text: Small-scale builders and developers continued to produce a considerable portion of
label: Paragraph

text: post-World War II suburbia, but the demands of the acute postwar housing shortage and
label: Paragraph

text: the stimulus provided by the Servicemen’s Readjustment Act of 1944 (or GI Bill) set the
label: Paragraph

text: stage for the use of mass-production processes, and production on a larger scale than ever
label: Paragraph

text: before. The most prominent figure in this transformation was the firm of Levitt and Sons,
label: Paragraph

text: who prior to 1945 had rapidly mass-produced thousands of homes for the war effort.
label: Paragraph

text: Their postwar showpiece was the community of Levittown, in the Town of Hempstead on
label: Paragraph

text: Long Island, where by 1947 they had completed, ready for occupancy, the first of some
label: Paragraph

text: 17,447 houses. Like many other postwar subdivisions, Levittown was exclusively white;
label: Paragraph

text: yet there were also a number of African-American subdivisions, mostly in the South,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Hamilton Park, a suburb of Dallas, and Bunche Park and Richmond Heights,
label: Paragraph

text: suburbs of Miami.
label: Paragraph

text: As developed tracts soon backed up against each other, however, lack of community-
label: Paragraph

text: and region-wide planning often left little opportunity to alleviate the monotony of the
label: Paragraph

text: homogeneous domestic environment. Efforts to articulate some sort of community focus
label: Paragraph

text: often were limited to building shopping centers. As early as the 1920s it was recognized
label: Paragraph

text: that an elegant, convenient, high-quality retail center could enhance the desirability of a
label: Paragraph

text: subdivision, as demonstrated by the opening in 1923 of the nation’s first automobile-
label: Paragraph

text: oriented shopping center, Country Club Plaza, as a much-vaunted amenity of
label: Paragraph

text: J.C.Nichols’ subdivision in Kansas City. The need remained, however, to address the
label: Paragraph

text: lack of civic focus and activity in areas of vast subdivisions. One effort to remedy this
label: Paragraph

text: was the country’s first fully enclosed shopping mall, Southdale Shopping Center
label: Paragraph

text: (designed by Victor Gruen, 1956) in Edina, Minnesota.
label: Caption

text: Occasional attempts of a different order in the 1960s and 1970s to restore the full
label: Paragraph

text: breadth of civic and community life to suburban subdivisions are perhaps epitomized in
label: Paragraph

text: Reston, Virginia, developed beginning in 1962 by Robert E.Simon. Considerably
label: Paragraph

text: indebted to examples of contemporary governmentfunded new town planning in Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: Simon’s private-sector effort envisioned a town with a comparable range of housing
label: Paragraph

text: opportunities, civic and educational institutions, and possibilities for employment and
label: Paragraph

text: recreation, all to be kept in harmonious relation with the landscape. Despite major
label: Paragraph

text: changes of ownership and direction in the 1960s through 1980s, Reston fulfilled much of
label: Paragraph

text: that vision, becoming a town of seven village clusters plus a town center, and a wide
label: Paragraph

text: range of recreational facilities, as well as a corporate business center employing over a
label: Paragraph

text: third of the town’s residents, all laid out on a well-landscaped, hierarchized system of
label: Paragraph

text: major through roads, looping residential streets, and separated pedestrian pathways,
label: Paragraph

text: serving a mixture of detached houses, townhouses, and apartments.
label: Paragraph

text: Reston was part of a shift, beginning in the 1960s, toward suburban planning that
label: Paragraph

text: aimed to afford a greater sense of identity, community, and security through consistency
label: Paragraph

text: of design and centralized, long-term management. Some of these efforts were on a
label: Paragraph

text: deliberately limited scale, as with Planned Unit Developments (PUDs), which in many
label: Paragraph

text: cases incorporated considerable sensitivity to landscape, community, and design quality,
label: Paragraph

text: often trading an increase in housing density for more continuous open space between and
label: Paragraph

text: around the houses. In many of these developments, however, as with larger-scale Master
label: Paragraph

text: Planned Communities (MPCs), standards of design and rules for land use were
label: Paragraph

text: appropriated to a central authority, either the developer or a community board
label: Paragraph

text: empowered to maintain the developer’s original restrictions. One of the largest MPCs is
label: Paragraph

text: the Irvine Ranch, a tract of over 50,000 acres southeast of Los Angeles, originally
label: Paragraph

text: planned in 1960 by William Pereira as a collection of village clusters centered around a
label: Paragraph

text: university campus, along with adjacent industrial, commerical, and agricultural tracts. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1970 Pereira’s plan was superseded by the SWA Group, who began by laying out
label: Paragraph

text: Woodbridge, one of Irvine’s earliest villages, in a highly controlled yet picturesque
label: Paragraph

text: fashion that incorporates a complex combination of mixed housing types and public and
label: Paragraph

text: private spaces. A recent and controversial example is Celebration, near Orlando, where
label: Paragraph

text: the Disney Corporation has both imposed rigid design restrictions and retained
label: Paragraph

text: considerable authority over municipal government and influence in the school system.
label: Paragraph

text: But perhaps the ascendant form of development at the end of the century is the gated
label: Paragraph

text: community. Harking back to such smaller-scale prototypes as Llewellyn Park or Tuxedo
label: Paragraph

text: Park, these enclosed tracts emphasize privacy, security, and in many cases status; but as
label: Paragraph

text: Blakely and Snyder (1997) have shown they also have the pernicious effect of decoupling
label: Paragraph

text: residence and community from the civic realm.
label: Paragraph

text: However closely planned and managed some communities may be, the predominant
label: Paragraph

text: mode of suburban development is thoroughly piecemeal, producing the wasteful and
label: Paragraph

text: chaotic consumption of land known as sprawl. Seeking to reverse this trend on both local
label: Paragraph

text: and regional bases, the nationwide Congress for the New Urbanism (CNU) has sought
label: Paragraph

text: since its establishment in 1993 to restructure design, policy, and planning practices in
label: Paragraph

text: ways that reconcentrate existing communities and incorporate new communities with
label: Paragraph

text: compact centers, public spaces, coherent plans, and a diverse mix of facilities and
label: Paragraph

text: activities. Architects working in this vein include the firm of Andres Duany and Elizabeth
label: Paragraph

text: Plater-Zyberk, and Calthorpe Associates. Parallel efforts, undertaking development in
label: Paragraph

text: conjunction with explicitly ecological and conservationist objectives, are found in
label: Paragraph

text: communities such as Prairie Crossing (Grayslake, Illinois), opened in 1994. Here
label: Paragraph

text: development has been limited to approximately one fourth of a 2500-acre nature
label: Paragraph

text: preserve, concentrated in ways that safeguard the natural landscape, protect native
label: Paragraph

text: vegetation and wildlife, conserve energy, and afford long views of open space, while
label: Paragraph

text: maintaining a sense of place and sustainable community.
label: Paragraph

text: SUBWAY
label: Title

text: The subway is a 19th-century idea realized largely in the 20th century. The industrial
label: Paragraph

text: revolution was the primary catalyst for the advent of underground transportation; without
label: Paragraph

text: it the iron horse that pulled the trains, the tunneling technology that bored through the
label: Paragraph

text: earth, and the iron walls that held those tunnels up would have been impossible. The
label: Paragraph

text: problem of the subway also had its political and social implications. Mass transit meant
label: Paragraph

text: reform, for increased mobility freed the working classes from the urban center and gave
label: Paragraph

text: them greater share of the public realm.
label: Paragraph

text: The leader in the industrial revolution, Great Britain came to the forefront of subway
label: Paragraph

text: design as well. The Metropolitan Railway was opened to the public to much acclaim in
label: Paragraph

text: 1863. The stations on this first line were architecturally undistinguished; the line’s
label: Paragraph

text: engineers quite naturally borrowed their architectural vocabulary from the established
label: Paragraph

text: railroads, and so a distinct Underground aesthetic would not be developed until the first
label: Paragraph

text: years of the 20th century, when consolidation finally allowed a cohesive architectural
label: Paragraph

text: expression to develop, as ably accomplished by Leslie Green. Green designed more than
label: Paragraph

text: 50 stations for the Underground; the details of these stations are closely associated with
label: Paragraph

text: the Arts and Crafts design movement, as extensive tilework unifies the entire station: the
label: Paragraph

text: exterior, the interior of the booking hall, and the platform. The Underground continued to
label: Paragraph

text: expand and change throughout the century. After World War I, the lines were routed
label: Paragraph

text: farther into the suburban hinterlands. Charles Holden designed many of the Under
label: Paragraph

text: ground’s stations for this expansion, those on the Northern Line in a stripped classical
label: Paragraph

text: mode that continued the Underground’s signature use of thermal windows. In 1930
label: Paragraph

text: Holden traveled throughout Northern Europe, experiencing firsthand Continental modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. His stations for the Piccadilly Line evince his conversion to the modern
label: Paragraph

text: cause and continued the Underground’s excellence in design. Postwar expansions and
label: Paragraph

text: new lines have not always maintained this architectural excellence, but they have
label: Paragraph

text: consolidated a uniform corporate identity through the use of supergraphics and
label: Paragraph

text: typography.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the first Continental subway was constructed in Budapest, the Paris Métro is
label: Paragraph

text: the early European subway best remembered for its architecture. Hector Guimard’s
label: Paragraph

text: stations interpreted plant and animal forms to create an otherworldly art. Guimard
label: Paragraph

text: himself thought of these designs as being entirely rational, and in fact the Métro was at
label: Paragraph

text: the time on the cutting edge of French industrial technology, and Guimard’s stations are
label: Paragraph

text: very much industrial products. They were designed to be mass produced, being made of
label: Paragraph

text: enameled steel and manufactured glass, and yet the form that Guimard adopts is anything
label: Paragraph

text: but a machine aesthetic and not simple transformations of natural forms. For example,
label: Paragraph

text: Guimard’s lamp standards were designed not after a plant stem but after the sap within
label: Paragraph

text: the plant stem. Three different station types were designed to give the entire system a
label: Paragraph

text: coherence and a corporate look. The simplest and most common were the balustrades and
label: Paragraph

text: signposts, the second topped these balustrades with an iron-and-glass canopy, and the
label: Paragraph

text: third comprised an entire pavilion into which a ticket booth and newspaper stand were
label: Paragraph

text: incorporated. Guimard’s tenure with the Métro was short-lived, and subsequent designs
label: Paragraph

text: have been less adventurous, conforming to the engineering requirements of the systems.
label: Paragraph

text: Opportunities for inventive underground public spaces, such as at the massive
label: Paragraph

text: interchange at Chatelet, were missed. However, public art and signature graphics
label: Paragraph

text: emboldened the visual experience of the Métro in the final decades of the century.
label: Paragraph

text: The Vienna Stadtbahn, more of a depressed railroad than a true subway for most of its
label: Paragraph

text: run, is one of the best designed and aesthetically consistent systems in the world; it was
label: Paragraph

text: Otto Wagner who made it so. Wagner was made the artistic director of the subway
label: Paragraph

text: system and the Niissdorf and Kaiserbad Dams in 1894. Few men in Vienna were as well
label: Paragraph

text: qualified for the task. Wagner had studied civil engineering and understood the
label: Paragraph

text: interdependent roles that the engineer and the architect must play in order to bring a
label: Paragraph

text: complex public works project to a successful conclusion. A comprehensive design
label: Paragraph

text: program prevailed at the Stadtbahn. Wagner and his design team designed the stations,
label: Paragraph

text: the bridges, the tunnels and cuts, and just about everything except the rolling stock and
label: Paragraph

text: the locomotives. Wagner built 36 stations from 1894 to 1900, most which survive in
label: Paragraph

text: some form. All are located in the inner city and along the Wien River. The stations’
label: Paragraph

text: forms vary according to the site conditions and the mood of the architect, but all share a
label: Paragraph

text: similar vocabulary and material and are unified by their structural logic, proportion
label: Paragraph

text: systems, and decorative motifs. Many of the stations are unapologetically classical in
label: Paragraph

text: their vocabulary, and others are less overtly “architectural.” Bridgelike forms are
label: Paragraph

text: frequent, particularly on the elevated lines. Probably the most famous of the stations
label: Paragraph

text: along the Stadtbahn is that at the Karlsplatz. The twin entry pavilions are modeled on the
label: Paragraph

text: Turkish kiosk, a referent equally important to subways under construction in Budapest
label: Paragraph

text: and New York. This exotic form fits the Karlsplatz stations perfectly, as the strong
label: Paragraph

text: curvilinear rooflines of the pavilions respond to the elliptical dome of the Karlskirche
label: Paragraph

text: across the square. The highly ornamented walls of the pavilions were composed of
label: Paragraph

text: standardized panels, allowing them, in theory, to be mass produced. Wagner understood
label: Paragraph

text: the importance of the emerging technical society and embraced it. He was able to
label: Paragraph

text: reassemble his versatile forms in many ways in order to solve the numerous different
label: Paragraph

text: sites the Stadtbahn demanded, thus ensuring a corporate look to the enterprise. This is a
label: Paragraph

text: quality that other systems lacked.
label: Paragraph

text: New York’s subway also owes its existence and initial appearance to a brilliant
label: Paragraph

text: engineer. After numerous abortive attempts at subway building on Manhattan, the
label: Paragraph

text: Interborough Rapid Transit Company finally realized the plans of William Barclay
label: Paragraph

text: Parsons between 1900 and 1904. Although New York’s system was only the second in
label: Paragraph

text: operation in North America (Boston’s subway was inaugurated in 1897), it quickly
label: Paragraph

text: became the most extensive system in the world. Although the system was largely
label: Paragraph

text: constructed using excavation techniques perfected in London and Paris, Parson’s greatest
label: Paragraph

text: engineering achievement might be his establishment of a four-track main trunk.
label: Paragraph

text: Architecturally, the first stations on the line were fairly simple affairs that again
label: Paragraph

text: combined features of Parisian and London station design. A station’s street presence was
label: Paragraph

text: marked by mass-produced iron-and-glass kiosks, recalling the entry pavilions in
label: Paragraph

text: Budapest. The stations themselves were largely rectangular in section, as appropriate to
label: Paragraph

text: their shallow cut-and-cover construction, and distinguished by the forest of steel supports
label: Paragraph

text: supporting the street above and the terra-cotta and tile murals that identified each stop.
label: Caption

text: The most elaborate station, at City Hall, was designed by Heins and Lafarge and vaulted
label: Paragraph

text: in Guastavino tile—the effect was intended to induce a spiritual response among the
label: Paragraph

text: throngs who used the station. As the New York system expanded into Brooklyn and
label: Paragraph

text: Queens, the architectural qualities of the original line were sacrificed to economy and
label: Paragraph

text: efficiency. Stations became less uniquely identifiable, and lines in the outer boroughs
label: Paragraph

text: were as often as not perched on bents several stories above the street, remnants of the el
label: Paragraph

text: system that was slowly supplanted by the subway across the East River.
label: Paragraph

text: While many subway systems purposefully projected a modern, industrial design
label: Paragraph

text: stance, in Stalin’s Moscow political symbolism prevailed over any avant-garde aesthetic.
label: Paragraph

text: Begun in 1931, construction of the Moscow subway was led by Lazar Kaganovich, the
label: Paragraph

text: labor boss of the Dnieper Hydroelectric Dam and Nikita Khrushchev, and the labor was
label: Paragraph

text: supplied by tens of thousands of conscripted unfortunates, thousands of whom died in the
label: Paragraph

text: works. The initial line was completed in May 1935, but construction continued under
label: Paragraph

text: accelerated conditions until the Nazi invasion of Russia in the early 1940s. Whereas the
label: Paragraph

text: engineering of the Moscow subway was quite forward looking, the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: presentation of the subway stations was by contrast decidedly traditionalist. The classical
label: Paragraph

text: vocabulary of many of the stations was designed to allude to great moments in Russia’s
label: Paragraph

text: past and was a part of the larger public works effort, the “Columns for the People”
label: Paragraph

text: campaign. The monumental classical spaces of the subway, such as the rococo foyer of
label: Paragraph

text: the Komsolskaya station, were intended to demonstrate that the wealth of the nation, once
label: Paragraph

text: squandered on the nobility and their palaces, was as graciously serving the needs of the
label: Paragraph

text: proletariat under the Soviet regime. Although Western architects may not have found
label: Paragraph

text: Moscow’s historicist vocabulary worthy of emulation, the Moscow subway did
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrate that architecturally significant spaces could be achieved five stories
label: Paragraph

text: underground.
label: Paragraph

text: Ironically, the subway most akin to Moscow’s in its emphasis on architectural space
label: Paragraph

text: was built in Washington, D.C.Whereas most postwar subway design aspired to nothing
label: Paragraph

text: more than functionalism, the Washington, D.C., Metro achieved a meaningful
label: Paragraph

text: architectural experience; this success is due to the genius of Harry Weese. Weese was
label: Paragraph

text: trained by both Alvar Aalto and Eliel Saarinen in the grammar of modern architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: yet he was also the restoration architect of Adler and Sullivan’s Auditorium Building in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago and Daniel Burnham’s Union Station in Washington, D.C.Weese’s sensitivity to
label: Paragraph

text: the classical heritage of the District of Columbia fused with his functionalist sensibilities
label: Paragraph

text: to produce a dynamic set of station designs that were at once monumental, almost
label: Paragraph

text: sublime, and yet were produced from a limited set of architectural elements, most notably
label: Paragraph

text: the deeply coffered concrete vault. Allusions to Washington’s classical heritage are made
label: Caption

text: by Weese but are never literal, as in Moscow. With their soaring intersecting groin vaults,
label: Paragraph

text: the primary interchange stations at Gallery Place and Metro Center are particularly
label: Paragraph

text: effective and have become memorable spaces in their own right in a city of overscaled
label: Paragraph

text: interiors.
label: Paragraph

text: The formal design of the subway station depended very much on the personal
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy of the architect. Where that philosophy was in tune with the artistic
label: Paragraph

text: movements of the day, contemporary architecture resulted. Where the architect was not
label: Paragraph

text: so moved, nothing in the subway problem prevented a revivalizing aesthetic. The best
label: Paragraph

text: subway systems hired designers who understood the complex contextual problems of the
label: Paragraph

text: subway and responded with an architecture that melded the technical requirements of the
label: Paragraph

text: building type with their own aesthetic vision.
label: Paragraph

text: SULLIVAN, LOUIS 1856-1924
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: Louis Henry Sullivan was the first internationally recognized architect in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States to pursue the idea of a modern architecture independent of historic styles. He was
label: Paragraph

text: supremely gifted as a designer of architectural ornament, an important component of
label: Paragraph

text: almost all his major buildings and central to his thinking about architecture as art.
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan was the first American modernist to write extensively on architecture—
label: Paragraph

text: critically, theoretically, and philosophically. He was the most outstanding creative figure
label: Paragraph

text: of the Chicago School of the 1880s and 1890s, particularly because of his designs for tall
label: Paragraph

text: office buildings. His work and thought inspired a number of younger contemporaries
label: Paragraph

text: throughout his later life, including Frank Lloyd Wright, who was Sullivan’s assistant
label: Paragraph

text: from 1887 to 1893. From 1880 to 1895, Sullivan was continuously associated with
label: Paragraph

text: Dankmar Adler (1844-1900), whose skills in architectural engineering complemented
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan’s design abilities to make Adler and Sullivan one of the most extraordinary
label: Paragraph

text: partnerships in U.S. architectural history.
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Sullivan was born in Boston on 3 September 1856, the younger son of Patrick
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan, an lrish dancing master, and his wife, Andrienne, a Swiss-born pianist. After
label: Paragraph

text: graduating from Boston’s English High School, Louis studied architecture for one
label: Paragraph

text: academic year (1872-73) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where his
label: Paragraph

text: principal teacher was William Robert Ware, who had founded the institute’s Department
label: Paragraph

text: of Architecture in 1865 as the oldest in the United States. Sullivan worked for Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Furness, at the office of Furness and Hewitt in Philadelphia, from the summer to
label: Paragraph

text: November 1873. Following his parents to Chicago, Sullivan then worked there in the
label: Paragraph

text: office of William Le Baron Jenney from December 1873 to June 1874, after which time
label: Paragraph

text: he went to Paris, where he gained admission to the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in October 1874
label: Paragraph

text: as a student in the atelier of Joseph-Auguste-Emile Vaudremer. Sullivan studied at the
label: Paragraph

text: Ecole only into the spring of 1875, when he took an extended trip to Italy, visiting the
label: Paragraph

text: Sistine Chapel in Rome and recalling a stay of six weeks in Florence before leaving from
label: Paragraph

text: Paris to return to the United States in late May 1875. He then resumed work as a
label: Paragraph

text: draftsman and designer in Chicago, for at least three architectural firms, and
label: Paragraph

text: independently, between 1875 and about May 1880, by which time he had probably begun
label: Paragraph

text: his continuous association with Adler, with whom he had worked at least once in 1876.
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan became an equal partner in the firm of Adler and Sullivan from 1 May 1883 to
label: Paragraph

text: July 1895, when Adler briefly left architecture. Afterward, Sullivan practiced in Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: with a series of assistants (most importantly, George Grant Elmslie, from 1889 to 1909)
label: Paragraph

text: and then alone until his death there on 14 April 1924, when he was impoverished.
label: Paragraph

text: When Sullivan joined Adler, Adler had recently begun independent practice after
label: Paragraph

text: working with a series of architects in Detroit and Chicago and three years of service in
label: Paragraph

text: the U.S. Army during the Civil War, partly as a topographical engineer. Adler’s skills as
label: Paragraph

text: a planner, engineer, and acoustic designer and Sullivan’s unique abilities as an architect
label: Paragraph

text: of ornamental, richly colore
label: Paragraph

text: without peer in Chicago in th

label: Paragraph

text: hicago Auditorium Building (
label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: 886-90), then the largest
label: Paragraph

text: private architectural project in the city and the structure that did much to launch
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago’s reputation as a major center for early modern architecture. For their client,
label: Paragraph

text: Ferdinand W. Peck, Adler and Sullivan designed the Auditorium Building as a ten-story
label: Caption

text: block containing a 4,200-seat theater, a 400-room hotel with a set of elaborate public
label: Paragraph

text: interiors, and rentable stores and offices. The building’s massive granite and limestone
label: Paragraph

text: street fronts, inspired in part by Henry Hobson Richardson’s Marshall Field and Co.
label: Paragraph

text: Wholesale Store (1885-87) in Chicago, combined with the Auditorium’s 16-story tower
label: Paragraph

text: to make the building a prominent landmark on the lakefront at Michigan Avenue and
label: Paragraph

text: Congress Street. Inside, the Auditorium Theater was meant in part to contrast with the
label: Paragraph

text: Metropolitan Opera House (1880-83) in New York City, which was planned mainly for
label: Paragraph

text: its wealthy box holders seated in 122 boxes set in horseshoe-shaped tiers around the
label: Paragraph

text: theater, which sat a total of 3,045. In the Auditorium, there were only 40 boxes set to the
label: Paragraph

text: sides of the house, whose vast parquet, balcony, and two upper galleries were meant to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate large middle- and working-class audiences for grand opera, orchestral and
label: Paragraph

text: choral concerts, lectures, and other events. The theater’s acoustics, acclaimed by leading
label: Paragraph

text: singers of the period, depended in large measure on its innovative elliptically arched
label: Paragraph

text: ceiling, which steps up and out in four segments from the proscenium. The acoustics,
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical stage equipment, and Sullivan’s original program of ornamental plasterwork
label: Paragraph

text: and stencils, integrated with incandescent electric lighting and ventilation, combined to
label: Paragraph

text: make the theater one of the world’s outstanding rooms for opera.
label: Paragraph

text: The Auditorium Theater’s opening in December 1889 was a national event that
label: Paragraph

text: initiated Adler and Sullivan’s international reputation. From 1890 to 1895, they designed
label: Paragraph

text: other theaters inside multistoried business blocks, including the Schiller Theater Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1890-92, demolished 1961) in Chicago. Sullivan was also the principal designer of the
label: Paragraph

text: distinctively polychrome Transportation Building at the mostly neoclassical World’s
label: Paragraph

text: Columbian Exposition of 1893. Yet, historically, the firm’s most renowned works of the
label: Paragraph

text: early 1890s were their tall steel-framed office buildings. In addition to the Schiller, Adler
label: Paragraph

text: and Sullivan’s built works of this type were the Wainwright Building (designed 1890,
label: Paragraph

text: built 1891) in St. Louis, the Union Trust Building (designed 1891-92, built 1892-93) in
label: Paragraph

text: St. Louis, the Chicago Stock Exchange Building (designed 1892-93, built 1893-94,
label: Caption

text: demolished 1972), and the Guaranty Building (designed 1894-95, built 1895-96) in
label: Paragraph

text: Buffalo. After Adler left the partnership in July 1895, Sullivan designed the Bayard
label: Paragraph

text: Building (designed 1897-98, built 1898-99) on Bleecker Street in New York City.
label: Caption

text: Except for the Chicago Stock Exchange, all these tall office buildings had exterior street
label: Paragraph

text: fronts wherein continuous vertical piers projected forward of windows and horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: lintels. In his single most famous essay, “The Tall Office Building Artistically
label: Paragraph

text: Considered,” of 1896, Sullivan emphasized the accentuation of verticality in the exterior
label: Paragraph

text: form of tall office buildings as the appropriate expression of their multistoried height and
label: Paragraph

text: lofty steel frame. Sullivan’s extensive use of terra-cotta ornament on the exteriors of his
label: Paragraph

text: tall buildings demonstrated that, unlike some of his European contemporaries and many
label: Paragraph

text: later modernists, Sullivan did not consider ornament to be an anathema in modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Rather, he was against the use of overtly historical ornamental and
label: Paragraph

text: architectural forms. In his essay “Ornament in Architecture,” of 1892, Sullivan had
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized the complementary relationship between structure and ornament in the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of buildings that embodied what he termed the organic ideal, meaning
label: Paragraph

text: architecture as living form, analogous to forms in biological nature.
label: Paragraph

text: In the aftermath of the dissolution of his partnership with Adler in mid-1895, Sullivan
label: Paragraph

text: received much professional praise from fellow architects and critics but relatively fewer
label: Paragraph

text: commissions, especially after 1900, although he continued to write extensively. From his
label: Paragraph

text: earlier partnership, he retained one major Chicago client, David Mayer, who in 1898
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned Sullivan to design the new Schlesinger and Mayer Store, to be a 12-story
label: Paragraph

text: iron-and-steel-framed department store for retailing on State and Madison Streets at the
label: Caption

text: center of Chicago’s shopping district. Built in stages in 1899 and 1903-04, this structure
label: Paragraph

text: was then acquired by Carson Pirie Scott and Co. and is historically known by that firm’s
label: Paragraph

text: name. The building featured a two-story base of ornamental cast iron (originally
label: Paragraph

text: envisioned as bronze) framing plate-glass show windows for mercantile display. Above,
label: Caption

text: the upper stories were clad in white terra-cotta (initially designed as white Georgia
label: Paragraph

text: marble), with each structural bay filled with a Chicago window (a broad, central, fixed
label: Paragraph

text: pane flanked by an operable sash window on either side). Unlike the subdivided interior
label: Paragraph

text: floors of tall office buildings, the department store’s floors were open lofts in need of
label: Paragraph

text: maximal daylight. Carson Pirie Scott’s upper elevation as the direct expression of its
label: Paragraph

text: iron-and-steel frame made this building a canonical work of early 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, one often cited in modernist historiography of the Chicago School.
label: Paragraph

text: From 1906 to 1919, Sullivan designed a remarkable series of bank buildings in small
label: Paragraph

text: Midwestern towns that served as centers for surrounding farming regions. At a time when
label: Paragraph

text: bank buildings in the United States were almost uniformly neoclassical, Sullivan’s essays
label: Paragraph

text: in the type were richly colored, ornamentally elaborate, and highly individual designs.
label: Paragraph

text: The most architecturally ambitious and historically acclaimed among these buildings was
label: Paragraph

text: the first of the series, the National Farmers’ Bank at Owatonna, Minnesota, designed and
label: Paragraph

text: built from 1906 to 1908. With the support of the bank’s president, Carl K.Bennett,
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan, assisted by Elmslie, created a unique structure, nearly cubic in its basic form.
label: Paragraph

text: Lower walls were faced in cut brownstone as a base below upper walls faced in variably
label: Paragraph

text: colored paver or tapestry brick, polychrome ornamental terra-cotta, and bands of glazed
label: Caption

text: mosaic. Externally, the bank’s form conveyed security of deposits, concentration of
label: Paragraph

text: wealth, and association with agriculture, all elements of functional character consistent
label: Paragraph

text: with the building’s type and locale. Inside, the bank’s main floor is one high spatial
label: Paragraph

text: volume that receives daylight through a central sky-light and the art-glass panels set into
label: Paragraph

text: the 36-foot-wide arched windows in the south and west upper walls. These sources
label: Paragraph

text: illuminate the richly colored decorative plasterwork and stenciling that form the borders
label: Paragraph

text: of the arches set in the opposite north and east walls. These mural arches framed
label: Paragraph

text: paintings of regional land-scapes with dairy cows, the main source of local agricultural
label: Caption

text: wealth and thus of the bank’s deposits. Sullivan’s later bank
label: Paragraph

text: Savings and Loan Association (1916-18) in Sidney, Ohio; and the Farmers’ and
label: Paragraph

text: Merchants’ Union Bank (1919-20) in Columbus, Wisconsin. Sullivan’s last multistoried
label: Paragraph

text: building was the steel-framed dry-goods store (1911-14) for John D.Van Allen and Son
label: Paragraph

text: in Clinton, lowa, whose design partly recalls that of Carson Pirie Scott.
label: Paragraph

text: As an architectural thinker, Sullivan sought to broaden his influence through his many
label: Paragraph

text: published writings, which appeared from 1885 until his death. These writings included
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan’s 52 short essays titled “Kindergarten Chats,” first published serially in
label: Paragraph

text: Cleveland’s Interstate Architect and Builder from February 1901 to February 1902 and
label: Paragraph

text: later edited by Sullivan and others in subsequent editions. In these essays, Sullivan
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized the need for an American architecture as the authentic expression of modern
label: Paragraph

text: social, economic, cultural, and technical conditions. In this vein, his position is usually
label: Paragraph

text: understood to be much like that of modernist European architects in the early 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century. Sullivan’s pursuit of these themes made him appear in retrospect to be a
label: Paragraph

text: “prophet of modern architecture,” the subtitle of his first
label: Paragraph

text: Detail of ornamentation, Guaranty Building
label: Caption

text: © Buffalo and Erie County Historical Society
label: Title

text: biography by Hugh Morrison, originally published in 1935. Yet Sullivan’s concern for
label: Paragraph

text: individual imagination, nature as a prime source of inspiration, botanically inspired
label: Paragraph

text: ormmament, and architectural expression of American ideals of democracy distinguished
label: Paragraph

text: his work and thought from that of many modernists. In the 1980s, a new cycle of Sullivan
label: Paragraph

text: scholarship coincided with the rise of Postmodern historicism, and his work was
label: Paragraph

text: reexamined not only as prophetic of the later modern movement but also for its relation
label: Paragraph

text: to 19th-century architecture and theory. There was renewed interest in his systems of
label: Paragraph

text: ormament and color and in his idea of expressing the functional character of building
label: Paragraph

text: types, a premise taught at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts. Sullivan once cited this school as a
label: Paragraph

text: chief source of the idea most often associated with him, that “form follows function,” an
label: Paragraph

text: aphorism that Sullivan thought applied to living forms in nature as models for an organic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: SUPERMODERNISM
label: Title

text: Critic and historian Hans Ibelings—borrowing from anthropologist Marc Augé—uses the
label: Paragraph

text: term “supermodernism” (also called “hypermodernism”) to describe a style of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture emerging in the 1990s, characterized by structures that are often airy,
label: Paragraph

text: minimalist or monolithic, and transparent or translucent and that use an abundance of
label: Paragraph

text: glass. Although supermodern structures exploit technological innovation, they are
label: Paragraph

text: generally visually and symbolically simple, with clean lines, a minimalist style, and
label: Paragraph

text: neutral materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Theoretically, Ibelings situates supermodernism in relation to Postmodernism and
label: Paragraph

text: Deconstructivism and in conjunction with some of the aims of modernism. Ibelings
label: Paragraph

text: noticed common tendencies in several architectural books published in the mid-1990s:
label: Paragraph

text: Terence Riley’s Light Construction (1995), Rodolfo Machado and Rodolphe el-Khoury’s
label: Paragraph

text: Monolithic Architecture (1995), Vittorio Savi and Josep Ma Montaner’s Less fs More:
label: Paragraph

text: Minimalism in Architecture and the Other Arts (1996), and Daniela Colfrancescchi’s
label: Paragraph

text: Architettura in superfice; Materiali, figure e technologie delle nuove facciate urbane
label: Paragraph

text: (1995). The almost simultaneous publication of these texts describing a similar aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: led Ibelings to condense formal and theoretical tendencies into a description of a coherent
label: Paragraph

text: architectural style.
label: Paragraph

text: Contributors to this style include contemporary international architectural firms such as
label: Paragraph

text: Rem Koolhaas’s Office of Metropolitan Architecture (OMA), Jean Nouvel, Dominique
label: Caption

text: Perrault, Herzog and De Meuron, and Ifiaki Abelos and Juan Herreros. Noteworthy
label: Caption

text: examples of supermodernist architecture include Jean Nouvel’s beautifully transparent
label: Paragraph

text: Cartier Foundation for Contemporary Art and Head Office of Cartier France (1991—94) in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris as well as his design for the Tour sans Fin (1989), a glass-topped tower to be built
label: Paragraph

text: in Paris’s La Défense. Also significant are Dominque Perrault’s new home for the
label: Paragraph

text: Bibliothéque Nationale (1989-96) in Paris as well as her Hotel Industriel Berlier (1985—
label: Paragraph

text: 90) in Paris and Koolhaas and OMA’s Educatorium (1997), a multipurpose building
label: Paragraph

text: designed for Utrecht University in the Netherlands.
label: Caption

text: Supermodernism is a phenomenological architecture, an architecture that appeals to the
label: Paragraph

text: experience of place rather than to ideas or symbols. Although postmodernist and
label: Paragraph

text: deconstructivist approaches to architecture often appeal to intellectual and historical
label: Paragraph

text: relationships among forms, supermodernism suggested a shift toward (perhaps even a
label: Paragraph

text: return to) the formal qualities of space and the visual and tactile sensations that
label: Paragraph

text: accompany them. According to Ibelings, the emphasis on space and place rather than on
label: Paragraph

text: form (or style as an end it itself} contradicts one of the main tenets of postmodern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture—that a particular building is an often-contradictory composite of symbols or
label: Paragraph

text: signs that carry cultural and linguistic meanings. Supermodern architecture rejects the
label: Paragraph

text: desire or need to decode symbols and instead appeals to a range of physical as well as
label: Paragraph

text: psychological qualities perceived through the experience of the forms. Supermodern
label: Paragraph

text: buildings reflect neither the history of architecture nor extraarchitectural ideas.
label: Paragraph

text: The supermodern structure in part appeals to universal concerns (a stronghold of
label: Paragraph

text: modernist ideology of the earlier part of the century). This emphasis on universality
label: Paragraph

text: reflects the current interest in globalization, which Ibelings links to homogenization and
label: Paragraph

text: commodification in art and architecture. Global homogenization has generated a rash of
label: Paragraph

text: chain stores, internationally recognized products, and expressionless, nondescript
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in world cities that resemble one another as well as architecture that is no
label: Paragraph

text: longer built by local architects in local styles.
label: Paragraph

text: Linked to globalization is the development of what Augé calls “nonspace.” Nonspaces
label: Paragraph

text: are spaces that “cannot be defined as relational, or historical, or concerned with
label: Paragraph

text: identity” (Augé, 1995). Rather than social centers where communities gather for
label: Paragraph

text: collective activity, nonspaces function as common places where groups of people come
label: Paragraph

text: together yet experience the space separate from others. The current built environment is,
label: Paragraph

text: according to Augé's somewhat relativist reading, meaningless. However, meaningless
label: Paragraph

text: space arises as a reaction to three kinds of abundance: an abundance of space, an
label: Paragraph

text: abundance of signs, and an abundance of individualism. The plethora of nonspaces
label: Paragraph

text: creates what Augé calls the supermodern condition, an obvious reference to French
label: Paragraph

text: philosopher Jean-Francois Lyotard’s 1979 seminal study La condition postmoderne:
label: Paragraph

text: rapport sur le savoir (The Postmodern Condition: A Report on Knowledge).
label: Paragraph

text: Because globalization has increased world travel to a phenomenal extent, the airport
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps functions as the quintessential nonplace, although supermarkets, hotels, and
label: Paragraph

text: oversized malls could be added to this list. Ibelings argues that the airport structure has
label: Paragraph

text: evolved into a universal type he describes as “an exposed
label: Paragraph

text: Hotel Industriel Berlier, Paris, designed by Dominique Perrault and Partners
label: Caption

text: © Perrault and Partners
label: Title

text: steel construction (a space-frame or gigantic trusses), a marked preference for vaulted
label: Paragraph

text: roofs, a colour palette of grey, white, pale blue and light green and, above all, acres and
label: Paragraph

text: acres of glass” (1998). Examples of this design include Kansai International Airport
label: Paragraph

text: Terminal, Osaka (Renzo Piano Building Workshop, 1988-1994); Hong Kong
label: Caption

text: International Airport, Hong Kong, Chek Lap Kok (Foster and Partners, 1992-98);
label: Paragraph

text: Stansted Airport, Essex, England (Foster and Partners, 1981-91); and Europier,
label: Paragraph

text: Heathrow Airport, London (Richard Rogers Partnership, 1992-95). Functionally, the
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary airport encompasses services such as shopping in addition to a means of
label: Paragraph

text: travel, and further serves as an economic center for the surrounding area, a trend that
label: Paragraph

text: reflects the transition of the symbolic city center to the periphery.
label: Paragraph

text: Supermodernism maintains particular traditions of modernism; namely, an aesthetic of
label: Paragraph

text: neutrality, minimalism, and abstraction. Yet supermodernist architects seek expressivity;
label: Paragraph

text: buildings are intended to be as autonomous and obviously separate from their
label: Paragraph

text: surroundings; as contemporary and new, reflecting the present; as technically innovative;
label: Paragraph

text: and finally, as a clean slate, an intended break from the past. Nonetheless, contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: critics and stress the need to not only examine these qualities but to locate them within
label: Paragraph

text: our contemporary global experience.
label: Paragraph
