text: SUSTAINABILITY AND SUSTAINABLE
label: Title

text: ARCHITECTURE
label: Title

text: Buildings consume one-third of the total energy produced in the United States, produce
label: Paragraph

text: 40 percent of the carbon dioxide emissions that have been linked to global warming and
label: Paragraph

text: air pollution, and generate 33 percent of landfill construction waste. These statistics have
label: Paragraph

text: resulted in a growing trend whereby buildings are designed, constructed, operated,
label: Paragraph

text: reused, and deconstructed in ways that will enhance human health and protect
label: Paragraph

text: environmental quality. Sustainable architecture is the expression coined for
label: Paragraph

text: environmentally responsive building practices. It differs from conventional design by
label: Paragraph

text: considering the environmental impacts of design decisions throughout the entire building
label: Paragraph

text: life cycle from cradle to cradle instead of cradle to grave. It provides a comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: examination of all aspects of architectural design including site selection, energy
label: Paragraph

text: conservation, passive solar strategies, low-energy systems, building materials, indoor air
label: Title

text: quality, water conservation, waste minimization, lighting, and use of renewable energies.
label: Paragraph

text: The roots of sustainable architecture can be traced to the ancient theoreticians that
label: Paragraph

text: include Vitruvius, who in The Ten Books on Architecture discussed the benefits of
label: Paragraph

text: designing with the local climate and indigenous materials (Morgan 1960). The skills of
label: Paragraph

text: preindustrial builders, the mastery of using on-site resources such as proper orientation,
label: Paragraph

text: thermal mass, shading, ventilation, and local construction materials, were all but
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned after the invention of artificial lighting and air conditioning. Except for
label: Paragraph

text: several notable exceptions (i.e., organic movement), architecture of the first half of the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century disregarded the environmental context of buildings. The energy crisis
label: Paragraph

text: brought about by the 1973 Arab oil embargo hastened the return to energy-efficient
label: Paragraph

text: design. The passive solar architecture movement of the 1970s responded by offering
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate technical solutions that, for the most part, failed to address broader
label: Paragraph

text: environmental and architectural concerns. The sustainability movement emerged in the
label: Paragraph

text: late 1980s as an outgrowth of this period, adding to a heightened environmental
label: Paragraph

text: awareness determined to achieve more comprehensive and integrated design solutions.
label: Paragraph

text: The term sustainability has its origins in the 1987 World Commission on Environment
label: Paragraph

text: and Development report, Our Common Future. The concept was central to “a global
label: Paragraph

text: agenda for change” in current development patterns focusing on both underdeveloped
label: Paragraph

text: and industrialized countries. The term recognizes the interdependency of economic,
label: Paragraph

text: social, and environmental factors necessary to sustain life on Earth. The defining quote
label: Paragraph

text: from this report is: “Sustainable development seeks to meet the needs and aspirations of
label: Paragraph

text: the present without compromising the ability to meet those of the future” (WCED 1987).
label: Paragraph

text: Buildings and sites that utilize natural systems to minimize their global, regional, and
label: Paragraph

text: local environmental impacts on land, energy, water, and materials form the basis of
label: Paragraph

text: “sustainable” or “green” architecture. Human health, economic affordability, and social
label: Paragraph

text: equity are also considered attributes of sustainable design.
label: Paragraph

text: Sustainable architecture involves both design philosophy and technology. Practitioners
label: Paragraph

text: in the field have written manifestos, statements of principles, and guidelines to clarify the
label: Paragraph

text: goals, intentions, and aspirations for sustainable design. One such widely published
label: Paragraph

text: document is the Hannover Principles by William McDonough, named after the World’s
label: Paragraph

text: Fair 2000 city in which the principles were drafted. The statements in this document
label: Paragraph

text: elucidate the inherent value of nature and our need to seek a more symbiotic relationship
label: Paragraph

text: with it. Guidelines for sustainable design by contrast tend to focus on applications of
label: Paragraph

text: design strategies or technologies. The journal Environmental Building News of
label: Caption

text: Brattleboro, Vermont, provides one such checklist, which serves as a concise listing of
label: Paragraph

text: building design and construction practices for any home owner, builder, or designer
label: Paragraph

text: interested in building sustainability.
label: Paragraph

text: Technologies for sustainable architecture form a long, cross-cutting list of alternatives
label: Paragraph

text: that need to be adapted to local environmental conditions. Daylighting design (Guzowski
label: Paragraph

text: 2000), passive solar heating (Mazria 1979), passive cooling (Givoni 1994), water
label: Paragraph

text: recycling and reuse, and biological wastewater treatment are primary sustainable design
label: Paragraph

text: strategies that combine innovations in technology with extensive design knowledge and
label: Paragraph

text: expertise. Computer tools are still mostly segmented providing design assistance for
label: Paragraph

text: particular building performance issues such as energy (Energy-plus, DOE2, and Energy-
label: Paragraph

text: 10) and lighting design (Lightscape and Lumen-micro). A design tool that links disparate
label: Paragraph

text: design and analysis components is Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratories’ Building
label: Paragraph

text: Design Advisor. The Green Building Advisor by the Center for Renewable Energy and
label: Caption

text: Sustainable Technology (CREST), E build, Inc., and Design Harmony, Inc. gives
label: Paragraph

text: designers qualitative recommendations for sustainable design including bibliographic,
label: Paragraph

text: video, and electronic resources as well as documented case study buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Selection of building materials is another key focus of sustainable architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Construction materials and methods are sought that are low impact throughout the entire
label: Paragraph

text: material life cycle; that is, the materials should create less environmental damage in their
label: Paragraph

text: extraction, processing, use, waste, and disposal phases than conventional alternates.
label: Paragraph

text: Green building materials typically have one or more of the following traits: they are
label: Paragraph

text: durable, compostable, recyclable, re-usable, and nontoxic to humans. Many of the green
label: Paragraph

text: building materials not only demonstrate superior environmental performance but also do
label: Paragraph

text: not degrade indoor air quality when strict adherence to non-toxic content is heeded in
label: Paragraph

text: installation as well as in the material. Recent history of sick building syndrome calls
label: Paragraph

text: attention to the health risks of creating sealed buildings with insufficient ventilation and
label: Paragraph

text: finish materials that cause chemicals to disperse into the indoor environment. In 1996 the
label: Paragraph

text: American Institute of Architects published their guide to environmental building products
label: Paragraph

text: called the Environmental Resource Guide. This book gave qualitative descriptions of the
label: Paragraph

text: impacts of common building materials. Alternative building construction materials also
label: Paragraph

text: play an important role in sustainable design (Elizabeth and Adams 2000). Straw bale
label: Paragraph

text: (Bainbridge et al. 1994), rammed earth (Easton 1996), cob, recycled tires (Reynolds
label: Paragraph

text: 1993), and fired ceramics (Khalili 1986) are the most familiar alternatives to
label: Paragraph

text: conventional construction systems used in sustainable building.
label: Paragraph

text: There are a number of exemplary buildings that illustrate the principles of sustainable
label: Paragraph

text: architecture spanning a wide range of building types, scales, and geographical locations.
label: Paragraph

text: The examples presented here highlight the qualities that differentiate sustainable design
label: Paragraph

text: from conventional practice.
label: Paragraph

text: The Center for Regenerative Studies at California State Polytechnic University at
label: Caption

text: Pomona is an example of an integrated design solution demonstrating ecological site
label: Paragraph

text: planning as well as sustainable building strategies. The project, built on 16 acres across
label: Paragraph

text: from the main university campus, completed the first phase of construction in 1993
label: Paragraph

text: although design ideas originated in the classroom almost 20 years earlier under the
label: Paragraph

text: tutelage of the late Professor of Landscape Architecture at Cal PolyPomona, John
label: Caption

text: Tillman Lyle. Professor Lyle elaborated on the design process and solution in his book,
label: Paragraph

text: Regenerative Design for Sustainable Development. The specific sustainable design
label: Paragraph

text: strategies applied to the landscape include biological wastewater treatment through pond
label: Paragraph

text: ecosystems, a solar farm with experimental solar electric technologies, habitat
label: Paragraph

text: preservation for wildlife, and edible landscapes woven throughout the building site. The
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were designed by the architectural firm Dougherty and Dougherty as
label: Paragraph

text: demonstration facilities, with a variety of passive solar heating and cooling strategies.
label: Paragraph

text: Building materials were selected for their durability, low maintenance, and low embodied
label: Paragraph

text: energy. Recycled materials were used in the landscapes such as recycled tires for
label: Paragraph

text: retaining walls and recycled concrete paving for outdoor patio spaces. The Center also
label: Paragraph

text: enjoys its unique status as a social experiment for participatory student cohousing.
label: Paragraph

text: Another example of an integrated building and landscape solution is the passive solar
label: Paragraph

text: subdivision, Village Homes, in Davis, California, by Mike and Judy Corbett that was
label: Paragraph

text: started in 1975 (Corbett 1988). This 70-acre site with 220 homes manages storm water
label: Paragraph

text: drainage using natural landscape features, narrow shaded streets to decrease exterior
label: Paragraph

text: summer temperatures, a street layout that supports solar access, and edible landscapes
label: Paragraph

text: throughout. Shared open space is developed between units adding to recreational use as
label: Paragraph

text: well as a sense of community. Energy consumption for the passive solar homes in this
label: Paragraph

text: subdivision is less than half that of conventional homes in the surrounding area. Less than
label: Paragraph

text: 10 per cent of the homes use mechanical cooling, which is a testimonial to passive
label: Paragraph

text: cooling in a climate that has many days reaching 100 degrees Fahrenheit in summer.
label: Paragraph

text: An example of a retail project utilizing the principles of sustainable architecture is the
label: Paragraph

text: Real Goods Headquarters in Hopland, California. Real Goods, a retailer of renewable
label: Paragraph

text: energy products, commissioned a building design that reinforced their corporate
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy toward environmental stewardship. Architects from the Ecological Design
label: Title

text: Institute of Sausalito, California, designed a straw bale structure finished with
label: Caption

text: “PISE” (pneumatically installed stabilized earth). The south-facing semicircular plan
label: Caption

text: optimizes interaction with the sun, with tall clerestory windows on the southeast to
label: Paragraph

text: capture morning light and shorter clerestories on the southwest to reduce late afternoon
label: Paragraph

text: solar gain. An exterior trellis protects lower windows from the hot summer sun where
label: Paragraph

text: visitors can enjoy the evaporative cooling effect from a water fountain in the entrance
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard. Light shelves on the interior diffuse and reflect light creating a soft glow.
label: Paragraph

text: Thermal mass is achieved through the concrete floor and interior PISE walls. The site has
label: Paragraph

text: additional sustainable design elements, some built, others planned. There is a solar
label: Paragraph

text: powered water pump at the entry, flow forms that can be used in water treatment as
label: Paragraph

text: sculptural water elements, and retention ponds that form part of the landscape ecology.
label: Paragraph

text: The parking lot utilizes biofilters to minimize the effects of nonpoint source pollution
label: Paragraph

text: from automobiles. The restrooms for this complex are touted to passersby on the nearby
label: Paragraph

text: highway as a “must-see.” Waterless urinals, recycled plastic toilet stalls, and reused toilet
label: Paragraph

text: tank tops as wainscoting are the predominant features. This project and a more general
label: Paragraph

text: discussion of the design team’s sustainable design philosophy are described in Ecological
label: Paragraph

text: Design by Sim Van der Ryn and Stuart Cowan (1996) and A Place in the Sun by John
label: Caption

text: Shaeffer (1997).
label: Paragraph

text: To illustrate that sustainable design can be achieved in a more extreme climates, the
label: Paragraph

text: Rocky Mountain Institute in Snowmass, Colorado, ofifers an excellent example of
label: Paragraph

text: combining home, office, and indoor farm into an exceptionally energy efficient and
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetically pleasing environment. The owners, Hunter and Amory Lovins, have created
label: Paragraph

text: a building that mirrors the resource-efficiency concerns that occupy their professional
label: Paragraph

text: ives (Hawken, et al. 1999, Lovins 1977). Although the 4000-squarefoot building is
label: Paragraph

text: located in a cold (8700 Fahrenheit heating degree day) climate, it is 99 per cent passively
label: Paragraph

text: solar heated. The building, built in 1984, uses high-performance window technology,
label: Paragraph

text: daylighting, energy-efficient electric lighting, high insulation levels, thermal mass, a
label: Paragraph

text: sunspace, interior water features, and photovoltaics. The building boasts a ten-month
label: Paragraph

text: payback period in energy savings to recover the initial cost of the energy improvements.
label: Paragraph

text: Office buildings, because of their emphasis on lighting and the high monetary value
label: Paragraph

text: placed on the employees occupying these buildings, are a prime candidate for sustainable
label: Paragraph

text: design. Worker productivity studies, as well as student performance in sustainable
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, are beginning to connect design quality and occupant health, as illustrated in
label: Paragraph

text: the studies by Dr. Judith Heerwagen of Seattle, Washington, and researchers at the
label: Paragraph

text: Heshong-Mahone Group near Sacramento, California. Two notable office building
label: Caption

text: examples discussed in more detail here are the ING Bank by Alberts and Von Huut and
label: Paragraph

text: the C.K.Choi Building by Matsuzaki Wright Architects.
label: Caption

text: The ING Bank (formerly NMB) headquarters building near Amsterdam, the
label: Paragraph

text: Netherlands is a corporate bank headquarters consisting of 10 vertical towers connected
label: Paragraph

text: by a serpentine plan linking offices and support spaces. The towers use daylight, stack
label: Paragraph

text: ventilation, plant materials, water features, and orientation devices to enliven as well as
label: Paragraph

text: enhance the transition zones between buildings. Office workers are guaranteed natural
label: Paragraph

text: light either from the exterior windows, with no worker being more than 20 feet from a
label: Paragraph

text: window, or from the interior borrowed light. Site development includes several gardens
label: Paragraph

text: placed in part to conceal a parking garage below. The building, built in 1987, is unique in
label: Paragraph

text: terms of the participatory process used, which involved representatives from all future
label: Paragraph

text: building occupant groups as well as all members of the design and consultancy teams
label: Paragraph

text: from the beginning of the process. The 538,000 square foot building is also renowned for
label: Paragraph

text: using 90 per cent less energy per square meter than the previous bank building,
label: Paragraph

text: recovering the costs of energy improvements in energy savings after four months and
label: Paragraph

text: reducing absenteeism by 15 percent (Roodman and Lenssen 1995). The bank is not only
label: Paragraph

text: energy efficient, but it is also evocative in the variety of spatial experiences and
label: Paragraph

text: environments it creates.
label: Paragraph

text: The C.K.Choi Building at the University of British Columbia utilizes a surprising array
label: Paragraph

text: of bold and more common sustainable design strategies that are well integrated into the
label: Paragraph

text: final design solution. The three-story 30,000-square-fbot office building has a long north-
label: Paragraph

text: south axis to preserve adjacent forest land. Although this could pose a challenge for
label: Paragraph

text: passive solar heating, the architects skillfully used roof forms to maximize north
label: Paragraph

text: daylighting while creating a surface for mounting solar electric panels in the future.
label: Paragraph

text: Reclaimed materials used in the building include salvaged wood trusses from a
label: Paragraph

text: neighboring building undergoing demolition at the same time and recycled bricks. The
label: Paragraph

text: architects experimented with a trickle ventilation system at the windows to encourage the
label: Paragraph

text: infiltration of limited quantities of fresh air and utilized stack ventilation through the
label: Paragraph

text: daylight atriums to avoid a conventional ducted ventilation system. The immediate
label: Paragraph

text: landscape utilizes the building’s gray water. One of the building’s more unusual features
label: Paragraph

text: for the building type is its use of composting toilets in an office building.
label: Paragraph

text: There are many more examples of sustainable office buildings worthy of further
label: Paragraph

text: examination. These include the Audubon Building in New York City by the Croxton
label: Paragraph

text: Collaborative, the Building Establishment (BRE) Headquarters in Hertfordshire,
label: Paragraph

text: England, by Feilden Clegg Architects, the Menara Mesiniaga in Selangor, Malaysia by
label: Caption

text: Kenneth Yeang, the Thoreau Center for Sustainability at the San Francisco Presidio by
label: Caption

text: TLMS Architects, and an environmental studies building at Oberlin College in Ohio by
label: Paragraph

text: William McDonough.
label: Paragraph

text: As seen in these projects, sustainable design goes beyond the energy savings goals of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1970s by creating buildings that satisfy energy as well as ecological, aesthetic, and
label: Paragraph

text: functional considerations through the overall design of building envelope, components,
label: Paragraph

text: systems, and siting. Besides computer analysis of building systems, much of the decision-
label: Paragraph

text: making and evaluation of sustainable architecture, however, is of a highly qualitative
label: Paragraph

text: nature. Quantitative assessments that benchmark sustainable buildings for performance is
label: Paragraph

text: a logical next step in the mainstreaming of sustainable architecture. A few of the current
label: Paragraph

text: assessment methods are discussed next.
label: Paragraph

text: An attempt to combine economic and environmental measures for sustainable building
label: Paragraph

text: materials has produced a number of computer-based life-cycle assessment tools. BEES,
label: Paragraph

text: Building for Environmental and Economic Sustainability, from the National Institute of
label: Caption

text: Standards and Technology allows comparative analysis of material selections on their
label: Paragraph

text: environmental merit (e.g., global warming, ozone depletion, embodied energy) as well as
label: Paragraph

text: their economic cost. Other life-cycle assessment tools, such as the Canadian product
label: Paragraph

text: ATHENA, allow a detailed environmental accounting of a product throughout its entire
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturing and use cycles in terms of energy, water, air, and solid waste effects. A
label: Paragraph

text: concept called the “ecological footprint,’ developed by Mathis Wackernagel and Bill
label: Paragraph

text: Rees at the University of British Columbia, considers the far-reaching energy, water, and
label: Paragraph

text: material resource effects involved in everyday patterns and products of consumption but
label: Paragraph

text: does so in terms of replacement resources to ameliorate the environmental impact.
label: Paragraph

text: Another means for assessing environmental performance of sustainable architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: through the use of green building rating systems. Rating systems assign building
label: Paragraph

text: performance categories a value judged against a set of prescribed baseline criteria.
label: Paragraph

text: Malcolm Wells’s 1969 Wilderness-based Checklist is one of the earliest rating systems
label: Paragraph

text: using ecologically based accounting to tally the rewards of designs that improve
label: Paragraph

text: environmental quality against the penalties of those with the opposite effect. More
label: Paragraph

text: recently, the U.S. Green Building Council developed a national rating system called
label: Paragraph

text: Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED). Regional adaptations to the
label: Paragraph

text: categories in this system allow jurisdictions, such as cities, to tailor the ratings to their
label: Paragraph

text: locality. Other examples of rating systems include the Austin, Texas, Green Builder
label: Paragraph

text: Program and Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method
label: Title

text: (BREEAM) in the United Kingdom.
label: Paragraph

text: Sustainable architecture developed in response to a cascade of environmental concerns
label: Paragraph

text: of the late 20th century described by such authors as Rachel Carson, Donella and Dennis
label: Paragraph

text: Meadows, Aldo Leopold, Buckminister Fuller, David Brower, Amory Lovins, Paul
label: Caption

text: Hawken, and others. A series of international commissions, from the 1987 Bruntland
label: Paragraph

text: Report to the 1992 Earth Summit’s Agenda 21, to the Montreal Protocol and the Kyoto
label: Caption

text: Agreement, have crystallized the global importance of environmental issues that serve as
label: Paragraph

text: a backdrop for design intervention. These concerns are echoed at the beginning of the
label: Paragraph

text: 21st century when emerging fields such sustainable architecture, ecological engineering,
label: Paragraph

text: sustainable agriculture, industrial ecology, and others begin to address the complexities
label: Paragraph

text: of balancing environmental, economic, and social factors. Design decisions that affect
label: Paragraph

text: land, energy, water, and material resource consumption, as well as human health and the
label: Paragraph

text: human spirit, set sustainable design apart from conventional design and will continue to
label: Paragraph

text: do so for years into the future.
label: Paragraph

text: SWEDEN
label: Title

text: Swedish architecture at the beginning of the 20th century was characterized by the same
label: Paragraph

text: search for an appropriate style that was taking place on the European continent at the
label: Paragraph

text: same time. In addition to a range of stylistic tendencies, architects faced new tasks
label: Paragraph

text: resulting from social and political changes, housing shortages, rapid urban growth, and
label: Paragraph

text: the development of new materials and principles of construction. One of the most
label: Paragraph

text: significant responses to the advent of novel materials and construction techniques came
label: Paragraph

text: from Ferdinand Boberg, the architect of the 1897 Stockholm Art and Industry Exhibition.
label: Paragraph

text: Boberg rejected the prevalent adherence to a neo-Renaissance style, instead employing
label: Paragraph

text: simpler medieval and Romanesque forms and reevaluating the role of ormmament
label: Paragraph

text: (Electricity Works, 1889-92; Rosenbad Bank Building, 1899-1904). Although he did not
label: Caption

text: reject the uses of ornament, Boberg believed that a building’s form should be based on
label: Paragraph

text: function and that the inherent properties of materials used in its construction should be a
label: Paragraph

text: primary consideration. These notions would be further developed and find their fullest
label: Paragraph

text: expression later in the century.
label: Paragraph

text: Governed by economic necessity, commercial buildings constructed around the turn of
label: Paragraph

text: the century employed new, more efficient materials and methods of construction
label: Paragraph

text: imported from outside Sweden. In 1898, Johan Laurentz constructed the first building for
label: Paragraph

text: commercial purposes in Stockholm using iron and glass as the major elements for the
label: Paragraph

text: facade. One year earlier, in 1898, Ernst Stenhammar had used a steel frame to construct a
label: Paragraph

text: facade devoid of ornament derived from historical references; Stenhammar was also the
label: Paragraph

text: first Swedish architect to use reinforced concrete in the Myrstedt and Stern Building
label: Caption

text: Like materials and methods of construction, stylistic tendencies were subject to
label: Paragraph

text: importation and further contributed to the debate over what was appropriate. One end of
label: Paragraph

text: the spectrum was represented by Carl Bergsten, whose Industrial Hall at the 1906 Art and
label: Paragraph

text: Industry Exhibition in Norrképing was clearly influenced by the work of Otto Wagner
label: Paragraph

text: and other architects active in Vienna at the time, and the other by Georg A.Nilsson,
label: Paragraph

text: whose stripped-down facades and clear plans anticipated functionalism. Reacting to the
label: Paragraph

text: former tendency, Carl Westman criticized the Royal Dramatic Theatre in Stockholm,
label: Paragraph

text: completed in 1908 by
label: Paragraph

text: Gothenburg City Hall Extension (1913-37), by Gunnar Asplund
label: Caption

text: © Kevin Mitchell
label: Title

text: Fredrik Lilljekvist, for its adherence to style at the expense of function and the
label: Paragraph

text: inconsistent use of ornament derived from the Art Nouveau and Jugendstil movements
label: Paragraph

text: that had developed in continental Europe. Westman’s own position was made clear in the
label: Paragraph

text: Medical Association Building (1904—06) in Stockholm, which is characterized by clear
label: Paragraph

text: expression of material and simple facade treatment. The work of Westman and those
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by it, such as Ragnar Ostberg (Ostermalm Teacher’s College, 1906-10;
label: Paragraph

text: Stockholm Town Hall, 1902-23), Lars Israel Wahlman (Engelbrekt Church, 1905-14),
label: Caption

text: and Sigfrid Ericson (Masthugget Church, 1907-14), has been categorized as part of a
label: Paragraph

text: movement known as “National Romanticism.”
label: Paragraph

text: Reactions to National Romanticism included a return to a classical form language, as
label: Paragraph

text: exemplified in Ivar Tengbom’s Enskilda Bank Building (1912-15) and Swedish Match
label: Paragraph

text: Corporate Headquarters Building (1926-28). During this period, influences from
label: Paragraph

text: neighboring Denmark were readily apparent and served to inspire the return to
label: Paragraph

text: classicism, as in Carl Petersen’s Faaborg Museum (1912-15). The influence of classicism
label: Paragraph

text: is apparent in the early work of Gunnar Asplund and Sigurd Lewerentz. Of particular
label: Paragraph

text: note is the proposed crematorium for Helsingborg designed by Lewerentz and Torsten
label: Paragraph

text: Stubelius in 1914 and the development of the original proposal for the Woodland
label: Paragraph

text: Cemetery developed by Lewerentz and Asplund in 1915. While continuing work on the
label: Paragraph

text: Woodland Cemetery, Asplund completed the Lister County Courthouse (1919-21), a
label: Paragraph

text: decidedly classical building based on pure geometric forms, and the Stockholm Public
label: Paragraph

text: Library (1924-28), which can be seen as indicative of the shift from neoclassicism to
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism.
label: Paragraph

text: During the mid-1920s, attention turned to developments occurring on the European
label: Paragraph

text: continent. One of the major proponents of the ideas developed there was Uno Ahrén, who
label: Paragraph

text: had traveled to the 1925 Paris Exhibition and reported on the work of Le Corbusier. The
label: Paragraph

text: 1927 Stuttgart Exhibition and new housing being developed in Germany influenced
label: Title

text: architects in Sweden at the time, as did the periodical Kritisk Revy, published by the
label: Paragraph

text: Danish architect Poul Henningsen between 1926 and 1928.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the earliest functionalist buildings designed by Swedish architects were the
label: Paragraph

text: industrial structures and housing in a company town known as the Kvarholm Complex in
label: Paragraph

text: Nacka (1927-34) and the Tiden office building (1929), both designed by the Cooperative
label: Paragraph

text: movement’s architects office headed by Eskil Sundahl. Other significant functionalist
label: Paragraph

text: buildings included an office building on Drottninggatan in central Stockholm, designed
label: Paragraph

text: by Wolter Gahn, and the Student’s Building (1930) at the Royal College of Technology
label: Caption

text: and the Helsingborg Concert Hall (1932), designed by Sven Markelius.
label: Paragraph

text: The 1930s was a time of great change in the social and economic structure of Sweden.
label: Paragraph

text: High unemployment, housing shortages, and substandard living conditions plagued the
label: Paragraph

text: country. The response by architects came via the 1930 Stockholm Exhibition and the
label: Paragraph

text: accompanying manifesto titled acceptera, or “accept.” The manifesto was written by
label: Paragraph

text: Gregor Paulsson (director of the Swedish Handicraft Association and general
label: Paragraph

text: commissioner of the exhibition), Gunnar Asplund, Wolter Gahn, Sven Markelius, Eskil
label: Caption

text: Sundahl, and Uno Ahrén. This document and the exhibition out of which it grew
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to outline an approach based on “everyday” issues. The main Exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1930), designed by Asplund, who was appointed principal architect, clearly
label: Paragraph

text: reveals his affinity for functionalism. Asplund would go on to complete other significant
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in Sweden, including the crematorium and adjoining chapels at the Woodland
label: Paragraph

text: Cemetery (1935-40), the Bredenberg Department Store (1935), the extension to the
label: Paragraph

text: Gothenburg Court House (1936), and the National Bacteriological Laboratory (1937).
label: Paragraph

text: One of the major themes of the Stockholm Exhibition was housing, and of particular
label: Paragraph

text: interest were the open-plan terrace houses designed by Uno Ahrén. Problems associated
label: Paragraph

text: with housing continued to plague Swedish society well into the 20th century, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Housing Commission was appointed in 1933 to investigate the problems and propose
label: Paragraph

text: solutions. Out of these investigations came the concept of “collective” housing, and the
label: Paragraph

text: most significant contributions to this building type were the apartment block on John
label: Paragraph

text: Ericssongatan by Sven Markelius in 1935 and the Yrkeskvinnornas House (1939) by
label: Paragraph

text: Albin Stark and Hillevi Svedberg.
label: Caption

text: Throughout the 1940s, the government worked to establish guidelines for housing.
label: Paragraph

text: During this time, many architects reacted against the monotony resulting from the rows
label: Paragraph

text: of parallel blocks of apartments built to solve the housing shortage throughout the 1930s;
label: Paragraph

text: notable proposals included the first tower block houses in Sweden, known as “star
label: Paragraph

text: houses” because of their starlike plan configuration, built in Stockholm by Sven
label: Paragraph

text: Backstrém and Leif Reinius in 1945. Backstrém and Reinius were responsible for other
label: Paragraph

text: inventive proposals, including a large housing area in Gréndal built between 1945 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1952. The concern for large-scale solutions to housing problems is also manifest in plans
label: Paragraph

text: for the area of Arsta in Stockholm, initiated in 1942 by Uno Ahrén and continued by Erik
label: Paragraph

text: and Tore Ahlsén into the 1950s.
label: Paragraph

text: The 1940s brought increased international attention to architecture in Sweden as a
label: Paragraph

text: result of the work of Backstrém and Reinius and others. Attention was once again
label: Paragraph

text: focused on Sweden with the publication of Sweden Builds in 1950 by G.E.Kidder Smith.
label: Paragraph

text: In a 1947 article, the English periodical Architectural Review labeled the work in Sweden
label: Paragraph

text: as a part of a movement known as “New Empiricism,” which was characterized as a way
label: Paragraph

text: of building on the basis of experience and a practical knowledge of material traditions.
label: Paragraph

text: One the most significant contributions came from Nils Tesch, who, just as the previous
label: Paragraph

text: generation of architects, turned to Denmark for inspiration, particularly the work of Kay
label: Paragraph

text: Fisker and C.F.Meller. A number of Danish architects had emigrated to Sweden during
label: Paragraph

text: World War IJ, and a number of them worked for Tesch, including Erik Asmussen, who
label: Paragraph

text: would go on to become the main architect for the Anthroposophical movement and
label: Paragraph

text: complete a series of buildings for this group in Jarna between 1968 and 1992.
label: Caption

text: In 1942, the English architect Ralph Erskine began to work in Sweden. Although
label: Paragraph

text: clearly influenced by developments in Sweden, Erskine’s work is highly expressive and
label: Paragraph

text: incorporates a wide range of seemingly disparate materials. Of particular significance are
label: Paragraph

text: the Tourist Hotel in Borgafjall (1948); a housing, school, and commercial center (1945—
label: Paragraph

text: 55) in Gyttorp; the Luleaé Shopping Center (1955); the Byker housing development
label: Paragraph

text: (1968-82) in Newcastle, England; and a series of buildings done for Stockholm
label: Paragraph

text: University since 1972.
label: Paragraph

text: Many of the large-scale projects initiated in the 1950s would carry over into the 1960s,
label: Paragraph

text: including the central area of Stockholm and a suburban area of the city known as
label: Paragraph

text: Vallingby, both based on plans by Sven Markelius. Another large-scale undertaking, the
label: Paragraph

text: “Million Program,” was initiated to construct one mil-lion dwellings between 1965 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1974 and exerted great influence on architecture and planning during these years. The
label: Paragraph

text: center of Stockholm was transformed during the 1960s by the pureglass PUB Department
label: Paragraph

text: Store (1960) by Erik and Tore Ahlsén, Ahléns Department Store (1964) by Backstrém
label: Caption

text: and Reinius, and the Culture House, Town Theatre, and Bank of Sweden Building, all
label: Caption

text: designed by Peter Celsing between 1966 and 1976.
label: Caption

text: Celsing was also responsible for the Harlanda Church, which was awarded as a result
label: Paragraph

text: of a competition in 1952 and completed in 1958. Just as at Harlanda, Celsing went on to
label: Paragraph

text: complete a series of simple churches built from dark-fired Helsingborg bricks, including
label: Caption

text: the Church of St. Thomas in Vallingby (1959), Almtuna Church in Uppsala (1959), and
label: Paragraph

text: Bolinden Church (1960). Although Celsing introduced a building style that explored the
label: Paragraph

text: role of brick in religious structures, it was Sigurd Lewerentz who demonstrated the full
label: Paragraph

text: potential of brick construction in religious buildings with St. Mark’s Church (1960) and
label: Paragraph

text: St. Peter’s Church (1963-67).
label: Caption

text: The last building to be constructed by Lewerentz was a small flower kiosk (1969)
label: Caption

text: within the Malmo Eastern Cemetery that he had planned and worked on since 1916. The
label: Paragraph

text: influence of Lewerentz is apparent in the work of friend and colleague Klas Anshelm,
label: Paragraph

text: including the Lund Town Hall (1961-66), the Lund Art Gallery (1954-57), the Malmé
label: Paragraph

text: Art Museum (1976), and the buildings completed for Lund University between 1948 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1978. Bernt Nyberg, an architect who had worked with both Lewerentz and Anshelm,
label: Caption

text: reveals his indebtedness to both of them in the Lund County Archive (1971), the Héér
label: Paragraph

text: Chapel (1972), and the “Sparta” student housing complex and Lund University (1964—
label: Paragraph

text: The oil crisis in 1974 greatly affected Sweden’s economy and contributed to the
label: Paragraph

text: collapse of the Million Program. Large-scale building programs were no longer feasible,
label: Paragraph

text: and much of the work for architects involved renovations and the upgrading of existing
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. Economic recovery in the 1980s generated new building commissions
label: Paragraph

text: resulting from urban-renewal programs and a number of “new towns” planned as an
label: Paragraph

text: alternative to urban sprawl. Of particular relevance is the area of Skarpnack on the
label: Paragraph

text: outskirts of Stockholm.
label: Paragraph

text: The search for an appropriate style that characterized turnof-the-century debates has
label: Paragraph

text: reappeared in Sweden, accompanied by a multiplicity of approaches and stylistic
label: Paragraph

text: tendencies. Whereas the Vasa Museum (1990) by Mansson and Dahlback was clearly
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by contemporary architecture based on complex geometries and a divorce of
label: Paragraph

text: plan and section, architects such as Gunnar Mattsson and Carl Nyrén have adopted a
label: Paragraph

text: classical form language reminiscent of Postmodern architecture, but with a greater care
label: Paragraph

text: for material and detailing. The work of contemporary architects Gert Windgardh, Anders
label: Caption

text: Landstrém, and Johan Celsing represents efforts to reconcile Postmodernism and the
label: Paragraph

text: clean lines that characterized Swedish architecture during the 1930s and 1940s.
label: Paragraph

text: Although architecture in Sweden during the 20th century has been characterized by
label: Paragraph

text: intense exchange of ideas with other countries, actual buildings by foreign architects did
label: Paragraph

text: not appear in the country until the final part of the century, with the notable exception of
label: Paragraph

text: a series of houses by the Austrian architect Josef Franck in the late 1920s and early 1930s
label: Paragraph

text: and two apartment complexes by Swiss architects Alfred Roth and Ingrid Wallberg in
label: Paragraph

text: 1930. Recent buildings by architects from other countries include the Volvo Headquarters
label: Paragraph

text: (1984) by the American Romaldo Giurgola, the SAS Headquarters (1987) by the
label: Paragraph

text: Norwegian Niels Torp, and the Malmé Town Library by Henning Larsen from Denmark.
label: Caption

text: In 1990, an international competition for the Museums of Modern Art and Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: was won by the Spanish architect Rafael Moneo. Completed in 1998, this complex
label: Paragraph

text: thoughtfully considers the development of architecture in Sweden during the 20th century
label: Paragraph

text: and offers a significant contribution to the debate about its future directions.
label: Paragraph

text: Like other European architects during the latter part of the 20th century, Swedish
label: Paragraph

text: architects have considered issues of sustainability and ecology. Contributions in this area
label: Paragraph

text: come from the HSB:S Architects Office at the Understenshdjden Residential
label: Paragraph

text: Development (1990-95) by Christer Nordstrém and White architects. With broad-based
label: Paragraph

text: popular and political support, Sweden has the possibility of developing an economically
label: Paragraph

text: and ecologically sustainable architecture. However, the question remains whether
label: Paragraph

text: architects in Sweden can mediate between international influences and the high level of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural production that has warranted praise from historians and critics of 20th-
label: Paragraph

text: century architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: SWITZERLAND
label: Title

text: Like other European countries, Switzerland’s architecture was dominated by historicism
label: Paragraph

text: at the turn of the century. This style emphasized correctness and distinction in design and
label: Paragraph

text: produced buildings that excelled in formal and aesthetic aspects. The Swiss National
label: Paragraph

text: Museum (1898) in Ziirich by Gustav Gull exemplifies this approach with an irregular,
label: Paragraph

text: picturesque grouping of building shapes inspired by medieval architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: At the beginning of the 20th century, Art Nouveau became the choice for architects
label: Paragraph

text: intent on expressing a new beginning, a new “spring.” In Switzerland, this style
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized superficial qualities above all else and is found primarily in the decorative
label: Paragraph

text: treatment of structural parts. Buildings were assembled from heavy elements, in utter
label: Paragraph

text: contrast to the delicacy of Belgian and Austrian Art Nouveau. These forms were derived
label: Paragraph

text: from historical styles but transformed into seemingly lighter structures. Through
label: Paragraph

text: decoration, individual forms merge fluidly into one another. The ornamental treatment
label: Paragraph

text: emphasizes relationships and influences between parts and focuses on movement
label: Paragraph

text: expression. This is demonstrated especially in large building complexes that are
label: Paragraph

text: articulated as pillar architecture, an example of which is the main building of the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Ziirich (1914). Its architect, Karl Moser, was a pivotal figure in early 20th-
label: Paragraph

text: century architectural development in Switzerland. During the 1920s, he would become a
label: Paragraph

text: champion of modern architecture, even designing the Church of St. Antonius (1927) in
label: Paragraph

text: Basel in reinforcedconcrete construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism in Switzerland presents the efforts of architects to transform an imported
label: Paragraph

text: style into a nationalized idiom. The machine aestheticism of the International Style
label: Paragraph

text: seemed to complement Switzerland’s propensity to manufacture quality products. Thus,
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss architects excelled in adapting modernism and did not need to create a distinct
label: Paragraph

text: version. A close contact with the design cultures surrounding the country has always been
label: Paragraph

text: a trademark of Swiss architecture. Architects simply experimented with the new
label: Paragraph

text: constructional means and materials instead of producing creative transformations.
label: Paragraph

text: The Swiss national ethos of sobriety manifested itself as a combination of practical
label: Paragraph

text: reason and moral claims in this style. Rational logic was at the heart of this modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, the International Style became a mirror for the Swiss self-view. This view was
label: Paragraph

text: based on values that were identical to the ideological intentions of modernist architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Buildings were solidly constructed in pure, slick cubical forms with flat roofs. In housing
label: Paragraph

text: settlements, the buildings were differentiated according to typology, and groupings took
label: Paragraph

text: into consideration the exposure to sunlight. Interiors tended to be open and well lit, thus
label: Paragraph

text: allowing for grand vistas in rather small spaces. Things inside were placed into the light
label: Paragraph

text: to allow easy orientation. The buildings used setbacks and had balconies, and the plans
label: Paragraph

text: are efficiently laid out. The “dwelling for the existence minimum” was a big theme. For
label: Paragraph

text: modernist architects in Switzerland, dwelling almost defined the profession. The best
label: Paragraph

text: modernist work in the 1920s and 1930s is found in housing, either in individual structures
label: Paragraph

text: or in communal settlements. In 1929, the Swiss Werkbund sponsored the Neubihl
label: Paragraph

text: settlement in Ziirich (finished 1932), which continues to be considered a standard.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from having educated one of the masters of the International Style, Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: who designed a few exemplary houses in La-Chaux-de-Fonds in an attempt at a regional
label: Paragraph

text: version of Art Nouveau, Switzerland also boasts a masterpiece of Expressionist
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, the main alternative to the International Style. Rudolf Steiner’s Goetheanum
label: Paragraph

text: (1928) in Dornach exemplifies this more intuitive, mystical interpretation of the industrial
label: Paragraph

text: age. Its amorphous building mass uses a particular formal language, expressing the shell
label: Paragraph

text: that harbors renewal and whose purpose is to find the way to the spirit. William Lescaze
label: Paragraph

text: and Sigfried Giedion are two other Swiss names that are synonymous with the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style.
label: Paragraph

text: The political influence of German Fascism during the 1930s created a strong
label: Paragraph

text: opposition to modernism in Switzerland. The contrasting forces fought over stylistic
label: Paragraph

text: choices, particularly in the temporary exhibition structures for the national exhibition of
label: Paragraph

text: 1939 in Ziirich. This event became a watershed that pitted sobriety against sentimentality.
label: Paragraph

text: Ultimately, the authorities compromised by charging modernist Hans Hoffmann with the
label: Paragraph

text: master plan but distributing individual pavilions to members of both camps.
label: Paragraph

text: Consequently, regional Romanticism was side by side with a socialist modernism. Famed
label: Paragraph

text: bridge builder Robert Maillart designed a parabolic reinforced-concrete shed for the
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss cement industry, and there was also a nostalgic little village containing examples
label: Paragraph

text: of regional houses. The temporary buildings were constructed in wood and had to
label: Paragraph

text: represent national contents through associations. Architects were forced to express the
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual program of the exhibition, which had been set along notions of Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: community. Architecturally, these political demands produced a mixed bag. Demands of
label: Paragraph

text: representation and symbolism were made of modernist forms that they were not able to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate by their nature. It became clear that soberness was not sufficient as an
label: Paragraph

text: ideological content. Architecture also had to cater to feelings, not just the intellect.
label: Paragraph

text: Consequently, architectural images became conventional. Picturesque groupings replaced
label: Paragraph

text: abstraction, and typological investigations of communal space became important. The
label: Paragraph

text: previously mentioned Maillart had opened new horizons in modern reinforcedconcrete
label: Paragraph

text: bridge construction. The shape of the supporting arch was used to stabilize the bridge and
label: Paragraph

text: also became a trademark icon.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the slowdown in building activity during World War II allowed the nascent
label: Paragraph

text: modernist attempts to mature into a competent stylistic expression that provided a solid
label: Paragraph

text: foundation for future architecture. After the war, the characteristics of building materials
label: Paragraph

text: and their impact on structure, proportional systems, high quality of execution, and
label: Paragraph

text: simplicity of form became trademarks of Swiss architecture. Nevertheless, the prewar
label: Paragraph

text: design elements were reorganized. Rationality was now contrasted with sensuality,
label: Paragraph

text: feeling, and emotion. Pragmatism was combined with aesthetic design. Human needs and
label: Paragraph

text: a newly found respect for traditions changed functional design. However, typical Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: character traits—freedom of thought, high standard of living, justice, and neutrality—are
label: Paragraph

text: hard to represent and thus have not had a dramatic effect on architecture. Consequently,
label: Paragraph

text: modernist functionalism continued to be the mainstream of architectural development.
label: Paragraph

text: Especially the sculptural vehemence of Le Corbusier’s postwar work served as
label: Paragraph

text: inspiration. Atelier 5’s Halen Settlement (1961) in Berne, as well as buildings by Dolf
label: Caption

text: Schneebli, adapted the master’s concepts to local patterns of housing. Halen spread
label: Paragraph

text: collective services over a gently sloped site. Such designs experimented with the
label: Paragraph

text: sculptural potential of reinforced-concrete construction. Other Swiss architects exploited
label: Paragraph

text: sloping sites for terraced housing settlements. The Swiss sense for precision and
label: Paragraph

text: refinement came out in luxuriously detailed adaptations of Mies van der Rohe’s steel-
label: Paragraph

text: and-glass boxes. Some architects excelled in designing for the traditional materials, wood
label: Paragraph

text: and brick, and exploited them for interesting spatial explorations. Ernst Gisel’s Park
label: Paragraph

text: Theater (1954) in Grenchen is almost a literal copy of Alvar Aalto’s Saynatsalo Civic
label: Paragraph

text: Center.
label: Paragraph

text: These propitious beginnings would later fizzle out into empty applications of
label: Paragraph

text: technology to generate profit. This shoe box architecture was balanced by wildly shaped
label: Paragraph

text: concrete buildings that were for the most part trivial. There was also a large number of
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, especially for tourist functions, that used a typical “Heimatstil.” Especially
label: Paragraph

text: large hotels in the mountains were shaped like overfed chalets or other farm and
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular buildings. Nevertheless, Swiss architects hardly ever indulged in the historicist
label: Paragraph

text: frivolities that Postmodern architects produced in the United States. Good architecture
label: Paragraph

text: was still thought to rest on pragmatic principles. Swiss architects chose either to adapt
label: Paragraph

text: modernist forms to the topography or to expressively interpret the site. An example of the
label: Paragraph

text: former is the megalomaniac Cité du Lignon (1971) in Geneva. This is a huge apartment
label: Paragraph

text: building in the form of a bent, one-kilometer-long slab with smooth facades that lacks
label: Paragraph

text: any human scale.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1960s, urban design in Switzerland was characterized by integrations of
label: Paragraph

text: new structures into existing environments. Multifunctional buildings expressed the high
label: Paragraph

text: civilization of the country. Housing settlements of sequential units interspersed with open
label: Paragraph

text: areas were built. Diversity was felt to be commensurate with the liberal and multicultural
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss society. Swiss architects also began building in developing countries. Andre
label: Paragraph

text: Studer’s innovative 1954 apartment building in Casablanca is a successful example of the
label: Paragraph

text: exportation of such Western standards to developing countries. In the Swiss Ticino
label: Paragraph

text: region, architects such as Luigi Snozzi and Aurelio Galfetti integrated modernist shapes
label: Paragraph

text: into the rustic landscape and created a strong regionalist typology. There was a
label: Paragraph

text: rediscovery of primitive architecture, which was praised for its rootedness in topography.
label: Paragraph

text: The Ticino School advocated an architecture of rational technology, displayed in
label: Paragraph

text: impeccable details and execution. Their architecture was to focus on its most objective
label: Paragraph

text: features. This, after all, is what the Swiss generally excel in. The main part of Galfetti’s
label: Paragraph

text: Communal Swimming Pool (1970) in Bellinzona is a footbridge that allows visitors to
label: Paragraph

text: survey the entire complex. The renovations and remodelings of the castle in Bellinzona
label: Caption

text: have served many an architect to excel in combinations of new and old. Nevertheless,
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss architects did not advocate taking history only as myth or imagery but also as a
label: Paragraph

text: source of knowledge and continuity. The Collegiate Church (1966) in Sarnen by Naef,
label: Caption

text: Studer and Studer embedded references to oval baroque plans into its bulging forms.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, sculptural shapes on the outside become rich spatial experiences inside.
label: Paragraph

text: The younger generation of Ticinese architects, led by Mario Botta, has fashioned for
label: Paragraph

text: itself an image of craft, even though their buildings are machine built. For these
label: Paragraph

text: architects, architecture represents through abstraction. It intends to continue the
label: Paragraph

text: tendencies inherent in the land and in history, thus the title “Tendenzen” of the 1975
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition that put this architecture on the map.
label: Paragraph

text: The various movements of the 1970s in one way or another provided updated
label: Paragraph

text: interpretations of modernism. Continuing into the 1980s, Swiss architects produced a
label: Paragraph

text: good number of qualitatively excellent high-tech buildings. Theo Hotz’s Tele-phone
label: Paragraph

text: Exchange (1980) in Ziirich marks the edge of the city and stands out in its drab
label: Paragraph

text: environment as a cathedral to technology. Structure and mass of the building enter into a
label: Paragraph

text: mutual dialogue.
label: Paragraph

text: Historic preservation became a significant architectural task as well. An example is the
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Contemporary Art (1980) in Basel by K. and W.Steib. The new addition adds
label: Paragraph

text: a moment of development to the existing context of warehouse buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Emphasis on pure materiality was transmitted from the Ticino School to Herzog and de
label: Paragraph

text: Meuron and Diener and Diener, two firms that were actively involved in the international
label: Paragraph

text: reevaluation of Swiss architecture during the late 1980s and early 1990s. However, the
label: Paragraph

text: globalization of the information age has resulted in an utterly superficial approach to
label: Paragraph

text: building materials. Herzog and de Meuron’s buildings use contrasting materials in an
label: Paragraph

text: autonomous manner that is no longer structurally determined so that they ultimately lose
label: Paragraph

text: all meaning. The materials form simple contrasts without ever reaching a synthesis.
label: Paragraph

text: Together with the abstract forms of their buildings, this produces pure geometry without
label: Paragraph

text: details. None of the materials is allowed to dominate, and there is no effort to integrate
label: Paragraph

text: them. Instead, each part is treated as a separate element, and the viewer is charged with
label: Paragraph

text: their integration. Effects are created only through the materials, not through forms or
label: Paragraph

text: other conventional features. Thus, imagery is purely material. The buildings then become
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual expressions; that is, there is no metaphor, no iconography, no personal manner,
label: Paragraph

text: and no attempt to create a complete, fulfilled form. The buildings present an architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of entropy in which accepted notions and conventions are not applicable. Through this,
label: Paragraph

text: the viewer is given a mere projection, just like reality is condensed on thin film in a
label: Paragraph

text: movie.
label: Paragraph

text: However, there is hope yet for Swiss architecture. Successors have taken this aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: level of materiality to a more mundane level and attempted to create beautiful buildings
label: Paragraph

text: with everyday materials, such as wood and brick, and with traditional forms, such as
label: Paragraph

text: pitched slate roofs. This contemporary architecture rests on the foundations of modernism
label: Paragraph

text: but also considers the properties of materials and construction as well as the
label: Paragraph

text: characteristics of the topographical situation. These architects do not see the need to
label: Paragraph

text: produce original masterworks. It almost seems as if the current generation of Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: architects has learned the lessons that the modernist architects realized and spread after
label: Paragraph

text: World War Il. The present generation’s flag bearer is Peter Zumthor. His architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: characterized by a virtuoso treatment of materials, first of wood, later also of stone and
label: Paragraph

text: glass. This is a far cry from the blasé materials of the stars of the 1980s. His Chapel Sogn
label: Paragraph

text: Benedetg (1989) at Sumvitg imitates stone masonry, but because it uses wood, it
label: Paragraph

text: reintegrates the building back to the people, making this religious structure look and age
label: Paragraph

text: as the people’s own houses. Wood here gained a layer of symbolism. For Zumthor,
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is not what is in the materials but what these materials mean. His is an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of reduction—to the essential forms and constructions without imposed
label: Paragraph

text: meanings. It is the building that needs to spark the imagination.
label: Paragraph
