text: SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA
label: Title

text: From the top of the Sydney Harbour Bridge (1932), the city is divided in two by its
label: Paragraph

text: famous harbor and to the north by the Hawkesbury River, which circles around the back
label: Paragraph

text: of Sydney and limits the Cumberland Plain, joining the Pacific Ocean at Broken Bay. To
label: Paragraph

text: the south is Botany Bay, which was proposed as the original site of settlement and later
label: Paragraph

text: discarded because it lacked a reliable source of fresh water; beyond it, the Hlawarra
label: Paragraph

text: Escarpment shuts the city off to the south, and on the west, the escarpment of the Blue
label: Paragraph

text: Mountains bars the way to the inland. Sydney is imprisoned by its geography.
label: Paragraph

text: The hard Hawkesbury sandstone tabletop on which the city rests has been deeply cut
label: Paragraph

text: into by water, lifted, and then partly submerged and tilted up at its ocean edge; Port
label: Paragraph

text: Jackson and Middle Harbour, once separate harbors with their own outlets, are now
label: Paragraph

text: merged into one extensive harbor that breaks through to the ocean between two lofty
label: Paragraph

text: heads a little over a mile apart. Sydney occupies a difficult if alluring site, hidden from
label: Paragraph

text: the oceanside by its narrow entrance.
label: Paragraph

text: Following the revolt of the American colonies in 1776, at the suggestion of Joseph
label: Paragraph

text: Banks, Botany Bay was selected for the site of a new penal settlement to replace what
label: Paragraph

text: had been lost. The institution was founded in 1788 by 1,487 souls who reached Australia
label: Paragraph

text: in 11 ships after a prolonged voyage. A little over half their number were convicts.
label: Paragraph

text: Captain Phillip, the naval officer in charge of the enterprise, selected a cove 8 kilometers
label: Paragraph

text: from the entrance on the south shore for the settlement because it possessed the best
label: Paragraph

text: springwater, and its depth permitted his ships to anchor close to the shore. The
label: Paragraph

text: developing township was named after British Home Secretary Thomas Townsend, Lord
label: Paragraph

text: Sydney.
label: Paragraph

text: Sydney began as a collection of tents and huts. Organized along military lines, it soon
label: Paragraph

text: acquired a makeshift, disorderly aspect that provoked successive governors to propose
label: Paragraph

text: orderly town plans that were resisted by the inhabitants on the principle that the example
label: Paragraph

text: of civic order in architecture would inspire social discipline and respect.
label: Paragraph

text: A small settlement sprang up on the west shore of Sydney Cove known today as The
label: Paragraph

text: Rocks because it was built against a rocky ridge, one of two that framed the site. The
label: Paragraph

text: early buildings were primitive: Bricks were laid with clay or mud, the native timber was
label: Paragraph

text: cranky and iron-hard, and only the she-oak provided fine roof shingles. The Government
label: Paragraph

text: House, a modest two-story dwelling in a plain Georgian style on the east side of the cove,
label: Paragraph

text: was occupied by Governor Phillip in June 1789 and was the first building of importance.
label: Paragraph

text: Walls were whitewashed for additional protection, giving the settlement the air of a
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean village.
label: Paragraph

text: During the late 18th and 19th centuries, Australian architecture faithfully mirrored
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic developments, as it followed the succession of English styles: Georgian, then
label: Paragraph

text: Regency, followed by Gothic Revival, Victorian, and a diluted version of Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: and Art Nouveau. American influence increased after the gold rush, especially in
label: Paragraph

text: commercial and domestic architecture, causing a split in the sourcing of style influences.
label: Paragraph

text: The esteem with which such mimicry was greeted depended largely on its fidelity to the
label: Paragraph

text: original. Architecture was appreciated according to how well it reproduced English
label: Paragraph

text: models and had an important nostalgic function to re-create a New World version of Old
label: Paragraph

text: England. Local political and historical factors, the tyranny of distance (which delayed the
label: Paragraph

text: taking up of new styles), the unavailability of materials, and shortages of skilled
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmen forced innovation and together distanced Australian architecture from its
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic models, helping sound a false note of independence. Until recently, the measure
label: Paragraph

text: of architectural quality has been fidelity of interpretation, not idiosyncratic originality.
label: Paragraph

text: Mortimer Lewis (1796-1879), who arrived in Sydney in 1829, was typically
label: Paragraph

text: schizophrenic in his choice of style, moving fluently between classical and Gothic. An
label: Paragraph

text: adept at Gothic Revival, this did not prevent him from applying Greek Revival to the
label: Paragraph

text: courthouse at Darlinghurst, which was his finest essay. He supervised the military-Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: Government House (1845), de-
label: Caption

text: Rugby Field and Stands of Stadium Australia (1998), Homebush Bay, designed
label: Caption

text: for the 2000 Olympic Games
label: Title

text: © Australian Picture Library/CORBIS
label: Title

text: signed and unsuitably oriented to the northern hemisphere by Edward Blore in England.
label: Paragraph

text: It supplied a political symbol, an architectural climax, and a harbor focus for the city until
label: Paragraph

text: the Sydney Opera House (1973) replaced it.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1842, wild land speculation led to a collapse of the money market and brought ruin
label: Paragraph

text: to many people. Following a period of considerable prosperity and optimism, it hit the
label: Paragraph

text: pastoral economy hard and brought colonial building to a halt. In 1851, the discovery of
label: Paragraph

text: gold west of Sydney altered the complexion and mood of Australian architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: bringing with it a new expansionism.
label: Paragraph

text: In the decade after 1841, Sydney’s population jumped by 14,267 to 44,240. By 1901,
label: Paragraph

text: half a century later, it would be 481,830. Sydney expanded to the south and west as the
label: Paragraph

text: wealth of the gold fields flowed back to it. The early Victorian period started innocently
label: Paragraph

text: enough, incorporating Gothic for ecclesiastical work and schools and classical for public
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. Saint Andrew’s Anglican cathedral by Edmund Blacket was consecrated in
label: Caption

text: 1868, having been finished in stages. A vastly busy William Wardell commenced St.
label: Paragraph

text: Mary’s Cathedral beside Hyde Park in 1865. Commercial buildings set out to catch the
label: Paragraph

text: eye of customers by what might be called a potpourri style of fanciful frippery. By 1860,
label: Paragraph

text: terrace houses began to be built in large tracts spreading out from and surrounding the
label: Paragraph

text: city center.
label: Paragraph

text: The Victorian period was notable for the rise of ornament and the blurring of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural fashions. It was a period of grand public buildings. Sydney’s General Post
label: Paragraph

text: Office (1894) was commenced in 1864 by James Barnet, and Town Hall (1888) by J.H.
label: Paragraph

text: Wilson set an example for the richer banks and commercial buildings that were to follow.
label: Paragraph

text: The boom style of the 1880s, Italianate, which touched many residential buildings, had its
label: Paragraph

text: origin in the English fascination with Romantic traditions and the picturesque. The
label: Paragraph

text: application of Italianate style to commercial buildings led to the mass production of cast-
label: Paragraph

text: iron columns and beams, whereas domestic architecture acquired decorative trims, gabled
label: Paragraph

text: roofs, corner towers, and bull-nosed verandas. The florid phase of High Victorian design,
label: Paragraph

text: which reached its peak in the 1880s, ended with the 1893 depression, which was sparked
label: Paragraph

text: by a financial collapse three years earlier in Argentina.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1880s, four stories was the rule for ornate office buildings built with traditional
label: Paragraph

text: stone and brick exterior walls. The first Otis-type passenger lift was installed in the
label: Caption

text: Farmer’s Store (1881). The effect of lifts soon became evident, and by 1892 there were
label: Paragraph

text: several buildings reaching 10 to 12 stories. Some towers, such as the Lands Department
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1890) by James Barnet on Bent Street, rose well over 33 meters. Skyscraping
label: Caption

text: got off to a shaky start with Spain and Cosh’s Culwalla Chambers (1912), which rose to a
label: Paragraph

text: height of 52 meters and frightened the city into enacting a height limit of 46 meters, a
label: Paragraph

text: limit that survived until 1957.
label: Paragraph

text: The Australian domestic version of Queen Anne Revival consisting of terra-cotta
label: Paragraph

text: roofing tiles and exposed deep red bricks was called “Federation.” Substantial Federation
label: Paragraph

text: and Arts and Crafts residences were built in the northern harborside suburbs for the
label: Paragraph

text: upper-middle class in Mosman and Cremorne, whereas the lower-middle and working
label: Paragraph

text: classes were housed at Haberfield and Dacey Gardens Estate (Daceyville) west and south
label: Paragraph

text: of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: An outbreak of the bubonic plague caused by poor sanitation led to the reconstruction
label: Paragraph

text: of port facilities; new standardized wharf structures, such as the Walsh Bay finger wharfs
label: Paragraph

text: and Woolloomooloo Deep Sea Wharf; and a seawall barrier to prevent rats from coming
label: Paragraph

text: ashore during the first two decades of the century.
label: Paragraph

text: After winning the competition for Australia’s capital, Canberra, Walter Burley Griffin
label: Paragraph

text: (1876-1937), who had previously been Frank Lloyd Wright’s office manager in Chicago,
label: Paragraph

text: settled in Australia. He planned and established the suburb of Castlecrag, where he later
label: Paragraph

text: built a small cluster of seven houses. His ideas on integrating nature and architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: his reverence for the native flora produced a unique result.
label: Paragraph

text: Wyldefel Gardens (1936), by W.A.Crowl and John Brogon, and Prevost House (1937)
label: Caption

text: at Bellevue Hill, by Sydney Ancher (1904-78), signaled the arrival of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in Sydney. Wyldefel consisted of 20 terraced garden apartments on either
label: Paragraph

text: side of a cascading central garden and copied a housing scheme that existed outside
label: Paragraph

text: Oberammergau, Bavaria. The apartments had flat roofs, round corner glazing, steel
label: Caption

text: windows, and concrete frames. The nautical-style Prevost House was a compact version
label: Paragraph

text: of Mies van der Rohe’s Tugendhat House (1930) at Brno.
label: Caption

text: The former City Mutual Life Building (1936), an Art Deco design by Emil Sodersten,
label: Paragraph

text: was the first building in Sydney to be fully air-conditioned. It used a serrated zigzag
label: Paragraph

text: window treatment and was the most impressive and innovative building at the time. The
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s and 1930s were eras that saw the building of huge atmospheric cinemas with
label: Paragraph

text: streamlined interiors in the American style, an example of which is the New Orpheum
label: Paragraph

text: Theatre (1930) at Cremorne by G.N.Kenworthy.
label: Caption

text: The weakness that the British showed when challenged by Japanese expansionism in
label: Paragraph

text: the Pacific during World War Il and America’s role in avoiding defeat led to a
label: Paragraph

text: reconsideration of Australia’s defense relationship with London and a gradual weakening
label: Paragraph

text: of ties with the home country. After the war, a mass immigration program from Britain
label: Paragraph

text: and Europe changed the cultural face of Australia. By 1958, Sydney’s population had
label: Paragraph

text: doubled, from one million in 1926 to two million.
label: Paragraph

text: The period since World War II has been one of increasing international influence in
label: Paragraph

text: Australian architecture, with a shift away from Britain and a much greater awareness of
label: Paragraph

text: European, Japanese, and American influences. Sydney, situated in the southwest Pacific,
label: Paragraph

text: was well situated to take advantage of these shifts. Its hedonism and lack of well-
label: Paragraph

text: considered theory resulted in a superficial borrowing of ideas rather than a deeply
label: Paragraph

text: considered and well-assimilated style. In the 1950s, a split occurred between the
label: Paragraph

text: supporters of Frank Lloyd Wright’s Romantic organic interpretation, led by what became
label: Paragraph

text: known afterward as the “Sydney school,” a misnomer insofar as it referred to Oak Park,
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago, not Sydney. Arrayed against the neo-Wrightian camp were the proponents of
label: Paragraph

text: the European modern cause, with Gropius, Breuer, and Le Corbusier as its exemplars. As
label: Paragraph

text: a division, it hid a deeper split between those supporting an Australian national identity
label: Paragraph

text: and those wanting Sydney architecture to be more international. The arrival in 1948 on
label: Paragraph

text: the Sydney scene of the Viennese-born and Harvard-trained Harry Seidler (1923—) would
label: Paragraph

text: serve to heighten this division later. The neo-Wrightians in the opposing camp were
label: Paragraph

text: represented by Peter Muller (Audette House, Castlecrag, 1953; Whale Beach house,
label: Caption

text: 1954, for his family; and the ambitious “Kumale” residence at Palm Beach, 1956),
label: Paragraph

text: Neville Gruzman (Goodman House, 1956, and Holland House, 1962, both at Middle
label: Caption

text: Cove}, and Bruce Rickard’s “Mirrabooka” at Castle Hill (1964). All testify to the extent
label: Paragraph

text: of Wright’s influence at the time.
label: Paragraph

text: Seidler’s first work was the Rose Seidler House (1950) at Killara, built for his mother.
label: Paragraph

text: He had designed this house in New York for another client and later relocated it to
label: Paragraph

text: Killara. Its uncompromising modern character, flat roof, and open planning, as well as its
label: Paragraph

text: New England modern, Breuer-inspired detailing and contrast of smooth industrial steel
label: Paragraph

text: windows against rough mass sandstone walls, shocked Sydney residents and provoked
label: Paragraph

text: wide debate.
label: Paragraph

text: Australian architecture since 1945 has largely been about two architects: Harry Seidler
label: Paragraph

text: (1923-) and Glenn Murcutt (1936—). Both are Sydney architects, and both are committed
label: Paragraph

text: to modern architectural principles, yet they manage to exemplify the two quite different,
label: Paragraph

text: if not opposed, architectural currents: a place-based modernism versus a modernist
label: Paragraph

text: internationalism.
label: Paragraph

text: Seidler’s career spans 50 years and includes a large number of high-quality houses. In
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s, he designed the 183-meter-high Australia Square Tower (1967) with Nervi as
label: Paragraph

text: his structural consultant and the 65-story MLC Centre (1978). In the 1980s, Seidler
label: Paragraph

text: became increasingly engaged in office tower projects, resulting in a geometrically
label: Paragraph

text: disciplined series in Melbourne and Perth as well as Sydney’s Grovernor Place (1988)
label: Paragraph

text: and a radical departure from his customary freestanding approach, the Capita Centre
label: Paragraph

text: (1990), which, like the Ford Foundation Headquarters (1968) in New York, was based
label: Paragraph

text: around a garden atrium.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1956, Sydney held an international architectural competition for the design of a
label: Paragraph

text: performing arts center—a long-needed addition to its musical and theater cultural
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructure. Jorn Utzon, a Dane, won the competition in a field of 230 submissions for
label: Paragraph

text: a remarkable design that he set about developing from Hellebaek. After three years of
label: Paragraph

text: intense investigation by his structural consultant, Ove Arup and Partners, for the dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: shell roofs, Utzon proposed a spherical geometry to suit prefabrication of the elements. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1966, Utzon withdrew from the project and was replaced by a Sydney consortium led by
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Hall that completed the project for its opening in October 1973.
label: Paragraph

text: Utzon employed Australian assistants; of these, Richard Le Plastrier (1939—) has been
label: Paragraph

text: the most faithful follower in terms of an anonymous landscape-based, organic domestic
label: Paragraph

text: idiom. The principal legacy of Utzon was the contribution of his Opera House to the city
label: Paragraph

text: itself and recognition that as a sculpture it completed and gave the city a climax that
label: Paragraph

text: oriented it toward the harbor. Utzon’s personal influence, which was small, survives
label: Paragraph

text: through a few of his young Australian assistants, including Richard Le Plastrier. The
label: Paragraph

text: Sydney Opera House remains unchallenged as Australia’s greatest work of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and as an international synonym for the city.
label: Paragraph

text: Glenn Murcutt’s career began with the Marie Short farmhouse (1975) near Kempsey,
label: Paragraph

text: and although much of his work has been done in Sydney, his best houses are reserved for
label: Paragraph

text: its fringes or beyond. This has given him an undeserved reputation as a rural designer. In
label: Paragraph

text: Sydney, his Carpenter house, Point Piper (1982); Stuart Littlemore house, Woollahra
label: Caption

text: (1986); Tom Magney house, Paddington (1990); and Ken Done House, Mosman (1991)
label: Caption

text: testify to his ability to deal with tight city sites and to inject a degree of lyricism and
label: Paragraph

text: environmental common sense into the urban context.
label: Paragraph

text: Compared to Seidler, who ignored local factors in his identification with an
label: Paragraph

text: international modern tradition inspired by Gropius, Breuer, and Le Corbusier, Murcutt’s
label: Paragraph

text: veranda-inspired spaces and celebration of vernacular verities, such as corrugated iron,
label: Paragraph

text: glass louvres, and standard ridge ventilators, together with
label: Paragraph

text: landscape, were widely perceived as distinctively Australian.
label: Paragraph

text: Besides giving an enormous stimulus to the Homebush Bay
label: Paragraph

text: his poetic response to
label: Paragraph

text: site west of the central
label: Caption

text: business district, the 2000 Olympic Games boosted architectural activity in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: hotels, rail, airport, and road transport. Barcelona was adopted as
label: Paragraph

text: way in which the Olympics could be used to upgrade the city
label: Paragraph

text: $300 million in new pedestrian squares, a Barcelona-derived
label: Paragraph

text: Central Station (1999), and the Cook and Phillip Park swimming
label: Paragraph

text: south of St. Mary’s Cathedral. Sculpture walks, new smart lighting, granite paving, and
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The 110,000-seat Stadium Australia (1998) is typical of the new Olympic venues: it
label: Paragraph

text: impresses more by its size, engineering, and straightforward planning than by any
label: Paragraph

text: imaginative qualities. Only the main Olympic Park railway station (1998) by Hassel Pty
label: Caption

text: Ltd and the Archery 2000 building (1999) by Stutchbury and Pape rise much above the
label: Paragraph

text: mundane.
label: Paragraph

text: Clearly, Sydney is struggling to deal with its size and its uncontrolled expansion to the
label: Paragraph

text: west and north. The investment in facilities at its center is matched by the poor air
label: Paragraph

text: quality, road congestion, and underfunding of public transport at its fringes.

text: SYDNEY OPERA HOUSE
label: Title

text: Designed by Jorn Utzon; completed 1973 Sydney, Australia
label: Caption

text: The force behind the Sydney Opera House was Eugene Goossens, who was appointed
label: Paragraph

text: conductor of the Sydney Symphony Orchestra in 1946 and a year later started an “opera
label: Paragraph

text: house” movement. He was supported by the Labor politician Joseph Cahill (1891-1959),
label: Paragraph

text: who held the local government portfolio and subsequently became premier of New South
label: Paragraph

text: Wales in 1952.
label: Paragraph

text: The project languished until November 1954, when Cahill sponsored a conference that
label: Paragraph

text: led to the establishment of a public committee that later agreed to hold an international
label: Paragraph

text: architectural competition in 1956 for which Jorn Utzon’s design was awarded first prize
label: Paragraph

text: in a field of 230 entries. Utzon’s scheme was enthusiastically endorsed by a jury
label: Paragraph

text: comprising Sir Leslie Martin and Eero Saarinen.
label: Paragraph

text: Conceived in the mid-1950s, the Sydney Opera House project brief was formulated as
label: Paragraph

text: a performing arts center with facilities for opera, concerts, and theater under one roof.
label: Paragraph

text: The enterprise was fraught with party politics from the outset. It was seen as a project of
label: Paragraph

text: a Labor Party premier who sought to enlarge access to music and theater for all the
label: Paragraph

text: citizens of Sydney during a period of acute postwar shortages. Popular opposition arose
label: Paragraph

text: even within his own party, and Cahill cleverly circumvented these arguments by
label: Paragraph

text: establishing an Opera House Lottery to pay for the building.
label: Paragraph

text: The Opera House supplied Sydney with a much-needed civic climax that recognized
label: Paragraph

text: the concentrating visual effect of its magnificent harbor and that, in the process,
label: Paragraph

text: cemented its identity. Today, it is an international architectural icon and is regarded by
label: Paragraph

text: many people as one of the ten greatest architectural works of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1956, when Utzon made his design, there was great interest in shell structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Vilhelm Lauritzen had built two remarkable shells in Copenhagen before this: the first
label: Paragraph

text: airport terminal in Kastrup (1939) and the Radio Building’s Studio 1 (1945). Utzon’s
label: Paragraph

text: Sydney design resembled these in its adoption of an inner acoustic shell suspended from
label: Paragraph

text: a heavier outer shell. Felix Candela in Mexico and Eero Saarinen in the United States, in
label: Paragraph

text: his TWA Terminal (1962), which was designed the same year with a paired arrangement
label: Paragraph

text: of balanced flower-petal shells, are other examples.
label: Paragraph

text: Both Saarinen and Utzon chose “free” structural forms that lacked circular,
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular, or parabolic geometries. Although the TWA Terminal kept its free form,
label: Paragraph

text: Utzon was criticized for his design’s lack of geometry, which was essential to standardize
label: Paragraph

text: the formwork. When, after three years of intense research, Ove Arup and Partners failed
label: Paragraph

text: to establish a satisfactory mathematical description of the shell shapes after applying
label: Paragraph

text: parabolic and then elliptical systems, Utzon broke the impasse in mid-1960 by proposing
label: Paragraph

text: a spherical geometry.
label: Paragraph

text: In May 1965, there was a change of government. The incoming minister for public
label: Paragraph

text: works placed himself in charge of the Opera House project, withheld permission for
label: Paragraph

text: Utzon to proceed with his scheme to use plywood for the interior acoustic shells and
label: Paragraph

text: glass wall mullions, and delayed fee payments. In February 1966, Utzon withdrew and
label: Paragraph

text: was replaced by an Australian team led by Peter Hall, who completed the third stage for
label: Paragraph

text: the interiors in October 1973. Hall attempted to realize the work as Utzon intended, but a
label: Paragraph

text: Review of Programme submitted in December 1966 recommended that the Major Hall
label: Paragraph

text: should be a single-purpose hall and that the opera should be transferred to the Minor Hall,
label: Paragraph

text: thereby eliminating the latter’s use as a theater on the grounds that the multipurpose hall
label: Paragraph

text: would not be functionally satisfactory. The acceptance of this flawed advice resulted in
label: Paragraph

text: the elimination of grand opera and invalidated the composition of the roofs, whose size
label: Paragraph

text: had been determined by the volumetric requirements of the interior functions; the
label: Paragraph

text: demolition of the stage tower and the stage machinery from the Main Hall permanently
label: Caption

text: crippled the Opera House. Its cost rose from $50 million to $102 million, and the
label: Paragraph

text: building’s completion was delayed four years.
label: Paragraph

text: The changes to the interiors were attended by a severe aesthetic loss when Peter Hall
label: Paragraph

text: failed to continue in the same spirit as Utzon. Fortunately, the outside was largely
label: Paragraph

text: unaffected, and the fame of the Opera House today rests largely on the brilliance of the
label: Paragraph

text: building’s external relationship to its maritime surroundings.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier completed his chapel at Ronchamp in June 1955. It is no accident that the
label: Paragraph

text: Ronchamp chapel and Utzon’s Opera House are formidable sculptural achievements: Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier reacted to the four horizons and its isolated situation atop a sacred acropolis;
label: Paragraph

text: Utzon’s approach was similar: he visualized a promenade from the city to the Opera
label: Paragraph

text: House leading to its theaters and heightened its isolation further by pushing it to the end
label: Paragraph

text: of Bennelong Point to increase the surprise of arrival. Like Le Corbusier, who similarly
label: Paragraph

text: applied the idea of a “Promenade Architecturale” to Ronchamp, Utzon incorporated a
label: Paragraph

text: promenade into his architecture to enhance the pedestrian experience and increase the
label: Paragraph

text: interaction between his building and the site and its surroundings.
label: Paragraph

text: Utzon’s great concern was to devise the most dramatic route to approach his work by
label: Paragraph

text: entering it from below and moving upward through its interior spaces to reach the opera
label: Paragraph

text: and concert and theater halls. The building juts out into the harbor on a platform that he
label: Paragraph

text: shaped and extended vertically and that contains all the performance services. At its
label: Paragraph

text: highest, he scooped out a pair of Greek amphitheaters, treating the platform as an
label: Paragraph

text: artificial hill. With the two stages adjoining the south foyers, the two principal halls,
label: Paragraph

text: placed lengthwise side by side, have dual foyers
label: Caption

text: Sydney Opera House (1973)
label: Caption

text: © GreatBuildings.com
label: Title

text: at their north and south ends but are entered along the sides. To reach the halls, patrons
label: Paragraph

text: climb a monumental external flight of stairs at the front or use an internal staircase to
label: Paragraph

text: reach the southern foyers and then move around the stage backs and up the platform to
label: Paragraph

text: access the halls. The north foyers, used at intervals, face the water. The side spaces are
label: Paragraph

text: pressed between the auditoriums and the V-shaped ribs of the precast-concrete roof
label: Paragraph

text: vaults.
label: Paragraph

text: The glory of the Opera House is its white-tiled roofs surmounting the pink precast-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete platform. The Main Hall is straddled by three asymmetrical vaults and the Minor
label: Caption

text: Hall by similar smaller vaults, and a separate vault encloses the restaurant on the
label: Paragraph

text: southwest edge of the platform. Between the two main vault groups, a narrow canyonlike
label: Caption

text: cleavage is formed; below this, a tunnel street gives access to the main under-stage
label: Paragraph

text: service areas. The open ends of the original shells were intended to be enclosed by gull-
label: Paragraph

text: wing saddles of suspended glass between hollow plywood tubes, but Utzon’s proposal
label: Paragraph

text: was crudely simplified into stiff glass hoods supported on steel trusses.
label: Paragraph

text: The sculptural expressiveness and romantic immersion in the harbor setting went
label: Paragraph

text: beyond and challenged the prevailing functional ethic of modern architecture in 1957. Its
label: Paragraph

text: assertion of humanist values rooted in Gunnar Asplund and Alvar Aalto proclaimed a
label: Paragraph

text: new experiential sensibility that sought to soften the image of a machine aesthetic by an
label: Paragraph

text: appeal to the simple verities of an anonymous vernacular building. The freshness of the
label: Paragraph

text: Opera House has not dimmed with time; it seems as ageless as the Australian bush. Utzon
label: Paragraph

text: was inspired by an anonymous language of technique, the building creating its own style
label: Paragraph

text: from the perfection of its means in the same way that a yacht achieves beauty through the
label: Paragraph

text: refinement and ultimate perfection of its shape in meeting the challenge of the sea and
label: Paragraph

text: wind.
label: Paragraph

text: In tying his Opera House so perfectly to its peninsula, Utzon created for Sydney a
label: Paragraph

text: symbol and identity of such extraordinary power that it is impossible to conceive of the
label: Paragraph

text: city as complete without it.
label: Paragraph

text: Further Reading
label: Title

text: Utzon’s resistance to scholarly research and documentation and his reticence to cooperate
label: Paragraph

text: with critical assessment have created severe problems for the serious historian, with the
label: Paragraph

text: unfortunate consequence that there is a proliferation of errors resulting from an
label: Paragraph

text: overreliance on secondary source material. There has been far more publication and
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation than research into establishing reliable facts. The Fromonot account, for
label: Paragraph

text: instance, is largely a compilation of material copied from Zodiac numbers 5, 10, and 14,
label: Paragraph

text: with additions. Because these issues are rare, their republication in this way is
label: Paragraph

text: undoubtedly useful. Utzon scholarship remains at an early stage.

text: SYMBOLISM
label: Title

text: If architecture is as a system of cultural symbols expressing the identity, technology, and
label: Paragraph

text: condition of a society—or of one group within a particular class or location—at a specific
label: Paragraph

text: point in time, then the symbolism attributed to individual buildings constitutes one way
label: Paragraph

text: of interpreting cultural context and the built environment. Form, ornamentation, and the
label: Paragraph

text: choice of materials are all critical elements articulating symbolic content in architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Symbolism was especially crucial for architecture in the Western world during the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century, reflecting the tremendous meaningful changes occurring in everyday life, in
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual and political values, and in society. Because these changes were both synchronic
label: Paragraph

text: and diachronic, different styles of architecture were produced and promoted
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously by professionally trained architects as well as amateur builders.
label: Paragraph

text: Sometimes this diversity recorded differences in economics, application, and intention,
label: Paragraph

text: but in other instances stylistic distinctions reflected profound oppositions in thinking. For
label: Paragraph

text: example, at the beginning of the century, Beaux-Arts-trained architects produced both
label: Paragraph

text: Neoclassical and Arts and Crafts-inspired buildings. The structures following in the
label: Paragraph

text: classical tradition indicated a desire for monumentality, formality, and the continuance of
label: Paragraph

text: traditional values, societal hierarchies, and building typologies, whereas the Arts and
label: Paragraph

text: Crafts-inspired buildings used local materials, changes in building form and plan, and
label: Paragraph

text: motifs selected from medieval vernacular architecture to represent ideals of home,
label: Paragraph

text: handicraft, and the simplicity of a preindustrialized world in reaction to the political,
label: Paragraph

text: economic, and social turbulence of the time.
label: Paragraph

text: The beginning of the 20th century is also notable for the work of other architects who
label: Paragraph

text: experimented with form, materials, and ornament to create a new style of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: expressive of the Zeitgeist. Art Nouveau was one new aesthetic resulting from this
label: Paragraph

text: exploration exemplified in the organic designs of Victor Horta, Hector Guimard, and
label: Paragraph

text: Henry van de Velde. These Euro pean architects and designers sought inspiration in
label: Paragraph

text: nature in the same way that their contemporaries, such as Josef Hoffman, Charles Rennie
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh, and Antonio Gaudi, looked to local building traditions for inspiration.
label: Paragraph

text: Another new aesthetic celebrated the materials and capabilities of industry. The
label: Paragraph

text: exposedaluminum rivets in Otto Wagner’s Post Office Savings Bank (1904-06) in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna and Peter Behrens’ steel stanchions in the AEG factory (1908-09) in Berlin are
label: Paragraph

text: early examples of architects using building components to express innovations in
label: Paragraph

text: building construction and the wider promise and potential of the machine.
label: Paragraph

text: By the 1930s, the machine aesthetic evolved into what came to be called International
label: Paragraph

text: Style architecture by Henry-Russell Hitchcock and Philip Johnson in the catalogue
label: Caption

text: accompanying the 1932 Museum of Moder Art (New York) exhibition. The machine
label: Caption

text: aesthetic was utopian at its core and aimed at improving the lives of the working classes
label: Paragraph

text: through the introduction of affordable, utilitarian, machine-produced goods and economic
label: Paragraph

text: construction. Conventional applied ornamentation, considered a demonstration of the
label: Paragraph

text: class systems and social ambitions that led to World War |, was rejected as historical and
label: Paragraph

text: emblematic of an outmoded way of life. In its place, designers substituted factory-sash
label: Paragraph

text: and ship railings to symbolize their belief in the propensity of new industrialized societies
label: Paragraph

text: to house populaces in clean, safe, and healthy environments and to address problems
label: Paragraph

text: scientifically, efficiently, and unemotionally. Consequently, the dramatic change in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and aesthetics inherent in the International Style signified a new highly
label: Paragraph

text: disciplined, standardized, and organized life that, in the extreme, eliminated individual
label: Paragraph

text: character and emotion and in all phases celebrated the belief that the new architecture
label: Paragraph

text: appropriately demonstrated the rational thinking and technical capabilities characteristic
label: Paragraph

text: of the period.
label: Paragraph

text: The machine age was also celebrated in the stylized motifs and exotic materials of Art
label: Paragraph

text: Deco, in the contours and materials of Streamline Moderne, and even in the pared-down
label: Paragraph

text: simplicity and machine-produced aesthetic of Beaux-Arts-trained architects such as
label: Paragraph

text: Bertram Goodhue and Paul Cret. The acceptance of the International Style in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States in the 1930s and after World War II lacked the social purpose and initiative of
label: Paragraph

text: European modernism and instead became adopted by corporate clients as a symbol of
label: Paragraph

text: progressive business practices and financial success. This thinking, coupled with the
label: Paragraph

text: prosperity and pride following World War IL, prompted the transformation of regionally
label: Paragraph

text: expressive, human-scaled American cities to concentrations of curtain-walled skyscrapers
label: Paragraph

text: placed within recently leveled downtowns in the process of implementing the radical
label: Paragraph

text: urbanplanning ideas of Le Corbusier.
label: Paragraph

text: By midcentury, the disruption and destruction of the traditional fabric and the
label: Paragraph

text: proliferation of high-rises, symbolizing the regularized working and living environments
label: Paragraph

text: of their inhabitants, failed to produce a vital, rich environment with positive social
label: Paragraph

text: solutions. In response, architects, including Eero Saarinen, Louis Kahn, and even Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier (Notre-Dame-du-Haut, Ronchamp, France, 1950-54), introduced dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: forms in concrete and other materials to create expressive, sculptural, and monumental
label: Paragraph

text: forms, or architecture as art rather than architecture as social program. This reaction was
label: Paragraph

text: compounded in 1966 with the publication of Robert Venturi’s book, Complexity and
label: Paragraph

text: Contradiction., which condemned the banality and reductivism of
label: Paragraph

text: Post Office Savings Bank, Vienna, interior detail of doorway (1906)
label: Caption

text: © Howard Davis/GreatBuildings.com
label: Caption

text: modernism and advocated the reintroduction of communicative symbols to produce a
label: Paragraph

text: richer architecture of multiple meanings, articulations, and intentions. Charles Jencks
label: Caption

text: labeled Venturi’s ideas and recommended style as “Postmodern,” legitimizing a return to
label: Paragraph

text: the incorporation of conventional architectural elements, to stylistic references, and to a
label: Paragraph

text: renewed respect for historical urban context and specific places.
label: Paragraph

text: The expansion of architectural ideas and vocabularies in Postmodernism spurred a new
label: Paragraph

text: pluralism in architecture, reflecting the compound nature and diversification of
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary conditions and thinking and the perception of architecture as both a
label: Paragraph

text: cultural product and a cultural symbol. This pluralistic attitude rejects the belief in
label: Paragraph

text: universal narratives and global solutions and shifts the focus of the designer from the
label: Paragraph

text: generic to the specific, realized in a conscious attempt to understand the nature of each
label: Paragraph

text: task and to respond to the needs, problems, and circumstances of the particular client and
label: Paragraph

text: location.
label: Paragraph

text: Some of the forms produced within this environment are outgrowths of modernism,
label: Paragraph

text: seen in the work of High-Tech architects such as Richard Rogers and Norman Foster,
label: Paragraph

text: who continue to venerate structural and technological innovation, and in the motifs and
label: Paragraph

text: early modern aesthetic prominent in the work of Richard Meier. Another outgrowth of
label: Paragraph

text: modernism is the abstraction and simplicity inherent in the International Style brought to
label: Paragraph

text: a level of elegance and sublimity in the late 20th-century designs of Tadao Ando,
label: Paragraph

text: Antoine Predock, and the late Luis Barragan. The most symbolic architecture at the end
label: Paragraph

text: of the century, however, derives from the fields of philosophy and semiology.
label: Paragraph

text: Deconstructivism and poststructuralism often use elements from 1920s Constructivism
label: Paragraph

text: twisted and contorted to signify the end of meaning (absolute knowledge) and the
label: Paragraph

text: realization of a world pushing technology beyond the limits of human comprehension and
label: Paragraph

text: control. The fractured, distorted, and dynamic forms suggesting confusion and instability
label: Paragraph

text: produced by Bernard Tschumi, Peter Eisenman, Coop Himmelb(Iau, and others
label: Caption

text: represent linguistic, archeological, and deconstructive concepts from the philosophy of
label: Paragraph

text: Jacques Derrida and Michel Foucault. Other architects, however, present a totally
label: Paragraph

text: different worldview and aesthetic, demonstrated in works associated with Neoclassicism,
label: Paragraph

text: New Expressionism, and an appreciation of vernacular constructions. Although this wide-
label: Paragraph

text: ranging inclusiveness might suggest indeterminate architectural chaos, the variety of
label: Paragraph

text: buildings produced can be understood as symbols of the divergent values and theories of
label: Paragraph

text: their creators as well as significations of the complexity, multiculturalism, and diversity
label: Paragraph

text: of contemporary culture.
label: Paragraph

text: SYNAGOGUE
label: Title

text: At the tum of the 20th century, the spirit of integration lay behind much of new
label: Paragraph

text: synagogue construction in Europe and America. Some examples of the distinctive
label: Paragraph

text: Moorish-style building continued to be erected, such as the Jerusalem Street Synagogue
label: Paragraph

text: in Prague (Wilhelm Stiassny and Alois Richter, 1906). Other historic styles such as
label: Paragraph

text: Romanesque and Gothic (Szeged, Hungary, 1900-03) continued late 19th-century
label: Paragraph

text: traditions. A few distinctive synagogue designs broke with tradition such as Hector
label: Paragraph

text: Guimard’s striking Art Nouveau Rue Pavée Synagogue in Paris (1911-13), or adapted
label: Paragraph

text: new traditions, such as the synagogue in Subotica, Yugoslavia (Komor and Jakab, 1901),
label: Paragraph

text: combining Balkan, Hungarian, and Jewish folk and architectural traditions.
label: Paragraph

text: A strong trend toward classicism, however, especially in America, resulted in the
label: Paragraph

text: notable Congregation Beth El, Detroit (Albert Kahn, 1903), Beth Ahabah, Richmond
label: Caption

text: (Noland and Baskerville, 1904) Mikveh Israel, Philadelphia (William Tachau and Lewis
label: Caption

text: Pilcher, 1909), Temple Society of Concord, Syracuse (Arnold Brunner, 1910), and scores
label: Caption

text: of similar buildings. Brunner’s designs for Syracuse and the Henry §.Frank Memorial
label: Paragraph

text: Synagogue in Philadelphia (1901) were the first synagogues built to directly refer to
label: Paragraph

text: archaeological finds of ancient synagogues in Palestine.
label: Paragraph

text: This form of classical Revivalism, which in most cases resulted in synagogues hardly
label: Paragraph

text: distinguishable from banks, libraries, and government and university buildings evolved
label: Paragraph

text: into the more distinctive Byzantine-Revival style, particularly popular after World War I.
label: Paragraph

text: Here, following the earlier lead of Brunner, patrons and architects justified their designs
label: Paragraph

text: by likening them to new archaeological finds from Palestine, but they also reinvented the
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive exoticism that had characterized the Jewish Moorish style begun by Gottfried
label: Paragraph

text: Semper at Dresden (1838-40) and continued so effectively for more than half a century.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike the Moorish style, however, the new Byzantine design emphasized plan and
label: Paragraph

text: massing over decoration. Free standing buildings were often ingeniously sited in new
label: Paragraph

text: urban parklike settings, and they often featured open plans that linked main sanctuaries to
label: Paragraph

text: auxiliary administrative, educational, and social spaces—an innovation already hinted at
label: Paragraph

text: in Kahn’s Classical Beth El of 1903 and that would be more fully developed in the new
label: Paragraph

text: suburban synagogues and community centers built after World War IL. The central dome
label: Caption

text: over the sanctuary space became especially common—it was given many meanings: the
label: Paragraph

text: cosmos, community, and tradition. A frequent urban variation of this style—especially
label: Paragraph

text: where synagogues still occupied traditional urban sites, emphasized a single giant facade
label: Paragraph

text: portal, as at B’nai Jeshurun, New York (Schneider and Herts, 1918) and Temple Emanu-
label: Paragraph

text: El, New York (Kahn Butler and Stein, 1930). Emanu-El’s interior, with its enormous
label: Paragraph

text: rows of arches, recalls contemporary modern architecture in Italy in its austerity and
label: Paragraph

text: gigantism.
label: Paragraph

text: In Europe, similar simpler architectural forms prevalent in the nascent modern
label: Paragraph

text: movement were easily adapted for syn agogue design. The synagogue of Zilina, Slovakia
label: Paragraph

text: (Peter Behrens, 1928-30) was, in many ways, a stripped-down version of the Byzantine
label: Paragraph

text: domed synagogue popular in Hungary and the Balkans. Behrens’s design set a half dome
label: Paragraph

text: on a rectangular block. Within, the dome rises on slender concrete piers from a square set
label: Paragraph

text: within the rectangular mass. Outside, the ground floor is faced in stone, and the rest of
label: Paragraph

text: the structure is of reinforced concrete. Despite the use of concrete, the building looks
label: Paragraph

text: traditional due to its massing and the monumental stairway that leads to the main
label: Paragraph

text: entrance. Nothing about the building’s architecture identifies it as a synagogue. Applied
label: Paragraph

text: Stars of David set on each exterior corner served this purpose. Like Zelina, the
label: Paragraph

text: monumental Great Synagogue in Tel Aviv, Israel (c. 1930) combined traditional elements
label: Paragraph

text: such as arched windows and a large central dome with the plain smooth wall surfaces and
label: Paragraph

text: combined massing of blocklike forms typical in early European modernism. The
label: Paragraph

text: Yeshurun Synagogue in Jerusalem (Friedmann, Rubin, and Stolzer, 1934-5) eschewed
label: Paragraph

text: the complex hierarchical arrangement of multiple forms for a simple joining of two main
label: Paragraph

text: masses—a rectangular block, entered on its long side, with a tall half cylinder housing the
label: Paragraph

text: sanctuary joined to the rear.
label: Paragraph

text: There had been previous experiments with modernism in synagogue design before the
label: Paragraph

text: war. In Amsterdam, Jewish architect Harry Elte built the Jacob Obrechtplein Synagogue
label: Paragraph

text: in a Dutch-Cubist style in 1927-28. The building recalls early designs by Frank Lloyd
label: Paragraph

text: Wright, especially the Unity Temple near Chicago. Perhaps the most radical and most
label: Paragraph

text: modern synagogue design of the interwar years was that of Plauen, Germany. The
label: Paragraph

text: synagogue was conceived as a white box elevated on stilts at one end. The arrangement
label: Paragraph

text: of windows differentiates the discreet functions of the building, much as was done in
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary industrial buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Also in Amsterdam, the Lekstraat Synagogue (A.Elzas, 1936-37) is a plain stone box
label: Paragraph

text: with simple square windows that emphasizes only the Ark and Bimah. Elzas won a
label: Paragraph

text: competition among nine Jewish architects for the commission, which even today ranks as
label: Paragraph

text: one of the sparest architect designed synagogues. The simplicity of the building’s
label: Paragraph

text: geometry and white concrete walls is offset slightly by the use of stone on the exterior
label: Paragraph

text: and the introduction of vast amounts of natural light through large windows. Elsewhere,
label: Paragraph

text: Sir E(van} Owen Williams designed the modern Dollis Hill Synagogue in London with a
label: Paragraph

text: very open interior with galleries cantilevered from the wall rather than supported by piers
label: Caption

text: of columns. The walls and roof are made of specially designed corrugated concrete that
label: Paragraph

text: strengthens the structure. Hexagonal and shield-shaped windows recall the Star of David,
label: Paragraph

text: now an accepted Jewish motif.
label: Paragraph

text: American and Canadian Jews had begun an exodus from the urban tenement
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods in the years following World War | leading to new Jewish neighborhoods
label: Title

text: on city fringes. Large “synagogue-centers” developed to serve the religious and
label: Paragraph

text: recreational needs of thousands of congregants. These large freestanding monumental
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in the classical or Byzantine style stood as civic monuments. Immediately after
label: Paragraph

text: World War II, however, demand for suburban synagogues created a boom of Modern-
label: Paragraph

text: style community centers, which gave special attention to school facilities.
label: Paragraph

text: Modern architecture was preferred as an expression of this new Judaism—for historic,
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic, and financial reasons. Prewar trends in synagogue architecture made Jewish
label: Paragraph

text: communities
label: Title

text: Kehilath Anshe Ma’ariv Synagogue, Cook County, Chicago, IL, designed by
label: Caption

text: Adler and Sullivan
label: Title

text: © Historic American Buildings Survey/Library of Congress
label: Caption

text: receptive to modernism. Byzantine Revival and the Art Deco synagogues were primarily
label: Paragraph

text: studies in spatial geometry that often emphasized qualities of the building material (most
label: Paragraph

text: often brick and tile) and limited decoration to flat surface ornament. They emphasized
label: Paragraph

text: variants on the cube and sphere and utilized natural light as much as possible. They also
label: Paragraph

text: addressed the modern concerns of adjustable space and incorporation of multiple
label: Paragraph

text: functions—including social halls, kitchens, gymnasia, swimming pools, libraries,
label: Paragraph

text: schools, and offices—within a single complex structure.
label: Paragraph

text: The full expansion of the sanctuary and multiple-use of spaces was fully developed by
label: Paragraph

text: Erich Mendelsohn, who developed important concepts for modern synagogue design,
label: Paragraph

text: including the accentuation of the sanctuary section of a large complex using elevated and
label: Paragraph

text: curvilinear forms and the creation of adaptable spaces, connectable by sliding partitions
label: Paragraph

text: to serve diverse functions at different times of the day or year. At B’nai Amoona (St.
label: Paragraph

text: Louis, 1950} a dramatic parabolic roof rises from the ark wall to the entrance wall, the
label: Paragraph

text: top of which is glazed, allowing light to pour in over the congregation and onto the bimah
label: Paragraph

text: and ark. At the Park Synagogue in Cleveland, Mendelsohn designed the sanctuary as a
label: Paragraph

text: hemispheric dome that rose straight from the ground. B’nai Amoona also included
label: Paragraph

text: adaptable spaces in a larger plan in which the sanctuary and spillover space were
label: Paragraph

text: balanced by a classroom wing across a small open court. Connecting the two sections
label: Paragraph

text: were a range of offices.
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn’s designs were quickly understood by Percival Goodman and formed the
label: Paragraph

text: basis of most suburban synagogue architecture from the late 1940s through the 1980s.
label: Paragraph

text: Goodman built over 50 synagogues in his lifetime. Although most lack the excitement
label: Paragraph

text: and drama of Mendelsohn’s plans, Goodman incorporated modern sculpture to
label: Paragraph

text: accentuate certain elements, rather than sculpting space.
label: Paragraph

text: Influenced by Mendelsohn and Goodman, and continuing with Frank Lloyd Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: Beth Shalom Synagogue (Elkins Park, 1959), congregations and architects replaced ties
label: Paragraph

text: to history through the manipulation of form for symbolic association—often favoring
label: Paragraph

text: building profiles recalling mountains or tents. Frank Lloyd Wright expressed his intent
label: Paragraph

text: for the interior of Beth Sholom: “We want to create the kind of building that people, on
label: Paragraph

text: entering it, will feel as if they were resting in the very hands of God.” At Congregation
label: Paragraph

text: Israel in Glencoe, Illinois (Minoru Yamasaki, 1964), a series of large concrete arches
label: Paragraph

text: frame the building, but large gaps in the structure fill the sanctuary with filtered light.
label: Paragraph

text: The interior is spacious, and the use of light, white walls and little ornamentation create a
label: Paragraph

text: cerebral space. The tall thin gilded ark has been likened to a prayer shawl wrapping the
label: Paragraph

text: Torah scrolls, but from the sanctuary entrance it also suggests a single flame—a burning
label: Paragraph

text: bush or eternal light.
label: Paragraph

text: In postwar Europe, of note is the Ruhrallee Synagogue at Essen, Germany (Dieter
label: Paragraph

text: Knoblauch and Heinz Heise, 1959). Like Mendelsohn’s Cleveland synagogue, the
label: Paragraph

text: primary element in Essen is a hemisphere that rises directly from the ground—there is no
label: Paragraph

text: visible substructure. The simple unified shape may symbolize the monotheism of
label: Paragraph

text: Judaism, but it also reflects current trends in architecture—which included a search for
label: Paragraph

text: pure geometric forms. Inside, the half-dome includes more simple shapes. The ark is a
label: Paragraph

text: rectangle inscribed within a broad triangle, set into the shell of the hemispheric dome. At
label: Paragraph

text: the apex of the dome, a Star of David is inscribed, articulated with a series of small round
label: Paragraph

text: windows that define the shape with light.
label: Paragraph

text: The most dramatic postwar European synagogue is in Livorno, Italy (1962), which
label: Paragraph

text: replaced the famous but totally destroyed Renaissance synagogue. On the outside, the
label: Paragraph

text: new expressive structure is defined by a series of crooked concrete buttresses, which are
label: Paragraph

text: connected by concrete walls, appearing to exert intense pressure to keep the building
label: Paragraph

text: together. This wall allows a large unimpeded interior sanctuary; like the Renaissance
label: Paragraph

text: predecessor, this synagogue has ranges of seats all around.
label: Paragraph

text: In Israel, similar expressive tendencies are found. The synagogue in Beersheba (1961)
label: Paragraph

text: nestles under a sweeping concrete vault that covers the sanctuary like a turtle shell. The
label: Paragraph

text: vault is anchored in the ground to either side of the small prayer hall, which is lit by a
label: Paragraph

text: wall perforated from floor to ceiling by hexagonal openings. Unlike Beersheba, which is
label: Paragraph

text: so rooted to the earth, the Israel Goldstein Synagogue on the Givat Ram campus of the
label: Paragraph

text: Hebrew University (Heinz Rau and David Reznik, 1957) appears to float. The
label: Paragraph

text: windowless synagogue looks something like a giant balloon; its smooth white bulbous
label: Paragraph

text: form seems to levitate off the ground, at which level it is pierced with wide arched
label: Paragraph

text: openings that light the entire structure, including the sanctuary, which is encased in the
label: Paragraph

text: building’s upper part. Perhaps the most inventive of modern synagogues is the one at the
label: Paragraph

text: army officer training school, Mitzpeh Ramon (Zvi Hecker, 1969), set in dreary desert
label: Paragraph

text: surroundings. The exterior of the small sanctuary is concrete faceted like crystal creating
label: Paragraph

text: a complex arrangement of colored shapes and patterns.
label: Paragraph

text: More recently, the Great Synagogue in Jerusalem (1982) continues the modernist
label: Paragraph

text: vocabulary of the 1930s, albeit somewhat updated. The main sanctuary is hexagonal,
label: Paragraph

text: recalling the shape of the Star of David. Unlike most Israeli synagogues, it incorporates
label: Paragraph

text: some stained glass decoration in five tall, narrow windows over the ark. Common with
label: Paragraph

text: the Jerusalem synagogue of 1934 and so many other buildings in the city, the Great
label: Paragraph

text: Synagogue is built of local yellow limestone. For various reasons—tradition, climate,
label: Paragraph

text: light, and security—Israeli synagogues tend to be built of stone or concrete and look
label: Paragraph

text: massive, whatever their size. A synagogue at Hadera built in 1935 included a watchtower
label: Paragraph

text: and courtyard to shelter up to 2,000 people in case of an attack. Although Israeli
label: Paragraph

text: architects have sensibly not adopted the skin of glass, favored by many synagogue
label: Paragraph

text: architects in America in the 1960s and 1970s, they have instead experimented with
label: Paragraph

text: concrete to create sculptural forms.
label: Paragraph

text: An exception to abstract expressive and symbolic forms are the many buildings that
label: Paragraph

text: refer in plan, elevation, detail, or material to the wooden synagogues of Poland, made
label: Paragraph

text: known in publications since the 1950s. For example, Congregation Sons of Israel in
label: Paragraph

text: Lakewood, New Jersey (Davis, Brody and Wisniewski, 1963) recalls Polish plan types
label: Paragraph

text: and building profiles. Louis Kahn mixed pure geometric shapes and volumes at Temple
label: Caption

text: Beth El (Chappaqua, New York, 1972), where the central wood-paneled light shaft
label: Caption

text: recalls the Polish wooden sanctuaries, as does the selective use of wood in Norman
label: Paragraph

text: Jaffe’s Gates of Grove Synagogue (East Hampton, New York, 1989).
label: Caption

text: In the last quarter of the 20th century, stability and even complacency can be found in
label: Paragraph

text: synagogue architecture throughout the world. Big synagogue projects declined, and
label: Paragraph

text: resources shifted to the erection of large regional community centers and to Jewish
label: Paragraph

text: museums and Holocaust memorials. In a reaction to modernism, some communities
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to recreate the lost intimacy of Old World and inner-city synagogues—often by
label: Paragraph

text: erecting smaller chapels adjacent to big sanctuaries, and incorporating historical styles or
label: Paragraph

text: including symbolic elements referring to the lost synagogue culture of the Old World.
label: Paragraph

text: Similarly, many new congregations formed, as the traditional segmentation of Judaism
label: Paragraph

text: was modified with new liturgical variations, including the increased involvement of
label: Paragraph

text: women in the service—an issue that divided many congregations. The synagogues of
label: Paragraph

text: new congregations, often small and struggling, were frequently adaptations of existing
label: Paragraph

text: TAFURI, MANFREDO 1935-94
label: Title

text: Architectural historian and critic, Italy
label: Title

text: Manfredo Tafuri was among the more dominant thinkers of architecture and society in
label: Paragraph

text: the final third of the 20th century. Tafuri was born in Rome in 1935 to a Jewish mother
label: Paragraph

text: and Catholic father. His early interests included painting and philosophy. Trained as an
label: Paragraph

text: architect at the University of Rome, he moved quickly from design to research, becoming
label: Paragraph

text: involved in issues of planning and urban organization in the early 1960s. In the late 1960s
label: Paragraph

text: and early 1970s, he wrote a series of penetrating books that became the guides for
label: Paragraph

text: advanced thinking about architecture in the modern world. In the later 1970s, he shifted
label: Paragraph

text: his interests to Renaissance architecture, and though his work in that field did not achieve
label: Paragraph

text: the same following, he became one of its keenest observers.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Tafuri studied architecture at the University of Rome, his was not a
label: Paragraph

text: conventional education. His early years were marked by the formation of oppositional
label: Paragraph

text: groups. He created seminars and discussion groups and founded a magazine
label: Paragraph

text: (Contropiano) with other disaffected colleagues (notably Alberto Asor Rosa, Mario
label: Paragraph

text: Tronti, and Massimo Cacciari). At one point Tafuri sought to form a union of architects
label: Paragraph

text: and architectural students to bring an uncorrupted voice to the discussion of the
label: Paragraph

text: regulatory plan for Rome. He was an assistant within the architecture department in
label: Paragraph

text: Rome from 1964 to 1966. From 1966 to 1967, he taught at the University of Palermo. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1968 he was brought to the University of Venice by Giuseppe Samona.
label: Paragraph

text: The key work of Tafuri’s early career was titled Teorie e storia dell’architettura
label: Paragraph

text: (Theories and History of Architecture) (1968). There he took a stance against what he
label: Paragraph

text: called “critica operativa” (operative criticism), the instrumentalization of the past to
label: Paragraph

text: justify current actions or, more dangerously, the use of the past to validate the potentials
label: Paragraph

text: of future freedom. In this formulation he leaned heavily on the writings of Martin
label: Paragraph

text: Heidegger, but he was also very much interested in the writings of Marc Bloch and
label: Paragraph

text: Lucien Febvre from the French Annales school of history, then little known in Italy.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1968 Tafuri took over the leadership of Istituto Universitario di Architettura at the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Venice. He used it as a forum to bring together specialists from various
label: Paragraph

text: disciplines in the university to study historical issues and gathered there a brilliant group
label: Paragraph

text: of architectural historians, including Giorgio Ciucci, Marco de Michelis, Mario Manieri-
label: Paragraph

text: Elia, and Francesco dal Co. Concerned with practical but fundamental matters of
label: Paragraph

text: scholarly historical method, he also reached out to other disciplines and quickly
label: Paragraph

text: developed a series of initiatives. A conference “Socialism: City, Architecture” (1970), for
label: Paragraph

text: example, examined the nature of urban planning in the 1920s and 1930s in the Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: Union, and a jointly authored book on the American city titled La cittd americana dalla
label: Paragraph

text: guerra civile al New Deal (The American City from the Civil War to the New Deal)
label: Title

text: (1973) took up the nature of development under capitalism. Both were helpful in defining
label: Paragraph

text: Tafuri’s political position in this turbulent period, and he became a significant participant
label: Paragraph

text: in debates on the role of the Italian Communist Party.
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, Tafuri’s work also began to be noticed in the United States. In 1974
label: Paragraph

text: he published his first essay in the periodical Oppositions, which later published more of
label: Paragraph

text: his essays as well as those of his Venetian collaborators, most notably Dal Co and Ciucci.
label: Paragraph

text: He helped to introduce the work of Aldo Rossi in the United States. Tafuri had, naturally,
label: Paragraph

text: a particular reception in the United States. North American architects were engaged in the
label: Paragraph

text: critique of modernism and intrigued by the revival of history and theory. Tafuri’s first
label: Paragraph

text: title that was translated into English was Architecture and Utopia (1976; Italian edition:
label: Paragraph

text: Progetto e utopia: Architettura e sviluppo capitalistico, 1973), a work that, like Teorie e
label: Paragraph

text: storia dell’architettura, attempted to redefine (and limit) the functions of the architect
label: Paragraph

text: and historian within contemporary culture. Tafuri brought to American architecture an
label: Paragraph

text: entirely new language of analysis based on “distance,” “alienation,” and “masquerade,”
label: Paragraph

text: terms borrowed from European philosophy that presume a tragic view of human history.
label: Paragraph

text: For Americans accustomed to their own optimistic or descriptive readings of architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: Tafuri’s analyses were startling, and the influence of Tafuri has been traced by Ockman
label: Paragraph

text: to the work of both Peter Eisenman and John Hejduk. Tafuri’s thoughts on the avantgarde
label: Paragraph

text: and on American architecture were collected in La sfera e il labirinto: Avanguardie e
label: Paragraph

text: architettura da Piranesi agli anni ‘70 (The Sphere and the Labyrinth: Avant-gardes and
label: Title

text: Architecture from Piranesi to the 1970s) (1980; English edition, 1987).
label: Paragraph

text: One of the great difficulties in coming to grips with Tafuri’s writing is his protean
label: Paragraph

text: nature. He operated on many fronts simul-taneously and with equal effect. In the same
label: Paragraph

text: year as La citta americana, for example, he published a book on the Via Giulia subtitled
label: Paragraph

text: Una utopia urbanistica del ‘500 (Villa Giulia: An urbanistic utopia of the 1500s) (1973),
label: Caption

text: which followed the fate of a single street through the process of its development starting
label: Paragraph

text: with Pope Julius Il in the early 16th century. From the later 1970s, in fact, Tafuri’s
label: Paragraph

text: interests shifted to a deeper past. Venezia e il Rinascimento: Religione, scienza,
label: Paragraph

text: architettura (Venice and the Renaissance: Religion, Science, Architecture} (1985) and
label: Paragraph

text: Ricerca del Rinascimento: Principi, citta, architetti (Renaissance Research: Princes,
label: Caption

text: Cities, Architects) (1992) defined the range of his interests in a total history of the sort
label: Paragraph

text: that recalls earlier interest in the Annales school.
label: Paragraph

text: Efforts to define the stages of Tafuri’s career tend to fall into the kinds of Hegelian
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic categorization that Tafuri himself eschewed. It is true that his later withdrawal
label: Paragraph

text: from contemporary issues of architecture entailed a retreat from some of the political
label: Paragraph

text: issues that marked his work in the 1960s. Moreover, his involvement with exhibitions
label: Paragraph

text: (notably Giulio Romano and Francesco di Giorgio) gives the impression of a return to
label: Paragraph

text: more traditional forms of biography. Tafuri helped sponsor some of the most
label: Paragraph

text: conservative scholars of Italian architecture at the University of Venice. All of this has
label: Paragraph

text: led some to define the later, Renaissance-based period of his scholarly activity as
label: Paragraph

text: conservative. Yet these decisions were probably strategic and personal rather than
label: Paragraph

text: principled. Tafuri defined himself as an educator and saw exhibitions, even monographic
label: Paragraph

text: exhibitions, as a way to raise historical issues to a broader public. Tafuri modeled his
label: Paragraph

text: own scholarly practice on the architectural team and was anxious to have the best
label: Paragraph

text: specialists around him.
label: Paragraph

text: Tafuri’s scholarship concerning the Renaissance remains buoyantly transgressive.
label: Paragraph

text: Giulio Romano and Francesco di Giorgio, to whom he devoted extensive attention, are
label: Paragraph

text: figures whose willingness to run against the academic traditions of their own times
label: Paragraph

text: appealed to him enormously, and he caught their contrary nature very well. He was even
label: Paragraph

text: able to find the rebelliousness in a drably academic architect such as Antonio da Sangallo
label: Paragraph

text: the Younger, as is revealed in his posthumously published essay and entries for the
label: Paragraph

text: corpus of architectural drawings by that architect.
label: Paragraph
