text: TALIESIN WEST
label: Title

text: Designed by Frank Lloyd Wright; completed 1937 Scottsdale, Arizona
label: Caption

text: There were two significant transitional points in Frank Lloyd Wright’s long career.
label: Paragraph

text: One is marked by the abandonment of his first practice in Oak Park and the design of his
label: Paragraph

text: rural Wisconsin home known as Taliesin (1911-14). The other is marked by his move
label: Paragraph

text: beyond Wisconsin to the Arizona desert and the construction of Taliesin West (1937).
label: Paragraph

text: During the early portion of his career, Wright had been engaged with the interior realm of
label: Paragraph

text: the family and its relationship to the larger society beyond, ideas embodied in his “Prairie
label: Paragraph

text: house” designs. His move to Taliesin is marked by the study of the relationship of man
label: Paragraph

text: and mind to landscape. Almost 30 years later, Taliesin West marks the fulfillment of that
label: Paragraph

text: effort as a giant step forward in Wright’s ability to conceive architectural languages as
label: Paragraph

text: expressions of the human condition.
label: Paragraph

text: The “desert compound,” as Taliesin West was originally known, consisted of a loosely
label: Paragraph

text: woven group of enclosures divided roughly into four quadrants by two crossing axes. The
label: Paragraph

text: orientation of the primary north-south axis in the plan is about 20 feet west of south,
label: Paragraph

text: facing the afternoon sun. Along with a drafting room, a large room for communal
label: Paragraph

text: gatherings, and Wright’s own study, the compound initially included quarters for the
label: Paragraph

text: families of the architect and his apprentices, sheltered places for dining and kitchen
label: Paragraph

text: duties, fireplaces, pools, and gardens. In its original form, these were not so much rooms
label: Paragraph

text: as places for the designated activi-
label: Paragraph

text: Taliesin West, Scottsdale, Arizona (1937)
label: Caption

text: © GreatBuildings.com
label: Title

text: ties of the Taliesin Fellowship strewn about the desert in an openly ordered pattern.
label: Paragraph

text: Taliesin West was built by Wright and the apprentices of his Taliesin Fellowship with
label: Paragraph

text: minimal help from professional builders. Large stones were gathered from the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding land-scape and stacked loosely together in battered wooden forms. A lean
label: Paragraph

text: mixture of concrete and desert sand was poured over the rocks. The resulting recumbent
label: Paragraph

text: walls are intermingled with level terraces stretching 300 feet across the desert floor,
label: Paragraph

text: barely protruding above the ground in some cases, in others rising to create cavelike
label: Paragraph

text: sanctuaries protected from the searing heat of the desert sun. The large drafting and
label: Paragraph

text: gathering spaces, as well as Wright’s private study, were spanned with redwood trusses.
label: Paragraph

text: These reach across entire sections with skeleton-like repetition, acting as ribs beneath
label: Paragraph

text: which were hung canvas stretched frames lapped to shed what little rain there was.
label: Paragraph

text: Similar canvas frames added around the sides and under the eaves could be opened to
label: Paragraph

text: regulate the presence of sun and wind. The contrast between the heavy raking masonry
label: Paragraph

text: walls and these floating, light-filled canvas panels formed the architectural backdrop for
label: Paragraph

text: the activities of the camp.
label: Paragraph

text: In its original form, the entire roof structure was disassembled each spring in
label: Paragraph

text: preparation for the Fellowship’s annual move back to Wisconsin. The canvas panels were
label: Paragraph

text: taken down and stored, leaving only the low stone walls and open redwood frames to
label: Paragraph

text: suffer the intense heat of the Arizona summer. In later years, as Wright began to stay
label: Paragraph

text: longer into the summer season, the canvas was replaced by plastic, the open spaces were
label: Paragraph

text: glazed, and the central parts of the building were eventually air conditioned, making it
label: Paragraph

text: quite a different place today.
label: Paragraph

text: The plan of Taliesin West is organized by the use of two crossing axes that intertwine
label: Paragraph

text: distant features of the landscape and its history with the pursuit of daily activities in the
label: Paragraph

text: camp. The pattern of movement along these assumes a quartering of space and
label: Paragraph

text: experience that was characteristic of Wright’s domestic designs going back to his Prairie
label: Paragraph

text: houses. Here in the desert, the quartered scheme is opened outward in a new way along
label: Paragraph

text: axes that emerge from the land to direct attention through the man-made forms to the
label: Paragraph

text: stark beauty of the natural world beyond. His own evaluation is perhaps the most
label: Paragraph

text: poignant: “The whole opus looked like something we had been excavating, not building”
label: Paragraph

text: The entry establishes an axis of movement through the compound, from the public
label: Paragraph

text: areas of contact with the city and the automobile to private areas of staff and family,
label: Paragraph

text: cloisters, and walled gardens. The left side of the plan generally contains places of work.
label: Paragraph

text: The right side of the plan contains places that contact with the stillness of the desert: the
label: Paragraph

text: apprentice quarters and Wright’s own Usonian dwelling. The pathway between these two
label: Paragraph

text: spaces is sunk into the ground of the mesa. This pathway, dominated and sheltered by the
label: Paragraph

text: mountains, brings the viewer into contact with another axis moving downward to the
label: Paragraph

text: south. The point of crossing of these axes was originally dramatically marked. As the
label: Paragraph

text: crossing was reached, the earth forced its way through the retaining wall and across a
label: Paragraph

text: small pool of water directly on axis with the 6,000-foot height of Thompson’s Peak in the
label: Paragraph

text: distance. Here the architectural forms open to the right under a shaded loggia into which
label: Paragraph

text: one is naturally drawn out of the heat of the Arizona sun. It is from this point that the
label: Paragraph

text: immensity of the view southward across the desert first becomes apparent. One is drawn
label: Paragraph

text: by this vista, unavoidably, down a few steps and out again into the full force of the sun to
label: Paragraph

text: peer upward into the distance.
label: Paragraph

text: This experience is reached by a movement downward in plan, from shelter to exposure,
label: Paragraph

text: from depression in the earth, where you are close to rock and water, to an elevated
label: Paragraph

text: position in the full glare of the desert sun with almost infinite vista. The upper portions of
label: Paragraph

text: the plan as originally built were left mostly natural and devoid of buildings and offered
label: Paragraph

text: controlled views of the wall of mountains to the north. In contrast the lower portions of
label: Paragraph

text: the plan offer exposure to the distance and to the desert sun. The first axis had led away
label: Paragraph

text: from civilization into areas of recess, retreat, and privacy. This second movement is more
label: Paragraph

text: elemental in nature. It leads from physical to ethereal, from solid to open, from earth to
label: Paragraph

text: sky. Years earlier at Taliesin, the crest of a hill occupied the center of the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: composition; here in the desert, at Wright’s final home, that center was thrown out across
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape in expression of the timeless quest for the bond that exists between the
label: Paragraph

text: mind of man and the natural world.
label: Paragraph

text: TANGE, KENZO 1913
label: Title

text: Architect, Japan
label: Title

text: For the quarter century following World War I, Kenzo Tange was among the world’s
label: Paragraph

text: leading architects; his work defined post-war modernism in Japan. Tange’s promising
label: Paragraph

text: beginning, after graduating from the University of Tokyo in 1938 and then working for
label: Paragraph

text: Kunio Maekawa for four years, was enhanced by the almost complete disappearance of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural practice during the latter days of the war. This absence allowed him to
label: Paragraph

text: return to the University of Tokyo in 1946, and he remained there as a student and
label: Paragraph

text: member of the faculty until 1974.
label: Paragraph

text: In his spectacular debut, winning first place in the Far East Greater Coprosperity
label: Paragraph

text: Sphere Competition of 1942, Tange engaged the nationalist spirit of the time, gaining
label: Paragraph

text: recognition through the controversy that emerged. His proposal for a monument to
label: Paragraph

text: Japan’s fallen soldiers, to be built on a long axis beginning at the foot of Mount Fuji, was
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by Japan’s temple precincts. By blending Japanese traditions with European
label: Paragraph

text: modernism, Tange took a very different position than others of his generation who
label: Paragraph

text: wholeheartedly embraced an international style.
label: Paragraph

text: For many years Tange’s work was unabashedly regionalist. Through 1960 Tange
label: Paragraph

text: defined a new Japan, infused with tradition and optimistically reflecting the utopian
label: Paragraph

text: hopes of the era. He embraced the symbols Japan’s citizens held dear but overlaid them
label: Paragraph

text: with an enthusiasm for new technologies. This approach is seen in some of his best built
label: Paragraph

text: works: his first, the Hiroshima Peace Memorial and Museum (1955), was inspired by the
label: Paragraph

text: sukiya character of buildings such as Katsura Imperial Villa; the surface treatments of the
label: Paragraph

text: facades at both Kagawa Prefectural Offices (1959) and Kurashiki City Hall (1960) drew
label: Paragraph

text: on Japan’s timber traditions, but in concrete used at a monumental scale; and in the later
label: Paragraph

text: Olympic Stadia (1964, Tokyo), Tange’s roofs were structurally remarkable but
label: Paragraph

text: comfortingly close to the form of Japan’s traditional farmhouses. Critics, however,
label: Paragraph

text: tended to disparage buildings with ties to tradition, favoring more sculptural efforts, such
label: Paragraph

text: as the Children’s Library (1953) at Hiroshima. Tange began to treat traditional nuances as
label: Paragraph

text: a failing, but today it is those buildings that were initially dismissed by critics that better
label: Paragraph

text: define his reputation. Yet while Tange’s early sculptural works were clumsy, they served
label: Paragraph

text: as the basis for several extraordinary buildings from the 1960s, including not only the
label: Paragraph

text: Olympic Stadia but also St. Mary’s Cathedral (1964, Tokyo) and the Memorial to Fallen
label: Paragraph

text: Soldiers (1966).
label: Paragraph

text: From the beginning Tange also emphasized the urban and regional scale, using axiality
label: Paragraph

text: as an ordering device. Throughout the 1950s and 1960s, Tange drew on an emerging
label: Paragraph

text: political will, reflecting the introduction of democratic ideals through his “mass-human”
label: Paragraph

text: spaces dedicated to collective activities. Many of his designs for government institutions
label: Paragraph

text: sandwiched offices between publicly accessible roof terraces (the Kagawa Prefectural
label: Paragraph

text: Hall had a popular cocktail bar on its rooftop) and an open ground plane slipped through
label: Paragraph

text: first-floor pilotis.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1961 Tange founded URTEC, Urbanists and Architects Team, inspired by Gropius’s
label: Paragraph

text: The Architects’ Collaborative. His designs from the 1960s tended toward structuralism.
label: Paragraph

text: Complexes were organized into a three-dimensional system made up of service cores,
label: Paragraph

text: circulation paths, and bridgelike blocks or figural units dedicated to programmatic needs,
label: Paragraph

text: with opportunities for future additions. The most powerful of these is a 1961 plan for
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo Bay, developed with students at the University of Tokyo. Participants in this
label: Paragraph

text: design—among them Fumihiko Maki, Arata Isozaki, Kiyonori Kikutake, and Kisho
label: Paragraph

text: Kurokawa—went on to shape Japan’s most exciting architectural movement,
label: Paragraph

text: Metabolism. Although none of Tange’s urban plans were executed, two notable buildings
label: Paragraph

text: were completed using similar principles: the Yamanashi Press and Broadcasting Center
label: Paragraph

text: (1966) and the Shizuoka Press and Broadcasting Center (1970) in Tokyo. The final
label: Paragraph

text: Metabolist undertaking was Expo ‘70 in Osaka, the first full-scale demonstration of a
label: Paragraph

text: Metabolist city. The public received the project more as an entertainment than as a rare
label: Paragraph

text: opportunity to recognize the value of a comprehensive urban proposal, and the movement
label: Paragraph

text: collapsed under its failure to be understood.
label: Paragraph

text: At roughly the same time, community resistance scrapped Tange’s proposal for Yerba
label: Paragraph

text: Buena (1969) in San Francisco, which was also based on structuralist principles.
label: Paragraph

text: Suddenly, enormous size was no longer a merit: The architect whose works had deftly
label: Paragraph

text: represented the conflicts and ideals of Japan’s postwar boom found himself out of step.
label: Paragraph

text: At first Tange found opportunities to work in Europe, but as the West and Japan began to
label: Paragraph

text: address the ecological fallout of megaprojects, demand for Tange’s work shifted to Arab
label: Paragraph

text: nations and, in the early 1980s, Southeast Asia. At one point 70 to 80 percent of the
label: Paragraph

text: firm’s work came from abroad. His projects from this period often remained unbuilt, and
label: Paragraph

text: those that were completed took an average of ten years from basic design through
label: Paragraph

text: execution, making it difficult for Tange to respond to innovations in construction
label: Paragraph

text: technologies. Furthermore, he was less able to develop a language that reflected the
label: Paragraph

text: hopes of these unfamiliar cultures, and buildings from this period seem awkwardly fitted
label: Paragraph

text: to their time and place.
label: Paragraph

text: Tange’s architecture continued to draw on many earlier themes. He remained
label: Paragraph

text: concerned with large-scale complexes organized in response to clear principles. In his
label: Paragraph

text: interiors he often developed a polished monumentality, especially notable in the Akasaka
label: Paragraph

text: Prince Hotel (1982). His architecture from this period is generally less appreciated,
label: Paragraph

text: though, as strategies from his earlier work became formulaic. In the final years of his
label: Paragraph

text: career, however, Tange began again to build symbolically important works in his native
label: Paragraph

text: country, especially the New Tokyo City Hall (1991) and the United Nations University
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1992). These buildings, while not as vigorous as works from his youth, retain a
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality and sense of detail that are clearly related to his earlier masterpieces.
label: Paragraph

text: Tange also found a way, in the end, to create a large-scale order in the city of Tokyo—
label: Paragraph

text: not through his revisions to the Tokyo Bay Plan (1986) but in his design of two of
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo’s tallest buildings. The New Tokyo City Hall and the nearby Tokyo Park Tower
label: Paragraph

text: can be seen from the megalopolis’s farthest suburbs and establish an order in the region
label: Paragraph

text: that Tange once reserved for Mount Fuji.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Biography
label: Title

text: Born Imabari, Shikoku, Japan, 1913. Graduated from the University of Tokyo (bachelor’s
label: Paragraph

text: degree, 1938; Ph.D., 1959). Taught at the University of Tokyo, 1946-1974; visiting
label: Paragraph

text: professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, (1959-1960) and
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard University (1972). Established URTEC in 1961; selected awards include the
label: Paragraph

text: annual prize of the Japanese Architecture Institute in the years 1954, 1955, 1958, and
label: Paragraph

text: 1965, including highest honors in 1986. Awarded Royal Gold Medal, the Royal Institute
label: Paragraph

text: of British Architects (RIBA) in 1965; Gold Medal, American Institute of Architects
label: Caption

text: (AIA), 1966. Received the Pritzker Prize in 1987 and the Praemium Imperiale in 1993. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1979 Tange was acknowledged as a Person of Merit in Japanese Cultural Achievement
label: Paragraph

text: and was recognized as a Sacred Treasure (Japan) in 1994.

text: TANIGUCHI, YOSHIO 1937
label: Title

text: Architect, Japan
label: Title

text: Yoshio Taniguchi is rare among architects, being steadfastly unwilling to dedicate any
label: Paragraph

text: effort to promoting his work. He seldom lectures or participates in symposia, he refuses
label: Paragraph

text: interviews, and he is notoriously difficult to the few journalists and academics who do
label: Paragraph

text: gain access. However, this taciturn position is justified by his architecture. Although his
label: Paragraph

text: buildings are certainly photogenic, it is impossible to appreciate their spatial and
label: Paragraph

text: contextual strengths without physically experiencing them.
label: Paragraph

text: Taniguchi’s maternal grandfather was one of Japan’s earliest architects and later
label: Paragraph

text: became the head of the Tokyo branch of a major construction company. Taniguchi’s
label: Paragraph

text: father, Yoshiro Taniguchi, was a contemporary of Kunio Maekawa and a respected
label: Paragraph

text: architect in his own right. Although little known abroad, Yoshiro Taniguchi was
label: Paragraph

text: entrusted with several commissions on behalf of Japan’s royal family, and he also
label: Paragraph

text: designed notable religious and commemorative structures. Originally inspired by
label: Paragraph

text: northern European modernism, Taniguchi’s father also designed his own house—a
label: Paragraph

text: laboratory for the father and an inspiration to his son. In some ways Yoshio Taniguchi’s
label: Paragraph

text: work is the fruit of two generations; he shares many objectives with his father, especially
label: Paragraph

text: an appreciation for serial experience and for compositionally pure organization.
label: Paragraph

text: Yoshio Taniguchi holds fond memories of childhood visits to construction sites, but he
label: Paragraph

text: also feared that his father’s reputation stood as too significant a challenge. He initially
label: Paragraph

text: decided to pursue a related field, taking a degree in mechanical engineering from Keio
label: Paragraph

text: University in 1960. His father, however, conspired with Kiyoshi Seike to encourage the
label: Paragraph

text: younger Taniguchi to go to the United States; Taniguchi graduated from Harvard
label: Paragraph

text: University with a master’s degree in architecture in 1964. He was the first Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: architect to receive licensing following an architectural education exclusively gained
label: Paragraph

text: abroad, and he took Japan’s licensing examinations only following some difficulty.
label: Paragraph

text: While at Harvard, Taniguchi met Kenzo Tange, and he joined Tange’s office and his
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo University research laboratory on his return to Japan in 1965, staying with the
label: Paragraph

text: firm until 1972. Taniguchi’s approach from this period closely resembles his mentor’s
label: Paragraph

text: methods, with an inclination to pursue culturally significant projects, enriching them
label: Paragraph

text: through collaboration. Taniguchi works frequently with graphic designers, sculptors, and
label: Paragraph

text: other artists, most notably Gen’ichiro Inokuma and the tea master Hiroshi Teshigahara.
label: Paragraph

text: Both Taniguchi and his father collabo rated with sculptor Isamu Noguchi, and Yoshio
label: Paragraph

text: Taniguchi is currently on the Noguchi Foundation board. The landscape architect Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Walker has also worked with Taniguchi, expressing architecture and landscape as a
label: Paragraph

text: seamlessly integrated art form. Together they have designed the IBM Makuhari Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1991), the Marugame Museum of Contemporary Art (1991), and the Toyota Municipal
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Art (1995).
label: Paragraph

text: Taniguchi’s first working experiences were as part of a design team (along with Arata
label: Paragraph

text: Isozaki) working on Tange’s plans for the rebuilding of Skopje, Yugoslavia. Two
label: Paragraph

text: features of this plan, an encircling “City Wall” punctured by prominent “City Gates” at
label: Paragraph

text: crucial locations, seem to have influenced Taniguchi’s work. Embracing protective walls
label: Paragraph

text: with highlighted entry points recur in his exquisite, carefully proportioned plans.
label: Paragraph

text: Amplifying this strategy, boxes nested within boxes establish an increasingly removed
label: Paragraph

text: domain where Taniguchi controls a heightened experience. His architecture is precise,
label: Paragraph

text: serene, and understated, often informed by contrast. Movement through his earliest
label: Paragraph

text: buildings juxtaposes centripetal and centrifugal spaces, and in later works, dark alternates
label: Paragraph

text: with light.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the crisp, modernist appearance of his work, Taniguchi strives for a timeless
label: Paragraph

text: character and is comfortable embracing Japan’s design traditions. Many of his finest
label: Paragraph

text: works, including the Tsukuba City Theater (1999) and the Tokyo National Museum of
label: Paragraph

text: Horyuji Treasures (1998), are successors to Katsura Imperial Villa: delicate, complex,
label: Paragraph

text: and highly refined. His sparing use of exquisitely apt materials demonstrates both artful
label: Paragraph

text: restraint and subdued elegance. Diaphanous screens, slender columns, and tapered
label: Paragraph

text: extremities are evident in his frequently published sections and detail drawings and result
label: Paragraph

text: in an exaggerated thinness. These knifelike planes demarcate expansive, fluid spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Buildings extend into their surroundings through the controlled use of shakkei (borrowed
label: Paragraph

text: landscape), and the edge between interior and exterior is often articulated by a stepped
label: Paragraph

text: configuration said to resemble geese flying in formation, further blurring the distinction
label: Paragraph

text: between inside and outside.
label: Paragraph

text: With the exception of the Tokyo Sea Life Park Aquarium (1989), Taniguchi’s work is
label: Paragraph

text: at its best when it is strictly orthogonal. His architecture is based on movement through
label: Paragraph

text: an uncompromising three-dimensional spatial matrix, determined not only by an
label: Paragraph

text: organizing lattice but also by a complex layering of horizontal and vertical planes.
label: Paragraph

text: Sharply drawn lines link contiguous spaces whereas taut, uninterrupted planes extend
label: Paragraph

text: from one room to the next. Taniguchi is concerned with the processional character of his
label: Paragraph

text: buildings and their spaces; as a consequence the quality of light has become increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: important in his designs. Glowing interiors draw one deeper into these buildings through
label: Paragraph

text: bounded, cavelike enclosures. He plays with a notable range of light effects, from single
label: Paragraph

text: beams breaking dim rooms to large, brightly lit volumes. Taniguchi has also
label: Paragraph

text: experimented with varying degrees of translucency, from the extraordinary clarity
label: Paragraph

text: resulting from the insubstantial-looking glass cage of the Kasai Rinkai Visitors’ Center
label: Paragraph

text: (1996) to the milky surfaces of the Toyota Museum of Art, achieved with two mullion-
label: Paragraph

text: free layers of fritted glass.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1975 Taniguchi opened his own office, but the intervening years have yielded a
label: Paragraph

text: relatively small number of published buildings. Most of Taniguchi’s buildings are public
label: Paragraph

text: works, and many of these are art museums, including the Higashiyama Kai’i Gallery for
label: Paragraph

text: the Nagano Prefectural Shinano Art Museum (1990) and his competition-winning
label: Paragraph

text: proposal for the Museum of Modern Art (1997) in New York. Despite the public nature
label: Paragraph

text: of these commissions, he has been able to develop supportive relationships with his
label: Paragraph

text: clients. His buildings are often the result of generous budgets and schedules, and a
label: Paragraph

text: number are repeat projects for the same client. Even among Japanese architects, who
label: Paragraph

text: enjoy a great deal of support and flexibility during design and construction, Taniguchi’s
label: Paragraph

text: craftsman-like design process and his constant presence on the construction site are
label: Paragraph

text: considered extreme. As one frequent collaborator has noted, “Every step of the process of
label: Paragraph

text: design and building is lovingly overseen and often reviewed. No detail remains
label: Paragraph

text: unconsidered. No idea is unchallenged, often changed even during construction. Basic
label: Paragraph

text: materials are considered and reconsidered right until their final installation.” Taniguchi
label: Paragraph

text: makes a point of acknowledging the contributions of experienced constructors, and he
label: Paragraph

text: uses these relationships to exploit the latest material and technological innovations.
label: Paragraph

text: The result of his intense focus on each project is a pristine perfection. Taniguchi’s
label: Paragraph

text: dignified and uncompromising architecture has led more than one author to revive the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of an architectural morality that sets him apart.
label: Paragraph

text: TAUT, BRUNO 1880-1938
label: Title

text: Architect and urban planner, Germany
label: Title

text: Bruno Taut was one of the leading architects in the development of a modem
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in Germany. He worked from a traditional historicist style to a colorful
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism before World War | and then helped create a rationalized “New Building”
label: Paragraph

text: in which he maintained a sense of color and creativity that transcended the austere
label: Paragraph

text: machine aesthetic and objectivity of his International Style peers. His career can best be
label: Paragraph

text: divided into four major phases: training and early works, 1903-12; Expressionist
label: Paragraph

text: experiments, 1912-23; large-scale social housing projects in Berlin, 1924-31; and exile
label: Paragraph

text: in Russia, Japan, and Turkey, 1932-38.
label: Caption

text: Taut was born in K6nigsberg, East Prussia (present-day Kaliningrad, Russia), the son
label: Paragraph

text: of a merchant and older brother of prominent architect Max Taut. He was educated at the
label: Paragraph

text: local building college and received further training in the offices of leading contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: architects Bruno MGhring in Berlin (1903), Theodor Fischer in Stuttgart (1904—08), and
label: Paragraph

text: the urban designer Theodor Goecke at the Technical University in Berlin (1909). In 1909
label: Paragraph

text: Taut opened an office in Berlin with Franz Hoffmann and was joined by his brother Max
label: Paragraph

text: in 1914, although they maintained separate design practices. The first commissions were
label: Paragraph

text: for apartment buildings in Berlin in which Taut created abstracted, Secessionist-style
label: Paragraph

text: compositions within a traditional framework.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1912 Taut was appointed advisory architect to the reform-oriented German Garden
label: Paragraph

text: City Association, which led to commissions for two housing developments: the “Reform”
label: Paragraph

text: Siedlung (housing estate) in Magdeburg, Germany (1913-14, 1921-23), and the
label: Paragraph

text: Falkenberg Garden City southeast of Berlin (1913-14). In both developments Taut
label: Paragraph

text: combined traditional garden city ideals and small, plain pitched-roof houses with brightly
label: Paragraph

text: colored facades as an inexpensive, expressive way to enliven architecture without
label: Paragraph

text: traditional historicist ornament.
label: Paragraph

text: Beginning in 1912, Taut also received a series of commissions for important
label: Paragraph

text: experimental exhibition pavilions to advertise new construction materials, including the
label: Paragraph

text: “Monument to Iron” in Leipzig (1913) and the famous “Glass House” at the Werkbund
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition in Cologne (1914). The Glass House, a propaganda building for the German
label: Caption

text: glass industry, contained glass-block floors, a sparkling waterfall, walls lined with
label: Paragraph

text: brightly colored tiles and prism glass, and a multifaceted, colored-glass dome with
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete ribs. The pavilion was dedicated to the poet Paul Scheerbart, whose
label: Caption

text: fantastical writings praised glass as the material of the future. The important critic and
label: Paragraph

text: Taut’s friend Adolf Behne championed glass in the popular press as the harbinger of a
label: Paragraph

text: new, modern architecture for the future.
label: Paragraph

text: As a committed pacifist, Taut refused to participate in World War |, but in December
label: Paragraph

text: 1918, within days of the German surrender, he and Walter Gropius formed the short-lived
label: Paragraph

text: revolutionary Working Council for Art. This was an organization of young artists and
label: Paragraph

text: architects intent on promoting a visionary new architecture of colorful, magical forms
label: Paragraph

text: that were free of all the burdens of past traditions, ornament, and materials. Taut
label: Paragraph

text: publicized his own dreams in several books, including Alpine Architektur (1919; Alpine
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture) and Die Aufldsung der Stddte (1920; The Dissolution of Cities), and a
label: Paragraph

text: series of utopian writings circulated among his friends that were later dubbed the “Crystal
label: Paragraph

text: Chain Letters.” All advocated the dissolution of existing cities in favor of a purified,
label: Paragraph

text: crystalline architecture of colored glass. Throughout his life Taut used the power of the
label: Paragraph

text: press to circulate his ideas to a larger audience, writing 21 books and nearly 300 articles
label: Paragraph

text: over the course of his career.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1921 the newly elected socialist government of Magdeburg hired Taut as chief city
label: Paragraph

text: architect, offermg him an opportunity to implement some of his utopian ideas. He
label: Paragraph

text: oversaw the extension of his own colorful Reform Siedlung, built a large concreteframe
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition hall, and initiated a controversial but widely publicized program of colorizing
label: Paragraph

text: existing urban facades to enliven the drab cityscape of postwar Magdeburg. Rampant
label: Paragraph

text: inflation and increasing criticism of his avant-garde ideas, however, soon ended his
label: Paragraph

text: tenure.
label: Paragraph

text: The most productive phase of Taut’s career began in 1924, when he accepted an offer
label: Paragraph

text: to oversee the design of large socialized housing developments in Berlin for the
label: Paragraph

text: communal building association GEHAG in cooperation with the chief city planner of
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin, Martin Wagner. In seven very productive years, Taut designed more than 10,000
label: Paragraph

text: units of affordable housing that proved to be among the most important achievements in
label: Paragraph

text: public housing of the century. Alongside Wagner, Taut became increasingly committed
label: Paragraph

text: to rationalized, standardized, and largely prefabricated construction systems, and
label: Paragraph

text: functional and efficient apartment layouts and furnishings that became models for
label: Paragraph

text: housing all over the world. Large-scale developments, such as the “Horseshoe” Siedlung
label: Paragraph

text: in Berlin-Britz (21,374 units, 1925-31) and Onkel Tom’s Hiitte in Berlin-Zehlendorf
label: Paragraph

text: (1915 units, 1926-31), were built in a radically modern architecture of mostly flat roofs,
label: Paragraph

text: unornamented facades (except for Taut’s trademark color), and plenty of green space that
label: Paragraph

text: provided a welcome relief for Berlin’s working class. The developments helped alleviate
label: Paragraph

text: a dire housing shortage and, along with built-in social institutions such as libraries, sports
label: Paragraph

text: fields, communal laundries, dining facilities, and social clubs, helped promote worker
label: Paragraph

text: solidarity and the socialist political ideals of Berlin’s city government.
label: Paragraph

text: The success of these projects earned Taut a prestigious professorship in housing and
label: Paragraph

text: city planning at the Technical University of Berlin from 1930 to 1932 as well as an
label: Paragraph

text: honorary membership in the American Institute of Architects. The worldwide economic
label: Paragraph

text: depression and an increasingly conservative and rightwing press and political machinery,
label: Paragraph

text: however, once again forced him out of work and office. After 1931 he accepted various
label: Paragraph

text: offers to work in the young Soviet Union, which had been relatively untouched by the
label: Paragraph

text: worldwide economic depression and which offered great promise to many important
label: Paragraph

text: German architects in search of opportunities to implement their dreams of a new
label: Paragraph

text: architecture for a new socialist society. Taut moved to Russia in 1932 and began plans for
label: Paragraph

text: a hotel and several institutional buildings as well as a master plan for Moscow. However,
label: Paragraph

text: political pressure soon forced him on the move again, briefly to Germany, where Adolf
label: Paragraph

text: Hitler had started to campaign against all modern architects in 1933, and then on to
label: Paragraph

text: Japan.
label: Paragraph

text: Taut stayed in Japan for three years, writing books, designing well-crafted furnishings
label: Paragraph

text: and household objects, and studying the ancient building traditions of Japan, which he
label: Paragraph

text: found surprisingly similar to European modern architecture. He was, however, unable to
label: Paragraph

text: build anything in Japan because of his émigré status. Eager to build, in 1936 Taut once
label: Paragraph

text: again followed a number of German colleagues and accepted an offer from the Turkish
label: Paragraph

text: government for a professorship at the Academy of Art in Istanbul and a position in the
label: Paragraph

text: Ministry of Education. His attempt to combine local Turkish building traditions with
label: Paragraph

text: European modernism in several university and institutional buildings, and his attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: use architecture to create a new society for postrevolutionary Turkey, earned him great
label: Paragraph

text: fame and respect and put Taut back in his element in an adopted homeland. When his life
label: Paragraph

text: was cut short by failing health in December 1938, he was honored by being the only
label: Paragraph

text: European buried in the national cemetery.
label: Paragraph

text: TAVORA, FERNANDO 1923-
label: Title

text: Architect, Portugal
label: Title

text: Fernando Tavora can be considered one of the most important exponents of
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary Portuguese architecture; he symbolizes the deep cultural renewal that has
label: Paragraph

text: gradually allowed Portugal to again play an important role in European architecture. His
label: Paragraph

text: poetical language is the fine result of a particular cultural background that has led him to
label: Paragraph

text: create a new Portuguese architecture based on a careful dialogue between modernity and
label: Paragraph

text: tradition. Most of his works show that he has explored new paths to enhance the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional values of rural Portuguese architecture: Each project evokes the past, but his
label: Paragraph

text: designs follow principles of modernity, including functional spaces, accurate details,
label: Paragraph

text: refined shapes, perfect integration to natural sites, and traditional materials. In other
label: Paragraph

text: words, Tavora’s architecture is not “something different, special, sublime, but work made
label: Paragraph

text: for man by man.” Thanks to his long teaching experience (university professor, Faculty
label: Paragraph

text: of Architecture in Oporto and Coimbra), he has become one of the main reference points
label: Paragraph

text: for a new generation of Portuguese architects.
label: Paragraph

text: Fully aware of architecture by Le Corbusier and Mies van der Rohe, Tavora sought
label: Paragraph

text: ways to blend traditional Portuguese architectural forms with those of the modernists. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1947 he wrote an essay titled “O problema da casa portuguesa” (The Problem of the
label: Paragraph

text: Portuguese House), in which he explained his point of view for reinvigorating Portuguese
label: Paragraph

text: architectural language: “The typical house will provide us with many important lessons
label: Paragraph

text: when properly studied, since it is the most functional and less fanciful; in short it comes
label: Paragraph

text: closest to the new intentions. ...In contemporary architecture, a promising consistency is
label: Paragraph

text: looming on the horizon...with which Portuguese architecture should merge, without fear
label: Paragraph

text: of losing its identity... It does not fade away like so much smoke; if we do possess this
label: Paragraph

text: individuality, nothing will be lost by studying foreign architecture.” However, in the
label: Paragraph

text: works of this period (1947-52), Tavora appears not yet to be able to adapt these
label: Paragraph

text: principles to his projects.
label: Paragraph

text: Tavora’s efforts to combine modernity and tradition show promise in one of his first
label: Paragraph

text: public projects for Oporto, the Municipal Park of Quinta da Conceicao (1960), which
label: Paragraph

text: included the simple Tennis Pavilion, his first masterpiece. The park shows elements of its
label: Paragraph

text: past: an old monastery, founded in the 15th century. In the quiet landscape of the old
label: Paragraph

text: cloister, the chapel and the pools fit well with the elegant design of new modernist
label: Paragraph

text: spaces. Tavora himself describes the Tennis Pavilion as the work of “a young architect
label: Paragraph

text: torn between reality and dream, the local and the international, the model and the
label: Paragraph

text: history.” The design recalls traditional elements of Portuguese rural architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese religious structures. With its balanced proportions and the use of traditional
label: Paragraph

text: materials (wooden trusses and white concrete), the small pavilion “contains a certain
label: Paragraph

text: remote oriental influence, as does traditional Portuguese architecture from the sixteenth
label: Paragraph

text: century onwards.”
label: Paragraph

text: Tavora’s experiments continue to blend different elements, modern and traditional, in
label: Paragraph

text: the Summer House (1958) in Ofir. Placed in a Mediterranean pine grove, the house is
label: Paragraph

text: divided into three functional blocks (living room area, services, and bedroom area)
label: Paragraph

text: connected by a large covered passage. The whole building evokes local rural architecture
label: Paragraph

text: with its geometric white surfaces, wooden trusses, red-tiled roof, paved loggias, and
label: Paragraph

text: colored chimneys.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout his career, Tavora has incorporated moder and traditional Portuguese
label: Paragraph

text: forms to create simple and clean spaces where various cultural references coexist. His
label: Paragraph

text: literary discussion about architecture carries on and generates other complex works, such
label: Paragraph

text: as the Gondomar Convent (1971), the Convent of Santa Marinha da Costa Inn (1984),
label: Paragraph

text: and the Agriculture High School Refoios do Lima (1993). They highlight the evolution of
label: Paragraph

text: his thinking about traditional and modern architecture in Portugal.
label: Paragraph

text: The Gondomar Convent is articulated into various blocks, each fulfilling a different
label: Paragraph

text: function (dormitories, chapel, meeting rooms, and refectory). Linking buildings with the
label: Paragraph

text: site, Tavora arranged the blocks to follow the natural slope of the landscape. Materials
label: Paragraph

text: (gray granite, white concrete, and red-tiled roofs) recall local rural architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: enhance a critical reuse of Portuguese architectural values. The conversion of the 18th-
label: Paragraph

text: century Convent of Santa Marinha da Costa to a pousada (the typical Portuguese inn)
label: Caption

text: allowed Tavora to further develop his principles. This project is not a mere restoration of
label: Paragraph

text: the old walls of the convent but rather a subtle attempt to insert modern structures in an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural continuity. The conceptual methodology adopted in the restoration of the
label: Paragraph

text: convent is clearly explained by Tavora himself: “The general criterion used was to carry
label: Paragraph

text: on innovating the already long life of the old building, by preserving its most important
label: Paragraph

text: areas and creating spaces of quality resulting from the new functional use introduced.”
label: Paragraph

text: The new bedroom section is not a simple addition of forms but rather represents the
label: Paragraph

text: continuous transformation of the whole building. Popular forms of rural architecture
label: Paragraph

text: inspired the design of the new parts of the convent: the integration between the old and
label: Paragraph

text: the new suggests continuity more than rupture. A similar conception was successively
label: Paragraph

text: adopted for the Refoios do Lima Convent’s conversion to the High School for
label: Paragraph

text: Agriculture (1987). The interior values of the existing structures are unchanged, and the
label: Paragraph

text: yellow ancient walls are carefully linked with the new buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: In summing up Tavora’s contribution to 20th-century architecture, it is useful to
label: Paragraph

text: conclude with the words of the critic Manuel Mendes. He asserts that “Tavora’s
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is not influenced by any particular architect, by any one particular school or
label: Paragraph

text: period, it encompasses the whole dimension of memory: his work in its apparent
label: Paragraph

text: simplicity, is the most original and erudite stylistic research carried out in recent years in
label: Paragraph

text: Portugal.”
label: Paragraph

text: STEFANIA ATTIL
label: Title

text: See also Corbusier, Le (Jeanneret, Charles-Edouard) (France); Mies van der
label: Paragraph

text: Rohe, Ludwig (Germany)
label: Caption

text: Biography
label: Title

text: Tavora’s thinking about modern and traditional values originated with his upbringing and
label: Paragraph

text: education. Born in Oporto, Portugal, 25 August 1923, to a rich and well-educated family,
label: Paragraph

text: he attended the Oporto School of Fine Arts, where he graduated in architecture in 1952.
label: Paragraph

text: The discovery of new international architects (Le Corbusier, Gropius, and others) and
label: Paragraph

text: the principles of the Modern movement caused in Tavora a deep change of mind and
label: Paragraph

text: boosts a new reflection on Portuguese architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Granted a scholarship by the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation and the Institute for
label: Paragraph

text: Culture in the United States and Japan. Attended the CIAM summer course at the Faculty
label: Paragraph

text: of Architecture of Venice. Assistant director at the UIA/Oporto Summer School.
label: Caption

text: Architect for Oporto Town Council, consultant to the Commission for the Urban
label: Caption

text: Renovation of the Ribeira/Barredo project, consultant in the Technical Bureau of the
label: Paragraph

text: Northern Planning Commission, consultant in the local Technical Bureau of Guimaraes
label: Paragraph

text: Town Council. President of the Ad Hoc Committee of the Faculty of Architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: Oporto, university professor at the Faculty of Architecture of Oporto and professor at the
label: Paragraph

text: Department of Architecture of the University of Coimbra. Awarded the First Prize for
label: Caption

text: Architecture by the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation, the Europa Nostra Award, the 1985
label: Caption

text: Tourism and Heritage Award, the 1987 National Award for Architecture, and the Golden
label: Paragraph

text: Medal of the city of Oporto. Doctor Honoris Causa at the University of Coimbra.
label: Caption

text: Member of the Association of Portuguese Architects, the International Union of
label: Paragraph

text: Architects, the Advisory Committee for Training in the Field of Architecture (European
label: Paragraph

text: Economic Community). Correspondent of the National Academy of Fine Arts.
label: Paragraph

text: His works have been hosted in important exhibitions: Washington (United States),
label: Paragraph

text: Clermont-Ferrand (France), Brussels (Belgium), Lisbon (Portugal), Milan and Venice
label: Paragraph

text: (Italy).

text: TAYLOR, ROBERT R. 1868-1942
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: Robert R.Taylor, the first professionally trained African American architect, was a
label: Paragraph

text: designer, teacher, and administrator at Tuskegee Institute (now University) in Alabama.
label: Paragraph

text: Taylor was born in Wilmington, North Carolina, to relative privilege for a black
label: Paragraph

text: southerner. After graduating from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology with a
label: Paragraph

text: degree in architecture in 1892, he rejected several teaching offers and started an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural practice in Cleveland, Ohio, which had a black community with long ties to
label: Paragraph

text: the Wilmington area. Taylor was less immune to the blandishments of Booker
label: Paragraph

text: T.Washington, who lured him to Tuskegee, which was then a secondary school.
label: Paragraph

text: Washington had a full understanding of the power of architecture to inspire its
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants, instill racial pride, and present the school by photographs in the national
label: Paragraph

text: press. Washington wanted to showcase black-designed and black-built buildings as well
label: Paragraph

text: as develop courses in architectural and mechanical drawing. All students in all trades
label: Paragraph

text: were to draw their projects—stovepipes, wagon wheels, shoes, and carpentry joints—as a
label: Paragraph

text: precondition to making them. Teachers and ministers as well as those learning
label: Paragraph

text: Douglass Hall (1902-04), Tuskegee Institute, Tuskegee, Alabama
label: Caption

text: Photo by Frances Benjamin Johnson. © Library of Congress
label: Caption

text: building trades must also be able to draw and then build their own schools, houses, and
label: Paragraph

text: churches or adapt whatever poor structures they might be assigned in their remote rural
label: Paragraph

text: destinations. By hiring Taylor, Washington had acquired not only the country’s only
label: Paragraph

text: school-trained black architect but also an able administrator who would soon direct the
label: Paragraph

text: Boys’ Industries Division and manage Tuskegee’s building program, serving as its
label: Paragraph

text: contractor as well as architect.
label: Paragraph

text: Taylor’s design tracks at Tuskegee remain clear, even with the loss of three major
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. The Chapel (1898) initially seated 2000 (later 3000) under a hammer-beam
label: Paragraph

text: roof. Although it burned in 1957, it has lived on as the scene of the hero’s epiphany in
label: Paragraph

text: Ralph Ellison’s fnvisible Man. (Paul Rudolph designed the replacement.) In 1918 a fire
label: Paragraph

text: took the SlaterArmstrong Memorial Trades Building (1899), and the Huntington
label: Paragraph

text: Memorial Academic Building (1905) burned recently. Still, enough remains to leave a
label: Paragraph

text: remarkably attractive campus of gently scaled, white-trimmed brick structures
label: Paragraph

text: punctuating the green and hilly landscape. Taylor’s buildings vary in shape and style, but
label: Paragraph

text: all have modest detailing that sets off sharp-edged wall surfaces that display Tuskegee’s
label: Paragraph

text: student-made bricks. The trials of getting the school’s brickyards started loomed large in
label: Paragraph

text: Tuskegee’s collective memory. Building donors knew that their gifts did triple duty in
label: Paragraph

text: shelter, student support, and education, as students did most of the construction, learning
label: Paragraph

text: trades as they earned money.
label: Paragraph

text: About two dozen other brick buildings remain that were designed by Taylor and the
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Drawing Division. There are many dormitories, a classroom building (now
label: Paragraph

text: offices), an administration building, Booker T.Washington’s house (now a museum), and
label: Paragraph

text: an unusually elegant Laundry Building (now the George Washington Carver Museum).
label: Paragraph

text: The exterior of the Girls’ Industrial Building still stands, although the interior has been
label: Paragraph

text: gutted. The Carnegie Library (1902) is fronted by the school’s first two-story portico.
label: Caption

text: Critics now interpret southern high classicism as reified white triumphalism based on Jim
label: Paragraph

text: Crow laws and sanctioned violence. Tuskegee’s library portico was built just when a new
label: Paragraph

text: Alabama constitution denied most black people the vote and just when Booker
label: Paragraph

text: T.Washington was excoriated throughout the region for taking a meal with Theodore
label: Paragraph

text: Roosevelt in the White House, thereby seeming to claim social equality. However, even
label: Paragraph

text: Tuskegee’s harshest critics accepted its several classical porticoes and a dome without
label: Paragraph

text: questioning them for effrontery.
label: Paragraph

text: Taylor also designed buildings elsewhere: Carnegie libraries at Livingstone College in
label: Paragraph

text: Salisbury, North Carolina (1906), and Wiley University in Marshall, Texas (1907); brick
label: Paragraph

text: school buildings in Cambria, Virginia (1897), and Selma, Alabama (1921); a church in
label: Paragraph

text: the town of Tuskegee (1907); a Masonic Temple and office building in Birmingham,
label: Paragraph

text: Alabama (1922); many wooden houses; wooden schools in the countryside; and perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: a house for C.A. Correa in Mexico City (1908). Taylor did not design all of historic
label: Paragraph

text: Tuskegee. A white Georgian designed the domed Tompkins Dining Hall (1910), although
label: Paragraph

text: Taylor did the interiors and supervised construction. Other black architects teaching in
label: Paragraph

text: the Architectural Drawing Division, such as Walter T.Bailey (trained at the University of
label: Paragraph

text: Illinois), William S.Pittman (Tuskegee and Drexel Institute), Wallace A.Rayfield (Pratt
label: Paragraph

text: Institute), Louis H.Persley (Carnegie Institute of Technology), and the office-trained
label: Paragraph

text: William A.Hazel, also played active design roles. Tuskegee nurtured black architects
label: Paragraph

text: with teaching jobs and prepared students for architecture schools (Pittman and Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Brent to Drexel and Vertner W.Tandy to Cornell) or practice (Charles Bowman in Kansas
label: Paragraph

text: City; Charles T.Russell in Richmond; John A.Lankford in Washington, D.C.; and several
label: Paragraph

text: others in Puerto Rico and Cuba).
label: Paragraph

text: Taylor’s life and architecture were, then, closely bound to Tuskegee, which he made
label: Paragraph

text: into a center of architectural activity for African Americans. Although he left briefly to
label: Paragraph

text: resume his Cleveland practice, he designed Tuskegee buildings as a part of it. In 1929 the
label: Paragraph

text: Phelps-Stokes Fund sent him to Liberia to help create the Booker Washington Institute as
label: Paragraph

text: an “African Tuskegee.” The reticent, diplomatic academic administrator observed
label: Paragraph

text: Liberia’s controversial social and economic conditions, proposed a program and staffing,
label: Paragraph

text: planned the campus, and designed its first buildings. He retired soon after this adventure
label: Paragraph

text: and spent his remaining years in Wilmington. His son, Robert Rochon Taylor, carried on
label: Paragraph

text: in some sense, becoming the Chicago Housing Authority administrator for whom the
label: Paragraph

text: high-rise Robert Taylor Homes were named.
label: Paragraph

text: Taylor was too modest or too honest to claim for himself the role of the first black
label: Paragraph

text: professional, an honor that he might have given his older colleague William A.Hazel
label: Paragraph

text: (185?-1929). Taylor’s architectural reputation was eclipsed during his own lifetime by
label: Paragraph

text: the stellar Los Angeles career of Paul R.Williams (1894-1980). However, recognition
label: Paragraph

text: has come recently through the naming of prizes and associations in his honor and by
label: Paragraph

text: MIT’s attention to its first African American graduate.
label: Paragraph

text: ELLEN WEISS
label: Title

text: Biography
label: Title

text: Born in Wilmington, North Carolina, 8 June 1868. Father was a white planter’s son who
label: Paragraph

text: was free before emancipation and had prospered as a coastal trader, merchant, and
label: Paragraph

text: carpenter/builder. Attended an American Missionary Association school for black
label: Paragraph

text: children in New England; met Henry and Francis Bacon—the first a future architect, the
label: Paragraph

text: second a Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) architecture student in 1888;
label: Paragraph

text: attended MIT, 1888-92; bachelor of science degree in architecture 1892. His thesis was a
label: Paragraph

text: home for aged Civil War veterans, northern and southern together. Married; son, Robert
label: Paragraph

text: Rochon Taylor, administrator of the Chicago Housing Administration. In private practice,
label: Paragraph

text: Cleveland 1892-96; brief private practice, Tuskegee, Alabama. Professor and
label: Caption

text: administrator, Tuskegee Institute (now University), Alabama from 1896; designer and
label: Paragraph

text: administrator, Booker Washington Institute, Liberia 1929-34. Died in Wilmington, 13
label: Caption

text: December, 1942.

text: TEAM X (NETHERLANDS)
label: Title

text: Team X was an architectural group formed in the early 1950s by a number of young
label: Paragraph

text: European architects. The participants were dissatisfied with the mid-20th-century Modern
label: Paragraph

text: movement, particularly with the ideals of CLAM (Congrés Internationaux d’ Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: Moderne), with which they had previously been affiliated. Oscar Newman’s CLAM ‘59 in
label: Paragraph

text: Otterlo and Alison Smithson’s The Emergence of Team 10 out of C.LA.M. document
label: Paragraph

text: Team X’s official secession from CIAM. Factions that began to appear at the CIAM IX
label: Paragraph

text: meeting in Aix-en-Provence in 1953 between the old guard and the younger generation
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated the split. Under that meeting’s theme, “Habitat,” the younger members
label: Paragraph

text: contested the simplistic divisions of living, working, leisure, and circulation that had been
label: Paragraph

text: established in the Athens Charter. Alison Smithson contends in Team 10 Meetings:
label: Paragraph

text: 1953-1984 that the first Team X meeting took place during the meeting at Aix-en-
label: Paragraph

text: Provence. Following the events of CLAM IX, the “youngers” were entrusted with
label: Paragraph

text: preparing the subject matter for the CIAM X meeting and from then on were known as
label: Paragraph

text: Team X.Alison and Peter Smithson (England), Aldo van Eyck (Netherlands), Jaap
label: Caption

text: Bakema (Netherlands), Georges Candilis (France), Shadrack Woods (France), John
label: Paragraph

text: Voelcker (England), and William and Jill Howell (England) were the founding members
label: Paragraph

text: of Team X. Participants in Team X altered considerably during the group’s existence, but
label: Paragraph

text: in general the group remained small and was defined by its reaction to the inefficiencies
label: Paragraph

text: of the large CIAM commissions.
label: Paragraph

text: Curtis maintains in Modern Architecture since 1900 that the members of Team X
label: Paragraph

text: initially advocated the moral convictions of the early Modern movement but were
label: Paragraph

text: discontented with CLAM’s incapacity to respond to growth and change. They felt that
label: Paragraph

text: culture, climate, and context were not being addressed and opposed the modernist
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy of “tabula rasa.” However, Francis Strauven acknowledges in his article “The
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch Contribution: Bakema and Van Eyck” that even the method of achieving these
label: Paragraph

text: mutual goals was not easily agreed on by the members of the group. Bakema and van
label: Paragraph

text: Eyck, both of whom requested modification of an original draft by the Smithsons of the
label: Paragraph

text: Doom Manifesto (January/February 1954), had their suggestions for the document
label: Paragraph

text: initially ignored. Finally, an appendix to this manifesto, called the “Dutch Supplement,”
label: Paragraph

text: was added.
label: Paragraph

text: Few similarities generally existed between Team X members. Individual participants
label: Paragraph

text: varied in their method of working and in their perception of how a building was
label: Paragraph

text: produced. Alison Smithson argues in Team 10 Meetings: 1953-1984 whether even the
label: Paragraph

text: group’s function as a forum for the development of individual architectural concerns was
label: Paragraph

text: necessary for each architect’s work to have advanced.
label: Paragraph

text: The most influential manifesto produced by Team X is the Team 10 Primer, published
label: Paragraph

text: in 1962 and edited by Alison Smithson. It consists of a compilation of quotations from its
label: Paragraph

text: members at the time. John Voelcker and William and Jill Howell were no longer listed as
label: Paragraph

text: members in Team 10 Primer, being replaced by Giancarlo de Carlo (Italy), José Antonio
label: Paragraph

text: Coderch y de Sentmenat (Spain), C.Pologni (Hungary), Jerzy Soltan (Poland), and
label: Paragraph

text: S.Wewerka (Germany). Extracts explore issues initiated by the CLAM commissions, such
label: Paragraph

text: as mass housing and urbanism through the multilevel city, including the Smithson’s
label: Paragraph

text: proposal for the Golden Lane Housing Competition using the concept of “streets in the
label: Paragraph

text: air.” This proposal was strongly influenced by their relationship with Nigel Henderson, a
label: Paragraph

text: photographer of London’s working-class communities, and their involvement in the art
label: Paragraph

text: collaborative, the Independent Group.
label: Paragraph

text: Van Eyck’s elaboration of the doorstep metaphor and his criticism of twin phenomena
label: Paragraph

text: is another important contribution found in Team /0 Primer. In the chapter on Van Eyck
label: Paragraph

text: in Modern Architecture: A Critical History, Kenneth Frampton acknowledges how Van
label: Paragraph

text: Eyck differed from the other participants of Team X in regard to the severity of his
label: Paragraph

text: critique of the Modern movement. Before his involvement with Team X, Van Eyck had
label: Paragraph

text: undertaken extensive studies of anthropological concerns through his personal interest in
label: Paragraph

text: “primitive” cultures.
label: Paragraph

text: Formal meetings of Team X members were generally held annually. In 1962 a well-
label: Paragraph

text: documented Team X meeting occurred at Abbaye Royaumont. Its importance lay in
label: Paragraph

text: Team X’s acknowledged independence from CIAM concerns. Once again the listed
label: Paragraph

text: participants had changed. Projects presented included the Waterford School in Swaziland
label: Paragraph

text: by Pancho Guedes (South Africa/ Portugal), the Tibro housing project by Ralph Erskine,
label: Paragraph

text: John Voelcker’s Council Offices and proposal for Tilbury House in Maidstone, Peter
label: Caption

text: Smithson’s studies of metropolitan London, José Antonio Coderch y de Sentmenat’s
label: Paragraph

text: studies of slums in Barcelona, Christopher Alexander’s study of Indian villages,
label: Paragraph

text: Kurokawa’s capsules, Aldo van Eyck’s interest in the large-house/ little-city image, Jaap
label: Paragraph

text: Bakema’s gallery housing, Giancarlo de Carlo’s plans for Milan, Christopher Dean and
label: Paragraph

text: Brian Richards’s studies of Euston Station, Shad Woods’s interest in pedestrian avenues,
label: Paragraph

text: and Georges Candilis’s Toulouse-le-Mirail. The records of “Team 10 at Royaumont”
label: Paragraph

text: differ from those in Team 10 Primer in that they chronicle the interactive discourse by
label: Paragraph

text: participants in the projects presented. The contributions of architects of different
label: Paragraph

text: nationalities, speaking English to varying degrees, resulted in frustration with this
label: Paragraph

text: meeting’s outcomes.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1982 the final Team X family included Alison and Peter Smithson, Aldo van Eyck,
label: Paragraph

text: Georges Candilis, José Antonio Coderch y de Sentmenat, Giancarlo de Carlo, Jerzy
label: Caption

text: Soltan, Ralph Erskine (Sweden), Manfred Schiedhelm (Germany), Pancho Guedes, and
label: Paragraph

text: Julian de La Fuente (France). No longer driven to respond to CIAM inadequacies, the
label: Paragraph

text: group lost effectiveness and was disbanded in 1984.
label: Paragraph

text: The contributions made to 20th-century architecture by Team X include the production
label: Paragraph

text: of important writings such as Team 10 Primer and their capacity to reassess the existing
label: Paragraph

text: canon of the Modern movement. Equally important are the built works and writings of
label: Paragraph

text: Team X members. In his article “Team 10 after the Sex Pistols,” Willem Jan Neutelings
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledges the impact of Team X on the Dutch architecture that followed, citing a link
label: Paragraph

text: to Rem Koolhaas’s work. Similarly the Smithsons influenced British architecture through
label: Paragraph

text: Reyner Banham’s promotion of them as founders of the Brutalist movement.
label: Paragraph

text: See also Congres Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne (CLAM)
label: Caption
