text: TECTONICS
label: Title

text: The term ¢ectonics alludes to the formally expressive capabilities inherent in architectural
label: Paragraph

text: forms, both as singular components and in relation to the building assembly as a whole.
label: Paragraph

text: This aspect of architectural form has, therefore, a greater meaning than either the
label: Paragraph

text: dictionary definition of tectonic as merely “pertaining to building or construction in
label: Paragraph

text: general” or the simple revealing of constructional techniques. Tectonics, in architectural
label: Paragraph

text: discourse, refers to the poetics of construction in the original Greek sense of poesis as an
label: Paragraph

text: act of making and revealing.
label: Paragraph

text: The term tectonic derives from Greek word tekton, meaning carpenter or builder, in
label: Paragraph

text: turn borrowed from the Sanskrit taksan, referring to the craft of carpentry and to the use
label: Paragraph

text: of the ax. Remnants of a similar term can also be found in Vedic, where it again refers to
label: Paragraph

text: carpentry and to the art of construction in general. This meaning undergoes further
label: Paragraph

text: evolution as the term passes from being something specific and physical, such as
label: Paragraph

text: carpentry, to the more generic notion of construction and later to becoming an aspect of
label: Paragraph

text: poetry.
label: Paragraph

text: The history of tectonic form has two major theoretical lines divided roughly between
label: Paragraph

text: the German lineage of J.J. Winckelmann, Karl Boetticher, Gottfried Semper, and Karl
label: Paragraph

text: Friedrich Schinkel and the French tradition of Abbé Laugier, Claude Perrault, Jacques-
label: Paragraph

text: Germain Soufflot, Henri Labrouste, and Eugéne-Emmanuel Viollet-le-Duc. Whereas the
label: Paragraph

text: German architects and writers focused on the post-Enlightenment dilemma of the
label: Paragraph

text: disjunction between form and spirit as applied to architecture, French thinkers were
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupied with the expression of statical logic and the rationality of construction
label: Paragraph

text: procedures insofar as they could be revealed with greater clarity than before using the
label: Paragraph

text: new materials of iron and concrete informed by the newly developed science of statics.
label: Paragraph

text: The first architectural use of the term tectonics in German dates from its appearance in
label: Paragraph

text: Karl Otfried Miiller’s Handbuch der Archaologie der Kunst (1878; Handbook of the
label: Caption

text: Archaeology of Art), wherein he defines tektonische as applying to a series of art forms
label: Paragraph

text: “such as utensils, vases, dwellings and meeting places of men.... We call this string of
label: Paragraph

text: mixed activities tectonic; their peak is architecture, which mostly through necessity rises
label: Paragraph

text: high and can be a powerful representation of the deepest feelings.” Karl Boetticher, in his
label: Paragraph

text: Die Tektonik der Hellenen (1874; The Tectonic of the Hellenes), elaborated the concept
label: Paragraph

text: of the tectonic in several ways. At one level he described a process of building made of a
label: Paragraph

text: series of appropriately interlocking constructional elements. Simultaneously articulated
label: Paragraph

text: and integrated, this series of joints constituted the body-form, or Kérperbilden, of the
label: Paragraph

text: building that enabled construction of the building and made such assemblies symbolic
label: Paragraph

text: components of an expressive system. At another level Boetticher distinguished between
label: Paragraph

text: the Kernform, or nucleus, and the Kunstform, or decorative cladding, the latter having the
label: Paragraph

text: purpose of representing and symbolizing the status of the work.
label: Paragraph

text: The German architect Gottfried Semper was particularly influential in the evolution of
label: Paragraph

text: tectonics in his work Die vier Elemente der Baukunst (1851; The Four Elements of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture). Inspired by a Caribbean hut in the Great Exhibition of 1851, Semper
label: Paragraph

text: evolved the notion of a paradigmatic primitive hut that embodied the four basic tectonic
label: Paragraph

text: elements of architecture: the earthwork, the hearth, the framework (and roof}, and the
label: Paragraph

text: light-weight enclosing membrane. This model was more anthropological and
label: Paragraph

text: transcultural than Marc-Antoine Laugier’s well-known proposal in his Essai sur
label: Paragraph

text: Varchitecture (1755; An Essay in Architecture), which presented a framed pedimented
label: Paragraph

text: edifice, adopted as an archetype by neoclassical architects. At the same time, Semper
label: Paragraph

text: divided architectural form into two broader categories: the tectonics of the frame, in
label: Paragraph

text: which lightweight linear components are in a spatial grid, and the stereotomics of the
label: Paragraph

text: earthwork, where mass and volume are formed concurrently through the use of
label: Paragraph

text: heavyweight elements. Stereotomics is derived from the Greek terms stereos, for solid,
label: Paragraph

text: and tomia, to cut. This distinction between light and heavy is reflected in overall material
label: Paragraph

text: differences and construction techniques—wood, steel, and other tensile components for
label: Paragraph

text: the former and brick, stone, reinforced concrete, or their compressive equivalents for the
label: Paragraph

text: latter. This opposition between iconic construction typologies and their resultant space-
label: Paragraph

text: forms as a basis for an architectural language is borne out in vernacular building
label: Paragraph

text: traditions throughout the world. In Semper’s Der Stil in den technischen und tektonischen
label: Paragraph

text: Kiinsten, oder praktische Aesthetik (1879; Style in the Technical and Tectonic Arts, or
label: Paragraph

text: Practical Aesthetics), he emphasized the joint or the knot, particularly between the
label: Paragraph

text: stereotomic base of a building and its tectonic frame. Transitions between such elements
label: Paragraph

text: provided, for Semper, the most extensive opportunities for expression in architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: With this focus on the joint or knot, he wrote extensively about the nature of the textile
label: Paragraph

text: arts as the dominant primordial building element that was often preserved over time
label: Paragraph

text: stylistically in other, more permanent materials, such as stone or wood.
label: Paragraph

text: The tectonic in French architectural thought is traceable to Claude Perrault’s
label: Paragraph

text: Ordonnance des cing espéces de dolonnes selon la méthode des anciens (Treatise on the
label: Title

text: Five Kinds of Columns after the Method of the Ancients, 1783). Perrault proposed a
label: Paragraph

text: theory of positive versus arbitrary beauty in place of the prevailing academic theory
label: Paragraph

text: giving the five classical orders precedence over any other aesthetic ideas. He asserted that
label: Paragraph

text: such academic styles belonged to the realm of arbitrary beauty, whereas symmetry,
label: Paragraph

text: richness of materials, and precision of execution were the only means of judging a
label: Paragraph

text: positive or universal form of beauty, qualities that are tectonic insofar as they are based
label: Paragraph

text: on material substance and geometric order.
label: Paragraph

text: Two Paris masterworks by Henri Labrouste further developed the tectonic with
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary grace and clarity: the Bibliothéque Ste.-Geneviéve (1850) in Paris and the
label: Paragraph

text: Bibliothéque Nationale (1875), with the insertion of a prefabricated, fireproof iron
label: Paragraph

text: framework into an exterior masonry shell, with each element clearly expressed and
label: Paragraph

text: articulated. The tectonic aspect of this work lay in its attempt to discredit scenographic
label: Paragraph

text: eclecticism and to establish in its place architecture as an art of construction. Concerned
label: Paragraph

text: with the economy of structure, he evolved a system of “iron network vaulting” of his own
label: Paragraph

text: devising—an expressive vocabulary of lightweight iron members and articulated joints
label: Paragraph

text: that revealed their resistance to gravity in surprising and inventive ways while set within
label: Paragraph

text: a more traditional heavy outer masonry shell. This syntax was developed further by his
label: Paragraph

text: pupil Anatole de Baudot in a series of proposals for large-scale, long-span exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: halls. The last French theorist of the Greco-Gothic ideal was Francois Auguste Choisy,
label: Paragraph

text: who, in his Histoire de l’architecture (1899; History of Architecture), suggested that
label: Paragraph

text: great civilizations arrived at their zenith when their essence, subject to geographic and
label: Paragraph

text: material conditions, became expressed collectively in tectonic form. In part because of
label: Paragraph

text: the nature of the renowned isometric drawings illustrating this work, Choisy presented
label: Paragraph

text: the space-form of buildings as inseparable from their mode of construction, thus
label: Paragraph

text: anticipating the tectonic possibilities of reinforced concrete in the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Certain major architects of the 20th century have pursued tectonics as a determinant of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural form in all or part of their work. The pioneering work of Auguste Perret
label: Paragraph

text: (1874-1954) was almost exclusively concerned with the expression of the structural
label: Paragraph

text: frame in opposition to its in-fill. Utilizing the new vocabulary of architectural reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete, buildings such as the Théatre des Champs-Elysées (1913) in Paris created a
label: Paragraph

text: fusion of classical rationalism with the Greco-Gothic ideal. Ludwig Mies van der Rohe
label: Paragraph

text: (1886-1969) pursued a tectonic form of intense rigor and precision throughout his career,
label: Paragraph

text: first with brick in a series of houses in Germany and later with steel in such buildings as
label: Paragraph

text: the Farnsworth House (1950) in Plano, Illinois, and the campus at the Illinois Institute of
label: Paragraph

text: Technology (1939-57) in Chicago. It is likely that Frank Lloyd Wright (1867-1959) was
label: Paragraph

text: aware of Semper’s writing and developed paradigms in many projects that included
label: Paragraph

text: Semper’s four elements, particularly in the so-called Usonian houses built mainly
label: Paragraph

text: between 1934 and 1944 and the “textile-block” system of concrete block construction
label: Paragraph

text: patented in 1923. Louis Kahn (1901-74) gave primacy in his work to understanding the
label: Paragraph

text: expressive nature of the joint in architecture and emphasized the tectonic element in
label: Paragraph

text: nearly every project of his career.
label: Paragraph

text: In the Kimbell Art Museum (1972) in Fort Worth, Texas, Kahn’s manifestation of the
label: Paragraph

text: Semperian earthwork-and-frame opposition utilized the former as a means of integrating
label: Paragraph

text: the building into its site and the latter to provide space and reveal light. The work of the
label: Paragraph

text: Norwegian architect Jorn Utzon has sought to express structure and construction as a
label: Paragraph

text: major determinant of architectural form in both large- and small-scale projects. These
label: Paragraph

text: works nearly always seek inspiration from non-European, often vernacular, models and
label: Paragraph

text: distinguish clearly between the earthwork and roofwork components, the former often
label: Paragraph

text: accommodating building services within the site and the latter composed of “floating”
label: Paragraph

text: folded plate or shell-roof structures for the honorific habitable space above the podium.
label: Paragraph

text: This is clearly manifest in the Sydney Opera House (1973). The tectonic aspect of the
label: Paragraph

text: work of Carlo Scarpa (1906-78) lies primarily in the extreme emphasis he placed on the
label: Paragraph

text: constructional joint—its rhetorical amplification and subsequent elaboration—regardless
label: Paragraph

text: of the building’s program or size.
label: Paragraph

text: Other architects who have made tectonics an integral part of their work include the
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch architect H.P. Berlage (1856-1934), who achieved a masterful tectonic synthesis
label: Paragraph

text: in his Amsterdam Stock Exchange (1903), and the late work of Le Corbusier (1887-—
label: Paragraph

text: 1965), where expressive structure began to dominate the character of the work beginning
label: Paragraph

text: with the Maison Week-End (1935) in St.-Cloud. The Dutch architects Aldo van Eyck and
label: Paragraph

text: Herman Hertzberger developed the tectonic potential of the reiteration of singular spatial
label: Paragraph

text: units and highly articulated structural form to create an evolved syntax of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: form. In England, Foster Associates and the Richard Rogers Partnership have explored
label: Paragraph

text: the potential of structural efficiency and its expression throughout their respective
label: Paragraph

text: practices. In Switzerland the work of the Ticino School, as exemplified by Mario Botta
label: Paragraph

text: and Livio Vacchini, falls easily into this category, as do many late 20th-century Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: architects, among them Alejandro de la Sota and Bonell and Rius. In Greece the
label: Paragraph

text: architects Aris Konstantinidis and Dimitris Pikionis worked to successfully unify local
label: Paragraph

text: regional building and craft traditions with a modern tectonic expression. Finally, the work
label: Paragraph

text: of Sverre Fehn in Norway as an example of a small practice and that of the Renzo Piano
label: Paragraph

text: Building Workshop as a large international firm have been producing work that
label: Paragraph

text: rigorously pursues an architecture rooted in a philosophy of tectonics, work in which the
label: Paragraph

text: poetics of construction is a primary determinant of form, a determinant that invites
label: Paragraph

text: adaptation and distortion brought about by exigencies of typological and topographic
label: Paragraph

text: circumstance.

text: TENSILE STRUCTURES
label: Title

text: The most common tensile structure is a tent, which is a thin, saddle-shaped tension
label: Paragraph

text: membrane supported by a compression arch or mast. In a tent the fabric carries all or part
label: Paragraph

text: of the tensile forces. Small tents, made entirely of fabric, are typically supported by masts
label: Paragraph

text: (columns) or arches. As the span increases, membrane tension forces increase, and the
label: Paragraph

text: surface area must be subdivided by cables that carry the principal tensile loads with fabric
label: Paragraph

text: spanning between cables.
label: Paragraph

text: If the edge of a tent is flexible (unattached), it is usually shaped into a concave curve to
label: Paragraph

text: ensure that it remains in tension. Because the edge is a region of high stress, it is usually
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced with cable that continues to the anchor point. The anchor point may be
label: Paragraph

text: connected to a guy cable (which transmits tension forces to the foundation), or it may be
label: Paragraph

text: supported by a mast or compression strut (which transfers compression loads to the
label: Paragraph

text: ground).
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps the best way to develop an intuitive understanding of appropriate shapes for
label: Paragraph

text: tents is to experiment with scale models using a stretchy, lightweight double-knit fabric
label: Paragraph

text: supported by arches, masts, or strings. At the scale of buildings, however, a minimum of
label: Paragraph

text: stretch is desired; in fact tent fabrics are selected for their resistance to stretch under load
label: Paragraph

text: (among other qualities). The three-dimensional form represented in the model by the
label: Paragraph

text: stretched fabric is constructed at full scale by adjusting the shape and location of the
label: Paragraph

text: individual panels before assembly. This technique is also used in the design and
label: Paragraph

text: construction of boat sails to ensure the correct aerodynamic shape. In contemporary tent
label: Paragraph

text: structures, three-dimensional computer models are used to plan the shape of the tent and
label: Paragraph

text: its individual panels and to calculate internal tensile stresses. For wind stability (as well
label: Paragraph

text: as longevity), it is essential that tents be designed as double-curvature structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Tents are most easily supported by central masts, but this may be functionally
label: Paragraph

text: undesirable for nonstructural reasons. Catenary cables can be suspended from side masts
label: Paragraph

text: to support the membrane peaks at several points. Where center supports are used, fabric
label: Paragraph

text: stress may be reduced by distributing the load over a larger area through the use of a
label: Paragraph

text: mushroom-shaped mast capital.
label: Paragraph

text: Traditionally, tents were considered to be suitable only for temporary structures
label: Paragraph

text: because of the deterioration of fabrics due to prolonged exposure to sunlight. The
label: Paragraph

text: development of improved fabrics (notably fiberglass) and coatings that minimize the
label: Paragraph

text: deterioration due to sunlight (e.g., Dupont Teflon) have increased the useful life of tent
label: Paragraph

text: fabrics to over 20 years, making them suitable for use on permanent structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Tent Case Studies
label: Title

text: Riyadh Stadium
label: Title

text: Horst Berger, a pioneer in tension structure technology, was the engineer on this graceful
label: Paragraph

text: project (1986; Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; Fraser, Roberts, and Partners, architects). The
label: Paragraph

text: structure consists of 24 identical tent modules repeated around a circle to form a ring
label: Paragraph

text: canopy covering the grandstands. The open center is over the playing field. Like the
label: Paragraph

text: Munich Olympic Stadium, the masts are positioned behind the seating to maintain the
label: Paragraph

text: unobstructed view of the playing field from the grandstands, which seat 60,000. The tent
label: Caption

text: covers a total area of 500,000 square feet (46,500 square meters).
label: Paragraph

text: The fabric membrane is stretched between ridge cables, valley cables, and catenary
label: Paragraph

text: edge cables. The ridge cables are connected to the main mast and are radial in plan. The
label: Paragraph

text: valley cables between the ridge cables are connected to the bottom anchor and stabilize
label: Paragraph

text: the structure against wind uplift; they are also radial in plan. The outer edge of the ridge
label: Paragraph

text: cables and the outer edge of the catenary edge cables are held at a fixed point created by
label: Paragraph

text: the sloping mast and the two triangulated guy cables. The inner end of the membrane is
label: Paragraph

text: attached to a ring cable that counterbalances the outward thrust of the sloping mast and
label: Paragraph

text: guys. To make the structure erectable and to provide redundancy and additional stiffness,
label: Paragraph

text: an additional cable system was added. This consists of adding a suspension cable, a
label: Paragraph

text: stabilizing cable, and an upper support cable, all aligned with the ridge cable of each
label: Paragraph

text: module. These, together with the masts, the rear support cables, and the ring cable, form a
label: Paragraph

text: stable system not requiring the participation of the fabric.
label: Paragraph

text: The structure includes a roof-washing system designed to maintain the fabric’s 8
label: Paragraph

text: percent daylight transmittance and 75 percent solar reflectance. The high solar
label: Paragraph

text: reflectance, coupled with the natural convection ventilation induced by the openings at
label: Paragraph

text: the peak, helps maintain spectator comfort. Rain drains outward to the lower anchor
label: Paragraph

text: points to spill into a perimeter drainage basin. The center ring cable supports speaker and
label: Paragraph

text: field lighting systems; uplights reflect off the underside of the tent at night to provide
label: Paragraph

text: general illumination of the grandstands.
label: Caption

text: Mound Stands, Lord’s Cricket Field
label: Caption

text: When asked to design the new mound stands for the Lord’s Cricket Field (1987; London;
label: Paragraph

text: Michael Hopkins and Partners, architects; Ove Arup and Partners, structural engineers),
label: Paragraph

text: Hopkins used fabric roofs to create an elegant tent, recalling the temporary structures of
label: Paragraph

text: the 17th century erected on the green for a Saturday afternoon’s cricket match. In
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration with the engineers, Hopkins devised a steel superstructure above the
label: Paragraph

text: existing stadium to house two new tiers of seating, a mezzanine level of services, and the
label: Paragraph

text: elegant roof that characterizes the structure.
label: Paragraph

text: Structurally independent of the existing brick terrace, the tent is supported by six 16-
label: Paragraph

text: inch (406-millimeter)-diameter tubular steel columns that also support a spine of steel
label: Paragraph

text: girders. Cantilevering from the spine are a series of beams that form the floor of the top
label: Paragraph

text: level and the ceiling above the viewing boxes. At the back of the building, the beams are
label: Paragraph

text: connected by plate girders that transfer loads to the vertical steel tension rods placed
label: Paragraph

text: every 59 feet (18 meters) between the arches of the colonnade.
label: Paragraph

text: The top tier of seating is covered by the fabric tent, stressed by a framework of steel
label: Paragraph

text: struts and catenary cables. Originally intended to be Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric,
label: Paragraph

text: PVC-coated polyester was finally specified because of fire restrictions. The fabric was
label: Paragraph

text: cut using computer-generated patterns and ultrasonically welded into seven sections that
label: Paragraph

text: extend between the six masts.
label: Paragraph

text: TENSIONED MEMBRANE STRUCTURE
label: Title

text: Tensioned structures (from the Latin tendere, “to stretch”) are ones that resist only
label: Paragraph

text: tension forces and pull rather than push. A list would include traditional tents, suspension
label: Paragraph

text: bridges, modern saddle-shaped prestressed membrane and cable roofs, convertible or
label: Paragraph

text: retractable roofs for temporary covers, air-supported or pneumatic constructions, and
label: Paragraph

text: combinations of cables and compression struts, referred to as “tensegrity” structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Some are simply stabilized by their own weight, whereas others resist uplift as well as
label: Paragraph

text: gravity loadings by being prestressed and having anticlastic surfaces. The majority are
label: Paragraph

text: either linear or surface structures. A tensioned membrane structure is one in which two
label: Paragraph

text: dimensions dominate and loads are resisted in a planar manner, such as occurs in tents,
label: Paragraph

text: membrane, cable-net, and convertible or retractable roofs, and pneumatic constructions.
label: Paragraph

text: The origins of tensioned membrane structures arise from three archetypes: tents,
label: Paragraph

text: suspension bridges, and balloons and airships. Although the tent is the oldest, suspension
label: Paragraph

text: bridges were more influential. Balloons and airships antedate air-stabilized or pneumatic
label: Paragraph

text: structures, in which a small pressure differential substitutes for masts or arch supports.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to wire rope and bridge strand for cable or clastic suspended roofs, a
label: Paragraph

text: number of fabrics are employed, including cotton, canvas, and coated synthetics; of these
label: Paragraph

text: polyester coated with polyvinyl chloride (PVC) has proven to be the most useful. The
label: Paragraph

text: experimental introduction of vinyl-coated fiberglass for the shallow cable-reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: dome of the United States Pavilion at Expo ‘70 in Osaka, Japan, stimulated the search for
label: Paragraph

text: longer-lasting fabrics. Teflon-coated fiberglass was used for La Verne College (1973),
label: Paragraph

text: California, and subsequently for many different building types, the most famous being
label: Paragraph

text: the Pontiac Silverdome (1975) in Pontiac, Michigan, and the giant King Abdul Aziz
label: Paragraph

text: International Airport (1980) in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.
label: Paragraph

text: For the most part, nonprestressed or simply suspended cable roofs resemble types of
label: Paragraph

text: bridges: in a cable-suspended roof, the deck is carried directly on cables in the same
label: Paragraph

text: manner as in a catenary bridge. The Wuppertal Swimming Pool (1957) and an aircraft
label: Paragraph

text: hangar at Kempen (1957) both in Germany, are examples. The most famous is the Dulles
label: Paragraph

text: Airport Terminal (1962) in Washington, D.C. Jor Utzon adopted similar roofs for the
label: Paragraph

text: National Assembly Building (1983) in Kuwait City, Kuwait.
label: Caption

text: Tents and ancient Roman theater vela are some of the earliest traditional examples.
label: Paragraph

text: The Raleigh Arena (1952) in Raleigh, North Carolina, is usually given as a seminal
label: Paragraph

text: instance of a clastic saddle shape whose prestressed cable roof supplied the prototype for
label: Paragraph

text: many later structures, such as the Ingalls Hockey Rink (1958) at Yale University in New
label: Paragraph

text: Haven, Connecticut, and the Sidney Myer Music Bowl (1956) in Melbourne, Australia.
label: Paragraph

text: Frei Otto’s experimental development of fabric structure marked the 1950s departure
label: Paragraph

text: from the previous engineering-inspired suspension bridge model and promoted the tent
label: Paragraph

text: model. Otto was anticipated by a Russian engineer, V.G.Shookhov, who in 1896
label: Paragraph

text: designed a series of four steel tents for the Exhibition at Nizhni Novgorod. In his early
label: Paragraph

text: projects, Otto concentrated his efforts on finding the most efficient minimal surfaces for
label: Paragraph

text: modest textile pavilions, but when challenged by larger spans in works such as the
label: Paragraph

text: German Pavilion at Expo ‘67 in Montreal, he developed a system of flexible prestressed
label: Paragraph

text: wide-rope cable nets on which he hung the fabric-enclosing membrane. A further step
label: Paragraph

text: was taken with the 1972 Munich Olympic Stadium, which was significant for its material
label: Paragraph

text: and technological advances that resulted in the application of computer methods of
label: Paragraph

text: structural analysis for the first time.
label: Paragraph

text: Parallel with this, Otto developed miniature cable tractors that travel on the supporting
label: Paragraph

text: cables and permit the membrane envelope to be fully stretched or retracted or bunched
label: Paragraph

text: for automatic storage. After the Bad Hersfeld (Hesse) centrally retracting roof, Otto
label: Caption

text: collaborated on constructing convertible roofs with Roger Taillibert over an open-air
label: Paragraph

text: theater (1965) at Cannes and a swimming pool at Boulevard Carnot (1967) in Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: This construction is possible to do without masts and arches entirely in air-supported
label: Paragraph

text: membranes, which use a small airpressure differential to hold up the structure and resist
label: Paragraph

text: external loads. The two main types are air-inflated structures, consisting of rib and dual-
label: Paragraph

text: walled structures, and air-supported structures. To these a third, hybrid type that
label: Paragraph

text: combines features of both can be added.
label: Paragraph

text: An English engineer, Frederick William Lanchester, in a suggestion that he made for a
label: Paragraph

text: field hospital in 1917, was the first to propose that the balloon principle be applied to
label: Paragraph

text: building. During World War II in the United States, Herbert Stevens proposed that a
label: Paragraph

text: pneumatic structure be used for aircraft production. The first actual application had to
label: Paragraph

text: wait until Walter W. Bird, who enclosed radar dishes in the Distant Early Warning Line
label: Paragraph

text: inside pneumatic bubbles. The success of these “Radomes” led Bird to establish Birdair
label: Paragraph

text: Structures Incorporated in 1956. Civilian applications followed, including a theater for
label: Paragraph

text: the Boston Arts Center (1959) and a Portable Exhibition Pavilion for the U.S. Atomic
label: Paragraph

text: Energy Commission.
label: Paragraph

text: With the Brussels World’s Fair, pneumatics, which was almost entirely American,
label: Paragraph

text: crossed the Atlantic with the Pan-American Airways Pavilion (1958). Around this time
label: Paragraph

text: Frei Otto began making studies of pneumatic forms and cable-reinforced air-supported
label: Paragraph

text: membranes. The possible range of applications grew to include sports facilities, roofs for
label: Paragraph

text: stadiums, warehouses, offices, and pavilions at the New York (1963-64) and Osaka
label: Paragraph

text: (1970) World’s Fairs.

text: TENT
label: Title

text: Traditional tents come in two categories: noble tents, which are affiliated with urban
label: Paragraph

text: societies belonging to warriors and kings, and nomad tents, which are the property of
label: Paragraph

text: nomadic and seminomadic pastoralists. Nomad tents are seen in many varieties, including
label: Paragraph

text: conical skin-covered tents of northern Eurasia and North America, cylindrical felt-
label: Paragraph

text: covered trellis tents of central Asia, and the black goats’ hair tents of the Near and
label: Paragraph

text: Middle East and North Africa. There are also species of primitive tents, such as the bone
label: Paragraph

text: tent of northeastern Siberia and the skin and mat tents that survive in North Africa among
label: Paragraph

text: the Tuareg and others.
label: Paragraph

text: Tents arose gradually, often evolving from existing fixed dwellings and huts that had
label: Paragraph

text: been simplified and lightened under the pressure of nomadism to give the tent cloth a
label: Paragraph

text: greater structural role in resisting loads imposed by the wind, snow, and rain and to
label: Paragraph

text: increase the ease of erecting and transporting them.
label: Paragraph

text: Tents belonging to urban peoples existed in the ancient world well before Mohammed
label: Paragraph

text: and are extremely old. Tents are depicted in an Egyptian encampment at the battle of
label: Paragraph

text: Kadesh in 1285 B.C., and twin semicupola skin tents are illustrated in Assyrian bas-
label: Paragraph

text: reliefs from 645 B.C. Images of black tents can be seen in the same Assyrian reliefs, and
label: Paragraph

text: it is very probable that they existed before the 11th century B.C.
label: Paragraph

text: Tents come in two basic plan configurations: circular and rectangular. Structurally, the
label: Paragraph

text: division is elementary as well: frame tents have a limp, unstressed membrane that is hung
label: Paragraph

text: on a structural supporting frame that carries the imposed loads and is secured by thongs
label: Paragraph

text: or straps to prevent the membrane from flying off; frameless tents have a load-bearing
label: Paragraph

text: and load-distributing cover that is supported at points or linear arrangements of
label: Paragraph

text: compression members, such as struts or arches. Very few traditional nomad tents have
label: Paragraph

text: wholly, or true, prestressed membranes. The tent cover of the black goats’ hair tent is
label: Paragraph

text: comparatively heavy, and its weight, especially when it is wet, helps stabilize it.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the cloth is stretched and deformed by rope around its edges to improve its
label: Paragraph

text: stability under lateral wind loads. Thus, the tent is partly prestressed and partly weight
label: Paragraph

text: stabilized. Structurally, traditional tents can be divided into unstressed frame tents;
label: Paragraph

text: stressed tents without frames supported by poles, arches, and horizontal bars or tensile
label: Paragraph

text: cords or filaments; and any combination of these.
label: Paragraph

text: The conical tent fundamentally is a primitive dwelling used by peoples at the hunting
label: Paragraph

text: stage. It is a circumpolar trait found in the boreal regions of North America and Eurasia.
label: Paragraph

text: The tent is retained as a summer dwelling by many nomadic and seminomadic herdsmen
label: Paragraph

text: and even by some sedentary and agricultural tribes. It consists of a conical frame of
label: Paragraph

text: radially inclined poles in a circle, with their slim upper ends secured at the peak. The
label: Paragraph

text: pattern of the pole frame and the material used as a cover (but not the basic form) are
label: Paragraph

text: remarkably uniform. Two, three, or four poles make up the foundation for the secondary
label: Paragraph

text: poles, which are laid in the V-fork of the crossing. The conical frame tent belongs to the
label: Paragraph

text: region of northern taiga forest among the Samoyed, Syran, Mansi, Sel’kupi, Ostayak,
label: Paragraph

text: Vogul, Northern Evenki Tungus, Yeniseians, Khanti, Nganasani, and Lapps in Keti,
label: Paragraph

text: Upper Yukaghir. Even the Kalmuck of Astrakhan and the Kirghiz use felt-covered
label: Paragraph

text: conical tents. The tepee of the Great Plains Indians is a late modification of this
label: Paragraph

text: circumpolar type and displays such essential features of the Eurasian conical frame tent
label: Paragraph

text: as the central fire, a smoke hole centering on the crossing of the poles, an eastern
label: Paragraph

text: entrance, and a place of honor opposite the doorway.
label: Paragraph

text: The cylindrical felt-covered trellis tent is a further, highly developed frame tent that is
label: Paragraph

text: found in the vast region surrounding the Volga River and the Anatolian plateau in the
label: Paragraph

text: west and the Khingan Mountains in the east. The shape and construction of the trellis tent
label: Paragraph

text: are surprisingly uniform and have remained unchanged over the past four centuries. The
label: Paragraph

text: two main types are a felt-covered cylindrical walled trellis tent with a conical ribbed roof,
label: Paragraph

text: found among the Mongol peoples and some Turkicspeaking tribes of northern central
label: Paragraph

text: Asia, and a convex domical roofed version, found among Turkic-speaking tribes of
label: Paragraph

text: western and southern Siberia, such as the Kirghiz, Uzbek, and Turkoman.
label: Paragraph

text: The black tent type is a frameless tent with a partially stressed membrane with an
label: Paragraph

text: anticlastic or flat saddlelike surface supported by ridge, arches, or high points and
label: Paragraph

text: anchored to the ground by long, extended stays. It most resembles the modern prestressed
label: Paragraph

text: tent and uses the least amount of wood of any type, with the possible exception of Inuit
label: Paragraph

text: tents. Black tents are distributed in a nearly continuous narrow belt between 25 and 40
label: Paragraph

text: degrees north latitude, extending from Mauritania in northwestern Africa to Afghanistan,
label: Paragraph

text: with the Tibetan group forming an isolated island. This distribution approximates the
label: Paragraph

text: region of desert vegetation across North Africa and the Middle East and is related to two
label: Paragraph

text: animals: the goat, from whose hair the tent cloth is woven, and the dromedary, which is
label: Paragraph

text: used for the tent’s transport.
label: Paragraph

text: Notable differences exist between the Arabian black tents and tents on the northern
label: Paragraph

text: fringes of Arabia and North Africa: the cloth tent of the desert Bedouin, the Sba’a and
label: Paragraph

text: Rwala, has three longitudinal rows of poles supporting a rectangular cloth, with the
label: Paragraph

text: central row higher than the remainder, giving its characteristic ridge profile. The tents of
label: Paragraph

text: North Africa differ significantly in having two rather than three rows of poles: a front
label: Paragraph

text: row and a central row but no back row. The North African black tent was brought to the
label: Paragraph

text: region with the Arab expansion in the 11th century B.C. and has a striped awning.
label: Paragraph

text: Inuit and Tuareg tents occur in extreme culture-resistance zones and typically are
label: Paragraph

text: minimal constructions of considerable ingenuity.
label: Paragraph

text: Sumptuous tents were introduced into Western Europe in the 12th century A.D. as a
label: Paragraph

text: result of the Crusades and then spread from France, where their immediate effect was
label: Paragraph

text: great, and quickly became identified with the tournaments, and warfare that were part of
label: Paragraph

text: the chivalric tradition in neighboring regions. Tents were symbols for the heavenly city of
label: Paragraph

text: Jerusalem and the exotic Near East. Tents influenced the design of pavilions and of turret
label: Paragraph

text: roofs for churches, castles, and palaces (a very fashionable architectural motif) as well as
label: Paragraph

text: the interior design and decoration of palaces, especially the boudoir. Miniature tents, to
label: Paragraph

text: symbolize the Old Testament tabernacle, were frequently adopted for reliquaries and
label: Paragraph

text: monstrances in medieval Christian ritual. Elaborate, fabulously decorated tents were
label: Paragraph

text: revived in the 15th century, reaching a climax under Francis | and Henry VIII in 1520 at
label: Paragraph

text: Ardes and later under Emperor Napoleon at the beginning of the 19th century. In the 16th
label: Paragraph

text: century, the word pavillon came to dignify anything likened to a tent—any lightly
label: Paragraph

text: constructed ornamental building or pleasure house in a garden. Even more widespread
label: Paragraph

text: was the tent roof that was derived from the conical shape of the parasol-roofed tent or the
label: Paragraph

text: square pavilion tent with its draped pyramid-shaped canopy.
label: Paragraph

text: Tents generally are identified with nomadism, whether a full-blown nomadism; the
label: Paragraph

text: itinerant nomadism of armies and royal progresses; or that of an individual or groups who
label: Paragraph

text: are forced by their lifestyle to move often and who, to this end, require a light, portable
label: Paragraph

text: shelter. The relationship between tents and permanent monumental architecture is a
label: Paragraph

text: complex two-way one, with exchanges occurring in both directions, reflecting the
label: Paragraph

text: interdependence between sedentary urban and nomadic pastoral cultures. Because of their
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic prestige, tent forms have been imitated and preserved in stone buildings and in
label: Paragraph

text: other durable constructions, resulting in a hybrid class of pseudo-tent buildings, a
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenon that is very noticeable in France after the Crusades and that spread to
label: Paragraph

text: Stockholm, Dresden, and Vienna.
label: Paragraph

text: PHILIP DREW
label: Title

text: Further Reading
label: Title

text: Much of the material on tents occurs within ethnographic studies of nomadic life that are
label: Paragraph

text: not written from an architectural viewpoint but that treat the tent as an expression of
label: Paragraph

text: culture and weaving technique. The subject of urban tents has received even less attention
label: Paragraph

text: by comparison, and there are no architectural histories or separate technical accounts of
label: Paragraph

text: their construction, origin, and development. This selection is biased toward the tents of
label: Paragraph

text: nomadic peoples and includes some of the more pertinent ethnological reports in addition
label: Paragraph

text: to popular accounts.

text: TERRA-COTTA
label: Title

text: Terra-cotta (Italian for “baked earth"), a building material with ancient roots, found its
label: Paragraph

text: fullest expression in architecture of the first half of the 20th century. Architectural terra-
label: Paragraph

text: cotta is ceramic or fired clay, most often glazed, used primarily in the 20th century for
label: Paragraph

text: fireproofing and exterior cladding of buildings. The earliest known use of terra-cotta is in
label: Paragraph

text: early Mesopotamia, where examples are found from as early as 3200 B.C. Terra-cotta
label: Paragraph

text: was also used by the ancient Egyptians and the Etruscans as well as the Greeks and the
label: Paragraph

text: Romans.
label: Paragraph

text: Lost with the fall of Rome, the art of terra-cotta was rediscovered in 14th-century
label: Paragraph

text: Germany and Italy, as exemplified by the work of Luca della Robbia and his family, who
label: Paragraph

text: introduced polychrome techniques on panels and plaques used as architectural
label: Paragraph

text: decoration. The techniques for making terra-cotta found their way to England, where
label: Paragraph

text: unglazed terra-cotta was used as early as the 16th century, mostly as decorative detail on
label: Paragraph

text: brick and stone buildings. During the 18th century, technological advances resulted in a
label: Paragraph

text: steady increase in England in the use of terra-cotta, which was noted for its durability and
label: Paragraph

text: resistance to weathering. Terra-cotta was also admired because of the its ability to mimic
label: Paragraph

text: the appearance of stone at a fraction of the cost.
label: Paragraph

text: By the 19th century, terra-cotta was widely used in England for architectural
label: Paragraph

text: ormamentation. Its popularity grew because it was available in a range of colors and
label: Paragraph

text: textures and could be molded with fine detail emulating carved stone. Terra-cotta was
label: Paragraph

text: also being produced in North America on a limited basis during this period. Factories in
label: Paragraph

text: New York, Philadelphia, and Chicago produced unglazed terra-cotta for ornamental
label: Paragraph

text: detail for the facades of buildings, including string courses, capitals, and window
label: Caption

text: surrounds.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite its early introduction to the United States, architects and builders tended to be
label: Paragraph

text: skeptical of the claims for terra-cotta’s durability. This began to change after Chicago's
label: Paragraph

text: Great Fire of 1871. After the devastation of the fire, the emphasis in Chicago and
label: Paragraph

text: nationwide was to construct buildings that were as fire resistant as possible. Structural
label: Paragraph

text: terra-cotta provided an extra measure of fireproofing to buildings. At the same time, the
label: Paragraph

text: last quarter of the 19th century, advances in the terra-cotta manufacture and architectural
label: Paragraph

text: design that capitalized on the inherent malleability of terra-cotta as a cladding material
label: Paragraph

text: spurred the growth of the fledgling American industry.
label: Paragraph

text: As terra-cotta was receiving acceptance as a building material, dramatic changes were
label: Paragraph

text: occurring in the technology of building construction. Technological innovations—
label: Paragraph

text: notably skeleton-frame construction—led to the development of the modern skyscraper.
label: Paragraph

text: The use of structural metal to form a skeleton on which finish materials could be hung
label: Paragraph

text: meant that buildings could rise to heights previously unimagined. At the same time,
label: Paragraph

text: architects were anxious to develop new design motifs to celebrate this new building type.
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural terra-cotta proved to be the ideal material. Terra-cotta cost 90 percent less
label: Paragraph

text: than a piece of ornamental stone and was one-third the weight. In addition, because terra-
label: Paragraph

text: cotta was molded rather than carved, repeating motifs in a complex design was easily
label: Paragraph

text: achieved. Variations in surface texture and colors were also possible. One of the earliest
label: Paragraph

text: structures to use terra-cotta as a cladding material was New York’s Flatiron Building
label: Paragraph

text: (built 1901-03, designed by Daniel Burnham). This 22-story building, the tallest building
label: Paragraph

text: in the city when it was built, has a stone base, with brick and terra-cotta finishing up the
label: Paragraph

text: floors above.
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Sullivan exploited the plasticity of terra-cotta perhaps better than any other
label: Paragraph

text: practitioner of his time. The intricate interplay of the design motifs on the facades of
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan’s commercial buildings and skyscrapers exemplifies terra-cotta’s ability to be
label: Paragraph

text: shaped and molded to fit the architect’s design. Because of the material’s malleability,
label: Paragraph

text: architects and designers for the terra-cotta manufacturer often cooperated to produce
label: Paragraph

text: beautiful systems of wall surfaces and ornament. By the 191 0s skyscrapers were soaring
label: Paragraph

text: to new heights, and terra-cotta was increasingly employed because of its many
label: Paragraph

text: ormmamental and constructional advantages. Both the Woolworth Building in New York,
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Cass Gilbert and completed in 1913, and Chicago’s Wrigley Building of
label: Paragraph

text: 1924, by Graham, Anderson, Probst, and White, are important examples of buildings
label: Paragraph

text: fully clad in terra-cotta.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early years, the finish color of terra-cotta depended on the color of the clay used.
label: Paragraph

text: Most terra-cotta manufactured in the United States was gray or buff in color to emulate
label: Paragraph

text: the stone it was meant to replace. During the early decades of the 20th century, terra-cotta
label: Paragraph

text: was accepted as a material in its own right, and its success depended less on its ability to
label: Paragraph

text: imitate other materials. At the same time, architects began to experiment with colored
label: Paragraph

text: glazes to provide another layer of detail to their designs.
label: Paragraph

text: Terra-cotta was adapted as the ideal material for the streamlined Art Deco and Art
label: Paragraph

text: Moderne styles that became popular after the 1925 Paris Exposition. Improvements in the
label: Paragraph

text: manufacture of terra-cotta resulted in the introduction of thinner panels that were lighter
label: Paragraph

text: in weight. Terra-cotta was easily molded into the geometric, stylized, and colorful
label: Paragraph

text: decorative elements that are found on a variety of small and large buildings from this era.
label: Paragraph

text: Terra-cotta can be found on myriad commercial structures, small apartment buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: automobile-related buildings such as garages and showrooms, and movie theaters dating
label: Paragraph

text: from the early decades of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Terra-cotta was replaced as a structural and as a decorative component by a material
label: Paragraph

text: that could be produced even less expensively: concrete. Reinforced concrete initially
label: Paragraph

text: provided the structural fireproofing capabilities of terra-cotta at a reduced price.
label: Paragraph

text: Eventually, concrete proved to be better suited to the unadorned architecture that became
label: Paragraph

text: popular at midcentury.
label: Paragraph

text: TERRAGNI, GIUSEPPE 1904-43
label: Title

text: Architect, Italy
label: Title

text: Giuseppe Terragni was among the most talented and esteemed of the Italian modernist
label: Paragraph

text: architects working in the period between the world wars. His Casa del Fascio (1936) in
label: Paragraph

text: Como is generally considered the emblematic modernist building to have been built
label: Paragraph

text: under the Fascist regime, and his Sant’Elia Nursery School (1937), also in Como, ranks
label: Paragraph

text: as a tour de force of modern European architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In December 1926 Terragni burst onto the Italian architectural scene with the first of
label: Paragraph

text: four magazine articles on which he collaborated with six of his contemporaries. These
label: Paragraph

text: essays, published in the esoteric and unillustrated magazine La Rassegna Italiana, \ater
label: Paragraph

text: came to be known as the “Rationalist Manifesto.” Terragni and his friends of the Gruppo
label: Paragraph

text: Sette (Group 7) argued in these essays against revivalism in Italian architecture and that
label: Paragraph

text: rationalism must shape all decisions about form, structure, and function. The avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: in Italy were henceforth known as the “rationalists.”
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s first major building was the Novocomum Apartment House (1927-29) in
label: Paragraph

text: Como. A controversial building from the moment of its unveiling, it was hailed as the
label: Paragraph

text: first rationalist work in Italy. Terragni went on to design a total of 26 built works and
label: Paragraph

text: numerous unbuilt projects in a 15-year career that was cut short by World War II.
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s undisputed masterpiece—the Casa del Fascio in Como (a local Fascist Party
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters that the architect named the “Glass House of Fascism”)—was begun in
label: Paragraph

text: 1932 and completed in 1936. The building is a prismatic exercise in modern geometric
label: Paragraph

text: form and structure, with four different facades that nevertheless together possess
label: Paragraph

text: compositional coherence and harmony. The building contains a two-story atrium space
label: Caption

text: encased by a system of clerestory windows, one of the first of its kind in Europe and an
label: Paragraph

text: influence on post-World War II atria. The play of transparency and opacity created by
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s use of materials (glass and marble, respectively) results in fascinating visual
label: Paragraph

text: contradictions. The building was initially condemned by the local Fascist Party chief as
label: Paragraph

text: being too ordinary for an important state edifice. To appease his critics, Terragni
label: Paragraph

text: employed an artist and industrial designer, Marcello Nizzoli, to develop a decorative
label: Paragraph

text: figural design scheme for the building facade. The ensuing panels were never added as
label: Paragraph

text: envisaged, however.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1936 Terragni had built five apartment houses in Milan (in collaboration with
label: Paragraph

text: Pietro Lingeri) and had gained recognition in the competition for the National Fascist
label: Paragraph

text: Party Headquarters (1934) in Rome. In 1937-38 he built several significant villas
label: Paragraph

text: including the Villa Bianca in Seveso and the Sant’Elia Nursery School in Como.
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s plan for the nursery school drew on a radical sense of interior transparency,
label: Paragraph

text: using glass partitions in the design of the flexible free plan derived from Le Corbusier.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1938 Terragni and Lingeri designed the Danteum project for Rome. The building
label: Paragraph

text: was to have been an exercise in the
label: Paragraph

text: Giuseppe Terragni, Casa del Fascio, Como, Italy (1936)
label: Caption

text: © Howard Davis/Greatbuildings.com
label: Caption

text: relation of architecture to literary and political themes, with its composition derived in
label: Paragraph

text: part from Dante’s Divine Comedy and its forms referencing the iconography of the
label: Paragraph

text: resurrected Roman Empire, which Benito Mussolini had declared after the Ethiopian War
label: Paragraph

text: (1935-41). With its thick marble walls and processional promenade, the Danteum
label: Paragraph

text: building previsioned much of the massive architecture of the postwar period.
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s last major work—the Casa Giuliani Frigerio Apartment House (1939-40) in
label: Paragraph

text: Como—was completed by his assistant, Luigi Zuccoli. It was realized when Terragni
label: Paragraph

text: (now serving in the Italian army) was on his way to the Russian front. At the battle of
label: Paragraph

text: Stalingrad, he suffered a nervous collapse, and after being returned to Italy in the winter
label: Paragraph

text: of 1943, he died in Como six days before the coup that deposed Mussolini.
label: Paragraph

text: THOMAS SCHUMACHER
label: Title

text: See also Fascist Architecture; Rome, Italy
label: Caption

text: Biography
label: Title

text: Born in Meda, Italy, 18 April 1904; moved to Como as a child. Attended Liceo
label: Paragraph

text: Scientifico in Como, graduated 1921; attended Politecnico di Milano, Facolta di
label: Paragraph

text: Architettura, 1921-26, degree granted 1926. Founding member, Gruppo 7 1926. Hired
label: Caption

text: Luigi Zuccoli as assistant 1927; formed partnership with Pietro Lingeri, 1933; the pair
label: Paragraph

text: worked together on competitions, five apart ment houses in Milan, and the Danteum
label: Paragraph

text: Project for Rome. Worked with brother Attilio, an engineer, on buildings in and around
label: Paragraph

text: Como, 1927-39. Participated in Palazzo Littorio competition, 1934, 1937; won second
label: Caption

text: prize in Palazzo dei Congressi competition, Rome 1939. Founder and editor, Valori
label: Caption

text: Primordiali 1937. Inducted into Italian army shortly after the start of World War I,
label: Paragraph

text: served in the Balkans and the USSR. Died of a brain embolism 19 July 1943. Rumors of
label: Paragraph

text: suicide have persisted until today, but have not been substantiated.

text: TERRAZZO
label: Title

text: One of the oldest types of flooring, terrazzo was developed by Venetians in the 16th
label: Paragraph

text: century and was popularized during the late 19th century. Modern terrazzo flooring is
label: Paragraph

text: composed of 70 percent marble or granite chips (or a combination of both) and 30
label: Paragraph

text: percent white, gray, or pigmented Portland cement. After curing, the surface is ground
label: Paragraph

text: smooth, giving the stone chips a polished surface. Terrazzo flooring is very durable and
label: Paragraph

text: can be arranged in decorative patterns. During the 1930s terrazzo was very popular for
label: Paragraph

text: commercial buildings, fitting in well with the Art Deco design then so popular. Public
label: Paragraph

text: and commercial buildings such as schools, banks, and hospitals and government
label: Paragraph

text: buildings such as post offices incorporate terrazzo into main corridors and lobby areas. A
label: Paragraph

text: special type of terrazzo flooring is used in hospital operating rooms.
label: Paragraph

text: Terrazzo flooring developed from the first “composition” floors developed by the
label: Paragraph

text: ancient Greeks. Over time the rubble and charcoal flooring was held together with
label: Paragraph

text: cement mortar and then developed into flooring of lava cement and charcoal set with
label: Paragraph

text: marble pieces in imitation of mosaic flooring. This type of flooring was often laid in
label: Paragraph

text: service areas and on terraces. The name terrazzo comes from the Italian word for
label: Paragraph

text: “terrace.”
label: Paragraph

text: In Venice, Italy, during the 1500s, a finely finished terrazzo flooring was developed
label: Paragraph

text: that consisted of the 70-30 marble-to-mortar binder still in use today. After placing the
label: Paragraph

text: marble chips in the binder matrix, the surface was polished smooth. This type of terrazzo
label: Paragraph

text: flooring became very popular for use in Italian villas. During the late 19th century,
label: Paragraph

text: travelers to Italy were impressed by the beauty and function of this flooring. Wealthy
label: Paragraph

text: travelers, on returning home from Italian excursions, had terrazzo flooring installed in the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance halls of their homes. The use of terrazzo in public buildings soon became
label: Paragraph

text: popular as well.
label: Paragraph

text: Because of terrazzo’s strength, durability, and potential to create decorative patterns
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of mosaic flooring, it became a popular flooring in public and commercial
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. In particular the use of a pigmented binding matrix made the flooring popular
label: Paragraph

text: during the Art Deco movement of the 1930s. It is most often used in the same locations
label: Paragraph

text: that stone flooring would be. Where appearance and durability are needed in high-traffic
label: Paragraph

text: areas, it is a cost-effective option. Most train stations, movie theaters, fire stations, city
label: Paragraph

text: and state offices, and schools built during the first third of the 20th century include
label: Paragraph

text: terrazzo flooring in high-traffic areas.
label: Caption

text: The original method for installing terrazzo flooring is cast-in-place. It ranges from 1/4
label: Paragraph

text: inch (6 mm) to 3 inches (72 mm) thick placed over a mortar bed or secured to the
label: Paragraph

text: substrate floor using direct bonding. A layer of sand 1/4 inch (6 mm) is used as a cushion
label: Paragraph

text: when structural movement is anticipated. The sand is covered with a waterproof paper
label: Paragraph

text: and wire mesh. A 2-1/8-inch (54 mm) concrete slab is poured over the sand. Divider
label: Paragraph

text: strips are embedded in the concrete with 5/8 inch (16 mm) left exposed. These divider
label: Paragraph

text: strips help control shrinkage and cracking and allow color changes. They also serve as a
label: Paragraph

text: guide for installing the topping. Bonded floors, used in areas where structural movement
label: Caption

text: is unlikely (such as corridors, walks, and swimming pool decks), have a total thickness of
label: Paragraph

text: 1-1/8 inches (29 mm). The base slab is coated with Portland cement to ensure a good
label: Paragraph

text: bond. The underbase is poured and divider strips are set before the topping is installed.
label: Paragraph

text: The terrazzo topping is installed by first coating the underbed with a layer of grout
label: Paragraph

text: matching the color of the binding matrix. The topping is placed using the divider strips as
label: Paragraph

text: guides. The topping is sprinkled with marble chips matching the color percentages of the
label: Paragraph

text: stone in the topping. Heavy rollers compact the topping until most of the water is
label: Paragraph

text: removed. The surface is then troweled until the divider strips are exposed. The floor must
label: Paragraph

text: cure for at least six days before grinding and polishing the surface smooth. After curing
label: Paragraph

text: and first grinding, a light application of grout cement is used to fill voids. The final
label: Paragraph

text: grinding levels the floor and exposes the 70 percent stone composition. The floor is then
label: Paragraph

text: cleaned, sealed, and machine buffed to reveal the color and luster of the marble.
label: Paragraph

text: Terrazzo floors can also be installed monolithically with the structural slab. Divider
label: Paragraph

text: strips are placed when the slab is poured and 5/8 inch (16 mm) is left for the terrazzo
label: Paragraph

text: topping. Curing, grinding, cleaning, sealing, and buffing follow the same procedure as
label: Paragraph

text: with bonded and sand-cushioned cast-in-place terrazzo.
label: Paragraph

text: Although modern terrazzo floors include a mixture of stones capable of taking a high
label: Paragraph

text: polish, terrazzo originally stuck to marble and granite chips. The advent of linoleum and
label: Paragraph

text: other durable flooring made the expense of quarrying stone for use in terrazzo, together
label: Paragraph

text: with the effect of terrazzo’s long curing time on tight construction schedules, less
label: Paragraph

text: desirable to architects and builders. Cheaper alternatives to both budget and schedule
label: Paragraph

text: caused terrazzo to fall out of popularity during the decades of the mid-20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Other disadvantages included the thickness (and thus weight) necessary for terrazzo
label: Paragraph

text: flooring, and the efforts necessary to prevent cracking as buildings shift and settle.
label: Paragraph

text: Developments Expand Terrazzo’s Options
label: Paragraph

text: Systems for applying thin-set terrazzo and precast terrazzo tiles and products have
label: Paragraph

text: reawakened an interest in terrazzo flooring. During the last decades of the 20th century,
label: Paragraph

text: terrazzo flooring in both commercial and residential settings gained popularity.
label: Paragraph

text: Thin-set terrazzo reduces the weight of traditional terrazzo by eliminating the
label: Paragraph

text: underbed. The topping, ranging from 1/4 to 5/8 inch (6 to 16 mm) thick, is bonded
label: Paragraph

text: directly to the structural slab. The matrix mix, which includes epoxies, polyesters, or
label: Paragraph

text: latex instead of Portland cement, adds to the adhesion of the topping and shortens the
label: Paragraph

text: curing time to as little as 24 hours. Divider strips are not necessary, except for color
label: Paragraph

text: changes and in locations where movement or stress is likely (such as around columns or
label: Paragraph

text: over beams).
label: Paragraph

text: Precast terrazzo tiles also open up options for terrazzo flooring; thus, its renewed
label: Paragraph

text: popularity. Precast tiles allow easy color changes and patterning and also include
label: Paragraph

text: additional uses for terrazzo, such as stair treads, risers, bases, and shower receptors.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonskid finishes are also available. Precast terrazzo products are bonded to surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: using epoxies and other adhesives as directed by the specific manufacturer.
label: Paragraph

text: Special-Use Terrazzo
label: Title

text: Conductive terrazzo is commonly used in hospital operating rooms. Acetylene carbon
label: Paragraph

text: black in the matrix binder as well as the underbed provides a path for electrical
label: Paragraph

text: conductivity. Static electricity between people and equipment is absorbed by the
label: Paragraph

text: acetylene carbon black. This type of terrazzo is also used in some laboratory settings.
label: Paragraph

text: Acrylic or vinyl emulsions may also be added to the matrix for thin-set terrazzo. These
label: Paragraph

text: emulsions increase allowable tensile and flexural stresses, allowing the terrazzo topping
label: Paragraph

text: to be decreased to as little as 1/4 inch (.6 cm). The Portland cement matrix can also be
label: Paragraph

text: replaced with a plastic matrix, thus expanding use options. Rustic or washed terrazzo
label: Paragraph

text: provides a pebbly finish rather than a smooth and polished finish. Marble, quartz, onyx,
label: Paragraph

text: and granite chips are used in a white or colored matrix. After curing, the floor is washed
label: Paragraph

text: with either water or acid to expose the stone chips, creating the pebble effect.
label: Paragraph

text: TESSENOW, HEINRICH 1876-1950
label: Title

text: Architect, Germany
label: Title

text: Heinrich Tessenow was born in Rostock in 1876. He was introduced to the art of
label: Paragraph

text: building by his father, a successful carpenter with whom he worked before studying at
label: Paragraph

text: the building schools in Neustadt and Leipzig. In 1900 he enrolled at the Technical
label: Paragraph

text: University in Munich, where he studied architecture under Friedrich von Thiersch.
label: Paragraph

text: However, he left the university after three semesters and joined the office of the
label: Paragraph

text: prominent Jugendstil architect Martin Dilfer. Tessenow also worked for Paul Schultze-
label: Paragraph

text: Naumburg.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the sporadic nature of his own education, Tessenow was an accomplished
label: Paragraph

text: teacher. After leaving Dilfer’s office in 1902, he accepted a position at the Building
label: Paragraph

text: School in Sternberg. He taught at the Building School in Liichow and the School of
label: Paragraph

text: Applied Arts in Trier before accepting a position at the Technical University in Dresden
label: Paragraph

text: as Diilfer’s assistant. From 1913 until 1919, he was a professor at the School of Applied
label: Paragraph

text: Arts in Vienna. In 1920 he taught at the Academy of Fine Arts in Dresden. In 1926 he
label: Paragraph

text: was selected by Bruno Paul to lead a master class at the School of Fine and Applied Arts
label: Paragraph

text: in Berlin. He held a concurrent professorship at the Technical University in the capital.
label: Paragraph

text: As an architect Tessenow was fascinated by the problems of mass housing. In 1903 he
label: Paragraph

text: had developed a housing type with roughcast walls, tiled roofs, and carefully detailed
label: Paragraph

text: woodwork that was evocative of traditional rural building. Tessenow’s aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: preferences were suggestive of the Heimatstil (vernacular style) advocated by his former
label: Paragraph

text: employer, Schultze-Naumburg. However, Tessenow’s residential designs, as exemplified
label: Paragraph

text: by projects such as his Workers Housing for the Electric Power Station in Trier of 1906,
label: Paragraph

text: were not merely copies of traditional rural buildings. His workers’ houses reflected a
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic balance between comfort and affordability. They were carefully designed to
label: Paragraph

text: encourage efficient lighting and ventilation and typically included sensible built-in
label: Paragraph

text: furnishings and a garden to provide for a measure of self-sufficiency. For Tessenow the
label: Paragraph

text: Heimatstil represented a vocabulary of architectural reform. This theme was conveyed in
label: Paragraph

text: his book Der Wohnungsbau (House Building), published in 1909.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1910 Tessenow designed his best-known project, the Dalcroze Institute for
label: Paragraph

text: Rhythmic Dance in the garden city of Hellerau near Dresden. This project, with its severe
label: Paragraph

text: and attenuated neoclassical forms and simple geometries, represented the translation of
label: Paragraph

text: the principles of formal abstraction that characterized his houses to a project of
label: Paragraph

text: substantial scale. The Dalcroze Institute also illustrated the increasing simplicity o
label: Paragraph

text: Tessenow’s projects, a tendency that was also apparent in the houses he designed for
label: Paragraph

text: Hellerau between 1910 and 1911. These small stucco houses combined his sensitive
label: Paragraph

text: detailing with creative features, such as the Patentwand system for the construction o
label: Paragraph

text: internally ventilated walls.
label: Caption

text: In 1916 Tessenow published Hausbau und Aergleichen (House Building and Such
label: Paragraph

text: Things), in which he reiterated his beliefs concerning industry, craft, and the design o
label: Paragraph

text: modern housing. Although he maintained his dedication to the precedent of vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: architecture throughout the years of the Weimar Republic, he was an active member o
label: Paragraph

text: the artistic avantgarde. In 1910 he had joined the Werkbund and in 1921 entered the
label: Paragraph

text: radical Novembergruppe, whose architectural section was directed by Ludwig Mies van
label: Paragraph

text: der Rohe. He was also one of the founding members of der Ring. His interest in social
label: Paragraph

text: progress extended to his own designs, in which he demonstrated an increasing concern
label: Paragraph

text: for the entire built environment, from furniture through urban planning. In 1925 he
label: Paragraph

text: designed a school at Klotzsche for the government of the land of Saxony, a regular,
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical composition of individual pavilions with pitched tile roofs arranged around
label: Paragraph

text: expansive courtyards. The plan reflected his theories of urban design, which were also
label: Paragraph

text: manifested in the residential developments that he composed. The individual building
label: Paragraph

text: masses at Klotzsche were stark and geometric, with Tessenow’s characteristic detailing
label: Paragraph

text: limited to the door and window surrounds. The same qualities were apparent in his
label: Paragraph

text: Heinrich-Schitz-Schule in Kassel of 1927. In Kassel, Tessenow dispensed with a pitched
label: Paragraph

text: roof and designed a loosely symmetrical composition in which the tradition of antique
label: Paragraph

text: typology was apparent only in the regular disposition of fenestration and the elegant
label: Paragraph

text: sense of proportion that pervaded the design.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1930 Tessenow’s design to rebuild Schinkel’s Neue Wache in Berlin as a memorial
label: Paragraph

text: to the fallen of World War | was selected in a competition over submissions by many of
label: Paragraph

text: Germany’s most successful architects, including Peter Behrens, Hans Poelzig, and Mies
label: Paragraph

text: van der Rohe. His plan was notable for its pervasive simplicity. The interior was a stark,
label: Paragraph

text: cubic volume lit by a circular oculus placed above a prismatic black stone supporting a
label: Paragraph

text: bronze wreath in commemoration of the dead. The exquisitely careful detailing of the
label: Paragraph

text: interior provided a counterpoint to its monumental severity. The drum of the oculus
label: Caption

text: maintained a subtle, elegant compound curve in its profile. A complex molding de-fined
label: Paragraph

text: the joint between the metal drum and the stucco ceiling. A similar molding elaborated the
label: Paragraph

text: joint between the ceiling and the stone veneer of the walls. Tessenow used these
label: Paragraph

text: abstracted classical details only where they were functionally justified by a change of
label: Paragraph

text: materials or methods of construction. The interface between the stone walls and the stone
label: Paragraph

text: pavement was a simple mortar joint. Tessenow’s new interior for the Neue Wache
label: Paragraph

text: represented a distillation of the neoclassical tradition to an essential form that existed in a
label: Paragraph

text: perfect accord with tectonic and functional requirements.
label: Paragraph

text: The nationalistic and racist promotion of the Heimatstil by Paul Schultze-Naumburg
label: Paragraph

text: and its subsequent association with the ideology of the Nazi government have until
label: Paragraph

text: recently relegated Tessenow to a position of relative insignificance in the standard
label: Paragraph

text: histories of 20th-century design. However, during his lifetime Tessenow was an
label: Paragraph

text: influential author and educator, and his theories were familiar throughout Germany. He
label: Paragraph

text: was one of the progenitors of the Modern movement. Throughout the first half of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century, his successful solutions to the problem of mass housing in Central Europe served
label: Paragraph

text: as a point of reference for subsequent experiments in the field, and his transformation of
label: Paragraph

text: the vocabulary of German neoclassicism as an example of the vitality of traditional forms
label: Paragraph

text: within the context of modern design.
label: Paragraph
