text: TESTA, CLORINDO 1923-
label: Title

text: Architect and painter, Argentina
label: Title

text: If one had to identify Le Corbusier’s counterpart in 20th-century Latin America,
label: Paragraph

text: Clorindo Testa, a major figure in Argentinean architecture in this period, would almost
label: Paragraph

text: certainly be the choice. He is not referred to here as a “disciple” or “follower,” but as a
label: Paragraph

text: similar personality in terms of his constant innovative and creative capacity, his dialectic
label: Paragraph

text: and changing relationship to the natural and urban surroundings, his passion for painting
label: Paragraph

text: and drawing, and his interpretation of society and history in his artistic production. He
label: Paragraph

text: was the son of an Italian immigrant residing in Argentina, who originated from the town
label: Paragraph

text: of Ceppaloni. He was born in Naples in 1923 and maintained a persistent emotional
label: Paragraph

text: relationship with Italy (in 1997 he was declared an honorary citizen of Ceppaloni) despite
label: Paragraph

text: his full identification with the city of Buenos Aires. He pursued a career in engineering,
label: Paragraph

text: but his artistic vocation (he started drawing at a very early age) led him to the College of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture and Urbanism, where he graduated in 1947. He worked for one year in the
label: Paragraph

text: Master Plan of the City of Buenos Aires (1948), where he met Ernesto N. Rogers, whose
label: Paragraph

text: criticism of the “rationalist” project for a collection of residences that was being built
label: Paragraph

text: definitively distanced him from the rigid designs of the Modern movement. With a
label: Paragraph

text: scholarship from the College of Architecture and Urbanism, he traveled to Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: extending his tour for almost three years (1949-52). He did not go to Paris, where Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier was based, nor did he accept Rogers’s offer to work in his Milan studio
label: Paragraph

text: (BBPR). Painting constituted his principal interest during that period, and he held his first
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition at the Van Riel Gallery on Florida Street, Buenos Aires (1952).
label: Caption

text: Associated with the architects Dabinovic, Rossi and Gaido, he obtained various prizes
label: Paragraph

text: in competitions for public and private works, such as the headquarters of the Argentinean
label: Paragraph

text: Chamber of Building Contractors (1952), a group of health centers in Misiones (1955),
label: Paragraph

text: and the Civic Center of Santa Rosa in the province of La Pampa (1956). This ensemble of
label: Paragraph

text: public buildings, which included the Government House, underwent various successive
label: Paragraph

text: stages in 1972 (Legislature) and in 1981 (Court and Cultural Center) which illustrate the
label: Paragraph

text: expressive changes in Testa’s language, from the Le Corbusier-inspired Brutalist
label: Paragraph

text: orthodoxy of exposed concrete and the transparent facades of the canopies to the free and
label: Paragraph

text: unprejudiced planimetric and volumetric composition of the 1980s decade,
label: Paragraph

text: foreshadowing the aesthetic values of “supermodernism.” From then on, he always
label: Paragraph

text: worked in teams of professionals from different generations, though his dominant
label: Paragraph

text: presence could still immediately be identified by the originality of the successive artistic
label: Paragraph

text: languages used. Two works reached international importance, identified as the expression
label: Paragraph

text: of Latin American creative freedom even by traditionalist critics such as Nikolaus
label: Paragraph

text: Pevsner: the Bank of London and South America Head Office (1959-66), in
label: Caption

text: collaboration with the SEPRA studio (an Argentinean version of the SOM) and the
label: Paragraph

text: National Library, a team project also involving Francisco Bullrich and Alicia Gazzaniga
label: Paragraph

text: (1962-95). Both buildings are configured by gigantic outer structures of reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete, a Jurassic exoskeleton according to Berkel and Bos. In the first he created an
label: Paragraph

text: expanded interior space with hanging trays suggesting an interaction between a Roman
label: Caption

text: cathedral and the dynamism of the Carceri de Piranesi. The library, suspended in air by a
label: Caption

text: base that includes a circulation system, substituted Borges’s labyrinth for the image of the
label: Paragraph

text: Tower of Babel, a metaphor for the integration of universal knowledge.
label: Paragraph

text: From the 1960s onward, Testa abandoned Brutalist language and the principle of the
label: Paragraph

text: autonomy of the “monument,” which still continues in the marine shapes of the Central
label: Paragraph

text: Naval Hospital (1970), in order to work with the multisignifying components of the urban
label: Paragraph

text: context. Both the Cultural Center of the City of Buenos Aires (with Jacques Bedel and
label: Paragraph

text: Luis Benedit 1979) and the Design Center in the Recoleta area (1990-93), integrate free
label: Paragraph

text: forms and a strong chromatism within the preexisting historical buildings, rescuing the
label: Paragraph

text: open and unprejudiced discourse of contemporaricity. Simultaneously he was able to
label: Paragraph

text: introduce in the shopping center’s configuration aesthetic attributes similar to those
label: Paragraph

text: existing in the neighboring Cultural Center. There emerges a constant assimilation of the
label: Paragraph

text: particular qualities of the surroundings that generate an architectural response, the
label: Paragraph

text: undulating coastal landscape of the seaside resort La Perla in Mar del Plata (1985-90) or
label: Paragraph

text: the mimesis with the neighborhood’s anonymity in the exterior treatment of the La Paz
label: Paragraph

text: Sgiar Auditorium (1995-96) in the city of Buenos Aires, whose artistic and spatial values
label: Paragraph

text: unfold in the interior areas.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1970s he reflected the dark social climate created in Argentina by the military
label: Paragraph

text: dictatorship and the increment in the contradictions inherent to modern urban life in a
label: Paragraph

text: series of paintings entitled “The Plague in the City” and “The Plague in Ceppaloni,”
label: Paragraph

text: dramatized by the obsessive use of black and white. In the 1980s chromatism appears in
label: Paragraph

text: the free forms that identify his artworks and architectural works. It is worth asserting that,
label: Paragraph

text: despite the spatial and formal control that Testa exerted on his large-scale works—he also
label: Paragraph

text: carried out urban projects through his participation in the competitions for Puerto Madero
label: Paragraph

text: (1992), Retiro (1996), and the Acropolis Museum in Athens (1992)—the enigma, the
label: Paragraph

text: humor, and the unpredictability of his artistic solutions also appear in his designs for
label: Paragraph

text: smaller residences. This is where architecture, painting, sculpture, and design are unified
label: Paragraph

text: in the freshness of an achieved poetic synthesis. The Capotesta houses (1983-85) and the
label: Paragraph

text: Altera art gallery in Pinamar and La Tumbona in Ostende (1985-87) surface as colorful
label: Paragraph

text: and geometric objets trouvés amid the marine scenery, characterized by the unexpected
label: Paragraph

text: volumetric “deconstruction” of the original cubic forms. The antithetical dialogue with
label: Paragraph

text: history reaches its maximum expression with the Ghirardo House in Martinez, Province
label: Paragraph

text: of Buenos Aires (1992), a Tudor mansion from the 1920s that is penetrated by colorful
label: Paragraph

text: metallic structures and internally hollowed out with diagonal sliding walls that greatly
label: Paragraph

text: modify the traditional structure of compartmentalized spaces. Testa thus shows that
label: Paragraph

text: individual creativity has no end and that the artist’s dialogue with his environment
label: Paragraph

text: implies a persistent rediscovery of the reality that daily surrounds him.
label: Paragraph

text: ROBERTO SEGRE
label: Title

text: See also Bank of London and South America, Buenos Aires; Brutalism; Buenos
label: Caption

text: Aires, Argentina; Corbusier, Le (Jeanneret, Charles Edouard) (France);
label: Paragraph

text: Deconstructivism; Supermodernism
label: Title

text: Biography
label: Title

text: His father, an Italian immigrant living in Argentina, decided that Clorindo had to be born
label: Paragraph

text: in Naples, (10 December 1923). Following the sentimental desire of his family, he never
label: Paragraph

text: became an Argentine citizen. He returned in 1924 to Buenos Aires where he lived all of
label: Paragraph

text: his life. After attempting to study naval engineering in La Plata and civil engineering in
label: Paragraph

text: Buenos Aires, he started to study architecture in 1942 at the University of Buenos Aires,
label: Paragraph

text: becoming an architect in 1947, and began to work in the Master Plan of Buenos Aires.
label: Paragraph

text: There he met Emesto N.Rogers, who had a strong influence on his architectural
label: Paragraph

text: development. With a fellowship from the School of Architecture, he traveled in Europe
label: Paragraph

text: between 1949 and 1952, devoting himself to painting more than architecture. As soon as
label: Paragraph

text: he returned to Buenos Aires, he began his professional career associated with Dabinovic,
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi and Gaido, and obtained the first prize for the Argentine in Chamber of Building
label: Paragraph

text: Contractors (1952) and the Civic Center (government building) of Santa Rosa, La Pampa
label: Paragraph

text: Province. Other buildings for this Center were designed in 1972 and 1981. In partnership
label: Paragraph

text: with the SEPRA office (Sanchez Elia, Peralta Ramos, Agostini), they won the first prize
label: Paragraph

text: for the construction of the Bank of London and South America Head Office in Buenos
label: Caption

text: Aires (1959-66). Immediately, associated with Bullrich and Gazzaniga, he obtained the
label: Paragraph

text: first prize in the competition for the National Library (1962), built between 1971 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1995. In the early 1970s, he built the Central Naval Hospital (1970-83). In this period, he
label: Paragraph

text: was mostly devoted to painting activities and obtained several prizes: Punta del Este
label: Paragraph

text: Bienal, Uruguay (with the Team 5) (1957), Torcuato di Tella International Prize (1961),
label: Caption

text: Second Latin America Kaiser Bienal, Cordoba (1965), Itamarati Mayor Prize at the XIV
label: Caption

text: Sao Paulo Bienal (1977), and the Trienal Prize “Architect of America,” by FAPA (1987).
label: Paragraph

text: In the last two decades he designed important buildings: Recoleta Cultural Center of the
label: Paragraph

text: City of Buenos Aires (1979-80); La Perla beach complex (Mar del Plata, 1985-90),
label: Caption

text: Buenos Aires Design Center (1990—93), and the Soka Gakkai International Auditorium in
label: Paragraph

text: Buenos Aires (1993-96), nominated in the final selection of the First Mies van der Rohe
label: Paragraph

text: Latin American Prize (1999). In 1976 he was included in the Buenos Aires Academy of
label: Paragraph

text: Fine Arts and received a Doctorate Honoris Causa at the University of Buenos Aires
label: Paragraph

text: (1992), and Honorary Professor at the Faculty of Architecture in Buenos Aires (1996).
label: Paragraph

text: His paintings were shown in museums and galleries throughout the world, and in 1999
label: Paragraph

text: the Museum of Fine Arts in Buenos Aires devoted a complete exhibition to his main
label: Paragraph

text: design production. In 2000 the Netherlands Institute of Architecture in Rotterdam
label: Paragraph

text: presented his architectural works in Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: THE ARCHITECTS COLLABORATIVE
label: Title

text: (TAC) (UNITED STATES)
label: Caption

text: Formed in December 1945 by Walter Gropius and a number of graduates from the
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard School of Design, The Architects Collaborative (TAC) was a firm whose output
label: Paragraph

text: reflected some of the most cherished and derided aspects of postwar architectural design.
label: Paragraph

text: TAC was a global firm, with offices and projects spanning the globe from Cambridge to
label: Paragraph

text: Baghdad, and its legacy is predicated primarily on three intertwined elements: the
label: Paragraph

text: collaborative and democratic principles that guided both the management of the firm and
label: Paragraph

text: its designs, the prestige associated with Gropius, and the tremendous range (and size) of
label: Paragraph

text: the firm’s work.
label: Paragraph

text: In the tradition of the Bauhaus, Gropius and the other architects at TAC worked in
label: Paragraph

text: collaborative groups headed by “job captains,” resisting the postwar trend toward
label: Paragraph

text: specialization and
label: Title

text: Harvard University Graduate Center, designed by Walter Gropius and TAC
label: Caption

text: © G.E.Kidder-Smith, Courtesty of Kidder Smith Collection, Rotch Visual
label: Caption

text: Collections, M.L.T.
label: Title

text: corporatization. Also in the Bauhaus tradition, the architects of TAC sought to align
label: Paragraph

text: architecture with the disciplines of art, economics, and sociology. This effort, in theory,
label: Paragraph

text: enabled architects to treat design as a social process, one responsive to the needs of
label: Paragraph

text: individual patrons and sites. In the firm’s later years, however, many critics argued that
label: Paragraph

text: TAC simply designed the same solution to any number of different architectural
label: Paragraph

text: problems, falling into a period of modernist repetition. Although TAC was founded on
label: Paragraph

text: the notion of challenging the professional tradition of highly individualized firms or
label: Paragraph

text: ateliers led by a single, famous master architect, in fact it was Gropius’s name that was
label: Paragraph

text: most often associated with the firm. If the anonymity behind the name The Architects
label: Paragraph

text: Collaborative was supposed to deemphasize Gropius’s role in the firm, it might have
label: Paragraph

text: instead helped to keep TAC’s other partners from sharing in both the praise and the
label: Paragraph

text: criticism leveled at the firm. TAC, at various points, included Jean Fletcher, Norman
label: Paragraph

text: Fletcher, John Harkness, Sarah Harkness, Robert McMillan, Louis McMillan, Benjamin
label: Caption

text: Thompson, Richard Brooker, Alex Cvijanovic, Herbert Gallagher, William Geddis,
label: Caption

text: Roland Kluver, Peter Morton, and H. Morse Payne, Jr., many of whom had attended the
label: Paragraph

text: Graduate School of Design at Harvard University during Gropius’s tenure there from
label: Paragraph

text: 1937 to 1953. In 1963 TAC legally incorporated, becoming TAC, Inc.
label: Paragraph

text: Important works from the firm’s early years include the Six Moon Hill development
label: Paragraph

text: (1948) in Lexington, Massachusetts. Eventually home to more than 30 families (and
label: Paragraph

text: seven of the eight partners in TAC at the time), Six Moon Hill was planned along the
label: Paragraph

text: standard (soon to become ubiquitous) suburban cul-de-sac road. However, the effort to
label: Paragraph

text: leave large spaces open for communal use and its equal division of land prices and lot
label: Paragraph

text: sizes make it an interesting early deviation from the broader trend of postwar suburban
label: Paragraph

text: development. Perhaps the most famous project from the first 15 years of its history was
label: Paragraph

text: TAC’s design for the Harvard Graduate Center (1949) in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
label: Paragraph

text: Located on a wedge-shaped lot near the northern edge of the Harvard University campus,
label: Paragraph

text: the Graduate Center exemplified Gropius’s (and, by extension, TAC’s) own ambivalent
label: Paragraph

text: feelings about the relationship between architecture and history. Although the Graduate
label: Paragraph

text: Center took on the traditional form of the Harvard Yard or academic quad, the
label: Paragraph

text: appearance of the individual buildings that made up the center seemed to have little to do
label: Paragraph

text: with their surroundings. Another relevant project from this period was the U.S. Embassy
label: Paragraph

text: (1956) in Athens, Greece, whose construction signaled the coming widescale adoption of
label: Paragraph

text: modernism as the symbol of post-World War Il American power and prosperity.
label: Paragraph

text: By the late 1950s, TAC had largely abandoned small-scale efforts along the lines of
label: Paragraph

text: Six Moon Hill. Instead the firm became increasingly involved with large corporate
label: Paragraph

text: commissions. The capitulation of social concerns to the requirements of the market-place
label: Paragraph

text: that such a move entailed are strikingly visible in the Pan Am Building (1963) in New
label: Paragraph

text: York City, designed in collaboration with Emery Roth and Sons and Pietro Belluschi.
label: Paragraph

text: With a record 2,350,000 square feet of rentable office space, 64 elevators, and 18
label: Paragraph

text: escalators, the building’s size seemed to obliterate the spaces around it. Responses to the
label: Paragraph

text: Pan Am Building were largely negative, and today it is for many an example of the worst
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of an overly programmatic and formal modernist tradition. Critics attacked the
label: Paragraph

text: building for destroying the historic vistas of Park Avenue and claimed that it destroyed
label: Paragraph

text: the silhouette of the New York Central Building (Warren and Wetmore, 1929), reducing
label: Paragraph

text: it to a mere shadow. Gropius seemed baffled by the criticism and responded that he
label: Paragraph

text: thought that the New York Central Building should be torn down to provide the Pan Am
label: Paragraph

text: Building with a proper forecourt. The public’s refusal to embrace the objective and
label: Paragraph

text: stylistically neutral design of the Pan Am Building puzzled Gropius, who seemed unable
label: Paragraph

text: to comprehend the attachment that New Yorkers felt for older urban forms and spaces, an
label: Paragraph

text: attachment that Gropius considered outdated and archaic.
label: Paragraph

text: Significant later commissions undertaken by TAC included the plan for Baghdad
label: Paragraph

text: University (1958) in Iraq, construction of which was often interrupted because of
label: Paragraph

text: political instability. The members of TAC had always considered involvement with
label: Paragraph

text: education one of the defining characteristics of the firm, arguing that sensitive design was
label: Paragraph

text: an integral element of the learning process. Efforts such as Baghdad University, however,
label: Paragraph

text: seemed at best a pale effort to incorporate faux regional design elements (in this case
label: Paragraph

text: Islamic ones) onto a standard steel-framed concrete box. Despite such missteps in 1964
label: Paragraph

text: TAC received the Firm Award of the American Institute of Architects (ALA). Eight years
label: Paragraph

text: later TAC designed the national headquarters of the AIA (Washington, D.C.). TAC also
label: Paragraph

text: contributed to the massive Boston development known as Government Center with the
label: Paragraph

text: design for the JFK Federal Office Building in 1968.
label: Caption

text: The demise of the firm was precipitated by the death of Gropius in 1969 and the rising
label: Paragraph

text: influence of Postmodernism in the architectural profession and among the public.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the reputation of TAC was still quite solid abroad (particularly in the Middle
label: Paragraph

text: East), in the last two decades of its existence the firm seemed to flounder without the
label: Paragraph

text: guiding and unifying influence of Gropius. Seemingly unable to adapt or respond to the
label: Paragraph

text: changing milieu of the architectural world, fewer commissions came to the firm, and for
label: Paragraph

text: financial reasons the doors finally closed at TAC in 1996.
label: Paragraph

text: TIMBER FRAME
label: Title

text: Timber framing, although largely outmoded by the beginning of the 20th century, not
label: Paragraph

text: only persevered in its centuries-old, low-technology form but developed as well into
label: Paragraph

text: high-technology structural systems. Aside from its universal aesthetic appeal, timber
label: Paragraph

text: construction—eclipsed by steel, concrete, and lightweight wood framing—maintained
label: Paragraph

text: interest among architects, owners, and builders because of its economy, durability, and
label: Paragraph

text: ecology.
label: Paragraph

text: In the United States, timber framing refers to traditional post-and-beam construction
label: Paragraph

text: (known as “heavy timber” at the industrial scale). Internationally, however, descriptions
label: Paragraph

text: of timber-frame buildings often include lightweight wood-stud construction. This
label: Paragraph

text: discussion considers only the heavier construction—whose columns are usually at least 8
label: Paragraph

text: inches by 8 inches, with beams no less than 6 inches by 10 inches—where significant
label: Paragraph

text: advances were made throughout the past 100 years.
label: Paragraph

text: In regions with ready access to timber, vernacular styles of framing with various in-fill
label: Paragraph

text: materials had become established over the centuries. In Europe and England, timber
label: Paragraph

text: frames with brick, rubble, or wattle-and-daub walls were ubiquitous. In North America
label: Paragraph

text: colonial buildings often were clad in wood as well as brick. In tropical Asia and the
label: Paragraph

text: Pacific islands, wood or other native materials served as sheathing. Japan and China had
label: Paragraph

text: long traditions of timber temples, palaces, and houses.
label: Paragraph

text: Architects of the 20th century working with timber frequently drew on those
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular references for their own work. At Hvittrask (1902) near Helsinki, Finland, a
label: Paragraph

text: housing-studio compound that Eliel Saarinen (1873-1950), Herman Gesellius (1874—
label: Paragraph

text: 1916), and Armas Lindgren (1874-1929) designed for their own use, the architects
label: Paragraph

text: adapted their country’s rustic tradition to create what became known as the National
label: Paragraph

text: Romantic style.
label: Paragraph

text: The English Arts and Crafts movement of the late 19th century continued to influence
label: Paragraph

text: architects well into the 20th century. Timber was just one of the natural materials used by
label: Paragraph

text: proponents of the movement. In the United States, California, with its abundance of
label: Paragraph

text: timber and increasing affluence, generated several timber styles. In the United States, the
label: Paragraph

text: brothers Charles Sumner Greene (1868-1957) and Henry Mather Greene (1870-1954)
label: Paragraph

text: ushered in a golden age of timber design with a widely admired series of houses near Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles. Influenced by Japanese and Swiss vernacular timber craft, their Gamble House
label: Paragraph

text: (1908) in Pasadena may have been the apotheosis of 20th-century timber houses. This
label: Paragraph

text: sprawling masterpiece revealed the architects’ obsessive attention to finishing each
label: Paragraph

text: exposed structural timber, articulating every handcrafted joint, and specifying the finest
label: Paragraph

text: wood finishes.
label: Paragraph

text: Many architects who worked mostly in other materials used timber to great effect in
label: Paragraph

text: combination with those materials. The San Francisco Bay Area’s most prominent
label: Paragraph

text: architect, Bernard Maybeck (1882-1957), accented the interior of the First Church of
label: Paragraph

text: Christ Scientist (1910) in Berkeley, California, with massive decorative timberwork; in
label: Paragraph

text: his own studio (1924) in Berkeley, the innovative Maybeck used timber framing but
label: Paragraph

text: added an experimental concrete finish.
label: Paragraph

text: In Europe, Austrian architect Adolf Loos (1870-1933) included exposed timber in his
label: Paragraph

text: Steiner House (1910) in Vienna and, more heavily, in the rustic Khuner Villa (1930) near
label: Paragraph

text: Payerback, Austria. The modernist Serge Chermayeff (1900-96) designed his house
label: Paragraph

text: Bentley Wood (1938) in Sussex, England, in timber and brick, an unusual choice for an
label: Paragraph

text: English country house at that time, which typically would have been all masonry.
label: Paragraph

text: Tree heights determined timber spans, and the largest timbers became scarcer as the
label: Paragraph

text: oldest trees were harvested. Even while steel and concrete increased in popularity, the
label: Paragraph

text: economy of wood—plentiful and easy to erect—encouraged technological development
label: Paragraph

text: of timber for increasingly demanding structural purposes. Maybeck had experimented
label: Paragraph

text: with a timber arch of smaller pieces of wood strapped together. However, not until
label: Paragraph

text: engineers applied the technology of plywood—an early 20th-century innovation whereby
label: Paragraph

text: wood veneers were glued together to form a monolithic panel—to heavy timbers did
label: Paragraph

text: wood become reestablished as a competitive structural component. Relatively small
label: Paragraph

text: sections of solid timber were laminated together with special glues into one large
label: Paragraph

text: structural member called a glu-lam (glued-laminated timber).
label: Paragraph

text: The economy of laminated timber widened its appeal during the Great Depression of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1930s. The shortage of steel for buildings during World War II further encouraged the
label: Paragraph

text: use of timber in structures such as hangars and other utilitarian buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Assembled for beauty as well as structural predictability, glulam beams, girders,
label: Paragraph

text: columns, and trusses began to appear prominently in low-rise, long-span structures, such
label: Paragraph

text: as buildings for worship, auditoriums, exhibition halls, sports arenas, and recreational
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. The fact that engineered timber could be prebent and custom shaped allowed
label: Paragraph

text: architects to create dramatic arches, domes, and organic sculptural effects beyond the
label: Paragraph

text: capabilities of natural timber. Later technologies introduced high-tech connectors to
label: Paragraph

text: enhance the wood’s strength.
label: Paragraph

text: In Japan, whose vernacular architecture inspired the Greene brothers and Frank Lloyd
label: Paragraph

text: Wright, among many others, architects after World War Il embraced concrete as their
label: Paragraph

text: material of choice, yet some evoked natural beauty with occasional spare, timber-frame
label: Paragraph

text: houses and other small structures. More ambitious was the elegantly spiraling timber-roof
label: Paragraph

text: structure of the Puppet Theater (1992) in Seiwa, Japan, by Katsuhiro Ishii (b. 1944).
label: Caption

text: In Finland, a land of ubiquitous timber resources, Heikki Siren (b. 1918) and Kaija
label: Paragraph

text: Siren (b. 1920) made their mark with the asymmetrical timber trusses at Otaniemi
label: Paragraph

text: Technical University Chapel (1959, burned 1975) near Helsinki. Other Finnish architects
label: Caption

text: experimented with multistory timber-frame apartment houses during the 1990s.
label: Paragraph

text: Architects who used the sculptural potential of laminated timber included the Hungarian
label: Paragraph

text: Imre Makovecz (b. 1935), whose organic buildings included the Farkasret funeral chapel
label: Paragraph

text: (1977) in Budapest.
label: Paragraph

text: Late-century forays with traditional framing into public spaces included Hugh Boyd’s
label: Paragraph

text: 37,000-square-foot Public Market (1998) in Portland, Maine, whose concrete columns
label: Caption

text: carry the largest traditional timber roof in New England. The natural
label: Paragraph

text: Sea Ranch Condominium, Sea Ranch, California (1964-65), designed by
label: Caption

text: MLTW (Moore, Lyndon, Turnbull and Whitaker)
label: Caption

text: © GreatBuildings.com
label: Title

text: timber beams span up to 40 feet in length. In contrast, the new Globe Theatre (1998) in
label: Paragraph

text: London re-created the mortise-and-tenon oak timber craft of Shakespearean England, but
label: Paragraph

text: this time around the wood cladding was treated for fire resistance.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1990s European researchers pioneered the use of timber for new
label: Paragraph

text: commercial buildings and multistory apartment houses. The British group Timber
label: Paragraph

text: Research and Development Associates (TRADA) notably included a six-story timber
label: Paragraph

text: structure (1997) in a testing facility alongside concrete-and-steel structures. Such
label: Paragraph

text: experiments promised a future for timber framing in building types where fire or
label: Paragraph

text: structural limitations typically limited its use.
label: Paragraph

text: During the last quarter of the century, producers in the United States of off-the-shelf
label: Paragraph

text: timber components and designs developed a healthy market for “do-it-yourself” timber-
label: Paragraph

text: frame house kits and even rustic log homes. The affordable option of a timber-frame
label: Paragraph

text: house enhanced the awareness of this traditional construction type among the general
label: Paragraph

text: public.
label: Paragraph

text: By century’s end the conversion of heavy-timber warehouses and other industrial
label: Paragraph

text: buildings to new uses had become routine in many cities. The resulting lofts with offices,
label: Paragraph

text: residential spaces, entertainment venues, and shopping malls popularized a timber-and-
label: Paragraph

text: masonry aesthetic among urban residents, businesses, and tourists in search of open,
label: Paragraph

text: flexible spaces with a historic character. These recycled buildings also won favor with
label: Paragraph

text: proponents of sustainable architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: With the focus on sustainable environments and renewable resources, new timber
label: Paragraph

text: construction qualified as alternative, so-called “green” architecture, as long as the
label: Paragraph

text: material was harvested from carefully managed forests. While environmental crusades
label: Paragraph

text: curbed the use of old-growth timber from dwindling ancient forests, ecologically
label: Paragraph

text: conscious architects and builders turned to timber from managed sources.
label: Paragraph

text: By the end of the century, traditional timber was used in combination with efficient
label: Paragraph

text: new building materials, such as structural insulated panels, and even in composite
label: Paragraph

text: applications where steel or concrete was integrated with the wood structure.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: TOKYO, JAPAN
label: Title

text: In the course of only one century, Tokyo has evolved from a city trying to imitate
label: Paragraph

text: Western centers to a major metropolis and a center of high-quality architecture. The
label: Paragraph

text: architectural design work and the theories of contemporary Japanese architects, most of
label: Paragraph

text: them based in Tokyo, have found interest worldwide. Their projects often reflect the
label: Paragraph

text: specific architecture and context of Japanese cities, particularly its capital.
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo’s urban landscape is characterized by a juxtaposition of high-rise modern
label: Paragraph

text: business districts and high-density, mixed-function neighborhoods composed mainly of
label: Paragraph

text: wooden single-family buildings, resembling Asian more than European cities. The
label: Paragraph

text: nongeometric organization, the multitude of centers, and the cellular addition of
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods have been handed down from Edo, as the city was called before the Meiji
label: Paragraph

text: Restoration of 1868. The urban layout of the Edo period—its patchwork of extended
label: Paragraph

text: areas for the warrior class on the yamanote highlands and the low-lying shitamachi areas,
label: Paragraph

text: which housed the ordinary people—provided an ideal background for the integration of
label: Paragraph

text: new functions related to the modernization of the country. The spacious lots and extended
label: Paragraph

text: green spaces of the daimyo areas permitted the realization of large-scale developments
label: Paragraph

text: and buildings, such as the government area at Hibiya and the Marunouchi district in the
label: Paragraph

text: vicinity of the Imperial Palace and Fumihiko Maki’s comprehensive design of Hillside
label: Paragraph

text: Terrace (1969-92).
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast to European cities, where buildings often define public places, the liveliest
label: Paragraph

text: spaces in Tokyo are not given particular architectural form. Infrastructure nodes, such as
label: Paragraph

text: Shibuya or Ikebukuro on the Yamanote railway ring, are social spaces characterized by a
label: Paragraph

text: maze of billboards, huge screens, multilevel infrastructure, and a large variety of
label: Paragraph

text: commercial buildings. Buildings of different scale, height, and age, designed without any
label: Paragraph

text: concern for aesthetic unity, stand next to one another. The 109 Building (1978) by
label: Caption

text: Minoru Takeyama, with its tall, aluminum-clad tower, exemplifies commercial
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in Tokyo. A marker in the billboard environment, its facade and layout had
label: Paragraph

text: to take into account a small wooden restaurant because its owner did not want to sell.
label: Paragraph

text: The absence of aesthetic and height control in Tokyo buildings is not a recent
label: Paragraph

text: development. In 1937, Bruno Taut, in his Houses and People of Japan, criticized the
label: Paragraph

text: chaos of forms and styles, and other westerners have done the same. Recently, this
label: Paragraph

text: attitude has started to change: Yoshinobu Ashihara and other writers view Tokyo as the
label: Paragraph

text: urban model for the 21st century, considering the city as the evocation of such recent
label: Paragraph

text: ideas as chaos theory. Tokyo’s architects have made the chaotic urban landscape a central
label: Paragraph

text: design theme. Maki’s Spiral Building (1985), with its collaged and fragmented facade,
label: Paragraph

text: reflects this, as does Kazuo Shinohara’s Centennial Hall (1987) for the Tokyo Institute of
label: Paragraph

text: Technology.
label: Paragraph

text: The reasons for the chaotic appearance of Tokyo are manifold. Tokyo, a wooden city,
label: Paragraph

text: has been destroyed by fires and earthquakes regularly. In the 20th century alone, the city
label: Paragraph

text: saw devastation twice in the Great Kanto Earthquake (1923) and the large-scale bombing
label: Paragraph

text: in World War IL The city has a tradition of rebuilding, and few old constructions remain.
label: Paragraph

text: Buildings of the Meiji period (1868-1912) are becoming rare, and major works of
label: Paragraph

text: postwar modern architecture, including Kenzo Tange’s Tokyo City Hall (1957) and
label: Paragraph

text: Kunio Maekawa’s Harumi Apartments (1958), have been demolished. Even Toyo Ito’s
label: Paragraph

text: well-published Nomad Restaurant (1986) disappeared as early as 1990. The permanent
label: Paragraph

text: threat of another major earthquake, the need to meet recently enacted legal requirements,
label: Paragraph

text: and high land prices that dwarf construction costs further explain the relative freedom of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Early Meiji Architecture
label: Title

text: When Japan opened its gates to the outside world, it did not have a tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: monumental public architecture, vistas, and high-rise landmarks comparable with that of
label: Paragraph

text: major European metropolises. The traditional Japanese prints (ukiyo-e) show that natural
label: Paragraph

text: features in the city’s vicinity, such as Mount Fuji, gave a feeling of place. Furthermore,
label: Paragraph

text: the city did not have a monumental public core: the center was and is occupied by the
label: Paragraph

text: Imperial Palace and its huge gardens, which are closed to the public.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early Meiji period, under the influence of the government, Tokyo became the
label: Paragraph

text: showcase for the rapid transformation of Japan. The Tsukiji Hotel (1868) and the first
label: Paragraph

text: Mitsui Bank (1872) by Kisuke Shimizu II illustrate early Meiji attempts to adopt Western
label: Paragraph

text: (European and American) forms. They were crowned by towers (novelties in Japan) but
label: Paragraph

text: were not part of the cityscape in the same way as their European counterparts. The
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were separated from public space through gates and walls, as in traditional
label: Paragraph

text: daimyo residences. It took years until Japanese architects started to use buildings as
label: Paragraph

text: public monuments. Even now, vertical markers, such as the Tokyo Tower (1958), do not
label: Paragraph

text: have the same symbolic value as their Western models. The creation of landmark
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in Tokyo remains an important topic, taken up particularly by Maki.
label: Paragraph

text: Foreign architects, surveyors, or amateurs created many of the early Meiji buildings:
label: Paragraph

text: an Englishman, Thomas Waters, designed the urban outlay and the brick buildings of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ginza after a fire in 1872. The Berlin office of Béckmann and Ende projected the
label: Paragraph

text: Ministry of Justice (1895) and Supreme Court (1896) buildings. A central figure among
label: Paragraph

text: these foreigners was the English architect Josiah Conder (1852-1920). Author o
label: Paragraph

text: numerous important buildings, including the Rokumeikan (1883), a government guest
label: Paragraph

text: house, he was also a professor at the newly founded Tokyo Imperial University,
label: Paragraph

text: predecessor of the University of Tokyo, where he introduced Western educationa
label: Paragraph

text: concepts.
label: Paragraph

text: The first generation of Japanese architects in Tokyo, many of whom had studied with
label: Paragraph

text: Conder, realized a number of eclectic buildings that include Kingo Tatsuno’s Bank o
label: Paragraph

text: Japan (1896) and his Tokyo Station (1914) as well as the Akasaka Detached Palace
label: Paragraph

text: (1909) by Tokuma Katayama and the Hyokeikan Museum (1909) in Ueno. By the end o
label: Caption

text: the Meiji period, after two victorious wars, Japan had established itself as a powerful
label: Paragraph

text: modern state, and Tokyo’s architecture was exported to the colonies.
label: Paragraph

text: The most recent architectural styles were adopted quickly in Tokyo and other Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: cities, as the country strove for international recognition. In contrast to colonial
label: Paragraph

text: situations, tra-ditional forms were not suppressed. When the need arose in Nara to
label: Paragraph

text: integrate new large-scale buildings into a traditional setting, a modern Japanese style
label: Paragraph

text: developed that combined the new scale and function with traditional forms and an overal.
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese look, particularly in the design of the roof and the entrance space. This modern
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese style quickly spread to Tokyo. The memorial (1930) for the victims of the 1923
label: Paragraph

text: earthquake in the form of a pagoda by Chuta Ito and the New Kabuki Theater (1924) by
label: Caption

text: Shinichiro Okada exemplify the combination of new building techniques and materials
label: Paragraph

text: with traditional forms. Other examples show the adoption of Western style in the facade
label: Paragraph

text: and the business spaces and the maintenance of traditional spaces for the living areas.
label: Paragraph

text: The least Western influence occurred in the field of urban planning, as the strong
label: Paragraph

text: attachment to the land and the scattered character of land ownership hindered
label: Paragraph

text: redevelopment.
label: Paragraph

text: “Modern Style” Architecture in Japan
label: Title

text: The start of modern architecture in Japan largely coincided with the presence of Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd Wright and the construction of the Imperial Hotel (1923-69, dismantled} in Tokyo,
label: Caption

text: one of the city’s best-known buildings because of its size and the name of its architect.
label: Paragraph

text: The fact that it withstood the Great Kanto Earthquake on the day of its opening further
label: Paragraph

text: contributed to its fame, even though the “Marubiru” office building (1923), built by the
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller Company in the Marunouchi district, and other major constructions also withstood
label: Paragraph

text: the quake. Modern architecture was still rare in Japan at that time, and some of the
label: Paragraph

text: earliest works, including the Reinanzaka House (1923-24) in Azabu, were produced by
label: Paragraph

text: Antonin Raymond, a former collaborator with Wright at the Imperial Hotel.
label: Paragraph

text: The rapid reconstruction after the 1923 earthquake reinforced the functionalist trends:
label: Paragraph

text: street widening and replotting took precedence over urban design, and modernist
label: Paragraph

text: principles were used for public buildings. Examples are Tetsuro Yoshida’s Tokyo Central
label: Paragraph

text: Post Office (1927-31) and several public schools designed by the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: department of the Tokyo Municipality, including the Yotsuya Fifth Primary School
label: Paragraph

text: (1934) and the Takanawadai Primary School (1935). Social housing became another field
label: Paragraph

text: for rationalist design. A nonprofit government foundation, the Dojunkai, was created in
label: Paragraph

text: 1924 to provide temporary structures for quake relief. It continued to function afterward
label: Paragraph

text: and provided the city with 2501 ferroconcrete apartment units in 15 new developments
label: Paragraph

text: between 1926 and 1933. The Aoyama apartments (1926) and some others remain
label: Paragraph

text: functional today. Many, including the Daikanyama complex (1926), have been
label: Paragraph

text: demolished for higher-density reconstruction.
label: Caption

text: Many Japanese architects of the 1910s and 1920s were influenced by German
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism and the Viennese Secession. Kikuji Ishimoto’s Secessionist-style Asahi
label: Paragraph

text: Newspaper Offices (1927) at Sukiyabashi was demolished, but Shozo Uchida’s Yasuda
label: Paragraph

text: Hall (1925) at the Imperial University of Tokyo, Hongo, survives as a good example of
label: Paragraph

text: the North German Expressionist inspiration. The Secessionist Architectural Society
label: Paragraph

text: (Bunri Ha Kenchiku Kai; 1920-28), founded by six Japanese architects, was a cradle for
label: Paragraph

text: modernist architecture. Two of its members, Sutemi Horiguchi and Mamoru Yamada,
label: Paragraph

text: later became major representatives of the International Style. Horiguchi was
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged particularly for the Okada Residence (1934), which elegantly integrates
label: Paragraph

text: traditional Japanese elements and modern Western concepts. Yamada, author of the
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist Central Telegraph Office (1925), was the only Japanese architect to have a
label: Paragraph

text: building—the Electrical Laboratory (1930)—included in the 1932 International Style
label: Caption

text: exhibition of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, marking the entry of Japanese
label: Caption

text: modern architecture on the global scene. Both returned to more traditional forms later, as
label: Paragraph

text: shown in Horiguchi’s Sukiya-style teahouse (1965) in the Minato ward and Yamada’s
label: Paragraph

text: Nippon Budokan (1964), a hall for judo competition with an octagonal pyramidal roof
label: Paragraph

text: that reinterprets traditional Japanese forms.
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo’s architects had intimate contacts with leading modernist designers abroad.
label: Paragraph

text: Kikuji Ishimoto, a student of Walter Gropius, produced the Shirokiya Department Store
label: Paragraph

text: (1931) and the Tokyo Airport Office (1932), which reflect his knowledge of works by
label: Paragraph

text: Erich Mendelsohn and the Bauhaus. Bunzo Yamaguchi worked with Gropius between
label: Paragraph

text: 1930 and 1932 and, after his Expressionist phase, produced several modernist works in
label: Paragraph

text: the Tokyo area, such as the Yamada House (1934) in KitaKamakura, the Nihon Dental
label: Paragraph

text: College Hospital (1934), and the Bancho Siedlung (1933), which recalls the
label: Paragraph

text: Weissenhofsiedlung (1927). Junzo Sakakura and Kunio Maekawa, who studied with Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier, also realized major works in Tokyo.
label: Paragraph

text: In the mid-1930s, the so-called Imperial Crown style (teikan yoshiki) became the
label: Paragraph

text: symbol of Japanese nationalism. The term was developed in the context of the
label: Paragraph

text: competition for the Imperial Diet Building (1917-19). Although the prize-winning entry
label: Paragraph

text: was not realized, the term relates to buildings that feature huge Japanese-style roofs, such
label: Paragraph

text: as Ryoichi Kawamoto’s Soldiers’ Hall (1934) and Hitoshi (Jin) Watanabe’s Imperial
label: Paragraph

text: Museum (1937) in Ueno and Dai-ichi Seimei Building (1938), used as general
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters of the American command after World War IL.
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture in Tokyo after World War LL
label: Title

text: Tokyo suffered major destruction in the Allied bombings, particularly through fire:
label: Paragraph

text: 92,778 persons were killed, 129,300 were injured, and 850,000 lost their homes. The
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction of the capital symbolized Japan’s renewal and revival and was expressed
label: Paragraph

text: in modernist architecture. Raymond’s Reader’s Digest Building (1951, demolished 1964)
label: Caption

text: and Sakakura’s Prefectural Museum of Modern Art (1951, addition 1966) in Kamakura
label: Caption

text: are major examples. However, the main figures of postwar reconstruction were Tange
label: Paragraph

text: and Maekawa.
label: Paragraph

text: Tange, who had won international recognition with his Hiroshima Peace Center,
label: Paragraph

text: designed major buildings in Tokyo, including the Tokyo City Hall (1957) and the Tokyo
label: Paragraph

text: Metropolitan Government Building (1991) in Shinjuku. His Olympic Stadiums (1964),
label: Paragraph

text: with their suspended roofs, have landmark character and symbolize the major urban
label: Paragraph

text: transformations of that period.
label: Paragraph

text: Maekawa authored several buildings in Tokyo’s Ueno Park, including the Metropolitan
label: Paragraph

text: Festival Hall (1961), a huge cultural center with a powerful protruding roof of exposed
label: Paragraph

text: concrete; the Tokyo Municipal Museum of Art (1975); and the addition to Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Western Art (1979). Other architects of roughly the same generation who
label: Paragraph

text: were influential and revered designers and teachers in Tokyo are Isoya Yoshida, Yoshiro
label: Paragraph

text: Tani-
label: Title

text: Tokyo City Hall (1957) Shinjuku district, by Kenzo Tange
label: Caption

text: © Michael S.Yamashita/CORBIS
label: Caption

text: guchi, Hiroshi Oe, and Togo Murano. Their works drew on a larger range of historical
label: Paragraph

text: and modern forms and have still to be fully acknowledged in the West.
label: Paragraph

text: The economic boom of the 1960s provoked rapid urbanization and overcrowding in
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo and other Japanese cities. Confronted with the scarcity of land and carried by their
label: Paragraph

text: belief in continuing technical and economic development, several visionary projects for
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo were developed that suggested extension onto the sea and into the air. Tange’s
label: Paragraph

text: project for a city axis (1960) extending over Tokyo Bay reflected visionary ideas
label: Paragraph

text: sketched by Kiyonori Kikutake as early as 1958. Several young designers, some of whom
label: Paragraph

text: had been working on the Tange project, took up these ideas, designing megastructures
label: Paragraph

text: such as Arata Isozaki’s Sky Cities (1961 and 1962), Kisho Kurokawa’s Helix City Plan
label: Paragraph

text: (1961), and Kikutake’s Ocean City (1961) and Marine City (1963). These projects were
label: Paragraph

text: often presented as suggestions for Tokyo, thereby further promoting the capital. Its name
label: Paragraph

text: was already connected to the emergence of the Metabolist movement at the World
label: Paragraph

text: Design Conference of 1960.
label: Paragraph

text: Several buildings reflecting Metabolist ideas were realized in Tokyo, including the
label: Paragraph

text: Shizuoka Press and Broadcasting Center (1966-67) by Tange, the Nakagin Capsule
label: Caption

text: Building (1972) by Kurokawa, and later, Kikutake’s Edo-Tokyo Museum (1992). No
label: Paragraph

text: visionary cities were realized, but they prefigured and paralleled major transformations of
label: Paragraph

text: the city at that time: the construction of huge highways and high-speed trains, land
label: Paragraph

text: reclamation and the extension of the city on artificial islands, and the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: huge underground passageways and structures, particularly around the stations, are the
label: Paragraph

text: real megastructures of the city. However, the design of these developments was in the
label: Paragraph

text: hands mainly of the major construction companies rather than the visionary architects.
label: Paragraph

text: The concentration of people and economy in the large centers was reinforced when the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional height limitation of 31 meters was replaced by a system of floor ratio in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1961 Building Standards Law. The first skyscraper, the 36-floor Kasumigaseki Building
label: Caption

text: by Yamashita architects and engineers, was completed in 1968. Further skyscrapers rose
label: Paragraph

text: in the Shinjuku subcenter on the site of a former water purification plant to the west of
label: Paragraph

text: the station on the Yamanote railway. Based on a development plan from 1960, a
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper district came into existence, starting with the Keio Plaza Hotel (1971). Major
label: Paragraph

text: buildings are the NSBuilding (1982) by Nikken Sekkei and the Postmodern Tokyo
label: Paragraph

text: Metropolitan Government Building (1991) by Tange, which displays two cathedral-like
label: Paragraph

text: towers and a huge public plaza embraced by wing buildings and the assembly hall.
label: Paragraph

text: The most pressing issue for the steadily growing city remained housing. Various
label: Paragraph

text: policies for decentralization were instigated that led to the creation of new towns, such as
label: Paragraph

text: the research and university city of Tsukuba outside Tokyo, known for its Center Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1983) designed by Arata Isozaki. The creation of Tama New Town to the west of Tokyo
label: Paragraph

text: included the relocation of the Tokyo Metropolitan University, which features several
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernist buildings (1991) by Tetichi Takahashi and DaiichiKobo.
label: Caption

text: The negative effects of economic development, including the chaotic landscape of
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese cities, became obvious in the 1970s, and contemporary architecture responded
label: Paragraph

text: to this environment in various ways. Toyo Ito’s U-shaped House (1976) in Nakano
label: Paragraph

text: Honcho and Kikoo Mozuna’s Mirror Image Hall (1980) mark an introverted attitude,
label: Paragraph

text: concentrating on the interior space and turning nearly closed facades to the outside.
label: Paragraph

text: Kazuhiro Ishii’s House of 54 Windows (1975) and Takefumi Aida’s Toy Bloc Houses of
label: Paragraph

text: the early 1980s show a more playful response.
label: Paragraph

text: High real estate prices and limited sites made it increasingly difficult for people to live
label: Paragraph

text: in the city. Takamitsu Azuma’s Tower House (1967) expresses the difficulties of inner-
label: Paragraph

text: city private housing: on a basic floor space of 10 square meters, it offers an overall living
label: Paragraph

text: space of 60 square meters. The lack of buildable land brought about inspiring projects for
label: Paragraph

text: housing several generations of one family on the same site. Tadao Ando’s Kidosaki
label: Paragraph

text: House (1986) and Riken Yamamoto’s Hamlet (1988) demonstrate the possibility of
label: Paragraph

text: housing three generations in one building complex. Kazuo Shinohara’s House under High
label: Caption

text: Voltage Lines (1981) expresses the necessity to use every single site in densely built
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo, and Kunihiko Hayakawa’s Yoga-A-Flat (1993) addresses the growing diversity
label: Paragraph

text: of housing needs. Recent smallscale projects, such as Shigeru Ban’s Curtain Wall House
label: Paragraph

text: (1995) and Itsuko Hasegawa’s Sumida Culture Factory (1995), illustrate the growing
label: Paragraph

text: understanding of Tokyo’s neighborhoods as a positive life environment.
label: Paragraph

text: The land boom of the 1980s paved the ground for expensive and eccentric structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Shin Takamatsu’s machinelike Ima-
label: Title

text: Asahi Beer Hall and Brewery (1989), designed by Philippe Starck
label: Caption

text: © Angelo Hornak/CORBIS
label: Caption

text: nishi Motoakasaka Building (1992) and his mainly subterranean Earthtecture (1990),
label: Paragraph

text: Atsushi Kitagawara’s theatrical Rise Cinema Complex (1986), Makoto Sei Watanabe’s
label: Paragraph

text: Aoyama Technical College (1990), Itsuko Hasegawa’s futuristic and vernacular design of
label: Paragraph

text: the Shonandai Cultural Center (1991), and the commercial Collezione (1990) of the
label: Paragraph

text: Osaka-based architect Tadao Ando became possible during this period. Young emerging
label: Paragraph

text: architects of the 1990s were given chances to prove themselves in small-scale structures,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Kazuyo Sejima’s Chofu police station (1994). Simultaneously, international
label: Paragraph

text: architects, including Mario Bellini, Mario Botta, Branson Coates, Peter Eisenman,
label: Paragraph

text: Norman Foster, Steven Holl, Richard Rogers, and Aldo Rossi, were called on to create
label: Paragraph

text: landmark buildings, with Philippe Starck’s Asahi Beer Hall (1989) being the most
label: Paragraph

text: visible. The list of Tokyo’s grand projects is crowned by Rafael Vifioly’s Tokyo
label: Paragraph

text: International Forum (1996), one of the unique designs in Japan to result from an
label: Paragraph

text: international competition.
label: Paragraph

text: When the economic boom ended, the construction of many large-scale projects was
label: Paragraph

text: postponed or abandoned. The 1996 Tokyo Frontier World Cities Expo, which was
label: Paragraph

text: supposed to explore possibilities for the city of the 21st century, was ultimately canceled.
label: Paragraph

text: In the same waterfront area, the smaller-scale Tokyo Teleport Town, initiated in 1987 as
label: Paragraph

text: a new subcenter, is taking shape in reduced form. Tange’s Fuji Television Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1997) is one of its most visible markers. The Tokyo waterfront project faces competition
label: Paragraph

text: from two other major developments on the waterfront of Tokyo Bay: Yokohama started
label: Paragraph

text: to build Minato Mirai 21 in 1985, and Chiba is developing Makuhari New Town, which
label: Paragraph

text: features a housing development characterized by strict planning legislation, a rarity in
label: Paragraph

text: Japan.
label: Paragraph

text: Some large-scale interventions have been carried out despite the recession, such as the
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo University Komaba Campus redevelopment (1999) by Hiroshi Hara. Further
label: Caption

text: development proposals and futuristic plans are projected for Tokyo, such as sky cities and
label: Paragraph

text: developments in Tokyo Bay, by Kisho Kurokawa, Shin Takamatsu, and the Shimizu and
label: Paragraph

text: Takenaka corporations. At the dawn of the 21st century, discussion about relocating the
label: Paragraph

text: capital city continues.
label: Paragraph

text: Further Reading
label: Title

text: Few books discuss solely the architectural history of Tokyo. Most publications on Japan,
label: Paragraph

text: however, give a major space to the capital city. Stewart provides the most comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: account of modern architecture in Tokyo from the Meiji period to the present. The studies
label: Paragraph

text: by Fujimori and Inagaki limit themselves to the period from Meiji to 1945. The work by
label: Paragraph

text: Suzuki, Banham, and Kobayashi is a richly illustrated overview of contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in Japan from the postwar period to the 1980s. Bognar discusses the 1980s
label: Paragraph

text: and 1990s in particular. Yatsuka examines Japanese architectural history in its
label: Paragraph

text: international context.

text: TORONTO CITY HALL
label: Title

text: Designed by Viljo Revell, completed 1965 Toronto, Ontario
label: Caption

text: In November 1961 sod was first turned to construct a new city hall, the design of Viljo
label: Paragraph

text: Revell (1910-64) and the result of the most significant architectural competition in
label: Paragraph

text: Canadian history. Revell did not live to see his design completed, but its impact continues
label: Paragraph

text: to shape the evolving character of the city of Toronto to this day. In its evocative fusion
label: Paragraph

text: of the unfettered reexamination of function and material characteristic of the International
label: Paragraph

text: Style, with a poised expressionism capable of imparting symbolic presence, New City
label: Paragraph

text: Hall dramatically broadened the resonant potential of modern architecture to its citizenry.
label: Paragraph

text: Even more, the design for its accompanying civic square provided Torontonians with a
label: Paragraph

text: new paradigm for both inhabiting and imagining their unfolding city.
label: Paragraph

text: The apparent origin of this fortuitous event lay in a proposal submitted to the city in
label: Paragraph

text: 1911. John Lyle, a local architect who had trained at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts,
label: Caption

text: envisioned a City Beautiful scheme that included a civic square adjacent to E.J.Lennox’s
label: Paragraph

text: Richardsonian Romanesque city hall (1899). Subsequent proposals for this site followed
label: Paragraph

text: regularly, but it was not until
label: Paragraph

text: New City Hall, Nathan Phillips Square, Toronto
label: Caption

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: 1946, with the anticipation of a postwar development boom, that public acquisition of the
label: Paragraph

text: land was approved by a plebiscite. It was another five years before the city council agreed
label: Paragraph

text: to build a new city hall, giving the commission to a triumvirate of well-connected and
label: Paragraph

text: stylistically conservative firms. The subsequent design was met with criticism from
label: Paragraph

text: members of the city’s arts community, who saw in the design a symbol of an “old guard”
label: Paragraph

text: that had resisted for decades the influence of modernism on painting and sculpture as
label: Paragraph

text: well as on architecture. Once local papers gave voice to these arguments, public opinion
label: Paragraph

text: went against the proposal, and it was defeated in a second
label: Paragraph

text: plebiscite, although yet another
label: Paragraph

text: vote subsequently reinstated the public’s desire for a new building.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Revell opened a Toronto office in April 1959 in association with John B.Parkin
label: Paragraph

text: Partnership. Parkin was a committed modernist who would soon join with Mies van der
label: Paragraph

text: Rohe in realizing Mies’ final, and arguably finest, tower complex, the Toronto-Dominion
label: Paragraph

text: Centre (1969). Revell and Parkin spent the next two years refining the design and
label: Paragraph

text: experimenting with details that would accommodate Revell’s vision within a North
label: Paragraph

text: American constructional idiom. The results reveal one of the most thoroughly crafted
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in Canada from the latter half of the century. The concave surfaces of the
label: Paragraph

text: single-loaded towers are veiled in an elegantly proportioned stainless-steel curtain wall.
label: Paragraph

text: The convex sides are clad with windowless precast-concrete panels inlaid with strips of
label: Paragraph

text: rough-faced Pentelic marble whose fluted surface recalls that of a Doric column. These
label: Paragraph

text: same marble strips are repeated in the floors of the lobby, embedded in a smooth matrix
label: Paragraph

text: of black terrazzo. The portly main doors are composed of staggered, laminated strips of
label: Paragraph

text: oak, with oversize, sculpted door handles of laminated wood.
label: Paragraph

text: Approaching the building along the curved front face of the podium, the visitor is
label: Paragraph

text: enfolded by a double-height colonnade from which the second-floor offices of the mayor
label: Caption

text: and city councillors are clearly visible through floor-to-ceiling glass. Moving inside, the
label: Paragraph

text: lobby opens up into a clerestory-lit public forum around which an ample circumference
label: Paragraph

text: of counters allows for contact with municipal services. Graceful curved stairs lead to
label: Paragraph

text: second-floor offices and committee rooms. At the center of this circular assemblage lies a
label: Paragraph

text: stepped ceremonial pit, an umbilicus urbis, out of which thrusts the massive, flaring
label: Paragraph

text: column supporting the council chamber, which nonetheless seems to float serenely above
label: Caption

text: the clerestory. Revell intended the chamber to recall a classical theater in which rising
label: Paragraph

text: tiers of public seating surround concentric rings of council desks. The mayoral dais is
label: Paragraph

text: framed by a slightly concave, freestanding scena frons, itself framed by the gently domed
label: Paragraph

text: ceiling. Set within the trussed perimeter supporting this dome, a continuous arc of glazing
label: Caption

text: provides a panoramic view of Nathan Philips Square and the downtown core beyond.
label: Paragraph

text: The status of Toronto City Hall as the symbolic center of the city is dramatically
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced by the success of this square. Bordered by an elevated promenade that extends
label: Paragraph

text: the frontal colonnade, the square’s dominant feature transforms seasonally, from fountain
label: Paragraph

text: pool to a perennially popular ice-skating rink. Henry Moore’s Three-Way Piece No. 2 and
label: Paragraph

text: a leafy outcropping known as the “Peace Garden” complete the perimeter of a central
label: Paragraph

text: space occupied by a succession of public concerts, rallies, and demonstrations in addition
label: Paragraph

text: to art shows and market days. In stark contrast to the common criticism of modernist
label: Paragraph

text: public space as sterile, Nathan Philips Square is enlivened by a constantly shifting
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitation both day and night, even during the deepest of Canadian winters. As Dendy
label: Paragraph

text: and Kilbourn noted in their book Toronto Observed (1986), “It is to Viljo Revell and his
label: Paragraph

text: humanistic concept of ancient and modern city forms, and of urban life itself, that
label: Paragraph

text: Toronto owes the success of its civic square. Without it the building would have been
label: Paragraph

text: forever incomplete.”
label: Paragraph
