text: TORONTO, ONTARIO
label: Title

text: If any one building in Toronto may mark the transition from the 19th century to the next,
label: Paragraph

text: that building is Old City Hall (1899, E.J.Lennox). Lennox’s masterwork marks the
label: Paragraph

text: culmination in the city of Romanesque Revival, a style influenced by the works of
label: Paragraph

text: McKim, Mead, and White, and H.H.Richardson, particularly his Allegheny County
label: Paragraph

text: Courthouse (1884). Other local examples of this genre include the Gooderham House
label: Paragraph

text: (1892), designed by David Roberts, and the Ontario Legislative Building (1892, known
label: Paragraph

text: also as “Queen’s Park’), by R.A.Waite. These buildings share the robust Richardsonian
label: Paragraph

text: complement of rusticated stonework, massive rounded arches, steep gabled roofs, and
label: Paragraph

text: richly ornamented interior woodwork. More generally, Old City Hall marks the
label: Paragraph

text: culmination of High Victorian Toronto, which, in addition to the Romanesque style,
label: Paragraph

text: looked toward an eclectic array of Renaissance Revival, Second Empire, Italianate, and
label: Paragraph

text: Queen Anne. These templates were modified by a web of influences, including a
label: Paragraph

text: constructional idiom founded on the versatile red and yellow brick produced from local
label: Paragraph

text: clay pits and the ever-present specter of winter. The most enduring legacy of this period
label: Paragraph

text: is the near ubiquitous semidetached housing type known as Toronto Bay-n-Gable,
label: Paragraph

text: variations of which continued to be built throughout the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Into the new century, Lennox would continue to match the ambitions of his patrons
label: Paragraph

text: with the flamboyance of his designs. A case in point is Casa Loma (1911), commissioned
label: Paragraph

text: by Sir Henry Pellatt, a pioneer in the development of hydroelectric power from Niagara
label: Paragraph

text: Falls. Here, Lennox forged an elaborate confection composed of French Medieval and
label: Paragraph

text: early Renaissance that may well have found favor with King Ludwig of Bavaria. Such
label: Paragraph

text: extravagance was the exception to the rule in Edwardian Toronto, for although the
label: Paragraph

text: explosive accretion of wealth and population continued along its Victorian trajectory, the
label: Paragraph

text: opulence of Richardsonian Romanesque gave way to more subtle shades of English
label: Paragraph

text: domestic architecture. The dominant model for the first two decades of the century was
label: Paragraph

text: neo-Georgian, all red brick and white trim, although it is in the Cottage style that we
label: Paragraph

text: recognize two of the city’s most significant neighborhood models: Wychwood Park and
label: Paragraph

text: Riverdale Courts.
label: Paragraph

text: Wychwood Park was founded by Marmaduke Matthews, an English-born landscape
label: Paragraph

text: painter who envisioned an artists’ idyll set amid ten acres of ravine land west of Casa
label: Paragraph

text: Loma. Most of the development dates from after 1907, when the architect Eden Smith, in
label: Paragraph

text: addition to building his own residence, designed a further half dozen houses in the park.
label: Paragraph

text: All were executed in the Lutyens-inspired Cottage style, comprising deceptively simple
label: Paragraph

text: assemblages of sweeping rooflines, stucco walls, and timber de-tailing. Smith employed
label: Paragraph

text: this combination throughout other affluent neighborhoods that were then taking shape in
label: Paragraph

text: the city, but it is to his credit that he was able to apply the fruit of this experience to an
label: Paragraph

text: altogether different challenge. Riverdale Courts (1914) was the inaugural project of the
label: Paragraph

text: Toronto Housing Company, a coalition of political and philanthropic organizations
label: Paragraph

text: concerned with the lack of affordable housing. Set among a solidly middle-class area east
label: Paragraph

text: of the city (and soon to be connected across the Don valley by the Prince Edward
label: Paragraph

text: Viaduct, 1918), Smith’s picturesque Cottage vocabulary provided a palatable image to
label: Paragraph

text: both residents and neighbors. The original phase included 208 units, varying in size from
label: Paragraph

text: one to four bedrooms, in three-story blocks arranged around quadrangles. These courts
label: Paragraph

text: had the double advantage of providing every unit with a veranda-level entrance while
label: Paragraph

text: maximizing the amount of land set aside for lawn and play space. The careful articulation
label: Paragraph

text: of common and private spaces enabled a balanced sense of community and provided a
label: Paragraph

text: role model for many of the successful publicly assisted in-fill projects built subsequently:
label: Paragraph

text: the Garden Court Apartments (1942, Forsey Page and Steele), Sherbourne Lanes (1976,
label: Caption

text: Diamond and Myers), and the much larger St. Lawrence Neighborhood (1983, various
label: Paragraph

text: architects).
label: Paragraph

text: The prosperity of Toronto in the early decades of the century was perhaps most clearly
label: Paragraph

text: embodied in the head offices of the banks that grew in importance as both domestic and
label: Paragraph

text: foreign investment fueled the development of railways and manufacturing and the
label: Paragraph

text: exploitation of natural resources. An early example of this is the Traders’ Bank Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1905), designed by the New York firm of Carrére and Hastings, which was later known
label: Paragraph

text: for the design of the New York Public Library (1911), designed in association with John
label: Caption

text: M.Lyle. The bank building is composed of a series of layers. A ground level of polished
label: Paragraph

text: granite supports a double-height banking hall encased in a Doric colonnade. Above that,
label: Caption

text: eight floors of office space are clad in smooth stone and punched windows and crowned
label: Paragraph

text: by a broad cornice. The Dominion Bank Building (1914), designed by the Toronto firm
label: Caption

text: of Darling and Pearson, is noteworthy for its pair of banking halls, the upper hall
label: Paragraph

text: featuring double-height arcuated piers suggestive of an Albertian basilica and combined
label: Caption

text: with a richly coffered timber ceiling. Commissioned by Edmund Walker and soaring to
label: Caption

text: 34 stories, the Canadian Bank of Commerce Building (1931) remained the tallest
label: Paragraph

text: building in the British Empire for more than 30 years. York and Sawyer, on the heels of
label: Paragraph

text: its headquarters for the Royal Bank in Montreal (1928), designed a subtly tapering office
label: Paragraph

text: shaft clad in piers of buff limestone. The tower is wrapped by a banking hall, its gilded
label: Paragraph

text: coffered vault modeled on the Baths of Caracalla. Across King Street, the construction
label: Caption

text: site of John Lyle’s Bank of Nova Scotia (begun 1929, redesigned by Mathers and
label: Caption

text: Haldenby, 1951) was mothballed, as the crash of 1929 abruptly halted the upward urge of
label: Paragraph

text: Canadian banks for a quarter century.
label: Paragraph

text: Edmund Walker the banker was also a founding patron of the Royal Ontario Museum,
label: Paragraph

text: and for that institution the firm of Darling and Pearson chose an equally exuberant
label: Paragraph

text: modern Romanesque style in which to garb its original wing (1914). The facade features
label: Paragraph

text: a rich brick and terra-cotta matrix, enlivened by an articulated profusion of fretwork,
label: Paragraph

text: corbeling, and friezes, offset by projecting bays and recessed three-story arched windows.
label: Caption

text: More typical of public buildings in the first half of the century was Beaux-Arts
label: Paragraph

text: classicism, as witnessed by the Toronto Public Reference Library (1909, with significant
label: Paragraph

text: additions, 1929), by A.H. Chapman with Wickson and Gregg, and Union Station (1927).
label: Caption

text: Although planning for the new station began in 1905, technical complexities, combined
label: Paragraph

text: with financial and legal entanglements, delayed the opening of the station for a total of 22
label: Paragraph

text: years. John Lyle, in collaboration with Ross and McDonald, architects of Union Station
label: Caption

text: in Ottawa (1912), and Hugh G. Jones, created one of the most imposing yet urbane public
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in Canada. As with the Bank of Commerce Building, a grand vaulted hall is
label: Paragraph

text: modeled on the Roman imperial baths, replete with Tennessee marble and Missouri
label: Paragraph

text: Zumbro. Light floods this space both through north and south clerestory openings and at
label: Paragraph

text: the short ends of the hall through four-story arched windows, their filigree of rippled-
label: Paragraph

text: glass-and-steel trusswork doing double duty as glazed corridors bridging office wings
label: Paragraph

text: flanking the hall to the east and west.
label: Caption

text: The most intriguing public building in the city, without reservation, is the R.C.Harris
label: Paragraph

text: water filtration plant (1937), named for the public works czar responsible for its
label: Paragraph

text: construction (he was a kindred spirit of Robert Moses and William Mulholland).
label: Paragraph

text: Designed by English architect Thomas Pomphrey and constructed during the leanest
label: Caption

text: years of the Depression, its hydrological panoply of pumps, impellers, Venturi tunnels,
label: Paragraph

text: and filter pools is housed in a sumptuous neo-Byzantine fortress. Calling it “the Palace of
label: Paragraph

text: Purification,” the building is memorialized by Michael Ondaatje’s fm the Skin of a Lion:
label: Paragraph

text: “Harris had dreamed the marble walls, the copper banded roofs. He pulled down Victoria
label: Paragraph

text: Park Forest and the essential temple swept up in its place, built on the slopes towards the
label: Paragraph

text: lake.” The building still functions with its original equipment, capable of delivering a
label: Paragraph

text: billion liters of clean water a day. Its audacity was the exception to the rule of the middle
label: Paragraph

text: third of the century, when the city appeared to have entered a state of suspended
label: Paragraph

text: animation, its energies sidetracked by the Depression and the global war.
label: Paragraph

text: The arrival of the International Style, that hallmark of postwar economic recovery, was
label: Paragraph

text: slow to make its mark in Toronto. A few worthy examples include the Anglo Canada
label: Paragraph

text: Insurance Building (1954, James Murray) and the Shell Oil Tower (1955, George Robb),
label: Paragraph

text: both since grievously demolished. Peter Dickinson’s Benvenuto Place (1955) established
label: Paragraph

text: a paradigm for modern apartment dwellings, as the planned community of Don Mills
label: Paragraph

text: (begun 1953) did for suburban development. However, it was not until the onset of the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s that a critical mass of influences and projects decisively marked the second great
label: Paragraph

text: wave of expansion and experimentation in the city. Beneifiting from a massive buildup in
label: Paragraph

text: postsecondary education, a new generation of architects sought to advance and adapt
label: Paragraph

text: modernism in an academic setting. A supreme example of this synthesis is embodied in
label: Paragraph

text: Massey College (1962), a graduate residence of the University of Toronto. Ron Thom
label: Caption

text: combined the tradition of Collegiate Gothic (a nearby example, Sproatt and Rolph’s
label: Paragraph

text: elegantly functional Hart House, 1919, was endowed by the same Massey Foundation
label: Paragraph

text: that sponsored Thom’s design} with modernist influences from the Netherlands into a
label: Paragraph

text: superbly crafted environment of total design, right down to the silverware, that is
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of Wright’s Prairie period. Scarborough College (1965, John Andrews
label: Caption

text: Architects and Page and Steele), a satellite of the University of Toronto, challenged
label: Paragraph

text: existing notions of what constituted a campus. Arranged along the northern brow of a
label: Paragraph

text: forested ravine, the college is essentially a single building extend-ing along the contours
label: Paragraph

text: of the valley and interconnected along an internal, temperature-controlled pedestrian
label: Paragraph

text: spine. The heroic scale of the Brutalist in situ concrete forms, conceived of at the scale of
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape, is balanced by skillfully modulated spaces of public gathering arranged in
label: Paragraph

text: succession along the central “street.”
label: Paragraph

text: At the center of the city, sustained immigration, particularly from southern and Eastern
label: Paragraph

text: Europe, progressively enriched the realm of public space. The Colonnade (1964, Gerald
label: Caption

text: Robinson) cast in a modernist idiom the often antimodernist concept of mixed use,
label: Paragraph

text: reflecting in a single complex the more incremental transformations taking shape in
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods such as Yorkville and Kensington Market. The symbolic apotheosis of
label: Paragraph

text: Toronto’s cosmopolitan metamorphosis was the arrival of New City Hall (1965), which
label: Paragraph

text: saw Finnish architect Viljo Revell’s design emerge from a competition field of 520
label: Paragraph

text: entries. Unremittingly modern yet sinuously sculptural, the building was matched in
label: Paragraph

text: impact by its accompanying urban square, which continues to provide a sustained and
label: Paragraph

text: lively focus to civic events and public gatherings. Equally significant was the Toronto-
label: Paragraph

text: Dominion Centre (1969, Mies van der Rohe, with John B.Parkin Associates, and
label: Paragraph

text: Bregman and Hamann), Mies’s final, and perhaps finest, corporate tower complex. Set on
label: Paragraph

text: a gray granite podium, two characteristically prismatic towers offset the supremely
label: Paragraph

text: elegant banking pavilion, a 150-square-foot clear-span essay in Miesian refinement. Their
label: Paragraph

text: dramatic effect on the skyline was equaled by an initially more subtle intervention: that of
label: Paragraph

text: the commercial services buried beneath the podium. Joimed with similar underground
label: Paragraph

text: adjuncts to a cluster of subsequent towers (including Commerce Court, 1972, 1.M.Pei,
label: Paragraph

text: with Page and Steele, and the Royal Bank Plaza, 1976, WZMH Partnership), this
label: Paragraph

text: concourse grew to encompass most of the subterranean area of the downtown core,
label: Paragraph

text: including a half dozen subway stations. Along with a similar development in Montreal, it
label: Paragraph

text: represents a uniquely Canadian response to the nexus of metropolitan life and the forces
label: Paragraph

text: of nature.
label: Paragraph

text: Increasingly identified as the “livable city,” Toronto took steps to forestall the blight
label: Paragraph

text: plaguing American urban centers. Curtailment of the Spadina Expressway saved several
label: Paragraph

text: historic neighborhoods while simultaneously privileging public over private
label: Paragraph

text: transportation. Similarly, government-sponsored initiatives favored in-fill and renovation
label: Paragraph

text: rather than the tabula rasa of “urban renewal” that local transplant Jane Jacobs had
label: Paragraph

text: castigated in her seminal Death and Life of Great American Cities. Situated on artificial
label: Paragraph

text: landfill, Ontario Place (1971, Craig, Zeidler, and Strong) was a publicly sponsored
label: Paragraph

text: amusement park inspired by the success of Expo ‘67 in Montreal. Designed as a
label: Paragraph

text: showcase for the burgeoning province, Eberhard Zeidler created a broad array of high-
label: Paragraph

text: tech follies set amid a picturesque landscape of linked islands and lagoons: giant white
label: Paragraph

text: pods cantilevered on slender pylons several hundred feet above water, a hyperbolic
label: Paragraph

text: paraboloid “tent” for outdoor concerts (ignobly demolished), and a geodesic sphere
label: Paragraph

text: containing the first-ever IMAX cinema. It was also instrumental in focusing public
label: Paragraph

text: attention on the city’s shoreline and led to the establishment of Harbourfront (begun
label: Paragraph

text: 1972}—a 100-acre strip of abandoned piers and warehouses that became Canada’s first
label: Paragraph

text: urban national park. Here, Zeidler’s renovation of Queen’s Quay Terminal (1983)
label: Caption

text: followed on the heels of the immensely influential Eaton Center (1979, Bregman and
label: Paragraph

text: Hamann, with the Zeidler Partnership). Connected at both ends to the main subway line
label: Paragraph

text: running beneath Yonge Street (and to the subterranean concourse begun by Mies), this
label: Paragraph

text: urban mall offers a parallel climate-controlled “street,” a 900-foot-long glazed vault
label: Paragraph

text: enclosing five levels of retail from street level down, as many office and parking levels
label: Paragraph

text: above, and 20 million visitors annually. Like the now ubiquitous profile of the CN Tower
label: Paragraph

text: (1976, John Andrews, with WZMH Partnership, and E.R. Baldwin), this “street” has
label: Paragraph

text: served as a lightning rod for critics and boosters alike, joining Revell’s City Hall in the
label: Paragraph

text: pantheon of postcard symbols of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: A severe recession in the early 1980s, followed by a lengthy economic downturn
label: Paragraph

text: through much of the final decade of the 20th century, brought to an end the dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: experimentation of the postwar period. As elsewhere, although the relative merits of
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernism were discussed in academic circles, historicist pastiche began to
label: Paragraph

text: dominate the sprawl of subdivisions and shopping malls engulfing the exurban
label: Paragraph

text: hinterland. Notable exceptions buoyed the hopes of conscientious objectors:
label: Paragraph

text: A.J.Diamond’s Central YMCA (1984), a taut assemblage of Platonic volumes with
label: Paragraph

text: nuanced references to Roman shermae, among others, and Mississauga City Hall (1987,
label: Paragraph

text: Jones and Kirkland Architects}, which drew on both vernacular and modernist influences.
label: Paragraph

text: Financially squeezed local governments lost influence over powerful developers,
label: Paragraph

text: resulting in projects that ran counter to the spirit of consultation and compromise that had
label: Paragraph

text: been the cornerstone of the “livable city” formula. The practice of architecture itself
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly fell to the sway of bottom-line economics of design-build management,
label: Paragraph

text: eroding the traditional role of the architect. Despite all of this, the city continued to be an
label: Paragraph

text: enviable place to live, with rich cultural deposits, vibrant neighborhoods, an invigorating
label: Paragraph

text: waterfront, and an economy poised to meet the challenges of the coming decades. A new
label: Paragraph

text: generation of architects waits in the wings.
label: Paragraph

text: TORRE, SUSANA 1944
label: Title

text: Architect, theorist, and urban designer, United States
label: Caption

text: Susana Torre is theorist, educator, practicing architect, urban and interior designer,
label: Paragraph

text: social activist, and architectural critic.
label: Paragraph

text: Fire Station Five, Columbus, Indiana (1987)
label: Caption

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: Torre has demonstrated her talents in several design competitions and prestigious awards
label: Paragraph

text: since graduating with an architecture degree from the Universidad de Buenos Aires in
label: Paragraph

text: 1967. Torre’s ability to incorporate allegory and metaphor into complex, plastic forms is
label: Paragraph

text: nowhere more evident than in her design for the restoration and adaptive reuse of Ellis
label: Paragraph

text: Island in New York Harbor (1981). She transformed this abandoned relic of immigration
label: Paragraph

text: into a delightful park of memorable symbols and enjoyable relaxation. Torre’s Ellis
label: Paragraph

text: Island project has been displayed in architectural exhibitions at more than 40 universities
label: Paragraph

text: and, through numerous publications, educated the general public about architecture’s
label: Paragraph

text: ability to express a culture’s narrative histories.
label: Paragraph

text: Among her earlier projects, Torre’s 1977 design for the offices of Manhattan lawyer
label: Paragraph

text: Harry Torcyner suggests a pristine orchestration of the relationship between art and
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. (The space was also designed to house Torcyner’s art collection.) Torre
label: Paragraph

text: subtly used color to amplify the structural grid and employed texture and color to contrast
label: Paragraph

text: the permanent exterior walls with the flexible interior partitions. Vivid surrealist
label: Paragraph

text: paintings and primitive objects of art are showcased by sensitively configured
label: Paragraph

text: architectural spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Two of her commissions—Fire Station Five (1987) at Tipton Lake, Columbus,
label: Caption

text: Indiana, and the Garvey House (1988) in Amagansett, Long Island—embody
label: Paragraph

text: recognizable yet thoroughly abstracted references to site and context. Fire Station Five’s
label: Paragraph

text: plan is generated by the square. One of the interlocking squares shelters the functional
label: Paragraph

text: and technical apparatus of the station, whereas another square houses the “human”
label: Paragraph

text: facilities (sleeping and living areas, kitchen, and offices.) The shape and form of the
label: Paragraph

text: building echo its suburban and bucolic environment. The exposed steel frame alludes to a
label: Paragraph

text: barnlike structure meant to house fire trucks. References to silos (the cylindrical stair
label: Caption

text: with a fireman pole and the tower for fire hoses) tie the two functions of the building
label: Paragraph

text: together formally and physically while making clear reference to Midwest agricultural
label: Paragraph

text: building traditions. Elegant details and balanced colors augment the architectonic
label: Paragraph

text: integrity of this admired landmark.
label: Paragraph

text: The semicircular two-story Garvey residence gracefully balances vernacular and
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual traditions. Clad in local cedar, it also pays tribute to the American classicism
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture through its symmetrical street facade with a central stair tower. The
label: Paragraph

text: stunning oceanview site ensures direct sunlight all day long.
label: Paragraph

text: Torre has integrated her aesthetic concerns with those of education and social reform.
label: Paragraph

text: In her 1980 studio at Syracuse University’s School of Architecture, Torre focused the
label: Paragraph

text: curriculum on the housing needs of two-income families, asking the students to
label: Paragraph

text: reexamine the contemporary roles of parents and children. As director of the Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: Program (1982-85) at Barnard College, Columbia University, she shaped the educational
label: Paragraph

text: experiences of many young women. While chairing the Environmental Design
label: Paragraph

text: Department of the Parsons School of Design (1991-94), she implemented curricula that
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized social needs of the late 20th century. In collaboration with government
label: Paragraph

text: agencies and professional offices, she offered a hands-on housing design program for
label: Paragraph

text: low-income and mentally ill families. The students created plans and models for three
label: Paragraph

text: sites in Manhattan’s Lower East Side and participated in subsequent implementation.
label: Paragraph

text: Torre has curated several traveling exhibitions of architecture, including the innovative
label: Paragraph

text: and acclaimed “Women in American Architecture: A Historic and Contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: Perspective,” displayed at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, New York (1977). The same
label: Paragraph

text: year Torre organized the traveling exhibition “Childbirth Centers,” installed at the New
label: Paragraph

text: Jersey Institute of Technology, where she was an associate professor (1977-78). A
label: Paragraph

text: decade later Torre arranged a symposium and traveling exhibition, “Hispanic Traditions
label: Paragraph

text: in American Architecture and Urbanism,” at Columbia University in New York. After
label: Paragraph

text: touring the United States, this exhibition was shown in Argentina and Spain.
label: Paragraph

text: TORRE VELASCA (VELASCA TOWER)
label: Caption

text: Designed by Lodovico, B.di Belgiojoso; completed 1958; Milan, Italy
label: Caption

text: Completed in 1958, the 26-story Torre Velasca (Velasca Tower} was built by architects
label: Paragraph

text: Lodovico B.di Belgiojoso (1909-), Enrico Peressutti (1908-76), and Ernesto N.Rogers
label: Paragraph

text: (1909-69) of the Studio Architetti BBPR in collaboration with structural engineer Arturo
label: Paragraph

text: Danusso. Only the second skyscraper to be built in Italy, it followed the Pirelli Tower,
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Gio Ponti with structural engineer Pier Luigi Nervi, by two years. Milan’s
label: Paragraph

text: two highrise towers redefined the skyline of the most industrial city in Italy at precisely
label: Paragraph

text: the moment when modern life began to eclipse the traditional agrarian economy and
label: Paragraph

text: bleak wartime conditions were giving way to new prosperity. Unlike the Pirelli Tower,
label: Paragraph

text: located in the vicinity of Milan’s Stazione Centrale, and thus somewhat removed from
label: Paragraph

text: the historic center of the city, the Velasca Tower was situated at the intersection of Corso
label: Paragraph

text: di Porta Romana and Via Velasca, in the ambit of the unique Gothic Duomo and
label: Paragraph

text: Giuseppe Mengoni’s Galleria Vittorio Emmanuele.
label: Caption

text: The tower was named after the street, Via Velasca, which in turn had been named for
label: Paragraph

text: Fernando Velasca, Spanish governor of Milan 1592-1600 and 1610-12. Conceived as a
label: Paragraph

text: tripartite structure, the building comprises a two-story canopied entrance pavilion at
label: Paragraph

text: ground level, which houses retail shops; a robust rectangular shaft with central elevator
label: Paragraph

text: core accommodating commercial office space; and a slightly larger rectangular crown
label: Paragraph

text: overhanging the central shaft, occupied by private residences and topped by a copper-
label: Caption

text: clad hipped roof. To accommodate the broad base of the structure, war-damaged
label: Caption

text: residential buildings on the site were demolished to expand Via Velasca into the large,
label: Paragraph

text: open Piazza Velasca that surrounds the tower. In a gesture that echoes Mies van der
label: Paragraph

text: Rohe’s solution for the Seagram Building’s (1954-58) plaza in New York, a place of
label: Paragraph

text: repose was created in
label: Paragraph

text: the dense urban fabric of Milan. Together, the shaft of the tower and its overhanging
label: Paragraph

text: crown—which critics have likened to a medieval fortified palace—are visually unified by
label: Paragraph

text: steel-reinforced concrete ribs that span the height of the building, recalling August
label: Caption

text: Perret’s Raynouard Street apartment building in Paris (1932) and his Notre Dame du
label: Paragraph

text: Raincy (1922). The structure of the Velasca Tower also recalls Pier Luigi Nervi’s
label: Paragraph

text: Palazzetto dello Sport (1957). However, in contrast to the lightness of Nervi’s work, the
label: Paragraph

text: sheer mass of the Velasca Tower asserted a striking monumentality that was mediated by
label: Paragraph

text: the void of the surrounding piazza.
label: Paragraph

text: Designed for the Milan offices of the Societa Generale Immobiliare (Real Estate
label: Caption

text: Association), the monumentality of the building suggests longevity and permanence. The
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete in-fill panels and vertical ribs evoke the stone architecture of Italy’s
label: Paragraph

text: past at much grander scale, rather than employing the curtain wall introduced in slightly
label: Paragraph

text: earlier American skyscrapers, including Skidmore, Owings and Merrill’s Lever House
label: Paragraph

text: (New York City, 1951-52) and Mies’ Seagram Building. The with ornamental details
label: Caption

text: that recall both the nearby Duomo and roof of the overhanging crown is clad with copper
label: Paragraph

text: and trimmed medieval fortifications. Even when glass was employed for the tower’s
label: Paragraph

text: fenestration, vast planes of glass that made visible the building’s viscera were avoided,
label: Paragraph

text: and windows were moderately scaled.
label: Paragraph

text: Provoking heated debate in local and international architecture circles at a time when
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers were still new to European cities, the distinctive Velasca Tower contradicted
label: Paragraph

text: the tenets of International Style modern architecture; it appeared antimodern. The effect
label: Paragraph

text: of lead architect Ernesto Rogers’s rejection of the ethical and aesthetic mandate of
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture was no doubt exacerbated by BBPR’s decision to present the tower
label: Paragraph

text: together with the work of Giancarlo de Carlo (Housing in Matera, 1956-57), Ignazio
label: Paragraph

text: Gardella (Olivetti Cafeteria in Ivrea, 1953-59), and Vico Magistretti (Villa in Arenzano,
label: Paragraph

text: 1959) at the Otterlo Congrés Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne (CIAM) meeting of
label: Caption

text: 1959. Controversy generated at this meeting concerning the future of Modern architecture
label: Caption

text: ultimately led to the collapse of the organization, and thus the loss of one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: prominent forums for debate on Modern architecture and urban planning.
label: Paragraph

text: Consciously attempting to evoke the ambience of Milan, austere yet sophisticated,
label: Paragraph

text: urban yet introverted, historic fabric punctuated by gaps and contemporary interventions,
label: Paragraph

text: BBPR’s design for the Velasca Tower sought to make manifest the concept of continuity
label: Paragraph

text: (continuita) that Rogers had adumbrated in his editorial in the December 1953/January
label: Paragraph

text: 1954 issue of the journal Casabella, which he renamed Casabella-Continuita. For Rogers
label: Caption

text: continuity referred to historical context in the broad sense, what he termed architecture’s
label: Paragraph

text: “pre-existing environment” (preesistenze ambientali). From its founding in 1932, amid
label: Paragraph

text: heated debate over rationalist architecture and its ties to the Italian Fascist regime, Studio
label: Paragraph

text: Architetti BBPR took both the classical tradition and the vernacular heritage of the Italian
label: Paragraph

text: peninsula to be vital sources for modern Italian designers. This position was also
label: Paragraph

text: pervasive—albeit articulated in different ways—among architects of the postwar period,
label: Paragraph

text: despite the attempts of the critic and historian Bruno Zevi to promote “organic”
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Consideration of context was a necessity for Italian architects operating in
label: Paragraph

text: war-torn Italy under conditions that forced them to rebuild damaged buildings wherever
label: Paragraph

text: possible; where older structures
label: Paragraph

text: Velasca Tower plan (1958)
label: Caption

text: Photo courtesy Michelangelo Sabatino
label: Caption

text: were damaged beyond repair, architects were called on to insert new residential,
label: Paragraph

text: institutional, or industrial structures into the dense historic urban fabric.
label: Paragraph

text: The Velasca Tower was conceived as the remedy for a wartorn site, and no doubt
label: Paragraph

text: symbolized rebirth in this city that had suffered great losses of its historic building stock
label: Paragraph

text: during the war. It became a symbol of a revitalized Italy, liberated from the ideological
label: Paragraph

text: excesses of the Fascist regime and inspired by the hope of rebuilding the country without
label: Paragraph

text: negating its built heritage.
label: Paragraph

text: The Velasca Tower could be compared with late 19th- and early 20th-century tall
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in New York (e.g., Cass Gilbert’s Woolworth Building, 1913), in that it
label: Paragraph

text: borrowed from historical models such as the medieval fortified castle and tower. The
label: Paragraph

text: reliance on “traditional” historical types was rejected by modernists in favor of formal
label: Paragraph

text: innovation. Yet the decision to radically expand the tower’s scale and proportions is
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of the striking modernity that one sees, for example, in Adolf Loos’s Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: Tribune Tower Competition entry of 1922.
label: Caption

text: Departing from the reductive language of international modernism, Studio Architetti
label: Paragraph

text: BBPR looked to the local context, adapting the built forms of Milan and northern Italy to
label: Paragraph

text: advanced building technologies to demonstrate that Modern architecture could be
label: Paragraph

text: representative of the individual as well as the collective, the local, national, and
label: Paragraph

text: international. The appropriation of the medieval past was not merely an archaeological
label: Paragraph

text: exercise. Rogers and his associates sought to reinvent the past in light of the
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary needs, both spiritual and functional. The fundamental contribution of the
label: Paragraph

text: Velasca Tower to the history of 20th-century modern architecture lies in its ability to
label: Paragraph

text: convey the prescient message—against the grain of international modernism—that
label: Paragraph

text: Modern architecture need not necessarily break with the past but, rather, should aspire to
label: Paragraph

text: engage in a creative dialogue with it.
label: Paragraph

text: TRANSPORTATION PLANNING
label: Title

text: Transportation planning in the 20th century grew up with the automobile. Only for the
label: Paragraph

text: first few years of the century were streetcars able to compete with interest in the
label: Paragraph

text: automobile. Comprehensive plans that included rail transit, such as those for Llewellyn
label: Paragraph

text: Park, New Jersey, and Forest Hills Gardens, New York, quickly proved to be the
label: Paragraph

text: exception. Transportation planning soon became the handmaiden of the automobile,
label: Paragraph

text: taking it where it wanted to go, often regardless of the consequences.
label: Paragraph

text: By the early 1920s, the popularity of the automobile had largely displaced interest in
label: Paragraph

text: planning for public transportation, which faced declining ridership and loss of profits.
label: Paragraph

text: Nationwide, voters turned their backs on public transit investments in referenda,
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes influenced by huge contributions by automobile and parts manufacturers. The
label: Paragraph

text: automobile quickly became the emblem of the future and national progress. The number
label: Paragraph

text: of electric streetcars peaked for the century in 1917 at 72,911, and total ridership was
label: Paragraph

text: greatest in 1923, when 15.7 billion transit trips were taken. The planners’ preference was
label: Paragraph

text: certified at the 1924 National Conference on City Planning when the way of the
label: Paragraph

text: “horizontal city of the future” was declared—by the automobile.
label: Paragraph

text: The sudden tidal wave of automobility swept over cities throughout the 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: Suddenly, suburbs began to grow at a much faster rate than cities. As early as 1923, some
label: Paragraph

text: cities were debating the banning of cars downtown because of congestion. Commuters by
label: Paragraph

text: automobile quickly outnumbered those by transit. In the early years of the meteoric
label: Paragraph

text: ascendance of the automobile, transportation planners raced to facilitate its needs. The
label: Paragraph

text: single answer for congestion was to build more roads, usually in straight radial lines from
label: Paragraph

text: the center of the city into territories of developable land at the city’s edge.
label: Paragraph

text: The “good roads” movement gained in popularity. Taking advantage of Progressive
label: Paragraph

text: Era sentiment against the monopolistic practices of railroads and toll-road operators, the
label: Paragraph

text: good-roads movement advocated for public ownership and construction of roads. The
label: Paragraph

text: concept of a continuous national system of highways was instituted in the Federal Aid
label: Paragraph

text: Highway Act of 1921 with the adoption of a numbered U.S. highway system composed
label: Paragraph

text: of routes extending across the nation. By the early 1930s, the objective of constructing a
label: Paragraph

text: system of two-lane roads connecting the centers of population had been largely
label: Paragraph

text: completed, making it possible to travel across the country on an all-weather highway
label: Paragraph

text: system.
label: Paragraph

text: No one was more aggressive at road building than Robert Moses, who, from 1924,
label: Paragraph

text: amassed unprecedented power in New York to steamroll thousands of miles of highway
label: Paragraph

text: building projects. Moses’s first parkways were designed for the recreational driver, but
label: Paragraph

text: by the early 1930s the wide thoroughfares became conduits for commuters. Moses’s
label: Paragraph

text: massive transportation projects, which combined urban expressways, bridges, and
label: Paragraph

text: tunnels, had an immediate effect of pumping up suburban migration in New York’s
label: Paragraph

text: suburbs, particularly to Westchester and Nassau Counties.
label: Paragraph

text: Moses was many things, but he was only figuratively a planner, as he concentrated on
label: Paragraph

text: building a bureaucratic empire. Many of his massive transportation building projects
label: Paragraph

text: found their source in the landmark 1929 Regional Plan of New York, a privately funded
label: Paragraph

text: transportation and development plan for the New York metropolitan region. The plan was
label: Paragraph

text: a mix of proposals for decentralizing and “decongesting” New York, calling for the
label: Paragraph

text: expansion of highways and rail links and at the same time recognizing, in Clarence
label: Paragraph

text: Perry’s classic section on neighborhood units, that the automobile was inevitably creating
label: Paragraph

text: the cellular city.
label: Paragraph

text: As Moses drew from the Regional Plan of New York, other large-scale plans attempted
label: Paragraph

text: to envision and shape the future of automobile transportation. The Regional Plan
label: Paragraph

text: Association of America (RPAA), composed of the era’s most reform-minded planners,
label: Paragraph

text: including Lewis Mumford, Clarence Stein, and Henry Wright, proposed the idea of the
label: Paragraph

text: “townless highway,” thoroughfares that would “encourage the building of real
label: Paragraph

text: communities at definite and favorable points off the main road.” However, without
label: Paragraph

text: Moses to take up the idea, the RPAA’s plan languished as the Great Depression set in.
label: Paragraph

text: With the Federal Aid Highway Act of 1934, Congress authorized funds to state
label: Paragraph

text: governments for surveys, plans, engineering, and economic analyses for future highway
label: Title

text: construction projects. By 1940, all states were participating in this program.
label: Paragraph

text: Transportation planning moved into another realm of influence in 1940 with the opening
label: Paragraph

text: of the Arroyo Seco Parkway (later the Pasadena Freeway) in Los Angeles (the term
label: Paragraph

text: “freeway” had been coined initially in 1928 in a New York Times article by Edward M.
label: Paragraph

text: Bassett, a New York planner). Los Angeles’ first freeway plan, by Lloyd Aldrich, was
label: Paragraph

text: not developed until 1939, and by World War Il Los Angeles had only 11 miles of
label: Paragraph

text: freeway. However, Los Angeles soon became the world model of up-to-the-minute
label: Paragraph

text: modernity in its enthusiastic embrace of transportation planning for the automobile.
label: Paragraph

text: The most shining vision of the future of 20th-century transportation, however, was
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited at the 1939 World’s Fair in New York. Rarely has a plan of the future city
label: Paragraph

text: shown such prescience. The most popular exhibit at the fair was General Motors’
label: Paragraph

text: Futurama, which attracted long lines of visitors who wanted to visit a future envisioned
label: Paragraph

text: by America’s most successful automobile manufacturer and that resembled nothing so
label: Paragraph

text: much as the southern California landscape, circa 1955. When Secretary of Defense
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Wilson asserted that what was good for General Motors “was also good for the
label: Paragraph

text: country,” no voices were heard in dissent. Eventually, more than five million visitors
label: Paragraph

text: came to the Futurama exhibit to wonder at the expanse of miniature elevated freeways
label: Paragraph

text: that designer Norman Bel Geddes had created to show the prospects of “modern and
label: Paragraph

text: efficient city planning—breath-taking architecture—each city block a complete unit in
label: Paragraph

text: itself [with] broad, one-way thoroughfares—space, sunshine, light and air.”
label: Paragraph

text: Although the arrival of World War IL brought a halt to the rise in automobile
label: Paragraph

text: ownership and slowed the momentum of transportation planning, significant efforts were
label: Paragraph

text: made that contributed to the huge surge in highway construction afterward. Congress
label: Paragraph

text: passed the Federal Aid Highway Act of 1944, financing an interurban system of 32,000
label: Paragraph

text: miles that bypassed urban areas. The act immediately created a debate: transportation
label: Paragraph

text: planners, such as Harold Bartholomew, and power broker Robert Moses wanted to use
label: Paragraph

text: new roads to attack “urban blight,” charting expressways through urban residential areas
label: Paragraph

text: to entirely redevelop them. However, initially at least, federal aid focused on intercity
label: Paragraph

text: connections.
label: Paragraph

text: The increased interest of the federal government in transportation planning and
label: Paragraph

text: highway development soon aroused the in-terest of lobbyists, the most significant of
label: Paragraph

text: which, the American Road Builders Association, established one of the most effective
label: Paragraph

text: campaigns in the history of pressure-group politics to advance the cause of federally
label: Paragraph

text: supported highway building. Members of the group further set out to systematically
label: Paragraph

text: dismantle municipal streetcar systems in large portions of the country. General Motors,
label: Paragraph

text: Firestone Tire, Standard Oil of California, and Phillips Petroleum were eventually
label: Paragraph

text: convicted of antitrust violations for setting up an illegal transportation company, National
label: Paragraph

text: City Lines Inc., whose purpose was to obtain control of transit companies throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: Midwest and West and to dismantle streetcars in favor of buses, which were financed by
label: Paragraph

text: the same manufacturers and suppliers.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1953, when the highway lobby sponsored a nationwide essay contest on the need for
label: Paragraph

text: more highways, the winner was, aptly enough, Robert Moses, who received a $25,000
label: Paragraph

text: prize for his essay “How to Plan and Pay for Better Highways.” The essay proved to be a
label: Paragraph

text: preliminary script for more federal funding of highway construction. Although the
label: Paragraph

text: Eisenhower administration initially had kept highways separate from its 1954 Urban
label: Paragraph

text: Renewal Act, as had Truman in the original 1949 act, Eisenhower soon became
label: Paragraph

text: enamored of the prospects for a large-scale highway transportation project.
label: Paragraph

text: Eisenhower, whose military success during World War Il came on the German
label: Paragraph

text: autobahns, listened carefully to arguments that a massive federal highway-building
label: Paragraph

text: project would benefit national defense and stimulate an economic boom. Once again, the
label: Paragraph

text: debate over “roads fight blight” came to center stage, with many planners insisting that
label: Paragraph

text: the new highways must penetrate to the center of urban areas to remove slums and
label: Paragraph

text: improve the connection between outlying suburbs and downtown offices and retail areas.
label: Paragraph

text: In June 1956, the Interstate Highway Act was passed with only a single vote in
label: Paragraph

text: opposition. The $41 billion bill became the largest public works program in the history of
label: Paragraph

text: the world, setting in place a gigantic imbalance that favored the private automobile over
label: Paragraph

text: public transit. With an effect befitting its size and cost, the Interstate Highway Act did
label: Paragraph

text: not by itself create the massive suburbanization that defined the evolution of cities in the
label: Paragraph

text: second half of century, but it abetted it in an extremely consequential fashion.
label: Paragraph

text: By the early 1960s, the automobile was essentially putting other forms of
label: Paragraph

text: transportation out of business. Between 1950 and 1972, transit patronage declined by 62
label: Paragraph

text: percent. Outside of urban areas, it was virtually nonexistent, with only 5 percent of the
label: Paragraph

text: nation’s transit patronage available in rural areas and cities with a population less than
label: Paragraph

text: 50,000. During the same period, the volume of automobile traffic more than tripled.
label: Paragraph

text: It soon became apparent to transportation planners that an undue reliance on the
label: Paragraph

text: automobile was creating as many problems as it was eliminating. As each new interstate
label: Paragraph

text: was completed, fresh new problems of disp.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: other voices began to be heard in support o
label: Paragraph

text: acement, pollution, and congestion arose.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the idea of “balanced transportation.” In
label: Paragraph

text: 1962, for example, the San Francisco Bay Area passed a voters’ referendum for a 71-mile
label: Paragraph

text: rail transit system after a prolonged “freeway
label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964 (UMTA) was the first significant effort of
label: Paragraph

text: the century to recognize the need to improve and expand public transit. Expenditures
label: Paragraph

text: increased from approximately $100 million in 1964—65 to approximately $1.3 billion at
label: Paragraph

text: the end of the 1970s. Under the program, a type of balance was anticipated against the
label: Paragraph

text: huge federal subsidy for highway building by offering matching funds for capital
label: Paragraph

text: acquisitions of local transit, and the principal aim was to attain congestion relief by
label: Paragraph

text: making public transit faster and more comfortable.
label: Paragraph

text: The immediate effect of the act was to provide new equipment for public transit buses.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the act also promoted plans for new rail transit, such as the Bay Area Rapid
label: Paragraph

text: Transit (BART) in the San Francisco Bay Area. Extensions were funded in New York,
label: Paragraph

text: Boston, Cleveland, Philadelphia, and Chicago. New rail systems were built in
label: Paragraph

text: Washington, D.C., Baltimore, Miami, and Atlanta, and planning was begun in Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles and Honolulu.
label: Paragraph

text: The ironic consequence of most of these public transit efforts, however, was to spread
label: Paragraph

text: decentralization of urban downtowns and frequently contribute to the deterioration of
label: Paragraph

text: central city neighborhoods, often increasing racial segregation. Many of the public transit
label: Paragraph

text: improvements only facilitated suburban commuting in place of intracity transportation.
label: Paragraph

text: BART, for example, became a high-speed conduit for financial district office workers
label: Paragraph

text: from the East Bay suburbs of Contra Costa and Alameda. San Francisco residents were
label: Paragraph

text: seldom to be found on the bright futuristic cars that sped beneath the city streets. In city
label: Paragraph

text: after city, the main beneficiaries of the new systems or extensions were suburban
label: Paragraph

text: commuters, not residents of central cities.
label: Paragraph

text: The initial presumption of UMTA was that increased expenditures on capital
label: Paragraph

text: improvements would relieve traffic congestion. However, by the mid-1970s, planners
label: Paragraph

text: began to realize the need for a more complex approach. Other influences brought about
label: Paragraph

text: experiments in vanpooling, dial-a-ride arrangements, and carpool lanes. The principal
label: Paragraph

text: impetus to these revised approaches was the establishment of the Environmental
label: Paragraph

text: Protection Agency (EPA). After 1970, pollution in urban areas became a major federal
label: Paragraph

text: concern, and the EPA sought to develop plans that would diminish traffic in urban areas
label: Paragraph

text: to reduce pollution, although planners generally continued to ignore the automobile’s
label: Paragraph

text: contribution to urban sprawl. The shift in focus from reducing congestion to reducing
label: Paragraph

text: pollution brought about certain restrictions on automobiles in central areas, converted
label: Paragraph

text: downtown streets into pedestrian malls, and reduced downtown speed limits.
label: Paragraph

text: Although critics continued to argue that the federal role in transportation planning was
label: Paragraph

text: only codifying the decentralization of urban areas or providing Band-Aids to the
label: Paragraph

text: problems of automobile pollution, the notion of balanced transportation continued to be
label: Paragraph

text: advanced. In 1975, UMTA and the Federal Highway Administration began to require
label: Paragraph

text: transportation system management plans that had to account for an overall balanced
label: Paragraph

text: reckoning of transportation needs as a requirement for federal funding. In 1978,
label: Paragraph

text: requirements were added that focused on the needs of disabled transit riders and residents
label: Paragraph

text: of densely populated urban areas. During the 1970s, transit planners experimented with a
label: Paragraph

text: number of varied alternatives to the automobile. In addition to the expansion of bus
label: Paragraph

text: services and train services, two new modes of transportation came into consideration. The
label: Paragraph

text: first of these was personal rapid transit, which attempted to answer the mobility of the
label: Paragraph

text: automobile with small independent conveyances. Systems were tried in Tampa, in
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia, and at Duke University. The second new mode of transportation was not
label: Paragraph

text: really new at all: light rail vehicles, as they were newly christened, were really a spiffed-
label: Paragraph

text: up reinstitution of the old inner-city streetcar systems that had been systematically
label: Paragraph

text: removed from most urban areas.
label: Paragraph

text: Increasingly, the federal role in transportation planning grew more inconsistent during
label: Paragraph

text: the 1980s. Public transit advocates complained that the government was not doing
label: Paragraph

text: enough, local jurisdictions complained that it was requiring too much, and congressional
label: Paragraph

text: representatives increased their opposition to what they termed “big-government intrusion
label: Paragraph

text: into local affairs.” A kind of stalemate ensued throughout the 1980s, with mounting
label: Paragraph

text: opposition to freeway building by quality-of-life advocates and suburban home owners
label: Paragraph

text: on the one hand and by public transit advocates faced with reduced federal subsidies for
label: Paragraph

text: public transit development on the other. Although there were some notable successes of
label: Paragraph

text: locally funded transit programs, such as in San Diego, California, and a number of other
label: Paragraph

text: cities that cobbled together funding for new light rail vehicle systems, congestion and
label: Paragraph

text: sprawl continued to increase as a new phenomenon of “edge cities” grew into the
label: Paragraph

text: planners’ purview with the most farreaching requirements for automobile commuting yet.
label: Paragraph

text: The 1990s saw the influence of numerous state growth-management plans that for the
label: Paragraph

text: first time addressed the comprehensive relationship of urban growth to balanced
label: Paragraph

text: transportation principles. States such as Oregon, Florida, Maine, and New Jersey sought
label: Paragraph

text: to link transportation planning with the wider implications of urban sprawl, loss of open
label: Paragraph

text: space, and cost of municipal services. Oregon’s growth-management plan, the oldest and
label: Paragraph

text: most far-reaching, called for the establishment of urban growth boundaries to stave off
label: Paragraph

text: urban sprawl while at the same time increasing the use of public transportation within
label: Paragraph

text: areas of increased density.
label: Paragraph

text: As state growth-management plans began to extend the idea of what balanced
label: Paragraph

text: transportation meant, federal transportation planning was also influenced. Passage of the
label: Paragraph

text: Intermodal Surface Transportation Act attempted to put the highway-only approach to
label: Paragraph

text: transportation planning to rest forever. For the first time, federal transportation planning
label: Paragraph

text: included significant provisions to balance local land use planning, the environment,
label: Paragraph

text: historic preservation, and mobility for children, the elderly, and the disabled. Light rail
label: Caption

text: and subway systems, even bicycle and pedestrian travel, were featured as important
label: Paragraph

text: components of an overall transportation planning approach.
label: Paragraph

text: The notion of what transportation planning is or should be has unequivocally grown
label: Paragraph

text: more complex, increasingly attentive to a wide complex of consequences that flow from
label: Paragraph

text: the simple act of traveling from one point to another. The pessimist would point to the
label: Paragraph

text: stranglehold of the automobile on everything from the shape of cities to the air we
label: Paragraph

text: breathe and conclude that transportation planning has only contributed to the problem.
label: Paragraph

text: Citing the increased congestion in urban areas, the growing number of gas-guzzling
label: Paragraph

text: vehicles, and the rampant path of sprawl, the doubter would have ample evidence.
label: Paragraph

text: The optimist, however, might point to the incremental progress that is apparent in
label: Paragraph

text: transportation planning over time, including the increasing interest in what is often called
label: Paragraph

text: “smart growth” legislation that attempts to address the relationship of transportation
label: Paragraph

text: planning and land use, and the increased use of public transportation. As the century
label: Paragraph

text: ended, public transportation ridership was again on the rise, with an equivalent of a
label: Paragraph

text: million new trips of public transportation ridership, increasing by percentages greater
label: Paragraph

text: than any other travel modes, including motor vehicle travel. Significantly, these gains
label: Paragraph

text: were evident in central cities, suburbs, and even rural areas, and the idea of a
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive approach to transportation planning shows evidence of spreading with
label: Paragraph

text: increased levels of influence and acceptance.
label: Paragraph

text: TRIBUNE TOWER INTERNATIONAL
label: Title

text: COMPETITION (1922), CHICAGO
label: Caption

text: On 10 June 1922—the occasion of the newspaper’s diamond (75th) anniversary—the
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago Tribune announced a competition for the building of a new headquarters. Given
label: Paragraph

text: the title “The Tribune Tower Competition,” the competition was conceived of as a
label: Paragraph

text: vehicle for commemorating the substantial growth and achievements of both the
label: Paragraph

text: newspaper and the city of Chicago. In statements accompanying the program, site, and
label: Paragraph

text: submission requirements, the Tribune Building Corporation—the stated “Owner” in the
label: Paragraph

text: competition documents—hoped for something even grander: an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: representation of a new time and place befitting the postwar era of limitless and
label: Paragraph

text: boundless opportunity. Viewing the submissions for the competition, Louis I. Sullivan,
label: Paragraph

text: the well-known member of the so-called Chicago School of Architecture, registered his
label: Paragraph

text: own messianic hopes for the future of architecture in an issue of Architectural Record.
label: Paragraph

text: Equating architecture with humanity’s redemption, Sullivan gave voice to the highly
label: Paragraph

text: romanticized, Nietzschean spirit of the time:
label: Paragraph

text: The craving for beauty thus set forth by The Tribune is imbued with romance;
label: Paragraph

text: both that high Romance which is the essence, the vital impulse, that inheres in
label: Paragraph

text: all the great works of man in all places and all times, that vibrates in his loftiest
label: Paragraph

text: thoughts, his heroic deeds, his otherwise inexplicable sacrifices, and which
label: Paragraph

text: forms the halo of his great compassions, and of the tragedy within the depths of
label: Paragraph

text: his sorrows. So deeply seated, so persistent, so perennial in the heart of
label: Paragraph

text: humanity is this ineffable presence, that, suppressed in us, we decay and die.
label: Paragraph

text: For man is not born to trouble, as the sparks fly upward; he is born to hope and
label: Paragraph

text: to achieve,
label: Paragraph

text: Prominently featured in both trade journals and traditional newspapers, the Tribune
label: Paragraph

text: Tower Competition engendered extensive debate among national and international
label: Paragraph

text: architects and advocates of architecture. Perhaps exceeding the Tribune Building
label: Paragraph

text: Corporation’s expectations, notice of the competition provided a touchstone for a vital
label: Paragraph

text: discussion of contemporary architecture, resulting in debates that considered not only
label: Paragraph

text: matters of style and taste but social, intellectual, and technological ideals as well. The
label: Paragraph

text: competition’s brief was notable for its conscious attempt to elicit an iconic model for the
label: Paragraph

text: future both of architecture and of mankind’s aspirations for the New World, and all this
label: Paragraph

text: was to be represented by the skyscraper. In addition, prominent citizens of the city of
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago—always conscious of their competition with cities on the eastern seaboard—
label: Paragraph

text: proposed the competition as a challenge to both the city and the world. Appearing with
label: Paragraph

text: great fanfare in the foremost national and international newspapers, the prominence of
label: Paragraph

text: the Tribune Building Corporation’s flagship newspaper ensured the competition’s
label: Paragraph

text: visibility across the Americas and Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: The Tribune Tower Competition brief noted the phenomenal growth of the Tribune by
label: Paragraph

text: chronicling the humble beginnings of the newspaper, growing from a small daily that
label: Paragraph

text: began with the printing of 400 copies to a circulation of over four million copies per
label: Paragraph

text: week at the time. Mirroring language used by the Tribune’s contemporaries—a list that
label: Paragraph

text: included major corporations and civic-minded cultural and educational institutions—the
label: Paragraph

text: primary reason for the competition was said to be “the creation of a building that would
label: Paragraph

text: enhance civic beauty and pride while at the same time augmenting the profile and
label: Paragraph

text: visibility of the newspaper.” As if to downplay the more practical aspects of the
label: Paragraph

text: competition, the actual building program was outlined in rather mundane if relatively
label: Paragraph

text: sparse terms: the building was to be “erected on North Michigan Avenue property to
label: Paragraph

text: house its executive and business departments,” with the consideration that the enlarged
label: Paragraph

text: (and growing) departments in the plant (production) building would also be
label: Paragraph

text: accommodated. In addition, the building as designed was to provide for the future
label: Paragraph

text: adaptation and expansion of all departments.
label: Paragraph

text: A more significant component of the competition brief was the Tribune Building
label: Paragraph

text: Corporation’s choice of the building site. Underlining the importance of the site—located
label: Paragraph

text: between numbers 431 and 439 Michigan Avenue just north of the famous downtown
label: Paragraph

text: Loop—the visibility of the building was stated clearly from the outset: It was to be
label: Paragraph

text: “situated at the heart of the business and shopping district of Chicago,” thus ensuring that
label: Paragraph

text: the newspaper would be a prominent aspect of the cityscape. By providing an anchor for
label: Paragraph

text: the development of this particular part of the city, the building was to be thought of as a
label: Paragraph

text: prominent node in the current and future development of the city and was therefore seen
label: Paragraph

text: as simultaneously benefiting both the corporate institution and the general population, a
label: Paragraph

text: joining of two constituencies in the shared goal of great civic achievement. Accordingly,
label: Paragraph

text: the site appeared to many civic officials and urban planners to be ideal, if not tinged with
label: Paragraph

text: an air of inevitability, as the boulevard on which the property fronted (Michigan Avenue)
label: Paragraph

text: had been substantially improved by the city of Chicago to enable the area’s increased
label: Paragraph

text: visibility relative to other vital areas of the city. Becoming a central component of
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago’s urban fabric, the site was proposed as both the real and the imaginary central
label: Paragraph

text: node for the financial, social, and political workings of Chicago, a city that many people
label: Paragraph

text: at the time perceived to be the capital city of the industrialized upper Midwest, the fabled
label: Paragraph

text: “City of Broad Shoulders.” The design and construction of a new office tower to house
label: Paragraph

text: the region’s most important newspaper would seal Chicago’s fate as a center of visionary,
label: Paragraph

text: albeit practical, significance.
label: Paragraph

text: In the language of its time, the final aim of the Tribune Tower Competition was stated
label: Paragraph

text: in vague aesthetic terms. Accordingly, the successful entrant architect was challenged to
label: Paragraph

text: “erect the most beautiful and distinctive office building in the world.” In formulating the
label: Paragraph

text: mission of the competition, the board of the Tribune had sought professional advice,
label: Paragraph

text: asserting that “this competition has been instituted [with the guidance of] the American
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of Architects.” In recognition of the better-regarded architects of the time and to
label: Paragraph

text: ensure the highest profile among members of the architectural profession, the competition
label: Paragraph

text: issued a special invitation to ten architects of national renown, with the rest of the
label: Paragraph

text: submissions garnered from those responding to a published “general invitation.” The
label: Paragraph

text: winner of the competition was also given the guarantee of being “engaged by the Owner
label: Paragraph

text: [the Tribune Building Corporation] for the commission of the winning entry. Although
label: Paragraph

text: quite specific, the actual submission requirements were relatively minimal: a sketch floor
label: Paragraph

text: plan at the Michigan Avenue level, showing main entrance lobby, stair and elevator
label: Caption

text: distribution, and the connection of the new building with the plant at one-eighth-inch
label: Paragraph

text: scale; a typical office floor on a 24-by-36-inch sheet of paper; the Michigan Avenue
label: Paragraph

text: (west) elevation; the Austin Avenue (south) elevation; a longitudinal section from west to
label: Paragraph

text: east; and a perspective showing the entire building from the southwest.
label: Paragraph

text: The cumulative prize awards for the competition were set at $100,000, an enormous
label: Paragraph

text: sum of money at the time. The closing of the competition would occur on 1 November
label: Paragraph

text: 1922, with a one-month grace allowed for drawings arriving from foreign “distant
label: Paragraph

text: points.” By the time of the “absolute closing date” for competition submissions on 1
label: Paragraph

text: December 1922 (the date the winners of the competition would be announced), 204
label: Paragraph

text: designs had been received by the initial due date, with 49 more designs received “after
label: Paragraph

text: the competition was closed.” In the Tribune’s publication of the competition entries, 260
label: Paragraph

text: submissions were eventually included.
label: Paragraph

text: On 23 November 1922, exactly eight days prior to the 1 December closing date, the
label: Paragraph

text: competition jury, made up of selected architects, city officials, several members of the
label: Paragraph

text: newspaper’s board of directors, and other interested parties (a group collectively referred
label: Paragraph

text: to as the competition’s “advisory committee”) met to whittle the large number of entrants
label: Paragraph

text: to a small group of 12 semifinalists, apparently leaving open the option of considering
label: Paragraph

text: any late (foreign) entries. With an obvious seriousness of purpose, the same advisory
label: Paragraph

text: committee announced that
label: Title

text: hie ga Tite
label: Title

text: Tribune Tower, Chicago, Illinois, Hood and Howells, 1925
label: Caption

text: © GreatBuildings.com
label: Title

text: it had reached a tentative decision on the final order of prizes on 29 November, when, in
label: Paragraph

text: what was recorded retrospectively in rather dramatic fashion, “entry number 187 was
label: Paragraph

text: cleared through customs from Finland” and reassembled for submission. The
label: Paragraph

text: committee’s final decision was finally posted on 3 December 1922. Deemed a unanimous
label: Paragraph

text: decision, the prize winners were the firms of John Mead Howells and Raymond M.Hood
label: Paragraph

text: Associates of New York City (first prize, with an award of $50,000); entry number 187
label: Paragraph

text: from Finland, the architect Eliel Saarinen (second prize, with an award of $20,000); and
label: Paragraph

text: the Chicago firm of Holabird and Roche, who were awarded third prize with a cash
label: Paragraph

text: award of $10,000. The remainder of the prize money was then distributed in $2,000
label: Paragraph

text: increments to the ten American architects invited to enter the competition at the outset,
label: Paragraph

text: invitees that included, among others, firms headed by Bertram Goodhue and James
label: Paragraph

text: Gamble Rogers; the New York firm Hood and Howells Associates; and two prominent
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago firms, Holabird and Roche and D.H.Burnham and Company.
label: Paragraph

text: At the close of the competition, 23 countries were represented. Announcements of the
label: Paragraph

text: winners of the competition and further details regarding the entrants and the nature of
label: Paragraph

text: their work were published in metropolitan newspapers throughout the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: Newspapers in Europe, including the Tribune's European edition, highlighted the
label: Paragraph

text: outcome of the competition; it also received prominent attention in domestic and
label: Paragraph

text: international architectural trade journals of the time. The publication of the competition
label: Paragraph

text: results only contributed to the debates surrounding the future of architecture in Europe
label: Paragraph

text: and the Americas.
label: Paragraph

text: Further recognition of the importance of the Tribune Tower Competition continued for
label: Paragraph

text: some time after the announcement of the competition winners. Multiple requests for the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition of the drawings were fielded by the newspaper’s offices, including requests
label: Paragraph

text: from numerous art institutes, associations, and schools; many chapters of the American
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of Architects; and large universities and educational institutions throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: United States. In recognition of these requests for a publication or exhibition of the
label: Paragraph

text: entries, the Tribune Building Corporation agreed to a traveling exhibition featuring
label: Paragraph

text: drawings by the competition’s entrants. The exhibition, accompanied by a publication of
label: Paragraph

text: record, specifically addressed the competition’s educational and cultural potential. In
label: Paragraph

text: announcing its response to the flurry of requests from across the country, the Tribune
label: Paragraph

text: Building Corporation issued the following statement on | January 1923: “The importance
label: Paragraph

text: of such an exhibit to furthering the advance of architecture, especially in the study of the
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper, cannot well be exaggerated. The designs in some instances have cost the
label: Paragraph

text: architects competing from 1000 to 10,000 dollars each. With 23 countries represented,
label: Paragraph

text: the exhibition will show the ideas of the great architects from all parts of the world.”
label: Paragraph

text: The exhibition consisted of 135 perspective drawings, each drawn on a board
label: Paragraph

text: measuring 36 by 66 inches in accordance with the original, standard competition
label: Paragraph

text: requirement. The first exhibit of the competition took place at the University of Illinois,
label: Paragraph

text: both because of its proximity to the city of Chicago and because it happened to have the
label: Paragraph

text: largest enrollment of any school of architecture in the country at the time. The program
label: Paragraph

text: for the exhibition was stated to be primarily educational, with the stated benefit of
label: Paragraph

text: allowing for the study of the drawings by students and architects. Both the publicity and
label: Paragraph

text: the expense of the exhibition were borne by the Tribune.
label: Paragraph

text: The Tribune’s accompanying statement about the importance of the original
label: Paragraph

text: competition and the reason for the traveling exhibit speaks directly to the perception that
label: Paragraph

text: the Tribune Competition was a signal event—sentiments reflected in Louis Sullivan’s
label: Paragraph

text: observations in Architectural Record:
label: Title

text: There never has been such a contest and it is very doubtful that there ever will
label: Paragraph

text: be another.... The greatest architectural contest of history will result not only in
label: Paragraph

text: achievement of what the Tribune announced as its desire, the most beautiful and
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive office building in the world, but it will produce many other beautiful
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. It will give Chicago an architecture gem of the first water and it will
label: Paragraph

text: add permanently to the resources of the modern architect a mine of new ideas
label: Paragraph

text: and suggestions. This was the hope of the Tribune and it has been fully realized.
label: Paragraph

text: With these words, the Tribune Building Corporation reflected the general optimism of the
label: Paragraph

text: new century, an optimism that was reflected in the promotion of the “genius” of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and its makers. Both Louis Sullivan’s and Frank Lloyd Wright’s views on
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, published in popular journal articles and in numerous books, suggest a
label: Paragraph

text: similar point of view promulgated by advocates of the Chicago style, a school of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that viewed architecture as the direct manifestation of the genius of an
label: Paragraph

text: unfettered and un-self-conscious spirit. The city of Chicago, emblematic of the
label: Paragraph

text: burgeoning faith in the American Experiment, comprised a time and place in which
label: Paragraph

text: social, technological, and cultural progress were greeted not only optimistically but also
label: Paragraph

text: as above reproach. It was in this sense that architecture and urban planning were almost
label: Paragraph

text: universally—that is, until the spectacular failures of the socially progressive architectural
label: Paragraph

text: ideals of the post-World War Il era—regarded as the material revelation of the destiny
label: Paragraph

text: and greatness of a new age.
label: Paragraph
