text: TRUSS SYSTEMS
label: Title

text: Trusses are triangulated frameworks used as spanning or bracing elements in buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: bridges, transmission towers, and other structures. What distinguishes the truss from
label: Paragraph

text: other structural forms is precisely its triangulation, from which two benefits accrue: first,
label: Paragraph

text: the triangular geometry is inherently stable; second, all internal stresses—at least in
label: Paragraph

text: “ideal” trusses whose bars are pinned together at the vertices of each triangular panel and
label: Paragraph

text: whose loads are applied only at these pinned joints—are axial, that is, limited to pure
label: Paragraph

text: tension and pure compression.
label: Paragraph

text: Aside from its web of triangular panels, the truss has no intrinsic formal identity. Put
label: Paragraph

text: another way, it is the specific pattern of internal diagonal, vertical, or horizontal bars
label: Paragraph

text: (patterns that in many cases bear the names of their 19th-century inventors: Pratt, Howe,
label: Paragraph

text: Town, Warren, etc.) that makes the structure a truss, not its overall shape. One may
label: Paragraph

text: design an arch as a truss, a beam or column as a truss, or any number of tower forms—
label: Paragraph

text: essentially beams cantilevered from the ground plane—as trusses. Advantages of truss
label: Paragraph

text: construction include the following: (1) large trusses can be assembled from small
label: Paragraph

text: members pinned together, facilitating production, transportation, and erection; (2)
label: Paragraph

text: because all internal stresses are axial, with no bending stresses present, the truss is an
label: Paragraph

text: extremely efficient structural form; (3) because trusses are typically assembled from
label: Paragraph

text: individual elements bolted, welded, or nailed together, it is relatively easy to customize
label: Paragraph

text: the overall shape of the truss in relation to external loads and spans, and to adjust the
label: Paragraph

text: cross-sectional area of each member in relation to anticipated internal stresses.
label: Paragraph

text: Trusses have been used for many centuries; Andrea Palladio illustrated truss bridges in
label: Paragraph

text: his Four Books of Architecture as early as 1570. However, it was in the 19th century that
label: Paragraph

text: industrial expansion—in particular the need for long-span exhibition and market halls,
label: Paragraph

text: railroad terminals, and bridges—together with the development of engineering theory and
label: Paragraph

text: improvements in the production of cast and wrought iron, and later steel, provided the
label: Paragraph

text: motive and means for most of the advances in truss design that were exploited within
label: Paragraph

text: early 20th-century architecture. For example, the influence of 19th-century iron
label: Paragraph

text: trusswork in Henri Labrouste’s Biblioteque Nationale Reading Room in Paris (1875) can
label: Caption

text: be seen in the vaulted ceiling above the main concourse in McKim, Mead and White’s
label: Caption

text: Pennsylvania Station in New York City (1910); and the tradition of long-span three-
label: Paragraph

text: hinged arched trusses, epitomized in such 19th-century masterpieces as Contamin and
label: Paragraph

text: Dutert’s Galerie des Machines in Paris (1889), continues in 20th-century structures like
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Behrens’s AEG Turbine Factory in Berlin (1909) and Tony Garnier’s Municipal
label: Paragraph

text: Slaughterhouse in Lyons, France (1913).
label: Caption

text: Trusses are seldom found as expressive elements within the canon of mainstream early
label: Paragraph

text: 20th-century modernism. Like Gothic buttresses, trusses are directly constrained by the
label: Paragraph

text: geometrical logic of their structural form and, unlike prismatically pure columns and
label: Paragraph

text: slabs, or expressively cast concrete elements, cannot easily be subsumed within
label: Paragraph

text: modernism’s abstract, formal systems. It is only with Russian Constructivist and
label: Paragraph

text: derivative projects from the 1920s and 1930s that trusses were first exploited as
label: Paragraph

text: expressive elements within an explicitly modernist context. Prominent examples include
label: Paragraph

text: Alexander and Viktor Vesnin’s Pravda Building project in Moscow (1923), in which
label: Paragraph

text: trusses are used as wind-bracing elements within a composition that includes bold text,
label: Paragraph

text: angled planes, and glazed elevator towers; and Johannes M.Brinkman and L.C.van der
label: Caption

text: Vlugt’s Van Nelle Factory in Rotterdam (1930) featuring dynamic horizontal and sloping
label: Paragraph

text: trussed connecting bridges.
label: Paragraph

text: Early 20th-century trusses are also important as infrastructure (bridges) and as
label: Paragraph

text: industrial (long-span factory roofs), vernacular (ordinary wooden gable roofs), or
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic (hidden bracing or support) building elements. Gustav Lindenthal’s arched
label: Caption

text: Hell’s Gate Bridge in New York City (1916) and Albert Kahn’s Glenn Martin Aircraft
label: Title

text: Plant in Middle River, Maryland (1937), both utilize steel trusses that were the longest
label: Paragraph

text: spans of their type when constructed. Steel trusswork is commonly employed (and
label: Paragraph

text: hidden) within the central service “cores” of 20th-century commercial buildings to
label: Paragraph

text: provide bracing against horizontal wind and earthquake forces. Steel trusses are used to
label: Paragraph

text: transfer loads over large spans—allowing hotel rooms to be placed on top of lower-floor
label: Paragraph

text: ballrooms, or office buildings over railroad tracks—without themselves being expressed
label: Paragraph

text: as part of the architectural form. William LeMessurier’s development in the 1960s of a
label: Paragraph

text: “staggered truss” system is another example of an entirely pragmatic invention utilizing
label: Paragraph

text: trusses to minimize floor-to-floor dimensions in multistory steel-framed housing or hotel
label: Paragraph

text: blocks. Pre-engineered, factory-produced triangular wooden trusses made from common
label: Paragraph

text: lumber connected with toothed metal plates are widely used in 20th-century wood-
label: Paragraph

text: framed residential roof construction. Open-web steel joists, essentially off-the-shelf
label: Caption

text: trusses first manufactured in the early 1920s, routinely achieved spans of up to 144 feet
label: Paragraph

text: (44 meters) by the end of the century and are ubiquitous in one-story commercial and
label: Paragraph

text: industrial buildings. Even precastconcrete trusses, consisting of thin prismatic bars of
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete joined by steel gusset plates, were proposed for ordinary roof spans in
label: Paragraph

text: England during World War II, as an expedient response to the short supply of steel.
label: Paragraph

text: Where trusses are used deliberately as expressive elements within later 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, it is most often by appropriating and reinterpreting the industrial, off-the-
label: Paragraph

text: shelf, or pragmatic applications described above. Thus, ordinary steel openweb joists
label: Paragraph

text: were used in California by architect Raphael Soriano as early as 1938, by Ray and
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Eames in the influential house they built for themselves in Pacific Palisades,
label: Paragraph

text: California (1949), and in various industrialized building system designs such as Ezra
label: Paragraph

text: Ehrenkrantz’s School Construction Systems Development (SCSD, 1961). Alvar Aalto’s
label: Paragraph

text: fan-shaped bolted timber trusses supporting the double-skin roof of the Sdynatsalo town
label: Caption

text: hall council chamber in Finland (1952) recall, in their detailing, vernacular heavy-timber
label: Paragraph

text: roof trusses of 19th-century mill buildings. Mies van der Rohe’s project for a Chicago
label: Caption

text: Convention Hall (1953) visually integrates the diagonal members of its horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: trusswork within the orthogonal pattern of its exterior curtain wall. Vertical wind-bracing
label: Caption

text: trusses, typically hidden within the framework of tall buildings, are given similar
label: Paragraph

text: architectural expression on the exterior of Skidmore, Owings and Merrill’s Hancock
label: Caption

text: Building in Chicago (1970).
label: Paragraph

text: Trusses are commonly featured in so-called High Tech architecture of the late 20th-
label: Paragraph

text: century. Buildings within this genre reprise to some extent the Constructivists’ interest in
label: Paragraph

text: industrial production, but differ from Constructivist projects in at least two respects: High
label: Paragraph

text: Tech buildings tend to be less influenced by abstract compositional formulas and often
label: Paragraph

text: evidence a more theoretically grounded appreciation of structural systems as potential
label: Paragraph

text: sources of architectural expression. In Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers’s Pompidou
label: Paragraph

text: Center in Paris (1977), virtually the entire architectural concept relies on exposed
label: Paragraph

text: trusswork. Long-span roof trusses are used as dramatic and expressive elements in
label: Paragraph

text: innumerable High Tech buildings; examples include Norman Foster’s Sainsbury Visual
label: Paragraph

text: Arts Center near Norwich, England (1978), Michael Hopkins’s Research Laboratories for
label: Paragraph

text: Schlumberger in Cambridge, England (1984), and Nicholas Grimshaw’s Waterloo
label: Paragraph

text: International Rail Terminal (1994) in London, to name but a few.
label: Paragraph

text: TSCHUMI, BERNARD 1944
label: Title

text: Architect, Switzerland and France
label: Title

text: Bernard Tschumi’s architectural projects are probably best understood in relation to his
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical writings and ideas, many of which reflect his interest in surrealism and
label: Paragraph

text: poststructuralism. His sources range from Georges Bataille’s writings on philosophy and
label: Paragraph

text: eroticism to Jacques Derrida’s deconstruction as a methodology. A review of a few
label: Paragraph

text: specific adaptations of these ideas for architecture will help us understand the
label: Paragraph

text: significantly different way in which Tschumi conceived of the nature and purpose of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Three important theoretical concepts include the pleasures of architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: strategies of disjunction, and “cross-programming.”
label: Paragraph

text: The pleasures of architecture, according to Tschumi, are based on the relationships
label: Paragraph

text: between the physical (body) and the conceptual (mind) rather than the complete
label: Paragraph

text: absorption of one mode or experience by the other. Two written works, published to
label: Paragraph

text: accompany the exhibition of his work at the Museum of Modern Art in New York
label: Caption

text: (Event-Cities, 21 April-5 July 1994), demonstrate this proposition: one text is a
label: Paragraph

text: collection of his theoretical essays and the other a book of projects (works from his
label: Paragraph

text: architecture practice). Event-Cities establishes the duality of theory and practice that
label: Paragraph

text: allows for dialectical movement between the physical and the conceptual.
label: Paragraph

text: The experience of duality (or “in-between”) applies to his architecture as well as his
label: Paragraph

text: writings. Tschumi relies on the principle of disjunction (a strategy he developed in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1970s) to reveal the contradictions that exist in architecture between form and function,
label: Paragraph

text: as well as other oppositions and contradictions. Tschumi argued that habits and
label: Paragraph

text: conventional assumptions about architecture had to be interrupted or “displaced” in order
label: Paragraph

text: to make other experiences possible. He employed strategies of shock and
label: Paragraph

text: defamiliarization to radically shift design paradigms and challenge the viewer.
label: Paragraph

text: The theory of disjunction is evident in his critique of the modernist precept that form
label: Paragraph

text: must follow function. In his explanation of the design for the Pare de la Villette (Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: 1987-91), for example, Tschumi argued that form and function could ignore or even
label: Paragraph

text: conflict, and he proceeded to explore this disjunction or rupture by breaking up the space
label: Paragraph

text: as described in the competition program into volumes placed at the intersections of a
label: Paragraph

text: superimposed, non-site-specific grid. The volumes were designed as “folies,” a play on
label: Paragraph

text: the double meaning of the French word folie (madness or mental imbalance) and follies,
label: Paragraph

text: small pleasure pavilions or ruins popular in 19th-century landscape design. More
label: Paragraph

text: important, the shape and form of Tschumi’s folies were not determined by specific
label: Paragraph

text: functions; but rather were ingeniously designed as formal exercises and then modified
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent to their construction to accommodate specific functions, a process that
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated that function could follow form.
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi’s later work continued to explore other strategies of disjunction through dis-
label: Paragraph

text: or cross-programming. The opportunities for new architectural experiences made possible
label: Paragraph

text: by these concepts ranged from the “unclassifiable” or “unprogrammed” spaces of his
label: Paragraph

text: later projects such as Kansai Airport (Japan, 1988} and Le Fresnoy National Center for
label: Paragraph

text: the Contemporary Arts (Tourcoing, France, 1992—98) to those heterogeneous projects
label: Paragraph

text: that encompass multiple uses or functions, such as the Rouen Concert Hall and
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition Center in France and the Columbia University Student Center (Alfred Lerner
label: Title

text: Hall, New York City, 1994-99). He defined “in-between spaces” as inherently
label: Paragraph

text: ambiguous; they were not dedicated to a single or specific function. This ambiguity
label: Paragraph

text: provoked the uncanny, the strange, and the unfamiliar in architecture. Heterogeneous
label: Paragraph

text: spaces contained several normally unrelated functions simultaneously, such as those he
label: Paragraph

text: illustrated in The Manhattan Transcripts (1981): “the quarter-back tangoes on the skating
label: Paragraph

text: rink; the battalion skates on the tightrope.” Heterogeneous spaces are not solely
label: Paragraph

text: determined by function because life exceeds architecture, according to Tschumi. These
label: Paragraph

text: spaces invited the multiplicity and diversity of a contemporary fragmented culture.
label: Paragraph

text: With the Alfred Lerner Hall at Columbia University, Tschumi attempted to
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrate these spatial and design principles by containing a series of ramps for
label: Paragraph

text: circulation between
label: Title

text: Pare de la Villette, Paris, 1987-91
label: Caption

text: © Dan Delgado d2 Arch
label: Caption

text: floors, student mailboxes, and several other sitting, standing, and viewing conditions that
label: Paragraph

text: set up multiple possibilities for social contact.
label: Paragraph

text: Shock and disjunction made it possible for subjects to experience and recognize the
label: Paragraph

text: connections that subjects make between fragments that are artificial and yet habituated in
label: Paragraph

text: experience and thought. When habits are displaced, new experiences are possible.
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi’s goal was to redefine the experience of architecture itself.
label: Paragraph

text: JEAN LA MARCHE
label: Title

text: Biography
label: Title

text: Berard Tschumi was born in Lausanne, Switzerland, 25 January 1944; father was
label: Paragraph

text: architect Jean Tschumi (1904-62). Graduated with architecture degree from
label: Paragraph

text: Eidgendissische Technische Hochschule (Federal Institute of Technology) in Zurich,
label: Caption

text: 1969. Taught at Architectural Association in London (1970-79), the Institute for
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture and Urban Studies in New York (1976), Princeton University (1976, 1980),
label: Paragraph

text: and the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, New York City (1980-
label: Caption

text: 83). Dean, Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation, Columbia
label: Caption

text: University, New York City, 1988-2003. Won international competition for the planning
label: Caption

text: of the Pare de la Villette (Paris, 1983), an award that would propel him into international
label: Paragraph

text: architectural fame. Appointed chairman, Flushing Meadows Task Force in New York
label: Caption

text: (1987-89); member, Collége International de Philosophie; a chevalier in the Legion
label: Paragraph

text: d’Honneur; officer, Ordre des Arts et Lettres in France. Received the Grand Prix National
label: Caption

text: d’Architecture of France (1996) and England’s Royal Victoria Medal.

text: TUGENDHAT HOUSE, BRNO, CZECH
label: Caption

text: REPUBLIC
label: Title

text: Designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe; completed 1930
label: Caption

text: Among the most significant private houses of the 20th century, Ludwig Mies van der
label: Paragraph

text: Rohe’s Tugendhat House represents a material unity of steel, stone, and glass. Situated on
label: Paragraph

text: a slope to provide ample views, the Tugendhat House echoed Mies’ use of continuous
label: Paragraph

text: space first realized in the German Pavilion in Barcelona (1929).
label: Paragraph

text: The owners, Grete Weiss L6w-Beer and Fritz Tugendhat, met Mies in Berlin in 1927
label: Paragraph

text: before their marriage. They shared a preference for a modern style and an aversion to
label: Paragraph

text: traditional interiors. After viewing several of Mies’ buildings, including the Wolff house
label: Paragraph

text: in Guben, they commissioned the Berlin architect to design their new house.
label: Paragraph

text: In September 1928 Mies went to Brno to view the lot on which the house was to be
label: Paragraph

text: built, and on the evening of 31 December 1928, the first sketches were discussed. The
label: Paragraph

text: final design of the house was decided on around July 1929, when work on the
label: Paragraph

text: foundations was begun. Several changes were made during construction.
label: Paragraph

text: The house is built on an incline, with the living area on the southern side with a view
label: Paragraph

text: of the garden and the Brno cityscape. On the street, or northern side, the house looks
label: Paragraph

text: unremarkable, presenting a low and closed facade with a wide, covered entry area. The
label: Paragraph

text: garage and chauffeur’s quarters are on the right. On the left are the bedrooms and
label: Paragraph

text: bathrooms and a terrace with a view of the garden. These private rooms are separated
label: Paragraph

text: from the entryway by a vestibule that also contains the stairway to the lower floor. The
label: Caption

text: lower floor contains the servants’ quarters, kitchen, and pantry on the eastern side, but
label: Caption

text: most of the space is taken up with the living room. That living space, which is not visible
label: Paragraph

text: from the street, forms the center of the house and functions as dining room, workroom,
label: Paragraph

text: library, and sitting room. The living area gives access to another terrace on the same
label: Paragraph

text: level, from which a staircase leads into the garden. The cellars, which can be reached
label: Paragraph

text: from the kitchen by means of a circular staircase, contains spaces for the furnace,
label: Paragraph

text: machines to operate the windows, a laundry room, and so on. Originally it also contained
label: Paragraph

text: a darkroom because Fritz Tugendhat was an amateur filmmaker.
label: Paragraph

text: The most remarkable section of the house is the living area, spreading over an area of
label: Paragraph

text: 223 square meters (about 2400 square feet). Instead of designing a series of closed
label: Paragraph

text: spaces, Mies chose to build a single continuous space. This freedom in spatial division
label: Paragraph

text: was made possible by the use of a steel frame, which dispensed with the need for internal
label: Paragraph

text: supporting walls. Mies had already experimented with this principle in his houses for the
label: Paragraph

text: Weissenhofsiedlung in Stuttgart of 1927. In Brno his use of steel permitted a different
label: Paragraph

text: layout for each level, thus providing an exceptional openness of the living space. This
label: Paragraph

text: openness was reinforced by floor-to-ceiling windows on the southern and western sides.
label: Paragraph

text: The windows open up the interior space to the outside, much like the German Pavilion.
label: Paragraph

text: In the living area, the separate functions are structured and suggested by spatial means
label: Paragraph

text: and beautiful, pristine materials. A freestanding onyx wall separates the living room from
label: Paragraph

text: the workroom. A semicircular wooden wall with a Macassar veneer defines the dining
label: Paragraph

text: area. The arrangement of the furniture also structures the space, marking places for
label: Paragraph

text: various living functions. Moving it would undermine the “zoning” of the space. In the
label: Paragraph

text: living space, most of the furniture was metal, including Mies’ tube chair from Stuttgart
label: Paragraph

text: (1927) and his Barcelona armchair (1929). He also designed the sheet-metal “Brno
label: Paragraph

text: armchair” and the “Brno dining room chair.”
label: Paragraph

text: The technical facilities of the house were exceptional for the time. Central heating was
label: Paragraph

text: supplemented in the living area with a forced-hot-air system in the winter that also served
label: Paragraph

text: as airconditioning in the summer. In addition the house had built-in humidifiers and air
label: Paragraph

text: purifiers, a hydraulic system that lowered the living-area windows into the ground, and a
label: Paragraph

text: light sensor that automatically locked the front door at night.
label: Paragraph

text: The house’s high cost and the luxurious interior gave rise to criticism. Modernist
label: Paragraph

text: architects of Brno and Prague objected to the project on the basis of their social
label: Paragraph

text: convictions. Mies’ German origins and the fact that he had succeeded Hannes Meyer at
label: Paragraph

text: the Bauhaus also played a role in the disapproval from his Czech colleagues. As a
label: Paragraph

text: consequence Czech architectural circles ignored the house. A different controversy arose
label: Paragraph

text: in Germany, where Die Form asked whether the architectural ideas of Mies determined
label: Paragraph

text: the lifestyle of the inhabitants to too great a degree. Fritz and Grete Tugendhat denied this
label: Paragraph

text: in their response, also published in Die Form, but admitted that it was not possible to
label: Paragraph

text: change anything in the interior without disturbing the architect’s design.
label: Paragraph

text: The inhabitants did not have much time to try out Mies’ living concepts. In 1938 the
label: Paragraph

text: family decided to emigrate to Venezuela as a result of the threatened expansion of the
label: Paragraph

text: Nazi regime in Germany. The house stood empty for a year before being appropriated by
label: Paragraph

text: the German occupier. After 1945 the house first became a ballet school and then, in 1950,
label: Paragraph

text: part of the Brno children’s hospital, which used the space for physical therapy. In 1970
label: Paragraph

text: the City of Brno took over the house, but renovation on the house did not start until the
label: Paragraph

text: period 1983-86. The building was freed of additions and adaptations, but the original
label: Paragraph

text: furniture and equipment were largely lost. In 1995 the restoration of the interior was
label: Paragraph

text: undertaken, with remakes of the original furnishings. Since 1996 the house has been open
label: Paragraph

text: to visitors as part of the Bmo City Museum.
label: Paragraph

text: TURKEY
label: Title

text: As with other areas of cultural production, in Turkey the prevailing theme in both the
label: Paragraph

text: practice and the discourse of architecture in the 20th century was the tension between a
label: Paragraph

text: desire to assert a uniquely national character and the quest to become modern by keeping
label: Paragraph

text: up with international trends in the profession and by responding to the demands of an
label: Paragraph

text: ever-changing global context. The balance between the two tendencies shifted frequently,
label: Paragraph

text: remaining a constant source of debate throughout the century. On the basis of
label: Paragraph

text: overarching similarities in the organization of professional practice and education, the
label: Paragraph

text: dominant discourses in architecture, the types of buildings commissioned, and the
label: Paragraph

text: identity of the clients, as well as broader issues concerning national and international
label: Paragraph

text: politics, economic policies, and ideological orientations, we may divide the time line
label: Paragraph

text: between the 1890s and the present into four periods. Longer surveys offer further
label: Paragraph

text: subperiodizations on the basis of the identity of the architects and stylistic preferences.
label: Paragraph

text: The early Republican years have been divided into First Nationalist (1890s—1927), First
label: Paragraph

text: International (1927—late 1930s), and Second Nationalist (late 1930s—late 1940s).
label: Paragraph

text: 1890s to Mid-1920s
label: Title

text: The decades preceding the post-World War I collapse and subsequent partition of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ottoman Empire were defined by turbulent wars followed by waves of mass migration,
label: Paragraph

text: the encroachment of European imperialism, and formidable economic problems. To
label: Paragraph

text: remedy these, the Ottoman government implemented various measures designed to
label: Paragraph

text: modernize the state and its institutions after European models. Similarly, in an effort to
label: Paragraph

text: raise the standards in professional education, in 1882 the School of Fine Arts (Senayii
label: Paragraph

text: Nefise}, based loosely on the Beaux-Arts model, was founded, followed in 1884 by the
label: Paragraph

text: School of Engineering (Hendese-i Miilkiye Mektebi), for which faculty were recruited
label: Paragraph

text: mainly from Germany and Austria. Foreign faculty from both schools were also
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned for various projects, many of which were novel building types that housed
label: Paragraph

text: some new function of the modernizing Ottoman capital. The Ottoman Public Debt
label: Paragraph

text: Administration (1899), the Imperial College of Medicine (1903), and the Museum of
label: Paragraph

text: Archaeology (1891-1907) were designed by Alexandre Vallaury of the Fine Arts School,
label: Paragraph

text: and the Deutsche Bank and the Sirkeci Railroad Terminal (1890) were the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Professor Jachmund. Among other foreign professionals in Istanbul at the time,
label: Paragraph

text: Raimondo D’Aronco designed several pavilions at the Yildiz Palace, and Otto Ritter and
label: Paragraph

text: Helmut Cuno were commissioned to build the Haydarpasa Railroad Terminal (1908). The
label: Paragraph

text: professional sensibilities of Istanbul’s foreign builders differed, depending on their
label: Paragraph

text: backgrounds. However, when confronted with the challenge of building in a densely
label: Paragraph

text: packed city with a complex history, a diverse population, and enduring architectural
label: Paragraph

text: traditions, they typically resorted to incorporating some Ottoman decorative elements
label: Paragraph

text: into the mainly neoclassical decorative scheme of the interior and exterior surfaces of
label: Paragraph

text: their buildings while adhering to spatial layouts with the recognizable symmetry and
label: Paragraph

text: axiality of the Beaux-Arts tradition. Young Ottoman architects trained in the new schools
label: Paragraph

text: or Europe also experimented with these ideas. Generally known as Ottoman Revivalism,
label: Paragraph

text: these efforts to incorporate historical references into distinctively modern building
label: Paragraph

text: programs were comparable to contemporary trends in Europe in terms of discourse and
label: Paragraph

text: practice. This was evident, for example, in the similarity of the functional layout,
label: Paragraph

text: volumetric composition, and handling of historical references in Kemalettin Bey’s
label: Paragraph

text: Dérdiincii Vakif Hani (1912-26) business complex and Harikzedegan Apartments to their
label: Paragraph

text: European contemporaries and in Vedad (Tek) Bey’s Sirkeci Post Office (1909), which
label: Paragraph

text: bears a striking resemblance to Otto Wagner’s Postal Savings Bank (1904-06) in Vienna.
label: Paragraph

text: The conceptual breakdown between the spatial organization and the decorative
label: Paragraph

text: schemes (in Ottoman Revivalism) also dovetailed conveniently with the tenets of the
label: Paragraph

text: rising Turkish nationalism, which, albeit artificially, drew a distinction between
label: Paragraph

text: civilization and culture. The nationalists deemed civilization to be a system of objectively
label: Paragraph

text: formulated universal truths and rules pertaining to practical matters that could be
label: Paragraph

text: borrowed from the West, but defined culture as a subjective system of beliefs and mores
label: Paragraph

text: that had to be jealously guarded as the core of a distinctively Turko-Islamic identity.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite its dubious grounding, the analogy was extended into architecture, where new
label: Paragraph

text: construction technologies and building types were imported as products of Western
label: Paragraph

text: civilization, whereas the formal repertoire of Ottoman architecture was retained as a
label: Paragraph

text: vestige of the national culture. Eventually, when the protonationalist Young Turks seized
label: Paragraph

text: power in 1908, their ambitious initiative to construct administrative and institutional
label: Paragraph

text: buildings throughout the empire effectively converted Ottoman Revivalism into the
label: Paragraph

text: official architecture and, more important, replaced its imperial associations with
label: Paragraph

text: nationalist ones.
label: Paragraph

text: After the proclamation of the republic (1923), which marked Turkey’s transition to
label: Paragraph

text: nation-statehood, their credentials as the creators of the nationalist architecture helped
label: Paragraph

text: Kemal and Vedat Bey and their cohorts secure important commissions for some of the
label: Paragraph

text: first official buildings of the country’s new capital, Ankara. Kemalettin Bey’s Gazi
label: Caption

text: School of Education (1926-30) and Vakif Apartments (1928); Vedat Bey’s Parliament
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1926) and the Ankara Palas Hotel (1924-27), Arif Hikmet’s (Koyunoglu)
label: Caption

text: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (1927), Turkish Hearths (1927-30), and Museum of
label: Paragraph

text: Ethnography (1927-30); and Giulio Mongeri’s Agriculture Bank (1926-29) and Labor
label: Paragraph

text: Bank (1928) stand among the most prominent buildings of the new republic’s early years.
label: Paragraph

text: Mid-1920s to Late 1940s
label: Title

text: Beyond introducing a new political entity, by founding a new republic, Turkey’s leaders
label: Paragraph

text: tried to inaugurate a modern national identity for the country and its people through
label: Paragraph

text: extensive legal, institutional, and administrative reforms. During this formative period,
label: Paragraph

text: Turkey’s collaboration with longtime ally Germany brought German experts and capital,
label: Paragraph

text: shaping the principles and direction of the modernization process. Turkey’s leaders
label: Paragraph

text: regarded architecture and urbanism as crucial instruments for rendering their reforms
label: Paragraph

text: tangible. Thus, building a new capital in Ankara, for which they commissioned a plan
label: Paragraph

text: from Hermann Jansen (1928-32), was one of their most ambitious undertakings. As the
label: Paragraph

text: first plan introducing modern planning principles—such as land use zoning and a
label: Paragraph

text: greenbelt system—on the scale of an entire city, Jansen’s plan was regarded as a model
label: Paragraph

text: for the subsequent development of all Turkish cities.
label: Paragraph

text: In architecture, incoming foreign professionals sidelined their Turkish counterparts in
label: Paragraph

text: obtaining government commissions, as the omission of historicist references in their
label: Paragraph

text: projects favored them to Turkey’s leaders, who by then had moved away from a
label: Paragraph

text: particularist nationalism with strong Turko-Islamic associations toward a universalist
label: Paragraph

text: position, seeking to integrate Turkey with Europe. In actuality, the stripped-down Central
label: Paragraph

text: European Neoclassicism of Theodor Post’s Ministry of Health, Ankara (1926-27) or
label: Paragraph

text: Clemens Holzmeister’s ministerial buildings (1929-36) in the new government quarter,
label: Paragraph

text: to name a few, shared the same Beaux-Arts-inspired compositional principles with
label: Paragraph

text: nationalist architecture. However, it was more appealing to Turkey’s leaders because its
label: Paragraph

text: restrained unornamented appearance imparted a desirable sense of stately dignity and
label: Paragraph

text: also because it was less labor intensive and required cheaper materials.
label: Paragraph

text: As evidenced by the recruitment of artists, architects, and intellectuals fleeing Nazi
label: Paragraph

text: persecution alongside those with ties to the German government, the Turkish government
label: Paragraph

text: was interested more in the expertise and skills of its foreign specialists than in their
label: Paragraph

text: political associations. Although they rarely found a platform for expressing their political
label: Paragraph

text: views, émigré architects injected a different strain of modernist sensibilities into Turkey’s
label: Paragraph

text: professional and intellectual discourses both through their involvement in the massive
label: Paragraph

text: overhaul of higher education and through projects that displayed the trademark traits of
label: Paragraph

text: German modernism, such as broken masses, interlocking volumes, open plans, and a
label: Paragraph

text: move away from symmetry and axiality. Bruno Taut’s Faculty of Language, History, and
label: Paragraph

text: Geography (1937) and Trabzon High School (1937-38) and Martin Elsaesser’s
label: Paragraph

text: Sumerbank Headquarters (1937) figure among the prominent examples of the work of
label: Paragraph

text: German émigrés in Turkey. Moreover,
label: Paragraph

text: Turkish Historical Society, central court atrium, designed by Turgut Cansever
label: Caption

text: © Aga Khan Trust for Culture
label: Title

text: Martin Wagner’s consultancy for the Istanbul Municipality and Ernst Reuter’s tenure in
label: Paragraph

text: the School of Political Science in Ankara served as a foundation for modern town-
label: Paragraph

text: planning education in Turkey.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, local architects denounced their exclusion from most major government
label: Paragraph

text: projects in Arkitekt, the first Turkish-language professional journal, which provided
label: Paragraph

text: information about the latest trends and debates in the profession. Arkitekt also promoted
label: Paragraph

text: the work of Turkish architects, who, as evidenced by Sekip Akalin’s Ankara Railroad
label: Paragraph

text: Terminal (1937), Seyfi Arkan’s Palace of Exhibitions (1933), and Harbi Holtan’s
label: Paragraph

text: Istanbul University Observatory (1936), were experimenting with both modernist and
label: Paragraph

text: neoclassical repertoires. In the late 1930s, Sedad Hakki Eldem, one of the most prolific
label: Paragraph

text: Turkish architects of the century, spearheaded the Second Nationalist movement, calling
label: Paragraph

text: for a return to national precedents for inspiration. However, as in the examples of
label: Paragraph

text: Atatiirk’s Mausoleum (1942-53, by Emin Onat and Orhan Arda) and the Colleges of
label: Paragraph

text: Sciences of the Istanbul (1944) and Ankara (1945) universities (by $.H. Eldem and Emin
label: Paragraph

text: Onat), rather than introducing new spatial ideas, the second wave of nationalists retained
label: Paragraph

text: their connection to the Beaux-Arts tradition, adhering to the organizational principles of
label: Paragraph

text: the Central European Neoclassicism of Clemens Holzmeister and Paul Bonatz. Their
label: Paragraph

text: references to local traditions took the form of stylized Ottoman decorative elements with
label: Paragraph

text: a heightened awareness of precedents in civic and domestic architecture in the
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of masses and plans.
label: Paragraph

text: More ubiquitous although less studied in this period are the numerous urban plans and
label: Paragraph

text: institutional structures (schools, railroad stations, and community centers) that constituted
label: Paragraph

text: the recurring and recognizable elements of a standardized national landscape. Designed
label: Paragraph

text: and built by central state agencies, these structures were integral to the nation-building
label: Paragraph

text: and modernization strategies. Among others, Turkey’s first female architects, Leman
label: Paragraph

text: Tomsu and Munewer Belen, built their careers on these commissions.
label: Paragraph

text: Late 1940s to Mid-1980s
label: Title

text: In the aftermath of World War IL, the onset of the Cold War and the polarization of the
label: Paragraph

text: international arena into rival blocs brought Turkey closer to the United States politically,
label: Paragraph

text: economically, and culturally. American experts, capital, and models of modernization
label: Paragraph

text: replaced those of Germany. The single-party rule ended in 1950, and more liberal
label: Paragraph

text: economic policies were gradually adopted.
label: Paragraph

text: Significant changes also occurred in the architectural profession and education. With
label: Paragraph

text: more architects graduating and venturing into private practice, the Chamber of Architects
label: Paragraph

text: was formed in 1950 to protect the interests of the profession and to promote fair
label: Paragraph

text: practices, especially in government commissions. In 1956, the Middle East Technical
label: Paragraph

text: University Faculty of Architecture was opened in Ankara, adding American models of
label: Paragraph

text: professional education to French and German models adopted earlier by the two schools
label: Paragraph

text: in Istanbul.
label: Paragraph

text: During this period, the state continued to be the primary source of projects and jobs,
label: Paragraph

text: but a growing clientele of private entrepreneurs also began to commission projects, such
label: Paragraph

text: as factories, hotels, and office buildings. Nevzat Erol’s Istanbul City Hall (1953);
label: Paragraph

text: Skidmore, Owings and Merrill’s Istanbul Hilton Hotel (1952, with S.H. Eldem); Bozkurt,
label: Paragraph

text: Bolak, and Beken’s Ulus Business Complex (1954); and Behruz and Altug Cinici’s
label: Paragraph

text: Middle East Technical University campus (starting in 1955) stand out as early examples
label: Paragraph

text: of the expanding repertoire of architectural practice.
label: Paragraph

text: The diversification of projects, the increasing numbers of architects, and changes in
label: Paragraph

text: education multiplied the stylistic, theoretical, and ethical discourses, especially after the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s. The various strains of postwar internationalism with which Turkish architects
label: Paragraph

text: experimented may be observed in Giinay Cilingiroglu’s Istanbul Reklam (1969) and
label: Paragraph

text: Tercuman Press Facilities (1974), Sevki Vanli’s M.S.-B. Dormitories (1967-68), Sisa
label: Caption

text: and Tekeli’s Lassa Tire Factory (1975-77), and Sargin an Béke’s Is Bank Headquarters.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, as early as 1962, architects and scholars began to debate questions of
label: Paragraph

text: contextualism and cultural heritage. Eldem’s Zeyrek Social Security Complex (1963-70),
label: Caption

text: Turgut Cansever’s Turkish Historical Society (1966), and Cengiz Bektas’s Turkish
label: Paragraph

text: Language Society (1972-78) are examples of projects addressing issues of heritage,
label: Paragraph

text: context, and regional character. In the 1960s, population increase and waves of internal
label: Paragraph

text: migration resulted not only in the densification of major metropolitan areas, with
label: Paragraph

text: speculative apartment buildings emerg-
label: Title

text: Dogan Media (Printing) Center, designed by Hayati and Murat Tabanlioglu
label: Caption

text: © Aga Khan Trust for Culture
label: Title

text: ing as the dominant type of urban housing, but also in the growth of squatter settlements
label: Paragraph

text: around them. Although the academic and professional discourse became highly
label: Paragraph

text: politicized in response to these problems, little could be implemented to resolve them.
label: Paragraph

text: 1980s to the Present
label: Title

text: Starting in 1980, the introduction of liberal economic measures, designed to integrate
label: Paragraph

text: Turkey into the globalization process, followed by a military coup that facilitated their
label: Paragraph

text: implementation, triggered profound changes in society, culture, and politics and widened
label: Paragraph

text: the gap between the rich and the poor.
label: Paragraph

text: The state’s role in initiating new projects diminished, but with their newfound
label: Paragraph

text: autonomy, local governments organized competitions for various projects, such as
label: Paragraph

text: Davran Eskinat’s Ankara Bus Terminal (1995) and Hasan Ozbay and Tamer Basburg’s
label: Paragraph

text: Gaziantep City Hall (1987), among others. Meanwhile, the private sector clearly became
label: Paragraph

text: the major source of commissions. International partnerships and the influx of foreign
label: Paragraph

text: capital transformed existing patterns of work and consumption. Like their contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: counterparts that were mushrooming around the world, the new building types, which
label: Paragraph

text: were designed to accommodate emerging uses, were not particularly distinctive by
label: Paragraph

text: design, yet they stood as a remarkable novelty within the Turkish landscape. Exclusive
label: Paragraph

text: resort hotels, such as the Sheraton Voyager (1990, by S.Basatemir) and Falez (1990, by
label: Paragraph

text: Y. and §.Erdemir and S.Akkaya) in Antalya, and holiday villages, such as Pamfilya (by
label: Paragraph

text: Tuncay Cavdar), burgeoned in coastal regions. Luxury corporate hotels (the Sheraton and
label: Paragraph

text: Hilton in Ankara and the Swissotel, and Conrad Istanbul), business centers (Dogan Media
label: Paragraph

text: Center by Aydin Boysan and Hayati and Murat Tabanlioglu and Sabanci Center by Haluk
label: Caption

text: Tiimay and Ayhan Boke), and downtown shopping centers (Akmerkez by Han Karabey
label: Paragraph

text: and Atakule by Ragip Bulug) were built in major cities, which at the same time were
label: Paragraph

text: challenged by rampant unemployment and massive internal migration. Although squatter
label: Paragraph

text: settlements encircled many a Turkish metropolis, large housing developments accelerated
label: Paragraph

text: suburbanization. Such developments include both upscale (MESA Korusitesi and
label: Paragraph

text: Elvankent) and medium-range (Eryaman and Batikent) ones, gated communities
label: Paragraph

text: (Mercansaray Evleri and Kemer Country), malls (Galleria Atakéy, 1989, by Hayati
label: Caption

text: Tabanlioglu and Capitol Shopping Center, 1990-93, by Adnan Kazmaoglu and Murat
label: Caption

text: Cilingiroglu), and megastores catering primarily to the upper-middle and upper classes.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1990s, the conversion of Ciragan Palace and Sultanahmet Prison into luxury
label: Paragraph

text: hotels, the gradual gentrification of older urban neighborhoods, and the random formalist
label: Paragraph

text: replication of traditional motifs in new buildings, as well as a growing interest in
label: Paragraph

text: miscellaneous traditional artifacts, indicated the increasing commodification of
label: Paragraph

text: “heritage” in Turkey. As exemplified by the eclectic remix of historical precedents in
label: Paragraph

text: Kemer Country designed by Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk and Andres Duany, local tradition
label: Caption

text: had become one among many choices available to a select segment of Turkish society
label: Paragraph

text: with access to the benefits of globalization. Given the relative scarcity of debate about the
label: Paragraph

text: displacement of meanings in these examples and the rather indiscriminate importation of
label: Paragraph

text: global trends, such approaches to historical context can hardly be considered critical or
label: Paragraph

text: regionalist.
label: Paragraph

text: TWA AIRPORT TERMINAL
label: Title

text: Designed by Eero Saarinen; completed 1962 New York City, New York
label: Caption

text: Initially known as the Trans World Flight Center, the TWA Airport Terminal rose as
label: Paragraph

text: one of several stand-alone terminals that made up the original Idlewild Airport (now JFK
label: Paragraph

text: International) in Queens, a borough of New York City. The TWA Terminal, by Eero
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen and Associates, became the culminating work in Saarinen’s search for dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: sculptural expression in reinforced-concrete construction. The architect died during
label: Paragraph

text: emergency neurosurgery in 1961, the year before the terminal building opened.
label: Paragraph

text: The commission from the Trans World Airlines Company was made in 1956, just as
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen came to worldwide prominence with the completion of the General Motors
label: Paragraph

text: Technical Center (1955) in Warren, Michigan—a Mies-inspired scheme of a corporate-
label: Paragraph

text: scale campus begun with his father, architect Eliel Saarinen, in the 1940s. The airline
label: Paragraph

text: company wanted something much bolder from the younger Saarinen for its New York
label: Paragraph

text: terminal, expecting that its masterpiece would likewise represent the airline’s status as
label: Paragraph

text: the industry leader.
label: Paragraph

text: Eero Saarinen had already made clear his self-stated “urge to soar” in architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: starting with his 1948 competition winner for the Jefferson National Expansion
label: Paragraph

text: Memorial, colloquially known as the St. Louis Gateway Arch (1964). His quest
label: Paragraph

text: continued with the thin-shelled triangular concrete roof of the Kresge Auditorium (1955)
label: Caption

text: at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge and at Yale University’s
label: Paragraph

text: Ingalls Hockey Rink (1959) in New Haven, Connecticut. The rink, with its cablestrung
label: Paragraph

text: roof suspended from a humpbacked central concrete spine, was the forerunner of
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen’s Dulles International Airport (1962) in Chantilly, Virginia, and of Kenzo
label: Paragraph

text: Tange’s Tokyo Olympic Swim Hall (1964) as much as its formal considerations affected
label: Paragraph

text: the TWA design.
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen took his cue from its site, positioned at the far corner of the Idlewild property,
label: Paragraph

text: opposite the airport entry. The building was angled to sweep gently across at sidewalk
label: Paragraph

text: level to align itself with the curvature of its corner frontage roadway. Inside, behind the
label: Paragraph

text: encircling arms of the ticket lobby, Saarinen envisioned a shallow rise to a spacious
label: Paragraph

text: waiting hall from which matched winding staircases would lead passengers to the
label: Paragraph

text: departure level with its finger ramp out to waiting planes. (A second finger ramp was
label: Paragraph

text: added by the inheritors of the firm, Kevin Roche and John Dinkeloo.) Passenger
label: Paragraph

text: movement through the terminal building was to be channeled, gradually but with absolute
label: Paragraph

text: clarity, by the curved forms of the interior—a circulation process seen by Saarinen as
label: Paragraph

text: akin in spirit to the science of aerodynamics.
label: Paragraph

text: After a year spent working on trial models for the terminal, the chief obstacle for
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen and his firm lay in sorting out the best way to put a roof on the building. Along
label: Paragraph

text: with matters of site and function, structural integrity was the third guiding principle for
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen’s architectural practice. As a rule he worked closely with the firm’s associated
label: Paragraph

text: engineers. This was particularly the case with Ammann and Whitney, collaborators on
label: Paragraph

text: the TWA design as well as that for the Dulles Airport. In addition Saarinen was well
label: Paragraph

text: schooled in the works of Pier Luigi Nervi in Italy and was friends with Minoru
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki, a principal in the firm of Yamasaki, Hellmuth and Leinweber, architects for
label: Paragraph

text: the St. Louis Air Terminal (1954), with its domed interior spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen jettisoned earlier TWA roof schemes in favor of a more complex arrangement
label: Paragraph

text: of four interlocking vaulted segments, set on a perimeter of concrete edge beams. As with
label: Paragraph

text: Jorn Utzon’s counterbalanced roof sails in the Sydney Opera House (the entry that
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen supported in that city’s commission), a support system had yet to be devised for
label: Paragraph

text: the terminal roof. The firm and the engineers jointly solved the problem with the
label: Paragraph

text: introduction of a four-poster arrangement of irregular Y-shaped piers, the front two
label: Paragraph

text: serving as markers for the terminal entry. Model photographs document how the piers
label: Caption

text: were molded, as if carved from a bar of soap, in keeping with Saarinen’s aesthetic vision
label: Paragraph

text: for the building as a whole, without any loss of structural integrity. A rudimentary
label: Paragraph

text: version of the various new roof and support elements was recorded as a set of thumbnail
label: Paragraph

text: sketches preserved as part of the Eero Saarinen Papers at his alma mater, Yale University.
label: Caption

text: Also hearkening back to the Saarinens’ Finnish background, Kevin Roche among others
label: Paragraph

text: has noted how the shape of the terminal echoes that of an old Norseman’s helmet, with its
label: Paragraph

text: split shell and upturned edge.
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen saw the final composition for the building as somewhat baroque in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: its fluid, sequential layout, “creating a [comparable] dynamic space...but using different
label: Paragraph

text: play blocks” to create “a total environment” where each part of the design “belonged to
label: Paragraph

text: the same form-world” (1968). Some architecture critics, notably Vincent Scully, Jr., were
label: Paragraph

text: initially dismissive of the building but later determined that it had its merits. Art historian
label: Paragraph

text: Henry-Russell Hitchcock similarly dismissed the building in the Zodiac (1962). The
label: Paragraph

text: flying public had no such reservations.
label: Paragraph

text: In a tribute to Saarinen, published by Architectural Forum in October 1961, editor
label: Paragraph

text: Douglas Haskell made fond reference to “Eero’s ‘big bird’ in concrete.” Through his
label: Paragraph

text: final days, even as the terminal roofs were being finished, Saarinen downplayed any
label: Paragraph

text: zoomorphic interpretations of the building, preferring instead that it be seen and
label: Paragraph

text: experienced as a visual analogy of flight. Unfortunately, for the terminal building and
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen’s hopes for it, the nature of air travel has altered dramatically over intervening
label: Paragraph

text: decades, prompting a host of changes to airport infrastructure. Nearly all the changes
label: Paragraph

text: have wreaked havoc with the layout of Saarinen’s once-expansive interiors. Thirty-three
label: Caption

text: years after Saarinen’s last sight of the unfinished building, with both TWA and its
label: Paragraph

text: flagship terminal reeling in the wake of postReagan airline deregulation, architecture
label: Paragraph

text: critic Herbert Muschamp did find one silver lining for the beleaguered masterwork. In his
label: Paragraph

text: column of 6 November 1994 for the New York Times, “Stay of Execution for a Dazzling
label: Paragraph

text: Airline Terminal,” Muschamp reported that the New York City Council had voted to
label: Paragraph

text: uphold the air terminal’s designation as a municipal landmark.
label: Paragraph

text: TYPOLOGY
label: Title

text: Typology, the study of types or classes of objects, has long served to catalyze debates
label: Paragraph

text: about both representation and invention. In architecture the types in question may be
label: Paragraph

text: defined by form (such as central plan churches), by their presumed originary role (such as
label: Paragraph

text: the “primitive hut”), by program or function (schools and museums), or by a historical
label: Paragraph

text: sedimentation of characteristics (for example, English terrace housing). “Types” are
label: Paragraph

text: objects of study, and “typology” is the study of them.
label: Paragraph

text: Typology must be exhaustive concerning its chosen class of objects, and thus its limits
label: Paragraph

text: are as important as its particular content, as when Nikolaus Pevsner opened his Outline of
label: Paragraph

text: European Architecture (1943) by excluding the utilitarian “bicycle shed.” Any typology
label: Paragraph

text: aims to reduce the potentially infinite variety of objects considered. In the most explicitly
label: Paragraph

text: typological studies of architecture and urban morphology, this gives rise to arrays of
label: Paragraph

text: diagrams depicting variations in plan, section, and elevation, of which a thorough
label: Paragraph

text: German tradition is a useful example (Geist, 1983). Related networks of researchers in
label: Paragraph

text: France, Italy, and the United States continue to work explicitly in a methodological vein
label: Paragraph

text: known as “typomorphology” (see Vernez Moudon, 1994).
label: Paragraph

text: Interest in type among architects and theorists can be understood as the search for a
label: Paragraph

text: middle ground between the poles of pure invention and blind determinism. Since the
label: Paragraph

text: beginnings of architectural modernity in the 18th and 19th centuries, advocates of type as
label: Paragraph

text: a guide or foundation of design have tended to define it by exclusion of these extremes;
label: Paragraph

text: hence A.C. Quatremére de Quincy’s (1755-1849) classic distinction, made in 1829,
label: Paragraph

text: between the “type” and the “model.” The type, for this influential French theoretician, is
label: Paragraph

text: an ideal schema that is reproduced without copying, whereas the model is to be imitated
label: Paragraph

text: “as it is.’ Quatremeré’s type is above all not a model and cannot be fully incarnated in
label: Paragraph

text: any single instance; moreover, its various instances might not even resemble one another.
label: Paragraph

text: Leaving as it does a wide terrain open for formal invention, this notion allies architecture
label: Paragraph

text: with fine arts such as painting and sculpture, in which such latitude is important.
label: Paragraph

text: Quatremeré’s definition has remained a touchstone for many of the succeeding
label: Paragraph

text: reflections on type.
label: Paragraph

text: However, architectural practice, responding to the modern pressure for standardization
label: Paragraph

text: of all sorts, has made other demands on the idea of type. In particular, the pedagogical
label: Paragraph

text: approach traced to J.N.L.Durand (1760-1834), who taught architecture to engineering
label: Paragraph

text: students at the turn of the 19th century, proposes to view the design of a building as a
label: Paragraph

text: combination of preexisting elements—rooms, colonnades, courtyards, and the like—that
label: Paragraph

text: could be cataloged, selected, and distributed in a modular, axial plan arrangement. This
label: Paragraph

text: so-called rationalist approach finds strong echoes in the literature of professional manuals
label: Paragraph

text: up to the present day.
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, the structure of architectural commissions has changed under
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization and the modern state. Where once a single patron, at least symbolically,
label: Paragraph

text: would have given the order, clients since the 19th century have been increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: collective—mainly governments and commercial consortia—and have formulated new
label: Paragraph

text: and complex needs for spaces of production and administration, recorded in the form of
label: Paragraph

text: detailed written programs. As professional attention has concentrated around
label: Paragraph

text: considerations of function, they have come to dominate in many contexts over form as a
label: Paragraph

text: basis for classifying what are now called “building types.”
label: Paragraph

text: The functional or programmatic type provides a partial answer to Quatremére de
label: Paragraph

text: Quincy’s mysterious contention that works stemming from a common type might not
label: Paragraph

text: resemble one another. For although the operation of a type must somehow involve a
label: Paragraph

text: direct shaping of matter to produce a family of similar instances, Quatremeré’s argument
label: Paragraph

text: signals a growing distrust of simple resemblance. Such an attitude, surprisingly enough,
label: Paragraph

text: is not incompatible with Durand’s impulse to demote the pictorial (and thereby the
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic) from among architecture’s first principles. Thus, it is easy enough to find
label: Paragraph

text: examples of train stations, hospitals, and town halls that belong to the same functional
label: Paragraph

text: type and yet are dissimilar in plan, elevation, massing, size, or style. If architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: considered to be determined by criteria that can be written and calculated in programs,
label: Paragraph

text: then questions of mimesis—literally, what a building looks like—are of secondary
label: Paragraph

text: importance. On the other hand, the figural characters of the architectural plan and facade
label: Paragraph

text: remain critical to evaluating designs. In this sense the functional type and its
label: Paragraph

text: representational or iconic aspects remain intertwined (see Holl, 1980).
label: Paragraph

text: Twentieth-century modernism’s abstraction is fertile terrain for typological thinking.
label: Paragraph

text: What unites disparate creations is a negative quality, the exclusion of some aspects in
label: Paragraph

text: order to leave others visible. Canonically, this is seen in the removal of ornament, which
label: Paragraph

text: allows the imagination to bracket the building’s material specificity and to see it as an
label: Paragraph

text: actual type instead of merely an instance of one. Such a straightforward reduction is quite
label: Paragraph

text: close to the basic typological operation of reducing complexity to find the essential traits
label: Paragraph

text: of a group. Yet what Anthony Vidler (1998) refers to as questions of ontology (essential
label: Paragraph

text: being), first raised among 18th- and 19th-century theorists, remains heavily implicit in
label: Paragraph

text: the modernist context as a tension between an “explanation of origins” and a “principle of
label: Paragraph

text: form.”
label: Paragraph

text: Hermann Muthesius (1861-1927) argued in the early years of the century that
label: Paragraph

text: architecture strives toward the typical. As if in direct response to this remark, the facade
label: Paragraph

text: of Adolph Loos’s (1870-1933) Steiner House (1910), with its bare punched windows,
label: Paragraph

text: eliminates much of the evidence that would allow it to be read in stylistic dialogue with
label: Paragraph

text: preceding works. This choice to eliminate historically specific ornament—
label: Paragraph

text: counterbalanced by sensitivity toward materials—is followed through, albeit in otherwise
label: Paragraph

text: diverse ways, in the work of such later architects as Ludwig Mies van der Rohe (1886—
label: Paragraph

text: 1969) and Louis Kahn (1901-74). All three develop what might be called an essentialist
label: Paragraph

text: or archetypal dimension, placing particular emphasis on elements that can be argued as
label: Paragraph

text: present in any work of architecture and can be recognized in all its manifestations: the
label: Paragraph

text: column, the wall and its openings, the roof, and the ground plane. Such an attitude, tied to
label: Paragraph

text: history but opposed to historicism, can be contrasted with the lively interest in prototypes
label: Paragraph

text: displayed by other modern architects.
label: Paragraph

text: Proposing industrial repetition as a substitute for cultural sedimentation, the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: movement abounds in prototypes intended to launch a kind of typological revolution.
label: Paragraph

text: These projects are perhaps closer to Quatremeré’s “model” than to his “type,” except
label: Paragraph

text: insofar as they embrace the idea of variants and adaptation. Le Corbusier’s (1887-1965)
label: Paragraph

text: Dom-ino Houses (1915) seek to define a skeletal substructure on which variation can
label: Paragraph

text: happen. In fact a great number of Le Corbusier’s projects, from the Ville Contemporaine
label: Paragraph

text: (1922) to the Unite d’Habitation (Marseilles, 1947-52), employ typological reasoning,
label: Paragraph

text: proposing a typical solution across widely varying circumstances. The strategy is pursued
label: Paragraph

text: with even greater rigor and persistence by early contemporaries, such as Ludwig
label: Paragraph

text: Hilbersheimer (1885-1967), who seek to modernize society through architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: repeated, industrially manufactured housing.
label: Paragraph

text: Although these projects rarely continue beyond the level of projects and prototypes, a
label: Paragraph

text: great deal of post-World War II construction, both in the United States and in Europe, is
label: Paragraph

text: based on the quasi-industrial repetition of basic types. Issues or considerations of
label: Paragraph

text: construction and financing have enforced homogeneity in the service of political and
label: Paragraph

text: financial rather than aesthetic goals. To cite only two well-known cases, the single-family
label: Paragraph

text: suburban house (see Wright, 1981) and the “typical-plan” office building (see Koolhaas
label: Paragraph

text: and Mau, 1995) have achieved an ambiguous hegemony, seemingly omnipresent even
label: Paragraph

text: though widely criticized. This situation in turn has created larger and larger markets such
label: Paragraph

text: that, even if whole buildings are only rarely mass-produced (see Herbert, 1984), their
label: Paragraph

text: components certainly are.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, it is in part this galloping homogeneity and the reliance on top-down or
label: Paragraph

text: market-driven solutions that elicited a growing critical reaction among architects
label: Paragraph

text: becoming active in the 1950s and 1960s. The reaction is particularly visible in the group
label: Paragraph

text: known as Team X, who organized the last of the Congrés Internationaux d’ Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: Moderne (CIAM) in 1956: Aldo Van Eyck (1918-99), Alison and Peter Smithson (1928—
label: Paragraph

text: 93, 1923-}, Shadrach Woods (1923-73), Giancarlo de Carlo (1919-), and others. These
label: Paragraph

text: architects view the imposition of a uniform culture of functional planning and faceless
label: Paragraph

text: public and banal private housing as a result, among other things, of modernist
label: Paragraph

text: architecture’s abdication of its proper cultural role. They invoke, another kind of
label: Paragraph

text: typological reasoning whereby, instead of a refined industrial model to be repeated by the
label: Paragraph

text: thousands, the type could be understood as a collective product issuing from local or
label: Paragraph

text: regional culture. These architects, practicing what Manfredo Tafuri has referred to as
label: Paragraph

text: typological criticism, propose an anti-subjective aesthetic, seeing the long collective
label: Paragraph

text: refinement of cultural artifacts as superior to the work of the individual intellect or the
label: Paragraph

text: technocratic planner.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the debate concerning typology that will be freshest in most English-
label: Paragraph

text: speaking readers’ minds is the one that crystallized around a group of Italian architects
label: Paragraph

text: who, beginning in the 1960s, promoted a critical reevaluation of traditional architectural
label: Paragraph

text: and urban form. The group, called La Tendenza (neorationalism), is diverse but has in
label: Paragraph

text: common an attachment to the idea that correctly conceived buildings and urban spaces
label: Paragraph

text: would show more affinity with history than with the functional reason-ing of the moment
label: Paragraph

text: and might also outlast their current uses to house very different, indeed unforeseeable,
label: Paragraph

text: ones in the future.
label: Paragraph

text: Neorationalism carries the ambiguous charge that already accrues to the different
label: Paragraph

text: forms of rationalism discernible in architecture: it could be seen as anchored in the
label: Paragraph

text: rational, that is, what could be explained or considered reasonable. However, it could also
label: Paragraph

text: be concerned with the exercise of a pure reason, to a point that could in fact be seen as
label: Paragraph

text: irrational. It is indeed this flip side of the rational that the best-known neorationalist, Aldo
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi (1931-96), exploited most heavily, especially the ironic, antihumanist projects of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1970s.
label: Paragraph

text: As a representation of the weight of the past on architectural invention, the notion of
label: Paragraph

text: type has been central through two centuries of debate in architecture. Its lack of precision,
label: Paragraph

text: while yet purporting to guide practice, has allowed richly differing uses and has kept the
label: Paragraph

text: notion from becoming the intellectual property of any single group. In architectural and
label: Paragraph

text: urban history and theory, the study of building types helps to counter the tendency to
label: Paragraph

text: concentrate on a single building or author. In design practice, type has proven useful both
label: Paragraph

text: as a workaday professional category and as a point of departure for debates over
label: Paragraph

text: continuity and innovation. Some sort of typological reasoning is practically indispensable
label: Paragraph

text: to architecture as an intellectual enterprise.
label: Paragraph
