text: UNGERS, OSWALD MATHIAS 1926
label: Title

text: Architect, Germany
label: Title

text: Born on 12 July 1926 in Kaiseresch (Eifel), Oswald Mathias Ungers helped shape the
label: Paragraph

text: international architectural scene of the second half of the 20th century. He studied at the
label: Paragraph

text: Karlsruhe Technical University from 1947 to 1950 under Egon Eiermann, beginning a
label: Paragraph

text: private practice in Cologne in 1950 and in Berlin in 1964. His work can be divided into
label: Paragraph

text: three broad categories. His early career saw construction primarily of residences in a
label: Paragraph

text: Modern style, up to the 1960s. This was followed by a theoretical and conceptual phase,
label: Paragraph

text: from approximately 1963 to 1980, focusing on major competitions. The last decades of
label: Paragraph

text: the 20th century provided Ungers with the opportunity for a full elaboration of his
label: Paragraph

text: architectural ideas and ethos, based on intellectual and spiritual responsibility and the
label: Paragraph

text: definition of architecture as an autonomous discipline. This commitment, together with
label: Paragraph

text: his daring use of the cube form, situated him firmly as a leading figure in Postmodernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Ungers constructed his early works primarily in the Cologne area, where he opened his
label: Paragraph

text: first office in 1950. The influence of Eiermann is unmistakable. The elegant lines of his
label: Paragraph

text: single-family house on Oderweg (1951) in Cologne-Diinnwald or his apartment building
label: Paragraph

text: on Hiiltzstrasse (1951) in Cologne-Braunsfeld underline a sleek and sober modernism as
label: Paragraph

text: regards design and materials. Ungers’s residences from a few years later show an
label: Paragraph

text: influence by the Brutalism movement, inspired by Le Corbusier, including
label: Paragraph

text: experimentation with new approaches to space as well as material. The multiple-family
label: Paragraph

text: residence on Brambachstrasse (1955-57) in Cologne-Dellbriick employed his material of
label: Paragraph

text: choice, rough brick, and represented a departure from the earlier, simple box form typical
label: Paragraph

text: of modernism. The design of the roof and eaves, situated behind the facade, is a technical
label: Paragraph

text: feat that he would return to often in later works.
label: Paragraph

text: Ungers’s move toward new architectural forms and representations is clearest in his
label: Paragraph

text: apartment building on Belvederstrasse (1958-59) in Cologne-Miingersdorf, where the
label: Paragraph

text: stacked cubes form the basis of a new exploration of space and volume. Although the
label: Paragraph

text: house’s materials and form reference the neighboring buildings, it stands out as a defiant,
label: Paragraph

text: new construction. Its expressiveness has caused more than one critic to describe it as part
label: Paragraph

text: of the German Expressionist movement, a development that plunged Ungers into an
label: Paragraph

text: analysis of Expressionist architecture. His essay from this period, presented in 1964 in
label: Paragraph

text: Florence at a symposium on Expressionism, declared his now famous motto
label: Paragraph

text: “Construction is not utopia, but rather battle.” The library “cube house” addition (1989)
label: Caption

text: strengthened the interplay of constructed and free spaces within and between the two
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, lending the constellation an association of an urban setting and earning it the
label: Paragraph

text: description of a city in miniature, or a house-city.
label: Paragraph

text: The early 1960s provided Ungers with a few larger projects, including the competitions
label: Paragraph

text: for an art museum (1960) in Diisseldorf and a Roman-Germanic museum (1960) in
label: Paragraph

text: Cologne. One of his biggest critical failures stems from this period as well, the residential
label: Paragraph

text: construction of the Markisches Viertel (1962-67) in Berlin-Wittenau. Initially designed
label: Paragraph

text: as stacked buildings of 3 to 6 stories, the buildings were actually constructed with 8 to 16
label: Paragraph

text: stories, compromising the original statement of the design. This period represented a
label: Paragraph

text: rupture in Ungers’s career, coinciding with an appointment at the Technical University in
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin, where he taught from 1963 to 1969.
label: Paragraph

text: Partly because of a lack of commissions and partly the result of Ungers’s desire to
label: Paragraph

text: reflect on his work, the next years were filled with a “theoretical” construction phase. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1965 and 1967, he served as a visiting critic at Cornell University. Three projects from
label: Paragraph

text: these years reflect the new conceptual forms that he had found for his architectural ideals:
label: Paragraph

text: the design for the Dutch student dormitory (1964) in Enschede, the design for the Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: museum complex (1965), and the design for the German embassy (1965) in Rome. Using
label: Paragraph

text: the geometric forms of the circle, square, and triangle, Ungers proceeded to create
label: Paragraph

text: variations on these basic themes. The result was a harmonious constellation of contrasts
label: Paragraph

text: and progressions that would influence his work even decades later.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Ungers was unable to build most of the projects he designed during this
label: Paragraph

text: period, usually competition designs, they helped define the possibilities and limits of his
label: Paragraph

text: architectural thought and practice. Until the late 1970s, he produced numerous plans for
label: Paragraph

text: major construction projects, including his design for the Berlin-Tegel airport (1966), with
label: Paragraph

text: its flexible plan for updating the construction according to new airplane models and its
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on steel and aluminum. Ungers also entered the competition for Cologne’s
label: Paragraph

text: Wallraf-Richartz Museum (1975), a design that foresaw the building as an extension of
label: Paragraph

text: the cathedral area and connected the pedestrian zone with Breslauer Platz. He also began
label: Paragraph

text: a time of much professional and academic international movement. In 1969 he became
label: Paragraph

text: chair of the Department of Architecture at Cornell, and he opened an office in New York
label: Paragraph

text: in 1970 after receiving his license there. In 1973 and 1978, he went to Harvard University
label: Paragraph

text: as a visiting professor and was also a visiting professor at the University of California,
label: Paragraph

text: Los Angeles, in 1974-75. In 1976 he opened an office in Frankfurt/Main. He went to the
label: Paragraph

text: University for Applied Arts in Vienna from 1978 to 1980 and opened another office in
label: Paragraph

text: Karlsruhe in 1983. He began to work at the university in Diisseldorf in 1986.
label: Paragraph

text: The late 1970s heralded a new era of large building projects, including the German
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Museum (1979-84) in Frankfurt and the residential complex on
label: Paragraph

text: Liitzowplatz (1979-83) in Berlin, with its bands of vertical window lines topped by
label: Paragraph

text: triangular gables eliciting the impression of massive, moving arrows punctuating the long
label: Paragraph

text: wall. Ungers’s practice was then inundated with commissions, establishing his signature
label: Paragraph

text: OMU as an established but dynamic architectural firm. In this new period of
label: Paragraph

text: construction, Ungers’s commitment to the cube form became the basis of almost all his
label: Paragraph

text: future work. However, despite the reaffirmations of his theoretical plans, Ungers was
label: Paragraph

text: forced to recognize that the translation of his designs into reality often resulted in
label: Paragraph

text: compromises that weakened the strength of his structures. In this sense his architectural
label: Paragraph

text: plans have been in some ways more important than the buildings themselves in elevating
label: Paragraph

text: him to international status.
label: Paragraph

text: The last two decades of the 20th century offered Ungers the opportunity to realize
label: Paragraph

text: many of his ideas in new forms. In 1990 he exhibited “Kubus,” five three-meter-high
label: Paragraph

text: cubes in a Cologne gallery, demonstrating his mastery of dividing space between
label: Paragraph

text: concrete forms and emptiness. Numerous publications date from these years as well,
label: Paragraph

text: including his thoughtful anthology, Rectangular Houses (1986). His constructions reflect
label: Paragraph

text: the near half century of attempts to infuse his designs with uncompromising boldness
label: Paragraph

text: through imposing geometric forms, such as the Alfred Wegener Institute for Polar
label: Paragraph

text: Research (1980-84) in Bremerhaven.
label: Paragraph

text: Ungers ended the 20th century with a personally satisfying commission: the design of
label: Paragraph

text: the new Wallraf-Richartz Museum (1996-99) in Cologne. He thereby completed a
label: Paragraph

text: project for which he had not been selected nearly two decades earlier. Opened in the first
label: Paragraph

text: month of 2001, the building allowed Ungers to display the many successful techniques he
label: Paragraph

text: developed during his career, in the city where he had first begun to build. The museum’s
label: Paragraph

text: design alludes to its historic location between the Giirzenichstrasse and the city hall.
label: Paragraph

text: Here, as in other designs, his building is a massive cube, but it is less imposing than in his
label: Paragraph

text: other constructions, is less rigorous in its dimensions, and has an almost flowing, elegant
label: Paragraph

text: quality. Now the newest home to Germany’s oldest private art collection, the Wallraf-
label: Paragraph

text: Richartz Museum is a fitting testimony to Ungers’s determination to address the practical
label: Paragraph

text: challenges of construction and tradition while insisting on architecture’s right to self-
label: Paragraph

text: determination and a building’s responsibility to fulfill the individual spiritually and
label: Paragraph

text: intellectually.
label: Paragraph

text: UNITE D’HABITATION, MARSEILLES
label: Caption

text: Designed by Le Corbusier, completed 1952 Marseilles, France
label: Caption

text: Although it never quite fulfilled its higher social purpose in its short life as public
label: Paragraph

text: housing, the Unite d’Habitation at Marseilles today is occupied by families who clearly
label: Paragraph

text: appreciate the building’s history and architectural lineage. The first of Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: Unite d’habitation a grandeur conforme to be realized, the giant, multipurpose complex
label: Paragraph

text: containing 337 flats was meant to house 1600 people in 23 variants of the typical
label: Paragraph

text: apartment. The two-story units range in size from small apartments for childless couples
label: Paragraph

text: to multibedroom small houses for families of eight or more. Based loosely on the
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal housing blocks on pilotis examined in the architect’s 1930 book Cité radieuse
label: Paragraph

text: (Radiant City), the Unite d’Habitation at Marseilles, like much of Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: domestic architecture, was originally conceived as only part of a larger urban scheme.
label: Paragraph

text: However, envisioning the need for postwar reconstruction in France, many of his
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent town plans employed the principles laid out in the Radiant City and the
label: Paragraph

text: Athens Charter of 1943 and contained plans for ultimately unrealized but similar garden
label: Paragraph

text: cities. After the war, Raoul Dautry, a friend of Le Corbusier’s, was appointed the first
label: Paragraph

text: minister of reconstruction and urbanism and handed Le Corbusier the task of designing
label: Paragraph

text: new housing in the poverty-stricken port city of Marseilles. Not quite the extensive town-
label: Paragraph

text: planning project that Le Corbusier was hoping for (French architect and planner Auguste
label: Paragraph

text: Perret had been drawing up the new urban plan for Le Havre in the meantime), he
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless garnered the support of seven subsequent ministers of reconstruction and
label: Paragraph

text: overcame political instability in the still-Communist Marseilles, countless delays, huge
label: Paragraph

text: cost overruns, misunderstandings at the site, and harsh criticisms from politicians,
label: Paragraph

text: doctors, and architects alike. Ultimately, Le Corbusier managed to get an “experimental”
label: Paragraph

text: tag placed on his plans and thus avoided the constricting zoning ordinances that would
label: Paragraph

text: have made the building, as it was envisioned, impossible to build.
label: Paragraph

text: The self-contained “city” that the architect envisioned for Marseilles relinquished
label: Paragraph

text: tradition for the convenience of the residents. The garden was on the roof, easily
label: Paragraph

text: accessible to the nursery school and swimming pool; the “streets” were placed on floors
label: Paragraph

text: 2,5, 7, 8, 10, 13, and 16; and shops were placed on parts of the seventh and eighth floors
label: Paragraph

text: instead of being intertwined with the commercial life of the city outside.
label: Paragraph

text: The basic apartment was laid out over two floors with a double-height living room, a
label: Paragraph

text: kitchen, two bathrooms, two bedrooms for children separated by a movable screen to
label: Caption

text: make for a larger playroom, and a third bedroom for parents. All living rooms faced onto
label: Paragraph

text: a bris-soleil-style balcony that allowed sunlight to enter the apartment in winter and
label: Paragraph

text: blocked it during the hot summer months. The kitchen is the single, unchanging element
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the 23 different unit types. The kitchens gave a nod to the materials and
label: Paragraph

text: beliefs employed by Americans Charles and Ray Eames and George Nelson, utilizing
label: Paragraph

text: wood and laminated metal for countertops, tables, and cabinets and furthering the relation
label: Paragraph

text: of the kitchen to the living room by opening the rooms to each other. There were
label: Paragraph

text: openings from the hallways directly into the refrigerators for the delivery of ice and food,
label: Paragraph

text: further advancing the ideas of convenience and self-containment.

text: concrete facade. The beehive-like structure,
label: Paragraph

text: ates Le Corbusier’s original metaphor of the
label: Paragraph

text: apartment block as bottle rack, in which each apartment was inserted like a bottle into the
label: Paragraph

text: structure. He even envisioned in future housing units that the apartment units would be
label: Paragraph

text: constructed off-site and hoisted into place, into the rack. The ground that the “rack” sits
label: Paragraph

text: on is a table or platform supported by hollow pilotis or stilts that provide an area for
label: Paragraph

text: services beneath the great monolithic structure.
label: Paragraph

text: The Unité d’ Habitation at Marseilles was Le Corbusier’s great experimental site where
label: Paragraph

text: he applied to the entire structure his Modular measuring scheme. Everywhere, the more
label: Paragraph

text: rational qualities of Le Corbusier’s rambling half-scientific, half-mystical system of
label: Paragraph

text: measure are employed and illustrated down to the inscribed “modular man” on the side of
label: Paragraph

text: the building. There is one exception to the Modular rule, and it occurred by mistake; the
label: Paragraph

text: bris-soleil frames on the outside of the building were mismeasured and misproportioned
label: Paragraph

text: in the construction phase. Le Corbusier decided to have the frames brightly painted in his
label: Paragraph

text: trademark palette, acknowledging the moment of inspiration that one could find through
label: Paragraph

text: error.

text: UNITED KINGDOM
label: Title

text: When the 20th century opened, the United Kingdom was at the height of its political
label: Paragraph

text: power and influence and moreover was valued in Europe as a source of ideas in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. In terms of modern art, Charles Rennie Mackintosh was seen to be an
label: Paragraph

text: originator of the Art Nouveau style and became a positive influence on the Secessionist
label: Paragraph

text: style as it developed in Vienna. During 1898, Adolf Loos wrote many polemical articles
label: Paragraph

text: in Vienna’s Neue freie Presse praising English fashion and products. With Hermann
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius’s publication of Das englischer Haus in 1904, Britain seemed to be ahead of
label: Paragraph

text: continental Europe in providing more flexible models of houses and housing, one of the
label: Paragraph

text: main strands of modernism in architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the development was not confined to matters of taste. In terms of economics,
label: Paragraph

text: the social structure of Britain had been changing since the onset of the industrial
label: Paragraph

text: revolution in the later 18th century and had now created the conditions pertaining to a
label: Paragraph

text: mass culture. Britain had pioneered the development of new industrial products from the
label: Paragraph

text: time of the Great Exhibition of 1851. The rapid growth of London, following the
label: Paragraph

text: explosion of the middle class and the concurrent expansion of metropolitan railways, had
label: Paragraph

text: ensured that Britain was ahead both in achieving urban growth and thereby in being
label: Paragraph

text: forced to begin dealing with typical 20th-century problems.
label: Paragraph

text: The speed with which agricultural land on the outer rim was being consumed by new
label: Paragraph

text: housing led to anxieties about the loss of food production, and with the publication in
label: Paragraph

text: 1902 of Ebenezer Howard’s Garden Cities of Tomorrow, urban growth was for the first
label: Paragraph

text: time subjected to theory, the theory of limiting it by means of new towns located within a
label: Paragraph

text: “green belt” of protected countryside. First Letchworth in 1903 and later Welwyn in 1920
label: Paragraph

text: confirmed local government acceptance of Howard’s thesis as the basis of urban
label: Paragraph

text: expansion. However, this context also explains why home building in Britain took on a
label: Paragraph

text: “rural” character because it was conceived as the opposite to city living. No doubt, a love
label: Paragraph

text: of medieval models and the enormous success of the Arts and Crafts movement promoted
label: Paragraph

text: by William Morris in the tradition of John Ruskin contributed to this attitude. Vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was thought proper for suburban housing and was also adopted by architects
label: Paragraph

text: working individually for more affluent clients: architects such as C.R.Ashbee,
label: Paragraph

text: C.F.A.Voysey, Richard Norman Shaw, and Edwin Landseer Lutyens.
label: Caption

text: However, British culture remained strangely parochial. The French scandal of the new
label: Paragraph

text: century turned on the Dreyfus case, a question of social identity, but the corresponding
label: Paragraph

text: British scandal turned on Oscar Wilde, a question of personal identity. Fleeing from
label: Paragraph

text: social ostracism, Wilde took refuge in France, and France remained the cultural center of
label: Paragraph

text: Europe. During the years of the Entente Cordiale, French influence became paramount.
label: Paragraph

text: At a time when even well-to-do people could not afford to build individual town houses,
label: Paragraph

text: apartment living began to appeal to the middle class, and many apartments serviced by
label: Paragraph

text: elevators were built in Marylebone and in Battersea, popularly known as “mansion flats.”
label: Paragraph

text: Building apartments rather than one-family houses added more effectively to city fabric,
label: Paragraph

text: and the popular center around Piccadilly Circus became the focus of Edwardian
label: Paragraph

text: pretensions. Shaw’s style became eclectic, and his Piccadilly Hotel (1905-08) and
label: Paragraph

text: Regent Street Quadrant are imbued with a heavy classicism. His disciple, Reginald
label: Paragraph

text: Blomfield, later built two sides of Piccadilly Circus (1913-30) in an elegant French
label: Paragraph

text: baroque. Mewés and Davis built the Ritz Hotel (1906), of which the grand arcade to
label: Paragraph

text: Piccadilly is modeled on Percier and Fontaine’s rue de Rivoli. It is noteworthy that
label: Paragraph

text: Lutyens took French models for much of his later rural work, and his imperial work in
label: Paragraph

text: New Delhi, although highly original, is conceived in a spirit of French grandeur. Between
label: Paragraph

text: 1901 and 1913, Aston Webb laid out the Rond Point with Queen Victoria’s statue, in
label: Paragraph

text: front of Buckingham Palace, and Admiralty Arch in emulation of the Place de la
label: Caption

text: Concorde and the Are de Triomphe.
label: Paragraph

text: Howard Robertson, architect of the Financial Times Building in London, was the main
label: Paragraph

text: source of theory in the schools, his Principles of Composition being based largely on
label: Paragraph

text: Guadet. The Beaux-Arts dominated architectural education until the outbreak of World
label: Paragraph

text: War I, with Robertson at the Architectural Association, Albert Richardson at London
label: Caption

text: University, and Charles Reilly and W.A. Eden at Liverpool University. Where the Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts model did not hold, it was the classical model that did. Courtenay Square
label: Paragraph

text: (1914) in Kennington, by Adshead and Ramsey, is probably the last example of a reduced
label: Paragraph

text: classicism still executed with conviction. By the 1920s, a neo-Georgian style dominated
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture, as it did in poetry.
label: Paragraph

text: Howard Robertson’s influence extended beyond theory, and his participation in the
label: Paragraph

text: Paris Exposition of 1925 led to a considerable enthusiasm for the Art Deco style, which
label: Paragraph

text: he promoted during the 1920s. This style is demonstrative and populist without attaining
label: Paragraph

text: the modernist ideal of renouncing style as much. Many town halls, cinemas, and lidos
label: Paragraph

text: were built in a lighthearted vein across the country, and the most distinguished probably
label: Paragraph

text: are those by Oliver Bernard, whose foyers for the Strand Palace Hotel (1929-30) are
label: Paragraph

text: superb. To this taste was added a liking for decorative brickwork stemming from the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of W.M. Dudok’s Hilversum Town Hall, apparent in the Royal Masonic
label: Paragraph

text: Hospital (1930-34) by Sir John Burnett Tait and Lorne. The latter firm was typical in
label: Paragraph

text: veering between a monumental classicism, sometimes with Egyptian overtones, and a
label: Paragraph

text: reduced moderne, until in 1932 it dipped into a crude streamlined modernism, as
label: Paragraph

text: exemplified in the Mount Royal Hotel on Oxford Street.
label: Paragraph

text: A certain eclecticism was in order. The Hoover Factory in Western Avenue by Wallis
label: Paragraph

text: Gilbert, in a sort of modernized palatial mode, is the most exuberant instance of the
label: Paragraph

text: hybrid architecture produced in Britain at this time, but the same architect could come
label: Paragraph

text: close to an authentic modern idiom in his Daimler Car Hire Garage (1931). Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Holden could build the Senate House and Library (1932-34) for London University in an
label: Paragraph

text: inflated if stripped-down classical style and at the same time prefigure the modern in his
label: Paragraph

text: very controlled work for the Piccadilly Line Underground stations at Arnos Grove and
label: Paragraph

text: Southgate. Only Joseph Emberton, formerly an assistant to Gordon Tait, achieved
label: Paragraph

text: genuine modernity with his Yacht Club (1930-32) at Burnham-on-Crouch and two
label: Paragraph

text: London stores, Simpson’s Piccadilly (1934-36) and the HMV Building (1938-39) on
label: Paragraph

text: Oxford Street.
label: Paragraph

text: The Modern style as such did not appear in England until the very end of the 1920s by
label: Paragraph

text: way of private individuals building villas. A breakthrough was made by the architect
label: Paragraph

text: Amyas Connell in his famous High and Over (1927-29) at Amersham in
label: Paragraph

text: Buckinghamshire. It is almost contemporary with Le Corbusier’s Les Heures Claires at
label: Paragraph

text: Poissy and appears to derive its aesthetic from the LaRoche-Jeanneret houses in the rue
label: Paragraph

text: du Docteur Blanche, which Connell had seen on a visit to Paris in 1926. Here the trefoil
label: Paragraph

text: plan does not conform to the new rationalism but stems, rather, from Lutyens. The
label: Paragraph

text: influence of Le Corbusier was furthered by the publication in 1927 of Frederick Etchell’s
label: Paragraph

text: translation of Vers Une Architecture. Connell joined with two others to form the Connell,
label: Paragraph

text: Ward, and Lucas partnership, and throughout the 1930s they produced a number of
label: Paragraph

text: radical houses in a white-walled modern style, with windows arranged in horizontal runs.
label: Paragraph

text: Particularly noteworthy is a group of three houses at Saltdean where the flat-roof terrace
label: Paragraph

text: is approached by an extruded external staircase, as in Le Corbusier’s “gratte-ciel” houses
label: Paragraph

text: at Pessac of 1925. However, they also succeeded in building in the heart of conservative
label: Paragraph

text: Hampstead a canonic modern house at 66 Frognal.
label: Paragraph

text: A wider European horizon was opened up by the arrival of refugees from Hitler’s
label: Paragraph

text: Germany. Walter Gropius, Marcel Breuer, Erick Mendelsohn, and Serge Chermayefi
label: Caption

text: appeared within a short period, and the last two collaborated to build the De La Warr
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion at Bexhill-on-Sea, Sussex, while Chermayeff also completed a villa (1934) at
label: Paragraph

text: Rugby, his own house (1935-38) at Bendey Wood near Hallam, and a warehouse for
label: Paragraph

text: Gilbey’s Gin in Camden Town. In several cases, important collaborations were entered
label: Paragraph

text: on, with an effect on the future of English practice. Gropius collaborated with E.Maxwel.
label: Paragraph

text: Fiy in a house in Chelsea and in several unbuilt university projects as well as the
label: Paragraph

text: Impington Village College in Cambridgeshire, which became a model for much
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent English practice. Breuer collaborated with F.R.S.Yorke in a house (1936-37)
label: Paragraph

text: at Angmering-on-Sea and more famously for an exhibit at the Ideal Home Exhibition o
label: Paragraph

text: 1936, which projected an ultramodern image of “The Garden City of the Future.” Fry
label: Paragraph

text: succeeded at the same time in invading Hampstead with his own version of modernity,
label: Paragraph

text: the “Sun House” at 9 Frognal Way, which was well received and prepared the way for a
label: Paragraph

text: wider acceptance of the Modern style after the war.
label: Paragraph

text: There were a few indigenous architects who made their mark in the 1930s and made
label: Paragraph

text: important contributions to the development of an English modernism: H.S.Goodhart-
label: Paragraph

text: Rendel (Hays Wharf, 1929-31}, George Checkley (“Thurso” house, in Cambridge,
label: Caption

text: 1932), Christopher Nicolson (studio for Augustus John, 1933-34, and the London
label: Caption

text: Gliding Club, Dunstable, 1934-35), Frederick Gibberd (Pullman Curt, Streatham, 1935),
label: Caption

text: Raymond McGrath (house in Chertsey, 1936-37), and David Pleydell-Bouverie
label: Paragraph

text: (Ramsgate Municipal Airport, 1936-37). It is undeniable, however, that the more original
label: Paragraph

text: impulses came from abroad: conspicuous were Wells Coates (from Canada), whose
label: Paragraph

text: Isokon Apartments in Camden, designed for the Pritchards in 1932-34, are still highly
label: Paragraph

text: desired by young professionals and whose apartments (1934—35) at Brighton are a model
label: Paragraph

text: of directness and elegance; William Lescaze (from Switzerland), whose buildings (193 1—
label: Paragraph

text: 36) for the progressive school at Dartington Hall were architecturally progressive, too;
label: Paragraph

text: and Erno Goldfinger (from Hungary), who won competitions but whose projects were
label: Paragraph

text: unbuilt until after the war.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps most important was the collaboration between the natives Francis Skinner and
label: Paragraph

text: Lindsey Drake and the Russian émi-gré Berthold Lubetkin in the partnership called
label: Paragraph

text: Tecton. Lubetkin not only was energetic but also believed that the functionalist creed to
label: Paragraph

text: which he subscribed did not deny the architect’s right to make art. The Penguin Pool
label: Paragraph

text: (1932) at the London Zoo is as playful as it is geometric, and the apartment blocks
label: Paragraph

text: constructed at Highgate—Highpoint I (1933-35) and Highpoint Il (1936—-38)—are
label: Paragraph

text: equally virtuoso in their deployment of abstract forms. Published in The Architectural
label: Paragraph

text: Review, these buildings signaled the acceptance of Modern architecture by establishment
label: Paragraph

text: critics. Its acceptance by the general public had to wait until after World War II.
label: Paragraph

text: A young architect who first joined Tecton and later worked on his own account was
label: Paragraph

text: important in effecting this transition. This was Denys Lasdun. In 1948, still collaborating
label: Paragraph

text: with Tecton, he began work on an extensive estate of public housing at Hallfield, in
label: Paragraph

text: Paddington, together with a primary school. The elevations are marked by Lubetkin’s
label: Paragraph

text: preference for breaking the pattern of verticals at alternate floors, but the finesse Lasdun
label: Paragraph

text: showed here gave him a central role in introducing the Modern style to a wider public.
label: Paragraph

text: With the election of a Labour government in 1945, England was motivated by a new
label: Paragraph

text: spirit of cooperation produced through the war years. This spirit was celebrated in the
label: Paragraph

text: Festival of Britain (1951), a coordinated group of exhibition buildings on semiderelict
label: Paragraph

text: land on the south bank of the Thames opposite Charing Cross, highly visible to the
label: Paragraph

text: public. It was put together with speed and virtuosity under the direction of Hugh Casson.
label: Paragraph

text: With the installation of a Labour government, municipalities and local authorities were
label: Paragraph

text: given new powers to clear slums and bomb damage and to expand public investment in
label: Paragraph

text: building housing, schools, new universities, and even new towns. Architecture in Britain
label: Paragraph

text: in the 1950s was earnest and populist, taking its cue from the Festival of Britain style. In
label: Paragraph

text: the eyes of the younger generation, it was condemned as fainthearted.
label: Paragraph

text: The Smithsons, Alison and Peter, were the first representatives of the postwar
label: Paragraph

text: generation. Fiercely critical of the Festival style, they expressed a determination to
label: Paragraph

text: remake architecture in the name of ordinary people without ceasing to be radical. Their
label: Paragraph

text: design for housing in the Golden Lane Competition (1952) showed how the access decks
label: Paragraph

text: for high-rise housing could become “street decks,” linking different quarters together
label: Paragraph

text: with a pedestrian network free from traffic circulation. This was not simply a proposal for
label: Paragraph

text: housing; rather, it was a fundamental reworking of the city and, in theory, a way of
label: Paragraph

text: building whole towns. The open-air access deck had been instituted through poor-law
label: Paragraph

text: housing built by the Peabody Estate in the 1890s, and the system was now adopted by
label: Paragraph

text: municipalities. The Smithsons provided intellectual leadership for the younger
label: Paragraph

text: generation, addressing themselves to the architectural establishment as would-be
label: Paragraph

text: reformers. Their polemic against what they called the “wasteland of the Four Functions”
label: Paragraph

text: brought an end to the bureaucratic rationalism of CIAM (Congrés Internationaux
label: Paragraph

text: d’Architecture Moderne) and replaced it with the more self-critical although short-lived
label: Paragraph

text: meetings of Team X.
label: Paragraph

text: Their design for Hunstanton School (1950-54) was broadly Miesian in origin but less
label: Paragraph

text: monumental, reflecting also the influence of Rudolf Wittkower, who had brought the
label: Paragraph

text: achievements of Palladio into new focus: if Palladio could create architecture out of farm
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, surely the modern architect could do it with utilitarian sheds. The light steel
label: Paragraph

text: structure was used with an extreme economy, and structural walls, pipes, and services
label: Paragraph

text: were left exposed. The result, in the view of the critic Reyner Banham, was the defining
label: Paragraph

text: moment of a new approach—the New Brutalism—seeking an absolute honesty by
label: Paragraph

text: exposing the mechanisms as well as the structure. Although hardly a British invention,
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalism dominated British architecture for several decades. It was an important
label: Paragraph

text: influence in the formation of the Archigram Group by Peter Cook in 1962 and led on to
label: Paragraph

text: the High-Tech style, which by the 1980s had become the dominant style in Britain.
label: Paragraph

text: In many respects, the Smithsons’ design for the Economist Building (1963-64)
label: Paragraph

text: represents their considered view of what an honest architecture “without rhetoric” should
label: Paragraph

text: be. This design broke with commercial grandiosity and showed how a building could be
label: Paragraph

text: divided into smaller entities that could be more easily absorbed into the city pattern. After
label: Paragraph

text: the Economist Building, the Smithsons were well placed to become a successful practice.
label: Paragraph

text: However, this did not happen, and their public housing at Robin Hood Lane was not well
label: Paragraph

text: received.
label: Paragraph

text: The architects were not alone to blame for this. Both Labour and Conservative
label: Paragraph

text: governments fell into the trap of assessing housing policy in terms of quantity rather than
label: Paragraph

text: social effectiveness. Many mistakes were made in terms of both social environment and
label: Paragraph

text: technical construction. In London, the collapse of an apartment block at Ronan Point
label: Paragraph

text: signaled the end of the belief that reconstruction had been successful. Later, this collapse
label: Paragraph

text: took on a symbolic significance, roughly equivalent to the tearing down of the Pruitt Igoe
label: Paragraph

text: estate in St. Louis. It marked an end to the supposition that progress was inevitable and
label: Paragraph

text: preordained.
label: Paragraph

text: However, this was not just a local phenomenon; it was worldwide in its impact. In the
label: Paragraph

text: United States, the Vietnam War, in which a powerful industrial nation could not prevai
label: Paragraph

text: against a determined people, had introduced doubt about the inevitability of technological
label: Paragraph

text: growth. Europe, too, felt a certain loss of vision after the student events of 1968 and the
label: Paragraph

text: oil crisis of 1973. Banham was disappointed in the reception of Brutalism by architects
label: Paragraph

text: and accused them of monumentalism. The influence that led to this tendency was that o
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier, but it would not have taken hold so quickly had it not been for the
label: Paragraph

text: advocacy of Leslie Martin. As chief architect of the London County Council (LCC) in
label: Paragraph

text: 1953, he promoted a rationalized use of the Le Corbusian grid. After the construction o
label: Paragraph

text: miniature Unite d’Habitation at Roehamption (1951-60), the Le Corbusian style was
label: Paragraph

text: adopted for much local authority housing in London.
label: Paragraph

text: On resigning from the LCC, Leslie Martin founded a new professional school o
label: Paragraph

text: architecture at Cambridge University. Martin’s task was to balance the claims of research
label: Paragraph

text: and practice and normalize an architecture that could be seen to fit into the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: campus setting. He took a number of young architects with him who shared his
label: Paragraph

text: admiration for rational outcomes but who were also able to act with discretion. Among
label: Paragraph

text: these were Colin St. John Wilson, Patrick Hodgkinson, and Ivor Smith. The influence o
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier remained primary, but there was also an influence from Alvar Aalto. In
label: Paragraph

text: Harvey Court (1957-62), a block of student residences for Gonville and Caius College
label: Paragraph

text: designed with Wilson and Hodgkinson, the structure is in reinforced concrete, but the
label: Paragraph

text: facing is in brickwork, so that the appearance is softened and adapted to the Cambridge
label: Paragraph

text: scene. The internal court is also softened by stepping back the accommodation in tiers.
label: Paragraph

text: Hodgkinson collaborated with Martin in the public housing (1965-73) carried out for
label: Paragraph

text: Camden Council at the Foundling Estate near Russell Square. Here again, we have a
label: Paragraph

text: stepped section, with private balconies facing east and west. Quite remarkable is the
label: Paragraph

text: profiling of the service towers: the tops with their carefully detailed vents have more than
label: Paragraph

text: a hint of Sant’ Elia futurism, and the gable ends reveal a powerful sculptural aspect that
label: Paragraph

text: comes pretty close to Expressionism.
label: Paragraph

text: Another young Cambridge architect heavily influenced by Leslie Martin was Ivor
label: Paragraph

text: Smith. His fame rests on his role as chief designer to J.L. Womersley, the chief architect
label: Paragraph

text: to the city of Sheffield, in the construction of housing (1955-65) at Park Hill and Hyde
label: Paragraph

text: Park, but somewhat problematically it takes on the huge scale of what Banham termed a
label: Paragraph

text: “megastructure.” Another influence in the same direction came from the architect Denys
label: Paragraph

text: Lasdun, who further adapted the Le Corbusian model by a confident use of the stepped
label: Paragraph

text: section. His mammoth layout (1962-69) for the University of East Anglia and his
label: Paragraph

text: residential extensions (1969-70) to Christ’s College, Cambridge, both use stepped forms
label: Paragraph

text: to allow the buildings to melt into the landscape. In another megastructure at Alexandria
label: Paragraph

text: Road, public housing (1969-79) for the London County Council, the architect Neave
label: Caption

text: Brown created yet another project based on the setback section, but with an explicit
label: Paragraph

text: ideology not about landscape as such but attempting to recuperate the street as a social
label: Paragraph

text: space.
label: Paragraph

text: The search for a constructional method more suitable for the British climate led to an
label: Paragraph

text: exploration of brickwork, probably encouraged by Le Corbusier’s design for the Maisons
label: Paragraph

text: Jaoul in Paris. Most visible were the many buildings (1962-75), some using Jaoul-type
label: Paragraph

text: vaults, constructed by Basil Spence for the University of Sussex. Most influential on
label: Paragraph

text: other architects was the very precise use of brickwork adopted by the architects Stirling
label: Paragraph

text: and Gowan, first in their flats (1955-58) at Ham Common and then in their building
label: Paragraph

text: (1959-63) for the Engineering Faculty at Leicester University, where it was combined
label: Paragraph

text: with large areas of standard glazing to spectacular effect. After the dissolution of the
label: Paragraph

text: partnership, Stirling continued this “red-brick” attack on the ancient universities with his
label: Paragraph

text: History Faculty (1964-67) at Cambridge and the Florey Building (1966-71) at Oxford.
label: Paragraph

text: Although he built a major extension of the Tate Gallery in London, Stirling was not fully
label: Paragraph

text: appreciated in Britain during his lifetime. He built in the United States for Rice
label: Paragraph

text: University, the University of California, and Harvard University, and his Performing Arts
label: Paragraph

text: Center (1983-88) at Cornell University is a gem of a building. He was appreciated as a
label: Paragraph

text: master architect in Germany and built there extensively: at Stuttgart (the Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Staatsgalerie and Music School, 1977-94), at Berlin (the Wissenschaftszentrum, 1979—
label: Paragraph

text: 87), and at Melsungen (the Braun Pharmaceutical Headquarters, 1989-92}. He is
label: Paragraph

text: arguably the most important and distinctive British architect of his generation, and his
label: Paragraph

text: contribution to world architecture has not yet been fully assessed.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1980s, British architecture was most influential when presented as a
label: Paragraph

text: continuation of the Brutalist tradition founded by the Smithsons, emphasizing structure
label: Paragraph

text: and services as principal expression. Important for this outcome were the teaching of
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Cook and the fantasies of the Archigram Group, which he founded in 1962.
label: Paragraph

text: Members of this group were employed by Piano and Rogers in making the detailed
label: Paragraph

text: drawings for the Centre Pompidou (1971-77) in Paris, so there is a direct connection.
label: Paragraph

text: Rogers’s design for Lloyds Headquarters (1978-86) in London was in a similar vein, and
label: Paragraph

text: specialized industrial buildings in the United States, Wales, and France have confirmed
label: Paragraph

text: his reputation as a “scientific” architect. More recently, his European Court of Human
label: Paragraph

text: Rights (1989-94) at Strasbourg and other projects for France show an increasing interest
label: Paragraph

text: in the use of expressive curves as well as in adapting themselves more cogently to their
label: Paragraph

text: sites. Designing for buildings in the city center had brought out a need to accommodate to
label: Paragraph

text: context, and Rogers’s commitment to the inner city was confirmed by the publication of
label: Paragraph

text: his Reith Lectures (1995), where he made a strong argument for buildings that will be
label: Paragraph

text: part of both a sustainable environment and a dense city fabric.
label: Paragraph

text: More versatile in his use of industrial components, Norman Foster has become the
label: Paragraph

text: leading exponent of what is now referred to as the High-Tech style. Originally in
label: Paragraph

text: partnership with Rogers (and both of their wives) as Team Four, they share a similar
label: Paragraph

text: approach. He was first recognized for the Willis Faber and Dumas Building (1975) in
label: Paragraph

text: Ipswich and the Sainsbury Centre for the Visual Arts (1978) at the University of East
label: Caption

text: Anglia. More recently, the elegance of Stansted Airport (1990-91) has made him known
label: Paragraph

text: to a wider public. The telecommunications tower at Torre di Collserola, near Barcelona,
label: Caption

text: exploits the image of mechanism to great effect, but the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank
label: Paragraph

text: (1979-85) in Hong Kong and the Carré d’Art at Nimes (1984-93) in France, by their
label: Paragraph

text: very differences, indicate that, for all the emphasis on structure, Foster is sensitive to site
label: Paragraph

text: conditions and can make appropriate interventions in different contexts. His ability to
label: Paragraph

text: adjust to existing conditions was proved in the Sackler Gallery (1985-92) at the Royal
label: Paragraph

text: Academy and confirmed by his renovations of the German Reichstag and the British
label: Paragraph

text: Museum, both of which use elegant steel-and-glass structures to modernize classical
label: Paragraph

text: buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Younger architects who followed the High-Tech line were Farrell and Grimshaw. A
label: Paragraph

text: partnership at the outset, they split dramatically in 1980, when Terry Farrell adopted a
label: Paragraph

text: more variable Postmodern approach. His most conspicuous success is Embankment
label: Paragraph

text: Place, a new commercial construction built above Charing Cross Station and highly
label: Paragraph

text: visible from the river. Nicholas Grimshaw stayed loyal to the fixed canon of industrial
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, but his Eurostar Terminal at Waterloo demonstrates great verve in the way it
label: Paragraph

text: exploits the site conditions to make an expressive space. A near contemporary, Michael
label: Paragraph

text: Hopkins, made a sophisticated industrial tent (1985) for Schlumberger at Cambridge but
label: Paragraph

text: has shown great sensitivity with his Mound Stand (1987) at Lords Cricket Ground and
label: Paragraph

text: the new opera house (1992-94) at Glyndbourne. His new offices for members of
label: Paragraph

text: Parliament, opposite Big Ben, make the exposed ducting for natural ventilation into a sort
label: Paragraph

text: of medieval roof, a strange metamorphosis of Louis Kahn’s idea that the exposed
label: Paragraph

text: servicing systems should supply the monumental aspect of a modern building.
label: Paragraph

text: It may be possible to deduce from these examples that, in today’s United Kingdom,
label: Paragraph

text: discretion is more important than ideology. Yet the worship of technological know-how
label: Paragraph

text: pervades British architecture, and a still-younger generation bows to it. Will Alsop, of
label: Paragraph

text: Alsop and Stormer, has risen to prominence with his Town Hall for Marseilles (Le Grand
label: Paragraph

text: Bleu), and they have constructed a rail station at North Greenwich, one of the many new
label: Paragraph

text: stations required to service the Jubilee Line, the only completely new Underground line
label: Paragraph

text: to be constructed in London since the war, most of which make expressive use of steel
label: Paragraph

text: and glass. Jan Kaplicky, cofounder with Amanda Levete of the aptly named Future
label: Caption

text: Systems, has so far built little but has received funding from the National Lottery for the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of a spectacular Eco-Centre at Doncaster. All these architects employ
label: Paragraph

text: industrial components not as rational expedients but with an eye to their expressive
label: Paragraph

text: potential. It is possible to speak of a trend that looks to revive the expressive aspects
label: Paragraph

text: discovered by the Brutalists in the 1950s.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, with the 20th century now safely completed, the drive to attach architecture
label: Paragraph

text: firmly to its purely physical determinants seems to have weakened to the point where one
label: Paragraph

text: can discern a movement to revive the concept of architecture as art, as originally
label: Paragraph

text: proposed by the Russian Constructivists. This tendency was pronounced in the early
label: Paragraph

text: work of the Office of Metropolitan Architecture, founded in 1975 by Rem Koolhaas,
label: Paragraph

text: Madelon Vriesendorp, and Elia Zenghelis, which at its inception practiced from London.
label: Paragraph

text: From that background, Zaha Hadid has risen to prominence, largely because of the
label: Paragraph

text: rejection of her winning design for the Cardiff Opera House, which led to a sympathetic
label: Paragraph

text: reaction in her favor. She now has important commissions on foot in Germany, Italy, and
label: Paragraph

text: Israel. Her presentations, as distinct from her constructions, are still remarkable insofar as
label: Paragraph

text: they imitate the weightless qualities of Malevich’s paintings. When they are transformed
label: Paragraph

text: into actual constructions, as with the Fire Station (1993, with Patrik Schumacher) at Vitea
label: Paragraph

text: in Weil am Rhein, some loss of spirit occurs. Rem Koolhaas, who still maintains an
label: Paragraph

text: office in London, was the originator of this manner; in construction, however, his projects
label: Paragraph

text: take on a distinctly surreal aspect, as with his Villa Dall’Ava in Paris (1985-91) and his
label: Paragraph

text: Convention Hall (1991-97) at the International Business Centre at Lille and still more
label: Caption

text: with his villa at Bordeaux.
label: Paragraph

text: Even more equivocal, from the rationalist point of view, are the designs proposed in
label: Paragraph

text: Britain by the American-Polish architect Daniel Libeskind: an extension to the Victoria
label: Caption

text: and Albert Museum in London and the Imperial War Museum for Manchester. In both
label: Paragraph

text: cases, the design arises from a distinctly personal impulse: it is conceptual, indeed, but
label: Paragraph

text: above all it is gestural. These designs are hardly representative of Britain, but the fact that
label: Paragraph

text: they have been accepted by British cities is highly significant. Now the traditional forms
label: Paragraph

text: of modernism, supposedly derived from rational procedure and with all the security of an
label: Paragraph

text: objective judgment, suddenly appear as personal expression, which in principle means
label: Paragraph

text: subject to whim and open to question. Britain, it appears, has finally joined the rest of the
label: Paragraph

text: world in accepting the fundamental uncertainty of the postmodern condition.
label: Paragraph

text: UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS
label: Title

text: New York City, completed 1953
label: Caption

text: On 26 June 1945, 50 nations founded the United Nations Organization in order to
label: Paragraph

text: establish international political consultations for the post-World War II period. In April
label: Paragraph

text: 1946 the United Nations Secretariat and General Assembly officially replaced the League
label: Paragraph

text: of Nations based in Geneva. After international diplomatic debates, New York City was
label: Paragraph

text: chosen to host the United Nations Headquarters. New York’s influential city planner
label: Paragraph

text: Robert Moses proposed to locate the United Nations buildings in a park at Flushing
label: Paragraph

text: Meadows, Queens, on the site of the 1939 World’s Fair, but the businessman John
label: Paragraph

text: D.Rockefeller offered to buy and donate to the United Nations a site in Manhattan
label: Paragraph

text: between First Avenue and the East River and East 42nd and 48th Streets. Although this
label: Paragraph

text: site had accommodated slaughterhouses, and despite the lack of building space for the
label: Paragraph

text: suborganizations (for example, UNICEF), the Secretariat and General Assembly were
label: Paragraph

text: placed there. Planning began in 1947, and the buildings were finished in 1953.
label: Paragraph

text: A planning commission of ten international architects directed by Wallace K.Harrison
label: Paragraph

text: had to devise a design that was both significant and functional. Architects and critics
label: Paragraph

text: regarded the buildings as important models for postwar political representation through
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. A series of sketches by Le Corbusier, emphatically promoted and refined by
label: Paragraph

text: the Brazilian modernist and member of the commission Oscar Niemeyer, directed the
label: Paragraph

text: style debates toward a modern, functionalist design. Only certain American congressmen,
label: Paragraph

text: who asked for a conservative classical, domed building, and the Russian delegate, who
label: Paragraph

text: tried to push through Stalinist neoclassicism, opposed the cultural risk of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architectural representation. Nevertheless, the International Style pattern was legitimized
label: Paragraph

text: as appropriate for international and moder politics. Already in the 1920s, at the
label: Paragraph

text: competition for the League of Nations Building in Geneva, the modernist architect
label: Caption

text: Hannes Meyer had promoted a type of transparent architecture without ornament,
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated only to efficient administration and political representation without any historic
label: Paragraph

text: monumental references.
label: Paragraph

text: European emigrant architects such as Richard Neutra, Walter Gropius, and Mies van
label: Paragraph

text: der Rohe had prepared the United States to accept modern architecture, and American
label: Paragraph

text: architectural firms such as Harrison and Abramovitz and Skidmore, Owings and Merrill
label: Paragraph

text: were professionally prepared to develop large-scale projects such as the United Nations
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. This European-American coproduction was reflected in the design process.
label: Paragraph

text: While the basic idea can be traced back to the sketches of Le Corbusier (who felt himself
label: Paragraph

text: betrayed by his American colleagues), it was Wallace K.Harrison who simplified and
label: Paragraph

text: elaborated the concept into a professional design for an administration building, thus
label: Paragraph

text: presenting to the international public a prototype for modern office towers.
label: Paragraph

text: The building complex includes a high-rise slab (544 feet high and 72 feet thick) for the
label: Paragraph

text: Secretariat offices and, on the northern edge of the site, the curving, low horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: structure of the General Assembly. In 1963 Harrison, Abramovitz and Harris attached a
label: Paragraph

text: library to its northeastern corner. All architectural elements of the United Nations
label: Caption

text: complex are generously located in open spaces that were expanded to the west by Dag
label: Paragraph

text: Hammarskjéld Plaza, and part of First Avenue was tunneled in order to reduce traffic
label: Paragraph

text: noise at the site. Within the dense building context of Manhattan, this urban scheme of
label: Paragraph

text: high-rise building and openness became prototypical for urban development in New York
label: Paragraph

text: City and in other cities of the world during the 1950s and 1960s. Lever House, completed
label: Caption

text: one year after the United Nations buildings; the Seagram Building in Manhattan; and
label: Paragraph

text: thousands of architectural International Style copies for business uses worldwide
label: Paragraph

text: produced a new urban order.
label: Paragraph

text: The rectangular design of the Secretariat slab with its reflecting curtain wall of green
label: Paragraph

text: glass in a regular, thin aluminum grid set international design standards for postwar
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture. Photographs of it circulated in all international reviews.
label: Paragraph

text: Representations of the United Nations high-rise building in stamp designs of many
label: Paragraph

text: countries aesthetically educated postwar planners and citizens worldwide. Only the
label: Paragraph

text: dynamically rising concrete roof of the Assembly Building breaks with the aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: principle of rectangularity. In lieu of applied ornament, the United Nations building
label: Paragraph

text: complex was equipped with donated works of modern art, among them murals and
label: Paragraph

text: sculptures by avant-garde artists Fernand Léger and Henry Moore.
label: Paragraph

text: Shortly after its completion, the United Nations Secretariat was presented in an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art as prototypical modern American architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In the public debate about the building, the critic Lewis Mumford recognized a specific
label: Paragraph

text: mixture of Le Corbusian utopianism and American commercialism. Many architects and
label: Paragraph

text: politicians for different reasons rejected his positive aesthetic evaluation of the
label: Paragraph

text: transparency and sculptural quality of the slab. Frank Lloyd Wright saw nothing more
label: Paragraph

text: than a “characterless package” and a gloomy, dismal landmark of International Style in
label: Paragraph

text: the building, whereas East
label: Paragraph

text: United Nations Headquarters, view looking east (1953)
label: Caption

text: © Museum of the City of New York and The Port Authority of New York
label: Caption

text: European politicians refused the moder design for ideological reasons. Stalinist
label: Paragraph

text: architectural doctrine regarded Western modernism as cultural colonialism of the United
label: Paragraph

text: States. Other critics were worried about the image of bureaucracy and machinery
label: Paragraph

text: displayed by the standardized curtain wall and office cells.
label: Caption

text: When postwar International Style architecture spread to the business districts of New
label: Paragraph

text: York and other global cities by the end of the 20th century, the aesthetic effect of
label: Paragraph

text: transparency encoded as political openness and honesty of a peace-oriented world
label: Paragraph

text: administration became corrupted by commercialization and banality.
label: Paragraph

text: The United Nations Secretariat’s aesthetics of transparency and regular cubic forms
label: Paragraph

text: were reinterpreted by late modernism with Kevin Roche and John Dinkeloo’s towers,
label: Paragraph

text: immediately west of the Secretariat, for the hotel and office buildings called 1 and 2
label: Paragraph

text: United Nations Plaza (1976, 1983), thus promoting political representation by corporate
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Without the historical background of New York’s architectural history and
label: Paragraph

text: international debates about the political iconography of architecture, the United Nations
label: Paragraph

text: building complex seems to lack importance, perhaps because of the decreasing political
label: Paragraph

text: power of this world organization. Nevertheless, the United Nations Secretariat and
label: Paragraph

text: General Assembly buildings remain landmarks of cultural and political history.
label: Paragraph
