text: UNITED STATES
label: Title

text: Twentieth-century architecture in the United States exhibits multiple overlapping themes
label: Paragraph

text: that include historicism, regionalism, and various forms of modernism. Although
label: Paragraph

text: architects, historians, and critics throughout the 20th century sought continuities,
label: Paragraph

text: disjuncture appeared more frequently. One attempt at constancy involved reliance on
label: Paragraph

text: history as the source for design, as in McKim, Mead and White’s Pennsylvania Station
label: Paragraph

text: (1902-10), New York City, and Robert A.M.Stern’s Darden Business School (1992-96)
label: Caption

text: at the University of Virginia, Charlottesville. An alternative approach lay with the
label: Paragraph

text: regionalists or nativists, who sought a unique American expression based on the local
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular and, often, landscape, such as with Frank Lloyd Wright’s early Prairie style
label: Paragraph

text: houses and Antoine Predock’s abstraction of native American forms. The third theme, a
label: Paragraph

text: quest for a modern architecture, occupied many individuals and includes buildings as
label: Paragraph

text: diverse as R.M.Schindler’s King Road House (Los Angeles, 1921-22), Marcel Breuer’s
label: Paragraph

text: St. John’s Abbey (Collegeville, Minnesota, 1953-61), and I.M.Pei’s Louvre Pyramid
label: Caption

text: (Paris, 1983-93). All three examples paid homage to abstraction and advanced building
label: Paragraph

text: materials and techniques. Ideas concerning the American city have ricocheted from grand
label: Paragraph

text: plazas, as with John Bakewell and Arthur Brown’s San Francisco Civic Center and City
label: Paragraph

text: Hall (1912-16, renovations 1995—99); to setback skyscrapers and elevated roads, pictured
label: Caption

text: by Hugh Ferris’s Metropolis of Tomorrow (1929); to monolithic towers with little
label: Paragraph

text: connection to the city, exemplified by John Portman’s Renaissance Center (1971-77,
label: Paragraph

text: Detroit); and finally the ideas of Duany and Plater-Zyberk (Andrés Duany and Elizabeth
label: Paragraph

text: Plater-Zyberk) for new towns that captured the critical discourse of the 1990s and that
label: Paragraph

text: make up a movement termed New Urbanism. Instead of singularity, American
label: Paragraph

text: architecture offers a competition of themes and a bewildering variety of expressions.
label: Paragraph

text: American Characteristics
label: Title

text: Conditioning American architecture is the unprecedented wealth and standard of living of
label: Paragraph

text: the country and its emergence as a dominant world power in the 20th century. What
label: Paragraph

text: would be the nature of American culture and how it would define itself has been a
label: Paragraph

text: perennial problem as the cult of individuality reigns.
label: Paragraph

text: Historicism
label: Title

text: The strongest and most continuous theme in American architecture remains an
label: Paragraph

text: infatuation with history and the employment of imagery from the past. The method of
label: Paragraph

text: how this past has been quoted—from fidelity to distortion—and the range of
label: Paragraph

text: appropriation from Colonial to European and Oriental has varied. The semiotician
label: Paragraph

text: Umberto Eco observed that the American imagination craves the real thing, and to
label: Paragraph

text: establish that reassurance, Americans fabricate, or reproduce imitations. Architects create
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in which the quotation is proudly displayed: the English Georgian country
label: Paragraph

text: houses of David Adler, such as Castle Hill, Ipswich, Massachusetts, (1924-27) or the
label: Paragraph

text: Roman villa as the basis for the J.Paul Getty Museum (1972-74), Malibu, California, by
label: Caption

text: Langdon, Wilson and Garrett, with Norman Neuerberg as consultant.
label: Paragraph

text: The American Renaissance, dominant from, 1890s to the 1930s and led by the firm of
label: Paragraph

text: McKim, Mead and White and others, posited that American architecture and art could not
label: Paragraph

text: be invented but, rather, that it should draw upon the classical past of Europe and
label: Paragraph

text: America. Out of this approach came the great courts of honor at the various American
label: Paragraph

text: fairs from Buffalo (1901) to Philadelphia (1926). These courts of honor provided a model
label: Paragraph

text: of civic architecture and led directly to the City Beautiful Movement and civic centers
label: Paragraph

text: such as Arthur Brown’s in San Francisco and state capitols that lasted well into the
label: Paragraph

text: Depression, as for example with Cass Gilbert’s West Virginia Capitol (Charleston, 1930—
label: Paragraph

text: 32) and John Russell Pope’s National Gallery of Art (Washington, D.C., 1936-41).
label: Caption

text: Opposed to this classicism stood the medieval revival led by Ralph Adams Cram, who
label: Paragraph

text: argued for the validity of the Gothic and designed over a hundred churches and
label: Paragraph

text: significant portions of university campuses between 1900 and 1940. Cram succeeded in
label: Paragraph

text: creating a Boston-based Gothic School that affected thousands of churches across the
label: Paragraph

text: country, such as Frohman, Robb and Little’s (and others) National Cathedral (1906-90)
label: Paragraph

text: in Washington, D.C.
label: Paragraph

text: Colonial Revival, whether Spanish, English, or other nationalities, has proved to be the
label: Paragraph

text: most lasting historicist approach. The myth of Colonial as the truest, and the earliest,
label: Paragraph

text: American style had an effect on others that appear to be far removed. The restoration of
label: Paragraph

text: Colonial Williamsburg (1927—) gave great impetus to Colonial Revival and made the
label: Paragraph

text: brick Virginia Tidewater Georgian house a national image. In Florida and the Southwest,
label: Paragraph

text: a Mission and then a Spanish Colonial Revival developed as a localized colonial revival
label: Paragraph

text: response. Since 1926 towns such as Santa Barbara have continued to rebuild themselves
label: Paragraph

text: along the lines of a Spanish town, even though that history is mostly fictional.
label: Paragraph

text: Recognition of the validity of a historicist approach vacillated in 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: America. From 1900 to the 1930s, historicism was the accepted norm, and architectural
label: Paragraph

text: periodicals showed and promoted historical prototypes. However, beginning in the 1920s,
label: Paragraph

text: the historical approach came under fire, and by the 1940s the appearance in professional
label: Paragraph

text: architectural periodicals of buildings in historical dress was rare. From the 1940s through
label: Paragraph

text: the mid-1970s, serious discussion of historicism as a contemporary approach to design
label: Paragraph

text: disappeared from the profession, the schools, and writings by most critics and historians.
label: Paragraph

text: Not all historically based design disappeared, for it thrived with builders and contractors
label: Paragraph

text: at the suburban house level and also in the hands of many local architects. Allan
label: Paragraph

text: Greenburg’s design for the Brant House (Greenwich, Connecticut, 1979-83), which takes
label: Paragraph

text: elements of Washington’s Mount Vernon, received rave reviews in the professional
label: Paragraph

text: press, indicating the changed climate. The work of Hartman-Cox Architects (George
label: Caption

text: Hartman and Warren Cox), who began as modernists but turned to preexisting models,
label: Paragraph

text: received similar praise. Their Georgetown University Law Center Library (Washington,
label: Paragraph

text: D.C., 1984-89) and their additions to the Chrysler Museum (1982-89) in Norfolk,
label: Paragraph

text: Virginia, appear as if they have stood since the 1930s.
label: Paragraph

text: The recognition of historicism as a valid architectural approach began in the late 1960s
label: Paragraph

text: with a reevaluation by architects who became known as Postmodernists and by a group of
label: Paragraph

text: younger historians who began to investigate the hitherto forbidden (i.e., outmoded)
label: Paragraph

text: Victorian and Beaux-Arts eras. However, the greatest contributing element to the new
label: Paragraph

text: historicism was the Historic Preservation movement, which gained great support in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s and 1970s because of new federal and local legislation. From 1900 to the 1950s,
label: Paragraph

text: preservation had a reputation as elitist—only concerned with the homes of the wealthy
label: Paragraph

text: and in recreating historical villages. In the 1960s, however, preservationists questioned
label: Paragraph

text: urban renewal and the destruction of sections of older cities and whole buildings such as
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania Station (1961) in New York and the construction of unsympathetic modern
label: Paragraph

text: structures. A reevaluation of the American built past took place with new recognition of
label: Paragraph

text: the more recent Victorian, American Renaissance, and Art Deco buildings and even
label: Paragraph

text: streamlined diners. One effect of the preservation movement has been to direct attention
label: Paragraph

text: to the validity of historically based design. Within inner cities there developed an
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledgment of the historic townscape and a contextual approach to design. Kevin
label: Paragraph

text: Roche, a modernist, continued the original architect Francoise ler’s style for an addition
label: Paragraph

text: to the Jewish Museum (1989) in New York; in Washington, D.C., for a new building in
label: Caption

text: the Federal Triangle, James L. Freed, of Pei, Cobb, Freed, employed classical orders for
label: Paragraph

text: the Reagan International Building (1989-98). Older structures were adapted for new
label: Paragraph

text: purposes, such as The Cannery (San Francisco, 1968) by Joseph Esherick and Quincy
label: Paragraph

text: Markets (Boston, 1976) by Ben Thompson. These so-called “festival markets” helped
label: Paragraph

text: influence a semisuccessful attempt to revive main streets across the country.
label: Paragraph

text: The New Urbanism movement spearheaded by Duany and Plater-Zyberk at Seaside,
label: Paragraph

text: Florida, and other places and by the firm Cooper-Robertson (Alexander Cooper and
label: Paragraph

text: Jaquelin Robertson) and others at Celebration, Florida, draws on nostalgic interpretations
label: Paragraph

text: of the 19th- and early 20th-century small town. All types of revival houses compete for
label: Paragraph

text: attention. In a sense these are architectural theme parks—Disneyland as permanent
label: Paragraph

text: lifestyle. The power of historicism and nostalgia for an earlier time are strong traits in
label: Paragraph

text: America and have created one of its most enduring legacies.
label: Paragraph

text: Regionalism and Nativism
label: Title

text: The search for a native American architecture that could be based on the local vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: or nature has animated many architects. A recognition of localized conditions of
label: Paragraph

text: environment can be traced far back in American history, but regionalism as a coherent
label: Paragraph

text: architectural approach owes a debt to the Arts and Crafts philosophy of William Morris
label: Paragraph

text: and his followers that reached America from the 1870s onward. Simple overall form and
label: Paragraph

text: complex details became a trademark of both furniture and buildings, which often had
label: Paragraph

text: wood peg joints and leaded glass windows contrasted with plain woodwork. In England
label: Paragraph

text: one of the fundamental touchstones was an antimachine, anti-industry attitude and a
label: Paragraph

text: return of artisans to the production of objects and buildings. Some Americans did adopt a
label: Paragraph

text: handicraft ethic—especially decorative arts artisans—but overall Americans remained
label: Paragraph

text: tied to the machine, and the Arts and Crafts aesthetic was widely commercialized in
label: Paragraph

text: America. Frank Lloyd Wright’s 1901 talk, “The Art and Craft of the Machine,” noted
label: Paragraph

text: that the machine could better provide the aesthetic qualities of simplicity and
label: Paragraph

text: rectilinearity than the hand.
label: Paragraph

text: The Arts and Crafts movement in America persisted into the 1920s. Although the
label: Paragraph

text: overall intention was for a regional response, the movement existed at the national level
label: Paragraph

text: through the writings of publicists like Gustav Stickley and The Crafisman magazine.
label: Paragraph

text: Stickley and others popularized the concept of the bungalow, the low-rising story- to-
label: Paragraph

text: story-and-a-half house that fit easily into the landscape of suburbia and nature.
label: Paragraph

text: Bungalows appeared from coast to coast and became the archetypal nativist house for the
label: Paragraph

text: period of 1900 to 1925. In southern California, Irving Gill abstracted the Mission into a
label: Paragraph

text: simplified concrete type of construction that was remarkable for its absence of details and
label: Paragraph

text: purity of form. Also in southern California, brothers Charles Sumner and Henry Mather
label: Paragraph

text: Greene created a very different expression, making the shingle-covered wood bungalow
label: Paragraph

text: into an exquisite art object of delicately wrought construction. The basis of their design
label: Paragraph

text: was the local vernacular and the elaboration of wood construction, as in the Gamble
label: Paragraph

text: house (Pasadena, California, 1906-08). Farther north, in the Bay Area around San
label: Caption

text: Francisco, Bernard Maybeck created his own personalized—and_ eclectic—regional
label: Paragraph

text: response, using various foreign and American elements.
label: Paragraph

text: The Chicago area, led by Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright, created a distinctive
label: Paragraph

text: regionalism in the Prairie School. Sullivan’s early work was large, urban, and
label: Paragraph

text: commercial, but after 1900 he found such commissions difficult to secure and turned to
label: Paragraph

text: house and small-town bank designs that fit squarely within the Arts and Crafts regional
label: Paragraph

text: ethic. His National Farmer’s Bank (1907), Owatonna, Minnesota, designed in
label: Caption

text: conjunction with George Grant Elmslie, demonstrated a nativistic and original creation of
label: Paragraph

text: ormament drawn from nature and geometry. Sullivan represented one side of the Prairie
label: Paragraph

text: School; his descendants William Gray Purcell and Elmslie followed his lead with
label: Paragraph

text: essentially boxy forms articulated by openings, structural members, and ornament.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright, who had worked for Sullivan, represents the other, better-known side of the
label: Paragraph

text: Prairie style. Wright openly attempted to recall the landscape through low-rising forms,
label: Paragraph

text: open spaces, and ornamental details. Except for his earliest buildings and his inexpensive
label: Paragraph

text: housing solutions, Wright tended to break apart the form, to stretch it out, to articulate the
label: Paragraph

text: parts into a coherent whole. The Robie House (Chicago, 1906-08) is composed of a
label: Paragraph

text: series of layers that move upward and outward, pinned to the earth by a large chimney
label: Paragraph

text: core, and that shelter a continuous living-dining space. Out of Wright’s Oak Park Studio
label: Paragraph

text: came a group of architects such as Walter Burley Griffin, Marion Mahony, and others
label: Paragraph

text: who elaborated Wright’s ideas and helped spread them not only nationwide but
label: Paragraph

text: internationally.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s career in the United States went into an eclipse between 1914 and 1936; he
label: Paragraph

text: built little except for works in Tokyo and southern California. This work moves beyond
label: Paragraph

text: the Arts and Crafts, as Wright attempted to create a native language appropriate to the
label: Paragraph

text: site. In the Los Angeles area, Wright drew on preColumbian Indian forms. Although
label: Paragraph

text: viewed as a modernist abroad and by many at home, Wright always claimed that his
label: Paragraph

text: architecture came from American conditions, and he employed the word “organic” as a
label: Paragraph

text: definition. Fallingwater (Bear Run, Pennsylvania, 1935-37) announced Wright’s return
label: Paragraph

text: to prominence and posited that American modern design should respond to the localized
label: Paragraph

text: conditions of site. His later Usonian houses and the Guggenheim Museum (New York
label: Paragraph

text: City, 1943-59) were attempts to forge an American architecture free of either historical
label: Paragraph

text: or European modern prototypes.
label: Paragraph

text: Later followers of Wright in this quest for a nativist American design would include
label: Paragraph

text: his Taliesin Fellowship, a few of his students, E.Fay Jones, and at some removal,
label: Paragraph

text: independents like Bruce Goff.Jones’s work has Wrightian forms and details, though with
label: Paragraph

text: more vertical articulation. His Interdenominational Chapel (1980), Thorncrown,
label: Caption

text: Arkansas, uses wooden uprights and trusses to create a magical space in the middle of a
label: Paragraph

text: grove. Goff s work has no parallels, for although he admitted to initially being affected
label: Paragraph

text: by Wright, his designs departed from the essentially geometrical basis of Wright. Goff
label: Paragraph

text: eccentrically used prows, peaks, towers, carpeted walls, and fringe. His Ford House
label: Paragraph

text: (Aurora, Illinois, 1947-50) is a round shape with two attached bedroom pods; the form is
label: Paragraph

text: composed of lower walls of coal embedded with hunks of green glass that carry a
label: Paragraph

text: Quonset hut frame covered in lapped siding and shingles. The interior, as with most of
label: Paragraph

text: Goff s work, is unsettling in its unconventionality and exhilarating in its expansiveness.
label: Paragraph

text: Another branch of regionalism, more historically based, continued in the 1920s and
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s with architects such as John Gaw Meem in New Mexico, Robert McGoodwin in
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania, and Royal Barry Wills in Massachusetts. They designed buildings that
label: Paragraph

text: eclectically drew on the local vernacular imagery and met modern requirements. The
label: Paragraph

text: work of these regionalists was accomplished and in many cases distinguished; Wills’s
label: Paragraph

text: work was especially influential because he publicized it through a series of books for
label: Paragraph

text: homeowners, whereas Meem created an image for an entire region.
label: Paragraph

text: Beginning in the 1930s, a new school of abstract regionalism developed in the far west,
label: Paragraph

text: where architects in southern California (Harwell Hamilton Harris), in the Bay Area
label: Paragraph

text: (William Wurster), and in Oregon (Pietro Belluschi} drew on the local vernacular of
label: Paragraph

text: cabins, barns, and ranches and also on the earlier work of Maybeck and the brothers
label: Paragraph

text: Greene. Harris and Wurster created a “woodsy” California vernacular, using the older
label: Paragraph

text: ranch house plan, but with open plans and simplified details influenced by the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style. By the late 1940s, a new West Coast School was openly
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged, though it sometimes went under more specific names: the Redwood
label: Paragraph

text: School, or the Bay Area Group. In the 1950s and 1960s came Joseph Esherick and the
label: Paragraph

text: firm of Moore, Lyndon, Trumbull and Whitaker. The latter’s work at Sea Ranch (1964—
label: Paragraph

text: 74), with Lawrence Halprin, picked up on the mid-19th century wooden forms from the
label: Paragraph

text: nearby Russian settlement at Fort Ross and combined them with landscape sensitivity.
label: Paragraph

text: Also emerging in the late 1960s and 1970s as part of the counterculture revolution would
label: Paragraph

text: be a “butcher block,” or ad hoc aesthetic of buildings constructed of seemingly random
label: Paragraph

text: elements for specific sites.
label: Paragraph

text: The term “critical regionalism,” coined by the critic Kenneth Frampton in 1983,
label: Paragraph

text: although seeming to indicate a regionalist response, was really a recognition of certain
label: Paragraph

text: local modernist idioms that had grown up internationally. Placing stress on tectonics and
label: Paragraph

text: building processes, critical regionalism was really a critique of Postmodernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Architects sometimes labeled as critical regionalists—Samuel Mockbee and Clark and
label: Paragraph

text: Menefee—do draw on the local forms, but in a modernist vein. Antoine Predock created
label: Paragraph

text: in the southwest a compelling abstraction of landscape and indigenous building forms, as
label: Paragraph

text: in the Fine Arts Center (1985-89), Arizona State University, Tempe. The large geometric
label: Caption

text: forms exude an air of nativist mystery in the harsh sunlight.
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism
label: Title

text: The quest for a new or modern architecture dominated much of 20th-century American
label: Paragraph

text: architectural thought. A polemical warfare existed between factions who attempted to
label: Paragraph

text: define modern architecture by rigid stylistic criteria. With historical perspective,
label: Paragraph

text: however, one can see modernism as a broad theme that contains—and continues to
label: Paragraph

text: have—a number of different thrusts and styles or idioms, which might be labeled
label: Paragraph

text: decorative, constructive, abstract, and Postmodern. Common to all approaches was a
label: Paragraph

text: belief that reliance on older historical styles was intellectually bankrupt, given the
label: Paragraph

text: tremendous social and technological changes that had occurred. A zeitgeist, or a new
label: Paragraph

text: spirit, had arisen, brought into being by the machine or other technological advances.
label: Paragraph

text: Architects would be avant-garde, and like painters they should create a new expression.
label: Paragraph

text: All architectural modernists paid at least lip service to the notion of functionalism, but
label: Paragraph

text: how it was interpreted differed widely. Few architects belonged exclusively to the
label: Paragraph

text: decorative, constructive, abstract, or Postmodern approach. Mies van der Rohe argued
label: Paragraph

text: that his buildings were reflective of their structure with their revealed frame, as with the
label: Paragraph

text: apartment towers on Lake Shore Drive (Chicago, 1948-51). However, Mies was equally
label: Paragraph

text: concerned with creating elegant abstract objects irrespective of the revealed frame, as in
label: Paragraph

text: his Seagram Building (New York City, 1954-58). Similarly, Henry-Russell Hitchcock
label: Paragraph

text: and Philip Johnson noted the new methods of construction as a basis for The
label: Paragraph

text: international Style (1932), a book they wrote in conjunction with an exhibition at the
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Modern Art. However, they argued that the International Style existed
label: Paragraph

text: irrespective of technology, with its own abstract principles that included the avoidance of
label: Paragraph

text: applied decoration, volume rather than mass, and regularity rather than symmetry. The
label: Paragraph

text: International Style is similar to the American Renaissance in the attempt to fix a single
label: Paragraph

text: national architecture for all purposes. In this concern for a new universal style, some
label: Paragraph

text: modernists stand out. Mies van der Rohe created forms that could be—and were—built
label: Paragraph

text: everywhere.
label: Paragraph

text: The decorative modernist approach first emerged in the 1920s and 1930s and
label: Paragraph

text: frequently goes under the name of Art Deco or Art Moderne. Some American
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was directly influenced by the International Exhibition of Decorative Arts,
label: Paragraph

text: Paris (1925), and also by the European Secessionist movement. This comes forth most
label: Paragraph

text: obviously in the ornamental appliqué Eliel Saarinen placed on his Chicago Tribune
label: Caption

text: Tower entry (1922) or in Parkinson and Parkinson’s Bullocks-Wilshire Department Store
label: Caption

text: (Los Angeles, 1928). Saarinen’s later work remains within the decorative tradition seen
label: Paragraph

text: especially in his highly colorful Kingswood School (Cranbrook, Michigan, 1929-31). In
label: Paragraph

text: the later 1930s and 1940s, he evolved a more reticent and simpler modernism, though it
label: Paragraph

text: was tied to the ornamental texture of materials.
label: Paragraph

text: An aspect of the Art Deco was geometrical elements in a setback form with
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate ornament, which appeared in Bertram Goodhue’s Nebraska State Capitol
label: Paragraph

text: (Lincoln, 1921-31) and then in skyscrapers by Ralph Walker, Raymond Hood, and
label: Paragraph

text: William Van Alen. The 1916 New York zoning regulations helped in this development
label: Paragraph

text: because they mandated setbacks in high-rise buildings, and architects across the country
label: Paragraph

text: imitated the form, irrespective of local zoning regulations. Hugh Ferris, an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: renderer, showed architects how the setbacks of the tall masses could be molded. Van
label: Paragraph

text: Alen’s Chrysler Building (New York City, 1928-31) combined setbacks with a stainless
label: Paragraph

text: steel radiating crest. At an urban scale, Raymond Hood, as the leader of a team of
label: Paragraph

text: architects, planned Rockefeller Center (New York City, 1928-38)—a group of
label: Paragraph

text: extravagantly decorated setback buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: A new decorative approach appeared in the 1950s and 1960s in some works by Philip
label: Paragraph

text: Johnson, Wallace K.Harrison, Minoru Yamasaki, and Edward Durell Stone. They
label: Paragraph

text: introduced patterned blocks and screens and also created forms that recalled classicism,
label: Paragraph

text: as in Stone’s United States Embassy (1954) in New Delhi, India. Johnson’s Sheldon
label: Paragraph

text: Museum (1960-63), University of Nebraska, is bounded by decorative, ahistorical
label: Paragraph

text: pilasters and arches with subtle curves and profiles that are perhaps too graceful.
label: Paragraph

text: The Constructivist approach takes as its premise that technology and construction are
label: Paragraph

text: the major design determinants and should be reflected in the final product. The 19th-
label: Paragraph

text: century Chicago School, with its emphasis on the revealed frame, was a major influence
label: Paragraph

text: on American architecture from the 1930s onward. Construction as the form determinant
label: Paragraph

text: can be seen most prominently in the work of Albert Kahn, a leading factory designer in
label: Paragraph

text: the first half of the 20th century. He produced large, elegant factories of curtain walls
label: Paragraph

text: enclosing trusses, columns, and open interior spaces. In California the Case Study
label: Paragraph

text: housing program of the 1940s and 1950s, led by designers such as Charles Eames and
label: Paragraph

text: Craig Ellwood, created steel-framed houses out of industrial components. A High-Tech
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility emerged in which great prominence was given to industrial materials, the
label: Paragraph

text: structure, and the heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems. The later work of
label: Paragraph

text: Ellwood (Art Center College of Design, Pasadena, California, 1977), the early work of
label: Paragraph

text: Hardy, Holtzman and Pfeiffer (Orchestra Hall, Minneapolis, Minnesota, 1974), and the
label: Caption

text: work of Helmut Jahn (Michigan City, Indiana, Public Library, 1977) all exploited
label: Caption

text: technology both as the basic expression of the building and as ornament.
label: Paragraph

text: Far different is the Brutalist approach of Louis Kahn, who saw technology and
label: Paragraph

text: structure as elements to emphasize, as with the giant laboratory exhausts and reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete, prestressed, posttensioned framing elements in the Richards Medical
label: Caption

text: Laboratory (Philadelphia, 1957-61). Kahn acted as a father figure to a group of
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia-based architects such as Romaldo Giurgola. Kahn’s work, however, is more
label: Paragraph

text: than just construction; it is also a concern for light and an employment of abstract
label: Paragraph

text: references to historical prototypes such as the Italian hill town towers at the Richards
label: Paragraph

text: Laboratory; the Romanesque barrel vaults at the Kimbell Art Museum, Fort Worth,
label: Caption

text: Texas; or the tapering Egyptian pylons and Renaissance palazzos at the Phillips Exeter
label: Paragraph

text: Library (Exeter, New Hampshire, 1965-71). As with many creative architects, Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: escapes any precise classification.
label: Paragraph

text: Abstract modernism, the third major direction, is a radical ahistoricism in which all
label: Paragraph

text: traditional imagery is absent. It first appeared in the work of émigrés such as
label: Paragraph

text: R.M.Schindler and Richard Neutra. Schindler wanted an architecture that bore no relation
label: Paragraph

text: to anything of the past and equally avoided contemporary stylisms. His Lovell Beach
label: Paragraph

text: House (Newport Beach, California, 1924-26) was a series of stacked trays held aloft by a
label: Paragraph

text: concrete frame and his later houses were exploded boxes of “Space Architecture,” as he
label: Paragraph

text: claimed, perched precariously on hillsides. Schindler fits in no stylistic categories,
label: Paragraph

text: whereas Richard Neutra was more derivative of the Europe-based International Style. His
label: Paragraph

text: Lovell Health House (Los Angeles, 1927-29), with its white gunite skin and steel frame,
label: Paragraph

text: was actually more advanced technologically than its European contemporaries.
label: Paragraph

text: Technology was always an important element of abstract modernism, but never a
label: Paragraph

text: determinant. The arrival in the later 1930s of another group of European émigrés such as
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Gropius, Marcel Breuer, and Mies van der Rohe helped to make abstract
label: Paragraph

text: modernism into the dominant American expression. Mies was the more important form-
label: Paragraph

text: giver, and through his teaching in the College of Architecture at the Illinois Institute of
label: Paragraph

text: Technology, Chicago—his campus design served as a demonstration—his steel-and-glass
label: Paragraph

text: expression came to dominate American cities.
label: Paragraph

text: American followers of the International Style included George Howe, who with the
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss émigré William Lescaze designed the PSFS Building (Philadelphia, 1929-32). The
label: Paragraph

text: PSFS skyscraper, with its cool, high-styled abstraction, became a forerunner of a post-
label: Paragraph

text: World War Il phenomenon—the large, aggressively modern corporate headquarters.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead of the safety of history as an image to be associated with, corporation presidents
label: Paragraph

text: now sought the novel and modern. The American firm of Skidmore, Owings and Merrill
label: Paragraph

text: became the acknowledged leaders of this building type. Under the guidance of designers
label: Paragraph

text: Gordon Bunshaft and Bruce Graham, Skidmore, Owings and Merrill created crisp and
label: Paragraph

text: elegant skyscrapers including the Lever House (New York City, 1949-52) and the Sears
label: Paragraph

text: Tower (Chicago, 1974-76), as well as suburban headquarters such as Connecticut
label: Paragraph

text: General Life (Bloomfield, Connecticut, 1954-57). The glass office tower assumed
label: Caption

text: political symbolism with the United Nations Headquarters (New York City, 1947-52),
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Wallace K.Harrison in association with foreign advisers.
label: Caption

text: Eero Saarinen provided a challenging pluralism of a different style for each
label: Paragraph

text: commission in contrast to the single-minded steeland-glass approach. His General Motors
label: Paragraph

text: Technical Center (Warren, Michigan, 1948-56) suggested a Miesian aesthetic, but he
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly recognized that form knew no boundaries. In his later works such as the
label: Paragraph

text: TWA Airport Terminal (1956-62) at New York’s John F.Kennedy Airport, or the Dulles
label: Paragraph

text: Airport Terminal in Chantilly, Virginia (1958-62), Saarinen created tremendously
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic forms. He also explored a historical contextualism in Morse and Stiles Colleges,
label: Paragraph

text: Yale University (New Haven, Connecticut, 1958-62), in which the earlier Gothic Revival
label: Paragraph

text: campus was loosely recalled.
label: Paragraph

text: A roughness of concrete and dramatic sculptural form similar to Le Corbusier’s late
label: Paragraph

text: manner at Harvard University’s Carpenter Center (Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1960-63)
label: Caption

text: became a popular idiom with a group of architects from the late 1950s through the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1970s. Paul Rudolph’s Yale University Art and Architecture Building (New Haven,
label: Caption

text: Connecticut, 1958-62) echoes both Wright and Le Corbusier in forms. Although
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalism found a following, more important was the “rebirth of solids” and “a new
label: Paragraph

text: plasticity,” as Marcel Breuer explained it. He exploited the massive concrete frame in a
label: Paragraph

text: series of large bureaucratic office buildings in the United States and abroad.
label: Paragraph

text: From the 1960s onward, minimalist and scaleless exterior forms reflecting the
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaneous minimal art movement in painting and sculpture became a line of
label: Paragraph

text: development in abstract modernism. Gordon Bunshaft’s Hirshhorn Museum
label: Caption

text: (Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C., 1967-74) was essentially a large piece of
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture—a pure round and monolithic form. Exteriors of buildings appeared to become
label: Paragraph

text: a single, unified material, such as reflective glass on ILM. Pei and Henry Cobb’s John
label: Paragraph

text: Hancock Buildings (Boston, 1973-77), Kevin Roche’s U.N. Plaza (New York City,
label: Caption

text: 1976-83), or Cesar Pelli’s Pacific Design Center (Los Angeles, 1973-75). The reflective
label: Paragraph

text: glass skin was an American trademark; similarly, long stretches of limestone with few
label: Paragraph

text: subdivisions, as in Pei’s East Wing of the National Gallery (Washington, D.C., 1968-78),
label: Paragraph

text: also produced this clean, minimal effect.
label: Paragraph

text: The “white box” of the 1920s International Style experienced a revival in the 1960s
label: Paragraph

text: and 1970s via a younger generation. The “New York Five” (Richard Meier, Michael
label: Paragraph

text: Graves, Peter Eisenman, John Hedjuk, and Charles Gwathmey) were greatly influenced
label: Paragraph

text: by Le Corbusier’s pavilions of the 1920s and by the Anglo-American critic Colin Rowe.
label: Paragraph

text: All moved on to different work, though Meier retained the most allegiance, showing an
label: Paragraph

text: ability to inflate the white box into a large and more complicated scale, as with his U.S.
label: Paragraph

text: Courthouse (Central Islip, New York, 2000).
label: Caption

text: Postmodernism in the 1970s and 1980s might have been considered a separate theme,
label: Paragraph

text: but as the term implies, it was (or is) not a total break with modernism, but the opening of
label: Paragraph

text: a discourse with subjects that modernism had ignored up to that point. Born of a sense of
label: Paragraph

text: disillusionment and what was termed at the time a “failure” of abstract and technological
label: Paragraph

text: modernism, Postmodernism frequently exhibited a contextual approach in design and a
label: Paragraph

text: certain nostalgia for the past that contained analogies with decorative modernism. The
label: Paragraph

text: term Postmodernism did not receive wide currency until its adoption by proponents such
label: Paragraph

text: as Robert A.M.Stern and Charles Jencks in the mid-1970s, but its roots go back to the
label: Paragraph

text: dissatisfaction with modernism seen in the work of Johnson, Stone, and others in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s. Jane Jacobs’s The Death and Life of Great American Cities (1961) criticized the
label: Paragraph

text: modernist fascination with isolated buildings. Robert Venturi’s Complexity and
label: Paragraph

text: Contradiction in Architecture (1966) and his later (with Denise Scott Brown and Steven
label: Paragraph

text: Izenour) Learning from Las Vegas (1972) were the earliest key texts of the movement.
label: Paragraph

text: Influenced by the contemporaneous pop art movement, Venturi argued that architects
label: Paragraph

text: should look to the roadside “strip” and that buildings were primarily “signs” with
label: Paragraph

text: communicative systems involving nonfunctional elements such as ornament. Symbolism
label: Paragraph

text: treated with irony became his firm’s trademark. Venturi’s mother’s house (Vanna Venturi
label: Paragraph

text: House, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 1962-64) reflects this approach with raised moldings,
label: Caption

text: an oblique entrance, and a split gable that can be read as a pediment. Venturi and his
label: Caption

text: partners frequently demonstrate a witty streak, as in the play on the 1910s revival of the
label: Paragraph

text: English Jacobean Revival at Princeton University in their Wu Hall (Princeton, New
label: Caption

text: Jersey, 1980-83). Initially, Charles Moore’s architecture of the 1960s had a regionalist
label: Paragraph

text: orientation, as at Sea Ranch condominiums (Sea Ranch, California, 1964-65); however,
label: Paragraph

text: Moore also showed a sensibility to history and used ornament in an unorthodox and even
label: Paragraph

text: distorted manner. A peripatetic teacher at many schools and universities, Moore
label: Paragraph

text: influenced a tremendous number of younger architects. Stylized references through
label: Paragraph

text: abstraction and distortion to earlier buildings and forms can be seen as the basis of a
label: Paragraph

text: group of Postmodernists such as Michael Graves. Graves, who began as a neo-Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusian in his earlier works, retained a modernist search for a distinctive personal
label: Paragraph

text: language. His Public Services Building (Portland, Oregon, 1980-82), with its unique
label: Paragraph

text: polychrome pastels and over-scaled and patently false applied classical detail, contains a
label: Paragraph

text: lurking figurative molding of space and form. Similarly, his Den-ver Public Library
label: Paragraph

text: (1995) has a relation to the particularized western mining context but contains its own
label: Paragraph

text: individuality. Postmodernism’s critique of the failure of modernism included its lack of
label: Paragraph

text: theory that went beyond function and technology. The result was a theory fad that
label: Paragraph

text: crashed through academia and promoted approaches drawn from other disciplines such as
label: Paragraph

text: semiotics, anthropology, and gender studies. The most prominent was a form of abstract
label: Paragraph

text: modernism called deconstructivism, which emerged in the 1980s and drew on French
label: Paragraph

text: literary theory and philosophy and also on the Russian Constructivism of the 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: Deconstructivist architecture existed not as a unified approach but as a group of
label: Paragraph

text: individuals, including Peter Eisenman, who challenged harmony, unity, and stability by
label: Paragraph

text: designing buildings or theoretical projects in which forms are rotated, along with the
label: Paragraph

text: appearance of odd angles, disruptive materials, and a general sense of alienation of the
label: Paragraph

text: occupant. As shown in his Wexner Center (1985-89), Ohio State University, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Columbus Convention Center (1989—92)—both in Columbus, Ohio—Eisenman’s work is
label: Paragraph

text: characterized by a progressive distortion and an additive and subtractive design process
label: Paragraph

text: to create conflict-ridden, unsettling forms.
label: Paragraph

text: Avoiding this complex theoretical base, a new wave of abstract modernism far more
label: Paragraph

text: sculptural and distorted in form emerged in the 1980s and 1990s, as seen in the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Gehry, Thom Mayne and Morphosis, and Eric Owen Moss—all centered in the
label: Paragraph

text: Los Angeles area. Gehry’s early work, such as his own house (Santa Monica, California,
label: Paragraph

text: 1977-78, 1992), delighted in collage and the treatment of fragmentary elements in
label: Paragraph

text: unorthodox ways, including asphalt floors, open stud frames, and chainlink fencing. As
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s work developed, it became more sculptural, as with his Advanced Technology
label: Paragraph

text: Laboratory (1987-92) at the University of lowa, lowa City, and the Guggenheim
label: Paragraph

text: Museum (Bilbao, Spain, 1993-97). The lowa work is composed of tiled geometrical
label: Paragraph

text: blocks, whereas in Spain, the 258,000-square-foot museum exudes a strongly organic feel
label: Paragraph

text: with its long curling surfaces. Partially clad in titanium, the Bilbao structure continues the
label: Paragraph

text: collage approach with its juncture of various geometries and materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s Guggenheim at Bilbao and other late 20th-century works such as the Korean
label: Paragraph

text: Presbyterian Church (2000), Queens, New York, by Garofalo, with Lynn and McInturf—
label: Caption

text: with its extruded frame like wings—have been likened to computer-created designs.
label: Paragraph

text: Certainly, the working drawings and building materials fabrication were done by
label: Paragraph

text: computer programs. Computers did aid in opening Gehry and Garofalo’s vision to new
label: Paragraph

text: exciting and abstract forms, but computers did not create the fantastic forms that were
label: Paragraph

text: still products of the designers’ imaginations.
label: Paragraph

text: At the end of the 20th century, American architecture was as diffuse as Gehry’s project
label: Paragraph

text: for a 40-story-tall new Guggenheim building in New York and Robert A.M.Stern’s
label: Caption

text: design for a Public Library in Nashville, Tennessee. Gehry’s project is a wild
label: Paragraph

text: combination of forms, whereas Stern’s library recalls Paul Cret’s work of the 1930s.
label: Paragraph

text: They represent an alpha and omega of architecture: two extremely different ideas of what
label: Paragraph

text: is American. This multiplicity of approaches in American architecture during the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century is its ultimate characteristic. The consequence has been many competing themes
label: Paragraph

text: and approaches with none totally dominant and, indeed, no promise of that occurrence in
label: Paragraph

text: the near future.
label: Paragraph

text: UNITED STATES AIR FORCE ACADEMY
label: Title

text: CHAPEL
label: Title

text: Designed by Skidmore, Owings and Merrill; completed 1963
label: Caption

text: Colorado Springs, Colorado
label: Title

text: The U.S. Air Force Academy Cadet Chapel, today the most visited man-made structure
label: Paragraph

text: in Colorado, was once the source of a bitter controversy that extended all the way to the
label: Paragraph

text: U.S. Congress. Because of this battle, the chapel design, completed by Walter A.Netsch,
label: Paragraph

text: Jr., of the Chicago office of Skidmore, Owings and Merrill (SOM), was altered and
label: Paragraph

text: finally completed after five years of planning and four years of construction. SOM was
label: Paragraph

text: also responsible for the overall design of the campus, which they completed in the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style. The chapel was to be both literally and figuratively the crowning
label: Paragraph

text: element of the complex with its pointed profile, symbolizing the surrounding Rocky
label: Paragraph

text: Mountains or, perhaps more appropriately, a group of upended fighter jets, rising above
label: Paragraph

text: the other structures of the campus.
label: Paragraph

text: mn
label: Title

text: U.S. Air Force Academy Chapel, Colorado Springs
label: Caption

text: Photo courtesy United States Air Force Academy Headquarters
label: Caption

text: Netsch’s first design for the chapel, a modified A-frame structure with folding concrete
label: Paragraph

text: plates, was not well received when presented to the public as part of the overall campus
label: Paragraph

text: design in May 1955. It was labeled an “assembly of wigwams” and a “modernistic
label: Paragraph

text: cigarette factory.” In July 1955, Frank Lloyd Wright led the criticism against the complex
label: Paragraph

text: when it was presented to Congress, calling the design “half baked” and “resembling a
label: Paragraph

text: wayside market.” Congress held back the necessary funds for the undertaking, but the Air
label: Paragraph

text: Force fought back, hiring a committee of architectural experts, including Eero Saarinen,
label: Paragraph

text: Wallace K.Harrison, Welton Becket, and Pietro Belluschi, to help redesign and positively
label: Paragraph

text: promote the project. Within days, a new scheme, complete with a more traditional chapel
label: Paragraph

text: design located on a different part of the site, found its way to the Senate floor.
label: Paragraph

text: Additionally, SOM and the Air Force made it clear that the chapel design was just
label: Paragraph

text: preliminary and would not be addressed for another four years. The Senate voted to
label: Paragraph

text: release the monies for the complex, and the Academy was saved, but the future of the
label: Paragraph

text: chapel’s design was uncertain.
label: Paragraph

text: Netsch, confident in the quality of his design but distraught over the lack of its
label: Paragraph

text: acceptance, left for Europe. The trip was not only a much-needed break from the chapel
label: Paragraph

text: conflict but also a chance to view religious architecture, which he did from Italy to
label: Paragraph

text: England. Renewed and refreshed, Netsch went back to work
label: Paragraph

text: U.S. Air Force Academy Chapel, interior detail of stained glass on ceiling
label: Caption

text: Photo courtesy United States Air Force Academy Headquarters
label: Caption

text: on the design of the chapel on his return to the United States. Still, disagreement clouded
label: Paragraph

text: the process. This time, it was concern over how to provide worship space for three
label: Paragraph

text: separate faiths: Protestant, Catholic, and Jewish. Should there be three separate chapels,
label: Paragraph

text: or should there be one chapel that would house all three faiths? Finally, in August of
label: Paragraph

text: 1957, after a number of design options had been explored, Netsch and SOM presented the
label: Paragraph

text: chapel’s final design to Congress. The building, triangular in profile, was comprised of
label: Paragraph

text: 19 spires covered with aluminum. The design was modernistic, even industrial, but
label: Paragraph

text: Congress approved its funding. The Air Force supported Netsch’s work by stating that
label: Paragraph

text: the building would be built as designed, rejuvenating Netsch, who promptly set off with
label: Paragraph

text: the building’s model and plans on a promotional tour across the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: Work on the building began under the contractor Robert E. McKee of Santa Fe, New
label: Caption

text: Mexico, on 28 August 1959. The chapel was placed on a podium adjacent to the
label: Paragraph

text: Academy’s Court of Honor. The only change from the final design to the built structure
label: Paragraph

text: was a reduction in the number of spires from 19 to 17 because of cost constraints. The
label: Paragraph

text: spires were fashioned from 100 tubular steel-framed tetrahedrons anchored by joints to
label: Paragraph

text: concrete buttresses. The tetrahedrons, spaced one foot apart to accept interstitial stained
label: Caption

text: glass, were clad in aluminum. Inside, the chapel was divided into two levels, the upper
label: Paragraph

text: housing the Protestant chapel and the lower the Catholic, Jewish, and All Faiths chapels.
label: Paragraph

text: This two-level arrangement might have been impressed on Netsch from his visits to the
label: Paragraph

text: Sainte-Chapelle in Paris, France, and the monastic church of St. Francis in Assisi, Italy.
label: Paragraph

text: The tetrahedrons meet 99 feet above the terrazzo floor of the 900-seat Protestant
label: Paragraph

text: chapel. Twenty-four thousand pieces of glass, with 35 percent of it chipped to give it a
label: Paragraph

text: jewellike appearance, fill the spaces between the tetrahedrons. Netsch carefully arranged
label: Paragraph

text: the layout of the glass by placing the darkest of the 24 shades used at the entrance end of
label: Paragraph

text: the chapel and progressing to the lighter colors in the front. A special laminated glass fills
label: Paragraph

text: the triangular spaces at the chapel’s northern and southern ends. A 14-foot-tall mosaic
label: Caption

text: reredos completed by the painter-sculptor Lumen Martin Winter, a 46-foot-tall aluminum
label: Caption

text: cross, and a 15-foot marble altar in the shape of a ship fill the liturgical north end.
label: Caption

text: The major portion of the lower level is reserved for the 500-seat Catholic chapel. The
label: Paragraph

text: space, accessible from the south on the terrace level, consists of precast-concrete beams
label: Paragraph

text: and columns filled with blue and amber glass sidewalls. The Baptistery and Blessed
label: Paragraph

text: Sacrament Chapel are located on either side of the main entrance. The focal point of the
label: Paragraph

text: space is the sanctuary with its blue-carpeted, three-step predella; a white marble altar; and
label: Paragraph

text: Venetian glass reredos. The Catholic chapel takes its name from the marble sculpture of
label: Paragraph

text: Our Lady of the Skies, one of the two figures in bas-relief on the 18-by-45-foot reredos,
label: Caption

text: the other being the Guardian Angel. Winter was responsible for the reredos, Stations of
label: Paragraph

text: the Cross, and the six-foot sculptured nickel silver crucifix over the altar.
label: Paragraph

text: Adjacent to the Catholic chapel on the north is the 100-seat Jewish chapel. Two
label: Paragraph

text: separate entrances from the terrace arcade give access to the space. The chapel is circular
label: Paragraph

text: in form and placed within a square foyer of purple-glass panels alternating with windows
label: Paragraph

text: of green and blue glass. Cypress stanchions separated by translucent pebble glass
label: Caption

text: separate the foyer from the chapel proper. Ludwig Y.Wolpert of the Jewish Museum in
label: Caption

text: New York City designed the ecclesiastical appointments, including the Holy Ark,
label: Paragraph

text: menorah, and Eternal Light. To the north of the Jewish chapel is the All Faiths Room, a
label: Paragraph

text: simple space devoid of ornament and religious symbolism in order to accommodate a
label: Paragraph

text: variety of faiths. The interior furnishing of each chapel was completed under the
label: Paragraph

text: guidance of leaders of each faith, including the General Commission on Chaplains in the
label: Paragraph

text: Armed Services to represent Protestant groups, the National Jewish Welfare Board, and
label: Paragraph

text: the Roman Catholic Military Ordinariate.
label: Paragraph

text: On 22 September 1963, nine years after its original presentation, the Cadet Chapel was
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated. The dedication did not, however, end the controversy surrounding it. The
label: Paragraph

text: debate over its new, nontraditional, and moder design was reported again in the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural and popular press. Indeed, the quest for what is appropriate in religious
label: Paragraph

text: architecture came from the design of a creator-architect supported by a patron, in this
label: Paragraph

text: case Walter Netsch designing for the U.S. Air Force. As the Air Force superintendent
label: Paragraph

text: stated at the building’s dedication, “The Cadet Chapel is the architectural and spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: centerpiece of our academy. As such, it plays a vital role in developing and nurturing the
label: Paragraph

text: character of our cadets. It is a reminder that we are a nation under God dedicated to the
label: Paragraph

text: promotion of peace and goodwill among all nations of the world. The young women and
label: Paragraph

text: men who come to study here do so in order to prepare themselves to protect freedom—
label: Paragraph

text: freedom which is God’s gift to all people.”
label: Paragraph

text: UNITY TEMPLE
label: Title

text: Designed by Frank Lloyd Wright; completed 1909 Oak Park, Illinois
label: Caption

text: Unity Temple is the building for what was originally Unity Church (since 1961 known
label: Paragraph

text: as the Unitarian-Universalist Church) at 875 Lake Street in the west Chicago suburb of
label: Paragraph

text: Oak Park, Illinois, designed and built by Frank Lloyd Wright from 1905 to 1909. The
label: Paragraph

text: structure was Wright’s first church and his first building wholly of concrete. Its stark
label: Paragraph

text: geometry and new material marked it to contemporaries as a work of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. It is among the most well-known modernist church buildings of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century. Unity Temple is one of Wright’s two outstanding nonresidential works of his
label: Paragraph

text: first mature period before 1910, the other being the Larkin Company Administration
label: Paragraph

text: Building in Buffalo, New York, designed and built in 1902-06. In his autobiography,
label: Paragraph

text: Wright wrote of Unity Temple as one of the works that best exemplified his method of
label: Paragraph

text: design.
label: Paragraph

text: Unity Church in Oak Park had previously worshiped in a traditional neo-Gothic wood
label: Paragraph

text: building with a tall frontal steeple, which was destroyed by fire in a lightning storm in
label: Paragraph

text: June 1905, just after Wright had returned from his first trip abroad to Japan. Wright had
label: Paragraph

text: been raised as a Unitarian and was a member of Unity Church during his residence in
label: Paragraph

text: Oak Park from 1887 to 1909. After the destruction of its older building, Unity Church
label: Paragraph

text: acquired a more centrally located site and appointed a committee, headed by Rev.
label: Paragraph

text: Rodney Johonnot, that chose Wright as architect for a new building by September 1905.
label: Paragraph

text: After much discussion, Unity Church approved Wright’s design for Unity Temple in
label: Paragraph

text: April 1906 for the new site on Oak Park’s Lake Street amid the expensive monumental
label: Caption

text: stone buildings of other Protestant churches. In the spring of 1906, construction began on
label: Paragraph

text: Unity House, the lower rectangular southern part of the building used as a parish hall for
label: Paragraph

text: social events, and it opened in September 1907. Unity Temple proper, the higher cubic
label: Paragraph

text: auditorium for worship services on the site’s north side, was opened for its first service in
label: Paragraph

text: October 1908, although work continued into 1909.
label: Paragraph

text: Working within a tight site and a minimal budget, Wright planned Unity Temple and
label: Paragraph

text: Unity House as two semi-independently built volumes with a common central entrance
label: Paragraph

text: hall between them set back from Lake Street. From this street, paths along either side of
label: Paragraph

text: Unity Temple lead back and up steps to raised outdoor terraces on the east and west sides
label: Paragraph

text: of the entrance hall. Above the doors on both sides of the hall is a Unitarian motto of the
label: Paragraph

text: period, affixed in bronze letters, that reads, “For the Worship of God and the Service of
label: Paragraph

text: Man,” perhaps referring to the distinct functions of Unity Temple and Unity House to
label: Paragraph

text: either side. Once inside the entrance hall, one proceeds directly south on the same level to
label: Paragraph

text: enter Unity House. To enter Unity Temple, one moves to the north side of the entrance
label: Paragraph

text: hall, toward its northeast and northwest corners, into walkways on the same level that
label: Paragraph

text: extend along the east and west sides of the temple but below its main floor. From these
label: Paragraph

text: low walkways, or “cloisters” as Wright called them, one rises to the auditorium’s main
label: Paragraph

text: floor via half flights of steps in each of its four corners. From the main floor, other corner
label: Caption

text: steps lead upward to the lower and upper galleries around the auditorium’s east, north,
label: Paragraph

text: and
label: Title

text: Interior looking north, Unity Temple, Oak Park, Illinois (1909)
label: Caption

text: © Historic American Buildings Survey/Historic American Engineering Record
label: Title

text: (Library of Congress) Photograph by Philip Turner
label: Caption

text: west sides. These galleries, as well as the pews on the main floor level, address the pulpit
label: Paragraph

text: in the center of the auditorium’s south side, behind which rises the tall organ screen
label: Caption

text: covering the room’s central south wall. Worshipers at all levels were to exit the
label: Paragraph

text: auditorium by filing to either side of the pulpit, where they could greet the minister, and
label: Paragraph

text: then descend steps back down to the entrance hall.
label: Paragraph

text: Unity Temple’s auditorium has clerestory windows of mostly clear glass around all
label: Paragraph

text: four sides and a coffered ceiling of concrete beams filled with panes of colored art glass.
label: Caption

text: The combination of the fully skylit central ceiling and the continuous clerestory windows
label: Paragraph

text: around all four sides of the space makes Unity Temple’s interior consistently bright with
label: Paragraph

text: daylight. Yet because of the depth of the ceiling coffers and the deep overhang of the roof
label: Paragraph

text: slabs beyond the clerestory windows, the ambient daylight is even, unlike unmodulated
label: Paragraph

text: direct sunlight. The overall luminosity of the temple contrasts with the darkness of the
label: Paragraph

text: low side access “cloisters” so that on entering the temple, one passes through darkness to
label: Paragraph

text: light. The linear designs for both the clerestory and the skylight glass, like the designs for
label: Paragraph

text: squared lamps that descend from the central ceiling’s four corners, are related to the
label: Paragraph

text: room’s overall square and rectilinear geometry. The whole structure is of concrete, either
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced with steel rods or encasing steel beams or trusses. Practically, the choice of
label: Paragraph

text: concrete created a fireproof church. Symbolically, the monolithic construction conveyed
label: Paragraph

text: the Unitarian ideal of unity, just as the liberal religious concept of divinity residing in
label: Paragraph

text: humanity was conveyed in the auditorium’s volume (which accommodated 450
label: Paragraph

text: worshipers who face one another in a room only 35 feet wide between balcony fronts).
label: Paragraph

text: Wright used narrow dark-stained oak strips to define the variably tinted planar surfaces of
label: Paragraph

text: plastered and plain concrete. The colored planes and wood lines create the room’s
label: Paragraph

text: abstract aesthetic with minimal means. In 1984, Unity Temple’s original interior colors
label: Paragraph

text: were restored, as were those of the entrance hall. Outside, Wright used repeated wood
label: Caption

text: formwork for pouring walls, roof slabs, corner stair blocks, and ornamentally cast
label: Caption

text: columns. The original exterior revealed the lines of this wood formwork and the pour
label: Paragraph

text: layers of the concrete, whose surface featured an aggregate of bird’s-eye gravel. In 1973—
label: Paragraph

text: 74, the building’s exterior was almost entirely recoated to approximate the original
label: Paragraph

text: surface, which was retained on the ornamental columns and roof slab soffits.
label: Paragraph

text: Although highly original as a design for a church building, Unity Temple might
label: Paragraph

text: represent Wright’s response to a wide range of historic and recent sources. The basic plan
label: Paragraph

text: of Unity Temple and Unity House joined by the entrance hall recalls that of
label: Paragraph

text: Unity Temple, Oak Park, Illinois (1909)
label: Caption

text: © James Reber. Photo courtesy The Frank Lloyd Wright Archives
label: Caption

text: the 17th-century Taiyu-in Mausoleum in Nikko, where Wright stayed briefly in April
label: Paragraph

text: 1905. Wright’s cubic geometry and ornamental columns recall the exterior massing and
label: Paragraph

text: carved surfaces of Mayan temples known to Wright from at least 1893. A sympathetic
label: Caption

text: response to such non-Western architectures would have been consistent with Unitarian
label: Paragraph

text: convictions as to the oneness of all human religions and the antiquity of the idea of the
label: Paragraph

text: unity of divinity. As Wright indicated, Unity Temple’s square shape and galleried seating
label: Paragraph

text: reinterpreted a long tradition of Protestant meetinghouses going back to the 16th century,
label: Paragraph

text: including non-conformist chapels in Wales and England as well as Puritan colonial
label: Paragraph

text: meetinghouses in New England. In modernist historiography, Unity Temple’s cubic
label: Paragraph

text: exterior and geometric interior were seen as one forerunner of Dutch De Stijl
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Retrospectively, Wright himself emphasized Unity Temple as the work in
label: Paragraph

text: which he first fully engaged with architectural form as an expression of interior space. In
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s later oeuvre, the idea of a top-lit sanctuary-like room recurred in such works as
label: Paragraph

text: his Annie M.Pfeiffer Chapel (1938-41) for Florida Southern College in Lakeland and his
label: Paragraph

text: Guggenheim Museum (1943-59) in New York City.
label: Paragraph

text: JOSEPH M.SIRY
label: Title

text: See also Church; Wright, Frank Lloyd (United States)
label: Caption

text: Further Reading
label: Title

text: The comprehensive monograph on Unity Temple is by Siry. Wright devoted a section of
label: Paragraph

text: his autobiography to the building. Other recent sources include discussions of Unity

text: UNIVERSITY LIBRARY, UNIVERSIDAD
label: Title

text: NACIONAL AUTONOMA DE MEXICO
label: Title

text: Designed by Juan O’Gorman, Gustavo Saavedra, and Juan Martinez Velasco; completed
label: Caption

text: 1952 Mexico City, Mexico
label: Caption

text: The University Library at the Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico (UNAM) in
label: Paragraph

text: Mexico City was built as both a national book and newspaper repository and the main
label: Paragraph

text: library of the enormous new University City complex. Since its completion in 1952, the
label: Paragraph

text: 13-story library, its top ten floors sheathed in figurative stone mosaics, has become the
label: Paragraph

text: signature building of the University City and one of the iconic images of 21st-century
label: Paragraph

text: Mexico.
label: Paragraph

text: By the 1940s, the 400-year-old University of Mexico’s outmoded facilities lay
label: Paragraph

text: scattered across the capital city. In 1947, the Mexican government acquired 1730 acres of
label: Paragraph

text: land in the wild, 2000-year-old Pedregal lava field at the city’s southern edge—
label: Paragraph

text: immediately adjacent to the site of Luis Barragan’s Jardines del Pedregal, where work
label: Paragraph

text: was just then beginning. Some 200 million pesos were allocated for the construction of a
label: Paragraph

text: new, integrated campus for 25,000 to 30,000 students, and architects Enrique Del Moral,
label: Paragraph

text: Mario Pani, and Mauricio Campos were commissioned to develop the overall plan and
label: Paragraph

text: conduct competitions for the individual buildings. In 1950, Carlos Lazo was appointed
label: Paragraph

text: director general of the project and made responsible for coordinating the efforts of the
label: Paragraph

text: more than 100 architects, engineers, and artists, and 7000 workmen. Ground was broken
label: Paragraph

text: for the first buildings that year, and by 20 November 1952, when Mexican President
label: Paragraph

text: Miguel Aleman officially dedicated the project, the campus was 80 percent complete.
label: Paragraph

text: Juan O’Gorman, Gustavo Saavedra, and Juan Martinez Velasco were chosen to design
label: Paragraph

text: the University Library. O’Gorman led this team and was also the sole designer of the
label: Paragraph

text: building’s mosaics and relief sculpture. During the 1930s, O’Gorman, an accomplished
label: Paragraph

text: painter, had also been among the most radical exponents in Mexico of European-style
label: Paragraph

text: functionalist modern architecture—a devoted disciple of Le Corbusier. The stripped-
label: Paragraph

text: down, reinforced-concrete houses, schools, and factories that he built during those years
label: Paragraph

text: were underlain by his fervent belief in the universal applicability of Le Corbusier’s ideas
label: Paragraph

text: and by his equally passionate desire to uplift a Mexican nation wracked by years of
label: Paragraph

text: internecine warfare. By 1936, however, he withdrew from architectural practice, citing
label: Paragraph

text: what he saw as the sterility and inappropriateness to Mexican culture of the very architec-
label: Paragraph

text: University Library, UNAM, Mexico City
label: Caption

text: © Royalty-Free/CORBIS
label: Title

text: ture that he had advocated and built. When he began designing again in the mid-1940s, it
label: Paragraph

text: was to assist painter Diego Rivera with the Anahuacalli Museum (1944-66) in Mexico
label: Paragraph

text: City; built to house Rivera’s collection of pre-Columbian art, this was a dense, stone-
label: Paragraph

text: walled, Mayan Revival-style truncated pyramid with corbeled arches and figurative
label: Paragraph

text: reliefs. By this time, O’Gorman had discovered the organic architecture of Frank Lloyd
label: Paragraph

text: Wright—he had stayed at Fallingwater as a guest of the owners and now called Wright
label: Paragraph

text: the greatest architect of the century—and took this as the inspiration for a Mexican
label: Paragraph

text: architecture adapted to the peculiarities of site and local culture.
label: Paragraph

text: The initial plan for the library submitted by O’Gorman’s team called for another
label: Paragraph

text: truncated pyramid, not unlike Anahuacalli, but larger and cleaner, with translucent onyx
label: Paragraph

text: windows. This was ultimately rejected for diverging too far from the rectilinear structures
label: Paragraph

text: that dominated in the central part of the campus. As finally built, the library was
label: Paragraph

text: composed of two rectangular slabs: a horizontally disposed base surmounted by a tower.
label: Paragraph

text: Like many of the other buildings on the UNAM campus, the library consists mainly of a
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete frame whose interspaces are filled with hollow ceramic tile. The first
label: Paragraph

text: two stories house reading rooms, offices, and reference and circulation areas. External
label: Caption

text: walls at this level consist of metal-framed glass windows and translucent onyx
label: Paragraph

text: clerestories. Beyond these are outdoor reading rooms surrounded by heavy stone walls
label: Caption

text: decorated with low-relief sculpture showing Aztec-inspired imagery. Finally, standing
label: Paragraph

text: directly atop a one-story glass base is the virtually windowless tower containing the book
label: Paragraph

text: stacks. The ten air-conditioned, fluorescent-lighted stack floors were designed to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate 120,000 volumes each, or 1.2 million volumes total.
label: Paragraph

text: The building’s most striking feature is the 4400 square yards of mosaics completely
label: Paragraph

text: covering the surface of its tower. Inspired, according to O’Gorman, by the architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: Antoni Gaudi and the French naifs Fernand Cheval and Raymond Isidore and by Aztec
label: Title

text: codices and the social realist murals of Rivera and José Clemente Orozco, the library’s
label: Paragraph

text: mosaics depict a history of ideas in Mexico. In this, they are in keeping with the deep and
label: Paragraph

text: pervasive interest in post-World War Il Mexico in defining and giving form to the
label: Paragraph

text: national character. The north wall is devoted to the Aztecs, the south wall to the Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: colonial era, and the two narrower end walls to the effects of these two periods on the
label: Paragraph

text: modern nation. Principal themes represented include religion, humanism, civic life,
label: Paragraph

text: ceremony, warfare, conquest, education, art, and science. Thirteen different colors of
label: Paragraph

text: natural stone—brought from all parts of the country and carefully tested for color and
label: Paragraph

text: durability—were used along with cerulean blue glass. The mosaics were prefabricated in
label: Paragraph

text: one-meter-square panels, and full-scale drawings were used to guide the placement of the
label: Paragraph

text: stones and concrete to bind them. Once dried, the panels were lifted and cemented into
label: Paragraph

text: place on a metal framework fixed to the library walls. O’Gorman touted the mosaics for
label: Paragraph

text: bringing mural-type imagery outdoors, for blending the building into the landscape (via
label: Paragraph

text: the colors of the stone), and for their low cost (just over $50,000 for materials and labor).
label: Paragraph

text: The library’s mosaics, along with the many other mosaics, murals, and sculptures
label: Paragraph

text: appearing on the campus, were part of a concerted effort to link architecture with the
label: Paragraph

text: other arts. O’Gorman extolled this “integracién plastica,” as he called it, as essential to a
label: Paragraph

text: modern Mexican architecture. Many of Mexico’s best-known artists, among them the
label: Paragraph

text: muralists Rivera and David Alfaro Siqueiros, supported this integration and worked for it
label: Paragraph

text: at the University City. Many, however, including several of the artists and architects
label: Paragraph

text: involved there, were disappointed with the results, seeing the university’s artwork as
label: Paragraph

text: either not integrated enough or as unnecessary, undesirable, and injurious to the
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. In a scathing critique in the November 1953 issue of Progressive
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture, Sibyl Moholy-Nagy faulted the library for its “continuous mural that leaves
label: Paragraph

text: not a square inch of the building material free to breathe.” Several others at the time,
label: Paragraph

text: however, both inside and outside Mexico, praised the library as a key element in one of
label: Paragraph

text: the most ambitious, significant, and successful projects in contemporary world
label: Paragraph

text: architecture—an architectural coming of age for Mexico in which functional modern
label: Paragraph

text: forms took on a distinctive localized character. The building continues to serve as
label: Paragraph

text: UNAM’s central library.
label: Paragraph
