text: UNIVERSUM CINEMA, BERLIN
label: Caption

text: Designed by Eric Mendelsohn; completed 1928 (Schaubitihne am Lehninerplatz,
label: Caption

text: reconstruction by Jiirgen Sawade, 1978-81)
label: Caption

text: The Universum Cinema and the WOGA (Wohnhaus-Grundstiicks-Verwertungs-
label: Title

text: Aktien-Gesellschaft) housing complex—Mendelsohn’s sole realized urban project—was
label: Paragraph

text: conceived and built in various phases between 1925 and 1931 on the last undeveloped
label: Paragraph

text: block along the western section of the Kurfiirstendamm in Berlin. The genesis of the
label: Paragraph

text: project was made difficult by the evolving program and the rivalry with Jiirgen
label: Paragraph

text: Bachmann, another architect hired for his experience in speculative development by the
label: Paragraph

text: site owner Mosse.
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn’s first scheme (1925) for a large residential program was quite
label: Paragraph

text: revolutionary in the context of the bourgeois district, as it integrated the typological
label: Paragraph

text: advances of the urban (Paul Mebes in Berlin-Stieglitz) and suburban housing reform
label: Paragraph

text: movement (Taut and Wagner at Berlin Britz). The thin bars of cross-ventilated
label: Paragraph

text: apartments with common green areas at the back contrasted with the lot-based character
label: Paragraph

text: of the neighborhood. As construction proceeded at Paulsborner and Albrecht-Achilles
label: Paragraph

text: streets according to Bachmann’s plans (they showed a similar housing layout and interior
label: Paragraph

text: residential street), Mendelsohn redesigned his scheme.
label: Paragraph

text: The motion picture theater and its characteristic semicircular volume on the Kudamm
label: Paragraph

text: appeared in the second version of 1926. Lined with shops, the “streamlined” interior
label: Paragraph

text: street or “Basarstrasse” opened on the boulevard; the other end terminated into an ellipse-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped Revuetheater. In the definitive layout of 1928, Mendelsohn shortened the inner
label: Paragraph

text: street and framed it with a seven-story 300-room hotel. To the left the circular Kabarett
label: Caption

text: der Komiker was placed behind a restaurant, whereas on the other side, the interior axis
label: Paragraph

text: of the 1800-seat Universum Cinema was now asymmetrically shifted to accommodate a
label: Paragraph

text: ring of shops. A long five-story housing bar closed the site along Cicerostrasse (rebuilt in
label: Paragraph

text: 1980-81). Its multiple entrances servicing two large apartments per floor were marked by
label: Paragraph

text: slightly projecting curved balconies. Bands of brick-clad walls connected them, thus
label: Paragraph

text: creating strong horizontal accents terminated by returning semicircular balconies. The
label: Paragraph

text: half-cylindrical and glazed staircases rhythmically accentuated the garden facade.
label: Caption

text: Mendelsohn rejected the urban-utopian component of the Expressionist movement as
label: Paragraph

text: well as advocates of an International Style that espoused purity of aesthetic means over
label: Paragraph

text: context. He studied in Munich with Theodor Fischer (1862—1938) along with Bruno Taut,
label: Paragraph

text: Hannes Meyer, J.J.P.Oud, and Ernst May. Under Fischer’s tutelage these architects
label: Paragraph

text: assimilated the lessons of Camillo Sitte, and further kept the street, albeit reinvented, as
label: Paragraph

text: the primary element of their urban design strategy.
label: Paragraph

text: At the WOGA complex, Mendelsohn attempted to interpret the collective memory of
label: Paragraph

text: the city. His final and genuinely tridimensional arrangement of masses—elevator shafts,
label: Paragraph

text: stage tower above the screen, vertical hotel—achieved quasi-medieval spatial effects. The
label: Caption

text: bridgelike structure of the hotel brings to mind the Torhaus or gatehouse, a centuries-old
label: Paragraph

text: sight of the German city and a popular building type that Walter Gropius used at the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus-Dessau, and Bruno Taut and Otto Salvisberg in their Berlin housing projects.
label: Paragraph

text: For Mendelsohn it became a recurrent device as seen in his first project for the Deutsche
label: Paragraph

text: Metallarbeiter-Verbandshaus (1929-30) or in his design for the Alexanderplatz (1931—
label: Paragraph

text: 32). The shape of the Universum also recalled Friedrich Gilly’s sketches for a modern
label: Paragraph

text: theater (1798) inspired by the Théatre Feydeau in Paris. Mendelsohn’s brickclad volume
label: Paragraph

text: did not reveal the theater itself as in Gotfried Semper’s Opera House in Dresden (1878),
label: Paragraph

text: but the dramatic foyer was accessed through a recessed entrance between the shops.
label: Paragraph

text: The WOGA complex became the point of reference for Martin Wagner’s redesign of
label: Paragraph

text: central Berlin, where the “flow lines” of motorized traffic and the “walking lines” of the
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrians would smoothly guide the steps of the modern flaneur. This commercial
label: Paragraph

text: Grossstadtarchitektur had to be inexpensive yet striking to capture the buying power of
label: Paragraph

text: the “distracted” Berliner. From 1924 (Metropolis) the facades of the Ufa-Palast and other
label: Paragraph

text: theaters in Berlin became brilliantly lighted billboards. Mendelsohn made them into
label: Paragraph

text: architecture (Reklamearchitektur, according to Adolf Behne). It was so “cinematic” that
label: Paragraph

text: its glass walls and rounded corners became the background of Sunrise, the first
label: Paragraph

text: Hollywood film by Murnau in 1927.
label: Paragraph

text: Color, form, and light were the ingredients of Mendelsohn’s architectural version of
label: Paragraph

text: Nietzsche’s The Birth of Tragedy, where “the music of masses in motion was contrasted
label: Paragraph

text: with the spirit of gravity” (Neumeyer, 1999). The luminous blue of the ceiling dominated
label: Paragraph

text: the double-height entrance hall, with the futurist glass-enclosed ticket office in the center.
label: Caption

text: The mahogany-red cinema followed Mendelsohn’s sketches quite closely: the bright
label: Paragraph

text: balcony and the ceiling lights made the eyes converge toward the flat screen. For all its
label: Paragraph

text: modernity, the cinema was still conceived of as a theater, with an orchestra pit and a
label: Paragraph

text: small fly tower above the screen and its curtain.
label: Caption

text: The Universum influenced an entire generation of theaters around the world: from
label: Paragraph

text: Argentina to England (the Odeon cinemas by Harry Weedon) and Tel Aviv, where I.
label: Paragraph

text: Megidovitch’s curved volume of the Kino Esther Cinema at Dizengoff Circle (1938-39)
label: Caption

text: matched Mendelsohn’s urban statement. In the United States, two Manhattan interiors
label: Paragraph

text: prolonged Mendelsohn’s experiment in conciseness. Frederick Kiesler’s (1890-1965)
label: Paragraph

text: Film Guild Cinema (1928-30) had a megaphone-shaped auditorium and a curtainless
label: Paragraph

text: screen in the center of a painted circle; in the New School for Social Research (1929-31)
label: Caption

text: by Joseph Urban (1872-1933), the egg-shaped auditorium displayed a bold set of red and
label: Paragraph

text: gray colors.
label: Paragraph

text: The Ufa Cinema was sold in 1937. Heavily damaged by bombs during the war, it was
label: Paragraph

text: unsympathetically remodeled several times. Put up for sale in 1975, it was saved by
label: Paragraph

text: architect Jiirgen Sawade, who convinced director Peter Stein and scenographer Karl-
label: Paragraph

text: Emst Herrmann to relocate their avant-garde theater, the Schaubiihne am Halleschen
label: Paragraph

text: Ufer. However, the structural problems encountered during construction and Stein’s
label: Paragraph

text: rendition of Gropius’s Totaltheater eventually imposed a complete reconstruction. In the
label: Paragraph

text: absence of a fly tower, the entire floor (including the seating) was made up of movable
label: Paragraph

text: platforms on hydraulic supports. Inaugurated in 1981, the adaptable theater interior bore
label: Paragraph

text: little relation to the historic facades and volumes. The debate about total reconstruction as
label: Paragraph

text: legitimate means of urban renewal or historic preservation has been open since, as the
label: Paragraph

text: controversy about the re-erection of the Berlin Stadtschloss and Schinkel’s Bauakademie
label: Paragraph

text: continues to demonstrate.
label: Paragraph

text: URBAN PLANNING
label: Title

text: Cities are mankind’s most universal contribution on earth. Throughout human history, it
label: Paragraph

text: is within cities that mankind has explored all counterpoints of himself in relation to his
label: Paragraph

text: physical world: man within architecture, man within nature, man as individual and
label: Title

text: communal being, man and machine, mankind within temple and shelter. From the ancient
label: Paragraph

text: urbs of Rome to the modernity of downtown America, the historical aim of urban
label: Paragraph

text: planning has been to impose physical order on things that by nature are chaotic. For two
label: Paragraph

text: millennia, cities have been formed by the seemingly omniscient hand of urban planning
label: Paragraph

text: or, less fortunately, by the lack thereof. Herein lies the virtually impossible meaning of
label: Paragraph

text: urban planning.
label: Paragraph

text: Defining Urban Planning
label: Title

text: Urban planning is both art and social science. It encompasses the contemporary city, the
label: Paragraph

text: historical site, architecture, the environment, economics, and social interaction. Urban
label: Caption

text: planning constructs the city of today while creating the model of the city that will exist in
label: Paragraph

text: the next decades. Unlike architecture, urban planning is a public profession dedicated not
label: Paragraph

text: to individual clients but to the common good, which is a weighty responsibility. Even for
label: Paragraph

text: an urban planner, it is difficult to define the obligations and limits of the profession. To
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to define urban planning, this article will limit itself to physical planning, to
label: Paragraph

text: major Western cities, and to the most influential threads in the history and theory of
label: Paragraph

text: planning.
label: Paragraph

text: Parameters of the subject of physical planning include facilities for housing,
label: Paragraph

text: transportation, education, health care, and basic urban infrastructure, such as streets,
label: Paragraph

text: sidewalks, and water supply, down to the most mundane enterprises of sewers and waste
label: Paragraph

text: disposal. Urban planning, although often unobserved, is operating on the micro- and the
label: Paragraph

text: macroscale. The city, as we experience its immediate urban form, is composed of street
label: Paragraph

text: pattern, skyline, vista, and details such as streetscape, signage, and building setbacks.
label: Paragraph

text: Urban planning must also deal with the larger issues of city form and the distribution of
label: Paragraph

text: urban land resources through zoning, land use controls, density, and neighborhood
label: Paragraph

text: considerations. In the urban environment, open space, greenery, and parks are integral to
label: Paragraph

text: urban planning, and public art enlivens the city; the arts and nature are fundamental to
label: Paragraph

text: urban design. The context of buildings is an important design element of cities; hence, the
label: Paragraph

text: relationships of new architecture to existing urban fabric and to historical districts must
label: Paragraph

text: be respected by the planner. The city must further be considered not in isolation but in its
label: Paragraph

text: larger regional context. These parameters only begin to define the minimum functional
label: Paragraph

text: city.
label: Paragraph

text: In the greatest of cities, function is only a starting point for urbanism, and urban design
label: Paragraph

text: reaches higher toward monumentality, achieved through the symbolic meaning of visual
label: Paragraph

text: configurations and architectural landmarks. We can observe historical examples of
label: Paragraph

text: planned cities that have exceeded the expectations of function to become symbolic urban
label: Paragraph

text: spaces in New York, London, Paris, and Rome.
label: Paragraph

text: A Brief History of Urban Planning
label: Title

text: Modern Western urban planning has its origins in the Roman concept of the castrum city,
label: Paragraph

text: the infinitely logical encampment created in a coherent grid in the Roman provinces, still
label: Paragraph

text: visible in the antique sections of European towns, such as the City section of London, in
label: Paragraph

text: the Ile de la Cité of Paris, or in Tuscan squares. Thus, the contemporary idea of a city as
label: Paragraph

text: an entity that can be envisioned, designed, constructed, and administered by a thinking
label: Paragraph

text: authority, a kind of bureaucratic but benevolent despot (which might be thought of as the
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical basis of modern city planning), is really quite an ancient concept. After the
label: Paragraph

text: decline of the Roman Empire, the concept of the ordered city declined as well, as order
label: Paragraph

text: was more often relegated to the sacred space of the cathedral than to the secular space of
label: Paragraph

text: the city. In the French town of Chartres, for example, one finds the chaos of the medieval
label: Paragraph

text: city’s streets pushing up against the organized mass of the divinely ordered architectural
label: Paragraph

text: universe of the cathedral.
label: Paragraph

text: The Renaissance, with its rebirth of ancient forms, derived and ultimately
label: Paragraph

text: monumentalized the Roman ideal of city planning. Michelangelo’s plan for the Roman
label: Paragraph

text: Campidoglio is one of the most complete and perfectly executed plans for a city sector,
label: Paragraph

text: constructed to front a medieval agglomeration of buildings that themselves had grown up
label: Paragraph

text: on the edge of the once highly ordered Roman Forum. Although the Campidoglio was
label: Paragraph

text: intended not as an inhabitable city but as a symbolic urban space, it followed the Roman
label: Paragraph

text: ideal of the imposition of physical order on chaos. Based on Michelangelo’s ingenious
label: Paragraph

text: geometric patterning and centered on the Roman statue of Marcus Aurelius, this
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance masterpiece recalls the order and majesty of ancient Roman planning.
label: Paragraph

text: Great baroque urban schemes dwarfed even these Renaissance plans. Bernini’s
label: Paragraph

text: extension of St. Peter’s exterior space into Rome via his colonnade set the stage for
label: Paragraph

text: sweeping baroque urban-planning schemes, with their spatial command and shaping of
label: Paragraph

text: urban space. Cities extended themselves as medieval city walls were torn down and
label: Paragraph

text: replaced with dynamic baroque schemes throughout Europe. Whole cities became works
label: Paragraph

text: of art as urban planning reached its dramatic heights in the 16th and 17th centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: The greatest sweep of urban planning, however, was yet to come in the deconstruction
label: Paragraph

text: and reassemblage of Paris in the 19th century. Paris saw the massive imposition of
label: Paragraph

text: planning on a chaotic, medieval city with the fervor of Baron von Haussmann’s straight,
label: Paragraph

text: grand éfoile, or star, of boulevards, with bridges and Napoleonic monuments highlighted.
label: Paragraph

text: The grand radiating boulevards of Paris created vistas and promenade spaces through the
label: Paragraph

text: city that we now identify with the French Enlightenment, with clarity and reason in urban
label: Paragraph

text: design. The influence of French planning can be felt in the United States in L’Enfant’s
label: Paragraph

text: radiating plan for Washington, D.C.
label: Caption

text: Urban planning in London is quite a contrast to Paris, for London never experienced an
label: Paragraph

text: overlaid unifying design but remained instead a kind of crazy quilt city of interconnected
label: Paragraph

text: sectors, some of which have within them their own individual internal order. In the
label: Paragraph

text: United States, Boston is the closest analogy to London in form: antique, irrational street
label: Paragraph

text: patterns contrasting with 19th-century planned sectors. Geometric classicism in urban
label: Paragraph

text: design had enlightened London from the 18th through the early 19th century in the
label: Paragraph

text: planning of the west end. London’s Bloomsbury, in particular, was developed with order
label: Paragraph

text: imposed via gridded streets and squares and by the graceful repetition of building forms
label: Paragraph

text: in the standardized 18th-century row houses.
label: Paragraph

text: In opposition to the urbane geometric order of Bloomsbury, however, British urban
label: Paragraph

text: planning likewise produced plans that were decidedly antiurban and picturesque. The late
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century in England felt a schism between city and town, urban life and suburban,
label: Paragraph

text: that developed as a reaction to the tragic consequences of industrialization. Picturesque
label: Paragraph

text: inventions in urban planning, the schemes for garden cities and suburbs for the
label: Paragraph

text: amelioration of slums, such as Ebenezer Howard’s Garden Cities of To-morrow (1902),
label: Paragraph

text: were alternatives to cities. In the United States, the City Beautiful movement, epitomized
label: Paragraph

text: by Daniel Burnham’s Chicago and San Francisco plans, with their romanticized
label: Paragraph

text: picturesque curvilinear lines, can be traced to this aesthetic.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, the ideal of the planned city has been seen to move over two millennia from
label: Paragraph

text: encampment to éoile, from geometric griddedness to picturesqueness, and now again
label: Paragraph

text: will return to the enduring grid, for the most profoundly influential imposition in history
label: Paragraph

text: of plan on a city is certainly the grid configuration on New York City. The grid of
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan, the consummate city, in conjunction with Central Park, created the city plan
label: Paragraph

text: by which all other cities are judged. The configuration dictates the lives of millions who
label: Paragraph

text: define their physical space by the plan: “uptown, downtown, east side, west side.” The
label: Paragraph

text: significance of urban planning is demonstrated every day on the streets of New York
label: Paragraph

text: City, for the concrete canyons of Manhattan, so often romantically sung, are in fact more
label: Paragraph

text: prosaically the product of New York City’s 1811 grid city plan, its 1860s Olmsted park
label: Paragraph

text: plan, and its 1916 skyscraper zoning laws.
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Urban Planning
label: Title

text: In the 20th century, there was a tremendous shift in the historical concept of urban
label: Paragraph

text: planning from art to technics. The practice of urban planning from the mid- to late 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century had little to do with the artistic grandeur of earlier times and more to do with the
label: Paragraph

text: technician’s approach to the city as a functional entity. Massive urban population growth,
label: Paragraph

text: the movement from rural to urban areas, two major world wars, the machine economy,
label: Paragraph

text: the automobile, and the triumph of Marx over monarchy meant that the burden of urban
label: Paragraph

text: planning became more about the amelioration of living conditions for the masses and less
label: Paragraph

text: about a carriage ride through the park for those who could afford a carriage.
label: Paragraph

text: As urban planning took on the life of the masses, it acquired a new urgency. In the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century, theories of urban planning swung in wide and contradictory arcs—with very
label: Paragraph

text: concrete consequences for cities. From the broad-stroke city plans of Le Corbusier to the
label: Paragraph

text: curbside observations of Jane Jacobs, the city in the 20th century had seemingly every
label: Paragraph

text: perceptive perspective and every evil visited on it. There actually exist American cities
label: Paragraph

text: where one can trace the theoretical swings in urban planning simply by riding a bus
label: Paragraph

text: across town, seeing the once bright future and the dashed hopes of urban occupants
label: Paragraph

text: strewn in planned fervor on the landscape. In the East New York section of Brooklyn,
label: Paragraph

text: where the federally funded Model Cities program collapsed before completion (but not
label: Paragraph

text: before tearing down all existing buildings), the scarred urban land was left vacant for
label: Paragraph

text: decades. Urban planning acquired a checkered history in the 20th century. Let us next
label: Paragraph

text: investigate how this came to be in our times. If good intentions really did make paving,
label: Paragraph

text: we could put an end to asphalt.
label: Paragraph

text: Early 20th-Century Planning
label: Title

text: The early 20th century tended toward a utopianism in urban planning that we find bizarre
label: Paragraph

text: today, exemplified in the metaphorical crystalline city depicted in Fritz Lang’s film
label: Paragraph

text: Metropolis. These early utopian planners survived one world war, lived in urban
label: Paragraph

text: devastation, and were trying to create new cities from the depths of disillusionment with
label: Paragraph

text: their European past. Certain of the early utopian modernists, such as Walter Gropius and
label: Paragraph

text: the German Bauhaus designers, had humane aspirations underlying their metaphors, and
label: Paragraph

text: they tried to bring analysis to tragedy. Empathizing with the proletariat, Gropius sought
label: Paragraph

text: through planning to bring them the most basic necessities—in his words,
label: Paragraph

text: “Existenzminimum,” or minimum standards for living. He brought to his compassionate
label: Paragraph

text: stance for the disenfranchised a new scientific standard, attempting for the first time to
label: Paragraph

text: quantify quality-of-life issues: minimal space requirements, standards of health and
label: Paragraph

text: hygiene, and light and fresh air in the city.
label: Paragraph

text: With their methodological approach, the planners of Germany reconstructed their war-
label: Paragraph

text: ravaged cities and built some of the largest housing projects for the urban masses ever
label: Paragraph

text: attempted, the Sied/ungen, or housing projects, of the 1920s to 1930s. Although perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: oppressive and mechanistic by today’s values, these repetitive plans were humanely
label: Paragraph

text: intentioned. The modern European ideals of urban planning became international through
label: Paragraph

text: the meetings of CIAM (Congrés Internationaux d’ Architecture Moderne), held in Europe
label: Paragraph

text: from the 1920s to the 1950s, and were disseminated by J.L. Sert in his prophetically titled
label: Paragraph

text: Can Our Cities Survive? (1942).
label: Paragraph

text: The most powerful, although perhaps not the most prudent, voice of CLAM and of
label: Paragraph

text: 20th-century urbanism in general was, of course, Le Corbusier. Following in the French
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of Haussmann, through his sweeping unbuilt Parisian plans on paper—the
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporary City (1922) and the Ville Radieuse (1935)—Le Corbusier reinvented
label: Paragraph

text: French creative urban design. Although his urban designs were brilliant aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: exercises, they were frightening living environments. Le Corbusier’s plans are grandiose
label: Paragraph

text: and potentially destructive of cities that, unlike the German, were not even destroyed by
label: Paragraph

text: war. Le Corbusier introduced into modern urban planning the fallacy of viewing the city
label: Paragraph

text: solely as a spatial pattern seen metaphorically and visually from above, forgetting that
label: Paragraph

text: below, humans seek to live out their sometimes irrational, unpatterned urban lives.
label: Paragraph

text: If one were to compare the long-term influence on urban planning of Gropius’s
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus functionalism and Le Corbusier’s French aestheticism, one might conclude that
label: Paragraph

text: the derivations of both were harmful to the urban fabric of the 20th century. What
label: Paragraph

text: differentiates them, however, is intention: the city for the common man or the city for
label: Paragraph

text: self? While in the history of urban planning we can trace Gropius’s methodical study of
label: Paragraph

text: the angle of the sun as it hit the windows of his Sied/ungen, we are likewise told the
label: Paragraph

text: anecdote of Le Corbusier’s designing the city of Brasilia while sitting in a restaurant,
label: Paragraph

text: cavalierly scrawling crossed lines on a cocktail napkin. Although there is ample room for
label: Paragraph

text: ego and self-aggrandizement in architecture, it should have no place in the discipline of
label: Paragraph

text: urban planning.
label: Paragraph

text: Against the European background of the planning debates of CLAM came the work of
label: Paragraph

text: the most famous American architect of the 20th century, Frank Lloyd Wright, who
label: Paragraph

text: designed but never built his theoretical Broadacre City in 1938. The “Broadacre” of the
label: Paragraph

text: title was accurate, for the design allowed each resident one acre of land for subsistence
label: Paragraph

text: farming, but the word “City” was certainly a misnomer, for Wright’s utopia was the very
label: Paragraph

text: antithesis of the concept of city. It was antiurban in every sense, isolationist in its vision,
label: Paragraph

text: and totally automobile dependent, so much so that we may credit Broadacre City with
label: Paragraph

text: spreading the concept of the suburb and inadvertently its concomitant sprawl all over the
label: Paragraph

text: United States. Wright’s vision, born of his agrarian American roots and of the
label: Paragraph

text: Depression, was not to ameliorate urban problems but to offer an American alternative
label: Paragraph

text: that would render the city a nasty anachronism of the preautomobile age.
label: Paragraph

text: Critiques of Urban Planning
label: Title

text: Without question, by the early 20th century, cities in Europe and the United States
label: Paragraph

text: needed fixing. By necessity, the rise of urban planning as a profession distinct from
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, economics, and urban sociology was taking root with such major
label: Paragraph

text: constituents as the New York Regional Planning Association. After utopianism took its
label: Paragraph

text: last gasp through the planners of the 1939 New York World’s Fair, cynicism about cities
label: Paragraph

text: replaced beliefs in beauty and human aspiration in urban planning. As planning moved
label: Paragraph

text: away from beauty and toward technology as its goal, it lost its soul. A nadir of urban
label: Paragraph

text: planning was reached in the mid-20th century with the advent of statistical and
label: Paragraph

text: technological planning severed from all humanitarian concerns, as Cold War thinking
label: Paragraph

text: marked city plans destructively with the introduction of military-industrial planning
label: Paragraph

text: applied to city planning. Cities lost their individual realities as new planners were
label: Paragraph

text: schooled only in applications of generic models without human content and taught to
label: Paragraph

text: substitute mindless formulas invented for the design of complex nuclear war machines.
label: Paragraph

text: Cities, however, are not submarines, and humans are not mathematical models. With the
label: Paragraph

text: desperation of those who felt inferior to the technologists, urban planners repressed their
label: Paragraph

text: innate social motivations. Disastrous results, such as the wholesale destruction of
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods as “slum clearance,” were often compounded by highspeed freeways
label: Paragraph

text: cutting through neighborhoods. Worst-case examples left acres of urban land looking
label: Paragraph

text: bombed.
label: Paragraph

text: By the mid-20th century, thoughtful critical voices were emerging as a counterpoint to
label: Paragraph

text: the grandiose schemes of the utopian 1920s and 1930s and the cynical 1950s and 1960s.
label: Paragraph

text: Primary among those voices were those of two American planners and their texts of
label: Paragraph

text: simple messages, Kevin Lynch’s The Image of the City (1960) and Jane Jacobs’s The
label: Paragraph

text: Death and Life of Great American Cities (1961), which together helped turn the tide of
label: Paragraph

text: city planning toward a closer examination of the existing urban fabric and to the patterns
label: Paragraph

text: of behavior of its inhabitants. Both had a kind of folksy style that appealed to urban
label: Paragraph

text: planners, architects, sociologists, and even the general public, so often the enemy of
label: Paragraph

text: urban planning, and thus both books have continued to be influential for decades.
label: Paragraph

text: Lynch was observational and insightful. On the one hand, he explained the nature of
label: Paragraph

text: cities with a rational model, defining the city as a hierarchy of spaces; on the other hand,
label: Paragraph

text: he simultaneously presented the irrational side of urban patterns based on humans’
label: Paragraph

text: uncanny ability to navigate urban space in relation to memory and landmarks. What
label: Paragraph

text: makes Lynch’s approach so novel is that it was based not on a preconceived or imposed
label: Paragraph

text: model but on actually asking city dwellers how they moved within their physical
label: Paragraph

text: environment. Jacobs, who wrote literally from the perspective of her own window on her
label: Paragraph

text: street in lower Manhattan, showed that the social interactions of an active pedestrian
label: Paragraph

text: street life of a city are the essence of the urban place. She defended the life not only of
label: Paragraph

text: city people but of city buildings as well, pointing out cogently the significance of
label: Paragraph

text: retaining old buildings within cities. The Death and Life of Great American Cities
label: Paragraph

text: remains a memorable David-versus-Goliath of wrong-headed urban planning.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps the quietly successful revolution of Lynch, Jacobs, and others of this bent now
label: Paragraph

text: needs reexamination, for it is spurring on movements in urban planning that are actually
label: Paragraph

text: antiurban. Jacobs wanted to preserve old buildings not as historical artifacts or self-
label: Paragraph

text: consciously arty edifices but as low-rent generators of urban innovation. Instead, we are
label: Paragraph

text: today boutiqueing our cities out of existence, falsifying the urban fabric. Further,
label: Paragraph

text: nostalgic but inauthentic new towns spring forth on former desert- and farmland all over
label: Paragraph

text: the United States, and these false places are controlled by restrictive covenants that are
label: Paragraph

text: the antithesis of urban life. Beware planners bearing faux cities that, although certainly
label: Paragraph

text: pretty, by definition cannot ever be real urban environments.
label: Paragraph

text: The Future of Urban Planning
label: Title

text: The point of urban planning is to encompass the complexity of human experience and to
label: Paragraph

text: formulate for that experience a physical environment that will be ever self-renewing.
label: Paragraph

text: Authentic urban places existed in the 20th century, and they give us hope for the life of
label: Paragraph

text: the city in the 21 st century. In London, a supreme example of urbane living is still found
label: Paragraph

text: in Bloomsbury’s squares of parks and row houses and in the 20th-century revival of 17th-
label: Paragraph

text: century Covent Garden. In Paris, a zenith of 20th-century urban design was achieved by
label: Paragraph

text: the physical reorganization of the museums, from the Louvre to the Gare d’Orsay along
label: Paragraph

text: the Seine, relating beauty, urban form, antiquity, and modernism, in the image of
label: Paragraph

text: I.M.Pei’s metaphorical pyramid. In Chicago, the last decade of the 20th century
label: Paragraph

text: witnessed the expansion of urban beauty, fulfilling again the visions presented to the
label: Paragraph

text: world in the first decade of the century by Daniel Burnham and Edward H.Ben-nett in
label: Paragraph

text: their Plan of Chicago. Parkways, boulevards, urban parks, and well-ordered streets
label: Paragraph

text: display Chicago’s vision as a city in a garden. In New York, urban planning has created
label: Paragraph

text: the scaffolding on which city life thrives. To find urban planning for oneself,
label: Paragraph

text: experientially, explore the planned places of Manhattan. Walk any day, any season, from
label: Paragraph

text: Rockefeller Center up Fifth Avenue toward Central Park. Observe the living urban
label: Caption

text: tableau of sleek skyscrapers, hot dog stands, hasty inhabitants, and yellow taxis in
label: Paragraph

text: counterpoint to the park’s oasis of rocks, trees, and sky. Certainly this is as close to the
label: Paragraph

text: complete human experience of the active and the contemplative, of order amid chaos, of
label: Paragraph

text: the power of urban planning, as any city experience is ever likely to come.
label: Paragraph

text: URBAN RENEWAL
label: Title

text: Urban renewal defies simple and brief definition and explanation. Historically,
label: Paragraph

text: constitutive elements of urban renewal have included planning, zoning, the City Beautiful
label: Paragraph

text: movement, the modernist ideals of the Congrés Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne
label: Paragraph

text: (CLAM) and others, the development of public housing, slum clearance, segregation in all
label: Paragraph

text: of its varieties, the rise of gentrification, the effects of suburbanization on cities, the rise
label: Paragraph

text: of highways (particularly in the United States), and more recently the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: festival marketplaces and theories of “new” urbanism. Although renewal has taken on
label: Paragraph

text: different forms in different locations, it has been mainly a top-down hierarchical process,
label: Paragraph

text: one that is often criticized by the very communities that it was intended to improve. The
label: Paragraph

text: central impulse behind urban renewal, and certainly the publicly stated purpose behind all
label: Paragraph

text: such efforts, is to make a place (a neighborhood or a whole city) better than it was before.
label: Paragraph

text: It is the method or approach taken to such improvement that lies behind most conflicts
label: Paragraph

text: over urban renewal.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early 20th century, urban renewal was often inspired by an earnest desire to help
label: Paragraph

text: the poor by improving the conditions in which they labored and lived. A desire to help,
label: Paragraph

text: however, was also commingled with a variety of widely held beliefs about the
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between the moral character of a neighborhood’s residents and its physical
label: Paragraph

text: condition. Usually labeled “common sense,” these assumptions about the recursive
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between bad neighborhoods and bad residents (i.e., the poor, recent
label: Paragraph

text: immigrants, and minorities) were often reinforced by early sociological works attempting
label: Paragraph

text: to explain the social origins of crime, juvenile delinquency, prostitution, and so on. In the
label: Paragraph

text: United States, furthermore, the city of the early 20th century was the product of
label: Paragraph

text: prejudices particular to the late 19th century. With the rise of immigration and
label: Paragraph

text: urbanization, as Peter Hall notes, “many civic-minded bourgeoisie, faced with increasing
label: Paragraph

text: ethnic and cultural heterogeneity” and a perceived threat of escalating social disorder,
label: Paragraph

text: saw as their task “the very preservation of the urban social fabric” (1996).
label: Paragraph

text: An American solution to this dilemma—one that had its antecedents in Haussmann’s
label: Paragraph

text: reorganization of Paris under Napoleon I[l—was the City Beautiful movement, the
label: Paragraph

text: principles of which are expressed vividly in Daniel Burnham and Edward H. Bennett’s
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago Plan of 1909. Their plan sought to restore a lost (in the eyes of the city’s elite)
label: Paragraph

text: harmonious social order by establishing a dominant neobaroque and Beaux-Arts aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: that would dominate not only the design of individual buildings but also the layout of the
label: Paragraph

text: city as a whole. This City Beautiful design conspicuously embraced hierarchies of race
label: Paragraph

text: and class, subordinating the pressing need for housing, schools, and sanitation, and
label: Paragraph

text: instead imagined a future for Chicago in which immigrant machine politics had been
label: Paragraph

text: expelled and proper Anglo-Saxon order restored. The City Beautiful movement spread
label: Paragraph

text: both throughout Europe and, under the British raj, to New Delhi, India, with a plan
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Edwin Lutyens and Herbert Baker.
label: Caption

text: In his groundbreaking text The City (1925), Robert Park stated, “In the great city the
label: Paragraph

text: poor, the vicious, and the delinquent, crushed in an unhealthful and contagious intimacy,
label: Paragraph

text: breed in and in, soul and body.” Park’s assessment, with its treatment of crime and
label: Paragraph

text: poverty as the result largely of individual pathologies rather than structural inequalities
label: Paragraph

text: and racism, provided an academic justification for the continued restriction of certain
label: Paragraph

text: groups to the less-favorable sections of the city. If they (“the poor, the vicious”) hoped to
label: Paragraph

text: move up and out of the slums, they would have to undertake a process of self-
label: Paragraph

text: improvement, of moral elevation. To eradicate the slums, in such a formulation, required
label: Paragraph

text: the eradication of the individual traits that produced and sustained slums. Park’s analysis,
label: Paragraph

text: although significantly more nuanced than the mainstream interpretation, still served to
label: Paragraph

text: justify approaches to urban renewal that treated urban decline as the fault of the
label: Paragraph

text: disadvantaged, as the result of faulty morals and decaying family structures. lt was a view
label: Paragraph

text: that would remain in circulation (particularly in the United States) for decades.
label: Paragraph

text: Following World War LI, urban renewal occurred on a global scale as nations began
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilding after the devastation that the war produced. For some nations, rebuilding in the
label: Paragraph

text: late 1940s meant repairing not only war damage but also the structural decline that had
label: Paragraph

text: taken effect during the years of widespread economic depression that preceded the war.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition, in what was then West Germany, urban renewal also required the
label: Paragraph

text: development of a new, identifiably democratic building style that would break from the
label: Paragraph

text: traditions of architecture and urban design established by the Nazi regime (similar efforts
label: Paragraph

text: on different scales and to different ends were also undertaken in Italy, East Germany, and
label: Paragraph

text: Japan).
label: Paragraph

text: In the United States, the decades following World War Il were years when the
label: Paragraph

text: economic might of the government was channeled largely into the development of the
label: Paragraph

text: interstate highway system and efforts to increase the number of Americans who owned
label: Title

text: their own homes. Both efforts precipitated decades of urban decline. Highways, when
label: Paragraph

text: they passed into or through a city, invariably did so by smashing through poor and
label: Paragraph

text: minority neighborhoods. The U.S. Federal Housing Administration (FHA), responsible
label: Paragraph

text: for insuring the mortgages that allowed middle- and lower-income families to purchase
label: Paragraph

text: homes, instituted regulations that discriminated against neighborhoods whose residents
label: Paragraph

text: were poor and/or nonwhite. The FHA rules, prejudiced against heterogeneous
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods and wary of “inharmonious racial or nationality groups” (Jackson, 1985),
label: Paragraph

text: served to encourage the rapid decline of urban centers by encouraging the flight of capital
label: Paragraph

text: and the middle class to the suburbs.
label: Paragraph

text: In an attempt to counter the decay fostered by such “white flight” and renovate the
label: Paragraph

text: aging housing stock of cities such as Chicago, New York, and St. Louis, the U.S.
label: Paragraph

text: government embarked on a campaign to spur urban renewal through the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: public housing. The limited success and (in some opinions) monumental failure of this
label: Paragraph

text: effort are encapsulated best by Jane Jacobs’s broadside The Death and Life of Great
label: Paragraph

text: American Cities (1961) and writer James Baldwin’s assessment that urban renewal
label: Paragraph

text: constituted in fact “Negro removal.” Entire neighborhoods were razed, and massive
label: Paragraph

text: housing block developments, usually in some derivative form of the International Style,
label: Paragraph

text: were built (as cheaply as possible) in the poorer neighborhoods of cities across the United
label: Paragraph

text: States.
label: Paragraph

text: By the late 1960s, the United States experienced several waves of urban uprisings.
label: Paragraph

text: Discontent was centered around racial and economic inequality, conditions that many felt
label: Paragraph

text: were symptomatic of modernist urban renewal and housing projects. At around the same
label: Paragraph

text: time, the U.S. government was channeling public funds in ever greater amounts to the
label: Paragraph

text: war in Vietnam, diverting public money away from the domestic War on Poverty (the
label: Paragraph

text: broad collection of government programs responsible for many urban-renewal projects)
label: Paragraph

text: instigated by President Lyndon Johnson. By the late 1970s and early 1980s, the
label: Paragraph

text: speculative real estate market was taking an increasingly active role in reshaping
label: Paragraph

text: impoverished neighborhoods. Gentrification, particularly in the United States, has
label: Paragraph

text: replaced the government as the primary “renovator” of “blighted” neighborhoods.
label: Paragraph

text: Gentrification is a process that takes advantage of liberal public policy and capital’s
label: Paragraph

text: endless reproductive drive and is, at the dawn of the 21st century, manifested on a global
label: Paragraph

text: scale, “having emerged widely in the cities of Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and
label: Paragraph

text: Europe, and more sporadically in Japan, South Africa, and Brazil” (Smith, 1996).
label: Paragraph

text: UTOPIAN PLANNING
label: Title

text: Thomas More’s book Ufopia of 1517 named and inspired a genre of publications
label: Paragraph

text: concerned with future projections of ideal societies. The term “utopia,” in its basic
label: Paragraph

text: meaning “no place,” describes political, economic, and sociocultural structures of a
label: Paragraph

text: society. One essential part of the utopia concerns the relation between social forms and
label: Paragraph

text: urban planning. Therefore, the utopia as a literary expression challenged artists,
label: Paragraph

text: architects, and urban planners to visualize the ambience of ideal communities. More
label: Paragraph

text: implictly “utopia” referred to an increasing interest in designing ideal cities in the 15th
label: Paragraph

text: and 16th centuries. Based on the Aristotelian idea of architecture and urban planning as
label: Paragraph

text: practical philosophy or on strict Platonic models of ideal societies in regular geometric
label: Paragraph

text: city forms, thinkers such as Tommaso Campanella (Civitas solis, 1602) and Francis
label: Paragraph

text: Bacon (Nova Atlantis, 1638) developed the philosophical idea of a better society with
label: Paragraph

text: architectural and urban concepts. Liberated from any reference to existing political
label: Paragraph

text: pressures, utopias served as imaginative spaces with experimental values for future
label: Paragraph

text: development. As political imagination allows radical concepts, the utopia as a reflexive
label: Paragraph

text: and imaginative medium turned out to be very attractive for architects and urban planners
label: Paragraph

text: all through history.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 20th century, utopian thinking and designing constituted one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: influential sources for cultural development. Economic changes such as_ the
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization or political changes caused by two world wars provided, ex negativo,
label: Paragraph

text: utopian planning with a rich material. Already in 1890, when William Morris published
label: Paragraph

text: his News from Nowhere, the consequences of early capitalism challenged alternative
label: Paragraph

text: models, that is, utopian visions of humane and ecological living conditions in
label: Paragraph

text: preindustrial town settings. Opposite to that retrospective utopian thinking, artists and
label: Paragraph

text: architects of the early 20th-century avant-garde, influenced by Nietzschean cultural
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy and impressed by the first totally industrialized war in 1914, proposed radical
label: Paragraph

text: visual concepts for the design of a future society, which in postwar times changed from
label: Paragraph

text: monarchy to democracy (Germany) or communism (Russia).
label: Paragraph

text: With few exceptions, such as Camillo Sitte’s famous urban manual, future-oriented
label: Paragraph

text: urban and architectural proposals dominated utopian thinking during the first third of the
label: Paragraph

text: century. Russian Constructivism (El Lissitzky), Dutch De Stijl (Theo van Doesburg),
label: Caption

text: German Expressionism (Bruno Taut} and Bauhaus (Walter Gropius), or Italian futurism
label: Paragraph

text: (Antonio Sant’Elia) required the total negation of cultural heritage to present new
label: Paragraph

text: architectures for a new type of human race.
label: Paragraph

text: In perhaps no other architectural ideology does this condition for utopian design
label: Paragraph

text: emerge more clearly than in the post—World War | writings and drawings of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier. His radical pro-posal for a City of Three Million Inhabitants, situated in a
label: Paragraph

text: cultural no-man’s-land with no traditional references, reveals all the problems of modern
label: Paragraph

text: utopian planning in the 20th century: a total design of standardized architectural and
label: Paragraph

text: urban pattern for standardized members of society, thus realizing More’s description of
label: Paragraph

text: total regularity of all cities on the island of Utopia.
label: Paragraph

text: The destruction of many European cities during World War II allowed avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: architects and planners to transfer utopian wonderlands of architecture into existing
label: Title

text: spaces. Large-scale projects, such as the urban-renewal programs in the United States,
label: Paragraph

text: exemplify a kind of utopian planning applied to urban housing. Dense historical networks
label: Paragraph

text: of urban structures were wiped out in favor of International Style architecture. Out of the
label: Paragraph

text: cultural critique of totalitarian functionalism (Lewis Mumford, Jane Jacobs, and many
label: Paragraph

text: others), the retrospective utopia again gained influence. However, the most striking
label: Paragraph

text: reaction based on insufficient post-World War Il planning was the exaggeration of
label: Paragraph

text: functional and systematic topics of modern planning.
label: Paragraph

text: The megastructures in enormous dimensions proposed by architectural groups such as
label: Paragraph

text: the Metabolists, Archigram, or Superstudio were presented as the ultimate solutions for
label: Paragraph

text: an overcrowded, polluted, and culturally exhausted planet. More or less seriously
label: Paragraph

text: elaborated, utopian megastructures at a global scale presented technological instruments
label: Paragraph

text: as revolutionary sociocultural tools. However, even visions of space colonies (Fritz
label: Paragraph

text: Haller with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology) could not hide the problems of
label: Paragraph

text: one-dimensional utopian planning. Challenged by the lack of complexity of many high-
label: Paragraph

text: tech utopias, Postmodern ideologies, such as the end of history or the rehabilitation of
label: Paragraph

text: vulgar commercial culture (Robert Venturi), determined utopian thinking in the 1970s
label: Paragraph

text: and 1980s. Free exchanges of visual meanings, optical pollution by trademarks, and
label: Paragraph

text: arbitrary style selections in architecture resulted in a capitalist utopia called Global City.
label: Paragraph

text: Revising the history of utopian planning now reveals a basic anthropological pattern:
label: Paragraph

text: society wants to know and explore the future. Whereas negative utopias or frustrated
label: Paragraph

text: illusions of modernity request difficult and complex reevalutions of the relations between
label: Paragraph

text: political and aesthetic ideas, contemporary utopian thinking at the dawn of the 21st
label: Title

text: century reduces More’s model to a mere discussion of surfaces. In this way it seems
label: Paragraph

text: understandable how the politically encoded forms of Soviet Constructivism could be
label: Paragraph

text: reduced to the banal and global frame of deconstructivism in the 1990s. Therefore, it
label: Paragraph

text: might seem reasonable that current architectural and urban-planning theories hardly
label: Paragraph

text: include political and sociocultural dimensions. Finally, reducing the complex imaginative
label: Paragraph

text: space of utopia seems to be a consequence of many naive utopian intentions to translate
label: Paragraph

text: political forms into architectural forms. Utopian planning is more reflection than
label: Paragraph

text: application. Within this cultural context of the late 20th century, science fiction films and
label: Paragraph

text: computer and Internet technology gained more importance as utopian media than
label: Paragraph

text: architectural drawings. Film sets for Blade Runner or The 5th Element display a negative
label: Paragraph

text: megapolitan utopia for the masses and thus revitalize utopian reflection.
label: Paragraph

text: Computer-aided design is located virtually in the “no place” and, if not reduced to a
label: Paragraph

text: business superstructure, opens spaces of political imagination and aesthetic critique to a
label: Paragraph

text: global utopian community.
label: Paragraph

text: UTZON, JORN 1918
label: Title

text: Architect, Denmark
label: Title

text: Jorn Utzon occupies a special position in 20th-century architecture that defies simple
label: Paragraph

text: categorization. As a Dane, he invites com-parison with German Expressionism,
label: Paragraph

text: especially Hans Scharoun; his greatest works are in Australia, Kuwait, and Mallorca; and
label: Paragraph

text: although he gave Gunnar Asplund, Alvar Aalto, and the Dane Kay Fisker as his mentors,
label: Paragraph

text: his casual spontaneity, his daring, and the absence of a fastidious refinement go against
label: Paragraph

text: the grain of Danish tradition in much the same way as Asger Jorn’s paintings. His
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is self-consciously sculptural in its appeal, making Utzon more Finnish and
label: Paragraph

text: European than Danish. Instead of intensely focusing inward in the way that Arne
label: Paragraph

text: Jacobsen did, Utzon relocated his vision outside Denmark, taking his models from within
label: Paragraph

text: the modern Scandinavian tradition and from Le Corbusier; this was, at the same time,
label: Paragraph

text: allied to a new interest in an anonymous vernacular building aesthetic.
label: Paragraph

text: His outstanding contribution was the application of an anonymous vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: expression to repetitive industrial building production disciplined by geometry to create a
label: Paragraph

text: more varied, flexible, romantic building form that responds to changing human
label: Paragraph

text: requirements.
label: Paragraph

text: Jorn Utzon was born in Copenhagen in 1918 but spent his childhood at Alborg, where
label: Paragraph

text: his father, Aage Utzon, was engineering director of the local shipyard. He completed his
label: Paragraph

text: schooling at the Alborg Katedralskole in 1936 and was accepted at the Kunstakademiets
label: Paragraph

text: Arkitektskole in Copenhagen, from which he graduated in 1942. While living in
label: Paragraph

text: Stockholm, where he stayed for the remainder of the German occupation, he was
label: Paragraph

text: awarded a minor Royal Academy Gold Medal (1944) for his design for a music academy
label: Paragraph

text: in Copenhagen. In 1950, Utzon returned to Denmark and started in private practice.
label: Paragraph

text: At the Royal Academy, Utzon was exposed to Kay Fisker and to the historian and
label: Paragraph

text: planner Steen Eiler Rasmussen, whose experiential theory of architecture in his small
label: Paragraph

text: book Experiencing Architecture, published in 1959, Utzon seems subsequently to have
label: Paragraph

text: adopted.
label: Paragraph

text: Utzon traveled extensively in the early years after the war, first a short stint in Alvar
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto’s Munkkiniemi office in 1946, followed by trips to Morocco in 1947 and to the
label: Paragraph

text: United States and Mexico in 1949. These travel experiences helped solidify his maturing
label: Paragraph

text: organic approach. From 1945 to 1957, he vigorously participated in many competitions
label: Paragraph

text: that he combined with extensive travel, absorbing influences from Islamic, Chinese, and
label: Paragraph

text: Mayan architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: He worked alone and with others, including such Danish contemporaries as Tobias
label: Paragraph

text: Faber and Mogens Irming; however, the most important collaborator was the Norwegian
label: Paragraph

text: modernist Amme Korsmo. Other influences were Gunnar Asplund (from his time in
label: Paragraph

text: Sweden) and the organic architecture of Frank Lloyd Wright, Alvar Aalto, and Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier, whom he met in 1948.
label: Paragraph

text: Utzon adopted the additive composition principle of combining standard industrial
label: Paragraph

text: components that could be augmented by adding extra elements, so that his buildings
label: Paragraph

text: appear to grow in a manner that crudely mimics the replication of cellular organisms.
label: Paragraph

text: Utzon was inspired in his architecture by natural phenomena, such as clouds, beech
label: Paragraph

text: forests, and breaking waves, that he adopted in the early conceptual stage in developing
label: Paragraph

text: his ideas.
label: Paragraph

text: A number of architectural ideas recur in Utzon, the courtyard house being one and the
label: Paragraph

text: motif of the platform as a technique for relating group forms another. In 1953, with Ib
label: Paragraph

text: Molegelvang, he won the Skaanske low-cost housing competition for “Scania” house
label: Paragraph

text: types. His scheme was based on the ancient Chinese courtyard house, and although it was
label: Paragraph

text: not built, Utzon went on to design the Kingohusene Housing Estate (1960) near
label: Paragraph

text: Helsinger and a more elaborate development (1963) at Fredensborg using the courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: principle. Although these are less known than Sydney’s Opera House, they are no less
label: Paragraph

text: significant, and they demonstrate Utzon’s humanitarian commitment to housing
label: Paragraph

text: innovation. The timber-component house system known as “Espansiva” (1969) took this
label: Paragraph

text: a step further and attempted to simplify and adapt housing to exploit simple industrial
label: Paragraph

text: materials and methods. The same concern is apparent in his Utsep Mobler Flexible
label: Paragraph

text: Furniture (1968) system, which also applied the same additive architecture principle.
label: Paragraph

text: Jorn Utzon’s world fame rests largely on one work: the Sydney Opera House. Winning
label: Paragraph

text: the international competition in 1957 thrust him overnight into the international
label: Paragraph

text: architectural spotlight. Its completion in October 1973 made Sydney instantly
label: Paragraph

text: recognizable and provided it with an architectural symbol that emphasized the
label: Paragraph

text: importance of its harbor.
label: Paragraph

text: Utzon’s Sydney Opera House scheme coincided with Le Corbusier’s break with the
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s cubist aesthetic for the Ronchamp chapel, Notre-Dame-du-Haut, completed in June
label: Caption

text: 1955. Both emphasized the organic quality of their forms inspired by exceptional
label: Paragraph

text: landscapes: the small plateau and acropolis at Ronchamp and a low-lying sandstone
label: Paragraph

text: peninsula jutting out into and surrounded on three sides by the harbor in Sydney.
label: Paragraph

text: A number of factors help explain the Sydney Opera House’s unprecedented originality
label: Paragraph

text: and use of shell-concrete roofs. The 1930s in Copenhagen witnessed the early
label: Paragraph

text: development of shell concrete for the Kastrup Airport Terminal (1939) and the Radiohus
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1946) by Vilhelm Lauritzen. In 1946, Utzon collaborated on a submission in
label: Paragraph

text: the Crystal Palace International Competition that introduced the identical theme of
label: Paragraph

text: concert halls with sculptural shell roofs mounted on a common platform.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the accusation was justified that progress on the Sydney Opera House was
label: Paragraph

text: unacceptably slow, it is unlikely that this fact would have provoked the extreme reaction
label: Paragraph

text: in Europe that it did in Sydney in 1966. The intransigence of Utzon’s new political
label: Paragraph

text: master convinced him that he was no longer trusted, and this caused his withdrawal from
label: Paragraph

text: the project. At the time this happened, Utzon had overcome the last remaining problems
label: Paragraph

text: of acoustics and construction in the interiors and was in a position to complete the work
label: Paragraph

text: in a reasonable time and cost. The client, Davis Hughes, and party politics prevented him
label: Paragraph

text: from doing so.
label: Paragraph

text: The interiors and glass walls enclosing the open ends of the concrete vault roofs,
label: Paragraph

text: completed by his replacement, Hall Todd and Littlemore, are neither as original nor as
label: Paragraph

text: daring as Utzon’s. The Opera House function was emasculated by relegating opera to the
label: Paragraph

text: smaller hall, which could no longer function as a drama theater. Acoustic problems have
label: Paragraph

text: dogged the concert hall and will be expensive, if impossible, to remedy. Despite these
label: Paragraph

text: shortcomings, the outside is clear proof of Utzon’s sculptural genius. It stands as a
label: Paragraph

text: monument to the human imagination, shared by an entire city, on an extraordinarily
label: Paragraph

text: sensitive site on the edge of the city where it thrusts into the harbor. Not surprisingly, it
label: Paragraph

text: has since become the foremost symbol of Sydney around the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Of his later works the Bagsvaerd Church (1976) in Copenhagen and the Kuwait
label: Paragraph

text: National Assembly Building (1983), Kuwait City, Kuwait, provide further evidence of
label: Caption

text: his determination to seek a new anonymous industrial aesthetic using standardized
label: Paragraph

text: National Assembly Building (1983), Kuwait City, Kuwait
label: Caption

text: © Yann Arthus-Bertrand/CORBIS
label: Caption

text: industrial processes that can be varied to match each requirement and that are sensitive to
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: The State Theater complex for Zurich embodied the same’ lessons of geometry and
label: Paragraph

text: standardization that Utzon learned in Sydney and that were transferred to Kuwait and, to
label: Paragraph

text: a lesser extent, to Bagsvaerd Church. At Kuwait, Utzon introduced simply draped
label: Paragraph

text: concrete sheets similar to Eero Saarinen’s Dulles Airport Terminal (1963) but gave them
label: Paragraph

text: additional sculptural complexity by folding them laterally so that they echo the folds of
label: Paragraph

text: the Bedouin black tent. The National Assembly Building is an elaborate mix of standard
label: Paragraph

text: precast-concrete units that Utzon contrasted with his hanging tent roofs looking out
label: Paragraph

text: across the Persian Gulf and backed by the desert.
label: Paragraph

text: The Bagsvaerd Church incorporates a freely unfolding shell of sprayed concrete that is
label: Paragraph

text: used to support the outer metal roof and that admits a soft, muted, indirect light into the
label: Paragraph

text: nave. Inspired in part by medieval stave churches, stacked standard precast elements are
label: Paragraph

text: used for the double-wall frame. Its linear rectangular plan is of great simplicity and
label: Paragraph

text: elegance. Outside, it looks more like a factory than a church.
label: Paragraph

text: One of Utzon’s most satisfying small works is “Can Lis” (1973), his cliff house near
label: Paragraph

text: Santyani on Mallorca. Its expression is firmly rooted in the Mallorcan vernacular but
label: Paragraph

text: incorporates deep window embrasures that are reminiscent of the south wall of Le
label: Caption

text: Corbusier’s Ronchamp chapel to frame the sea vistas. It was conceived as a miniature
label: Paragraph

text: village of four pavilions jostling one another at various odd angles that add interest to the
label: Paragraph

text: whole and form mysterious spaces between.
label: Paragraph

text: Shy and charming by turns and not unlike the movie actress Greta Garbo, whom he
label: Paragraph

text: resembles, Utzon adopted the life of a recluse after 1970. Since the 1980s, Utzon has
label: Paragraph

text: been less active in architecture, his professional involvement being mostly indirect in a
label: Paragraph

text: series of collaborations with his two architect sons, Jan and Kim Utzon, on unsuccessful
label: Paragraph

text: large-scale commercial projects to rejuvenate the Copenhagen waterfront, a project for a
label: Paragraph

text: Danish Museum of Modern Art (1988) in Fredensborg and museums at Bornholm
label: Caption

text: (1988), Skagen, and Samsg Island (1995-), the latter yet to be realized.
label: Paragraph

text: Further Reading
label: Title

text: Utzon’s resistance to scholarly research and documentation and his reticence to cooperate
label: Paragraph

text: with critical assessment has created severe problems for the serious historian, with the
label: Paragraph

text: unfortunate consequence that there is a proliferation of errors resulting from an
label: Paragraph

text: overreliance on secondary source material. There has been far more publication and
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation than research into establishing reliable facts. The Fromonot account, for
label: Paragraph

text: instance, is largely a compilation of material copied from Zodiac numbers 5, 10, and 14,
label: Paragraph

text: with additions. Because these issues are rare, their republication in this way is
label: Paragraph

text: undoubtedly useful. Utzon scholarship remains at an early stage.

text: CANADA
label: Title

text: The city of Vancouver is truly of the 20th century. When the small town of Granville was
label: Paragraph

text: incorporated as the city of Vancouver in 1886, it had more in common with American
label: Paragraph

text: cities west of the Rocky Mountains than with the rest of Canada. San Francisco had
label: Paragraph

text: served as Vancouver’s main link to the east before the completion of Canada’s
label: Paragraph

text: transcontinental railway in 1887. Within five years the community of 1000 had grown to
label: Paragraph

text: nearly 14,000 and the young city became a supply depot and investment center for the
label: Paragraph

text: Klondike gold rush of 1897-98. From these boomtown beginnings, metropolitan
label: Paragraph

text: Vancouver is now home to more than 1.8 million people.
label: Paragraph

text: During the early 20th century, rapid growth fueled construction of neighborhoods
label: Paragraph

text: along the street railway and interurban lines. Before 1910 many homes were constructed
label: Paragraph

text: of a prefabricated, insulated, four-foot modular system, designed and manufactured by
label: Paragraph

text: the B.C.Mills, Timber, and Trading Company. Known as Vancouver Boxes, these
label: Paragraph

text: efficient and economical houses were characterized by a single story set on a high
label: Paragraph

text: foundation, a hip roof with dormer windows, and a broad front veranda. From 1910 until
label: Caption

text: the mid-1920s, the most popular house for middle- and lower-class families was a variant
label: Paragraph

text: of the California bungalow, typified by front gables, exposed rafter ends, and wall
label: Paragraph

text: brackets, and often chimneys, porch piers, and foundations of rough brick or stone. These
label: Paragraph

text: Craftsman homes, a small-scale version of the Queen Anne style, were popular amongst
label: Paragraph

text: the suburban working classes. At one point South Vancouver was expanding at a rate of
label: Paragraph

text: 200 families per month, all housed in California bungalows.
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast the region’s affluent families required large formal estates for entertaining.
label: Paragraph

text: British expatriates had a fondness for Tudor revivals, English country manors, or Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts-style homes. In Point Grey and Shaughnessy Heights, abundantly timbered
label: Paragraph

text: properties were developed according to the tenets of the City Beautiful movement,
label: Paragraph

text: creating elegant neighborhoods of parks and scenic drives. In both Victoria (the
label: Paragraph

text: provincial capital) and Vancouver, one of the most sought-after architects of this era was
label: Paragraph

text: Samuel Maclure, whose early bungalows were modest versions of the California style—
label: Paragraph

text: single-storied, wood-framed buildings with cross-axial plans and wood-shingle cladding.
label: Caption

text: Influenced by the art and architecture of Charles F.A.Voysey and Frank Lloyd Wright,
label: Paragraph

text: Maclure often used Tudor-revival facades to mollify his clients while creating modern
label: Paragraph

text: designs that maximized the potential of the site and locally available materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Thriving business concerns led to the importation of New York and Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper technologies. In 1908 David Spencer and Company built a nine-story
label: Paragraph

text: department store that was followed by the 13-story Dominion Trust Building in 1910,
label: Paragraph

text: touted as the most modern and tallest office building in Canada. Originally designed for
label: Paragraph

text: the Imperial Trust Company by the English-trained architect J.S.Helyer and his son
label: Paragraph

text: Maurice, the Dominion Trust Building had a brick exterior with yellow terracotta features
label: Paragraph

text: emulating the detailing of classical orders and was capped by a lofty Second Empire-style
label: Paragraph

text: roof. Others followed, including the W.T.Whiteway’s World Building (1912), now
label: Paragraph

text: known as the Old Sun Tower, whose 17-story corner hexagonal office tower eclipsed the
label: Paragraph

text: Dominion Trust Building; Parr and Fee’s Vancouver Block (1912), with its conspicuous
label: Paragraph

text: clock atop a central tower; and the Weart Building (1913) by Russell, Babcock and Rice,
label: Caption

text: now known as the Standard Building. The Credit Foncier Franco-Canadien (1914) by
label: Caption

text: H.L.Stevens and Company offers the most faithful emulation of neoclassical detailing.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1914 architect Francis Swales was commissioned to design the Hotel Vancouver to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate business travelers and tourists who used the Canadian Pacific Railway.
label: Paragraph

text: This impressive assembly of cubic forms with intricate Italianate detailing and
label: Paragraph

text: overhanging roofs dominated the Vancouver skyline until its controversial demolition in
label: Paragraph

text: 1949. To serve the competing Canadian National Railway, another Hotel Vancouver was
label: Paragraph

text: built in the Chateau style by Archibald and Schofield. Although construction had begun
label: Paragraph

text: in 1929, it was abandoned during the Great Depression, and the hotel was only completed
label: Paragraph

text: in time for the 1939 Royal Tour. This building’s facade was an elegant expression of the
label: Paragraph

text: restrained modern classicism in vogue at the time. Another example was the new
label: Paragraph

text: Vancouver City Hall (1936), constructed near recently annexed South Vancouver. The
label: Paragraph

text: architects, Townley and Matheson, adhered to the modern classical precedents
label: Paragraph

text: established by other government architecture of the time by stepping down a series of
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrically arranged cubic forms on opposing sides of a large central tower.
label: Paragraph

text: After World War I, Vancouver's thriving port facilities had fostered development of
label: Paragraph

text: the waterfront and the commercial heart of the city, even during the Depression. The
label: Paragraph

text: most noteworthy building of this period was J.Y.McCarter and George C. Nairme’s
label: Paragraph

text: Marine Building (1930). Both the 20-story tower and a 10-story wing have richly
label: Paragraph

text: decorated parapets, executed in pink and green terra-cotta, which contrast with the pale-
label: Paragraph

text: red brick walls. The striking Art Deco ornamentation incorporates terracotta panels
label: Caption

text: illustrating histories of transportation and the Pacific coast.
label: Paragraph

text: Economic restraints during World War IJ limited construction to essential projects.
label: Paragraph

text: Afterward, however, Vancouver thrived, as veterans returned to the city and foreign
label: Paragraph

text: demand for Canada’s natural resources escalated. The immigration of British-trained
label: Paragraph

text: architects and the influence of Walter Gropius, Richard Neutra, and Marcel Breuer
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged the development of modernist building. In 1946 a department of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: was established at the University of British Columbia under Frederick Lasserre that
label: Paragraph

text: began to attract international attention. Efforts of early modernists, such as C.B.K.Van
label: Paragraph

text: Norman, Robert A.D.Berwick, Bertram C.Binning, and Peter Thornton, were quickly
label: Paragraph

text: overtaken by younger designers like Charles E. Pratt, Ron Thom, and Fred
label: Paragraph

text: Hollingsworth, who used new lumber products and prefabricated building systems to
label: Paragraph

text: create a distinctive West Coast style. With an intricate arrangement of flatroofed terraces
label: Paragraph

text: stepping down the West Bay hillside, C.E.Pratt demonstrated the West Coast style in a
label: Paragraph

text: house designed for lumber company executive William S.Brooks (1947). Wood, steel,
label: Caption

text: stone, and large expanses of glass were presented in a manner that highlighted the
label: Paragraph

text: interrelationship between the building’s interior and its natural surroundings.
label: Paragraph

text: In commercial building Semmens and Simpson’s design for the Vancouver offices of
label: Paragraph

text: Marwell Construction (1950) won the inaugural round of the national Massey Medal
label: Paragraph

text: awards in 1952. Components of this scrupulously functional design transcended the
label: Paragraph

text: normal barriers between exterior and interior. The first Vancouver high-rise constructed
label: Paragraph

text: since the Depression era was the Burrard Building (1956) by C.K.B.Van Norman and
label: Paragraph

text: Associates, which used a space-saving curtain wall facade.
label: Paragraph

text: The 1963 competition for a new university in the adjacent city of Burnaby relieved the
label: Paragraph

text: slow pace of local construction. The successful entry by the Vancouver partnership of
label: Paragraph

text: Arthur Erickson and Geoffrey Massey proved to be the springboard for Arthur Erickson’s
label: Paragraph

text: international career. His scheme for Simon Fraser University revolved around a strong
label: Paragraph

text: central axis linking all campus buildings and incorporating contemporary approaches to
label: Paragraph

text: pedagogy. In addition to the campus plan, Erickson and Massey designed the
label: Paragraph

text: Transportation Centre (1965) and Central Mall (1965), in which massive girders of
label: Paragraph

text: douglas fir and steel supported a glass canopy. The campus has continued to expand;
label: Paragraph

text: Erickson also designed a university extension to the West Mall (1994) that remains
label: Paragraph

text: faithful to the form and materials of the original campus.
label: Paragraph

text: The phenomenal growth of Vancouver forced developers to build vertically. High-rise
label: Paragraph

text: residential buildings, including Rix Reinecke’s Ocean Towers (1958), began to dominate
label: Paragraph

text: the West End skyline following a permissive 1956 zoning amendment. The consequences
label: Paragraph

text: of the rampant demolition of the 1960s and 1970s were not fully appreciated until much
label: Paragraph

text: of the city’s architectural fabric had been decimated. An emerging heritage conservation
label: Paragraph

text: movement encouraged reuse and adaptation, one prominent example being the Sylvia
label: Paragraph

text: Hotel addition, designed by Henriquez Partners. Noted for being the tallest building in
label: Paragraph

text: the West End until 1958, the Sylvia Court Apartments (1912), designed by W.P. White
label: Paragraph

text: and converted to a hotel during the 1930s, received heritage designation in 1975. This
label: Paragraph

text: staid brick, stone, and terra-cotta structure was expanded by Richard Henriquez’s tower
label: Paragraph

text: Economic recession in the 1970s and 1980s proved to be a transitional stage between
label: Paragraph

text: modernism and regionalism. Just before this construction hiatus, the firm of Rhone and
label: Paragraph

text: Iredale was awarded the commission for Crown Life Place (1978). Their principal
label: Paragraph

text: designer, Peter Cardew, created a dramatic V-shaped office tower in the late modern
label: Paragraph

text: idiom, using green-tinted glass curtain walls. The 1986 Vancouver Centennial and World
label: Paragraph

text: Exposition spurred development of Granville Island Public Market and transformation of
label: Paragraph

text: the False Creek industrial area into a livable community. Canada Place (1986) by Zeidler
label: Caption

text: Roberts Partnership hosts public events and welcomes cruise ships. Its multipurpose
label: Paragraph

text: design incorporates a docking terminal, the PanPacific Hotel, and a row of large display
label: Paragraph

text: halls, distinctively covered in white sail-shaped fabric.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1990s competing architectural styles dominated, including Paul Merrick’s
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodern Cathedral Place (1991), a controversial complex that replaced McCarter and
label: Paragraph

text: Nairme’s much admired Georgia Medical Dental Building (1929); Moshe Safdie’s
label: Paragraph

text: Vancouver Library Square (1995); and the Chan Centre for the Performing Arts (1997),
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Bing Thom Architects.
label: Caption
