text: VAN DOESBURG, THEO 1883-1931
label: Title

text: Architecture historian, critic, theorist, Netherlands
label: Title

text: As founder and polemicist for the Dutch avant-garde group De Stijl, Theo van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg systematically propagated his ideas of the visual arts, architecture, design, and
label: Paragraph

text: theory in many forms and forums. Van Doesburg was a critic, poet, novelist, performance
label: Paragraph

text: artist, teacher, publisher, typographer, and art historian. Instrumental in the development
label: Paragraph

text: of modern architecture, he was committed to the idea of universal synthesis. Although
label: Paragraph

text: well known in his lifetime through associations with many international art and
label: Paragraph

text: architectural groups, he was ultimately unsuccessful in achieving the integration of art
label: Paragraph

text: and life through the doctrine of Neoplasticism (New Forming}. Nonetheless, he was
label: Paragraph

text: innovative in his ideas that connected art and architecture with cultural and political
label: Paragraph

text: issues through literature, urbanism, exhibitions, performance, education, and criticism.
label: Paragraph

text: Immediately after his service in the Dutch army during World War I, he formed the De
label: Paragraph

text: Stijl group with the poet Antony Kok, the painters Piet Mondrian and Bart van der Leck,
label: Paragraph

text: the Hungarian painter and designer Vilmos Huszar, and the architects J.J.P.Oud and Jan
label: Paragraph

text: Wils. In 1917, he began the journal De Stijl, remaining its editor and driving force
label: Paragraph

text: throughout its irregular publication until 1931. Van Doesburg promoted De Stijl as “The
label: Paragraph

text: Style,” the vehicle to annul the plurality of styles to culminate inevitably in neoplastic
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis.
label: Paragraph

text: Architecturally, van Doesburg enacted this mission by appropriating ideas from
label: Paragraph

text: painting to several buildings by Oud, Wils, and other Dutch architects. He applied
label: Paragraph

text: primary colors to window frames and glass panels and developed colored geometric
label: Paragraph

text: patterns for interiors beginning 1917, simultaneously writing essays and manifestos,
label: Paragraph

text: launching De Stijl’s “Manifesto 1” in 1918. Demanding the reformation of art and culture
label: Paragraph

text: through collective collaboration, van Doesburg simultaneously emphasized the dystopic
label: Paragraph

text: condition of the world through his efforts with the Dada artists Kurt Schwitters and
label: Paragraph

text: Tristan Tzara. As a counterpoint to and groundwork for De Stijl, he wrote essays, sound-
label: Paragraph

text: poems, and a novel and performed and created art under the Dada pseudonyms
label: Paragraph

text: 1.K.Bonset and Aldo Camini. Hoping to establish a pedagogical base for De Stijl, van
label: Caption

text: Doesburg attempted to infiltrate the Bauhaus in Weimar between 1921 and 1922. When
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Gropius refused him a teaching position, he formed his own De Stijl architecture
label: Paragraph

text: course nearby.
label: Paragraph

text: Van Doesburg orchestrated De Stijl’s international debut at the exhibition Les
label: Paragraph

text: Architectes du Groupe “de Styl” held in the Galerie L’Effort Moderne in Paris in 1923.
label: Caption

text: Here, among several architectural projects by members of the De Stijl group, including
label: Paragraph

text: Gerrit Rietveld and Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, van Doesburg, in collaboration with
label: Caption

text: Cornelis van Eesteren, developed two theoretical houses in drawings and models
label: Paragraph

text: influential to the spatial and ideological development of modern architecture. The Maison
label: Paragraph

text: d’Artiste and the Maison Particuliére were three-dimensional experiments derived from
label: Paragraph

text: the universalizing forms explored in painting by van Doesburg and Mondrian. Their
label: Paragraph

text: rectilinear volumes pinwheel about a voided center, emphasizing oblique movement.
label: Paragraph

text: Their dynamic asymmetries are harmoniously balanced by the primary colors red, blue,
label: Paragraph

text: and yellow and the noncolors black, white, and gray. Van Doesburg drew several
label: Paragraph

text: spatially floating axonometrics, or “counter-constructions,” from the Maison Particuliére.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike the singular fixed vantage point of traditional perspective, these speculative
label: Paragraph

text: projections allow unlimited points of entry and exit in infinite extension. Van Doesburg
label: Paragraph

text: photographed the models from below and proposed a sixth elevation for architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: detached from the specificity of a site. His attempts to define an ungrounded, new
label: Paragraph

text: conception of space in relation to time were derived from the work of Albert Einstein;
label: Paragraph

text: van Doesburg owned several books by or about him.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1926 and 1928, van Doesburg transformed two large rooms of an 18th-
label: Paragraph

text: century building in Strasbourg, France, to the Café Aubette. Designing each as a three-
label: Caption

text: dimensional De Stijl environment, he didactically positioned the rooms in relation to one
label: Paragraph

text: another. The Small Dance Hall’s primary color panels on the walls and ceiling align
label: Paragraph

text: orthographically with the rectilinear room. Enacting van Doesburg’s transition into
label: Paragraph

text: “Elementarism” and influenced by the oblique “counter-constructions” from the Maison
label: Paragraph

text: Particuliére, his other room, the Cinema-Dance Hall, features diagonal patterns extending
label: Paragraph

text: through the room’s comers beyond the confines of the space. In the Café Aubette,
label: Paragraph

text: reconstructed in 1995, the projection of cinema and the oblique gestures of bodies in
label: Paragraph

text: motion establish the spatial dialogue between art and life. Synthesizing architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: painting as Gesamtkunstwerk, or total work of art, van Doesburg incorporated several
label: Paragraph

text: different materials into the spaces and designed the menu, furniture, and signs.
label: Paragraph

text: Van Doesburg designed and built a house for himself and his wife, Nelly, in Meudon-
label: Paragraph

text: Val Fleury, outside of Paris, from 1927 to 1930. Intended as a teaching studio and a
label: Paragraph

text: residence, its main cubic space rests on pilotis, suspended over an open terrace. Its
label: Paragraph

text: natrow site constricted it into a diagonal sectional arrangement. At the same time, van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg planned a series of towers titled “Cité de Circulation.” This diagonally oriented
label: Paragraph

text: collection of 11-story residences, based on previous tower schemes by Le Corbusier,
label: Caption

text: holds four living units per floor, each similar to his Meudon House, pinwheeling around a
label: Paragraph

text: central open core. A rotated axonometric drawing of the Meudon House demonstrates the
label: Paragraph

text: interdependence of the two projects—connecting painting to interior to house to city,
label: Paragraph

text: elevated high above the ground.
label: Paragraph

text: Biography
label: Title

text: Born in Utrecht, Holland, 30 August 1883 as Christiaan Emil Marie Kiipper; renamed
label: Paragraph

text: himself after Dutch stepfather. Began painting and writing art criticism (1908-10);
label: Paragraph

text: published essays on Leonardo, Michelangelo, and Rembrandt. Served in Dutch army,
label: Paragraph

text: 1914-16, subsequently settled in Leiden, began collaborating with J.J.P.Oud and Jan
label: Paragraph

text: Wils. In 1917 formed De Stijl group and publication of the same name (with Piet
label: Paragraph

text: Mondrian, Vilmos Huszar, Bart van der Leck, and Georges Vantongerloo). Visited Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: and Weimar (1921), where he met Raoul Hausmann, Mies van der Rohe, Hans Richter,
label: Paragraph

text: and Le Corbusier; participated in architectural exhibitions, Galerie l’Effort Moderne
label: Paragraph

text: (1923, Paris) and Ecole Spéciale d’Architecture (Paris, 1924). Collaborated with Jean
label: Paragraph

text: Arp and Sophie Taueber-Arp for decorations for Café Aubette, Strasbourg, France;
label: Caption

text: returned to Paris (1929), began designing house at Meudon-Val Fleury with Cornelis van
label: Paragraph

text: Eesteren; published first issue of avant-garde jour-nal Art concret 1929. Died 7 March
label: Caption

text: 1931 of tuberculosis in Davos, Switzerland.

text: VANNA VENTURI HOUSE, CHESTNUT
label: Caption

text: HILL
label: Title

text: Designed by Robert Venturi, completed 1964 Chestnut Hill, Pennsylvania
label: Caption

text: Robert Venturi’s house for his mother in Chestnut Hill, Pennsylvania, marked the
label: Paragraph

text: formal reintroduction of architectural history into the formulaic modernist practice of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Designed and constructed between 1959 and 1964, the Vanna Venturi house
label: Paragraph

text: represents the integration of historical precedents, the demonstration of Venturi’s
label: Paragraph

text: architectural theory, and a critique of American domesticity. In a frequently cited
label: Paragraph

text: description of the house, Venturi explains that it
label: Paragraph

text: recognizes complexities and contradictions; it is both complex and simple, open
label: Paragraph

text: and closed, big and little; some of its elements are good on one level and bad on
label: Paragraph

text: another; its order accommodates the generic elements of the house in general
label: Paragraph

text: and the circumstantial elements of a house in particular. (Venturi, 1966)
label: Caption

text: Concentrating a variety of ideological and formal issues into the approximately 1700-
label: Paragraph

text: square-foot house, Venturi produced five complete preliminary designs before arriving at
label: Paragraph

text: the sixth and final scheme.
label: Paragraph

text: A house for a family member is a typical early commission for a young architect, and
label: Paragraph

text: Venturi’s achieved notoriety through the carefully composed elevational photograph
label: Paragraph

text: centered at its entry of Vanna Venturi looking up from her book. As it was exposed to the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural public, the Vanna Venturi house often was vilified but seldom dismissed. It
label: Paragraph

text: soon was referenced in the work of other architects, as in the facades of the Phillips
label: Paragraph

text: Exeter Academy Dining Hall (1972) by Louis Kahn, who was one of Venturi’s mentors.
label: Paragraph

text: By reaching low and broadly to vernacular domestic imagery while rigorously
label: Paragraph

text: manipulating architectural precedent at a time when architecture had turned its back on
label: Paragraph

text: history, the Vanna Venturi house profoundly disturbed the status quo of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Robert Venturi, enacting a genteel form of avante-garde disruption, ushered in
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernism with a building and a book to accompany it. Complexity ana
label: Paragraph

text: Contradiction in Architecture, written between 1956 and 1964, was Venturi’s companion
label: Paragraph

text: piece for the Vanna Venturi house. In a recent interview, Venturi said, “What | wrote in
label: Paragraph

text: the book was what | was thinking about while | was drawing the house” (Schwartz,
label: Paragraph

text: 1992). Venturi published plans for the Vanna Venturi house along with a portfolio of his
label: Paragraph

text: other work as the last chapter of Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture, blurring
label: Paragraph

text: theory and practice while seamlessly weaving his architecture into the canon of
label: Paragraph

text: significant historical buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Demonstrating a modern version of the strategy of mannerism—the human desire to
label: Paragraph

text: impair perfection—Venturi appropriated and critiqued the history of Western architecture
label: Paragraph

text: while remaining deeply engaged with its modernist tendencies. The Vanna Venturi house
label: Paragraph

text: quotes freely from the nymphaeum at Andrea Palladio’s Villa Barbaro (1554), McKim,
label: Caption

text: Mead and White’s Low House (1887), Bruno Taut’s Double House (1921), the Casa
label: Paragraph

text: Girasole by Luigi Moretti (1950), and Venturi’s own Beach House project (1959),
label: Paragraph

text: depicted and discussed in Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture. Venturi’s Guild
label: Paragraph

text: House, designed between 1960 and 1963 for the elderly Quaker community in
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia, may be interpreted as a public version of his private house for his mother,
label: Paragraph

text: an elderly member of the Quaker church. Each building has similar configurations in plan
label: Paragraph

text: and elevation, and they share similar windows, front arches, taut skins, and a combination
label: Paragraph

text: of marble and everyday materials.
label: Paragraph

text: The uniquely pale green, stuccoed front facade of the Vanna Venturi house presents at
label: Paragraph

text: first impression a Palladian monumental symmetry. This overall symmetry is shifted and
label: Paragraph

text: rearranged in asymmetrical elements, such as the slightly off-center actual chimney set
label: Paragraph

text: within the centered, large-scale chimney block and in the reciprocal distribution of five
label: Paragraph

text: windows on each half of the house, corresponding to the rooms within. The split
label: Paragraph

text: pediment challenges the norm of the typical gable-roofed house and vi-
label: Paragraph

text: Vanna Venturi House, Chestnut Hill, Pennsylvania, designed by Robert Venturi
label: Caption

text: © Rollin La France. Photo courtesy Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates
label: Caption

text: sually exaggerates the structural capacity of the exposed concrete beam over the entry.
label: Paragraph

text: Venturi applied a shallow arced dado molding to the facade, split by the central gap and
label: Paragraph

text: passing over the concrete lintel. The application of thin moldings and the overall simple
label: Paragraph

text: edges of the house make “the facades look almost like drawings” (Venturi, 1982).
label: Paragraph

text: Venturi has privileged the perception of the drawn house over the appearance of the
label: Paragraph

text: house itself. The front facade frequently has been compared to a child’s drawing of a
label: Paragraph

text: generic house, conveying “houseness” in its articulation of the fundamental pragmatic
label: Paragraph

text: and symbolic elements of house—entry, window, gabled roof, and chimney. Both
label: Paragraph

text: elementary and complex, the front facade of the Vanna Venturi house displays a tension
label: Paragraph

text: between its perceived ornament and structure and exhibits Venturi’s conception of
label: Paragraph

text: “superadjacency”—drawing together elements of disparate scales.
label: Paragraph

text: The side facades barely exist, leftovers between front and rear. Notched patio spaces at
label: Paragraph

text: each end minimize their presence. The rear facade combines standard window shapes in a
label: Paragraph

text: thin-edged floating plane that seems detached from the body of the house. The extended
label: Paragraph

text: facade wall screens a narrow deck on the upper floor with a “real” arched window behind
label: Caption

text: it, in contrast to the applied arched molding at the front facade.
label: Paragraph

text: The plan of the house, which could be contained within a box, is based on an overall
label: Paragraph

text: symmetry. Similar to the front facade, it diverts into a studied asymmetry. Approaching
label: Paragraph

text: from the driveway, which is skewed to accommodate a sewer main in the street, the
label: Paragraph

text: overscaled entry is blocked by the massive chimney. The curved foyer to the right sweeps
label: Caption

text: into the dining area, with its large-scale marble tile floor setting it off from the rest of the
label: Paragraph

text: house and suggesting a grand vestibule itself. Its high, arched ceiling envelops an
label: Paragraph

text: independent pipe column. At the focus of the interior, the fireplace and its companion
label: Caption

text: piece—the abruptly narrowing central stair—merge into a codependent entity. The shape
label: Paragraph

text: of the wall surrounding the overscaled fireplace suggests an enormous version of an
label: Paragraph

text: elderly woman’s shoe, bringing to mind the old woman who lived in a shoe, a figurative
label: Paragraph

text: domestic association.
label: Paragraph

text: The stair to the upper-level bedroom pinches in to accommodate barely one person.
label: Caption

text: The upper level, which Robert Venturi occupied for about three years, contains a tiny
label: Paragraph

text: utilitarian bathroom and storage spaces tucked under the roof eaves. An even narrower
label: Paragraph

text: steep stair provides access to clean the high rear window, paint the clerestory, or change
label: Paragraph

text: the exposed lightbulb. This quotidian finale is pure bathos, extending from elegant refine-
label: Paragraph

text: ment to a strategically banal dead end.
label: Paragraph

text: From its overall site planning to the ergonomic detail of its stair rail, the Vanna Venturi
label: Paragraph

text: house simultaneously recalls a typical American residence, gestures to a multitude of
label: Paragraph

text: historical refer-
label: Title

text: Vanna Venturi House interior
label: Caption

text: © Rollin La France. Photo courtesy Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates
label: Caption

text: ences, and deliberately subverts the status of orthodox modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: VAN NELLE FACTORY, NETHERLANDS
label: Caption

text: Designed by J.A.Brinkman and L.C.van der Vlugt with Mart Stam, Completed 1930
label: Caption

text: Rotterdam, Netherlands
label: Title

text: The Van Nelle factory (1930) in Schiedam, Rotterdam, Netherlands, was designed by
label: Paragraph

text: the firm of J.A.Brinkman and L.C. van der Vlugt with Mart Stam. Completed between
label: Paragraph

text: 1926 and 1930, it was admired by fellow modern architects and industrialists alike. The
label: Paragraph

text: factory complex included industrial buildings for packaging, offices, and warehouse
label: Paragraph

text: facilities for the Dutch company Van Nelle, renowned for its coffees, teas, and tobaccos.
label: Paragraph

text: The factory still exists today.
label: Paragraph

text: Van Nelle Factory, Rotterdam (1928), by Johannes A-Brinkman and L.C.van
label: Caption

text: der Vlugt
label: Title

text: © GreatBuildings.com
label: Title

text: Over a ten-year period, the building plans changed and developed because of World War
label: Paragraph

text: las well as Van Nelle’s need to purchase and unify an appropriate site not being realized
label: Paragraph

text: until the fall of 1926, the year construction began on the factory buildings. The design for
label: Paragraph

text: the project was initiated by architect Michiel Brinkman (1873-1925), who died before its
label: Paragraph

text: completion, so the project was passed on to his young son, J.A. (Jan) Brinkman (1902-
label: Paragraph

text: 49), who, working with a more experienced architect, L.C. (Leendert Cornelis) van der
label: Paragraph

text: Vlugt (1894-1936), completed the project.
label: Paragraph

text: Key in the building’s innovative design was the active role of the factory owner, Kees
label: Paragraph

text: van der Leeuw, who was involved in the design of the complex, the construction
label: Paragraph

text: methods, and the spatial planning. As a Theosophist, he cared for his employees, which
label: Paragraph

text: was reflected in his concern to provide them with adequate daylight. This desire
label: Paragraph

text: paralleled the insight he gained from his 1925 travels to America, where he saw the
label: Paragraph

text: modern factories of Albert and Moritz Kahn, all noted for their attention to light. His
label: Paragraph

text: paternalistic view of the happy worker was similar to that of Henry Ford, and he was
label: Paragraph

text: keen to test the already proven methods of Taylorism in factory organization and
label: Paragraph

text: employee comfort. His knowledge of Walter Gropius’s newly completed Bauhaus
label: Paragraph

text: building in Dessau and Fagus factory in Germany inspired the transparent design of the
label: Paragraph

text: Van Nelle factory.
label: Paragraph

text: The main entrance with a gatehouse opens onto the complex by means of the sweeping
label: Paragraph

text: curved facade of the four-story administrative building for the offices and warehouses. A
label: Caption

text: bridge enclosed in glass and steel connects this building to the factory at the second floor,
label: Paragraph

text: creating the sense of the assembly lines in the flow of the buildings. The ground floor of
label: Paragraph

text: the office building is set back, with a column supporting the corner curve that sweeps
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the main rectangular structure. Along the curved facade are the managing
label: Paragraph

text: director’s office, meeting rooms, drafting offices, and sample rooms, and the open
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular volume has the combined general administrative offices and employee
label: Paragraph

text: cafeteria. This program and its manifestation demonstrate the architects’ interest in
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus principles.
label: Paragraph

text: The manufacturing buildings are sited adjacent to the Overschie River for easy
label: Paragraph

text: transport of goods. The final built scheme, only part of what was originally planned,
label: Paragraph

text: consists of a main factory block of different heights in one rectangular bar. The boiler
label: Paragraph

text: house was built separately for safety. An eight-story tobacco factory, a six-story coffee
label: Paragraph

text: factory, and a three-story tea factory were connected by glazed exterior stair towers. As a
label: Paragraph

text: vertically organized factory, typical of the early 20th-century type, the production line
label: Paragraph

text: moved from the upper to the lower floor, with the final product being transferred to the
label: Paragraph

text: warehouses via exterior conveyor belts in transparent bridges. The roof of the building is
label: Paragraph

text: capped with a circular glazed tearoom and viewing platform for visitors and staff.
label: Caption

text: As an early use of a glass-and-steel curtain wall, the arresting transparent facade is one
label: Paragraph

text: of the building’s genuinely iconic elements. The technical achievements in the design of
label: Paragraph

text: this glass curtain wall and its construction using machine-made parts led to the further
label: Paragraph

text: exploration of curtain-wall technologies for many other building types. The vertical
label: Paragraph

text: mullion elements are steel, sprayed with a zinc coating, and the horizontal spandrels are
label: Paragraph

text: steel sheets. The effect was of a continuous band of glass and metal in a new industrial
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic.
label: Paragraph

text: To keep the floors of the factory open for flexible use and to hold the heavy packing
label: Paragraph

text: machinery, engineer Jan Gerko Wiebenga (1886-1974), who often worked with Van der
label: Paragraph

text: Vlugt, designed an open system. Using a concrete frame, he placed octagonal concrete
label: Paragraph

text: mushroom columns on the interior’s perimeter within two rows of central columns
label: Caption

text: spaced in 5-by-5.70-meter modules in the tobacco factory and 5.70-by-5.70-meter
label: Paragraph

text: modules in the other two sections. This design created beamless concrete floor slabs that
label: Paragraph

text: were cantilevered beyond the perimeter columns and allowed space along the facade for
label: Paragraph

text: conduits and hallways. The polished concrete floor also contained cables and electric
label: Paragraph

text: conduits. The last phases of the project included a workers’ cafeteria, playing fields, store
label: Paragraph

text: blocks, and garages. Many years after the Van Nelle factory was constructed, Reyner
label: Paragraph

text: Banham noted that Mart Stam had played a more significant role in the design of the
label: Paragraph

text: building than previously considered (footnote in Reyner Banham, Theory Design in the
label: Paragraph

text: Machine Age, Architectural Press, London, 1960).
label: Caption

text: Van Nelle was seminal as part of the Dutch Nieuwe Bouwen, one of the many groups
label: Paragraph

text: of European architects who concentrated on the issues of technical progress and modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and who worked to improve the quality of housing and working
label: Paragraph

text: environments. While providing a decent working environment, the building allowed in
label: Paragraph

text: plenty of light and air and provided spaces for administrative staff and factory workers,
label: Paragraph

text: thus being pragmatic in its form to serve the function of the factory. Brinkman and Van
label: Paragraph

text: der Vlugt went on to design stores for Van Nelle, including housing and commercial
label: Paragraph

text: buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: VAN DE VELDE, HENRI 1863-1957
label: Title

text: Architect and interior designer, Belgium
label: Title

text: Henri van de Velde was a leading figure of Belgian Art Nouveau. He was born in
label: Paragraph

text: Antwerp into a family with strong interest in the arts. His father was a pharmacist and a
label: Paragraph

text: director of the local arts festival. After having contemplated a career as a composer, van
label: Paragraph

text: de Velde chose to become a painter instead. He studied at the Antwerp Art Academy
label: Paragraph

text: (1880-83) and at the atelier of Carolys Duran in Paris (1884-85). On his return from
label: Paragraph

text: Paris in 1886, van de Velde moved to the Belgian countryside, where he started to
label: Paragraph

text: develop a more holistic approach toward art and environment. In 1887, he discovered
label: Paragraph

text: pointillism, which allowed him to develop a more analytic approach to painting and form,
label: Paragraph

text: and from 1890 on, he started to broaden his artistic production to the realm of applied
label: Paragraph

text: arts, then to interior design, and finally to architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, van de Velde established himself as a theorist and propagandist. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1894, he started a series of lectures that promoted the revival of architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: decorative arts by combining the moral principles of the English Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: movement with the acceptance of machine production and social changes. These lectures
label: Paragraph

text: were published in 1901 under the title Die Renaissance im Kunstgewerbe (The
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance of Applied Arts). Van de Velde’s theoretical position was informed by
label: Paragraph

text: readings of William Morris, Friedrich Nietzsche, and Leo Tolstoy, in which art and
label: Paragraph

text: beauty were understood as a significant force for social advancement and cultural
label: Paragraph

text: renewal.
label: Paragraph

text: His first venture into architecture came with his own house, Bloemenwerf (1895-96),
label: Paragraph

text: in Uccle, near Brussels, where van de Velde, who had no architectural training,
label: Paragraph

text: collaborated with local craftsmen in a design that is somewhat a combination of a
label: Paragraph

text: traditional farmhouse and an urban villa. It was van de Velde’s first attempt to create a
label: Paragraph

text: total work of art in which furniture, wallpaper, and even his wife’s reform dress are
label: Paragraph

text: understood as an integral part of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Van de Velde’s reputation spread rapidly in the mid-1890s. The reception was
label: Paragraph

text: particularly favorable in Germany, and in 1895 the German art dealer Samuel Bing and
label: Paragraph

text: art critic Julius Meier-Graefe commissioned him to design three room interiors. First
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited in the Salon Art Nouveau in Paris the same year (and further in 1897 in
label: Paragraph

text: Dresden), these interiors, characterized by dynamic, curved forms, launched van de
label: Paragraph

text: Velde’s career as a furniture maker and interior designer while also launching a new
label: Paragraph

text: style: Art Nouveau. Bing and Meier-Graefe played an important part in van de Velde’s
label: Paragraph

text: career, the former becoming van de Velde’s dealer in Paris and the latter the first critic to
label: Paragraph

text: write about his work.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1900 Karl Emst Osthaus invited van de Velde to design the interiors for the
label: Paragraph

text: Folkwang Museum (1901-04) in Hagen, Germany. Only five years after the completion
label: Paragraph

text: of their own house, the family moved to Berlin. Contrary to his hopes, Berlin did not
label: Paragraph

text: offer a breakthrough for other larger projects, and in 1902 he accepted the offer of the
label: Paragraph

text: duke of Sachsen-Weimar to become the director of the Weimar Kunstgewerblicher
label: Paragraph

text: Institut. The duke also commissioned van de Velde to design the new school buildings:
label: Paragraph

text: the Kunstgewerbeschule (school of applied arts, 1904) and the Kunstschule (art school,
label: Paragraph

text: 1906), which became his first major architectural commissions. During his 12-year tenure
label: Paragraph

text: at Weimar, van de Velde embraced and inspired the future generation and developed a
label: Paragraph

text: successful architectural practice. The most notable works from this period include several
label: Paragraph

text: private villas for Weimar’s cultural elite; van de Velde’s own second house, called Hohe
label: Paragraph

text: Pappels (1908); a Tennis Club (1908) in Chemnitz; an interior design of the Nietzsche
label: Paragraph

text: Archive (1911); and most notably the theater for the 1914 Werkbund Exhibition in
label: Paragraph

text: Cologne.
label: Paragraph

text: Van de Velde’s resignation in 1914 came right after the 1914 Werkbund meeting in
label: Paragraph

text: Cologne, where he came under a fierce attack by Hermann Muthesius (1861-1927) for
label: Paragraph

text: representing a reactionary and outdated individualist position and resisting the need for
label: Paragraph

text: standardized production and typification. Van de Velde recommended Walter Gropius as
label: Paragraph

text: his successor, thus laying the foundation for the future Bauhaus.
label: Paragraph

text: This so-called Werkbund debate is indicative of why many other members of the first
label: Paragraph

text: generation of the Modern movement, such as Peter Behrens and Frank Lloyd Wright,
label: Paragraph

text: came to surpass van de Velde in their historical significance as pioneers of 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. However, van de Velde was one of the seminal thinkers around 1890, when
label: Paragraph

text: 19th-century architectural historicism came into a crisis. Informed by FLinfiihlung
label: Paragraph

text: (empathy) theory, van de Velde believed that line was the fundamental element of art.
label: Paragraph

text: According to his motto “a line is a force” (Kunstgewerbliche Laienpredigten, 1902), form
label: Paragraph

text: is an outcome of spontaneous, creative expression based on inner necessity, both
label: Paragraph

text: structural and emotional. This led to a design strategy based on the combination of
label: Paragraph

text: constructive and functional logic and dynamic formal expression.
label: Paragraph

text: Van de Velde’s life after leaving Weimar in 1917 was divided among Switzerland,
label: Paragraph

text: Holland, and Belgium, where in 1925-47 he held a professorship at the University of
label: Paragraph

text: Ghent. His mature work includes the Belgian Pavilions for the Paris (1937} and New
label: Paragraph

text: York (1939) World Exhibitions and the Rijksmuseum Krdller-Miiller (1937-54) in
label: Paragraph

text: Otterlo. After his retirement, van de Velde returned to Switzerland to write his memoirs,
label: Paragraph

text: Geschichte meines Lebens (1962; The Story of My Life), a wonderfully creative
label: Paragraph

text: testimony of his long and eventful life.
label: Paragraph

text: VENICE BIENNALE PAVILIONS
label: Title

text: Designed by various architects, 1895-1995 Venice, Italy
label: Caption

text: The Venice Biennale began in 1895 as an exhibition of international art held every two
label: Paragraph

text: years in the Castello Gardens at the southeast edge of Venice. Its pavilions, each
label: Paragraph

text: representing an individual country, perform as autonomous nationalistic objects and as a
label: Paragraph

text: strategically assembled collection of 20th-century architecture. As an evolving modernist
label: Paragraph

text: project, new national pavilions accrued between 1895 and 1995, with critical acts of
label: Paragraph

text: demolition, alteration, addition, refacading, restoration, and re-allocation. The Biennale
label: Paragraph

text: pavilions, as architectural representations for sovereign nations, can be categorized in
label: Paragraph

text: terms of Neoclassicism, vernacular nationalism, historicist nationalism, ideological
label: Paragraph

text: nationalism, and international modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Two fundamental definitions of the word describe these pavilions: “a summerhouse or
label: Paragraph

text: other decorative building in a garden” and “‘a temporary stand at an exhibition.” Although
label: Paragraph

text: often dismissed by critics as diminutive pleasure follies or curiosity collections for
label: Paragraph

text: tourists, they form a permanent extraurban community of 20th-century modernist icons—
label: Paragraph

text: exterior representational expositions encasing interior mutable exhibitions. Their status
label: Paragraph

text: oscillates between architectural ambassador and miniature museum for contemporary art.
label: Paragraph

text: The original Castello Gardens were constructed on reclaimed marsh between 1808 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1812 by Giannantonio Selva. In 1895, the Biennale was founded, and its first building,
label: Paragraph

text: the Palazzo dell’Esposizione (or Central Pavilion) by Enrico Trevisanato, contained 16
label: Caption

text: exhibition rooms around a domed space. The artists Marius de Maria and Bartolomeo
label: Caption

text: Bezzi designed its neoclassical facade.
label: Paragraph

text: Belgium provided the first national pavilion, or “house of art,” in 1907, a
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary Art Nouveau project by Léon Sneyers. Most of the early pavilions
label: Paragraph

text: displayed a neoclassical or vernacular character, derived from both museum and villa
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The British Pavilion (1909) by Edwin Rickards, built on a prominent hill,
label: Caption

text: quotes Andrea Palladio’s 16th-century villas and their modifications as Italianate English
label: Paragraph

text: country houses. A Venetian architect, Daniele Donghi, designed the Bavarian Pavilion in
label: Paragraph

text: the same year. Figural ornament was added to its neoclassical facade when it became the
label: Paragraph

text: German Pavilion in 1912. Géza Maroti’s Hungarian Pavilion (1909), a_ richly
label: Paragraph

text: ormmamented, transplanted vernacular building, was picturesquely sited off the main axis
label: Paragraph

text: of the Gardens. The neoclassical French Pavilion (1912) by the Venetian architect Fausto
label: Caption

text: Finzi joined Great Britain and Germany at the southeast corner of the Gardens. Ferdinand
label: Paragraph

text: Boberg designed the Sweden Pavilion in 1912, converted to the Holland Pavilion in
label: Paragraph

text: 1914. The Central (Italian) Pavilion received a concave Liberty-style facade by Guido
label: Caption

text: Cirilli in 1914. Just before the outbreak of World War I in 1914, the Russian Pavilion,
label: Paragraph

text: resembling a vernacular Byzantine church, was completed by Aleksej Scusev. In 1924,

text: Most pavilions built between World Wars | and II recirculated historicist imagery or
label: Paragraph

text: conveyed an ideological nationalism. Spain’s pavilion (1922) by Javier de Luque featured
label: Paragraph

text: a Churriguersque facade displaying its country’s 18th-century synthesis of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and sculpture. Uniquely, the Czechoslovakian architect Otakar Novotny designed his
label: Paragraph

text: country’s pavilion (1926) as an example of contemporary Czech Cubism. Delano and
label: Paragraph

text: Aldrich created the United States Pavilion (1930) as a neoclassical colonial version of
label: Paragraph

text: Thomas Jefferson’s neo-Palladian Monticello. Carl Brummer’s neoclassical Danish
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion (1932) occupied the middle of the Gardens. A Venetian Pavilion for decorative
label: Paragraph

text: arts (1932) by Brenno Del Giudice was built on the other side of the Canal di Sant’Elena,
label: Paragraph

text: with flanking pavilions for Poland and Switzerland. Its white, “stile-littorio classicism”
label: Paragraph

text: followed official state architecture under Mussolini. Identical pavilions for Romania and
label: Paragraph

text: Yugoslavia were added in 1938, stringing together autonomous nations in a unified
label: Paragraph

text: structure. Duilio Torres’s similar new facade for the Central (Italian) Pavilion (1932)
label: Caption

text: proclaimed itself “Italia” in large block letters. Josef Hoffman’s minimalist Austrian
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion (1934), north of the Venetian Pavilion, contained an open central arcade and
label: Paragraph

text: clerestory lighting. The masonry, neo-Byzantine Greek Pavilion (1934) by M.
label: Caption

text: Papandréou was sited axially opposite Austria’s pavilion.
label: Paragraph

text: Under Hitler, Germany’s pavilion was demolished in 1938 and replaced by a
label: Paragraph

text: monumental “meta-neo-classical” structure by Ernst Haiger. After Germany invaded
label: Paragraph

text: Austria, Czechoslovakia, Poland, Romania, Hungary, and Yugoslavia, their pavilions
label: Paragraph

text: were closed. Italy displayed military imagery in the British, French, and United States
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilions in 1942.
label: Paragraph

text: After World War II, the Biennale reopened in 1948. The Venetian architect Virgilio
label: Paragraph

text: Vallot replaced the facade of the Belgium Pavilion that year. Carlo Scarpa designed
label: Caption

text: several projects for the Biennale, beginning in 1950 with the triangular/trapezoidal Book
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion near the Italian Pavilion portico. This pavillion, Scarpa’s leaflike Ticket Office
label: Paragraph

text: (1952), and his Italian Pavilion courtyard (1952) have been destroyed. Significantly, the
label: Paragraph

text: first post-World War II new pavilion was for Israel (1952), an “international modern”
label: Paragraph

text: trapezoidal structure by the Tel Aviv architect Zeev Rechter. Bruno Giacometti designed
label: Caption

text: Switzerland’s pavilion (1952), a complex assemblage of volumes, sited near the Gardens
label: Paragraph

text: entry. Egypt occupied the former Swiss Pavilion. The Spanish Pavilion was stripped of
label: Paragraph

text: its ornament and received a simpler masonry facade by Joaquin Vaquero Palacios in
label: Paragraph

text: 1952. Carlo Scarpa’s innovative Venezuelan Pavilion (1954-56), wedged between those
label: Paragraph

text: of Switzerland and the Soviet Union, referred to traditional Japanese architecture and the
label: Paragraph

text: work of Frank Lloyd Wright and Ludwig Mies van der Rohe. In 1954, Gerrit Rietveld
label: Paragraph

text: designed a new “late De Stijl” Dutch Pavilion, replacing the previous one. Alvar Aalto’s
label: Caption

text: wedge-shaped Finnish Pavilion (1956) was similar to Scarpa’s Book Pavilion. Painted
label: Paragraph

text: Finnish blue and white, it was prefabricated and transported to the site. The Le Corbusian
label: Paragraph

text: Japan Pavilion (1956) by Takamasa Yoshizaka is a concrete box on four massive
label: Paragraph

text: supports with an Oriental garden on the sloping land below. Denmark’s pavilion was
label: Paragraph

text: extended with a series of brick boxes by Peter Koch in 1958, and Uruguay built a simple
label: Paragraph

text: new pavilion in the same year. The Italian architects BBPR erected the octagonal
label: Paragraph

text: Canadian Pavilion (1958) around two existing trees. Several trees were also retained
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch Pavilion, by Gerrit Rietveld, Venice Biennale (1954)

label: Paragraph

text: 69. Little architectural work took place at the Biennale Gardens until the metal-clad,
label: Caption

text: domestic-scaled Australian Pavilion (1988) was built by Philip Cox along the Gardens
label: Paragraph

text: canal. Slipped within an allée near the Gardens entry, James Stirling and Michael Wilford
label: Caption

text: produced the Book Pavilion, or “bookship,” in 1991. In 1995, Josef Hoffman’s Austrian
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion was significantly altered by the Viennese architects Coop Himmelb(l)au. They
label: Paragraph

text: infiltrated the historic pavilion with an assemblage of columns, a roof, and a screen. Seok
label: Paragraph

text: Chul Kim’s Korean Pavilion (1995) acknowledges the rising titles by lifting itself up on

label: Paragraph

text: common to both Venice and Korea and a recognition of the ephemeral condition of the
label: Paragraph

text: Biennale. Many of the pavilions and the Gardens themselves are in poor condition, and as
label: Paragraph

text: Venice continues to be inundated by the lagoon, this unique collection of 20th-century
label: Paragraph

text: architecture requires preservation and the ability to evolve. The Venice Biennale
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilions serve collectively as a connotative inventory of 20th-century modernism.

text: VENTURI, ROBERT 1925
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: Robert Venturi is the principal partner of Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates with
label: Paragraph

text: Denise Scott Brown, Steven Izenour, and David Vaughn. He is best known for his
label: Paragraph

text: architectural ideas outlined in his two influential books, Complexity and Contradiction in
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture (1966) and Learning from Las Vegas (1972), written with Scott Brown and
label: Paragraph

text: Izenour. Both texts critique the often dogmatic and narrow design agenda of modernist
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and have been viewed as an antidote to the polemics of modernist architects
label: Paragraph

text: such as Adolf Loos, who famously wrote that “ornament is crime,” and Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: who authored the classic manifesto Towards a New Architecture (1923). Directing 20th-
label: Paragraph

text: century architects to study the commercial landscape of Main Street and the roadside as
label: Paragraph

text: well as the classical tradition, Venturi and Scott Brown embrace historicism, decoration,
label: Paragraph

text: language, and vernacular symbols. Learning from Las Vegas in particular argued for the
label: Paragraph

text: celebration of both “high” and “low” architecture of the past, from the richness of
label: Paragraph

text: classical Rome to the messiness of the commercial strip. Its emphasis on visual
label: Paragraph

text: ambiguity, contradiction, dialectic, context, and complexity led to designs that were full
label: Paragraph

text: of wit and rich in connotations. Venturi’s residential architecture of the 1960s expressed
label: Paragraph

text: his interest in the vernacular symbols and historical allusions outlined in Complexity and
label: Paragraph

text: Contradiction. The Guild House (1960), a senior citizens apartment complex in
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, referenced the classicism of Andrea Palladio in the design of
label: Paragraph

text: its facade and pointed to the architecture of commerce with its prominent sign above the
label: Paragraph

text: entry. The Vanna Venturi House (1962) in Chestnut Hill, Pennsylvania, borrowed from
label: Caption

text: the forms of the American saltbox (shingle style) and emphasized axial symmetry.
label: Paragraph

text: The humorous and historical came together in Venturi’s creation of Benjamin
label: Paragraph

text: Franklin’s “house” and museum (1973-76) in Independence National Historical Park in
label: Caption

text: Philadelphia. Rather than reconstructing the long-demolished home of Franklin, Venturi
label: Paragraph

text: and partners designed a vividly colored steel-frame outline of the house, which had been
label: Paragraph

text: described by Franklin in letters to his wife, and placed the museum in the ground below.
label: Paragraph

text: The firm has long had an interest in urban design, reflecting its focus on the American
label: Paragraph

text: landscape. Planning work has included the South Street Rehabilitation Plan (1970) for
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia and the Pennsylvania Avenue Project (1978-79) for Washington, D.C.
label: Caption

text: Other projects have included industrial design and furniture design as well as
label: Paragraph

text: exhibitions. “Signs of Life: Symbols in the American City” at the Renwick Gallery in
label: Caption

text: Washington, D.C. (1976) was an exhibit of historical and contemporary signs. The
label: Paragraph

text: display celebrated the American bicentennial by presenting the rich variety of signage
label: Paragraph

text: found in the United States. Such work remained consistent with the firm’s appreciation of
label: Paragraph

text: the vernacular and illustrated how Venturi and his partners have refused to limit the
label: Paragraph

text: application of their ideas to one field.
label: Paragraph

text: After 1980 Venturi received a number of large commissions. Such projects, while
label: Paragraph

text: remaining true to the original theories of the firm, have tended toward the practical, thus
label: Paragraph

text: helping shed Venturi’s reputation for superficial cleverness. Important commissions for
label: Paragraph

text: universities and museums evidence the office’s wider acceptance. Princeton University
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned three buildings, including Wu Hall (1983), which referenced the style of
label: Paragraph

text: English manor houses, thus complementing the campus’s eclectic mix of buildings. The
label: Paragraph

text: Sainsbury Wing (1991) of the National Gallery in London alluded to the adjacent
label: Paragraph

text: classical building yet reconfigured the purist style, referencing Victorian train sheds in
label: Paragraph

text: the interior. Recent designs continued to reflect the firm’s commitment to historical styles
label: Paragraph

text: and vernacular symbols. The Seattle Art Museum (1991) contained sensitive gallery
label: Paragraph

text: spaces as well as massive incised lettering along the top of the limestone exterior. The
label: Paragraph

text: Mielparque Nikko Kirifuri Resort (1997) in Nikko, Japan, reflects the traditional rural
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of Japan.
label: Paragraph

text: The global influence of Venturi and his partner Denise Scott Brown has been widely
label: Paragraph

text: recognized through extensive writing, teaching, and lecturing. Consistent with an
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic of contradiction, Venturi’s works deal with both the formal and theoretical
label: Paragraph

text: intersections of modernism and Postmodernism by engaging with the conditions of
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary society, construction, and culture.
label: Paragraph

text: VERNACULAR ARCHITECTURE
label: Title

text: Although it had been in use among specialists for well over a century, the term
label: Paragraph

text: “vernacular architecture” became widely accepted only with its adoption in 1976 by the
label: Paragraph

text: International Council on Monuments and Sites (ICOMOS). Other terms persist, such as
label: Paragraph

text: “traditional,” “rural,” “regional,” “local,” “peasant,” “folk,” and “indigenous”
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, serving collectively to identify the field of building encompassed by the
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular. Its original meaning (from the Latin), “the language of the people,” is
label: Paragraph

text: applicable to architecture as an extension of the commonly employed idea of
label: Paragraph

text: “architecture as language,” in which styles of design are analogous to grammar or syntax.
label: Paragraph

text: “Arquitectura popular,” used in both Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries,
label: Paragraph

text: corresponds to the increasingly prevalent definition of the vernacular as “the architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of, and by, the people.” With the wider acceptance of the term “vernacular architecture,”
label: Paragraph

text: a distinction is made between buildings that are self-built or community built and used
label: Paragraph

text: and those that are designed for the people, such as fast-food outlets, chain stores, filling
label: Paragraph

text: stations, and strip malls. Including mobile homes, these latter types, as professionally
label: Paragraph

text: designed structures for general use, are regarded as popular architecture. As such, they
label: Paragraph

text: are distinguished from the vernacular, which broadly corresponds to the building
label: Paragraph

text: traditions depicted in Bernard Rudofsky’s exhibition and catalog Architecture without
label: Paragraph

text: Architects (1964) at the Museum of Modern Art, New York. The exhibition emphasized
label: Paragraph

text: the aesthetic merits of vernacular traditions from nearly 30 countries that had been an
label: Paragraph

text: inspiration for many architects in the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: As early as 1910, Frank Lloyd Wright applauded “folk building[s] growing in response
label: Paragraph

text: to actual needs, fitted into environment by people who knew no better than to fit them to
label: Paragraph

text: it with native feeling,” which were “for us better worth study than all the highly self-
label: Paragraph

text: conscious academic attempts at the beautiful throughout all Europe” (see Gutheim,
label: Paragraph

text: 1941). A year later, Le Corbusier was sketching the peasant houses of Serbia and
label: Paragraph

text: Bulgaria and praising “the konak, the Turkish wooden house,... an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: masterpiece.” He was profoundly drawn to the vernacular buildings of the Greek islands
label: Paragraph

text: and the Algerian M’Zab, and many architects followed his pursuit of purity and function
label: Paragraph

text: in the “white” villages of the Mediterranean. Independently, Alvar Aalto in Finland,
label: Paragraph

text: Michel de Klerk in the Netherlands, and later Luis Barragan in Mexico were among the
label: Paragraph

text: many architects who drew on regional building for inspiration. In such cases, the
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular was a source of stimulation for some and a justification of their design
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic for others. Simplicity of form and structure and the moral value of the
label: Paragraph

text: Miesinspired truth to materials and economy of means were increasingly established as
label: Paragraph

text: the modernist architecture par excellence. Following the legacy of Adolf Loos’s essay
label: Paragraph

text: “Ornament and Crime” (1908), vernacular traditions that employed decoration were
label: Paragraph

text: generally disregarded in favor of reductivism. Vernacular examples offered less to
label: Paragraph

text: architects who were seeking models of varied spatial experience, but their “fitness for
label: Paragraph

text: purpose” and, above all, their functionality were seen as paradigms of modern approaches
label: Paragraph

text: to architectural design.
label: Paragraph

text: Undoubtedly, all these qualities could be seen in a wide range of vernacular buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: from farmhouses to workshops, granaries to cow barns, and lime kilns to windmills that
label: Paragraph

text: not only helped clarify design objectives in the minds of many architects but also served
label: Paragraph

text: to reinforce modernist principles. However, although some followed Wright’s advice to
label: Paragraph

text: study “folk building,” his somewhat patronizing view of its builders was echoed by many
label: Paragraph

text: architects and writers who referred to the “spontaneous,” “unconscious,” or “intuitive”
label: Paragraph

text: building processes. Professional architects studied the vernacular more for their own
label: Paragraph

text: benefit than for any that might accrue for the survival or protection of the traditions
label: Paragraph

text: themselves, which in the years following World War II were threatened. The ravages of
label: Paragraph

text: war, industrialization of building processes, need for mass housing, and universal
label: Paragraph

text: adoption of Le Corbusian “tower blocks” and “slab blocks” marked the international
label: Paragraph

text: success of modernism and, in many instances, the imminent demise of many vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: traditions.
label: Paragraph

text: Decline in the vernacular in many Western countries had been evident since the
label: Paragraph

text: beginning of the 20th century. Largely through voluntary effort, examples of folk and
label: Paragraph

text: traditional building were salvaged in many countries and displayed in open-air
label: Paragraph

text: (Openlucht or Freilicht) museums, the earliest example being the Skansen in Sweden
label: Paragraph

text: (1897), followed by museums in Maihaugen, Norway; Seurasaari, Finland; Amhem,
label: Paragraph

text: Holland; and Lyngby, Denmark. Other policies of protection, such as in situ
label: Paragraph

text: conservation, relocation, rebuilding, reconstruction, and environmental rehabilitation,
label: Title

text: were implemented, exemplified in the United States in Old Deerfield; Colonial
label: Paragraph

text: Williamsburg; the Henry Ford Museum and Greenfield Village in Dearborn, Michigan;
label: Paragraph

text: Old Sturbridge Village, Massachusetts; Cades Cove, Tennessee; and many other sites.
label: Paragraph

text: In Europe, the open-air-museum movement resulted in many thousands of buildings
label: Paragraph

text: being saved and open to the public in literally hundreds of locations in Scandinavian and
label: Paragraph

text: Central European countries. Only a few museums opened in Germany and Britain, and
label: Paragraph

text: none, until the 1980s, opened in Spain, France, or Italy. Although such enterprises did
label: Paragraph

text: much to conserve specific vernacular buildings, the unfurnished interiors could appear
label: Paragraph

text: bleak. Many curators solved this problem by depicting a historic period with appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: artifacts and furniture, or with reenactments of daily life in the form of dioramas. Such
label: Paragraph

text: methods were instructive, if nostalgic, ensuring the popular success of these museums but
label: Paragraph

text: associating the vernacular only with past ways of life, having little relevance to the
label: Paragraph

text: present or the future. Unfortunately, in most European countries, relatively little
label: Paragraph

text: continuity of vernacular building was seen in the second half of the 20th century, as the
label: Paragraph

text: imperative lessened and skills declined in the face of the expansion of the city suburbs
label: Paragraph

text: and high-rise developments and the industrializing of building components and
label: Paragraph

text: construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Globalization, it might seem, is incompatible with the vernacular, and traditional
label: Paragraph

text: building of and by the people seems scarce. However, this is not the case. At the middle
label: Paragraph

text: of the 20th century, the world’s population was estimated at 3.5 billion; by the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: century, the population had almost doubled to six billion. Attempts at urban housing
label: Paragraph

text: schemes have failed to make a significant impression on the demand for dwellings, as the
label: Paragraph

text: everexpanding bustees, favelas, barriadas, bidonvilles, gecekondu, and other peri-urban
label: Paragraph

text: squatter settlements in the industrially developing world dramatically demonstrate. Built
label: Paragraph

text: of scrap materials and frequently illegal, they are the desperate measures taken by
label: Paragraph

text: migrants to the cities; however, lacking in expression of skills or tradition and meeting no
label: Paragraph

text: other needs beyond crude and minimal shelter, they are not vernacular.
label: Paragraph

text: Of the world’s six billion people, a third live in the People’s Republic of China, and
label: Paragraph

text: another billion on the Indian subcontinent. In these countries, housing is mainly
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular, as it is in Indonesia and Southeast Asia and in much of Africa. The
label: Paragraph

text: Earth-molded, nontrabeated structures, including granary, shade shelter, and
label: Paragraph

text: living unit from Gurunsi culture, northern Ghana
label: Caption

text: © Paul Oliver
label: Title

text: growth in population has been accommodated largely through the absorption of families
label: Paragraph

text: within existing unmodified structures and through the lateral or vertical extension of
label: Paragraph

text: others. New building to traditional models has been not only of dwellings but also of
label: Paragraph

text: innumerable stores, workshops, and religious buildings. It is unknown how many
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular buildings are extant worldwide, whether old and still in use or of recent date
label: Paragraph

text: and purpose built. Estimates (that might well be conservative) of around 800 million are
label: Paragraph

text: cited, representing over 90 percent of the total building stock.
label: Paragraph

text: To a great extent, these vernacular traditions have been overlooked by architects and
label: Paragraph

text: architectural historians. Those histories that acknowledge that architecture is not solely a
label: Paragraph

text: European and American phenomenon pay attention principally to monumental temples,
label: Paragraph

text: pagodas, mosques, and palaces, with some reference to colonial or administrative
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, commercial structures, airports, and stadiums in the International Style of the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century. Lack of recognition has served as a disincentive to do original research in
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular architecture; this was left to the enthusiasm of concerned architects and the
label: Paragraph

text: personal motivations of devoted amateurs.
label: Paragraph

text: Serious recording of vernacular buildings was undertaken in Germany in the late 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century, in the 1900s by English architects, and more widely in Europe and the United
label: Paragraph

text: States with the growth of the open-air museums. American research was boosted in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s by the Historic American Buildings Survey (HABS), and subsequently, in France,
label: Paragraph

text: Portugal, and Romania, intensive national surveys were undertaken, recording the state o
label: Paragraph

text: the vernacular on a provincial basis. Later, such surveys were conducted in Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: although often only with institutional support. Methodologically, they followe
label: Paragraph

text: conventional architectural practices, with plans, elevations, sections, and details being
label: Paragraph

text: drawn, often with supporting photographic record and sometimes with historical
label: Paragraph

text: documentation. Frequently, as in France and the United States, a typological approach
label: Paragraph

text: was taken, although the concept of “type” was for some the identification of function and
label: Paragraph

text: for others the classification of features, such as plan or roof form.
label: Paragraph

text: As early as 1882, British architect W.Simpson published a report on the architecture o
label: Paragraph

text: the Himalayas, prompting regional officials of the Western colonial powers to
label: Paragraph

text: occasionally examine the indigenous buildings in their territories. Lacking any agreed
label: Paragraph

text: program, objectives, or coordination of research, such studies varied greatly in quality
label: Paragraph

text: and method and were widely dispersed. A concerted study of the vernacular traditions o
label: Paragraph

text: French Cameroun by architectural students of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts, published in
label: Paragraph

text: 1952, marked a significant advance in research in non-Western countries. Preparation o:
label: Paragraph

text: materials, building construction methods, and domestic space use were examined and
label: Paragraph

text: recorded. Preoccupations with typologies or historic derivation were shown to be largely
label: Paragraph

text: irrelevant in such contexts, where the respective economies, material resources, and
label: Paragraph

text: available technologies were important in the determination of their building forms.
label: Paragraph

text: In the ensuing years, a number of important studies were made of specific vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: traditions in parts of Asia, sub-Saharan Africa, the Middle East, North America, and to a
label: Paragraph

text: lesser extent, Latin America. Often these were local, and researchers had problems
label: Paragraph

text: developing appropriate methods for comparative studies. Historical resources such as
label: Paragraph

text: wills, deeds, or parish records used in European research were seldom available, and
label: Paragraph

text: conventional orthographic techniques were unsuitable for recording cave dwellings, tents,
label: Paragraph

text: or molded, nontrabeated structures. Comparison of building traditions or the
label: Paragraph

text: identification of the distribution or diffusion of structural systems or details was hindered
label: Paragraph

text: by lacunae in research and the lack of comprehensive reference works. Many former
label: Paragraph

text: studies, although useful in indicating constancy or change in buildings, were superficial
label: Paragraph

text: visual records. Researchers encountered techniques of, for example, earth construction,
label: Paragraph

text: which previously had not been subject to scrutiny; craft skills in the working of different
label: Paragraph

text: kinds of stone, timbers, palms, and fibrous plant materials involved tools and methods of
label: Paragraph

text: assembly, jointing, and cladding that were largely unclassified or undocumented.
label: Paragraph

text: Classification of building forms seemed necessary so that the vast range of vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: structures could be comprehended. From the domes of the Zulu (southern Africa) to the
label: Paragraph

text: ring-walled multiple dwellings of the Keijia (southeastern China), they demonstrated
label: Paragraph

text: both the persistence of systems transmitted over generations and the variety to be found
label: Paragraph

text: within every tradition. Although the fundamental rectangular prism of trabeated
label: Paragraph

text: structures and mass-walled stone and adobe and brick structures was widespread, so too
label: Paragraph

text: were the rondavels, or cylindrical units, whose diversity was evident in their compound
label: Paragraph

text: clusters. Roof forms displayed even greater variety, with gabled, hipped, and half-hipped
label: Paragraph

text: roofs of diverse pitches evident throughout Europe, from Scotland to Moldavia. Upswept
label: Paragraph

text: gables that were dispersed throughout insular Southeast Asia, from the Batak of Sumatra
label: Paragraph

text: to the great saddle roofs of the Toraja of Celebes, were perceived as characteristic of
label: Paragraph

text: indigenous “styles.”
label: Paragraph

text: Although the technical problems were not inconsiderable, vernacular studies revealed
label: Paragraph

text: indigenous methods of climate modification, such as the Egyptian mashrabivah, or
label: Paragraph

text: balconied window screens, and the “wind scoops,” found in hot, arid climates in the
label: Paragraph

text: Middle East, that transmit cool air to rooms. Hot and humid or monsoon climates require
label: Paragraph

text: cross ventilation and protection from seasonal precipitation, whereas hurricanes
label: Paragraph

text: necessitate shallow roof pitches and light construction. In temperate climates, protection
label: Paragraph

text: is required against heavy rainfall and strong winds, whereas insulation and safeguards
label: Paragraph

text: against snow loading are necessary in cold conditions. Such means of adaptation led to
label: Paragraph

text: theories of climatic determinism, with broad principles being defined for settlement
label: Paragraph

text: forms and building types in certain environments, including desert, savanna, forest,
label: Paragraph

text: coastal, and insular locations. Exceptions arising from the demands of different
label: Paragraph

text: economies, whether nomadic or sedentary, pastoral or agricultural, emphasized, as Forde
label: Paragraph

text: had done in the 1930s, the relationship among society, economy, and habitat.
label: Paragraph

text: The publication in 1969 of House Form and Culture by Amos Rapoport and of the
label: Paragraph

text: edited collection of case studies Shelter and Society marked a new stage in vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: studies. Although anthropologists such as Lewis H.Morgan and Victor Mindeleff in their
label: Paragraph

text: researches among Native American tribes in the 1880s had demonstrated the significance
label: Paragraph

text: of culture in defining building form, their work had been neglected. Now the cultural and
label: Paragraph

text: anthropological aspects of building were given as much attention as their structural and
label: Paragraph

text: architectural characteristics. The writings of anthropologists such as Griaule on the
label: Paragraph

text: Dogon (Mali) and Bourdier on the Kabyle (Algeria), among many others, revealed the
label: Paragraph

text: importance of kinship, social structures, belief systems, ritual, and symbolism in the
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular architecture of cultures the world over. Features formerly regarded as styles
label: Paragraph

text: were now revealed as signifiers of values and expressions of collective identity and were
label: Paragraph

text: elucidated in, for example, the work of Hugh-Jones (Amazonia), Nabokov and Easton
label: Paragraph

text: (Native America), and Bourdier and Minh-ha (West Africa).
label: Paragraph

text: Anthropologists brought a cultural awareness to the study of vernacular but were
label: Paragraph

text: seldom familiar with building principles and processes. The need for interdisciplinary
label: Paragraph

text: dialogue and research inspired in the 1980s the biennial “Built Form and Culture
label: Paragraph

text: Research” conferences alternating with those of the International Association for the
label: Paragraph

text: Study of Traditional Environments ([ASTE). Both emanated from the United States, but
label: Paragraph

text: IASTE meetings were also held in Europe and North Africa. Both published proceedings,
label: Paragraph

text: and books on local vernacular architecture proliferated. Some of these were written by
label: Paragraph

text: non-Western authors, with the publications of the Aga Khan Award for Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (AKAA) providing a forum for Islamic and development studies.
label: Paragraph

text: For some years, there had been a growing awareness of the vernacular on the part of
label: Paragraph

text: architects in the Middle East and Asia. Several endeavored to relate their buildings to
label: Paragraph

text: local traditions, notably the Egyptian architect Hassan Fathy, whose village of New
label: Paragraph

text: Gourna in West Luxor used the vault construction skills of Sudanese mud builders. In
label: Paragraph

text: Turkey, Sedad Hakki Eldem interpreted traditional models. More widely recognized was
label: Paragraph

text: the work of the Indian architects Charles Correa and Balkrishna Doshi, whose large-scale
label: Paragraph

text: projects were modernist in approach but who also designed more modest projects
label: Paragraph

text: compatible with the local vernacular. Geoffrey Bawa in Sri Lanka, Robi Sularto in
label: Paragraph

text: Indonesia, and Andre Ravereau in Africa were among the architects who respected
label: Paragraph

text: regional traditions.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the extent of research, the lack of informed awareness among architects and
label: Paragraph

text: their clients, whether public or private, of the significance of vernacular traditions has led
label: Paragraph

text: to disparagement, disregard, and often demolition. By the late 1980s, the need for a
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive reference work that could inform both anthropologists and architects and
label: Paragraph

text: professionals and politicians became increasingly apparent. A ten-year project led
label: Paragraph

text: eventually to the publication in 1997 of the Encyclopedia of Vernacular Architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: the World, to which researchers from more than 80 countries contributed. Organized on a
label: Paragraph

text: cultural rather than a national basis, it was unprecedented in bringing together research on
label: Paragraph

text: the vernacular architecture and its cultural contexts extant on all continents in the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century. Principles of building with available resources, the nature of craft skills,
label: Paragraph

text: environmental conditions and responses, and economies and their bear-ing on building
label: Title

text: functions, meaning, symbolism, and motifs are considered in relation to societal systems
label: Paragraph

text: and building needs. However, attention is drawn to the deficiencies of certain vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: traditions with regard to services, sanitation, and health.
label: Paragraph

text: Much remains to be done, but the question of why such work should be undertaken and
label: Paragraph

text: acted on must be addressed. Vernacular architecture not only accounted for the vast
label: Paragraph

text: majority of all buildings up to the 1950s but also met immense housing demands as the
label: Paragraph

text: world population doubled in the second half of the 20th century. Yet this achievement
label: Paragraph

text: has never been measured, and neither has the effort in human endeavor or the use of
label: Paragraph

text: available or renewable resources in building or land. By comparison, officially
label: Paragraph

text: sanctioned housing, whether government promoted or commercially developed, is
label: Paragraph

text: minimal in its effect and produced at costs that would be beyond the capacity of most
label: Paragraph

text: national economies in attempting to meet the demands of the next half century. Although
label: Paragraph

text: neither acknowledged nor budgeted, vernacular architecture will be essential to meet the
label: Paragraph

text: housing needs of the projected further doubling of the population. Recognizing this and
label: Paragraph

text: providing adequate support in services while planning the economic survival of rural
label: Paragraph

text: communities, developing nations could ensure that appropriate housing can be achieved
label: Paragraph

text: through vernacular means, as it has been in the past.
label: Paragraph
