text: VESNIN, ALEXANDER, LEONID VESNIN,
label: Title

text: AND VIKTOR VESNIN
label: Title

text: Architects, Russia
label: Title

text: Among the many architects whose work adhered to the principles of Constructivism,
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps the most stalwart and productive proponents of the movement were the Vesnin
label: Paragraph

text: brothers: Leonid (1880-1933), Viktor (1882-1950), and Alexander (1883-1959), all of
label: Paragraph

text: whom were raised in the town of lurevets on the Volga River.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the brothers went to St. Petersburg at the beginning of the century for their
label: Paragraph

text: professional education (Leonid graduated from the architectural program at the Academy
label: Paragraph

text: of Arts in 1909 and Viktor and Alexander from the Institute of Civil Engineering in
label: Paragraph

text: 1912), their careers were largely connected with Moscow both before and after their
label: Paragraph

text: graduation. For example, in 1905-07 they worked as assistants to such leading Moscow
label: Paragraph

text: proponents of the neoclassical revival as Ilarion Ivanov-Schitz and Roman Klein, and in
label: Paragraph

text: 1909 Leonid worked with the artist V.A. Simonov in designing a large Arts and Crafts-
label: Paragraph

text: style house for V.A. Nosenkov in the Moscow suburbs. Alexander, the most artistically
label: Paragraph

text: gifted of the three, worked in Vladimir Tatlin’s studio between 1912 and 1914 and also
label: Paragraph

text: revealed a considerable talent as a stage designer.
label: Paragraph

text: During the material restrictions of the early postrevolutionary years, the theater stage
label: Paragraph

text: provided the Vesnins—Alexander in particular—with a means for exploring methods of
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic construction in space, under the obvious influence of Tatlin. The most
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable product of this phase was Alexander Vesnin’s set design in 1922 for
label: Paragraph

text: Alexander Tairov’s production of The Man Who Was Thursday at the Moscow Chamber
label: Caption

text: (Kamernyi) Theater. With its intersecting planes and ramps, the set not only emphasized
label: Paragraph

text: the dynamic of the actors’ motion but also bridged the gap between the theoretical
label: Paragraph

text: constructions of artists such as El Lissitzky, Kazimir Malevich, and Antoine Pevsner and
label: Paragraph

text: the practical design of large structures.
label: Paragraph

text: The Vesnins’ progression from dynamic, avant-garde set constructions to the much
label: Paragraph

text: larger scale of major architectural projects was soon evident in their 1923 design for the
label: Paragraph

text: Palace of Labor competition. Although their submission was awarded only third prize, it
label: Paragraph

text: served as a programmatic statement in the development of a Constructivist aesthetic,
label: Paragraph

text: combining both monumentality and severe functionalism in the massing of simple
label: Paragraph

text: geometric shapes in a complex balance. The center of the plan was the oval meeting hall
label: Paragraph

text: in the form of an amphitheater, 75 by 67 meters in size. The array of radio masts and
label: Paragraph

text: docking ports for airships around the top was functionally justified despite its futuristic
label: Paragraph

text: appearance in the context of a war-ravaged country reestablishing a modicum of civilized
label: Paragraph

text: existence.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1925 Alexander and Viktor Vesnin, together with Moisei Ginzburg, founded the
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist organization OSA (Organization of Contemporary Architecture). Indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: the preceding year Alexander had designed the book jacket for Ginzburg’s programmatic
label: Paragraph

text: work Style and Epoch. With the quickening tempo of state construction during the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s, all three brothers were actively engaged in projects extending from the Caucasus
label: Paragraph

text: to the colossal hydroelectric dam across the Dnieper River, the DneproGES, designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Viktor Vesnin in collaboration with Nikolai Kolli and others. Although each brother
label: Paragraph

text: maintained a separate, distinct practice, they are best known for the projects they did
label: Paragraph

text: together.
label: Paragraph

text: The brief flourishing of private commerce toward the end of the New Economic Policy
label: Title

text: (NEP) period is represented in the Vesnins’ design of the Mostorg retail department store
label: Paragraph

text: (1927-29) in central Moscow. Located on an awkward trapezoidal lot in the Krasnaia
label: Caption

text: Presnia working-class district, the store, with its double-glazed facade framed by a
label: Paragraph

text: ferroconcrete structure, appeared strikingly modern when first constructed in its context
label: Paragraph

text: of 19th-century brick buildings. It has since suffered by the addition of another story and
label: Paragraph

text: by a lack of proper maintenance.
label: Paragraph

text: Like other major architects of the late 1920s, the Vesnins were much concerned with
label: Paragraph

text: the creation of institutions for social communication. One of the most modernistic of such
label: Paragraph

text: designs—and one of the last Constructivist buildings in Moscow—was the club for the
label: Paragraph

text: Society of Tsarist Political Prisoners, begun in 1931. In addition to meeting rooms and a
label: Paragraph

text: theater hall, the extensive complex was to contain a museum. In 1934, however, the
label: Paragraph

text: society was disbanded (an ominous prelude to the Stalinist purges, which would create an
label: Paragraph

text: altogether new society of political prisoners), and the larger plans for a museum were
label: Paragraph

text: eliminated. Even in this truncated and deformed version, the harmony of the pure,
label: Paragraph

text: undecorated volumetric forms is evident and reflects, if coincidentally, some of the oldest
label: Paragraph

text: formal traditions in Russian architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The culminating project in the Vesnins’ Constructivist oeuvre was an outgrowth of the
label: Paragraph

text: concept of the workers’ club. In order to serve the social needs of the Proletarian district,
label: Paragraph

text: which contained an automobile factory and workers’ settlement in southeast Moscow, the
label: Paragraph

text: Vesnins designed a large complex of three buildings. The site overlooked the Moscow
label: Paragraph

text: River and was adjacent to the Simonov Monastery, part of whose walls were razed in the
label: Paragraph

text: course of constructing the project. Yet the largest part of the ensemble, a theater with a
label: Paragraph

text: circular hall designed to seat 4000, was never built, nor was the projected sports building.
label: Paragraph

text: The central element, however—the club building itself—was built between 1931 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1937. This period was marred by the death of Leonid in 1933 and by the brothers’
label: Paragraph

text: increasing need to defend their Constructivist designs.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, the Vesnins persevered to a remarkable degree, bending to the system
label: Paragraph

text: without rejecting the work that stood at the center of the Constructivist movement. In
label: Paragraph

text: their writings it is clear that Viktor and Alexander Vesnin considered the Proletarian
label: Paragraph

text: Region Club one of their most significant works, not only for its union of functions—a
label: Paragraph

text: 1000-seat theater, ballroom, meeting halls, and exhibition space—but also for the way in
label: Paragraph

text: which form followed function and space flowed effortlessly from one component to
label: Paragraph

text: another.
label: Paragraph

text: The manner in which the design combined an acute aesthetic sensibility with function
label: Paragraph

text: was particularly important at a time when Constructivism was under attack for its
label: Paragraph

text: purported inability to recognize the people’s aesthetic needs. In the club building, the
label: Paragraph

text: Vesnins’ fluency was reflected on the exterior in such details as the contours of the large
label: Paragraph

text: rounded bay window over the entrance to the auditorium and a semicircular conservatory
label: Caption

text: extending from the river facade. The club also included a small astronomy observatory,
label: Paragraph

text: which created an additional visual component for the upper structure. Unfortunately, the
label: Paragraph

text: interior of the building has been considerably modified since the Vesnins’ original
label: Paragraph

text: design, but the structure itself is still relatively well maintained.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1935 the Vesnin brothers attempted a reply to the growing retrospectivist tendency
label: Paragraph

text: in Stalinist architecture by stating that “the canonization of an old form, however
label: Paragraph

text: excellent, is a brake on the development of content.” At the same time, Viktor and
label: Paragraph

text: Alexander remained active in the architectural profession, were awarded high state
label: Paragraph

text: honors, and participated in major competitions, such as the design for the People’s
label: Paragraph

text: Commissariat of Heavy Industry (unrealized). Although structural concepts of the
label: Paragraph

text: classical revival with which they began their careers appeared in their later designs, they
label: Paragraph

text: continued to reject the role of monumental painting and sculpture that became so
label: Paragraph

text: prominent in architecture of the late Stalinist period. To the end they adhered to their
label: Paragraph

text: belief in the integrity of structure as the determining principle in architectural design.
label: Paragraph

text: VIDHAN BHAVAN (STATE ASSEMBLY
label: Title

text: BHOPAL)
label: Title

text: Designed by Charles Correa, completed 1986 Bhopal, India
label: Caption

text: The Vidhan Bhavan (1980-86), designed by Charles Correa, sits on a crest that offers
label: Paragraph

text: magnificent views of the city of Bhopal, the capital of the state of Madhya Pradesh. It
label: Paragraph

text: houses the state assembly (the lower house with 366 members, the upper house with 75),
label: Paragraph

text: the offices of the chief minister and other ministers of the cabinet, the speaker, the chief
label: Paragraph

text: secretary, various committee rooms, and rooms for the supporting staff.
label: Paragraph

text: The design is conceived in terms of the circular fortified enclosure within which are
label: Paragraph

text: housed various buildings that can be accessed from three directions. The formal
label: Paragraph

text: organization of this complex follows a nine-part layout that the architect attributes to the
label: Paragraph

text: mandala diagram. Each of the nine parts is distinct, partly because of the function that
label: Paragraph

text: each section houses and partly because of the iconographic scheme. For example, the
label: Paragraph

text: Vidhan Sabha (Lower House} is located at the southwest corner within the form of a
label: Paragraph

text: stupa, representing the stupa at Sanchi, a major architectural monument in the state. The
label: Paragraph

text: focus of movement is invested in the two axes, whereas the places of congregation—the
label: Paragraph

text: “Combined Hall,” the Vidhan Sabha, the Vidhan Parishad (Upper House), and the
label: Paragraph

text: library—are located at the four outer corners. The three main entrances are situated on
label: Paragraph

text: the two axes, with the legislators’ entrance and the VIP entrance for the speaker opposite
label: Paragraph

text: each other and the public entrance on the southwest axis.
label: Paragraph

text: The legislative axis takes one from the legislators’ entrance through the foyer and
label: Paragraph

text: central hall and ends at the legislators’ foyer adjacent to the VIP entrance. The Vidhan
label: Paragraph

text: Sabha and Vidhan Parishad sit on either side at the end. In contrast to this axis, if one
label: Paragraph

text: follows the more dominant axis of movement, which is supposed to be for public
label: Paragraph

text: entrance, it seems to have more of a symbolic aspect incorporated into the sequence of
label: Paragraph

text: movement. It can be compared to the Indian temple, wherein the most sacred element is
label: Paragraph

text: situated at the very end of the axis—in this case, the cabinet room and the chief
label: Paragraph

text: minister’s office. The architect engages with the images associated with land and water
label: Paragraph

text: and reverses the traditionally received conceptions along this axis. Here the entrance area
label: Paragraph

text: is paved in a pattern of waves and has the map of the state on one side, which marks the
label: Paragraph

text: water body. This entrance plaza leads to the court of the people, which is in the form of a
label: Paragraph

text: traditional Awnd (water tank). The images associated with the sea are repeatedly
label: Paragraph

text: employed within the complex, such as the conchlike shapes for the combined hall and the
label: Paragraph

text: undulating wavelike form for the roofs.
label: Paragraph

text: The uniqueness of the project is its use of mythical and historic symbols not only in its
label: Paragraph

text: organizational scheme but also in its decorative scheme, although the manner in which
label: Paragraph

text: these symbols are employed in both cases is strictly figurative. The use of folk art in the
label: Paragraph

text: murals and other artwork in this complex contributes to the revival of traditional art and
label: Paragraph

text: motifs without an excessive feeling of pastiche. The large murals covering the walls
label: Paragraph

text: around the Aund (painted by the finest folk artists of the Bastar region), sculptures such as
label: Paragraph

text: the green-marbled sculpture of the Goddess of the Narmada River floating above the
label: Caption

text: reflecting pool, and paintings and other artwork found throughout the building are
label: Paragraph

text: distinct examples of the rich artistic traditions of the state. At the same time, the building
label: Paragraph

text: is replete with iconic elements, such as the gateway of the Sanchi stupa, which is
label: Paragraph

text: replicated at the entrance of the Vidhan Sabha.
label: Caption

text: Although the building has a monumental character, because of the use of a fortified
label: Paragraph

text: citadel-like enclosure, the architect manages to break down the feeling of a monolithic
label: Paragraph

text: whole by the use of a series of courtyards, pathways, and halls, thereby creating the
label: Paragraph

text: feeling of a city within a city. Formally expressed as a unified assembly building, the
label: Paragraph

text: complex is not so much of the country as it is of the diverse nature of the state of Madhya
label: Paragraph

text: Pradesh through the use of iconographic elements that are supposed to be emblematic of
label: Paragraph

text: different aspects of the state.
label: Paragraph

text: This project received the Aga Khan Award in 1998 and has been commended by critics
label: Paragraph

text: for its “heroic scale,” “the wide range of spatial experiences that it offers,” and its “use of
label: Paragraph

text: mythical and historical symbols.” Although much has been written about the “ritualistic
label: Paragraph

text: pathway” and the building’s being a veritable temple to democracy, the success of these
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of the building might be overstated. The complex can be seen as one more
label: Paragraph

text: exploration of what has often been referred to as the “architecture of horizontal planes—
label: Paragraph

text: of roofs and platforms, open colonnades, verandahs and courtyards,” a characteristic seen
label: Paragraph

text: in a chain of other projects by Correa, such as Bharat Bhavan, the Crafts Museum, and
label: Paragraph

text: Vidhan Bhavan (State Assembly), Bhopal, India, designed by Charles Mark
label: Caption

text: VIENNA SECESSION
label: Title

text: The Vienna Secession has attained such an exalted role in the saga of early modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and design that its origins as a society composed mostly of easel painters has
label: Paragraph

text: been almost forgotten. Like the Munich and Berlin Secessions, which were also formed
label: Paragraph

text: in the 1890s, the organization—whose official title was the Vereinigung Bildender
label: Paragraph

text: Kiinstler Osterreichs (Secession) (Association of Austrian Fine Artists [Secession])—was
label: Paragraph

text: born of a revolt against the artistic establishment, but its objectives were initially as much
label: Paragraph

text: commercial as ideological. However, it soon emerged at the forefront of the efforts to
label: Paragraph

text: reform art and architecture, and until the split of the Klimt faction in 1905, it became
label: Paragraph

text: virtually synonymous with the Vienna Moderne.
label: Paragraph

text: The target of the young revolfés in Vienna was the Kiinstlerge-nossenschaft (Artists’
label: Paragraph

text: Association), or as it was more commonly known, the Kiinstlerhaus, a private artists’
label: Paragraph

text: alliance that, in the absence of a well-developed gallery system, exercised nearly
label: Paragraph

text: complete control of exhibitions and sales of art. The proximate cause of the rebellion was
label: Paragraph

text: the reelection of the archconservative Eugen Felix to the presidency of the Kiinstlerhaus
label: Paragraph

text: in November 1896. Many of the more radical members, including the painters Josef
label: Paragraph

text: Engelhart, Carl Moll, and Gustav Klimt and the young architect Joseph Maria Olbrich,
label: Paragraph

text: already angered by the treatment of impressionists and plein air painters, formed a new,
label: Paragraph

text: alternate exhibiting society at the beginning of April 1897, and in late May, Klimt and 12
label: Paragraph

text: others artists formally resigned from the Kiinstlerhaus. They were eventually joined by
label: Paragraph

text: many of the city’s other progressive artists, designers, and architects, including Josef
label: Paragraph

text: Hoffmann and, in November 1899, Otto Wagner.
label: Paragraph

text: From the start, the Secession espoused no single artistic philosophy or style. What
label: Paragraph

text: united its members instead was a shared rejection of historical realism in painting and
label: Paragraph

text: revivalism in architecture, and although the Secessionist movement subsequently became
label: Paragraph

text: closely associated with the Austrian Art Nouveau or Jugendstil (or, as it was often
label: Paragraph

text: referred to at the time, the Secessionsstil), the association’s membership represented a
label: Paragraph

text: wide array of modernist influences and ideas, from naturalism and impressionism to Art
label: Paragraph

text: Nouveau and protofunctionalism. The Secession also brought together artists working in
label: Paragraph

text: a variety of media: painters, sculptors, graphic artists, typographers, and designers, as
label: Paragraph

text: well as architects. The aims of the group were similarly broad. The formation of the
label: Paragraph

text: Secession developed, as Klimt expressed in a protest letter to the leadership of the
label: Paragraph

text: Kiinstlerhaus,
label: Caption

text: out of a recognition of the necessity of bringing artistic life in Vienna into more
label: Paragraph

text: lively contact with the continuing development of art abroad, and of putting
label: Paragraph

text: exhibitions on a purely artistic footing, free from any commercial
label: Paragraph

text: considerations; of thereby awakening in wider circles a purified, modern view of
label: Paragraph

text: art; and lastly, of inducing a heightened concern for art in official circles.
label: Paragraph

text: (quoted in Vergo, 1975)
label: Caption

text: To realize these aspirations, the Secessionists launched their own journal, Ver Sacrum
label: Paragraph

text: (Sacred Spring), in 1898. The title of the journal was drawn from the Roman ritual of
label: Paragraph

text: consecration of youth in times of national peril, a reflection of the Secessionists’ goal of
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic and cultural regeneration. Lavishly produced in its early years, Ver Sacrum
label: Paragraph

text: encapsulated the desire of the Secessionists not only to elevate the standards of Austrian
label: Paragraph

text: artistic production and to embrace the new but also to bring together all the arts. In
label: Paragraph

text: addition to reproductions of paintings, drawings, graphic design, and architecture, the
label: Paragraph

text: journal featured music, poetry, and essays by leading Austrian and foreign modernists.
label: Paragraph

text: Even more central to this program was the series of exhibitions that the Secessionists
label: Paragraph

text: organized just before and after the turn of the century. The first of these exhibitions
label: Paragraph

text: opened in late March 1898. It featured, along with works by the Austrian members of the
label: Paragraph

text: association, paintings, lithographs, and drawings by Fernand Khnopff, Alphonse Mucha,
label: Caption

text: Auguste Rodin, Giovanni Segatini, James McNeill Whistler, and others. The
label: Paragraph

text: responsibility for the design and arrangement of the exhibition (held in rented rooms of
label: Paragraph

text: the Horticultural Society Building on the Parkring) was accorded to Hoffmann and
label: Paragraph

text: Olbrich, who also outfitted a “Ver Sacrum room,” the first of a series of spaces combining
label: Paragraph

text: the newest ideas in the applied arts and interior design. The inaugural exhibition proved to
label: Paragraph

text: be a huge financial success (despite Klimt and his colleagues’ vociferous disavowal of the
label: Paragraph

text: rampant commercialism of the Kiinstlerhaus), but it also underscored the need for a
label: Paragraph

text: permanent exhibition hall. Through various connections with the Vienna city government,
label: Paragraph

text: the Secessionists succeeded in securing a long-term lease on a parcel of land on the
label: Paragraph

text: Karlplatz adjacent to the Academy of Fine Arts, and the task of designing the new
label: Paragraph

text: building was given over to Olbrich.
label: Paragraph

text: Olbrich’s gallery, which was completed in time for the second exhibition in November
label: Paragraph

text: 1898, has become the most recognized architectural symbol of the Secession.
label: Paragraph

text: Emblazoned over its portal are the words of the critic and supporter of the Secession
label: Paragraph

text: Ludwig
label: Title

text: Secession House, detail of door, designed by J.M.Olbrich
label: Caption

text: © Howard Davis/GreatBuildings.com
label: Caption

text: Hevesi: “Der Zeit ihre Kunst, der Kunst ihre Freiheit” (To Every Age Its Art, to Art Its
label: Paragraph

text: Freedom). It was the building’s golden dome—an open, gilded ironwork sphere of laurel
label: Paragraph

text: leaves and berries—however, that drew the immediate attention, as well as the sarcasm,
label: Paragraph

text: of the Viennese public, who mockingly christened it “the golden cabbage” and “the
label: Paragraph

text: Mahdi’s tomb.” However, the revolutionary nature of Olbrich’s creation extended beyond
label: Paragraph

text: its gleaming dome, chaste white walls, and sinuous vegetal graffiti. By relying on a light
label: Paragraph

text: steel truss and glass roofing system supported by thin columns, Olbrich provided a
label: Paragraph

text: remarkably open and adaptable space, one that suited perfectly the Secession’s ambitious
label: Paragraph

text: and varied exhibition program.
label: Paragraph

text: The second exhibition, like its predecessor, again featured easel art by Viennese and
label: Paragraph

text: foreign artists. A large area, however, was given over to a group of architectural drawings
label: Paragraph

text: by Otto Wagner and his students, and an entire room was devoted to a display of applied
label: Paragraph

text: arts by Olbrich, Hoffmann, Koloman Moser, and others. The emphasis on architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and the applied arts reflected a conviction within most of the Secession’s confraternity of
label: Paragraph

text: a changing relationship of art and design. Painting and sculpture—previously regarded as
label: Paragraph

text: a higher form of artistic work—were now displayed on an equal basis with furniture,
label: Paragraph

text: metal- and glasswork, textiles, and graphic design. Although this trend was evident in
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde circles throughout Europe, in Vienna the striving toward a unification of the
label: Paragraph

text: arts was even more pronounced, and it accounted for the special character of many of the
label: Paragraph

text: Secession’s subsequent exhibits.
label: Paragraph

text: The idea of the Gesamtkunstwerk, or total work of art, reached its apotheosis in the
label: Paragraph

text: 14th exhibition, held from April to June 1902. It featured a single work, a statue of a
label: Paragraph

text: seated Beethoven by Leipzig artist Max Klinger, which was placed on a carefully framed
label: Paragraph

text: platform at the far end of the gallery. Surrounding it were murals by Klimt, Roller, and
label: Caption

text: others. Klimt’s Beethoven frieze, recently permanently reinstalled in the Secession
label: Caption

text: Building, constituted a visual representation of ideas of the music and ideas of
label: Paragraph

text: Beethoven’s music—perhaps, as some historians have argued, the final, choral movement
label: Paragraph

text: of Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, which was performed at the exhibit’s opening. The
label: Paragraph

text: installation also included an abstract relief by Hoffmann, one that likewise merged the
label: Paragraph

text: newest ideas in painting and the decorative arts.
label: Paragraph

text: Many of the Secession’s early exhibitions also included the works of some of the
label: Paragraph

text: foremost modernist designers in Europe. The eighth exhibition presented objects by
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Robert Ashbee, Henri van de Velde, and Charles Rennie Mackintosh and his
label: Title

text: wife, Margaret Macdonald. Later exhibitions introduced many of the leading young
label: Paragraph

text: designers in Vienna, among them Joze Plecnik, Robert Orley, and Leopold Bauer.
label: Paragraph

text: Before 1901, both the exhibition designs and most of the objects on display evinced the
label: Paragraph

text: swirling forms of the early, curvilinear Jugendstil. However, by 1901 there was a decided
label: Paragraph

text: trend toward a new rectilinearity and reductivism in design. This transformation was
label: Paragraph

text: most evident in the works of Hoffmann and Moser, who together forged what became the
label: Paragraph

text: emblematic form language of the Secession, a modular, geometricized vocabulary that
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated the later emergence of functionalism. The era of the geometric Jugendstil in
label: Paragraph

text: the Secession proved to be shortlived, however. In 1903, Hoffmann and Moser founded
label: Paragraph

text: their own artists’ collective, the Wiener Werkstatte, and they increasingly devoted their
label: Paragraph

text: time and efforts to its operation. Many of the exhibitions after 1903 also failed to match
label: Paragraph

text: the quality and inventiveness of the Secession’s early years. Among the few significant
label: Paragraph

text: later exhibitions was the 23rd, which included Wagner’s projects for the Steinhof Church
label: Paragraph

text: and his ill-starred Stadtmuseum.
label: Paragraph

text: The decline in standards was in part the result of a growing rift within the Secession
label: Paragraph

text: that began to manifest itself around 1904. The split was a consequence largely of
label: Paragraph

text: differing views in the membership over the relative roles of painting and applied arts.
label: Paragraph

text: Many of the pure painters (Nur-Maler) resented the privileged role of Hoffmann and the
label: Paragraph

text: other Raumkiinstler (decorative artists), charging that architecture and design were being
label: Paragraph

text: promoted at the expense of easel art. The Secession had broken into two opposing camps:
label: Paragraph

text: the Klimt-Gruppe, which included Hoffmann, Moser, Wagner, and most of the other
label: Paragraph

text: architects and designers, and the pure painters, led by Josef Engelhart. For a time, the two
label: Paragraph

text: groups continued to coexist, but in 1905 Klimt and most of the other prominent artists,
label: Paragraph

text: architects, and designers resigned over an argument concerning the Klimt faction’s
label: Paragraph

text: affiliation with a local gallery, leaving the more traditional painters in control. Although
label: Paragraph

text: the Secession survived as an organization and continued to mount exhibitions, it ceased
label: Paragraph

text: to be a driving force in Austrian art.
label: Paragraph

text: During its heyday, the Vienna Secession provided a vibrant forum for the city’s avant-
label: Paragraph

text: garde to explore the newest currents in art, architecture, and design. For a time, the union
label: Paragraph

text: succeeded brilliantly in achieving its goals of elevating the standards of Austrian art,
label: Paragraph

text: establishing contacts abroad, and promoting modernism. However, the Secessionists
label: Paragraph

text: failed in their bid to win full government support, a situation that would have fateful
label: Paragraph

text: consequences for Wagner, Klimt, and many of the other progressive members. The
label: Paragraph

text: position of the Secession in the larger history of modernism is also an ambiguous one.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Hoffmann, Moser, Olbrich, and the other applied artists were able to foster an
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary new design direction, their reliance on traditional craft and deluxe materials
label: Paragraph

text: ensured that most of the Secession’s products would remain inaccessible to a broad
label: Paragraph

text: spectrum of society. In the end, the growing reliance on industrial production and mass
label: Paragraph

text: marketing would render their achievements more and more irrelevant. The
label: Paragraph

text: Gesamtkunstwerk ideal of the complete aestheticization of life proved to be
label: Paragraph

text: unsustainable.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Caption

text: From the time of its dedication in 1982, the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in
label: Paragraph

text: Washington, D.C., has enjoyed a rare combination of both critical and popular acclaim.
label: Paragraph

text: Perennially one of the most visited sites in the nation’s capital, the landscape-and-
label: Paragraph

text: earthworks construction was the competition-winning design of then-21-year-old Yale
label: Paragraph

text: University student Maya Ying Lin. On completion the work was also one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: controversial public landscapes ever executed in the United States. Lin’s design was
label: Paragraph

text: attacked by various conservative cultural and political audiences offended by the
label: Paragraph

text: memorial’s rejection of the officially sponsored neoclassical language of white
label: Title

text: monuments conventional to the Mall. Despite that vocal minority opinion, the lucid
label: Paragraph

text: minimal design garnered critical praise as a rare example of the highest quality of public
label: Paragraph

text: work.
label: Paragraph

text: The power of Lin’s design resides, at least in part, in its inversion of conventional
label: Paragraph

text: expectations for memorials on the Mall. In lieu of representing the state-sanctioned
label: Paragraph

text: official history of U.S. involvement in Vietnam, the Wall (as it came to be known) was
label: Paragraph

text: conceived and designed as an “open work” intended to be read in multiple ways by
label: Paragraph

text: diverse audiences. Each participant is capable of reading the Wall’s contents relative to
label: Paragraph

text: the particulars and specifics of his or her own unique experience. Rather than objectifying
label: Paragraph

text: the state’s powerful interest in recording a received history of the war, the Vietnam
label: Paragraph

text: Veterans Memorial was conceived, financed, and constructed as a memorial by and for
label: Paragraph

text: the public rather than its government.
label: Paragraph

text: Lin’s conception encompasses two black, granite-faced retaining walls cut into a
label: Paragraph

text: mound of earth known as Constitution Gardens. The two sloping wall segments intersect
label: Paragraph

text: at their highest point, forming an interior angle of 120 degrees, whereas the lower ends
label: Paragraph

text: are axially aligned with the larger site beyond, effectively grounding the work’s geometry
label: Paragraph

text: in the broader landscape. On the reflective surface of the black stone panels, the names of
label: Paragraph

text: each of the 58,000 U.S. personnel missing, presumed dead,
label: Paragraph

text: Vietnam Veterans Memorial, architectural drawing (ca. 1980) showing
label: Caption

text: memorial as plan and perspective, with textual description, for
label: Paragraph

text: competition
label: Title

text: © Library of Congress and Maya Lin
label: Title

text: Vietnam Veterans Memorial
label: Title

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: and killed in the Vietnam conflict are inscribed. Organized chronologically, the
label: Paragraph

text: inscription of those lost suggests the relatedness of those killed at a particular point in
label: Paragraph

text: time while embedding any particular sought-after name in a sea of adjacent and nearly
label: Paragraph

text: indistinguishable names. The public and collective experience of searching for a lost
label: Paragraph

text: friend’s or relative’s name has sponsored the related material practices of rubbing
label: Paragraph

text: engraved names to record them on paper and the leaving of memorial objects at the base
label: Caption

text: of the Wall. Although the Wall reinterprets certain well-established American funerary
label: Paragraph

text: traditions, the closest precedents for the work can be found in cultural developments
label: Paragraph

text: within minimalist sculpture and land art, both of which found receptive audiences in
label: Paragraph

text: schools of architecture in the Postmodern era. Lin’s design, which earned her a “B” in her
label: Paragraph

text: class in funerary architecture at Yale, was selected from among more than 1400 entries to
label: Paragraph

text: an open design competition by a jury of distinguished figures in architecture, landscape,
label: Paragraph

text: and public art. Lin’s conception of an inverted, absent monumentality takes the form of a
label: Paragraph

text: low wall retaining the earth behind, implicating the surrounding landscape and one’s
label: Paragraph

text: experience of it as the context for the work. By rejecting the contextual clues of the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding neoclassical monuments, Lin’s design offers an intimate, individually
label: Paragraph

text: constructed, and ultimately political work of Postmodern landscape sculpture.
label: Paragraph

text: Although garnering immediate critical support in the art and design communities, as
label: Paragraph

text: well as being warmly embraced by untold numbers of veterans, the design was roundly
label: Paragraph

text: and loudly criticized by culturally conservative constituencies and many political
label: Paragraph

text: operatives, including several key members of the Republican White House under Ronald
label: Paragraph

text: Reagan. For many of these conservatives, the Wall was seen as elitist, abstract, and not
label: Paragraph

text: appropriately representational of what they took to be the legitimately heroic content of
label: Paragraph

text: the war. At the height of this sentiment, the Wall was infamously referred to as a “black
label: Paragraph

text: gash of shame” by veteran and Purple Heart recipient Tom Carhart. The memorial’s
label: Caption

text: many detractors eventually succeeded in compromising the Wall’s simple planar
label: Paragraph

text: geometry with the addition of a piece of figural sculpture to the site. This sculpture, “The
label: Paragraph

text: Three Fightingmen” (1984), by Frederick Hart was intended to provide an appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: literalness that a minority of culturally conservative lay audiences found lacking in the
label: Paragraph

text: somber power of Lin’s “anti-monument.” Similar concerns over the Wall’s inclusiveness
label: Paragraph

text: of reading by various constituencies led to the incorporation of a second figural sculpture
label: Paragraph

text: depicting the sacrifices of women veterans of the Vietnam era. This second sculpture,
label: Paragraph

text: titled “Vietnam Women’s Memorial” (1993), by Glenna Goodacre, although enjoying
label: Paragraph

text: similar political and financial support for its inclusion on site, never approached the
label: Paragraph

text: cultural and critical achievement of Lin’s original design while fundamentally
label: Paragraph

text: compromising its accomplishment. Rather, it is precisely the Wall’s clear refusal to
label: Paragraph

text: engage in an uncritical ahistorical valorization of the Vietnam War that affords multiple
label: Paragraph

text: viewers the possibility of reading into the work something of their own experience.
label: Paragraph

text: Understood as an “open text” intended to be read differently depending on the
label: Paragraph

text: expectations and experience of the viewer, Lin’s design offers a subtle and mutable lens
label: Paragraph

text: through which various political contents might be read. Subsequent public reception of
label: Paragraph

text: the memorial has been equally kind, and the Wall continues to enjoy broad public support
label: Paragraph

text: in the United States and internationally as a seminal work of Postmodern landscape. The
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary and seemingly unparalleled breakthrough of Lin’s design rests precisely on
label: Paragraph

text: its ability to be read simultaneously by countless individuals implicated in its subject
label: Paragraph

text: matter toward absolutely diverse political, social, and personal conclusions.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the status of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial will continue to change over
label: Paragraph

text: time, the open interpretive nature of the work ensures its continued relevance well
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the life expectancy of state-sanctioned monuments whose contents may be
label: Paragraph

text: rendered redundant by the passage of time. More so than traditional historical
label: Paragraph

text: representations of official state history, the meaning of the memorial depends on the
label: Paragraph

text: reading of social and political history by future generations of participants. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: traditional monuments codify for future legibility the consensus view of history
label: Paragraph

text: concretized by their creators, the Wall constructs a surface of reflection from which
label: Paragraph

text: changing and multiple viewpoints on historical events might be read.
label: Paragraph

text: VILLA MAIREA
label: Title

text: Designed by Alvar Aalto, completed 1939 Noormarkku, Finland
label: Caption

text: In 1937, the Finnish industrialist Harry Gullichsen and his wife, Maire, commissioned
label: Paragraph

text: Alvar Aalto to design a family residence
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Mairea, main entrance, designed by Alvar Aalto.
label: Caption

text: Photo © G.Welin/Alvar Aalto Archives
label: Caption

text: Villa Mairea, living room
label: Caption

text: Photo © Alvar Aalto Archives
label: Caption

text: in Noormarkku, Finland, that would be traditionally Finnish yet modern. By this time,
label: Paragraph

text: Alvar Aalto was well known as a proponent of modern, concrete construction and already
label: Paragraph

text: famous for his International Style buildings, such as the Tuberculosis Sanitorium in
label: Paragraph

text: Paimio, Finland. The International Style aesthetic of whiteness and abstraction, with an
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on industrial production, was and is fundamentally at odds with the strong
label: Paragraph

text: traditions of handcraft in Finland. As a result, the Villa Mairea is never quite what it
label: Paragraph

text: appears to be. Early on, the house was received as a masterpiece but, because of the many
label: Paragraph

text: apparently contradictory elements, remained problematic as to its meaning and
label: Paragraph

text: significance.
label: Paragraph

text: The first glimpse of its dominant white volume amid pine trees suggests a rigorous
label: Paragraph

text: modern composition of clear geometries. As one approaches more closely, the free-form
label: Paragraph

text: entry canopy is the first surprise, contrasting with the “pure” white volume behind. More
label: Paragraph

text: surprising still, this irregular canopy is screened and supported by lashed bamboolike
label: Paragraph

text: poles, suggesting primitive, perhaps even Japanese, construction. Here, at the entry, Aalto
label: Paragraph

text: has announced a dialectic between traditional and modern that is sustained throughout.
label: Paragraph

text: Once inside, one’s attention is pulled diagonally to the left by the fireplace in the far
label: Paragraph

text: corner of the living room. Aalto takes the traditional Finnish corner stove, with its extra
label: Caption

text: children’s bunk above, and transforms it into something uniquely modern by converting
label: Paragraph

text: the stair opening leading to the bunk into a hollowed sculptural profile at the side.
label: Caption

text: Perhaps the most memorable aspect of the living room is a modern stair of open risers
label: Caption

text: that is elaborately supported and intricately joined to vertical wooden poles. The whole
label: Paragraph

text: ensemble is adjacent to a large, sliding glass panel leading outside to the rear courtyard.
label: Caption

text: The juxtaposition of stair and glass produces an unexpected result; the view through the
label: Paragraph

text: stair to the courtyard is reminiscent of looking out through the forest’s edge into a
label: Paragraph

text: landscape beyond. The blurring of the distinction between inside and outside is enhanced
label: Paragraph

text: by the extensive use of wood in the ceiling and occasional interior columns wrapped in
label: Paragraph

text: rattan.
label: Paragraph

text: At this remove, it is generally accepted that one of Aalto’s most significant
label: Paragraph

text: achievements is this creation of a “forest space.” This metaphorical experience of a forest
label: Paragraph

text: inside his buildings is a reference to the primary experience of his beloved Finland. The
label: Paragraph

text: living room at the Villa Mairea is the one of the clearest statements of this idea.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the abundant stylistic contradictions, the house is a comfortable, livable home.
label: Paragraph

text: The interior unfolds as a succession of controlled vistas and carefully formed spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Much of this ease results from the L-shaped plan, which is divided into a kitchen-
label: Paragraph

text: servants’ wing and a family-living area. This organization is probably derived from plans
label: Paragraph

text: of 19th-century aristocratic Scandinavian manor houses, with which Aalto would have
label: Paragraph

text: been familiar. Meanwhile, the “L” also forms a courtyard that is reminiscent of much
label: Paragraph

text: older Finnish peasant farms and faintly of Italian courtyards. Thus, even in the plan,
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto makes references to other architectures and other places and resolves complex
label: Paragraph

text: programmatic issues. The combination of conflicting references continues within the
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard, where there is a traditional sauna combined with a free-form plunge pool.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the pool is an unfamiliar farm element, the larger reference is to the Finnish
label: Paragraph

text: landscape with its many lakes. The wooden sauna with its turf roof is a rustic, vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: structure, and it is connected to the house by a turf-covered breezeway supported by
label: Paragraph

text: metal pipe columns and a single concrete pier. Countering the sauna, diagonally across
label: Caption

text: the courtyard, is Maire Gullichsen’s second-floor study, which is collaged onto the main,
label: Paragraph

text: white volume of the house. The ambiguous form of the study, sheathed with vertical
label: Paragraph

text: wood strips, is a combination of crafted material with abstract modern form. Despite the
label: Paragraph

text: modern elements, the overall effect is to integrate the building with its place. Such an
label: Paragraph

text: integration is unusual for modern buildings of this period, which usually were treated as
label: Paragraph

text: objects distinct from their sites.
label: Paragraph

text: In all these examples and in the whole of this project, Aalto successfully brought
label: Paragraph

text: together the opposed worlds of Finnish vernacular and International Style modernism. In
label: Paragraph

text: so doing, he produced a work that has had a substantial and lasting influence on the
label: Paragraph

text: history and development of modern architecture. Here, he provided one of the few
label: Paragraph

text: examples of a “humanized modernism” that recognized the significance and experience
label: Paragraph

text: of the individual as opposed to focusing on the often dehumanizing effects of industrial
label: Paragraph

text: technique.
label: Paragraph

text: In recent years, the Villa Mairea, with its references to other architectures, times, and
label: Paragraph

text: traditions, has been a significant touchstone for Postmodernism, whose practitioners see
label: Paragraph

text: in Aalto’s work useful examples of referential and metaphorical design strategies. In
label: Paragraph

text: particular, various critics have remarked on Aalto’s design method as being
label: Paragraph

text: fundamentally “typological”; that is, designing in plan, elevation, and detail with specific
label: Paragraph

text: references to historic and basic “types” of architecture. It was Aalto’s genius that
label: Paragraph

text: constantly transformed and mixed those types to produce complex works whose richness,
label: Paragraph

text: subtlety, and variety set a new standard for architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite all the referential games that he played in his buildings, Aalto awakens the
label: Paragraph

text: viewer to the deep and fundamental connection between humans and the natural world. It
label: Paragraph

text: is this awareness that remains the moving and transforming core of the Villa Mairea.
label: Paragraph

text: LAURENCE KEITH LOFTIN IIL

text: VILLA SAVOYE, POISSY, FRANCE
label: Caption

text: Designed by Le Corbusier, completed 1930
label: Caption

text: Le Corbusier (Charles-Edouard Jeanneret) had been living in Paris since 1916,
label: Paragraph

text: collaborating with Amédée Ozenfant in the production of the review L ‘Esprit nouveau,
label: Paragraph

text: constructing several private homes, including the La Roche-Jeanneret houses (which
label: Paragraph

text: would later become the Fondation Le Corbusier), and proposing ambitious projects for
label: Paragraph

text: mass housing. By 1925, he succeeded in securing official backing for the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: an experimental housing enclave at Pessac, near Bordeaux—an enterprise that seemed to
label: Paragraph

text: presage a revolution in the building industry by bringing to construction the benefits of
label: Paragraph

text: mass production that had made the automobile industry. He now began to receive
label: Paragraph

text: commissions for luxury villas from families with interests in industry or with American
label: Paragraph

text: connections. Among these were the designs made for Mongermon, one of the directors of
label: Paragraph

text: the Voisin car and airplane industries, and in 1926 a villa at Garches for Michael and
label: Paragraph

text: Sarah Stein.
label: Paragraph

text: The process by which Le Corbusier obtained the collaboration of his clients was not an
label: Paragraph

text: easy one, as his ideas were as much directed to using new materials and developing a
label: Paragraph

text: new lifestyle as they were to securing satisfied clients. In the case of the commission for
label: Paragraph

text: the Villa Savoye, which arrived in 1928, the clients rejected his first design but returned
label: Paragraph

text: to it after he had explored alternatives and presumably after he had succeeded in gaining
label: Paragraph

text: the confidence not only of Pierre Savoye but of his wife, Emilie, as well. The villa was
label: Paragraph

text: completed in 1930, at a cost almost double that of the estimate. It was used by the family
label: Paragraph

text: as a weekend retreat until it was abandoned at the outbreak of war in 1939. However, it
label: Paragraph

text: was plagued by leaks from the windows, skylights, and flat-roof terraces, and in
label: Paragraph

text: September 1936 Madame Savoye complained to the architect that “it is raining in my
label: Paragraph

text: bedroom.”
label: Paragraph

text: During the war years, the villa was commandeered by the Germans, then by the
label: Paragraph

text: Americans, and came under threat when the Commune of Poissy planned to absorb the
label: Paragraph

text: land for the construction of a school. Le Corbusier was forced to make representations in
label: Paragraph

text: high places, including to his friend André Malraux, minister of cultural affairs, in order to
label: Paragraph

text: prevent its demolition.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite Villa Savoye’s rather unsatisfactory history of cost overruns and architectural
label: Paragraph

text: defects, it was acquired by the government as a national landmark. More than any other
label: Paragraph

text: of the time, the Villa Savoye embodies the qualities that were to be ascribed to modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture produced under functionalism, and as such it has entered into history. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1938, Henry-Russell Hitchcock and Philip Johnson published their influential book The
label: Paragraph

text: international Style and chose a picture of the Villa Savoye for the dustcover. It embodies
label: Paragraph

text: the idea of a functional architecture pared down to essentials, and it has, in addition,
label: Paragraph

text: something exceptional that makes all the difference: a sweet sense of form, and a flair for
label: Paragraph

text: style. There is a marvelous balance between form and content, each increasing the effect
label: Paragraph

text: of the other, and so it seems to crystallize the very idea of modernism in architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Savoye, Poissy, France (1930)
label: Caption

text: Photo © Alan Windsor
label: Caption

text: The villa occupied an extensive field surrounded by a belt of trees. Le Corbusier placed it
label: Paragraph

text: on the slightly higher ground in the middle of this field, so that it commanded views in all
label: Paragraph

text: directions, and gave it four similar sides, one for each direction. There is some weight in
label: Paragraph

text: the critic Colin Rowe’s suggestion that it compares with Palladio’s Villa Rotunda, just as
label: Paragraph

text: the villa at Garches can be compared with Palladio’s Villa Malcontenta, and there is
label: Paragraph

text: much about the design that gives it a classical feel, but this aspect has been totally
label: Paragraph

text: transformed by the idea of the machine aesthetic. To begin with, the frontality of the plan
label: Paragraph

text: is full of paradox. For a weekend house some 30 kilometers from Paris, the car is
label: Paragraph

text: obligatory. Instead of directly approaching a front porch, the visitor drives under the
label: Paragraph

text: house on a gravel surface, sweeps around the back, and stops at the opposite side. The
label: Paragraph

text: back becomes the front. The ground-floor accommodation is retracted to allow this, and it
label: Paragraph

text: curves precisely to the sweep of the car.
label: Paragraph

text: The entrance door is classically placed on the central axis of the house, but the hal
label: Paragraph

text: opens out asymmetrically. Directly opposite, instead of the traditional staircase there is a
label: Paragraph

text: narrow ramp that dives deep into the house before bending back at the half landing.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the front door, which parts in the center with two sliding leaves, is on the
label: Paragraph

text: centerline of the house, this axis is also occupied by a row of columns, and on the hal
label: Paragraph

text: landing one crosses this line.
label: Paragraph

text: The space of the ramp is fully glazed above, so that it attracts the visitor upward
label: Paragraph

text: toward the light. Once on the second level, it can be seen that it continues farther upward,
label: Paragraph

text: on the outside, providing access to the solarium on the roof. The house now appears like
label: Paragraph

text: an apartment, with all the family accommodations on the raised level, the ground leve.
label: Paragraph

text: reserved for the servants’ quarters. However, a good slice of this upper level is given to
label: Paragraph

text: an extensive roof terrace, onto which the living room looks, with large sliding windows
label: Paragraph

text: facing southwest. There is a Mediterranean feeling about this terrace, with its fixed
label: Paragraph

text: concrete table ready for the moment of the aperitif. All the family spaces around the
label: Paragraph

text: house are lit by a continuous band of glazing, the glass omitted where the wall traverses
label: Paragraph

text: the terrace, so that the appearance on the outside is constant on all sides. The regularity of
label: Paragraph

text: the outer face is offset by the dynamic thrust of the ramp and the curved roof forms that
label: Paragraph

text: shelter the solarium from the wind.
label: Paragraph

text: In this design, Le Corbusier synthesized elements from his art with elements from his
label: Paragraph

text: idea of a machine architecture derived from industrial processes. To review the different
label: Paragraph

text: stages by which he arrives at the final design is to review a tentative process, for it only
label: Paragraph

text: crystallizes along the way. Yet the finished result is so imbued with his conviction, so
label: Paragraph

text: certain in its balance, that it sums up not just an episode but an epoch as well.
label: Paragraph

text: VILLANUEVA, CARLOS RAUL 1900-72
label: Title

text: Architect, Venezuela
label: Title

text: Known as Venezuela’s greatest 20th-century architect, Carlos Raul Villanueva
label: Paragraph

text: straddled opposing political regimes, cultural milieus, and architectural styles during his
label: Paragraph

text: long and eclectic career but left no school or followers. His most significant contribution
label: Paragraph

text: to the country’s architecture, a modernist style inflected by Venezuelan vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and influenced by the Venezuelan tropical climate, proved too personal to be
label: Paragraph

text: imitated. Although his residential designs are well known, it is in the public sphere—
label: Paragraph

text: schools, housing projects, and universities—that Villanueva had the greatest effect. In
label: Paragraph

text: particular his commitment to implementing his vision of the “synthesis of the arts” in
label: Paragraph

text: public spaces made his work important to the Venezuelan urban context.
label: Paragraph

text: Villanueva began to practice his profession in Caracas in 1929 when he was appointed
label: Paragraph

text: to the post of architect and director of building in the Ministry of Public Works under the
label: Paragraph

text: regime of General Juan Vicente Gomez. From this period buildings such as the Plaza de
label: Paragraph

text: Toros de Maracay (1931-33) and the Museums of Fine Arts and Natural Sciences (1934—
label: Paragraph

text: 35), among others, demonstrate how Villanueva tempered his interest in vanguard
label: Paragraph

text: European architectural movements with a Neoclassicism designed to appeal to a
label: Paragraph

text: conservative elite.
label: Paragraph

text: The next period of the architect’s career is marked by a clearer influence of European
label: Paragraph

text: modernism, as buildings such as the Gran Colombia School of Caracas (1939; today
label: Paragraph

text: Francisco Pimentel), lack the ornamentation of earlier projects and instead employ
label: Paragraph

text: molded reinforced concrete to create curving forms and masses. These buildings also
label: Paragraph

text: illustrate Villanueva’s evolving concern with light and shadow. Demonstrating his early
label: Paragraph

text: interest in incorporating works of art into buildings, Villanueva integrated a sculpture by
label: Paragraph

text: Venezuelan modernist sculptor Francisco Narvaez into the main wall of the school.
label: Caption

text: In 1940 Villanueva was named chief architect and consultant of the Banco Obrero
label: Paragraph

text: (Workers’ Bank) of Venezuela, a government institution whose mission was to improve
label: Paragraph

text: the living condi tions of the lower and working classes. One of his first projects was to
label: Paragraph

text: remodel the neighborhood of El Silencio (1941-43), a barrio in the center of the city
label: Paragraph

text: known for its high crime and unhygienic, poor housing conditions. With the remodeling
label: Paragraph

text: of this zone would begin his preoccupation with urban spaces, in particular with the
label: Paragraph

text: design of large-scale public housing. El Silencio embodied the challenges faced by
label: Paragraph

text: Villanueva in attempting works on this scale, produced under competing interests and
label: Paragraph

text: compromised by political circumstances.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1944 he commenced work on the University City of Venezuela (Ciudad
label: Paragraph

text: Universitaria, also known as the Universidad Central de Venezuela [UCV], or Central
label: Paragraph

text: University of Venezuela), which would not be completed until 1959. At the UCV,
label: Paragraph

text: Villanueva achieved the apogee of his personal style, a Le Corbusian-derived,
label: Paragraph

text: Venezuelan-inflected organicism that took as its touchstone the modernist dream of the
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis of the arts. For Villanueva the creation of this “aesthetic consortium” would
label: Paragraph

text: enable the city’s inhabitants to become truly integrated in aesthetic, spiritual, and
label: Paragraph

text: functional terms, as he believed that the natural environment of painting and sculpture is
label: Paragraph

text: “plazas, gardens, public buildings, factories, and airports: all the places where man
label: Paragraph

text: perceives man as a companion, a partner, a helping hand, a hope, and not as a flower
label: Paragraph

text: withered by isolation and indifference” (Villanueva, 1957, 11). Although its style has not
label: Paragraph

text: been duplicated elsewhere, the UCV had a great effect on the course of Venezuelan
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. In particular, Venezuelan intellectual and political elites came to see
label: Paragraph

text: modernism as the style most appropriate for embodying Venezuelan identity, and the
label: Paragraph

text: incorporation of works of art into buildings was an idea taken up by succeeding
label: Paragraph

text: architects.
label: Paragraph

text: Concurrently with his work on the UCV, Villanueva continued his association with the
label: Paragraph

text: Workers’ Bank and the Taller de Arquitectura Banco Obrero (Workers’ Bank
label: Title

text: Architectural Workshop, or TABO). The projects commissioned by the Workers’ Bank,
label: Paragraph

text: beginning in the late 1940s, became larger and more frequent under the regime of
label: Paragraph

text: Venezuela’s last dictator, Marcos Pérez Jiménez (1952-58), ending with some of the
label: Paragraph

text: largest public housing projects ever built in Latin America by the end of the decade. The
label: Paragraph

text: most representative of these, Villanueva’s housing community “23 de Enero” (23 January
label: Paragraph

text: 1957), originally named “2 de Diciembre,” is usually cited by critics as a turning point in
label: Paragraph

text: the city’s growth. Because of its massive scale, it stood as a concrete symbol of the
label: Paragraph

text: regime’s objective of eradicating the ranchos, or slums, that had sprouted on hillsides,
label: Paragraph

text: under bridges, and in ravines in Caracas. In projects such as this, Villanueva incorporated
label: Paragraph

text: elements from different phases of his career, such as the use of polychrome paintings as
label: Paragraph

text: exterior decoration; window and wall treatments that protected interiors from wind, sun,
label: Paragraph

text: and rain; and Le Corbusian—derived ideas about rational living spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Villanueva’s critics describe his use of modernist styles as superficial and eclectic, and
label: Paragraph

text: in comparison with the work of other modernist Latin American architects, Villanueva’s
label: Paragraph

text: personal style is less fully realized. However, in context, Villanueva stands out as the first
label: Paragraph

text: Venezuelan to combine a tropical sensibility with European modernist architecture. For
label: Paragraph

text: this reason the UCV is regarded as Venezuela’s most important architectural monument.
label: Paragraph

text: This, perhaps, is Villanueva’s most important legacy: the incorporation of works of art
label: Paragraph

text: into architectural projects, particularly in the capital. Large-scale freestanding sculptures
label: Paragraph

text: and mu-rals are found all over the city—in private office buildings, plazas, and subway
label: Paragraph

text: stations and alongside highways—making Caracas a significant public art center on a par
label: Paragraph

text: with New York City and Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: VILLE RADIEUSE (Ca. 1930)
label: Caption

text: Designed by Le Corbusier
label: Caption

text: While working on the Tzentrosoyuz (central statistical office) building in 1930, Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier received an inquiry from the Soviet officials concerning the reorganization of
label: Paragraph

text: Moscow. His illustrative proposal, entitled “Ville Radieuse” (radiant city), was grounded
label: Paragraph

text: essentially in individual freedom, exerted no influence in the Soviet Union, and remained
label: Paragraph

text: a project on paper only. Le Corbusier continued to develop and relentlessly promote Ville
label: Paragraph

text: Radieuse as a platform on which to present his thoughts about urbanism; it became a
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical summary of Le Corbusier’s most advanced views on town planning and
label: Paragraph

text: design, eventually evolving into a model of a modern “ideal city” in the best tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: old-fashioned utopias.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier treated the Moscow inquiry as a case study assessed through a relatively
label: Paragraph

text: independent theoretical framework: the answers to the questions “were Moscow,” but the
label: Paragraph

text: illustrations (about 20 of them) “were the phenomenon of the organiza-tion of life in the
label: Paragraph

text: city of the machine age, the present age” (Le Corbusier, 1935, p. 90). Essentially, Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier tried to solve the city as a problem and kept pursuing an absolute formula that
label: Paragraph

text: would guarantee the highest quality to any urban space. His approach was not wholly
label: Paragraph

text: new; Ville Radieuse included and refined Le Corbusier’s earlier thoughts on urban
label: Paragraph

text: design, including the Contemporary City for Three Million Inhabitants, the Voisin Plan
label: Paragraph

text: for Paris, and the ideas expressed in his books Urbanisme (The City of To-morrow) and
label: Paragraph

text: Precisions.
label: Paragraph

text: This new city was a revised version of his Contemporary City for Three Million
label: Paragraph

text: Inhabitants, first launched for the Parisian Autumn Salon in 1922. It remained rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: in form but allowed for lateral growth on both sides of the central communication axis,
label: Paragraph

text: thus eliminating rigidity, the major shortcoming of the previous model. The business
label: Paragraph

text: center, in the pattern of sixteen wide-spaced, cruciform skyscrapers, was concentrated at
label: Paragraph

text: the “top” edge of the plan, tangential to the circular transportation terminal with a
label: Paragraph

text: heliport on its rooftop. The industrial zone was located at the “bottom” end of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: Areas of civic and commercial activities flanked the NW—SE communication while
label: Paragraph

text: serving as a buffer zone to the set-back, residential superblocks. Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupation with a total, wholesome living environment, filled with air, sun, light, and
label: Paragraph

text: greenery inside and out was presented as an immersion of buildings into the large green
label: Paragraph

text: areas. Although the “garden city” suburbs and the hierarchic population distribution used
label: Paragraph

text: in previous models were eliminated, the principles like a multilevel transportation system
label: Paragraph

text: and a “biological unit,” the cell of 14 square meters per occupant, were elaborated on,
label: Paragraph

text: and a nursery, kindergarten, and primary school were introduced in the “neighborhood
label: Paragraph

text: unit” of 2,700.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout the 1930s, applying “radiant city” urbanization principles, now formulated
label: Paragraph

text: as a more universal model of urban planning, Le Corbusier produced a wide variety of
label: Paragraph

text: unbuilt projects, mostly competition entries for various cities, the majority of which were
label: Paragraph

text: included in the subsequent book titled The Radiant City; Elements of a Doctrine of
label: Paragraph

text: Urbanism to Be Used as the Basis of Our Machine-Age Civilization.
label: Paragraph

text: The book spanned projects from his Voisin Plan for Paris of 1925, which was designed
label: Paragraph

text: to revitalize the center of the city, to four Latin American cities, among which the site
label: Paragraph

text: and ambience of Rio de Janeiro inspired particularly poetic expressions, resulting in the
label: Paragraph

text: concept of an elevated highway with incorporated housing below; this megastructure was
label: Paragraph

text: to become a focus of the later plan for Algiers. Although the geometry of Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: model seemingly presupposed a flatness of site and indifference to topographic concerns,
label: Paragraph

text: the scheme was only intended to facilitate the paradigm, whereas some of the most
label: Paragraph

text: imaginative of Le Corbusier’s applications were inspired by the most tregular
label: Paragraph

text: topographies.
label: Paragraph

text: He blamed the migration to cities for some of the gravest urban problems and proposed
label: Paragraph

text: solving it by redevelopment and revitalization of the rural areas. The resulting concepts
label: Paragraph

text: for the Radiant Farm and Radiant Village eulogized the modern highspeed connection
label: Paragraph

text: between the city and country, but his proposed modernization targeted only country
label: Paragraph

text: living and did not include working conditions.
label: Paragraph

text: With the Ville Radieuse, Le Corbusier established some of the 20th century’s most
label: Paragraph

text: memorable and influential urban images and created the concept of urban environment
label: Paragraph

text: that still underlies much of contemporary design, despite the fact that he was denied
label: Paragraph

text: urban planning commissions for most of his lifetime. Yet, through the Charter of Athens,
label: Paragraph

text: a manifesto of the Modern movement, and CLAM gatherings, Le Corbusier promulgated
label: Paragraph

text: the Ville Radieuse approach to urban planning and design as a recipe for the quality of
label: Paragraph

text: the living and dwelling environment. His vision presupposed a revolution in dwelling,
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, and urbanism. That Le Corbusier’s romanticized and futuristic urban dreams
label: Paragraph

text: exerted such influence among generations of architects all over the world was a result of
label: Paragraph

text: his sophisticated theories that successfully combined a persistent and contagious
label: Paragraph

text: enthusiasm for the architect’s doctrine.
label: Paragraph

text: VISITOR CENTER
label: Title

text: The visitor center is a product of the post-World War II automobile age, welcoming road-
label: Paragraph

text: weary tourists with promises of comfort, education, and entertainment. Prominently
label: Paragraph

text: situated at historic areas, national parks, and state borders, the visitor center combines a
label: Paragraph

text: wide range of functions, such as rest rooms, information kiosks, bookstores, and museum
label: Paragraph

text: exhibits, that were once housed separately.
label: Paragraph

text: The term and concept of “visitor center” were brought into widespread use by the
label: Paragraph

text: National Park Service during its “Mission 66“building improvement program (1956-66).
label: Paragraph

text: Under Mission 66 the Park Service promoted 100 newly created visitor centers as the hub
label: Paragraph

text: of a ten-year, billion-dollar effort to improve tourist and administrative facilities in the
label: Paragraph

text: national parks. Mission 66 aimed to satisfy an astronomical rise in the number of visitors,
label: Paragraph

text: growing from 17 million annually in 1940 to 54 million a year by 1954, at park sites that
label: Paragraph

text: had not been substantially upgraded since the 1930s. Rangers could not handle the
label: Paragraph

text: massive influx of tourists in the existing structures, small “rustic” buildings often lacking
label: Paragraph

text: basic conveniences such as air-conditioning or indoor rest rooms.
label: Paragraph

text: Under Mission 66, Park Service planners created a prototype design for a new building
label: Paragraph

text: type—the visitor center—that could be adapted to the unique character and specific
label: Paragraph

text: requirements of each site. The prototypical visitor center consisted of a compact building
label: Paragraph

text: equipped with clean rest rooms, public telephones, a large circulation lobby, an
label: Paragraph

text: information desk, staff offices, and areas for interpretive exhibits. Centers for more
label: Caption

text: popular parks might include an auditorium with regularly scheduled orientation films, a
label: Paragraph

text: cafeteria, a research room, and a library. A convenient parking area nearby
label: Paragraph

text: accommodated visitors’ automobiles and trailers. These basic elements remain at the core
label: Paragraph

text: of visitor center planning today.
label: Paragraph

text: As the first stop for tourists, the visitor center created a transition zone between the
label: Paragraph

text: environment outside the park and the natural and cultural features inside. Park planners
label: Paragraph

text: sited the buildings at strategic points in an effort to funnel tourists through an orientation
label: Paragraph

text: process, a critical component of the Mission 66 visitor center campaign. Once inside the
label: Paragraph

text: building, visitors found interpretive exhibits, safety guidelines, educational pamphlets,
label: Paragraph

text: maps, and a helpful ranger to answer questions. Many of the buildings offered panoramic
label: Paragraph

text: views of nearby scenic vistas; a well-marked exit might lead to an open patio for an on-
label: Paragraph

text: site ranger presentation or the first stop on a self-guided tour.
label: Paragraph

text: To attract visitors, architects created innovative, high-profile buildings that promised
label: Paragraph

text: modern facilities in even the most remote locales. Bold dramatic rooflines, wide expanses
label: Paragraph

text: of glass, overhanging eaves, and prominent entryways raised the visibility, and therefore
label: Paragraph

text: the appeal, of the buildings to the public. To maintain a contextual continuity, architects
label: Paragraph

text: incorporated physical or symbolic characteristics of the site in the building design. For
label: Paragraph

text: example, architect Richard Neutra designed the Visitor Center and Cyclorama Building at
label: Paragraph

text: Gettysburg National Military Park (1961) as a memorial to Abraham Lincoln and his
label: Paragraph

text: famous address. The monumental profile of the stark white cylindrical building,
label: Caption

text: displaying such modern design elements as movable sun louvers and a concrete spider-
label: Paragraph

text: leg, reflects the commemorative character of the 1863 Civil War battlefield and nearby
label: Paragraph

text: cemetery. Similarly, Romaldo Giurgola of Mitchell/Giurgola Architects conveyed the
label: Paragraph

text: spirit of innovation in designing a visitor center for the Wright Brothers National
label: Paragraph

text: Memorial at Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina (1960). The center’s sweeping sculptural
label: Caption

text: concrete form rises prominently from the sand dunes and connects the historic past to the
label: Paragraph

text: present by invoking the character of modern airport terminals of the 1960s.
label: Paragraph

text: Quarry Visitor Center (1956-58), Dinosaur National Monument, Jensen, Utah
label: Caption

text: © Christine Madrid French, 2000
label: Caption

text: The visitor center prototype introduced by the National Park Service in the mid-1950s
label: Paragraph

text: has been widely adopted by other civic and corporate entities in the decades since. Older
label: Paragraph

text: structures designed as small-scale museums, information centers, or nature centers were
label: Paragraph

text: remodeled or replaced by multipurpose facilities; others were simply renamed “visitor
label: Paragraph

text: centers.” In the late 1960s, Pacific Gas and Electric of California established visitor
label: Paragraph

text: centers at its nuclear power plants as part of a massive pronuclear public relations
label: Paragraph

text: campaign. British Nuclear Fuels Limited followed quickly with its own center, featuring
label: Paragraph

text: a life-size model of a nuclear reactor core and a walk-in “Fission Tunnel.” Other
label: Paragraph

text: government agencies, such as the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation and the National Forest
label: Paragraph

text: Service, followed the Park Service example and created their own system of visitor
label: Paragraph

text: centers in the 1970s at national recreation areas and national forests.
label: Paragraph

text: Once considered gateways to other featured attractions, visitor centers are now
label: Paragraph

text: marketed as destinations in themselves. It is not unusual to find photographs of visitor
label: Paragraph

text: centers proudly displayed on postcards or prominently featured in promotional brochures.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, several early examples of the building type are now recognized by leading
label: Paragraph

text: architects and scholars as American cultural landmarks, worthy of preservation and
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 50 years since its introduction, the visitor center has evolved into an
label: Paragraph

text: entertainment complex as well as an information service center, combining full-scale
label: Paragraph

text: museum features, retail outlets, and research facilities. It is a testament to the utility and
label: Paragraph

text: adaptability of this modern building type that we now consider the visitor center a
label: Paragraph

text: timeless element of the American roadside landscape.
label: Paragraph
