text: VOISIN PLAN FOR PARIS (1925)
label: Caption

text: Designed by Le Corbusier
label: Caption

text: In the Voisin Plan, Le Corbusier adapted the principles of his Contemporary City for
label: Paragraph

text: Three Million Inhabitants (1922) to the specific situation of Paris. In 1922 a sketch
label: Paragraph

text: accompanying the Contemporary City demonstrated an adaptation of the plan to the
label: Paragraph

text: historic center of Paris. In 1925 the renovation of Paris became the main issue. The plan
label: Paragraph

text: was exhibited at the Pavilion of Esprit Nouveau at the International Decorative Arts
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition of 1925. The pavilion was an architectural manifesto that showcased two
label: Paragraph

text: projects: a residence type that systematically used standard elements and a study of the
label: Paragraph

text: principles of standardization in their urban and interurban context. The former was
label: Paragraph

text: represented by a full-scale model of a unit from the Immeuble Villas block. The latter,
label: Paragraph

text: the Voisin Plan and the Contemporary City, were featured in an annex of the pavilion.
label: Caption

text: Although a theoretical exercise, the plan was also a concrete proposal aimed at the
label: Paragraph

text: transformation of Paris and marked the first of Le Corbusier’s numerous proposals for
label: Paragraph

text: Paris, including the Ville Radieuse (Radiant City; ca. 1930) and Le Destin de Paris (The
label: Paragraph

text: Destiny of Paris; 1941). Eugéne Hénard’s Etudes sur les transformations de Paris
label: Caption

text: (Studies on the Transformations of Paris; 1903-06) was an influential precedent.
label: Paragraph

text: Somewhat sensational, the radical Voisin Plan was severely denigrated by critics who
label: Paragraph

text: accused Le Corbusier of wanting to destroy Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: The plan addressed the urgent problems facing Paris: overcrowding, traffic congestion,
label: Paragraph

text: and the lack of office space. Central to the plan was Le Corbusier’s conception of the
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between skyscrapers and traffic routes, based on the principles of high
label: Paragraph

text: density, open space, and speed. Le Corbusier wrote in Urbanisme (City of Tomorrow,
label: Paragraph

text: 1925) that the plan did not provide definitive solutions to the problems of Paris but that
label: Paragraph

text: its primary aim was to cut through small, uncoordinated efforts at renovation and raise
label: Paragraph

text: the level of discussion to large-scale reforms that would incorporate contemporary issues.
label: Paragraph

text: To transform Paris into a modem city, Le Corbusier invoked the tradition of urban
label: Paragraph

text: planning. Facing the dilemma of medicine or surgery, he referred to the tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: applying both and chose surgery for the historical center. The projected site was an L-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped area of 240 hectares located northeast of the Louvre on the Right Bank. Most
label: Paragraph

text: buildings and streets were to be demolished for the area to be built anew in a rigorous
label: Paragraph

text: geometric pattern. Only a few isolated, historic buildings were to be preserved: the
label: Paragraph

text: Louvre, Palais Royal, Place Vendéme, Place de la Concorde, Arc de Triomphe, Opera,
label: Caption

text: and a few churches and town houses.
label: Paragraph

text: In the business district on the eastern half of the area facing the Ile de la Cité, 18
label: Caption

text: cruciform office towers, surrounded by open, green space, were to be built along the axis
label: Paragraph

text: of the Boulevard Sébastopol. In the western, residential district were to be the setback, or
label: Paragraph

text: redent, blocks, either of the Immeuble-Villas type that form large blocks or covered with
label: Paragraph

text: immense sheets of glass. Streets were replaced by elevated terraces with shops, cafes, and
label: Paragraph

text: restaurants for social and commercial functions. Underlying the ideology of creating
label: Paragraph

text: well-being and happiness through large-scale planning was the political notion that the
label: Paragraph

text: problems of social disorder could be resolved by the provision of the essential joys of
label: Paragraph

text: sunlight, greenery, and leisure.
label: Paragraph

text: Another essential component of the plan was hygienic and comfortable dwellings. The
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited full-scale model unit was a standardized modern duplex that, superimposed
label: Paragraph

text: with other duplexes, formed the apartment block. This seminal building type marked a
label: Paragraph

text: new approach to architecture. Built in reinforced concrete and Cubist in form, its design
label: Paragraph

text: centered around spatial proportions and volumes rather than around a two-dimensional
label: Paragraph

text: facade. Its double-height living area and garden terrace would recur in Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: designs. The unit was furnished according to the purist canon of objets-types that
label: Paragraph

text: balanced folk, craft, and machine-made objects.
label: Paragraph

text: The name Voisin points to one of the essential aims of the project: the creation of a
label: Paragraph

text: wide east—west artery parallel to the rue de Rivoli for fast automobile traffic. To finance
label: Paragraph

text: the Pavilion of Esprit Nouveau, Le Corbusier sent out letters to the biggest names in the
label: Paragraph

text: automobile industry—Voisin, Michelin, and Citroén—asking them to contribute funds in
label: Paragraph

text: exchange for publicity. The Voisin car and airplane cartel, which was interested in mass-
label: Paragraph

text: produced housing, supported the project. Le Corbusier regarded locomotion
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously as a modern influence threatening Paris that required reorganization and
label: Paragraph

text: also as one of the fundamental sources of power for the modern commercial city, as is
label: Paragraph

text: illustrated by his entrepreneurial aphorism “A city made for speed is a city made for
label: Paragraph

text: success.” Financially, however, as with other aspects of the plan, the construction of the
label: Paragraph

text: artery was not a viable idea. If enacted, it would have been one of the most costly as well
label: Paragraph

text: as destructive projects to be carried out in Paris. Financially and politically, the plan was
label: Paragraph

text: unrealistic.
label: Paragraph

text: In the history of urban planning, the Voisin Plan has often been singled out as a
label: Paragraph

text: symbol of the Modern movement’s disregard for the past. However, Le Corbusier’s own
label: Paragraph

text: view was that through the plan the prestigious vestiges of Paris were not only preserved
label: Paragraph

text: but rescued as well. By opening up the area around the monuments, they were to be
label: Paragraph

text: protected from the daily urban activities that endangered them. According to this logic,
label: Paragraph

text: the buildings now became monuments to be conserved and thus were reintegrated into
label: Paragraph

text: the fabric of the modern city. In this way Le Corbusier’s dogmatic project nonetheless
label: Paragraph

text: underlined the dynamic between renovation and conservation. Moreover, in later plans
label: Paragraph

text: some of the most radical features of the plan were modified. In 1933 the cruciform
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper was replaced with a smaller, Y-shaped type that allowed in more sunlight. In
label: Paragraph

text: the later plans, these skyscrapers were to be built far from the existing center. Although it
label: Paragraph

text: was the earlier, cruciform towers that were enthusiastically adopted by planners through
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s, other aspects of the plan, such as the Immeuble-Villas unit and the overall call
label: Paragraph

text: for systematic planning, fundamentally influenced 20th-century architecture.

text: VON MOOS, STANISLAUS 1940
label: Title

text: Architecture historian and critic, Switzerland
label: Title

text: In the history of modern architecture, Switzerland is the European country whose role
label: Paragraph

text: and import have been sorely underplayed and underacknowledged. However, thanks to
label: Paragraph

text: the assiduous and careful scholarship of Stanislaus von Moos, the Swiss contribution to
label: Paragraph

text: 20th-century building has been immeasurably enhanced. More than any other Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: national, Von Moos has maintained a vigorous sponsorship of art and architecture from
label: Paragraph

text: his native country through a varied program of publishing, curatorial practice, and above
label: Paragraph

text: all, pedagogy.
label: Paragraph

text: Born in Lucerne in 1940, Von Moos studied at the Eidgenés-sische Technische
label: Paragraph

text: Hochschule in Zurich and later at the University of Zurich and the Universita degli Studi
label: Paragraph

text: in Florence. From the university he received a Ph.D. with a thesis on military architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and its impact on 15th- and 16th-century European palaces and villas, later published as
label: Paragraph

text: Turm und Bollwerk: Beitrdge zu einen politischen [konographie der italienischen
label: Title

text: Renaissancearchitektur (1974). However, during his studies in Zurich, he had the good
label: Paragraph

text: fortune to serve as research assistant to Sigfried Giedion, whose Space, Time, and
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture (1941) certainly whetted his appetite for future studies of the modern period
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture and served as a template for his own major publications.
label: Paragraph

text: Von Moos’s foray into 20th-century topics began when he was asked to contribute to a
label: Paragraph

text: series of monographs on notable Swiss men and women, an assignment that would
label: Paragraph

text: determine the trajectory of his career from that moment forward. Noting the absence in
label: Paragraph

text: the late 1960s of a comprehensive and critical study of Le Corbusier, Von Moos
label: Paragraph

text: embarked on such a project, to be published in 1968 as Le Corbusier; Elemente einer
label: Paragraph

text: Synthese (published a decade later in English translation). For the first time since Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s death in 1965, and continuing more or less to the present day, Von Moos’s
label: Paragraph

text: chef d’oeuvre was and is the only attempt to understand Le Corbusier’s career from a
label: Paragraph

text: synthetic point of view, encompassing his paintings and graphics, writings, unbuilt
label: Paragraph

text: projects, and built work. The success of the work is tied to Von Moos’s meticulous
label: Paragraph

text: research and his access (beginning with Giedion) to many of Le Corbusier’s compatriots
label: Paragraph

text: and collaborators.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier: Elements of a Synthesis, the work’s English title, is presented as a series
label: Paragraph

text: of essays on different aspects of Le Corbusier’s work, including purism, urbanism,
label: Paragraph

text: utopian visions, typology, and public commissions. Von Moos writes of Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: “visual and poetic approach to reality,” a formal reading that allows the author to
label: Paragraph

text: establish a teleology of Le Corbusier’s oeuvre from the Villas Fallet and Schwob (his
label: Paragraph

text: earliest works in Switzerland), to his purist paintings of the 1920s, to the later works of
label: Paragraph

text: Chandigarh and La Tourette monastery, foregrounding what Von Moos sees as Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s Ruskinian tendency to identify a fundamental order and organization within
label: Paragraph

text: nature.
label: Paragraph

text: As the first book to treat Le Corbusier as a historical subject, Elements is responsible
label: Paragraph

text: for many of the originary ideas about the architect’s works; for example, Von Moos
label: Paragraph

text: indicates the use of continuous typologies for specific building uses, such as the
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal box for dwellings, the spiral for museums, and the triangle for assembly halls.
label: Paragraph

text: In doing so, Von Moos builds on earlier work by Colin Rowe that analyzes Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s recycling of themes and motifs in differmg projects as a process of
label: Paragraph

text: “displacement.” Thus, the book’s strength lies in its central belief in a specific
label: Paragraph

text: architectural practice’s underlying system that found its ultimate epiphany in Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s Modulor system of measurement, one that expressed “a common
label: Paragraph

text: denominator between human proportions and elemental geometry.”
label: Paragraph

text: Von Moos’s interest in architectural polemicists led him to his next major subject: the
label: Paragraph

text: writings and practice of Robert Venturi. Von Moos had already broached the similarities
label: Paragraph

text: between Venturi and Le Corbusier in Elements, which led him to recognize the attention
label: Paragraph

text: to typological study that bound these two architects together. While teaching at Harvard
label: Paragraph

text: University in the early 1970s, Von Moos found in Venturi an introduction to American
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular architecture; building on the apparent relationship between Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: Towards a New Architecture (1923) and Venturi’s Complexity and Contradiction in
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture (1966)—which share an ahistoricism and privileging of aesthetics over
label: Paragraph

text: history—he embarked on the first major study of the latter’s work (Venturi, Rauch, and
label: Paragraph

text: Scott Brown: Buildings and Projects [1987]).
label: Caption

text: The book is arranged as an extended essay and catalogue raisonné, with the essay “The
label: Paragraph

text: Challenge of the Status Quo: 5 Points on the Architecture of VRSB” belying a further
label: Paragraph

text: debt to Le Corbusier. Von Moos adopts the role of apologist, elucidating one of the first
label: Paragraph

text: and most extended defenses of Venturi’s built work and providing the means away from
label: Paragraph

text: a narrow vision of Venturi as mere pop theorist and toward one that considers his
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in a serious manner. As in his treatment of Le Corbusier, thematic and
label: Paragraph

text: typological motifs (such as the segmented arch, adapted from Louis Kahn) are traced
label: Paragraph

text: through their use in different contexts as a means of exploring the plastic and fungible
label: Paragraph

text: quality of architectural themes in Venturi’s practice.
label: Paragraph

text: Von Moos also fashioned a career as an important curator, having organized important
label: Paragraph

text: exhibitions devoted to Venturi (“Venturi and Rauch: Architektur im Alltag Amerikas”)
label: Caption

text: for the Kunstgewerbemuseum in Zurich (1979) and a major show cele-brating Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s 100th birthday (“L’Esprit nouveau: Le Corbusier und die Industrie, 1920-
label: Title

text: 1925”) for the Museum fiir Gestaltung in Zurich (1987). In the latter exhibition, Von
label: Paragraph

text: Moos revisited familiar terrain, focusing on Le Corbusier’s early theories and their
label: Paragraph

text: organization around industrial themes. In addition, as curator of the Swiss Pavilion for
label: Paragraph

text: the 1998 Milan Triennale, he initiated a recuperation of another much maligned figure:
label: Paragraph

text: the Swiss artist/architect/teacher Max Bill.
label: Paragraph

text: Von Moos’s work displays an admirable ability to project patriotic pride while
label: Paragraph

text: avoiding xenophobia. One of his most enduring and selfless projects was as founder and
label: Paragraph

text: editor in chief of the architectural quarterly archithese. From its appearance in 1970 and
label: Paragraph

text: continuing to the present, this journal has provided a crucial voice for European
label: Paragraph

text: architectural criticism and theory, with a purview beyond mere Swiss national concerns.
label: Paragraph

text: As a professor in Europe and abroad, Von Moos has maintained a commitment to
label: Paragraph

text: pedagogy seemingly at odds with the vast amount of writing and research required of his
label: Paragraph

text: manifold other projects.
label: Paragraph

text: VOYSEY, CHARLES FRANCIS ANNESLEY
label: Title

text: Architect and designer, England
label: Title

text: C.F.A.Voysey was, on the one hand, a late product of the English Gothic Revival and,
label: Paragraph

text: on the other, an original and innovative architect who is regarded today as important for
label: Paragraph

text: the development of the new architecture of the 20th century. Although he lived long
label: Paragraph

text: enough to know and to dislike the International Style of the 1920s and 1930s, the
label: Paragraph

text: publication of Voysey’s designs in British, German, Belgian, and Austrian magazines
label: Paragraph

text: before 1900 was definitely influential on those who formulated the new architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Soon after the turn of the century, his work was also noticed, exhibited, and admired in
label: Paragraph

text: the United States and in Scandinavia. C.R.Mackintosh, whose work Voysey did not like,
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged his formative influence. Acknowledged as an enigmatic architect with
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat ambiguous ties to the English Gothic and Arts and Crafts movements of the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century, Voysey nonetheless provided many architects of the first third of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century with a sense of invention and synthesis in his practice of design. Seeking to
label: Paragraph

text: extract meaning from rural vernacular architecture and from contemporary work by C.R.
label: Paragraph

text: Ashbee or Arthur H.Mackmurdo, Voysey emphasized simplicity, a principle that
label: Paragraph

text: mattered to many architects both inside and outside the Modern movement.
label: Paragraph

text: He was born at Hessle in Yorkshire, the eldest son of a Church of England clergyman,
label: Paragraph

text: and his father had a profound influence on him. The Reverend Charles Voysey was a man
label: Paragraph

text: of resolute faith who was nevertheless eventually expelled from the Anglican Church for
label: Paragraph

text: heresy: He denied the doctrine of everlasting hell. Reverend Voysey then formed his own
label: Paragraph

text: Theistic Church based on rational principles. Voysey’s religious convictions, firm
label: Paragraph

text: independence, and unshakable integrity owed much to his father’s example. He was
label: Paragraph

text: taught at home until he was 14 and then attended Dulwich College for two years (1871—
label: Paragraph

text: 73), after which he briefly had a private tutor. As he was a slow learner whose grammar
label: Paragraph

text: and spelling always remained shaky, his education appears to have been narrow and
label: Paragraph

text: limited.
label: Paragraph

text: At the age of 17, Voysey was articled to John Pollard Seddon and remained in his
label: Paragraph

text: London office for six years. He then worked briefly (1879) in the office of Saxon Snell,
label: Paragraph

text: who specialized in hospitals, before spending the next two years with the fashionable
label: Paragraph

text: country house architect George Devey.
label: Caption

text: In 1881, at the age of 24, Voysey set up his own practice in Westminster. He was a
label: Paragraph

text: passionate devotee of the writings of both Pugin and Ruskin, both of whom had been
label: Paragraph

text: known personally by his father; from them, he developed his conviction that the laws of
label: Paragraph

text: design and construction should be learned from the study of nature. One of the strongest
label: Paragraph

text: professional influences on Voysey was that of A.LH.Mackmurdo, a protégé of Ruskin’s,
label: Paragraph

text: who introduced Voysey to the design of wallpapers and encouraged him to join the Art
label: Paragraph

text: Workers’ Guild in 1884.
label: Paragraph

text: “To be simple is the end, not the beginning of design,” Voysey wrote in 1893. He
label: Paragraph

text: usually drew together the elements of his houses into a single volume, covering this
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular form with a high-pitched gable or hipped roof of slate. Wall surfaces were
label: Paragraph

text: plain, characteristically rendered with gray- or white-painted roughcast. Buttresses,
label: Caption

text: incorporated sculpturally into the wall treatment, were needed to support the deep,
label: Paragraph

text: sweeping roofs. His windows were usually stone mullioned, with metal casements, and
label: Paragraph

text: arranged in long horizontal groups. Chimney stacks were few and were sculpturally
label: Paragraph

text: related to the walls and buttresses in material and form.
label: Caption

text: Voysey’s first commission was for The Cottage (1888-89) in Warwickshire, for which
label: Paragraph

text: he employed roughcast rendering, as his client was a cement manufacturer. From that
label: Paragraph

text: time on, he preferred this wall treatment; he also almost always used greenish gray slates
label: Paragraph

text: for roofs, seldom paying attention to local building traditions. His tall, narrow, white and
label: Paragraph

text: gray house at 14 South Parade (1888-91) in Bedford Park still contrasts sharply with its
label: Paragraph

text: red-brick, red-tiled neighbors by Norman Shaw, although he was obliged to use the latter
label: Paragraph

text: materials for his twin town houses, 14 and 16 Hans Road (1891-92).
label: Caption

text: Similar in style is a superb series of houses in the country: Perrycroft (1893) in
label: Paragraph

text: Malvern; Lowicks (1894) in Tilford; Annesley Lodge (1895), for his father, in London;
label: Paragraph

text: Greyfriars (1896),
label: Paragraph

text: House at Lowicks, Surrey, designed by Charles F.A. Voysey
label: Caption

text: © Alan Windsor
label: Title

text: for the American writer Julian Sturgis, in Surrey; Norney and New Place (both 1897;
label: Paragraph

text: both in Surrey); and his own house, The Orchard (1899), in Chorleywood. All have cool,
label: Paragraph

text: spare interiors. The welcoming entrance hall has a fireplace; the staircase rises, usually
label: Paragraph

text: with a screen of tall, thin, plain, square-sectioned wooden balusters uniting the lower and
label: Paragraph

text: upper floors. Living rooms usually have inglenook fireplaces, ceramic tiled or paneled
label: Paragraph

text: with plain marble sheets. In each bedroom, a small ventilator panel of pierced and
label: Caption

text: decorated metal admits fresh air through three narrow slits in the center of the gable
label: Paragraph

text: outside. Norney and New Place have semicircular, or “bow,” windows, a feature that
label: Paragraph

text: subsequently became very popular in England for small suburban houses. The guttering
label: Paragraph

text: of the house is characteristically supported at intervals on thin, prominent iron brackets.
label: Caption

text: Doors have long wrought-iron hinge straps terminating in a heart shape and are
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes pierced with a hole of that shape; another Voysey signature is the sly, almost
label: Paragraph

text: hidden grotesque caricature of himself or of his client as an unobtrusive profile molding
label: Paragraph

text: on a staircase or porch bracket. “Simplicity, sincerity, repose, directness and frankness
label: Caption

text: are moral qualities as essential to good architecture as they are to good men,” wrote
label: Paragraph

text: Voysey.
label: Paragraph

text: At Broadleys (1898) on Lake Windermere, Voysey’s most celebrated masterpiece, he
label: Paragraph

text: introduced three commanding bow windows to provide maximum enjoyment of the
label: Paragraph

text: views of the lake and the mountains beyond; Voysey’s houses are always sensitively
label: Paragraph

text: responsive to their settings.
label: Paragraph

text: An exceptional commission was for the Sanderson’s Wallpaper Factory (1902) in
label: Paragraph

text: Chiswick: a three-story rectangular building in which concrete floors resting on steel
label: Paragraph

text: joists are supported by hollow piers that act also as ventilation shafts. Between these
label: Paragraph

text: extend large steel-framed windows; there are no walls. The roof is hidden behind a tall
label: Paragraph

text: parapet of wavy-topped sections between each pier. The whole building is clad in white-
label: Paragraph

text: glazed bricks, and although quite unlike any of his houses, Voysey’s design vocabulary is
label: Paragraph

text: here perfectly consistent with certain aspects of his style, particularly that of his furniture.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite his international fame, Voysey’s practice almost ceased after 1914, and for the
label: Paragraph

text: rest of his long life, apart from a handful of commissions and some extensions to earlier
label: Paragraph

text: houses, his main income came from designing wallpapers, fabrics, metalwork, and
label: Paragraph

text: furniture. In 1924, he became master of the Art Workers’ Guild. He was awarded the
label: Paragraph

text: Royal Gold Medal of the Royal Institute of British Architects in 1940.
label: Caption

text: WAGNER, OTTO 1841-1918
label: Title

text: Architect, Austria
label: Title

text: Otto Wagner’s career spanned the transition from 19th-century historical revivalism to
label: Paragraph

text: the emergence of a new modern architecture. From the mid-1890s to the time of his death
label: Paragraph

text: at the end of World War I, he occupied a place at the forefront of the modernist assault in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna. Yet Wagner’s works and ideas were often complex and contradictory, and his
label: Paragraph

text: position with respect to the modernist program was not infrequently ambiguous.
label: Paragraph

text: Although he was among the foremost early proponents of a new tectonic rationalism,
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner never wholly shed traditional notions of style and beauty, and his lifelong
label: Paragraph

text: ambition, to become the architect to the Habsburg imperial household, stood in glaring
label: Paragraph

text: opposition to his desire to forge a new building art for the modern metropolis.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner’s early years paralleled the development of the Vienna Ringstrasse, and many
label: Paragraph

text: of his assumptions were shaped by the prevailing ideals and practices of the era. Born in
label: Paragraph

text: 1841 into a family of wealthy bourgeois bureaucrats, Wagner received his early
label: Paragraph

text: architectural training at the Vienna Technical University (1857-59) and the Royal
label: Paragraph

text: Building Academy in Berlin (1860), where he studied with the successors of Karl
label: Paragraph

text: Friedrich Schinkel. However, it was at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna, which
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner entered in October 1861, where he encountered the two figures who would form
label: Paragraph

text: his architectural outlook: August Sicardsburg and Eduard van der Nill. Sicardsburg and
label: Paragraph

text: van der Niill, designers of the Vienna Opera House, had long advocated the necessity of
label: Paragraph

text: finding a “rational expression for modern architecture” (quoted in Graf, 1987). Wagner’s
label: Paragraph

text: later appreciation of utility and his search for a new language of construction arose from
label: Paragraph

text: their teachings, and it was to van der Nill that he attributed his refined facility for
label: Paragraph

text: drawing.
label: Paragraph

text: After completing his education at the Academy in 1863, Wagner embarked on his
label: Paragraph

text: architectural career. Early on, however, he found few commissions for public projects,
label: Paragraph

text: and he worked instead on a series of apartment houses, a number of which he financed
label: Paragraph

text: himself as speculative ventures. Many of these buildings were executed in a “free
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance” style, and this new astringent and innovative classicism became the young
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner’s hallmark. By the late 1880s, Wagner was considered the preeminent builder of
label: Paragraph

text: tenement houses in Vienna, but his attempts to secure more prestigious works remained
label: Paragraph

text: mostly fruitless. Among the notable exceptions were his Orthodox Synagogue (1871-76)
label: Paragraph

text: in Budapest and the Osterreichische Landerbank (1882-84) in Vienna. The former was
label: Paragraph

text: executed in a neo-Moorish idiom and the latter in Wagner’s more characteristic
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance style, but in both buildings the outer historicist skin concealed what were—
label: Paragraph

text: in material, constructional, and spatial terms—already remarkably modern buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner, however, continued to experiment with more conventional ideas of
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality and form, as his neobaroque <Artibus project of 1880 powerfully
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrates, and it was not until the early 1890s that he fully emerged in the guise of an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural reformer.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner’s transformation followed in the wake of his successful entry into the Vienna
label: Paragraph

text: city-planning competition held in 1893. Drawing on his own growing sense of the
label: Paragraph

text: primacy of functionality, Wagner’s proposal emphasized the creation of an extensive
label: Paragraph

text: urban rail network as well as the regulation of the Danube Canal and the Wien River.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner’s straightforward response to the problems of traffic and urban expansion drew
label: Paragraph

text: widespread praise, and as a consequence, he was named chief architect of the municipal
label: Paragraph

text: railway system in 1894. The work, which continued until 1901, not only required Wagner
label: Paragraph

text: to design more than 30 stations but also involved the siting and design of a series of
label: Paragraph

text: bridges, tunnels, and viaducts. Wagner’s first stations, executed in brick and stucco with
label: Paragraph

text: pronounced classical detailing, reflected traditional ideas of building “art.” However, as
label: Paragraph

text: construction progressed, he began to explore a more stripped and utilitarian idiom. After
label: Paragraph

text: 1897, Wagner also investigated the possibilities of the new Jugendstil language, which he
label: Paragraph

text: combined with elements of Renaissance and baroque classicism. In some instances, such
label: Paragraph

text: as the twin stations on the Karlsplatz that he produced in collaboration with his younger
label: Paragraph

text: protégé, Josef Maria Olbrich, Wagner’s solutions pointed toward a new mode of
label: Paragraph

text: building—a light iron skeleton framing thin slabs of marble—that anticipated the
label: Paragraph

text: constructions of the 1920s and beyond. Yet other features of Wagner’s designs reveal his
label: Paragraph

text: continuing allegiance to the past: the private railway pavilion he designed for the imperial
label: Paragraph

text: family at the Schénbrunn Palace—despite its ebullient iron porte-cochére—was still
label: Paragraph

text: firmly rooted in the “style architecture” of the Ringstrasse era, and many of his other
label: Paragraph

text: stations included features—swags, statuary, wreaths, and rustication—intended to
label: Paragraph

text: disguise or aestheticize their structural details.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1894, shortly after beginning work on the city railway project, Wagner was
label: Paragraph

text: appointed professor of architecture at the Academy of Fine Arts. Although the chair,
label: Paragraph

text: previously occupied by the noted Ringstrasse architect Carl von Hasenauer, was reserved
label: Paragraph

text: for a “convinced representative of classical Renaissance,” Wagner in his inaugural
label: Paragraph

text: address called for a new, “realist” approach to the problem of modern building:
label: Paragraph

text: Our living conditions and methods of construction must be fully and completely
label: Paragraph

text: expressed if architecture is not to be reduced to caricature. The realism of our
label: Paragraph

text: time must pervade the developing work of art. It will not harm it, nor will any
label: Paragraph

text: decline of art ensue as a consequence of it; rather it will breathe a new and
label: Paragraph

text: pulsating life into forms, and in time conquer new fields that today are still
label: Paragraph

text: devoid of art—for example that of engineering. (quoted in Mallgrave, 1993)
label: Paragraph

text: He sounded these same themes again in his book, Modern Architecture, which appeared
label: Paragraph

text: the following year. Conceived as both textbook and manifesto, the work assailed the
label: Paragraph

text: inability of 19th-century “style architecture” to meet the needs of modern urban life.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner called instead for a visual language suited to the
label: Paragraph

text: Church of St. Leopold am Steinhof (1907)
label: Caption

text: Photo © Mary Ann Sullivan
label: Caption

text: new age, one that could fulfill the requirements of the expanding metropolis. Wagner’s
label: Paragraph

text: insistence on pragmatism, like his chosen motto for the Stadtbahn project (borrowed
label: Paragraph

text: from Gottfried Semper), artis sola domina necessitas (Necessity is the only master of
label: Paragraph

text: art), however, merely concealed his own lofty “artistic” ideals: he maintained that the
label: Paragraph

text: mission of the architect was to find a means of reconciling the realistic and utilitarian
label: Paragraph

text: with the forms of artistic expression and that it was only through this mediation that mere
label: Paragraph

text: building could be elevated to Baukunst (building art).
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner sought to communicate these ideas not only through his works but also in his
label: Paragraph

text: teachings. Between 1894 and 1912, he devoted a significant portion of his time and
label: Paragraph

text: energy to his “Special class”—the so-called Wagnerschule, or Wagner School—at the
label: Paragraph

text: Academy; and his students, who included Josef Hoffmann, Joze Plecnik, Jan Kotera,
label: Paragraph

text: Pavel Janak, Rudolf Perco, Karl Ehn, and Hubert and Franz Gessner, among others,
label: Paragraph

text: subsequently assumed a central position in the avant-garde in Central Europe. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner’s stated conviction that truthful and logical construction should constitute the
label: Paragraph

text: basis for architecture’s renewal, however, many of his students were more taken with his
label: Paragraph

text: language of form, which emphasized the importance of masking or wrapping the internal
label: Paragraph

text: structure in an outer aesthetic veil. This idea, adapted by Wagner from Semper’s theory
label: Paragraph

text: of Bekleidung, or “dressing,” emphasized the use of poetic forms or symbols to represent
label: Paragraph

text: themes that could not be expressed through structure alone. Such an approach stood in
label: Paragraph

text: direct opposition to later concepts of modernism, which advocated clarity and rationality,
label: Paragraph

text: yet it had a profound and lasting impact on a whole range of younger Central European
label: Paragraph

text: architects and designers, who reshaped it to articulate a wide array of social, cultural, and
label: Paragraph

text: economic messages.
label: Paragraph

text: In Wagner’s own work, this tactic of Bekleidung assumed various guises. In 1898-99,
label: Paragraph

text: in a pair of adjacent buildings on the Linke Wienzeile, it appeared in the form of a florid
label: Paragraph

text: Jugendstil idiom, the ornament often reduced to two-dimensional graphics or low-relief
label: Paragraph

text: appliqué. By the early years of the 20th century, however, Wagner had abandoned this
label: Paragraph

text: language in favor of a stripped, utilitarian classicism, which he combined with geometric
label: Paragraph

text: forms. His Postal Savings Bank (1904-06, 1910-12), for example, still observed the
label: Paragraph

text: conventions of a rusticated base and elaborate cornice, but he added to it elements of the
label: Paragraph

text: new rectilinear Jugendstil. Consistent with his belief in the necessity of adopting new
label: Paragraph

text: forms of construction, Wagner employed reinforced concrete for the floors of this large
label: Paragraph

text: office block and made extensive use of aluminum, which he exploited both for its
label: Paragraph

text: structural qualities and for its aesthetic values. Yet the most dramatic feature of its
label: Paragraph

text: exterior, the aluminum-headed pins that appear to affix the thin stone panels to the walls
label: Paragraph

text: while reinforcing the impression of tectonic play, were as much symbolic as structural.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the pins (which were actually iron but clad in lead with polished aluminum
label: Paragraph

text: caps so that they would not discolor the marble) served a purpose—to support the
label: Paragraph

text: underlying mortar—they were also intended to express solidity and stability and thus to
label: Paragraph

text: reinforce the idea of the building’s “dress.”
label: Paragraph

text: If the Postal Savings Bank betokened a new Nuizstil, or utilitarian style, Wagner’s
label: Paragraph

text: unrealized designs for the Franz Josef-Stadtmuseum (city museum) suggested how past
label: Paragraph

text: and new forms might be fused to fashion a modern monumentality. Wagner labored on
label: Paragraph

text: the project for more than a decade, from 1900 to 1912, producing a number of variant
label: Paragraph

text: designs. However, despite his efforts to forge a “modern way of building” that retained
label: Paragraph

text: the monumental grandeur associated with 19th-century architecture, his building failed to
label: Paragraph

text: find official or public acceptance—a telling reminder of how strongly Wagner’s
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic, even in its most traditional form, ran counter to the contemporary taste.
label: Paragraph

text: Around 1905, Wagner produced two further examples of the stone-panel-and-
label: Paragraph

text: aluminum-pin idiom he had announced in the Postal Savings Bank: the Church of St.
label: Paragraph

text: Leopold am Steinhof (1905-07) and the Kaiserbad Control House (1904-05) on the
label: Paragraph

text: Danube Canal. However, in his subsequent designs he returned to a highly simplified,
label: Paragraph

text: functional language. This last phase of his work is perhaps best exemplified by the
label: Paragraph

text: residential apartment building (1909-10) at Neustiftgasse 40, which, with its clear,
label: Paragraph

text: blocklike form and regular fenestration, pointed firmly in the direction of a developing
label: Paragraph

text: modularity.
label: Paragraph

text: This gesture toward a new practical aesthetic similarly informed the design of the
label: Paragraph

text: housing blocks depicted in Wagner’s Project for the Future Twenty-second District of
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna, published in his work Die Grossstadt (1911; The Metropolis). The 23-page
label: Paragraph

text: pamphlet laid out Wagner’s mature ideas on city planning, describing in precise terms
label: Paragraph

text: both an architectural and an economic solution to the problem of the expanding city. He
label: Paragraph

text: argued that future growth could be financed through municipal control of public utilities
label: Paragraph

text: and by permitting the city authorities to buy and sell properties. To enable the city to
label: Paragraph

text: grow, he called for new urban districts of 100,000 to 150,000 inhabitants, with both
label: Paragraph

text: dwellings and places of work in close proximity to allow residents to work and reside in
label: Paragraph

text: the same area. Each district would have a formal “air center” for its public and cultural
label: Paragraph

text: institutions surrounded by uniform apartment buildings. The basic street system would
label: Paragraph

text: follow a grid, and radial arteries and circular belts of roads and rail would provide
label: Paragraph

text: connections with the center and other districts. Monumentality would not be achieved by
label: Paragraph

text: the individual residential blocks but would arise out of their regularity and repetition.
label: Paragraph

text: Die Grossstadt was by turns both practical and utopian, but in its advocacy of rational
label: Paragraph

text: approaches to the problem of the modern city, it was consistent with Wagner’s
label: Paragraph

text: fundamental belief that purpose should be a primary determinant of form. Wagner’s
label: Paragraph

text: vision of modernism, however, although emphasizing the principle of functionality, was
label: Paragraph

text: considerably more complex and variegated. Despite his emphasis on the constructional
label: Paragraph

text: and practical aspects of building, he sought at the same time to perpetuate the
label: Paragraph

text: monumental and representational values of the old architecture as a means to maintain a
label: Paragraph

text: link with the past. In addition, he remained committed to the ideals of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: quality and art that, by the end of his life, were rapidly losing currency. Nonetheless,
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner stands as one of the great early modernist form givers, and his influence reached
label: Paragraph

text: far into the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Designed by Daniel H.Burnham, completed 1911 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
label: Caption

text: The point-and-click mentality of on-line shopping and the average neighborhood mall
label: Paragraph

text: of the late 20th century are worlds away from what was designed to be an elegant, social,
label: Paragraph

text: and even educational experience in the first department stores. This spirit was manifest in
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia’s Wanamaker’s Store. Its patron, John Wanamaker, was a_ clever
label: Paragraph

text: businessman who helped to revolutionize retailing in the United States and, while making
label: Paragraph

text: himself rich, gained the respect and loyalty of generations of Philadelphians who saw his
label: Paragraph

text: building as more than a department store: Wanamaker’s was a monument to the
label: Paragraph

text: entrepreneurial spirit, deserved success, and benevolence of John Wanamaker.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1861 Wanamaker opened a men’s apparel shop in Philadelphia with an idea that he
label: Paragraph

text: could improve the current American

text: system based on haggling and narrow specialization; by 1876 the business was successful
label: Paragraph

text: enough to fill an abandoned railroad depot, offering over two acres of floor area and a
label: Paragraph

text: variety of goods, proving the effectiveness of Wanamaker’s introduction of such French
label: Paragraph

text: retailing principles as accommodating browsing, exchanges and returns, and clearly
label: Paragraph

text: marking all goods with the same price for all. By the turn of the 20th century,
label: Paragraph

text: Wanamaker had determined to build a new, even larger establishment. After acquiring a
label: Paragraph

text: lot on Market Street in downtown Philadelphia adjacent to the Second Empire City Hall,
label: Caption

text: he looked for an architect who could house and give proper expression to his flourishing
label: Paragraph

text: business on this prestigious site. With dozens of large-scale buildings, high-rises, and
label: Paragraph

text: planning projects to his credit, Chicago architect Daniel Hudson Burnham was certainly
label: Paragraph

text: capable of an adequate solution for as big a building as Wanamaker proposed. Burnham’s
label: Paragraph

text: experience and success with this new building type, as with such clients as Marshall
label: Paragraph

text: Field, the Gimbel Brothers, Edward Filene, and Selfridge of London, made him the
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged leader of department store architecture. In addition to his technical and
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic talents, Wanamaker must have admired an architect who shared his vision:
label: Paragraph

text: Wanamaker observed of
label: Paragraph

text: John Wanamaker Building, interior Grand Court
label: Caption

text: Photo courtesy Friends of the Wanamaker Organ, Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania
label: Caption

text: Burnham, “I think he never had from his boyhood a small idea in his head” (Appel,
label: Paragraph

text: Ground was broken in February 1902. Constructed across eight years, the new building
label: Paragraph

text: was phased such that the older store emptied a section at a time into it without ever
label: Paragraph

text: halting business; parts of the new store opened successively in 1905, 1908, and 1910. Its
label: Paragraph

text: grand opening was held in 1911, Wanamaker’s jubilee year in business. The dedication
label: Paragraph

text: was celebrated in the highest style of any commercial building to date, its trappings
label: Paragraph

text: indicative of the public character of this privately financed building and 30,000 people in
label: Paragraph

text: attendance. Of special note was speaker William H.Taft; because U.S. presidents usually
label: Paragraph

text: bestowed the decorum of their office only on occasions meant to improve or enhance the
label: Paragraph

text: public welfare, the Wanamaker Store was interpreted on par with such progressive, civic-
label: Paragraph

text: minded, and publicly oriented projects as the opening of railroads or the celebration of a
label: Paragraph

text: historical event. Taft glorified the store as “one of the most important instrumentalities in
label: Paragraph

text: modern life for the promotion of comfort among people” by bringing under one roof at
label: Paragraph

text: low and fixed prices all of life’s necessities (Appel, 1930). Wanamaker, too, lauded the
label: Paragraph

text: societal importance of his store and compared it with great building projects of the past:
label: Paragraph

text: unlike the Colosseum—an architectural masterpiece but an otherwise “empty shell”—he
label: Paragraph

text: compared his store with the Cooper Union, the Carnegie Institute, and Girard College,
label: Paragraph

text: each a gift of education from a businessman. At Wanamaker’s, space was set aside for
label: Paragraph

text: workers to complete high school degrees. More generally, customers with a world of
label: Paragraph

text: goods at their fingertips could learn the geography and produce of different countries
label: Paragraph

text: along with economic lessons; they also had access to free concerts and Wanamaker’s
label: Paragraph

text: own art collection, drawn from the Paris salons, which adorned the store.
label: Paragraph

text: The building’s form was expressive of its cultured mission. Like many of his earlier
label: Paragraph

text: office blocks and department stores (especially Marshall Field’s, 1902, in Chicago),
label: Paragraph

text: Burnham conceived the Wanamaker Store after the model of a Renaissance palazzo in
label: Paragraph

text: plan and elevation. Hewn of Maine granite, the tripartite facades feature a three-story
label: Caption

text: base with large squared openings glazed with broad plate-glass display windows. Above,
label: Caption

text: seven nearly identical floors, articulated with paired windows between piers and topped
label: Caption

text: with arched windows, express the building’s repetitive steel structure in a pattern
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of H.H. Richardson’s Marshall Field Wholesale Store (1885). A classical
label: Paragraph

text: cornice two stories tall caps the building. With another three additional stories below
label: Caption

text: street level, the hulking mass commanded a full city block, its footprint measuring
label: Paragraph

text: roughly 500 by 250 feet. Hailed as the most monumental commercial structure in the
label: Paragraph

text: world, the $10 million store housed two million square feet of retailing space from which
label: Paragraph

text: one could buy literally anything, including automobiles and airplanes.
label: Paragraph

text: A model of corporate efficiency, the store was the first in America to employ a
label: Paragraph

text: pneumatic tube system, telephone service, and a ventilation fan system and to provide a
label: Paragraph

text: restaurant and U.S. parcel post delivery. The display areas were spacious and well
label: Paragraph

text: illuminated (power was furnished by Wanamaker’s own power plant on Ludlow Street),
label: Paragraph

text: arranged logically around a courtyard to provide ease of navigation through the huge
label: Paragraph

text: store. Although the functionality of the floor area was of prime concern to Burnham and
label: Paragraph

text: Wanamaker, both saw the building as more than a place to buy and sell. The building’s
label: Paragraph

text: focus is a centralized Grand Court rising 150 feet to its ceiling and surrounded by arcaded
label: Paragraph

text: galleries opening from the first seven floors, whose ceiling heights range from 15 to 25
label: Paragraph

text: feet. Giant lonic and Corinthian columns, a marble floor, and classical ornaments in
label: Caption

text: plaster and Keene cement articulate the space in which Wanamaker deposited two
label: Paragraph

text: souvenirs from the 1903 St. Louis World’s Fair: a large bronze eagle sculpture that
label: Caption

text: became a landmark in itself (Philadelphians have met under its beak for generations) and
label: Paragraph

text: a great pipe organ, advertised as the second largest in the world, on which daily concerts
label: Paragraph

text: were performed. The balcony at its base accommodated 100 musicians. In an attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: make the retail experience elegant and uplifting, as well as to educate the public in music,
label: Paragraph

text: concerts were also provided in the 1,500-seat Egyptian Room, which was adorned with
label: Paragraph

text: columns based on those at Karnak, on sphinxes, and on other Egyptian motifs. A smaller
label: Caption

text: auditorium also fitted with an organ, the mahogany-paneled Greek Room, seated 600
label: Caption

text: among sturdy Doric pilasters and columns. In keeping with the Gilded Age’s interest in
label: Paragraph

text: period rooms, the store also featured a Byzantine Hall, Empire Room, and Moorish Room
label: Paragraph

text: for special goods, further conjoining cultural lessons with retail merchandising, the
label: Paragraph

text: overall goal of Wanamaker’s.

text: WAREHOUSE
label: Title

text: Warehouses, buildings that provide storage for commercial gain, have had two primary
label: Paragraph

text: functional mandates—the provision of storage space on floors with a high load capacity
label: Paragraph

text: and the facilitation of the movement of goods and freight with materials-handling
label: Paragraph

text: equipment—since the mid-19th century, when the building type and term became
label: Paragraph

text: common. Nevertheless, warehouses underwent fundamental changes in form as well as in
label: Paragraph

text: architectural presence during the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: General-purpose, cold-storage, bonded, and household-goods warehouses, as well as
label: Paragraph

text: industry-specific facilities, were in use by the turn of the 20th century. At that time the
label: Paragraph

text: typical warehouse was a loft structure of five stories in which goods were moved with
label: Paragraph

text: platform elevators. The interior framing of these structures consisted of wood, cast-iron,
label: Paragraph

text: and wrought-iron members combined to support heavy floor loads. Masonry wareouses
label: Paragraph

text: were often divided by interior firewalls into a series of discrete spaces, and such divisions
label: Paragraph

text: were sometimes expressed on their exteriors through piers and fenestration patterns.
label: Paragraph

text: These warehouses had enough windows to light the interior without the introduction of
label: Paragraph

text: the fire hazard of lanterns and to allow for conversion of the building to other uses; as
label: Paragraph

text: electric lighting became more commonly used in warehouses, the number of window
label: Paragraph

text: openings was reduced. Exterior, raised loading platforms sheltered by sheet-metal
label: Caption

text: awnings and series of wide doorways articulated the street levels of warehouses.
label: Paragraph

text: A functional yet expressive tone of architectural styling for warehouses was set during
label: Paragraph

text: the 19th century. The sturdy brick forms and detailing of the Rundbogenstil, with piers,
label: Paragraph

text: arcades, corbeled brick cornices, and arched window openings, were often selected to
label: Paragraph

text: express both a warehouse’s stability and strength and its important role in commerce. In a
label: Paragraph

text: series of articles that appeared in the Architectural Record, the critic Russell Sturgis drew
label: Paragraph

text: attention to early 20th-century warehouse design that offered a similar clear expression of
label: Paragraph

text: structure and monumentality and was not cluttered with any applied ornament. Many
label: Paragraph

text: ware houses built during the first half of the 20th century exhibited architectural presence
label: Paragraph

text: and expressed this aesthetic sensibility as utilitarian purpose tempered references to
label: Paragraph

text: current styles.
label: Paragraph

text: During the first decades of the 20th century, warehouses reflected both the continued
label: Paragraph

text: success of capitalism and advances in building arts as the warehouses became even larger
label: Paragraph

text: and stronger and incorporated new materials-handling methods. The use of expensive
label: Paragraph

text: steel beams was often limited to the framing of wide bays on the ground floor for the
label: Paragraph

text: accommodation of rail and motor vehicles. Reinforced concrete, however, was widely
label: Paragraph

text: adopted because it was strong and fire resistant. The United States Army Supply Base
label: Paragraph

text: (1918) in Brooklyn, New York, designed by architect Cass Gilbert, consisted of a pair of
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced-concrete loft buildings that flanked a covered rail siding commanded by a
label: Paragraph

text: traveling crane. The facility was widely admired because of its materials-handling system
label: Paragraph

text: as well as for the way in which Gilbert carefully modeled the stark concrete facades to
label: Paragraph

text: convey great scale and strength. Another American project, the Starrett-Lehigh Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1930-31) in New York City, designed by Cory and Cory with Yasuo Matsui, associate
label: Caption

text: architect, demonstrated the ultimate development of the multistory warehouse both in the
label: Paragraph

text: vertical movement of goods and in the architectural expression of function. This structure
label: Paragraph

text: covered an entire block and rose to a height of 19 stories. Its steel-framed central service
label: Paragraph

text: and circulation core, which served as a “vertical street” to bring trucks to each warehouse
label: Paragraph

text: floor, was articulated by soaring pilasters. More dominant in the design, however, were
label: Paragraph

text: the flanking lofts. Their walls were slightly cantilevered beyond the exterior columns to
label: Paragraph

text: permit horizontal bands of windows and rounded corners. With its interpretation of
label: Paragraph

text: European architectural modernism of the day, the Starrett-Lehigh Building earned notice
label: Paragraph

text: in the Museum of Modern Art’s “Modern Architecture: International Exhibition” of
label: Paragraph

text: A new preference for the horizontal movement of goods, the relocation of warehousing
label: Paragraph

text: operations to sites outside of urban cores, and a heightened desire to minimize
label: Paragraph

text: warehousing costs led to dramatic changes for warehouses during the middle third of the
label: Paragraph

text: century. Experimentation with platform trucks during the 1930s demonstrated the
label: Paragraph

text: advantages of one-story facilities; after World War II, forklift trucks and pallets that
label: Paragraph

text: “unitized” goods storage and shipment became the modern tools of warehousing. The
label: Paragraph

text: warehouse design problem changed to become a matter of limiting initial costs and
label: Paragraph

text: choosing the best size and shape of a one-story structure that would have masonry
label: Paragraph

text: bearing walls and a lightweight flat roof. Ceiling heights of 20 feet or more and smooth
label: Paragraph

text: floors were provided to accommodate forklift trucks and pallets. An office area with a
label: Paragraph

text: public entry and fenestration was positioned to screen the rest of the building from the
label: Paragraph

text: street or to occupy a corner of the building. Freight doors, truck docks, and railroad
label: Paragraph

text: sidings became the only features of the other sides of these windowless warehouses.
label: Paragraph

text: Brick and other siding materials enclosed bland, unstyled warehouses intended to blend
label: Paragraph

text: in with nearby commercial and industrial structures.
label: Paragraph

text: During the late 20th century, warehousing operations and buildings continued to
label: Paragraph

text: evolve in response to a just-in-time manufacturing philosophy and the development of
label: Paragraph

text: distribution networks that used a smaller number of larger warehouses. Even more
label: Paragraph

text: emphatically, the warehouse building became perceived as merely a means to protect the
label: Paragraph

text: storage medium and materialshandling systems that were the important components of
label: Paragraph

text: the operation. To serve Europe, Nike, Inc., developed a pair of side-by-side distribution
label: Paragraph

text: centers (1994-95) near Meerhout, Belgium, that are representative of the quite large
label: Paragraph

text: facilities developed during the 1990s. The structures enclose one million square feet and
label: Paragraph

text: cover 23 acres as they accommodate high-bay storage that rises to a height of nearly 100
label: Paragraph

text: feet.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet even as most new warehouses became little-noticed background buildings in
label: Paragraph

text: industrial developments and port areas, older urban warehouses were rehabilitated for
label: Paragraph

text: new uses. Since the 1970s warehouses with style and versatile loft floors in Copenhagen,
label: Paragraph

text: London, New York, and many other cities have provided space for people to live and
label: Paragraph

text: work in lively mixed-use neighborhoods and waterfront areas.
label: Paragraph

text: BETSY HUNTER BRADLEY
label: Title

text: Further Reading
label: Title

text: Architectural historians and critics have seldom turned their attention to the warehouse.
label: Paragraph

text: Some books on industrial architecture, such as Bradley, address both the functional and
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic aspects of warehouses. Works by engineers on facilities design (Harmon;
label: Paragraph

text: Heragu) are useful to trace changes in warehousing practice and operation. Architectural
label: Paragraph

text: periodicals remain the best source for warehouse design trends. American warehouses in
label: Paragraph

text: historic districts and redevelopment areas have often been documented in local
label: Paragraph

text: preservation agency reports, such as the New York City Landmarks Preservation
label: Paragraph

text: Commission’s SoHo and TriBeCa Historic District Designation Reports.

text: WASHINGTON, D.C.
label: Caption

text: A discussion of Washington, D.C., architecture must begin with the city plan developed
label: Paragraph

text: by Pierre Charles L’Enfant in 1791, for it established a strong context of geometry, scale,
label: Paragraph

text: and hierarchy. L’Enfant’s plan overlaid an orthogonal grid of streets with diagonal
label: Paragraph

text: avenues. The narrower, orthogonal streets serve as utilitarian means of access, whereas
label: Paragraph

text: the wide, tree-lined avenues connect open-space nodes. The heights of buildings along all
label: Paragraph

text: Washington thoroughfares are limited by law so that no building can be taller than the
label: Paragraph

text: Capitol.
label: Paragraph

text: L’Enfant’s plan established a monumental federal precinct surrounded by smaller-
label: Paragraph

text: scaled mercantile and residential precincts. The Capitol was placed on the highest hill
label: Paragraph

text: within a Congress Garden, linked by Pennsylvania Avenue to the White House, set in the
label: Paragraph

text: President’s Park. On the axis west from the Capitol to the Potomac River was the Grand
label: Paragraph

text: Avenue, now the Mall, a vast open space lined with federal buildings. This area
label: Paragraph

text: developed haphazardly until the Senate Park Commission Plan of 1901 established a
label: Paragraph

text: clear master plan. Since 1972 the Pennsylvania Avenue Development Corporation has
label: Paragraph

text: redesigned this avenue and controlled development along its north side.
label: Paragraph

text: The context for architecture in the federal precinct was established early by the Capitol
label: Paragraph

text: and the White House: neoclassical, light-colored stone, figural, symmetrical, and
label: Paragraph

text: monumental. All the early buildings of the 20th century, the memorials and museums,
label: Paragraph

text: were designed in this idiom. In the last half of the century, architects struggled with these
label: Paragraph

text: contextual restrictions and found ways to vary the materials and alter the stylistic
label: Paragraph

text: formula.
label: Paragraph

text: The context for architecture in the mercantile precinct changed the most during the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century from low-scale mixed use to high-density commercial. It is highly varied,
label: Paragraph

text: with examples from all eras of the city’s history. Metro, Washington’s rapid transit and
label: Paragraph

text: subway system, was opened in 1976 with handsome stations dominated by concrete
label: Paragraph

text: barrel vaults consistently designed by Harry Weese and Associates of Chicago.
label: Paragraph

text: The first part of the 20th century, from 1900 to 1940, was a very active period of
label: Paragraph

text: design and construction, primarily within the federal precinct. A great number of high-
label: Paragraph

text: quality buildings were built as the federal government acted on the recommendations of
label: Paragraph

text: the Senate Park Commission. The first act was to remove the train station from the Mall
label: Paragraph

text: and to construct a new one west of the Capitol. The Beaux-Arts-inspired Union Station
label: Paragraph

text: and Columbia Plaza were completed in 1908 as designed by the noted Chicago architect
label: Paragraph

text: Daniel Burnham.
label: Paragraph

text: This was followed by development of the Mall, capitol square, and the federal triangle.
label: Paragraph

text: The Lincoln Memorial (1922) by Henry Bacon, on axis with the Capitol, features the
label: Paragraph

text: marble statue of Abraham Lincoln by Daniel Chester French. The Jefferson Memorial
label: Caption

text: (1943) by John Russell Pope, on axis with the White House, features the enormous statue
label: Paragraph

text: of Thomas Jefferson by Rudolph Evans. New buildings added to capitol square included
label: Caption

text: the Supreme Court Building (1935) between twin buildings for the House and the Senate
label: Caption

text: built in 1908. New buildings along the north side of the Mall were the National Museum
label: Paragraph

text: of Natural History (1911) and the National Gallery of Art (1941). The federal triangle
label: Paragraph

text: was developed as an ensemble of large neoclassical buildings featuring the National
label: Paragraph

text: Archives (1935) by John Russell Pope. Defining the north side of the Mall west of the
label: Caption

text: White House were Constitution Hall (1939), the Organization of American States (1910),
label: Paragraph

text: the Federal Reserve Building (1937), the National Academy of Sciences (1924), and the
label: Paragraph

text: American Pharmaceutical Association (1933). This series of white pavilions set within a
label: Paragraph

text: verdant landscape and designed by very notable architects is probably the most handsome
label: Paragraph

text: series of buildings along one avenue in Washington.
label: Caption

text: The most glorious building commenced during this era is the Washington National
label: Paragraph

text: Cathedral (1907-90) by Henry Vaughn and George Bodley, the last Gothic cathedral
label: Caption

text: structure to be built in the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Hirshhorn Museum (1974), designed by Gordon Bunshaft (Skidmore, Owings,
label: Caption

text: and Merrill)
label: Title

text: © Ernest and Kathleen Meredith/GreatBuildings.com
label: Caption

text: From 1945 to 1960, the country and city were recovering from the aftermath of World
label: Paragraph

text: War IL. Much good architecture was destroyed during the urban-renewal era of the 1950s
label: Paragraph

text: for the sake of highways or real estate development. The historic preservation movement
label: Paragraph

text: abated this destruction, but it still did occur many times, with only historic pieces of
label: Paragraph

text: blocks and buildings saved and incorporated into new development. The replacement
label: Paragraph

text: buildings usually were not noteworthy. Modern architecture was introduced to
label: Paragraph

text: Washington during this period in the work of architects Joseph Abel, Charles Goodman,
label: Paragraph

text: and Chloethiel Woodard Smith.
label: Paragraph

text: From 1960 to 2000, both the quality and the quantity of architecture in Washington
label: Paragraph

text: increased substantially. Two early buildings from this period worth noting are the
label: Paragraph

text: exquisite Pre-Columbian Museum (1963) at Dumbarton Oaks by Philip Johnson and the
label: Caption

text: boldly curvilinear Watergate (1965) by Luigi Moretti.
label: Caption

text: During this era, the firms of Hartman-Cox and Keyes Condon Florance (KCF)
label: Paragraph

text: developed an approach to developer architecture that was sympathetic to the Washington
label: Paragraph

text: urban context while also exploring inventive design expressions. George Hartman and
label: Paragraph

text: Warren Cox began their practice designing very modern buildings, such as the Euram
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1971) on Dupont Circle and the National Permanent Building (1976) at 18th
label: Caption

text: Street and Pennsylvania Avenue. They progressed to a number of contextual commercial
label: Paragraph

text: projects that incorporated historic buildings, such as Sumner School (1986) and 1001
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania Avenue, NW (1986). Their two best projects are One Franklin Square
label: Paragraph

text: (1990) and Market Square (1990). The former, on Franklin Square, strongly defines the
label: Paragraph

text: north side of this space and adds two pyramid-topped towers. The latter, on Pennsylvania
label: Paragraph

text: Avenue across from the National Archives, is suitably neoclassical and incorporates the
label: Paragraph

text: Navy Memorial.
label: Paragraph

text: KCF began as Keyes Lethbridge Condon, designing the modern curvilinear housing of
label: Paragraph

text: Columbia Plaza (1967). The firm then became Keyes Condon Florance, designing
label: Paragraph

text: urbanistically appropriate buildings with strong street walls, such as Lafayette Square
label: Paragraph

text: (1991). Many of their projects have been at street intersections that they exploit. A good
label: Paragraph

text: example is at 2401 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW (1980), with its curved windows and
label: Paragraph

text: balconies. The firm then changed partners to become Florance Eichbaum Esocoff King
label: Paragraph

text: and designed the Art Deco office building at 1100 New York Avenue, incorporating the
label: Paragraph

text: Greyhound bus station as an entry. Three other firms that have been developing a
label: Paragraph

text: Washington style of abstract contextualism are Shalom Baranes Associates, David M.
label: Paragraph

text: Schwarz, and Weinstein Associates.
label: Paragraph

text: The most influential out-of-town firm has been I.M. Pei and Partners, now Pei, Cobb,
label: Paragraph

text: Freed and Partners. Their work began with urban-renewal projects in the southwest part
label: Paragraph

text: of the city: Town Center Plaza (1962) and L’Enfant Plaza (1968). This was followed by
label: Paragraph

text: the East Building of the National Gallery of Art (1978), a tour de force of monumental
label: Caption

text: abstract forms encompassing an exhilarating atrium. The United States Holocaust
label: Paragraph

text: Memorial Museum (1993), designed by James Ingo Freed, maintains a balance between
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality and contextual resolution with a highly energized central space. Their
label: Paragraph

text: latest project is the enormous Ronald Reagan Building (1998), which completes the
label: Paragraph

text: federal triangle. Here, Freed’s exterior is more influenced by the monumental
label: Paragraph

text: neoclassical context, whereas the engaging interior public space is very modern in
label: Paragraph

text: expression.
label: Paragraph

text: The international firm of Skidmore, Owings and Merrill (SOM) has had a strong
label: Paragraph

text: influence on Washington architecture because it maintained a local office for many years
label: Paragraph

text: under the direction of partner David Childs. During this period it produced some of the
label: Paragraph

text: refined modern office buildings for which it is known. These include the Inter-American
label: Paragraph

text: Development Bank at 1300 New York Avenue, NW (1983), with its spectacular atrium,
label: Paragraph

text: and 1201 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW (1984), with its triangular atrium. The best-known
label: Paragraph

text: and most controversial building by SOM is the circular concrete Hirshhorn Museum
label: Paragraph

text: (1974) on the Mall, designed by partner Gordon Bunshaft.
label: Caption

text: Washington has also been the locus for numerous buildings by well-known architects
label: Paragraph

text: from around the world. Although these buildings have usually challenged their context,
label: Paragraph

text: they add an element of surprise attraction that enlivens the cityscape. The earliest of these
label: Paragraph

text: projects is the Brutalist concrete Department
label: Title

text: by Marcel Breuer. Later projects include the
label: Paragraph

text: the Performing Arts (1971) by Edward Dure:
label: Caption

text: of Housing and Urban Development (1968)
label: Title

text: boxlike, white-marble Kennedy Center for
label: Caption

text: 1 Stone; the stark steel Martin Luther King,
label: Caption

text: Jr., Memorial Library (1972) by Mies van der Rohe; and the marble-and-glass cubes of
label: Paragraph

text: the National Air and Space Museum (1976) b
label: Caption

text: ry Hellmuth, Obata and Kassabaum.
label: Paragraph

text: , it has embassies that add another aspect of
label: Paragraph

text: interest, as they try to reflect the spirit of their country. The earliest of these
label: Paragraph

text: is the British Embassy (1931) by Sir Edwin Lutyens, a quirky interpretation of an English
label: Paragraph

text: country house. The Canadian Chancery (
label: Caption

text: 989) by Arthur Erickson is in the most
label: Paragraph

text: prominent location on Pennsylvania Avenue
label: Caption

text: is a gray-marble building of varied forms w
label: Paragraph

text: between the Capitol and the White House. It
label: Paragraph

text: ith an open courtyard facing John Marshall
label: Caption

text: Park. The recent Embassy of Finland (1994) by Heikkinen and Komonen has attracted
label: Paragraph

text: much attention for its deference to the natural setting, utilizing transparent screens.
label: Paragraph

text: Washington is a city with architecture that abides by its civic role. The strong context
label: Paragraph

text: was established at its founding by the L’Enfant plan and continues to be followed. The
label: Paragraph

text: building masses form clearly defined streets and open spaces, and the materials and
label: Paragraph

text: colors are contextually appropriate. There is a civility to the architecture that gives this
label: Paragraph

text: city more design integrity than any other American city.
