text: WISSA WASSEF, RAMSES 1911-74
label: Title

text: Architect, Egypt (Africa)
label: Title

text: Ramses Wissa Wassef was born into a prominent and cultured Francophile Coptic
label: Paragraph

text: (Egyptian Christian) family in Cairo. His father was an influential member of the
label: Paragraph

text: nationalist Wafd Party and one of the founders of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Cairo,
label: Paragraph

text: which opened, in the teeth of opposition from the office of the British consul-general in
label: Paragraph

text: Egypt, in 1908. Wissa Wassef completed his education in France and studied architecture
label: Paragraph

text: at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris, where he received his diploma in 1935. His diploma
label: Paragraph

text: project, “The Potter’s House in Old Cairo,” already revealed his interest in and
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge of the traditional crafts of his homeland.
label: Paragraph

text: On returning to Egypt in 1936, Wissa Wassef was appointed professor of the art and
label: Paragraph

text: history of architecture in the Department of Architecture of the School of Fine Arts,
label: Caption

text: Cairo. The Department of Architecture at the School of Fine Arts, in Zamalek on Gezira
label: Caption

text: Island between the two arms of the Nile near Cairo, was the first modern school of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture to be founded in Egypt. Presently incorporated in the University of Helwan
label: Paragraph

text: (Zamalek Campus), the school continues the arts-and-crafts tradition pioneered by
label: Paragraph

text: Hassam Fathy and Wissa Wassef.
label: Paragraph

text: Wissa Wassef had followed Hassan Fathy as head of the Department of Architecture at
label: Paragraph

text: the School of Fine Arts, and both men shared a passion for the traditional vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of their native land. Field study visits into the rural areas of the Nile delta
label: Paragraph

text: and of Lower and Upper Egypt were annual events for students of the School of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture under their direction; and for both men, the traditional architecture of Nubia,
label: Paragraph

text: the southernmost region of Egypt above and around the Aswan Dam, became and
label: Paragraph

text: remained a perennial source of inspiration. Wissa Wassef was primarily a teacher, fired
label: Paragraph

text: by the desire to communicate his love and profound knowledge of architecture and of arts
label: Paragraph

text: and crafts generally not only to his architecture students but also to children. He stated, “I
label: Paragraph

text: had this vague conviction that every human being was born an artist, but that his gifts
label: Paragraph

text: could be brought out only if artistic creation were encouraged by the practising of a craft
label: Paragraph

text: from early childhood” (see de Stefano, n.d.).
label: Paragraph

text: In 1941 Wissa Wassef was commissioned by a social welfare organization to design a
label: Paragraph

text: small primary school in the Coptic quarter of Old Cairo. This provided him with the
label: Paragraph

text: opportunity to test his conviction, and he persuaded the management committee to let
label: Paragraph

text: him teach weaving to the children after school. He chose weaving, a craft about which he
label: Paragraph

text: knew very little, as the first craft to teach young children because he believed that the
label: Paragraph

text: simple techniques could be easily learned and that the craft process would enable
label: Paragraph

text: children to develop and express their innate creativity through producing colorful visual
label: Paragraph

text: images. His pupils,
label: Paragraph

text: El-Dar Restaurant, view from the roof showing its mud-brick dome
label: Caption

text: © Aga Khan Trust for Culture
label: Title

text: children from the humblest homes, were producing work that gave them both great
label: Paragraph

text: satisfaction and a potential source of income, and so within a few years he resolved to
label: Paragraph

text: build his own school and craft training center where he could realize his vision of a
label: Paragraph

text: cooperative of artist-craftsmen, living and working in the local community. His wife,
label: Paragraph

text: Sophie Habib Gorgy, was a sculptor and shared his enthusiasm and his vision. In 1951,
label: Paragraph

text: they purchased a small plot of land on the outskirts of the village of Harraniya, a few
label: Paragraph

text: miles south of Giza on the west bank of the Nile, and began to build the school that was
label: Paragraph

text: eventually to bear his name, the Ramses Wissa Wassef Arts Centre. He devoted the
label: Paragraph

text: greater part of the rest of his life, especially after his retirement from the School of Fine
label: Paragraph

text: Arts in 1969, to its completion.
label: Paragraph

text: Although primarily a teacher, Wissa Wassef was a sensitive and accomplished
label: Paragraph

text: architect, and his built works are many and varied. Apart from the Arts Centre at
label: Paragraph

text: Harraniya, his best-known works are the Mahmoud Mokhtar Sculpture Museum (1962-
label: Paragraph

text: 64) in Cairo, the Church of al-Mar’ashali in Zamalek, Cairo, and the Virgin Mary Church
label: Caption

text: in Cairo. He designed and built several houses for private clients, including the Ina Magar
label: Paragraph

text: Country Home (1969), Adam Hennen Residence (1968), the Mohi Houssin Residence
label: Caption

text: (1970), and his own house in Agouza. In 1968, Wissa Wassef incorporated traditional
label: Paragraph

text: Nubian structures in the design of El-Dar Restaurant in Giza, Egypt, that he built of mud
label: Paragraph

text: brick with vault and dome technology.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1961, he was awarded a National Prize for the Arts for the stained-glass windows he
label: Paragraph

text: designed and made for the National Festival Hall in Cairo and in 1964 a National Prize
label: Caption

text: for the Arts for the design of the Mahmoud Mokhtar Sculpture Museum.
label: Caption

text: WEISSENHOFSIEDLUNG, DEUTSCHER
label: Title

text: WERKBUND (STUTTGART, 1927)
label: Caption

text: Exhibition by various architects, 1927 Stuttgart, Germany
label: Caption

text: The Weissenhofsiedlung was one of the most significant architectural exhibitions of
label: Paragraph

text: the 20th century. It brought together for the first time the work of some of the most
label: Paragraph

text: influential and progressive European designers from the early decades of the century. The
label: Paragraph

text: exposition, held in Stuttgart, Germany, in 1927, focused on “Die Wohnung” (the
label: Paragraph

text: Dwelling). Initiated by the Deutscher Werkbund and financed by the city of Stuttgart, it
label: Paragraph

text: presented current ideas in modern residential design. The central feature of the event was
label: Paragraph

text: a development of 21 domestic buildings located on the Weissenhof hillside overlooking
label: Paragraph

text: the city. Over a half million people visited the Siedlung during the summer of 1927.
label: Paragraph

text: The full-scale model housing development was only one part of the exhibition.
label: Paragraph

text: Domestic products and furniture were displayed together in the exhibit “The Interior
label: Paragraph

text: Design of the House,” located at Gewerbeplatz in Stuttgart. The exhibit featured the
label: Paragraph

text: Spiegelglashalle, a plate-glass hall designed by Lilly Reich and Ludwig Mies van der
label: Caption

text: Rohe that consisted of wall planes of various glass materials—a predecessor to Mies’s
label: Paragraph

text: German Pavilion designed two years later for the Barcelona Exposition. The
label: Paragraph

text: “International Exhibition of Modern Architecture: Designs and Models,” held in the
label: Paragraph

text: center of Stuttgart, contained plans, drawings, models, and photographs of foreign
label: Paragraph

text: buildings that reflected the new architectural ideas promoted in the designs of the
label: Paragraph

text: Siedlung. A third group of exhibits, located at a site adjacent to the Weissenhof estate,
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated the attributes of recently developed building materials and new methods of
label: Paragraph

text: construction, including industrial prefabrication.
label: Paragraph

text: The initial underlying social goal of the exhibition was to present modern solutions to
label: Paragraph

text: the urgent need for low- and middle-income housing. Event organizers sought to
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrate ways to reduce housing costs and improve living conditions through the use
label: Paragraph

text: of recently introduced building materials and construction methods. Many of the 17
label: Paragraph

text: architects involved in the Siedlung, however, ignored the basic economic objective of the
label: Paragraph

text: show and created designs more appropriate for affluent families. Many of the individual
label: Paragraph

text: housing units even contained maid’s quarters.
label: Paragraph

text: Participating designers came from Austria, Holland, Switzerland, Belgium, and
label: Paragraph

text: Germany. Organizers hired Mies van der Rohe as artistic director, and Richard Docker
label: Paragraph

text: served as technical director. Other architects who contributed designs for the
label: Paragraph

text: development included Peter Behrens, Le Corbusier and his partner Pierre Jeanneret, Josef
label: Paragraph

text: Frank, Walter Gropius, Ludwig Hilber-seimer, J.J.P. Oud, Hans Poelzig, Adolf Rading,
label: Caption

text: Hans Scharoun, Adolf Schneck, Mart Stam, Bruno Taut, and Max Taut. A house
label: Caption

text: designed by the Belgian architect Victor Bourgeois located adjacent to the development
label: Caption

text: was also incorporated into the exhibition.
label: Paragraph

text: Most of the buildings in the Siedlung were situated on streets that curved along the
label: Paragraph

text: Weissenhof hillside. The designs featured flat, unadorned facades; flat roofs; ribbon
label: Paragraph

text: windows; and pipe railing. Although the basic, formal characteristics of the buildings
label: Paragraph

text: suggested a great sense of unity among the designers, the unique nature of each of their
label: Paragraph

text: architectural ideologies was apparent in the details. Individual designers focused on
label: Paragraph

text: different aspects of modern housing. Mies van der Rohe designed a fourstory block of
label: Paragraph

text: terrace apartments that served as the centerpiece of the exhibition. Inside, he showed how
label: Paragraph

text: universal spaces could be adapted to meet individual needs. Le Corbusier illustrated his
label: Paragraph

text: own ideas for the modern dwelling in two houses of reinforced concrete that he designed
label: Paragraph

text: with Pierre Jeanneret. The architect realized the concept of his Citrohan House in the first
label: Paragraph

text: residence, whereas the second house featured the five points of architecture discussed in
label: Paragraph

text: his 1923 treatise Towards a New Architecture. Some designers, such as Gropius, Stam,
label: Paragraph

text: and Max Taut, explored newly available building materials and ideas regarding
label: Paragraph

text: prefabrication. Others, such as Scharoun, Poelzig, and Schneck, were more interested in
label: Paragraph

text: producing functional layouts that could better meet the needs of the modern family.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the facades of the Weissenhof buildings appear neutral in black-and-white
label: Paragraph

text: photographs, in reality many of the walls were originally painted in shades of yellow,
label: Paragraph

text: blue, and other colors. Bruno Taut, Max Taut, and Le Corbusier all incorporated intense
label: Paragraph

text: colors in their designs. Bruno Taut, for example, specified different saturated hues for the
label: Paragraph

text: individual walls of his small, single-family residence, leading one critic to describe the
label: Paragraph

text: vivid colors as coming right out of a paint box.
label: Paragraph

text: The architecture of the Weissenhofsiedlung was strongly rejected by the National
label: Paragraph

text: Socialists in Germany, who labeled it the “product of ‘cultural Bolshevists.’” The event
label: Paragraph

text: was better received in European and American design journals. The success of the
label: Paragraph

text: Siedlung led to a succession of similar housing exhibitions in Germany and elsewhere
label: Paragraph

text: across Central Europe, including events in Prague, Brno, and Vienna. Progressive
label: Paragraph

text: European architects used these exhibitions to present and debate their modern design
label: Paragraph

text: ideologies. Their desire to further develop such dialogue led to the formation of CLAM
label: Paragraph

text: (Congrés Internationaux d’ Architecture Moderne) in 1929, which provided a platform for
label: Paragraph

text: designers to discuss developing ideas in modern architecture. The formal unity of the
label: Paragraph

text: designs included in the Siedlung contributed to the concept of an International Style in
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture that was heavily promoted five years later by Henry Russell Hitch-
label: Paragraph

text: House for Weissenhofsiedlung, designed by Le Corbusier, Stuttgart (1927)
label: Caption

text: Photo © Donald Corer and Jenny Young/GreatBuildings.com
label: Caption

text: cock and Philip Johnson in the “Modern Architecture—International Exposition” show
label: Title

text: held at the Museum of Modern Art in 1932. The exhibit and subsequent book featured
label: Paragraph

text: several buildings from the Weissenhofsiedlung.
label: Caption

text: The site of the Weissenhof development was sold to the German state in 1938 for use
label: Paragraph

text: by the military. Bombs destroyed houses located in the center of the estate in 1944. New
label: Caption

text: houses replaced these and several other residences that were torn down after World War
label: Paragraph

text: IL. At the end of the century, only 11 of the original buildings remained standing. The
label: Paragraph

text: Siedlung underwent an extensive restoration in the mid-1980s that was completed in time
label: Paragraph

text: for a 60th anniversary celebration of the exhibition. Today the development continues to
label: Paragraph

text: attract visitors interested in experiencing full-scale examples of progressive modern
label: Paragraph

text: housing designs from the mid-1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: WERKBUND EXHIBITION, COLOGNE
label: Caption

text: The Werkbund Exhibition held in Cologne, Germany, on the eve of World War | was the
label: Paragraph

text: first major manifesto of the Deutscher Werkbund (DWB; German Work Association), an
label: Paragraph

text: organization founded in 1907 by artists, architects, and industrialists to address the
label: Paragraph

text: problem of form and design in the industrial age. The exhibit sought to show the world
label: Paragraph

text: the Werkbund’s successful attempt to ally the creative potential of art with the modern
label: Paragraph

text: power of industry to create more aesthetically pleasing and higher-quality products and
label: Paragraph

text: thereby raise German exports in an increasingly competitive world market.
label: Paragraph

text: Architecturally, the exhibit gained nearly instant fame through a number of very
label: Paragraph

text: innovative exhibit pavilions built by some of Germany’s most distinguished architects as
label: Paragraph

text: well as the theoretical “Werkbund Debate,” which greatly influenced the future of
label: Paragraph

text: modern German design and architecture after the war.
label: Paragraph

text: Much like a world’s fair, the exhibition was a microcosm of prewar German culture,
label: Paragraph

text: products, and know-how designed by more than 1000 Werkbund members. The vast
label: Paragraph

text: exhibits contained “everything from couch cushions to city building,” as a contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: slogan proclaimed. The primary exhibits featured architecture and applied arts, but there
label: Paragraph

text: were also displays on sport, women’s fashion, religious art, colonial wares, worker
label: Paragraph

text: housing, factories, cabaret, cinema, transportation, theater, garden design, funerary
label: Title

text: sculpture, and much more. A large amusement park was integrated into the exhibit to
label: Paragraph

text: provide entertainment and eating establishments for the more than one million visitors
label: Paragraph

text: who came. The city built advanced mass transit systems to ensure easy access to the
label: Paragraph

text: fairgrounds from all over the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the city of Cologne previously had very few connections to the Werkbund,
label: Paragraph

text: by agreeing to pay for the exhibit, and with its strategic location in the center of one of
label: Paragraph

text: Germany’s most industrialized regions and close to the French border, Cologne proved to
label: Paragraph

text: be an ideal host for this exhibit of the pride of German industry. Intent on success, the
label: Paragraph

text: organizers commissioned the famed architect and designer Peter Behrens to create the
label: Paragraph

text: overall exhibit organization and hired only the biggest-name architects to design the
label: Paragraph

text: various pavilions. The main festival hall by Behrens, the primary exhibit building by
label: Caption

text: Theodor Fischer, several buildings by Hermann Muthesius, the Austrian Pavilion by
label: Caption

text: Josef Hoffmann, as well as most of the other buildings at the fair were all designed in a
label: Paragraph

text: spare form of German Neoclassicism, a formal vocabulary based on established traditions
label: Paragraph

text: and conventions that regained popularity after the exuberant, individualist Art Nouveau
label: Paragraph

text: style at the turn of the century. Other buildings were more purely classical or Renaissance
label: Paragraph

text: in style, and a mock vernacular town was built in a stylized version of local brick
label: Paragraph

text: architectural traditions to introduce visitors to regional culture.
label: Paragraph

text: There were, however, three major exceptions to these conservative designs. One of the
label: Paragraph

text: first buildings that visitors saw on entering the fairgrounds that received much attention
label: Paragraph

text: in the press was the small “Glass House” designed by Bruno Taut to display products of
label: Paragraph

text: the German glass industry. It was intended as a poetic essay in glass block, colored glass,
label: Paragraph

text: tile, mirrors, light, and water that were to show off the completely new aesthetic that
label: Paragraph

text: could be achieved by a more intense use of glass in the building industry. A theater with
label: Paragraph

text: an innovative, flexible stage configuration, designed by the Belgian designer Henri van
label: Paragraph

text: de Velde, was equally popular. It featured bold geometric volumes, softened through
label: Paragraph

text: some flowing curves in plan and in the main facade, as well as some sculptural reliefs by
label: Caption

text: Hermann Obrist that recalled the Art Nouveau style of a few years earlier. Finally, toward
label: Paragraph

text: the rear of the exhibit, Walter Gropius designed a model Werkbund factory and office
label: Paragraph

text: building with a symmetrical brick facade inspired by American technology and the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of Frank Lloyd Wright but flanked by two daring concrete spiral stairs
label: Caption

text: cantilevered inside glass cylinders. The rear elevation of the same building featured a
label: Caption

text: glass curtain wall that looked out over a large courtyard and exhibit hall crammed full of
label: Paragraph

text: modern machines and engineering, including some Pullman car interiors by Gropius.
label: Paragraph

text: The contrast between the rather conventional, classicized designs and the more
label: Paragraph

text: individualized, artistically daring buildings formed the backdrop to a very heated debate
label: Paragraph

text: that erupted almost without warning at the exhibit. During his opening speech,
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius, the vice president of the Werkbund, outlined a series of ten programmatic
label: Paragraph

text: points to direct the future of the Werkbund’s efforts. He called for more standardized,
label: Paragraph

text: typical, and conventionalized forms in architecture and industrial design to counter the
label: Paragraph

text: rampant individualism and arbitrary forms that he perceived in the modern, industrialized
label: Paragraph

text: consumer culture around him. On the basis of interpretations of the knotty word
label: Paragraph

text: Typisierung (meaning “type” or “standardize”) used by Muthesius, many historians have
label: Paragraph

text: given him credit for anticipating the standardization and machine aesthetic that were to
label: Paragraph

text: become hallmarks of avant-garde design and International Style modern architecture after
label: Paragraph

text: World War | in Germany. Stanford Anderson, however, has more perceptively argued
label: Paragraph

text: that Muthesius intended to reinforce the conservative statement made by the classicism of
label: Paragraph

text: his own buildings and that he surely spoke for many of the reform-minded architects
label: Paragraph

text: present.
label: Paragraph

text: Others at the exhibit, however, disagreed completely with Muthesius and were
label: Paragraph

text: outraged that he voiced these ideas as Werkbund policy. The next day, speaking for a
label: Paragraph

text: group of younger architects, including Gropius and Taut, van de Velde proposed ten
label: Paragraph

text: “countertheses” that insisted that the road to success for the Werkbund lay not in
label: Paragraph

text: fostering standards, norms, or conventions but rather in the creative, individual artistic
label: Paragraph

text: talents of designers in search of innovative forms and production techniques. Those
label: Paragraph

text: historians who have seen Muthesius’s remarks as an early call for standardization have
label: Paragraph

text: criticized van de Velde’s countertheses as a retreat to earlier, Romantic sensibilities about
label: Paragraph

text: artistic genius espoused by Art Nouveau rather than as the more general recantation o
label: Paragraph

text: stultifying norms that Anderson credits him with.
label: Paragraph

text: The intense debate between the Muthesius and van de Velde camps concerning the
label: Paragraph

text: future of Werkbund policy raged on until the exhibition suddenly closed its doors on
label: Paragraph

text: August 1914, just as the German kaiser declared war on Russia and on nearby France
label: Paragraph

text: and, with it, the beginning of World War I. Although discussion halted in the fervor o
label: Paragraph

text: war, the legacy of the debate continued for decades. Blaming German industry for much
label: Paragraph

text: of the devastation of the Great War and with the revolutionary zeal to replace everything
label: Paragraph

text: that was old, established, and conservative after the war, the younger architects took over
label: Paragraph

text: the Werkbund in 1919 and insisted on van de Velde’s theses that individual artistic
label: Paragraph

text: design was the key to modern design. Paradoxically, however, through the writings o
label: Paragraph

text: critics such as Adolf Behne and Adolf Loos, the Werkbund, alongside the Bauhaus and
label: Paragraph

text: modern architects and designers all over Germany, began to connect the search for new
label: Paragraph

text: artistic forms with an increasingly rational, standardized, and industrially mass-produced
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic. The uniform International Style architecture that became the norm for most o
label: Paragraph

text: the Western world just before and after World War II thus combined aspects of both the
label: Paragraph

text: artistic and the standardized sides of the famous Werkbund debate initiated at the
label: Paragraph

text: Cologne exhibit.
label: Paragraph

text: WILLIAMS, AMANCIO (1913-89)
label: Title

text: Architect, Argentina
label: Title

text: Amancio Williams is considered one of the most significant architects in Argentina’s
label: Paragraph

text: history. His work is characterized by recurring modernist themes: the use of technology
label: Paragraph

text: to generate lyrical forms, concern for hygienic and functional issues, and minimal
label: Paragraph

text: application of ornament. The thematic schemes of Le Corbusier and the classicist
label: Paragraph

text: tendency and attention to detail of Mies van der Rohe also influenced his projects.
label: Paragraph

text: Williams’s work addressed the concept of type or paradigmatic space. Over time these
label: Paragraph

text: concepts were explored, refined, and often expressed through the building section.
label: Paragraph

text: Aspects of modern life can be seen in his development typologies, such as the “Housing
label: Paragraph

text: in Space” project, the large cultural complex, the office tower, the airport, the hospital,
label: Paragraph

text: and the exhibit space. Williams’s projects are identified and qualified through the
label: Paragraph

text: integration of type, structure, architecture, and site.
label: Paragraph

text: From 1948 to 1951, Williams served as construction supervisor for Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: Currutchet House project in La Plata, Argentina. Williams produced most of the
label: Paragraph

text: construction documents for this house and supervised the project’s structural and
label: Paragraph

text: concrete work.
label: Paragraph

text: In his Housing in Space project (1943), Williams explored the relationship between
label: Paragraph

text: site and climate. Williams’s new approach toward creating a settlement is revealed in the
label: Paragraph

text: manner in which the units are stepped to maximize light and ventilation, and a gentle
label: Paragraph

text: curving roof offers broader views for all residents.
label: Paragraph

text: The House over the Brook (1945) in Mar del Plata synthesized many significant ideas
label: Paragraph

text: for Williams. Designed for his father, a musician, it remains one of his few built projects.
label: Paragraph

text: Williams described this house, which embodies his classicist attitudes, as “a form in
label: Paragraph

text: space that cannot deny nature...concrete—its material—is exposed, and textured by
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical and chemical procedures: form, structure and quality are thus here the same
label: Paragraph

text: thing” (Frampton, p. 10). Two pillars support the bridgelike structure, and the curvature
label: Paragraph

text: of the building responds to the landscape. The manner in which the house spans the brook
label: Paragraph

text: is related to Maillart’s bridge (1933) over the Schawanbach River. It exemplifies
label: Paragraph

text: Williams’s belief in the confluence of engineering and architecture. The interior displays
label: Paragraph

text: his concern for detail and his poetic sensibility toward the use of materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Structural typology also plays a crucial role in Williams’s proposal for the Airport of
label: Paragraph

text: Buenos Aires (1945). The solution is logical in its simplicity. Located 8 kilometers from
label: Paragraph

text: the city, the airport was proposed to sit on massive slabs resembling airplane wings and
label: Paragraph

text: was supported by enormous pillars embedded into the shallow river. The proposal
label: Paragraph

text: connected the airport with the city via a platform, beneath which hung all airport
label: Paragraph

text: circulation and services.
label: Paragraph

text: The Suspended Office Building project (1946) was designed in collaboration with
label: Paragraph

text: Janello, Janello and Butler. This suspended skyscraper, designed for a site in Buenos
label: Paragraph

text: Aires, is the most paradigmatic among all Williams’s projects. Four concrete columns
label: Paragraph

text: support two beams from which hang a steel framework for 28 floors divided into three
label: Caption

text: sectors. The first slab was suspended 18 meters above the entrance, thereby generating a
label: Paragraph

text: covered open space for a densely populated area of the city. The interior had flexible
label: Paragraph

text: partitions, a structural type that was developed decades later by Sir Norman Foster in the
label: Paragraph

text: Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank Buildings.
label: Caption

text: In Williams’s Hall for Visual Spectacle and Sound in Space (1953), the development
label: Paragraph

text: of the typology is determined not by the location but rather by objective scientific study.
label: Paragraph

text: Research that investigated the propagation of sound in space was used to shape the
label: Paragraph

text: auditorium and optimize acoustics for all listeners. Rotating a vertical axis generated the
label: Paragraph

text: shell; thus, it created a mushroomlike amphitheater capable of providing a variety of
label: Paragraph

text: visual spectacles.
label: Paragraph

text: Since the late 1940s, Williams produced a series of projects that studied the
label: Paragraph

text: relationships between program-function, sitestructure, and climate-city. Several of these,
label: Paragraph

text: executed from 1951 to 1966, employed concrete building shells of minimum thickness.
label: Paragraph

text: Others in the early 1960s rearticulated his strategies for the use of high roof structures. In
label: Paragraph

text: both cases the structures consisted of thin building shells or roofs that were supported by
label: Paragraph

text: large columns.
label: Paragraph

text: The shells in several projects acted as umbrellas that either grouped together or isolated
label: Paragraph

text: spaces. They were carefully calculated to incorporate alternative functions to easily
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate production processes and responded to differing contexts and programs.
label: Paragraph

text: Among these proposals are the Hospitals in Corrientes, the proposals for Mbucuruya and
label: Paragraph

text: Curuzu-Cuatia (1948-53), the Gas Station (1955) in Avellaneda, the Industrial School
label: Paragraph

text: (1960) in Olavarria, the House (1960) in Punta del Este, and the Bunge and Born
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition Stand (1966).
label: Paragraph

text: The series of projects employing high roof structures is part of Williams’s research and
label: Paragraph

text: innovative attitude toward design. In these cases individual shells are replaced with
label: Paragraph

text: continuous large roof structures supported by few columns. Horizontal panels or glass
label: Caption

text: membranes hang from the roof to offer protection from the climate and provide
label: Paragraph

text: continuity with the existing context. The basic structural components generate ample
label: Paragraph

text: space that can accommodate diverse programs and activities. Examples of this approach
label: Paragraph

text: are the factory building proposal (1962) for Iggam, a small furniture shop (1962) in
label: Paragraph

text: Buenos Aires, and a monument (1964) for the city of Berlin.
label: Caption

text: Many of Williams’s later major projects were also unrealized. Among these is an urban
label: Paragraph

text: proposal for a linear city of 300 kilometers in length by 6 kilometers in width. It is
label: Paragraph

text: modeled after Le Corbusier’s approach to urban design, with the buildings supported by
label: Paragraph

text: pilotis, thereby reclaiming the ground space to promote greater contact with nature. An
label: Paragraph

text: additional unrealized project is Williams’s design for a 200-meter-high cross standing
label: Paragraph

text: over the river (1988). It was to be situated on a large platform outside the port of Buenos
label: Paragraph

text: Aires.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1981 the critic Kenneth Frampton wrote that Williams “was an enigmatic figure...a
label: Paragraph

text: brilliant designer whose influence has been totally disproportionate to the extent of his
label: Paragraph

text: own rather limited output” (Frampton, 1981). A renewed interest in architectural
label: Paragraph

text: typology and Latin American architecture led to Williams’s work being exhibited at
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard University in 1987. The exhibit contributed to a greater understanding and
label: Paragraph

text: deeper appreciation of Williams’s contribution to modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: mostly experimental, and very few of his projects were ever built. Williams was one of
label: Paragraph

text: WILLIAMS, E.OWEN 1890-1969
label: Title

text: Architectural engineer, England
label: Title

text: Considered to be one of the individuals responsible for the establishment of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, Sir (Evan) Owen Williams is best known as the civil engineer who
label: Paragraph

text: introduced structural methods pioneered in Europe, notably by the Swiss engineer Robert
label: Paragraph

text: Maillart, into Great Britain. Williams was one of a number of architects who were
label: Paragraph

text: skeptical about the imitators and vulgarizers of the new modern architecture who lacked
label: Paragraph

text: integrity. As early as 1932, he denounced “Facadism” as forgery.
label: Paragraph

text: Born in Tottenham, London, Williams studied at the University of London before
label: Paragraph

text: working for Electric Tramways between 1905 and 1911. He served as chief aircraft
label: Paragraph

text: designer for Wells Aviation until World War L setting up an independent engineering
label: Paragraph

text: practice in 1919. From about 1930 on, Williams dispensed with the collaboration of a
label: Paragraph

text: consulting architect and produced his own designs, building up a successful practice
label: Paragraph

text: specializing in industrial and commercial buildings using reinforced-concrete frame
label: Paragraph

text: construction.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1924 Williams was appointed consulting engineer for the British Empire Exhibition,
label: Paragraph

text: Wembley, in association with architect Sir John Simpson, with whom he collaborated on
label: Paragraph

text: the design of Wembley Stadium (1925). Williams’s reinforced-concrete design for the
label: Paragraph

text: Dorchester Hotel (1930) in London was thought far too advanced, and Curtis Green was
label: Paragraph

text: employed to devise a suitably restrained and elegant facade.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1930s Williams designed a number of bridges in reinforced concrete, working
label: Paragraph

text: mostly with the architect Maxwell Ayrton, but it was his design for the Boots Factory
label: Paragraph

text: (1932) in Beeston, Nottingham, that was to be one of the most remarkable buildings of
label: Paragraph

text: the Modern movement in Britain. New constructional techniques were employed on a
label: Paragraph

text: more complete, vast, and uncompromising scale than in any other European building.
label: Paragraph

text: Williams, an engineer with a sophisticated tectonic sensibility, showed how ideally fitted
label: Paragraph

text: “mushroom” construction was for industrial buildings. The use of reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: columns from which the concrete floor slabs spring outward in all directions created
label: Paragraph

text: wider spans and allowed movement of goods around unobstructed voids. The floors are
label: Paragraph

text: entirely supported by a row of these columns down each wing of the building, and the
label: Paragraph

text: external walls, relieved of their load-bearing responsibilities, are glass clad from floor to
label: Paragraph

text: ceiling. The central space was a sort of nave interrupted by cross galleries and top lit by a
label: Paragraph

text: thin-glass, brick-and-concrete membrane roof. The effect was assertive and tough yet
label: Paragraph

text: ennobling, a quality that understandably endeared it to the so-called New Brutalists of the
label: Paragraph

text: The laboratory of a cement factory (1932) at Thurrock in Essex is a simple rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: building. Reinforced-concrete benches, suitably clad, run round the walls with a shelf
label: Caption

text: above, and the walls are opaque to this level, with glass above with slender concrete
label: Paragraph

text: mullions. Powerful electric lamps were employed to provide an equivalent to daylight.
label: Paragraph

text: The warehouse for Lilley and Skinner (1933) again used “mushroom” columns and slab
label: Paragraph

text: construction. Long horizontal bands run between the windows, which wrap around the
label: Paragraph

text: corners of the building. The Empire Swimming Pool (1934) at Wembley, the largest hall
label: Caption

text: to be built in England to date, covered a space of 341 feet by 236.5 feet. The pool was
label: Paragraph

text: constructed with a reinforced-concrete frame and used a grid system; the use of
label: Paragraph

text: standardized units contributed to the speed of its eight-month construction. The Pioneer
label: Paragraph

text: Health Centre (1935) in Peckham, London, was privately developed and financed and
label: Paragraph

text: became famous as a pioneer social and health enterprise. Its founders believed that
label: Paragraph

text: physical disorders were the result of environmental factors. The flexible space created in
label: Paragraph

text: this rectangular three-story structure of reinforced concrete provided opportunities for
label: Paragraph

text: various physical, social, and cultural activities. Members could meet and discuss their
label: Paragraph

text: problems with trained staff who could give diagnoses and advice. The ultimate aim was
label: Paragraph

text: not to cure conventional diseases but, rather, through preventive action, to sustain the
label: Paragraph

text: health of the community. Various parts of the building were grouped around a central
label: Paragraph

text: swimming pool, covered by a steeply pitched glass roof. The gymnasium was on the left,
label: Paragraph

text: the theater on the right, and between them the children’s covered playground with sliding
label: Paragraph

text: glazing designed to make it an open-air space. On the first floor were spacious lounges
label: Paragraph

text: with their shallow, bowed bays, cafeteria, and kitchen. The second floor housed medical
label: Paragraph

text: rooms, a library, a study, and rest rooms. Unfortunately, because of a lack of support, the
label: Paragraph

text: center closed in March 1950.
label: Paragraph

text: Williams was consulting engineer for Ellis and Clarke, who designed the Daily
label: Paragraph

text: Express Buildings in Fleet Street, London (1932), Manchester (1939), and Glasgow. His
label: Paragraph

text: other work included Dollis Hill Synagogue (1938) in London and a proposal (1935) for a
label: Paragraph

text: new Wateroo Bridge. Postwar work includes all bridges on the M1 motorway and the
label: Paragraph

text: maintenance headquarters at Heathrow Airport in London.
label: Paragraph

text: WILLIAMS, PAUL REVERE 1894-1980
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: A native of Los Angeles, Paul Revere Williams designed some of the most distinctive
label: Paragraph

text: residences and public structures known throughout the United States during a long and
label: Paragraph

text: distinguished career. His achievements paralleled the growth of Los Angeles, where his
label: Paragraph

text: eclectic practice varied from designing homes for the city’s elite, including famous
label: Paragraph

text: figures of the entertainment industry, to important institutional and commercial
label: Paragraph

text: landmarks. These accomplishments reflect his mastery for adapting a multitude of revival
label: Paragraph

text: and modern styles to the culture of southern California’s Mediterranean climate. His
label: Paragraph

text: success is also notable considering that Williams was the first African American architect
label: Paragraph

text: licensed in California (1921) and the first to be accepted as a member of the American
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of Architects (AIA) (1923). His recognition as a master designer, member of
label: Paragraph

text: numerous civic and government bodies, and mentor to generations of minority architects
label: Paragraph

text: led to his induction as the first African American Fellow of the AIA (1957).
label: Paragraph

text: On graduation from the University of Southern California, Williams worked for
label: Paragraph

text: another noted Los Angeles architect, John C.Austin (1920-22), expanding his knowledge
label: Paragraph

text: while working on major civic structures, including the 5000-seat Shrine Auditorium
label: Paragraph

text: (1922) and numerous public schools. His association with Austin led to a collaboration
label: Paragraph

text: on many future projects and a lifelong friendship. Recognizing his diverse skills as a city
label: Paragraph

text: planner, Williams was appointed to Los Angeles’s first planning com-mission (1920),
label: Paragraph

text: beginning service on what would amount to more than a dozen public bodies during his
label: Paragraph

text: 60-year career at the local, state, and federal levels. By 1923 Williams opened his own
label: Paragraph

text: practice, Paul R.Williams and Associates, Architects, in the fashionable Stock Exchange
label: Caption

text: Building at the core of a booming Los Angeles. His first projects were for politician and
label: Paragraph

text: developer Senator Frank J.Flint for his new development of Flintridge in the hills
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking Pasadena.
label: Paragraph

text: Williams adapted to the cultural racial biases of his times, including restrictions against
label: Paragraph

text: his living in most of the communities where he designed homes. Nonetheless, he
label: Paragraph

text: designed many cultural institutions and businesses for the booming African American
label: Paragraph

text: community at or below cost to improve opportunity and activities in his community of
label: Paragraph

text: south-central Los Angeles. These included many neighborhood YMCAs (1925-27) and
label: Paragraph

text: churches, including the Second Baptist Church (1924). His client roster included
label: Paragraph

text: Hollywood royalty and elite of the booming region. So great were his talents in
label: Paragraph

text: diminishing the boundaries to success that he would create sketches for Anglo clients
label: Paragraph

text: upside down, sitting opposite so as not to come into close contact with them. This so
label: Paragraph

text: impressed many skeptics that he rarely lost a commission because of the color of his skin.
label: Paragraph

text: Prejudices aside, Williams was able to design comfortable surroundings that evoked a
label: Paragraph

text: sense of grandeur while maintaining
label: Title

text: Theme Building at Los Angeles International Airport, by Paul Revere Williams
label: Caption

text: © Joseph Sohm; Chromo Sohm Inc./CORBIS
label: Caption

text: a human scale. Past experience with master architects taught Williams a deep respect for
label: Paragraph

text: the varied revival-style structures that were in vogue throughout his practice. This, in
label: Paragraph

text: turn, influenced the fashion-conscious of Hollywood to seek out his design sensibilities.
label: Paragraph

text: Following World War U, Williams embraced modernism like most of his
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaries, but with a style and grace that evoked the balanced classical
label: Paragraph

text: compositions of the prewar period. This can best be seen in his addition to the Beverly
label: Paragraph

text: Hills Hotel (1947-51), the Los Angeles County Courthouse and Hall of Administration
label: Paragraph

text: (1955), and the Frank Sinatra residence (1956). The postwar years also saw expansion
label: Paragraph

text: with allied offices in Bogota, Colombia, and Washington, D.C. The number of
label: Paragraph

text: commissions for public and commercial structures following World War II eclipsed his
label: Paragraph

text: prewar residential commissions, with his offices swelling to more than 60 draftsmen. It
label: Paragraph

text: was during this period that one of his greatest landmarks was designed in association with
label: Paragraph

text: Pereira and Luckman and Welton Becket Associates: the Los Angeles International
label: Title

text: Airport Theme Building (1961-65).
label: Caption

text: After a prosperous career, Williams spent his final years lecturing around the world
label: Paragraph

text: about dedication to one’s desires and the obstacles that must be overcome to achieve
label: Paragraph

text: them. He continued his practice until the mid-1970s, taking on projects that more closely
label: Paragraph

text: resembled those from his practice during the first two decades of his career. Williams
label: Paragraph

text: understood more keenly than most design professionals that many outside influences
label: Paragraph

text: affected how and what is built. His dedication to improving design went well beyond the
label: Paragraph

text: drafting room tables.
label: Paragraph

text: JEFFREY B.SSAMUDIO
label: Title

text: Biography
label: Title

text: Born Los Angeles, 18 February 1894, son of poor recent immigrants from the southern
label: Paragraph

text: United States, orphaned at an early age. Attended Los Angeles Polytechnic High School;
label: Paragraph

text: attended the Los Angeles School of Art and the Beaux-Arts School of Design Atelier
label: Paragraph

text: 1912-16; winner of the Beaux-Arts Medal and First Prize for a Neighborhood Center in
label: Paragraph

text: Pasadena, California. Attended the University of Southern California School of
label: Paragraph

text: Engineering, specializing in structural design and engineering 1916-19. Married Della
label: Paragraph

text: Mae Givens 27 June 1917. Member of the first Los Angeles Planning Commission 1920—
label: Caption

text: 28; certified as an architect, state of California 1921. Established firm of Paul R.
label: Caption

text: Williams, Architect 1922; became member of the Southern California Chapter of the
label: Paragraph

text: American Institute of Architects 1923; appointed to the National Monuments Committee
label: Caption

text: by President Calvin Coolidge 1929; appointed to the first Los Angeles Housing
label: Paragraph

text: Commission 1933-41. Won first AIA award for design of the Music Corporation of
label: Caption

text: America corporate offices (1937), Beverly Hills, in 1939; received honorary doctorate of
label: Paragraph

text: science degree, Lincoln University, Missouri. Enlisted as a navy architect during World
label: Paragraph

text: War II 1942-45. First major public buildings 1940-41, Long Beach Naval Station;
label: Caption

text: followed after the war with major additions to the Los Angeles General Hospital 1947;
label: Paragraph

text: also that year he was appointed to the board, serving as vice president, then director of
label: Paragraph

text: Broadway Federal Savings and Loan, the oldest federal savings and loan headed by
label: Paragraph

text: African Americans west of the Mississippi. Appointed by governor, and later chief justice
label: Paragraph

text: of the Supreme Court, Earl Warren, to the California Housing Commission 1949-55.
label: Caption

text: Received honorary doctor of architecture degree, Howard University (presented by
label: Caption

text: President Truman); appointed to the National Commission on Housing by President
label: Paragraph

text: Eisenhower 1953. Retired from practice following his commission to design a sorority
label: Paragraph

text: house at his alma mater, USC 1973. Died in Los Angeles, 23 January 1980.

text: WILLIAMS, TOD (1943-) AND BILLIE
label: Title

text: TSIEN (1949-)
label: Title

text: Architects, United States
label: Title

text: The architecture of Tod Williams and Billie Tsien has been characterized as one that is
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupied with the craft of making. Working together in practice in New York, these
label: Paragraph

text: two architects have developed particular interests in the inherent qualities of materials
label: Paragraph

text: that they have combined with investigations of the details of the physical and
label: Paragraph

text: philosophical nature of construction. They have explored these interests through a range
label: Paragraph

text: of projects that originated in designs for exhibitions and performance and that have
label: Paragraph

text: subsequently developed to embrace more conventional architectural commissions that
label: Paragraph

text: have included houses, educational facilities, and civic buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: After studying architecture at Princeton University and working for Richard Meier for
label: Paragraph

text: six years, Tod Williams opened his own office in 1974. Billie Tsien’s first degree was in
label: Paragraph

text: fine arts, and she went on to study architecture at the University of California, Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles, before joining Williams. Together they have developed a practice that has been
label: Paragraph

text: significantly influenced by their backgrounds in architecture and fine art. However, theirs
label: Paragraph

text: is also a practice that reflects a collaborative effort that grows out of their relationship as
label: Paragraph

text: a married couple, and they have frequently spoken of their interest in “bringing together
label: Paragraph

text: the issues of life and architecture.”
label: Paragraph

text: In their early work, Williams and Tsien experimented with materials in the designs for
label: Paragraph

text: installations at the Museum of the Chinese in the Americas in New York and elsewhere.
label: Caption

text: They used unconventional materials and also reconsidered how familiar materials could
label: Paragraph

text: be used in unfamiliar ways. For an exhibition of Noguchi’s Akari lanterns, they used
label: Paragraph

text: obsidian with lit fiberglass screens, and a project that was developed with the Elisa
label: Paragraph

text: Monte Dance Company in New York advanced the ideas of large screens to create a
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic backdrop for the staging of dance productions.
label: Paragraph

text: These investigations informed their subsequent architectural work. The design for new
label: Paragraph

text: galleries at the Phoenix Art Museum explored the use of glass and metal and of different
label: Paragraph

text: aggregates in the making of the concrete for the building. The systems of construction
label: Paragraph

text: were also developed to define paths of movement that organize the new galleries and link
label: Paragraph

text: them into an existing building. This consideration of the path as an organizing element in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and also as a place of meeting and social interaction has become increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: influential in their work. In the planning of the Neurosciences Institute in La Jolla,
label: Paragraph

text: California, a theoretical and clinical research campus for the study of the brain, Williams
label: Caption

text: and Tsien designed places of informal meeting that are integrated with spaces for work
label: Paragraph

text: by creating a series of paths that become meandering walks through the building. These
label: Paragraph

text: paths also integrate the institute into a surrounding natural landscape framed by the Santa
label: Paragraph

text: Rosa Mountains.
label: Paragraph

text: In the development and design of the Cranbrook Estate in Michigan, the architect Eliel
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen, together with his client George Booth, established a strong relationship among
label: Paragraph

text: landscape, art, and architecture. It was a relationship that was also reflected in the
label: Paragraph

text: organization of a curriculum that sought to connect the mental and the physical through
label: Paragraph

text: the integration of academic and athletic activities there. Increases in enrollment at
label: Paragraph

text: Cranbrook prompted the need for new and improved facilities, and Williams and Tsien
label: Paragraph

text: were commissioned to prepare a plan for new buildings there to provide gymnasiums,
label: Paragraph

text: exercise rooms, and a swimming pool. Their design developed ideas of movement and
label: Paragraph

text: path embodied in their earlier designs for academic buildings in California, at Princeton,
label: Paragraph

text: and at the University of Virginia. The coeducational natatorium at Cranbrook has been
label: Paragraph

text: planned to connect to existing buildings, and large occuli and doors enable the building to
label: Paragraph

text: be opened up during spring and summer. These devices successfully connect the building
label: Paragraph

text: to the landscapes of the Cranbrook Estate. The first building in this phased development,
label: Paragraph

text: which was completed in 1999, is one of the most successful new educational buildings in
label: Paragraph

text: the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: Commissions to design houses for sites in New York City, Long Island, and Phoenix
label: Caption

text: have enabled Williams and Tsien to explore these issues of materiality, path, and the
label: Paragraph

text: integration of building with site at another scale. These explorations are particularly
label: Paragraph

text: successful in the houses in Phoenix and Long Island, which were completed in 1997 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1999, respectively.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1998 Williams and Tsien received a commission to design the Museum of Folk Art
label: Paragraph

text: in New York. This project develops these ideas within the confines of a restricted site on
label: Paragraph

text: Fifty-third Street. Of necessity the scheme organizes the galleries as a series of spaces
label: Paragraph

text: that are linked vertically. An elevator is itself designed as a gallery. Internally, a series of
label: Paragraph

text: shafts are also cut through the building to link spaces and define the paths that connect
label: Paragraph

text: them with natural light. The facade on the 40-foot-wide street front-age, proposed as a
label: Paragraph

text: folded plane of white bronze panels, is mainly solid. Not only does the fold give the
label: Paragraph

text: museum a greater presence on the street, but the material was selected to reflect the
label: Paragraph

text: dynamism of changing light throughout the day. This new museum opened in 2001.
label: Paragraph

text: In its preoccupation with materials and the details of fabrication, the work of Williams
label: Paragraph

text: and Tsien recalls that of Charles and Ray Eames. By working closely together, they have
label: Paragraph

text: been able to develop interests in the craft of making architecture and shaping space to a
label: Paragraph

text: level that articulates an important alternative to corporate practice and the
label: Paragraph

text: overwhelmingly generic buildings that frequently result from industrial production.
label: Paragraph

text: WILSON, (SIR) COLIN ST. JOHN 1922
label: Title

text: Architect, England
label: Title

text: Colin Wilson, with his firm of Colin St. John Wilson and Partners, founded in 1971, is
label: Paragraph

text: responsible for the largest and most expensive (£511 million) architectural commission in
label: Paragraph

text: Britain—the British Library—which on its completion in 1998 had been some 36 years in
label: Paragraph

text: the making. Wilson faced hostility and ridicule during the design and construction, but
label: Paragraph

text: his courage and confidence finally brought vindication—today the British Library enjoys
label: Paragraph

text: immense popularity and prestige. While this monumental building constitutes Wilson’s
label: Paragraph

text: chief constructed architectural legacy, as an educator and persuasive author, Wilson has
label: Paragraph

text: had an effect on architecture that transcends his numerically modest built output. He has
label: Paragraph

text: been a very important voice for those who care about integrity more than fashion and
label: Paragraph

text: who believe that architecture should serve human needs over time, be embellished by
label: Paragraph

text: use, served in and provide a frame in which human actions are made manifest.
label: Paragraph

text: Educated at Cambridge University and University College, London, after wartime
label: Paragraph

text: naval service, Wilson served in the Housing Division of the London County Council
label: Paragraph

text: (LCC) between 1950 and 1955, when public housing was the most important task on the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural agenda in a Britain still recovering from wartime damages. After a year with
label: Paragraph

text: the developer John De Vere Hunt, Wilson moved to Cambridge at the invitation of Leslie
label: Paragraph

text: Martin, principal architect at the LCC before his appointment in 1956 as professor at the
label: Paragraph

text: School of Architecture, to teach and to associate with him on architectural projects.
label: Paragraph

text: Initially, Wilson had been captivated by Le Corbusier, especially his sculptural post
label: Paragraph

text: war Brutalist work. Thus, Wilson’s extension to the Architecture School at Cambridge
label: Paragraph

text: has the textured roughness of Le Corbusier’s Unite d’ Habitation (Marseilles, 1946-52)
label: Caption

text: and the Maisons Jaoul (Paris, 1952-56). Ultimately, however, Alvar Aalto would be
label: Paragraph

text: much more influential. Wilson often quotes the Finnish master’s observation about
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture of the heroic period, made when Aalto received the RIBA Medal in
label: Paragraph

text: 1957: “Like all revolutions it starts with enthusiasm and stops with some sort of
label: Paragraph

text: Dictatorship” (Architectural Reflections, p. 84). Thus, Wilson began to seek an
label: Paragraph

text: alternative tradition for modern architecture, which he found in the work of other
label: Paragraph

text: Scandinavians like Sigurd Lewerentz and Gunnar Asplund, as well as German organicists
label: Paragraph

text: like Hugo Har-ing and Hans Scharoun. Aalto’s immediate effect can be recognized in
label: Paragraph

text: Harvey Court at Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge, in the dominant materials of
label: Paragraph

text: brick (rather than the prevailing béton brut), natural wood, and copper; in the
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement of a raised courtyard (as at the Town Hall, Saéynatsalo, 1950-52) with a
label: Paragraph

text: pyramidal skylight admitting light to below; and in the way the stairs are expressed (both
label: Paragraph

text: devices also recalling Aalto’s Baker House at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology,
label: Paragraph

text: 1946-49). Although at Harvey Court the image of La Tourette also lingered, increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: it was Aalto and the German Expressionists who excited Wilson’s admiration. Thus, the
label: Paragraph

text: fan shape of the William Stone Building at Peterhouse College (1960-64) brings to mind
label: Paragraph

text: one of Aalto’s favorite motifs.
label: Paragraph

text: In his designs and his writings, Wilson vigorously combats the leading tendency of the
label: Paragraph

text: 1980s and 1990s to view architecture as autonomous and as a discipline, a mode of
label: Paragraph

text: abstract thinking, that exists outside the practice of making buildings and creating space.
label: Paragraph

text: Wilson has also set himself against “inauthenticity,” which he has found both in the
label: Paragraph

text: modernism of the International Style and in Postmodernism. Probity is a revered quality,
label: Paragraph

text: and Wilson seeks an ethical dimension that is hardly new; its sources can be found in
label: Paragraph

text: A.W. N. Pugin and John Ruskin no less than H.P. Berlage or Aalto—all intellectual
label: Paragraph

text: forebears.
label: Paragraph

text: Nourished on a diet of astute English critics of widely varied opinions, including
label: Paragraph

text: Ruskin, Geoffrey Scott, and Adrian Stokes, Wilson is passionate about architecture
label: Paragraph

text: without being narrowminded or doctrinaire. He is also a bibliophile, and it is appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: that he should have become a specialist in redefining the program of the contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: library. Thus, with Martin he designed three libraries for Oxford University (1959-64),
label: Paragraph

text: with Long he worked on the National Libraries Feasibility Study as well as the libraries
label: Paragraph

text: for the Bishops’ School and for Queen Mary College, and he acted as consultant for the
label: Paragraph

text: Harold Washington Library in Chicago by Hammond Beeby Babka.
label: Caption

text: At the same time, Wilson is also profoundly involved in the visual arts as painter,
label: Paragraph

text: draftsman, and sculptor; as museum trustee; and as collector. He has been the intimate
label: Paragraph

text: friend, and often mentor, of many artists: Peter Blake, Eduardo Paolozzi, R.J. Kitaj,
label: Paragraph

text: Howard Hodgkin, Richard Hamilton, and William Turnbull, among others; his extensive
label: Paragraph

text: collection of their work has been promised to the Pallant House Gallery in Chichester, for
label: Paragraph

text: which he designed an extension.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1994 Wilson suggested that Long and their associate Rolfe Kentish establish a new
label: Paragraph

text: partnership to supplement the existing firm, and he subsequently has involved himself
label: Paragraph

text: with projects by Long and Kentish. Although many laurels have come his way since the
label: Paragraph

text: opening of the British Library—for example, a knighthood and an exhibition at the
label: Paragraph

text: British Pavilion of the Venice Biennale (1996), as well as numerous invitations to teach
label: Paragraph

text: and lecture—Wilson is still deeply engaged in shaping architectural practice to embody
label: Paragraph

text: his deeply felt principles.
label: Paragraph
