label: Title

text: The dramatic technological, environmental, political, and economic changes that
label: Paragraph

text: occurred during the 20th century irrevocably changed the way in which wood is used in
label: Paragraph

text: all types of building. Three major themes can be discerned: improved technology and
label: Paragraph

text: accelerating scientific research have resulted in novel uses for wood as well as in
label: Paragraph

text: structural and decorative substitutes for wood; improved transportation, rising demand,
label: Paragraph

text: and freer trade have created large, new worldwide markets for all types of timber and
label: Paragraph

text: wood fiber; and, despite constantly shifting styles, steady change in construction
label: Paragraph

text: technology has reduced wood’s relevance to architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The immense investment of energy, time, and wealth in scientific research by
label: Paragraph

text: governments, businesses, and universities throughout the 20th century bore fruit in
label: Paragraph

text: practically every field of endeavor, and wood, despite its seemingly elemental nature,
label: Paragraph

text: was not neglected. The fundamental innovations of the 20th century were to devise new
label: Paragraph

text: ways to break wood down into its boards, strips, strands, fibers, and even molecules and
label: Paragraph

text: to concoct new and better ways to reattach these components. Another breakthrough,
label: Paragraph

text: although of questionable environmental merit, was the gradual development of improved
label: Paragraph

text: techniques for planting, growing, and harvesting trees. These innovations had the net
label: Paragraph

text: result of increasing both the usefulness and the value of wood in society. They also
label: Paragraph

text: permitted, for the first time, many physical weaknesses of wood to be significantly
label: Paragraph

text: ameliorated.
label: Paragraph

text: Except for scarce “old growth” timber, which can be up to 10 feet in diameter and over
label: Paragraph

text: 100 feet in length, trees produce lumber that is not very long, very straight, or very stable.
label: Paragraph

text: Premodern carpentry accommodated the slender, flexible, environmentally sensitive
label: Paragraph

text: nature of wood by devising intricate, laborintensive methods of combining small pieces
label: Paragraph

text: of wood to create architectural surfaces and structural frames. Carpenters in the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century, by contrast, were able to use many new wood products that are, in theory,
label: Paragraph

text: infinitely wide, flat, long, stiff, uniform, and stable. The most famous example of this is
label: Paragraph

text: plywood, actually a trade name for a Douglas fir product that was first exhibited at the
label: Paragraph

text: Lewis and Clark Centennial Exposition of 1905. Plywood is best known because, by the
label: Paragraph

text: middle of the 20th century, it was being used for everything from furniture designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright to P.T. boats, but it is just one of many different types of composite
label: Paragraph

text: wood panels made up of layers of wood veneer glued together. Because the layers of
label: Paragraph

text: veneer are laid at cross angles to one another, plywood warps, shrinks, and cracks very
label: Paragraph

text: little. Although it is sold today primarily in panels four feet wide by eight feet long, it can
label: Paragraph

text: theoretically be manufactured to any dimension and in virtually any thickness. Many
label: Paragraph

text: types of veneer panel were being manufactured in limited quantities during the 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century, but the growing usefulness of composite wood panels in the 20th century
label: Paragraph

text: depended primarily on the increasing strength, durability, and water resistance of the
label: Paragraph

text: adhesives.
label: Paragraph

text: Composite panels could also be made from straw, wood, sugarcane, or practically any
label: Paragraph

text: other kind of vegetable fiber. Such products as Masonite, Homasote, Celotex, Insulite,
label: Paragraph

text: and Presdwood were developed and produced throughout the 20th century and offered
label: Paragraph

text: builders some of the same advantages as plywood, namely, perfect uniformity of size and
label: Paragraph

text: strength, extreme economy, and tremendous structural efficiency. Because these products
label: Paragraph

text: had limited insulating quality—and also because they were cheap, easy to produce, and
label: Paragraph

text: manufactured from agricultural or lumber waste products—they were in extremely high
label: Paragraph

text: demand during World War II. As the Masonite Man boasted in a wartime advertisement:
label: Paragraph

text: Many a U.S. fighting man, from the north pole to the tropics, lives and works in
label: Paragraph

text: a Quonset Hut, lined entirely with Masonite Presdwood. The entire lining for a
label: Paragraph

text: Hut is shipped easily in one compact crate...painted and ready to install. These
label: Paragraph

text: Masonite Presdwood walls resist both the frigid blasts of the Arctic and the
label: Paragraph

text: heat, humidity and insects of the equator.
label: Paragraph

text: Another product that achieved popularity and importance in the 20th century was the
label: Paragraph

text: “glue-lam” timber. The first recorded use of glued laminated arches was in Basel,
label: Paragraph

text: Switzerland, in 1893. In 1901 the first patent was awarded to Otto Hetzer of Weimar,
label: Paragraph

text: Germany. Thereafter, glued laminated arches were known in Europe as the Hetzer
label: Paragraph

text: construction method. In the United States, the first glued laminated timbers were
label: Paragraph

text: manufactured by Max C. Hanisch, Sr., a German immigrant and the founder of the Unit
label: Paragraph

text: Structures Corporation of Peshtigo, Wisconsin, in 1934. The principle of the glue-
label: Paragraph

text: laminated beam was probably first employed by Bronze Age fletchers who manufactured
label: Paragraph

text: bows of extreme flexibility and power by gluing thin strips of animal horn together. In
label: Paragraph

text: the case of the glue-lam timber, however, scientists in the 20th century developed
label: Paragraph

text: efficient ways to laminate small, dry boards together to create, in theory, infinitely long,
label: Paragraph

text: deep timbers of uniform cross section and stable composition. Gluelam timbers could
label: Paragraph

text: also be bent into any shape, increasing the variety of architectural effects that could be
label: Paragraph

text: achieved.
label: Paragraph

text: In the past several decades, numerous variations on these two themes have been
label: Paragraph

text: developed in an effort to reduce costs, preserve timber, increase efficiency, and raise
label: Paragraph

text: profits. Oriented strand board, Para-lam timbers, pre-primed plywood siding, and
label: Caption

text: trussjoists, to list just four among hundreds of brand-new products, utilize super-strong
label: Paragraph

text: new waterproof adhesives and small, thin, dry boards or even mill scraps. The advantage
label: Paragraph

text: of all this innovation has been constantly increasing speed of construction, vastly
label: Paragraph

text: increased efficiency in the use of diminishing timber resources, ever lighter-weight
label: Paragraph

text: structures, and lower building costs. The drawback to all these new products is greater
label: Paragraph

text: fire hazard, slimmer margins of engineering safety, shorter life spans, and a reliance on
label: Paragraph

text: an increasing number of synthetic glues and preservative chemicals.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout the 20th century, but particularly after World War Ll, many nations and
label: Paragraph

text: regions began to export formerly untapped timber resources, and many developing
label: Paragraph

text: nations established strong new wood-manufacturing industries. Increased trade in the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century had two major effects: the largest Western economies were benefited from
label: Paragraph

text: the increased availability of foreign wood species, were formerly tiny, insular economies
label: Paragraph

text: were being affected by international trends in construction, timber harvesting, and
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturing.
label: Paragraph

text: The international timber trade is at least as old as recorded history. In biblical times the
label: Paragraph

text: ceiling of Solomon’s temple was reputedly framed of cedar beams imported from
label: Paragraph

text: Lebanon. During the Middle Ages, most of the highest-quality oak boards used in
label: Paragraph

text: England for doors and furniture were brought by ship from the Baltic. One result of
label: Paragraph

text: growing trade in the 20th century, however, was the availability of larger and
label: Paragraph

text: comparatively less expensive quantities of foreign timber than ever before. The species
label: Paragraph

text: might be exotic, such as teak from Myanmar or mahogany from Brazil, valued by
label: Paragraph

text: shipbuilders, cabinetmakers, and other specialty secondary industries, or they might
label: Paragraph

text: simply be inexpensive softwood for framing, such as the huge quantities of fir, spruce,
label: Paragraph

text: hemlock, and pine pouring onto the world market from Canada, Russia, and other Baltic
label: Paragraph

text: countries. Naturally, this increased trade was largely a result of rising demand. Annual
label: Paragraph

text: world demand for all types of wood is expected to rise in 2010 to approximately 2.7
label: Paragraph

text: billion cubic meters, according to the United Nations. This is approximately 15 percent
label: Paragraph

text: higher than the world’s production capacity in 1997.
label: Paragraph

text: Increased international trade also increased pressure in many markets to standardize or
label: Paragraph

text: to adopt new techniques. In Japan, for example, where carpentry is a ferociously
label: Paragraph

text: defended traditional craft, pressures were mounting to incorporate Westernstyle framing
label: Paragraph

text: because of its low cost and its efficient earthquake resistance. This was contrary both to
label: Paragraph

text: popular opinion in Japan, where traditionally framed structures are believed to flex and
label: Paragraph

text: bend with earth tremors, and to carpenters’ preferred methods of work. Nevertheless, the
label: Paragraph

text: effectiveness of Western-style framing was demonstrated during the Kobe earthquake of
label: Paragraph

text: 1995. Following the terrible devastation, engineers in Japan noted that modern American-
label: Paragraph

text: style plywood boxes had proven quite durable, whereas many traditionally framed
label: Paragraph

text: postwar buildings had performed poorly. American-style platform framing, however,
label: Paragraph

text: relies on standardized kiln-dried lumber and plywood, which American lumber
label: Paragraph

text: companies are eager to begin exporting to Japan in larger quantities. Japanese carpenters
label: Paragraph

text: and lumber companies, on the other hand, would much prefer to import select American
label: Paragraph

text: logs and process the lumber themselves, thereby preserving jobs and, they believe,
label: Paragraph

text: increasing quality. The serious consideration in Japan of the adoption of Western-style
label: Paragraph

text: framing, Western lumber dimensions, and offshore labor exemplifies the power of
label: Paragraph

text: international trends to change even the most entrenched traditional local uses of wood in
label: Paragraph

text: construction. Such shifts have occurred throughout the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Probably the most interesting—and misleading—force that influenced wood’s use in
label: Paragraph

text: the 20th century was the fluctuating popularity of many different fads, trends, styles, and
label: Paragraph

text: practitioners of architecture. These influences are difficult to disentangle from
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneous technological, economic, and political changes and indeed were usually
label: Paragraph

text: precipitated by the more powerful shifts of the world at large.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most notable shifts of the early 20th century was a worldwide move away
label: Paragraph

text: from romantic, historicizing styles of building to the International Style. In the United
label: Paragraph

text: States, this meant that Richardsonian Romanesque, Neoclassical, Craftsman, Edwardian,
label: Paragraph

text: Art Nouveau, and a host of other styles of building were slowly overcome by the
label: Paragraph

text: machinery of the building itself. This shift was not merely stylistic. As Henry-Russell
label: Paragraph

text: Hitchcock noted as early as 1928, “Indeed a client, while he may ask for a Tudor or a
label: Paragraph

text: Georgian or even a Maya design, is unlikely to permit any serious sacrifice of /e comfort
label: Paragraph

text: moderne to the exigencies of a past style” (Hitchcock, 1928).
label: Paragraph

text: In retrospect, it was inevitable that as the building became filled with more and more
label: Paragraph

text: lighting, heating, cooling, communication, and transportation equipment, not to mention
label: Paragraph

text: a strong new steel skeleton, it would divide into at least three parts: guts, bones, and skin.
label: Paragraph

text: The inconsistency of having fresh, young, vigorous guts and bones sealed in a leathery
label: Paragraph

text: old skin from a previous millennium slowly became more objectionable until advocates
label: Paragraph

text: of the International Style proposed a solution: the entire building ought to be a new, up-
label: Paragraph

text: to-date machine for living.
label: Paragraph

text: Naturally, this shift had a powerful influence on how wood was used in architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Where the Greene brothers, Charles Rennie Mackintosh, and Victor Horta glorified the
label: Paragraph

text: skill of the craftsman, the physical beauty of architectural materials, and the expense and
label: Paragraph

text: complexity of fabricating architecture, the International Style celebrated the economy,
label: Paragraph

text: simplicity, and directness of mass-produced materials and components. Metals, glass,
label: Paragraph

text: concrete, plastics, and rubber became the preferred palette of leading architects from the
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s on. Wood was acceptable if it was served up in flat, straight, square, uniform,
label: Paragraph

text: repetitive chunks—in other words, if it imitated the stripped-down, mass-produced
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic of the other parts of the machine. Frank Lloyd Wright expressed the disgust that
label: Paragraph

text: many modern architects felt toward traditional wooden embellishments very clearly when
label: Paragraph

text: he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: Wood, therefore, has more human outrage done upon it than man has ever done,
label: Paragraph

text: even upon himself.... In his search for novelty, wood in his hands has been
label: Paragraph

text: joined and glued, braced and screwed, boxed and nailed, turned and tortured,
label: Paragraph

text: scroll sawed, beaded, fluted, suitably furbelowed and flounced at the carpenter’s
label: Paragraph

text: party—enough to please even him. By the aid of “modern” machines the
label: Paragraph

text: carpenter-artist got it into Eastlake composites of trim and furniture, into
label: Paragraph

text: Usonian jigger porches and corner-towers eventuating into candle snuffer
label: Paragraph

text: domes or what would you have?; got it all over Queen Anne houses outside and
label: Paragraph

text: inside—the triumph of his industrial ingenuity—until carpentry and millwork
label: Paragraph

text: became synonymous with butchery and botchwork. (Wright, 1928)
label: Paragraph

text: According to Wright, the machine itself was not to blame—it could easily produce the
label: Paragraph

text: smooth, rectangular, geometrically pure pieces that he and many other modernists desired
label: Paragraph

text: and put to use in Wright’s Prairie-style houses and many other buildings. Naturally,
label: Paragraph

text: therefore, the scientific and technological advances in the use of wood during the early
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century appealed to modern architects, and they made excellent use of new materials
label: Paragraph

text: and techniques.
label: Paragraph

text: What is not obvious, perhaps even to the architects and critics of the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: movement themselves, is that some of the bestknown and most contentious commentators
label: Paragraph

text: of the 20th century were merely running a few steps ahead of the pack, ten moist fingers
label: Paragraph

text: to the wind. Far more influential—and ultimately irresistible in its power—was the tide
label: Paragraph

text: of economics and technology that swept everything architectural in its wake. Rising labor
label: Paragraph

text: costs, decreasing quality of timber resources, sudden enormous wartime demands, the
label: Paragraph

text: growth and monopolization of wood industries, and, most important, the growing
label: Paragraph

text: dominance of mechanical systems have been far more influential than any style or
label: Paragraph

text: architect despite what some might say about Alvar Aalto’s plywood chairs or Tadao
label: Paragraph

text: Ando’s rustic wall treatments. According to Kenneth Frampton, two-thirds of the total
label: Paragraph

text: budget of any large building built in the 1990s is expended on mechanical and electrical
label: Paragraph

text: provisions of one kind or another, from airconditioning to piped information.
label: Paragraph

text: This observation has many implications. First, combined with the fact that most large
label: Paragraph

text: buildings today are framed in steel, it means that high-status architecture utilizes very
label: Paragraph

text: little wood and consequently has practically no influence on the lumber industry.
label: Paragraph

text: Custom-furnishings manufacturers provide the entire (small) package of fittings,
label: Paragraph

text: furnishings, trim, and moldings. Wherever possible in their design, they will substitute a
label: Paragraph

text: cheaper synthetic material, such as plastic laminate or metal. Where wood is absolutely
label: Paragraph

text: required, it will usually be a thin veneer over a particleboard backing. Second, because
label: Paragraph

text: most “vernacular” structures—everything from tract homes to taco stands—are designed
label: Paragraph

text: with absolute economy and relatively short life expectancies, lumber manufacturers are in
label: Paragraph

text: cutthroat competition to produce the cheapest possible structural components—and these
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular wood-framed buildings, designed by builders and engineers, make up nearly
label: Paragraph

text: 86 percent of all American structures and a growing percentage of new structures
label: Paragraph

text: worldwide. The innovations of the lumber industry, consequently, will rarely reflect the
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic or philosophical attitudes of architects, and because architects have little reason
label: Paragraph

text: to be interested in the lumber industry anyway, only contractors, engineers, and
label: Paragraph

text: environmentalists will be left to argue over how scarce timber resources ought to be used,
label: Paragraph

text: protected, or augmented. In short, wood has moved out of the purview of the most
label: Paragraph

text: influential architects.
label: Paragraph

text: The main difficulty in an analysis of any topic as broad as the 20th-century use of
label: Paragraph

text: wood is to distinguish causes from effects. Scientists and engineers in the 20th century
label: Paragraph

text: created marvelous new uses for wood and surprising new ways to reconfigure wood.
label: Paragraph

text: Large new supplies of timber came onto the world market from all corners of the world;
label: Paragraph

text: and, most noticeably to those of us who are architects and historians of architecture, there
label: Paragraph

text: were extremely novel and exciting new applications for wood devised in the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century. No one who has visited one of Alvar Aalto’s buildings can fail to be impressed
label: Paragraph

text: by his sensitive handling of a material as mundane as birch plywood, and no one who has
label: Paragraph

text: stood in a modern church sanctuary vaulted by glue-lam beams can fail to be impressed
label: Paragraph

text: by their warmth, clarity, and dramatic effect. However, wood is rarely a major
label: Paragraph

text: component in high-status architecture. Wood’s flexibility, warmth, beauty, and dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: vitality are used by leading architects only as special effects. Instead of being revered as
label: Paragraph

text: the essential, expensive, natural material that it once was, it has become another cheap
label: Paragraph

text: mass-produced commodity sold by the truckload to weekend do-it-yourselfers and tract
label: Paragraph

text: home builders. Scientific technology, which facilitated so many exciting changes in
label: Paragraph

text: wood’s use throughout the 20th century, eventually brought forth other materials and
label: Paragraph

text: systems. Those new systems, namely, electrical, plumbing, insulating, heating,
label: Paragraph

text: communication, and transportation, have assumed prominence in construction projects of
label: Paragraph

text: all types, and they, far more than any structural or decorative material, will continue to be
label: Paragraph

text: primary architectural influences throughout the 21st century.
label: Paragraph

text: WOOLWORTH BUILDING, NEW YORK
label: Caption

text: CITY
label: Title

text: Designed by Cass Gilbert; completed 1913
label: Caption

text: The Woolworth Building in New York was designed by the architect Cass Gilbert
label: Caption

text: during 1910-13. Frank Woolworth, the founder of the popular F.W.Woolworth
label: Caption

text: Company, undertook the project in 1910, after having expanded his business from a
label: Paragraph

text: single store in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, established in 1879 to a chain of 318 stores. That
label: Paragraph

text: year, he selected a site at Broadway and Park Place, across from the Brooklyn Bridge and
label: Paragraph

text: Fronting City Hall Park. For the purposes of financing his skyscraper, Woolworth formed
label: Paragraph

text: a limited partnership, the Broadway-Park Place Company, with Irving National Exchange
label: Paragraph

text: Bank.
label: Paragraph

text: Woolworth chose Gilbert as the project’s architect after Gilbert designed the Broadway
label: Paragraph

text: Chambers (1896-1900) and the West Street buildings (1905-07), achieving renown for
label: Paragraph

text: his skyscrapers. Gilbert’s West Street Building, his first “skyscraper Gothic” design,
label: Paragraph

text: featured rational verticals inspired by Louis Sullivan’s Bayard Building and a pinnacled,
label: Paragraph

text: picturesque crown.
label: Paragraph

text: Woolworth selected the Victoria Tower at the Houses of Parliament in London, a
label: Paragraph

text: perpendicular Gothic tower, as the model for his skyscraper. Gilbert’s objective,
label: Paragraph

text: however, was to create a “civic” or “commercial” identity for the headquarters of the
label: Paragraph

text: F.W.Woolworth Company. This he based on his study of the secular Gothic hotels des
label: Paragraph

text: villes, cloth halls, and belfries of medieval Flanders. Woolworth also envisioned his
label: Paragraph

text: project as a “giant signboard.” In November 1911, he merged his chain with those of
label: Paragraph

text: competitors to create the F.W. Woolworth Company,
label: Paragraph

text: Graphite sketch for elevation of Woolworth Building, by Cass Gilbert
label: Caption

text: © Library of Congress
label: Title

text: Sat
label: Title

text: amen ae Ha! AE
label: Title

text: Woolworth Building, New York (1913)
label: Caption

text: © Museum of the City of New York. Gift of Collection LeRoy Barton
label: Caption

text: with a new total of 597 stores; his new retailing empire stretched from England across the
label: Paragraph

text: Atlantic to the American shores of the Pacific.
label: Paragraph

text: The Woolworth Building’s final design, which Gilbert completed in January 1911, had
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic verticals showing a heightened energy and rhythm. An ingenious system of portal
label: Paragraph

text: arch wind bracing, designed by the project’s structural engineer, Gunvald Aus, made
label: Paragraph

text: possible the exterior’s soaring, attenuated, and diaphanous qualities. Flamboyant Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: canopies, the gables of the crown, the tower’s recessing stages, and the culminating
label: Paragraph

text: tourelles—all of which were modeled in ivory-colored terracotta—enhanced the design’s
label: Paragraph

text: picturesqueness in the city. Gilbert used accenting blues, greens, and yellows to suggest
label: Paragraph

text: depth and shadows in the elevations and to relate the tower to the surroundings of clouds
label: Paragraph

text: and sky.
label: Paragraph

text: Woolworth, who chose to build in an already overbuilt market for office space, devised
label: Paragraph

text: strategies for advertising the Woolworth Building to prospective tenants. He and his press
label: Paragraph

text: agent, Hugh McAtemney, exploited the skyscraper’s design and construction as the
label: Paragraph

text: “world’s highest” in an aggressive program of publicity. They had President Woodrow
label: Paragraph

text: Wilson push a telegraphic button in Washington, D.C., on 24 April 1913, staging the
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper’s opening as a great lighting spectacle. In January 1915 Woolworth installed a
label: Paragraph

text: permanent lighting scheme that he hailed as a “standing advertisement.” Woolworth also
label: Paragraph

text: developed the tower as a sensational pinnacle observatory, which drew up to 1000
label: Paragraph

text: visitors a day and became an important landmark in the tourist’s itinerary of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: The Woolworth Building’s lobby-arcade, designed as an entrance to both the
label: Paragraph

text: F.W.Woolworth Company and Irving National Bank, was one of the most opulent and
label: Paragraph

text: colorful in the city. A cross between a Romanesque cathedral nave and the early
label: Paragraph

text: Christian mausoleum of Galla Placidia, it featured C. Paul Jennewein’s murals “Labor”
label: Paragraph

text: and “Commerce.” The interior’s semipublic spaces, among them Irving National Bank’s
label: Paragraph

text: “Elizabethan” banking hall, the “medieval German” Rathskeller, and Woolworth’s own
label: Paragraph

text: Napoleonic “Empire style” executive offices on the 24th story, enriched the experience of
label: Paragraph

text: office work with environments of fantasy that evoked the treasures of Europe. Offices for
label: Paragraph

text: tenants were unusually light filled, and some had ceilings 20 feet high. Tenant
label: Paragraph

text: conveniences included 18 stores in the lobby-arcade, direct access to two adjacent
label: Paragraph

text: subway lines, and 26 high-speed electric elevators outfitted with Ellithorpe air cushions.
label: Paragraph

text: Woolworth and McAtemney touted the skyscraper as “the highest, safest, and most
label: Paragraph

text: perfectly appointed office structure in the world (Real Estate Record, p. 587).
label: Paragraph

text: The Woolworth Building was christened the “Cathedral of Commerce” by the
label: Paragraph

text: Reverend S.Parkes Cadman in 1916, and during the vibrant economy of the 1920s, it was
label: Paragraph

text: viewed at home and abroad as a symbol of America’s optimism, progress, and material
label: Paragraph

text: success. After the Depression, however, it became a lightning rod for modernist
label: Paragraph

text: historians, who chided its Gothic ornament as out of step with the times. It was named a
label: Paragraph

text: national historical landmark in 1983 and subsequently underwent two restorations, the
label: Paragraph

text: first by the Ehrenkrantz Group in 1978-80 and the second by Beyer Blinder Belle,
label: Paragraph

text: Architects and Planners, in 1998-99.
label: Paragraph

text: WORLD TRADE CENTER, NEW YORK
label: Caption

text: CITY
label: Title

text: Designed by Minoru Yamasaki; completed 1976, destroyed 11 September 2001
label: Caption

text: The design and building of the World Trade Center complex (1966-76) comprised a
label: Paragraph

text: unique architectural vision, the application of innovative technology, and public interest.
label: Paragraph

text: Conceived of as a public project in 1960 by the Port Authority Commissions of New
label: Paragraph

text: York and New Jersey, the World Trade Center was intended to unite private and public
label: Paragraph

text: interests in trade and commerce in one major building complex. Among the goals were
label: Paragraph

text: bringing together government agencies and international trade businesses, rehabilitating
label: Paragraph

text: the appearance of the lower Manhattan financial district, and attracting new businesses to
label: Paragraph

text: the blighted downtown neighborhood by adding more modern office space. The building
label: Paragraph

text: site, encompassing 16 acres located on the far west side of Manhattan along the Hudson
label: Paragraph

text: River, was chosen as a prominent place for an important architectural statement. The
label: Paragraph

text: convergence of major transportation routes from northern Manhattan, Brooklyn, and New
label: Paragraph

text: Jersey was also a consideration for conceiving a central trade center. The selection of
label: Paragraph

text: Minoru Yamasaki, a Michigan-based architect with no experience in designing
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers, over other major figures in International Style design offered a distinctive
label: Paragraph

text: vision of modern architecture to the landscape of lower Manhattan. The Port Authority’s
label: Paragraph

text: mandate for more than ten million square feet of space required the additional assistance
label: Paragraph

text: of Emery Roth, a noted builder of many large-scale commercial and residential projects
label: Paragraph

text: in New York City.
label: Paragraph

text: Minoru Yamasaki, born in 1912 in Seattle, presented an architectural style that showed
label: Paragraph

text: a preference for subtly ornamented modern structures set within open plaza spaces. After
label: Paragraph

text: several experimental models, Yamasaki presented a design for a World Trade Complex
label: Paragraph

text: that included a pair of giant towers, surrounded by three smaller buildings: a hotel, the
label: Paragraph

text: first in lower Manhattan since 1836; a large above-ground plaza; and a subterranean
label: Paragraph

text: shopping and transportation concourse. A below-ground parking garage was the site of a
label: Paragraph

text: terrorist attack in 1993, foreshadowing the devastating destruction of the two towers by
label: Paragraph

text: terrorist attacks on 11 September 2001.
label: Paragraph

text: The plaza and underground spaces reflected Yamasaki’s concern for the functional
label: Paragraph

text: needs of people in an urban setting and were intended to serve as a contemplative open
label: Paragraph

text: space for public respite from the noise and congestion of the narrow, crowded streets of
label: Paragraph

text: lower Manhattan. The placement of the twin towers at angles to one another offset the
label: Paragraph

text: importance of the plaza and drew attention to the buildings themselves. Encased in new
label: Paragraph

text: Alcoa aluminum and rising more than 110 stories to 1368 feet, to become the tallest
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in New York City since the Empire State Building, the towers were intended to
label: Paragraph

text: be seen from a distance as gleaming monoliths, symbolic of the power of New York
label: Paragraph

text: commerce.
label: Paragraph

text: Closer views of the twin-tower complex, particularly from street level, show that the
label: Paragraph

text: steel-encased piers commenced on the open ground floor area as expansive, glass-filled
label: Paragraph

text: spaces that narrowed into Gothic arches and rose to the top of the structure. The subtle
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic design imposed on the exterior and visible in lower interior lobby areas related to
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki’s personal aesthetic interest in architectural elements, most notably the arch,
label: Paragraph

text: borrowed from notable buildings of the past—in this case from Venetian architecture. In
label: Paragraph

text: his incorporation of historic details, Yamasaki transformed the meaning and
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation of the modern glass skyscraper, popularized in the International Style. As a
label: Paragraph

text: result the appearance of the World Trade Center stood out from other notable skyscrapers
label: Paragraph

text: built in lower Manhattan in the same period, including the Chase Manhattan Bank (1960)
label: Caption

text: and the Marine Midland Bank (1967) buildings, both designed by Skidmore, Owings and
label: Paragraph

text: Merrill, the architects and promoters of glass skyscraper architecture in New York City.
label: Paragraph

text: The construction of the World Trade Center, which commenced in 1966, contained
label: Paragraph

text: many feats of modern engineering. The excavation of the site alone required innovative
label: Paragraph

text: planning and the implementation of new technologies. The prime waterfront property,
label: Paragraph

text: actually landfill extending about 600 feet from the original shoreline, required that the
label: Paragraph

text: foundations for the two towers be dug to a very deep level to reach the bedrock of
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan Island. The depth of the digging, to 75 feet, or about six stories below the
label: Paragraph

text: bottom of the adjacent Hudson River, also caused the underground train service to be
label: Paragraph

text: temporarily elevated,
label: Paragraph

text: World Trade Center towers under construction, 27 March 1972
label: Caption

text: Photograph by T.Sheehan © Museum of the City of New York and The Port
label: Caption

text: Authority of New York
label: Title

text: but it was not disrupted at any point during construction. A slurry wall system, previously
label: Paragraph

text: used for the construction of subway tunnels, was implemented to anchor the concrete
label: Paragraph

text: foundations to heavy steel plates that were bolted into the bedrock. The dirt dug for the
label: Paragraph

text: foundations led to the creation of a new neighborhood along the riverbank that became
label: Paragraph

text: another notable new neighborhood: Battery Park City.
label: Paragraph

text: The construction of the twin towers also required engineering ingenuity. The structural
label: Paragraph

text: engineering firm Skilling, Helle, Christiansen, Robertson coordinated the buildings to be
label: Paragraph

text: built from the inside out, starting at the elevator cores. Through tests conducted on
label: Paragraph

text: models of the towers in wind tunnels, a shock-absorbing damping system was devised to
label: Paragraph

text: minimize the swaying of the tall buildings in high-wind conditions.
label: Paragraph

text: The elevator system was sectionalized into three separate banks. Express elevators
label: Paragraph

text: were designed to reach sky lobbies constructed at various intervals, where passengers
label: Paragraph

text: would then board another set of local elevators to reach the intervening floors. The result
label: Paragraph

text: was greater efficiency in terms of both the movement of people and the opening up of
label: Paragraph

text: more valuable floor space for office rental. The exterior walls were constructed with
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated panels combining two horizontal windows and three vertical windows,
label: Paragraph

text: producing a uniform pattern of fifty-eight 22-inchwide windows spread across each
label: Paragraph

text: facade and separated by spandrels and columns. Prefabrication was also introduced in the
label: Paragraph

text: floor framing. The exterior walls were also designed to be load bearing. With the
label: Paragraph

text: assistance of Skilling, Helle, Christiansen, Robertson, a bracing system of vierendrel
label: Caption

text: trusses, consisting of horizontal and vertical members, was incorporated into the exterior
label: Paragraph

text: wall design, applying a nontraditional kind of stabilizing system that appeared to be
label: Paragraph

text: lighter and did not diminish usable interior space.
label: Paragraph

text: With more than 30 million visitors reported to have made the vertical journey to the
label: Paragraph

text: observation deck on the 107th floor of the second tower, the World Trade Center more
label: Caption

text: than fulfilled Yamasaki’s expressed confidence that the monoliths would be experienced
label: Paragraph

text: as some of the most significant and loved New York City buildings. The numbers of
label: Paragraph

text: visitors and tourists alike who continue to be drawn to the site in downtown New York
label: Paragraph

text: City, which is still undergoing repair and reconstruction as of 2003, indicates the
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic and iconic resonance the World Trade Center buildings maintained for a quarter
label: Paragraph

text: of a century.
label: Paragraph

text: WRIGHT, FRANK LLOYD 1867-1959
label: Title

text: Architect and designer, United States
label: Caption

text: Frank Lloyd Wright remains America’s most original, influential, and significant
label: Paragraph

text: architect. His works are more popular today, more than a century after he began his
label: Paragraph

text: practice in 1893 and more than 40 years after his death, than they were at any time during
label: Paragraph

text: his lifetime. During his 72-year career, Wright designed more than 600 built works and
label: Paragraph

text: 600 unbuilt projects, employing an astonishing range of forms and methods, yet he
label: Paragraph

text: always described his life’s work as being one singular effort, emphasizing the
label: Paragraph

text: fundamental and unchanging ordering principles that consistently determined his work
label: Paragraph

text: from beginning to end.
label: Paragraph

text: The first of these fundamental ordering principles, and by far the most important, was
label: Paragraph

text: the primacy of the space of inhabitation, which he called “the space within.” Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: concepts for architectural space evolved first in his designs for interior spaces and were
label: Paragraph

text: only later projected or expressed in the exterior forms. For Wright, the spatial
label: Paragraph

text: composition must be determined by the experience of the inhabitants and not by some
label: Paragraph

text: preconceived formal order. The second principle was that space is given its essential
label: Paragraph

text: character through its construction. Wright believed that the way a space is experienced is
label: Paragraph

text: directly related to the way it is constructed and that the architect must work with “the
label: Paragraph

text: nature of materials.” The third principle was that architecture takes place in nature, where
label: Paragraph

text: interior and exterior space are woven together to make an integral whole. The
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between architecture and the landscape was of fundamental importance to
label: Paragraph

text: Wright, and he believed that the design of a building should start with the ground from
label: Paragraph

text: which it was to grow. Wright designed buildings not simply as freestanding forms but as
label: Paragraph

text: contributing elements in the larger order of both the landscape and the city.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright was raised in a household where the rigorously structured study of natural
label: Paragraph

text: forms, the Unitarian faith, the ideas of American Transcendental philosophy, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Froebel kindergarten training methods were all powerfully present. These complementary
label: Paragraph

text: systems of thought had in common the belief that the material and spiritual worlds could
label: Paragraph

text: not be separated but were in fact one and the same. Emerson had written that “all form is
label: Paragraph

text: an effect of character,” and Wright came to believe that every physical form had spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: and moral meaning. Wright’s development as an architect involved the evolution of this
label: Paragraph

text: moral imperative through the search for a more principled relation to historical form, for
label: Paragraph

text: a monumentality appropriate to the young American nation, and for a systematic yet
label: Paragraph

text: personal process of architectural design.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s education as an architect took place in Chicago from 1888 until 1893, when
label: Paragraph

text: he apprenticed for his mentor, Louis Sullivan. In his public lectures at this time, Sullivan
label: Paragraph

text: was calling attention to the absence of an appropriate American architecture but also
label: Paragraph

text: warning against efforts to speed its arrival by transplanting European historical styles
label: Paragraph

text: onto the American continent. Rejecting imported Beaux-Arts classicism, Sullivan held
label: Paragraph

text: that any truly organic American architecture would develop only on a regional basis, with
label: Paragraph

text: variations dependent on local climate, landscape, building methods, and materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright, who would later fulfill this prophecy of Sullivan’s, assisted Sullivan in his search
label: Paragraph

text: for alternatives to what they believed to be the exhausted European classical tradition,
label: Paragraph

text: analyzing the patterns from Islamic, Oriental, and Celtic sources presented by Owen
label: Paragraph

text: Jones in The Grammar of Ornament.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1893, the year Wright started his own practice, he saw the efforts of Sullivan’s
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago School style overwhelmed by the classical architecture dictated for the World’s
label: Paragraph

text: Columbian Exposition of 1893 in Chicago. This academic classicism, as defined by the
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts School in Paris, was canonically uniform, explicitly noncontextual, and
label: Paragraph

text: intended to be the same around the world—the first true “International Style.” For
label: Paragraph

text: Wright, it was this universal applicability, as something that had nothing to do with the
label: Paragraph

text: particular character of a place, that would always be unacceptable and that led him to
label: Paragraph

text: later oppose International Style modernism as forcefully as he now opposed BeauxArts
label: Paragraph

text: classicism.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet, even as Wright attacked the Beaux-Arts as a superficial style, he was directly
label: Paragraph

text: engaging its source, integrating the formal order underlying the architecture of classical
label: Paragraph

text: antiquity into his work of the Prairie period (1895-1915). In the first comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: national publication of his work in 1908, “In the Cause of Architecture,” written when he
label: Paragraph

text: was 40 years old, Wright challenged the academic classicists’ exclusive control over
label: Paragraph

text: historical form. He argued that his designs, with their symmetry, axial planning, and
label: Paragraph

text: hierarchical ordering from earth to sky, but without any classical forms, demonstrated a
label: Paragraph

text: more principled manner of relating and remaining true to the architectural forms inherited
label: Paragraph

text: from history. Although Wright characterized the appearance of his buildings as radical in
label: Paragraph

text: comparison with the prevalent classicism, he noted that his designs were the result of
label: Paragraph

text: reverential yet rigorous analyses of the great architecture of the past.
label: Paragraph

text: While this battle raged in the professional publications, Wright was in fact well on his
label: Paragraph

text: way to winning the war by establishing a truly American architecture, one based on his
label: Paragraph

text: perfection of a particularly American building type, the single-family suburban house. By
label: Paragraph

text: 1910, when his designs were first extensively published in Europe, Wright had completed
label: Paragraph

text: more than 150 built works, the vast majority of them houses. The prairie house was first
label: Paragraph

text: defined in Wright’s two prototypes published in Ladies’ Home Journal in 1901 and built
label: Paragraph

text: out in the Ward Willits House (1902), the Thomas Hardy House (1905), the Robert Evans
label: Paragraph

text: House (1908), and the Avery Coonley House (1908). The Frederick Robie House (1909)
label: Caption

text: was Wright’s greatest urban residential design, engaging its compressed site to create a
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic sequence of interlocking spaces, culminating in the famous living room and
label: Paragraph

text: dining room, joined by their common ceiling, which passes through the open center of the
label: Paragraph

text: fireplace. The Darwin Martin House (1904), five structures comprising a series of
label: Caption

text: interpenetrating cruciform spaces woven into the landscape, was Wright’s greatest
label: Paragraph

text: suburban residential design, its plan an astonishingly resolved masterpiece of formal
label: Paragraph

text: composition and the inhabitation of its exquisitely articulated interior spaces a comforting
label: Paragraph

text: yet profoundly meaningful experience.
label: Paragraph

text: In Wright’s prairie house, the solid fireplace mass anchored the center while the space
label: Paragraph

text: opened out in all directions at eye level, the outriding walls and overhanging eaves acting
label: Paragraph

text: to layer the house into the earth, giving the suburban site a geometric order so that the
label: Paragraph

text: house and the landscape were inextricably bound to each other. Wright’s prairie houses
label: Paragraph

text: combined the formal order of symmetrical planning with the dynamism of
label: Paragraph

text: interpenetrating spaces to produce the open, multifunctioning interiors, integrated with
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding nature, that have since become the most popular characteristic of modern
label: Paragraph

text: domestic architecture. Wright’s prairie houses crystallized a uniquely American
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation of the dwelling place, allowing the inhabitant to experience both comfort
label: Paragraph

text: and inspiration, shelter and outlook, freedom and order.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to the reinvention of the American house, Wright’s Prairie period also
label: Paragraph

text: produced new forms for public architecture. At the time Wright left Sullivan’s office, an
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate monumental form for American public architecture had not yet emerged. The
label: Paragraph

text: egacy of the steel-framed office tower, which Wright had received from Sullivan and the
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago School, had proved totally incapable of giving monumental form to the
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of the public realm. As a manifestation of the economic determinism of scale
label: Paragraph

text: and massing, the universal planning grid, and the production of uniform interior spaces to
label: Paragraph

text: e “styled” later by tenants, the Chicago frame skyscraper was a projection of private
label: Paragraph

text: commercial interests at a scale heretofore given only to public buildings yet without any
label: Paragraph

text: of the essential qualities necessary for monumentality.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright understood monumentality to originate in the fundamental uniqueness of each
label: Paragraph

text: place, regardless of its scale within the city. This understanding was reflected in Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: work only a year after leaving Sullivan’s office with his project for the Monolithic
label: Paragraph

text: Concrete Bank (1894), a diminutive single-room edifice that nevertheless had the
label: Paragraph

text: powerful presence of an Egyptian temple. In his repeatedly revised designs for the All
label: Paragraph

text: Souls Church, later renamed the Abraham Lincoln Center (1897-1905), Wright
label: Paragraph

text: transformed the spatial uniformity of Sullivan’s skyscrapers into a monumental form that
label: Paragraph

text: precisely articulated on the exterior the diverse functional spaces of the interior.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright achieved his fully developed vision of an appropriate monumentality for public
label: Paragraph

text: buildings with his design and construction of the Larkin Building (1904) and Unity
label: Paragraph

text: Temple (1906). The plans of these two buildings were simple rectangles, with
label: Paragraph

text: mezzanines surrounding and overlooking a central multistory space, lit by high clerestory
label: Paragraph

text: windows and continuous skylights and allowing no views out at eye level. On the exterior
label: Paragraph

text: these buildings were closed and solid and possessed a severity of form unlike anything
label: Paragraph

text: else of their time, seeming to relate more to the stark rectilinearity of ancient monuments.
label: Paragraph

text: For Wright the monumentality appropriate to American public spaces would inevitably
label: Paragraph

text: take the form of an introverted compound, seen from the outside as a grouping of
label: Paragraph

text: powerful independent masses bound together by mutual purpose. Entry occurred between
label: Paragraph

text: these masses, leading to a low, dark, horizontal, rotating movement sequence that
label: Paragraph

text: compressed and then released the occupant into the tall, light, hidden, vertical central
label: Paragraph

text: space. The singularity of the central space, and the manner in which it fused form,
label: Paragraph

text: structure, material, and experience, were profoundly monumental. The entire spatial and
label: Paragraph

text: omamental program for Wright’s public buildings, from plans and massing to furniture
label: Paragraph

text: and carpet patterns, was given order through developments of the square and cube, which
label: Paragraph

text: Wright considered to be the most perfect of geometries. Wright intended that his public
label: Paragraph

text: buildings be experienced as sacred spaces, whatever their function, their introspective
label: Paragraph

text: interiors flooded from above with transcendent light to create a morally edifying effect
label: Paragraph

text: for those inhabiting the public place.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright went through a personal and professional crisis in 1909, closing his Oak Park
label: Paragraph

text: office, abandoning his family, and taking up residence in Italy. There, he and a select
label: Paragraph

text: group of draftsmen prepared drawings for publication by the Wasmuth Company, a
label: Paragraph

text: German publishing house that was to issue a set of drawings of Wright’s work in 1910
label: Paragraph

text: and a book of photographs of Wright’s built works in 1911 that together were to exercise
label: Paragraph

text: considerable influence in Europe. That year, Wright returned to the United States and
label: Paragraph

text: began construction on his home and studio, called Taliesin (1911), outside Spring Green,
label: Paragraph

text: Wisconsin. Like his favorite of the prairie houses, the Coonley House, Taliesin was
label: Paragraph

text: organized around an exterior garden courtyard, framing but not completely enclosing the
label: Paragraph

text: brow of the hill on which it was built. This courtyard house type was developed by
label: Paragraph

text: Wright in response to commissions, such as those for the unbuilt Henry Ford (1909) and
label: Paragraph

text: Harold McCormick (1907) Houses and the Aline Barnsdall “Hollyhock” House (1917-—
label: Caption

text: 20), built around the brow of Olive Hill in Los Angeles, which called for far larger
label: Paragraph

text: compositions than what could be organized within the pyramidal massing of the
label: Paragraph

text: prototypical prairie house.
label: Paragraph

text: During this same period, from 1909 to 1920, Wright designed a series of public
label: Paragraph

text: buildings that focused on interior garden courtyards. In contrast to his courtyard houses,
label: Paragraph

text: which were inevitably asymmetrical and informal in plan, these public courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were rigorously symmetrical, illustrating Wright’s use of symmetry to
label: Paragraph

text: distinguish between the public and the private realms. The Midway Gardens (1913), an
label: Paragraph

text: indoor and outdoor garden for music and dining, is perhaps Wright’s most completely
label: Paragraph

text: resolved total work of art, for here he designed not only the architecture but also the band
label: Paragraph

text: shell, interiors, furniture, dishes, sculpture, decorations, and landscaping. The Imperial
label: Paragraph

text: Hotel (1914-22), a commission that required Wright to live in Japan during its
label: Paragraph

text: construction, was a composition of monumental grandeur, unlike anything else in
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s opus. This massive building was designed by Wright to float on a field of
label: Paragraph

text: structural piers sunk into the unstable soil, an innovative seismic precaution almost
label: Paragraph

text: immediately tested when the Imperial Hotel survived the devastating 1923 Tokyo
label: Paragraph

text: earthquake.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright engaged new materials with almost every design, yet reinforced concrete
label: Paragraph

text: proved to be the most consistently challenging to him. Despite his early success with
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete in Unity Temple, Wright remained critical of concrete’s lack of
label: Paragraph

text: inherent order and its ability to be formed into any shape at the whim of the designer;
label: Paragraph

text: unlike all other construction materials, concrete did not exhibit a “nature” that would
label: Paragraph

text: determine its appropriate use. In 1906, the same year that construction began on Unity
label: Paragraph

text: Temple, Wright designed what he later called “the first block house,” developing the
label: Paragraph

text: concrete-block system of construction that he would realize 17 years later. The Alice
label: Paragraph

text: Millard House (1923), the John Storer House (1923), the Charles Ennis House (1923),
label: Paragraph

text: and the Samuel Freeman House (1923), all built in Los Angeles, were constructed using
label: Paragraph

text: concrete blocks cast in custom-designed forms. In these houses, Wright succeeded in
label: Paragraph

text: finding a means of expression suitable to reinforced concrete, the modular order imparted
label: Paragraph

text: to the concrete blocks giving character to this previously formless material.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1932, during the Great Depression in the United States, Wright was already 65 years
label: Paragraph

text: old, having written his autobiography while building only two houses since 1923. It is
label: Paragraph

text: thus understandable that both the American public and the architectural establishment
label: Paragraph

text: assumed that Wright had retired from active practice. However, Wright was already
label: Paragraph

text: laying the foundations for the most remarkable resurgence in architectural history, and he
label: Paragraph

text: would go on to construct almost twice as many designs in the next 27 years as he had
label: Paragraph

text: built in the preceding 40. Pivotal in this resurgence were the publication of Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: Autobiography, which brought new clients, and Wright’s opening of the Taliesin
label: Paragraph

text: Fellowship, an apprenticeship school and office housed in the new Drafting Room (1932)
label: Caption

text: addition to Hillside School (1902) at Taliesin, which provided both the architectural and
label: Paragraph

text: the farming workforce. The astonishing works that Wright designed in 1934-37
label: Paragraph

text: effectively reestablished his dominance of the American architectural profession. With
label: Paragraph

text: their publication in the January 1938 issue of Architectural Forum and Time magazine,
label: Paragraph

text: Wright was again hailed as the greatest living architect.
label: Paragraph

text: The Edgar Kaufmann House (1937), called Fallingwater, together with his own winter
label: Paragraph

text: home and studio, Taliesin West (1938), exemplified Wright’s belief that architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: born of its place and thus can never be the product of an “International Style,” as
label: Paragraph

text: European modernism was represented in 1932 at the Museum of Modern Art.
label: Paragraph

text: Fallingwater, built above a mountain stream in southwestern Pennsylvania, is Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: greatest “natural” house, a place where man can truly be at home in nature. Taliesin
label: Paragraph

text: West, built in the desert outside Scottsdale, Arizona, celebrated both the ephemerality of
label: Paragraph

text: life, with its canvas roofs that had to be replaced seasonally, and the permanence of place,
label: Paragraph

text: with its boulders cast into the concrete walls, still showing the carvings of the original
label: Paragraph

text: Native American inhabitants of this land-scape.
label: Paragraph

text: The Johnson Wax Building (1939) is Wright’s great “cathedral of work,” with its
label: Paragraph

text: innovative thin-shell concrete columns standing in small brass shoes that delicately touch
label: Paragraph

text: the floor of the central top-lit workroom, clad in streamlined brick and lit by tube glass
label: Caption

text: laid up like bricks in clerestories and skylights. Like his own Drafting Room at Taliesin,
label: Paragraph

text: employees work here in a room that feels as if it is in the forest, among the column trees,
label: Paragraph

text: in the light filtering down through the skylight leaves. Although dedicated to work and
label: Paragraph

text: not worship, the central room of the Johnson Wax Building illustrates the way in which
label: Paragraph

text: Wright celebrated everyday rituals and functions by housing them in sacred spaces. It is
label: Paragraph

text: without question one of the greatest spaces in architectural history.
label: Paragraph

text: Broadacre City (1934) was Wright’s visionary proposal for a pattern of land
label: Paragraph

text: development that sought to establish an ordered pattern of cultivation and inhabitation for
label: Paragraph

text: the enormous scale of the Jeffersonian grid while providing every household a place in
label: Paragraph

text: nature. A complete plan for the future expansion of America’s communities, it had
label: Paragraph

text: public, commercial, and religious structures woven into its underlying fabric of single-
label: Paragraph

text: family houses, giving the suburb an appropriate and precise spatial and social order. The
label: Paragraph

text: Herbert Jacobs House (1937) was the first of Wright’s “Usonian” houses, small and
label: Paragraph

text: affordable homes for the rapidly growing American middle class that were to be placed
label: Paragraph

text: on oneacre sites to form the basic pattern of Broadacre City. In the last 20 years of his
label: Paragraph

text: life, Wright designed hundreds of these Usonian houses for various climates and
label: Paragraph

text: construction types, each one a masterpiece of spatial generosity within remarkably small
label: Paragraph

text: total floor areas. Broadacre City was Wright’s counterproposal to the traditional city, to
label: Paragraph

text: the isolation of agrarian life, and to the sprawling spread of the developer’s speculative
label: Paragraph

text: suburb.
label: Paragraph

text: The last ten years of Wright’s life were incredibly productive, with hundreds of
label: Paragraph

text: designs emerging from Taliesin for virtually every conceivable building type. Among the
label: Paragraph

text: best of this last period was the Solomon Guggenheim Museum (1943-59), built facing
label: Paragraph

text: Central Park in New York City. A glorious expression of the plastic formal possibilities
label: Paragraph

text: of reinforced concrete, the Guggenheim Museum also explored dynamic spatial and
label: Paragraph

text: experiential territory, suspending the art and its spectators in a continuously spiraling
label: Paragraph

text: volume that opens toward the sky. The Beth Sholom Synagogue (1954), with its seating
label: Paragraph

text: within a folded concrete base anchored to the earth and its roof a translucent tent scaled
label: Paragraph

text: to the heavens, is a powerful summary of man’s condition as both permanent dweller and
label: Paragraph

text: perpetual wanderer. Finally, the Marin County Civic Center (1957-66), a series of
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal planes bridging between the low hills, although unfinished at his death, is
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps Wright’s most brilliant site design.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the extraordinary public commissions of his last years, it could be argued that
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s greatest accomplishment remained his designs for hundreds of modest,
label: Paragraph

text: inexpensive, yet spatially rich and experientially powerful Usonian houses. In a
label: Paragraph

text: surprisingly humble definition, Wright had early on stated his belief that architecture was
label: Paragraph

text: the background or framework for the daily life that takes place within it. Wright’s system
label: Paragraph

text: of design was measured, scaled, and calibrated precisely by the human body and its
label: Paragraph

text: experience, and although the geometric rigor of Wright’s planning is well known, the
label: Paragraph

text: esteem in which he held the concepts of use and comfort is not widely understood. The
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual and formal order of Wright’s designs was balanced by the physical and
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual engagement of the inhabitant: For Wright, architecture was understood to be the
label: Paragraph

text: shared discipline of principled place making. It could be argued that Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: achievement was virtually unmatched in the 20th century, which produced a rich
label: Paragraph

text: assortment of new architectural forms but few systematic conceptions that link spatial
label: Paragraph

text: form and order to human occupation and experience.
label: Paragraph

text: Further Reading
label: Title

text: Three comprehensive monographs exist on Wright. The earliest, Hitchcock, although not
label: Paragraph

text: including the work of Wright’s last two decades, is the only monograph written with
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s direct involvement and approval. Levine 1996 and McCarter 1997 vary
label: Paragraph

text: dramatically in approach, with the former placing Wright in the larger context of art-
label: Paragraph

text: historical interpretations, whereas the latter documents the experience of inhabiting the
label: Paragraph

text: spaces of Wright’s built works. Both of these monographs benefit from access to
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s archival material after its organization and selected publication by Bruce
label: Paragraph

text: Brooks Pfeiffer, documented in Futagawa 1984-88 (12 vols.). Wright’s own writings,
label: Paragraph

text: including his An Autobiography, are collected in Wright 1992-95 (5 vols.). A
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive catalog of all Wright’s built work is contained in Storrer. Several essay
label: Paragraph

text: collections offer appropriately varied views of Wright, including Riley 1994, McCarter
label: Paragraph

text: 1991, and Bolon, Nelson, and Seidel 1988. Finally, a number of excellent single-building
label: Paragraph

text: or building-type studies exist, such as Sergeant 1976, which, due to their narrow focus,
label: Paragraph

text: allow a sufficiently extended analysis to capture the richness of Wright’s individual
label: Paragraph

text: designs.

text: WU LIANGYONG 1922
label: Title

text: Architect, China
label: Title

text: Wu Liangyong was born in 1922 in Nanjing. He received his Bachelor of Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: degree from the National Central University in Chongqing in 1944 and completed his
label: Paragraph

text: Master of Architecture and Urban Design degree under Eliel Saarinen at Cranbrook
label: Paragraph

text: Academy in Cranbrook, Michigan, in 1949. On his return to China in 1950, he joined the
label: Paragraph

text: faculty of the Department of Architecture at Tsinghua University, a major school in
label: Paragraph

text: China for technical and engineering studies.
label: Paragraph

text: Wu has been recognized as a leading architectural designer and urban planner in
label: Paragraph

text: China, especially since the 1970s. He played a major role in the replanning and design of
label: Paragraph

text: Tiananmen Square, located in the center of Beijing. Surrounding the square are the
label: Paragraph

text: National Congress Hall and the National Museum of History. In 1976 Wu worked with a
label: Paragraph

text: team of five senior architects to win the competition for the design of the National
label: Paragraph

text: Library of China. In the projects he has designed, he strives to combine traditional spirit
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture with modern construction to create a new form of Chinese contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Wu’s most well-known project in urban and architectural preservation is the New
label: Paragraph

text: Courtyard House Complex (1987) at Juer Hutong, located in northeastern Beijing. Facing
label: Caption

text: the challenges of rapid economic growth, the single-story courtyard houses, which were
label: Paragraph

text: the major housing form for the old city of Beijing, had been in danger of disappearing
label: Paragraph

text: entirely from the city to make room for high-rise apartments. Wu and his design and
label: Paragraph

text: research group selected a typical neighborhood in the eastern district of Beijing as an
label: Paragraph

text: experimental project. It bears the main features of a multicourtyard system of housing
label: Paragraph

text: with multiple—usually three—stories in the structures to accommodate more residents.
label: Paragraph

text: The salvation of this traditional housing form turned out to be a success. The Juer Hutong
label: Paragraph

text: project won the World Habitat Award from the United Nations in 1993 and the Gold
label: Paragraph

text: Medal in Architecture from the Architects’ Regional Council in 1992.
label: Paragraph

text: Wu worked as a designer and planner for several cities in China: Beijing, Handan,
label: Paragraph

text: Beidaihe, Baoding, and Tangshan in the north; Beihai, Guilin, and Liuzhou in the south;
label: Paragraph

text: Jiuquan in the west; and Suzhou and Wuxi in the east. Zhangjiagang is a newly planned
label: Paragraph

text: city, and Wu worked there in 1993. He focused on Beijing for research in city design and
label: Paragraph

text: planning; he is on the committee for capital planning as a consultant for the municipal
label: Paragraph

text: government, helping in the strategic planning of the city. He vation for the city. also
label: Paragraph

text: participates in policy making and research on historic preser
label: Paragraph

text: As an educator in architecture, Wu led the School of Architecture at Tsinghua
label: Paragraph

text: University as the dean from 1977 to 1983. He was invited by the eminent architectural
label: Paragraph

text: scholar Liang Sicheng to participate in the founding of the school in 1946. Wu has since
label: Paragraph

text: then been one of the school’s most influential professors. He has formed two research
label: Paragraph

text: centers at Tsinghua: the Institute of Architecture and Urban Studies and the Center for
label: Title

text: Human Settlements. He serves as the director of both; many design and research projects
label: Paragraph

text: were completed by the centers under his directorship. The Institute of Confucianism in
label: Paragraph

text: Qufu, Confucius’s hometown, is one of the most recent projects that they have
label: Paragraph

text: completed.
label: Paragraph

text: Wu’s teaching covers studio instruction and lectures on theory and history of cities.
label: Paragraph

text: His 4 Brief History of Ancient Chinese City Planning (1986) is the first English-language
label: Paragraph

text: book on the topic ever published by a scholar of mainland China. Wu used this book as a
label: Paragraph

text: main reference when he taught at Gesamthochschule in Kassel, Germany. His teaching
label: Paragraph

text: extended to the seminar courses in Beijing for mayors. Wu was awarded the Jean
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi Prize by the UIA (Union Internationate des Architect) in 1996 for his renowned
label: Paragraph

text: contributions in architectural education.
label: Paragraph

text: A Theory of integral Architecture (2001) advanced Wu’s ideas in China for dealing
label: Paragraph

text: with design issues in a global perspective. His book A General Theory of Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (1990, Beijing; 1992, Taipei) discusses human settlements, world urbanism, China’s
label: Paragraph

text: responses to the challenges of environmental changes, and architectural regionalism,
label: Paragraph

text: among many other topics. Wu proposes that architectural studies in China should employ
label: Paragraph

text: “holistic thinking” and “cross-disciplinary research.” In that sense architectural and urban
label: Paragraph

text: studies in China should be combined closely in a system but should remain general:
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and its humanistic presence of time and space, architecture and its
label: Paragraph

text: geographical presence of time and space, architecture as the presence of culture and
label: Paragraph

text: tradition, technical essence in architecture, and finally, architecture as a cultural
label: Paragraph

text: expression for its aesthetic forms. Wu uses diagrammatic charts to illustrate his theory,
label: Paragraph

text: and he concludes that the general theory is a new subject that he calls a “science o
label: Paragraph

text: human settlement.” He further distinguishes his theory as a “new regionalism.”
label: Paragraph

text: China opened the door to the world after the Cultural Revolution that took place
label: Paragraph

text: between 1966 and 1976, and it resumed its international connections to the architectural!
label: Paragraph

text: world in the mid-1970s. Wu has performed a major role in representing China’s
label: Paragraph

text: architectural professionals in world organizations and conferences. In addition to his busy
label: Paragraph

text: schedule as visiting professor and research fellow in the United States and Europe, he
label: Paragraph

text: served as a vice president of UIA (1987-90) and the president of the World Society o
label: Paragraph

text: Ekistics. He is an honorary fellow of the American Institute of Architects and an
label: Paragraph

text: honorary fellow of the Royal Institute of British Architects, among other professional
label: Paragraph

text: memberships. Most recently, in the summer of 1999, he co-chaired the Beijing
label: Paragraph

text: conference of UIA and drafted the UIA Beijing Charter.
label: Paragraph
