text: WURSTER, WILLIAM 1895-1973
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: William Wurster was a chief exponent of the “Bay Region School” of architecture in
label: Paragraph

text: the United States. His development as an architect coincided with the years of the Great
label: Paragraph

text: Depression (1929-35) and his maturation with the years 1935-42, preceding World War
label: Paragraph

text: Il. Wurster’s architecture, like that of his contemporaries Pietro Belluschi, Harwell
label: Paragraph

text: Hamilton Harris, and O’Neil Ford, exemplified a form of rooted and indigenous
label: Paragraph

text: modernism that flourished in the United States before the internationalist orientation of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1950s. Wurster and his contemporaries believed that architecture, whether designed
label: Paragraph

text: for the Northwest, the Pacific coast, or the Southwest, should visibly express the identity
label: Paragraph

text: of a region.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1913 and 1918, Wurster visited works by well-known Bay Region architects,
label: Paragraph

text: among them Bernard Maybeck,
label: Paragraph

text: Saxon Pope House, Orinda, California (1940)
label: Caption

text: Ezra Stoller © Esto
label: Title

text: Emest Coxhead, and Willis Polk. Wurster especially appreciated Maybeck’s Christian
label: Paragraph

text: Science Church, which synthesized BeauxArts ornamental exuberance with experimental
label: Paragraph

text: building techniques and the Arts and Crafts ideals of simplicity, authenticity, and
label: Paragraph

text: naturalism. Wurster traveled to Paris in 1922 and from there departed on sketching tours
label: Paragraph

text: throughout Europe during 1922-23. Italy and Spain were key destinations: Their
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular traditions and rural landscapes held significance for California. After his
label: Paragraph

text: return William Adams Delano assisted Wurster with the financing of his own office in
label: Paragraph

text: Berkeley in 1924 and with introductions to some of Wurster’s most important early
label: Paragraph

text: clients.
label: Paragraph

text: Wurster launched his career with the Gregory Farmhouse (1927-28) near Santa Cruz.
label: Paragraph

text: Designed for Mrs. Warren (Sadie) Gregory, whom Wurster met through a friend of
label: Paragraph

text: Delano’s, the Farmhouse was widely published and functioned as a clear visual statement
label: Paragraph

text: of Wurster’s architectural principles. First, both Wurster and his client envisioned an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural character of crafted simplicity and calculated understatement. Wurster, who
label: Paragraph

text: was committed to the “cleanliness” of wood carpentry and inspired by the vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: structures in California’s gold-mining towns and early Monterey, conceived and detailed
label: Paragraph

text: a composition that was both ranchlike and modern yet conscientiously devoid of any
label: Paragraph

text: particular style. Finally, Wurster devised numerous strategies for integrating the house
label: Paragraph

text: with its country setting. Each individual room, for instance, opened onto a corredor, or
label: Paragraph

text: terrace, some of which served as “outdoor rooms,” and the house’s L-shaped plan framed
label: Paragraph

text: a central courtyard, recalling at once European manor houses, Italian villas, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish-influenced adobe houses of old Monterey.
label: Paragraph

text: During the years following the Gregory commission, Wurster continued to refine his
label: Paragraph

text: modern regionalist approach. In the early 1930s he designed 13 houses for Pasatiempo, a
label: Paragraph

text: country club and residential community near Monterey Bay, among them the
label: Paragraph

text: MacKenzie-Field House (1931). Wurster’s Pasatiempo houses, which he viewed as
label: Paragraph

text: antidotes to an overmechanized urban life, showed that he continued to develop his
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular-inspired architectural vocabulary, simple yet refined techniques of wood
label: Paragraph

text: construction, integration of indoor and outdoor spaces, and sensitivity to the natural
label: Paragraph

text: surroundings. The Voss House (1931) in the countryside of Big Sur, with a profile
label: Paragraph

text: embedded in the landscape, kitchen “cave,” and direct confrontation of the ocean vista,
label: Paragraph

text: epitomized Wurster’s search for a modern architecture that embodied the California
label: Paragraph

text: yearning for the simple yet “good” life in the open.
label: Paragraph

text: By the mid-1930s Wurster’s practice was well established. As his regionalist
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility matured, his houses also became more consistently modernist and abstract.
label: Paragraph

text: Wurster’s Clark House (1937) in Aptos, which had cubic volumes and flush planar
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces, and his Saxton Pope House (1940) in Orinda, with powerful geometries and
label: Paragraph

text: construction in concrete block and corrugated steel, exemplified his new, starker
label: Paragraph

text: approach. These houses suggested a greater affinity with the European avant-garde, at the
label: Paragraph

text: time promoted by the Museum of Modern Art as the “International Style.” Wurster,
label: Paragraph

text: however, argued that “modern” was a point of view and not a style. In 1937 Wurster
label: Paragraph

text: made his second European journey, with the objective of seeing the modern architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of Scandinavia and, in particular, the work of Alvar Aalto. Wurster valued Aalto’s
label: Paragraph

text: “humanist” approach; that is, his integration of architecture with the natural surroundings
label: Paragraph

text: and his attention to vernacular resources and to the sensuality of craftsmanship in wood.
label: Paragraph

text: After Wurster discovered Aalto’s own house on the outskirts of Helsinki, the two
label: Paragraph

text: architects visited Aalto’s Savoy Restaurant, Sunila Pulp Mill, and Paimio Sanatorium;
label: Paragraph

text: they discussed their shared philosophical viewpoints and established a friendship that
label: Paragraph

text: lasted throughout their lives.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1930s, Wurster became increasingly involved with the problem of low-cost
label: Paragraph

text: housing. His designs for individual minimum dwellings, such as his “Unit Steel
label: Paragraph

text: House” (1937) for the Soule Steel Company, along with housing communities such as
label: Paragraph

text: Valencia Gardens (1939) in San Francisco, a 246-unit project, demonstrated his
label: Paragraph

text: command of a range of housing scales. In 1939 Wurster met Catherine Bauer, whose
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Housing (1934) had become the seminal work on the subject. They married in
label: Paragraph

text: 1940, and Bauer’s emphasis on the virtues of large-scale projects and rationalized
label: Paragraph

text: construction techniques, along with her study of garden communities such as Radburn,
label: Paragraph

text: influenced Wurster’s approach to designing communities for war workers in the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1940s. Among these were his Carquinez Heights (1941) in Vallejo. In this project and
label: Paragraph

text: others, such as Chabot Terrace (1942) in Vallejo and Parker Homes (1943) in
label: Paragraph

text: Sacramento, Wurster aspired to integrate current thinking on standardized housing with
label: Paragraph

text: his own long-standing commitment to the client and to the environmental specifics of
label: Paragraph

text: landscape, climate, and views.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: YAAMA MOSQUE, TAHOUA, NIGER
label: Caption

text: Designed by Falké Barmou, completed 1982
label: Caption

text: The Yaama Mosque is a mud-brick building, but it is one that is strikingly different
label: Paragraph

text: from the Dyula-type mosques found in Mali. This is an example of a building built in a
label: Paragraph

text: local style but whose growth over time shows a desire for monumentality in size, form,
label: Paragraph

text: and the complexity of its decoration. It also emphasizes that there can be monuments
label: Paragraph

text: within a vernacular style of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: A mud-brick and tamped-earth building, the mosque was designed by mason and
label: Paragraph

text: farmer Falké Barmou in a semidesert region of Niger. Twenty years in the making, this
label: Paragraph

text: Friday mosque was completed in 1982. The client and the construction team was the
label: Paragraph

text: community of Yaama.
label: Paragraph

text: The mosque is squarish in plan. The initial building was a hypostyle hall, a field of
label: Paragraph

text: closely spaced heavy columns whose visual weight lends the building’s interior a somber
label: Paragraph

text: air. The building was initially roofed with a simple post-and-lintel system. In 1975
label: Paragraph

text: Barmou took advantage of the need to fix a leaking roof to replace the ceiling with a
label: Paragraph

text: livelier vaulted system. Barmou had traveled to Dakar and to Mecca and thus was
label: Paragraph

text: exposed to, and incorporated into his work, many building techniques.
label: Paragraph

text: Frequently referred to simply as “Hausa,” Labelle Prussin feels that a more accurate
label: Paragraph

text: term is “Fulani-Hausa.” Her term acknowledges the dual influences of the nomadic
label: Paragraph

text: Fulani, a Fulbe-speaking people who migrated into the region, which today lies in
label: Paragraph

text: northern Nigeria and Niger. The Hausa were the sedentary people native to the area.
label: Paragraph

text: Barmou used one of the most significant features of Hausa architecture: arches, vaults,
label: Paragraph

text: and domes made of bundled and bent reeds covered with a mud-and-straw mortar. On top
label: Caption

text: of these groin vaults, sticks are laid in a basket-weave pattern. When he replaced the roof,
label: Paragraph

text: Barmou also removed a central column that created a central space over which he added
label: Paragraph

text: a dome. This imposition of a central dome into the hypostyle hall shows the
label: Paragraph

text: interconnectedness of mosque architecture with multidomed Byzantine Christian
label: Paragraph

text: churches, such as St. Mark’s in Venice.
label: Paragraph

text: This vaulted-and-domed construction system demonstrates the continuity into a
label: Paragraph

text: permanent kind of architecture of tech niques derived from less-exalted kinds of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, such as tents and straw huts. With temporary structures a material (fabric,
label: Paragraph

text: hides, or straw) is laid over a framework. Prussin writes, “The Fulani-Hausa dome can be
label: Paragraph

text: construed as a visual synthesis of several contradictory aspirations into a unified image:
label: Paragraph

text: mobility, identity with Islam, and sedentarization” (Prussin, 1986).
label: Paragraph

text: The largest element in the project is the hypostyle prayer hall. As is customary with
label: Paragraph

text: mosques, a mihrab, or prayer niche, occupies the middle of the gibla wall (gibla denotes
label: Paragraph

text: the direction toward Mecca). As there is a central row of columns, in the Yaama Mosque
label: Paragraph

text: the mihrab is slightly off center so that it lies at the end of a visual axis. A low perimeter
label: Paragraph

text: wall creates an enclosed compound that can be used as an overflow area for prayers.
label: Paragraph

text: Some mosques (e.g. Djenné and Niono) are rectangular in plan, and the entry is in the
label: Paragraph

text: center of one of the long sides. This allows rows of worshipers to extend laterally as far
label: Paragraph

text: as possible. Other mosques are square in plan, something that Prussin argues relates to
label: Paragraph

text: the Islamic magic square. The magic square is an arrangement of numbers in a graphic
label: Paragraph

text: pattern found in a variety of Islamic arts. A typical example is a three-by-three nine-
label: Paragraph

text: house square. Both the overall plan of Yaama and the square-based dome are similar in
label: Paragraph

text: form to the Islamic magic square.
label: Paragraph

text: The roof is made of bundles of sticks that are visible on the interior although skim
label: Paragraph

text: coated with mud on the exterior. This kind of architecture, built of local materials and
label: Paragraph

text: using local craftsmen, was sustainable before the term sustainability achieved its current
label: Paragraph

text: popularity. This building was literally built by the community.
label: Paragraph

text: There are four corner towers, all different in form. The towers are divided into vertical
label: Paragraph

text: zones with setbacks. An initial simplicity has been augmented over time by an increasing
label: Paragraph

text: desire to add detail and monumentality, particularly considering the towers. Over time,
label: Paragraph

text: there has been an increasing concern for aesthetics and decoration.
label: Paragraph

text: None of the four towers, however, functions as a minaret. A minaret, the tower from
label: Paragraph

text: which worshipers are called to prayer, is not an essential part of a mosque. Minarets are
label: Paragraph

text: frequently significant vertical elements in the design of Ottoman and Middle Eastern
label: Paragraph

text: mosques.
label: Paragraph

text: The selection of the Yaama Mosque for an Aga Khan Award in 1986 provoked a
label: Paragraph

text: controversy within the Islamic architectural community. One of six winners, it was
label: Paragraph

text: controversial, but not because of any perceived failings of this particular mosque. By
label: Paragraph

text: excluding projects such as airports and skyscrapers, dissenting members of the judging
label: Paragraph

text: panel felt that the overall message sent by the Aga Khan Awards was overtly nostalgic
label: Paragraph

text: and traditional. Islamic architecture did not, they argued, have to be antiWestern,
label: Paragraph

text: antimodern, and antitechnology.
label: Paragraph

text: The Yaama Mosque reconciles local tradition and a modern Islam with a grace and
label: Paragraph

text: ease that were lacking in the Aga Khan Award debacle. At once restrained and massive,
label: Paragraph

text: delicate and decorative, this project shows the creative energy that still exists within
label: Paragraph

text: traditional African building techniques.
label: Paragraph

text: YAMASAKI, MINORU 1912-86
label: Title

text: Architect, United States
label: Title

text: Driven by the sincere belief that architecture should make daily life more beautiful and
label: Paragraph

text: emotionally fulfilling, JapaneseAmerican architect Minoru Yamasaki developed a highly
label: Paragraph

text: omamental architecture that drew on his world travels for inspiration. Although other
label: Paragraph

text: architects (notably Edward Durell Stone and Philip Johnson) also explored the
label: Paragraph

text: combination of modernist forms and materials with historicist motifs and elements,
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki’s ornamental eclecticism (drawing from a variety of sources, from mosques to
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic cathedrals) set him apart from his contemporaries. Although the sheer size of
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki’s best-known work, the World Trade Center Towers (1976) in New York
label: Paragraph

text: overwhelmed its neo-Gothic ornament, the majority of his architecture reflected an
label: Paragraph

text: interest in human scale and lightness of materials.
label: Paragraph

text: This approach pervades the McGregor Memorial Conference Center (1958) at Wayne
label: Paragraph

text: State University in Detroit, which Yamasaki adorned with triangular arches and inverted
label: Paragraph

text: pyramidal canopies over a glass atrium, all surrounded by a series of fountains and
label: Paragraph

text: platforms. Although derived from his genuine desire to harmonize architecture with
label: Paragraph

text: humanity, this preoccupation with ornament and surface effects has led many critics to
label: Paragraph

text: deride his work as self-indulgent, formalist, and overly decorative. Regardless of these
label: Paragraph

text: criticisms, Yamasaki enjoyed considerable suc cess with a public weary of the anonymity
label: Paragraph

text: of glass-and-steel modernism constructed in the second half of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: The 33 orange brick blocks of Yamasaki’s Pruitt lgoe Houses (1952-55) in St. Louis
label: Caption

text: seem an unlikely beginning for an architect committed to an architecture of serenity and
label: Paragraph

text: delight (Yamasaki even excluded the project from his autobiography). The award-
label: Paragraph

text: winning design for low-income public housing was praised for its modernist features
label: Paragraph

text: (including window-lined galleries intended to serve as outdoor socializing areas,
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of Le Corbusier) and cost-efficient design. However, in reality, the housing
label: Paragraph

text: project was a spectacular failure, plagued by crime, low occupancy, vandalism, and ill-
label: Paragraph

text: functioning services. The buildings’ demolition in 1972 received worldwide coverage
label: Paragraph

text: and was seen as representing the ultimate failure of the social engineering and
label: Paragraph

text: functionalist rhetoric of modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Even with the initially positive reception of the Pruitt Igoe housing project, Yamasaki
label: Paragraph

text: would depart radically from such doctrinaire modernism for the rest of his career.
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporary to the design of Pruitt Igoe, Yamasaki, Hellmuth, and Leinweber received
label: Paragraph

text: the commission for a new airport for the city of St. Louis. Intended to serve the demands
label: Paragraph

text: of air travel while functioning as a monumental entrance to the city, the soaring concrete
label: Paragraph

text: groin vaults of Lambert Airport (1956) recalled the grandeur of American railroad depots
label: Paragraph

text: in the early 20th century, such as New York’s Grand Central Station. The sweeping and
label: Paragraph

text: elegant concrete vaults of the Terminal Building established Yamasaki’s international
label: Paragraph

text: reputation and introduced a new idiom for airport design (further refined and developed
label: Paragraph

text: in the works of Eero Saarinen).
label: Paragraph

text: Following the success of Lambert Airport, Yamasaki increasingly incorporated overt
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic-, Islamic-, and Japanese-inspired ornament into his architecture. The elaborately
label: Paragraph

text: patterned aluminum screen walls at the Reynolds Metals Regional Sales Office (1959) in
label: Caption

text: Southfield, Michigan, demonstrate his interest in exotic patterns, whereas the concrete
label: Paragraph

text: ogee arches and canopies of the Dhahran Air Terminal (1961) in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia,
label: Caption

text: attempted to harmonize with the surroundings. Among his most elaborate works was the
label: Paragraph

text: enormously popular Federal Science Pavilion (1962) at the Seattle World’s Fair, which
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of a series of lacy canopies with parabolic arches, rendered in a kind of space-
label: Paragraph

text: age neo-Gothic style.
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki’s particular blend of ornament and modernist structure ensured him a
label: Paragraph

text: prominent place in the architecture of the United States and throughout the world. His
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was chosen to represent the United States with the U.S. Pavilion (1959) at
label: Paragraph

text: the World Agricultural Fair in New Delhi. Additionally, Yamasaki was invited to design
label: Paragraph

text: the Founders Hall (1983) in Shinji Shumeikai, Shiga prefecture, Japan. Overall,
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki was one of a few architects who dared to question the modernist mantra “Less
label: Paragraph

text: is more.” Through his inventive combination of historicist motifs and elements,
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki created an architecture that addressed far more than its overt functions, striving
label: Paragraph

text: to make modern architecture enjoyable to a broad spectrum of the public.
label: Paragraph

text: Unfortunately, there is a relative dearth of information concerning the life and
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of Minoru Yamasaki. The primary source for information about Yamasaki is
label: Paragraph

text: his autobiography, 4 Life in Architecture (1979), which offers insight into his practice
label: Paragraph

text: and philosophy of architec-ture. Articles by Veronese, Huxtable, and a host of others
label: Caption

text: position Yamasaki in the context of the late 1950s and early 1960s. Yamasaki enjoyed a
label: Paragraph

text: degree of prominence in the American press, appearing on the cover of Time magazine in
label: Paragraph

text: 1963; the accompanying article, “The Road to Xanadu,” balances a sympathetic appraisal
label: Paragraph

text: of his architecture with more critical statements by his fellow architects. Other than some
label: Paragraph

text: ongoing commentary surrounding the World Trade Center Towers, Yamasaki is
label: Paragraph

text: infrequently discussed by critics and historians.

text: YUGOSLAVIA
label: Title

text: Although Yugoslavia existed as an official state through much of the 20th century, its
label: Paragraph

text: architecture has been commonly presented through separate, regional surveys rather than
label: Paragraph

text: general overviews. On the basis of the major political events of the century, three phases
label: Paragraph

text: can be considered distinctive in terms of architectural analysis: the period before the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of Yugoslavia in 1918, the interwar period of the kingdom of Yugoslavia, and
label: Paragraph

text: the period after World War Il, when the country was officially the Socialist Federal
label: Paragraph

text: Republic of Yugoslavia.
label: Paragraph

text: Constituted on territory shared through the centuries by two quite different empires, the
label: Paragraph

text: Habsburg and the Ottoman, Yugoslavia had unequal potential for the development of
label: Paragraph

text: modernity in its eastern and western regions. However, the modern age was brought to
label: Paragraph

text: the whole country from the same source: the Central European metropolis. Being in
label: Paragraph

text: Austro-Hungarian territory at the turn of the century, buildings in Slovenia, Croatia, and
label: Paragraph

text: Bosnia-Herzegovina were designed either by foreign builders or by domestic architects
label: Paragraph

text: educated at leading schools of the empire. On the other hand, Serbia and Montenegro,
label: Paragraph

text: emancipated from the Ottoman government in the mid-19th century, passed through an
label: Paragraph

text: intense transformation, catching up with the trends of contemporary Europe. The first
label: Paragraph

text: Serbian architects to bring modern architectural features to the kingdom of Serbia
label: Title

text: (independent from 1878) were educated in Vienna, similar to their fellows from the
label: Paragraph

text: western regions.
label: Paragraph

text: The turning point in Slovenian architecture was the earthquake of 1895, after which the
label: Paragraph

text: cultural capital of Slovenia, Ljubljana, was rebuilt following the plans of Camillo Sitte
label: Paragraph

text: and Max Fabiani. Besides shaping the modern urban structure of Ljubljana, Max Fabiani
label: Paragraph

text: (1865-1962) brought the Viennese Secession to Slovenia, designing many public and
label: Paragraph

text: residential buildings, such as Hribar House (1905), Bamberg Palace (1906-07), and the
label: Paragraph

text: girls’ school Mladika (1906-07).
label: Paragraph

text: The first decades of 20th-century architecture in Croatia are associated with the name
label: Paragraph

text: of Viktor Kovacic (1874-1924), a student of Otto Wagner, who initiated an enthusiastic
label: Paragraph

text: struggle against “dogmatic historicism.” Joining a group of young artists and writers, the
label: Paragraph

text: founders of the Zagreb magazine Zivot (Life), Kovacic published a manifesto titled
label: Paragraph

text: “Modern Architecture” in its first issue of 1900. Whereas his projects such as Frank
label: Paragraph

text: House (1910) and the Church of St. Blaz (1913) vary the recognizable idiom of the
label: Paragraph

text: Wagnerschule, other chief examples of the Croatian Secession, such as Ignjat Fischer’s
label: Paragraph

text: Sanatorium (1908) and Rudolf Lubinsky’s University Library (1913), both in Zagreb,
label: Paragraph

text: pres ent a closer interpretation of the Viennese “geometric” forerunner.
label: Paragraph

text: After the Austrian occupation of Bosnia-Herzegovina of 1878, the favored style for
label: Paragraph

text: new public buildings, chosen to present the distinctiveness of the mixed population, was
label: Paragraph

text: the pseudo-Moorish. Richly decorated edifices in Sarajevo, such as Wittek and
label: Paragraph

text: Ivekovic’s City Hall (1892-96, almost destroyed in the civil war, 1992-95) or the
label: Paragraph

text: Evangelistic Church (1899), designed by the leading architect of the time, Karlo Parzik
label: Paragraph

text: (1857-1942), exemplify the popular within-the-empire trend of compiling “exotic,”
label: Paragraph

text: pseudo-Moorish and neo-Byzantine elements with the forms of Western Medieval
label: Paragraph

text: Revival. With exceptions such as Jan Kotera’s Slavija Bank (1910-11) in Sarajevo,
label: Paragraph

text: whose pure geometric forms anticipated his “revolutionary” Urbanek’s Mozarteum
label: Paragraph

text: Building in Prague, characteristic Secessionist buildings in Bosnia-Herzegovina were a
label: Paragraph

text: mixture of eclectic features and new decorative motifs, as on the Post Office in Sarajevo
label: Paragraph

text: (1907-13, severely damaged in the civil war, 1992-95), designed by Josip Vancas
label: Caption

text: Before the establishment of an architectural program at Belgrade Technical Faculty in
label: Paragraph

text: 1897, the first generation of Serbian architects earned their degrees from universities in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna, Munich, Berlin, Karlsruhe, and Zurich, bringing back both the academic
label: Paragraph

text: traditions as well as the new, turn-of-the-century tendencies. The Secession appeared in
label: Paragraph

text: Serbia in two different manners, one of which came as a synthesis of the eclectic method
label: Paragraph

text: and modern architectural elements (e.g., large continuous glass screens, characteristic
label: Paragraph

text: railings, and floral decoration) that can be seen on Svetozar Jovanovic’s Officers Union
label: Paragraph

text: (1908) in Belgrade. The other Secessionist manner, represented in the work of Branko
label: Paragraph

text: Tanazevic (1876-1945), such as the Telephone Exchange (1907-08) and the Ministry of
label: Paragraph

text: Education (1912-13), both in Belgrade, was closely related to the turn-of-the-century
label: Paragraph

text: National Romanticism of the Central European countries that introduced modem, stylized
label: Paragraph

text: folk motifs as the new forms of expression. This mode of Serbian Secession was a further
label: Paragraph

text: step in the creation of a “true” national idiom, already announced in the academic neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantine designs of the earlier generation of Theophil von Hansen’s pupils.
label: Paragraph

text: After the formation of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes in 1918 (in 1929
label: Paragraph

text: renamed the Kingdom of Yugoslavia), building was intensive in the strongest economic
label: Paragraph

text: centers, Ljubljana and Zagreb, and especially brisk in Belgrade, the capital of the entire
label: Paragraph

text: country. The significant event was the foundation of architectural schools at the
label: Paragraph

text: Technical Faculty of Ljubljana, led by Joze Plecnik (1872-1957) and Ivan Vurnik (1884—
label: Paragraph

text: 1971); at the Technical Faculty of Zagreb, guided by Viktor Kovacic and Edo Schén
label: Paragraph

text: (1877-1949); and at the Academy of Fine Arts, also in Zagreb, conceived by the radically
label: Paragraph

text: modern Drago Ibler (1894-1964). At the same time, the architectural faculty at the
label: Paragraph

text: Technical University of Belgrade was strengthened by a generation of professors who
label: Paragraph

text: faithfully continued academic traditions. The architectural character of the three national
label: Paragraph

text: capitals of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes (Belgrade, Zagreb, and Ljubljana)
label: Caption

text: reflected their different cultural climates and political aspirations. Whereas Belgrade’s
label: Paragraph

text: desire to grow into the capital of a major nation was promoted by the forms of “late
label: Paragraph

text: academicism” and the architectural face of Ljubljana was changed with enthusiasm to
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrate Slo-vene national character, Zagreb became the only strong center of the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural avant-garde of that time.
label: Paragraph

text: Different methods of dealing with historical vocabulary dominated the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: production of Yugoslavia during the interwar period. In addition to Belgrade, where
label: Paragraph

text: academic historicism determined the architectural scene during the 1920s and resulted in
label: Paragraph

text: noteworthy projects, such as those by Nikola Nestorovic (1868-1957), including the
label: Paragraph

text: University Library (1919-26, with Dragutin Djordjevic) and the Technical Faculty
label: Paragraph

text: (1925-31, with Branko Tanazevic), the eclectic method was also employed by architects
label: Paragraph

text: from the other regions. The Mortgage Bank (1923) in Zagreb, designed by one of the
label: Paragraph

text: most remarkable Croatian modernists, Hugo Ehrlich (1879-1936), who became well
label: Paragraph

text: known as Adolf Loos’s collaborator on the Villa Karma, on Lake Geneva, confirms that
label: Paragraph

text: the strict line between the eclecticist and the modernist cannot be drawn. For the
label: Paragraph

text: academic tradition, the writings of Belgrade architect Milutin Borisavljevic (Miloutine
label: Paragraph

text: Borissavliévitch, 1889-1970) were the only theoretical statements from interwar
label: Paragraph

text: Yugoslavia to receive a world reputation.
label: Paragraph

text: The Wagnerschule associates, Joze Plecnik and Viktor Kovacic, originated
label: Paragraph

text: recognizable modes of modern expression without denying historical references.
label: Paragraph

text: Plecnik’s achievements in Ljubljana, Zale Cemetery (1939-40) and the National
label: Paragraph

text: University Library (1936-40), as well as Kovacic’s works in Zagreb, among them his
label: Paragraph

text: masterpiece, the Stock Exchange (1922-27), can be considered distinguished examples of
label: Paragraph

text: European modernism in general.
label: Paragraph

text: A specific modern idiom of treating the past through the transformation of folk
label: Paragraph

text: motifs—a National Romantic variant of the Art Deco—arose in Yugoslav regions, as
label: Paragraph

text: among the majority of “small” European nations, from an attempt to create a unique
label: Paragraph

text: national style. A colorful facade of the Trade Union Bank (1922) in Ljubljana, decorated
label: Caption

text: with painted motifs reminiscent of peasant fabrics, informs Ivan Vurnik’s vivid approach
label: Paragraph

text: of generating a Slovene national style. In Serbia, an established agenda of shaping a
label: Paragraph

text: national style found its passionate devotee in Momir Korunovic (1883-1969). His most
label: Paragraph

text: famous buildings, Post Office No. 2 (1927-28) and the Postal Ministry (1927-30),
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrate his method of mixing motifs from folk art with elements from Serbian
label: Paragraph

text: medieval architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Zagreb was the only Yugoslav center to accept the avant-garde ideas of European
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism. Most of the leading Croatian architects of the time were either educated in
label: Paragraph

text: the avant-garde European schools or worked with some of the most famous European
label: Paragraph

text: architects: Loos, Behrens, Poelzig, and Le Corbusier. Peter Behrens’s involvement with
label: Paragraph

text: the reconstruction of the Elsafluid Building in 1927 had a special impact on Zagreb’s
label: Paragraph

text: architectural scene. Two architectural groups, Zemlja and Radna Grupa Zagreb (RGZ),
label: Paragraph

text: became leading generators of the new climate, working both on new, radical designs and
label: Paragraph

text: on architectural publications and exhibitions. The members of RGZ took an active role in
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM (Congrés Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne) of 1933 in Athens, opposing,
label: Paragraph

text: with their own proposals, the charter advanced by Le Corbusier.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the rare examples of Belgrade functionalism is the Union Bank (1929-30), the
label: Paragraph

text: masterpiece of Croatian architect Hugo Ehrlich. In contrast to the “monumental
label: Paragraph

text: modernism” of the 1930s, which was gladly received by Serbian architects, functionalism
label: Paragraph

text: found only a few followers: Djordje Tabakovic (1897-1971) in Novi Sad; Nikola
label: Paragraph

text: Dobrovic (1897-1967), who built mainly outside Serbia; and Milan Zlokovic (1898—
label: Paragraph

text: 1965), whose University Children’s Clinic (1933-40) in Belgrade is the main avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: accomplishment. Works of Dragisa Brasovan (1887-1965), among them the Government
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1930-39) of the Danube Region in Novi Sad and the Air Force Headquarters
label: Caption

text: (1935, damaged in the NATO bombing of 1999) in Zemun, offer key examples of the
label: Paragraph

text: monumental Modern idiom, created through a refined juxtaposition of Expressionism and
label: Paragraph

text: “purified” Neoclassicism. The Albania Palace (1938—40) in Belgrade, designed by a team
label: Caption

text: of architects from Zagreb and Belgrade, and especially the Yugoslavian Pavilion at the
label: Paragraph

text: Paris International Exhibition of 1937, by Croatian architect Josip Seissel (1904-87), are
label: Paragraph

text: outstanding examples of this “monumental manner.
label: Paragraph

text: After World War H, the political system in Yugoslavia was radically changed. First
label: Paragraph

text: associated with the politics of the Eastern bloc, “Tito’s socialism” shifted its course,
label: Paragraph

text: breaking with Stalinist politics. Because of the immense loans taken from the West from
label: Paragraph

text: the 1950s until the late 1970s, the potential for a high standard of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: productions was better than in other Eastern European countries. Being socialistic in
label: Paragraph

text: content and capitalistic in form, Yugoslavian architecture of the post-World War II
label: Paragraph

text: period dealt with a series of “socialistic” programs, such as collective housing,
label: Paragraph

text: community centers, houses of culture, and partisan memorials (best represented through
label: Paragraph

text: the work of Bogdan Bogdanovic), trying to keep abreast with current architectural trends
label: Paragraph

text: in Western Europe. The urban planning associated with the controlled economy found its
label: Paragraph

text: best expression in radical plans for new city districts, among which the one for New
label: Paragraph

text: Belgrade was the most ambitious.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the rare examples of designs from the late 1940s, when Soviet models were still
label: Paragraph

text: recommended, is the Federal Executive Government Building (1947-61) in Belgrade,
label: Paragraph

text: begun according to a project by a group of architects from Zagreb, although its “Eastern”
label: Paragraph

text: monumental features modified into the International Style during the construction as a
label: Paragraph

text: result of the political shift. During the 1950s and early 1960s, the International Style
label: Paragraph

text: dominated architectural production. Le Corbusier’s vocabulary occurred in works of his
label: Paragraph

text: assistants, Juraj Neidhardt from Sarajevo and the Slovene Edvard Ravnikar, but emerged
label: Paragraph

text: more obviously in Milorad Macura’s Military Printing House (1953) in Belgrade and
label: Paragraph

text: Drago Galic’s Apartment Block (1953-56) in Zagreb. The “constructional aesthetic” of
label: Paragraph

text: Pier Luigi Nervi found its reinterpretations in Vladimir Turina’s Dinamo Stadium (1954)
label: Paragraph

text: in Zagreb as well as in Milorad Pantovic’s new Belgrade Fair (1956-57). A new, more
label: Paragraph

text: individualistic and expressive trend of the international architecture appeared at the very
label: Paragraph

text: end of the 1950s with Vjenceslav Richter’s Pavilion for Expo ‘58 in Brussels, Nikola
label: Paragraph

text: Dobrovic’s Secretariat of National Defense (1957-63, severely damaged in the NATO
label: Paragraph

text: bombing of 1999), and Ivan Antic’s Museum of Contemporary Art (1960-65, with
label: Paragraph

text: Ivanka Raspopovic), the latter two in Belgrade. The most striking architectural events in
label: Paragraph

text: Yugoslavia of the time were the last meeting of CLAM, held in Dubrovnik in 1956, and
label: Paragraph

text: Kenzo Tange’s engagement with the reconstruction of the Macedonian capital, Skopje,
label: Paragraph

text: after the earthquake of 1963.
label: Paragraph

text: Yugoslav architects accepted the diversity of the late 1960s and 1970s following the
label: Paragraph

text: manners of Brutalism, late modern Expressionism, structuralism, regionalism, High-
label: Paragraph

text: Tech, and so on. Different Brutalist expressions can be summarized through a couple of
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable examples, such as those in Skopje after the earthquake, including Alfred
label: Paragraph

text: Roth’s Elementary School (1967), Janko Konstantinov’s Telecommunication Center
label: Paragraph

text: (1971-74), and Marko Music’s University Complex (1974), as well as through others, in
label: Paragraph

text: smaller Yugoslavian cities, including Svetlana Radevic’s Hotel Podgorica (1965-67) in
label: Paragraph

text: the Montenegrin capital of Podgorica, Milan Sosteric’s Bakery (1971) in Makarska,
label: Paragraph

text: Mladen Vodicka’s City Library (1976) in Karlovac, and the Military High School (1975)
label: Caption

text: in Ljubljana, designed by the group Studio 7. Application of the High-Tech vocabulary
label: Paragraph

text: found its best interpretations in Stojan Maksimovic’s Center Sava (1977-79) in Belgrade,
label: Paragraph

text: Milan Mihelic’s Telephone Exchange (1978) in Ljubljana, Boris Magas’s Stadium Poljud
label: Paragraph

text: (1979) in Split, and Stanko Kristl’s City Hospital (1979) in Izola. Designs of Bosnian
label: Caption

text: architect Zlatko Ugljen include the National Theater (1978, with Jahiel Finci) in Zenica,
label: Paragraph

text: Hotel Ruza (1978) in Mostar, and the White Mosque (1980) in Visoko, for which he
label: Paragraph

text: received the Aga Khan Award of 1983 and which represents one the most respected
label: Paragraph

text: works of the time.
label: Paragraph

text: Various Postmodern modes of the late 1970s and 1980s were welcome among
label: Paragraph

text: architects of different generations. The leading designs of the new wave, related to the
label: Paragraph

text: trends introduced by Aldo Rossi, Richard Meier, James Stirling, and the Berlin IBA, are
label: Paragraph

text: associated with the names of Milos Bonca, the group Kras, Penezic and Rogina, Branko
label: Paragraph

text: Siladjin, and Petar Vulovic. As a consequence of the civil war and the breakup of the
label: Paragraph

text: country in the last decade of the 20th century, a possible summary of Yugoslavian
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of the 1990s includes more examples of destruction than of construction.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: With the exception of the post-World War II period, general surveys of the architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of Yugoslavia hardly exist. Architectural monographs dealing with the most influential
label: Paragraph

text: figures from specific former-Yugoslav regions serve as the best point of departure.

text: ZEVI, BRUNO 1918-2000
label: Title

text: Architectural historian, Italy
label: Title

text: Bruno Zevi’s formation as Italy’s foremost architectural historian in the immediate
label: Paragraph

text: postwar period is closely linked with his early political activity. Born into a distinguished
label: Paragraph

text: Jewish family, Zevi studied at the Faculty of Architecture in Rome before the
label: Paragraph

text: introduction of the Fascist racial laws induced him to move to London. Zevi then left
label: Paragraph

text: Europe for the United States, studying at Columbia University in New York and Harvard
label: Paragraph

text: University’s Graduate School of Design, then under the directorship of Walter Gropius,
label: Paragraph

text: earning a bachelor’s degree in 1942.
label: Paragraph

text: A significant amount of Zevi’s time abroad was spent in antiFascist activities, such as
label: Paragraph

text: radio transmissions and the publication in Boston of the Carlo Rosselli—inspired
label: Paragraph

text: Quaderni italiani (Italian Notebooks). The network of contacts he developed on such
label: Paragraph

text: occasions brought him in touch with some influential Italian intellectuals, notably the art
label: Paragraph

text: historians Carlo Ludovico Ragghianti and Lionello Venturi; hence the openness of Zevi’s
label: Paragraph

text: cultural background and some of the peculiarities of his later intellectual engagement.
label: Paragraph

text: After returning to Rome in 1944, Zevi became critically engaged in a cultural battle for
label: Paragraph

text: a renewal of Italian architecture. Towards an Organic Architecture, his first book, was
label: Paragraph

text: published in 1945. The title echoed Le Corbusier’s Vers Une Architecture, but the
label: Paragraph

text: additional adjective, “organic,” hinted at the need to enrich the functionalist theories on
label: Paragraph

text: which the many branches of European architectural research in the 1920s and 1930s had
label: Paragraph

text: been based. The book was essentially a comparison of two worlds: Europe and the United
label: Paragraph

text: States. In both, Zevi argued, recent developments in modern architecture had paved the
label: Paragraph

text: way for a “humanisation” of the new language, a general tendency best illustrated by the
label: Paragraph

text: domestic buildings of Frank Lloyd Wright and the work of Alvar Aalto and other
label: Caption

text: Scandinavian architects. Italy was implicitly invited to follow the same route, and in 1945
label: Paragraph

text: Zevi founded the Association for Organic Architecture (APAO). For a time the
label: Paragraph

text: association’s local branches were a focal point for some of the architects who hoped to
label: Paragraph

text: play a leading role in the country’s reconstruction.
label: Paragraph

text: Three years later his How to Look at Architecture was the result of a more ambitious
label: Paragraph

text: approach that reflected Zevi’s familiarity with Benedetto Croce’s writing on aesthetics
label: Paragraph

text: and his grow ing interest in the Vienna School of art history. Despite the long discussions
label: Paragraph

text: about the peculiarities of architecture compared with other forms of artistic expression,
label: Paragraph

text: the book was mainly a reflection on the purpose and methodology of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: history. Zevi showed how the tools of modern architectural criticism (in particular a
label: Paragraph

text: notion of “space” partly inspired by an analysis of Wright’s buildings) could serve as the
label: Paragraph

text: basis for a new approach to the whole history of Western architecture. In his view, the
label: Paragraph

text: gap that existed between modern architectural design and academic architectural history
label: Paragraph

text: needed to be bridged to forge a link between the study of classical and medieval
label: Paragraph

text: buildings and the daily battle for a better built world.
label: Paragraph

text: In line with this principle, in 1948 Zevi began to teach architectural history at the
label: Paragraph

text: universities in Venice (1948-63) and Rome (1948-51, 1963-79) and became more
label: Paragraph

text: actively involved in the daily debates in the Italian architectural press. His ponderous
label: Paragraph

text: History of Modern Architecture, originally published in 1950 as a completely rewritten
label: Paragraph

text: version of his 1945 book, still stands as his most important work as a historian. It was the
label: Paragraph

text: first comprehensive historical narrative about the origins and the development of the
label: Paragraph

text: Modern movement to be published in Italy and one of the most original and sympathetic
label: Paragraph

text: European studies on the subject to appear in the postwar period. Substantially revised in
label: Paragraph

text: 1975 and 1996, the book was crucial in deciding the fortunes of architectural history as a
label: Paragraph

text: discipline in the Italian academic world, a secondary effect well documented by the
label: Paragraph

text: biographies of scholars such as Leonardo Benevolo and Manfredo Tafuri.
label: Paragraph

text: The core themes of History are still central to most of Zevi’s subsequent studies, such
label: Paragraph

text: as the ones on De Stijl architecture (1953) and Erich Mendelsohn (1970). Other essays
label: Paragraph

text: from the 1950s and 1960s further extended the chronological boundaries of his research,
label: Paragraph

text: focusing on a group of Renaissance architects, including Ferrara’s “planner” Biagio
label: Paragraph

text: Rossetti (1960) and Michelangelo Buonarroti. However, Zevi’s prescriptive, operational
label: Paragraph

text: approach to history increasingly began to show its limitations. His original sensitivity
label: Paragraph

text: toward the visual analysis of buildings became constricted within an oversimplified,
label: Paragraph

text: barely evolving conceptual framework based on a handful of binary opposites: classicism
label: Paragraph

text: versus anticlassicism, symmetry versus asymmetry, spatial (and political) freedom versus
label: Paragraph

text: dictatorship. It is therefore not surprising that Zevi’s most acclaimed and challenging
label: Paragraph

text: book after History was not a historical one but rather an essay about the methodology of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural design: the brilliant The Modern Language of Architecture, published in
label: Paragraph

text: After Zevi’s involvement with the Partito d’Azione (Party of Action) between 1944
label: Paragraph

text: and 1947, he still occasionally became involved in politics and was elected to Parliament
label: Paragraph

text: as a member of the Radical Party in 1987. In the late 1990s, renewed interest in his work
label: Paragraph

text: gave him the opportunity to become editor of a second series of architectural studies
label: Paragraph

text: (Turin: Testo e Immagine, 1996-), following the one he had edited for Dedalo Editions
label: Paragraph

text: (73 titles between 1978 and 1985). He also worked on a few historical overviews, the last
label: Paragraph

text: of which was published in 1998 with the title Counterhistory and History of Architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: ZONNESTRAAL SANATORIUM 1926-31
label: Title

text: Hilversum, Netherlands
label: Title

text: Thought to be a symbol of the solidarity of the Dutch workingclass movement at the
label: Paragraph

text: turn of the century, the Zonnestraal Sana-torium in Hilversum is considered one of the
label: Paragraph

text: most complex and influential buildings of its time. Deemed one of the major works by its
label: Paragraph

text: designer, Johannes (Jan) Duiker (1890-1935), the Sanatorium has long been associated
label: Paragraph

text: with the Modern architectural movement in the Netherlands.
label: Paragraph

text: An independent and innovative architect, Duiker studied at Delft University of
label: Paragraph

text: Technology with Bernhard Bijvoet (1889-1979), with whom he later became partners.
label: Paragraph

text: Together they worked in the office of their former professor, Henri Evers, architect of the
label: Paragraph

text: Rotterdam City Hall. Much of Duiker’s early influence can be attributed to Evers,
label: Paragraph

text: Hendrik Petrus Berlage and the Amsterdam School, and the American architect Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd Wright. Duiker garnered later influence from the developing International Style
label: Paragraph

text: and the Nieuwe Bouwen movement while employing new building materials and
label: Paragraph

text: methods in the integration of architecture and science. It is believed that Duiker was also
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat influenced by the De Stijl movement; however, he was more a proponent of
label: Paragraph

text: the “nonaesthetic” Modern architecture and not the movement’s “decorative facade
label: Paragraph

text: architecture,” feeling that it only concealed inferior floor plans. As a result, he became
label: Paragraph

text: the movement’s principal antagonist, further illustrated by his lack of exposure in their
label: Paragraph

text: periodical, choosing rather to subscribe to the philosophies of the functionalist De 8, later
label: Paragraph

text: known as the De 8 and Opbouw group.
label: Paragraph

text: Choosing functionality over aesthetic appearances, Duiker produced his own
label: Paragraph

text: functionalist idiom, which became stronger and more expressive as his design philosophy
label: Paragraph

text: developed. His quest for an ideal structural form created a dichotomy between simplistic
label: Paragraph

text: and complex avant-garde architecture that was influential enough to have inspired
label: Paragraph

text: Ludwig Mies van der Rohe’s Tuberculosis Sanatorium (1929-33) at Paimio, Finland.
label: Caption

text: Duiker’s unfortunate early death at the age of 45 meant that his design repertoire was not
label: Paragraph

text: as extensive as that of his peers. This and the demolition of much of what he did design
label: Paragraph

text: are perhaps the reasons for his apparent international obscurity. As a result, his remaining
label: Paragraph

text: architecture has suffered from indifference and neglect.
label: Paragraph

text: After winning the competition for elderly housing in Alkmaar (1917), the socially
label: Paragraph

text: conscious Duiker and Bijvoet desired to improve the quality of lower-income health
label: Paragraph

text: facility construction. Through associations with Berlage, Duiker and Bijvoet were
label: Paragraph

text: retained by the Koperen Stelen Fonds (KSF) foundation—a group of diamond workers
label: Paragraph

text: organized in 1905 whose motto was “renewed vitality’—to design a convalescent facility
label: Paragraph

text: for their tuberculosis-infected colleagues. Through fund-raising efforts by the foundation
label: Paragraph

text: and by Delft professor Henri ter Meulen, in 1919 the KSF purchased the Pampahoeve, a
label: Paragraph

text: country estate west of Hilversum. Designs were temporarily postponed, however, after
label: Paragraph

text: the diamond industry collapse in 1920.
label: Paragraph

text: Duiker, collaborating with structural engineer Jan Gerko Wiebenga, utilized the newest
label: Paragraph

text: structural technology, creating a cantilever system that produced a buoyant and
label: Paragraph

text: rhythmically tectonic architecture. Resting on concrete blocks, the skeletal structure of
label: Paragraph

text: the buildings consists of a three-meter (ten-foot) grid with structural columns every nine
label: Paragraph

text: meters. Concrete was generously used in the floor slabs and the prefabricated paneled
label: Paragraph

text: walls that were installed between steel | sections at each floor. Although still in its
label: Paragraph

text: infancy, reinforced concrete and the prefabricated-concrete building systems played a
label: Paragraph

text: monumental role in the development of the Sanatorium as well as the rest of Duiker’s
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The Zonnestraal Sanatorium consists of three large buildings: the main building, the
label: Paragraph

text: Henri ter Meulen Pavilion, and the Dresselhuys Pavilion, along with various smaller
label: Paragraph

text: outbuildings. The main building was begun in 1928 and was used to house the general
label: Paragraph

text: facilities of the complex. The functions were grouped together by their practical
label: Paragraph

text: relationships, dividing the boiler house/bathroom, the kitchen, the medical facility, and
label: Paragraph

text: the infirmary into four distinct linear sections. The cruciform-shaped upper floor spans
label: Paragraph

text: three of the four lower buildings, creating a unified mass.
label: Paragraph

text: Flanking the main building are two independent pavilions. Also functionally distinct,
label: Paragraph

text: each consists of a square central form connecting two long wings that flare out at
label: Paragraph

text: different angles to provide maximum sunlight to the southern-exposed patient rooms and
label: Paragraph

text: terraces. The Henri ter Meulen Pavilion was constructed in 1928, along with the skeleton
label: Paragraph

text: of the Dresselhuys Pavilion, completed in 1931. Nowhere in the complex is Duiker’s
label: Paragraph

text: coalescence of structure, form, and space so evident as in the pavilions. Structurally
label: Paragraph

text: identical to the main building, the rhythmic grid system provides the convalescent living
label: Paragraph

text: spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Between the years of 1919 and 1932, many outbuildings were constructed as part of
label: Paragraph

text: the complex. Dormitory huts were built in 1929 for patients who were at the end of their
label: Paragraph

text: convalescence, allowing them to transition out of the hospital setting. For economic and
label: Paragraph

text: occupational therapy reasons, the convalescents themselves constructed a number of
label: Paragraph

text: these buildings. Following the trends of the Amsterdam School, the first eight small
label: Paragraph

text: utilitarian buildings, constructed in 1919-20, were timber-floored load-bearing brick
label: Paragraph

text: structures. When construction resumed in 1924, Duiker’s conversion to concrete was
label: Paragraph

text: evident.
label: Paragraph

text: Most other buildings went unrealized. The most unusual was the Adamas diamond-
label: Paragraph

text: polishing works (1928), designed to prepare the healed convalescents for their return to
label: Paragraph

text: society. Construction, however, went no further than the reinforced-concrete skeleton. Its
label: Paragraph

text: notable feature was the unusual roof, consisting of alternating asymmetrical sawtooth
label: Paragraph

text: projections.
label: Paragraph

text: Unfortunately, the Sanatorium’s insufficiently prepared steel framing and structural
label: Paragraph

text: members proved unsuitable for the Dutch climate. After World War II, the complex was
label: Paragraph

text: expanded, but without any regard to Duiker’s original design concept. Along with an
label: Paragraph

text: apparent lack of interest in his architecture, by the 1970s the complex was in serious
label: Paragraph

text: decline. Recently restored, however, it is now listed as a national monument. The
label: Paragraph

text: Zonnestraal Sanatorium was the culmination of Duiker and Bijvoet’s utopian yet avant-
label: Paragraph

text: garde design philosophy. By using the latest structural technology, both the architects and
label: Paragraph

text: the buildings were significantly innovative for their time.
label: Paragraph

text: ZUMTHOR, PETER 1943
label: Title

text: Architect, Switzerland
label: Title

text: Switzerland today represents one of the most important centers of modern architectural
label: Paragraph

text: thought and practice, and Peter Zumthor has been among the major architects
label: Paragraph

text: representing the country since the 1980s. Zumthor presents in his work not only beautiful
label: Paragraph

text: form and masterly construction but the sensitive control of material and space achieved
label: Paragraph

text: only by gaining intimate knowledge of all these factors.
label: Paragraph

text: Trained as a cabinetmaker, Zumthor studied design instead of architecture at Basel’s
label: Paragraph

text: school of arts and crafts. He has concentrated on adapting the rural form and materials of
label: Paragraph

text: his headquarters, the Swiss canton of Graubuden, and he has built a small but captivating
label: Paragraph

text: oeuvre almost exclusively in his adopted home since his arrival there in 1967. Zumthor
label: Paragraph

text: has said that he “creates spaces with soul” that become part of the everyday and stand in
label: Paragraph

text: opposition to the “general artificiality of the world” (Peter Zumthor, Works, 1998). He
label: Paragraph

text: argues his case to great effect in all of his projects, including the Sogn Benedegt Chapel,
label: Paragraph

text: a shingled, leaf-shaped church perched high in the misty Surselva Mountains. A
label: Paragraph

text: weathered, earthy, and private place, the form is derived from the lemniscate, an
label: Paragraph

text: algebraic figure-8-shaped curve that when proportionately shortened also determines the
label: Paragraph

text: section. A delicate band of windows ringing the top of the building ensures steady natural
label: Paragraph

text: light. The chapel is an artful combination of rationality and poetry existing in an almost
label: Paragraph

text: dreamlike setting. The architect’s atelier in Haldenstein draws on the contrast between
label: Paragraph

text: softly finished local wood and brushed steel details to highlight the beauty in each. The
label: Paragraph

text: humble building, though sited in the middle of town, lends no notion to its purpose. The
label: Paragraph

text: modern addition to a traditional farmhouse in Versam, Switzerland, is an example of
label: Paragraph

text: Zumthor’s seamless straddling of old and new, tradition and modernization, and his
label: Paragraph

text: dedication to rooting buildings to the landscape. The architect was able to match almost
label: Paragraph

text: perfectly the wood of the original building and made a modern addition for a family
label: Paragraph

text: without interrupting the spirit of the old house.
label: Paragraph

text: The much publicized and much photographed thermal baths in Vals revisit the
label: Paragraph

text: importance and sheer pleasure of bathing known in ancient Roman baths. The entire
label: Paragraph

text: structure looks almost prehistoric, as if it emerged from the ground, and is con structed
label: Paragraph

text: entirely of whole slabs of locally quarried, gray gneiss laid one on top of another, to a
label: Paragraph

text: great monolithic effect. The beauty of the spa is awe-inspiring, as is its perfection in plan
label: Paragraph

text: and construction. The sensuality of the color, the water, the sounds echoed in the
label: Paragraph

text: chamber of the bath seem all but mathematically engineered by the architect—a stunning
label: Paragraph

text: feat matched by few, if any, other of his projects.
label: Paragraph

text: If the spa at Vals is all subterranean mystery, then Zumthor’s first non-Swiss site, the
label: Paragraph

text: Kunsthaus in Bregenz, Austria, is all light and transparency. Nestled beside a lake, the
label: Paragraph

text: glass box of a modern art museum goes from white to blue to glowing yellow during the
label: Paragraph

text: course of day to night. The light skin of the building allows but a peek into the frame and
label: Paragraph

text: at the silhouettes of the staircases between galleries. The glass panels of the museum’s
label: Caption

text: skin are not perforated and hang on a system of metal brackets held in place by large,
label: Paragraph

text: modified clamps. Lighting is controlled by the amount of natural light entering the
label: Paragraph

text: building at any given time through the massive glass skin of the structure. The interior
label: Paragraph

text: floors and walls of the gallery levels are concrete and uniquely climate controlled by the
label: Paragraph

text: circulation of water to the gallery floors and walls from an underground stream.
label: Paragraph

text: Zumthor’s plan for the Swiss Pavilion at the Hannover Expo 2000 was meant to echo a
label: Paragraph

text: lumberyard in its use of piles of timber in parallel walls and the notion that the lumber
label: Paragraph

text: will be sold after the close of the exposition. The multidimensional use of the space
label: Paragraph

text: speaks to all the senses: lines of poetry are projected on the walls, and small troupes of
label: Paragraph

text: dancers and musicians perform in the space, making it a living, beating organism.
label: Paragraph

text: The architect has succeeded by trying the “obvious but difficult solutions” first. Those
label: Paragraph

text: solutions make architecture the medium it is: construction, materials, earth and sky,
label: Paragraph

text: structure. He handles each with respect to create structures true to their surroundings,
label: Paragraph

text: reflective of their culture, and representative of an architect craftsman who blends
label: Paragraph

text: invention and sensitivity, intuition and intelligence.
label: Paragraph

text: is)
label: Title

text: EUGENIA BELL
label: Title

text: Biography
label: Title

text: Peter Zumthor was born in 1943 near Basel, Switzeland. The son of a furniture
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturer, he was trained as a cabinetmaker. He enrolled at the Pratt Institute in New
label: Paragraph

text: York as a visiting student in architecture and design in 1966, and opened his own
label: Paragraph

text: architecture practice in Haldenstein, Graubunden, in 1979. He has taught at the Academy
label: Paragraph

text: of Architecture in Mendrisio, Switzerland, the University of Zurich, and the Southern
label: Paragraph

text: California Institute of Architecture.
label: Caption
